Model-Free O
Functional O
Connectivity O
and O
Impulsivity O
Correlates O
of O
Alcohol O
Dependence O
: O
A O
Resting-State O
Study O
Background O
Alcohol O
dependence O
is O
characterized O
by O
impulsiveness O
toward O
consumption O
despite O
negative O
consequences O
. O

Although O
neuroimaging O
studies O
have O
implicated O
some O
regions O
underlying O
this O
disorder O
, O
there O
is O
little O
information O
regarding O
its O
large-scale O
connectivity O
pattern O
. O

This O
study O
investigated O
the O
within- O
and O
between-network O
functional O
connectivity O
( O
FC O
) O
in O
alcohol O
dependence O
and O
examined O
its O
relationship O
with O
clinical O
impulsivity O
measures O
. O

Methods O
Using O
Probabilistic O
Independent O
Component O
Analysis O
( O
PICA O
) O
on O
resting-state O
fMRI O
( O
rs-fMRI O
) O
data O
from O
25 O
alcohol O
dependent O
( O
AD O
) O
and O
26 O
healthy O
control O
( O
HC O
) O
participants O
, O
we O
compared O
the O
within- O
and O
between-network O
FC O
between O
AD O
and O
HC O
. O

Then O
, O
the O
relationship O
between O
FC O
and O
impulsiveness O
as O
measured O
by O
the O
Barratt O
Impulsiveness O
Scale O
( O
BIS-11 O
) O
, O
the O
UPPS-P O
Impulsive O
Scale O
and O
the O
delay-discounting O
task O
( O
DDT O
) O
was O
explored O
. O

Results O
Compared O
to O
HC O
, O
AD O
exhibited O
increased O
within-network O
FC O
in O
salience O
( O
SN O
) O
, O
default-mode O
( O
DMN O
) O
, O
orbitofrontal O
cortex O
( O
OFCN O
) O
, O
left O
executive O
control O
( O
LECN O
) O
and O
amygdala-striatum O
( O
ASN O
) O
networks O
. O

Increased O
between-network O
FC O
was O
found O
among O
LECN O
, O
ASN O
and O
SN O
. O

Between-network O
FC O
correlations O
were O
significantly O
negative O
between O
Negative-Urgency O
and O
OFCN O
pairs O
with O
RECN O
, O
anterior O
DMN O
( O
aDMN O
) O
, O
and O
posterior O
DMN O
( O
pDMN O
) O
in O
AD O
. O

DDT O
was O
significantly O
correlated O
with O
the O
between-network O
FC O
among O
the O
LECN O
, O
aDMN O
and O
SN O
in O
AD O
. O

Conclusions O
These O
findings O
add O
evidence O
to O
the O
concept O
of O
altered O
within-network O
FC O
and O
also O
highlight O
the O
role O
of O
between-network O
FC O
in O
the O
pathophysiology O
of O
AD O
. O

Additionally O
, O
this O
study O
suggests O
differential O
neurobiological O
bases O
for O
different O
clinical O
measures O
of O
impulsivity O
that O
may O
be O
used O
as O
a O
systems-level O
biomarker O
for O
alcohol O
dependence O
severity O
and O
treatment O
efficacy O
. O

Methods O
and O
Materials O
2.1 O
Participants O
Twenty-five O
alcohol-dependent O
( O
AD O
) O
subjects O
( O
8 O
females O
) O
with O
an O
average O
age O
of O
31.9 O
years O
( O
range O
: O
21 O
to O
44 O
, O
std O
: O
7.7 O
) O
and O
26 O
healthy O
controls O
( O
HC O
) O
subjects O
( O
15 O
females O
) O
with O
mean O
age O
at O
examination O
of O
26.3 O
years O
( O
range O
: O
22 O
to O
37 O
, O
std O
: O
3.9 O
) O
were O
examined O
( O
Table O
1 O
) O
. O

Healthy O
controls O
were O
recruited O
through O
newspaper O
advertisements O
and O
information O
notices O
distributed O
in O
the O
Washington O
, O
D.C. O
metropolitan O
area O
. O

Subjects O
comprising O
the O
alcohol-dependent O
group O
were O
recruited O
from O
the O
inpatient O
alcohol O
treatment O
unit O
at O
the O
National O
Institutes O
of O
Health O
Clinical O
Research O
Center O
in O
Bethesda O
, O
Maryland O
. O

Written O
informed O
consent O
to O
the O
study O
was O
obtained O
from O
all O
of O
subjects O
, O
which O
was O
approved O
by O
the O
Institutional O
Review O
Board O
of O
the O
National O
Institute O
on O
Alcohol O
Abuse O
and O
Alcoholism O
. O

2.2 O
Assessments O
The O
Structured O
Clinical O
Interview O
for O
DSM-IV-TR O
( O
SCID O
) O
was O
administered O
to O
all O
participants O
to O
determine O
diagnoses O
of O
alcohol O
dependence O
as O
well O
as O
other O
substance O
use O
and O
psychiatric O
disorders O
. O

The O
Wechsler O
Adult O
Intelligence O
Scale O
( O
WAIS-III O
) O
was O
administered O
to O
determine O
the O
intelligence O
quotient O
( O
IQ O
) O
of O
all O
participants O
. O

A O
90 O
day O
Timeline O
Followback O
( O
TLFB O
) O
calendar O
was O
used O
to O
measure O
the O
frequency O
and O
amount O
of O
drinking O
for O
all O
subjects O
. O

The O
first O
dimension O
of O
impulsivity O
, O
trait-impulsivity O
, O
was O
measured O
by O
the O
Barratt O
Impulsiveness O
Scale O
( O
BIS-11 O
) O
, O
which O
is O
one O
of O
the O
most O
widely-used O
self-report O
measures O
of O
trait-impulsivity O
, O
refers O
to O
aspects O
of O
inattention O
, O
spontaneous O
actions O
, O
and O
lack O
of O
forethought O
. O

Another O
one O
is O
the O
UPPS-P O
Impulsive O
Behavior O
Scale O
( O
UPPS O
) O
. O

This O
scale O
measures O
impulsivity O
across O
the O
Five-Factor O
Model O
of O
personality O
, O
measuring O
in O
this O
way O
distinct O
personality O
traits O
that O
lead O
to O
impulsive O
behavior O
. O

It O
includes O
Urgency O
( O
negative O
) O
( O
UPPS O
( O
− O
) O
) O
, O
Premeditation O
( O
lack O
of O
) O
, O
Perseverance O
( O
lack O
of O
) O
, O
Sensation-seeking O
, O
and O
Positive-urgency O
( O
UPPS O
( O
+ O
) O
) O
. O

Second O
dimension O
of O
impulsivity O
is O
choice O
impulsivity O
. O

This O
deficiency O
was O
measured O
by O
delay O
discounting O
task O
( O
DDT O
) O
. O

The O
DDT O
measures O
impulsivity O
by O
presenting O
the O
subject O
with O
an O
option O
between O
receiving O
a O
smaller O
immediate O
monetary O
reward O
or O
a O
potentially O
greater O
delayed O
reward O
. O

Participants O
were O
presented O
with O
a O
choice O
between O
an O
immediate O
reward O
and O
a O
fixed O
larger O
( O
$ O
100 O
) O
but O
delayed O
( O
zero O
to O
30 O
days O
) O
rewards O
. O

Accordingly O
, O
a O
discounting O
factor O
k O
represents O
the O
rate O
of O
discounting O
of O
the O
delayed O
outcome O
. O

As O
k O
values O
are O
not O
normally O
distributed O
, O
a O
natural O
log-transformation O
is O
usually O
applied O
and O
the O
ln O
( O
k O
) O
is O
used O
for O
the O
analyses O
. O

Higher O
ln O
( O
k O
) O
values O
mean O
greater O
preference O
for O
immediate O
rewards O
. O

A O
smoking O
questionnaire O
helped O
to O
determine O
the O
amount O
and O
frequency O
of O
a O
participant O
’ O
s O
cigarette O
use O
. O

2.3 O
Exclusionary O
criteria O
Exclusionary O
criteria O
included O
pregnancy O
, O
claustrophobia O
, O
significant O
neurological O
, O
or O
medical O
diagnoses O
. O

Participants O
were O
instructed O
not O
to O
consume O
any O
alcohol O
for O
24 O
hours O
and O
no O
more O
than O
half O
a O
cup O
of O
caffeinated O
beverages O
12 O
hours O
prior O
to O
each O
scanning O
visit O
. O

Participants O
could O
not O
participate O
if O
they O
had O
a O
positive O
alcohol O
breathalyzer O
or O
urine O
drug O
screen O
on O
the O
day O
of O
the O
scan O
. O

HC O
were O
excluded O
if O
they O
met O
criteria O
for O
any O
current O
or O
past O
alcohol O
use O
disorder O
. O

All O
subjects O
were O
required O
to O
be O
right O
handed O
and O
deemed O
physically O
healthy O
by O
a O
clinician O
. O

Subjects O
were O
excluded O
if O
they O
had O
a O
positive O
HIV O
test O
, O
active O
suicidal O
or O
homicidal O
ideations O
, O
or O
were O
currently O
taking O
psychotropic O
medication O
. O

Since O
the O
subjects O
were O
primarily O
recruited O
for O
fMRI O
tasks O
a O
failed O
neuromotor O
examination O
, O
which O
evaluated O
motor O
strength O
, O
deep O
tendon O
reflexes O
, O
extraocular O
movements O
, O
gait O
, O
and O
a O
cerebellar O
assessment O
, O
was O
also O
exclusionary O
. O

This O
allowed O
the O
researchers O
to O
exclude O
subjects O
who O
may O
possess O
neurological O
deficiencies O
that O
could O
potentially O
compromise O
task O
driven O
fMRI O
data O
. O

AD O
participants O
could O
not O
have O
severe O
symptoms O
of O
alcohol O
withdrawal O
as O
determined O
by O
a O
Clinical O
Institute O
Withdrawal O
Assessment O
of O
Alcohol O
Scale O
( O
CIWA O
) O
score O
of O
greater O
than O
8 O
. O

2.4 O
MRI O
Data O
acquisition O
Whole O
brain O
Anatomical O
images O
and O
five O
minutes O
of O
closed-eyes O
rs-fMRI O
were O
collected O
at O
the O
beginning O
of O
the O
scan O
session O
using O
a O
3T O
General O
Electric O
MRI O
scanner O
( O
General O
Electric O
, O
Milwaukee O
, O
WI O
) O
after O
a O
short O
3D O
brain O
localization O
. O

High-resolution O
T1-weighted O
3-D O
structural O
scans O
were O
acquired O
for O
each O
subject O
using O
an O
MPRAGE O
sequence O
( O
128 O
axial O
slices O
, O
TR O
= O
1200ms O
TE O
=30ms O
, O
256 O
× O
256 O
matrix O
) O
. O

Resting O
state O
fMRI O
datasets O
were O
collected O
using O
a O
single-shot O
gradient O
echo O
planar O
imaging O
pulse O
sequence O
with O
thirty-four O
5mm-thick O
axial O
slices O
acquired O
parallel O
to O
the O
anterior/posterior O
commissural O
line O
( O
TR O
= O
2000ms O
, O
TE O
= O
30ms O
, O
flip O
angle=90o O
, O
3.75 O
mm O
× O
3.75 O
mm O
× O
5.0 O
mm O
voxels O
) O
. O

Therefore O
, O
for O
each O
subject O
a O
total O
of O
150 O
resting O
state O
frames O
( O
volumes O
) O
were O
acquired O
. O

2.5 O
rs-fMRI O
data O
pre-processing O
Using O
Functional O
MRI O
of O
the O
Brain O
( O
FMRIB O
) O
's O
Software O
Library O
( O
www.fmrib.ox.ac.uk/fsl O
) O
we O
applied O
; O
1 O
) O
slice O
timing O
correction O
for O
interleaved O
acquisitions O
using O
Sinc O
interpolation O
with O
a O
Hanning O
windowing O
kernel O
; O
2 O
) O
motion O
correction O
; O
3 O
) O
non-brain O
removal O
; O
4 O
) O
spatial O
smoothing O
using O
a O
Gaussian O
kernel O
of O
full O
width O
at O
half O
maximum O
5mm O
; O
5 O
) O
grand-mean O
intensity O
normalization O
of O
the O
entire O
4D O
dataset O
by O
a O
single O
multiplicative O
factor O
, O
the O
size O
of O
the O
voxels O
is O
4×4×4 O
mm3 O
; O
6 O
) O
high-pass O
temporal O
filtering O
( O
Gaussian-weighted O
least-squares O
straight O
line O
fitting O
, O
with O
sigma=50s O
) O
; O
and O
7 O
) O
registration O
to O
high O
resolution O
structural O
MNI O
standard O
space O
images O
. O

We O
used O
a O
stringent O
threshold O
for O
head O
motion O
in O
pre-processing O
step O
. O

Subjects O
with O
head O
motion O
greater O
than O
0.3 O
mm O
for O
translation O
and O
0.3° O
for O
rotation O
between O
consecutive O
TRs O
were O
removed O
from O
the O
study O
. O

2.6 O
rs-fMRI O
connectivity O
analysis O
We O
applied O
Probabilistic O
Independent O
Component O
Analysis O
( O
PICA O
) O
by O
using O
the O
Multivariate O
Exploratory O
Linear O
Decomposition O
into O
Independent O
Components O
( O
MELODIC O
) O
toolbox O
of O
the O
FMRIB O
Software O
library O
( O
FSL O
) O
package O
( O
www.fmrib.ox.ac.uk/fsl O
) O
. O

A O
temporal O
concatenation O
tool O
in O
MELODIC O
was O
used O
to O
derive O
group O
level O
components O
across O
all O
subjects O
. O

Pre-processed O
data O
were O
whitened O
and O
projected O
into O
a O
35-dimensional O
subspace O
using O
PICA O
where O
the O
number O
of O
dimensions O
was O
estimated O
using O
the O
Laplace O
approximation O
to O
the O
Bayesian O
evidence O
of O
the O
model O
order O
. O

The O
whitened O
observations O
were O
decomposed O
into O
sets O
of O
vectors O
that O
describe O
signal O
variation O
across O
the O
temporal O
domain O
( O
time-courses O
) O
and O
across O
the O
spatial O
domain O
( O
maps O
) O
by O
optimizing O
for O
non-Gaussian O
spatial O
source O
distributions O
using O
a O
fixed-point O
iteration O
technique O
. O

These O
FC O
components O
maps O
were O
standardized O
into O
z O
statistic O
images O
via O
a O
normalized O
mixture O
model O
fit O
, O
thresholded O
at O
z O
> O
5 O
. O

Two O
criteria O
were O
used O
to O
remove O
biologically O
irrelevant O
components O
: O
( O
1 O
) O
those O
representing O
known O
artifacts O
such O
as O
motion O
, O
and O
high-frequency O
noise O
; O
and O
( O
2 O
) O
those O
with O
connectivity O
patterns O
not O
located O
mainly O
in O
gray O
matter O
. O

Networks O
of O
interest O
were O
identified O
as O
anatomically O
and O
functionally O
classical O
RSNs O
upon O
visual O
inspection O
. O

The O
between-subject O
analysis O
was O
carried O
out O
using O
dual O
regression O
, O
a O
regression O
technique O
that O
back-reconstructs O
each O
group O
level O
component O
map O
at O
the O
individual O
subject O
level O
. O

This O
technique O
allows O
for O
voxel-wise O
comparisons O
of O
resting O
state O
FC O
by O
carrying O
out O
the O
following O
steps O
: O
First O
, O
regresses O
the O
group O
level O
spatial O
maps O
into O
each O
individual O
’ O
s O
4D O
dataset O
to O
obtain O
a O
set O
of O
time O
series O
. O

Then O
, O
regresses O
those O
individual O
level O
time O
series O
into O
the O
same O
4D O
dataset O
to O
obtain O
a O
subject-specific O
set O
of O
spatial O
maps O
. O

Statistic O
inferences O
were O
then O
tested O
using O
FSL O
’ O
s O
randomize O
permutation-testing O
tool O
. O

In O
cases O
such O
as O
fMRI O
data O
, O
when O
the O
null O
distribution O
is O
not O
known O
, O
permutation O
testing O
is O
used O
for O
inference O
on O
statistical O
maps O
. O

Voxel-wise O
two-sample O
t-test O
was O
carried O
out O
to O
assess O
statistically O
significant O
differences O
in O
FC O
between O
the O
groups O
using O
a O
5000 O
non-parametric O
permutation O
testing O
. O

We O
utilized O
a O
threshold-free O
cluster O
enhanced O
( O
TFCE O
) O
technique O
to O
control O
for O
multiple O
comparisons O
. O

This O
method O
allows O
detecting O
significant O
clusters O
without O
having O
to O
define O
cluster O
size O
or O
the O
number O
of O
clusters O
prior O
to O
analysis O
. O

Finally O
, O
the O
resulting O
statistical O
maps O
were O
threshold O
at O
p O
< O
0.05 O
FWE-corrected O
for O
multiple O
comparisons O
for O
the O
main O
group O
effect O
. O

This O
step O
generated O
the O
probabilistic O
maps O
which O
represent O
the O
probability O
of O
FC O
between O
AD O
and O
HC O
: O
AD O
maps O
subtracted O
from O
HC O
one O
and O
vice O
versa O
for O
all O
RSNs O
of O
interest O
. O

The O
Harvard-Oxford O
cortical O
and O
subcortical O
atlases O
incorporated O
in O
FSL O
were O
used O
to O
identify O
the O
anatomical O
regions O
of O
the O
resulting O
PICA O
maps O
. O

2.7 O
Correlation O
Analysis O
Within-network O
connectivity O
correlation O
with O
impulsivity O
measures O
: O
Using O
Statistical O
Parametric O
Mapping O
8 O
( O
SPM8 O
) O
( O
http O
: O
//www.fil.ion.ucl.ac.uk/spm O
) O
, O
for O
each O
group O
, O
individual O
subject O
maps O
for O
the O
independent O
components O
for O
the O
impulsive O
system O
( O
ASN O
) O
, O
reflective O
system O
( O
OFCN O
, O
left O
ECN O
, O
right O
ECN O
) O
, O
insula O
cortex O
( O
SN O
) O
and O
DMN O
( O
a-DMN O
and O
p-DMN O
) O
, O
were O
entered O
as O
second-level O
regression O
analysis O
versus O
the O
impulsivity O
measures O
( O
BIS-11 O
, O
DDT O
, O
UPPS-P O
) O
as O
covariate O
with O
its O
own O
IC O
map O
as O
mask O
. O

All O
within-RSN O
correlational O
analyses O
were O
done O
with O
the O
cluster-level O
Family-wise O
error O
( O
FWE O
) O
corrected O
threshold O
of O
0.05 O
. O

Between-network O
connectivity O
correlation O
with O
clinical O
measures O
: O
Even O
though O
all O
component O
maps O
are O
spatially O
independent O
, O
time O
series O
of O
the O
components O
may O
still O
have O
significant O
temporal O
correlations O
. O

Network O
interaction O
comparisons O
( O
Correlation O
coefficients O
, O
Pearson O
’ O
s O
r O
) O
between O
AD O
and O
HC O
were O
computed O
between O
each O
subject O
time O
series O
for O
the O
RSNs O
of O
interest O
that O
were O
obtained O
by O
the O
first O
stage O
of O
the O
dual O
regression O
procedure O
. O

These O
correlation O
coefficients O
were O
Fisher O
z-transformed O
and O
unpaired O
t-tests O
were O
conducted O
to O
compare O
between O
network O
connectivity O
in O
AD O
and O
HC O
using O
Statistical O
Analysis O
System O
( O
SAS O
software O
, O
Copyright O
, O
SAS O
Institute O
Inc. O
SAS O
and O
all O
other O
SAS O
Institute O
Inc. O
) O
. O

Finally O
, O
the O
results O
were O
threshold O
at O
p O
< O
0.05 O
bonferroni-corrected O
for O
multiple O
comparisons O
. O

The O
differences O
in O
age O
, O
years O
of O
education O
, O
and O
IQ O
between O
AD O
and O
HC O
do O
not O
make O
for O
ideal O
comparisons O
. O

To O
minimize O
the O
potential O
confounding O
influence O
of O
age O
, O
years O
of O
education O
and O
IQ O
in O
these O
results O
, O
these O
parameters O
were O
used O
as O
nuisance O
covariates O
for O
each O
network O
of O
interest O
. O

No O
effect O
of O
age O
, O
years O
of O
education O
and O
IQ O
was O
detected O
in O
the O
fMRI O
FC O
results O
. O

Mapping O
thalamocortical O
functional O
connectivity O
in O
chronic O
and O
early O
stages O
of O
psychotic O
disorders O
Objective O
There O
is O
considerable O
evidence O
that O
the O
thalamus O
is O
abnormal O
in O
psychotic O
disorders O
. O

Resting-state O
fMRI O
( O
RS-fMRI O
) O
has O
revealed O
an O
intriguing O
pattern O
of O
thalamic O
dysconnectivity O
in O
psychosis O
characterized O
by O
reduced O
prefrontal O
cortex O
( O
PFC O
) O
connectivity O
and O
increased O
somatomotor-thalamic O
connectivity O
. O

However O
, O
critical O
knowledge O
gaps O
remain O
with O
respect O
to O
the O
onset O
, O
anatomical O
specificity O
, O
and O
clinical O
correlates O
of O
thalamic O
dysconnectivity O
in O
psychosis O
. O

Method O
RS-fMRI O
was O
collected O
on O
105 O
healthy O
subjects O
and O
148 O
individuals O
with O
psychosis O
, O
including O
53 O
early O
stage O
psychosis O
patients O
. O

Using O
all O
253 O
subjects O
, O
the O
thalamus O
was O
parceled O
into O
functional O
regions-of-interest O
( O
ROIs O
) O
on O
the O
basis O
of O
connectivity O
with O
six O
a-priori O
defined O
cortical O
ROIs O
covering O
most O
of O
the O
cortical O
mantle O
. O

Functional O
connectivity O
between O
each O
cortical O
ROI O
and O
its O
corresponding O
thalamic O
ROI O
was O
quantified O
and O
compared O
across O
groups O
. O

Significant O
differences O
in O
the O
ROI-to-ROI O
analysis O
were O
followed O
up O
with O
voxel-wise O
seed-based O
analyses O
to O
further O
localize O
thalamic O
dysconnectivity O
. O

Results O
ROI O
analysis O
revealed O
reduced O
PFC-thalamic O
connectivity O
and O
increased O
somatomotor-thalamic O
connectivity O
in O
both O
chronic O
and O
early O
stages O
psychosis O
patients O
. O

PFC O
hypo-connectivity O
and O
motor O
cortex O
hyper-connectivity O
correlated O
in O
patients O
suggesting O
they O
result O
from O
a O
common O
pathophysiological O
mechanism O
. O

Seed-based O
analyses O
revealed O
thalamic O
hypo-connectivity O
in O
psychosis O
localized O
to O
dorsolateral O
PFC O
, O
medial O
PFC O
, O
and O
cerebellar O
areas O
of O
the O
well-described O
‘ O
executive O
control O
’ O
network O
. O

Across O
all O
subjects O
, O
thalamic O
connectivity O
with O
areas O
of O
the O
fronto-parietal O
network O
correlated O
with O
cognitive O
functioning O
, O
including O
verbal O
learning O
and O
memory O
. O

Conclusions O
Thalamocortical O
dysconnectivity O
is O
present O
in O
both O
chronic O
and O
early O
stages O
of O
psychosis O
, O
includes O
reduced O
thalamic O
connectivity O
with O
the O
executive O
control O
network O
, O
and O
is O
related O
to O
cognitive O
impairment O
. O

METHODS O
AND O
MATERIALS O
Study O
Participants O
105 O
healthy O
subjects O
and O
148 O
individuals O
with O
a O
psychotic O
disorder O
were O
included O
in O
this O
investigation O
( O
see O
Table O
1 O
) O
. O

The O
psychosis O
group O
included O
individuals O
with O
schizophrenia/schizoaffective O
disorder O
( O
i.e O
. O

non-affective O
psychosis O
) O
and O
bipolar O
I O
disorder O
with O
psychotic O
features O
( O
i.e O
. O

affective O
psychosis O
) O
. O

53 O
patients O
were O
within O
two O
years O
of O
illness O
onset O
and O
considered O
early O
stage O
. O

Most O
early O
stage O
psychosis O
patients O
were O
studied O
at O
the O
time O
of O
their O
first O
hospitalization O
for O
a O
psychotic O
disorder O
, O
or O
very O
shortly O
thereafter O
, O
and O
had O
been O
ill O
for O
less O
than O
4 O
months O
on O
average O
. O

At O
the O
time O
of O
study O
participation O
, O
25 O
early O
stage O
patients O
were O
diagnosed O
with O
schizophreniform O
disorder O
. O

Follow-up O
diagnostic O
data O
was O
available O
on O
22 O
of O
these O
patients O
; O
20 O
converted O
to O
a O
non-affective O
psychotic O
disorder O
, O
1 O
remained O
diagnosed O
with O
schizophreniform O
disorder O
, O
and O
1 O
was O
subsequently O
re-classified O
as O
affective O
psychosis O
. O

All O
subjects O
underwent O
a O
structured O
clinical O
interview O
and O
completed O
a O
brief O
cognitive O
assessment O
that O
included O
the O
Wechsler O
Test O
of O
Adult O
Reading O
to O
estimate O
pre-morbid O
IQ O
and O
the O
Screen O
for O
Cognitive O
Impairment O
in O
Psychiatry O
which O
includes O
tests O
of O
verbal O
learning O
, O
working O
memory O
, O
verbal O
fluency O
, O
and O
processing O
speed O
. O

In O
addition O
, O
patients O
were O
also O
assessed O
with O
the O
Positive O
and O
Negative O
Syndrome O
Scale O
( O
PANSS O
: O
22 O
) O
to O
quantify O
severity O
of O
clinical O
symptoms O
. O

Study O
procedures O
and O
exclusion O
criteria O
are O
described O
in O
detail O
in O
the O
Supplemental O
Material O
. O

This O
study O
was O
approved O
by O
the O
Vanderbilt O
University O
Institutional O
Review O
Board O
. O

Neuroimaging O
Data O
Acquisition O
and O
Functional O
Connectivity O
Analysis O
Imaging O
data O
acquisition O
and O
pre-processing O
are O
described O
in O
detail O
in O
the O
Supplemental O
Material O
. O

Briefly O
, O
a O
7-minute O
echo-planar O
imaging O
resting-state O
scan O
and O
a O
high-resolution O
T1-weighted O
structural O
scan O
were O
collected O
on O
each O
subject O
. O

Functional O
images O
were O
slice-time O
corrected O
, O
motion O
corrected O
, O
co-registered O
to O
native O
space O
structural O
data O
, O
and O
normalized O
to O
MNI O
space O
. O

As O
described O
earlier O
, O
prior O
investigations O
of O
thalamocortical O
functional O
dysconnectivity O
in O
psychosis O
have O
either O
: O
1 O
) O
parceled O
the O
cortex O
into O
large O
, O
anatomically O
defined O
ROIs O
corresponding O
to O
the O
primary O
cortical O
targets O
of O
specific O
thalamic O
sub-regions O
( O
e.g O
. O

PFC O
) O
and O
used O
these O
as O
seeds O
to O
identify O
functional O
connectivity O
within O
the O
thalamus O
; O
or O
2 O
) O
used O
the O
whole O
thalamus O
as O
a O
seed O
to O
map O
thalamic O
connectivity O
with O
the O
rest O
of O
the O
brain O
. O

The O
primary O
advantage O
of O
the O
first O
method O
is O
that O
it O
can O
map O
multiple O
thalamic O
networks O
and O
segment O
the O
thalamus O
according O
to O
its O
functional O
connectivity O
. O

However O
, O
the O
use O
of O
large O
cortical O
ROIs O
limits O
spatial O
specificity O
within O
the O
cortex O
. O

Using O
the O
whole O
thalamus O
as O
a O
seed O
overcomes O
this O
limitation O
, O
but O
, O
by O
averaging O
BOLD O
signals O
from O
the O
entire O
thalamus O
, O
precludes O
an O
analysis O
of O
specific O
thalamocortical O
networks O
. O

To O
overcome O
these O
limitations O
, O
we O
combined O
elements O
of O
both O
methods O
. O

First O
, O
we O
performed O
a O
‘ O
cortical O
ROI-to-thalamus O
ROI O
’ O
analysis O
in O
which O
connectivity O
between O
anatomically O
defined O
cortical O
ROIs O
and O
functionally O
defined O
thalamic O
ROIs O
was O
calculated O
and O
compared O
across O
groups O
( O
see O
Figure O
1A O
) O
. O

This O
primary O
analysis O
was O
followed O
up O
with O
seed-based O
analyses O
examining O
connectivity O
of O
functionally O
defined O
thalamic O
sub-regions O
with O
the O
rest O
of O
the O
brain O
. O

The O
analysis O
steps O
were O
as O
follows O
. O

First O
, O
as O
described O
previously O
, O
the O
cortex O
was O
divided O
into O
six O
, O
a-priori O
defined O
non-overlapping O
ROIs O
shown O
in O
Figure O
1A O
. O

Functional O
connectivity O
maps O
, O
restricted O
to O
the O
Harvard-Oxford O
thalamus O
probabilistic O
atlas O
( O
thresholded O
at O
10 O
% O
) O
, O
were O
then O
created O
for O
each O
cortical O
ROI O
. O

Using O
the O
entire O
dataset O
of O
253 O
individuals O
, O
the O
thalamus O
was O
parceled O
into O
functional O
ROIs O
using O
the O
‘ O
winner O
take O
all O
’ O
strategy O
; O
each O
voxel O
in O
the O
thalamus O
was O
assigned O
to O
the O
cortical O
ROI O
it O
was O
most O
strongly O
connected O
to O
. O

Average O
connectivity O
of O
the O
voxels O
within O
each O
thalamic O
ROI O
with O
its O
respective O
cortical O
ROI O
was O
then O
calculated O
resulting O
in O
6 O
thalamocortical O
‘ O
network O
’ O
values O
for O
each O
subject O
; O
one O
for O
each O
cortical O
anatomical O
ROI O
and O
its O
corresponding O
thalamic O
functional O
ROI O
which O
served O
as O
the O
dependent O
variables O
in O
the O
statistical O
analysis O
. O

Thalamocortical O
network O
values O
were O
analyzed O
using O
multivariate O
repeated O
measures O
ANOVA O
with O
network O
entered O
as O
the O
within O
the O
subjects O
variable O
, O
group O
a O
between O
subjects O
variable O
, O
and O
age O
and O
sex O
entered O
as O
covariates O
. O

The O
‘ O
cortical O
ROI-to-thalamic O
ROI O
’ O
analysis O
described O
above O
was O
followed O
up O
with O
seed-based O
connectivity O
analyses O
using O
the O
thalamic O
functional O
ROIs O
as O
seeds O
to O
examine O
connectivity O
of O
specific O
thalamic O
sub-regions O
with O
the O
rest O
of O
the O
brain O
. O

Briefly O
, O
the O
mean O
BOLD O
times O
series O
derived O
from O
the O
thalamic O
ROIs O
was O
extracted O
from O
each O
subjects O
’ O
unsmoothed O
functional O
data O
and O
entered O
into O
a O
general O
linear O
model O
to O
create O
functional O
connectivity O
maps O
of O
specific O
thalamic O
ROIs O
. O

The O
functional O
connectivity O
maps O
, O
in O
beta O
units O
, O
were O
then O
smoothed O
( O
6 O
mm O
) O
and O
entered O
into O
a O
one-way O
ANOVA O
with O
group O
entered O
as O
the O
between O
subjects O
variable O
, O
and O
age O
and O
sex O
as O
covariates O
. O

A O
priori O
contrasts O
comparing O
healthy O
subjects O
to O
psychosis O
patients O
and O
each O
patient O
group O
( O
i.e O
. O

chronic O
, O
early O
stage O
) O
to O
healthy O
subjects O
were O
performed O
. O

Results O
were O
thresholded O
at O
the O
cluster-level O
pFWE-corrected=.05 O
for O
voxel-wise O
p=.005 O
, O
masked O
to O
include O
only O
voxels O
that O
demonstrated O
significant O
positive O
functional O
connectivity O
in O
healthy O
subjects O
and/or O
psychosis O
patients O
at O
the O
cluster-level O
pFWE-corrected=.05 O
for O
voxel-wise O
p=.005 O
. O

Functional O
connectivity O
maps O
for O
the O
thalamic O
ROIs O
were O
created O
using O
the O
CONN-fMRI O
Functional O
Connectivity O
toolbox O
. O

Briefly O
, O
the O
mean O
BOLD O
time O
series O
was O
extracted O
from O
an O
ROI O
and O
entered O
as O
a O
predictor O
in O
a O
multiple O
regression O
general O
linear O
model O
( O
GLM O
) O
. O

Regressors O
corresponding O
to O
the O
6 O
motion O
correction O
parameters O
and O
their O
first O
temporal O
derivatives O
, O
along O
with O
grey O
matter O
, O
white O
matter O
, O
and O
CSF O
were O
included O
to O
remove O
variance O
related O
to O
head O
motion O
, O
the O
global O
grey O
matter O
signal O
, O
white O
matter O
, O
and O
CSF O
, O
respectively O
. O

Functional O
data O
were O
band-pass O
filtered O
( O
.01-.10 O
Hz O
) O
. O

We O
took O
several O
steps O
to O
limit O
the O
effects O
of O
head O
motion O
. O

First O
, O
resting-state O
scans O
underwent O
“ O
motion O
scrubbing O
” O
as O
described O
by O
Power O
et O
al O
.. O

Volumes O
with O
frame-wise O
displacement O
greater O
than O
0.5 O
and O
BOLD O
intensity O
changes O
between O
frames O
greater O
than O
0.5 O
% O
were O
identified O
and O
excluded O
from O
the O
functional O
connectivity O
analysis O
by O
including O
the O
tagged O
scans O
as O
nuisance O
regressors O
in O
the O
connectivity O
GLM O
. O

Second O
, O
nuisance O
regressors O
for O
white O
matter O
and O
CSF O
were O
derived O
from O
each O
subject O
’ O
s O
white O
matter O
and O
CSF O
segmentations O
using O
the O
anatomical O
component-based O
noise O
reduction O
method O
( O
aCompCor O
) O
, O
as O
implemented O
in O
the O
Conn-fMRI O
toolbox O
. O

The O
aCompCor O
method O
has O
been O
shown O
to O
be O
effective O
at O
reducing O
the O
effects O
of O
head O
movement O
on O
functional O
connectivity O
estimates O
. O

Finally O
, O
motion O
correction O
parameters O
were O
regressed O
out O
before O
temporal O
band O
pass O
filtering O
was O
applied O
as O
performing O
these O
steps O
in O
reverse O
order O
( O
i.e O
. O

band-pass O
filtering O
before O
nuisance O
regression O
) O
over-estimates O
connectivity O
and O
exacerbates O
the O
effects O
of O
head O
motion O
due O
to O
re-introduction O
of O
nuisance O
related O
variation O
. O

Peripheral O
and O
prefrontal O
stress O
system O
markers O
and O
risk O
of O
relapse O
in O
alcoholism O
Previous O
research O
has O
shown O
that O
hyperactivation O
in O
ventral O
medial O
prefrontal O
cortex O
( O
VmPFC O
) O
and O
rostral O
anterior O
cingulate O
cortex O
( O
rACC O
) O
and O
high O
cortisol O
to O
corticotrophin O
ratio O
( O
cort O
: O
ACTH O
ratio O
) O
during O
neutral-relaxed O
states O
predict O
relapse O
in O
alcohol O
dependent O
( O
AD O
) O
patients O
. O

Other O
studies O
have O
shown O
that O
VmPFC/rACC O
deactivation O
and O
blunted O
cortisol O
release O
to O
stress O
and O
alcohol O
cues O
are O
predictive O
of O
time O
to O
relapse O
and O
relapse O
severity O
. O

However O
, O
no O
previous O
study O
has O
assessed O
the O
relationship O
between O
these O
markers O
of O
central O
and O
peripheral O
nervous O
system O
dysfunction O
in O
AD O
participants O
and O
their O
potential O
joint O
effects O
on O
relapse O
risk O
. O

Forty O
early O
abstinent O
, O
treatment O
engaged O
AD O
patients O
underwent O
a O
laboratory O
experiment O
with O
exposure O
to O
neutral O
, O
alcohol O
, O
and O
stress O
cues O
and O
a O
separate O
functional O
magnetic O
resonance O
imaging O
( O
fMRI O
) O
scan O
with O
similar O
cue O
exposure O
. O

Neutral-relaxed O
state O
cort O
: O
ACTH O
ratio O
was O
significantly O
associated O
with O
VmPFC O
hyperreactivity O
to O
neutral-relaxing O
cues O
, O
and O
also O
with O
hypoactivation O
in O
response O
to O
alcohol O
and O
stress O
cues O
in O
AD O
patients O
. O

Basal O
heart O
rate O
, O
neutral O
cort O
: O
ACTH O
ratio O
, O
and O
neutral O
VmPFC O
hyperreactivty O
were O
each O
associated O
with O
risk O
of O
relapse O
. O

However O
, O
abnormal O
VmPFC O
activation O
and O
elevated O
cort O
: O
ACTH O
ratio O
overlap O
in O
predicting O
risk O
for O
relapse O
, O
and O
dysfunctional O
VmPFC O
response O
was O
the O
sole O
significant O
predictor O
of O
odds O
of O
relapse O
in O
a O
joint O
model O
of O
relapse O
risk O
. O

These O
findings O
suggest O
that O
the O
Cort O
: O
ACTH O
ratio O
may O
serve O
as O
a O
peripheral O
marker O
of O
VmPFC O
brain O
dysfunction O
while O
aberrant O
VmPFC O
responses O
needs O
further O
evaluation O
as O
a O
potential O
biomarker O
of O
alcohol O
relapse O
risk O
in O
clinical O
outcome O
studies O
. O

Methods O
Participants O
For O
the O
current O
report O
, O
we O
included O
forty O
recovering O
AD O
patients O
( O
9 O
female O
; O
aged O
18–50 O
years O
) O
who O
had O
abstained O
from O
alcohol O
for O
4 O
to O
8 O
weeks O
( O
mean O
[ O
SD O
] O
: O
34 O
( O
7.6 O
) O
days O
; O
range O
, O
29–59 O
days O
) O
. O

All O
patients O
were O
residing O
in O
an O
inpatient O
treatment O
research O
facility O
and O
were O
actively O
engaged O
in O
substance O
abuse O
treatment O
for O
at O
least O
4 O
weeks O
. O

Individuals O
currently O
using O
opiates O
, O
those O
who O
ever O
met O
criteria O
for O
opiate O
dependence O
, O
and O
those O
taking O
prescribed O
, O
over O
the O
counter O
, O
or O
homeopathic O
medications O
for O
any O
current O
psychiatric O
or O
medical O
condition O
were O
excluded O
. O

Women O
were O
excluded O
from O
the O
study O
if O
they O
were O
using O
hormonal O
contraceptives O
or O
were O
in O
the O
follicular O
or O
early O
and O
mid-luteal O
phases O
during O
laboratory O
and O
fMRI O
sessions O
. O

All O
subjects O
underwent O
a O
complete O
medical O
evaluation O
, O
including O
electrocardiography O
and O
laboratory O
tests O
of O
renal O
, O
hepatic O
, O
pancreatic O
, O
hematopoietic O
, O
and O
thyroid O
functions O
, O
to O
ensure O
good O
physical O
health O
. O

All O
study O
procedures O
were O
approved O
by O
the O
Human O
Investigation O
Committee O
of O
the O
Yale O
University O
School O
of O
Medicine O
and O
all O
participants O
signed O
a O
written O
informed O
consent O
. O

The O
laboratory O
and O
fMRI O
studies O
were O
conducted O
1 O
month O
after O
admission O
to O
the O
inpatient O
unit O
to O
allow O
for O
normalization O
of O
neurobiological O
changes O
associated O
with O
acute O
alcohol O
withdrawal O
and O
to O
assess O
stress O
responses O
and O
craving O
in O
the O
early O
recovery O
period O
. O

Abstinence O
from O
drug O
and O
alcohol O
consumption O
during O
treatment O
was O
verified O
by O
urinalysis O
. O

Four O
structured O
smoking O
breaks O
were O
allowed O
in O
the O
inpatient O
treatment O
facility O
and O
subjects O
were O
permitted O
to O
smoke O
1–2 O
cigarettes O
during O
each O
break O
. O

The O
smoke O
breaks O
were O
implemented O
at O
the O
start O
of O
inpatient O
admission O
at O
least O
4 O
weeks O
prior O
to O
laboratory O
and O
fMRI O
testing O
, O
and O
thus O
AD O
patients O
had O
a O
4 O
week O
period O
to O
adapt O
to O
this O
schedule O
of O
nicotine O
consumption O
. O

This O
sample O
made O
up O
about O
half O
( O
43 O
% O
) O
of O
the O
sample O
reported O
on O
in O
the O
study O
and O
the O
majority O
( O
89 O
% O
) O
of O
the O
sample O
reported O
on O
in O
the O
study O
( O
see O
Figure O
S1 O
for O
a O
flowchart O
of O
the O
current O
study O
sample O
utilized O
from O
those O
reported O
in O
previous O
reports O
) O
. O

The O
criteria O
for O
inclusion O
in O
the O
present O
study O
was O
any O
AD O
patient O
who O
met O
the O
above O
described O

and O

criteria O
and O
also O
completed O
both O
the O

and O
the O

during O
the O

period O
of O
their O

, O
and O
also O
completed O
the O
90-day O

followup O
period O
for O
assessment O
of O
relapse O
risk O
. O

Individualized O
imagery O
method O
and O
script O
development O
Lab O
All O
participants O
underwent O
an O
imagery O
script O
development O

( O

3 O
of O
admission O
) O
during O
which O
they O
were O
asked O
to O
identify O
a O
highly O
stressful O
event O
from O
their O
own O
lives O
( O
rated O
by O
the O
subject O
as O
greater O
than O
8 O
on O
a O
10-point O
Likert O
scale O
for O
stressfulness O
) O
; O
a O
personal O
alcohol O
cue– O
related O
event O
that O
involved O
people O
, O
places O
, O
and O
objects O
related O
to O
alcohol O
use O
and O
led O
to O
subsequent O
alcohol O
use O
; O
and O
a O
personal O
neutral O
, O
relaxing O
event O
. O

Details O
of O
each O
situation O
were O
elicited O
using O
methods O
reviewed O
and O
summarized O
in O
. O

Scripts O
were O
developed O
using O
a O
standardized O
format O
, O
based O
on O
specific O
stimulus O
and O

of O

, O
and O

audiotaped O
for O

. O

MRI O
Two O
additional O
personalized O
scripts O
for O
each O
of O
the O
stress O
, O
alcohol O
cue O
and O
neutral-relaxing O
conditions O
were O
developed O
prior O
to O
the O
fMRI O
session O
according O
to O
the O
procedure O
described O
above O
. O

Each O
2-minute O
script O
was O
audiotaped O
and O
presented O
in O
random O
order O
during O
the O
scanning O
session O
. O

The O
neutral-relaxing O
script O
served O
as O
an O
active O
control O
state O
for O
the O
stress O
and O
alcohol O
cues O
because O
it O
has O
been O
shown O
not O
to O
increase O
alcohol O
craving O
and O
it O
controls O
for O
the O
nonspecific O
effects O
of O
the O
experimental O
manipulation O
. O

Laboratory O
Sessions O
On O
a O
day O
prior O
to O
the O
laboratory O
sessions O
, O
participants O
took O
part O
in O
a O
habituation O
and O
imagery O
training O
procedure O
that O
involved O
exposure O
to O
the O
stress O
of O
intravenous O
catheter O
insertion O
and O
specific O
instructions O
on O
progressive O
relaxation O
and O
guided O
imagery O
participation O
. O

This O
was O
followed O
by O
3 O
experimental O
sessions O
conducted O
at O
7:45 O
AM O
on O
each O
of O
3 O
consecutive O
days O
where O
subjects O
were O
exposed O
to O
5-minute O
audiotaped O
scripts O
of O
stress O
, O
alcohol-related O
, O
and O
neutral O
, O
relaxing O
scenarios O
. O

Only O
1 O
stimulus O
script O
was O
presented O
per O
session O
and O
condition O
order O
was O
randomized O
and O
counterbalanced O
across O
participants O
. O

HPA O
Axis O
Measures O
To O
assess O
basal O
plasma O
levels O
of O
ACTH O
and O
cortisol O
, O
4 O
mL O
of O
blood O
were O
collected O
in O
a O
heparinized O
tube O
that O
was O
placed O
on O
ice O
immediately O
after O
the O
blood O
was O
drawn O
. O

Within O
30 O
minutes O
of O
collection O
, O
the O
blood O
was O
centrifuged O
at O
4°C O
and O
the O
plasma O
was O
pooled O
and O
aliquoted O
for O
ACTH O
and O
cortisol O
assays O
. O

All O
tubes O
were O
stored O
at O
−70°C O
and O
analyzed O
using O
standard O
radioimmunoassay O
procedures O
as O
reported O
previously O
. O

Because O
cortisol O
secretion O
from O
the O
adrenal O
glands O
occurs O
in O
response O
to O
circulating O
ACTH O
, O
the O
cort O
: O
ACTH O
ratio O
serves O
as O
a O
measure O
of O
adrenal O
sensitivity O
. O

Functional O
Magnetic O
Resonance O
Imaging O
Acquisition O
and O
Procedure O
Magnetic O
resonance O
imaging O
data O
were O
collected O
using O
a O
3-T O
Siemens O
Trio O
MRI O
system O
equipped O
with O
a O
standard O
quadrature O
head O
coil O
, O
using O
T2 O
* O
-sensitive O
gradient-recalled O
single O
shot O
echo O
planar O
pulse O
sequence O
( O
parameters O
described O
in O
) O
. O

Six O
fMRI O
trials O
( O
2 O
per O
condition O
) O
were O
acquired O
using O
a O
block O
design O
. O

The O
order O
of O
the O
6 O
trials O
were O
randomized O
and O
counterbalanced O
across O
participants O
. O

Each O
script O
was O
presented O
only O
once O
for O
a O
participant O
, O
and O
scripts O
in O
the O
same O
condition O
were O
not O
presented O
consecutively O
. O

Each O
trial O
lasted O
5 O
minutes O
, O
including O
a O
1.5-minute O
quiet O
baseline O
period O
followed O
by O
2.5-minute O
imagery O
period O
( O
2 O
minutes O
of O
read O
imagery O
and O
0.5 O
minutes O
of O
quiet O
imagery O
) O
and O
a O
1-minute O
quiet O
recovery O
. O

During O
baseline O
, O
participants O
were O
instructed O
to O
stay O
still O
in O
the O
scanner O
without O
engaging O
in O
any O
mental O
activity O
. O

Between O
each O
trial O
, O
participants O
were O
engaged O
in O
2-minute O
progressive O
relaxation O
to O
normalize O
any O
residual O
anxiety O
or O
craving O
from O
the O
prior O
trial O
. O

This O
technique O
was O
mainly O
focused O
on O
relaxing O
physiological O
muscle O
tension O
in O
specific O
muscle O
groups O
and O
did O
not O
involve O
mental O
relaxation O
or O
imagery O
. O

fMRI O
Statistical O
Analysis O
Individual O
Subject O
Level O
Functional O
MRI O
data O
were O
converted O
from O
Digital O
Imaging O
and O
Communication O
in O
Medicine O
format O
to O
analyze O
( O
nifti O
) O
format O
using O
XMedCon O
. O

To O
achieve O
steady-state O
equilibrium O
between O
radiofrequency O
pulsing O
and O
relaxation O
, O
the O
first O
10 O
images O
of O
each O
trial O
were O
discarded O
. O

Images O
were O
slice-time O
corrected O
using O
a O
custom-designed O
MATLAB O
program O
. O

Motion O
correction O
was O
implemented O
using O
Statistical O
Parametric O
Mapping O
version O
5 O
for O
3 O
translational O
and O
3 O
rotational O
directions O
, O
removing O
trials O
with O
linear O
motion O
greater O
than O
1.5mm O
and O
a O
rotation O
exceeding O
2 O
mm O
. O

The O
recovery O
period O
( O
1 O
minute O
) O
was O
excluded O
from O
the O
data O
analysis O
to O
prevent O
carryover O
effects O
from O
the O
imagery O
period O
. O

Individual-level O
analysis O
was O
conducted O
using O
a O
general O
linear O
model O
on O
each O
voxel O
in O
the O
entire O
brain O
volume O
with O
a O
task O
specific O
regressor O
( O
2.5-minute O
imagery O
relative O
to O
a O
1.5-minute O
baseline O
) O
using O
Yale O
BioImageSuite30 O
( O
http O
: O
//www.bioimagesuite.org/ O
) O
. O

To O
account O
for O
potential O
variability O
in O
baseline O
fMRI O
signal O
, O
drift O
correction O
was O
included O
in O
the O
general O
linear O
model O
. O

Each O
trial O
was O
normalized O
against O
the O
immediate O
baseline O
period O
preceding O
the O
script O
and O
then O
the O
2 O
trials O
of O
the O
same O
type O
were O
averaged O
. O

Functional O
images O
were O
spatially O
smoothed O
with O
a O
6-mm O
Gaussian O
kernel O
, O
resulting O
in O
normalized O
beta O
maps O
in O
the O
acquired O
space O
( O
3.44 O
mm_3.44 O
mm_4 O
mm O
) O
. O

To O
adjust O
for O
individual O
anatomical O
differences O
, O
3 O
registrations O
were O
performed O
using O
the O
Yale O
BioImageSuite O
program O
: O
a O
linear O
individual O
registration O
of O
raw O
functional O
image O
into O
a O
2-dimensional O
anatomical O
image O
, O
2-dimensional O
to O
3-dimensional O
( O
1 O
mm_1mm_1 O
mm O
) O
linear O
registration O
, O
and O
a O
nonlinear O
registration O
to O
the O
reference O
3-dimensional O
Montreal O
Neurological O
Institute O
image O
. O

Group O
Level O
: O
Whole O
Brain O
Correlations O
Whole O
brain O
voxel-wise O
correlation O
analyses O
were O
run O
to O
determine O
the O
relationship O
between O
blood O
oxygen O
level O
dependent O
( O
BOLD O
) O
response O
to O
stress O
, O
neutral O
, O
and O
alcohol O
cues O
and O
laboratory O
session O
hormonal O
measurements O
at O
baseline O
and O
in O
response O
to O
neutral O
, O
alcohol O
, O
and O
stress O
cues O
. O

A O
family-wise O
error O
correction O
was O
applied O
to O
correct O
for O
multiple O
comparisons O
based O
on O
a O
MonteCarlo O
Simulation O
run O
in O
AFNI O
AlphaSim O
( O
p O
< O
0.05 O
, O
cluster O
size O
minimum=168 O
voxels O
) O
. O

To O
account O
for O
extreme O
values O
, O
90 O
% O
winsorization O
was O
applied O
to O
the O
cort O
: O
ACTH O
ratio O
of O
two O
outliers O
, O
whose O
heart O
rate O
and O
ROI O
Beta O
values O
were O
beyond O
2 O
standard O
deviations O
from O
the O
mean O
. O

Ninety O
percent O
winsorization O
is O
the O
process O
of O
determining O
the O
value O
of O
the O
95th O
and O
5th O
percentiles O
of O
a O
given O
measure O
and O
setting O
any O
outliers O
to O
these O
values O
. O

Prospective O
Follow O
up O
All O
patients O
were O
followed O
up O
with O
face-to-face O
interviews O
conducted O
on O
days O
14 O
, O
30 O
, O
and O
90 O
post O
discharge O
to O
evaluate O
relapse O
outcomes O
using O
both O
urinalysis O
and O
breathalyzer O
samples O
, O
in O
addition O
to O
the O
Form O
90 O
substance O
use O
timeline O
follow-back O
calendar O
based O
interview O
, O
as O
reported O
in O
our O
previous O
studies O
. O

Relapse O
Prediction O
Analyses O
Beta O
values O
for O
the O
VmPFC O
ROI O
reported O
to O
be O
predictive O
of O
future O
relapse O
risk O
and O
heart O
rates O
responses O
during O
fMRI O
from O
for O
the O
subgroup O
of O
AD O
patients O
included O
in O
the O
current O
study O
were O
extracted O
for O
each O
of O
the O
neutral O
imagery-baseline O
, O
stress O
imagery- O
neutral O
imagery O
, O
and O
alcohol O
imagery-neutral O
imagery O
contrasts O
. O

Similarly O
, O
for O
the O
same O
subgroup O
of O
AD O
individuals O
, O
their O
neuroendocrine O
responses O
to O
stress O
and O
alcohol O
craving O
were O
extracted O
from O
the O
laboratory O
experiment O
that O
assessed O
peripheral O
stress O
responses O
and O
alcohol O
craving O
and O
relationship O
to O
relapse O
. O

Then O
independent O
analyses O
to O
test O
the O
proposed O
current O
analyses O
were O
conducted O
using O
Cox O
proportional O
hazard O
regressions O
, O
with O
time O
to O
alcohol O
relapse O
as O
a O
censoring O
variable O
, O
to O
investigate O
whether O
the O
VmPFC O
Beta O
values O
, O
cort O
: O
ACTH O
ratio O
, O
and O
heart O
rate O
predicted O
the O
time O
to O
first O
alcohol O
relapse O
and O
time O
to O
heavy O
drinking O
. O

Effects O
of O
dexamphetamine-induced O
dopamine O
release O
on O
resting-state O
network O
connectivity O
in O
recreational O
amphetamine O
users O
and O
healthy O
controls O
Dexamphetamine O
( O
dAMPH O
) O
is O
not O
only O
used O
for O
the O
treatment O
of O
attention O
deficit O
hyperactivity O
disorder O
( O
ADHD O
) O
, O
but O
also O
as O
a O
recreational O
drug O
. O

Acutely O
, O
dAMPH O
induces O
release O
of O
predominantly O
dopamine O
( O
DA O
) O
in O
the O
striatum O
, O
and O
in O
the O
cortex O
both O
DA O
and O
noradrenaline O
. O

Recent O
animal O
studies O
have O
shown O
that O
chronic O
dAMPH O
administration O
can O
induce O
changes O
in O
the O
DA O
system O
following O
long-term O
exposure O
, O
as O
evidenced O
by O
reductions O
in O
DA O
transporters O
, O
D2/3 O
receptors O
and O
endogenous O
DA O
levels O
. O

However O
, O
only O
a O
limited O
number O
of O
studies O
have O
investigated O
the O
effects O
of O
dAMPH O
in O
the O
human O
brain O
. O

We O
used O
a O
combination O
of O
resting-state O
functional O
magnetic O
resonance O
imaging O
( O
rs-fMRI O
) O
and O
[ O
123I O
] O
IBZM O
single-photon O
emission O
computed O
tomography O
( O
SPECT O
) O
( O
to O
assess O
baseline O
D2/3 O
receptor O
binding O
and O
DA O
release O
) O
in O
15 O
recreational O
AMPH O
users O
and O
20 O
matched O
healthy O
controls O
to O
investigate O
the O
short- O
, O
and O
long-term O
effects O
of O
AMPH O
before O
and O
after O
an O
acute O
intravenous O
challenge O
with O
dAMPH O
. O

We O
found O
that O
acute O
dAMPH O
administration O
reduced O
functional O
connectivity O
in O
the O
cortico-striatal-thalamic O
network O
. O

dAMPH-induced O
DA O
release O
, O
but O
not O
DA O
D2/3 O
receptor O
binding O
, O
was O
positively O
associated O
with O
connectivity O
changes O
in O
this O
network O
. O

In O
addition O
, O
acute O
dAMPH O
reduced O
connectivity O
in O
default O
mode O
networks O
and O
salience-executive-networks O
networks O
in O
both O
groups O
. O

In O
contrast O
to O
our O
hypothesis O
, O
no O
significant O
group O
differences O
were O
found O
in O
any O
of O
the O
rs-fMRI O
networks O
investigated O
, O
possibly O
due O
to O
lack O
of O
sensitivity O
or O
compensatory O
mechanisms O
. O

Our O
findings O
thus O
support O
the O
use O
of O
ICA-based O
resting-state O
functional O
connectivity O
as O
a O
tool O
to O
investigate O
acute O
, O
but O
not O
chronic O
, O
alterations O
induced O
by O
dAMPH O
on O
dopaminergic O
processing O
in O
the O
striatum O
. O

Methods O
Participants O
Sixteen O
male O
AMPH O
users O
and O
age- O
, O
gender- O
and O
IQ-matched O
controls O
were O
recruited O
through O
online O
advertisements O
and O
flyers O
at O
local O
universities O
and O
colleges O
. O

Inclusion O
criteria O
for O
the O
AMPH O
users O
were O
at O
least O
30 O
occasions O
of O
use O
lifetime O
. O

The O
20 O
control O
subjects O
were O
healthy O
volunteers O
with O
no O
self-reported O
prior O
use O
of O
AMPH O
or O
other O
drugs O
that O
affect O
the O
dopaminergic O
system O
. O

Exclusion O
criteria O
for O
all O
participants O
were O
a O
history O
of O
a O
chronic O
neurological O
or O
psychiatric O
disorder O
, O
family O
history O
of O
sudden O
heart O
failure O
, O
current O
use O
of O
psychoactive O
medication O
, O
abnormal O
electrocardiogram O
( O
ECG O
) O
, O
positive O
drug O
screen O
, O
and O
a O
clinical O
diagnosis O
of O
ADHD O
, O
in O
addition O
to O
smoking O
more O
than O
15 O
cigarettes O
per O
day O
, O
drinking O
more O
than O
30 O
alcoholic O
beverages O
per O
week O
, O
and O
contraindications O
for O
undergoing O
an O
MRI O
scan O
( O
e.g O
. O

ferromagnetic O
fragments O
) O
or O
the O
SPECT O
procedure O
( O
e.g O
. O

allergy O
to O
iodine O
) O
. O

The O
results O
of O
the O
SPECT O
study O
in O
this O
cohort O
are O
more O
elaborately O
reported O
elsewhere O
( O
Schrantee O
et O
al O
. O
) O
. O

Participants O
agreed O
to O
abstain O
from O
smoking O
, O
caffeine O
, O
alcohol O
and O
cannabis O
for O
24 O
h O
prior O
, O
and O
for O
other O
drugs O
( O
including O
AMPH O
) O
one O
week O
prior O
to O
the O
assessments O
. O

Subjects O
were O
asked O
on O
the O
day O
of O
the O
scan O
if O
they O
had O
used O
any O
of O
these O
substances O
in O
the O
past O
two O
weeks O
. O

We O
verified O
the O
reported O
drug O
use O
with O
a O
drug O
screen O
on O
a O
urine O
sample O
with O
an O
enzyme-multiplied O
immunoassay O
for O
amphetamines O
, O
cocaine O
metabolite O
, O
opiates O
and O
marijuana O
) O
. O

In O
addition O
, O
a O
detailed O
drug O
history O
questionnaire O
was O
obtained O
and O
subjects O
filled O
in O
the O
drug O
use O
disorders O
identification O
test O
( O
DUDIT O
) O
to O
assess O
substance O
dependence O
( O
Voluse O
et O
al O
. O
) O
. O

The O
Dutch O
version O
of O
the O
National O
Adult O
Reading O
Test O
( O
DART O
IQ O
) O
was O
conducted O
as O
an O
estimate O
of O
verbal O
intelligence O
( O
Schmand O
et O
al O
. O
) O
. O

One O
participant O
in O
the O
AMPH O
group O
showed O
a O
positive O
drug O
screen O
and O
was O
therefore O
excluded O
, O
so O
the O
analyses O
were O
performed O
on O
20 O
controls O
and O
15 O
AMPH O
users O
. O

The O
medical O
ethics O
committee O
of O
the O
Academic O
Medical O
Center O
in O
Amsterdam O
approved O
the O
study O
procedures O
and O
written O
informed O
consent O
was O
obtained O
from O
all O
subjects O
and O
carried O
out O
in O
accordance O
with O
the O
standards O
of O
the O
Declaration O
of O
Helsinki O
. O

Design O
Participants O
were O
invited O
to O
the O
hospital O
for O
two O
study O
visits O
. O

On O
one O
day O
they O
underwent O
the O
SPECT O
scan O
with O
dAMPH O
administration O
and O
on O
the O
other O
day O
they O
underwent O
the O
MRI O
scan O
with O
dAMPH O
administration O
. O

The O
visits O
were O
at O
least O
one O
week O
apart O
to O
allow O
drug O
washout O
and O
were O
counterbalanced O
within O
groups O
. O

Both O
for O
the O
MRI O
and O
the O
SPECT O
scan O
, O
a O
cannula O
was O
inserted O
in O
the O
antecubital O
vein O
through O
which O
the O
dAMPH O
was O
administered O
( O
0.3 O
mg/kg O
) O
during O
2 O
min O
, O
followed O
by O
15 O
ml O
saline O
to O
flush O
( O
Fig O
. O

1 O
) O
. O

SPECT O
acquisition O
and O
analysis O
Each O
subject O
received O
an O
intravenous O
injection O
of O
180 O
MBq O
[ O
123I O
] O
IBZM O
( O
80 O
MBq O
bolus O
followed O
by O
constant O
infusion O
of O
20 O
MBq O
for O
5 O
consecutive O
hours O
) O
. O

Subjects O
underwent O
two O
[ O
123I O
] O
IBZM O
SPECT O
scans O
, O
using O
the O
sustained O
equilibrium/constant O
infusion O
technique O
, O
to O
assess O
baseline O
striatal O
DA O
D2/3 O
receptor O
availability O
and O
the O
decrease O
in O
D2/3 O
receptor O
binding O
after O
the O
dAMPH O
challenge O
, O
which O
provides O
an O
index O
of O
DA O
release O
( O
Kegeles O
et O
al O
. O
) O
. O

The O
radioligand O
[ O
123I O
] O
IBZM O
, O
which O
binds O
with O
high O
affinity O
to O
DA O
D2/3 O
receptors O
, O
was O
prepared O
by O
GE O
Healthcare O
( O
Eindhoven O
, O
The O
Netherlands O
) O
. O

Participants O
received O
potassium O
iodide O
tablets O
prior O
to O
the O
SPECT O
session O
to O
block O
thyroid O
uptake O
of O
free O
radioactive O
iodide O
. O

Images O
were O
acquired O
on O
a O
brain-dedicated O
SPECT O
system O
( O
Neurofocus O
810 O
, O
Inc. O
, O
Medfield O
, O
Massachusetts O
, O
USA O
) O
with O
the O
following O
parameters O
: O
matrix O
: O
64 O
× O
64 O
, O
energy O
window O
: O
135–190 O
keV O
, O
slice O
thickness O
: O
5 O
mm O
, O
acquisition O
time O
per O
slice O
: O
300 O
s O
, O
number O
of O
slices O
: O
12 O
. O

SPECT O
images O
were O
corrected O
for O
attenuation O
and O
reconstructed O
using O
iterative O
algorithms O
, O
as O
earlier O
described O
( O
Booij O
et O
al O
. O

; O
Boot O
et O
al O
. O
) O
. O

Binding O
potential O
( O
BPND O
) O
was O
calculated O
as O
follows O
: O
( O
mean O
striatal O
binding O
– O
mean O
binding O
occipital O
cortex O
) O
/mean O
binding O
occipital O
cortex O
. O

Standard O
templates O
with O
fixed O
ROIs O
were O
positioned O
on O
the O
striatum O
and O
occipital O
cortex O
( O
reflecting O
non-specific O
binding O
) O
, O
as O
earlier O
described O
( O
Booij O
et O
al O
. O

; O
Boot O
et O
al O
. O

; O
Figee O
et O
al O
. O
) O
. O

dAMPH-induced O
decrease O
in O
[ O
123I O
] O
IBZM O
BPND O
, O
used O
as O
a O
proxy O
for O
DA O
release O
, O
was O
expressed O
as O
a O
% O
of O
the O
pre-dAMPH O
BPND O
( O
Booij O
et O
al O
. O
) O
. O

FMRI O
acquisition O
Imaging O
was O
performed O
on O
a O
3-Tesla O
Ingenia O
scanner O
( O
Philips O
, O
Best O
, O
The O
Netherlands O
) O
equipped O
with O
a O
16-channel O
head O
coil O
. O

A O
T1-weighted O
anatomical O
scan O
was O
acquired O
for O
registration O
purposes O
. O

For O
the O
rs-fMRI O
scan O
with O
blood-oxygenation O
level-dependent O
( O
BOLD O
) O
contrast O
, O
130 O
whole O
brain O
volumes O
of O
T2 O
* O
-weighted O
gradient O
echo O
planar O
images O
( O
EPI O
) O
were O
obtained O
with O
the O
following O
scan O
parameters O
: O
TR/TE O
2300/25 O
ms O
; O
flip O
angle O
80° O
; O
FOV O
= O
220 O
× O
220 O
× O
117 O
; O
39 O
slices O
; O
voxel O
size O
2.3 O
× O
2.3 O
× O
3 O
mm O
, O
SENSE O
2.4 O
. O

The O
subjects O
underwent O
the O
rs-fMRI O
scan O
before O
dAMPH O
administration O
and O
approximately O
30 O
min O
post-dAMPH O
. O

In O
the O
time O
between O
the O
2 O
resting-state O
scans O
the O
subjects O
underwent O
an O
arterial O
spin O
labeling O
( O
ASL O
) O
scan O
. O

Subjects O
were O
instructed O
to O
keep O
their O
eyes O
open O
and O
let O
their O
mind O
wander O
. O

FMRI O
analysis O
ICA O
network O
extraction O
and O
connectivity O
analyses O
RS-fMRI O
data O
were O
preprocessed O
using O
tools O
from O
the O
FMRIB O
Software O
Library O
( O
Smith O
et O
al O
. O
) O
. O

Brain O
tissue O
was O
extracted O
for O
both O
anatomical O
and O
functional O
images O
using O
the O
brain O
extraction O
tool O
( O
BET O
) O
. O

Functional O
data O
were O
motion O
corrected O
, O
spatially O
smoothed O
with O
a O
Gaussian O
kernel O
of O
5 O
mm O
FWHM O
and O
high-pass O
temporal O
filtering O
at O
0.1 O
Hz O
was O
applied O
. O

In O
addition O
, O
single O
session O
independent O
component O
analysis O
( O
ICA O
) O
was O
performed O
to O
prepare O
the O
data O
for O
FMRIB O
’ O
s O
ICA-based O
Xnoiseifier O
( O
FIX O
) O
( O
Griffanti O
et O
al O
. O

; O
Salimi-Khorshidi O
et O
al O
. O
) O

to O
denoise O
the O
rs-fMRI O
data O
. O

Prior O
to O
analysis O
, O
all O
functional O
images O
were O
first O
registered O
to O
the O
high-resolution O
anatomical O
image O
( O
BBR O
) O
and O
subsequently O
to O
standard O
stereotactic O
space O
( O
2 O
mm O
, O
MNI152 O
template O
; O
Montreal O
Neurological O
Institute O
, O
Montreal O
QC O
) O
using O
affine O
transformation O
. O

Subsequently O
, O
the O
denoised O
data O
were O
used O
to O
investigate O
RS O
networks O
in O
our O
groups O
using O
multi-session O
ICA O
with O
temporal O
concatenation O
( O
as O
implemented O
in O
FSL O
MELODIC O
, O
Beckmann O
and O
Smith O
) O
. O

Automatic O
dimensionality O
estimation O
was O
used O
to O
estimate O
the O
number O
of O
components O
extracted O
. O

In O
addition O
to O
the O
CST O
network O
, O
we O
explored O
7 O
networks O
for O
further O
analysis O
based O
on O
their O
involvement O
in O
higher-order O
cognitive O
processes O
and/or O
DA-ergic O
function O
or O
DA-associated O
pathologies O
( O
Cole O
et O
al O
. O
) O
. O

These O
networks O
will O
be O
referred O
to O
as O
the O
( O
i O
) O
left-lateralised O
fronto-parietal O
network O
( O
lFPN O
) O
( O
ii O
) O
right-lateralised O
fronto-parietal O
network O
( O
rFPN O
) O
( O
iii O
) O
anterior O
default O
mode O
network O
( O
aDMN O
) O
( O
iv O
) O
posterior O
default O
mode O
network O
( O
pDMN O
) O
( O
v O
) O
ventral O
default O
mode O
network O
( O
vDMN O
) O
( O
vi O
) O
inferior O
salience/executive O
network O
( O
iSEN O
) O
( O
vii O
) O
dorsal O
salience/executive O
network O
( O
dSEN O
) O
. O

For O
those O
eight O
networks O
, O
the O
set O
of O
spatial O
maps O
from O
the O
group-average O
analysis O
was O
used O
to O
generate O
subject-specific O
versions O
of O
the O
spatial O
maps O
, O
and O
associated O
time-series O
, O
using O
dual O
regression O
with O
variance O
normalization O
( O
Beckmann O
et O
al O
. O

; O
Filippini O
et O
al O
. O
) O
. O

First O
, O
for O
each O
subject O
, O
the O
group-average O
set O
of O
spatial O
maps O
was O
regressed O
( O
as O
spatial O
regressors O
in O
a O
multiple O
regression O
) O
into O
the O
subject O
’ O
s O
4D O
space-time O
dataset O
. O

This O
results O
in O
a O
set O
of O
subject-specific O
time-series O
, O
one O
per O
group-level O
spatial O
map O
. O

Next O
, O
those O
time-series O
were O
regressed O
( O
as O
temporal O
regressors O
, O
again O
in O
a O
multiple O
regression O
) O
into O
the O
same O
4D O
dataset O
, O
resulting O
in O
a O
set O
of O
subject-specific O
spatial O
maps O
, O
one O
per O
group-level O
spatial O
map O
. O

To O
assess O
baseline O
group O
differences O
, O
the O
4D O
files O
for O
each O
network O
were O
then O
analyzed O
using O
non-parametric O
permutation O
testing O
( O
5000 O
permutations O
) O
with O
a O
two-sample O
t-test O
using O
the O
FSL O
Randomise O
tool O
( O
Winkler O
et O
al O
. O
) O
. O

To O
assess O
the O
effect O
of O
drug O
and O
the O
interaction O
effect O
of O
drug O
and O
group O
, O
we O
calculated O
difference O
values O
of O
the O
parameter O
estimates O
within O
subjects O
first O
using O
fslmaths O
, O
and O
then O
performed O
a O
one-sample O
t-test O
and O
a O
two-sample O
t-test O
respectively O
, O
again O
using O
Randomise O
. O

All O
analyses O
were O
initially O
thresholded O
at O
p-value O
< O
0.05 O
with O
a O
family O
wise O
error O
( O
FWE O
) O
correction O
using O
threshold O
free O
cluster O
enhancement O
( O
TFCE O
) O
( O
Smith O
and O
Nichols O
) O
. O

Comparison O
of O
changes O
in O
RS O
FC O
and O
DA O
release O
The O
4D O
files O
comprising O
subject-specific O
spatial O
maps O
of O
voxelwise O
connectivity O
with O
the O
CST O
that O
were O
obtained O
from O
the O
dual O
regression O
analysis O
, O
were O
used O
to O
assess O
the O
correlation O
between O
changes O
in O
RS O
FC O
and O
striatal O
DA O
release O
following O
acute O
dAMPH O
administration O
. O

We O
examined O
specifically O
this O
network O
because O
it O
incorporated O
the O
striatum O
, O
the O
brain O
region O
in O
which O
we O
measured O
DA O
release O
with O
SPECT O
, O
and O
because O
dAMPH O
is O
thought O
to O
exert O
its O
greatest O
effects O
in O
the O
basal O
ganglia O
( O
due O
to O
its O
intense O
DA-ergic O
input O
) O
. O

A O
striatal O
mask O
was O
created O
for O
the O
FC O
map O
using O
the O
MNI O
structural O
atlas O
( O
Collins O
et O
al O
. O
) O
. O

We O
tested O
whether O
individual O
differences O
in O
RS O
FC O
within O
this O
striatal O
mask O
were O
significantly O
positively O
or O
negatively O
correlated O
with O
DA O
release O
as O
measured O
with O
[ O
123I O
] O
IBZM O
SPECT O
within O
the O
same O
striatal O
mask O
in O
the O
CST O
using O
voxelwise O
non-parametric O
permutation O
testing O
as O
implemented O
in O
Randomise O
, O
with O
5000 O
permutations O
and O
5 O
mm O
variance O
smoothing O
. O

Voxels O
were O
considered O
significant O
at O
p-value O
< O
0.05 O
with O
a O
FWE O
correction O
for O
multiple O
comparisons O
using O
TFCE O
. O

Effects O
of O
heart O
rate O
of O
RS O
FC O
Changes O
in O
heart O
rate O
( O
HR O
) O
have O
been O
found O
to O
influence O
the O
BOLD O
signal O
, O
especially O
near O
large O
vessels O
, O
and O
consequentially O
influence O
FC O
in O
RSNs O
( O
Khalili-Mahani O
et O
al O
. O
) O
. O

Dopaminergic O
drugs O
such O
as O
dAMPH O
are O
known O
to O
increase O
HR O
and O
blood O
pressure O
( O
Lile O
et O
al O
. O
) O
. O

Although O
FIX O
denoises O
the O
data O
and O
thereby O
removes O
a O
lot O
of O
physiological O
variation O
, O
it O
has O
been O
shown O
that O
areas O
of O
physiological O
variation O
can O
overlap O
with O
our O
RSNs O
of O
interest O
. O

Therefore O
, O
we O
decided O
to O
repeat O
our O
analyses O
using O
average O
HR O
as O
a O
covariate O
. O

HR O
was O
monitored O
during O
the O
MRI O
scan O
session O
using O
a O
4-lead O
vector O
cardiogram O
( O
VCG O
) O
signal O
and O
data O
were O
extracted O
using O
an O
in O
house O
MATLAB O
script O
. O

Five O
of O
our O
HR O
measurements O
were O
missing O
and O
they O
were O
imputed O
with O
the O
average O
HR O
of O
the O
group O
and O
session O
the O
scan O
belonged O
to O
. O

Sample-Poor O
Estimation O
of O
Order O
and O
Common O
Signal O
Subspace O
with O
Application O
to O
Fusion O
of O
Medical O
Imaging O
Data O
Due O
to O
their O
data-driven O
nature O
, O
multivariate O
methods O
such O
as O
canonical O
correlation O
analysis O
( O
CCA O
) O
have O
proven O
very O
useful O
for O
fusion O
of O
multimodal O
neurological O
data O
. O

However O
, O
being O
able O
to O
determine O
the O
degree O
of O
similarity O
between O
datasets O
and O
appropriate O
order O
selection O
are O
crucial O
to O
the O
success O
of O
such O
techniques O
. O

The O
standard O
methods O
for O
calculating O
the O
order O
of O
multimodal O
data O
focus O
only O
on O
sources O
with O
the O
greatest O
individual O
energy O
and O
ignore O
relations O
across O
datasets O
. O

Additionally O
, O
these O
techniques O
as O
well O
as O
the O
most O
widely-used O
methods O
for O
determining O
the O
degree O
of O
similarity O
between O
datasets O
assume O
sufficient O
sample O
support O
and O
are O
not O
effective O
in O
the O
sample-poor O
regime O
. O

In O
this O
paper O
, O
we O
propose O
to O
jointly O
estimate O
the O
degree O
of O
similarity O
between O
datasets O
and O
their O
order O
when O
few O
samples O
are O
present O
using O
principal O
component O
analysis O
and O
canonical O
correlation O
analysis O
( O
PCA-CCA O
) O
. O

By O
considering O
these O
two O
problems O
simultaneously O
, O
we O
are O
able O
to O
minimize O
the O
assumptions O
placed O
on O
the O
data O
and O
achieve O
superior O
performance O
in O
the O
sample-poor O
regime O
compared O
to O
traditional O
techniques O
. O

We O
apply O
PCA-CCA O
to O
the O
pairwise O
combinations O
of O
functional O
magnetic O
resonance O
imaging O
( O
fMRI O
) O
, O
structural O
magnetic O
resonance O
imaging O
( O
sMRI O
) O
, O
and O
electroencephalogram O
( O
EEG O
) O
data O
drawn O
from O
patients O
with O
schizophrenia O
and O
healthy O
controls O
while O
performing O
an O
auditory O
oddball O
task O
. O

The O
PCA-CCA O
results O
indicate O
that O
the O
fMRI O
and O
sMRI O
datasets O
are O
the O
most O
similar O
, O
whereas O
the O
sMRI O
and O
EEG O
datasets O
share O
the O
least O
similarity O
. O

We O
also O
demonstrate O
that O
the O
degree O
of O
similarity O
obtained O
by O
PCA-CCA O
is O
highly O
predictive O
of O
the O
degree O
of O
significance O
found O
for O
components O
generated O
using O
CCA O
. O

2 O
. O

Materials O
and O
Methods O
2.1 O
. O

Theory O
2.1.1 O
. O

Traditional O
and O
Sample-poor O
Hypothesis O
Test O
Let O

assume O
that O
we O
have O
M O
independent O
and O

distributed O
( O

. O
) O

paired O
samples O
of O
x O
[ O
1 O
] O
∈ O
ℝn O
and O
x O
[ O
2 O
] O
∈ O
ℝm O
from O
the O

model O
, O
where O
s O
[ O
k O
] O
∈ O
ℝd+f O
, O
k O
= O
1 O
, O
2 O
, O
are O

= O

{ O

] O
( O

) O

} O

is O

. O

Thus O

] O

signals O
and O

. O

Without O

the O

of O

The O

zero-mean O
Gaussian O

Additionally O

of O

that O

fixed O

. O

We O

data O

. O

When O
performing O
CCA O
when O

< O

m+n−M O
of O

, O
k̂i O
, O

= O
1 O
, O
… O
, O
q O
, O
q O
= O
min O
( O
m O
, O

) O
, O
will O
be O
identically O
1 O

of O

of O

. O

Moreover O
, O

. O

This O

, O

of O

. O

A O
classical O
way O
of O

d O
is O
by O
assuming O
that O
the O
sources O
are O
drawn O
from O
a O
multivariate O
Gaussian O

and O
applying O
a O

of O
binary O

tests O
. O

The O
test O
begins O
with O
s O
= O
0 O
and O
compares O
the O
two O
hypotheses O
H0 O
: O
d O
= O
s O
and O
H1 O
: O
d O
> O
s. O
If O
the O
null O
hypothesis O
is O
rejected O
, O
then O
s O
is O
increased O
by O
one O
and O
the O
test O
is O
repeated O
, O
until O
either O
the O
null O
hypothesis O
is O
not O
rejected O
or O
s O
= O
q O
. O

This O
test O
is O
based O
on O
the O
Bartlett-Lawley O
statistic O
, O
which O
is O
given O
by O
and O
is O
asymptotically O
distributed O
under O
H0 O
as O
χ2 O
with O
( O
m−s O
) O
( O
n−s O
) O
degrees O
of O
freedom O
. O

The O
fact O
that O
the O
test O
statistic O
is O
distributed O
according O
to O
the O
χ2 O
distribution O
enables O
the O
determination O
of O
a O
threshold O
, O
T O
( O
s O
) O
, O
to O
meet O
a O
given O
probability O
of O

, O
PFA O
, O
for O
the O
test O
. O

A O
major O
constraint O
of O

traditional O
framework O
is O
the O
assumption O
of O
sufficient O
samples O
, O
i.e. O
, O
that O
the O
k̂i O
’ O

are O
accurate O

of O
the O
true O
ki O
’ O
s O
, O
making O
it O
not O
applicable O
for O
the O

. O

As O
proposed O
in O
, O
the O

of O

test O
selects O
where O
ℛ O
= O
{ O

rmax O
} O

= O
{ O

, O

( O

, O

) O

statistic O
is O
Note O
in O

that O

are O

of O

, O

By O

that O

. O

Note O

still O

χ2 O

( O

“ O
sufficiently O

smaller O

. O

This O

( O

, O

) O

. O

However O
, O

. O

Greater O

about O

2.1.2 O
. O

CCA O
for O
Multimodal O
Fusion O
Due O
to O
the O
inherent O
dissimilarities O
between O
different O
modalities O
, O
direct O
fusion O
of O
multimodal O
data O
is O
difficult O
. O

Therefore O
, O
rather O
than O
jointly O
analyzing O
the O
multimodal O
datasets O
directly O
, O
it O
is O
often O
beneficial O
to O
reduce O
each O
modality O
to O
a O
feature O
, O
a O
lower-dimensional O
multivariate O
representation O
of O
the O
data O
, O
for O
each O
subject O
within O
the O
study O
. O

See O
Section O
3.2 O
for O
greater O
detail O
about O
the O
features O
used O
in O
this O
study O
. O

This O
reduction O
enables O
the O
exploration O
of O
associations O
across O
feature O
sets O
through O
the O
analysis O
of O
variations O
across O
individuals O
. O

Such O
an O
investigation O
of O
variations O
between O
subjects O
through O
fused O
features O
provides O
a O
natural O
way O
to O
explore O
associations O
across O
modalities O
, O
since O
it O
constructs O
a O
common O
dimension O
for O
datasets O
of O
otherwise O
different O
dimensionality O
. O

In O
addition O
, O
due O
to O
the O
dissimilarities O
between O
modalities O
, O
the O
subject O
covariations O
provide O
the O
dimension O
of O
coherence O
in O
multimodal O
fusion O
using O
CCA O
, O
since O
similarity O
between O
covariations O
across O
modalities O
is O
expected O
. O

Figure O
1 O
depicts O
the O
model O
for O
multimodal O
fusion O
using O
CCA O
following O
spatial O
dimension O
reduction O
through O
PCA O
; O
the O
implementation O
of O
CCA O
for O
fusion O
is O
presented O
next O
. O

As O
explained O
in O
detail O
in O
Appendix O
B O
, O
we O
apply O
spatial O
dimension O
reduction O
through O
PCA O
, O
where O
the O
order O
, O
r O
, O
is O
selected O
using O
( O
3 O
) O
, O
to O
obtain O
dimension O
reduced O
feature O
datasets O
X̃ O
[ O
1 O
] O
and O
X̃ O
[ O
2 O
] O
. O

These O
datasets O
can O
be O
decomposed O
into O
the O
combination O
of O
subject O
covariations O
, O
S̃ O
[ O
1 O
] O
and O
S̃ O
[ O
2 O
] O
, O
and O
associated O
components O
, O
Ã O
[ O
1 O
] O
and O
Ã O
[ O
2 O
] O
, O
in O
the O
following O
manner O
, O
By O
using O
this O
decomposition O
, O
the O
relationship O
across O
modalities O
can O
be O
evaluated O
based O
on O
the O
correlation O
of O
the O
subject O
covariations O
between O
the O
two O
modalities O
. O

We O
assume O
that O
the O
subject O
covariations O
are O
uncorrelated O
within O
each O
modality O
and O
are O
correlated O
with O
at O
most O
one O
subject O
covariation O
from O
the O
other O
modality O
. O

This O
enables O
the O
exploration O
of O
the O
associations O
across O
the O
modalities O
. O

Additionally O
, O
note O
the O
lack O
of O
a O
noise O
term O
in O
( O
4 O
) O
, O
which O
emphasizes O
that O
this O
analysis O
occurs O
following O
dimension O
reduction O
through O
PCA O
. O

By O
exploiting O
the O
simple O
form O
of O
( O
4 O
) O
, O
we O
can O
use O
CCA O
to O
identify O
relations O
between O
the O
subject O
correlations O
. O

CCA O
seeks O
to O
transform O
these O
two O
sets O
of O
data O
in O
order O
to O
maximize O
their O
correlation O
. O

This O
can O
be O
expressed O
in O
the O
following O
maximization O
problem O
, O
where O
in O
the O
first O
stage O
we O
obtain O
the O
first O
rows O
of O
P O
[ O
1 O
] O
and O
P O
[ O
2 O
] O
, O
and O
, O
respectively O
, O
where O
R̂XiXj O
= O
X̃ O
[ O
i O
] O
( O
X̃ O
[ O
j O
] O
) O
T/M O
denotes O
a O
sample O
( O
cross- O
) O
covariance O
matrix O
and O
the O
operation O
corr O
( O
· O
, O
· O
) O
refers O
to O
the O
sample O
correlation O
between O
the O
columns O
of O
the O
given O
matrices O
. O

Subsequent O
rows O
of O
P O
[ O
1 O
] O
and O
P O
[ O
2 O
] O
are O
estimated O
analogous O
to O
( O
5 O
) O
with O
the O
additional O
constraint O
that O
The O
estimated O
subject O
covariations O
are O
given O
by O
, O
Greater O
detail O
about O
the O
implementation O
of O
CCA O
to O
perform O
source O
separation O
for O
multimodal O
data O
is O
found O
in O
Appendix O
B O
. O

The O
rows O
of O
Ŝ O
[ O
k O
] O
provide O
the O
loadings O
of O
each O
component O
across O
subjects O
. O

Thus O
, O
the O
p-th O
row O
of O
Ŝ O
[ O
k O
] O
, O
, O
represents O
the O
relative O
weights O
of O
the O
p-th O
source O
estimate O
, O
, O
for O
all O
subjects O
. O

Since O
each O
dataset O
has O
been O
reduced O
to O
a O
feature O
for O
each O
subject O
, O
to O
look O
for O
differences O
in O
the O
expression O
of O
components O
between O
two O
groups O
, O
a O
two-sample O
t-test O
can O
be O
performed O
on O
the O
subject O
covariations O
, O
where O
one O
group O
is O
represented O
by O
the O
subject O
covariations O
from O
the O
patients O
with O
schizophrenia O
and O
the O
second O
by O
the O
subject O
covariations O
from O
the O
healthy O
controls O
. O

This O
enables O
the O
detection O
of O
components O
that O
can O
differentiate O
patients O
from O
controls O
, O
providing O
insight O
into O
how O
brain O
disorders O
affect O
both O
neurological O
structure O
and O
function O
. O

2.2 O
. O

Simulation O
Setup O
For O
real O
brain O
data O
, O
the O
ground O
truth O
, O
i.e. O
, O
the O
true O
latent O
sources O
and O
subject O
covariations O
, O
is O
not O
available O
. O

Thus O
, O
in O
order O
to O
test O
the O
performance O
of O
PCA-CCA O
, O
we O
generate O
simulated O
data O
according O
to O
( O
1 O
) O
and O
examine O
the O
probability O
of O
correctly O
estimating O
the O
true O
number O
of O
correlated O
components O
as O
the O
dimension O
of O
the O
datasets O
, O
m O
and O
n O
, O
increases O
from O
10 O
to O
10,000 O
. O

We O
compare O
the O
performance O
of O
PCA-CCA O
to O
that O
of O
two O
classical O
ITC-based O
methods O
, O
AIC O
and O
MDL O
. O

These O
methods O
use O
the O
AIC O
and O
MDL O
framework O
in O
in O
the O
PCA O
step O
to O
select O
r O
, O
and O
then O
use O
the O
AIC O
and O
MDL O
framework O
described O
in O
to O
estimate O
the O
common O
order O
. O

For O
these O
simulations O
, O
we O
have O
M O
= O
50 O
samples O
and O
d O
= O
2 O
pairs O
of O
correlated O
components O
each O
with O
variance O
of O
2 O
and O
correlation O
coefficients O
, O
ρ1 O
= O
0.8 O
and O
ρ2 O
= O
0.7 O
. O

The O
number O
of O
uncorrelated O
components O
in O
s O
[ O
1 O
] O
and O
s O
[ O
2 O
] O
, O
f O
, O
is O
3 O
. O

The O
variances O
of O
the O
uncorrelated O
signals O
and O
the O
white O
noise O
are O
both O
1 O
. O

These O
parameters O
were O
selected O
to O
align O
with O
properties O
of O
real O
neurological O
data O
. O

The O
entries O
of O
the O
mixing O
matrices O
A O
[ O
k O
] O
are O
independently O
drawn O
from O
uniformly O
distributed O
random O
numbers O
between O
0 O
and O
1 O
. O

Additionally O
, O
we O
consider O
two O
values O
, O
0.001 O
and O
0.005 O
, O
for O
probability O
of O
false O
alarm O
, O
PFA O
. O

We O
have O
also O
used O
a O
minimum O
description O
length O
( O
MDL O
) O
based O
method O
, O
described O
in O
Appendix O
A O
, O
which O
does O
not O
require O
the O
selection O
of O
a O
probability O
of O
false O
alarm O
. O

The O
plots O
presented O
here O
are O
the O
average O
result O
of O
1000 O
independent O
Monte-Carlo O
simulations O
, O
where O
, O
for O
each O
simulation O
, O
every O
method O
was O
used O
on O
the O
same O
data O
. O

We O
repeated O
this O
simulation O
three O
times O
, O
changing O
only O
the O
distribution O
from O
which O
the O
sources O
, O
s O
[ O
k O
] O
, O
are O
drawn O
. O

In O
the O
first O
case O
, O
we O
consider O
sources O
drawn O
from O
a O
zero O
mean O
Gaussian O
distribution O
, O
which O
aligns O
with O
the O
form O
typically O
used O
in O
all O
derivations O
. O

The O
subsequent O
case O
considers O
sources O
that O
are O
uniformly O
distributed O
with O
zero O
mean O
and O
the O
same O
variance O
as O
the O
previous O
case O
. O

Such O
sub-Gaussian O
or O
platykurtic O
sources O
are O
a O
good O
approximation O
of O
the O
subject O
covariations O
, O
since O
if O
there O
is O
a O
difference O
between O
the O
two O
groups O
then O
the O
distribution O
describing O
the O
subject O
covariations O
will O
be O
bi-modal O
and O
hence O
sub-Gaussian O
. O

Thus O
, O
the O
performance O
of O
PCA-CCA O
in O
this O
case O
is O
of O
great O
interest O
. O

The O
final O
case O
considered O
is O
where O
the O
sources O
are O
Laplacian O
distributed O
with O
zero O
mean O
and O
the O
same O
variance O
as O
the O
previous O
distributions O
. O

Due O
to O
the O
ability O
of O
the O
Laplacian O
distribution O
to O
provide O
good O
approximations O
of O
empirical O
fMRI O
source O
distributions O
, O
studying O
the O
performance O
of O
PCA-CCA O
in O
this O
regime O
is O
of O
interest O
for O
the O
fusion O
of O
two O
fMRI O
datasets O
. O

Brain O
activation O
differences O
in O
schizophrenia O
during O
context-dependent O
processing O
of O
saccade O
tasks O
Background O
Brain O
function O
in O
schizophrenia O
has O
been O
probed O
using O
saccade O
paradigms O
and O
functional O
magnetic O
resonance O
imaging O
, O
but O
little O
information O
exists O
about O
how O
changing O
task O
context O
impacts O
saccade O
related O
brain O
activation O
and O
behavioral O
performance O
. O

We O
recruited O
schizophrenia O
and O
comparison O
subjects O
to O
perform O
saccade O
tasks O
in O
differing O
contexts O
: O
( O
1 O
) O
two O
single O
task O
runs O
( O
anti- O
or O
pro-saccades O
alternating O
with O
fixation O
) O
and O
( O
2 O
) O
one O
dual O
task O
run O
( O
antisaccades O
alternating O
with O
prosaccades O
) O
. O

Results O
Context-dependent O
differences O
in O
saccade O
circuitry O
were O
evaluated O
using O
ROI O
analyses O
. O

Distinction O
between O
anti- O
and O
pro-saccade O
activation O
across O
contexts O
( O
single O
versus O
dual O
task O
) O
suggests O
that O
the O
schizophrenia O
group O
did O
not O
respond O
to O
context O
in O
the O
same O
way O
as O
the O
comparison O
group O
. O

Conclusions O
Further O
investigation O
of O
context O
processing O
effects O
on O
brain O
activation O
and O
saccade O
performance O
measures O
informs O
models O
of O
cognitive O
deficits O
in O
the O
disorder O
and O
enhances O
understanding O
of O
antisaccades O
as O
a O
potential O
endophenotype O
for O
schizophrenia O
. O

Electronic O
supplementary O
material O
The O
online O
version O
of O
this O
article O
( O
doi:10.1186/s12993-016-0103-2 O
) O
contains O
supplementary O
material O
, O
which O
is O
available O
to O
authorized O
users O
. O

Methods O
Subjects O
We O
recruited O
thirty O
DSM-IV-TR O
diagnosed O
schizophrenia O
subjects O
( O
age O
M O
= O
37.8 O
years O
, O
SD O
= O
10.5 O
; O
60 O
% O
male O
, O
27 O
right O
handed O
) O
and O
twenty-nine O
comparison O
subjects O
( O
age O
M O
= O
36.3 O
years O
, O
SD O
= O
11.2 O
; O
55 O
% O
male O
, O
26 O
right O
handed O
) O
. O

Comparison O
subjects O
were O
given O
the O
non-patient O
edition O
of O
the O
structured O
clinical O
interview O
for O
DSM-IV-TR O
and O
the O
schizotypal O
personality O
questionnaire O
( O
SPQ O
) O
to O
rule O
out O
existing O
psychopathology O
. O

All O
subjects O
signed O
an O
informed O
consent O
and O
were O
screened O
for O
confounding O
factors O
: O
head O
trauma O
, O
drug O
use O
, O
and/or O
criteria O
related O
to O
MRI O
compatibility O
. O

This O
study O
was O
approved O
by O
the O
University O
of O
Georgia O
( O
UGA O
) O
Institutional O
Review O
Board O
. O

Procedure O
Imaging O
was O
performed O
at O
the O
UGA O
Bio-Imaging O
Research O
Center O
with O
a O
GE O
Excite O
HD O
3.0T O
MRI O
scanner O
( O
Milwaukee O
, O
Wisconsin O
, O
USA O
) O
. O

Subjects O
were O
given O
task-specific O
instructions O
before O
being O
positioned O
in O
the O
scanner O
. O

Heads O
were O
stabilized O
with O
foam O
padding O
and O
a O
forehead O
strap O
. O

Subjects O
viewed O
stimuli O
through O
a O
dual O
mirror O
box O
( O
16 O
cm O
above O
and O
in O
front O
of O
the O
eyes O
) O
on O
a O
screen O
at O
their O
feet O
( O
174 O
cm O
from O
the O
nasion O
) O
. O

Imaging O
acquisition O
included O
a O
fast O
3D O
T1-weighted O
structural O
scan O
BRAVO O
protocol O
( O
TE O
= O
4.6 O
ms O
, O

= O

, O

= O

× O

, O

= O

, O

× O

mm O
slice O
thickness O
, O

slices O
, O
scan O
time O
3 O
min O
7 O
s O
) O
to O

the O
angle O
of O
acquisition O
along O
the O
AC-PC O
line O
. O

An O

sequence O
( O

= O

, O

256 O

24 O

, O

× O

, O

mm O
slice O

, O

axial O
slices O
, O
scan O

6 O
min O

) O
was O
acquired O
to O

a O
high O

image O
of O
subjects O
’ O
brain O
anatomy O
. O

Three O
T2 O
* O
-weighted O
gradient O
echo O
whole O
brain O
EPI O
scans O
also O
were O
collected O
( O
TE O
= O

ms O
, O

= O

ms O
, O

= O

, O

= O
64 O
× O

, O

= O
22 O
cm O
, O

resolution O
3.4375 O
× O
3.4375 O
, O
4 O
mm O
slice O
thickness O
, O
33 O
slices O
, O
oblique O
acquisition O
( O
AC-PC O
aligned O
) O
, O
180 O

, O

) O
while O
eye O
