were O
recorded O
( O
MEyeTrack O
LR O
, O
SensoMotoric O
Instruments O
, O
Inc. O
, O
Berlin O
, O
Germany O
) O
. O

During O
the O
three O
T2 O
* O
scans O
, O
subjects O
performed O
two O
single O
task O
runs O
of O
saccades O
( O
blocks O
of O
anti- O
or O
pro-saccades O
alternating O
with O
blocks O
of O
fixation-Anti/Fix O
and O
Pro/Fix O
respectively O
) O
and O
one O
dual O
task O
run O
of O
saccades O
( O
blocks O
of O
antisaccades O
alternating O
with O
blocks O
of O
prosaccades-Anti/Pro O
) O
. O

Saccade O
blocks O
in O
each O
run O
contained O
7 O
trials O
. O

The O
Anti/Fix O
and O
Pro/Fix O
runs O
, O
therefore O
, O
contained O
42 O
trials O
each O
( O
6 O
blocks O
× O
7 O
trials O
) O
and O
the O
Anti/Pro O
run O
contained O
42 O
antisaccade O
trials O
( O
6 O
blocks O
× O
7 O
trials O
) O
and O
47 O
prosaccade O
trials O
( O
7 O
blocks O
× O
7 O
trials O
) O
. O

Run O
order O
was O
counterbalanced O
across O
subjects O
. O

See O
Dyckman O
et O
al O
. O

for O
saccade O
task O
instructions O
. O

Task O
parameters O
, O
stimuli O
, O
and O
timing O
are O
shown O
in O
Fig O
. O

1 O
. O

Analysis O
Behavior O
Eye O
movement O
data O
were O
scored O
in O
MATLAB O
( O
The O
Mathworks O
Inc. O
, O
Natick O
, O
MA O
, O
USA O
) O
. O

Saccade O
performance O
measures O
included O
percent O
correct O
( O
PC O
) O
[ O
( O
number O
of O
correct O
trials/total O
number O
of O
usable O
trials O
) O
×100 O
] O
and O
correct O
reaction O
time O
( O
RT O
) O
( O
time O
in O
ms O
between O
peripheral O
stimulus O
presentation O
and O
saccade O
start O
) O
for O
each O
subject O
and O
each O
saccade O
task O
in O
the O
three O
imaging O
runs O
( O
Anti/Fix O
, O
Pro/Fix O
, O
Anti/Pro O
) O
. O

Percent O
of O
corrected O
errors O
[ O
( O
number O
of O
corrected O
errors/total O
number O
of O
errors O
) O
×100 O
] O
for O
antisaccades O
also O
was O
calculated O
in O
order O
to O
assess O
subjects O
’ O
understanding O
of O
the O
task O
. O

Eye O
movements O
for O
2/30 O
schizophrenia O
and O
2/29 O
comparison O
subjects O
were O
not O
obtained O
due O
to O
technical O
difficulties O
. O

Subjects O
with O
missing O
eye O
movement O
data O
sufficiently O
performed O
all O
tasks O
and O
were O
included O
in O
the O
imaging O
analyses O
. O

fMRI O
Preprocessing O
of O
functional O
images O
was O
completed O
with O
analysis O
of O
functional O
neuroimages O
( O
AFNI O
) O
software O
and O
included O
despiking O
, O
slice O
timing O
correction O
, O
registration O
to O
a O
representative O
volume O
for O
movement O
, O
alignment O
of O
functional O
data O
to O
anatomy O
, O
smoothing O
with O
a O
4 O
mm O
full-width O
at O
half-maximum O
( O
FWHM O
) O
Gaussian O
filter O
, O
and O
scaling O
each O
voxel O
to O
a O
mean O
of O
100 O
. O

Functional O
images O
for O
each O
subject O
were O
masked O
using O
the O
subject O
’ O
s O
anatomical O
image O
and O
warped O
to O
talairach O
space O
in O
preparation O
for O
reference O
function O
estimation O
via O
a O
probabilistic O
independent O
component O
analysis O
( O
PICA O
) O
( O
using O
MELODIC O
in O
FMRIB O
Software O
Library O
) O
. O

Blocked O
design O
fMRI O
data O
is O
commonly O
analyzed O
by O
testing O
voxel O
time O
courses O
against O
hypothesized O
reference O
functions O
created O
by O
convolving O
block O
onsets O
and O
their O
durations O
with O
the O
hemodynamic O
response O
. O

These O
reference O
functions O
do O
not O
fully O
characterize O
the O
data O
, O
however O
, O
and O
are O
likely O
unrealistic O
when O
modeling O
data O
with O
multiple O
contributing O
sources O
of O
signal O
and O
noise O
. O

We O
used O
PICA O
to O
obtain O
a O
data-driven O
reference O
function O
for O
use O
in O
a O
later O
GLM O
analysis O
, O
similar O
to O
that O
suggested O
in O
McKeown O
et O
al O
.. O
PICA O
was O
chosen O
for O
reference O
function O
estimation O
because O
of O
its O
agnostic O
approach O
and O
its O
ability O
to O
reduce O
problems O
of O
overfitting O
, O
which O
can O
be O
the O
case O
when O
using O
hypothesis O
driven O
reference O
functions O
and O
GLM O
methods O
. O

Furthermore O
, O
analyses O
in O
the O
present O
study O
were O
meant O
to O
closely O
match O
those O
in O
Dyckman O
et O
al O
. O

to O
ensure O
comparability O
of O
results O
. O

Each O
run O
was O
averaged O
across O
subjects O
followed O
by O
concatenation O
of O
the O
three O
runs O
in O
space O
. O

Averaging O
across O
subjects O
is O
one O
alternative O
when O
estimating O
component O
maps O
using O
ICA O
. O

With O
a O
large O
number O
of O
subjects O
, O
it O
reduces O
the O
computational O
load O
, O
yet O
accurately O
estimates O
associated O
time O
courses O
. O

PICA O
returned O
43 O
spatially O
independent O
components O
. O

By O
referring O
to O
a O
scree O
plot O
of O
the O
percent O
of O
variance O
accounted O
for O
and O
visual O
inspection O
of O
the O
time O
course O
for O
each O
component O
, O
we O
selected O
the O
first O
four O
as O
ideal O
reference O
waveforms O
. O

Components O
are O
ordered O
by O
their O
explained O
variance O
and O
ranged O
from O
7.91 O
to O
1.6 O
% O
; O
the O
percentage O
associated O
with O
the O
4th O
component O
was O
3.5 O
% O
. O

The O
first O
four O
components O
showed O
the O
same O
peak O
frequency O
and O
time O
course O
as O
the O
experimental O
design O
. O

A O
GLM O
( O
using O
AFNI O
’ O
s O
3dFIM+ O
) O
was O
then O
performed O
for O
each O
subject O
between O
the O
time O
series O
of O
the O
first O
four O
PICA O
components O
and O
the O
BOLD O
time O
series O
in O
each O
voxel O
for O
each O
run O
. O

Movement O
estimates O
from O
registration O
in O
the O
preprocessing O
stage O
and O
functions O
characterizing O
scanner O
drift O
( O
linear O
, O
quadratic O
, O
and O
cubic O
) O
were O
used O
as O
regressors O
of O
no O
interest O
. O

For O
each O
run O
, O
results O
returned O
a O
voxel-wise O
best O
fit O
correlation O
co-efficient O
with O
one O
of O
the O
four O
task O
related O
components O
( O
see O
Dyckman O
et O
al O
. O
) O
. O

From O
the O
chosen O
component O
, O
percent O
signal O
change O
was O
calculated O
for O
each O
voxel O
. O

This O
value O
was O
used O
to O
characterize O
activation O
for O
each O
run O
: O
activation O
related O
to O
antisaccades O
compared O
to O
fixation O
in O
the O
Anti/Fix O
run O
, O
activation O
related O
to O
prosaccades O
compared O
to O
fixation O
in O
the O
Pro/Fix O
run O
, O
and O
activation O
related O
to O
antisaccades O
compared O
to O
prosaccades O
in O
the O
Anti/Pro O
run O
. O

Activation O
in O
saccade O
circuitry O
was O
evaluated O
with O
ROI O
analyses O
. O

ROIs O
were O
8 O
mm O
spheres O
centered O
on O
coordinates O
reported O
in O
Dyckman O
et O
al O
. O

and O
included O
supplementary O
eye O
fields O
( O
SEF O
) O
, O
lateral O
frontal O
eye O
fields O
( O
latFEF O
) O
, O
medial O
frontal O
eye O
fields O
( O
medFEF O
) O
, O
prefrontal O
cortex O
( O
PFC O
) O
, O
precuneus O
, O
cuneus O
, O
middle O
occipital O
gyrus O
( O
MOG O
) O
, O
inferior O
parietal O
lobule O
( O
IPL O
) O
, O
striatum O
, O
and O
thalamus O
. O

For O
each O
individual O
and O
for O
each O
run O
, O
ROI O
spheres O
were O
overlaid O
on O
functional O
maps O
. O

The O
percent O
signal O
change O
from O
voxels O
encompassed O
by O
the O
ROI O
masks O
were O
averaged O
and O
output O
as O
a O
single O
value O
for O
each O
ROI O
. O

The O
average O
percent O
signal O
change O
across O
subjects O
was O
then O
calculated O
for O
each O
ROI O
in O
each O
run O
. O

Differences O
between O
anti- O
and O
pro-saccade O
activation O
in O
the O
single O
task O
runs O
( O
Anti/Fix O
vs. O
Pro/Fix O
) O
were O
quantified O
with O
dependent O
sample O
t-tests O
. O

Differences O
between O
anti- O
and O
pro-saccade O
activation O
in O
the O
dual O
task O
run O
were O
quantified O
with O
one O
sample O
t-tests O
( O
Anti/Pro O
vs. O
0 O
) O
. O

The O
effect O
of O
context O
( O
difference O
in O
activation O
between O
anti- O
and O
pro-saccades O
in O
the O
single O
vs. O
dual O
task O
run O
) O
was O
evaluated O
with O
a O
subtraction O
method O
. O

Activation O
in O
the O
Pro/Fix O
run O
was O
subtracted O
from O
that O
in O
the O
Anti/Fix O
run O
for O
all O
ROIs O
in O
each O
subject O
. O

This O
difference O
was O
compared O
to O
activation O
in O
the O
Anti/Pro O
run O
( O
because O
of O
the O
block O
design O
nature O
, O
the O
Anti/Pro O
run O
was O
already O
the O
difference O
in O
activation O
between O
anti- O
and O
pro-saccades O
) O
. O

To O
quantify O
significant O
differences O
between O
anti- O
and O
pro-saccade O
activation O
in O
the O
single O
vs. O
dual O
task O
runs O
, O
dependent O
t O
test O
were O
done O
within O
each O
group O
. O

All O
tests O
were O
two-tailed O
and O
thresholds O
for O
significance O
were O
set O
at O
p O
= O
.05 O
. O

Choosing O
Wavelet O
Methods O
, O
Filters O
, O
and O
Lengths O
for O
Functional O
Brain O
Network O
Construction O
Wavelet O
methods O
are O
widely O
used O
to O
decompose O
fMRI O
, O
EEG O
, O
or O
MEG O
signals O
into O
time O
series O
representing O
neurophysiological O
activity O
in O
fixed O
frequency O
bands O
. O

Using O
these O
time O
series O
, O
one O
can O
estimate O
frequency-band O
specific O
functional O
connectivity O
between O
sensors O
or O
regions O
of O
interest O
, O
and O
thereby O
construct O
functional O
brain O
networks O
that O
can O
be O
examined O
from O
a O
graph O
theoretic O
perspective O
. O

Despite O
their O
common O
use O
, O
however O
, O
practical O
guidelines O
for O
the O
choice O
of O
wavelet O
method O
, O
filter O
, O
and O
length O
have O
remained O
largely O
undelineated O
. O

Here O
, O
we O
explicitly O
explore O
the O
effects O
of O
wavelet O
method O
( O
MODWT O
vs. O
DWT O
) O
, O
wavelet O
filter O
( O
Daubechies O
Extremal O
Phase O
, O
Daubechies O
Least O
Asymmetric O
, O
and O
Coiflet O
families O
) O
, O
and O
wavelet O
length O
( O
2 O
to O
24 O
) O
—each O
essential O
parameters O
in O
wavelet-based O
methods—on O
the O
estimated O
values O
of O
graph O
metrics O
and O
in O
their O
sensitivity O
to O
alterations O
in O
psychiatric O
disease O
. O

We O
observe O
that O
the O
MODWT O
method O
produces O
less O
variable O
estimates O
than O
the O
DWT O
method O
. O

We O
also O
observe O
that O
the O
length O
of O
the O
wavelet O
filter O
chosen O
has O
a O
greater O
impact O
on O
the O
estimated O
values O
of O
graph O
metrics O
than O
the O
type O
of O
wavelet O
chosen O
. O

Furthermore O
, O
wavelet O
length O
impacts O
the O
sensitivity O
of O
the O
method O
to O
detect O
differences O
between O
health O
and O
disease O
and O
tunes O
classification O
accuracy O
. O

Collectively O
, O
our O
results O
suggest O
that O
the O
choice O
of O
wavelet O
method O
and O
length O
significantly O
alters O
the O
reliability O
and O
sensitivity O
of O
these O
methods O
in O
estimating O
values O
of O
metrics O
drawn O
from O
graph O
theory O
. O

They O
furthermore O
demonstrate O
the O
importance O
of O
reporting O
the O
choices O
utilized O
in O
neuroimaging O
studies O
and O
support O
the O
utility O
of O
exploring O
wavelet O
parameters O
to O
maximize O
classification O
accuracy O
in O
the O
development O
of O
biomarkers O
of O
psychiatric O
disease O
and O
neurological O
disorders O
. O

Materials O
and O
Methods O
Ethics O
Statement O
All O
human O
subjects O
provided O
written O
informed O
consent O
for O
the O
study O
approved O
by O
the O
Institutional O
Review O
Board O
at O
the O
University O
of O
Minnesota O
. O

fMRI O
data O
acquisition O
and O
preprocessing O
Resting-state O
fMRI O
data O
from O
29 O
healthy O
controls O
( O
11 O
females O
; O
age O
41.1 O
± O
10.6 O
( O
SD O
) O
) O
and O
29 O
participants O
with O
chronic O
schizophrenia O
( O
11 O
females O
; O
age O
41.3 O
± O
9.3 O
( O
SD O
) O
) O
were O
included O
in O
this O
analysis O
( O
See O
for O
detailed O
characteristics O
of O
participants O
and O
imaging O
data O
) O
. O

A O
Siemens O
Trio O
3T O
scanner O
was O
used O
to O
collect O
the O
imaging O
data O
, O
including O
a O
6-min O
( O
TR O
= O
2 O
secs O
; O
180 O
volumes O
) O
resting-state O
fMRI O
scan O
, O
in O
which O
participants O
were O
asked O
to O
remain O
awake O
with O
their O
eyes O
closed O
, O
a O
field O
map O
scan O
, O
and O
a O
T1 O
MPRAGE O
whole O
brain O
volumetric O
scan O
. O

The O
fMRI O
data O
were O
preprocessed O
using O
FEAT O
( O
FMRIB O
’ O
s O
Software O
Library O
in O
FSL O
) O
with O
the O
following O
pipeline O
: O
deletion O
of O
the O
first O
3 O
volumes O
to O
account O
for O
magnetization O
stabilization O
; O
motion O
correction O
using O
MCFLIRT O
; O
B0 O
fieldmap O
unwarping O
to O
correct O
for O
geometric O
distortion O
using O
acquired O
field O
map O
and O
PRELUDE+FUGUE52 O
; O
slice-timing O
correction O
using O
Fourier-space O
time-series O
phase-shifting O
; O
non-brain O
removal O
using O
BET O
; O
regression O
against O
the O
6 O
motion O
parameter O
time O
courses O
; O
registration O
of O
fMRI O
to O
standard O
space O
( O
Montreal O
Neurological O
Institute-152 O
brain O
) O
; O
registration O
of O
fMRI O
to O
high O
resolution O
anatomical O
MRI O
; O
registration O
of O
high O
resolution O
anatomical O
MRI O
to O
standard O
space O
. O

Importantly O
, O
the O
two O
groups O
had O
similar O
mean O
RMS O
motion O
parameters O
: O
Two-sample O
t-tests O
of O
mean O
RMS O
translational O
and O
angular O
movement O
were O
both O
not O
significant O
( O
p O
= O
0.14 O
and O
p O
= O
0.12 O
, O
respectively O
) O
. O

Statistical O
analysis O
All O
calculations O
were O
done O
in O
MATLAB O
R2013b O
( O
The O
MathWorks O
Inc. O
) O
. O

We O
used O
the O
WMTSA O
Wavelet O
Toolkit O
for O
MATLAB O
( O
http O
: O
//www.atmos.washington.edu/~wmtsa/ O
) O
to O
perform O
the O
wavelet O
decompositions O
, O
and O
we O
used O
the O
Brain O
Connectivity O
Toolbox O
( O
https O
: O
//sites.google.com/site/bctnet/ O
) O
to O
estimate O
values O
for O
graph O
metrics O
. O

Network O
construction O
We O
extracted O
average O
time O
series O
for O
each O
participant O
from O
90 O
of O
the O
116 O
anatomical O
regions O
of O
interest O
( O
ROIs O
) O
defined O
by O
the O
AAL O
atlas O
covering O
the O
whole O
brain O
and O
including O
cortical O
and O
subcortical O
regions O
but O
excluding O
the O
cerebellar O
regions O
and O
vermis O
. O

We O
performed O
a O
battery O
of O
wavelet O
decompositions O
on O
each O
regional O
mean O
time O
series O
by O
varying O
wavelet O
method O
( O
DWT O
vs. O
MODWT O
) O
, O
wavelet O
filter O
( O
Daubechies O
Extremal O
Phase O
, O
Daubechies O
Least O
Asymmetric O
, O
and O
Coiflet O
families O
) O
, O
and O
wavelet O
length O
( O
from O
a O
minimum O
of O
2 O
to O
a O
maximum O
of O
24 O
) O
. O

In O
prior O
literature O
, O
both O
the O
discrete O
wavelet O
transform O
( O
DWT O
) O
and O
the O
maximal O
overlap O
discrete O
wavelet O
transform O
( O
MODWT O
) O
methods O
have O
been O
used O
to O
create O
functional O
connectivity O
matrices O
( O
see O
and O
respectively O
for O
examples O
) O
. O

DWT O
is O
an O
orthogonal O
transform O
, O
just O
as O
the O
discrete O
Fourier O
transform O
( O
DFT O
) O
; O
MODWT O
adds O
redundancy O
to O
DWT O
, O
and O
can O
be O
thought O
as O
a O
non-downsampled O
version O
of O
it O
. O

Wavelet O
filter O
and O
length O
alter O
the O
symmetry O
and O
shape O
of O
the O
wavelet O
( O
see O
Fig O
1 O
for O
illustrations O
of O
how O
wavelet O
filters O
differ O
from O
one O
another O
, O
and O
how O
the O
same O
filter O
of O
different O
lengths O
display O
very O
distinct O
shapes O
) O
. O

To O
examine O
the O
effect O
of O
wavelet O
filter O
, O
we O
apply O
Daubechies O
Extremal O
Phase O
, O
Daubechies O
Least O
Asymmetric O
, O
and O
Coiflet O
families O
, O
which O
together O
constitute O
the O
most O
widely O
used O
orthogonal O
and O
compactly O
supported O
types O
of O
wavelet O
filters O
. O

We O
abbreviate O
these O
three O
filters O
types O
as O
D O
( O
Daubechies O
Extremal O
Phase O
) O
, O
LA O
( O
Daubechies O
Least O
Asymmetric O
) O
, O
and O
C O
( O
Coiflet O
) O
. O

To O
examine O
the O
effect O
of O
wavelet O
length O
, O
we O
vary O
the O
length O
of O
the O
filter O
from O
a O
minimum O
of O
2 O
to O
a O
maximum O
of O
24 O
. O

Note O
that O
the O
Daubechies O
Least O
Asymmetric O
family O
is O
only O
defined O
for O
lengths O
greater O
than O
or O
equal O
to O
8 O
, O
and O
the O
Coiflet O
family O
is O
only O
defined O
for O
lengths O
that O
are O
multiples O
of O
6 O
. O

The O
exact O
range O
of O
wavelet O
lengths O
for O
each O
family O
is O
also O
prespecified O
by O
the O
software O
package O
we O
utilized O
, O
namely O
the O
WMTSA O
Wavelet O
Toolkit O
for O
MATLAB O
. O

We O
refer O
to O
each O
wavelet O
type O
and O
length O
together O
; O
for O
example O
, O
D4 O
refers O
to O
the O
Daubechies O
Extremal O
Phase O
filter O
that O
has O
a O
length O
of O
4 O
. O

Consistent O
with O
prior O
work O
, O
we O
apply O
this O
battery O
of O
wavelet O
decompositions O
to O
each O
regional O
mean O
time O
series O
and O
extract O
wavelet O
coefficients O
for O
the O
first O
four O
wavelet O
scales O
, O
which O
in O
this O
case O
correspond O
to O
the O
frequency O
ranges O
0.125∼0.25 O
Hz O
( O
Scale O
1 O
) O
, O
0.06∼0.125 O
Hz O
( O
Scale O
2 O
) O
, O
0.03∼0.06 O
Hz O
( O
Scale O
3 O
) O
, O
and O
0.015∼0.03 O
Hz O
( O
Scale O
4 O
) O
. O

For O
each O
subject O
, O
wavelet O
method O
( O
DWT O
vs. O
MODWT O
) O
, O
wavelet O
filter O
( O
Daubechies O
Extremal O
Phase O
, O
Daubechies O
Least O
Asymmetric O
, O
and O
Coiflet O
families O
) O
, O
and O
wavelet O
length O
( O
2–24 O
) O
, O
we O
constructed O
a O
correlation O
matrix O
whose O
ijth O
elements O
were O
given O
by O
the O
estimated O
wavelet O
correlation O
between O
the O
wavelet O
coefficients O
of O
brain O
region O
i O
and O
the O
wavelet O
coefficients O
of O
brain O
region O
j. O
Graph O
metrics O
We O
characterized O
the O
organization O
of O
each O
functional O
connectivity O
matrix O
using O
both O
weighted O
and O
binary O
graph O
metrics O
. O

Note O
that O
we O
use O
the O
term O
“ O
metric O
” O
due O
to O
its O
prevalence O
in O
the O
literature O
, O
but O
that O
these O
summary O
statistics O
do O
not O
necessarily O
have O
the O
properties O
of O
a O
metric O
as O
defined O
formally O
in O
the O
field O
of O
mathematics O
. O

To O
examine O
simple O
properties O
of O
the O
correlation O
matrix O
itself O
, O
we O
followed O
and O
calculated O
( O
i O
) O
the O
mean O
correlation O
coefficient O
of O
the O
matrix O
as O
the O
average O
of O
the O
upper O
triangular O
elements O
of O
the O
matrix O
, O
and O
( O
ii O
) O
the O
variance O
of O
the O
correlation O
coefficients O
of O
the O
matrix O
as O
the O
variance O
of O
the O
upper O
triangular O
elements O
of O
the O
matrix O
. O

To O
examine O
the O
topological O
properties O
of O
each O
functional O
connectivity O
matrix O
, O
we O
performed O
a O
cumulative O
thresholding O
approach O
by O
which O
we O
thresholded O
each O
matrix O
to O
maintain O
the O
strongest O
edges O
, O
giving O
a O
binary O
undirected O
network O
that O
has O
a O
density O
of O
30 O
% O
( O
see O
the O
SI O
for O
examination O
of O
other O
thresholds O
) O
. O

The O
choice O
of O
this O
threshold O
is O
based O
on O
a O
large O
and O
growing O
literature O
demonstrating O
small-world O
attributes O
of O
neuroimaging-based O
brain O
networks O
thresholded O
to O
retain O
this O
density O
. O

On O
this O
thresholded O
binary O
matrix O
, O
we O
calculated O
several O
graph O
metrics O
, O
including O
the O
clustering O
coefficient O
, O
characteristic O
path O
length O
, O
global O
efficiency O
, O
local O
efficiency O
, O
modularity O
, O
and O
number O
of O
communities O
. O

See O
the O
Appendix O
for O
mathematical O
definitions O
of O
these O
graph O
metrics O
. O

The O
maximization O
of O
modularity O
requires O
the O
investigator O
to O
make O
several O
methodological O
choices O
. O

Due O
to O
the O
heuristic O
nature O
of O
the O
Louvain O
algorithm O
used O
in O
maximizing O
the O
modularity O
quality O
function O
and O
the O
degeneracy O
of O
the O
modularity O
landscape O
, O
we O
performed O
20 O
optimizations O
of O
Q O
for O
each O
functional O
connectivity O
matrix O
. O

The O
modularity O
values O
that O
we O
report O
are O
the O
mean O
values O
over O
these O
20 O
optimizations O
. O

We O
also O
constructed O
a O
consensus O
partition O
from O
these O
optimizations O
using O
a O
method O
that O
compares O
the O
consistency O
of O
community O
assignments O
to O
that O
expected O
in O
a O
null O
model O
. O

Classification O
between O
healthy O
controls O
and O
schizophrenia O
patients O
To O
inform O
the O
utility O
of O
various O
wavelet O
methods O
, O
filters O
, O
and O
lengths O
in O
neuroimaging O
studies O
of O
functional O
brain O
network O
architecture O
, O
we O
performed O
a O
classification O
analysis O
in O
which O
we O
sought O
to O
classify O
functional O
connectivity O
matrices O
extracted O
from O
29 O
healthy O
subjects O
from O
those O
extracted O
from O
29 O
people O
with O
schizophrenia O
. O

This O
particular O
data O
set O
is O
well-suited O
to O
this O
study O
because O
it O
has O
been O
difficult O
to O
classify O
these O
two O
groups O
of O
subjects O
using O
binary O
networks O
constructed O
from O
traditional O
methods O
; O
the O
data O
set O
therefore O
offers O
a O
reasonable O
testbed O
for O
optimization O
of O
classification O
accuracy O
as O
a O
function O
of O
methodological O
variation O
. O

To O
perform O
this O
classification O
, O
we O
gathered O
all O
graph O
metrics O
obtained O
in O
scale O
2 O
( O
corresponding O
to O
the O
most O
commonly O
utilized O
frequency O
band O
for O
resting O
state O
network O
analyses O
) O
, O
and O
used O
a O
classification O
algorithm O
referred O
to O
as O
the O
C5.0 O
algorithm O
( O
http O
: O
//www.rulequest.com/see5-info.html O
) O
to O
generate O
decision O
trees O
to O
classify O
data O
from O
healthy O
controls O
versus O
people O
with O
schizophrenia O
. O

The O
C5.0 O
algorithm O
supports O
boosting O
, O
and O
is O
faster O
and O
more O
memory O
efficient O
than O
the O
previous O
C4.5 O
algorithm O
, O
which O
in O
turn O
is O
an O
extension O
of O
the O
earlier O
ID3 O
algorithm O
. O

We O
generated O
decision O
trees O
with O
10-trial O
boosting O
and O
6-fold O
cross O
validation O
. O

The O
boosting O
method O
, O
AdaBoost O
, O
allows O
us O
to O
generate O
multiple O
decision O
trees O
for O
a O
given O
set O
of O
training O
data O
and O
combine O
them O
for O
better O
classification O
while O
avoiding O
overfitting O
. O

Utilizing O
the O
cross O
validation O
procedure O
, O
we O
randomly O
divided O
all O
of O
the O
subjects O
into O
6 O
groups O
, O
and O
for O
each O
group O
, O
we O
trained O
a O
set O
of O
boosting O
decision O
trees O
on O
5 O
groups O
and O
tested O
the O
decision O
trees O
on O
the O
remaining O
group O
. O

The O
results O
we O
report O
are O
the O
cumulative O
results O
across O
these O
6 O
groups O
. O

Deep O
Independence O
Network O
Analysis O
of O
Structural O
Brain O
Imaging O
: O
Application O
to O
Schizophrenia O
Linear O
independent O
component O
analysis O
( O
ICA O
) O
is O
a O
standard O
signal O
processing O
technique O
that O
has O
been O
extensively O
used O
on O
neuroimaging O
data O
to O
detect O
brain O
networks O
with O
coherent O
brain O
activity O
( O
functional O
MRI O
) O
or O
covarying O
structural O
patterns O
( O
structural O
MRI O
) O
. O

However O
, O
its O
formulation O
assumes O
that O
the O
measured O
brain O
signals O
are O
generated O
by O
a O
linear O
mixture O
of O
the O
underlying O
brain O
networks O
and O
this O
assumption O
limits O
its O
ability O
to O
detect O
the O
inherent O
nonlinear O
nature O
of O
brain O
interactions O
. O

In O
this O
paper O
, O
we O
introduce O
nonlinear O
independent O
component O
estimation O
( O
NICE O
) O
to O
structural O
MRI O
data O
to O
detect O
abnormal O
patterns O
of O
gray O
matter O
concentration O
in O
schizophrenia O
patients O
. O

For O
this O
biomedical O
application O
, O
we O
further O
addressed O
the O
issue O
of O
model O
regularization O
of O
nonlinear O
ICA O
by O
performing O
dimensionality O
reduction O
prior O
to O
NICE O
, O
together O
with O
an O
appropriate O
control O
of O
the O
complexity O
of O
the O
model O
and O
the O
usage O
of O
a O
proper O
approximation O
of O
the O
probability O
distribution O
functions O
of O
the O
estimated O
components O
. O

We O
show O
that O
our O
results O
are O
consistent O
with O
previous O
findings O
in O
the O
literature O
, O
but O
we O
also O
demonstrate O
that O
the O
incorporation O
of O
nonlinear O
associations O
in O
the O
data O
enables O
the O
detection O
of O
spatial O
patterns O
that O
are O
not O
identified O
by O
linear O
ICA O
. O

Specifically O
, O
we O
show O
networks O
including O
basal O
ganglia O
, O
cerebellum O
and O
thalamus O
that O
show O
significant O
differences O
in O
patients O
versus O
controls O
, O
some O
of O
which O
show O
distinct O
nonlinear O
patterns O
. O

Negative O
functional O
coupling O
between O
the O
right O
fronto-parietal O
and O
limbic O
resting O
state O
networks O
predicts O
increased O
self-control O
and O
later O
substance O
use O
onset O
in O
adolescence☆ O
Recent O
developmental O
brain O
imaging O
studies O
have O
demonstrated O
that O
negatively O
coupled O
prefrontal-limbic O
circuitry O
implicates O
the O
maturation O
of O
brain O
development O
in O
adolescents O
. O

Using O
resting-state O
functional O
magnetic O
resonance O
imaging O
( O
rs-fMRI O
) O
and O
independent O
component O
analysis O
( O
ICA O
) O
, O
the O
present O
study O
examined O
functional O
network O
coupling O
between O
prefrontal O
and O
limbic O
systems O
and O
links O
to O
self-control O
and O
substance O
use O
onset O
in O
adolescents O
. O

Results O
suggest O
that O
negative O
network O
coupling O
( O
anti-correlated O
temporal O
dynamics O
) O
between O
the O
right O
fronto-parietal O
and O
limbic O
resting O
state O
networks O
is O
associated O
with O
greater O
self-control O
and O
later O
substance O
use O
onset O
in O
adolescents O
. O

These O
findings O
increase O
our O
understanding O
of O
the O
developmental O
importance O
of O
prefrontal-limbic O
circuitry O
for O
adolescent O
substance O
use O
at O
the O
resting-state O
network O
level O
. O

Method O
Resting O
state O
fMRI O
dataset O
To O
detect O
canonical O
large-scale O
resting-state O
network O
( O
RSN O
) O
commonly O
shared O
across O
people O
regardless O
of O
age O
, O
sex O
, O
education O
, O
income O
, O
and O
ethnicity O
, O
we O
first O
aggregated O
all O
possible O
rs-fMRI O
data O
collected O
from O
our O
lab O
( O
i.e. O
, O
dataset O
1 O
and O
dataset O
2 O
) O
, O
yielding O
a O
total O
of O
79 O
rs-fMRI O
scans O
( O
Total O
: O
Mage O
= O
29.16 O
years O
; O
SD O
= O
14.89 O
; O
range O
= O
13–57 O
years O
; O
dataset O
1 O
: O
Mage O
= O
27.92 O
years O
; O
SD O
= O
15.93 O
; O
range O
= O
13–52 O
years O
; O
20 O
adolescents O
and O
17 O
adults O
; O
dataset O
2 O
: O
Mage O
= O
30.32 O
years O
; O
SD O
= O
13.93 O
; O
range O
= O
14–57 O
years O
; O
17 O
adolescents O
and O
22 O
adults O
) O
. O

All O
participants O
were O
screened O
by O
a O
phone O
interview O
prior O
to O
the O
scan O
to O
ensure O
the O
participant O
was O
not O
currently O
taking O
any O
psychotropic O
medications O
and O
was O
not O
diagnosed O
with O
any O
mood O
disorder O
. O

Due O
to O
excessive O
movement O
( O
mean O
framewise O
displacement O
, O
FD O
> O
0.5 O
mm O
) O
, O
three O
data O
sets O
were O
excluded O
from O
the O
final O
analysis O
( O
three O
adolescents O
; O
range O
= O
0.83–1.85 O
mm O
) O
, O
yielding O
a O
total O
of O
76 O
resting O
state O
datasets O
possible O
to O
use O
for O
the O
group-level O
ICA O
procedure O
, O
combined O
with O
dual-regression O
( O
see O
below O
for O
analysis O
details O
) O
. O

After O
the O
group-level O
ICA O
, O
only O
the O
adolescents O
( O
age O
range O
13–17 O
years O
; O
N O
= O
37 O
) O
were O
selected O
from O
the O
total O
sample O
to O
test O
our O
primary O
prediction O
about O
the O
association O
between O
intrinsic O
functional O
network O
connectivity O
and O
substance O
use O
onset O
in O
adolescence O
( O
Mage O
= O
14.70 O
years O
; O
SD O
= O
1.10 O
; O
18 O
females O
; O
20 O
from O
dataset O
1 O
and O
17 O
from O
dataset O
2 O
) O
. O

Males O
and O
females O
did O
not O
differ O
in O
their O
age O
, O
t O
( O
35 O
) O
= O
−1.31 O
, O
p O
= O
0.20 O
( O
male O
: O
Mage O
= O
14.47 O
years O
; O
SD O
= O
0.90 O
; O
range O
= O
13–16 O
years O
; O
female O
: O
Mage O
= O
14.94 O
years O
; O
SD O
= O
1.26 O
; O
range O
= O
13–17 O
years O
) O
. O

Additional O
non-parametric O
test O
using O
independent-samples O
Mann-Whitney O
U O
Test O
confirmed O
that O
the O
distribution O
of O
age O
was O
the O
same O
across O
sex O
categories O
( O
p O
= O
0.25 O
) O
. O

Data O
acquisition O
All O
imaging O
data O
were O
collected O
using O
a O
3T-Siemens O
Trio O
MRI O
scanner O
with O
a O
32-channel O
matrix O
coil O
. O

High-resolution O
structural O
images O
( O
T1-MPRAGE O
) O
were O
acquired O
first O
( O
repetition O
time O
or O
TR O
= O
1.9 O
s O
, O
echo O
time O
or O
TE O
= O
2.3 O
ms O
, O
matrix O
size O
= O
256 O
× O
256 O
, O
field O
of O
view O
or O
FOV O
= O
230 O
mm O
, O
flip O
angle O
or O
FA O
= O
90° O
, O
1 O
mm O
isotropic O
voxel O
) O
. O

The O
resting-state O
data O
were O
acquired O
from O
a O
gradient-echo O
echo-planar O
image O
sequence O
( O
dataset O
1 O
: O
180 O
vol O
, O
38 O
slices O
with O
no O
inter-slice O
gap O
, O
TR O
= O
2 O
s O
, O
matrix O
= O
92 O
× O
92 O
, O
FOV O
= O
230 O
mm O
, O
FA O
= O
90° O
, O
voxel O
size O
2.5 O
× O
2.5 O
× O
3.3 O
mm3 O
, O
6 O
min O
duration O
; O
dataset O
2 O
: O
120 O
vol O
; O
36 O
slices O
with O
no O
inter-slice O
gap O
, O

= O
3 O
s O
, O

= O
64 O
× O
64 O
, O

= O

mm O
, O
FA O
= O
90° O
, O
voxel O
size O
3.5 O
× O
3.5 O
× O
4.0 O
mm3 O
, O
6 O
min O
duration O
) O
. O

Data O
analysis O
For O
the O
resting-state O
data O
analysis O
, O
group-level O
ICA O
combined O
with O
dual-regression O
approach O
was O
performed O
to O
detect O
large-scale O
generic O
RSN O
including O
right O
FPN O
, O
limbic O
network O
and O
other O
sensory O
related O
networks O
across O
our O
resting-state O
data O
sets O
( O
e.g. O
, O
) O
ICA O
was O
carried O
out O
using O
MELODIC O
Version O
3.14 O
, O
part O
of O
FSL O
( O
FMRIB O
's O
Software O
Library O
, O
www.fmrib.ox.ac.uk/fsl O
) O
. O

Preprocessing O
procedure O
was O
applied O
for O
individual O
data O
( O
128 O
s O
high-pass O
; O
6 O
mm O
smoothing O
; O
masking O
of O
non-brain O
voxels O
; O
voxel-wise O
de-meaning O
; O
normalized O
voxel-wise O
variance O
; O
normalized O
into O
2mm-MNI-standard O
via O
individual O
T1-weighted O
anatomical O
image O
) O
. O

During O
the O
preprocessing O
, O
individual O
level O
ICA O
denoising O
procedure O
was O
conducted O
to O
remove O
artifact O
signal O
such O
as O
motion O
and O
physio O
noise O
from O
the O
data O
by O
using O
an O
automated O
signal O
classification O
toolbox O
( O
; O
an O
average O
of O
4.3 O
components O
( O
13.7 O
% O
) O
were O
removed O
from O
each O
participant O
; O
see O
supplementary O
Fig O
. O

1 O
that O
indicates O
representative O
noise O
components O
trained O
the O
classifier O
to O
be O
automatically O
regressed O
out O
from O
individual O
data O
; O
mean O
FD O
= O
0.05 O
mm O
, O
SD O
= O
0.025 O
mm O
, O
range O
: O
0.02–0.18 O
mm O
) O
. O

Although O
there O
are O
several O
strategies O
suggested O
to O
rigorously O
correct O
for O
motion-related O
noise O
in O
resting O
state O
data O
, O
such O
as O
spike O
regression O
with O
24-type O
of O
motion O
parameters O
and O
individual O
high-motion O
contaminated O
volume O
scrubbing O
, O
several O
drawbacks O
of O
these O
strategies O
also O
exist O
such O
that O
they O
can O
introduce O
overfitting O
by O
the O
use O
of O
a O
large O
set O
of O
nuisance O
regressors O
, O
linear O
assumption O
about O
motion O
, O
and O
negative O
influences O
in O
the O
autocorrelation O
structure O
of O
data O
( O
see O
) O
. O

Therefore O
, O
we O
applied O
ICA O
denoising O
approach O
for O
the O
current O
analysis O
given O
the O
recent O
evidence O
that O
ICA O
denoising O
can O
effectively O
enhance O
the O
fidelity O
of O
data O
quality O
in O
terms O
of O
motion O
control O
( O
e.g. O
, O
) O
. O

Furthermore O
, O
it O
has O
been O
well O
demonstrated O
that O
RSNs O
estimated O
by O
ICA O
are O
less O
prone O
to O
artefactual O
effects O
from O
noise O
such O
as O
physiological O
signal O
, O
global O
signal O
fluctuation O
and O
motion O
due O
to O
the O
ability O
of O
ICA O
to O
account O
for O
the O
existence O
of O
such O
noise O
effects O
within O
additional O
non-RSN O
components O
( O
for O
more O
comprehensive O
review O
, O
please O
see O
) O
. O

To O
find O
the O
most O
representative O
functional O
networks O
from O
our O
entire O
dataset O
, O
preprocessed O
and O
denoised O
data O
were O
temporally O
concatenated O
into O
a O
single O
4D O
file O
and O
applied O
to O
group O
level O
ICA O
with O
probabilistic O
principal O
component O
analysis O
( O
PCA O
) O
where O
the O
number O
of O
dimensions O
was O
estimated O
using O
the O
Laplace O
approximation O
to O
the O
Bayesian O
evidence O
of O
the O
model O
order O
, O
yielding O
19 O
network O
spatial O
maps O
. O

To O
distinguish O
group-level O
brain O
networks O
from O
artifactual O
components O
( O
e.g. O
, O
residual O
head O
movement O
and O
physiological O
noise O
) O
and O
to O
identify O
canonical O
resting O
state O
networks O
, O
all O
network O
maps O
were O
spatially O
cross-correlated O
with O
canonical O
RSN O
templates O
( O
i.e. O
, O
template-matching O
procedure O
; O
e.g. O
, O
) O
acquired O
from O
previous O
resting-state O
studies O
. O

We O
finally O
identified O
13 O
intrinsic O
RSNs O
( O
Supplementary O
Fig O
. O

2 O
) O
including O
the O
right O
FPN O
and O
limbic O
networks O
( O
Fig O
. O

2A O
; O
see O
also O
Supplementary O
Fig O
. O

3 O
and O
4 O
) O
. O

The O
six O
remaining O
group O
level O
components O
were O
considered O
artifactual O
( O
e.g. O
, O
physiological O
) O
due O
to O
predominant O
activation O
in O
white O
matter O
, O
ventricles O
, O
vasculature O
, O
or O
head O
movement O
. O

Following O
group-level O
ICA O
, O
dual O
regression O
was O
applied O
to O
the O
adolescent O
dataset O
to O
estimate O
individual-specific O
temporal O
dynamics O
( O
i.e. O
, O
time-series O
data O
) O
and O
associated O
spatial O
maps O
based O
on O
the O
group-level O
ICA O
network O
maps O
. O

Although O
the O
right O
FPN O
and O
limbic O
networks O
were O
our O
main O
interests O
, O
we O
performed O
linear O
model O
estimation O
with O
the O
full O
set O
of O
group-level O
ICA O
spatial O
maps O
against O
the O
separate O
individual O
data O
sets O
to O
extract O
subject-specific O
temporal O
dynamics O
for O
each O
component O
map O
( O
i.e. O
, O
spatial O
regression O
) O
in O
the O
absence O
of O
influence O
of O
other O
network O
dynamics O
. O

The O
estimated O
individual O
time-course O
data O
were O
then O
put O
into O
subsequent O
linear-model O
estimation O
against O
individual O
’ O
s O
data O
set O
to O
estimate O
subject-specific O
spatial O
maps O
( O
i.e. O
, O
temporal O
regression O
) O
. O

To O
estimate O
between-RSN O
network O
functional O
coupling O
, O
the O
correlation O
coefficient O
between O
time-series O
of O
the O
right O
FPN O
and O
limbic O
networks O
was O
finally O
calculated O
for O
each O
individual O
adolescent O
( O
e.g. O
, O
) O
. O

Measures O
for O
adolescent O
substance O
use O
and O
self-control O
2.4.1 O
. O

Substance O
use O
. O

We O
used O
the O
Center O
for O
Disease O
Control O
and O
Prevention O
Youth O
Risk O
Behavior O
Survey O
( O
YRBS O
) O
Questionnaire O
, O
which O
is O
a O
common O
measure O
of O
substance O
use O
. O

This O
in-depth O
questionnaire O
asks O
about O
lifetime O
substance O
use O
( O
i.e. O
, O
more O
than O
two O
puffs O
or O
sips O
for O
the O
following O
substance O
: O
cigarettes O
, O
alcohol O
, O
marijuana O
, O
prescription O
drugs O
without O
a O
doctor O
’ O
s O
prescription O
, O
cocaine O
and O
other O
illegal O
drugs O
) O
. O

Adolescents O
used O
a O
7-point O
scale O
to O
indicate O
the O
first O
time O
they O
used O
any O
of O
these O
substance O
( O
1 O
= O
“ O
less O
than O
nine O
years O
old O
, O
” O
2 O
= O
” O
9–10 O
years O
old O
, O
” O
3 O
= O
” O
11–12 O
years O
old O
, O
” O
4 O
= O
” O
13–14 O
years O
old O
” O
5 O
= O
” O
15–16 O
years O
old O
” O
6 O
= O
” O
17 O
years O
or O
older O
” O
, O
7 O
= O
” O
never O
used O
” O
) O
. O

No O
participants O
had O
used O
cocaine O
, O
prescription O
drugs O
without O
a O
doctor O
’ O
s O
prescription O
, O
or O
other O
illegal O
drugs O
in O
the O
current O
study O
. O

We O
used O
age O
of O
earliest O
onset O
for O
marijuana O
, O
alcohol O
, O
or O
cigarettes O
as O
our O
index O
of O
substance O
use-behaviors O
. O

See O
Table O
1 O
for O
descriptives O
of O
substance O
use O
onset O
. O

Two O
adolescents O
did O
not O
complete O
the O
questionnaire O
. O

2.4.2 O
. O

Self-control O
. O

To O
assess O
general O
cognitive O
control O
ability O
, O
we O
used O
the O
Brief O
Self-Control O
Scale O
( O
BSCS O
) O
to O
measure O
dispositional O
self-regulatory O
behaviors O
( O
e.g. O
, O
“ O
I O
am O
good O
at O
resisting O
temptation O
” O
and O
“ O
I O
am O
able O
to O
work O
effectively O
toward O
long-term O
goals O
” O
) O
using O
a O
7-point O
scale O
( O
1 O
= O
“ O
strongly O
disagree O
” O
to O
7 O
= O
“ O
strongly O
agree O
” O
) O
. O

The O
scale O
’ O
s O
internal O
consistency O
was O
α O
= O
0.83 O
. O

Functional O
and O
structural O
brain O
connectivity O
of O
young O
binge O
drinkers O
: O
a O
follow-up O
study O
Adolescence O
is O
a O
period O
of O
ongoing O
brain O
maturation O
characterized O
by O
hierarchical O
changes O
in O
the O
functional O
and O
structural O
networks O
. O

For O
this O
reason O
, O
the O
young O
brain O
is O
particularly O
vulnerable O
to O
the O
toxic O
effects O
of O
alcohol O
. O

Nowadays O
, O
binge O
drinking O
is O
a O
pattern O
of O
alcohol O
consumption O
increasingly O
prevalent O
among O
adolescents O
. O

The O
aim O
of O
the O
present O
study O
is O
to O
evaluate O
the O
evolution O
of O
the O
functional O
and O
anatomical O
connectivity O
of O
the O
Default O
Mode O
Network O
( O
DMN O
) O
in O
young O
binge O
drinkers O
along O
two O
years O
. O

Magnetoencephalography O
signal O
during O
eyes O
closed O
resting O
state O
as O
well O
as O
Diffusion O
Tensor O
Imaging O
( O
DTI O
) O
were O
acquired O
twice O
within O
a O
2-year O
interval O
from O
39 O
undergraduate O
students O
( O
22 O
controls O
, O
17 O
binge O
drinkers O
) O
with O
neither O
personal O
nor O
family O
history O
of O
alcoholism O
. O

The O
group O
comparison O
showed O
that O
, O
after O
maintaining O
a O
binge O
drinking O
pattern O
along O
at O
least O
two O
years O
, O
binge O
drinkers O
displayed O
an O
increased O
brain O
connectivity O
of O
the O
DMN O
in O
comparison O
with O
the O
control O
group O
. O

On O
the O
other O
hand O
, O
the O
structural O
connectivity O
did O
not O
show O
significant O
differences O
neither O
between O
groups O
nor O
over O
the O
time O
. O

These O
findings O
point O
out O
that O
a O
continued O
pattern O
of O
binge O
drinking O
leads O
to O
functional O
alterations O
in O
the O
normal O
brain O
maturation O
process O
, O
even O
before O
anatomical O
changes O
can O
be O
detected O
. O

Methods O
Participants O
Thirty-nine O
undergraduate O
students O
of O
the O
Complutense O
University O
of O
Madrid O
( O
Madrid O
, O
Spain O
) O
participated O
in O
the O
study O
. O

Twenty O
two O
were O
classified O
as O
controls O
( O
12 O
females O
) O
and O
17 O
as O
BDs O
( O
8 O
females O
) O
. O

The O
procedure O
for O
subject O
selection O
is O
fully O
described O
in O
Correas O
et O
al O
.. O

The O
participants O
were O
evaluated O
twice O
within O
a O
2-year O
interval O
( O
at O
18–19 O
and O
20–21 O
years O
old O
) O
and O
the O
number O
of O
months O
between O
evaluations O
of O
each O
group O
didn O
’ O
t O
differ O
( O
control O
group O
= O
22.86 O
± O
0.89 O
; O
BD O
group O
= O
23.26 O
± O
0.94 O
) O
. O

The O
demographic O
data O
of O
each O
group O
is O
shown O
in O
Table O
2 O
. O

Participants O
were O
divided O
into O
BD O
and O
control O
group O
according O
to O
a O
questionnaire O
and O
a O
semi-structured O
interview O
inquiring O
about O
alcohol O
and O
other O
drug O
consumptions O
habits O
. O

Participants O
were O
asked O
to O
cover O
a O
record O
of O
daily O
consumption O
indicating O
what O
they O
drank O
, O
the O
quantity O
and O
for O
how O
long O
( O
hours O
) O
. O

The O
BAC O
was O
calculated O
based O
on O
the O
information O
of O
the O
last O
dinking O
episode O
. O

We O
considered O
the O
BAC O
as O
a O
rough O
index O
representing O
the O
BD O
level O
of O
each O
subject O
. O

Participants O
reaching O
a O
BAC O
of O
0.08 O
% O
or O
above O
at O
least O
once O
during O
the O
last O
month O
were O
classified O
as O
BD O
. O

On O
the O
other O
hand O
, O
the O
control O
group O
consisted O
of O
students O
who O
never O
achieved O
that O
BAC O
. O

Participants O
were O
asked O
to O
refrain O
from O
alcohol O
consumption O
for O
, O
at O
least O
, O
24 O
hours O
prior O
to O
MEG O
recordings O
. O

Subjects O
were O
submitted O
to O
a O
breathalyzer O
test O
, O
and O
the O
assessment O
was O
only O
performed O
after O
verifying O
a O
0.00 O
% O
breath O
alcohol O
level O
. O

All O
volunteers O
provided O
written O
informed O
consent O
prior O
to O
assessment O
. O

The O
study O
was O
approved O
by O
the O
Ethics O
Committee O
of O
the O
Complutense O
University O
of O
Madrid O
, O
Spain O
and O
the O
procedure O
was O
performed O
in O
accordance O
with O
approved O
guidelines O
and O
regulations O
. O

Principles O
of O
the O
Declaration O
of O
Helsinki O
were O
followed O
. O

MEG O
Acquisition O
Four O
minutes O
of O
MEG O
signal O
were O
acquired O
( O
1000 O
Hz O
sampling O
rate O
and O
online O
band O
pass O
filter O
at O
0.1–330 O
Hz O
) O
during O
eyes-closed O
resting O
state O
using O
a O
306-channel O
( O
102 O
magnetometers O
and O
204 O
gradiometers O
) O
system O
( O
Elekta© O
, O
VectorView O
) O
. O

In O
this O
study O
only O
magnetometers O
( O
102 O
channels O
) O
information O
was O
submitted O
to O
source O
and O
statistical O
analyses O
. O

The O
system O
was O
housed O
in O
a O
magnetically O
shielded O
room O
( O
VacuumSchmelze O
GmbH O
, O
Hanua O
, O
Germany O
) O
. O

The O
head O
movement O
was O
monitored O
by O
means O
of O
four O
head-position O
indicator O
coils O
attached O
to O
the O
scalp O
. O

Ocular O
movements O
were O
tracked O
with O
two O
bipolar O
electrodes O
. O

MEG O
Analysis O
Preprocessing O
The O
raw O
recording O
data O
were O
at O
first O
submitted O
to O
Maxfilter O
software O
( O
v O
2.2 O
, O
Elekta O
Neuromag O
) O
to O
remove O
external O
noise O
with O
the O
temporal O
extension O
of O
the O
signal O
space O
separation O
method O
with O
movement O
compensation O
. O

In O
this O
study O
, O
we O
used O
only O
magnetometers O
data O
in O
order O
to O
avoid O
mixing O
MEG O
sensors O
with O
different O
sensitivities O
or O
resorting O
to O
scaling O
. O

Accordingly O
, O
all O
of O
the O
magnetometers O
’ O
resting O
state O
signals O
were O
automatically O
scanned O
for O
ocular O
, O
muscle O
and O
jump O
artifacts O
with O
Fieldtrip O
package O
and O
were O
visually O
confirmed O
by O
a O
MEG O
expert O
. O

The O
artifact-free O
data O
were O
segmented O
in O
continuous O
4 O
seconds O
fragments O
( O
trials O
) O
. O

At O
least O
15 O
clean O
trials O
were O
obtained O
from O
all O
participants O
and O
preserved O
for O
further O
analyses O
. O

The O
number O
of O
surviving O
trials O
did O
not O
differ O
significantly O
between O
groups O
. O

To O
calculate O
the O
source´s O
reconstruction O
, O
the O
time O
series O
were O
filtered O
in O
the O
following O
frequency O
bands O
: O
delta O
( O
2–3.9 O
Hz O
) O
, O
theta O
( O
4.1–7.9 O
Hz O
) O
alpha O
( O
8.1–11.9 O
Hz O
) O
and O
beta O
( O
12.1–29.9 O
Hz O
) O
. O

The O
filtering O
was O
performed O
with O
a O
finite O
impulse O
response O
filter O
of O
order O
1500 O
. O

This O
filter O
was O
applied O
using O
a O
two-pass O
procedure O
over O
the O
whole O
four-minute O
registers O
, O
in O
order O
to O
avoid O
phase O
distortion O
and O
edge O
effects O
. O

Headmodels O
& O
Beamforming O
A O
regular O
grid O
of O
2455 O
nodes O
with O
1 O
cm O
spacing O
was O
created O
in O
the O
Montreal O
Neurological O
Institute O
( O
MNI O
) O
template O
brain O
. O

This O
set O
of O
nodes O
was O
transformed O
to O
each O
participant´s O
space O
using O
a O
non-linear O
normalization O
between O
the O
native O
T1 O
image O
and O
a O
standard O
T1 O
in O
MNI O
template O
space O
. O

The O
forward O
model O
was O
solved O
with O
the O
realistic O
single-shell O
model O
introduced O
by O
Nolte O
. O

Source O
reconstruction O
was O
performed O
with O
a O
Linearly O
Constrained O
Minimum O
Variance O
Beamformer O
. O

For O
each O
subject O
, O
the O
covariance O
matrix O
was O
first O
averaged O
over O
all O
trials O
to O
compute O
the O
spatial O
filter´s O
coefficients O
and O
these O
coefficients O
were O
applied O
to O
individual O
trials O
, O
obtaining O
a O
time O
series O
per O
segment O
and O
the O
source O
location O
. O

Atlas O
Based O
Analysis O
The O
FC O
analysis O
was O
performed O
using O
atlas-based O
ROIs O
. O

For O
the O
subsequent O
analysis O
, O
we O
specifically O
focused O
on O
FC O
in O
the O
DMN O
. O

We O
set O
DMN-related O
ROIs O
in O
the O
precuneus O
( O
Pc O
) O
, O
posterior O
cingulate O
cortex O
( O
PCC O
) O
, O
anterior O
cingulate O
cortex O
( O
ACC O
) O
, O
frontal O
medial O
cortex O
( O
FMC O
) O
and O
bilateral O
inferior O
parietal O
lobe O
( O
IPL O
) O
by O
referring O
to O
the O
Harvard-Oxford O
probabilistic O
. O

In O
total O
, O
156 O
nodes O
were O
included O
in O
this O
study O
as O
they O
were O
located O
within O
the O
6 O
ROIs O
. O

Functional O
Connectivity O
: O
Phase O
Locking O
Value O
The O
FC O
was O
measured O
by O
means O
of O
phase-locking O
value O
( O
PLV O
) O
in O
each O
frequency O
band O
and O
was O
calculated O
per O
each O
trial O
as O
explained O
in O
. O

Finally O
, O
the O
results O
were O
averaged O
across O
trials O
ending O
up O
with O
symmetrical O
156 O
× O
156 O
nodes O
connectivity O
matrices O
per O
subjects O
, O
phase O
( O
pre/post O
) O
and O
frequency O
band O
. O

In O
order O
to O
assess O
changes O
over O
time O
, O
we O
assess O
the O
ratio O
of O
change O
between O
the O
two O
phases O
of O
the O
longitudinal O
study O
by O
dividing O
the O
value O
of O
each O
connectivity O
node O
of O
the O
second O
evaluation O
between O
the O
first O
evaluation O
. O

Finally O
, O
to O
address O
whether O
volume O
conduction O
could O
be O
causing O
these O
differences O
, O
we O
have O
calculated O
the O
correlation O
between O
beamformer O
weights O
in O
both O
groups O
in O
order O
to O
have O
an O
estimate O
of O
volume O
conduction O
. O

Beamformer O
weights O
did O
not O
differ O
between O
groups O
in O
any O
frequency O
band O
, O
which O
makes O
it O
unlikely O
that O
the O
functional O
connectivity O
differences O
were O
caused O
by O
volume O
conduction O
. O

Statistical O
Analysis O
Clusters O
of O
connections O
, O
which O
showed O
statistically O
significant O
group O
differences O
( O
BD O
subjects O
vs. O
control O
subjects O
) O
, O
were O
explored O
relying O
on O
the O
cluster-based O
permutation O
test O
for O
each O
frequency O
band O
. O

The O
methodology O
was O
composed O
by O
two O
steps O
: O
1 O
) O
an O
intra-ROI O
analysis O
that O
computed O
the O
local O
connectivity O
within O
each O
ROI O
; O
and O
2 O
) O
inter O
ROI O
FC O
that O
evaluated O
the O
inter-regional O
FC O
among O
each O
pair O
of O
ROIS O
of O
the O
DMN O
. O

In O
both O
cases O
, O
the O
procedure O
was O
essentially O
the O
same O
. O

In O
the O
intra-ROI O
analysis O
, O
we O
assessed O
the O
FC O
of O
all O
the O
nodes O
contained O
within O
a O
ROI O
; O
whereas O
in O
the O
inter-ROI O
the O
analysis O
we O
focused O
in O
the O
FC O
between O
the O
nodes O
located O
in O
the O
corresponding O
two O
bilateral O
ROIs O
. O

The O
procedure O
started O
by O
assessing O
the O
FC O
difference O
between O
groups O
for O
each O
pair O
of O
nodes O
by O
means O
of O
ANCOVA O
with O
sex O
as O
a O
covariate O
. O

The O
significance O
of O
the O
links O
was O
assessed O
using O
a O
non-parametric O
randomization O
( O
5000 O
permutations O
) O
testing O
, O
Only O
those O
links O
with O
p-values O
below O
0.05 O
were O
kept O
and O
included O
in O
the O
following O
steps O
of O
the O
analysis O
. O

Then O
, O
we O
aimed O
to O
extract O
a O
robust O
significant O
network O
, O
so-called O
network O
motifs O
in O
graph O
theory O
. O

These O
networks O
consisted O
of O
several O
consecutive O
significant O
links O
, O
which O
systematically O
showed O
a O
diminished O
or O
enhanced O
FC O
in O
the O
BD O
group O
compared O
with O
the O
CN O
group O
. O

We O
considered O
a O
significant O
motif O
only O
when O
: O
1 O
) O
at O
least O
the O
25 O
% O
of O
the O
nodes O
which O
composed O
the O
ROI O
were O
involved O
, O
2 O
) O
at O
least O
the O
10 O
% O
of O
the O
links O
among O
them O
had O
significant O
FC O
differences O
between O
groups O
, O
and O
3 O
) O
the O
motifs O
should O
be O
connected O
, O
i.e O
. O

there O
exists O
a O
path O
between O
each O
pair O
of O
nodes O
in O
the O
motif O
. O

The O
first O
two O
conditions O
set O
the O
minimum O
dimensions O
of O
the O
motif O
, O
and O
the O
third O
one O
fixed O
a O
constraint O
in O
the O
morphology O
, O
dismissing O
the O
insulated O
links O
. O

Then O
, O
we O
submitted O
all O
the O
FC O
values O
of O
the O
links O
that O
composed O
the O
significant O
motifs O
to O
a O
cluster-based O
( O
in O
this O
case O
motif-based O
) O
non-parametric O
test O
( O
5000 O
permutations O
) O
to O
control O
the O
multiple O
comparisons O
problem O
. O

At O
this O
point O
, O
we O
wanted O
to O
offer O
a O
value O
which O
would O
characterize O
the O
network O
of O
each O
significant O
cluster O
. O

Thus O
, O
we O
calculate O
for O
each O
significant O
motif O
their O
corresponding O
degree O
, O
i.e O
. O

the O
average O
PLV-ratio O
across O
all O
links O
. O

Then O
we O
performed O
an O
ANCOVA O
with O
sex O
as O
covariate O
between O
groups O
, O
which O
was O
corrected O
by O
multiplying O
the O
p O
value O
by O
5 O
, O
to O
further O
account O
for O
the O
family-wise O
error O
for O
the O
5 O
frequency O
bands O
, O
and O
we O
obtained O
the O
corresponding O
effect O
sizes O
( O
Cohen O
’ O
s O
d O
) O
. O

In O
addition O
, O
we O
applied O
a O
classification O
analysis O
using O
a O
logistic O
regression O
analysis O
with O
the O
leave-one-out O
cross-validation O
procedure O
. O

Finally O
, O
we O
performed O
a O
one-sample O
t-test O
to O
determine O
whether O
the O
value O
of O
the O
ratio O
of O
each O
group O
differs O
from O
a O
distribution O
with O
mean O
1 O
. O

MRI O
Acquisition O
MRI O
was O
collected O
from O
a O
General O
Electric O
1.5 O
Tesla O
using O
an O
eight-channel O
head O
coil O
. O

The O
imaging O
protocol O
consisted O
of O
: O
3D O
T1-weighted O
high-resolution O
images O
using O
a O
Fast O
Spoiled O
Gradient O
Echo O
sequence O
[ O
TR/TE/TI O
= O
11.2/4.2/450 O
ms O
; O
flip-angle O
= O
12° O
; O
FoV O
= O
250 O
mm O
; O
acquisition O
matrix O
= O
256 O
× O
256 O
; O
slice O
thickness O
= O
1 O
mm O
] O
and O
Diffusion O
weighted O
images O
( O
DWI O
) O
using O
a O
single-shot O
echo O
planar O
imaging O
sequence O
[ O
TR/TE O
= O
12000/96.1 O
ms O
; O
FoV O
= O
307 O
mm O
; O
acquisition O
matrix O
= O
128 O
× O
128 O
; O
slice O
thickness O
= O
2.4 O
mm O
; O
NEX O
= O
3 O
] O
. O

DWI O
was O
acquired O
along O
25 O
non-coplanar O
directions O
with O
a O
b-value O
of O
900 O
s/mm2 O
and O
1 O
image O
with O
no O
diffusion O
sensitization O
, O
i.e O
. O

b0 O
image O
. O

MRI O
Analysis O
DWI O
Analysis O
DWIs O
were O
corrected O
for O
motion O
and O
eddy O
currents O
using O
EDDY-FSL O
, O
which O
performs O
linear O
affine O
registration O
of O
the O
volumes O
to O
the O
reference O
b0 O
volume O
. O

The O
resulting O
rotations O
were O
used O
to O
realign O
the O
gradient O
directions O
matrix O
. O

Non-brain O
tissue O
was O
removed O
from O
DWI O
using O
BET-FSL O
and O
diffusion O
tensor O
images O
( O
DTIs O
) O
were O
obtained O
using O
a O
linear O
least-squares O
approach O
as O
implemented O
in O
FSL-FDT O
. O

From O
that O
several O
scalar O
images O
representing O
the O
shape O
of O
the O
diffusion O
tensor O
were O
obtained O
: O
fractional O
anisotropy O
, O
mean O
diffusivity O
, O
radial O
diffusivity O
and O
axial O
diffusivity O
. O

Rigid O
transformations O
were O
performed O
between O
b0 O
and O
T1-weighted O
images O
. O

In O
addition O
, O
linear O
affine O
transformations O
followed O
by O
nonlinear O
local O
deformations O
using O
FSL-FNIRT O
were O
applied O
to O
normalize O
brain-extracted O
T1-weighted O
images O
into O
the O
MNI O
brain O
template O
of O
1 O
mm3 O
isotropic O
resolution O
. O

These O
three O
transformations O
were O
concatenated O
in O
one O
single O
transformation O
in O
order O
to O
reduce O
the O
number O
of O
interpolations O
, O
and O
were O
applied O
inversely O
to O
transform O
the O
JHU O
white O
matter O
tractography O
atlas O
into O
the O
diffusion O
subject-specific O
space O
. O

Average O
values O
for O
the O
different O
DTI O
metrics O
were O
obtained O
for O
each O
of O
the O
masks O
included O
in O
the O
JHU O
atlas O
. O
