surface O
) O
and O
GM-CSF O
interfaces O
( O
pial O
surface O
) O
; O
( O
6 O
) O
topological O
defect O
correction O
on O
the O
surface O
; O
( O
7 O
) O
individual O
surface O
mesh O
inflation O
to O
a O
sphere O
; O
and O
( O
8 O
) O
estimation O
of O
the O
deformation O
between O
the O
resulting O
spherical O
mesh O
and O
a O
common O
spherical O
coordinate O
system O
to O
align O
the O
cortical O
folding O
patterns O
across O
subjects O
. O

As O
a O
quality O
assessment O
, O
intermediate O
results O
from O
the O
above O
steps O
were O
visually O
inspected O
based O
upon O
the O
screenshots O
generated O
using O
CCS O
. O

Subjects O
with O
bad O
brain O
extraction O
, O
tissue O
segmentation O
and O
surface O
reconstruction O
were O
excluded O
from O
the O
subsequent O
analysis O
. O

For O
each O
subject O
, O
six O
morphological O
metrics O
were O
derived O
from O
the O
cortical O
surface O
model O
created O
using O
FreeSurfer O
, O
including O
cortical O
vol O
, O
area O
, O
thick O
, O
curv O
, O
lgi O
, O
and O
sulc O
. O

All O
abbreviations O
are O
listed O
in O
Supplementary O
Text O
1 O
, O
and O
detailed O
descriptions O
of O
the O
meaning O
and O
computation O
of O
these O
metrics O
are O
presented O
in O
Supplementary O
Text O
2 O
. O

The O
area O
metric O
was O
set O
to O
the O
total O
area O
of O
the O
triangles O
connected O
to O
a O
vertex O
( O
Fischl O
and O
Dale O
) O
. O

The O
total O
cortical O
area O
generated O
using O
the O
FreeSurfer O
model O
was O
consistent O
with O
the O
surface O
area O
derived O
from O
postmortem O
studies O
and O
has O
been O
validated O
on O
several O
brain O
phantoms O
and O
compared O
with O
other O
surface-based O
analysis O
packages O
( O
Lee O
et O
al O
. O

; O
Makris O
et O
al O
. O
) O
. O

The O
thick O
metric O
was O
calculated O
using O
the O
average O
linking O
distance O
between O
the O
pial O
and O
white O
surfaces O
( O
Fischl O
and O
Dale O
) O
. O

This O
measure O
of O
cortical O
thickness O
showed O
adequate O
test–retest O
reliability O
across O
time O
, O
scanner O
manufacturers O
and O
field O
strengths O
( O
Han O
et O
al O
. O
) O
. O

The O
vol O
metric O
was O
calculated O
as O
the O
product O
of O
the O
thick O
and O
area O
metrics O
. O

The O
curv O
metric O
represents O
the O
mean O
of O
the O
two O
principal O
curvatures O
, O
which O
measures O
the O
maximum O
and O
minimum O
bending O
of O
the O
cortical O
surface O
at O
the O
vertex O
( O
Pienaar O
et O
al O
. O
) O
. O

The O
lgi O
is O
a O
metric O
that O
quantifies O
the O
amount O
of O
cortex O
buried O
within O
the O
sulcal O
folds O
compared O
with O
the O
amount O
of O
cortex O
on O
the O
outer O
visible O
cortex O
. O

A O
cortex O
with O
extensive O
folding O
has O
a O
large O
lgi O
, O
whereas O
a O
cortex O
with O
limited O
folding O
has O
a O
small O
lgi O
. O

In O
Freesurfer O
, O
lgi O
was O
computed O
at O
thousands O
of O
points O
over O
the O
entire O
cortical O
surface O
( O
Schaer O
et O
al O
. O
) O
. O

Moreover O
, O
the O
sulc O
metric O
is O
the O
integrated O
dot O
product O
of O
the O
movement O
vector O
with O
the O
surface O
norm O
during O
inflation O
, O
indicating O
the O
large-scale O
geometry O
of O
the O
cortical O
surface O
. O

When O
deep O
regions O
consistently O
move O
outward O
, O
these O
regions O
have O
positive O
values O
of O
sulc O
, O
whereas O
when O
superficial O
regions O
move O
inward O
, O
these O
regions O
have O
negative O
values O
. O

Each O
of O
these O
metrics O
was O
computed O
in O
the O
native O
space O
and O
subsequently O
transferred O
onto O
the O
fsaverage O
standard O
spherical O
surface O
. O

To O
enable O
further O
comparisons O
with O
functional O
metrics O
, O
these O
metric O
maps O
were O
down O
sampled O
to O
an O
fsaverage5 O
standard O
cortical O
surface O
with O
10,242 O
vertices O
per O
hemisphere O
, O
and O
a O
Gaussian O
filter O
( O
FWHM O
= O
4 O
mm O
) O
was O
applied O
to O
smooth O
the O
surface O
maps O
. O

An O
outlier O
detection O
procedure O
was O
further O
performed O
to O
exclude O
subjects O
with O
extremely O
low/high O
metrics O
. O

A O
subject O
was O
excluded O
from O
subsequent O
analyses O
when O
any O
of O
the O
six O
metrics O
was O
an O
outlier O
at O
any O
vertex O
of O
the O
fsaverage5 O
surface O
. O

The O
outliers O
were O
determined O
using O
the O
generalized O
extreme O
Studentized O
deviate O
test O
( O
p O
< O
0.001 O
) O
( O
Rosner O
) O
. O

Preprocessing O
and O
quality O
control O
: O
functional O
images O
Connectome O
computation O
system O
was O
employed O
to O
analyze O
rfMRI O
data O
using O
a O
functional O
pipeline O
. O

The O
following O
procedures O
were O
included O
: O
( O
1 O
) O
eliminating O
the O
first O
5 O
EPI O
volumes O
from O
each O
scan O
for O
signal O
equilibration O
; O
( O
2 O
) O
de-spiking O
the O
time O
series O
to O
detect O
and O
reduce O
outliers O
( O
spikes O
) O
using O
an O
hyperbolic O
tangent O
function O
; O
( O
3 O
) O
slice O
timing O
using O
Fourier O
interpolation O
to O
temporally O
correct O
the O
interleaved O
slice O
acquisition O
; O
( O
4 O
) O
aligning O
each O
volume O
to O
a O
“ O
base O
” O
image O
( O
the O
mean O
EPI O
image O
) O
using O
Fourier O
interpolation O
to O
correct O
between-head O
movements O
; O
( O
5 O
) O
normalizing O
the O
4D O
global O
mean O
intensity O
to O
10,000 O
to O
allow O
inter-subject O
comparisons O
; O
( O
6 O
) O
regressing O
out O
the O
WM/CSF O
mean O
time O
series O
and O
the O
Friston-24 O
motion O
time O
series O
to O
reduce O
the O
effects O
of O
these O
confounding O
factors O
; O
( O
7 O
) O
filtering O
the O
residual O
time O
series O
with O
a O
band-pass O
filter O
( O
0.01–0.1 O
Hz O
) O
to O
extract O
low-frequency O
fluctuations O
; O
( O
8 O
) O
removing O
both O
linear O
and O
quadratic O
trends O
; O
and O
( O
9 O
) O
aligning O
individual O
motion-corrected O
functional O
images O
to O
the O
individual O
structural O
image O
using O
a O
GM-WM O
boundary-based O
registration O
( O
BBR O
) O
algorithm O
. O

The O
preprocessed O
time O
series O
were O
subsequently O
projected O
onto O
the O
fsaverage5 O
standard O
cortical O
surface O
. O

For O
each O
subject O
in O
both O
preprocessed O
datasets O
, O
we O
computed O
six O
functional O
metrics O
that O
character O
low-frequency O
fluctuations O
( O
0.01–0.1 O
Hz O
) O
, O
including O
alff O
and O
its O
fractional O
variant O
( O
falff O
) O
, O
dc O
, O
ec O
, O
and O
surface-based O
regional O
homogeneity O
with O
length-one O
( O
reho O
) O
and O
length-two O
( O
reho2 O
) O
neighbors O
. O

These O
metrics O
were O
commonly O
used O
to O
characterize O
properties O
of O
intrinsic O
connectivity O
networks O
( O
see O
Zuo O
and O
Xing O
for O
a O
review O
) O
. O

Here O
, O
we O
provide O
a O
brief O
description O
of O
these O
metrics O
and O
more O
details O
are O
presented O
in O
Supplementary O
Text O
3 O
. O

The O
alff O
metric O
indicates O
the O
power O
of O
low-frequency O
oscillations O
in O
the O
BOLD O
time O
series O
( O
Zang O
et O
al O
. O
) O
. O

The O
normalized O
form O
, O
falff O
, O
further O
divides O
the O
alff O
value O
by O
the O
power O
of O
the O
entire O
frequency O
spectrum O
( O
Zou O
et O
al O
. O
) O
. O

These O
metrics O
characterize O
single O
voxel/vertex O
properties O
. O

In O
contrast O
, O
from O
a O
graph-theoretical O
perspective O
( O
Bullmore O
and O
Sporns O
) O
, O
the O
dc O
and O
ec O
metrics O
depict O
the O
relationships O
of O
the O
BOLD O
time O
series O
between O
a O
given O
location O
and O
all O
other O
locations O
in O
the O
brain O
. O

The O
relationships O
between O
the O
time O
series O
were O
characterized O
using O
Pearson O
’ O
s O
Correlation O
coefficients O
. O

The O
reho O
and O
reho2 O
metrics O
measure O
the O
multi-vertex O
relationship O
in O
a O
local O
neighborhood O
( O
Zang O
et O
al O
. O

; O
Zuo O
et O
al O
. O

) O
, O
reflecting O
the O
local O
homogeneity O
of O
the O
BOLD O
time O
series O
. O

The O
radius O
of O
the O
local O
neighborhood O
is O
different O
between O
the O
reho O
and O
reho2 O
metrics O
, O
where O
the O
reho O
metric O
has O
a O
radius O
of O
1 O
vertex O
, O
and O
reho2 O
has O
a O
radius O
of O
2 O
vertices O
. O

We O
conducted O
the O
following O
quality O
assessments O
for O
functional O
images O
. O

To O
examine O
the O
head O
motion O
during O
rfMRI O
acquisition O
, O
we O
computed O
( O
1 O
) O
the O
maximum O
distance O
of O
translational O
head O
movement O
( O
maxTran O
) O
, O
( O
2 O
) O
the O
maximum O
degree O
of O
rotational O
head O
movement O
( O
maxRot O
) O
, O
and O
( O
3 O
) O
the O
mean O
frame-wise O
displacement O
( O
meanFD O
) O
. O

To O
evaluate O
the O
quality O
of O
functional–structural O
image O
realignment O
with O
BBR O
registration O
, O
we O
collected O
the O
minimal O
cost O
of O
the O
BBR O
co-registration O
( O
mcBBR O
) O
. O

Subjects O
were O
excluded O
from O
further O
analysis O
when O
the O
following O
criteria O
were O
not O
met O
: O
( O
1 O
) O
maxTran O
≤ O
2 O
mm O
, O
( O
2 O
) O
maxRot O
≤ O
2° O
, O
( O
3 O
) O
meanFD O
≤ O
0.2 O
mm O
, O
and O
( O
4 O
) O
mcBBR O
≤ O
0.75 O
. O

As O
a O
result O
of O
the O
quality O
control O
procedures O
for O
both O
structural O
and O
functional O
images O
, O
184 O
subjects O
from O
FCP-Cambridge O
( O
female O
117 O
, O
age O
range O
18–30 O
) O
and O
340 O
subjects O
from O
CoRR-SWU O
( O
female O
= O
180 O
, O
age O
range O
17–27 O
) O
were O
retained O
for O
further O
analyses O
. O

Structure–function O
co-variance O
analysis O
: O
discovery O
A O
discover-confirm O
scheme O
was O
illustrated O
in O
Fig O
. O

1 O
and O
was O
applied O
to O
the O
preprocessed O
FCP-Cambridge O
( O
N O
= O
184 O
) O
and O
CoRR-SWU O
( O
N O
= O
340 O
) O
datasets O
. O

Besides O
Fig O
. O

1 O
, O
we O
made O
an O
animation O
to O
demonstrate O
the O
procedures.2 O
FCP-Cambridge O
was O
used O
in O
the O
discover O
stage O
. O

We O
first O
decomposed O
the O
cross-subject O
variability O
of O
each O
cortical O
metric O
in O
FCP-Cambridge O
into O
a O
number O
of O
independent O
components O
. O

Specifically O
, O
an O
n O
by O
v O
matrix O
was O
formed O
for O
each O
of O
the O
12 O
metrics O
, O
where O
n O
is O
the O
number O
of O
subjects O
( O
n O
= O
184 O
) O
, O
and O
v O
is O
the O
number O
of O
vertices O
on O
the O
surface O
map O
( O
for O
the O
‘ O
fsaverage5 O
’ O
mesh O
, O
v O
= O
20,484 O
) O
. O

Independent O
component O
analysis O
( O
ICA O
) O
, O
as O
implemented O
in O
the O
MELODIC O
module O
of O
FSL O
software O
( O
Beckmann O
and O
Smith O
) O
, O
was O
applied O
to O
the O
matrices O
( O
step O
1 O
in O
Fig O
. O

1 O
) O
. O

The O
numbers O
of O
components O
were O
automatically O
determined O
using O
the O
Laplacian O
estimator O
in O
MELODIC O
. O

The O
ICA O
outputs O
are O
referred O
to O
as O
surface O
component O
maps O
( O
SCMs O
) O
, O
each O
representing O
a O
spatial O
pattern O
of O
vertices O
. O

Each O
SCM O
is O
accompanied O
with O
a O
subject O
course O
that O
depicted O
the O
variation O
of O
the O
corresponding O
SCM O
across O
subjects O
. O

Since O
the O
SCM O
is O
an O
unthresholded O
, O
continuous O
map O
of O
vertices O
, O
the O
values O
on O
the O
vertices O
indicate O
the O
relative O
contribution O
of O
the O
vertices O
to O
the O
subject O
course O
. O

The O
above O
ICA O
decomposition O
was O
applied O
to O
the O
12 O
metrics O
separately O
. O

Next O
, O
we O
adopted O
gRAICAR O
( O
Yang O
et O
al O
. O

; O
Yang O
et O
al O
. O
) O

to O
cluster O
the O
SCMs O
from O
the O
12 O
metrics O
( O
step O
2 O
in O
Fig O
. O

1 O
) O
. O

The O
gRAICAR O
algorithm O
is O
effective O
in O
revealing O
intrinsic O
inter-subject O
relationships O
( O
Kyathanahally O
et O
al O
. O

; O
Yang O
et O
al O
. O
) O

or O
patient O
subtypes O
( O
Yang O
et O
al O
. O
) O
. O

Supplementary O
Fig O
. O

1 O
presents O
a O
demonstration O
of O
the O
gRAICAR O
algorithm O
. O

Specifically O
, O
gRAICAR O
first O
constructed O
a O
full O
similarity O
matrix O
( O
FSM O
) O
containing O
pair-wise O
similarity O
between O
all O
the O
SCMs O
from O
the O
12 O
metrics O
( O
Fig O
. O

S1A O
) O
. O

The O
similarity O
between O
the O
SCMs O
was O
defined O
as O
the O
Pearson O
’ O
s O
correlation O
coefficients O
between O
their O
subject O
courses O
. O

The O
value O
of O
this O
similarity O
reflects O
the O
coherence O
between O
two O
SCMs O
in O
terms O
of O
their O
cross-subject O
variations O
. O

gRAICAR O
then O
searched O
through O
the O
FSM O
for O
clusters O
of O
SCMs O
( O
demonstrated O
in O
Fig O
. O

S1 O
) O
. O

The O
first O
operation O
in O
the O
search O
procedure O
was O
ranking O
the O
SCMs O
according O
to O
their O
“ O
popularity O
” O
among O
SCMs O
from O
different O
metrics O
. O

The O
following O
steps O
were O
conducted O
to O
compute O
the O
“ O
popularity O
” O
of O
SCMs O
: O
( O
1 O
) O
the O
FSM O
was O
segmented O
into O
metric-blocks O
, O
so O
that O
the O
FSMs O
from O
the O
same O
metric O
stayed O
together O
and O
the O
similarity O
values O
between O
them O
were O
represented O
in O
a O
block O
within O
the O
FSM O
( O
Fig O
. O

S1A O
) O
. O

( O
2 O
) O
The O
similarity O
values O
were O
converted O
into O
relative O
values O
( O
Zrow O
) O
within O
each O
row O
in O
each O
metric-block O
( O
Fig O
. O

S1B O
) O
. O

( O
3 O
) O
The O
maximal O
value O
in O
each O
row O
of O
each O
metric-block O
in O
Zrow O
was O
then O
retained O
in O
a O
new O
matrix O
( O
Zmax O
) O
, O
and O
all O
other O
values O
were O
set O
to O
0 O
( O
Fig O
. O

S1C O
) O
. O

Each O
row O
in O
the O
Zmax O
matrix O
thus O
revealed O
the O
most O
similar O
SCMs O
from O
different O
metrics O
to O
the O
SCM O
represented O
in O
current O
row O
. O

( O
4 O
) O
The O
Zmax O
matrix O
was O
multiplied O
to O
its O
transform O
( O
multiply O
elements O
in O
corresponding O
locations O
, O
Fig O
. O

S1D O
) O
. O

This O
operation O
eliminated O
unpaired O
inter-metric O
maximal O
similarities O
. O

( O
5 O
) O
In O
the O
resultant O
matrix O
, O
the O
sum O
of O
each O
row O
yielded O
the O
“ O
popularity O
” O
value O
for O
each O
SCM O
, O
representing O
a O
special O
form O
of O
centrality O
that O
takes O
specificity O
and O
mutual O
correspondence O
of O
SCMs O
into O
account O
. O

We O
then O
computed O
a O
standardized O
FSM O
by O
adding O
the O
Zrow O
matrix O
to O
its O
transpose O
, O
so O
that O
the O
similarity O
between O
a O
pair O
of O
SCMs O
from O
different O
metrics O
was O
standardized O
among O
all O
SCMs O
from O
the O
relevant O
metrics O
( O
Fig O
. O

S1E O
) O
. O

Starting O
from O
the O
top O
SCM O
in O
the O
popularity O
rank O
, O
11 O
SCMs O
from O
different O
metrics O
were O
identified O
in O
the O
standardized O
FSM O
, O
by O
searching O
for O
maxima O
in O
metric-blocks O
on O
the O
top O
SCM O
’ O
s O
row O
( O
Fig O
. O

S1F O
) O
. O

As O
a O
result O
, O
the O
identified O
12 O
SCMs O
shared O
similar O
trends O
of O
variability O
across O
subjects O
, O
and O
were O
grouped O
as O
a O
multi-metric O
co-variance O
unit O
( O
MMCU O
) O
. O

An O
inter-metric O
co-variance O
matrix O
was O
extracted O
from O
the O
FSM O
for O
each O
MMCU O
to O
characterize O
the O
subject O
course O
similarity O
between O
SCMs O
from O
different O
metrics O
( O
Fig O
. O

S1G O
) O
. O

These O
12 O
SCMs O
were O
thus O
eliminated O
from O
the O
popularity O
rank O
, O
and O
the O
above O
procedure O
was O
repeated O
until O
all O
SCMs O
were O
assigned O
to O
MMCUs O
. O

Because O
different O
metrics O
had O
different O
numbers O
of O
SCMs O
, O
the O
number O
of O
MMCUs O
detected O
using O
gRAICAR O
equals O
the O
second O
maximal O
number O
of O
SCMs O
among O
the O
12 O
metrics O
( O
An O
MMCU O
at O
least O
associates O
two O
metrics O
) O
. O

Structure–function O
co-variance O
analysis O
: O
validation O
In O
the O
confirm O
stage O
, O
we O
examined O
whether O
the O
MMCUs O
detected O
in O
FCP-Cambridge O
were O
reproducible O
across O
datasets O
. O

This O
step O
is O
necessary O
because O
odd O
subjects O
or O
image O
artifacts O
might O
influence O
the O
MMCUs O
obtained O
in O
FCP-Cambridge O
. O

We O
first O
correlated O
each O
SCM O
in O
each O
MMCU O
( O
obtained O
in O
FCP-Cambridge O
) O
to O
the O
corresponding O
metric O
map O
of O
each O
subject O
in O
CoRR-SWU O
. O

As O
a O
result O
, O
we O
obtained O
a O
series O
of O
correlation O
coefficients O
; O
each O
coefficient O
was O
from O
a O
participant O
in O
CoRR-SWU O
. O

We O
treated O
the O
correlation O
coefficients O
as O
a O
cross-subject O
fluctuation O
course O
in O
CoRR-SWU O
for O
a O
given O
SCM O
in O
a O
given O
MMCU O
obtained O
in O
FCP-Cambridge O
( O
step O
3 O
in O
Fig O
. O

1 O
) O
. O

For O
instance O
, O
we O
correlated O
the O
SCM O
of O
the O
vol O
metric O
( O
obtained O
in O
FCP-Cambridge O
) O
to O
the O
vol O
map O
of O
all O
subjects O
in O
CoRR-SWU O
, O
yielding O
a O
course O
of O
correlation O
coefficients O
that O
represented O
fluctuating O
contributions O
of O
the O
vol O
SCM O
to O
the O
subjects O
in O
CoRR-SWU O
. O

Next O
, O
for O
each O
MMCU O
, O
we O
computed O
a O
correlation O
matrix O
between O
the O
cross-subject O
fluctuation O
courses O
of O
the O
12 O
member O
SCMs O
in O
CoRR-SWU O
. O

We O
then O
used O
the O
intra-class O
correlation O
coefficient O
( O
ICC O
) O
to O
measure O
the O
consistency O
between O
the O
inter-metric O
co-variance O
matrices O
obtained O
in O
the O
CoRR-SWU O
and O
FCP-Cambridge O
datasets O
( O
step O
4 O
in O
Fig O
. O

1 O
) O
. O

The O
rationale O
for O
using O
ICC O
here O
is O
to O
consider O
both O
the O
intra-MMCU O
variability O
and O
the O
inter-MMCU O
variability O
. O

In O
this O
step O
, O
the O
elements O
of O
the O
co-variance O
matrices O
were O
first O
converted O
into O
Fisher O
’ O
s O
Z O
scores O
, O
and O
the O
co-variance O
matrices O
obtained O
in O
both O
datasets O
were O
deemed O
as O
two O
observations O
of O
the O
same O
variable O
. O

The O
resultant O
ICC O
, O
therefore O
, O
indicates O
the O
consistency O
between O
the O
inter-metric O
co-variance O
matrices O
obtained O
in O
FCP-Cambridge O
and O
CoRR-SWU O
, O
relative O
to O
the O
variability/similarity O
between O
the O
inter-metric O
co-variance O
matrices O
from O
different O
MMCUs O
. O

We O
conducted O
a O
permutation O
test O
to O
examine O
the O
significance O
of O
the O
ICC O
values O
. O

Specifically O
, O
the O
SCMs O
from O
different O
metrics O
were O
randomly O
grouped O
into O
fake O
MMCUs O
, O
and O
inter-metric O
co-variance O
matrices O
were O
computed O
by O
correlating O
the O
SCMs O
’ O
subject O
courses O
in O
FCP-Cambridge O
. O

Meanwhile O
, O
the O
subject O
courses O
corresponding O
to O
these O
SCMs O
were O
obtained O
in O
CoRR-SWU O
and O
were O
correlated O
to O
yield O
inter-metric O
co-variance O
matrices O
in O
CoRR-SWU O
. O

An O
ICC O
was O
then O
computed O
between O
every O
pair O
of O
fake O
inter-metric O
co-variance O
matrices O
( O
from O
FCP-Cambridge O
and O
CoRR-SWU O
, O
respectively O
) O
. O

This O
procedure O
was O
repeated O
5000 O
times O
to O
generate O
a O
null O
distribution O
of O
ICCs O
. O

Percentiles O
corresponding O
to O
the O
original O
ICCs O
were O
calculated O
in O
this O
null O
distribution O
, O
yielding O
empirical O
significance O
levels O
. O

This O
permutation O
test O
was O
only O
applied O
to O
MMCUs O
with O
ICC O
values O
above O
0.4 O
, O
since O
0.4 O
was O
commonly O
deemed O
as O
a O
threshold O
for O
fair O
reproducibility O
. O

Examine O
relevance O
to O
demographical O
variables O
The O
MMCUs O
with O
significant O
reproducibility O
were O
further O
examined O
for O
their O
relevance O
to O
demographical O
variables O
including O
age O
( O
18–30 O
) O
, O
sex O
( O
117 O
females O
) O
, O
and O
handedness O
( O
25 O
left O
handed O
) O
. O

Specifically O
, O
for O
each O
MMCU O
, O
the O
subject O
courses O
( O
obtained O
from O
ICA O
in O
the O
discover O
stage O
) O
corresponding O
to O
the O
member O
SCMs O
were O
collected O
and O
input O
into O
a O
principle O
component O
analysis O
. O

The O
first O
principle O
component O
represented O
the O
most O
common O
variance O
across O
all O
the O
subject O
courses O
and O
thus O
can O
be O
considered O
as O
a O
representative O
subject O
course O
for O
the O
given O
MMCU O
. O

A O
regression O
model O
was O
then O
constructed O
to O
explain O
this O
representative O
subject O
course O
by O
variability O
in O
age O
, O
sex O
, O
and O
handedness O
. O

Brain O
Circuitry O
Associated O
with O
the O
Development O
of O
Substance O
Use O
in O
Bipolar O
Disorder O
and O
Preliminary O
Evidence O
for O
Sexual O
Dimorphism O
in O
Adolescents O
Substance O
use O
disorders O
( O
SUDs O
) O
and O
mood O
disorders O
are O
highly O
comorbid O
and O
confer O
a O
high O
risk O
for O
adverse O
outcomes O
. O

However O
, O
data O
are O
limited O
on O
the O
neurodevelopmental O
basis O
of O
this O
comorbidity O
. O

Substance O
use O
initiation O
typically O
occurs O
during O
adolescence O
and O
sex-specific O
developmental O
mechanisms O
are O
implicated O
. O

In O
this O
preliminary O
study O
we O
review O
the O
literature O
and O
investigate O
regional O
gray O
matter O
volume O
( O
GMV O
) O
associated O
with O
subsequent O
substance O
use O
problems O
in O
adolescents O
with O
bipolar O
disorder O
( O
BD O
) O
and O
explore O
these O
associations O
for O
females O
and O
males O
. O

Thirty O
DSM-IV O
diagnosed O
BD O
adolescents O
with O
minimal O
alcohol/substance O
exposure O
completed O
baseline O
structural O
magnetic O
resonance O
imaging O
scans O
. O

At O
follow-up O
( O
on O
average O
6 O
years O
post-baseline O
) O
, O
subjects O
were O
administered O
the O
CRAFFT O
interview O
and O
categorized O
into O
those O
scoring O
at O
high O
( O
> O
2 O
: O
CRAFFTHIGH O
) O
versus O
low O
( O
< O
2 O
: O
CRAFFTLOW O
) O
risk O
for O
alcohol/substance O
problems O
. O

Lower O
GMV O
in O
prefrontal O
, O
insular O
, O
and O
temporopolar O
cortices O
were O
observed O
at O
baseline O
among O
adolescents O
with O
BD O
reporting O
subsequent O
alcohol O
and O
cannabis O
use O
compared O
to O
adolescents O
with O
BD O
who O
did O
not O
( O
p O
< O
0.005 O
, O
clusters O
> O
20 O
voxels O
) O
. O

Lower O
dorsolateral O
prefrontal O
GMV O
was O
associated O
with O
future O
substance O
use O
in O
both O
females O
and O
males O
. O

In O
females O
, O
lower O
orbitofrontal O
and O
insula O
GMV O
was O
associated O
with O
future O
substance O
use O
; O
while O
in O
males O
, O
lower O
rostral O
prefrontal O
GMV O
was O
associated O
with O
future O
use O
. O

Lower O
orbitofrontal O
, O
insular O
and O
temporopolar O
GMV O
was O
observed O
in O
those O
who O
transitioned O
to O
smoking O
tobacco O
. O

Findings O
indicate O
GMV O
development O
is O
associated O
with O
risk O
for O
future O
substance O
use O
problems O
in O
adolescents O
with O
BD O
, O
with O
results O
implicating O
GMV O
development O
in O
regions O
subserving O
emotional O
regulation O
in O
females O
and O
regions O
subserving O
executive O
processes O
and O
attention O
in O
males O
. O

Graphical O
abstract O
This O
study O
demonstrates O
regional O
gray O
matter O
volume O
decreases O
that O
may O
distinguish O
adolescents O
with O
Bipolar O
Disorder O
and O
elevated O
risk O
for O
future O
substance O
use O
problems O
. O

Preliminary O
findings O
suggest O
in O
females O
, O
regions O
associated O
with O
internalizing O
behavior O
and O
affective O
processing O
are O
related O
to O
risk O
; O
in O
males O
, O
regions O
associated O
with O
attention O
and O
other O
executive O
processes O
. O

MATERIALS O
AND O
METHODS O
Participants O
Subjects O
who O
were O
assessed O
and O
scanned O
in O
a O
cross-sectional O
study O
and O
consented O
to O
being O
re-contacted O
were O
re-contacted O
and O
recruited O
if O
they O
met O
inclusion O
and O
did O
not O
meet O
exclusion O
criteria O
. O

Participants O
included O
30 O
adolescents/young O
adults O
diagnosed O
with O
BD O
[ O
mean O
age O
at O
baseline O
+ O
standard O
deviation O
( O
SD O
) O
= O
16+2 O
years O
; O
29 O
( O
97 O
% O
) O
BDI O
, O
1 O
( O
3 O
% O
) O
BDII O
; O
50 O
% O
female O
; O
mean O
age O
at O
follow-up= O
22+3 O
years O
] O
( O
see O
Table O
1 O
for O
participant O
characterization O
) O
. O

The O
presence/absence O
of O
psychiatric O
diagnoses O
and O
mood O
state O
at O
time O
of O
neuroimaging O
were O
confirmed O
with O
the O
Structured O
Clinical O
Interview O
for O
DSM-IV O
Diagnosis O
for O
participants O
≥18 O
years O
and O
the O
Kiddie-Schedule O
for O
Affective O
Disorders O
and O
Schizophrenia O
for O
participants O
< O
18 O
years O
. O

At O
baseline O
assessment O
, O
all O
participants O
completed O
sMRI O
. O

At O
follow-up O
assessment O
, O
on O
average O
6+2 O
years O
after O
baseline O
assessment O
, O
subjects O
completed O
the O
CRAFFT O
interview O
to O
assess O
alcohol O
and O
substance O
use O
problems O
since O
baseline O
assessment O
. O

As O
the O
aim O
of O
this O
study O
was O
to O
examine O
baseline O
GMV O
as O
a O
predictor O
of O
future O
alcohol O
and O
substance O
use O
problems O
, O
subjects O
were O
excluded O
if O
at O
baseline O
they O
self-reported O
more O
than O
minimal O
alcohol O
and/or O
cannabis O
exposure O
or O
ever O
having O
used O
cocaine O
, O
opioids O
, O
phencyclidine O
, O
hallucinogens O
, O
or O
solvents/inhalants O
. O

Sixty-three O
percent O
of O
subjects O
( O
11 O
males O
, O
8 O
females O
) O
reported O
never O
trying O
alcohol O
or O
any O
other O
illicit O
substances O
or O
having O
tried O
a O
sip O
of O
alcohol O
once O
at O
a O
family O
gathering O
. O

Remaining O
subjects O
reported O
having O
tried O
alcohol O
or O
cannabis O
once O
or O
on O
a O
few O
occasions O
with O
peers O
. O

Subjects O
were O
not O
excluded O
for O
tobacco O
use O
. O

At O
baseline O
and O
follow-up O
assessment O
, O
tobacco O
use O
was O
assessed O
as O
smoking O
using O
the O
Fagerstrom O
Test O
for O
Nicotine O
Dependence O
( O
FTND O
) O
. O

At O
baseline O
, O
two O
subjects O
( O
7 O
% O
) O
reported O
current O
smoking O
and O
one O
subject O
( O
3 O
% O
) O
reported O
past O
history O
of O
, O
but O
not O
current O
, O
smoking O
. O

Transition O
to O
smoking O
was O
studied O
in O
remaining O
subjects O
. O

In O
addition O
to O
the O
3 O
subjects O
with O
a O
history O
of O
smoking O
tobacco O
at O
baseline O
, O
11 O
individuals O
( O
41 O
% O
; O
7 O
females O
) O
with O
no O
tobacco O
use O
at O
baseline O
reported O
history O
of O
smoking O
at O
follow-up O
( O
8 O
were O
currently O
smoking O
at O
follow-up O
assessment O
; O
4 O
female O
current O
smokers O
at O
follow-up O
) O
. O

Sixteen O
individuals O
( O
53 O
% O
; O
6 O
females O
) O
reported O
no O
history O
of O
smoking O
tobacco O
at O
either O
time O
point O
. O

On O
the O
neuroimaging O
day O
, O
urine O
toxicology O
screens O
for O
substances O
of O
abuse O
( O
cannabis O
, O
cocaine O
, O
amphetamine O
, O
methamphetamine O
, O
methadone O
, O
opiates O
, O
phencyclidine O
, O
barbiturates O
, O
and O
benzodiazepines O
) O
were O
negative O
for O
all O
subjects O
. O

Exclusion O
criteria O
included O
history O
of O
neurological O
illness O
, O
including O
head O
trauma O
with O
loss O
of O
consciousness O
for O
≥5min O
, O
or O
major O
medical O
illness O
. O

Subjects O
were O
not O
excluded O
for O
comorbidities O
or O
family O
history O
of O
psychiatric O
disorders O
as O
there O
are O
high O
rates O
of O
these O
in O
individuals O
with O
BD O
and O
excluding O
decreases O
generalizability O
. O

After O
complete O
description O
of O
the O
study O
, O
written O
informed O
consent O
was O
obtained O
from O
subjects O
≥18 O
years O
, O
and O
assent O
and O
parent/guardian O
permission O
from O
subjects O
< O
18 O
, O
in O
accordance O
with O
the O
Yale O
School O
of O
Medicine O
human O
investigation O
committee O
. O

MRI O
Acquisition O
and O
Processing O
High-resolution O
sMRI O
data O
were O
acquired O
for O
each O
subject O
with O
a O
3-Tesla O
Siemens O
Trio O
MR O
scanner O
( O
Siemens O
, O
Erlangen O
, O
Germany O
) O
. O

The O
sMRI O
sagittal O
images O
were O
acquired O
with O
a O
three-dimensional O
magnetization O
prepared O
rapid O
acquisition O
gradient O
echo O
( O
MPRAGE O
) O
T1-weighted O
sequence O
with O
parameters O
: O
repetition O
time O
( O
TR O
) O
=1500ms O
, O
echo O
time O
( O
TE O
) O
=2.83ms O
, O
matrix O
256 O
× O
256 O
, O
field O
of O
view O
( O
FOV O
) O
=256mm O
x O
256mm2 O
, O
and O
160 O
one-mm O
slices O
without O
gap O
and O
two O
averages O
. O

Images O
were O
processed O
with O
the O
DARTEL O
toolbox O
within O
Statistical O
and O
Parametric O
Mapping O
12 O
( O
SPM12 O
) O
( O
http O
: O
//www.fil.ion.ucl.ac.uk/spm O
) O
. O

The O
SPM O
segmentation O
function O
and O
SPM O
tissue O
probability O
maps O
for O
gray O
matter O
, O
white O
matter O
and O
cerebral O
spinal O
fluid O
were O
implemented O
for O
bias O
correction O
and O
segmentation O
and O
used O
to O
create O
DARTEL O
templates O
using O
the O
“ O
Run O
Dartel O
( O
create O
Templates O
) O
” O
command O
under O
DARTEL O
tools O
. O

Data O
were O
normalized O
to O
Montreal O
Neurological O
Institute O
( O
MNI O
) O
space O
and O
smoothed O
with O
an O
8mm O
full-width-at-half-maximum O
( O
FWHM O
) O
isotropic O
kernel O
. O

Alcohol O
and O
Substance O
Use O
Subjects O
were O
administered O
the O
CRAFFT O
interview O
, O
which O
consists O
of O
6 O
yes/no O
questions O
inquiring O
about O
risk O
indicators O
or O
problems O
experienced O
from O
alcohol O
or O
drug O
use O
. O

CRAFFT O
is O
an O
acronym O
with O
each O
letter O
representing O
one O
of O
6 O
items O
. O

C O
relates O
to O
history O
of O
driving O
or O
riding O
in O
a O
Car O
driven O
by O
someone O
who O
had O
been O
using O
alcohol/drugs O
, O
R O
if O
used O
alcohol/drugs O
to O
Relax O
, O
A O
if O
used O
alcohol/drugs O
while O
Alone O
, O
F O
if O
Forgotten O
things O
one O
did O
while O
using O
alcohol/drugs O
, O
F O
whether O
told O
by O
Family/Friends O
to O
cut O
down O
on O
alcohol/drug O
use O
, O
and O
T O
whether O
gotten O
into O
Trouble O
while O
using O
alcohol/drugs O
. O

The O
questions O
are O
equally O
weighted O
( O
one O
point O
for O
each O
yes O
answer O
) O
. O

The O
CRAFFT O
has O
substantial O
empirical O
support O
as O
a O
substance O
use O
screening O
instrument O
for O
adolescents O
in O
multiple O
settings O
, O
including O
outpatient O
general O
medical O
and O
inpatient O
psychiatric O
settings O
. O

A O
score O
of O
≥2 O
has O
been O
used O
as O
the O
threshold O
optimal O
for O
identifying O
alcohol/substance O
problems O
. O

At O
follow-up O
, O
19 O
( O
63 O
% O
) O
participants O
had O
a O
CRAFFT O
score O
of O
≥2 O
( O
CRAFFTmean+SD= O
2.3+2.1 O
; O
scores O
ranged O
from O
0–6 O
and O
showed O
a O
normal O
distribution O
in O
both O
males O
and O
females O
) O
. O

Additional O
Assessments O
Participants O
were O
assessed O
with O
the O
Young O
Mania O
Rating O
Scale O
and O
the O
2-subtest O
version O
( O
Matrix O
Reasoning O
and O
Vocabulary O
) O
of O
the O
Weschler O
Abbreviated O
Scales O
of O
Intelligence O
. O

Additionally O
, O
at O
baseline O
assessment O
, O
27 O
participants O
[ O
14 O
female O
( O
51 O
% O
) O
] O
completed O
the O
Child O
Depression O
Rating O
Scale O
( O
CDRS O
) O
and O
25 O
participants O
[ O
12 O
female O
( O
48 O
% O
) O
] O
the O
Barratt O
Impulsiveness O
Scale O
( O
BIS O
) O
-11 O
or O
BIS-11a O
. O

The O
BIS O
is O
a O
self-reported O
measure O
of O
trait O
impulsivity O
. O

The O
total O
BIS O
score O
is O
the O
sum O
of O
three O
subscale O
scores O
: O
non-planning O
impulsivity O
, O
cognitive-attentional O
impulsivity O
, O
and O
motor O
impulsivity O
. O

BIS-11a O
scores O
were O
prorated O
to O
BIS-11 O
scores O
as O
previously O
described O
. O

Statistical O
Analyses O
Demographic O
and O
Clinical O
Feature O
Analysis O
Subjects O
were O
categorized O
into O
those O
scoring O
at O
high O
( O
> O
2 O
: O
CRAFFTHIGH O
) O
versus O
low O
( O
< O
2 O
: O
CRAFFTLOW O
) O
risk O
for O
alcohol O
and O
substance O
use O
problems O
. O

Independent O
t-tests O
were O
performed O
to O
assess O
group O
differences O
in O
age O
at O
baseline O
scans O
, O
age O
at O
follow-up O
, O
interval O
between O
baseline O
scan O
and O
follow-up O
, O
and O
baseline O
IQ O
, O
years O
of O
education O
, O
Young O
Mania O
Rating O
Scale O
, O
CDRS O
and O
BIS O
( O
total O
and O
subscale O
) O
scores O
. O

Chi-square O
( O
or O
Fisher O
’ O
s O
exact O
) O
tests O
were O
used O
to O
examine O
whether O
clinical O
factors O
differed O
by O
CRAFFT O
group O
at O
baseline O
( O
see O
Table O
2 O
and O
Table O
3 O
) O
. O

These O
included O
mood O
state O
( O
euthymic O
, O
depressed O
, O
elevated O
) O
, O
history O
( O
yes/no O
) O
of O
hospitalization O
, O
rapid O
cycling O
, O
psychosis O
, O
suicide O
attempt O
, O
smoking O
tobacco O
, O
comorbid O
diagnosis O
( O
yes/no O
) O
of O
simple/specific O
phobia O
, O
ADHD O
, O
ODD O
, O
CD O
, O
or O
separation O
anxiety O
, O
and O
medication O
subclasses O
( O
on/off O
) O
. O

Analyses O
were O
repeated O
stratified O
by O
sex O
. O

Additionally O
, O
a O
Chi-square O
test O
was O
used O
to O
assess O
if O
the O
number O
of O
individuals O
transitioning O
to O
smoking O
tobacco O
between O
baseline O
and O
follow-up O
assessment O
differed O
by O
CRAFFT O
group O
( O
excluding O
3 O
individuals O
with O
baseline O
history O
of O
tobacco O
use O
) O
. O

A O
Fisher O
’ O
s O
exact O
test O
was O
used O
to O
assess O
whether O
CRAFFTHIGH O
males O
and O
females O
differed O
in O
the O
number O
of O
individuals O
who O
transitioned O
to O
smoking O
tobacco O
between O
baseline O
and O
follow-up O
assessment O
. O

Results O
were O
considered O
significant O
at O
p O
< O
0.05 O
. O

SPM O
Voxel-Based O
Analysis O
A O
two-sample O
t-test O
was O
conducted O
in O
SPM12 O
to O
assess O
CRAFFTHIGH O
versus O
CRAFFTLOW O
group O
differences O
in O
baseline O
GMV O
, O
including O
data O
from O
all O
subjects O
. O

For O
hypothesized O
regions O
, O
PFC O
, O
insular O
and O
temporopolar O
cortices O
and O
amygdala O
, O
results O
were O
considered O
significant O
at O
p O
< O
0.005 O
( O
uncorrected O
) O
and O
clusters O
> O
20 O
voxels O
. O

This O
threshold O
was O
chosen O
to O
balance O
for O
type O
I O
and O
type O
II O
errors O
in O
preliminary O
studies O
. O

For O
remaining O
brain O
regions O
, O
findings O
were O
considered O
as O
significant O
with O
p O
< O
0.05 O
Family-Wise O
Error O
( O
FWE O
) O
-corrected O
and O
a O
threshold O
of O
10 O
voxels O
for O
multiple O
comparisons O
. O

Mean O
GMV O
, O
extracted O
from O
clusters O
showing O
significant O
differences O
between O
CRAFFT O
groups O
, O
were O
calculated O
. O

Post O
hoc O
analysis O
was O
performed O
to O
assess O
effect O
of O
CRAFFT O
group O
when O
covarying O
age O
or O
IQ O
at O
baseline O
, O
with O
GMV O
from O
extracted O
clusters O
as O
the O
dependent O
variables O
. O

To O
further O
confirm O
regional O
GMV O
association O
with O
CRAFFT O
outcome O
, O
the O
relationship O
between O
mean O
GMV O
in O
significant O
clusters O
with O
total O
CRAFFT O
score O
was O
assessed O
with O
Pearson O
correlations O
across O
all O
subjects O
. O

Correlations O
were O
repeated O
stratified O
by O
sex O
to O
explore O
sex-related O
patterns O
in O
volumetric O
features O
associated O
with O
the O
development O
of O
substance O
use O
problems O
. O

Correlation O
analyses O
were O
also O
performed O
across O
all O
subjects O
, O
and O
stratified O
by O
sex O
, O
to O
assess O
relationship O
between O
GMV O
and O
baseline O
CDRS O
or O
BIS O
( O
total O
and O
subscale O
) O
scores O
. O

Based O
on O
our O
a O
priori O
hypotheses O
, O
GMV O
from O
clusters O
within O
rostral O
PFC O
( O
rPFC O
) O
and O
dorsolateral O
PFC O
( O
dlPFC O
) O
showing O
a O
significant O
difference O
between O
CRAFFT O
groups O
were O
assessed O
for O
relationship O
with O
BIS O
( O
total O
and O
subscales O
) O
scores O
; O
GMV O
from O
clusters O
within O
orbitofrontal O
cortex O
( O
OFC O
) O
and O
insular O
and O
temporopolar O
cortices O
were O
assessed O
for O
relationship O
with O
baseline O
CDRS O
scores O
. O

Post O
hoc O
analyses O
above O
were O
repeated O
after O
removing O
3 O
subjects O
with O
a O
history O
of O
tobacco O
use O
at O
baseline O
. O

A O
t-test O
was O
used O
to O
explore O
differences O
in O
extracted O
GMV O
, O
from O
significant O
regions O
identified O
in O
the O
CRAFFT O
group O
analysis O
above O
, O
between O
individuals O
who O
never O
smoked O
tobacco O
at O
either O
assessment O
( O
N=16 O
) O
and O
those O
who O
transitioned O
to O
smoking O
tobacco O
between O
baseline O
and O
follow-up O
assessment O
( O
N=11 O
) O
. O

Regional O
GMV O
identified O
as O
being O
associated O
with O
transitioning O
to O
smoking O
tobacco O
were O
explored O
across O
all O
subjects O
who O
transitioned O
and O
were O
currently O
smoking O
tobacco O
at O
follow-up O
using O
Pearson O
correlations O
to O
determine O
relationships O
with O
total O
FTND O
scores O
. O

We O
performed O
t-tests O
to O
explore O
associations O
between O
mean O
GMV O
in O
significant O
clusters O
with O
clinical O
and O
medication O
subclass O
factors O
present O
and O
absent O
at O
baseline O
in O
N O
> O
5 O
subjects O
, O
including O
mood O
state O
( O
euthymic O
versus O
elevated O
) O
, O
history O
( O
yes/no O
) O
of O
hospitalizations O
, O
rapid O
cycling O
, O
lifetime O
psychosis O
, O
and O
if O
taking O
( O
off/on O
) O
an O
antipsychotic O
, O
anticonvulsant O
, O
stimulant O
, O
lithium O
, O
antidepressant O
, O
or O
benzodiazepine O
. O

Analyses O
were O
repeated O
stratified O
by O
sex O
for O
clinical O
factors O
present O
or O
absent O
at O
baseline O
in O
N O
> O
5 O
female O
or O
male O
subjects O
, O
including O
history O
( O
yes/no O
) O
at O
baseline O
of O
rapid O
cycling O
, O
lifetime O
psychosis O
, O
and O
if O
taking O
( O
off/on O
) O
an O
antipsychotic O
at O
baseline O
. O

In O
females O
, O
we O
assessed O
effects O
of O
taking O
an O
anticonvulsant O
and O
differences O
between O
subjects O
transitioning O
to O
smoking O
tobacco O
between O
baseline O
and O
follow-up O
assessments O
( O
N=7 O
females O
) O
, O
compared O
to O
those O
reporting O
no O
history O
of O
smoking O
at O
either O
assessment O
( O
N=6 O
females O
) O
. O

In O
males O
, O
we O
assessed O
effects O
of O
comorbid O
ADHD O
and O
taking O
a O
stimulant O
or O
lithium O
at O
baseline O
assessment O
, O
but O
did O
not O
assess O
for O
smoking O
conversion O
as O
only O
4 O
males O
converted O
. O

These O
post O
hoc O
analyses O
were O
considered O
significant O
at O
p O
< O
0.05 O
. O

All O
significant O
results O
are O
reported O
below O
. O

Alcohol O
Affects O
Brain O
Functional O
Connectivity O
and O
its O
Coupling O
with O
Behavior O
: O
Greater O
Effects O
in O
Male O
Heavy O
Drinkers O
Acute O
and O
chronic O
alcohol O
exposure O
significantly O
affect O
behavior O
but O
the O
underlying O
neurobiological O
mechanisms O
are O
still O
poorly O
understood O
. O

Here O
we O
used O
functional O
connectivity O
density O
( O
FCD O
) O
mapping O
to O
study O
alcohol-related O
changes O
in O
resting O
brain O
activity O
and O
their O
association O
with O
behavior O
. O

Heavy O
drinkers O
( O
HD O
; O
N=16 O
; O
16 O
males O
) O
and O
normal O
controls O
( O
NM O
; O
N=24 O
; O
14 O
males O
) O
were O
tested O
after O
placebo O
and O
after O
acute O
alcohol O
administration O
. O

Group O
comparisons O
showed O
that O
NM O
had O
higher O
FCD O
in O
visual O
and O
prefrontal O
cortices O
, O
default-mode O
network O
regions O
, O
and O
thalamus O
, O
while O
HD O
had O
higher O
FCD O
in O
cerebellum O
. O

Acute O
alcohol O
significantly O
increased O
FCD O
within O
the O
thalamus O
, O
impaired O
cognitive O
and O
motor O
functions O
, O
and O
affected O
self-reports O
of O
mood/drug O
effects O
in O
both O
groups O
. O

Partial O
least O
squares O
regression O
showed O
alcohol-induced O
changes O
in O
mood/drug O
effects O
were O
associated O
with O
changes O
in O
thalamic O
FCD O
in O
both O
groups O
. O

Disruptions O
in O
motor O
function O
were O
associated O
with O
increases O
in O
cerebellar O
FCD O
in O
NM O
and O
thalamus O
FCD O
in O
HD O
. O

Alcohol-induced O
declines O
in O
cognitive O
performance O
were O
associated O
with O
connectivity O
increases O
in O
visual O
cortex O
and O
thalamus O
in O
NM O
, O
but O
in O
HD O
, O
increases O
in O
precuneus O
FCD O
were O
associated O
with O
improved O
cognitive O
performance O
. O

Acute O
alcohol O
reduced O
“ O
neurocognitive O
coupling O
” O
, O
the O
association O
between O
behavioral O
performance O
and O
FCD O
( O
indexing O
brain O
activity O
) O
, O
an O
effect O
that O
was O
accentuated O
in O
HD O
compared O
to O
NM O
. O

Findings O
suggest O
that O
reduced O
cortical O
connectivity O
in O
HD O
contribute O
to O
decline O
in O
cognitive O
abilities O
associated O
with O
heavy O
alcohol O
consumption O
, O
whereas O
increased O
cerebellar O
connectivity O
in O
HD O
may O
have O
compensatory O
effects O
on O
behavioral O
performance O
. O

The O
results O
reveal O
how O
drinking O
history O
alters O
the O
association O
between O
brain O
functional O
connectivity O
density O
and O
individual O
differences O
in O
behavioral O
performance O
. O

Methods O
Participants O
We O
studied O
two O
groups O
of O
participants O
: O
16 O
heavy O
drinkers O
( O
HD O
; O
age O
: O
M O
= O
34.6 O
years O
; O
SD O
= O
9.70 O
years O
; O
16 O
males O
) O
and O
24 O
normal O
controls O
( O
NM O
; O
age O
: O
M O
= O
32.5 O
years O
; O
SD O
= O
6.39 O
years O
; O
14 O
males O
) O
. O

Out O
of O
48 O
planned O
participants O
for O
both O
groups O
, O
these O
subjects O
completed O
required O
MRI O
sessions O
. O

We O
predicted O
at O
α O
= O
0.05 O
and O
80 O
% O
power O
, O
this O
sample O
size O
would O
allow O
to O
detect O
large O
group O
and O
condition O
effects O
on O
FCD O
( O
Cohen O
’ O
s O
d O
= O
0.9 O
; O
r O
= O
0.5 O
) O
. O

The O
inclusion O
criterion O
for O
HD O
was O
5 O
or O
more O
drinks O
a O
day O
on O
3 O
or O
more O
occasions O
per O
week O
. O

The O
HD O
reported O
their O
last O
use O
of O
alcohol O
within O
3 O
days O
of O
the O
MRI O
scans O
. O

In O
order O
to O
maximize O
group O
differences O
, O
for O
NM O
group O
we O
included O
participants O
with O
light O
drinking O
history O
of O
no O
more O
than O
one O
drink O
a O
day O
. O

Because O
we O
did O
not O
want O
to O
give O
alcohol O
for O
the O
first O
time O
to O
an O
individual O
without O
any O
alcohol O
experience O
, O
NM O
also O
had O
to O
have O
prior O
experience O
with O
alcohol O
. O

Exclusion O
criteria O
were O
: O
1 O
) O
urine O
positive O
for O
psychotropic O
drugs O
; O
2 O
) O
present O
or O
past O
history O
of O
dependence O
on O
alcohol O
or O
other O
drugs O
of O
abuse O
( O
except O
nicotine O
and O
allowed O
diagnosis O
of O
alcohol O
abuse O
though O
not O
dependence O
for O
HD O
) O
; O
3 O
) O
present O
or O
past O
history O
of O
neurological O
or O
psychiatric O
disorder O
; O
4 O
) O
use O
of O
psychoactive O
medications O
in O
the O
past O
month O
( O
i.e. O
, O
opiate O
analgesics O
, O
stimulants O
, O
sedatives O
) O
; O
5 O
) O
use O
of O
prescription O
( O
non-psychiatric O
) O
medication O
( O
s O
) O
, O
i.e. O
, O
antihistamines O
; O
6 O
) O
medical O
conditions O
that O
may O
alter O
cerebral O
function O
; O
7 O
) O
cardiovascular O
and O
metabolic O
diseases O
and O
8 O
) O
history O
of O
head O
trauma O
with O
loss O
of O
consciousness O
of O
more O
than O
30 O
min O
. O

Signed O
informed O
consents O
were O
obtained O
from O
the O
subjects O
prior O
to O
participation O
, O
approved O
by O
the O
Committee O
on O
Research O
in O
Human O
Subjects O
at O
Stony O
Brook O
University O
( O
IRBNet O
ID O
: O
137462 O
, O
CORIHS O
ID O
: O
20090792 O
) O
. O

Alcohol O
and O
placebo O
administration O
Each O
participant O
was O
tested O
on O
separate O
days O
( O
maximum O
3 O
days O
apart O
) O
to O
assess O
the O
effects O
of O
alcohol O
( O
ALC O
) O
and O
placebo O
( O
PLC O
) O
. O

The O
order O
of O
ALC O
and O
PLC O
conditions O
was O
randomly O
assigned O
across O
subjects O
( O
single O
blinded O
) O
. O

Subjects O
drank O
alcohol O
( O
0.75 O
g/kg O
mixed O
in O
a O
caffeine-free O
diet O
soda O
) O
or O
placebo O
( O
caffeine-free O
diet O
soda O
) O
beverages O
within O
a O
20 O
min O
period O
under O
blind O
conditions O
. O

For O
this O
purpose O
, O
we O
used O
a O
specialized O
drinking O
container O
with O
an O
alcohol-containing O
lid O
that O
provided O
the O
smell O
of O
alcohol O
and O
delivered O
the O
same O
volume O
of O
liquid O
in O
both O
conditions O
. O

The O
MRI O
scan O
started O
between O
90 O
and O
120 O
min O
of O
ALC O
or O
PLC O
administration O
. O

The O
alcohol O
dose O
( O
0.75 O
g/kg O
) O
was O
approximately O
equivalent O
to O
three O
drinks O
for O
a O
50 O
kg O
person O
and O
was O
within O
the O
range O
consumed O
by O
social O
drinkers O
. O

Blood O
alcohol O
concentration O
levels O
were O
measured O
prior O
to O
the O
fMRI O
scan O
, O
using O
a O
standard O
enzymatic O
assay O
. O

The O
average O
blood O
alcohol O
concentration O
( O
BAC O
) O
across O
participants O
was O
0.62 O
mg/ml O
( O
SD O
= O
0.27 O
mg/ml O
) O
at O
the O
beginning O
of O
the O
MRI O
scanning O
session O
. O

Behavioral O
measures O
Self-reports O
of O
mood O
and O
drug O
effects O
, O
motor O
evaluations O
, O
and O
cognitive O
tests O
were O
performed O
to O
assess O
the O
effects O
of O
alcohol O
or O
placebo O
on O
behavior O
in O
NM O
and O
HD O
. O

Measures O
were O
obtained O
prior O
to O
each O
MRI O
session O
, O
approximately O
90 O
min O
after O
placebo O
or O
alcohol O
administration O
( O
30 O
min O
prior O
to O
MRI O
session O
) O
. O

Self-report O
mood/drug O
effects O
were O
scored O
by O
the O
subject O
from O
0 O
( O
not O
at O
all O
) O
to O
10 O
( O
extremely O
) O
for O
feelings O
of O
stimulated O
, O
sedated O
, O
self-confident O
, O
social O
, O
irritable O
, O
dizzy O
, O
high O
, O
anxious O
, O
pleasant O
, O
alcohol O
desire O
, O
control O
, O
intoxicated O
, O
and O
restless O
. O

Motor O
function O
evaluated O
gait O
( O
time O
and O
errors O
) O
, O
standing O
on O
one O
leg O
( O
errors O
) O
, O
Romberg O
( O
time O
and O
errors O
) O
, O
and O
rhythm O
( O
time O
and O
errors O
) O
tasks O
. O

Cognitive O
evaluation O
was O
made O
by O
staff O
credentialed O
to O
perform O
psychological O
assessments O
and O
included O
the O
Stroop O
( O
neutral O
, O
congruent O
, O
and O
incongruent O
) O
, O
Symbol O
Digit O
Modalities O
test O
( O
SDMT O
) O
, O
and O
Word O
Association O
tasks O
. O

Behavioral O
data O
on O
two O
subjects O
( O
one O
NM O
and O
one O
HD O
) O
were O
not O
available O
. O

The O
between-subject O
factor O
of O
Groups O
and O
within-subject O
factor O
of O
Alcohol O
were O
modelled O
in O
MATLAB O
( O
The O
MathWorks O
Inc. O
, O
Natick O
, O
MA O
) O
while O
using O
smoking O
history O
and O
gender O
as O
covariates O
. O

We O
minimized O
multiplicity O
of O
comparisons O
by O
grouping O
the O
behavioral O
measures O
into O
three O
categories O
: O
mood O
and O
drug O
effects O
, O
motor O
, O
and O
cognitive O
performance O
( O
see O
partial O
least O
squares O
regression O
for O
further O
information O
) O
. O

MRI O
data O
acquisition O
Subjects O
underwent O
fMRI O
in O
a O
4-tesla O
Varian/Siemens O
MRI O
scanner O
( O
Siemens O
Medical O
Solutions O
, O
Erlangen O
, O
Germany O
) O
using O
a O
T2 O
* O
-weighted O
single-shot O
gradient-echo O
planar O
imaging O
sequence O
( O
echo O
time/repetition O
time O
, O
20/1600 O
ms O
; O
4-mm O
slice O
thickness O
; O
1-mm O
gap O
; O
33 O
coronal O
slices O
; O
3.1 O
× O
3.1 O
mm O
in-plane O
resolution O
) O
. O

Participants O
were O
instructed O
to O
remain O
silent O
, O
motionless O
, O
and O
awake O
with O
eyes O
open O
during O
the O
5-min O
resting-state O
scan O
with O
presentation O
of O
a O
fixation O
cross O
. O

fMRI O
data O
preprocessing O
All O
fMRI O
time O
series O
were O
realigned O
and O
normalized O
to O
the O
Montreal O
Neurological O
Institute O
( O
MNI O
) O
space O
with O
3-mm O
isotropic O
voxels O
in O
SPM8 O
( O
Wellcome O
Trust O
Centre O
for O
Neuroimaging O
, O
London O
) O
. O

There O
were O
no O
significant O
main O
effects O
of O
Group O
or O
Alcohol O
, O
or O
a O
significant O
interaction O
effect O
on O
estimates O
of O
subjects O
’ O
motion O
( O
p O
> O
0.05 O
) O
for O
mean O
frame-wise O
displacement O
calculated O
from O
6 O
translation O
and O
rotation O
parameters O
obtained O
from O
the O
realignment O
process O
. O

FMRI O
time O
points O
that O
were O
severely O
affected O
by O
motion O
were O
removed O
using O
a O
“ O
scrubbing O
” O
approach O
. O

Specifically O
, O
in O
each O
subject/session O
, O
less O
than O
4 O
% O
of O
time-points O
were O
removed O
with O
a O
root O
mean O
square O
signal O
change O
( O
that O
is O
, O
DVARs O
) O
threshold O
of O
5 O
% O
and O
a O
framewise O
displacement O
( O
that O
is O
, O
FD O
) O
threshold O
of O
0.5 O
mm O
. O

Remaining O
motion O
effects O
on O
fMRI O
time O
series O
were O
regressed O
out O
using O
the O
6 O
translation O
and O
rotation O
regressors O
. O

Voxels O
with O
poor O
temporal O
signal-to-noise O
( O
tSNR O
< O
50 O
) O
were O
eliminated O
, O
and O
band-pass O
temporal O
filtering O
( O
0.01–0.10 O
Hz O
) O
was O
used O
to O
remove O
magnetic O
field O
drifts O
of O
the O
scanner O
and O
to O
minimize O
the O
effects O
of O
physiologic O
noise O
on O
the O
high-frequency O
components O
. O

The O
effects O
of O
unwanted O
fluctuations O
within O
the O
white O
matter O
and O
cerebrospinal O
fluid O
( O
CSF O
) O
were O
excluded O
from O
the O
analysis O
by O
using O
a O
gray O
matter O
mask O
( O
N O
= O
57,713 O
) O
. O

Local O
functional O
connectivity O
density O
( O
lFCD O
) O
The O
Pearson O
correlation O
was O
used O
to O
assess O
the O
strength O
of O
functional O
connectivity O
, O
Cij O
, O
between O
voxels O
i O
and O
j O
. O

Consistent O
with O
prior O
FCD O
studies O
, O
a O
positive O
correlation O
threshold O
of O
r O
= O
0.6 O
( O
sufficient O
to O
Bonferroni O
correct O
for O
the O
number O
of O
correlations O
performed O
in O
the O
whole O
brain O
, O
p O
< O
0.05 O
) O
was O
used O
to O
compute O
the O
binary O
connectivity O
coefficients O
, O
aij O
= O
1 O
( O
if O
Cij O
> O
0.6 O
) O
or O
aij O
= O
0 O
( O
if O
Cij O
≤ O
0.6 O
) O
. O

The O
local O
functional O
connectivity O
density O
( O
or O
“ O
local O
degree O
” O
) O
for O
voxel O
i O
was O
computed O
as O
the O
size O
of O
a O
continuous O
cluster O
of O
voxels O
with O
aij O
= O
1 O
, O
that O
are O
connected O
by O
surface O
. O

A O
“ O
growing O
” O
algorithm O
was O
used O
for O
time O
efficient O
estimation O
of O
lFCD O
. O

Global O
functional O
connectivity O
density O
( O
gFCD O
) O
The O
gFCD O
, O
also O
called O
“ O
degree O
” O
was O
calculated O
as O
the O
total O
number O
of O
edges O
for O
voxel O
i O
, O
i.e. O
, O
significant O
correlations O
( O
at O
Cij O
> O
0.6 O
) O
between O
voxel O
i O
and O
all O
voxels O
: O
Statistical O
parametric O
mapping O
( O
SPM O
) O
SPM8 O
was O
used O
to O
perform O
voxel-wise O
analyses O
on O
FCD O
indices O
. O

Gender O
and O
smoking O
status O
were O
entered O
as O
covariates O
to O
control O
for O
differences O
between O
the O
groups O
in O
these O
variables O
. O

A O
flexible O
factorial O
design O
was O
used O
to O
model O
the O
between-subject O
factor O
of O
Group O
( O
NM O
vs. O
HD O
) O
and O
the O
within-subject O
factor O
of O
Alcohol O
( O
PLC O
and O
ALC O
) O
. O

Regions O
of O
interest O
( O
ROIs O
) O
were O
identified O
after O
family O
wise O
error O
( O
FWE O
) O
correction O
for O
multiple O
comparisons O
at O
the O
cluster O
level O
correction O
approach O
( O
pFWE O
< O
0.05 O
) O
with O
a O
minimum O
cluster O
size O
of O
k O
= O
75 O
and O
a O
cluster O
forming O
threshold O
of O
p O
< O
0.005 O
. O

Neurocognitive O
coupling O
analysis O
We O
define O
‘ O
neurocognitive O
coupling O
’ O
as O
the O
overall O
association O
between O
individual O
differences O
in O
regional O
resting O
activity O
( O
indexed O
here O
by O
ROI O
FCD O
) O
and O
individual O
differences O
in O
behavioral O
performance O
. O

Specifically O
, O
a O
two-way O
repeated O
measures O
ANOVA O
was O
performed O
in O
MATLAB O
to O
assess O
effects O
of O
Group O
and O
Alcohol O
on O
the O
distribution O
mean O
of O
Fisher O
’ O
s O
z-transformed O
correlations O
between O
functional O
ROIs O
that O
showed O
Group O
or O
Alcohol O
effects O
and O
behavioral O
measures O
that O
showed O
Group O
or O
Alcohol O
effects O
. O

This O
analysis O
was O
also O
repeated O
for O
a O
set O
of O
a O
priori O
anatomical O
ROIs O
( O
Supp O
. O

Fig O
. O

3 O
) O
. O

Partial O
least O
squares O
regression O
A O
partial O
least O
squares O
( O
PLS O
) O
regression O
analysis O
was O
performed O
in O
MATLAB O
to O
reduce O
the O
dimensionality O
of O
data O
and O
consequently O
the O
number O
of O
comparisons O
. O

Whereas O
, O
other O
approaches O
such O
as O
principal O
component O
analysis O
( O
PCA O
) O
find O
components O
that O
maximize O
the O
variance O
within O
a O
set O
of O
variables O
, O
PLS O
regression O
finds O
components O
in O
the O
independent O
variables O
based O
on O
the O
criteria O
of O
maximizing O
the O
amount O
of O
variance O
accounted O
for O
in O
both O
dependent O
and O
independent O
variables O
. O

For O
each O
behavioral O
category O
( O
i.e. O
, O
mood/drug O
effects O
, O
motor O
, O
and O
cognitive O
performance O
) O
, O
the O
goal O
of O
the O
PLS O
regression O
analysis O
was O
to O
find O
a O
linear O
combination O
of O
ROI O
FCDs O
( O
component O
scores O
) O
that O
maximizes O
the O
amount O
of O
variance O
accounted O
for O
in O
the O
included O
behavioral O
tests O
as O
well O
as O
ROI O
FCDs O
. O

The O
number O
of O
components O
selected O
from O
ROI O
FCDs O
was O
limited O
to O
1 O
for O
each O
behavioral O
category O
. O

For O
significance O
testing O
of O
the O
contribution O
of O
each O
ROI O
FCD O
to O
component O
scores O
, O
a O
permutation O
approach O
was O
used O
( O
N O
= O
100000 O
) O
to O
extract O
the O
null O
distribution O
of O
component O
loadings O
. O

All O
the O
p-values O
for O
PLS O
regression O
analysis O
are O
reported O
for O
a O
two-tailed O
test O
( O
i.e. O
, O
considering O
positive O
and O
negative O
loadings O
) O
. O

A O
phenome-wide O
examination O
of O
neural O
and O
cognitive O
function O
This O
data O
descriptor O
outlines O
a O
shared O
neuroimaging O
dataset O
from O
the O
UCLA O
Consortium O
for O
Neuropsychiatric O
Phenomics O
, O
which O
focused O
on O
understanding O
the O
dimensional O
structure O
of O
memory O
and O
cognitive O
control O
( O
response O
inhibition O
) O
functions O
in O
both O
healthy O
individuals O
( O
130 O
subjects O
) O
and O
individuals O
with O
neuropsychiatric O
disorders O
including O
schizophrenia O
( O
50 O
subjects O
) O
, O
bipolar O
disorder O
( O
49 O
subjects O
) O
, O
and O
attention O
deficit/hyperactivity O
disorder O
( O
43 O
subjects O
) O
. O

The O
dataset O
includes O
an O
extensive O
set O
of O
task-based O
fMRI O
assessments O
, O
resting O
fMRI O
, O
structural O
MRI O
, O
and O
high O
angular O
resolution O
diffusion O
MRI O
. O

The O
dataset O
is O
shared O
through O
the O
OpenfMRI O
project O
, O
and O
is O
formatted O
according O
to O
the O
Brain O
Imaging O
Data O
Structure O
( O
BIDS O
) O
standard O
. O

Methods O
Participants O
Healthy O
adults O
were O
recruited O
by O
community O
advertisements O
from O
the O
Los O
Angeles O
area O
. O

Participants O
with O
adult O
ADHD O
, O
bipolar O
disorder O
, O
and O
schizophrenia O
were O
recruited O
using O
a O
patient-oriented O
strategy O
involving O
outreach O
to O
local O
clinics O
and O
online O
portals O
( O
separate O
from O
the O
methods O
used O
to O
recruit O
healthy O
volunteers O
) O
. O

After O
receiving O
a O
verbal O
explanation O
of O
the O
study O
, O
participants O
gave O
written O
informed O
consent O
following O
procedures O
approved O
by O
the O
Institutional O
Review O
Boards O
at O
UCLA O
and O
the O
Los O
Angeles O
County O
Department O
of O
Mental O
Health O
. O

For O
both O
healthy O
and O
patient O
groups O
, O
participants O
were O
men O
or O
women O
ages O
21–50 O
years O
; O
NIH O
racial/ethnic O
category O
either O
White O
, O
not O
Hispanic O
or O
Latino O
; O
or O
Hispanic O
or O
Latino O
, O
of O
any O
racial O
group O
; O
primary O
language O
either O
English O
or O
Spanish O
; O
completed O
at O
least O
8 O
years O
of O
formal O
education O
; O
no O
significant O
medical O
illness O
; O
adequate O
cooperation O
to O
complete O
assessments O
; O
visual O
acuity O
20/60 O
or O
better O
; O
and O
urinalysis O
negative O
for O
drugs O
of O
abuse O
( O
Cocaine O
; O
Methamphetamine O
; O
Morphine O
; O
THC O
; O
and O
Benzodiazepines O
) O
. O

Participants O
in O
the O
healthy O
group O
were O
excluded O
if O
they O
had O
lifetime O
diagnoses O
of O
Schizophrenia O
or O
Other O
Psychotic O
Disorder O
, O
Bipolar O
I O
or O
II O
Disorder O
, O
or O
Substance O
Abuse O
or O
Dependence O
( O
not O
counting O
caffeine O
or O
nicotine O
) O
; O
or O
current O
Major O
Depressive O
Disorder O
; O
suicidality O
; O
Anxiety O
Disorder O
( O
Obsessive O
Compulsive O
Disorder O
, O
Panic O
Disorder O
, O
Generalized O
Anxiety O
Disorder O
, O
Post-Traumatic O
Stress O
Disorder O
) O
, O
Attention O
Deficit O
Hyperactivity O
Disorder O
( O
ADHD O
) O
. O

ADHD O
criteria O
were O
assessed O
using O
Adult O
ADHD O
Interview O
; O
healthy O
participants O
were O
screened O
for O
sub-threshold O
ADHD O
, O
defined O
as O
4 O
or O
more O
ADHD O
inattentive O
or O
hyperactive/impulsive O
symptoms O
in O
either O
childhood O
and O
adulthood O
; O
in O
addition O
, O
they O
could O
not O
have O
had O
medication O
treatment O
for O
ADHD O
within O
the O
prior O
12 O
months O
. O

Each O
of O
the O
patient O
groups O
( O
Schizophrenia O
, O
Bipolar O
Disorder O
, O
and O
ADHD O
) O
excluded O
anyone O
with O
one O
of O
these O
other O
diagnoses O
; O
stable O
medications O
were O
permitted O
for O
the O
patients O
. O

For O
MRI O
studies O
we O
excluded O
participants O
who O
were O
left O
handed O
, O
who O
believed O
they O
might O
be O
pregnant O
, O
or O
had O
other O
contraindications O
to O
scanning O
( O
e.g. O
, O
claustrophobia O
, O
metal O
in O
body O
, O
body O
too O
large O
to O
fit O
in O
scanner O
) O
. O

Diagnoses O
followed O
the O
Diagnostic O
and O
Statistical O
Manual O
of O
Mental O
Disorders O
, O
Fourth O
Edition—Text O
Revision O
, O
and O
were O
based O
on O
the O
Structured O
Clinical O
Interview O
for O
DSM-IV O
( O
SCID-I O
) O
supplemented O
by O
the O
Adult O
ADHD O
Interview O
( O
a O
structured O
interview O
form O
derived O
from O
the O
Kiddie O
Schedule O
for O
Affective O
Disorders O
and O
Schizophrenia O
, O
Present O
and O
Lifetime O
Version O
( O
KSADS-PL O
) O
) O
, O
in O
order O
to O
enable O
a O
more O
detailed O
characterization O
of O
lifetime O
history O
of O
ADHD O
in O
adults O
. O

Interviewers/raters O
were O
trained O
to O
criteria O
as O
described O
elsewhere O
; O
in O
brief O
minimum O
standards O
of O
acceptable O
symptom O
agreement O
were O
overall O
kappa O
of O
.75 O
, O
a O
kappa O
specificity O
of O
.75 O
and O
sensitivity O
of O
.75 O
, O
and O
.85 O
kappa O
for O
diagnostic O
accuracy O
. O

Diagnostic O
and O
Symptom O
elicitation O
skill O
was O
also O
assessed O
with O
the O
SCID O
Checklist O
of O
Interviewer O
Behaviors O
and O
the O
Symptom O
Checklist O
of O
Interviewer O
Behaviors O
. O

Ongoing O
quality O
assurance O
checks O
documented O
kappa O
above O
.75 O
for O
each O
rater O
annually O
during O
the O
course O
of O
the O
study O
. O

A O
subset O
of O
the O
larger O
healthy O
sample O
and O
patient O
sample O
took O
part O
in O
two O
separate O
fMRI O
sessions O
, O
which O
each O
included O
one O
hour O
of O
behavioral O
testing O
and O
a O
one-hour O
scan O
on O
the O
same O
day O
. O

Eligible O
English-speaking O
participants O
between O
the O
ages O
of O
21 O
and O
50 O
were O
recruited O
from O
the O
parent O
study O
if O
they O
successfully O
completed O
all O
previous O
testing O
sessions O
, O
and O
they O
did O
not O
meet O
the O
following O
additional O
exclusion O
criteria O
: O
left-handedness O
, O
pregnancy O
, O
history O
of O
head O
injury O
with O
loss O
of O
consciousness O
or O
cognitive O
sequelae O
, O
or O
other O
contraindications O
to O
scanning O
( O
e.g. O
, O
claustrophobia O
, O
metal O
in O
body O
) O
. O

The O
final O
sample O
included O
imaging O
data O
for O
healthy O
individuals O
from O
the O
community O
( O
130 O
subjects O
) O
, O
as O
well O
as O
samples O
of O
individuals O
diagnosed O
with O
Schizophrenia O
( O
50 O
) O
, O
Bipolar O
Disorder O
( O
49 O
) O
, O
and O
ADHD O
( O
43 O
) O
. O

Diagnostic O
information O
is O
included O
in O
Table O
1 O
. O

81 O
% O
of O
patients O
had O
at O
least O
one O
comorbid O
diagnosis O
; O
information O
on O
the O
prevalence O
comorbid O
conditions O
is O
included O
in O
Table O
2 O
, O
and O
additional O
details O
are O
available O
from O
the O
scid.tsv O
file O
in O
the O
phenotype O
directory O
of O
the O
datasets O
. O

Behavioral O
assessment O
Enrolled O
participants O
completed O
extensive O
neuropsychological O
testing O
; O
these O
data O
are O
included O
in O
the O
phenotype O
subdirectory O
, O
with O
each O
data O
file O
accompanied O
by O
an O
associated O
JSON O
metadata O
file O
. O

The O
list O
of O
tests O
performed O
during O
the O
behavioral O
session O
is O
presented O
in O
Table O
3 O
. O

Participants O
were O
debriefed O
and O
compensated O
for O
their O
time O
at O
the O
end O
of O
the O
final O
testing O
session O
. O

Neuroimaging O
assessment O
Imaging O
acquisition O
MRI O
data O
were O
acquired O
on O
one O
of O
two O
3T O
Siemens O
Trio O
scanners O
, O
located O
at O
the O
Ahmanson-Lovelace O
Brain O
Mapping O
Center O
( O
Siemens O
version O
syngo O
MR O
B15 O
) O
and O
the O
Staglin O
Center O
for O
Cognitive O
Neuroscience O
( O
Siemens O
version O
syngo O
MR O
B17 O
) O
at O
UCLA O
. O

Functional O
MRI O
data O
were O
collected O
using O
a O
T2 O
* O
-weighted O
echoplanar O
imaging O
( O
EPI O
) O
sequence O
with O
the O
following O
parameters O
: O
slice O
thickness=4 O
mm O
, O
34 O
slices O
, O
TR=2 O
s O
, O
TE=30 O
ms O
, O
flip O
angle=90° O
, O
matrix O
64×64 O
, O
FOV=192 O
mm O
, O
oblique O
slice O
orientation O
. O

Additionally O
, O
a O
T2-weighted O
matched-bandwidth O
high-resolution O
anatomical O
scan O
( O
with O
the O
same O
slice O
prescription O
as O
the O
fMRI O
scan O
) O
and O
MPRAGE O
were O
collected O
; O
the O
former O
is O
not O
included O
in O
the O
current O
data O
distribution O
. O

The O
parameters O
for O
the O
high-resolution O
scan O
were O
: O
4 O
mm O
slices O
, O
TR/TE=5000/34 O
ms O
, O
4 O
averages O
, O
matrix=128×128 O
, O
90 O
degree O
flip O
angle O
. O

The O
parameters O
for O
MPRAGE O
were O
the O
following O
: O
TR=1.9 O
s O
, O
TE=2.26 O
ms O
, O
FOV=250 O
mm O
, O
matrix=256×256 O
, O
sagittal O
plane O
, O
slice O
thickness=1 O
mm O
, O
176 O
slices O
. O

Diffusion O
weighted O
imaging O
( O
DWI O
) O
data O
were O
collected O
using O
an O
echo-planar O
sequence O
with O
parameters O
: O
64 O
directions O
, O
2 O
mm O
slices O
, O
TR/TE=9000/93 O
ms O
, O
1 O
average O
, O
96×96 O
matrix O
, O
90 O
degree O
flip O
angle O
, O
axial O
slices O
, O
b=1000 O
s/mm2 O
. O

Subjects O
participated O
in O
two O
scanning O
sessions O
( O
‘ O
A O
’ O
and O
‘ O
B O
’ O
) O
in O
a O
counterbalanced O
fashion O
. O

Session O
A O
included O
: O
localizer O
, O
MPRAGE O
, O
DWI O
, O
Matched O
Bandwidth O
Hires O
, O
Balloon O
Analog O
Risk O
Task O
, O
and O
Paired-associate O
Memory O
Task O
. O

Session O
B O
included O
: O
localizer O
, O
Matched O
Bandwidth O
Hires O
, O
Resting O
State O
, O
Breath O
Hold O
Task O
, O
Stop O
Signal O
Task O
, O
Spatial O
Capacity O
working O
memory O
task O
( O
SCAP O
) O
, O
and O
Task O
Switching O
Task O
. O

Resting O
fMRI O
The O
resting O
fMRI O
scan O
lasted O
304 O
s. O
Participants O
were O
asked O
to O
remain O
relaxed O
and O
keep O
their O
eyes O
open O
; O
they O
were O
not O
presented O
any O
stimuli O
or O
asked O
to O
respond O
during O
the O
scan O
. O

Task O
fMRI O
For O
each O
task O
described O
below O
, O
all O
participants O
received O
brief O
training O
on O
each O
task O
immediately O
before O
scanning O
. O

Each O
participant O
viewed O
the O
task O
stimuli O
through O
MRI-compatible O
goggles O
, O
responded O
with O
his O
or O
her O
right O
hand O
on O
an O
MR-compatible O
button O
box O
in O
the O
scanner O
, O
and O
performed O
one O
run O
of O
each O
task O
while O
in O
the O
scanner O
. O

The O
presentation O
and O
timing O
of O
all O
stimuli O
and O
response O
events O
were O
achieved O
using O
Matlab O
( O
Mathworks O
) O
and O
the O
Psychtoolbox O
( O
www.psychtoolbox.org O
) O
on O
an O
Apple O
Powerbook O
. O

Code O
for O
all O
tasks O
( O
except O
for O
Paired O
Associate O
Memory O
) O
is O
available O
at O
https O
: O
//poldracklab.stanford.edu/software O
. O

Balloon O
analog O
risk O
task O
In O
this O
task O
, O
participants O
were O
allowed O
to O
pump O
a O
series O
of O
virtual O
green O
( O
experimental O
) O
and O
white O
( O
control O
) O
balloons O
. O

On O
each O
trial O
, O
participants O
chose O
to O
pump O
the O
balloon O
or O
cash O
out O
and O
collect O
their O
accumulated O
earnings O
for O
that O
round O
. O

For O
experimental O
balloons O
, O
after O
a O
trial O
in O
which O
the O
participant O
successfully O
pumped O
the O
balloon O
( O
meaning O
it O
did O
not O
result O
in O
an O
explosion O
) O
, O
an O
image O
of O
a O
larger O
balloon O
was O
presented O
, O
the O
participant O
earned O
5 O
points O
, O
and O
was O
able O
to O
pump O
again O
or O
cash O
out O
. O

After O
a O
trial O
in O
which O
the O
participant O
chose O
to O
cash O
out O
, O
the O
participant O
’ O
s O
accumulated O
earnings O
for O
that O
round O
were O
displayed O
and O
the O
task O
moved O
onto O
the O
next O
round O
. O

On O
an O
explosion O
trial O
( O
necessarily O
following O
a O
pump O
trial O
) O
, O
an O
exploded O
balloon O
was O
presented O
, O
the O
participant O
received O
no O
points O
for O
that O
round O
, O
and O
the O
task O
moved O
onto O
the O
next O
round O
. O

In O
this O
version O
of O
the O
BART O
, O
balloons O
exploded O
randomly O
on O
a O
number O
drawn O
from O
a O
uniform O
distribution O
over O
numbers O
of O
pumps O
, O
with O
12 O
maximum O
pumps O
possible O
before O
an O
explosion O
or O
end O
of O
a O
round O
. O

Thus O
, O
participants O
experienced O
the O
probability O
as O
non-stationary O
, O
as O
the O
likelihood O
of O
a O
loss O
event O
increased O
with O
each O
trial O
in O
a O
round O
and O
as O
no O
information O
was O
provided O
to O
subjects O
about O
the O
probability O
of O
explosion O
. O

Subjects O
were O
not O
informed O
regarding O
the O
maximum O
pumps O
possible O
before O
an O
explosion O
or O
end O
of O
the O
round O
. O

Participants O
also O
responded O
to O
control O
balloons O
, O
which O
increased O
in O
size O
on O
successive O
trials O
, O
but O
which O
neither O
resulted O
in O
points O
nor O
exploded O
. O

For O
both O
balloons O
( O
green O
and O
white O
) O
, O
the O
balloon O
would O
disappear O
from O
the O
screen O
once O
the O
participant O
responded O
, O
and O
each O
balloon O
trial O
was O
separated O
by O
a O
jittered O
delay O
. O

An O
outcome O
trial O
( O
following O
a O
cash-out O
trial O
or O
an O
explosion O
) O
was O
displayed O
for O
a O
fixed O
duration O
of O
2 O
s. O
Each O
trial O
was O
separated O
by O
a O
blank O
screen O
that O
was O
presented O
for O
a O
variable O
duration O
( O
1–2 O
s O
, O
average O
1.5 O
s O
) O
; O
each O
round O
was O
separated O
by O
a O
blank O
screen O
that O
was O
presented O
for O
variable O
duration O
( O
1–12 O
s O
, O
average O
4 O
s O
) O
. O

The O
task O
performed O
in O
the O
scanner O
was O
self-paced O
, O
but O
the O
task O
was O
programmed O
such O
that O
participants O
saw O
approximately O
30 O
virtual O
balloons O
, O
with O
an O
approximate O
run O
time O
of O
9 O
min O
. O

Each O
successful O
pump O
was O
worth O
5 O
points O
, O
but O
participants O
did O
not O
collect O
their O
earnings O
at O
the O
end O
of O
the O
scan O
. O

Paired-associate O
memory O
task O
In O
this O
task O
, O
two O
scans O
were O
performed O
to O
assess O
declarative O
memory O
encoding O
and O
retrieval O
, O
respectively O
. O

The O
first O
scan O
consisted O
of O
a O
block O
of O
64 O
encoding O
trials O
. O

Forty O
of O
the O
encoding O
trials O
were O
‘ O
memory O
’ O
trials O
and O
24 O
were O
‘ O
control O
’ O
trials O
. O

During O
memory O
trials O
, O
first O
, O
two O
words O
appeared O
for O
1 O
s O
, O
one O
on O
each O
side O
of O
the O
screen O
. O

Then O
, O
line O
drawings O
of O
two O
objects O
that O
matched O
the O
words O
appeared O
above O
the O
words O
and O
they O
were O
presented O
together O
for O
3 O
more O
seconds O
, O
for O
a O
total O
of O
4 O
s O
per O
trial O
. O

One O
of O
the O
objects O
was O
drawn O
in O
black O
and O
white O
, O
and O
one O
object O
drawn O
using O
a O
single O
color O
( O
e.g. O
, O
orange O
) O
. O

For O
control O
trials O
, O
pairs O
of O
scrambled O
stimuli O
, O
one O
black O
and O
white O
and O
one O
colored O
, O
appeared O
for O
2 O
s. O
The O
subject O
indicated O
by O
button O
press O
which O
side O
the O
colored O
object O
was O
on O
. O

Subjects O
were O
instructed O
to O
remember O
the O
objects O
and O
the O
relationship O
between O
the O
objects O
. O

The O
trial O
types O
were O
intermixed O
. O

In O
total O
, O
the O
encoding O
run O
included O
242 O
TRs O
of O
which O
104 O
( O
42.9 O
% O
) O
were O
active O
task O
, O
and O
the O
ITI O
between O
trials O
was O
jittered O
. O

The O
encoding O
run O
, O
in O
total O
, O
was O
8.07 O
min O
long O
. O

During O
the O
retrieval O
scan O
there O
were O
104 O
total O
trials O
: O
24 O
control O
trials O
, O
40 O
correct O
trials O
, O
and O
40 O
incorrect O
trials O
, O
each O
trial O
was O
3 O
s O
long O
. O

The O
retrieval O
task O
required O
the O
subjects O
to O
look O
at O
a O
pair O
of O
objects O
and O
rate O
their O
confidence O
in O
their O
memory O
of O
the O
pairing O
. O

There O
were O
4 O
possible O
response O
options O
ranging O
from O
‘ O
Sure O
correct O
’ O
to O
‘ O
Sure O
incorrect O
’ O
, O
allowing O
the O
responses O
to O
be O
analyzed O
as O
a O
spectrum O
or O
binarized O
into O
yes/no O
type O
responses O
. O

During O
control O
trials O
, O
on O
one O
side O
of O
the O
screen O
was O
one O
of O
the O
four O
retrieval O
confidence O
response O
options O
‘ O
sure O
correct O
’ O
, O
‘ O
maybe O
correct O
’ O
, O
‘ O
maybe O
incorrect O
’ O
, O
or O
‘ O
sure O
incorrect O
’ O
. O

On O
the O
other O
side O
of O
the O
screen O
was O
‘ O
xxxx O
’ O
. O

Subjects O
were O
asked O
to O
press O
the O
button O
( O
1–4 O
) O
that O
corresponded O
to O
the O
response O
option O
displayed O
( O
for O
example O
, O
a O
response O
of O
1 O
if O
‘ O
sure O
correct O
’ O
appeared O
) O
. O

In O
the O
40 O
correct O
trials O
, O
items O
were O
shown O
paired O
as O
they O
had O
been O
at O
encoding O
. O

During O
the O
40 O
incorrect O
trials O
items O
were O
shown O
paired O
differently O
than O
they O
were O
at O
encoding O
; O
some O
individual O
objects O
had O
been O
displayed O
as O
part O
of O
pairs O
during O
encoding O
, O
but O
at O
retrieval O
were O
paired O
with O
different O
objects O
. O

The O
retrieval O
scan O
consisted O
of O
268 O
TRs O
, O
of O
which O
156 O
( O
58.2 O
% O
) O
were O
active O
task O
, O
and O
was O
8.93 O
min O
long O
. O

Spatial O
working O
memory O
task O
During O
the O
spatial O
delayed O
response O
task O
( O
or O
, O
spatial O
capacity O
task—SCAP O
) O
, O
subjects O
were O
shown O
a O
target O
array O
of O
1 O
, O
3 O
, O
5 O
or O
7 O
yellow O
circles O
positioned O
pseudorandomly O
around O
a O
central O
fixation O
cross O
. O

After O
a O
delay O
, O
subjects O
were O
shown O
a O
single O
green O
circle O
and O
were O
required O
to O
indicate O
whether O
that O
circle O
was O
in O
the O
same O
position O
as O
one O
of O
the O
target O
circles O
had O
been O
. O

A O
relatively O
long O
stimulus O
presentation O
time O
of O
two O
seconds O
was O
used O
to O
allow O
subjects O
to O
fully O
encode O
the O
target O
array O
, O
minimizing O
a O
potential O
encoding O
bias O
on O
the O
basis O
of O
set O
size O
interaction O
. O

Likewise O
, O
decision O
or O
selection O
requirements O
were O
kept O
constant O
across O
set O
sizes O
to O
reduce O
possible O
effects O
of O
set O
size O
on O
response O
processes O
. O

In O
addition O
to O
load O
, O
delay O
period O
was O
manipulated O
, O
with O
delays O
of O
1.5 O
, O
3 O
or O
4.5 O
s. O
Trial O
events O
included O
a O
2-sec O
target-array O
presentation O
, O
a O
1.5 O
, O
3 O
or O
4.5 O
s O
delay O
period O
, O
and O
a O
3-sec O
fixed O
response O
interval O
. O

A O
central O
fixation O
was O
visible O
throughout O
each O
of O
the O
48 O
trials O
( O
12 O
per O
memory O
set O
size O
, O
with O
4 O
at O
each O
delay O
length O
for O
each O
memory O
set O
) O
. O

Half O
the O
trials O
were O
true-positive O
, O
and O
half O
were O
true-negative O
. O

Before O
starting O
the O
in-scanner O
task O
, O
subjects O
underwent O
a O
supervised O
instruction O
and O
training O
period O
outside O
of O
the O
scanner O
, O
and O
once O
in O
the O
scanner O
were O
again O
reminded O
of O
the O
instructions O
. O

Stop O
signal O
task O
In O
this O
task O
, O
participants O
were O
instructed O
to O
respond O
quickly O
when O
a O
‘ O
go O
’ O
stimulus O
was O
presented O
on O
the O
computer O
screen O
, O
except O
on O
the O
subset O
of O
trials O
where O
the O
‘ O
go O
’ O
stimulus O
was O
paired O
with O
a O
‘ O
stop O
’ O
signal O
. O

Specifically O
, O
participants O
were O
shown O
a O
series O
of O
go O
stimuli O
( O
left- O
and O
right-wards O
pointing O
arrows O
) O
, O
to O
which O
participants O
were O
told O
to O
respond O
with O
left O
and O
right O
button O
presses O
, O
respectively O
( O
Go O
trials O
) O
. O

On O
a O
subset O
of O
trials O
( O
25 O
% O
) O
, O
a O
stop-signal O
( O
a O
500 O
Hz O
tone O
presented O
through O
headphones O
) O
was O
presented O
a O
short O
delay O
after O
the O
go O
stimulus O
appeared O
and O
lasted O
for O
250 O
ms O
( O
Stop O
trials O
) O
. O

Participants O
were O
instructed O
to O
respond O
as O
quickly O
and O
accurately O
as O
possible O
on O
all O
trials O
, O
but O
to O
withhold O
their O
response O
on O
Stop O
trials O
( O
on O
trials O
with O
the O
tone O
) O
. O

They O
also O
were O
instructed O
that O
stopping O
and O
going O
were O
equally O
important O
. O

On O
Stop O
trials O
, O
the O
delay O
of O
the O
onset O
of O
the O
stop-signal O
, O
or O
stop-signal O
delay O
( O
SSD O
) O
, O
was O
varied O
, O
such O
that O
it O
was O
increased O
after O
the O
participant O
successfully O
inhibited O
in O
response O
to O
a O
stop-signal O
( O
making O
the O
next O
stop O
trial O
more O
difficult O
) O
, O
and O
decreased O
after O
the O
participant O
failed O
to O
inhibit O
in O
response O
to O
a O
stop-signal O
( O
making O
the O
next O
stop O
trial O
less O
difficult O
) O
. O

Each O
SSD O
increase O
or O
decrease O
was O
in O
50-ms O
intervals O
. O

The O
SSD O
values O
were O
drawn O
from O
two O
interleaved O
staircases O
per O
block O
, O
resulting O
in O
16 O
trials O
from O
each O
staircase O
for O
a O
total O
of O
32 O
Stop O
trials O
per O
block O
. O

On O
the O
testing O
day O
, O
participants O
completed O
two O
experimental O
runs O
( O
one O
run O
outside O
of O
the O
scanner O
and O
one O
while O
inside O
of O
the O
scanner O
) O
. O

In O
the O
first O
task O
run O
completed O
outside O
of O
the O
scanner O
, O
SSD O
values O
started O
at O
250 O
and O
350 O
ms O
for O
staircase O
1 O
and O
2 O
, O
respectively O
. O

At O
the O
end O
of O
the O
behavioral O
run O
, O
the O
last O
SSD O
time O
from O
each O
staircase O
was O
then O
carried O
over O
to O
be O
the O
initial O
SSD O
for O
the O
scan O
run O
. O

This O
one-up/one-down O
tracking O
procedure O
ensured O
that O
subjects O
successfully O
inhibited O
on O
approximately O
50 O
% O
of O
inhibition O
trials O
. O

Also O
as O
a O
result O
, O
difficulty O
level O
is O
individualized O
across O
subjects O
and O
both O
behavioral O
performance O
and O
numbers O
of O
successful O
stop O
trials O
are O
equated O
across O
subjects O
. O

Each O
experiment O
run O
contained O
128 O
trials O
, O
96 O
of O
which O
were O
Go O
trials O
and O
32 O
of O
which O
were O
Stop O
trials O
, O
each O
presented O
randomly O
. O

All O
trials O
were O
preceded O
by O
a O
500 O
ms O
fixation O
cross O
in O
the O
center O
of O
the O
screen O
, O
then O
each O
trial O
began O
with O
the O
appearance O
of O
an O
arrow O
and O
ended O
after O
1000 O
ms O
, O
followed O
by O
the O
null O
period O
. O

Jittered O
null O
events O
separated O
every O
trial O
( O
with O
a O
blank O
screen O
) O
, O
with O
the O
duration O
of O
null O
events O
sampled O
from O
an O
exponential O
distribution O
( O
null O
events O
ranged O
from O
0.5 O
to O
4 O
s O
, O
with O
a O
mean O
of O
1 O
s O
) O
. O

Task-switching O
task O
In O
this O
task O
, O
participants O
were O
presented O
with O
a O
series O
of O
one O
of O
four O
possible O
stimuli O
and O
asked O
to O
respond O
to O
the O
stimulus O
based O
on O
the O
task O
cue O
presented O
prior O
to O
, O
and O
above O
, O
the O
image O
. O

The O
four O
stimuli O
included O
a O
red O
triangle O
, O
red O
circle O
, O
green O
triangle O
, O
and O
green O
circle O
. O

Participants O
switched O
between O
responding O
to O
the O
image O
’ O
s O
color O
( O
i.e. O
, O
red O
or O
green O
) O
or O
the O
shape O
( O
i.e. O
, O
triangle O
or O
circle O
) O
. O

Cues O
presented O
included O
either O
‘ O
SHAPE O
’ O
or O
‘ O
S O
’ O
on O
trials O
where O
participants O
were O
expected O
to O
respond O
to O
the O
shape O
of O
the O
stimulus O
; O
cues O
presented O
included O
either O
‘ O
COLOR O
’ O
or O
‘ O
C O
’ O
on O
trials O
where O
participants O
were O
expected O
to O
respond O
to O
the O
color O
of O
the O
stimulus O
. O

On O
33 O
% O
of O
trials O
the O
instructions O
switched O
, O
such O
that O
participants O
were O
instructed O
to O
switch O
from O
responding O
from O
shape O
to O
color O
, O
or O
vice O
versa O
. O

On O
67 O
% O
of O
trials O
, O
the O
instructions O
remained O
the O
same O
but O
the O
cues O
changed O
. O

This O
task O
is O
designed O
to O
measure O
the O
changes O
in O
reaction O
time O
between O
trials O
requiring O
versus O
not O
requiring O
a O
switch O
in O
responding O
. O

Participants O
completed O
a O
total O
of O
96 O
trials O
, O
for O
a O
total O
run O
time O
of O
6 O
min O
52 O
s. O
Breath O
holding O
task O
In O
this O
task O
, O
participants O
