were O
asked O
to O
alternate O
between O
holding O
their O
breath O
and O
breathing O
regularly O
while O
resting O
. O

Participants O
were O
presented O
with O
bars O
on O
the O
screen O
in O
order O
to O
pace O
breath O
holding O
. O

When O
the O
bar O
was O
green O
( O
lasting O
13.5 O
s O
) O
, O
they O
were O
asked O
to O
breathe O
regularly O
; O
when O
the O
bar O
was O
yellow O
( O
lasting O
3 O
s O
) O
, O
they O
were O
asked O
to O
prepare O
to O
hold O
their O
breath O
; O
and O
when O
the O
bar O
was O
red O
, O
they O
were O
asked O
to O
hold O
their O
breath O
for O
13.5 O
s. O
This O
cycle O
was O
repeated O
five O
times O
, O
for O
a O
total O
run O
time O
of O
2 O
min O
and O
46 O
s. O
Participants O
performed O
the O
BHT O
in O
the O
scanner O
while O
wearing O
a O
respiratory O
belt O
in O
order O
to O
measure O
breathing O
. O

The O
purpose O
of O
this O
task O
was O
to O
assess O
the O
contribution O
of O
respiratory O
rhythms O
to O
changes O
in O
the O
BOLD O
signal O
. O

Physiological O
recording O
During O
the O
breath O
holding O
and O
resting O
fMRI O
scans O
, O
physiological O
data O
were O
collected O
using O
a O
BIOPAC O
MP150 O
with O
Pulse O
Oximeter O
and O
Respiration O
modules O
. O

Data O
were O
sampled O
at O
1000 O
Hz O
and O
recorded O
using O
BIOPAC O
Acknowledge O
software O
. O

Data O
Records O
The O
data O
set O
is O
hosted O
on O
OpenfMRI O
under O
the O
accession O
number O
ds000030 O
( O
Data O
Citation O
1 O
) O
. O

The O
files O
are O
organized O
in O
the O
Brain O
Imaging O
Data O
Structure O
( O
BIDS O
) O
version O
1.0.0rc3 O
format O
, O
and O
provided O
in O
multiple O
gzip-compressed O
tar O
archives O
. O

BIDS O
provides O
a O
consistent O
naming O
convention O
and O
folder O
structure O
that O
is O
amenable O
to O
automated O
processing O
. O

At O
the O
top-level O
, O
machine-readable O
text O
files O
in O
javascript O
object O
notation O
( O
JSON O
) O
are O
provided O
describing O
each O
fMRI O
task O
. O

A O
demographics O
file O
( O
participants.tsv O
; O
tab-delimited O
format O
) O
contains O
the O
unique O
participant O
number O
, O
age O
group O
, O
diagnosis O
, O
and O
an O
indication O
of O
which O
scan O
data O
are O
present O
for O
each O
subject O
. O

func O
: O
BOLD O
contrast O
fMRI O
image O
data O
( O
both O
task-based O
and O
resting O
state O
) O
, O
fMRI O
task O
event O
files O
, O
physiological O
monitoring O
logs O
; O
anat O
: O
high O
resolution O
T1-weighted O
image O
data O
used O
for O
structural O
analysis O
, O
cortical O
parcellation O
, O
and O
co-registration O
to O
standard O
templates O
; O
dwi O
: O
Diffusion-weighted O
image O
data O
used O
for O
experimental O
white O
matter O
characterization O
methods O
such O
as O
Diffusion O
Tensor O
Imaging O
; O
beh O
: O
Stop O
Signal O
task O
training O
run O
collected O
outside O
of O
the O
MRI O
scanner O
. O

The O
neuroimaging O
data O
collected O
for O
each O
participant O
are O
organized O
in O
a O
sub- O
< O
subject_id O
> O
data O
folder O
. O

Each O
of O
these O
folders O
contain O
the O
following O
data O
files O
that O
collectively O
represent O
a O
participant O
’ O
s O
study O
visit O
: O
bart O
: O
Balloon O
analog O
risk O
task O
stopsignal O
: O
Stop O
signal O
task O
pamenc O
: O
Paired O
memory O
encoding O
task O
pamret O
: O
Paired O
memory O
retrieval O
task O
scap O
: O
Spatial O
working O
memory O
task O
taskswitch O
: O
Task O
switching O
task O
bht O
: O
Breath-holding O
task O
rest O
: O
Resting O
state O
( O
eyes O
open O
) O
The O
label O
< O
taskname O
> O
refers O
to O
data O
from O
one O
of O
the O
tasks O
performed O
during O
the O
visit O
: O
An O
additional O
directory O
named O
‘ O
phenotype O
’ O
contains O
additional O
phenotypic O
information O
( O
such O
as O
neuropsychological O
testing O
results O
) O
; O
for O
each O
measurement O
, O
there O
is O
a O
tab-delimited O
text O
file O
along O
with O
a O
JSON O
file O
containing O
the O
data O
dictionary O
and O
measurement-level O
metadata O
. O

Technical O
Validation O
Imaging O
files O
were O
converted O
from O
primary O
DICOM O
data O
to O
Neuroimaging O
Informatics O
Technology O
Initiative O
( O
NIfTI O
) O
version O
1.1 O
format O
using O
the O
dcm2niix O
( O
https O
: O
//github.com/neurolabusc/dcm2niix O
) O
program O
. O

dcm2niix O
extracts O
the O
image O
pixel O
data O
and O
pertinent O
metadata O
parameters O
from O
the O
DICOM O
files O
to O
populate O
the O
NIfTI O
file O
header O
. O

For O
diffusion O
weighted O
images O
, O
dcm2niix O
also O
extracts O
the O
diffusion O
gradient O
strengths O
and O
orientations O
to O
separate O
files O
. O

The O
dcm2niix O
program O
output O
was O
saved O
for O
each O
conversion O
and O
inspected O
for O
errors O
. O

Additional O
metadata O
were O
extracted O
from O
the O
DICOM O
files O
using O
the O
gdcm O
library O
( O
http O
: O
//gdcm.sourceforge.net/wiki/index.php/Main_Page O
) O
and O
converted O
to O
javascript O
object O
notation O
( O
JSON O
) O
format O
to O
accompany O
the O
respective O
image O
files O
. O

All O
relevant O
metadata O
were O
combined O
and O
plotted O
over O
the O
timeframe O
of O
the O
study O
to O
reveal O
instances O
where O
individual O
scans O
were O
performed O
with O
MRI O
parameter O
settings O
that O
deviated O
from O
the O
standard O
protocol O
and O
to O
highlight O
scans O
with O
non-standard O
dimensions O
. O

There O
were O
very O
few O
deviations O
, O
and O
most O
were O
minor O
in O
nature O
that O
did O
not O
warrant O
data O
exclusion O
; O
however O
the O
table O
of O
parameters O
and O
plots O
are O
included O
with O
the O
data O
set O
as O
reference O
material O
. O

After O
processing O
the O
source O
data O
, O
BOLD O
contrast O
( O
fMRI O
) O
and O
T1-weighted O
anatomical O
imaging O
data O
were O
processed O
by O
the O
MRI O
Quality O
Control O
protocol O
( O
MRIQC O
https O
: O
//github.com/poldracklab/mriqc O
) O
. O

MRIQC O
computes O
several O
quality O
control O
metrics O
available O
in O
the O
published O
literature O
. O

Anatomical O
T1w O
scans O
All O
T1-weighted O
images O
were O
skull-stripped O
[ O
AFNI O
3dSkullStrip O
] O
, O
corrected O
for O
intensity O
inhomogeneity O
due O
to O
B1 O
variations O
[ O
ANTS O
N4 O
] O
, O
and O
normalized O
to O
MNI-152 O
2 O
mm O
template O
space O
[ O
ANTS O
] O
. O

The O
background O
, O
gray O
matter O
, O
white O
matter O
, O
and O
cerebrospinal O
fluid O
were O
segmented O
[ O
FSL O
5.0.8/FAST O
] O
, O
and O
the O
resulting O
segmentations O
were O
used O
to O
compute O
the O
a O
set O
of O
quality O
control O
measures O
( O
See O
Table O
4 O
) O
. O

In O
addition O
to O
the O
quality O
metrics O
listed O
above O
, O
summary O
information O
about O
the O
mean O
and O
standard O
deviation O
of O
background O
, O
foreground O
, O
gray O
matter O
, O
white O
matter O
, O
CSF O
, O
and O
average O
inhomogeneity O
bias O
are O
provided O
for O
comparison O
across O
the O
subject O
population O
( O
see O
Fig O
. O

1 O
) O
. O

After O
the O
MRIQC O
was O
completed O
, O
each O
high-resolution O
T1-weighted O
anatomical O
scan O
was O
scrubbed O
of O
facial O
features O
using O
the O
mri_deface O
program O
. O

Visual O
inspection O
of O
all O
outputs O
was O
performed O
to O
ensure O
that O
the O
facial O
features O
were O
properly O
removed O
to O
preserve O
subject O
privacy O
. O

BOLD/T2 O
* O
-weighted O
functional O
scans O
Each O
BOLD-contrast O
fMRI O
scan O
was O
corrected O
for O
head O
motion O
during O
the O
acquisition O
using O
AFNI O
, O
and O
a O
brain O
mask O
was O
computed O
to O
separate O
the O
brain O
from O
the O
skull O
and O
outside O
air O
. O

Table O
5 O
lists O
the O
QC O
metrics O
that O
were O
were O
computed O
from O
these O
images O
, O
and O
Fig O
. O

2 O
shows O
the O
distribution O
of O
these O
measures O
. O

fMRI O
task O
event O
and O
physiological O
monitoring O
data O
fMRI O
task O
and O
event O
onsets O
were O
extracted O
from O
the O
raw O
matlab O
log O
files O
using O
R-matlab O
and O
are O
provided O
as O
tabular O
text O
files O
. O

These O
event O
files O
contain O
the O
onset O
, O
duration O
, O
type O
of O
trial O
, O
reaction O
time O
, O
and O
task-specific O
details O
. O

The O
onset O
time O
entries O
in O
each O
event O
file O
were O
corrected O
for O
the O
scanner O
trigger O
delay O
to O
account O
for O
extra O
T1 O
saturation O
equalization O
pre-scans O
performed O
by O
the O
scanner O
. O

In O
some O
cases O
the O
trigger O
delay O
was O
not O
explicitly O
available O
from O
the O
source O
data O
. O

Plots O
of O
all O
event O
files O
are O
provided O
with O
the O
data O
set O
for O
reference O
. O

Similarly O
, O
physiological O
recordings O
collected O
during O
resting O
state O
and O
breath-holding O
fMRI O
scans O
were O
converted O
from O
raw O
data O
( O
Acknowledge O
format O
, O
BioPac O
) O
using O
the O
Bioread O
python O
package O
( O
https O
: O
//github.com/njvack/bioread O
) O
. O

The O
individual O
recording O
traces O
were O
saved O
as O
gzip-compressed O
tab-separated O
value O
files O
, O
and O
the O
raw O
data O
header O
information O
( O
Channel O
Name O
, O
Units O
, O
Sampling O
Rate O
) O
was O
extracted O
to O
accompanying O
JSON O
files O
. O

Plots O
of O
physiological O
traces O
are O
provided O
overlaid O
with O
breath-hold O
instruction O
timings O
( O
ready O
, O
hold O
, O
rest O
) O
for O
reference O
. O

Diffusion-weighted O
imaging O
The O
diffusion-weighted O
data O
were O
corrected O
for O
eddy O
currents O
and O
head O
motion O
using O
the O
B0 O
image O
as O
the O
reference O
, O
and O
the O
motion O
parameters O
were O
saved O
for O
later O
analysis O
. O

The O
corrected O
volumes O
were O
then O
skull-stripped O
to O
remove O
the O
background O
and O
other O
non-brain O
scan O
regions O
. O

Diffusion O
tensor O
estimation O
was O
performed O
for O
each O
subject O
, O
and O
the O
mean O
fractional O
anisotropy O
( O
FA O
) O
and O
average O
diffusivity O
( O
AD O
) O
were O
computed O
for O
all O
brain O
voxels O
. O

Quality O
assurance O
was O
performed O
using O
a O
semi-automated O
method O
, O
including O
the O
following O
steps O
: O
confirmed O
that O
the O
b-values O
and O
applied O
directions O
were O
the O
same O
as O
expected O
, O
calculated O
mean O
in-mask O
FA O
and O
average O
or O
mean O
diffusivity O
( O
AD O
, O
MD O
) O
, O
calculated O
and O
plotted O
motion O
, O
created O
a O
standard O
deviation O
image O
based O
on O
regular O
and O
motion O
corrected O
files O
, O
and O
used O
regional O
maps O
to O
calculate O
the O
percentage O
of O
cropped O
voxels O
in O
the O
occipital O
lobe O
, O
frontal O
lobe O
, O
temporal O
lobes O
, O
cerebellum O
, O
and O
the O
most O
superior O
portion O
of O
the O
brain O
. O

Trained O
individuals O
then O
used O
the O
results O
of O
this O
script O
to O
evaluate O
scan O
quality O
. O

This O
included O
a O
visual O
inspection O
of O
the O
FA O
map O
, O
visual O
inspection O
of O
the O
color O
map O
to O
ensure O
tracts O
were O
coded O
correctly O
, O
a O
check O
for O
cropping O
in O
which O
if O
more O
than O
10 O
percent O
of O
voxels O
in O
a O
region O
were O
cropped O
, O
the O
map O
was O
visually O
inspected O
to O
ensure O
that O
the O
cropped O
region O
did O
not O
encroach O
on O
a O
major O
tract O
( O
i.e. O
, O
regions O
that O
would O
be O
included O
in O
the O
FSL O
DTI O
skeleton O
) O
, O
and O
the O
raw O
data O
were O
watched O
as O
a O
movie O
. O

Data O
were O
flagged O
for O
coverage O
( O
0=no O
cropping O
, O
1=minor O
cropping O
, O
2=severe O
unuseable O
cropping O
) O
, O
motion O
( O
based O
on O
watching O
raw O
data O
as O
movie O
, O
and O
on O
motion O
plots O
) O
, O
tensor O
direction O
flags O
( O
based O
on O
b-value O
and O
direction O
calculations O
, O
and O
on O
observation O
of O
the O
color O
map O
) O
, O
artifact O
flags O
( O
including O
noise O
, O
striping O
, O
and O
the O
vibration O
artifact O
that O
affected O
many O
Siemens O
Trio O
systems O
during O
this O
time O
period O
) O
. O

An O
overall O
quality O
score O
from O
1–4 O
was O
generated O
from O
these O
measures O
, O
in O
which O
1=excellent O
, O
2=good O
, O
3=fair O
( O
both O
2 O
and O
3 O
may O
be O
useable O
, O
but O
depending O
on O
analysis O
may O
want O
to O
consider O
the O
reason O
for O
the O
decreased O
score O
) O
, O
and O
4=unuseable O
( O
all O
individuals O
with O
vibration O
artifacts O
are O
in O
this O
category O
, O
along O
with O
other O
irreconcilable O
problems O
) O
, O
5=not O
evaluated O
; O
the O
distribution O
of O
these O
ratings O
is O
shown O
in O
Fig O
. O

3 O
. O

Ratings O
are O
included O
with O
the O
data O
download O
. O

, O
which O
places O
no O

on O

of O

. O

expect O
that O
users O
of O

follow O
the O
ODC O
Attribution-Sharealike O
Community O
Norms O

that O

Additional O
Information O
How O
to O
cite O
this O
article O
: O
Poldrack O
, O
R. O
A. O
et O
al O
. O

A O
phenome-wide O
examination O
of O
neural O
and O
cognitive O
function O
. O

Sci O
. O

Data O
3:160110 O
doi O
: O
10.1038/sdata.2016.110 O
( O
2016 O
) O
. O

Publisher O
’ O
s O
note O
: O
Springer O
Nature O
remains O
neutral O
with O
regard O
to O
jurisdictional O
claims O
in O
published O
maps O
and O
institutional O
affiliations O
. O

Cannabis O
and O
cocaine O
decrease O
cognitive O
impulse O
control O
and O
functional O
corticostriatal O
connectivity O
in O
drug O
users O
with O
low O
activity O
DBH O
genotypes O
The O
dopamine O
β-hydroxylase O
( O
DβH O
) O
enzyme O
transforms O
dopamine O
into O
noradrenaline O
. O

We O
hypothesized O
that O
individuals O
with O
low O
activity O
DBH O
genotypes O
( O
rs1611115 O
CT/TT O
) O
are O
more O
sensitive O
to O
the O
influence O
of O
cannabis O
and O
cocaine O
on O
cognitive O
impulse O
control O
and O
functional O
connectivity O
in O
the O
limbic O
‘ O
reward O
’ O
circuit O
because O
they O
experience O
a O
drug O
induced O
hyperdopaminergic O
state O
compared O
to O
individuals O
with O
high O
activity O
DBH O
genotypes O
( O
rs1611115 O
CC O
) O
. O

Regular O
drug O
users O
( O
N O
= O
122 O
) O
received O
acute O
doses O
of O
cannabis O
( O
450 O
μg/kg O
THC O
) O
, O
cocaine O
HCl O
300 O
mg O
and O
placebo O
. O

Cognitive O
impulse O
control O
was O
assessed O
by O
means O
of O
the O
Matching O
Familiar O
Figures O
Test O
( O
MFFT O
) O
. O

Resting O
state O
fMRI O
was O
measured O
in O
a O
subset O
of O
participants O
to O
determine O
functional O
connectivity O
between O
the O
nucleus O
accumbens O
( O
NAc O
) O
and O
( O
sub O
) O
cortical O
areas O
. O

The O
influence O
of O
cannabis O
and O
cocaine O
on O
impulsivity O
and O
functional O
connectivity O
significantly O
interacted O
with O
DBH O
genotype O
. O

Both O
drugs O
increased O
cognitive O
impulsivity O
in O
participants O
with O
CT/TT O
genotypes O
but O
not O
in O
CC O
participants O
. O

Both O
drugs O
also O
reduced O
functional O
connectivity O
between O
the O
NAc O
and O
the O
limbic O
lobe O
, O
prefrontal O
cortex O
, O
striatum O
and O
thalamus O
and O
primarily O
in O
individuals O
with O
CT/TT O
genotypes O
. O

Correlational O
analysis O
indicated O
a O
significant O
negative O
association O
between O
cognitive O
impulsivity O
and O
functional O
connectivity O
in O
subcortical O
areas O
of O
the O
brain O
. O

It O
is O
concluded O
that O
interference O
of O
cannabis O
and O
cocaine O
with O
cognitive O
impulse O
control O
and O
functional O
corticostriatal O
connectivity O
depends O
on O
DBH O
genotype O
. O

The O
present O
data O
provide O
a O
neural O
substrate O
and O
behavioral O
mechanism O
by O
which O
drug O
users O
can O
progress O
to O
drug O
seeking O
and O
may O
also O
offer O
a O
rationale O
for O
targeted O
pharmacotherapy O
in O
chronic O
drug O
users O
with O
high O
risk O
DBH O
genotypes O
. O

Methods O
Participants O
Participants O
were O
recruited O
at O
2 O
study O
sites O
( O
i.e O
. O

Maastricht O
and O
Nijmegen O
) O
that O
participated O
in O
this O
multicenter O
trial O
. O

In O
total O
, O
122 O
regular O
users O
of O
cannabis O
and O
cocaine O
( O
male O
N O
= O
96 O
, O
female O
N O
= O
26 O
) O
entered O
the O
study O
. O

On O
average O
, O
participants O
had O
been O
regular O
users O
of O
cannabis O
and O
cocaine O
for O
7 O
yrs O
. O

( O
min-max O
: O
1–23 O
) O
and O
3.2 O
yrs O
. O

( O
min-max:0.5–6 O
) O
respectively O
. O

Participants O
reported O
an O
average O
( O
SD O
; O
min-max O
) O
use O
of O
cannabis O
and O
cocaine O
on O
44.8 O
( O
26.8 O
) O
and O
3.7 O
( O
3.5 O
) O
occasions O
respectively O
during O
the O
previous O
3 O
months O
. O

Participants O
also O
reported O
the O
use O
of O
other O
substances O
such O
as O
MDMA O
( O
88 O
% O
) O
, O
amphetamines O
( O
73 O
% O
) O
, O
mushrooms O
( O
61 O
% O
) O
, O
LSD O
( O
20 O
% O
) O
and O
a O
range O
of O
miscellaneous O
drugs O
( O
60 O
% O
) O
such O
as O
nitrous O
oxide O
, O
MDMA O
crystals O
, O
DMT O
and O
ketamine O
. O

Mean O
( O
SD O
) O
age O
of O
participants O
was O
22.8 O
( O
3.7 O
) O
yrs O
. O

Mean O
( O
SD O
) O
trait O
impulsivity O
score O
as O
assessed O
with O
the O
Barratt O
Impulsiveness O
Scale O
was O
69.5 O
( O
9.6 O
) O
. O

Participants O
were O
recruited O
through O
advertisements O
in O
local O
newspapers O
, O
flyers O
distributed O
at O
targeted O
locations O
( O
e.g. O
, O
college O
campuses O
, O
bars O
, O
night O
clubs O
, O
concerts O
, O
head O
shops O
) O
and O
by O
word O
of O
mouth O
. O

Candidates O
received O
a O
medical O
examination O
by O
the O
medical O
supervisors O
who O
determined O
study O
eligibility O
. O

The O
medical O
supervisor O
checked O
vital O
signs O
, O
conducted O
a O
resting O
12-lead O
electrocardiogram O
( O
ECG O
) O
, O
took O
blood O
and O
urine O
samples O
. O

Participants O
filled O
out O
a O
standard O
questionnaire O
on O
medical O
history O
. O

Standard O
blood O
chemistry O
, O
hematology O
, O
DBH O
genotyping O
and O
drug O
screen O
tests O
were O
conducted O
on O
blood O
and O
urine O
samples O
respectively O
. O

Inclusion O
criteria O
were O
: O
written O
informed O
consent O
; O
age O
18–40 O
yrs O
. O

; O
( O
regular O
) O
use O
of O
cannabis O
( O
i.e O
. O

≥ O
2 O
times/3 O
mo O
) O
; O
cocaine O
use O
at O
least O
5 O
times O
in O
the O
previous O
year O
, O
good O
physical O
and O
mental O
health O
and O
normal O
weight O
( O
BMI O
18-28 O
) O
. O

Exclusion O
criteria O
were O
: O
cocaine O
dependence O
according O
to O
DSM-IV O
criteria O
; O
use O
of O
psychotropic O
medicinal O
drugs O
, O
presence O
or O
history O
of O
psychiatric O
or O
neurological O
disorder O
; O
pregnancy O
or O
lactating O
; O
cardiovascular O
abnormalities O
; O
excessive O
alcohol O
use O
( O
> O
20 O
units/week O
) O
or O
smoking O
( O
> O
15 O
cigarettes/day O
) O
, O
and O
hypertension O
. O

This O
study O
( O
Dutch O
Trial O
Register O
, O
trial O
number O
NTR2127 O
) O
was O
conducted O
according O
to O
the O
code O
of O
ethics O
on O
human O
experimentation O
as O
described O
in O
the O
declaration O
of O
Helsinki O
( O
1964 O
) O
, O
amended O
in O
Seoul O
( O
2008 O
) O
. O

The O
study O
protocol O
was O
approved O
by O
the O
Medical O
Ethics O
Committee O
of O
Maastricht O
University O
. O

Design O
, O
drug O
dose O
and O
administration O
Participants O
entered O
a O
double-blind O
, O
placebo-controlled O
, O
3-way O
crossover O
study O
. O

Treatments O
consisted O
of O
placebo O
, O
450 O
μg/kg O
THC O
( O
cannabis O
plant O
material O
, O
divided O
over O
2 O
successive O
doses O
of O
300 O
and O
150 O
μg/kg O
) O
and O
a O
single O
dose O
of O
300 O
mg O
cocaine O
HCl O
. O

Cannabis O
was O
prepared O
from O
batches O
that O
contained O
11–12 O
% O
THC O
. O

Cannabis O
doses O
were O
tailored O
to O
each O
individual O
subject O
to O
represent O
weight O
calibrated O
doses O
of O
300 O
μg/kg O
THC O
and O
150 O
μg/kg O
THC O
and O
administered O
using O
a O
Volcano O
vaporizer O
( O
Storz O
& O
Bickel O
Volcano O
® O
) O
. O

Cocaine O
HCl O
and O
placebo O
were O
administered O
in O
an O
opaque O
white O
capsule O
. O

Treatments O
were O
administered O
using O
a O
double O
dummy O
technique O
to O
synchronize O
time O
of O
maximal O
drug O
concentrations O
( O
Tmax O
) O
during O
performance O
testing O
and O
resting O
state O
fMRI O
. O

Cocaine O
or O
cocaine O
placebo O
capsules O
were O
administered O
at O
1,25 O
h O
prior O
( O
T0 O
) O
to O
assessment O
of O
performance O
in O
the O
MFFT O
, O
whereas O
the O
first O
dose O
of O
cannabis O
( O
300 O
μg/kg O
THC O
) O
or O
cannabis O
placebo O
was O
inhaled O
15 O
( O
T1 O
) O
min O
prior O
to O
MFFT O
. O

A O
second O
dose O
( O
T2 O
) O
of O
cannabis O
( O
150 O
μg/kg O
THC O
) O
or O
cannabis O
placebo O
was O
administered O
one O
hour O
after O
the O
first O
dose O
( O
T1 O
) O
and O
30 O
min O
prior O
to O
resting O
state O
fMRI O
. O

MFFT O
performance O
was O
collected O
from O
participants O
in O
both O
centers O
. O

However O
only O
participants O
recruited O
by O
the O
Maastricht O
center O
( O
N O
= O
61 O
) O
received O
a O
subsequent O
fMRI O
session O
. O

Treatment O
conditions O
were O
separated O
by O
a O
minimum O
wash-out O
period O
of O
7 O
days O
and O
counterbalanced O
across O
participants O
. O

Vital O
signs O
and O
blood O
samples O
were O
taken O
after O
treatment O
administrations O
( O
T0 O
, O
T1 O
and O
T2 O
) O
. O

Procedures O
Participants O
were O
familiarized O
with O
tests O
and O
procedures O
on O
a O
separate O
training O
day O
prior O
to O
the O
treatment O
conditions O
. O

Participants O
were O
instructed O
to O
refrain O
from O
drug O
use O
( O
except O
for O
cannabis O
) O
throughout O
study O
participation O
. O

In O
the O
morning O
of O
test O
days O
, O
absence O
of O
benzodiazepines O
, O
opiates O
, O
cocaine O
, O
marijuana O
, O
MDMA O
and O
( O
meth O
) O
amphetamine O
was O
assessed O
using O
urine O
screens O
and O
the O
absence O
of O
alcohol O
was O
measured O
using O
a O
breathalyzer O
. O

Female O
participants O
underwent O
an O
additional O
pregnancy O
test O
. O

Participants O
were O
only O
allowed O
to O
proceed O
when O
test O
results O
for O
drug O
( O
except O
cannabis O
) O
and O
alcohol O
use O
and O
pregnancy O
were O
negative O
. O

Participants O
that O
passed O
the O
screen O
test O
received O
a O
standard O
breakfast O
, O
followed O
by O
baseline O
measures O
of O
vital O
signs O
( O
blood O
pressure O
and O
heart O
rate O
) O
and O
a O
sample O
of O
blood O
. O

Matching O
familiar O
figures O
test O
( O
MFFT O
) O
The O
MFFT O
measures O
cognitive O
impulsivity O
. O

It O
involves O
simultaneous O
presentation O
of O
a O
target O
figure O
centered O
on O
the O
left O
half O
of O
the O
screen O
and O
an O
array O
of O
six O
alternatives O
on O
the O
right O
half O
of O
the O
screen O
, O
all O
except O
one O
differing O
in O
one O
or O
more O
details O
from O
the O
target O
figure O
. O

The O
participants O
are O
asked O
to O
find O
the O
item O
that O
exactly O
matches O
the O
target O
item O
by O
pressing O
a O
keyboard O
number O
corresponding O
to O
each O
of O
the O
items O
. O

If O
the O
initial O
selection O
is O
incorrect O
, O
this O
is O
signaled O
with O
a O
beep O
and O
participants O
are O
requested O
to O
respond O
again O
. O

Each O
subject O
is O
given O
2 O
practice O
trials O
followed O
by O
20 O
test O
trials O
. O

Mean O
latency O
of O
the O
first O
response O
and O
total O
number O
of O
errors O
, O
are O
recorded O
and O
used O
to O
calculate O
two O
primary O
measures O
after O
z-transformation O
: O
i.e O
. O

an O
Impulsivity O
score O
( O
I-score O
) O
and O
an O
Efficiency O
score O
( O
E-score O
) O
( O
Messer O
and O
Brodzinsky O
) O
. O

The O
I-score O
is O
a O
composite O
index O
of O
impulsivity O
and O
is O
calculated O
by O
subtracting O
the O
standardized O
score O
of O
the O
mean O
latency O
to O
first O
response O
from O
the O
standardized O
score O
of O
the O
total O
number O
of O
errors O
committed O
( O
Zerror-Zlatency O
) O
. O

The O
E-score O
is O
calculated O
by O
summing O
the O
standardized O
score O
of O
the O
mean O
latency O
to O
first O
response O
from O
the O
standardized O
score O
of O
the O
total O
number O
of O
errors O
committed O
( O
1- O
( O
Zerror O
+ O
Zlatency O
) O
) O
. O

Resting O
state O
fMRI O
MRI O
images O
were O
obtained O
in O
a O
3 O
T O
head-only O
scanner O
( O
Siemens® O
MAGNETOM O
Allegra O
) O
. O

During O
resting O
state O
240 O
EPI O
whole O
brain O
functional O
volumes O
were O
acquired O
( O
TR O
= O
2 O
s O
, O
TE O
= O
30 O
ms O
, O
flip O
angle O
= O
90° O
, O
matrix O
= O
64 O
× O
64 O
× O
32 O
, O
voxel O
size O
= O
3.5 O
× O
3.5 O
× O
3.5 O
mm O
) O
. O

Volunteers O
were O
asked O
to O
relax O
with O
the O
eyes O
open O
during O
resting O
state O
measurement O
. O

For O
anatomical O
reference O
, O
a O
3D O
MPRAGE O
( O
magnetization-prepared O
rapid O
gradient O
echo O
; O
TR O
= O
9.7 O
ms O
, O
TE O
= O
4 O
ms O
, O
flip O
angle O
= O
12° O
, O
matrix O
= O
256 O
× O
256 O
, O
voxel O
size O
= O
1 O
× O
1 O
× O
1 O
mm3 O
) O
image O
data O
set O
was O
acquired O
. O

The O
fMRI O
data O
were O
preprocessed O
using O
SPM8 O
software O
( O
Welcome O
Trust O
Center O
for O
Neuroimaging O
, O
London O
, O
UK O
) O
. O

The O
first O
2 O
volumes O
were O
removed O
from O
each O
fMRI O
data O
set O
to O
allow O
for O
magnetic O
equilibration O
. O

Preprocessing O
included O
3D O
motion O
correction O
and O
slice O
time O
correction O
. O

Individual O
anatomical O
data O
sets O
were O
normalized O
to O
standard O
3-D O
MNI O
space O
. O

Individual O
functional O
images O
were O
realigned O
, O
co-registered O
and O
normalized O
to O
the O
anatomical O
data O
, O
and O
resampled O
to O
a O
voxel O
size O
of O
3 O
× O
3 O
× O
3 O
mm3 O
. O

Spatial O
smoothing O
was O
conducted O
with O
a O
FWHM O
4 O
mm O
Gaussian O
kernel O
. O

Functional O
connectivity O
Functional O
connectivity O
data O
were O
produced O
with O
the O
MATLAB O
toolbox O
DPARSFA O
( O
Chao-Gan O
and O
Yu-Feng O
) O
. O

First O
, O
linear O
trends O
of O
time O
courses O
were O
removed O
followed O
by O
low O
band-pass O
filtering O
( O
0.01–0.08 O
Hz O
) O
of O
the O
preprocessed O
data O
to O
remove O
‘ O
noise O
’ O
attributable O
to O
physiological O
parameters O
. O

In O
addition O
, O
nuisance O
covariates O
including O
6 O
motion O
parameters O
, O
the O
white O
matter O
signal O
and O
the O
CSF O
signal O
were O
removed O
. O

Two O
spheres O
( O
radius O
4 O
mm O
) O
were O
created O
that O
were O
located O
( O
in O
MNI O
space O
) O
in O
the O
NAc O
of O
the O
left O
( O
−9 O
, O
9 O
, O
-9 O
) O
and O
right O
( O
9 O
, O
9 O
, O
-9 O
) O
hemisphere O
( O
Di O
Martino O
et O
al O
. O
) O
. O

Average O
time O
courses O
were O
obtained O
for O
each O
sphere O
separately O
and O
correlational O
analysis O
was O
performed O
voxel O
wise O
to O
generate O
functional O
connectivity O
maps O
for O
each O
sphere O
. O

Finally O
, O
the O
correlation O
coefficient O
map O
was O
converted O
into O
z-maps O
by O
Fisher O
’ O
s O
r-to-z O
transform O
to O
improve O
normality O
. O

Drug-induced O
changes O
in O
functional O
connectivity O
of O
the O
NAc O
have O
been O
shown O
to O
serve O
as O
a O
useful O
marker O
of O
drug O
activity O
in O
in O
the O
brain O
reward O
circuit O
( O
Ramaekers O
et O
al O
. O
) O
. O

Pharmacokinetics O
and O
pharmacogenetics O
Serum O
was O
used O
for O
detection O
of O
cannabinoids O
whereas O
cocaine O
and O
metabolites O
were O
determined O
in O
plasma O
. O

The O
determination O
of O
Δ9-tetrahydrocannabinol O
( O
THC O
) O
, O
11-hydroxy-THC O
( O
THC-OH O
) O
, O
11-nor-9-carboxy-THC O
( O
THC-COOH O
) O
, O
cocaine O
( O
COC O
) O
, O
benzoylecgonine O
( O
BZE O
) O
and O
ecgonine O
methyl O
ester O
( O
EME O
) O
in O
plasma O
was O
performed O
in O
a O
specialized O
forensic-toxicological O
laboratory O
using O
validated O
procedures O
38,39 O
. O

DBH O
genotype O
was O
analyzed O
after O
DNA O
isolation O
from O
blood O
collected O
at O
medical O
screening O
using O
standard O
protocols O
. O

The O
DBH O
polymorphism O
( O
rs1611115 O
) O
was O
genotyped O
using O
restriction O
fragment O
length O
polymorphism O
( O
RFLP O
) O
analysis O
. O

PCR O
was O
performed O
on O
50 O
ng O
genomic O
DNA O
using O
0.2 O
μM O
forward O
primer O
( O
5 O
’ O
-TGAATGTGCCCCTAAGGCTA-3 O
’ O
) O
and O
0.2 O
μM O
reverse O
primer O
( O
5 O
’ O
-CACCTCTCCCTCCTGTCCTCTCGC-3 O
’ O
) O
, O
0.25 O
mM O
dNTPs O
, O
2 O
U O
Taq O
DNA O
polymerase O
( O
Invitrogen O
, O
Breda O
, O
The O
Netherlands O
) O
in O
a O
1× O
PCR O
optimization O
buffer O
A O
( O
30 O
mM O
Tris-HCl O
pH O
8.5 O
, O
7.5 O
mM O
( O
NH4 O
) O
2SO4 O
, O
0.75 O
mM O
MgCl2 O
) O
. O

The O
cycling O
conditions O
were O
5 O
min O
92 O
°C O
, O
followed O
by O
35 O
cycles O
of O
1 O
min O
92 O
°C O
, O
1 O
min O
59 O
°C O
, O
1 O
min O
72 O
°C. O
, O
and O
a O
subsequent O
5 O
min O
72 O
°C.To O
purify O
the O
PCR-products O
, O
NucleoFast96 O
plates O
( O
Macherey-Nagel O
, O
Düren O
, O
Germany O
) O
were O
used O
. O

Restriction O
reaction O
was O
performed O
in O
a O
total O
volume O
of O
15 O
μl O
, O
containing O
10 O
μl O
purified O
PCR-product O
, O
5 O
U O
HhaI O
, O
1× O
NEBuffer O
4 O
and O
1× O
BSA O
. O

Digestion O
was O

at O
37 O
°C O
for O
16 O
h O
, O
which O
resulted O
in O
two O
fragments O
of O
200 O
bp O
and O
24 O
bp O
for O
the O
C O
allele O
, O
the O
T O
variant O
remained O
uncut O
( O
224 O
bp O
) O
. O

Statistics O
A O
total O
of O
122 O
participants O
entered O
the O
study O
. O

DBH O
genotype O
data O
was O
missing O
in O
6 O
participants O
and O
MFFT O
datasets O
of O
another O
6 O
participants O
were O
incomplete O
, O
due O
to O
technical O
failures O
. O

Consequently O
, O
110 O
participants O
with O
complete O
datasets O
entered O
the O
statistical O
analyses O
of O
MFFT O
data O
. O

For O
analysis O
, O
individuals O
with O
low O
activity O
DBH O
genotypes O
, O
i.e O
. O

CT O
( O
N O
= O
33 O
) O
and O
TT O
( O
N O
= O
4 O
) O
, O
were O
pooled O
( O
CT/TT O
) O
and O
compared O
to O
CC O
homozygotes O
( O
N O
= O
73 O
) O
. O

A O
total O
of O
61 O
participants O
( O
the O
Maastricht O
sample O
) O
participated O
in O
resting O
state O
measures O
. O

fMRI O
datasets O
were O
incomplete O
for O
22 O
participants O
due O
to O
technical O
failures O
or O
due O
to O
excessive O
movement O
during O
drug O
conditions O
, O
rendering O
39 O
participants O
with O
complete O
fMRI O
datasets O
. O

DBH O
genotype O
was O
missing O
in O
4 O
of O
those O
participants O
, O
which O
rendered O
35 O
participants O
with O
complete O
datasets O
to O
test O
for O
Drug O
x O
DBH O
interactions O
on O
functional O
connectivity O
. O

Effects O
on O
impulse O
control O
tasks O
from O
oral O
THC O
and O
cocaine O
HCl O
in O
dosages O
similar O
to O
those O
proposed O
for O
this O
study O
have O
achieved O
statistical O
significance O
in O
within O
subject O
designs O
employing O
20 O
or O
less O
participants O
( O
Fillmore O
et O
al O
. O

; O
Ramaekers O
et O
al O
. O

; O
Ramaekers O
and O
Kuypers O
) O
. O

Assuming O
an O
omnibus O
p O
< O
0.05 O
and O
power O
= O
0.8 O
, O
we O
estimated O
that O
the O
present O
study O
employing O
122 O
subjects O
would O
enable O
detection O
of O
performance O
differences O
between O
drug O
treatments O
with O
an O
effect O
size O
of O
0.3 O
( O
i.e. O
, O
a O
signal O
change O
of O
.3 O
times O
the O
standard O
deviation O
) O
in O
within O
subject O
comparisons O
. O

In O
addition O
, O
we O
estimated O
that O
between O
DBH O
group O
comparisons O
of O
genotypes O
would O
enable O
detection O
of O
performance O
differences O
with O
an O
effect O
size O
of O
.7 O
and O
.4 O
for O
sizes O
of O
N O
= O
30 O
and O
N O
= O
60 O
respectively O
. O

Straightforward O
power O
analysis O
for O
imaging O
data O
is O
less O
feasible O
. O

Because O
fMRI O
data O
analysis O
consists O
of O
a O
very O
large O
number O
of O
non-independent O
multiple O
comparisons O
, O
a O
proper O
power O
analysis O
with O
correction O
for O
multiple O
comparisons O
requires O
computer O
simulation O
. O

In O
addition O
, O
statistical O
power O
is O
not O
the O
same O
( O
i.e. O
, O
homogenous O
) O
over O
the O
brain O
, O
but O
varies O
across O
brain O
regions O
( O
Petersson O
et O
al O
. O
) O
. O

A O
common O
approach O
in O
the O
functional O
neuroimaging O
community O
is O
to O
estimate O
the O
number O
of O
subjects O
from O
previous O
empirical O
experience O
in O
the O
field O
, O
particularly O
when O
pilot O
data O
are O
lacking O
and O
analyses O
include O
the O
whole O
brain O
or O
multiple O
regions O
of O
interest O
( O
Mumford O
) O
. O

Previous O
resting O
state O
fMRI O
studies O
have O
employed O
15–20 O
subjects O
for O
showing O
significant O
drug O
effects O
( O
Honey O
et O
al O
. O

; O
Kelly O
et O
al O
. O

; O
Ramaekers O
et O
al O
. O

; O
Schrantee O
et O
al O
. O
) O
. O

Based O
on O
these O
experiences O
we O
expected O
no O
problem O
to O
demonstrate O
drug O
effects O
on O
fMRI O
measures O
in O
60 O
participants O
and O
that O
sample O
sizes O
of O
subgroups O
DBH O
genotypes O
( O
N O
= O
15–30 O
) O
would O
be O
sufficient O
for O
demonstrating O
between O
group O
differences O
. O

MFFT O
measures O
were O
analyzed O
with O
SPSS O
21.0 O
using O
a O
GLM O
univariate O
analysis O
of O
variance O
( O
ANOVA O
) O
with O
Drug O
( O
3 O
levels O
; O
placebo O
, O
cannabis O
and O
cocaine O
) O
as O
within O
subject O
factor O
and O
DBH O
genotype O
( O
2 O
levels O
; O
CC O
and O
CT/TT O
) O
as O
between O
group O
factor O
. O

The O
model O
tested O
for O
main O
effects O
of O
Drug O
, O
DBH O
genotype O
and O
their O
interaction O
. O

Significant O
main O
effects O
were O
subsequently O
followed O
by O
drug-placebo O
contrasts O
to O
establish O
the O
separate O
effects O
of O
cannabis O
( O
2 O
within O
subject O
levels O
; O
placebo O
and O
cannabis O
) O
and O
cocaine O
( O
2 O
within O
subject O
levels O
; O
placebo O
and O
cocaine O
) O
and O
their O
interaction O
with O
DBH O
genotype O
( O
2 O
between O
group O
levels O
; O
CC O
and O
CT/TT O
) O
. O

Functional O
connectivity O
data O
( O
i.e O
. O

correlation O
coefficient O
maps O
for O
each O
individual O
in O
each O
treatment O
condition O
) O
were O
analysed O
in O
2 O
GLM O
models O
of O
ANOVA O
in O
SPM8 O
. O

In O
the O
first O
GLM O
, O
complete O
datasets O
of O
39 O
participants O
were O
analysed O
using O
ANOVA O
with O
Drug O
( O
3 O
levels O
) O
as O
within O
subject O
factor O
. O

The O
GLM O
model O
established O
the O
effects O
of O
cannabis O
and O
cocaine O
separately O
by O
means O
of O
drug-placebo O
contrasts O
. O

DBH O
genotyping O
was O
only O
available O
for O
35 O
participants O
( O
CC O
genotype O
N O
= O
22 O
; O
CT/TT O
genotype O
N O
= O
13 O
) O
that O
were O
included O
in O
GLM O
1 O
. O

Therefore O
a O
2nd O
GLM O
was O
conducted O
that O
included O
35 O
participants O
for O
which O
both O
resting O
state O
and O
DBH O
data O
sets O
were O
complete O
. O

These O
data O
were O
entered O
in O
an O
ANOVA O
with O
Drug O
( O
3 O
levels O
) O
as O
within O
subject O
factor O
and O
DBH O
genotype O
( O
2 O
levels O
) O
as O
between O
group O
factor O
. O

From O
this O
model O
, O
main O
effects O
of O
DBH O
genotype O
and O
its O
interaction O
with O
cannabis O
and O
cocaine O
treatment O
were O
identified O
. O

The O
statistical O
threshold O
was O
set O
at O
p O
< O
.05 O
FWE O
cluster O
corrected O
( O
cluster O
size O
> O
50 O
) O
. O

Finally O
, O
voxel O
wise O
correlation O
analysis O
between O
FC O
data O
and O
MFFT O
composite O
measures O
of O
Impulsivity O
and O
Efficiency O
were O
conducted O
. O

Differentiating O
the O
Effects O
of O
Familial O
Risk O
for O
Alcohol O
Dependence O
and O
Prenatal O
Exposure O
to O
Alcohol O
on O
Offspring O
Brain O
Morphology O
BACKGROUND O
Offspring O
with O
a O
family O
history O
of O
alcohol O
dependence O
( O
AD O
) O
have O
been O
shown O
to O
have O
altered O
structural O
and O
functional O
integrity O
of O
corticolimbic O
brain O
structures O
. O

Similarly O
, O
prenatal O
exposure O
to O
alcohol O
is O
associated O
with O
a O
variety O
of O
structural O
and O
functional O
brain O
changes O
. O

The O
goal O
of O
this O
study O
was O
to O
differentiate O
the O
brain O
gray O
matter O
volumetric O
differences O
associated O
with O
familial O
risk O
and O
prenatal O
exposure O
to O
alcohol O
among O
offspring O
while O
controlling O
for O
lifetime O
personal O
exposures O
to O
alcohol O
and O
drugs O
. O

METHODS O
A O
total O
of O
52 O
high-risk O
( O
HR O
) O
offspring O
from O
maternal O
multiplex O
families O
with O
a O
high O
proportion O
of O
alcohol O
dependence O
were O
studied O
along O
with O
55 O
low-risk O
( O
LR O
) O
offspring O
. O

Voxel O
based O
morphometric O
( O
VBM O
) O
analysis O
was O
performed O
using O
statistical O
parametric O
mapping O
( O
SPM8 O
) O
software O
using O
3T O
structural O
images O
from O
these O
offspring O
to O
identify O
gray O
matter O
volume O
differences O
associated O
with O
familial O
risk O
and O
prenatal O
exposure O
. O

RESULTS O
Significant O
familial O
risk O
group O
differences O
were O
seen O
with O
HR O
males O
showing O
reduced O
volume O
of O
the O
left O
inferior O
temporal O
, O
left O
fusiform O
and O
left O
and O
right O
insula O
regions O
relative O
to O
LR O
males O
, O
controlling O
for O
prenatal O
exposure O
to O
alcohol O
drugs O
and O
cigarettes O
. O

High-risk O
females O
showed O
a O
reduction O
in O
the O
right O
fusiform O
but O
also O
showed O
a O
reduction O
in O
volume O
in O
portions O
of O
the O
cerebellum O
( O
left O
crus O
I O
and O
left O
lobe O
8 O
) O
. O

Prenatal O
alcohol O
exposure O
effects O
, O
assessed O
within O
the O
familial O
high-risk O
group O
, O
was O
associated O
with O
reduced O
right O
middle O
cingulum O
and O
left O
middle O
temporal O
volume O
. O

Even O
low O
exposure O
resulting O
from O
mothers O
drinking O
in O
amounts O
less O
than O
the O
median O
of O
those O
who O
drank O
( O
53 O
drinks O
or O
less O
over O
the O
course O
of O
the O
pregnancy O
) O
showed O
a O
reduction O
of O
volume O
in O
the O
right O
anterior O
cingulum O
and O
in O
the O
left O
cerebellum O
( O
lobes O
4 O
and O
5 O
) O
. O

CONCLUSIONS O
Familial O
risk O
for O
alcohol O
dependence O
and O
prenatal O
exposure O
to O
alcohol O
and O
other O
drugs O
show O
independent O
effects O
on O
brain O
morphology O
. O

Methods O
Participants O
The O
present O
report O
is O
based O
on O
structural O
MRI O
( O
sMRI O
) O
scans O
of O
107 O
third O
generation O
offspring O
who O
are O
part O
of O
an O
ongoing O
family O
study O
that O
selected O
families O
through O
their O
parents O
’ O
generation O
. O

A O
total O
of O
52 O
high-risk O
( O
HR O
) O
offspring O
from O
maternal O
multiplex O
families O
with O
a O
high O
proportion O
of O
AD O
were O
studied O
along O
with O
55 O
low-risk O
( O
LR O
) O
offspring O
. O

All O
participants O
in O
the O
MRI O
assessments O
were O
part O
of O
a O
larger O
longitudinal O
follow-up O
in O
which O
children O
, O
adolescents O
and O
young O
adults O
from O
high O
and O
low-familial O
risk O
for O
AD O
families O
were O
assessed O
clinically O
using O
age O
appropriate O
structured O
instruments O
. O

The O
offspring O
were O
followed O
through O
childhood O
at O
approximately O
annual O
intervals O
and O
through O
young O
adulthood O
, O
biennially O
. O

These O
follow-up O
visits O
provided O
extensive O
assessment O
of O
alcohol O
and O
drug O
use O
information O
obtained O
at O
each O
follow-up O
wave O
. O

All O
participants O
provided O
consent O
with O
each O
visit O
. O

Children O
provided O
assent O
with O
parental O
consent O
. O

The O
study O
has O
ongoing O
approval O
from O
the O
University O
of O
Pittsburgh O
Institutional O
Review O
Board O
. O

High-Risk O
Families O
High-risk O
( O
HR O
) O
families O
were O
identified O
through O
a O
proband O
pair O
of O
alcohol O
dependent O
sisters O
. O

One O
member O
of O
the O
proband O
pair O
was O
in O
a O
substance O
abuse O
treatment O
facility O
in O
the O
Pittsburgh O
area O
at O
the O
time O
of O
recruitment O
. O

The O
study O
design O
provided O
an O
ultra-high O
density O
of O
alcoholism O
in O
the O
pedigrees O
from O
which O
these O
offspring O
were O
selected O
. O

In O
person O
structured O
interviews O
( O
Diagnostic O
Interview O
Schedule O
[ O
DIS O
] O
) O
of O
the O
proband O
sisters O
, O
their O
spouses O
, O
and O
all O
available O
first O
degree O
relatives O
were O
conducted O
to O
determine O
the O
presence O
of O
axis O
I O
psychopathology O
and O
AD O
. O

Families O
were O
excluded O
if O
there O
was O
presence O
of O
bipolar O
disorder O
, O
schizophrenia O
, O
recurrent O
major O
depression O
, O
and O
drug O
dependence O
( O
i.e O
. O

drug O
dependence O
preceded O
AD O
by O
1 O
or O
more O
years O
) O
among O
proband O
sisters O
and O
their O
first O
degree O
relatives O
. O

Low-Risk O
Control O
Families O
Each O
control O
family O
was O
initially O
recruited O
by O
place O
of O
residence O
and O
whether O
children O
between O
the O
ages O
of O
8–18 O
lived O
within O
the O
home O
. O

Each O
control O
family O
was O
selected O
for O
their O
residence O
within O
a O
census O
track O
from O
which O
a O
high-risk O
family O
had O
been O
selected O
. O

This O
provided O
a O
yoked O
control O
for O
neighborhood O
characteristics O
. O

Families O
qualifying O
by O
these O
characteristics O
were O
further O
screened O
to O
determine O
the O
psychopathology O
within O
the O
family O
. O

Mothers O
were O
designated O
as O
the O
`` O
index O
'' O
case O
and O
screened O
for O
absence O
of O
alcohol O
and O
drug O
dependence O
using O
the O
DIS O
, O
though O
other O
psychopathology O
was O
free O
to O
vary O
with O
the O
exception O
of O
schizophrenia O
and O
bipolar O
disorder O
. O

Diagnostic O
data O
were O
also O
collected O
for O
all O
first O
degree O
relatives O
using O
either O
an O
in-person O
DIS O
interview O
or O
by O
obtaining O
multiple O
family O
history O
reports O
to O
ensure O
an O
absence O
of O
a O
family O
history O
of O
AD O
. O

Accordingly O
, O
all O
control O
families O
had O
a O
low O
density O
of O
familial O
AD O
. O

Assessment O
of O
Personal O
Exposure O
All O
participants O
were O
part O
of O
a O
longitudinal O
study O
that O
allowed O
determination O
of O
quantitative O
estimates O
of O
cigarette O
and O
alcohol O
use O
. O

Exposure O
to O
cigarettes O
and O
alcohol O
up O
to O
the O
time O
of O
the O
scan O
was O
calculated O
based O
on O
the O
longitudinally O
acquired O
data O
. O

Because O
alcohol O
and O
cigarettes O
were O
the O
most O
commonly O
used O
substances O
, O
values O
for O
lifetime O
use O
of O
alcohol O
and O
cigarettes O
and O
whether O
the O
individual O
met O
criteria O
for O
a O
substance O
use O
disorder O
before O
the O
scan O
were O
used O
as O
covariates O
in O
both O
VBM O
and O
SPSS O
analyses O
. O

Assessment O
of O
Prenatal O
Use O
of O
Substances O
Mothers O
of O
the O
offspring O
included O
in O
the O
present O
report O
were O
administered O
a O
structured O
interview O
concerning O
their O
drinking O
, O
smoking O
, O
and O
drug O
usage O
during O
pregnancy O
. O

The O
interview O
was O
performed O
on O
the O
occasion O
of O
the O
first O
follow-up O
visit O
to O
the O
laboratory O
when O
children O
were O
on O
average O
12.1 O
± O
3.3 O
years O
of O
age O
. O

The O
interview O
was O
designed O
in O
our O
laboratory O
with O
the O
goal O
of O
measuring O
quantity O
and O
frequency O
of O
drugs O
, O
alcohol O
, O
and O
cigarettes O
during O
each O
trimester O
of O
pregnancy O
. O

Mothers O
with O
multiple O
children O
were O
queried O
concerning O
each O
child O
separately O
. O

Three O
prenatal O
measures O
were O
derived O
from O
the O
interview O
of O
the O
mother O
: O
prenatal O
alcohol O
exposure O
( O
quantified O
as O
number O
of O
drinks O
during O
pregnancy O
) O
, O
prenatal O
cigarettes O
exposure O
( O
number O
of O
cigarettes O
smoked O
during O
pregnancy O
) O
, O
and O
number O
of O
drug O
days O
( O
representing O
number O
of O
days O
during O
pregnancy O
that O
the O
mother O
reported O
using O
drugs O
) O
. O

Imaging O
Parameters O
The O
MRI O
scans O
were O
performed O
at O
the O
University O
of O
Pittsburgh O
Medical O
Center O
( O
UPMC O
) O
Magnetic O
Resonance O
Research O
Center O
( O
MRRC O
) O
using O
a O
3T O
Siemens O
Trio O
scanner O
( O
Siemens O
Medical O
Systems O
, O
Ehrlangen O
, O
Germany O
) O
equipped O
with O
a O
fast O
gradient O
system O
for O
echoplanar O
imaging O
. O

A O
standard O
radio O
frequency O
head O
coil O
was O
used O
with O
foam O
padding O
to O
restrict O
head O
motion O
. O

A O
7-min O
3D O
T1-weighted O
Magnetization O
Prepared O
Rapid O
Gradient O
Echo O
Imaging O
( O
MPRAGE O
) O
sequence O
( O
TR=2300ms O
, O
TE=2.98 O
ms O
, O
FA=9° O
, O
field O
of O
view O
FOV=240mm O
, O
acquisition O
matrix O
= O
240 O
× O
256 O
, O
in-plane O
resolution O
1.0×1.0 O
mm2 O
, O
yielding O
160 O
transversal O
slices O
with O
a O
thickness O
of O
1.2mm O
) O
was O
used O
to O
acquire O
a O
high-resolution O
anatomical O
scan O
for O
VBM O
analysis O
. O

Preprocessing O
Structural O
data O
preprocessing O
and O
analysis O
for O
this O
study O
was O
performed O
with O
the O
VBM8 O
toolbox O
( O
http O
: O
//dbm.neuro.uni-jena.de/vbm/ O
) O
within O
the O
Statistical O
Parametric O
Mapping O
software O
SPM8 O
( O
Wellcome O
Department O
of O
Imaging O
Neuroscience O
, O
Institute O
of O
Neurology O
and O
the O
National O
Hospital O
for O
Neurology O
and O
Neurosurgery O
; O
London O
, O
England O
; O
http O
: O
//www.fil.ion.ucl.ac.uk/spm/ O
) O
running O
on O
MATLAB O
R2014a O
( O
Mathworks O
) O
. O

The O
VBM8 O
toolbox O
was O
used O
for O
structural O
data O
preprocessing O
and O
to O
check O
the O
quality O
of O
the O
data O
. O

Preprocessing O
was O
done O
using O
the O
“ O
estimate O
and O
run O
” O
module O
that O
performs O
bias O
correction O
, O
tissue O
segmentation O
, O
affine O
registration O
, O
normalization O
, O
and O
modulation O
. O

VBM8 O
uses O
a O
maximum O
posteriori O
method O
for O
segment O
tissue O
types O
. O

Segmented O
images O
were O
normalized O
to O
Montreal O
Neurological O
Institute O
( O
MNI O
) O
space O
using O
nonlinear O
DARTEL O
normalization O
. O

These O
quality O
controlled O
modulated O
images O
were O
then O
smoothed O
using O
a O
12mm O
full-width O
at O
half-maximum O
( O
FWHM O
) O
isotropic O
Gaussian O
kernel O
. O

The O
resulting O
SPM O
contrasts O
maps O
were O
thresholded O
with O
p O
< O
0.005 O
with O
a O
cluster O
size O
of O
200 O
voxels O
. O

The O
significance O
of O
these O
thresholded O
clusters O
was O
determined O
using O
a O
family O
wise O
error O
( O
FWE O
) O
correction O
threshold O
which O
was O
set O
at O
p=0.05 O
. O

Additionally O
, O
regional O
volumes O
were O
calculated O
using O
the O
MarsBaR O
ROI O
toolbox O
( O
http O
: O
//marsbar.sourceforge.net O
) O
to O
compare O
the O
gray O
matter O
( O
GM O
) O
volume O
of O
the O
specified O
regions O
of O
interest O
( O
ROIs O
) O
which O
were O
further O
compared O
in O
SPSS O
( O
version O
20 O
) O
. O

ROIs O
were O
calculated O
for O
each O
participant O
and O
entered O
into O
SPSS O
analyses O
along O
with O
multiple O
covariates O
to O
follow O
up O
on O
areas O
revealed O
in O
the O
whole O
brain O
analyses O
. O

VBM O
Whole O
Brain O
Statistical O
Analysis O
Structural O
MRI O
data O
from O
19 O
subjects O
did O
not O
pass O
our O
data O
quality O
standards O
and O
were O
excluded O
from O
further O
analysis O
. O

Reasons O
for O
exclusion O
included O
not O
passing O
the O
manual O
quality O
inspection O
due O
to O
structural O
abnormalities O
( O
N=4 O
) O
, O
poor O
quality O
of O
skull O
stripping O
( O
N=5 O
) O
, O
and O
poor O
gray O
matter O
image O
quality O
associated O
with O
extreme O
covariance O
parameters O
( O
N=10 O
) O
. O

The O
remaining O
88 O
scans O
, O
43 O
HR O
offspring O
( O
Mean O
age O
27.4 O
± O
3.6 O
years O
) O
and O
45 O
LR O
offspring O
( O
Mean O
age O
24.5 O
± O
4.1 O
years O
) O
were O
available O
for O
the O
VBM O
analysis O
. O

Cumulative O
estimates O
of O
personal O
exposure O
to O
alcohol O
, O
drugs O
, O
and O
cigarettes O
along O
with O
diagnoses O
concerning O
alcohol O
abuse O
, O
alcohol O
dependence O
, O
drug O
abuse O
and O
drug O
dependence O
up O
to O
the O
time O
of O
the O
MRI O
scan O
were O
available O
for O
all O
88 O
subjects O
who O
had O
participated O
in O
the O
longitudinal O
follow-up O
. O

Substance O
use O
disorder O
was O
defined O
as O
presence O
of O
either O
alcohol O
abuse O
or O
dependence O
, O
or O
drug O
abuse O
or O
dependence O
. O

The O
mothers O
’ O
use O
of O
alcohol O
, O
drugs O
, O
and O
cigarettes O
was O
not O
available O
for O
some O
participants O
( O
alcohol O
and O
drug O
exposure O
[ O
N=8 O
] O
, O
cigarette O
use O
[ O
N=5 O
] O
) O
. O

A O
total O
of O
75 O
subjects O
( O
HR=36 O
, O
LR=39 O
) O
had O
complete O
prenatal O
use O
data O
for O
VBM O
analysis O
. O

Personal O
use O
of O
substances O
up O
to O
the O
time O
of O
the O
scan O
was O
considered O
by O
coding O
each O
subject O
for O
presence O
or O
absence O
of O
a O
substance O
use O
disorder O
( O
SUD O
) O
. O

For O
the O
purpose O
of O
stratifying O
the O
level O
of O
prenatal O
exposure O
for O
the O
SPM O
analyses O
, O
the O
median O
number O
of O
drinks O
for O
those O
who O
reported O
any O
drinking O
during O
pregnancy O
was O
first O
determined O
. O

Those O
mothers O
who O
reported O
no O
drinking O
or O
drinking O
less O
than O
the O
median O
for O
the O
sample O
were O
classified O
as O
no O
or O
low O
exposure O
mothers O
and O
those O
with O
drinking O
above O
the O
median O
as O
high O
exposure O
. O

Accordingly O
, O
offspring O
who O
had O
prenatal O
exposure O
equal O
to O
or O
greater O
than O
54 O
drinks O
during O
the O
pregnancy O
were O
categorized O
as O
prenatally O
exposed O
and O
those O
with O
mothers O
reporting O
less O
than O
53 O
drinks O
were O
considered O
to O
be O
prenatally O
low O
or O
unexposed O
. O

To O
provide O
a O
more O
refined O
estimate O
of O
prenatal O
effects O
on O
offspring O
, O
comparisons O
were O
made O
between O
those O
grouped O
by O
whether O
the O
mother O
did O
not O
drink O
during O
pregnancy O
( O
nonexposed O
) O
versus O
those O
who O
drank O
less O
than O
the O
median O
( O
low-exposure O
) O
, O
and O
again O
using O
the O
nonexposed O
versus O
those O
with O
mothers O
having O
greater O
than O
the O
median O
use O
( O
high-exposure O
) O
. O

SPSS O
Region O
of O
Interest O
Statistical O
Analysis O
An O
SPSS O
mixed O
model O
analysis O
was O
performed O
on O
the O
clusters O
of O
brain O
structures O
showing O
significant O
( O
FWE O
corrected O
) O
differences O
in O
our O
whole O
brain O
VBM O
analysis O
. O

The O
volumes O
of O
these O
brain O
structures O
were O
extracted O
using O
MarsBaR O
and O
used O
in O
SPSS O
based O
mixed O
model O
analysis O
to O
provide O
statistical O
control O
for O
participants O
from O
families O
with O
multiple O
siblings O
using O
a O
family O
ID O
variable O
. O

Using O
the O
same O
covariates O
used O
in O
the O
VBM O
analysis O
, O
we O
investigated O
the O
effect O
of O
familial O
risk O
and O
the O
effect O
of O
prenatal O
alcohol O
exposure O
on O
gray O
matter O
volume O
. O

HR O
subjects O
were O
compared O
to O
LR O
subjects O
, O
and O
within O
the O
HR O
group O
, O
those O
with O
prenatal O
alcohol O
exposure O
were O
compared O
with O
HR O
subjects O
who O
had O
no O
or O
low O
prenatal O
alcohol O
exposure O
. O

The O
cumulative O
estimates O
of O
personal O
use O
of O
alcohol O
, O
drugs O
and O
cigarettes O
available O
from O
longitudinal O
data O
collection O
were O
used O
as O
quantitative O
variables O
in O
the O
SPSS O
analyses O
. O

Cognitive O
Pragmatic O
Rehabilitation O
Program O
in O
Schizophrenia O
: O
A O
Single O
Case O
fMRI O
Study O
Introduction O
. O

The O
present O
study O
was O
intended O
to O
evaluate O
the O
effects O
of O
a O
rehabilitative O
training O
, O
the O
Cognitive O
Pragmatic O
Treatment O
( O
CPT O
) O
, O
aimed O
at O
improving O
communicative-pragmatic O
abilities O
and O
the O
related O
cognitive O
components O
, O
on O
the O
cerebral O
modifications O
of O
a O
single O
case O
patient O
diagnosed O
with O
schizophrenia O
. O

Methods O
. O

The O
patient O
underwent O
two O
functional O
magnetic O
resonance O
imaging O
( O
fMRI O
) O
sessions O
, O
before O
and O
after O
the O
treatment O
. O

In O
order O
to O
assess O
brain O
changes O
, O
we O
calculated O
the O
Amplitude O
of O
Low O
Frequency O
Fluctuation O
( O
ALFF O
) O
index O
of O
the O
resting-state O
fMRI O
signal O
, O
which O
is O
interpreted O
as O
reflecting O
the O
intensity O
of O
the O
spontaneous O
regional O
activity O
of O
the O
brain O
. O

Behavioural O
measures O
of O
the O
patient O
's O
communicative O
performance O
were O
also O
gathered O
before O
and O
after O
training O
and O
at O
follow-up O
. O

Results O
. O

The O
patient O
improved O
his O
communicative O
performance O
in O
almost O
all O
tests O
. O

Posttraining O
stronger O
ALFF O
signal O
emerged O
in O
the O
superior O
, O
inferior O
, O
and O
medial O
frontal O
gyri O
, O
as O
well O
as O
the O
superior O
temporal O
gyri O
. O

Conclusions O
. O

Even O
if O
based O
on O
a O
single O
case O
study O
, O
these O
preliminary O
results O
show O
functional O
changes O
at O
the O
cerebral O
level O
that O
seem O
to O
support O
the O
patient O
's O
behavioural O
improvements O
. O

2 O
. O

Material O
and O
Methods O
2.1 O
. O

Profile O
of O
the O
Patient O
Patient O
S.T. O
, O
a O
39-year-old O
male O
, O
right O
handed O
, O
with O
a O
high-school O
diploma O
as O
electronics O
technician O
( O
13 O
years O
of O
education O
) O
, O
has O
been O
recruited O
from O
the O
Department O
of O
Mental O
Health O
( O
DSM-To2 O
) O
in O
Turin O
. O

He O
had O
a O
diagnosis O
of O
paranoid O
schizophrenia O
, O
made O
by O
a O
qualified O
clinician O
belonging O
to O
the O
clinical O
unit O
, O
using O
DSM-IV O
criteria O
. O

S.T O
. O

had O
lived O
for O
a O
few O
years O
in O
a O
therapeutic O
center O
, O
that O
is O
, O
a O
health O
care O
structure O
where O
people O
with O
several O
kinds O
of O
intellectual O
and O
psychiatric O
disorders O
live O
with O
the O
constant O
help O
and O
assistance O
of O
qualified O
staff O
such O
as O
nurses O
, O
professional O
educators O
, O
and O
psychologists O
. O

Nevertheless O
, O
at O
the O
moment O
of O
the O
study O
he O
used O
to O
live O
in O
sheltered O
accommodation O
in O
Turin O
, O
a O
housing O
arrangement O
where O
a O
small O
group O
of O
people O
with O
similar O
therapeutic O
conditions O
live O
together O
receiving O
assistance O
from O
specialized O
health O
workers O
for O
just O
a O
few O
hours O
per O
week O
; O
moreover O
, O
he O
was O
included O
in O
a O
supported O
employment O
program O
, O
under O
the O
supervision O
of O
the O
local O
mental O
health O
care O
unit O
. O

The O
symptomatology O
of O
the O
patient O
at O
the O
time O
of O
the O
first O
assessment O
was O
investigated O
with O
the O
Positive O
and O
Negative O
Syndrome O
Scale O
( O
PANSS O
) O
. O

The O
PANSS O
was O
completed O
by O
a O
qualified O
psychiatrist O
and O
reported O
15 O
scores O
at O
the O
negative O
symptoms O
scale O
, O
15 O
scores O
at O
the O
positive O
symptoms O
scale O
, O
and O
36 O
scores O
at O
the O
general O
symptoms O
scale O
( O
PANSS O
total O
score O
: O
66 O
) O
. O

S.T O
. O

was O
treated O
with O
atypical O
antipsychotics O
( O
risperidone O
) O
, O
anxiolytics O
( O
chlordesmethyldiazepam O
) O
, O
and O
sedative O
drugs O
aimed O
at O
sleep O
regulation O
( O
flurazepam O
) O
. O

At O
the O
moment O
of O
the O
study O
, O
S.T O
. O

was O
in O
the O
chronic O
phase O
of O
the O
illness O
. O

He O
demonstrated O
adequate O
cognitive O
skills O
tested O
by O
the O
achievement O
of O
a O
cut-off O
score O
of O
24/30 O
at O
Mini O
Mental O
State O
Examination O
( O
MMSE O
) O
. O

He O
had O
communicative-pragmatic O
deficits O
, O
as O
resulting O
from O
the O
administration O
of O
form O
A O
of O
the O
Assessment O
Battery O
for O
Communication O
( O
ABaCo O
) O
in O
comparison O
to O
normative O
data O
of O
ABaCo O
. O

He O
attended O
all O
the O
training O
sessions O
. O

He O
did O
not O
suffer O
from O
anxiety O
disorders O
such O
as O
claustrophobia O
or O
panic O
attacks O
or O
any O
disorders O
which O
could O
be O
catastrophically O
exacerbated O
by O
confined O
spaces O
, O
such O
as O
MRI O
. O

Moreover O
, O
the O
patient O
met O
predefined O
exclusion O
criteria O
referring O
to O
absence O
of O
leucotomy O
, O
neurological O
disability O
, O
and O
alcohol O
or O
drug O
addiction O
. O

S.T O
. O

was O
informed O
about O
the O
procedure O
and O
the O
features O
of O
the O
exam O
and O
he O
gave O
his O
informed O
written O
consent O
for O
the O
rehabilitative O
treatment O
, O
the O
behavioural O
assessment O
, O
and O
the O
fMRI O
scanning O
. O

The O
study O
was O
approved O
by O
the O
Bio-Ethics O
Committee O
of O
the O
University O
of O
Turin O
. O

2.2 O
. O

Experimental O
Design O
The O
study O
comprised O
a O
three-month O
training O
period O
and O
three O
experimental O
sessions O
, O
organized O
according O
to O
an O
ABA O
design O
as O
described O
in O
Figure O
1 O
. O

2.2.1 O
. O

T0 O
: O
Before O
Training O
The O
patients O
' O
communicative O
abilities O
were O
assessed O
immediately O
before O
the O
beginning O
of O
the O
rehabilitation O
program O
, O
through O
the O
equivalent O
form O
A O
of O
ABaCo O
. O

2.2.2 O
. O

T1 O
: O
After O
Training O
After O
completing O
the O
training O
program O
, O
form O
B O
of O
the O
ABaCo O
was O
administered O
to O
assess O
the O
efficacy O
of O
the O
training O
on O
the O
communicative O
abilities O
of O
the O
participants O
. O

2.2.3 O
. O

T2 O
: O
Follow-Up O
In O
order O
to O
assess O
the O
stability O
of O
the O
patients O
' O
performance O
in O
time O
, O
form O
A O
of O
the O
ABaCo O
was O
administered O
again O
three O
months O
after O
the O
rehabilitation O
program O
. O

2.3 O
. O

The O
Cognitive O
Pragmatic O
Treatment O
The O
patient O
took O
part O
in O
the O
CPT O
, O
and O
he O
underwent O
the O
fMRI O
scanning O
before O
and O
after O
treatment O
. O

The O
CPT O
lasted O
10 O
weeks O
and O
it O
was O
structured O
in O
two O
sessions O
per O
week O
, O
each O
one O
lasting O
90 O
minutes O
. O

Patients O
attended O
the O
sessions O
in O
small O
groups O
of O
five/six O
, O
led O
by O
a O
psychologist O
. O

The O
treatment O
mainly O
concentrated O
on O
the O
different O
expressive O
modalities O
of O
communication O
, O
that O
is O
, O
linguistic O
, O
extralinguistic O
, O
paralinguistic O
, O
social O
appropriateness O
, O
and O
conversational O
abilities O
. O

Moreover O
, O
other O
sessions O
were O
focused O
on O
aspects O
such O
as O
awareness O
, O
theory O
of O
mind O
, O
and O
planning O
, O
which O
have O
been O
shown O
to O
have O
a O
role O
to O
play O
in O
communicative O
performance O
. O

The O
training O
provided O
the O
patients O
with O
an O
ecological O
setting O
where O
they O
were O
encouraged O
to O
exercise O
their O
communicative O
abilities O
and O
learn O
how O
to O
face O
typical O
situations O
of O
everyday O
interactions O
; O
this O
goal O
was O
realized O
through O
self-monitoring O
strategies O
and O
feedback O
provided O
by O
the O
therapist O
. O

Communicative-pragmatic O
difficulties O
displayed O
by O
patients O
with O
schizophrenia O
are O
related O
to O
their O
difficulties O
in O
filling O
the O
gap O
between O
what O
is O
literally O
said O
and O
what O
is O
meant O
, O
as O
, O
for O
example O
, O
in O
indirect O
speech O
acts O
and O
figurative O
language O
( O
e.g. O
, O
) O
. O

For O
this O
reason O
, O
many O
activities O
along O
the O
training O
were O
focused O
on O
the O
understanding O
of O
the O
partner O
's O
intended O
meaning O
starting O
from O
the O
expressed O
literal O
message O
. O

Specific O
attention O
was O
also O
given O
to O
the O
ability O
to O
interpret O
and O
use O
nonverbal O
and O
paralinguistic O
cues O
, O
such O
as O
facial O
expression O
and O
the O
tone O
of O
voice O
, O
in O
order O
to O
identify O
the O
correct O
speaker O
's O
communicative O
intention O
; O
irony O
, O
for O
example O
, O
is O
characterized O
by O
specific O
paralinguistic O
cues O
that O
help O
a O
person O
to O
distinguish O
it O
from O
deceit O
. O

Moreover O
, O
frequently O
these O
patients O
have O
difficulty O
in O
modulating O
their O
speech O
according O
to O
the O
contextual O
information O
. O

This O
is O
the O
reason O
why O
many O
activities O
of O
the O
training O
were O
focused O
on O
the O
ability O
to O
decode O
violations O
of O
the O
conversational O
implicatures O
and O
to O
avoid O
digressions O
and O
derailments O
. O

An O
overview O
of O
each O
session O
is O
provided O
in O
Table O
1 O
. O

See O
also O
for O
a O
detailed O
explanation O
of O
CPT O
. O

2.4 O
. O

Behavioural O
Measures O
The O
communicative-pragmatic O
abilities O
of O
the O
patient O
were O
measured O
through O
the O
administration O
of O
the O
equivalent O
forms O
of O
ABaCo O
before O
and O
after O
treatment O
. O

The O
equivalent O
forms O
of O
the O
ABaCo O
have O
shown O
a O
good O
internal O
consistency O
, O
a O
good O
correlation O
between O
forms O
, O
and O
an O
excellent O
interrater O
agreement O
. O

They O
are O
comprised O
of O
four O
evaluation O
scales O
, O
that O
is O
, O
linguistic O
, O
extralinguistic O
, O
paralinguistic O
, O
and O
context O
, O
aimed O
at O
assessing O
the O
main O
pragmatic O
components O
of O
communication O
. O

Each O
scale O
is O
divided O
into O
two O
subscales O
, O
evaluating O
, O
respectively O
, O
comprehension O
and O
production O
abilities O
in O
each O
communication O
modality O
. O

A O
detailed O
description O
of O
the O
clinical O
tool O
, O
the O
procedure O
, O
and O
the O
scoring O
criteria O
is O
provided O
in O
; O
see O
also O
. O

2.5. O
fMRI O
Procedures O
In O
order O
to O
investigate O
whether O
any O
changes O
in O
functional O
brain O
activity O
were O
detectable O
after O
CPT O
, O
we O
used O
a O
resting-state O
paradigm O
( O
rs O
) O
for O
imaging O
data O
. O

The O
results O
obtained O
in O
the O
pre- O
and O
posttreatment O
phases O
at O
the O
rs-fMRI O
analyses O
have O
been O
compared O
, O
in O
order O
to O
establish O
the O
presence O
of O
objective O
effects O
of O
rehabilitation O
at O
the O
neuronal O
level O
. O

Data O
acquisition O
was O
performed O
at O
the O
Koelliker O
Hospital O
in O
Turin O
. O

Besides O
the O
rs O
scanning O
( O
18 O
minutes O
) O
, O
a O
set O
of O
anatomical O
MRI O
images O
were O
acquired O
( O
10 O
minutes O
) O
. O

The O
patient O
was O
instructed O
to O
lie O
on O
the O
scanner-bed O
and O
simply O
keep O
his O
eyes O
closed O
, O
thinking O
of O
nothing O
in O
particular O
, O
and O
not O
to O
fall O
asleep O
. O

Data O
acquisition O
was O
performed O
on O
a O
1.5-T O
Philips O
Intera O
with O
a O
Sense O
high-field O
high-resolution O
head O
coil O
( O
MRIDC O
) O
optimized O
for O
functional O
imaging O
. O

Functional O
T2-weighted O
images O
were O
acquired O
using O
echo O
planar O
imaging O
( O
EPI O
) O
sequences O
, O
with O
a O
repetition O
time O
( O
TR O
) O
of O
3000 O
ms O
, O
an O
echo O
time O
( O
TE O
) O
of O
60 O
ms O
, O
and O
a O
90° O
flip O
angle O
. O

The O
acquisition O
matrix O
was O
64 O
× O
64 O
; O
the O
field O
of O
view O
( O
FoV O
) O
was O
256 O
mm O
. O

For O
each O
paradigm O
, O
a O
total O
of O
100 O
volumes O
were O
acquired O
. O

Each O
volume O
consisted O
of O
25 O
axial O
slices O
, O
parallel O
to O
the O
anterior-posterior O
( O
AC–PC O
) O
commissure O
line O
and O
covering O
the O
whole O
brain O
; O
the O
slice O
thickness O
was O
4 O
mm O
with O
a O
0.5 O
mm O
gap O
. O

At O
the O
beginning O
of O
functional O
scanning O
, O
two O
scans O
were O
added O
, O
and O
their O
data O
was O
discarded O
, O
in O
order O
to O
reach O
a O
steady-state O
magnetization O
before O
acquisition O
of O
the O
actual O
experimental O
data O
. O

In O
the O
same O
session O
, O
a O
set O
of O
three-dimensional O
high-resolution O
T1-weighted O
structural O
images O
was O
acquired O
for O
each O
participant O
. O

This O
data O
set O
was O
acquired O
using O
a O
Fast O
Field O
Echo O
( O
FFE O
) O
sequence O
, O
with O
a O
repetition O
time O
( O
TR O
) O
of O
25 O
ms O
, O
the O
shortest O
echo O
time O
( O
TE O
) O
, O
and O
a O
30° O
flip O
angle O
. O

The O
acquisition O
matrix O
was O
256 O
× O
256 O
; O
the O
field O
of O
view O
( O
FoV O
) O
was O
256 O
mm O
. O

The O
set O
consisted O
of O
160 O
sagittal O
contiguous O
images O
covering O
the O
whole O
brain O
. O

The O
in-plane O
resolution O
was O
1 O
× O
1 O
mm O
and O
slice O
thickness O
was O
1 O
mm O
( O
1 O
× O
1 O
× O
1 O
mm O
voxels O
) O
. O

The O
functional O
data O
of O
each O
subject O
underwent O
the O
following O
preprocessing O
steps O
: O
( O
1 O
) O
mean O
intensity O
adjustment O
to O
prevent O
global O
signal O
variability O
; O
( O
2 O
) O
slice O
scan O
time O
correction O
, O
using O
a O
sinc O
interpolation O
algorithm O
; O
( O
3 O
) O
3D O
motion O
correction O
: O
all O
of O
the O
volumes O
were O
aligned O
spatially O
to O
the O
first O
volume O
by O
rigid O
body O
transformations O
, O
using O
a O
trilinear O
interpolation O
algorithm O
. O

The O
subject O
's O
slice-based O
functional O
scans O
were O
coregistered O
to O
their O
3D O
high-resolution O
structural O
scan O
, O
and O
the O
3D O
structural O
data O
set O
was O
transformed O
into O
Talairach O
space O
. O

Using O
the O
anatomical-functional O
coregistration O
matrix O
and O
the O
determined O
Talairach O
reference O
points O
, O
we O
transformed O
the O
functional O
time O
course O
into O
Talairach O
space O
and O
created O
the O
volume O
time O
course O
. O

Afterwards O
, O
the O
temporal O
series O
of O
each O
voxel O
have O
been O
filtered O
by O
a O
bandpass O
filtering O
( O
0.01 O
< O
f O
< O
0.08 O
Hz O
) O
in O
order O
to O
remove O
both O
the O
very O
low O
frequencies O
and O
the O
noise O
due O
to O
high O
frequencies O
( O
respiratory O
and O
cardiac O
frequencies O
) O
. O

Then O
the O
filtered O
time O
series O
have O
been O
transformed O
into O
a O
frequency O
domain O
with O
the O
Fourier O
transformation O
; O
this O
process O
allows O
decomposing O
a O
signal O
made O
of O
more O
frequencies O
and O
identifying O
the O
spectrum O
of O
the O
signal O
. O

The O
power O
spectrum O
represents O
the O
energy O
of O
the O
signal O
at O
different O
frequencies O
. O

We O
then O
calculated O
the O
Amplitude O
of O
Low O
Frequency O
Fluctuation O
( O
ALFF O
) O
index O
of O
the O
resting-state O
fMRI O
signal O
that O
is O
based O
on O
the O
amplitude O
of O
the O
low O
frequency O
fluctuations O
of O
the O
rs-fMRI O
signal O
and O
it O
is O
interpreted O
as O
reflecting O
the O
intensity O
of O
the O
spontaneous O
regional O
activity O
of O
the O
brain O
. O

The O
ALFF O
index O
was O
obtained O
calculating O
the O
square O
root O
of O
the O
power O
spectrum O
between O
0.01 O
and O
0.08 O
Hz O
, O
and O
it O
represents O
the O
average O
amplitude O
of O
the O
signal O
in O
a O
single O
voxel O
. O

In O
order O
to O
examine O
the O
difference O
between O
the O
neuronal O
activation O
before O
treatment O
and O
that O
after O
treatment O
, O
the O
functional O
map O
obtained O
before O
treatment O
was O
subtracted O
from O
that O
obtained O
after O
treatment O
, O
using O
a O
statistical O
threshold O
of O
p O
< O
0.05 O
, O
corrected O
for O
multiple O
comparisons O
using O
false O
discovery O
rate O
correction O
. O

The O
script O
used O
for O
the O
analyses O
produces O
specific O
output O
able O
to O
show O
Brodmann O
areas O
and O
the O
cerebral O
gyri O
and O
sulci O
implicated O
in O
the O
functional O
activity O
changes O
. O

Reality O
monitoring O
impairment O
in O
schizophrenia O
reflects O
specific O
prefrontal O
cortex O
dysfunction O
Reality O
monitoring O
impairment O
is O
often O
reported O
in O
schizophrenia O
but O
the O
neural O
basis O
of O
this O
deficit O
is O
poorly O
understood O
. O

Difficulties O
with O
reality O
monitoring O
could O
be O
attributable O
to O
the O
same O
pattern O
of O
neural O
dysfunction O
as O
other O
cognitive O
deficits O
that O
characterize O
schizophrenia O
, O
or O
might O
instead O
represent O
a O
separable O
and O
dissociable O
impairment O
. O

This O
question O
was O
addressed O
through O
direct O
comparison O
of O
behavioral O
performance O
and O
neural O
activity O
associated O
with O
reality O
monitoring O
and O
working O
memory O
in O
patients O
with O
schizophrenia O
and O
matched O
healthy O
controls O
. O

Participants O
performed O
a O
word-pair O
reality O
monitoring O
task O
and O
a O
Sternberg O
working O
memory O
task O
while O
undergoing O
fMRI O
scanning O
. O

Distinct O
behavioral O
deficits O
were O
observed O
in O
the O
patients O
during O
performance O
of O
each O
task O
, O
which O
were O
associated O
with O
separable O
task- O
and O
region-specific O
dysfunction O
in O
the O
medial O
anterior O
prefrontal O
cortex O
for O
reality O
monitoring O
and O
dorsolateral O
prefrontal O
cortex O
for O
working O
memory O
. O

The O
results O
suggest O
that O
reality O
monitoring O
impairment O
is O
a O
distinct O
neurocognitive O
deficit O
in O
schizophrenia O
. O

The O
findings O
are O
consistent O
with O
the O
presence O
of O
a O
range O
of O
dissociable O
cognitive O
deficits O
in O
schizophrenia O
which O
may O
be O
associated O
with O
variable O
functional O
and O
structural O
dysconnectivity O
in O
underlying O
processing O
networks O
. O

Highlights O
We O
examined O
reality O
monitoring O
and O
working O
memory O
in O
patients O
with O
schizophrenia O
. O

Distinct O
behavioral O
deficits O
observed O
during O
performance O
of O
each O
task O
Separable O
task- O
and O
region-specific O
dysfunction O
in O
distinct O
prefrontal O
cortex O
regions O
Reality O
monitoring O
appears O
to O
be O
a O
distinct O
neurocognitive O
deficit O
in O
schizophrenia O
. O

Methods O
and O
materials O
Participants O
Participants O
comprised O
20 O
patients O
who O
met O
the O
DSM-V O
criteria O
for O
schizophrenia O
, O
as O
diagnosed O
by O
their O
clinicians O
and O
verified O
using O
the O
Mini O
International O
Neuropsychiatric O
Interview O
, O
and O
20 O
matched O
healthy O
control O
individuals O
. O

All O
participants O
were O
native O
English O
speakers O
who O
had O
lived O
in O
the O
UK O
their O
whole O
lives O
. O

Written O
informed O
consent O
was O
obtained O
from O
participants O
in O
a O
manner O
approved O
by O
the O
UK O
National O
Research O
Ethics O
Service O
. O

To O
optimize O
the O
fMRI O
analysis O
, O
within-group O
variability O
was O
minimized O
by O
selecting O
patients O
who O
were O
clinically O
stable O
, O
high O
functioning O
, O
and O
able O
to O
meet O
the O
cognitive O
and O
psychological O
demands O
of O
the O
experiment O
. O

The O
patient O
and O
control O
groups O
were O
matched O
on O
age O
, O
gender O
, O
handedness O
, O
and O
verbal O
IQ O
( O
Table O
1 O
) O
. O

Patients O
exhibited O
the O
characteristic O
deficit O
in O
fluid O
IQ O
compared O
with O
the O
control O
participants O
. O

All O
patients O
were O
receiving O
antipsychotic O
medication O
but O
none O
were O
on O
drug O
regimens O
that O
included O
typical O
antipsychotics O
, O
anticholinergics O
or O
benzodiazepines O
. O

Participants O
were O
screened O
using O
the O
Mini O
International O
Neuropsychiatric O
Interview O
to O
ensure O
no O
additional O
current O
or O
previous O
neurological O
disorder O
. O

Data O
from O
the O
first O
experimental O
block O
for O
one O
patient O
was O
excluded O
due O
to O
anxiety O
causing O
adverse O
movement O
in O
the O
scanner O
during O
that O
block O
( O
i.e O
. O

translation O
of O
> O
3 O
mm O
, O
rotation O
of O
> O
4° O
) O
. O

Design O
Participants O
performed O
three O
tasks O
established O
in O
the O
previous O
literature O
to O
assess O
reality O
monitoring O
, O
working O
memory O
, O
and O
as O
a O
control O
condition O
, O
perceptual O
motor O
function O
. O

Reality O
monitoring O
Stimuli O
for O
the O
reality O
monitoring O
task O
consisted O
of O
144 O
well-known O
word-pairs O
( O
e.g O
. O

‘ O
Bacon O
and O
Eggs O
’ O
) O
. O

The O
task O
comprised O
six O
blocks O
of O
a O
study O
and O
test O
phase O
, O
with O
24 O
word-pair O
stimuli O
in O
each O
( O
six O
word-pairs O
presented O
in O
four O
combinations O
of O
Self/Researcher O
× O
Perceived/Imagined O
conditions O
; O
Fig O
. O

1 O
) O
. O

Each O
study O
trial O
commenced O
with O
a O
screen O
indicating O
whether O
the O
subject O
or O
researcher O
should O
read O
aloud O
the O
word-pair O
. O

The O
word-pair O
was O
then O
shown O
, O
either O
complete O
( O
‘ O
perceived O
’ O
trials O
) O
or O
with O
only O
the O
first O
letter O
of O
the O
second O
word O
provided O
such O
that O
the O
second O
word O
needed O
to O
be O
self-generated O
( O
‘ O
imagined O
’ O
trials O
) O
. O

In O
both O
cases O
the O
subject O
or O
researcher O
then O
had O
2.5 O
s O
to O
read O
aloud O
the O
entire O
word-pair O
, O
completing O
the O
word-pair O
as O
necessary O
for O
imagined O
trials O
. O

Each O
study O
phase O
was O
followed O
by O
its O
corresponding O
test O
phase O
, O
half O
the O
trials O
of O
which O
tested O
each O
of O
the O
different O
reality O
monitoring O
conditions O
. O

Each O
half O
of O
the O
test O
phase O
commenced O
with O
a O
question O
screen O
indicating O
the O
condition O
being O
tested O
, O
“ O
Was O
the O
accompanying O
word O
Seen O
or O
Imagined O
? O
” O
or O
“ O
Was O
the O
accompanying O
word O
said O
by O
Self O
or O
Researcher O
? O
” O
Each O
test O
phase O
trial O
involved O
presentation O
of O
the O
first O
word O
from O
one O
of O
the O
studied O
word-pairs O
together O
with O
the O
instruction O
to O
provide O
the O
appropriate O
response O
. O

Participants O
had O
4.5 O
s O
to O
make O
their O
response O
on O
a O
button O
box O
, O
using O
the O
first O
two O
fingers O
of O
their O
right O
hand O
. O

The O
order O
of O
presentation O
of O
reality O
monitoring O
conditions O
in O
the O
test O
phase O
alternated O
across O
the O
six O
full O
blocks O
of O
the O
task O
and O
was O
counterbalanced O
across O
participants O
. O

The O
word-pairs O
assigned O
to O
the O
perceived/imagined O
and O
self/researcher O
conditions O
were O
also O
counterbalanced O
across O
participants O
, O
and O
the O
order O
of O
presentation O
of O
word-pairs O
was O
pseudo-randomized O
to O
ensure O
no O
run O
of O
more O
than O
three O
items O
of O
the O
same O
condition O
in O
any O
study O
or O
test O
phase O
. O

Working O
memory O
task O
A O
version O
of O
the O
Sternberg O
Item O
Recognition O
Paradigm O
( O
SIRP O
) O
was O
used O
with O
stimulus O
loads O
and O
timings O
matching O
those O
used O
in O
the O
Functional O
Imaging O
Biomedical O
Informatics O
Research O
Network O
Consortium O
study O
into O
working O
memory O
in O
schizophrenia O
, O
see O
Fig O
. O

1 O
. O

The O
SIRP O
task O
was O
administered O
over O
six O
scanned O
blocks O
, O
with O
three O
working O
memory O
loads O
included O
in O
each O
block O
. O

Each O
level O
comprised O
an O
encode O
phase O
, O
in O
which O
participants O
were O
instructed O
to O
learn O
one O
, O
three O
, O
or O
five O
stimuli O
which O
were O
presented O
sequentially O
as O
individual O
randomly O
selected O
letters O
, O
for O
1.1 O
s O
each O
. O

The O
encode O
phase O
was O
followed O
by O
a O
respond O
phase O
, O
in O
which O
a O
response O
was O
given O
on O
a O
button O
box O
, O
using O
the O
first O
two O
fingers O
of O
the O
right O
hand O
, O
as O
to O
whether O
a O
probe O
stimulus O
had O
been O
included O
in O
the O
learned O
list O
. O

Fourteen O
probes O
were O
used O
for O
each O
level O
of O
the O
task O
, O
seven O
of O
which O
were O
learned O
targets O
, O
and O
seven O
non-studied O
foils O
. O

Participants O
were O
given O
1.1 O
s O
to O
make O
their O
response O
, O
and O
a O
jitter O
was O
introduced O
to O
the O
inter-trial O
interval O
in O
both O
encode O
and O
probe O
phases O
to O
maximize O
design O
efficiency O
and O
ensure O
participants O
paid O
attention O
to O
the O
screen O
. O

The O
working O
memory O
block O
was O
completed O
when O
all O
three O
load O
conditions O
had O
been O
undertaken O
. O

The O
order O
of O
presentation O
of O
loads O
was O
counterbalanced O
between O
participants O
and O
across O
blocks O
, O
and O
new O
randomly O
selected O
stimuli O
were O
used O
for O
each O
block O
of O
the O
task O
. O

Perceptual O
motor O
baseline O
task O
Participants O
made O
left O
and O
right O
key O
presses O
using O
the O
first O
two O
fingers O
of O
the O
right O
hand O
alternately O
to O
make O
a O
row O
of O
nine O
‘ O
X O
's O
flip O
as O
quickly O
as O
possible O
between O
a O
horizontal O
and O
vertical O
orientation O
. O

The O
stimulus O
was O
immediately O
removed O
from O
the O
screen O
after O
each O
key O
press O
, O
followed O
by O
a O
random O
delay O
( O
between O
300 O
and O
700 O
ms O
) O
to O
induce O
participants O
to O
pay O
attention O
to O
the O
stimuli O
. O

Procedure O
The O
three O
tasks O
were O
administered O
over O
six O
separate O
functional O
scanner O
runs O
, O
which O
were O
acquired O
consecutively O
during O
a O
single O
visit O
. O

Each O
run O
comprised O
one O
scanned O
block O
of O
each O
of O
the O
three O
tasks O
, O
presented O
in O
varying O
order O
over O
the O
six O
scans O
with O
the O
run O
order O
counterbalanced O
between O
participants O
by O
starting O
each O
participant O
with O
a O
different O
run O
order O
and O
progressing O
through O
the O
sequence O
( O
see O
Fig O
. O

2 O
) O
. O

Each O
run O
commenced O
with O
a O
spoken O
reality O
monitoring O
study O
phase O
, O
which O
was O
not O
scanned O
to O
avoid O
the O
disruption O
of O
scanner O
noise O
and O
of O
head O
movement O
associated O
with O
speech O
. O

In O
four O
of O
the O
six O
runs O
, O
additional O
versions O
of O
the O
working O
memory O
and O
perceptual O
motor O
tasks O
were O
administered O
before O
the O
scanner O
was O
switched O
on O
to O
equate O
the O
time O
( O
233 O
s O
) O
and O
cognitive O
demands O
between O
the O
study O
and O
test O
phases O
of O
the O
reality O
monitoring O
task O
across O
counterbalancing O
orders O
. O

The O
data O
from O
these O
additional O
versions O
of O
the O
tasks O
was O
not O
analyzed O
. O

Each O
of O
the O
six O
functional O
runs O
thus O
contained O
a O
single O
scanned O
block O
of O
each O
of O
the O
three O
tasks O
of O
interest O
, O
occurring O
in O
counterbalanced O
order O
. O

Imaging O
acquisition O
and O
data O
analysis O
A O
3 O
T O
Siemens O
Trio O
system O
was O
used O
to O
acquire O
structural O
and O
echo-planar O
functional O
images O
( O
TR O
2140 O
ms O
, O
TE O
30 O
ms O
, O
36 O
sequential O
axial O
slices O
oriented O
10–20° O
to O
the O
anterior O
commissure–posterior O
commissure O
transverse O
plane O
, O
2 O
mm O
