thickness O
, O
1 O
mm O
interslice O
skip O
, O
3 O
mm O
× O
3 O
mm O
in-plane O
resolution O
, O
64 O
× O
64 O
pixels O
, O
78° O
flip O
angle O
, O
6 O
functional O
runs O
each O
of O
170 O
volume O
acquisitions O
) O
. O

To O
correct O
for O
distortion O
, O
field O
maps O
were O
acquired O
( O
TE O
= O
5.19 O
and O
7.65 O
ms O
, O
TR O
= O
400 O
ms O
, O
matrix O
size O
= O
64 O
× O
64 O
) O
using O
32 O
slices O
covering O
the O
whole O
head O
( O
voxel O
size O
3 O
mm O
× O
3 O
mm O
× O
3 O
mm O
) O
. O

fMRI O
data O
were O
analyzed O
using O
SPM8 O
software O
( O
http O
: O
//www.fil.ion.ucl.ac.uk/spm O
) O
. O

The O
first O
five O
volumes O
from O
each O
functional O
run O
were O
discarded O
to O
allow O
for O
T1 O
equilibration O
. O

The O
remaining O
functional O
volumes O
were O
spatially O
realigned O
to O
the O
first O
image O
of O
the O
first O
series O
, O
and O
distortion O
corrections O
were O
applied O
based O
on O
the O
field O
maps O
using O
the O
unwarp O
routines O
in O
SPM O
. O

Thereafter O
, O
volumes O
were O
normalised O
against O
the O
MNI O
reference O
brain O
using O
tri-linear O
interpolation O
, O
and O
smoothed O
with O
an O
isotropic O
8 O
mm O
full-width O
half-maximum O
Gaussian O
kernel O
. O

The O
volumes O
acquired O
during O
the O
six O
scan O
runs O
were O
treated O
as O
separate O
time O
series O
. O

For O
each O
run O
, O
separate O
regressors O
coded O
for O
trial O
onsets O
for O
correct O
judgments O
for O
the O
self O
, O
researcher O
, O
perceived O
and O
imagined O
conditions O
in O
the O
reality O
monitoring O
task O
, O
correct O
responses O
for O
each O
load O
of O
the O
working O
memory O
task O
, O
and O
for O
responses O
to O
the O
perceptual O
motor O
baseline O
task O
. O

In O
each O
case O
, O
these O
were O
generated O
with O
delta O
functions O
corresponding O
to O
trial O
onsets O
convolved O
with O
a O
canonical O
hemodynamic O
response O
function O
. O

These O
regressors O
, O
together O
with O
a O
single O
regressor O
representing O
onsets O
for O
incorrect O
trials O
from O
all O
tasks O
, O
and O
six O
regressors O
coding O
movement O
parameters O
, O
comprised O
the O
full O
model O
for O
each O
run O
. O

The O
data O
and O
model O
were O
high-pass O
filtered O
to O
a O
cut O
off O
of O
1/128 O
Hz O
. O

Contrasts O
of O
interest O
were O
performed O
on O
individual O
subject O
data O
using O
the O
following O
contrasts O
between O
correct O
response O
regressors O
: O
reality O
monitoring O
> O
perceptual O
motor O
baseline O
task O
and O
working O
memory O
load O
5 O
> O
load O
3 O
. O

These O
contrasts O
were O
chosen O
to O
maximize O
power O
in O
terms O
of O
the O
number O
of O
trials O
available O
for O
the O
reality O
monitoring O
condition O
, O
and O
to O
maximize O
the O
difference O
in O
expected O
signal O
change O
in O
the O
dorsolateral O
PFC O
between O
groups O
for O
the O
working O
memory O
task O
, O
based O
on O
earlier O
findings O
using O
the O
same O
version O
of O
the O
SIRP O
task O
, O
( O
see O
) O
. O

Second-level O
one-sample O
t-tests O
were O
performed O
on O
the O
combined O
individual O
results O
to O
produce O
random-effects O
group O
analyses O
separately O
for O
the O
healthy O
control O
group O
and O
for O
the O
schizophrenia O
group O
. O

Second-level O
two-sample O
t-tests O
were O
then O
performed O
on O
the O
combined O
individual O
results O
to O
enable O
random-effects O
between-group O
analyses O
. O

To O
test O
the O
a O
priori O
hypothesis O
that O
the O
main O
contrasts O
of O
interest O
would O
reveal O
differences O
in O
distinct O
regions O
of O
the O
PFC O
, O
small O
volume O
corrections O
( O
SVCs O
) O
for O
multiple O
comparisons O
were O
conducted O
on O
the O
whole-brain O
group-level O
t-tests O
with O
a O
familywise-error O
( O
FWE O
) O
corrected O
voxel-wise O
height O
threshold O
of O
p O
< O
0.05 O
. O

Regions O
of O
interest O
each O
comprised O
an O
8 O
mm O
radius O
sphere O
centered O
on O
a O
priori O
coordinates O
derived O
from O
previous O
studies O
carried O
out O
on O
healthy O
adult O
participants O
as O
follows O
: O
Reality O
Monitoring O
: O
mean O
of O
the O
coordinates O
of O
peak O
activity O
in O
left O
( O
−16 O
, O
56 O
, O
14 O
) O
and O
right O
( O
20 O
, O
56 O
, O
9 O
) O
hemisphere O
medial O
anterior O
PFC O
from O
eight O
source O
memory O
studies O
testing O
recollection O
of O
self O
or O
other O
action O
, O
or O
perceived O
or O
self-generated O
stimulus O
generation O
; O
Working O
Memory O
: O
mean O
of O
the O
coordinates O
of O
peak O
activity O
in O
left O
( O
−45 O
, O
25 O
, O
25 O
) O
and O
right O
( O
43 O
, O
38 O
, O
18 O
) O
hemisphere O
dorsolateral O
PFC O
from O
four O
previous O
working O
memory O
studies O
which O
utilized O
load O
related O
contrasts O
for O
analysis O
of O
the O
SIRP O
task O
. O

Comparison O
of O
activity O
in O
each O
of O
these O
regions O
for O
the O
two O
tasks O
was O
undertaken O
by O
extracting O
the O
percentage O
signal O
change O
for O
each O
subject O
within O
each O
voxel O
, O
then O
comparing O
the O
mean O
values O
using O
a O
repeated O
measures O
Anova O
, O
with O
Greenhouse-Geisser O
correction O
used O
where O
necessary O
to O
correct O
for O
violations O
of O
sphericity O
. O

To O
further O
explore O
the O
nature O
of O
the O
activation O
associated O
with O
the O
two O
tasks O
in O
the O
different O
groups O
, O
activations O
outside O
the O
regions O
of O
interest O
were O
reported O
if O
they O
exceeded O
a O
FWE O
whole-brain O
corrected O
voxel-wise O
height O
threshold O
of O
p O
< O
0.05 O
. O

Association O
of O
polygenic O
risk O
for O
major O
psychiatric O
illness O
with O
subcortical O
volumes O
and O
white O
matter O
integrity O
in O
UK O
Biobank O
Major O
depressive O
disorder O
( O
MDD O
) O
, O
schizophrenia O
( O
SCZ O
) O
and O
bipolar O
disorder O
( O
BP O
) O
are O
common O
, O
disabling O
and O
heritable O
psychiatric O
diseases O
with O
a O
complex O
overlapping O
polygenic O
architecture O
. O

Individuals O
with O
these O
disorders O
, O
as O
well O
as O
their O
unaffected O
relatives O
, O
show O
widespread O
structural O
differences O
in O
corticostriatal O
and O
limbic O
networks O
. O

Structural O
variation O
in O
many O
of O
these O
brain O
regions O
is O
also O
heritable O
and O
polygenic O
but O
whether O
their O
genetic O
architecture O
overlaps O
with O
that O
of O
major O
psychiatric O
disorders O
is O
unknown O
. O

We O
sought O
to O
address O
this O
issue O
by O
examining O
the O
impact O
of O
polygenic O
risk O
of O
MDD O
, O
SCZ O
, O
and O
BP O
on O
subcortical O
brain O
volumes O
and O
white O
matter O
( O
WM O
) O
microstructure O
in O
a O
large O
single O
sample O
of O
neuroimaging O
data O
; O
the O
UK O
Biobank O
Imaging O
study O
. O

The O
first O
release O
of O
UK O
Biobank O
imaging O
data O
comprised O
participants O
with O
overlapping O
genetic O
data O
and O
subcortical O
volumes O
( O
N O
= O
978 O
) O
and O
WM O
measures O
( O
N O
= O
816 O
) O
. O

The O
calculation O
of O
polygenic O
risk O
scores O
was O
based O
on O
genome-wide O
association O
study O
results O
generated O
by O
the O
Psychiatric O
Genomics O
Consortium O
. O

Our O
findings O
indicated O
no O
statistically O
significant O
associations O
between O
either O
subcortical O
volumes O
or O
WM O
microstructure O
, O
and O
polygenic O
risk O
for O
MDD O
, O
SCZ O
or O
BP O
. O

These O
findings O
suggest O
that O
subcortical O
brain O
volumes O
and O
WM O
microstructure O
may O
not O
be O
closely O
linked O
to O
the O
genetic O
mechanisms O
of O
major O
psychiatric O
disorders O
. O

Methods O
Study O
population O
The O
first O
release O
of O
UK O
Biobank O
imaging O
data O
consisted O
of O
4,446 O
subjects O
( O
Nfemales/Nmales O
= O
2,342/2,104 O
; O
mean O
age O
± O
s.d O
. O

= O
55.52 O
± O
7.62 O
years O
; O
age O
range O
= O
40–70 O
years O
) O
with O
quality-checked O
volumetric O
and O
DTI O
data O
for O
the O
analysis O
( O
conducted O
by O
UK O
Biobank O
, O
Brain O
Imaging O
Documentation O
V1.1 O
, O
http O
: O
//www.ukbiobank.ac.uk O
) O
. O

In O
the O
current O
study O
, O
subjects O
were O
excluded O
if O
they O
did O
not O
provide O
genetic O
data O
, O
or O
if O
they O
were O
known O
to O
have O
participated O
in O
studies O
from O
the O
Psychiatric O
Genomics O
Consortium O
( O
PGC O
) O
GWAS O
dataset O
as O
this O
was O
used O
to O
construct O
the O
polygenic O
risk O
scores O
( O
PGRS O
) O
. O

In O
total O
, O
the O
volumetric O
analysis O
included O
978 O
subjects O
( O
Nfemales/Nmales O
= O
499/479 O
; O
mean O
age O
± O
s.d O
. O

= O
55.32 O
± O
7.38 O
years O
; O
age O
range O
= O
40–70 O
years O
) O
and O
the O
DTI O
analysis O
included O
816 O
subjects O
( O
Nfemales/Nmales O
= O
413/403 O
; O
mean O
age O
± O
s.d O
. O

= O
55.49 O
± O
7.26 O
years O
; O
age O
range O
= O
40–70 O
years O
) O
. O

Sample O
overlap O
( O
individuals O
included O
in O
both O
the O
DTI O
and O
volumetric O
analysis O
) O
included O
N O
= O
816 O
participants O
and O
the O
volumetric O
analysis O
included O
N O
= O
162 O
extra O
participants O
. O

In O
addition O
, O
a O
sensitivity O
analysis O
was O
performed O
where O
we O
imposed O
internal O
imaging O
quality O
checks O
, O
excluding O
individuals O
whose O
subcortical O
volume O
or O
FA O
values O
were O
greater O
than O
three O
standard O
deviations O
above O
or O
below O
the O
mean O
for O
that O
measure O
. O

The O
sensitivity O
analysis O
, O
further O
referred O
to O
as O
the O
sample O
excluding O
outliers O
, O
included O
892 O
( O
exclusion O
of O
86 O
subjects O
; O
Nfemales/Nmales O
= O
477/415 O
; O
mean O
age O
± O
s.d O
. O

= O
55.29 O
± O
7.31 O
years O
; O
age O
range O
= O
40–70 O
years O
) O
and O
733 O
( O
exclusion O
of O
83 O
subjecs O
; O
Nfemales/Nmales O
= O
373/360 O
; O
mean O
age O
± O
s.d O
. O

= O
55.31 O
± O
7.22 O
years O
; O
age O
range O
= O
40–70 O
years O
) O
subjects O
for O
the O
volumetric O
and O
DTI O
analysis O
respectively O
. O

Sample O
overlap O
for O
the O
sample O
excluding O
outliers O
included O
N O
= O
679 O
, O
and O
the O
volumetric O
analysis O
included O
213 O
unique O
observations O
, O
whereas O
the O
DTI O
analysis O
included O
54 O
unique O
observations O
. O

This O
study O
has O
been O
approved O
by O
the O
National O
Health O
Service O
( O
NHS O
) O
Research O
Ethics O
Service O
( O
approval O
letter O
dated O
17th O
June O
2011 O
, O
reference O
: O
11/NW/0382 O
) O
, O
and O
by O
the O
UK O
Biobank O
Access O
Committee O
( O
Project O
# O
4844 O
) O
. O

All O
experiments O
were O
performed O
in O
accordance O
with O
guidelines O
and O
regulations O
from O
these O
committees O
. O

Written O
informed O
consent O
was O
obtained O
from O
each O
subject O
. O

Genotyping O
and O
derivation O
of O
polygenic O
risk O
scores O
Procedures O
for O
DNA O
collection O
and O
genotyping O
in O
UK O
Biobank O
have O
been O
described O
previously O
by O
Hagenaars O
et O
al O
.. O

Subjects O
were O
excluded O
from O
the O
PGRS O
analysis O
if O
they O
had O
a O
non-British O
ancestry O
, O
gender O
mismatch O
, O
relatedness O
( O
r O
> O
0.044 O
) O
, O
and O
genotype O
missingness O
bigger O
than O
2 O
% O
. O

PGRS O
for O
the O
three O
traits O
of O
interest O
( O
i.e. O
, O
MDD O
, O
SCZ O
, O
BP O
) O
were O
created O
using O
PRSice O
. O

For O
each O
subject O
PGRS O
were O
calculated O
by O
summing O
the O
number O
of O
risk O
alleles O
weighted O
by O
the O
strength O
of O
its O
association O
with O
the O
trait O
of O
interest O
. O

The O
strength O
of O
this O
association O
has O
been O
calculated O
previously O
by O
the O
PGC O
( O
PGC2 O
for O
SCZ O
) O
. O

Prior O
to O
calculating O
the O
PGRS O
, O
single O
nucleotide O
polymorphisms O
( O
SNPs O
) O
were O
excluded O
if O
they O
had O
a O
minor O
allele O
frequency O
less O
than O
1 O
% O
, O
deviated O
significantly O
from O
Hardy-Weinberg O
equilibrium O
( O
p O
< O
1 O
× O
10−6 O
) O
in O
the O
total O
sample O
of O
founder O
individuals O
, O
or O
had O
a O
call O
rate O
of O
less O
than O
99 O
% O
. O

The O
remaining O
SNPs O
were O
used O
to O
calculate O
15 O
multidimensional O
scaling O
( O
MDS O
) O
ancestry O
components O
( O
to O
account O
for O
population O
structure O
) O
. O

For O
the O
main O
results O
, O
the O
SNP O
inclusion O
threshold O
was O
set O
as O
p O
≤ O
0.5 O
, O
as O
Purcell O
et O
al O
. O

and O
studies O
following O
this O
work O
, O
have O
shown O
that O
this O
threshold O
is O
generally O
the O
most O
predictive O
of O
case-control O
status O
in O
subsequent O
studies O
. O

Using O
the O
p O
≤ O
0.5 O
SNP O
inclusion O
threshold O
, O
631,763 O
, O
5,422,836 O
and O
1,283,324 O
SNPs O
( O
after O
LD O
pruning O
) O
were O
included O
for O
the O
calculation O
of O
MDD-PGRS O
, O
SCZ-PGRS O
and O
BP-PGRS O
, O
respectively O
. O

Results O
generated O
by O
a O
SNP O
inclusion O
threshold O
of O
p O
≤ O
0.01 O
, O
p O
≤ O
0.05 O
, O
p O
≤ O
0.1 O
and O
p O
≤ O
1.0 O
are O
reported O
in O
supplementary O
materials O
. O

Image O
acquisition O
and O
Neuroimaging O
data O
pre-processing O
Procedures O
for O
image O
acquisition O
and O
pre-processing O
have O
been O
performed O
by O
UK O
Biobank O
, O
and O
are O
available O
on O
the O
UK O
Biobank O
website O
( O
http O
: O
//www.ukbiobank.ac.uk/ O
) O
, O
and O
have O
been O
documented O
previously O
. O

In O
short O
, O
images O
were O
collected O
in O
Cheadle O
Manchester O
on O
a O
Siemens O
Skyra O
3.0 O
T O
scanner O
( O
Siemens O
Medical O
Solutions O
, O
Germany O
) O
with O
a O
32-channel O
head O
coil O
( O
https O
: O
//www.healthcare.siemens.com/magnetic-resonance-imaging O
) O
. O

T1-weighted O
scans O
were O
acquired O
using O
a O
3D O
MPRAGE O
( O
resolution O
1 O
mm3 O
isotropic O
voxels O
) O
sequence O
, O
and O
diffusion-weighted O
( O
DW O
) O
scans O
were O
acquired O
with O
a O
monopolar O
Steejskal-Tanner O
pulse O
sequence O
and O
multi-shell O
acquisition O
( O
b0 O
= O
0 O
s/mm2 O
, O
b O
= O
1,000 O
s/mm2 O
, O
b O
= O
2,000 O
s/mm2 O
) O
. O

Images O
were O
preprocessed O
and O
analysed O
with O
the O
FMRIB O
Software O
Library O
( O
FSL O
) O
( O
http O
: O
//fsl.fmrib.ox.ac.uk/fsl O
) O
. O

More O
detailed O
information O
is O
reported O
in O
the O
supplementary O
materials O
. O

Statistical O
analysis O
All O
analyses O
were O
performed O
using O
R O
( O
version O
3.2.3 O
) O
in O
the O
Linux O
environment O
( O
R O
Development O
Core O
Team O
, O
2010 O
) O
. O

To O
examine O
whether O
higher O
PGRS O
were O
associated O
with O
globally O
poor O
WM O
microstructure O
, O
general O
components O
for O
FA O
( O
gFA O
) O
and O
MD O
( O
gMD O
) O
across O
the O
27 O
WM O
tracts O
were O
calculated O
. O

Latent O
measures O
, O
explaining O
a O
portion O
of O
variance O
WM O
structure O
, O
were O
calculated O
for O
both O
FA O
and O
MD O
by O
extracting O
the O
scores O
on O
the O
first O
unrotated O
components O
, O
using O
a O
principal O
component O
analysis O
( O
PCA O
) O
on O
the O
27 O
WM O
tracts O
. O

The O
first O
components O
accounted O
for O
a O
mean O
of O
44.82 O
% O
and O
41.73 O
% O
of O
total O
variance O
in O
FA O
and O
, O
47.45 O
% O
and O
45.35 O
% O
in O
MD O
, O
in O
the O
sample O
including O
and O
excluding O
outliers O
respectively O
( O
loadings O
of O
tracts O
on O
the O
first O
latent O
component O
> O
0.15 O
) O
. O

To O
examine O
whether O
higher O
PGRS O
were O
selectively O
associated O
with O
poor O
WM O
structure O
in O
a O
certain O
classification O
, O
this O
PCA O
was O
also O
performed O
separately O
for O
groups O
of O
different O
categories O
of O
WM O
tracts O
, O
including O
association O
( O
inferior O
fronto-occipital O
fasciculus O
, O
inferior O
longitudinal O
fasciculus O
, O
superior O
longitudinal O
fasciculus O
, O
uncinate O
fasciculus O
, O
cingulum O
) O
, O
projection O
( O
forceps O
minor O
, O
forceps O
major O
, O
corticospinal O
tracts O
, O
acoustic O
radiation O
, O
medial O
lemniscus O
, O
middle O
cerebellar O
peduncle O
) O
and O
thalamic O
radiation O
fibers O
, O
separately O
( O
sample O
including O
outliers O
: O
variance O
explained O
= O
54.52 O
% O
, O
38.68 O
% O
and O
61.92 O
% O
respectively O
for O
each O
subset O
, O
and O
loading O
of O
first O
component O
> O
0.33 O
; O
sample O
excluding O
outliers O
: O
variance O
explained O
= O
60.05 O
% O
, O
32.05 O
% O
and O
72.05 O
% O
respectively O
for O
each O
subset O
and O
loading O
of O
first O
component O
> O
0.27 O
) O
. O

For O
bilateral O
brain O
regions O
, O
associations O
between O
the O
three O
PGRS O
and O
each O
imaging O
measure O
were O
examined O
using O
a O
repeated O
measure O
linear O
mixed-effects O
analysis O
, O
modelling O
hemisphere O
as O
a O
random O
factor O
( O
where O
the O
PGRS O
* O
hemisphere O
interaction O
itself O
was O
found O
to O
be O
non-significant O
) O
. O

For O
unilateral O
structures O
( O
e.g O
. O

total O
GM O
volume O
, O
forceps O
major O
, O
forceps O
minor O
and O
middle O
cerebellar O
peduncle O
) O
, O
and O
those O
where O
there O
was O
a O
significant O
interaction O
between O
PGRS O
and O
hemisphere O
, O
associations O
were O
analysed O
as O
single O
structures O
without O
repeated O
measurements O
and O
without O
hemisphere O
as O
a O
separate O
term O
in O
the O
model O
. O

For O
all O
models O
, O
additional O
fixed O
effects O
included O
age O
, O
age2 O
, O
gender O
, O
genotype O
batch O
, O
genotype O
array O
and O
15 O
ancestry-informative O
MDS O
components O
. O

Intracranial O
volume O
, O
calculated O
as O
the O
sum O
of O
WM O
, O
GM O
and O
ventricular O
CSF O
, O
was O
also O
modelled O
as O
a O
fixed O
effect O
in O
the O
analysis O
of O
subcortical O
volumes O
in O
order O
to O
adjust O
for O
differences O
in O
overall O
brain O
size O
. O

PGRS O
and O
imaging O
measures O
were O
scaled O
to O
zero O
mean O
and O
unitary O
standard O
deviation O
. O

Standardised O
Beta O
values O
are O
reported O
throughout O
results O
. O

Results O
were O
corrected O
for O
multiple O
comparisons O
using O
a O
false O
discovery O
rate O
( O
FDR O
) O
correction O
. O

Nagelkerke O
’ O
s O
R2 O
was O
used O
to O
estimate O
the O
proportion O
of O
variation O
explained O
by O
PGRS O
. O

Post-hoc O
positive O
control O
analyses O
, O
with O
age O
as O
an O
independent O
variable O
and O
each O
of O
the O
brain O
measures O
as O
dependent O
variable O
, O
were O
performed O
in O
order O
to O
test O
the O
sensitivity O
of O
UK O
Biobank O
imaging O
data O
, O
by O
verifying O
that O
we O
could O
replicate O
the O
widely O
reported O
negative O
associations O
between O
many O
structural O
brain O
measures O
and O
age O
( O
including O
those O
reported O
previously O
in O
an O
overlapping O
sample O
in O
UK O
Biobank O
) O
. O

Fixed O
effects O
included O
gender O
for O
all O
structures O
, O
and O
side O
of O
hemisphere O
for O
lateralized O
structures O
only O
. O

Polygenic O
risk O
for O
five O
psychiatric O
disorders O
and O
cross-disorder O
and O
disorder-specific O
neural O
connectivity O
in O
two O
independent O
populations O
Major O
psychiatric O
disorders O
, O
including O
attention O
deficit O
hyperactivity O
disorder O
( O
ADHD O
) O
, O
autism O
( O
AUT O
) O
, O
bipolar O
disorder O
( O
BD O
) O
, O
major O
depressive O
disorder O
( O
MDD O
) O
, O
and O
schizophrenia O
( O
SZ O
) O
, O
are O
highly O
heritable O
and O
polygenic O
. O

Evidence O
suggests O
that O
these O
five O
disorders O
have O
both O
shared O
and O
distinct O
genetic O
risks O
and O
neural O
connectivity O
abnormalities O
. O

To O
measure O
aggregate O
genetic O
risks O
, O
the O
polygenic O
risk O
score O
( O
PGRS O
) O
was O
computed O
. O

Two O
independent O
general O
populations O
( O
N O
= O
360 O
and O
N O
= O
323 O
) O
were O
separately O
examined O
to O
investigate O
whether O
the O
cross-disorder O
PGRS O
and O
PGRS O
for O
a O
specific O
disorder O
were O
associated O
with O
individual O
variability O
in O
functional O
connectivity O
. O

Consistent O
altered O
functional O
connectivity O
was O
found O
with O
the O
bilateral O
insula O
: O
for O
the O
left O
supplementary O
motor O
area O
and O
the O
left O
superior O
temporal O
gyrus O
with O
the O
cross-disorder O
PGRS O
, O
for O
the O
left O
insula O
and O
right O
middle O
and O
superior O
temporal O
lobe O
associated O
with O
the O
PGRS O
for O
autism O
, O
for O
the O
bilateral O
midbrain O
, O
posterior O
cingulate O
, O
cuneus O
, O
and O
precuneus O
associated O
with O
the O
PGRS O
for O
BD O
, O
and O
for O
the O
left O
angular O
gyrus O
and O
the O
left O
dorsolateral O
prefrontal O
cortex O
associated O
with O
the O
PGRS O
for O
schizophrenia O
. O

No O
significant O
functional O
connectivity O
was O
found O
associated O
with O
the O
PGRS O
for O
ADHD O
and O
MDD O
. O

Our O
findings O
indicated O
that O
genetic O
effects O
on O
the O
cross-disorder O
and O
disorder-specific O
neural O
connectivity O
of O
common O
genetic O
risk O
loci O
are O
detectable O
in O
the O
general O
population O
. O

Our O
findings O
also O
indicated O
that O
polygenic O
risk O
contributes O
to O
the O
main O
neurobiological O
phenotypes O
of O
psychiatric O
disorders O
and O
that O
identifying O
cross-disorder O
and O
specific O
functional O
connectivity O
related O
to O
polygenic O
risks O
may O
elucidate O
the O
neural O
pathways O
for O
these O
disorders O
. O

Highlights O
Altered O
cross-disorder O
functional O
connectivity O
related O
to O
PGRSs O
is O
detected O
. O

Altered O
disorder-specific O
functional O
connectivity O
related O
to O
PGRSs O
is O
detected O
. O

Altered O
functional O
connectivity O
related O
to O
PGRSs O
is O
involved O
in O
brain O
networks O
. O

Polygenic O
risk O
contributes O
to O
neurobiological O
phenotypes O
of O
psychiatric O
disorders O
. O

Materials O
and O
methods O
Demographics O
of O
participants O
Dataset O
1 O
: O
Dataset O
1 O
included O
360 O
healthy O
young O
Chinese O
subjects O
( O
Table O
1 O
) O
. O

The O
subjects O
and O
their O
relatives O
within O
the O
third-degree O
had O
no O
history O
of O
psychiatric O
disorders O
. O

None O
of O
the O
participants O
had O
a O
history O
of O
psychiatric O
treatment O
, O
drug O
or O
alcohol O
abuse O
, O
traumatic O
brain O
injury O
, O
or O
visible O
brain O
lesions O
on O
conventional O
magnetic O
resonance O
imaging O
( O
MRI O
) O
. O

They O
all O
gave O
full O
written O
informed O
consent O
to O
join O
the O
study O
. O

The O
Ethics O
Committee O
of O
the O
School O
of O
Life O
Science O
and O
Technology O
at O
the O
University O
of O
Electronic O
Science O
and O
Technology O
of O
China O
approved O
this O
study O
. O

Dataset O
2 O
: O
323 O
healthy O
young O
Chinese O
subjects O
were O
included O
in O
Dataset O
2 O
( O
Table O
1 O
) O
. O

None O
of O
the O
subjects O
nor O
their O
first-degree O
relatives O
had O
a O
history O
of O
psychiatric O
diagnoses O
, O
of O
neurological O
or O
metabolic O
illnesses O
, O
or O
of O
drug O
or O
alcohol O
abuse O
. O

They O
all O
gave O
full O
written O
informed O
consent O
to O
participate O
in O
the O
study O
. O

The O
Ethics O
Committee O
of O
Tianjin O
Medical O
University O
approved O
this O
study O
. O

Genotyping O
and O
quality O
control O
We O
collected O
whole O
blood O
and O
extracted O
genomic O
DNA O
using O
the O
EZgene O
Blood O
gDNA O
Miniprep O
Kit O
for O
all O
subjects O
. O

Next O
we O
performed O
whole-genome O
genotyping O
using O
the O
standard O
Illumina O
genotyping O
protocol O
on O
Illumina O
Human O
OmniZhongHua-8 O
BeadChips O
. O

Plink O
was O
used O
to O
perform O
quality O
control O
, O
using O
the O
same O
procedure O
for O
both O
datasets O
. O

First O
, O
the O
individuals O
, O
1 O
from O
Dataset O
1 O
and O
3 O
from O
Dataset O
2 O
, O
whose O
missing O
genotype O
rates O
were O
> O
0.05 O
were O
excluded O
. O

Then O
, O
we O
removed O
the O
one O
with O
the O
greater O
missing O
genotype O
rate O
from O
each O
pair O
that O
had O
more O
similar O
genotypes O
identified O
by O
estimating O
the O
pairwise O
identity-by-descent O
( O
IBD O
) O
than O
we O
would O
have O
expected O
in O
a O
random O
sample O
, O
removing O
2 O
individuals O
from O
Dataset O
1 O
and O
5 O
individuals O
from O
Dataset O
2 O
. O

Next O
, O
SNPs O
with O
missing O
genotype O
rates O
> O
0.05 O
, O
a O
minor O
allele O
frequency O
< O
0.01 O
, O
or O
a O
significant O
departure O
from O
Hardy-Weinberg O
Equilibrium O
( O
P O
< O
0.001 O
) O
were O
excluded O
. O

Finally O
, O
a O
principal O
component O
analysis O
( O
PCA O
) O
was O
performed O
to O
control O
for O
population O
stratification O
using O
EIGENSTART O
on O
a O
linkage O
disequilibrium O
( O
LD O
) O
pruned O
set O
of O
autosomal O
SNPs O
obtained O
by O
carrying O
out O
LD O
pruning O
with O
PLINK O
and O
removing O
5 O
long-range O
LD O
regions O
with O
the O
HapMap O
phase O
3 O
reference O
dataset O
. O

We O
removed O
the O
outliers O
of O
the O
sample O
( O
> O
6 O
SD O
) O
after O
we O
identified O
10 O
principle O
components O
. O

A O
Q-Q O
plot O
was O
applied O
and O
showed O
that O
the O
population O
stratification O
was O
well O
controlled O
with O
λ O
= O
1.03043 O
( O
Supplementary O
Fig O
. O

1 O
) O
. O

After O
these O
quality O
control O
procedures O
, O
356 O
and O
311 O
subjects O
respectively O
in O
Datasets O
1 O
and O
2 O
were O
included O
for O
subsequent O
analyses O
. O

Additionally O
, O
> O
700.000 O
SNPs O
survived O
the O
pruning O
procedures O
. O

Imputation O
and O
PGRS O
generation O
The O
genome O
coordinates O
were O
converted O
from O
hg19 O
to O
hg18 O
assembly O
using O
liftOver O
( O
https O
: O
//genome.ucsc.edu/cgi-bin/hgLiftOver O
) O
to O
be O
consistent O
with O
the O
reference O
dataset O
used O
to O
perform O
imputation O
and O
the O
training O
dataset O
used O
to O
calculate O
the O
PGRS O
. O

Ungenotyped O
SNPs O
were O
imputed O
using O
SHAPEIT O
and O
IMPUTE2 O
with O
an O
HapMap O
phase O
3 O
reference O
dataset O
. O

After O
imputation O
, O
1,381,116 O
SNPs O
were O
included O
for O
the O
following O
analysis O
. O

We O
removed O
the O
SNPs O
with O
imputation O
quality O
scores O
< O
0.8 O
, O
missing O
genotype O
rates O
> O
0.05 O
, O
a O
minor O
allele O
frequency O
< O
0.01 O
, O
or O
significant O
departure O
from O
Hardy-Weinberg O
Equilibrium O
( O
P O
< O
0.0001 O
) O
. O

About O
960,000 O
SNPs O
survived O
the O
pruning O
procedures O
and O
were O
used O
to O
calculate O
the O
PGRSs O
. O

The O
GWAS O
data O
used O
to O
calculate O
the O
PGRS O
was O
pruned O
for O
linkage O
disequilibrium O
( O
r2 O
< O
0.25 O
) O
at O
thresholds O
of O
PT O
< O
0.01 O
, O
PT O
< O
0.05 O
, O
PT O
< O
0.1 O
and O
PT O
< O
0.5 O
. O

It O
is O
important O
to O
choose O
an O
appropriate O
P-threshold O
to O
define O
PGRS O
and O
methods O
are O
proposed O
to O
choose O
the O
threshold O
. O

However O
, O
since O
this O
is O
a O
data O
driven O
study O
without O
predefined O
phenotypes O
, O
this O
method O
could O
not O
work O
on O
our O
study O
. O

A O
more O
stringent O
threshold O
generates O
a O
SNP O
set O
with O
less O
SNPs O
being O
truly O
associated O
with O
the O
disorders O
. O

With O
a O
more O
liberal O
threshold O
, O
more O
SNPs O
will O
be O
included O
, O
which O
will O
help O
increase O
the O
statistical O
power O
. O

But O
too O
liberal O
threshold O
will O
include O
SNPs O
that O
are O
too O
weakly O
associated O
with O
the O
disorders O
. O

So O
the O
statistical O
power O
will O
decrease O
. O

Among O
these O
four O
thresholds O
, O
PT O
< O
0.05 O
could O
be O
a O
balance O
of O
statistical O
power O
and O
the O
number O
of O
SNPs O
. O

So O
our O
research O
was O
primarily O
based O
on O
the O
PGRS O
calculated O
at O
PT O
< O
0.05 O
, O
and O
we O
analyzed O
PGRS O
at O
other O
thresholds O
based O
on O
the O
results O
of O
PT O
< O
0.05 O
. O

We O
calculated O
the O
PGRS O
using O
the O
method O
described O
in O
a O
previous O
paper O
. O

First O
we O
calculated O
the O
cross-disorder O
PGRSs O
and O
then O
calculated O
PGRSs O
for O
each O
of O
these O
five O
disorders O
( O
ADHD O
, O
autism O
, O
BD O
, O
MDD O
, O
schizophrenia O
) O
separately O
. O

The O
summary O
GWAS O
results O
from O
the O
PGC O
GWAS O
Cross O
Disorder O
group O
were O
used O
as O
training O
datasets O
. O

fMRI O
image O
acquisition O
and O
preprocessing O
The O
image O
acquisition O
from O
each O
scanner O
was O
finished O
within O
six O
months O
. O

There O
were O
no O
hardware O
or O
system O
upgrades O
for O
either O
scanner O
, O
and O
the O
sequence O
and O
protocols O
for O
each O
subject O
were O
kept O
constant O
in O
each O
scanning O
period O
. O

The O
subjects O
from O
Dataset O
1 O
were O
scanned O
on O
a O
MR750 O
3.0T O
magnetic O
resonance O
scanner O
( O
GE O
Healthcare O
, O
Milwaukee O
, O
WI O
) O
. O

Resting-state O
functional O
imaging O
data O
was O
obtained O
using O
a O
gradient-echo O
echo-planar-imaging O
( O
GRE-EPI O
) O
sequence O
with O
the O
following O
configuration O
: O
echo O
time O
( O
TE O
) O
= O
30 O
ms O
, O
repetition O
time O
( O
TR O
) O
= O
2000 O
ms O
, O
flip O
angle O
= O
90° O
, O
field O
of O
view O
( O
FOV O
) O
= O
240 O
× O
240 O
mm2 O
, O
matrix O
= O
64 O
× O
64 O
, O
voxel O
size O
= O
3.75 O
× O
3.75 O
× O
4.00 O
mm3 O
, O
39 O
slices O
and O
255 O
volumes O
. O

The O
subjects O
from O
Dataset O
2 O
were O
scanned O
using O
a O
Signa O
HDx O
3.0T O
scanner O
( O
GE O
Healthcare O
, O
Milwaukee O
, O
WI O
) O
. O

We O
used O
a O
single-shot O
gradient-echo O
echo-planar O
imaging O
( O
SS-GRE-EPI O
) O
sequence O
to O
perform O
resting-state O
functional O
imaging O
with O
the O
following O
parameters O
: O
repetition O
time O
( O
TR O
) O
= O
2000 O
ms O
, O
echo O
time O
( O
TE O
) O
= O
30 O
ms O
, O
field O
of O
view O
( O
FOV O
) O
= O
240 O
× O
240 O
mm2 O
, O
matrix O
= O
64 O
× O
64 O
, O
flip O
angle O
= O
90° O
, O
voxel O
size O
= O
3.75 O
× O
3.75 O
× O
4.00 O
mm3 O
, O
40 O
slices O
, O
and O
180 O
volumes O
. O

All O
participants O
were O
asked O
to O
close O
their O
eyes O
and O
avoid O
movement O
, O
think O
about O
nothing O
in O
particular O
, O
and O
avoid O
sleeping O
. O

After O
scanning O
, O
the O
subjects O
were O
asked O
if O
they O
fell O
asleep O
to O
ensure O
that O
they O
had O
all O
remained O
awake O
. O

The O
same O
preprocessing O
procedures O
were O
applied O
to O
each O
dataset O
, O
and O
DPARSFA O
( O
Data O
Processing O
Assistant O
for O
Resting O
State O
fMRI O
Advanced O
Edition O
, O
http O
: O
//www.restfmri.net/forum/DPARSF O
) O
was O
used O
to O
preprocess O
the O
images O
. O

The O
preprocessing O
procedures O
included O
: O
( O
1 O
) O
removing O
the O
first O
10 O
volumes O
; O
( O
2 O
) O
slice O
timing O
; O
( O
3 O
) O
head O
motion O
correction O
; O
( O
4 O
) O
spatial O
normalization O
; O
( O
5 O
) O
smoothing O
with O
a O
6 O
mm O
Gaussian O
kernel O
; O
( O
6 O
) O
removing O
the O
influence O
of O
the O
whole O
brain O
signals O
, O
head O
motions O
, O
and O
linear O
trends O
; O
and O
( O
7 O
) O
temporal O
band-pass O
filtration O
( O
0.01–0.08 O
HZ O
) O
. O

After O
preprocessing O
, O
28 O
and O
14 O
subjects O
respectively O
from O
Datasets O
1 O
and O
2 O
were O
excluded O
due O
to O
a O
maximum O
displacement O
> O
2 O
mm O
or O
a O
spin O
> O
2° O
in O
any O
of O
the O
cardinal O
directions O
. O

ROI O
definition O
Since O
cross-disorder O
PGRS O
indicates O
shared O
genetic O
risks O
for O
these O
five O
psychiatric O
disorders O
, O
brain O
regions O
that O
showed O
disruption O
in O
all O
five O
major O
psychiatric O
disorders O
were O
chosen O
as O
a O
ROI O
to O
investigate O
the O
associations O
between O
functional O
connectivity O
and O
cross-disorder O
PGRS O
and O
contributions O
of O
subscores O
for O
each O
of O
these O
five O
disorders O
to O
the O
cross-disorder O
impacts O
using O
resting-state O
fMRI O
. O

We O
used O
statistical O
inference O
maps O
acquired O
from O
Neurosynth O
( O
http O
: O
//neurosynth.org/ O
) O
to O
define O
the O
region O
of O
interest O
( O
ROI O
) O
for O
further O
functional O
connectivity O
analysis O
. O

We O
searched O
the O
meta-analysis O
results O
from O
Neurosynth O
( O
http O
: O
//neurosynth.org/ O
) O
for O
the O
5 O
major O
psychiatric O
disorders O
, O
separately O
using O
ADHD O
, O
autism O
, O
bipolar O
, O
depression O
, O
and O
schizophrenia O
as O
search O
terms O
. O

If O
a O
study O
used O
one O
of O
the O
searched O
keywords O
, O
we O
obtained O
statistical O
inference O
maps O
displaying O
z-scores O
according O
to O
the O
probability O
of O
a O
region O
's O
being O
activated O
. O

In O
other O
words O
, O
these O
maps O
displayed O
the O
brain O
regions O
that O
were O
consistently O
activated O
in O
studies O
that O
loaded O
highly O
on O
a O
specific O
term O
. O

A O
large O
z-score O
means O
that O
this O
region O
was O
reported O
more O
often O
than O
expectation O
under O
the O
hypothesis O
that O
activations O
in O
the O
brain O
would O
be O
equally O
likely O
. O

These O
maps O
were O
thresholded O
at O
a O
false O
discovery O
rate O
( O
FDR O
) O
of O
0.01 O
( O
Fig O
. O

1 O
) O
. O

The O
brain O
regions O
affected O
by O
all O
5 O
disorders O
were O
defined O
as O
an O
ROI O
. O

This O
ROI O
primarily O
included O
the O
bilateral O
insula O
, O
which O
is O
reasonable O
since O
the O
insulae O
have O
been O
suggested O
as O
being O
affected O
by O
all O
five O
major O
psychiatric O
disorders O
. O

Then O
we O
resampled O
the O
voxel O
size O
of O
the O
ROI O
to O
3 O
× O
3 O
× O
3 O
mm3 O
to O
match O
the O
voxel O
size O
of O
the O
fMRI O
images O
we O
acquired O
after O
preprocessing O
( O
Fig O
. O

1 O
) O
. O

Functional O
connectivity O
calculation O
Based O
on O
the O
defined O
ROI O
, O
we O
calculated O
voxel-wise O
bilateral O
insular O
functional O
connectivity O
maps O
for O
each O
subject O
throughout O
the O
whole O
brain O
. O

These O
functional O
maps O
were O
calculated O
by O
computing O
the O
Pearson O
's O
correlation O
coefficient O
between O
the O
average O
BOLD O
time O
series O
in O
the O
ROI O
and O
the O
time O
series O
from O
all O
the O
voxels O
within O
a O
gray O
matter O
mask O
of O
the O
whole O
brain O
. O

The O
correlations O
were O
transformed O
to O
a O
Gaussian O
distribution O
using O
Fisher O
's O
z-transformation O
. O

Statistical O
analysis O
We O
performed O
a O
second-level O
analysis O
using O
SPM12 O
( O
http O
: O
//www.fil.ion.ucl.ac.uk/spm/ O
) O
with O
the O
subjects O
in O
the O
two O
independent O
datasets O
, O
separately O
. O

We O
applied O
a O
multiple O
regression O
model O
and O
voxel-wise O
t-test O
to O
test O
for O
significant O
correlations O
between O
the O
PGRSs O
and O
the O
voxel-wise O
functional O
connectivity O
. O

Age O
, O
sex O
, O
and O
the O
3 O
top O
principle O
components O
were O
included O
in O
the O
model O
as O
covariates O
. O

To O
correct O
for O
multiple O
comparisons O
, O
an O
Alphasim O
algorithm O
implemented O
in O
REST O
was O
applied O
. O

Statistical O
maps O
were O
thresholded O
at O
a O
voxel-level O
of O
p O
< O
0.05 O
and O
cluster O
size O
> O
90 O
voxels O
to O
reach O
a O
cluster-level O
significance O
of O
alpha O
< O
0.05 O
. O

After O
correcting O
for O
multiple O
comparisons O
, O
we O
conducted O
conjunction O
analyses O
. O

First O
we O
performed O
a O
conjunction O
analysis O
to O
find O
consistent O
functional O
connectivity O
alterations O
associated O
with O
cross-disorder O
PGRS O
between O
these O
two O
datasets O
. O

Then O
we O
conducted O
another O
two O
conjunction O
analyses O
to O
find O
disorder-specific O
functional O
connectivity O
alterations O
, O
first O
performing O
a O
conjunction O
analysis O
for O
each O
dataset O
to O
find O
disorder-specific O
functional O
connectivity O
alterations O
and O
then O
conducting O
the O
second O
conjunction O
analysis O
to O
find O
consistent O
disorder-specific O
functional O
connectivity O
patterns O
with O
the O
bilateral O
insula O
in O
both O
datasets O
. O

Clusters O
larger O
than O
10 O
voxels O
were O
retained O
. O

Then O
to O
find O
whether O
PGRSs O
calculated O
using O
other O
thresholds O
produce O
similar O
results O
, O
we O
conducted O
the O
same O
analysis O
as O
above O
using O
PGRS O
calculated O
with O
PT O
< O
0.01 O
, O
0.1 O
and O
0.5 O
separately O
, O
but O
only O
considering O
the O
significant O
voxels O
at O
PT O
< O
0.05 O
, O
not O
the O
voxels O
in O
the O
whole O
brain O
. O

To O
correct O
for O
multiple O
comparisons O
, O
an O
Alphasim O
algorithm O
implemented O
in O
REST O
was O
applied O
. O

Statistical O
maps O
were O
thresholded O
at O
a O
voxel-level O
of O
p O
< O
0.05 O
and O
cluster O
size O
> O
12 O
voxels O
for O
autism O
, O
9 O
voxels O
for O
BD O
and O
7 O
voxels O
for O
schizophrenia O
to O
reach O
a O
cluster-level O
significance O
of O
alpha O
< O
0.05 O
. O

Functional O
Connectivity O
When O
Detecting O
Rare O
Visual O
Targets O
in O
Schizophrenia O
Individuals O
with O
schizophrenia O
demonstrate O
difficulties O
in O
attending O
to O
important O
stimuli O
( O
e.g. O
, O
targets O
) O
and O
ignoring O
distractors O
( O
e.g. O
, O
non-targets O
) O
. O

We O
used O
a O
visual O
oddball O
task O
during O
fMRI O
to O
examine O
functional O
connectivity O
within O
and O
between O
the O
ventral O
and O
dorsal O
attention O
networks O
to O
determine O
the O
relative O
contribution O
of O
each O
network O
to O
detection O
of O
rare O
visual O
targets O
in O
schizophrenia O
. O

The O
sample O
comprised O
25 O
schizophrenia O
patients O
and O
27 O
healthy O
controls O
. O

Psychophysiological O
interaction O
analysis O
was O
used O
to O
examine O
whole-brain O
functional O
connectivity O
in O
response O
to O
targets O
. O

We O
used O
the O
right O
temporo O
parietal O
junction O
( O
TPJ O
) O
as O
the O
seed O
region O
for O
the O
ventral O
network O
and O
the O
right O
medial O
intraparietal O
sulcus O
( O
IPS O
) O
as O
the O
seed O
region O
for O
the O
dorsal O
network O
. O

We O
found O
that O
connectivity O
between O
right O
IPS O
and O
right O
anterior O
insula O
( O
AI O
; O
a O
component O
of O
the O
ventral O
network O
) O
was O
significantly O
greater O
in O
controls O
than O
patients O
. O

Expected O
patterns O
of O
within- O
and O
between-network O
connectivity O
for O
right O
TPJ O
were O
observed O
in O
controls O
, O
and O
not O
significantly O
different O
in O
patients O
. O

These O
findings O
indicate O
functional O
connectivity O
deficits O
between O
the O
dorsal O
and O
ventral O
attention O
networks O
in O
schizophrenia O
that O
may O
create O
problems O
in O
processing O
relevant O
versus O
irrelevant O
stimuli O
. O

Understanding O
the O
nature O
of O
network O
disruptions O
underlying O
cognitive O
deficits O
of O
schizophrenia O
may O
help O
shed O
light O
on O
the O
pathophysiology O
of O
this O
disorder O
. O

2 O
. O

Methods O
2.1 O
. O

Participants O
Twenty-five O
patients O
with O
schizophrenia O
( O
4 O
female O
) O
and O
27 O
healthy O
controls O
( O
4 O
female O
) O
were O
recruited O
for O
the O
study O
. O

The O
participants O
in O
this O
study O
were O
largely O
overlapping O
with O
those O
in O
Wynn O
et O
al O
. O

that O
examined O
regional O
activation O
and O
EEG O
, O
but O
did O
not O
consider O
connectivity O
. O

Patients O
were O
recruited O
from O
outpatient O
treatment O
clinics O
at O
the O
Greater O
Los O
Angeles O
VA O
Medical O
Center O
( O
GLA O
) O
and O
the O
community O
. O

Patients O
met O
diagnostic O
criteria O
for O
schizophrenia O
based O
on O
the O
Structured O
Clinical O
Interview O
for O
DSM-IV O
Axis O
I O
Disorders O
( O
SCID O
) O
. O

Selection O
criteria O
were O
the O
same O
as O
previous O
studies O
from O
this O
laboratory O
. O

Patients O
were O
between O
18 O
and O
60 O
years O
of O
age O
, O
and O
were O
excluded O
from O
participation O
if O
they O
had O
: O
self-reported O
substance O
abuse O
in O
the O
past O
month O
or O
dependence O
in O
the O
last O
six O
months O
, O
IQ O
< O
70 O
based O
on O
examination O
of O
medical O
records O
, O
history O
of O
loss O
of O
consciousness O
for O
more O
than O
one O
hour O
, O
identifiable O
neurological O
disorders O
, O
or O
were O
not O
sufficiently O
fluent O
in O
English O
to O
consent O
and O
understand O
procedures O
. O

Psychiatric O
symptoms O
were O
evaluated O
using O
the O
24-item O
University O
of O
California O
, O
Los O
Angeles O
( O
UCLA O
) O
version O
of O
the O
Brief O
Psychiatric O
Rating O
Scale O
( O
BPRS O
) O
and O
Scale O
for O
the O
Assessment O
of O
Negative O
Symptoms O
( O
SANS O
) O
. O

For O
the O
BPRS O
we O
report O
means O
for O
the O
“ O
positive O
symptom O
, O
” O
“ O
negative O
symptom O
, O
” O
“ O
agitation/mania O
, O
” O
and O
“ O
depression/anxiety O
” O
factors O
. O

For O
the O
SANS O
we O
report O
four O
global O
scales O
: O
Affective O
Flattening O
, O
Alogia O
, O
Avolition-Apathy O
, O
and O
Anhedonia-Asociality O
. O

Healthy O
controls O
between O
18 O
and O
60 O
years O
of O
age O
were O
recruited O
through O
internet O
postings O
and O
interviewed O
with O
the O
SCID-I O
and O
portions O
of O
the O
Structured O
Clinical O
Interview O
for O
DSM-IV O
Axis O
II O
Disorders O
( O
SCID-II O
) O
. O

Exclusion O
criteria O
for O
potential O
controls O
included O
: O
an O
identifiable O
neurological O
disorder O
or O
head O
injury O
, O
a O
first-degree O
relative O
with O
schizophrenia O
or O
another O
psychotic O
disorder O
, O
insufficient O
fluency O
in O
English O
, O
a O
personal O
history O
of O
schizophrenia O
or O
other O
psychotic O
disorder O
, O
bipolar O
disorder O
, O
recurrent O
depression O
, O
a O
lifetime O
history O
of O
substance O
dependence O
, O
or O
any O
substance O
abuse O
in O
the O
last O
6 O
months O
, O
and O
any O
of O
the O
following O
Axis O
II O
disorders O
: O
avoidant O
, O
paranoid O
, O
schizoid O
, O
or O
schizotypal O
. O

All O
interviewers O
were O
trained O
through O
the O
Treatment O
Unit O
of O
the O
Department O
of O
Veterans O
Affairs O
VISN O
22 O
Mental O
Illness O
Research O
, O
Education O
, O
and O
Clinical O
Center O
( O
MIRECC O
) O
to O
a O
minimum O
kappa O
of O
0.75 O
for O
key O
psychotic O
and O
mood O
items O
. O

The O
study O
protocol O
was O
reviewed O
and O
approved O
by O
the O
Institutional O
Review O
Boards O
of O
the O
University O
of O
California O
, O
Los O
Angeles O
and O
Greater O
Los O
Angeles O
VA O
Medical O
Center O
. O

All O
participants O
had O
the O
capacity O
to O
give O
informed O
consent O
and O
provided O
written O
informed O
consent O
after O
all O
procedures O
were O
fully O
explained O
. O

2.2 O
. O

Procedures O
2.2.1 O
. O

Task O
design O
Participants O
completed O
a O
visual O
oddball O
task O
, O
modeled O
after O
prior O
studies O
, O
in O
which O
they O
viewed O
images O
of O
two O
letters O
, O
X O
and O
K O
; O
one O
letter O
served O
as O
a O
target O
and O
the O
other O
as O
a O
nontarget O
in O
a O
counterbalanced O
fashion O
. O

We O
used O
an O
event-related O
design O
and O
presented O
the O
stimuli O
in O
three O
separate O
blocks O
using O
magnet-compatible O
goggles O
( O
Resonance O
Technology O
, O
Northridge O
, O
CA O
) O
. O

Each O
stimulus O
was O
displayed O
for O
100 O
ms O
followed O
by O
an O
interstimulus O
interval O
( O
ISI O
) O
that O
was O
either O
900 O
, O
1900 O
, O
or O
2900 O
ms O
( O
mean O
ISI O
= O
1900 O
ms O
) O
. O

The O
ISIs O
were O
equiprobable O
and O
randomly O
distributed O
. O

Participants O
were O
instructed O
to O
push O
a O
button O
on O
a O
MRI-compatible O
button O
box O
whenever O
they O
detected O
the O
target O
and O
had O
3000 O
ms O
to O
make O
a O
response1 O
. O

Within O
each O
block O
a O
total O
of O
150 O
stimuli O
were O
presented O
: O
12 O
% O
were O
targets O
( O
n O
= O
18 O
) O
and O
88 O
% O
were O
non-targets O
( O
n O
= O
132 O
) O
. O

Additionally O
, O
null O
trials O
were O
interspersed O
throughout O
each O
block O
and O
consisted O
solely O
of O
a O
fixation O
point O
. O

Duration O
of O
each O
block O
was O
5 O
minutes O
. O

The O
task O
took O
approximately O
20 O
minutes O
to O
complete O
. O

2.2.2. O
fMRI O
data O
acquisition O
and O
preprocessing O
Scanning O
was O
performed O
on O
a O
Siemens O
3T O
( O
Erlangen O
, O
Germany O
) O
Trio O
MRI O
scanner O
. O

Functional O
runs O
( O
blocks O
) O
were O
acquired O
with O
150 O
T2 O
* O
-weighted O
echoplanar O
images O
( O
EPIs O
) O
[ O
repetition O
time O
( O
TR O
) O
2000 O
ms O
; O
echo O
time O
( O
TE O
) O
30 O
ms O
; O
flip O
angle O
= O
75° O
; O
33 O
slices O
; O
slice O
thickness O
4mm O
; O
matrix O
64 O
× O
64 O
; O
FOV O
220 O
mm O
] O
. O

The O
first O
two O
volumes O
of O
each O
functional O
scan O
are O
automatically O
discarded O
before O
data O
collection O
begins O
to O
allow O
for O
T1 O
equilibrium O
. O

Two O
sets O
of O
structural O
images O
were O
acquired O
for O
registration O
of O
functional O
data O
: O
a O
T1 O
weighted O
magnetization O
prepared O
rapid-acquisition O
gradient O
echo O
image O
( O
MPRAGE O
) O
[ O
TR O
, O
1900 O
ms O
; O
TE O
3.43 O
ms O
; O
flip O
angle O
= O
9° O
; O
160 O
sagittal O
slices O
; O
slice O
thickness O
1 O
mm O
; O
matrix O
256 O
× O
256 O
; O
FOV O
256 O
mm O
] O
; O
and O
a O
T2-weighted O
matched-bandwidth O
high-resolution O
scan O
with O
the O
same O
slice O
prescription O
as O
the O
EPI O
[ O
TR O
, O
6540 O
ms O
; O
TE O
, O
13 O
ms O
; O
flip O
angle O
= O
120° O
; O
33 O
slices O
; O
slice O
thickness O
4 O
mm O
; O
matrix O
128 O
× O
128 O
; O
FOV O
220 O
mm O
] O
. O

Preprocessing O
and O
data O
analysis O
was O
performed O
with O
the O
FMRIB O
Software O
Library O
( O
FSL O
v5.0 O
; O
Analysis O
Group O
, O
Oxford O
, O
UK O
) O
. O

To O
compensate O
for O
any O
head O
motion O
, O
images O
were O
realigned O
to O
the O
middle O
volume O
using O
MCFLIRT O
. O

Movement O
parameters O
calculated O
by O
MCFLIRT O
were O
also O
modeled O
in O
the O
analysis O
as O
nuisance O
covariates O
. O

Relative O
mean O
displacement O
estimates O
for O
the O
final O
sample O
did O
not O
exceed O
0.5 O
mm O
; O
however O
, O
estimates O
for O
patients O
were O
significantly O
greater O
than O
for O
controls O
( O
patients O
: O
M O
= O
.18 O
, O
SD O
= O
.11 O
; O
controls O
: O
M O
= O
.11 O
, O
SD O
= O
.01 O
; O
t O
( O
49 O
) O
= O
2.94 O
, O
p O
< O
.05 O
) O
. O

Two O
patients O
had O
one O
block O
( O
out O
of O
three O
) O
excluded O
for O
excessive O
head O
motion O
( O
relative O
mean O
displacement O
> O
0.5 O
mm O
) O
. O

One O
patient O
was O
excluded O
from O
the O
analysis O
due O
to O
having O
two O
out O
of O
three O
blocks O
with O
excessive O
head O
motion O
. O

Following O
these O
exclusions O
, O
24 O
patients O
with O
schizophrenia O
and O
27 O
normal O
controls O
were O
included O
in O
the O
PPI O
analyses O
. O

The O
data O
were O
temporally O
filtered O
with O
a O
high-pass O
filter O
cutoff O
of O
60 O
s O
and O
spatially O
smoothed O
with O
a O
5 O
mm O
full O
width O
half O
maximum O
Gaussian O
kernel O
in O
three O
dimensions O
. O

Registration O
was O
carried O
out O
using O
FSL O
’ O
s O
FLIRT O
. O

Each O
block O
of O
individual O
EPI O
data O
was O
registered O
first O
to O
the O
co-planar O
matched-bandwidth O
T2-weighted O
image O
, O
then O
to O
the O
T1-weighted O
MPRAGE O
( O
both O
using O
affine O
transformations O
; O
6 O
degrees O
of O
freedom O
) O
and O
finally O
, O
to O
Montreal O
Neurological O
Institute O
( O
MNI O
) O
standard O
space O
( O
affine O
transformation O
, O
12 O
degrees O
of O
freedom O
) O
. O

2.2.3 O
. O

Behavioral O
data O
analysis O
Task O
accuracy O
was O
recorded O
as O
percentage O
of O
correct O
responses O
during O
target O
trials O
as O
well O
as O
reaction O
time O
of O
correctly O
performed O
trials O
. O

Group O
differences O
in O
accuracy O
and O
reaction O
time O
were O
assessed O
separately O
using O
analysis O
of O
variance O
( O
ANOVA O
; O
p O
< O
.05 O
) O
. O

2.2.4 O
. O

Psychophysiological O
interaction O
( O
PPI O
) O
fMRI O
analysis O
Functional O
connectivity O
within O
and O
between O
dorsal O
and O
ventral O
attention O
networks O
during O
target O
detection O
was O
examined O
using O
whole-brain O
PPI O
analyses O
. O

Seed O
regions O
of O
interest O
( O
ROI O
) O
were O
created O
by O
placing O
a O
9 O
mm O
radius O
sphere O
around O
the O
coordinates O
listed O
below O
. O

Locations O
of O
ROI O
are O
illustrated O
in O
Figure O
1 O
. O

The O
seed O
regions O
for O
the O
ventral O
attention O
network O
( O
right O
TPJ O
) O
and O
the O
dorsal O
network O
( O
right O
IPS O
) O
were O
defined O
based O
on O
peak O
coordinates O
identified O
by O
a O
recent O
meta-analysis O
of O
visual O
and O
auditory O
oddball O
tasks O
in O
healthy O
controls O
( O
right O
TPJ O
MNI O
coordinates O
: O
56 O
, O
-38,22 O
; O
right O
IPS O
MNI O
coordinates O
: O
42 O
, O
-48,44 O
) O
. O

The O
seed O
ROI O
were O
defined O
at O
the O
group O
level O
in O
standard O
space O
and O
projected O
back O
to O
each O
individual O
subject O
’ O
s O
preprocessed O
functional O
data O
in O
their O
native O
space O
. O

The O
time O
course O
from O
each O
seed O
ROI O
was O
then O
extracted O
for O
each O
subject O
. O

A O
lower-level O
general O
linear O
model O
( O
GLM O
) O
was O
constructed O
for O
each O
subject O
using O
FSL O
’ O
s O
fMRI O
Expert O
Analysis O
Tool O
( O
FEAT O
) O
with O
four O
main O
regressors O
. O

A O
psychological O
regressor O
represented O
the O
experimental O
task O
variable O
of O
interest O
( O
“ O
targets O
” O
vs O
“ O
non-targets O
” O
) O
, O
modeled O
by O
convolution O
with O
a O
double-gamma O
canonical O
hemodynamic O
response O
function O
. O

A O
physiological O
regressor O
represented O
task-related O
BOLD O
activation O
in O
a O
priori O
seed O
regions O
( O
right O
TPJ O
for O
the O
ventral O
network O
and O
right O
IPS O
for O
the O
dorsal O
network O
) O
. O

An O
interaction O
regressor O
was O
used O
to O
model O
the O
interaction O
between O
the O
“ O
targets O
” O
vs O
“ O
non-targets O
” O
psychological O
regressor O
and O
the O
physiological O
regressor O
. O

An O
additional O
regressor O
of O
non-interest O
modeled O
shared O
variance O
between O
targets O
and O
non-targets O
( O
i.e. O
, O
“ O
targets O
” O
+ O
“ O
non-targets O
” O
) O
to O
improve O
overall O
model O
fit O
. O

Six O
parameters O
for O
motion O
correction O
were O
included O
as O
regressors O
of O
non-interest O
. O

From O
the O
lower-level O
parameter O
estimate O
maps O
, O
a O
second-level O
fixed-effects O
analysis O
was O
performed O
to O
average O
across O
the O
three O
task O
blocks O
for O
each O
participant O
. O

The O
resulting O
contrast O
images O
were O
entered O
into O
a O
group-level O
random-effects O
analysis O
using O
the O
FLAME O
( O
FMRIB O
’ O
s O
Local O
Analysis O
of O
Mixed O
Effects O
) O
stage O
1 O
module O
. O

At O
the O
group O
level O
, O
participant O
task O
performance O
was O
included O
to O
ensure O
that O
group O
effects O
were O
not O
attributable O
to O
group O
differences O
in O
accuracy O
and O
reaction O
time O
. O

Results O
were O
subjected O
to O
pre-threshold O
masking O
to O
constrain O
the O
search O
to O
areas O
activated O
by O
the O
target O
vs O
non-target O
contrast O
from O
the O
regional O
analysis O
of O
data O
( O
using O
a O
threshold O
of O
Z O
> O
3.1 O
, O
p O
< O
.05 O
) O
. O

This O
masking O
served O
to O
mitigate O
effects O
of O
a O
large O
amount O
of O
de-activation O
present O
in O
all O
subjects O
during O
non-target O
stimuli O
. O

Finally O
, O
resulting O
within O
group O
activation O
maps O
were O
thresholded O
at O
Z O
> O
2.3 O
, O
p O
< O
0.05 O
, O
cluster-corrected O
for O
whole-brain O
multiple O
comparisons O
to O
control O
for O
family O
wise O
Type O
I O
error O
rate O
. O

Family-based O
case-control O
study O
of O
homotopic O
connectivity O
in O
first-episode O
, O
drug-naive O
schizophrenia O
at O
rest O
Family-based O
case-control O
design O
is O
rarely O
used O
but O
powerful O
to O
reduce O
the O
confounding O
effects O
of O
environmental O
factors O
on O
schizophrenia O
. O

Twenty-eight O
first-episode O
, O
drug-naive O
patients O
with O
schizophrenia O
, O
28 O
family-based O
controls O
( O
FBC O
) O
, O
and O
40 O
healthy O
controls O
( O
HC O
) O
underwent O
resting-state O
functional O
MRI O
. O

Voxel-mirrored O
homotopic O
connectivity O
( O
VMHC O
) O
, O
receiver O
operating O
characteristic O
curve O
( O
ROC O
) O
, O
and O
support O
vector O
machine O
( O
SVM O
) O
were O
used O
to O
process O
the O
data O
. O

Compared O
with O
the O
FBC O
, O
the O
patients O
showed O
lower O
VMHC O
in O
the O
precuneus O
, O
fusiform O
gyrus/cerebellum O
lobule O
VI O
, O
and O
lingual O
gyrus/cerebellum O
lobule O
VI O
. O

The O
patients O
exhibited O
lower O
VMHC O
in O
the O
precuneus O
relative O
to O
the O
HC O
. O

ROC O
analysis O
exhibited O
that O
the O
VMHC O
values O
in O
these O
brain O
regions O
might O
not O
be O
ideal O
biomarkers O
to O
distinguish O
the O
patients O
from O
the O
FBC/HC O
. O

However O
, O
SVM O
analysis O
indicated O
that O
a O
combination O
of O
VMHC O
values O
in O
the O
precuneus O
and O
lingual O
gyrus/cerebellum O
lobule O
VI O
might O
be O
used O
as O
a O
potential O
biomarker O
to O
distinguish O
the O
patients O
from O
the O
FBC O
with O
a O
sensitivity O
of O
96.43 O
% O
, O
a O
specificity O
of O
89.29 O
% O
, O
and O
an O
accuracy O
of O
92.86 O
% O
. O

Results O
suggested O
that O
patients O
with O
schizophrenia O
have O
decreased O
homotopic O
connectivity O
in O
the O
motor O
and O
low O
level O
sensory O
processing O
regions O
. O

Neuroimaging O
studies O
can O
adopt O
family-based O
case-control O
design O
as O
a O
viable O
option O
to O
reduce O
the O
confounding O
effects O
of O
environmental O
factors O
on O
schizophrenia O
. O

Materials O
and O
Methods O
Participants O
This O
study O
was O
conducted O
in O
accordance O
with O
the O
Helsinki O
Declaration O
. O

Thirty O
right-handed O
patients O
were O
recruited O
from O
Mental O
Health O
Center O
of O
the O
First O
Affiliated O
Hospital O
, O
Guangxi O
Medical O
University O
in O
China O
. O

Clinical O
diagnosis O
was O
made O
in O
accordance O
with O
the O
Structured O
Clinical O
Interview O
of O
the O
DSM-IV O
( O
SCID O
) O
. O

To O
reduce O
the O
heterogeneity O
of O
symptom O
manifestations O
, O
only O
patients O
with O
paranoid O
schizophrenia O
were O
enrolled O
. O

The O
patients O
, O
who O
aged O
from O
18 O
to O
30 O
years O
old O
with O
more O
than O
9 O
years O
of O
education O
, O
were O
first-episode O
and O
drug-naive O
at O
the O
scan O
time O
. O

The O
illness O
duration O
was O
less O
than O
3 O
years O
. O

Patients O
who O
had O
neurological O
disorders O
, O
severe O
medical O
disorders O
, O
substance O
abuse O
, O
or O
electroconvulsive O
therapy O
were O
excluded O
. O

Symptom O
severity O
was O
rated O
using O
the O
Positive O
and O
Negative O
Symptom O
Scale O
( O
PANSS O
) O
. O

Thirty O
right-handed O
unaffected O
siblings O
of O
the O
patients O
were O
recruited O
as O
the O
FBC O
. O

Each O
patient O
was O
matched O
with O
one O
sibling O
from O
the O
same O
family O
. O

Forty-two O
right-handed O
HC O
were O
recruited O
from O
the O
community O
. O

The O
FBC O
and O
the O
HC O
were O
screened O
by O
SCID O
, O
non-patient O
edition O
. O

The O
age O
of O
the O
controls O
ranged O
from O
18 O
to O
30 O
years O
, O
and O
their O
education O
level O
was O
more O
than O
9 O
years O
. O

None O
of O
the O
controls O
had O
any O
neurological O
disorders O
, O
severe O
medical O
disorders O
, O
substance O
abuse O
or O
psychiatric O
disorders O
. O

Written O
informed O
consent O
was O
acquired O
from O
each O
participant O
prior O
to O
data O
collection O
. O

This O
study O
was O
approved O
by O
the O
local O
ethics O
committee O
of O
the O
First O
Affiliated O
Hospital O
, O
Guangxi O
Medical O
University O
. O

Data O
acquisition O
and O
preprocessing O
MRI O
images O
were O
obtained O
on O
a O
Siemens O
( O
Trio O
) O
3T O
scanner O
. O

Data O
Processing O
Assistant O
for O
Resting-State O
fMRI O
( O
DPARSF O
) O
software O
( O
version O
2.3 O
) O
was O
applied O
to O
preprocess O
the O
images O
. O

Details O
on O
data O
acquisition O
and O
preprocessing O
were O
provided O
in O
Supplementary O
files O
. O

VMHC O
analysis O
VMHC O
analysis O
was O
conducted O
with O
the O
REST O
software O
( O
version O
1.8 O
) O
. O

For O
each O
participant O
, O
homotopic O
FC O
was O
calculated O
as O
the O
Pearson O
correlation O
coefficient O
between O
each O
voxel O
’ O
s O
residual O
time O
series O
and O
that O
of O
its O
interhemispheric O
mirrored O
voxel O
. O

The O
coefficients O
were O
then O
Fisher O
z-transformed O
, O
and O
VMHC O
maps O
were O
generated O
for O
each O
participant O
. O

For O
each O
group O
, O
one-sample O
t-tests O
were O
applied O
to O
identify O
voxels O
that O
exhibited O
significant O
correlations O
with O
their O
mirrored O
counterparts O
. O

The O
significance O
level O
was O
set O
at O
p O
< O
0.05 O
for O
multiple O
comparisons O
corrected O
by O
Gaussian O
Random O
Field O
( O
GRF O
) O
theory O
( O
voxel O
significance O
: O
p O
< O
0.001 O
, O
cluster O
significance O
: O
p O
< O
0.05 O
) O
. O

Analyses O
of O
covariance O
( O
ANCOVA O
) O
, O
followed O
by O
post O
hoc O
t-tests O
( O
paired-sample O
t-tests O
were O
used O
to O
compare O
group O
differences O
between O
the O
patients O
and O
the O
FBC O
) O
, O
were O
performed O
to O
compare O
group O
differences O
within O
the O
union O
mask O
of O
one-sample O
t-tests O
of O
the O
three O
groups O
. O

Age O
and O
years O
of O
education O
were O
used O
as O
covariates O
to O
minimize O
the O
potential O
effects O
of O
these O
variables O
. O

Framewise O
displacement O
( O
FD O
) O
values O
were O
computed O
for O
each O
participant O
as O
described O
in O
a O
previous O
study O
, O
and O
FD O
was O
used O
as O
a O
covariate O
in O
the O
group O
comparisons O
. O

The O
significance O
level O
was O
set O
at O
p O
< O
0.05 O
( O
GRF O
corrected O
) O
. O

Correlation O
analysis O
Once O
significant O
group O
differences O
were O
found O
in O
any O
brain O
regions O
, O
the O
mean O
z O
values O
of O
these O
brain O
regions O
were O
extracted O
to O
assess O
the O
correlations O
between O
abnormal O
VMHC O
values O
and O
symptom O
severity O
in O
the O
patients O
. O

The O
correlation O
results O
were O
Bonferroni O
corrected O
at O
p O
< O
0.05 O
. O

To O
determine O
whether O
abnormal O
VMHC O
values O
were O
correlated O
in O
the O
patients O
and O
the O
FBC O
, O
we O
made O
a O
mask O
on O
the O
deficit O
clusters O
of O
the O
VMHC O
results O
between O
the O
patients O
and O
the O
FBC O
. O

Then O
, O
the O
mean O
z O
values O
within O
the O
mask O
were O
extracted O
in O
the O
patients O
and O
the O
FBC O
. O

Finally O
, O
Pearson O
correlation O
analysis O
was O
performed O
on O
the O
abnormal O
VMHC O
values O
between O
the O
patients O
and O
the O
FBC O
. O

In O
addition O
, O
the O
correlations O
between O
abnormal O
VMHC O
values O
for O
each O
cluster O
were O
computed O
between O
the O
patients O
and O
the O
FBC O
. O

Receiver O
operating O
characteristic O
curve O
( O
ROC O
) O
analysis O
and O
support O
vector O
machine O
( O
SVM O
) O
analysis O
using O
LIBSVM O
ROC O
analysis O
was O
conducted O
to O
determine O
whether O
VMHC O
in O
the O
brain O
regions O
with O
group O
differences O
can O
differentiate O
the O
patients O
from O
the O
controls O
. O

The O
LIBSVM O
software O
package O
( O
http O
: O
//www.csie.ntu.edu.tw/~cjlin/libsvm/ O
) O
in O
Matlab O
was O
applied O
to O
explore O
the O
possibility O
of O
combining O
these O
clusters O
to O
distinguish O
the O
patients O
from O
the O
HC/FBC O
. O

The O
Grid O
search O
method O
and O
Gaussian O
radial O
basis O
function O
kernels O
were O
used O
for O
parameter O
optimization O
. O

The O
“ O
leave-one-out O
” O
cross-validation O
method O
was O
applied O
to O
obtain O
the O
highest O
sensitivity O
and O
specificity O
. O

Language O
Context O
Processing O
Deficits O
in O
Schizophrenia O
: O
The O
Role O
of O
Attentional O
Engagement O
Individuals O
with O
schizophrenia O
exhibit O
problems O
in O
language O
comprehension O
that O
are O
most O
evident O
during O
discourse O
processing O
. O

We O
hypothesized O
that O
deficits O
in O
cognitive O
control O
contribute O
to O
these O
comprehension O
deficits O
during O
discourse O
processing O
, O
and O
investigated O
the O
underlying O
cognitive-neural O
mechanisms O
using O
EEG O
( O
alpha O
power O
) O
and O
ERPs O
( O
N400 O
) O
. O

N400 O
amplitudes O
to O
globally O
supported O
or O
unsupported O
target O
words O
near O
the O
end O
of O
stories O
were O
used O
to O
index O
sensitivity O
to O
previous O
context O
. O

ERPs O
showed O
reduced O
sensitivity O
to O
context O
in O
patients O
versus O
controls O
. O

EEG O
alpha-band O
activity O
was O
used O
to O
index O
attentional O
engagement O
while O
participants O
listened O
to O
the O
stories O
. O

We O
found O
that O
context O
effects O
varied O
with O
attentional O
engagement O
in O
both O
groups O
, O
as O
well O
as O
with O
negative O
symptom O
severity O
in O
patients O
. O

Both O
groups O
demonstrated O
trial-to-trial O
fluctuations O
in O
alpha O
. O

Relatively O
high O
alpha O
power O
was O
associated O
with O
compromised O
discourse O
processing O
in O
participants O
with O
schizophrenia O
when O
it O
occurred O
during O
any O
early O
portion O
of O
the O
story O
. O

In O
contrast O
, O
discourse O
processing O
was O
only O
compromised O
in O
controls O
only O
when O
alpha O
was O
relatively O
high O
for O
longer O
segments O
of O
the O
stories O
. O

Our O
results O
indicate O
that O
shifts O
in O
attention O
from O
the O
story O
context O
may O
be O
more O
detrimental O
to O
discourse O
processing O
for O
participants O
with O
schizophrenia O
than O
for O
controls O
, O
most O
likely O
due O
to O
an O
impaired O
ability O
to O
benefit O
from O
global O
context O
. O

Methods O
Participants O
Thirty O
individuals O
with O
schizophrenia O
or O
a O
schizophrenia-spectrum O
disorder O
and O
27 O
healthy O
controls O
completed O
the O
study O
. O

All O
participants O
provided O
informed O
consent O
prior O
to O
enrollment O
, O
with O
the O
approval O
of O
the O
Institutional O
Review O
Board O
at O
the O
University O
of O
California O
, O
Davis O
. O

All O
participants O
were O
compensated O
at O
a O
rate O
of O
$ O
15 O
per O
hour O
for O
EEG O
and O
behavioral O
testing O
; O
patient O
participants O
were O
compensated O
$ O
25 O
for O
completion O
of O
a O
clinical O
interview O
and O
symptom O
ratings O
session O
. O

Participants O
with O
schizophrenia O
were O
within O
5 O
years O
of O
the O
onset O
of O
their O
psychotic O
symptoms O
, O
and O
were O
recruited O
through O
the O
Early O
Diagnosis O
and O
Preventive O
Treatment O
of O
Psychosis O
( O
EDAPT O
) O
clinic O
at O
the O
University O
of O
California O
, O
Davis O
Medical O
Center O
. O

Four O
participants O
in O
the O
schizophrenia O
( O
SZ O
) O
group O
and O
three O
HC O
were O
ultimately O
excluded O
from O
all O
analyses O
due O
to O
the O
presence O
of O
excessive O
artifacts O
in O
their O
EEG O
data O
( O
see O
EEG O
Recording O
& O
Processing O
section O
below O
for O
details O
) O
. O

Thus O
, O
the O
SZ O
group O
included O
26 O
individuals O
and O
the O
HC O
group O
included O
23 O
individuals O
. O

Participants O
with O
schizophrenia O
ranged O
in O
age O
from O
18–30 O
years O
( O
mean O
: O
22.6 O
) O
; O
81 O
% O
were O
male O
. O

HC O
ranged O
in O
age O
from O
18–29 O
years O
( O
mean O
: O
22 O
) O
; O
74 O
% O
were O
male O
. O

All O
participants O
were O
recruited O
with O
the O
following O
exclusion O
criteria O
: O
( O
1 O
) O
IQ O
below O
70 O
, O
as O
measured O
by O
the O
Wechsler O
Abbreviated O
Scale O
of O
Intelligence O
or O
Wechsler O
Test O
of O
Adult O
Reading O
; O
( O
2 O
) O
history O
of O
neurological O
illness O
, O
including O
head O
injury O
; O
( O
3 O
) O
substance-related O
disorder O
in O
the O
previous O
six O
months O
; O
( O
4 O
) O
uncontrolled O
medical O
illness O
; O
( O
5 O
) O
history O
of O
electro-convulsive O
therapy O
. O

Twenty-four O
of O
the O
26 O
participants O
with O
schizophrenia O
were O
right-handed O
( O
92.3 O
% O
) O
, O
and O
21 O
of O
the O
23 O
HC O
were O
right-handed O
( O
91.3 O
% O
) O
. O

HC O
were O
evaluated O
using O
the O
Structured O
Clinical O
Interview O
for O
DSM-IV-TR O
( O
SCID O
) O
to O
exclude O
those O
with O
a O
history O
of O
an O
Axis O
1 O
disorder O
or O
first-degree O
relatives O
with O
a O
psychotic O
disorder O
. O

All O
participants O
tested O
negative O
on O
a O
urine O
drug O
screen O
test O
immediately O
prior O
to O
completion O
of O
the O
study O
. O

See O
Table O
2 O
for O
additional O
demographic O
information O
. O

Clinical O
and O
Functional O
Characteristics O
Clinicians O
conducted O
all O
diagnostic O
evaluations O
, O
and O
diagnoses O
were O
confirmed O
by O
consensus O
conference O
. O

All O
clinicians O
had O
demonstrated O
reliability O
, O
defined O
by O
> O
.8 O
intra-class O
correlation-coefficients O
for O
continuous O
measures O
, O
and O
kappa O
> O
.7 O
for O
categorical O
measures O
; O
all O
participated O
in O
monthly O
reliability O
checks O
to O
prevent O
drift O
from O
these O
standards O
. O

Clinical O
symptom O
scores O
were O
measured O
using O
the O
Scales O
for O
the O
Assessment O
of O
Positive O
and O
Negative O
Symptoms O
( O
SAPS O
and O
SANS O
) O
. O

EEG O
Task O
Stimuli O
The O
stimuli O
consisted O
of O
80 O
story O
sets O
. O

A O
set O
was O
comprised O
of O
two O
conditions O
of O
the O
same O
story O
: O
Animate O
and O
Inanimate O
. O

Stories O
were O
translated O
from O
Dutch O
to O
English O
and O
adapted O
for O
the O
purposes O
of O
the O
current O
study O
from O
those O
used O
in O
. O

Each O
story O
contained O
4 O
sentences O
. O

For O
all O
stories O
, O
an O
inanimate O
, O
cartoon-like O
character O
was O
introduced O
in O
the O
first O
sentence O
( O
e.g O
. O

a O
peanut O
that O
is O
described O
as O
happy O
and O
smiling O
) O
. O

The O
passages O
were O
written O
so O
that O
each O
sentence O
reinforced O
that O
the O
normally O
inanimate O
object O
( O
e.g. O
, O
the O
peanut O
) O
served O
as O
an O
animate O
character O
in O
this O
context O
. O

This O
was O
accomplished O
by O
references O
in O
the O
first O
three O
sentences O
to O
the O
character O
using O
pronouns O
reserved O
for O
animate O
characters O
( O
he/she O
) O
, O
and O
by O
the O
use O
of O
verbs O
and O
descriptions O
likewise O
reserved O
for O
animate O
characters O
( O
e.g O
. O

the O
peanut O
had O
a O
big O
smile… O
; O
the O
peanut O
was O
amazed… O
) O
. O

Then O
, O
in O
sentence O
4 O
, O
the O
character O
was O
described O
using O
a O
critical O
word O
that O
requires O
an O
animate O
or O
inanimate O
object O
to O
fill O
one O
of O
its O
thematic O
roles O
. O

This O
critical O
word O
was O
therefore O
consistent O
with O
either O
the O
immediately O
preceding O
context O
( O
cartoon-style O
context-Animate O
critical O
word O
) O
, O
or O
inconsistent O
( O
cartoon-style O
context-Inanimate O
critical O
word O
) O
. O

Inanimate O
critical O
words O
were O
chosen O
to O
be O
consistent O
with O
the O
most O
typical O
, O
non-cartoon-style O
meaning O
of O
the O
inanimate O
objects O
that O
served O
as O
the O
animate O
character O
. O

See O
Table O
1 O
for O
an O
example O
. O

The O
critical O
words O
( O
e.g O
. O

elated O
, O
salted O
) O
were O
matched O
in O
lexical O
frequency O
, O
length O
and O
number O
of O
syllables O
across O
conditions1 O
. O

To O
measure O
lexical O
frequency O
, O
we O
used O
LG10CD O
values O
from O
the O
SUBTLEXus O
database O
( O
http O
: O
//expsy.ugent.be/subtlexus O
) O
. O

The O
average O
LG10CD O
lexical O
frequency O
value O
for O
critical O
words O
in O
the O
Animate O
condition O
was O
1.94 O
( O
SD O
: O
.62 O
) O
, O
and O
1.8 O
( O
SD O
: O
.66 O
) O
in O
the O
Inanimate O
condition O
. O

Critical O
words O
were O
also O
matched O
in O
length O
and O
number O
of O
syllables O
. O

The O
average O
length O
of O
Animate O
critical O
words O
was O
7.9 O
characters O
( O
SD O
: O
1.7 O
) O
, O
and O
7.5 O
( O
SD O
: O
1.9 O
) O
for O
Inanimate O
critical O
words O
. O

The O
average O
number O
of O
syllables O
of O
Animate O
critical O
words O
was O
2.6 O
( O
SD O
: O
0.8 O
) O
, O
and O
2.4 O
( O
SD O
: O
0.84 O
) O
for O
Inanimate O
critical O
words O
. O

Stimuli O
were O
recorded O
for O
auditory O
presentation O
by O
a O
female O
speaker O
, O
using O
a O
natural O
inflection O
and O
speaking O
rate O
. O

The O
first O
three O
sentences O
of O
each O
passage O
, O
which O
comprised O
the O
discourse O
context O
for O
the O
fourth O
sentence O
( O
which O
contained O
the O
critical O
words O
) O
, O
were O
recorded O
separately O
from O
the O
critical O
fourth O
sentences O
. O

The O
onset O
and O
offset O
of O
all O
critical O
words O
were O
determined O
by O
visual O
inspection O
of O
the O
speech O
waveform O
and O
by O
listening O
to O
the O
waveforms O
using O
speech-editing O
software O
( O
Audacity O
, O
by O
Soundforge O
) O
. O

The O
average O
duration O
of O
the O
critical O
words O
was O
637.6 O
ms O
( O
range O
: O
366- O
974 O
ms O
) O
; O
the O
critical O
words O
did O
not O
differ O
in O
duration O
between O
conditions O
( O
p=.4 O
) O
. O

One O
hundred O
and O
sixty O
filler O
stories O
of O
comparable O
length O
and O
structure O
were O
also O
included O
. O

These O
served O
as O
experimental O
stories O
for O
a O
separate O
study O
, O
and O
also O
consisted O
of O
spoken O
4-sentence O
stories O
, O
but O
did O
not O
feature O
cartoon-style O
protagonists O
. O

Instead O
, O
the O
filler O
stories O
featured O
canonically O
animate O
protagonists O
in O
non-anomalous O
scenarios O
( O
e.g O
. O

a O
seamstress O
mending O
clothes O
) O
. O

These O
stories O
included O
a O
syntactic O
manipulation O
in O
which O
a O
prepositional O
phrase O
in O
the O
fourth O
sentence O
attached O
to O
the O
main O
verb O
or O
attached O
to O
the O
direct O
object O
( O
e.g O
. O

repaired O
the O
sock O
with O
the O
thread/hole O
) O
. O

Comprehension O
questions O
followed O
all O
stories O
( O
experimental O
items O
and O
fillers O
) O
. O

The O
correct O
answer O
to O
half O
of O
the O
questions O
was O
true O
, O
whereas O
the O
correct O
answer O
to O
the O
other O
half O
was O
false O
. O

Stimuli O
were O
divided O
into O
four O
lists O
for O
presentation O
, O
such O
that O
each O
list O
contained O
40 O
stories O
in O
each O
condition O
( O
Animate O
, O
Inanimate O
) O
, O
and O
no O
list O
contained O
both O
conditions O
of O
the O
same O
item O
. O

Stimuli O
for O
Behavioral O
Tasks O
In O
addition O
to O
the O
EEG O
task O
, O
participants O
completed O
three O
behavioral O
tasks O
designed O
to O
assess O
vocabulary O
, O
working O
memory O
, O
and O
cognitive O
control O
( O
the O
Nelson-Denny O
vocabulary O
test O
, O
Listening O
Span O
, O
and O
the O
AX-CPT O
, O
respectively O
) O
. O

All O
participants O
completed O
the O
vocabulary O
section O
of O
the O
Nelson-Denny O
Reading O
Test O
, O
a O
standardized O
paper O
and O
pencil O
multiple-choice O
assessment O
. O

Participants O
were O
allotted O
15 O
minutes O
to O
complete O
the O
section O
. O

Vocabulary O
is O
strongly O
predictive O
of O
language O
comprehension O
abilities O
and O
was O
employed O
in O
this O
study O
to O
examine O
individual O
variation O
in O
the O
ERP/EEG O
data O
that O
may O
be O
due O
to O
variability O
in O
verbal O
ability O
. O

Nelson-Denny O
vocabulary O
scores O
were O
calculated O
as O
the O
total O
percent O
correct O
for O
the O
vocabulary O
section O
, O
Form O
G O
( O
out O
of O
80 O
possible O
) O
. O

The O
Listening O
Span O
task O
was O
adapted O
from O
and O
consisted O
of O
25 O
sets O
of O
sentences O
ranging O
from O
two O
to O
six O
sentences O
per O
set O
; O
there O
were O
five O
sets O
of O
each O
set O
size O
. O

Participants O
were O
instructed O
to O
listen O
to O
all O
sentences O
within O
each O
set O
for O
comprehension O
and O
then O
to O
indicate O
whether O
each O
sentence O
was O
true O
or O
false O
immediately O
after O
hearing O
it O
. O

In O
addition O
, O
participants O
were O
instructed O
to O
remember O
the O
final O
word O
of O
each O
sentence O
in O
the O
set O
and O
were O
asked O
to O
recall O
them O
in O
any O
order O
after O
the O
whole O
set O
was O
presented O
. O

There O
was O
a O
1500 O
ms O
pause O
between O
each O
sentence O
during O
which O
participants O
made O
their O
true/false O
response O
. O

Presentation O
of O
sets O
was O
random O
. O

Each O
correct O
response O
( O
accurate O
final O
word O
recall O
) O
was O
scored O
as O
one O
point O
, O
for O
a O
maximum O
of O
100 O
points O
. O

The O
AX-CPT O
was O
designed O
to O
assess O
cognitive O
control O
mechanisms O
, O
specifically O
the O
ability O
to O
maintain O
task O
goals O
and O
task-relevant O
context O
. O

The O
version O
used O
here O
was O
developed O
as O
part O
of O
the O
CNTRACS O
( O
Cognitive O
Neuroscience O
Test O
Reliability O
and O
Clinical O
applications O
for O
Schizophrenia O
) O
initiative O
, O
and O
is O
freely O
available O
via O
the O
CNTRACS O
website O
( O
http O
: O
//cntracs.ucdavis.edu/task/dpx O
) O
. O

In O
this O
task O
, O
participants O
respond O
to O
a O
series O
of O
letters O
via O
key O
press O
. O

They O
are O
told O
to O
respond O
with O
their O
index O
finger O
only O
to O
the O
letter O
X O
( O
target O
) O
and O
only O
when O
the O
X O
is O
preceded O
by O
the O
letter O
A O
( O
cue O
) O
; O
they O
are O
asked O
to O
respond O
with O
a O
middle O
finger O
button O
press O
to O
all O
other O
letters O
. O

A-X O
cue-probe O
target O
sequences O
are O
frequent O
( O
70 O
% O
) O
and O
set O
up O
a O
tendency O
to O
make O
a O
target O
response O
when O
the O
letter O
X O
occurs O
. O

Therefore O
, O
participants O
often O
make O
errors O
when O
the O
letter O
X O
appears O
, O
but O
was O
not O
preceded O
by O
an O
A O
( O
e.g. O
, O
X O
preceded O
by O
the O
letter O
B O
) O
. O

Good O
performance O
involves O
the O
ability O
to O
attend O
to O
the O
context O
in O
which O
the O
letter O
X O
occurs O
and O
to O
maintain O
the O
task O
goal O
throughout O
processing O
. O

D-prime O
values O
were O
computed O
as O
a O
measure O
of O
context O
processing O
, O
using O
accuracy O
on O
AX O
trials O
, O
controlling O
for O
errors O
on O
BX O
trials O
. O

This O
provides O
a O
measure O
of O
the O
ability O
to O
maintain O
context O
( O
having O
just O
seen O
an O
A O
) O
in O
order O
to O
correctly O
respond O
to O
the O
target O
( O
X O
) O
, O
taking O
into O
account O
false O
alarms O
to O
BX O
trials O
( O
d O
’ O
context O
= O
z O
( O
AX O
accuracy O
) O
- O
z O
( O
BX O
error O
) O
) O
. O

Procedure O
Stimuli O
were O
presented O
through O
Beyer O
dynamic O
headphones O
using O
Presentation O
software O
( O
Neurobehavioral O
Systems O
) O
. O

Trials O
began O
with O
a O
white O
fixation O
marker O
at O
the O
center O
of O
the O
screen O
. O

The O
fixation O
marker O
was O
present O
from O
1000 O
ms O
before O
stimulus O
onset O
and O
remained O
on O
the O
screen O
throughout O
presentation O
of O
the O
story O
. O

Following O
story O
offset O
, O
the O
fixation O
marker O
remained O
on O
the O
screen O
for O
1000 O
ms O
, O
and O
was O
then O
replaced O
by O
a O
true/false O
comprehension O
question O
. O

Questions O
never O
queried O
information O
from O
the O
fourth O
sentence O
, O
which O
contained O
the O
critical O
target O
words O
. O

Participants O
were O
asked O
to O
make O
a O
true/false O
response O
via O
button O
press O
. O

Comprehension O
questions O
remained O
on O
the O
screen O
until O
participants O
responded O
. O

Each O
stimulus O
list O
was O
divided O
into O
20 O
blocks O
for O
presentation O
. O

Participants O
completed O
the O
20 O
blocks O
from O
one O
list O
over O
two O
EEG O
sessions O
. O

Each O
session O
began O
with O
a O
practice O
block O
consisting O
of O
8 O
stories O
. O

Lists O
and O
blocks O
were O
presented O
in O
counterbalanced O
order O
across O
participants O
. O

Participants O
completed O
the O
behavioral O
tasks O
after O
the O
second O
EEG O
session O
. O

EEG O
Recording O
& O
Processing O
EEG O
was O
recorded O
from O
29 O
tin O
electrodes O
fitted O
in O
an O
elastic O
cap O
( O
ElectroCap O
International O
) O
. O

The O
right O
mastoid O
electrode O
was O
used O
as O
the O
recording O
reference O
for O
all O
electrodes O
except O
those O
used O
to O
measure O
eye-movements O
. O

For O
these O
, O
electrodes O
above O
and O
below O
the O
left O
eye O
were O
referenced O
to O
each O
other O
and O
used O
to O
measure O
blinks O
; O
in O
addition O
, O
two O
electrodes O
at O
the O
outer O
canthi O
of O
each O
eye O
were O
referenced O
to O
each O
other O
and O
used O
to O
measure O
other O
eye-movements O
. O

Recordings O
from O
a O
left O
mastoid O
electrode O
were O
also O
obtained O
, O
and O
used O
for O
later O
re-referencing O
offline O
to O
the O
algebraic O
average O
of O
both O
mastoids O
. O

EEG O
was O
recorded O
using O
a O
Neuroscan O
Synamps O
2 O
system O
, O
and O
digitized O
at O
a O
rate O
of O
500 O
Hz O
, O
with O
half-amplitude O
cutoffs O
of O
.05 O
to O
100 O
Hz O
. O

Electrode O
impedances O
were O
kept O
below O
5 O
kΩ O
. O

MATLAB O
( O
Mathworks O
) O
was O
used O
to O
process O
and O
analyze O
data O
, O
with O
the O
EEGlab O
toolbox O
and O
ERPlab O
plugin O
, O
along O
with O
custom O
MATLAB O
code O
. O

Independent O
component O
analysis O
( O
ICA O
) O
was O
used O
to O
correct O
for O
artifacts O
caused O
by O
blinks O
, O
and O
single-trial O
waveforms O
were O
additionally O
screened O
for O
horizontal O
eye-movements O
, O
and O
any O
remaining O
blinks O
or O
movement-related O
artifacts O
. O

These O
artifact O
correction O
and O
rejection O
procedures O
were O
performed O
using O
epochs O
of O
1200 O
ms O
for O
ERP O
analysis O
time-locked O
to O
the O
critical O
words O
( O
−200 O
to O
1000 O
ms O
with O
respect O
to O
critical O
word O
onset O
) O
. O

Baseline O
correction O
was O
performed O
using O
a O
−200 O
to O
0 O
ms O
window O
relative O
to O
critical O
word O
onset O
. O

Average O
ERPs O
were O
computed O
using O
artifact-free O
trials O
in O
each O
of O
the O
two O
conditions O
. O

Four O
participants O
in O
the O
schizophrenia O
group O
and O
three O
in O
the O
healthy O
control O
group O
were O
excluded O
from O
all O
analyses O
because O
too O
few O
artifact-free O
trials O
( O
< O
20 O
per O
condition O
) O
remained O
following O
artifact O
correction O
and O
rejection O
procedures O
. O

The O
remaining O
participants O
in O
the O
HC O
group O
( O
N=23 O
) O
had O
an O
average O
of O
33 O
artifact-free O
Animate O
trials O
( O
SD O
: O
5.1 O
) O
and O
32 O
artifact-free O
Inanimate O
trials O
( O
SD O
: O
5.5 O
) O
. O

The O
remaining O
participants O
in O
the O
SZ O
group O
( O
N=26 O
) O
had O
an O
average O
of O
31 O
artifact-free O
Animate O
trials O
( O
SD O
: O
5.8 O
) O
and O
30 O
artifact-free O
Inanimate O
trials O
( O
SD O
: O
5.8 O
) O
. O
