, O
other O
medical O
condition O
affecting O
the O
brain O
( O
ex O
. O

Epilepsy O
) O
, O
severe O
psychiatric O
disability O
that O
would O
prevent O
participation O
( O
ex O
. O

psychosis O
or O
mania O
) O
, O
substance O
use O
by O
the O
participant O
, O
English O
as O
a O
second O
language O
, O
international O
adoption O
after O
age O
5 O
or O
within O
2 O
years O
of O
study O
visit O
, O
or O
contraindications O
to O
MRI O
scanning O
. O

Control O
participants O
were O
excluded O
for O
parent-reported O
history O
of O
prenatal O
substance O
exposure O
and O
for O
diagnosed O
psychiatric O
conditions O
. O

Parents O
or O
caregivers O
of O
all O
participants O
were O
administered O
the O
Diagnostic O
Interview O
Schedule O
for O
Children-IV O
( O
C-DISC-4.0 O
. O

Because O
pre-screening O
was O
utilized O
during O
recruitment O
, O
the O
DISC O
data O
for O
enrolled O
participants O
revealed O
only O
minimal O
parent-reported O
symptoms O
in O
the O
control O
group O
( O
2 O
controls O
had O
ADHD O
symptoms O
, O
5 O
had O
Oppositional O
Defiant O
symptoms O
, O
and O
3 O
had O
Conduct O
Disorder O
symptoms O
; O
no O
controls O
had O
anxiety O
or O
depressive O
symptoms O
or O
other O
major O
psychiatric O
symptoms O
) O
. O

Psychiatric O
co-morbidity O
was O
not O
an O
exclusion O
criterion O
for O
participants O
with O
PAE O
because O
it O
is O
well-recognized O
that O
co-morbidity O
is O
high O
in O
FASD O
. O

Based O
on O
the O
C-DISC-IV O
data O
, O
54 O
participants O
in O
the O
PAE O
group O
had O
ADHD O
symptoms O
, O
34 O
had O
Oppositional O
Defiant O
symptoms O
, O
13 O
had O
Conduct O
Disorder O
symptoms O
, O
6 O
had O
anxiety O
disorder O
symptoms O
, O
and O
4 O
had O
depressive O
disorder O
symptoms O
. O

Participants O
were O
7-17 O
year O
old O
at O
the O
time O
of O
neurocognitive O
evaluation O
and O
MRI O
scanning O
. O

The O
vast O
majority O
of O
participants O
completed O
the O
neurocognitive O
evaluation O
and O
MRI O
on O
the O
same O
day O
. O

In O
a O
few O
cases O
, O
they O
were O
separated O
by O
a O
few O
days O
or O
weeks O
. O

A O
total O
of O
165 O
participants O
( O
87 O
with O
PAE O
& O
78 O
Controls O
) O
met O
inclusion O
criteria O
. O

Table O
1 O
contains O
the O
demographics O
for O
the O
participants O
who O
were O
included O
in O
the O
analyses O
after O
eliminating O
those O
with O
excessive O
movement O
and O
incomplete O
networks O
( O
see O
results O
for O
complete O
description O
) O
. O

All O
participants O
underwent O
an O
Institutional O
Review O
Board O
( O

) O
-approved O
informed O
consent O
process O
involving O
a O
parent O
or O

as O
well O
as O
a O

process O
with O
the O
child O
. O

All O
study O
procedures O
were O
approved O
by O
the O

at O
each O
of O
the O
four O
sites O
. O

Participants O
were O
compensated O
for O
their O
time O
. O

Neurobehavioral O
Evaluation O
Primary O
caregivers O
were O
administered O
specific O
modules O
from O
the O
C-DISC-4 O
, O
a O
computerized O
structured O
interview O
based O
on O
the O
DSM-IV O
. O

Neuropsychological O
testing O
was O
conducted O
during O
one O
or O
two O
sessions O
by O
trained O
research O
assistants O
who O
were O
blind O
to O
exposure O
status O
. O

Quality O
control O
methods O
included O
a O
video O
review O
of O
test O
administration O
procedures O
and O
a O
scoring O
check O
for O
every O
10th O
administration O
. O

From O
a O
larger O
battery O
of O
neuropsychological O
measures O
administered O
in O
CIFASD O
, O
specific O
measures O
were O
chosen O
for O
analyses O
here O
based O
on O
domains O
that O
showed O
relationships O
with O
FC O
in O
previous O
studies O
. O

These O
include O
the O
Differential O
Ability O
Scales O
– O
Second O
Edition O
( O
DAS-II O
) O
, O
the O
California O
Verbal O
Learning O
Test O
– O
Children O
's O
Edition O
( O
CVLT-C O
) O
, O
the O
Delis-Kaplan O
Executive O
Functioning O
System O
( O
D-KEFS O
) O
, O
and O
the O
NEPSY-II O
Developmental O
Neuropsychological O
Assessment O
. O

MRI O
Acquisition O
Procedures O
MRI O
data O
were O
acquired O
at O
four O
sites O
on O
scanners O
from O
three O
vendors O
: O
Children O
's O
Hospital O
of O
Los O
Angeles O
( O
Philips O
Achieva O
) O
; O
University O
of O
California O
– O
San O
Diego O
( O
General O
Electric O
MR750 O
) O
; O
University O
of O
Minnesota O
and O
Emory O
University O
( O
both O
Siemens O
Tim O
Trio O
) O
. O

Acquisition O
sequences O
were O
modeled O
on O
protocols O
developed O
for O
multi-site O
imaging O
by O
the O
Pediatric O
Imaging O
Neurocognition O
and O
Genetics O
( O
PING O
) O
group O
( O
Table O
2 O
) O
( O
http O
: O
//ping.chd.ucsd.edu O
) O
. O

The O
sequence O
included O
high O
resolution O
T1-weighted O
images O
, O
a O
T2-weighted O
set O
, O
30-direction O
DTI O
, O
and O
gradient-echo O
EPI O
scans O
for O
resting-state O
fMRI O
. O

The O
acquisition O
parameters O
in O
Table O
2 O
are O
just O
those O
for O
data O
examined O
in O
the O
current O
set O
of O
analyses O
( O
T1 O
and O
fMRI O
) O
. O

Participants O
were O
not O
sedated O
for O
the O
MRI O
scan O
nor O
were O
their O
usual O
medications O
modified O
. O

During O
the O
resting-state O
fMRI O
scan O
, O
participants O
were O
instructed O
to O
close O
their O
eyes O
and O
remain O
still O
. O

Table O
2 O
contains O
details O
of O
the O
acquisition O
sequences O
by O
site O
. O

MRI O
Processing O
T1 O
Cortical O
Parcellation O
Cortical O
parcellation O
of O
the O
T1 O
volume O
was O
performed O
using O
FreeSurfer O
version O
5.3.0 O
( O
surfer.nmr.mgh.harvard.edu O
) O
and O
the O
default O
Desikan-Killiany O
atlas O
. O

Processing O
included O
removal O
of O
non-brain O
tissue O
, O
automated O
Talairach O
transformation O
, O
segmentation O
, O
intensity O
normalization O
, O
tessellation O
of O
the O
grey O
matter O
/ O
white O
matter O
boundary O
, O
topology O
correction O
, O
surface O
deformation O
, O
and O
automated O
parcellation O
of O
the O
cortical O
grey O
matter O
into O
34 O
ROIs O
per O
hemisphere O
. O

Each O
subject O
's O
data O
was O
visually O
inspected O
by O
a O
trained O
operator O
to O
ensure O
accuracy O
of O
the O
cortical O
parcellation O
, O
but O
manual O
editing O
was O
not O
employed O
. O

Resting-State O
Fmri O
Processing O
FMRI O
data O
processing O
was O
carried O
out O
using O
the O
FEAT O
tool O
from O
the O
FMRIB O
Software O
Library O
( O
FSL O
) O
version O
5.0.7 O
( O
http O
: O
//fsl.fmrib.ox.ac.uk/fsl/fslwiki/ O
) O
. O

The O
following O
pre-statistics O
processing O
was O
applied O
: O
motion O
correction O
, O
brain O
extraction O
, O
spatial O
smoothing O
( O
6mm O
FWHM O
) O
, O
grand-mean O
intensity O
normalization O
, O
and O
high O
pass O
temporal O
filtering O
( O
sigma=50s O
) O
. O

Correction O
for O
geometric O
distortion O
caused O
by O
magnetic O
field O
inhomogeneity O
was O
carried O
out O
on O
a O
subset O
of O
data O
: O
those O
data O
that O
were O
collected O
along O
with O
a O
reverse O
phase-encoded O
gradient O
echo O
fMRI O
scan O
acquired O
for O
this O
purpose O
( O
all O
Minnesota O
data O
and O
a O
subset O
of O
the O
Atlanta O
data O
) O
. O

ICA-based O
data O
analysis O
was O
also O
carried O
out O
during O
the O
FEAT O
processing O
step O
using O
the O
FSL O
tool O
MELODIC O
. O

The O
FSL O
tool O
fsl_fix O
was O
then O
used O
to O
perform O
automated O
ICA O
de-noising O
of O
the O
fMRI O
data O
. O

Registration O
of O
the O
T1 O
volume O
to O
the O
fMRI O
data O
was O
performed O
using O
the O
FreeSurfer O
tool O
bbregister O
. O

White O
matter O
and O
CSF O
masks O
were O
created O
on O
the O
fMRI O
data O
by O
registering O
the O
bilateral O
FreeSurfer O
lateral O
ventricle O
and O
white O
matter O
ROIs O
using O
the O
bbregister-determined O
transform O
applied O
using O
the O
FSL O
tool O
FLIRT O
. O

Timecourses O
from O
the O
CSF O
and O
white O
matter O
ROIs O
along O
with O
the O
six O
motion O
parameters O
were O
then O
used O
as O
voxel-wise O
nuisance O
regressors O
in O
processing O
the O
fMRI O
data O
with O
the O
FSL O
tool O
film_gls O
. O

To O
further O
reduce O
artifactual O
correlations O
within O
the O
fMRI O
data O
, O
volume O
scrubbing O
was O
applied O
to O
the O
data O
using O
methods O
outlined O
in O
. O

Time-Series O
Extraction O
The O
68 O
Freesurfer O
cortical O
ROIs O
( O
34 O
per O
hemisphere O
) O
were O
registered O
to O
the O
processed O
fMRI O
data O
using O
bbregister O
. O

The O
parcellations O
were O
dilated O
during O
registration O
, O
but O
none O
were O
allowed O
to O
overlap O
and O
voxels O
outside O
the O
brain-mask O
were O
excluded O
. O

ROIs O
that O
contained O
fewer O
than O
10 O
fMRI O
voxels O
for O
any O
participant O
were O
excluded O
from O
the O
final O
analysis O
. O

This O
resulted O
in O
the O
exclusion O
of O
6 O
ROIs O
( O
bilateral O
entorhinal O
, O
frontal O
pole O
and O
temporal O
pole O
) O
, O
leaving O
a O
total O
of O
62 O
ROIs O
( O
31 O
per O
hemisphere O
) O
. O

The O
mean O
fMRI O
time-series O
of O
all O
voxels O
within O
each O
ROI O
were O
then O
extracted O
for O
each O
participant O
. O

Computation O
Of O
The O
Network O
Metrics O
Pearson O
correlations O
were O
computed O
between O
the O
time-series O
from O
all O
possible O
pairs O
of O
the O
62 O
cortical O
ROIs O
using O
MATLAB O
( O
Mathworks O
, O
Natick O
, O
MA O
) O
. O

Graph O
theory O
network O
metrics O
were O
computed O
for O
each O
subject O
's O
Pearson O
correlation O
matrix O
utilizing O
tools O
from O
the O
BCT O
toolbox O
( O
http O
: O
//sites.google.com/a/brain-connectivity-toolbox.net/bct/Home O
) O
. O

Cortical O
ROIs O
served O
as O
network O
nodes O
and O
correlation O
values O
served O
as O
the O
connections O
( O
edges O
) O
. O

The O
cost O
of O
a O
network O
is O
defined O
as O
the O
ratio O
of O
existing O
connections O
to O
the O
total O
number O
of O
possible O
connections O
in O
the O
graph O
( O
( O
62 O
* O
61 O
) O
/ O
2 O
= O
1891 O
for O
a O
62 O
node O
network O
) O
. O

Binary O
, O
non-weighted O
and O
non-directional O
adjacency O
matrices O
were O
determined O
by O
applying O
a O
participant-specific O
threshold O
to O
each O
participant O
's O
data O
across O
a O
range O
of O
costs O
from O
0.1 O
to O
0.5 O
, O
with O
0.05 O
step O
increments O
. O

Four O
metrics O
of O
interest O
were O
derived O
: O
characteristic O
path O
length O
, O
mean O
clustering O
coefficient O
, O
local O
efficiency O
and O
global O
efficiency O
. O

Path O
length O
is O
the O
smallest O
number O
of O
connections O
that O
must O
be O
traversed O
to O
connect O
any O
pair O
of O
nodes O
in O
the O
network O
. O

The O
characteristic O
path O
length O
( O
CPL O
) O
is O
the O
average O
path O
length O
between O
all O
pairs O
of O
nodes O
in O
the O
network O
. O

A O
higher O
than O
normal O
CPL O
implies O
less O
reliance O
on O
highly O
efficient O
“ O
trunk-lines O
” O
for O
long O
distance O
communication O
and O
more O
reliance O
on O
multiple O
smaller O
“ O
jumps O
” O
between O
regions O
. O

The O
mean O
clustering O
coefficient O
( O
MCC O
) O
reflects O
the O
density O
of O
local O
connections O
. O

Global O
efficiency O
( O
GLOB O
) O
, O
inversely O
related O
to O
path O
length O
, O
reflects O
properties O
of O
the O
network O
associated O
with O
long-range O
connections O
that O
facilitate O
rapid O
communication O
between O
remote O
brain O
regions O
; O
it O
is O
thought O
to O
reflect O
the O
network O
's O
capacity O
for O
parallel O
information O
propagation O
and O
processing O
. O

In O
contrast O
, O
local O
efficiency O
( O
LOC O
) O
is O
thought O
to O
reflect O
properties O
of O
the O
network O
associated O
with O
modular O
processing O
within O
more O
localized O
brain O
regions O
. O

In O
network O
graph O
mathematics O
, O
cost O
has O
implications O
for O
overall O
topography O
of O
the O
network O
and O
there O
are O
multiple O
costs O
at O
which O
the O
network O
metrics O
can O
be O
examined O
. O

We O
examined O
the O
networks O
at O
a O
cost O
at O
which O
all O
participants O
had O
fully-connected O
networks O
. O

A O
fully-connected O
network O
contains O
at O
least O
one O
possible O
pathway O
between O
every O
node O
. O

Statistical O
Analyses O
Demographic O
data O
were O
tested O
for O
group O
differences O
using O
independent-samples O
t-tests O
and O
chi-square O
analyses O
. O

T-tests O
and O
chi-square O
analyses O
tested O
for O
differences O
between O
participants O
who O
were O
included O
in O
the O
study O
vs O
those O
who O
were O
excluded O
. O

T-tests O
were O
used O
to O
test O
for O
differences O
in O
motion O
parameters O
between O
the O
PAE O
group O
and O
controls O
. O

Prior O
to O
the O
primary O
analyses O
, O
a O
number O
of O
potential O
confounding O
factors O
were O
examined O
by O
testing O
for O
group O
differences O
using O
ANVOA O
. O

If O
no O
significant O
group O
differences O
were O
found O
across O
levels O
of O
the O
potentially O
confounding O
variable O
, O
the O
variable O
was O
not O
controlled O
for O
in O
subsequent O
analyses O
. O

Primary O
analyses O
comparing O
groups O
( O
PAE O
vs. O
control O
) O
on O
network O
connectivity O
measures O
consisted O
of O
independent O
samples O
t-tests O
. O

The O
impact O
of O
multiple O
comparisons O
was O
addressed O
with O
Benjamini O
and O
Hochberg O
False O
Discovery O
Rate O
( O
FDR O
) O
correction O
. O

A O
multiple O
ANOVA O
was O
utilized O
to O
test O
for O
group O
differences O
( O
PAE O
vs. O
control O
) O
in O
neurocognitive O
functioning O
. O

Lastly O
, O
Pearson O
correlations O
were O
used O
to O
directly O
examine O
relationships O
between O
network O
connectivity O
metrics O
and O
performance O
on O
neurocognitive O
tests O
. O

The O
metabolic O
basis O
of O
cognitive O
insight O
in O
psychosis O
: O
A O
positron O
emission O
tomography O
study O
The O
purpose O
of O
this O
study O
was O
to O
investigate O
the O
relationship O
between O
cognitive O
insight O
and O
cerebral O
metabolism O
in O
patients O
suffering O
from O
psychosis O
. O

The O
Beck O
Cognitive O
Insight O
Scale O
( O
BCIS O
) O
was O
administered O
to O
63 O
patients O
with O
psychosis O
undergoing O
Positron O
Emission O
Tomography O
investigation O
. O

The O
sample O
was O
divided O
into O
two O
groups O
considering O
the O
BCIS O
score O
. O

Data O
were O
analyzed O
using O
Statistical O
Parametric O
Mapping O
. O

Results O
: O
patients O
with O
low O
insight O
, O
compared O
to O
those O
with O
high O
insight O
, O
showed O
decreased O
metabolism O
in O
the O
right O
fusiform O
gyrus O
, O
left O
precuneus O
, O
superior O
temporal O
gyrus O
and O
insula O
bilaterally O
, O
as O
well O
as O
increased O
metabolism O
in O
the O
left O
orbito-frontal O
gyrus O
( O
all O
p O
< O
0.005 O
) O
. O

Our O
results O
suggest O
that O
reduced O
posterior O
( O
occipito-temporo-insulo-parietal O
) O
and O
increased O
anterior O
( O
orbitofrontal O
) O
cerebral O
metabolism O
may O
sustain O
low O
cognitive O
insight O
in O
psychosis O
. O

2 O
. O

Methods O
and O
materials O
2.1 O
Participants O
Sixty-three O
inpatients O
( O
17 O
women O
and O
46 O
men O
) O
, O
aged O
between O
18 O
and O
65 O
years O
, O
with O
acute O
psychosis O
according O
to O
the O
DSM-IV-TR O
( O
APA O
, O
2000 O
) O
criteria O
were O
enrolled O
in O
the O
current O
study O
. O

Thirty-six O
were O
diagnosed O
with O
affective O
psychosis O
( O
all O
with O
bipolar O
disorder O
type O
I O
) O
and O
twenty-seven O
with O
non-affective O
psychosis O
( O
10 O
with O
schizophrenia O
, O
17 O
with O
psychosis O
NOS O
) O
( O
for O
details O
see O
Tables O
1 O
and O
2 O
) O
. O

Exclusion O
criteria O
were O
cognitive O
deterioration O
( O
score O
lower O
than O
24 O
) O
as O
assessed O
by O
the O
Mini-Mental O
State O
Examination O
( O
MMSE O
) O
, O
consistent O
with O
normative O
data O
in O
the O
Italian O
population O
, O
or O
comorbidity O
with O
other O
neurological O
conditions O
involving O
Central O
Nervous O
System O
( O
e.g O
. O

cerebral O
tumors O
) O
and O
pregnancy O
or O
breastfeeding O
. O

The O
study O
was O
approved O
by O
the O
local O
Ethical O
Committee O
( O
Comitato O
Etico O
, O
Fondazione O
“ O
IRCCS O
Ca O
’ O
Granda O
” O
Policlinico O
di O
Milano O
) O
and O
informed O
written O
consent O
was O
obtained O
from O
all O
subjects O
. O

Capacity O
to O
consent O
was O
determined O
through O
clinical O
interview O
and O
MMSE O
, O
in O
order O
to O
assess O
the O
absence O
of O
cognitive O
deterioration O
. O

2.2 O
. O

Clinical O
assessment O
Diagnoses O
were O
conducted O
at O
baseline O
with O
the O
Structured O
Clinical O
Interview O
for O
DSM-IV-TR O
, O
Axis O
I. O
Socio-demographic O
data O
were O
collected O
by O
an O
interview O
completed O
by O
experts O
. O

Clinical O
assessment O
was O
carried O
out O
with O
the O
Brief O
Psychiatric O
Rating O
Scale O
( O
BPRS O
) O
to O
evaluate O
severity O
and O
change O
of O
psychotic O
and O
mood O
symptoms O
. O

Cognitive O
insight O
was O
quantified O
with O
the O
BCIS O
self-report O
inventory O
. O

The O
subscales O
“ O
self-reflectiveness O
” O
( O
formed O
by O
9 O
items O
) O
and O
“ O
self-certainty O
” O
( O
formed O
by O
6 O
items O
) O
are O
defined O
to O
measure O
separate O
aspects O
of O
cognitive O
insight O
. O

They O
rate O
the O
patients O
' O
ability O
to O
observe O
their O
mental O
productions O
and O
to O
reflect O
on O
alternative O
explanations O
and O
overconfidence O
in O
the O
validity O
of O
their O
beliefs O
. O

Accordingly O
, O
among O
psychotic O
patients O
an O
optimal O
cognitive O
insight O
is O
given O
by O
the O
results O
of O
high O
self-reflectiveness O
and O
low O
self-certainty O
; O
a O
composite O
index O
reflecting O
cognitive O
insight O
is O
the O
resulting O
difference O
between O
the O
two O
series O
. O

In O
the O
absence O
of O
cognitive O
insight O
, O
this O
index O
will O
have O
negative O
values O
. O

2.3 O
. O

FDG-PET O
scanning O
FDG-PET O
scanning O
was O
performed O
within O
7 O
days O
of O
insight O
and O
symptom O
assessment O
. O

Patients O
underwent O
FDG-PET O
at O
rest O
, O
after O
intravenous O
injection O
of O
170 O
MBq O
. O

Each O
acquisition O
included O
a O
Computed O
Tomography O
( O
CT O
) O
transmission O
scan O
of O
the O
head O
( O
50mAs O
lasting O
16 O
seconds O
) O
followed O
by O
a O
three-dimensional O
( O
3D O
) O
static O
emission O
of O
15 O
minutes O
using O
a O
Biograph O
Truepoint O
64 O
PET/CT O
scanner O
( O
Siemens O
) O
. O

FDG-PET O
sections O
were O
reconstructed O
using O
an O
iterative O
algorithm O
( O
OS-EM O
) O
, O
corrected O
for O
scatter O
and O
for O
attenuation O
using O
density O
coefficients O
derived O
from O
the O
low O
dose O
CT O
scan O
of O
the O
head O
obtained O
with O
the O
same O
scanner O
, O
with O
the O
proprietary O
software O
. O

Images O
were O
reconstructed O
in O
the O
form O
of O
transaxial O
images O
of O
128×128 O
pixels O
of O
2 O
mm O
, O
using O
an O
iterative O
algorithm O
, O
ordered-subset O
expectation O
maximization O
( O
OSEM O
) O
. O

The O
resolution O
of O
the O
PET O
system O
was O
4–5 O
mm O
FWHM O
. O

2.4 O
. O

Statistical O
analysis O
The O
statistical O
analyses O
were O
performed O
using O
Statistical O
Parametric O
Mapping O
( O
SPM8 O
, O
Wellcome O
Department O
of O
Cognitive O
Neurology O
, O
London O
, O
UK O
) O
. O

FDG O
PET O
data O
were O
subjected O
to O
affine O
and O
nonlinear O
spatial O
normalization O
into O
the O
MNI O
space O
. O

The O
spatially O
normalized O
set O
of O
images O
was O
smoothed O
with O
an O
8mm O
isotropic O
Gaussian O
filter O
to O
blur O
for O
individual O
variations O
in O
gyral O
anatomy O
and O
increase O
the O
signal-to-noise O
ratio O
. O

Images O
were O
globally O
normalized O
to O
50 O
using O
proportional O
scaling O
to O
remove O
confounding O
effects O
to O
global O
cerebral O
glucose O
consumption O
changes O
, O
with O
a O
masking O
threshold O
of O
0.8 O
. O

Subjects O
were O
divided O
into O
four O
groups O
considering O
the O
BCIS O
score O
( O
low O
insight O
with O
R-C O
= O
< O
5 O
and O
high O
insight O
with O
R-C O
> O
5 O
, O
see O
Table O
3 O
) O
and O
the O
diagnosis O
( O
affective O
vs O
non O
affective O
psychosis O
) O
. O

The O
choice O
of O
the O
cut-off O
of O
5 O
to O
divide O
the O
two O
FDG-PET O
groups O
with O
different O
BCIS O
composite O
index O
score O
( O
= O
< O
5 O
and O
> O
5 O
) O
was O
motivated O
by O
the O
average O
value O
( O
4,64 O
) O
shown O
in O
psychotic O
patients O
in O
the O
literature O
, O
similar O
to O
the O
median O
BCIS O
scores O
of O
our O
group O
of O
patients O
. O

We O
performed O
two-sample O
t-test O
between O
the O
low O
and O
the O
high O
insight O
groups O
to O
determine O
if O
the O
data O
were O
significantly O
different O
, O
considering O
P O
values O
< O
0.05 O
as O
statistically O
significant O
. O

We O
found O
no O
statistical O
differences O
between O
the O
two O
groups O
in O
any O
of O
the O
demographic O
or O
clinical O
variables O
employed O
in O
this O
study O
, O
including O
age O
( O
p O
= O
0,335 O
) O
, O
sex O
( O
χ2 O
= O
0,544 O
, O
p O
= O
0,461 O
) O
duration O
of O
illness O
( O
p O
= O
0,123 O
) O
and O
the O
BPRS O
scores O
( O
p O
= O
0,142 O
) O
. O

Finally O
, O
we O
found O
no O
significant O
differences O
between O
the O
two O
groups O
for O
the O
diagnosis O
( O
χ2 O
= O
0,049 O
, O
p O
= O
0,825 O
) O
. O

Significant O
differences O
in O
brain O
metabolism O
among O
the O
four O
groups O
( O
non O
affective O
psychosis O
with O
low O
insight O
, O
non O
affective O
psychosis O
with O
high O
insight O
, O
affective O
psychosis O
with O
low O
insight O
, O
and O
affective O
psychosis O
with O
high O
insight O
) O
were O
estimated O
by O
means O
of O
single-subject O
, O
conditions O
and O
covariates O
design O
, O
with O
the O
4 O
groups O
of O
psychosis O
modeled O
as O
conditions O
, O
with O
insight O
score O
as O
covariate O
variable O
of O
all O
patients O
and O
age O
as O
the O
nuisance O
variable O
for O
group O
analyses O
. O

First O
, O
we O
performed O
a O
one-way O
analysis O
of O
variance O
( O
ANOVA O
) O
between O
the O
four O
groups O
. O

Then O
, O
we O
performed O
two-sample O
t-test O
between O
pair O
of O
groups O
with O
low O
insight O
compared O
to O
those O
with O
high O
insight O
. O

All O
voxel-based O
statistical O
analyses O
of O
brain O
glucose O
metabolism O
images O
were O
performed O
by O
applying O
a O
statistical O
threshold O
of O
uncorrected O
p O
< O
0.005 O
at O
voxel O
level O
for O
F-test O
and O
p O
< O
0.005 O
corrected O
at O
cluster O
level O
for O
t-test O
, O
with O
an O
extent O
threshold O
of O
at O
least O
35 O
contiguous O
voxels O
. O

P O
values O
< O
0.005 O
were O
considered O
statistically O
significant O
in O
analysis O
of O
covariance O
to O
correlate O
the O
cognitive O
insight O
score O
with O
the O
metabolism O
. O

Abnormal O
resting-state O
functional O
connectivity O
in O
the O
orbitofrontal O
cortex O
of O
heroin O
users O
and O
its O
relationship O
with O
anxiety O
: O
a O
pilot O
fNIRS O
study O
Drug O
addiction O
is O
widely O
linked O
to O
the O
orbitofrontal O
cortex O
( O
OFC O
) O
, O
which O
is O
essential O
for O
regulating O
reward-related O
behaviors O
, O
emotional O
responses O
, O
and O
anxiety O
. O

Over O
the O
past O
two O
decades O
, O
neuroimaging O
has O
provided O
significant O
contributions O
revealing O
functional O
and O
structural O
alternations O
in O
the O
brains O
of O
drug O
addicts O
. O

However O
, O
the O
underlying O
neural O
mechanism O
in O
the O
OFC O
and O
its O
correlates O
with O
drug O
addiction O
and O
anxiety O
still O
require O
further O
elucidation O
. O

We O
first O
presented O
a O
pilot O
investigation O
to O
examine O
local O
networks O
in O
OFC O
regions O
through O
resting-state O
functional O
connectivity O
( O
rsFC O
) O
using O
functional O
near-infrared O
spectroscopy O
( O
fNIRS O
) O
from O
eight O
abstinent O
addicts O
in O
a O
heroin-dependent O
group O
( O
HD O
) O
and O
seven O
subjects O
in O
a O
control O
group O
( O
CG O
) O
. O

We O
discovered O
that O
the O
HDs O
manifested O
enhanced O
interhemispheric O
correlation O
and O
rsFC O
. O

Moreover O
, O
small-worldness O
was O
explored O
in O
the O
brain O
networks O
. O

In O
addition O
to O
the O
altered O
rsFC O
in O
the O
OFC O
networks O
, O
our O
examinations O
demonstrated O
associations O
in O
the O
functional O
connectivity O
between O
the O
left O
inferior O
frontal O
gyrus O
and O
other O
OFC O
regions O
related O
to O
anxiety O
in O
the O
HDs O
. O

The O
study O
provides O
important O
preliminary O
evidence O
of O
the O
complex O
OFC O
networks O
in O
heroin O
addiction O
and O
suggests O
neural O
correlates O
of O
anxiety O
. O

It O
opens O
a O
window O
in O
application O
of O
fNIRS O
to O
predict O
psychiatric O
trajectories O
and O
may O
create O
new O
insights O
into O
neural O
adaptations O
resulting O
from O
chronic O
opiate O
intake O
. O

Methods O
Participants O
From O
May O
5 O
, O
2015 O
to O
September O
15 O
, O
2015 O
, O
eight O
abstinent O
HD O
individuals O
were O
recruited O
from O
a O
local O
drug O
rehabilitation O
treatment O
center O
in O
Macao O
SAR O
and O
seven O
control O
subjects O
from O
the O
local O
community O
were O
enrolled O
with O
demographic O
factors O
matching O
those O
of O
the O
HDs O
( O
i.e. O
, O
age O
, O
education O
level O
, O
IQ O
, O
and O
years O
of O
smoking O
; O
Table O
1 O
) O
. O

All O
the O
subjects O
were O
smokers O
. O

In O
order O
to O
control O
for O
the O
effects O
of O
nicotine O
, O
daily O
cigarette O
consumption O
of O
the O
CGs O
was O
matched O
with O
the O
HDs O
. O

The O
protocol O
was O
approved O
by O
the O
Medial O
Ethics O
Committee O
of O
the O
University O
of O
Macau O
. O

The O
experiments O
were O
performed O
in O
accordance O
with O
the O
relevant O
guidelines O
and O
regulations O
in O
the O
latest O
version O
of O
the O
Declaration O
of O
Helsinki O
. O

After O
being O
providing O
with O
an O
informed O
description O
of O
the O
study O
procedures O
, O
all O
the O
participants O
signed O
informed O
consent O
forms O
prior O
to O
the O
experiments O
. O

The O
inclusion O
criteria O
for O
all O
the O
participants O
were O
as O
follows O
: O
( O
1 O
) O
aged O
18–65 O
years O
old O
, O
( O
2 O
) O
right-handed O
, O
( O
3 O
) O
Cantonese O
speakers O
, O
and O
( O
4 O
) O
normal O
or O
corrected-to-normal O
vision O
. O

The O
exclusion O
criteria O
for O
all O
the O
participants O
were O
as O
follows O
: O
( O
1 O
) O
history O
of O
neurological O
illness O
or O
psychiatric O
disorder O
other O
than O
heroin O
and O
nicotine O
dependence O
, O
( O
2 O
) O
reported O
additional O
use O
of O
psychoactive O
substances O
at O
least O
72 O
hours O
before O
any O
measurement O
, O
and O
( O
3 O
) O
history O
of O
head O
trauma O
or O
brain O
injury O
. O

All O
the O
HD O
subjects O
had O
a O
history O
of O
more-than-20-years O
of O
heroin O
abuse O
. O

Local O
medical O
doctors O
confirmed O
the O
diagnoses O
of O
drug O
addiction O
. O

All O
the O
participants O
were O
required O
to O
complete O
a O
preclinical O
interview O
performed O
by O
a O
local O
psychological O
counselor O
prior O
to O
inclusion O
in O
the O
study O
. O

The O
Structured O
Clinical O
Interview O
for O
DSM-IV O
( O
SCID O
) O
was O
used O
in O
the O
interview O
to O
verify O
opioid O
dependence O
, O
and O
the O
State-Trait O
Anxiety O
Inventory O
( O
STAI O
) O
was O
adopted O
to O
measure O
the O
degree O
of O
anxiety O
. O

None O
of O
the O
HD O
subjects O
had O
received O
any O
formal O
psychotherapeutic O
training O
. O

Information O
on O
the O
subjects O
’ O
demographic O
characteristics O
is O
provided O
in O
Table O
1 O
. O

After O
the O
preclinical O
interview O
, O
a O
urine O
sample O
was O
collected O
from O
each O
subject O
for O
mandatory O
drug O
screening O
to O
ensure O
that O
the O
subject O
had O
not O
taken O
any O
psychoactive O
drugs O
other O
than O
heroin O
and O
methadone O
before O
any O
assessments O
or O
recordings O
. O

Subjects O
were O
compensated O
with O
a O
small O
fee O
upon O
their O
completion O
of O
the O
experiment O
. O

The O
medication O
and O
substance-use O
status O
of O
the O
subjects O
is O
provided O
in O
Supplementary O
Information O
S7 O
. O

Experimental O
design O
The O
subjects O
were O
instructed O
to O
sit O
comfortably O
on O
a O
chair O
in O
a O
quiet O
and O
dim O
room O
. O

All O
the O
subjects O
underwent O
two O
sessions O
of O
fNIRS O
recordings O
of O
neural O
activities O
of O
the O
OFC O
. O

The O
first O
session O
was O
an O
11-min O
resting-state O
recording O
followed O
by O
the O
second O
session O
, O
an O
approximately O
3-minute O
gambling O
localizer O
task O
. O

During O
the O
resting-state O
session O
, O
the O
subjects O
were O
asked O
to O
close O
their O
eyes O
, O
relax O
their O
muscles O
and O
mind O
, O
think O
of O
nothing O
, O
remain O
still O
and O
make O
the O
least O
possible O
amount O
of O
motion O
, O
but O
to O
stay O
awake O
and O
alert O
. O

After O
the O
resting-state O
recording O
, O
the O
subjects O
were O
instructed O
to O
open O
their O
eyes O
to O
conduct O
a O
gambling O
task O
to O
retrain O
the O
OFC O
regions O
for O
further O
rsFC O
analysis O
. O

In O
the O
rsFC O
analysis O
, O
four O
functional O
connectivity O
methods O
were O
utilized O
to O
generate O
regional O
brain O
networks O
related O
to O
drug O
addiction O
, O
which O
included O
: O
( O
1 O
) O
interhemispheric O
correlation O
analysis O
, O
( O
2 O
) O
functional O
connectivity O
measurements O
generated O
by O
seed-based O
and O
whole-brain O
correlation O
analyses O
, O
( O
3 O
) O
graph-theory O
network O
analysis O
, O
and O
( O
4 O
) O
linear O
regression O
analysis O
( O
for O
experimental O
design O
details O
, O
see O
Supplementary O
Figure O
S1 O
) O
. O

fNIRS O
data O
acquisition O
The O
experiments O
were O
performed O
using O
a O
continuous O
wave O
( O
CW O
) O
fNIRS O
instrument O
with O
three O
sources O
and O
eight O
detectors O
( O
CW6 O
fNIRS O
system O
; O
TechEn O
Inc O
, O
Milford O
, O
MA O
) O
, O
as O
shown O
in O
Fig O
. O

7 O
. O

In O
this O
system O
, O
two O
CW O
lights O
at O
wavelengths O
of O
690 O
nm O
and O
830 O
nm O
were O
emitted O
at O
each O
source O
fiber O
, O
which O
provided O
sensitive O
detection O
of O
changes O
in O
both O
the O
HbO O
and O
Hb O
concentrations O
in O
the O
human O
brain O
. O

The O
configuration O
of O
the O
source-detector O
pairs O
is O
shown O
in O
Fig O
. O

7 O
, O
in O
which O
the O
sources O
and O
detectors O
were O
connected O
by O
optical O
fibers O
on O
the O
scalp O
to O
generate O
twelve O
fNIRS O
measurement O
channels O
covering O
the O
bilateral O
and O
medial O
OFC O
regions O
, O
which O
were O
positioned O
accurately O
based O
on O
the O
10–20 O
system O
. O

Each O
set O
of O
one O
source O
and O
four O
detectors O
covered O
one O
particular O
OFC O
, O
resulting O
in O
four O
ROIs O
; O
i.e. O
, O
the O
right O
lOFC O
, O
the O
left O
lOFC O
, O
the O
right O
mOFC O
, O
and O
the O
left O
mOFC O
( O
see O
Supplementary O
Table O
S2 O
) O
. O

The O
MNI O
coordinates O
of O
the O
channels O
were O
estimated O
using O
Homer2 O
( O
www.homer-fnirs.org/documentation O
) O
and O
its O
AtlasViewerGUI O
with O
the O
widely O
adopted O
automated O
anatomical O
labeling O
( O
AAL O
) O
. O

The O
three-dimensional O
locations O
of O
the O
fNIRS O
probes O
were O
also O
visualized O
with O
the O
NIRS-SPM O
software O
( O
http O
: O
//bispl.weebly.com/nirs-spm.html O
# O
/ O
) O
. O

The O
source-detector O
distance O
was O
30 O
mm O
, O
measuring O
the O
brain O
activity O
of O
the O
cerebral O
cortex O
with O
a O
penetration O
depth O
of O
2–3 O
cm O
. O

The O
sampling O
rate O
of O
our O
fNIRS O
system O
was O
50 O
Hz O
. O

Using O
MATLAB O
( O
MathWorks O
, O
Inc. O
, O
Natick O
, O
MA O
, O
USA O
) O
and O
BrainNet O
Viewer O
( O
https O
: O
//www.nitrc.org/projects/bnv O
) O
, O
statistical O
outcomes O
for O
each O
channel O
were O
shown O
on O
the O
surface O
of O
a O
normalized O
and O
a O
standardized O
brain O
. O

Preprocessing O
data O
All O
the O
resting-state O
fNIRS O
data O
were O
preprocessed O
using O
Homer2 O
. O

For O
the O
resting-state O
data O
, O
the O
first O
2-minute O
measurements O
were O
eliminated O
to O
generate O
relatively O
steady O
signals O
and O
rule O
out O
potential O
effects O
of O
unstable O
signals O
before O
rsFC O
analysis O
. O

For O
the O
localized O
task O
data O
, O
the O
first O
30-second O
recordings O
were O
eliminated O
for O
the O
recording O
signals O
to O
reach O
a O
steady O
rate O
. O

The O
following O
preprocessing O
procedures O
were O
performed O
for O
all O
the O
fNIRS O
data O
: O
( O
1 O
) O
Conversion O
of O
optical O
density O
measurements O
to O
concentration O
changes O
in O
HbO O
and O
Hb O
at O
different O
time O
points O
based O
on O
the O
modified O
Beer-Lambert O
Law O
; O
( O
2 O
) O
Bandpass O
filtering O
( O
resting-state O
: O
0.01 O
< O
fr O
< O
0.1 O
; O
task O
: O
0.012 O
< O
ft O
< O
0.18 O
in O
Hz O
) O
; O
( O
3 O
) O
Detrending O
; O
and O
( O
4 O
) O
Motion O
correction O
using O
the O
spline O
interpolation O
method O
and O
a O
correlation-based O
signal O
improvement O
( O
CBSI O
) O
method O
. O

To O
ensure O
high-quality O
fNIRS O
data O
for O
the O
rsFC O
network O
analyses O
, O
motion-induced O
artifacts O
and O
low O
signal-to-noise O
ratios O
( O
SNRs O
) O
were O
examined O
with O
an O
open-source O
package O
, O
FC_NIRS O
( O
https O
: O
//www.nitrc.org/projects/fcnirs/ O
) O
. O

Any O
data O
with O
low O
average O
signal O
intensity O
over O
five O
standard O
deviations O
of O
the O
HbO O
and O
Hb O
concentrations O
over O
time O
( O
i.e. O
, O
lower O
SNRs O
) O
were O
considered O
to O
result O
from O
poor O
contact O
between O
the O
optode O
and O
scalp O
and O
thus O
were O
excluded O
from O
the O
rsFC O
and O
network O
analyses O
. O

One O
CG O
subject O
’ O
s O
channel O
11 O
was O
excluded O
. O

For O
task-based O
fNIRS O
data O
, O
the O
HbO O
and O
Hb O
signals O
from O
each O
channel O
across O
all O
the O
subjects O
were O
extracted O
for O
statistical O
analysis O
to O
determine O
the O
seed O
channels O
for O
the O
rsFC O
analysis O
. O

For O
rsFC O
and O
graph O
analyses O
, O
two O
thresholding O
strategies O
were O
applied O
: O
( O
1 O
) O
a O
single O
threshold O
representing O
the O
absolute O
connectivity O
strength O
was O
chosen O
, O
and O
( O
2 O
) O
the O
entire O
range O
of O
relative O
sparsity O
thresholds O
and O
average O
graph O
property O
values O
over O
the O
range O
were O
studied O
. O

By O
applying O
these O
thresholding O
strategies O
together O
, O
we O
hoped O
to O
provide O
a O
comprehensive O
way O
to O
examine O
the O
network O
organizations O
of O
both O
groups O
. O

Interhemispheric O
correlation O
analysis O
We O
used O
interhemispheric O
correlations O
to O
demonstrate O
the O
long-range O
connectivity O
of O
the O
right O
and O
left O
lateral O
OFC O
( O
lOFC O
) O
and O
medial O
OFC O
( O
mOFC O
) O
in O
both O
the O
HDs O
and O
CGs O
. O

All O
ROIs O
within O
the O
OFC O
were O
investigated O
for O
local O
connectivity O
between O
the O
right O
and O
left O
hemispheres O
( O
see O
Supplementary O
Table O
S2 O
) O
. O

The O
typical O
patterns O
observed O
in O
the O
cortical O
blood O
flow O
during O
brain O
activation O
are O
an O
increase O
in O
HbO O
and O
a O
decrease O
in O
Hb O
. O

As O
the O
regions O
covered O
by O
the O
channels O
were O
very O
close O
to O
each O
other O
anatomically O
, O
we O
assume O
that O
the O
long-range O
activation O
plays O
a O
role O
in O
the O
connectivity O
because O
the O
interhemispheric O
correlations O
analysis O
is O
designed O
to O
study O
a O
long-distance O
brain O
connectivity O
that O
is O
likely O
connected O
to O
the O
intravascular O
( O
HbO O
and O
Hb O
) O
events O
between O
hemispheres O
. O

Therefore O
both O
HbO O
and O
Hb O
were O
considered O
for O
the O
interhemispheric O
analysis O
. O

Pearson O
’ O
s O
correlation O
coefficient O
between O
the O
time O
course O
of O
every O
channel O
and O
the O
matching O
symmetrical O
measurement O
channel O
in O
the O
other O
hemisphere O
from O
the O
selected O
ROI O
in O
the O
OFC O
system O
( O
overall O
, O
lOFC O
and O
mOFC O
) O
was O
calculated O
, O
and O
the O
mean O
correlation O
coefficient O
was O
then O
calculated O
for O
all O
related O
channels O
in O
each O
ROI O
. O

Functional O
connectivity O
measurements O
: O
seed-based O
and O
whole-brain O
correlation O
analyses O
To O
analyze O
the O
rsFC O
of O
the O
HDs O
and O
CGs O
, O
we O
used O
two O
approaches O
: O
( O
1 O
) O
a O
seed-based O
correlation O
analysis O
and O
( O
2 O
) O
a O
whole-brain O
correlation O
analysis O
. O

The O
former O
approach O
was O
used O
in O
order O
to O
estimate O
and O
detect O
the O
strength O
of O
pairwise O
relationships O
between O
a O
predefined O
seed O
channel O
and O
other O
channels O
covering O
other O
OFC O
regions O
. O

This O
allowed O
us O
to O
identify O
intrinsic O
functional O
connectivity O
in O
different O
OFC O
region O
systems O
. O

The O
second O
approach O
aimed O
to O
compute O
a O
functional O
connectivity O
map O
between O
any O
two O
channel O
pairs O
in O
the O
entire O
OFC O
system O
, O
where O
the O
measurement O
channels O
represented O
nodes O
, O
and O
the O
functional O
connections O
with O
correlation O
coefficients O
greater O
than O
a O
predefined O
threshold O
were O
considered O
edges O
. O

The O
change O
in O
HbO O
concentration O
is O
recognized O
to O
be O
the O
most O
responsive O
indicator O
of O
differences O
in O
cortical O
blood O
flow O
. O

We O
believe O
that O
HbO O
signals O
would O
be O
responsive O
enough O
to O
indicate O
changes O
in O
the O
local O
activity O
in O
the O
regions O
covered O
by O
the O
channels O
that O
were O
not O
far O
apart O
from O
each O
other O
as O
abovementioned O
. O

For O
simplicity O
, O
HbO O
was O
therefore O
considered O
for O
the O
remainder O
of O
the O
analyses O
. O

The O
Hb O
data O
was O
served O
as O
a O
reference O
only O
when O
needed O
. O

The O
gambling O
localizer O
task O
data O
were O
processed O
using O
a O
general O
linear O
model O
to O
estimate O
the O
task-induced O
response O
of O
each O
channel O
from O
each O
subject O
. O

The O
run O
averages O
of O
the O
normalized O
HbO O
data O
were O
first O
calculated O
for O
each O
channel O
, O
and O
then O
grand O
average O
results O
across O
all O
subjects O
by O
group O
were O
calculated O
and O
analyzed O
. O

A O
statistical O
t-test O
was O
performed O
to O
infer O
which O
channel O
was O
most O
significantly O
( O
p O
< O
0.05 O
) O
activated O
by O
the O
localizer O
task O
( O
see O
Supplementary O
Figure O
S3 O
) O
. O

The O
channel O
( O
s O
) O
and O
the O
corresponding O
channel O
( O
s O
) O
on O
the O
other O
hemisphere O
were O
then O
defined O
as O
the O
seeds O
for O
the O
rsFC O
analysis O
. O

For O
the O
resting-state O
data O
, O
functional O
connectivity O
was O
then O
constructed O
based O
on O
the O
seed-based O
and O
whole-brain O
correlation O
methods O
; O
thus O
, O
functional O
connectivity O
matrices O
and O
maps O
were O
first O
generated O
from O
group O
adjacencies O
computed O
from O
the O
individual O
adjacencies O
for O
the O
brain O
network O
analysis O
. O

For O
both O
the O
seed-based O
and O
whole-brain O
correlation O
methods O
, O
Pearson O
’ O
s O
correlation O
was O
used O
to O
weigh O
the O
strength O
of O
functional O
connectivity O
of O
the O
pairwise O
relationships O
between O
the O
selected O
seed O
channel O
and O
other O
channels O
and O
between O
any O
two O
node O
pairs O
within O
the O
entire O
OFC O
system O
in O
our O
study O
. O

Prior O
to O
any O
statistical O
analysis O
, O
the O
correlation O
values O
were O
converted O
to O
Fisher O
z-values O
using O
the O
Fisher O
z-transformation O
. O

Thus O
, O
the O
distribution O
of O
the O
Z O
to O
R O
correlation O
coefficients O
pairwise O
in O
the O
OFC O
can O
be O
observed O
in O
two O
groups O
using O
the O
seed-base O
analysis O
, O
and O
the O
neural O
network O
generated O
within O
the O
entire O
OFC O
regions O
between O
the O
groups O
can O
be O
explored O
using O
the O
whole-brain O
approach O
. O

Graph-theory O
network O
analysis O
To O
quantify O
rsFC O
for O
complex O
network O
analysis O
, O
powerful O
graph-theory O
approach O
was O
adopted O
to O
compare O
the O
fNIRS-based O
topological O
properties O
of O
the O
brain O
networks O
between O
the O
HDs O
and O
the O
CGs O
. O

Using O
the O
free O
software O
, O
GRETNA O
( O
http O
: O
//www.nitrc.org/projects/gretna O
) O
, O
the O
preprocessed O
fNIRS O
data O
with O
N O
nodes O
were O
used O
to O
form O
an O
N-by-N O
correlation O
matrix O
in O
which O
each O
value O
represented O
the O
connectivity O
strength O
. O

The O
network O
measures O
were O
categorized O
into O
global O
and O
nodal O
metrics O
. O

The O
global O
metrics O
used O
included O
small-world O
parameters O
, O
local O
efficiency O
and O
global O
efficiency O
. O

In O
the O
global O
network O
analysis O
, O
two O
important O
small-world O
parameters O
, O
( O
1 O
) O
clustering O
coefficient O
and O
( O
2 O
) O
characteristic O
path O
length O
, O
were O
then O
calculated O
and O
compared O
with O
the O
normalized O
small-world O
parameters O
between O
the O
brain O
networks O
of O
both O
HDs O
and O
CGs O
. O

These O
global O
network O
metrics O
provided O
a O
global O
topological O
framework O
of O
the O
whole-brain O
network O
, O
taking O
into O
account O
all-channel O
networks O
in O
the O
OFC O
system O
. O

In O
the O
nodal O
network O
analysis O
, O
the O
nodal O
degree O
strength O
of O
each O
channel O
and O
efficiency O
was O
examined O
. O

These O
nodal O
metrics O
provided O
information O
on O
the O
regional O
patterns O
of O
the O
functional O
brain O
network O
. O

Traditionally O
, O
a O
small-world O
graph O
is O
one O
where O
the O
clustering O
coefficient O
of O
a O
brain O
network O
is O
higher O
than O
that O
of O
a O
random O
network O
and O
where O
the O
path-length O
is O
characteristically O
similar O
to O
that O
of O
a O
random O
graph O
. O

Thus O
, O
normalization O
of O
clustering O
coefficients O
and O
path-length O
are O
traditionally O
computed O
with O
respect O
to O
random O
networks O
. O

However O
, O
it O
is O
not O
uncommon O
to O
compare O
the O
brain O
networks O
of O
subject O
groups O
to O
detect O
connectivity O
abnormalities O
in O
psychiatric O
disorders O
. O

Intuitively O
, O
in O
addition O
to O
this O
tradition O
, O
we O
wanted O
to O
explore O
whether O
the O
HD O
network O
is O
“ O
small-world O
” O
with O
respect O
to O
the O
CG O
network O
; O
thus O
, O
small-worldness O
was O
computed O
by O
comparing O
the O
HDs O
with O
the O
CGs O
( O
i.e. O
, O
γ O
= O
clustering O
coefficient O
in O
the O
HDs O
÷ O
clustering O
coefficient O
in O
the O
CGs O
; O
λ O
= O
characteristic O
path O
length O
in O
the O
HDs O
÷ O
characteristic O
path O
length O
in O
the O
CGs O
; O
γE O
= O
local O
efficiency O
in O
the O
HDs O
÷ O
local O
efficiency O
in O
the O
CGs O
; O
λE O
= O
global O
efficiency O
in O
the O
HDs O
÷ O
global O
efficiency O
in O
the O
CGs O
) O
. O

As O
such O
, O
this O
preliminary O
investigation O
may O
provide O
a O
direct O
metric O
to O
access O
“ O
small-worldness O
” O
in O
observed O
real-world O
networks O
, O
which O
are O
neither O
uniformly O
random O
nor O
ordered O
. O

A O
two-sample O
t-test O
( O
α O
= O
0.05 O
) O
followed O
by O
a O
correction O
approach O
with O
a O
false O
discovery O
rate O
( O
FDR O
) O
was O
applied O
to O
examine O
whether O
the O
HD O
brain O
network O
acquires O
significantly O
non-control O
and O
non-random O
construction O
. O

Further O
, O
the O
small-world O
network O
measure O
will O
be O
used O
to O
characterize O
differences O
between O
the O
metrics O
of O
the O
traditionally O
normalized O
coefficients O
( O
i.e. O
, O
HDnet/Randomnet O
and O
CGnet/Randomnet O
) O
and O
compare O
with O
the O
metric O
of O
the O
intuitively O
normalized O
ones O
( O
i.e. O
, O
HDnet/CGnet O
) O
. O

Regression O
analyses O
for O
anxiety O
scores O
and O
seed-based O
functional O
connectivity O
Linear O
regression O
analysis O
was O
conducted O
to O
examine O
the O
link O
between O
anxiety O
severity O
( O
STAI O
scores O
) O
and O
functional O
connectivity O
for O
all O
seed O
channels O
. O

Multiple O
regression O
analysis O
was O
performed O
for O
all O
significant O
results O
to O
statistically O
account O
for O
potential O
differences O
in O
age O
, O
years O
of O
education O
, O
IQ O
, O
STAI O
scores O
, O
daily O
cigarette O
consumption O
, O
years O
of O
smoking O
, O
and O
the O
effect O
of O
methadone O
treatment O
. O

The O
seed-based O
functional O
connectivity O
presented O
in O
the O
correlation O
coefficient O
R O
to O
Z O
values O
between O
all O
the O
selected O
seed O
channels O
and O
the O
remainder O
of O
the O
channels O
were O
examined O
with O
the O
anxiety O
scores O
after O
controlling O
for O
the O
covariates O
. O

To O
address O
the O
issue O
of O
multiple O
comparisons O
, O
all O
results O
were O
controlled O
using O
the O
Benjamini–Hochberg O
procedure O
at O
an O
FDR O
< O
10 O
% O
. O

Additional O
Information O
How O
to O
cite O
this O
article O
: O

, O

and O
Yuan O
, O

Abnormal O
resting-state O
functional O
connectivity O
in O
the O
orbitofrontal O
cortex O
of O
heroin O
users O
and O
its O
relationship O
with O
anxiety O
: O
a O
pilot O
fNIRS O
study O
. O

Sci O
. O

Rep. O
7 O
, O
46522 O
; O
doi O
: O
10.1038/srep46522 O
( O
2017 O
) O
. O

Publisher O
's O
note O
: O
Springer O
Nature O
remains O
neutral O
with O
regard O
to O
jurisdictional O
claims O
in O
published O
maps O
and O
institutional O
affiliations O
. O

From O
the O
neurobiological O
basis O
of O
comorbid O
alcohol O
dependence O
and O
depression O
to O
psychological O
treatment O
strategies O
: O
study O
protocol O
of O
a O
randomized O
controlled O
trial O
Background O
Alcohol O
use O
disorder O
and O
depression O
occur O
commonly O
in O
the O
community O
. O

Even O
though O
this O
high-prevalence O
comorbidity O
is O
associated O
with O
poorer O
posttreatment O
outcomes O
and O
greater O
utilization O
of O
costly O
treatment O
services O
, O
existing O
treatment O
trials O
often O
exclude O
patients O
with O
comorbid O
depressive O
and O
alcohol O
use O
disorders O
. O

Past O
research O
suggests O
that O
symptoms O
such O
as O
craving O
and O
anhedonia O
might O
be O
associated O
with O
alterations O
within O
the O
reward O
circuit O
, O
while O
emotion O
regulation O
deficits O
are O
related O
to O
disruptions O
within O
the O
default O
mode O
network O
. O

The O
aim O
of O
this O
clinical O
neuroimaging O
study O
is O
to O
transfer O
previous O
research O
about O
the O
reward O
circuit O
and O
default O
mode O
network O
underlying O
alcohol O
use O
disorder O
and O
depression O
to O
achieve O
a O
better O
understanding O
of O
neural O
signatures O
characterizing O
their O
comorbidity O
. O

In O
addition O
, O
the O
neurobiological O
results O
will O
be O
used O
to O
test O
whether O
two O
psychotherapeutic O
intervention O
programs O
, O
mindfulness-based O
training O
and O
behavioral O
activation O
training O
, O
are O
able O
to O
positively O
influence O
the O
identified O
pathomechanisms O
. O

Methods O
By O
means O
of O
functional O
magnetic O
resonance O
imaging O
( O
fMRI O
) O
, O
60 O
comorbid O
alcohol O
dependent O
and O
depressed O
patients O
are O
compared O
to O
30 O
patients O
with O
depression O
only O
, O
30 O
patients O
with O
alcohol O
use O
disorder O
only O
and O
30 O
healthy O
control O
participants O
. O

Comorbid O
patients O
are O
randomized O
to O
either O
receive O
a O
behavioral O
activation O
or O
mindfulness O
based O
training O
and O
asked O
to O
participate O
in O
a O
second O
fMRI O
session O
and O
3 O
month O
follow-up O
assessment O
. O

Thereby O
, O
we O
plan O
to O
explore O
whether O
these O
brief O
group O
psychotherapeutic O
intervention O
programs O
are O
able O
to O
positively O
influence O
the O
identified O
neurobiological O
pathomechanisms O
. O

The O
primary O
outcomes O
are O
reward O
and O
default O
mode O
network O
activity O
and O
connectivity O
evoked O
by O
paradigms O
measuring O
different O
facets O
of O
reward O
and O
emotion O
processing O
. O

Secondary O
outcome O
measures O
include O
craving O
and O
depression O
scores O
, O
as O
well O
as O
relapse O
rates O
. O

Predictors O
include O
participants O
’ O
characteristics O
, O
personality O
traits O
and O
indicators O
of O
mental O
health O
. O

Discussion O
The O
objective O
of O
the O
project O
is O
to O
identify O
common O
and/or O
distinct O
neural O
signatures O
underlying O
the O
comorbidity O
of O
alcohol O
dependence O
and O
depression O
. O

If O
the O
neurobiological O
understanding O
of O
alcohol O
addiction O
and O
depression O
is O
improved O
, O
this O
could O
potentially O
serve O
as O
a O
key O
predictor O
of O
treatment O
response O
to O
specific O
types O
of O
behavioral O
or O
mindfulness O
therapies O
hypothesized O
to O
alter O
reward O
and O
resting O
state O
systems O
. O

Trial O
registration O
German O
Clinical O
Trial O
Register O
DRKS00010249 O
. O

The O
trial O
was O
registered O
January O
23th O
2017 O
. O

Neurobiological O
informed O
treatment O
interventions O
for O
comorbidity O
: O
Psychotherapy O
The O
ultimate O
goal O
of O
a O
better O
understanding O
of O
the O
neurobiological O
underpinnings O
is O
to O
develop O
preventive O
and O
more O
effective O
treatment O
strategies O
. O

Compared O
to O
antidepressant O
or O
anticraving O
medication O
, O
less O
research O
has O
examined O
functional O
neural O
responses O
after O
psychotherapy O
. O

Available O
data O
suggest O
that O
psychotherapy O
predicts O
metabolic O
changes O
in O
reward O
, O
cingulate O
and O
frontal O
cortices O
in O
alcohol O
dependence O
and O
depression O
. O

To O
our O
knowledge O
, O
only O
a O
few O
studies O
evaluated O
the O
effects O
of O
a O
specific O
psychotherapeutic O
intervention O
like O
the O
brief O
Behavioral O
Activation O
Treatment O
( O
BAT O
) O
for O
depression O
on O
brain O
activation O
. O

Dichter O
and O
colleagues O
report O
functional O
changes O
in O
reward O
associated O
structures O
including O
the O
dorsal O
striatum O
during O
reward O
anticipation O
after O
a O
BAT O
intervention O
but O
did O
not O
include O
a O
depressed O
control O
group O
. O

Looking O
on O
the O
DMN O
connectivity O
, O
Crowther O
and O
colleagues O
found O
that O
the O
response O
to O
BAT O
in O
depressed O
patients O
was O
predicted O
by O
pretreatment O
connectivity O
of O
the O
right O
insula O
with O
the O
right O
middle O
temporal O
gyrus O
and O
the O
left O
intraparietal O
sulcus O
. O

Another O
psychotherapeutic O
intervention O
with O
potential O
effects O
on O
resting O
state O
networks O
is O
mindfulness O
based O
therapy O
( O
MBT O
) O
. O

MBT O
is O
a O
meditation O
practice O
that O
is O
recently O
receiving O
growing O
attention O
for O
its O
potential O
clinical O
applications O
in O
the O
context O
of O
alcohol O
dependence O
and O
depression O
. O

Neuroimaging O
studies O
showed O
that O
long-term O
meditators O
showed O
increased O
activation O
of O
prefrontal O
areas O
during O
meditation O
as O
compared O
with O
a O
rest O
condition O
or O
with O
matched O
control O
subjects O
naïve O
to O
meditation O
practice O
. O

In O
summary O
, O
dysfunctions O
in O
the O
reward O
circuit O
, O
as O
well O
as O
DMN O
have O
been O
identified O
as O
key O
domains O
underlying O
alcohol O
dependence O
and O
depression O
. O

We O
assume O
that O
these O
mechanisms O
also O
characterize O
the O
neurobiological O
underpinning O
of O
their O
comorbidity O
. O

Thereby O
, O
the O
identification O
of O
neural O
risk O
factors O
associated O
with O
their O
co-occurrence O
might O
help O
in O
understanding O
the O
pathophysiological O
mechanisms O
leading O
to O
their O
onset O
and O
course O
. O

The O
overall O
goal O
of O
improving O
our O
understanding O
of O
neurobiological O
mechanisms O
is O
to O
improve O
treatment O
. O

If O
the O
neurobiological O
understanding O
of O
alcohol O
dependence O
and O
depression O
is O
improved O
, O
this O
could O
potentially O
serve O
as O
a O
key O
predictor O
of O
treatment O
response O
to O
specific O
types O
of O
behavioral O
( O
BAT O
) O
or O
mindfulness O
( O
e.g O
. O

MBT O
) O
therapies O
shown O
to O
alter O
reward O
and O
resting O
state O
systems O
. O

Methods O
Study O
design O
In O
this O
randomized-controlled O
trial O
, O
comorbid O
alcohol O
dependent O
and O
depressed O
patients O
will O
be O
compared O
to O
depressed O
only O
, O
alcohol O
dependent O
only O
and O
healthy O
control O
participants O
. O

All O
participants O
are O
screened O
and O
after O
examination O
of O
inclusion O
and O
exclusion O
criteria O
admitted O
to O
the O
study O
. O

All O
participants O
will O
receive O
a O
baseline O
fMRI O
session O
( O
T1 O
) O
. O

Subsequently O
, O
only O
comorbid O
alcohol O
dependent O
and O
depressed O
patients O
will O
be O
randomized O
to O
either O
receiving O
group O
BAT O
or O
MBT O
training O
for O
6 O
weeks O
. O

Afterwards O
comorbid O
patients O
will O
receive O
an O
outcome O
fMRI O
session O
( O
T2 O
) O
and O
will O
be O
contacted O
after O
three O
months O
for O
a O
catamnestic O
exploration O
. O

For O
a O
flow O
chart O
of O
the O
study O
design O
please O
refer O
to O
Fig O
. O

1 O
. O

Participants O
Sixty O
comorbid O
alcohol O
dependent O
and O
depressed O
patients O
, O
30 O
alcohol O
dependent O
only O
and O
30 O
depressed O
only O
patients O
will O
be O
included O
for O
T1 O
assessment O
. O

Further O
, O
30 O
healthy O
control O
participants O
( O
matched O
according O
to O
age O
, O
gender O
and O
educational O
level O
) O
will O
be O
recruited O
. O

Eligibility O
All O
participants O
will O
be O
1 O
) O
aged O
between O
18 O
and O
65 O
years O
, O
2 O
) O
have O
to O
provide O
informed O
consent O
, O
3 O
) O
be O
right-handed O
, O
4 O
) O
show O
an O
appropriate O
comprehension O
of O
the O
German O
language O
and O
5 O
) O
must O
be O
able O
to O
accurately O
watch O
visual O
stimuli O
in O
the O
scanner O
environment O
. O

Alcohol O
use O
disorder O
and O
depression O
will O
be O
diagnosed O
according O
to O
DSM-5 O
criteria O
and O
patients O
must O
be O
abstinent O
for O
at O
least O
5 O
days O
before O
scanning O
. O

Exclusion O
criteria O
for O
all O
participants O
include O
1 O
) O
psychiatric O
Axis O
I O
disorders O
as O
measured O
by O
the O
SCID O
I O
interview O
within O
the O
past O
12-months O
( O
except O
for O
patients O
alcohol O
and O
nicotine O
abuse O
and O
depressive O
symptoms O
) O
, O
2 O
) O
neurological O
disorders O
, O
3 O
) O
MRI O
specific O
contraindications O
such O
as O
having O
a O
pace O
maker O
or O
implanted O
metal O
, O
4 O
) O
positive O
drug O
screening O
( O
opioids O
, O
cannabinoids O
, O
benzodiazepines O
, O
barbiturates O
, O
cocaine O
, O
amphetamines O
) O
, O
5 O
) O
any O
current O
psychoactive O
medication O
except O
anti-depressants O
, O
6 O
) O
pregnancy O
and O
7 O
) O
suicidal O
tendencies O
. O

During O
the O
participation O
in O
the O
group O
therapies O
, O
comorbid O
participants O
should O
not O
enroll O
in O
any O
other O
CBT O
or O
individual O
psychotherapeutic O
treatment O
. O

Sample O
size O
Power O
calculations O
were O
conducted O
by O
means O
of O
the O
G O
* O
Power O
3.1 O
software O
package O
. O

According O
to O
pilot O
studies O
, O
an O
effect O
size O
of O
at O
least O
d O
= O
1 O
can O
be O
assumed O
for O
the O
different O
paradigms O
and O
comparisons O
. O

For O
region O
of O
interest O
analysis O
with O
regions O
of O
200 O
voxels O
, O
a O
sample O
of O
30 O
per O
group O
should O
be O
sufficient O
to O
reach O
a O
power O
of O
80 O
% O
to O
detect O
differences O
at O
p O
< O
.05 O
( O
Bonferroni O
corrected O
for O
multiple O
tests O
) O
. O

For O
the O
intervention O
study O
the O
same O
comorbid O
alcohol O
dependent O
and O
depressed O
participants O
will O
be O
randomly O
assigned O
to O
one O
of O
two O
group O
therapy O
interventions O
and O
asked O
to O
participate O
in O
a O
second O
fMRI O
session O
and O
follow O
up O
measurement O
. O

When O
assuming O
a O
small O
to O
medium O
effect O
size O
( O
f O
= O
.2 O
) O
for O
the O
group O
x O
time O
interaction O
and O
a O
correlation O
among O
repeated O
measures O
of.7 O
( O
as O
typical O
for O
fMRI O
data O
) O
, O
we O
achieve O
a O
power O
of O
80 O
% O
to O
detect O
differences O
at O
p O
< O
.05 O
( O
Boferroni O
corrected O
for O
a O
k O
= O
200 O
, O
region O
of O
interest O
) O
on O
the O
neural O
level O
even O
when O
we O
have O
to O
face O
a O
drop-out O
rate O
of O
10 O
% O
. O

While O
we O
expect O
an O
attrition O
rate O
of O
20 O
% O
, O
recruitment O
will O
be O
continued O
until O
the O
desired O
sample O
sizes O
are O
reached O
and O
drop-outs O
will O
be O
replaced O
by O
new O
participants O
. O

Sample O
recruitment O
Participants O
of O
the O
study O
are O
recruited O
by O
means O
of O
several O
sources O
in O
the O
community O
around O
Mannheim O
, O
Germany O
. O

These O
include O
advertisement O
in O
local O
newspapers O
, O
announcements O
on O
our O
institutes O
’ O
homepage O
, O
flyers O
in O
local O
businesses O
and O
university O
campuses O
; O
and O
contact O
with O
potential O
referral O
sources O
, O
for O
example O
general O
practitioners O
, O
private O
psychologists O
and O
psychiatrists O
, O
as O
well O
as O
local O
psychiatric O
inpatient O
and O
outpatient O
units O
. O

Prospective O
participants O
express O
their O
interest O
to O
the O
research O
team O
through O
email O
or O
phone O
call O
. O

After O
carefully O
informing O
the O
participants O
about O
the O
aim O
, O
content O
, O
duration O
and O
potential O
risks O
and O
benefits O
of O
the O
study O
, O
trained O
research O
assistants O
assess O
initial O
eligibility O
using O
a O
specifically O
developed O
telephone O
screening O
. O

In O
case O
the O
participants O
are O
currently O
in O
one O
of O
the O
local O
inpatient O
or O
outpatient O
facilities O
of O
the O
institute O
, O
participants O
will O
be O
personally O
approached O
and O
screened O
. O

If O
the O
individual O
meets O
the O
inclusion O
criteria O
, O
they O
receive O
a O
letter O
including O
a O
detailed O
study O
description O
, O
the O
informed O
consent O
, O
time O
and O
date O
of O
their O
study O
appointment O
and O
an O
online O
link O
with O
questionnaires O
. O

Study O
procedure O
Before O
participants O
will O
be O
finally O
included O
in O
the O
study O
, O
any O
open O
questions O
, O
risks O
and O
benefits O
will O
be O
discussed O
with O
a O
trained O
psychologist O
at O
the O
T1 O
assessment O
. O

On O
agreement O
of O
the O
participant O
, O
the O
informed O
consent O
form O
will O
be O
signed O
and O
a O
copy O
handed O
to O
the O
participant O
. O

Afterwards O
, O
participants O
will O
undergo O
a O
psychological O
interview O
assessing O
previously O
received O
therapy O
, O
current O

and O
for O
patients O
symptoms O
of O
depression O
or O
alcohol O
use O
disorder O
according O
to O
DSM-5 O
. O

Before O
the O
fMRI O
measurement O
starts O
, O
all O
paradigms O
are O
explained O
to O
the O
participant O
. O

Also O
before O
and O
after O
the O
fMRI O
session O
, O
participants O
are O
asked O
to O
fill O
out O
questionnaires O
regarding O
their O
current O
mood O
and O
craving O
. O

Only O
comorbid O
alcohol O
dependent O
and O
depressed O
patients O
will O
be O
randomized O
to O
either O
receive O
BAT O
or O
MBT O
group O
training O
for O
6 O
weeks O
. O

For O
comorbid O
patients O
, O
the O
fMRI O
procedure O
followed O
at O
T1 O
will O
be O
repeated O
at O
T2 O
. O

Afterwards O
, O
comorbid O
patients O
will O
be O
contacted O
after O
three O
months O
for O
a O
catamnestic O
exploration O
. O

All O
participants O
will O
be O
compensated O
for O
their O
time O
with O
15€ O
per O
scanning O
session O
plus O
the O
money O
won O
in O
the O
reward O
paradigm O
. O

To O
promote O
participant O
retention O
and O
complete O
follow-up O
we O
will O
contact O
the O
comorbid O
patients O
by O
phone O
during O
the O
follow-up O
period O
. O

Randomization O
After O
completion O
of O
baseline O
assessment O
, O
comorbid O
patients O
will O
be O
randomly O
assigned O
to O
one O
of O
the O
two O
group O
interventions O
. O

To O
reduce O
the O
time O
between O
the O
initial O
study O
recruitment O
and O
the O
start O
of O
the O
group O
therapy O
, O
the O
randomization O
order O
will O
be O
determined O
with O
a O
block O
randomization O
with O
6 O
participants O
per O
block O
for O
each O
treatment O
arm O
. O

Randomization O
will O
be O
performed O
by O
a O
researcher O
who O
is O
not O
involved O
in O
the O
recruitment O
, O
using O
a O
computerized O
randomization O
tool O
implemented O
in O
MATLAB O
( O
The O
MathWorks O
Inc. O
, O
Natick O
, O
Massachusetts O
, O
United O
States O
) O
. O

Participants O
will O
be O
recruited O
and O
enrolled O
by O
trained O
research O
staff O
; O
the O
allocation O
sequence O
will O
be O
concealed O
from O
them O
. O

Since O
the O
study O
offers O
psychotherapeutic O
interventions O
, O
patients O
are O
not O
blinded O
to O
their O
intervention O
arms O
. O

Psychotherapeutic O
Interventions O
Comorbid O
patients O
will O
be O
randomly O
assigned O
to O
one O
of O
two O
group O
therapies O
consisting O
of O
6 O
participants O
. O

Both O
interventions O
consist O
of O
six O
sessions O
of O
2 O
h O
therapy O
with O
1 O
session O
per O
week O
offered O
by O
a O
psychotherapist O
. O

To O
increase O
adherence O
, O
﻿each O
participant O
will O
receive O
an O
individual O
therapy O
session O
before O
the O
group O
therapy O
begins O
. O

The O
group O
therapy O
protocols O
in O
both O
arms O
are O
manualized O
and O
supervised O
by O
an O
experienced O
psychotherapist O
to O
ensure O
protocol O
adherence O
. O

Patients O
who O
missed O
more O
than O
one O
session O
or O
experienced O
a O
severe O
relapse O
during O
the O
intervention O
period O
will O
be O
excluded O
from O
the O
protocol O
. O

In O
the O
unexpected O
case O
of O
an O
adverse O
event O
or O
harm O
during O
the O
psychotherapeutic O
intervention O
( O
for O
example O
, O
severe O
aggravation O
like O
suicidality O
) O
, O
the O
affected O
patient O
will O
also O
be O
excluded O
and O
additional O
in- O
or O
outpatient O
treatment O
will O
be O
offered O
by O
the O
psychotherapist O
. O

Behavioral O
activation O
treatment O
Behavioral O
Activation O
Treatment O
( O
BAT O
) O
is O
a O
structured O
and O
validated O
psychotherapy O
intervention O
designed O
to O
increase O
engagement O
with O
functional O
, O
potentially O
rewarding O
behaviors O
. O

Treatment O
proceeds O
through O
a O
series O
of O
structured O
units O
that O
( O
a O
) O
provide O
psychoeducation O
about O
depression O
and O
alcohol O
dependence O
, O
as O
well O
as O
a O
rationale O
for O
the O
treatment O
approach O
, O
( O
b O
) O
assess O
and O
monitor O
baseline O
activity O
levels O
, O
( O
c O
) O
identify O
and O
support O
more O
functional O
behaviors O
and O
personally O
valued O
goals O
as O
an O
alternative O
strategy O
to O
cope O
with O
cravings O
and O
low O
mood O
, O
( O
d O
) O
monitor O
, O
support O
, O
and O
reward O
achieving O
behavioral O
goals O
, O
and O
( O
e O
) O
improve O
problem O
solving O
skills O
. O

Previous O
studies O
have O
demonstrated O
that O
BAT O
for O
depression O
effectively O
reduces O
depressive O
symptoms O
and O
is O
well O
tolerated O
in O
outpatient O
settings O
. O

Mindfulness O
based O
therapy O
The O
mindfulness O
based O
intervention O
aims O
to O
increase O
awareness O
for O
and O
help O
patients O
to O
accept O
situational O
cues O
, O
negative O
thoughts O
, O
feelings O
, O
and O
behavioral O
impulses O
that O
have O
been O
associated O
with O
drinking O
. O

Participants O
are O
guided O
through O
structured O
units O
that O
( O
a O
) O
provide O
psychoeducation O
about O
depression O
and O
alcohol O
dependence O
, O
as O
well O
as O
a O
rationale O
for O
the O
treatment O
approach O
, O
( O
b O
) O
increase O
patients O
’ O
awareness O
of O
different O
experiences O
including O
low O
mood O
and O
cravings O
, O
( O
c O
) O
help O
clients O
to O
distance O
themselves O
from O
challenging O
experiences O
, O
e.g O
. O

by O
focusing O
on O
their O
breathing O
, O
( O
d O
) O
help O
them O
to O
respond O
to O
pleasant O
and O
unpleasant O
sensations O
with O
acceptance O
, O
and O
( O
e O
) O
foster O
their O
sense O
of O
strength O
and O
self-efficacy O
by O
enduring O
negative O
experiences O
and O
withstanding O
behavioral O
impulses O
. O

Additional O
information O
The O
study O
protocol O
is O
in O
accordance O
with O
the O
Standard O
Protocol O
Items O
: O
Recommendations O
for O
Interventional O
Trials O
( O
SPIRIT O
) O
guidelines O
for O
reporting O
interventional O
trials O
. O

Ethical O
approval O
and O
consent O
has O
been O
obtained O
by O
the O
leading O
ethics O
committee O
of O
the O
Medical O
Faculty O
Mannheim/University O
of O
Heidelberg O
( O
reference O
number O
: O
2015-606 O
N-MA O
) O
. O

The O
study O
will O
be O
conducted O
in O
compliance O
with O
the O
guidelines O
for O
Good O
Clinical O
Practice O
and O
the O
Declaration O
of O
Helsinki O
. O

Participants O
will O
provide O
informed O
consent O
prior O
to O
enrolment O
in O
the O
study O
. O

The O
trial O
is O
registered O
in O
the O
German O
Clinical O
Trial O
Registration O
( O
DRKS00010249 O
) O
. O

Any O
changes O
to O
the O
protocol O
will O
be O
described O
in O
this O
trial O
registry O
. O

The O
principal O
investigator O
( O
PK O
) O
, O
independent O
from O
the O
sponsor O
and O
with O
no O
competing O
interests O
to O
report O
, O
is O
responsible O
for O
data O
monitoring O
. O

All O
adverse O
events O
are O
documented O
. O

Interim O
analyzes O
are O
not O
planned O
but O
cross-sectional O
comparisons O
for O
T1 O
data O
will O
be O
conducted O
after O
inclusion O
of O
all O
T1 O
participants O
and O
before O
data O
collections O
at O
T2 O
and O
FU O
are O
completed O
. O

The O
day-to-day O
management O
of O
the O
study O
( O
e.g O
. O

contact O
with O
the O
participants O
and O
the O
invitation O
to O
conduct O
online O
surveys O
) O
is O
carried O
out O
by O
advanced O
researchers O
. O

The O
publication O
of O
the O
results O
will O
be O
independent O
of O
the O
results O
of O
the O
study O
, O
even O
if O
the O
intervention O
proves O
to O
have O
no O
influence O
on O
brain O
activation O
and O
connectivity O
. O

Authorship O
eligibility O
will O
be O
decided O
according O
to O
the O
guidelines O
for O
safeguarding O
good O
scientific O
practice O
provided O
be O
the O

Research O
Association O
. O

A O

of O
the O
results O
will O
also O
be O

to O

. O

, O

parameters O
and O
statistical O
code O
of O

will O
be O

. O

to O

, O

not O

for O
