. O

fMRI O
assessment O
battery O
Reward O
paradigm O
In O
this O
event-related O
paradigm O
, O
participants O
are O
asked O
to O
respond O
to O
a O
flashlight O
as O
fast O
as O
possible O
by O
pressing O
a O
button O
. O

Preceding O
the O
flashlight O
, O
an O
arrow O
cue O
informs O
the O
participant O
about O
the O
rewarding O
consequences O
of O
their O
response O
to O
the O
flash O
stimulus O
. O

Four O
conditions O
are O
included O
in O
the O
paradigm O
: O
( O
1 O
) O
in O
the O
so O
called O
monetary O
reward O
condition O
( O
arrow O
up O
) O
participants O
’ O
fast O
response O
to O
the O
flash O
is O
rewarded O
with O
2€ O
; O
( O
2 O
) O
in O
the O
punishment O
avoidance O
condition O
( O
arrow O
down O
) O
a O
slow O
response O
is O
punished O
by O
a O
loss O
of O
2€ O
while O
a O
fast O
response O
is O
rewarded O
by O
the O
avoidance O
of O
that O
loss O
; O
( O
3 O
) O
the O
verbal O
feedback O
condition O
( O
vertical O
double O
arrow O
) O
allows O
the O
participants O
to O
receive O
verbal O
feedback O
on O
their O
performance O
; O
( O
4 O
) O
in O
the O
passive O
control O
condition O
( O
horizontal O
double O
arrow O
) O
no O
response O
is O
required O
. O

During O
the O
outcome O
phase O
, O
the O
participants O
see O
the O
reward O
of O
the O
latest O
trial O
( O
“ O
2€ O
” O
, O
“ O
0″ O
or O
“ O
Fast O
response O
! O
” O
, O
“ O
Too O
slow O
” O
) O
as O
well O
as O
their O
cumulative O
total O
gain O
at O
that O
point O
in O
time O
. O

In O
order O
to O
ensure O
that O
all O
participants O
are O
able O
to O
win O
some O
money O
and O
have O
comparable O
winnings O
, O
the O
threshold O
for O
a O
fast O
response O
is O
adaptively O
tailored O
for O
each O
trial O
to O
the O
individual O
response O
times O
of O
the O
subject O
. O

The O
inter-trial O
interval O
was O
randomly O
varied O
between O
6 O
and O
9 O
s. O
Each O
condition O
is O
presented O
10 O
times O
in O
a O
pseudo-randomized O
trial O
order O
with O
no O
more O
than O
two O
equal O
conditions O
in O
succession O
. O

The O
total O
run O
length O
is O
9 O
min O
. O

The O
monetary O
reward O
anticipation O
task O
has O
been O
shown O
to O
reliably O
and O
robustly O
activate O
the O
ventral O
striatum O
including O
the O
nucleus O
accumbens O
. O

Erotic O
incentive O
delay O
task O
In O
order O
to O
measure O
different O
categories O
of O
reward O
processing O
, O
a O
variant O
of O
our O
own O
monetary O
reward O
task O
comprising O
erotic O
stimuli O
will O
be O
performed O
. O

Similar O
to O
the O
description O
above O
, O
participants O
have O
to O
respond O
to O
a O
cued O
probe O
to O
receive O
either O
erotic O
stimuli O
or O
matched O
social O
control O
stimuli O
. O

Again O
during O
the O
anticipation O
phase O
, O
distinct O
cues O
preceding O
the O
target O
inform O
the O
participants O
whether O
a O
rewarding O
erotic O
image O
will O
be O
shown O
or O
not O
. O

In O
previous O
studies O
it O
has O
been O
shown O
that O
striatal O
reward-associated O
brain O
activations O
can O
be O
reliably O
observed O
when O
erotic O
pictures O
are O
presented O
. O

Resting O
state/mood O
induction O
paradigm O
The O
so O
called O
mood O
induction O
paradigm O
has O
been O
successfully O
implemented O
in O
different O
studies O
. O

Here O
, O
we O
will O
use O
a O
modified O
version O
of O
the O
paradigm O
in O
order O
to O
directly O
test O
intervention O
associated O
activation O
and O
connectivity O
patterns O
. O

The O
paradigm O
consists O
of O
five O
blocks O
, O
each O
of O
which O
lasts O
4.5 O
min O
: O
a O
resting O
state O
block O
, O
a O
sad O
mood O
induction O
block O
, O
one O
alcohol O
cue-reactivity O
block O
, O
one O
mindfulness-based O
block O
and O
one O
behavioral O
activation O
block O
. O

The O
mindfulness-based O
block O
and O
the O
behavioral O
activation O
block O
are O
counterbalanced O
. O

During O
the O
resting O
state O
phase O
, O
participants O
are O
told O
to O
keep O
their O
eyes O
open O
and O
background O
pink O
noise O
is O
presented O
. O

During O
the O
sad O
mood O
induction O
phase O
, O
key O
words O
to O
remind O
participants O
of O
personal O
negative O
life O
events O
and O
background O
sad O
music O
( O
excerpt O
from O
Albinoni/Giazotto O
, O
Adagio O
in O
g-minor O
) O
are O
presented O
. O

Participants O
are O
asked O
to O
concentrate O
on O
the O
negative O
life O
events O
and O
empathize O
with O
the O
situation O
. O

During O
the O
alcohol O
cue-reactivity O
phase O
, O
participants O
are O
presented O
images O
of O
either O
beer O
or O
wine O
( O
depending O
on O
the O
participants O
preference O
) O
while O
they O
receive O
corresponding O
audio O
induction O
statements O
instructing O
them O
to O
imagine O
alcohol-associated O
situations O
. O

In O
the O
mindfulness- O
based O
phase O
, O
again O
, O
participants O
are O
presented O
images O
of O
beer O
or O
wine O
while O
this O
time O
they O
listen O
to O
mindfulness-based O
audio O
instructions O
. O

Correspondingly O
, O
in O
the O
behavioral O
activation O
training O
phase O
, O
participants O
are O
played O
audio O
instructions O
associated O
with O
imagining O
activities O
while O
viewing O
alcohol-associated O
pictures O
. O

In O
each O
phase O
, O
9 O
alcohol-associated O
cues O
are O
presented O
for O
15 O
s O
, O
while O
simultaneously O
9 O
audio O
statements O
are O
played O
. O

After O
each O
picture O
a O
fixation O
cross O
is O
presented O
for O
also O
15 O
s. O
After O
each O
block O
, O
participants O
are O
instructed O
to O
rate O
their O
mood O
by O
means O
of O
the O
Positive O
and O
Negative O
Affect O
Schedule O
( O
PANAS O
) O
, O
as O
well O
as O
their O
craving O
and O
self-control O
to O
abstain O
. O

For O
the O
T2 O
assessment O
, O
a O
different O
set O
of O
alcohol-associated O
pictures O
is O
presented O
. O

As O
mentioned O
above O
, O
the O
mindfulness-based O
block O
and O
the O
behavioral O
activation O
block O
are O
counterbalanced O
. O

Thus O
, O
a O
second O
randomization O
list O
will O
ensure O
that O
at O
T1 O
the O
order O
of O
the O
experimental O
blocks O
will O
be O
equally O
distributed O
above O
all O
participants O
. O

Comorbid O
patients O
will O
receive O
the O
reverse O
order O
of O
their O
T1 O
assessment O
at O
the O
T2 O
fMRI O
scanning O
. O

Anatomical O
image O
In O
order O
to O
assess O
the O
individual O
brain O
morphology O
of O
each O
participant O
, O
high-resolution O
T1-weighted O
anatomical O
images O
( O
MPRAGE O
) O
will O
be O
collected O
. O

Primary O
outcome O
In O
this O
study O
, O
neural O
activation O
and O
connectivity O
in O
the O
reward O
system O
and O
default O
mode O
network O
are O
the O
primary O
outcome O
measures O
. O

Neural O
correlates O
of O
reward O
and O
emotion O
processing O
in O
patients O
and O
healthy O
controls O
will O
be O
assessed O
by O
means O
of O
fMRI O
. O

While O
the O
first O
measurement O
will O
identify O
common O
and/or O
distinct O
neural O
signatures O
underlying O
the O
comorbidity O
of O
alcohol O
dependence O
and O
depression O
, O
the O
second O
measurement O
allows O
investigating O
the O
influence O
of O
the O
psychotherapeutic O
interventions O
on O
these O
target O
brain O
mechanisms O
. O

Secondary O
outcome O
measures O
Secondary O
outcome O
measures O
include O
craving O
and O
depression O
scores O
, O
as O
well O
as O
relapse O
rates O
. O

Predictors O
Predictors O
include O
participants O
’ O
characteristics O
and O
personality O
traits O
as O
assessed O
by O
questionnaires O
( O
See O
Table O
1 O
) O
, O
as O
well O
as O
ratings O
before O
, O
during O
and O
after O
scanning O
. O

Data O
analyses O
plan O
Analyses O
will O
be O
conducted O
on O
an O
intention O
to O
treat O
and O
treatment O
completers O
principle O
. O

Behavioral O
data O
analyses O
Analysis O
will O
be O
completed O
by O
using O
( O
repeated O
measures O
) O
analysis O
of O
variance O
( O
AN O
( O
C O
) O
OVA O
) O
in O
order O
to O
test O
group O
differences O
( O
AUD O
vs O
MD O
vs O
Co O
vs O
HC O
) O
and O
treatment O
groups O
( O
BAT O
vs O
MBT O
) O
. O

Difference O
scores O
will O
be O
calculated O
. O

All O
measures O
will O
be O
compared O
between O
groups O
, O
as O
well O
as O
treatment O
groups O
and O
interaction O
effects O
will O
be O
explored O
. O

Wherever O
appropriate O
, O
missing O
data O
will O
be O
imputed O
using O
multiple O
imputation O
. O

Activation O
fMRI O
analysis O
Preprocessing O
as O
well O
as O
statistical O
analyses O
of O
the O
experimental O
fMRI O
paradigms O
will O
be O
performed O
using O
SPM O
12 O
( O
Wellcome O
Department O
of O
Cognitive O
Neurology O
, O
London O
, O
UK O
) O
. O

In O
order O
to O
reduce O
systematic O
motion-related O
artifacts O
known O
to O
be O
especially O
prevalent O
in O
patient-control O
studies O
, O
we O
use O
the O
ART O
toolbox O
( O
http O
: O
//www.nitrc.org/projects/artifact_detect O
) O
to O
detect O
outlier O
volumes O
. O

The O
ART O
software O
identifies O
outliers O
if O
the O
normalized O
z-score O
of O
the O
global O
mean O
intensity O
of O
a O
volume O
exceed O
a O
specified O
threshold O
and/or O
if O
extensive O
composite O
movement O
from O
a O
preceding O
image O
occurs O
. O

Preprocessing O
will O
be O
conducted O
with O
the O
standard O
procedure O
analysis O
including O
slice O
time O
correction O
, O
realignment O
, O
co-registration O
, O
normalizing O
, O
smoothing O
. O

Statistical O
analysis O
on O
the O
first O
( O
individual O
) O
level O
will O
be O
performed O
by O
modeling O
the O
different O
conditions O
using O
boxcar O
functions O
convoluted O
with O
the O
hemodynamic O
response O
function O
as O
explanatory O
variables O
within O
the O
context O
of O
the O
general O
linear O
model O
( O
GLM O
) O
on O
a O
voxel-by-voxel O
basis O
. O

Connectivity O
fMRI O
analysis O
Task O
and O
resting O
state O
fMRI O
data O
will O
additionally O
be O
analyzed O
by O
connectivity O
approaches O
. O

To O
account O
for O
physiological O
and O
movement O
artifacts O
which O
strongly O
introduce O
artificial O
correlations O
into O
the O
data O
, O
heart O
beat O
and O
respiration O
will O
be O
monitored O
during O
scanning O
and O
physiological O
correction O
will O
be O
conducted O
with O
the O
software O
Aztec O
. O

Afterwards O
, O
images O
are O
preprocessed O
as O
described O
before O
by O
SPM O
12 O
. O

Task-dependent O
connectivity O
will O
be O
examined O
by O
functional O
connectivity O
and O
psychophysiological O
interaction O
analyses O
. O

Resting O
state O
data O
will O
be O
examined O
by O
conventional O
as O
well O
as O
dynamic O
functional O
connectivity O
analysis O
. O

Analyses O
in O
both O
task O
and O
rest O
will O
be O
conducted O
in O
a O
hypothesis-driven O
network-specific O
as O
well O
as O
more O
exploratory O
whole-brain O
manner O
. O

The O
whole-brain O
results O
will O
be O
further O
analyzed O
by O
graph O
theoretical O
tools O
to O
elucidate O
relevant O
changes O
in O
functional O
network O
topology O
. O

Data O
management O
The O
project O
data O
will O
be O
saved O
on O
the O
central O
server O
of O
the O
institute O
. O

The O
IT O
department O
professionally O
maintains O
the O
server O
; O
thereby O
a O
daily O
backup O
of O
all O
data O
is O
performed O
. O

Additionally O
, O
a O
network O
independent O
backup O
will O
be O
saved O
on O
local O
hard O
drive O
. O

Experimental O
data O
, O
as O
well O
as O
questionnaires O
will O
be O
saved O
in O
a O
pseudonymized O
form O
, O
separately O
from O
consent O
forms O
that O
contain O
the O
names O
of O
the O
participants O
. O

In O
addition O
, O
hard O
copy O
storage O
of O
reports O
, O
protocols O
, O
presentations O
or O
publication O
drafts O
will O
be O
realized O
. O

All O
data O
will O
be O
pseudonymized O
using O
unique O
study O
codes O
, O
which O
will O
be O
used O
to O
code O
and O
file O
all O
electronic O
information O
. O

The O
key O
linking O
this O
code O
to O
participant O
identity O
will O
be O
stored O
in O
a O
secured O
file O
, O
access O
to O
this O
key O
is O
available O
only O
to O
designated O
members O
of O
the O
research O
team O
. O

These O
researchers O
will O
have O
unrestricted O
access O
to O
all O
study O
data O
. O

As O
mentioned O
above O
, O
anonymized O
data O
will O
be O
made O
available O
for O
re- O
or O
meta-analysis O
after O
request O
. O

ENFORCING O
CO-EXPRESSION O
IN O
MULTIMODAL O
REGRESSION O
FRAMEWORK O
We O
consider O
the O
problem O
of O
multimodal O
data O
integration O
for O
the O
study O
of O
complex O
neurological O
diseases O
( O
e.g O
. O

schizophrenia O
) O
. O

Among O
the O
challenges O
arising O
in O
such O
situation O
, O
estimating O
the O
link O
between O
genetic O
and O
neurological O
variability O
within O
a O
population O
sample O
has O
been O
a O
promising O
direction O
. O

A O
wide O
variety O
of O
statistical O
models O
arose O
from O
such O
applications O
. O

For O
example O
, O
Lasso O
regression O
and O
its O
multitask O
extension O
are O
often O
used O
to O
fit O
a O
multivariate O
linear O
relationship O
between O
given O
phenotype O
( O
s O
) O
and O
associated O
observations O
. O

Other O
approaches O
, O
such O
as O
canonical O
correlation O
analysis O
( O
CCA O
) O
, O
are O
widely O
used O
to O
extract O
relationships O
between O
sets O
of O
variables O
from O
different O
modalities O
. O

In O
this O
paper O
, O
we O
propose O
an O
exploratory O
multivariate O
method O
combining O
these O
two O
methods O
. O

More O
Specifically O
, O
we O
rely O
on O
a O
’ O
CCA-type O
’ O
formulation O
in O
order O
to O
regularize O
the O
classical O
multimodal O
Lasso O
regression O
problem O
. O

The O
underlying O
motivation O
is O
to O
extract O
discriminative O
variables O
that O
display O
are O
also O
co-expressed O
across O
modalities O
. O

We O
first O
evaluate O
the O
method O
on O
a O
simulated O
dataset O
, O
and O
further O
validate O
it O
using O
Single O
Nucleotide O
Polymorphisms O
( O
SNP O
) O
and O
functional O
Magnetic O
Resonance O
Imaging O
( O
fMRI O
) O
data O
for O
the O
study O
of O
schizophrenia O
. O

2 O
. O

Methods O
2.1 O
. O

Learning O
with O
L1 O
penalty O
We O
consider O
M O
∈ O
ℕ+ O
distinct O
( O
i.e O
. O

from O
different O
modalities O
) O
datasets O
with O
n O
samples O
and O
pm O
∈ O
ℕ+ O
( O
m O
= O
1 O
, O
‥ O
, O
M O
) O
variables O
each O
. O

The O
m-th O
dataset O
is O
represented O
by O
a O
matrix O
Xm O
∈ O
ℝn×pm O
. O

Additionally O
, O
each O
sample O
is O
assigned O
a O
class O
label O
( O
e.g O
. O

case/controls O
) O
yi O
∈ O
{ O
−1 O
, O
1 O
} O
, O
i O
= O
1 O
, O
‥ O
, O
n. O
Our O
goal O
is O
to O
look O
for O
a O
linear O
link O
between O
those O
class O
labels O
and O
the O
M O
data O
matrices O
. O

Let O
us O
consider O
the O
following O
regression O
model O
: O
The O
model O
described O
by O
Eq O
. O

1 O
performs O
both O
variable O
selection O
and O
regularization O
. O

It O
often O
improves O
the O
prediction O
accuracy O
and O
interpretability O
of O
the O
results O
compared O
to O
the O
use O
of O
classical O
ℓ2 O
norm O
regularization O
terms O
, O
especially O
when O
the O
number O
of O
variables O
is O
far O
greater O
than O
the O
number O
of O
observations O
. O

In O
some O
situations O
, O
we O
have O
several O
output O
vectors O
ym O
, O
∀m O
= O
1 O
, O
‥ O
, O
M O
and O
the O
m O
datasets O
are O
from O
the O
same O
modality O
: O
multi-task O
Lasso O
was O
proposed O
to O
capture O
shared O
structures O
among O
the O
various O
regression O
vectors O
. O

We O
consider O
the O
following O
model O
: O
where O
P O
is O
the O
dimension O
of O
the O
problem O
and O
βp O
is O
the O
p-th O
row O
of O
the O
matrix O
such O
that O
β O
= O
[ O
β1 O
, O
‥ O
, O
βm O
] O
( O
i.e O
. O

the O
βm O
are O
stacked O
horizontally O
) O
. O

Such O
norm O
is O
also O
referred O
to O
as O
the O
ℓ1/ℓ2 O
norm O
, O
and O
is O
used O
to O
both O
enforce O
joint O
sparsity O
across O
the O
multiple O
βm O
and O
estimate O
only O

non-zero O
coefficients O
. O

Enforcing O
regularity O
within O
a O
modality O
( O
and O
across O
tasks O
) O
has O
been O
an O
active O
aspect O
of O
regression O
models O
, O
and O
has O
proven O
to O
increase O
reliability O
and O
results O
. O

However O
, O
since O
often O
pair-wise O
closeness O
is O
looked O
for O
in O
the O
common O
subspace O
, O
such O
methods O
will O
often O
fail O
to O
capture O
relationships O
across O
modalities O
. O

2.2 O
. O

Collaborative O
learning O
Collaborative O
( O
or O
Co-regularized O
) O
methods O
are O
based O
on O
the O
optimization O
of O
measures O
of O
agreement O
and O
smoothness O
across O
multi-modal O
datasets O
. O

Smoothness O
across O
modalities O
is O
enforced O
through O
a O
joint O
regularization O
term O
. O

Their O
general O
model O
can O
be O
expressed O
as O
follows O
: O
where O
the O
Um O
, O
m O
= O
1 O
, O
‥ O
, O
M O
are O
arbitrary O
matrices O
whose O
roles O
are O
to O
control O
the O
cross-view O
joint O
regularization O
between O
each O
pair O
of O
vectors O
( O
βm O
, O
βq O
) O
, O
m O
, O
q O
= O
1 O
, O
‥ O
, O
M. O
Scalar O
parameter O
γ O
≥ O
0 O
controls O
the O
influence O
of O
such O
cross-regularization O
term O
. O

Notice O
that O
if O
γ O
= O
0 O
, O
we O
fall O
back O
on O
the O
original O
Lasso O
formulation O
. O

Collaborative O
learning O
is O
an O
interesting O
extension O
of O
Eq.1 O
allowing O
the O
user O
to O
explicitly O
enforce O
regularization O
across O
modalities O
. O

In O
this O
work O
, O
we O
rely O
on O
a O
special O
case O
of O
collaborative O
methods O
( O
introduced O
later O
in O
section O
3 O
) O
to O
address O
the O
following O
aspects O
: O
( O
i O
) O
Extend O
the O
regularization O
idea O
across O
modalities O
, O
( O
ii O
) O
Assume O
that O
relationships O
between O
variable O
are O
not O
available O
as O
a O
prior O
knowledge O
( O
as O
opposed O
, O
e.g. O
, O
to O
Xin O
) O
, O
( O
iii O
) O
Define O
links O
between O
components O
using O
correlation O
measure O
. O

To O
do O
so O
, O
we O
first O
briefly O
introduce O
in O
the O
next O
section O
some O
of O
the O
classical O
methods O
to O
extract O
meaningful O
relationships O
between O
variables O
across O
modalities O
. O

2.3 O
. O

Extracting O
relationship O
between O
datasets O
A O
wide O
variety O
of O
problems O
amount O
to O
the O
joint O
analysis O
of O
multimodal O
datasets O
describing O
the O
same O
set O
of O
observations O
. O

Often O
, O
a O
mean O
to O
perform O
such O
analysis O
is O
to O
learn O
projection O
subspaces O
using O
paired O
samples O
such O
that O
structures O
of O
interest O
appear O
more O
clearly O
. O

Some O
of O
these O
methods O
are O
for O
example O
: O
Canonical O
correlation O
analysis O
( O
CCA O
) O
, O
Partial O
least O
squares O
( O
PLS O
) O
or O
cross-modal O
factor O
analysis O
( O
CFA O
) O
. O

Among O
them O
, O
CCA O
is O
probably O
the O
most O
widely O
used O
. O

Its O
goal O
is O
to O
extract O
linear O
combinations O
of O
variables O
with O
maximal O
correlation O
between O
two O
( O
or O
more O
) O
datasets O
. O

Using O
similar O
notations O
as O
in O
the O
previous O
section O
, O
and O
assuming O
M O
= O
2 O
, O
one O
formulation O
of O
CCA O
is O
expressed O
as O
follow O
: O
to O
which O
a O
constraint O
on O
the O
norm O
of O
canonical O
vectors O
β1 O
, O
β2 O
is O
added O
to O
avoid O
the O
trivial O
null O
solution O
. O

In O
recent O
years O
, O
CCA O
has O
been O
widely O
applied O
to O
genomic O
data O
analysis O
. O

As O
a O
consequence O
, O
many O
studies O
on O
sparse O
versions O
of O
CCA O
( O
sCCA O
) O
have O
been O
proposed O
to O
cope O
with O
the O
high O
dimension O
but O
low O
sample O
size O
problem O
. O

In O
the O
next O
section O
, O
we O
will O
rely O
on O
a O
CCA O
term O
to O
measure O
co-expression O
between O
variables O
from O
different O
modalities O
. O

3 O
. O

Enforcing O
cross-correlation O
in O
regression O
problems O
3.1 O
. O

MT-CoReg O
formulation O
As O
discussed O
in O

, O

to O
: O
( O

) O
Associate O
a O
phenotype O
and O
datasets O

prior O

solution O
, O
( O

relationships O
between O
coupled O
or O

datasets O
. O

In O
the O
present O
study O

to O

regression O
and O

frameworks O
in O

of O

= O
2 O
datasets O
. O

Our O

is O
to O

that O
also O

of O
correlation O
across O

. O

A O

) O

. O

Notice O
that O

. O

( O

. O

If O

. O

( O

) O

( O

) O
. O

Let O

Interestingly O

. O

. O

We O

3.2 O
. O

Optimization O

: O

. O

Assume O
β1 O
’ O

value O

β2 O

( O

) O
. O

Assume O
β2 O

value O
fixed O
, O
and O
update O
β1 O
using O
the O
adapted O
version O
of O
Eq O
. O
( O

) O
. O

Go O
back O
to O
step O
2. O
until O
convergence O
We O
solve O
the O
problem O
from O
Eq O
. O

( O

) O
by O

the O
βm O
’ O

over O

in O

Suppose O

β1 O

. O

Updating O
matrix O

can O

: O
where O

It O

As O

) O

: O
3.3 O
. O

Parameter O
selection O
Solving O
problem O
from O
Eq O
. O

( O
3.3 O
) O
requires O
the O
estimation O
of O
two O
parameters O
, O
λ O
and O
γ O
, O
which O
respectively O
control O
the O
weights O
of O
the O
sparsity O
and O
the O
co-expression O
regularization O
terms O
. O

The O
choice O
of O
sparsity O
parameter O
λ O
for O
this O
type O
of O
problems O
is O
known O
to O
display O
a O
high O
sensitivity O
. O

In O
order O
to O
make O
the O
searching O
process O
more O
robust O
, O
we O
chose O
to O
let O
the O
sparsity O
level O
of O
the O
solution O
control O
the O
tuning O
parameter O
value O
. O

Consider O
a O
column O
vector O
β O
∈ O
ℝp O
( O
e.g O
. O

a O
column O
of O
β O
from O
Eq O
. O

) O
: O
let O
us O
denote O
|β|κ O
the O
κ-th O
( O
κ O
∈ O
ℕ+ O
) O
largest O
absolute O
magnitude O
of O
λ O
. O

We O
can O
Define O
a O
correspondence O
between O
λ O
and O
κ O
by O
making O
sure O
that O
for O
each O
iteration O
, O
we O
have O
λ O
∈ O
[ O
|β|κ O
, O
|β|κ+1 O
] O
. O

The O
selection O
can O
be O
looked O
for O
around O
the O
sample O
size O
( O
i.e O
. O

κ O
= O
n O
for O
the O
entire O
estimation O
process O
) O
, O
which O
helps O
drastically O
stabilize O
the O
estimation O
process O
in O
practice O
. O

As O
for O
the O
estimation O
of O
γ O
, O
we O
chose O
to O
rely O
on O
a O
technique O
introduced O
by O
Sun O
et O
al O
. O

based O
on O
variable O
selection O
stability O
. O

Its O
main O
goal O
is O
to O
select O
a O
given O
tuning O
parameter O
so O
that O
the O
associated O
variable O
selection O
method O
( O
in O
our O
case O
, O
the O
model O
from O
Eq O
. O

( O
3.3 O
) O
) O
is O
stable O
in O
terms O
of O
the O
features O
it O
selects O
. O

In O
this O
framework O
, O
the O
training O
set O
is O
split O
in O
two O
halves O
using O
resampling O
( O
bootstrap O
resampling O
in O
our O
case O
) O
. O

The O
variable O
selection O
method O
is O
then O
applied O
to O
each O
of O
the O
subsamples O
along O
a O
grid O
of O
candidate O
values O
for O
the O
parameter O
. O

Kappa O
selection O
criterion O
is O
then O
used O
to O
measure O
the O
degree O
of O
agreement O
between O
the O
two O
sets O
of O
variables O
obtained O
for O
a O
given O
parameter O
value O
. O

This O
process O
is O
then O
repeated O
a O
number O
of O
times O
, O
and O
an O
approximated O
measure O
of O
selection O
consistency O
is O
derived O
. O

The O
parameter O
value O
for O
which O
this O
consistency O
is O
the O
highest O
( O
after O
correction O
for O
the O
number O
of O
non-zeros O
elements O
retained O
) O
is O
the O
one O
kept O
for O
the O
estimation O
. O

3.4 O
. O

MT-CoReg O
VS. O
CoReg O
As O
mentioned O
earlier O
in O

, O
in O

from O

. O

( O

) O

. O

. O

We O
then O

to O

of O

( O

. O

( O

) O

. O

( O

) O
) O
on O
a O

. O

We O
generated O

= O
2 O
data O

, O

such O

= O

= O

. O

so O
that O
columns O
p O
= O
[ O

‥5 O

‥15 O

. O

We O

[ O

‥25 O

∈ O
{ O

; O

} O
. O

Furthermore O

( O

Resulting O

In O

A O

TPR O

, O
while O

reflects O
the O

of O

that O

by O

model O
. O

We O

100 O

of O

. O

, O

, O

. O

Data O

Schizophreniac O
were O

citeria O
. O

Controls O
were O
free O
of O
any O

, O

of O

illnesses O
. O

fMRI O
were O

. O

Data O
were O

, O

and O

, O

, O

and O

. O

the O

. O

( O

. O

of O

that O

to O

Distribution O

γ O

. O

( O

, O

) O
. O

Most O

of O
feature O
consistency O
selection O
, O
that O
a O
non-zero O
weight O
for O
the O
CCA O
term O
in O
Eq O
. O

( O
3.3 O
) O
leads O
to O
improved O
performances O
. O

Default O
Mode O
Functional O
Connectivity O
is O
Associated O
with O
Social O
Functioning O
in O
Schizophrenia O
Individuals O
with O
schizophrenia O
display O
notable O
deficits O
in O
social O
functioning O
. O

Research O
indicates O
that O
neural O
connectivity O
within O
the O
default O
mode O
network O
( O
DMN O
) O
is O
related O
to O
social O
cognition O
and O
social O
functioning O
in O
healthy O
and O
clinical O
populations O
. O

However O
, O
the O
association O
between O
DMN O
connectivity O
, O
social O
cognition O
, O
and O
social O
functioning O
has O
not O
been O
studied O
in O
schizophrenia O
. O

For O
the O
present O
study O
, O
we O
used O
resting-state O
neuroimaging O
data O
to O
evaluate O
connectivity O
between O
the O
main O
DMN O
hubs O
( O
i.e. O
, O
the O
medial O
prefrontal O
cortex O
( O
mPFC O
) O
and O
the O
posterior O
cingulate O
cortex-anterior O
precuneus O
( O
PPC O
) O
) O
in O
individuals O
with O
schizophrenia O
( O
n=28 O
) O
and O
controls O
( O
n=32 O
) O
. O

We O
also O
examined O
whether O
DMN O
connectivity O
was O
associated O
with O
social O
functioning O
via O
social O
attainment O
( O
measured O
by O
the O
Specific O
Levels O
of O
Functioning O
Scale O
) O
and O
social O
competence O
( O
measured O
by O
the O
Social O
Skills O
Performance O
Assessment O
) O
, O
and O
if O
social O
cognition O
mediates O
the O
association O
between O
DMN O
connectivity O
and O
these O
measures O
of O
social O
functioning O
. O

Results O
revealed O
that O
DMN O
connectivity O
did O
not O
differ O
between O
individuals O
with O
schizophrenia O
and O
controls O
. O

However O
, O
connectivity O
between O
the O
mPFC O
and O
PCC O
hubs O
was O
significantly O
associated O
with O
social O
competence O
and O
social O
attainment O
in O
individuals O
with O
schizophrenia O
but O
not O
in O
controls O
as O
reflected O
by O
a O
significant O
group-by-connectivity O
interaction O
. O

Social O
cognition O
did O
not O
mediate O
the O
association O
between O
social O
functioning O
and O
DMN O
connectivity O
in O
individuals O
with O
schizophrenia O
. O

Our O
findings O
suggest O
that O
fronto-parietal O
DMN O
connectivity O
in O
particular O
may O
be O
differentially O
associated O
with O
social O
functioning O
in O
schizophrenia O
and O
controls O
. O

As O
a O
result O
, O
DMN O
connectivity O
may O
be O
used O
as O
a O
neuroimaging O
marker O
to O
monitor O
treatment O
response O
or O
as O
a O
potential O
target O
for O
interventions O
that O
aim O
to O
enhance O
social O
functioning O
in O
schizophrenia O
. O

Method O
Participants O
and O
Procedure O
Individuals O
with O
schizophrenia O
( O
n=28 O
) O
and O
controls O
( O
n=32 O
) O
ages O
18–45 O
were O
group-matched O
for O
age O
, O
gender O
, O
and O
race O
. O

Participants O
completed O
a O
clinical O
interview O
, O
neuropsychological O
battery O
, O
and O
resting-state O
functional O
magnetic O
resonance O
imaging O
scan O
. O

Participants O
were O
recruited O
from O
the O
Northwestern O
University O
Schizophrenia O
Research O
Group O
. O

Details O
on O
recruitment O
can O
be O
found O
in.1 O
Individuals O
with O
schizophrenia O
were O
included O
in O
the O
study O
if O
they O
1 O
) O
met O
the O
Diagnostic O
and O
Statistical O
Manual O
of O
Mental O
Disorders O
, O
4th O
edition O
( O
DSM-IV O
) O
criteria O
for O
a O
diagnosis O
of O
schizophrenia O
, O
2 O
) O
were O
clinically O
stable O
( O
i.e. O
, O
their O
symptoms O
remained O
unchanged O
for O
at O
least O
2 O
weeks O
) O
, O
and O
3 O
) O
were O
currently O
on O
antipsychotic O
medication O
. O

Individuals O
were O
excluded O
from O
the O
study O
if O
they O
1 O
) O
met O
DSM-IV O
criteria O
for O
intellectual O
disability O
, O
2 O
) O
met O
substance O
abuse O
or O
dependence O
DSM-IV O
criteria O
in O
the O
past O
6 O
months O
, O
3 O
) O
had O
a O
documented O
neurological O
injury O
or O
disorder O
, O
or O
4 O
) O
had O
a O
severe O
medical O
disorder O
. O

Controls O
were O
also O
excluded O
from O
the O
study O
if O
they O
1 O
) O
had O
a O
lifetime O
history O
of O
a O
DSM-IV O
Axis O
I O
psychiatric O
disorder O
or O
2 O
) O
had O
a O
first-degree O
relative O
with O
a O
psychotic O
disorder O
. O

Additionally O
, O
we O
excluded O
nine O
participants O
from O
the O
analysis O
( O
five O
individuals O
with O
schizophrenia O
and O
four O
controls O
) O
, O
for O
excessive O
in-scanner O
motion O
( O
mean O
absolute O
displacement O
above O
1.5 O
mm O
, O
or O
any O
absolute O
displacement O
( O
translations O
or O
rotations O
) O
above O
3 O
mm/degrees O
) O
. O

The O
institutional O
review O
board O
at O
Northwestern O
University O
Feinberg O
School O
of O
Medicine O
approved O
the O
study O
procedures O
, O
and O
all O
participants O
provided O
informed O
consent O
( O
IRB O
approval O
number O
: O
STU00013034 O
) O
. O

Measures O
Demographic O
and O
clinical O
measures O
DSM-IV O
diagnosis O
was O
determined O
through O
the O
Structured O
Clinical O
Interview O
for O
DSM O
Disorders O
( O
SCID-IV O
) O
( O
First O
, O
Spitzer O
, O
Gibbon O
, O
& O
Williams O
) O
. O

The O
SCID-IV O
was O
conducted O
by O
masters- O
or O
PhD-level O
research O
staff O
and O
validated O
through O
a O
semi-structured O
interview O
by O
a O
study O
psychiatrist O
. O

All O
antipsychotic O
medication O
dosages O
were O
converted O
to O
chlorpromazine O
equivalents O
( O
CPZeq O
) O
. O

Clinical O
symptoms O
of O
schizophrenia O
were O
assessed O
using O
the O
Scale O
for O
the O
Assessment O
of O
Positive O
Symptoms O
( O
SAPS O
) O
and O
the O
Scale O
for O
the O
Assessment O
of O
Negative O
Symptoms O
( O
SANS O
) O
. O

Global O
ratings O
for O
hallucinations O
, O
delusions O
, O
bizarre O
behavior O
, O
positive O
formal O
thought O
disorder O
, O
affective O
flattening O
, O
alogia O
, O
avolition O
, O
and O
anhedonia O
were O
provided O
by O
masters- O
or O
PhD-level O
research O
staff O
. O

We O
generated O
global O
scores O
for O
positive O
, O
negative O
, O
and O
disorganized O
symptoms O
by O
calculating O
the O
mean O
of O
positive O
SAPS O
items O
, O
negative O
SANS O
items O
, O
and O
disorganized O
SANS O
items O
. O

Mean O
parental O
socioeconomic O
status O
( O
SES O
) O
was O
assessed O
using O
the O
Barrett O
Simplified O
Measure O
of O
Social O
Status O
. O

Neurocognitive O
assessments O
Participants O
completed O
a O
battery O
of O
tests O
used O
to O
generate O
four O
neurocognitive O
domains O
, O
including O
: O
1 O
) O
Crystallized O
IQ O
from O
scores O
on O
the O
Vocabulary O
subtest O
of O
the O
Wechsler O
Adult O
Intelligence O
Scale O
– O
Third O
Edition O
( O
WAIS-III O
) O
, O
2 O
) O
Working O
Memory O
from O
scores O
on O
the O
Continuous O
Performance O
Task O
( O
CPT O
) O
and O
the O
Digit-Span O
, O
Spatial-Span O
, O
and O
Letter-Number O
Sequencing O
subtests O
of O
the O
Wechsler O
Memory O
Scale-Third O
Edition O
( O
WMS-III O
) O
, O
3 O
) O
Episodic O
Memory O
from O
scores O
on O
the O
Logical O
Memory O
I O
and O
Family O
Pictures O
I O
subtests O
of O
the O
WMS-III O
and O
the O
free O
recall O
score O
from O
the O
first O
five O
trials O
of O
the O
California O
Verbal O
Learning O
Test O
( O
CVLT O
) O
, O
4 O
) O
Executive O
Functioning O
from O
scores O
on O
the O
Wisconsin O
Card O
Sort O
Task O
( O
WCST O
) O
, O
Letter O
and O
Animal O
Fluency O
, O
the O
Trail O
Making O
Test O
Part O
B O
, O
and O
the O
Matrix O
Reasoning O
subtest O
of O
the O
WAIS-III O
. O

Domain O
scores O
were O
calculated O
by O
first O
standardizing O
individual O
subtests O
( O
using O
control O
group O
data O
) O
and O
then O
averaging O
across O
these O
standardized O
scores O
within O
each O
domain O
. O

A O
global O
neurocognitive O
score O
was O
computed O
using O
the O
average O
of O
these O
four O
domains O
. O

Social O
Cognition O
Social O
Perception O
We O
assessed O
social O
perception O
using O
a O
facial O
affect O
perception O
task O
and O
a O
social O
perception O
task O
. O

The O
facial O
affect O
perception O
task O
presented O
participants O
with O
30 O
faces O
displaying O
happiness O
, O
sadness O
, O
fear O
, O
disgust O
, O
anger O
, O
or O
neutrality O
, O
and O
participants O
selected O
the O
correct O
emotional O
expression O
from O
two O
emotion O
labels O
. O

We O
used O
the O
half-profile O
of O
nonverbal O
sensitivity O
( O
PONS O
) O
to O
measure O
social O
perception O
. O

Specifically O
, O
the O
task O
presented O
participants O
with O
110 O
video O
scenes O
containing O
facial O
expressions O
, O
voice O
intonations O
, O
and/or O
gestures O
. O

Following O
the O
scene O
, O
participants O
were O
presented O
with O
two O
labels O
and O
chose O
which O
label O
best O
described O
the O
social O
cue O
. O

We O
mean-centered O
accuracy O
rates O
to O
the O
control O
group O
, O
and O
averaged O
transformed O
scores O
from O
both O
tasks O
to O
obtain O
a O
social O
perception O
domain O
score O
. O

Mentalizing O
We O
assessed O
mentalizing O
using O
cognitive O
empathy O
tasks O
, O
specifically O
the O
Awareness O
of O
Social O
Inference O
Test O
( O
TASIT O
) O
Part O
III O
and O
an O
emotional O
perspective-taking O
task O
. O

The O
TASIT-III O
presented O
participants O
with O
16 O
video O
vignettes O
of O
common O
social O
interactions O
. O

Each O
vignette O
contained O
an O
untrue O
comment O
presented O
as O
either O
a O
lie O
or O
sarcasm O
. O

Participants O
answered O
yes/no O
questions O
about O
the O
thoughts O
, O
intentions O
, O
beliefs O
, O
and O
feelings O
of O
the O
people O
in O
the O
vignette O
. O

The O
emotional O
perspective-taking O
task O
presented O
participants O
with O
60 O
pictures O
of O
two O
person O
interactions O
depicting O
happiness O
, O
sadness O
, O
fear O
, O
disgust O
, O
anger O
, O
or O
neutrality O
. O

In O
each O
picture O
, O
one O
person O
’ O
s O
face O
was O
masked O
and O
participants O
chose O
which O
of O
two O
faces O
depicted O
the O
emotion O
of O
the O
masked O
actor O
. O

We O
mean-centered O
accuracy O
rates O
to O
the O
control O
group O
, O
and O
then O
averaged O
the O
transformed O
accuracy O
scores O
to O
obtain O
the O
mentalizing O
domain O
score O
. O

Social O
functioning O
Social O
attainment O
We O
assessed O
social O
attainment O
using O
the O
interview O
version O
of O
the O
Specific O
Levels O
of O
Functioning O
Scale O
( O
SLOF O
) O
, O
which O
is O
a O
30 O
item O
interview-based O
measure O
that O
assesses O
the O
following O
domains O
of O
social O
attainment O
: O
interpersonal O
relationships O
, O
social O
acceptability O
, O
activities O
of O
daily O
living O
, O
and O
work O
skills O
. O

Higher O
scores O
on O
the O
SLOF O
indicate O
better O
social O
attainment O
( O
range O
= O
84–150 O
) O
. O

Variance O
in O
SLOF O
scores O
did O
not O
significantly O
differ O
between O
groups O
( O
F27,31 O
= O
1.38 O
, O
P O
= O
.39 O
) O
. O

The O
SLOF O
is O
considered O
the O
gold O
standard O
for O
assessing O
current O
functioning O
based O
on O
findings O
from O
the O
VALERO O
Study O
. O

Social O
competence O
We O
assessed O
social O
competence O
using O
the O
Social O
Skills O
Performance O
Assessment O
( O
SSPA O
) O
, O
which O
is O
comprised O
of O
2 O
role-play O
scenes O
between O
a O
trained O
actor O
and O
the O
participant O
that O
are O
video-recorded O
. O

The O
scenes O
involve O
meeting O
a O
new O
neighbor O
and O
making O
a O
maintenance O
request O
to O
a O
landlord O
. O

Two O
trained O
research O
assistants O
rated O
the O
performance O
on O
a O
5-point O
scale O
across O
8 O
criteria O
for O
the O
first O
scene O
and O
9 O
criteria O
for O
the O
second O
scene O
. O

Additional O
details O
on O
the O
use O
of O
this O
measure O
can O
be O
found O
here O
: O
. O

We O
calculated O
a O
final O
score O
by O
averaging O
the O
scores O
for O
each O
scene O
( O
ICC O
= O
.97 O
for O
2 O
blinded O
raters O
on O
25 O
% O
of O
the O
videos O
) O
. O

Higher O
scores O
on O
the O
SSPA O
indicate O
better O
social O
competence O
( O
range O
= O
1.66–5.00 O
) O
. O

Variance O
in O
SSPA O
scores O
did O
not O
significantly O
differ O
between O
groups O
( O
F22,26 O
= O
1.89 O
, O
P O
= O
.12 O
) O
. O

The O
SSPA O
is O
considered O
the O
gold O
standard O
for O
assessing O
social O
competence O
in O
schizophrenia O
. O

fMRI O
data O
acquisition O
and O
pICA O
Resting-state O
scans O
were O
acquired O
on O
a O
3T O
TIM O
Trio O
system O
( O
Siemens O
Medical O
Systems O
) O
scanner O
at O
Northwestern O
University O
’ O
s O
Feinberg O
School O
of O
Medicine O
for O
the O
study O
sample O
. O

The O
scanning O
parameters O
included O
: O
gradient-echo O
echo-planar O
imaging O
of O
164 O
volumes O
; O
repetition O
time O
( O
TR O
) O
= O
2.5 O
s O
; O
echo O
time O
( O
TE O
) O
= O
20 O
ms O
; O
flip O
angle O
= O
80° O
; O
voxel O
size O
= O
1.7 O
× O
1.7 O
× O
3 O
mm O
. O

The O
group-level O
spatial O
maps O
were O
derived O
from O
resting-state O
scans O
of O
an O
independent O
community O
sample O
of O
218 O
volunteers O
collected O
at O
the O
University O
of O
Minnesota O
( O
mean O
age O
= O
26 O
years O
[ O
range O
20 O
to O
39 O
] O
, O
49 O
% O
male O
) O
. O

Data O
were O
preprocessed O
using O
the O
following O
preprocessing O
steps O
in O
the O
MELODIC O
( O
Multivariate O
Exploratory O
Linear O
Optimized O
Decomposition O
into O
Independent O
Components O
) O
toolkit O
in O
FSL O
( O
http O
: O
//fsl.fmrib.ox.ac.uk/fsl/fslwiki/MELODIC O
) O
: O
brain O
extraction O
, O
motion O
correction O
, O
and O
high-pass O
temporal O
filtering O
( O
threshold O
of O
0.1 O
Hz O
) O
. O

As O
a O
final O
step O
, O
the O
data O
underwent O
motion O
regression O
outside O
of O
FSL O
using O
participant-specific O
movement O
parameters O
generated O
during O
registration O
. O

As O
noted O
previously O
, O
the O
group-level O
spatial O
maps O
were O
generated O
from O
a O
larger O
dataset O
of O
218 O
community O
volunteers O
using O
a O
meta-melodic O
spatial O
pICA O
pipeline O
. O

More O
specifically O
, O
the O
MELODIC O
function O
in O
FSL O
was O
used O
to O
run O
25 O
temporal O
concatenation O
( O
model-free O
and O
multi-subject O
) O
group-level O
pICAs O
. O

Each O
ICA O
included O
a O
random O
order O
of O
80 O
participants O
as O
inputs O
to O
decrease O
the O
likelihood O
of O
over-fitting O
, O
with O
a O
dimensionality O
constraint O
of O
60 O
based O
on O
reliability O
research O
and O
findings O
that O
large-scale O
networks O
, O
such O
as O
the O
DMN O
, O
fractionate O
at O
higher O
dimensionalities O
. O

The O
60 O
components O
from O
each O
ICA O
were O
merged O
into O
one O
file O
which O
was O
used O
as O
the O
input O
to O
a O
meta-level O
MELODIC O
( O
meta-ICA O
) O
. O

The O
meta-ICA O
generated O
the O
60 O
most O
consistent O
group-level O
components O
. O

Visual O
inspection O
was O
done O
to O
identify O
artifactual O
components O
, O
which O
included O
components O
likely O
to O
show O
homeostatic O
fluctuations O
, O
white O
matter O
tracts O
, O
or O
movement O
. O

27 O
non-artifactual O
components O
were O
identified O
following O
these O
procedures O
. O

As O
recommended O
by O
prior O
research O
, O
we O
used O
maps O
from O
this O
external O
sample O
because O
maps O
generated O
from O
larger O
datasets O
are O
likely O
to O
be O
more O
robust O
and O
these O
maps O
were O
unbiased O
to O
the O
schizophrenia O
or O
control O
groups O
used O
in O
the O
present O
study O
. O

We O
also O
used O
ICA O
maps O
from O
this O
larger O
dataset O
rather O
than O
mPFC O
and O
PCC O
atlas O
masks O
because O
we O
did O
not O
want O
to O
make O
assumptions O
regarding O
exactly O
which O
voxels O
may O
contribute O
to O
a O
network O
. O

By O
using O
maps O
from O
an O
external O
sample O
, O
we O
were O
able O
to O
assess O
functional O
connectivity O
within O
and O
between O
functionally-derived O
networks O
as O
opposed O
to O
structurally-defined O
networks O
. O

We O
applied O
the O
group-level O
spatial O
maps O
from O
the O
external O
dataset O
to O
our O
current O
dataset O
through O
FSL O
’ O
s O
dual-regression O
function O
. O

This O
enabled O
us O
to O
derive O
individual O
timeseries O
and O
corresponding O
spatial O
maps O
for O
the O
current O
participants O
. O

We O
used O
the O
participant-specific O
timeseries O
and O
spatial O
maps O
to O
compute O
connectivity O
metrics O
for O
each O
participant O
. O

Inter-network O
connectivity O
metric O
computations O
We O
used O
dual O
regression O
to O
create O
connectivity O
maps O
and O
time O
courses O
for O
each O
subject O
based O
on O
the O
group-level O
spatial O
maps O
from O
the O
meta-ICA O
. O

We O
calculated O
inter-network O
connectivity O
metrics O
between O
all O
group-level O
spatial O
maps O
using O
the O
participant-level O
timeseries O
data O
from O
the O
dual O
regression O
. O

These O
values O
were O
Pearson O
correlations O
between O
all O
pairs O
of O
participant-level O
timeseries O
( O
i.e. O
, O
for O
all O
combinations O
of O
the O
60 O
networks O
) O
, O
and O
reflect O
the O
temporal O
association O
between O
network O
pairs O
. O

Group-level O
means O
were O
calculated O
using O
Fischer-Z O
values O
, O
and O
were O
transformed O
back O
to O
r-values O
for O
reporting O
. O

In O
the O
current O
study O
, O
we O
were O
interested O
in O
connectivity O
between O
the O
mPFC O
and O
the O
PPC O
( O
see O
Supplemental O
Figure O
1 O
) O
. O

Of O
the O
60 O
group-level O
spatial O
maps O
, O
three O
non-artifactual O
components O
included O
mPFC O
and O
twelve O
non-artifactual O
components O
included O
PPC O
( O
see O
Supplemental O
Table O
1 O
) O
. O

We O
examined O
the O
4 O
components O
that O
included O
an O
mPFC O
or O
PPC-overlap O
of O
at O
least O
750 O
voxels O
in O
our O
analyses O
to O
ensure O
appropriate O
mPFC O
or O
PPC O
contribution O
. O

These O
components O
included O
the O
following O
compositions O
: O
the O
PPC O
, O
the O
mPFC O
, O
the O
precuneus O
( O
P O
) O
, O
and O
the O
orbitofrontal O
cortex O
( O
OFC O
) O
. O

Other O
areas O
such O
as O
the O
OFC O
and O
angular O
gyrus O
( O
included O
in O
the O
PPC O
component O
) O
likely O
emerged O
through O
this O
analysis O
because O
they O
are O
highly O
functionally O
connected O
to O
the O
main O
DMN O
hubs O
and O
are O
related O
to O
social O
functioning O
. O

The O
inter-network O
connectivity O
metrics O
were O
then O
as O
follows O
: O
1 O
) O
PPC-to-P O
metric O
, O
2 O
) O
mPFC-to-PPC O
metric O
, O
3 O
) O
OFC-to-PPC O
metric O
, O
4 O
) O
mPFC-to-P O
metric O
, O
5 O
) O
OFC-to-P O
metric O
, O
and O
6 O
) O
mPFC-to-OFC O
metric O
( O
see O
Table O
1 O
for O
a O
full O
description O
of O
these O
metrics O
) O
. O

Potential O
movement O
confounds O
Movement O
was O
calculated O
as O
the O
root O
mean O
square O
( O
RMS O
) O
absolute O
and O
incremental O
movement O
for O
each O
group O
. O

We O
did O
not O
detect O
group O
differences O
in O
absolute O
( O
x̄absCON O
= O
0.36 O
, O
x̄absSCZ O
= O
0.31 O
, O
t45= O
−0.90 O
, O
P O
= O
0.37 O
) O
or O
incremental O
( O
x̄incCON O
= O
0.05 O
, O
x̄incSCZ O
= O
0.05 O
, O
t45= O
−0.73 O
, O
P O
= O
0.47 O
) O
movement O
. O

RMS O
incremental O
movement O
was O
significantly O
correlated O
with O
the O
PPC-to-P O
metric O
( O
r O
= O
0.31 O
, O
P O
< O
.05 O
) O
. O

Neither O
RMS O
absolute O
nor O
incremental O
movement O
was O
correlated O
with O
the O
other O
inter-network O
connectivity O
metrics O
, O
social O
attainment O
, O
or O
social O
competence O
( O
all O
P O
> O
.10 O
) O
. O

Therefore O
, O
we O
only O
included O
RMS O
incremental O
movement O
as O
a O
covariate O
in O
models O
that O
contained O
the O
PPC-to-P O
metric O
. O

Statistical O
Analyses O
Demographic O
and O
behavioral O
analyses O
Group O
differences O
for O
demographic O
variables O
, O
neurocognitive O
performance O
, O
social O
perception O
, O
mentalizing O
, O
social O
attainment O
, O
and O
social O
competence O
were O
evaluated O
using O
t-tests O
for O
continuous O
variables O
and O
chi-square O
( O
χ2 O
) O
tests O
for O
categorical O
variables O
. O

Connectivity O
analyses O
We O
used O
multivariate O
analysis O
of O
variance O
( O
MANOVA O
) O
to O
evaluate O
whether O
individuals O
with O
schizophrenia O
differed O
from O
controls O
with O
respect O
to O
the O
DMN O
connectivity O
metrics O
; O
in O
this O
model O
the O
PPC-to-P O
, O
mPFC-to-PPC O
, O
OFC-to-PPC O
, O
mPFC-to-P O
, O
OFC-to-P O
, O
and O
mPFC-to-OFC O
metrics O
served O
as O
the O
dependent O
variables O
. O

Connectivity O
and O
social O
functioning O
analyses O
Main O
Effects O
Model O
We O
used O
robust O
linear O
regression O
to O
assess O
the O
associations O
between O
our O
DMN O
connectivity O
variables O
and O
social O
attainment O
and O
social O
competence O
. O

More O
specifically O
, O
we O
created O
two O
models O
with O
social O
attainment O
as O
the O
dependent O
variable O
in O
the O
first O
model O
, O
social O
competence O
as O
the O
dependent O
variable O
in O
the O
second O
model O
, O
and O
the O
PPC-to-P O
, O
mPFC-to-PPC O
, O
OFC-to-PPC O
, O
mPFC-to-P O
, O
OFC-to-P O
, O
and O
mPFC-to-OFC O
metrics O
and O
group O
status O
as O
the O
independent O
variables O
in O
both O
models O
. O

We O
used O
the O
modeling O
package O
‘ O
robust O
’ O
in O
R O
to O
adjust O
for O
the O
presence O
of O
multivariate O
outliers O
. O

To O
rule O
out O
RMS O
incremental O
movement O
as O
confounds O
, O
we O
re-assessed O
the O
association O
between O
DMN O
connectivity O
and O
social O
attainment O
and O
social O
competence O
while O
including O
the O
aforementioned O
variable O
as O
a O
covariate O
. O

Follow-up O
Interaction O
Models O
We O
used O
robust O
linear O
regression O
to O
examine O
between-group O
differences O
in O
the O
associations O
between O
DMN O
connectivity O
and O
social O
attainment O
and O
social O
competence O
. O

To O
conserve O
power O
, O
we O
only O
included O
DMN O
connectivity O
metrics O
that O
were O
significantly O
associated O
with O
social O
attainment O
or O
social O
competence O
in O
the O
main O
effects O
models O
. O

We O
again O
created O
two O
models O
with O
social O
attainment O
as O
the O
dependent O
variable O
in O
the O
first O
model O
, O
social O
competence O
as O
the O
dependent O
variable O
in O
the O
second O
model O
, O
and O
the O
mPFC-to-PPC O
metric O
, O
group O
status O
, O
and O
a O
group-by-connectivity O
interaction O
term O
as O
the O
independent O
variables O
in O
both O
models O
. O

Based O
on O
prior O
research O
suggesting O
that O
social O
status O
may O
be O
associated O
with O
neural O
activity O
in O
the O
main O
DMN O
hubs O
, O
we O
included O
parental O
SES O
as O
a O
covariate O
in O
both O
models O
. O

To O
account O
for O
the O
association O
between O
neurocognitive O
and O
social O
deficits O
observed O
in O
schizophrenia O
, O
we O
also O
included O
mean O
global O
neurocognition O
as O
a O
covariate O
in O
both O
models O
. O

Finally O
, O
we O
included O
gender O
and O
age O
as O
covariates O
in O
both O
models O
given O
research O
that O
shows O
gender O
and O
age-related O
resting-state O
connectivity O
differences O
. O

Mediation O
analyses O
In O
order O
for O
a O
variable O
to O
be O
a O
mediator O
, O
it O
must O
be O
related O
to O
both O
the O
independent O
and O
dependent O
variables O
. O

Therefore O
, O
to O
determine O
if O
mediation O
analyses O
were O
appropriate O
for O
our O
proposed O
mediators O
( O
i.e. O
, O
social O
perception O
and O
mentalizing O
) O
, O
we O
first O
examined O
Pearson O
correlations O
to O
see O
whether O
the O
proposed O
mediators O
were O
significantly O
correlated O
with O
the O
social O
functioning O
variables O
and O
DMN O
connectivity O
in O
individuals O
with O
schizophrenia O
. O

For O
any O
significant O
associations O
, O
we O
performed O
mediation O
analyses O
to O
see O
if O
social O
perception O
or O
mentalizing O
mediated O
these O
associations O
. O

Connectivity O
and O
activities O
of O
daily O
living O
analysis O
As O
a O
final O
step O
, O
we O
assessed O
the O
specificity O
of O
any O
DMN O
connectivity O
and O
social O
functioning O
associations O
. O

Specifically O
, O
we O
tested O
for O
associations O
between O
DMN O
connectivity O
and O
a O
performance-based O
daily O
living O
skills O
measure O
( O
UPSA-B O
) O
. O

The O
neural O
correlates O
of O
priming O
emotion O
and O
reward O
systems O
for O
conflict O
processing O
in O
alcoholics O
Emotional O
dysregulation O
in O
alcoholism O
( O
ALC O
) O
may O
result O
from O
disturbed O
inhibitory O
mechanisms O
. O

We O
therefore O
tested O
emotion O
and O
alcohol O
cue O
reactivity O
and O
inhibitory O
processes O
using O
negative O
priming O
. O

To O
test O
the O
neural O
correlates O
of O
cue O
reactivity O
and O
negative O
priming O
, O
26 O
ALC O
and O
26 O
age-matched O
controls O
underwent O
functional O
MRI O
performing O
a O
Stroop O
color O
match-to-sample O
task O
. O

In O
cue O
reactivity O
trials O
, O
task-irrelevant O
emotion O
and O
alcohol-related O
pictures O
were O
interspersed O
between O
color O
samples O
and O
color O
words O
. O

In O
negative O
priming O
trials O
, O
pictures O
primed O
the O
semantic O
content O
of O
an O
alcohol O
or O
emotion O
Stroop O
word O
. O

Behaviorally O
, O
both O
groups O
showed O
response O
facilitation O
to O
picture O
cue O
trials O
and O
response O
inhibition O
to O
primed O
trials O
. O

For O
cue O
reactivity O
to O
emotion O
and O
alcohol O
pictures O
, O
ALC O
showed O
midbrain-limbic O
activation O
. O

By O
contrast O
, O
controls O
activated O
frontoparietal O
executive O
control O
regions O
. O

Greater O
midbrain-hippocampal O
activation O
in O
ALC O
correlated O
with O
higher O
amounts O
of O
lifetime O
alcohol O
consumption O
and O
higher O
anxiety O
. O

With O
negative O
priming O
, O
ALC O
exhibited O
frontal O
cortical O
but O
not O
midbrain-hippocampal O
activation O
, O
similar O
to O
the O
pattern O
observed O
in O
controls O
. O

Higher O
frontal O
activation O
to O
alcohol-priming O
correlated O
with O
less O
craving O
and O
to O
emotion-priming O
with O
fewer O
depressive O
symptoms O
. O

The O
findings O
suggest O
that O
neurofunctional O
systems O
in O
ALC O
can O
be O
primed O
to O
deal O
with O
upcoming O
emotion- O
and O
alcohol-related O
conflict O
and O
can O
overcome O
the O
prepotent O
midbrain-limbic O
cue O
reactivity O
response O
. O

Methods O
and O
materials O
Participants O
Study O
participants O
were O
26 O
abstinent O
chronic O
alcohol-dependent O
patients O
( O
ALC O
) O
and O
26 O
age O
and O
sex-matched O
controls O
( O
CTL O
) O
. O

Functional O
neuroimaging O
data O
from O
overlapping O
samples O
were O
published O
for O
different O
tasks O
and O
resting-state O
. O

Here O
, O
we O
focused O
on O
priming O
neural O
systems O
for O
emotion O
and O
alcohol-related O
conflict O
processing O
using O
a O
novel O
‘ O
Priming O
Alcohol O
and O
Emotion O
’ O
Stroop O
Match-to-Sample O
paradigm O
. O

ALC O
participants O
were O
recruited O
from O
local O
rehabilitation O
programs O
and O
self-help O
groups O
; O
controls O
were O
volunteers O
from O
the O
local O
community O
recruited O
through O
flyers O
, O
announcements O
, O
or O
word O
of O
mouth O
. O

All O
subjects O
underwent O
a O
Structural O
Clinical O
Interview O
for O
DSM-IV O
( O
SCID O
) O
to O
determine O
the O
diagnosis O
of O
alcohol O
dependence O
by O
consensus O
of O
at O
least O
two O
calibrated O
interviewers O
( O
clinical O
research O
psychologists O
, O
research O
nurse O
) O
and O
to O
characterize O
psychiatric O
history O
. O

History O
of O
schizophrenia O
and O
bipolar O
disorders O
were O
exclusions O
; O
the O
healthy O
control O
group O
had O
no O
current O
or O
past O
Axis O
1 O
psychiatric O
disorder O
. O

Current O
use O
of O
psychoactive O
medications O
; O
history O
of O
major O
neurological O
or O
medical O
disorder O
, O
head O
trauma O
with O
loss O
of O
consciousness O
( O
> O
30 O
min O
) O
, O
MRI O
contraindications O
( O
e.g. O
, O
irremovable O
metal O
) O
, O
color-blindness O
, O
and O
non-correctable O
vision O
were O
also O
exclusions O
. O

Although O
ALC O
were O
not O
necessarily O
seeking O
treatment O
at O
the O
time O
of O
the O
study O
, O
they O
had O
sought O
treatment O
at O
some O
time O
during O
the O
course O
of O
their O
disease O
. O

Of O
the O
26 O
ALC O
, O
25 O
met O
DSM-IV O
criteria O
for O
alcohol O
dependence O
and O
one O
for O
alcohol O
abuse O
( O
who O
was O
not O
an O
outlier O
from O
the O
ALC O
group O
and O
within O
the O
distributions O
for O
lifetime O
alcohol O
consumption O
and O
AUDIT O
scores O
) O
; O
24 O
were O
in O
early O
remission O
( O
met O
alcohol O
dependence O
criteria O
for O
≥3 O
months O
and O
< O
12 O
months O
) O
; O
one O
was O
in O
sustained O
remission O
( O
> O
12 O
months O
) O
by O
10 O
days O
, O
i.e. O
, O
had O
last O
met O
alcohol O
dependence O
criteria O
375 O
days O
ago O
. O

Additional O
clinical O
scales O
were O
administered O
to O
quantify O
alcoholism O
severity O
( O
the O
Alcohol O
Use O
Disorders O
Identification O
Test O
( O
AUDIT O
) O
) O
, O
subjective O
craving O
shortly O
before O
fMRI O
acquisition O
( O
Short O
Item O
Scale O
Alcohol O
Craving O
Questionnaire-Revised O
( O
ACQ-R O
) O
) O
, O
and O
emotional O
state O
( O
State-Trait O
Anxiety O
Inventory O
( O
STAI O
) O
, O
Beck O
Depression O
Inventory O
( O
BDI-II O
) O
) O
. O

Here O
, O
alcoholics O
with O
higher O
anxiety O
( O
STAI-S O
scores O
) O
also O
reported O
higher O
alcohol O
craving O
( O
ACQ-R O
scores O
) O
( O
ALC O
: O
Rho O
= O
.47 O
, O
p O
= O
0.009 O
; O
CTL O
: O
Rho O
= O
.02 O
, O
ns O
) O
. O

None O
of O
the O
controls O
and O
46 O
% O
of O
ALC O
met O
DSM-IV O
criteria O
for O
past O
drug O
dependence O
with O
cocaine O
being O
used O
most O
often O
by O
35 O
% O
( O
n O
= O
9 O
) O
, O
amphetamines O
by O
12 O
% O
( O
n O
= O
3 O
) O
, O
and O
opioids O
by O
12 O
% O
( O
n O
= O
3 O
) O
. O

In O
all O
cases O
alcohol O
was O
the O
drug O
of O
choice O
and O
alcohol O
dependence O
was O
more O
recent O
than O
drug O
dependence O
. O

The O
median O
numbers O
of O
years O
since O
last O
use O
was O
as O
follows O
: O
cocaine O
: O
1.3 O
years O
; O
amphetamines O
: O
6.5 O
years O
; O
and O
opioids O
: O
2 O
years O
. O

Current O
smokers O
included O
14 O
ALC O
and O
3 O
control O
subjects O
( O
χ2 O
( O
1 O
) O
= O
10.6 O
, O
p O
= O
0.001 O
) O
. O

Demographic O
data O
, O
alcohol O
and O
substance O
use O
history O
, O
mood O
, O
and O
premorbid O
intelligence O
scores O
are O
in O
Table O
1 O
. O

The O
groups O
were O
matched O
in O
handedness O
and O
did O
not O
differ O
in O
visual O
acuity O
, O
body O
mass O
index O
( O
BMI O
) O
, O
and O
physiological O
measures O
( O
heart O
rate O
, O
blood O
pressure O
) O
. O

Although O
the O
ALC O
had O
fewer O
years O
of O
education O
and O
a O
lower O
socioeconomic O
status O
( O
SES O
) O
than O
controls O
, O
both O
groups O
had O
received O
an O
average O
education O
beyond O
high O
school O
. O

Procedure O
The O
study O
was O
approved O
by O
the O
Institutional O
Review O
Boards O
at O
SRI O
International O
and O
Stanford O
University O
School O
of O
Medicine O
. O

All O
participants O
gave O
written O
informed O
consent O
for O
study O
participation O
. O

Stimuli O
and O
experimental O
design O
All O
subjects O
performed O
the O
‘ O
Priming O
emotion O
and O
alcohol O
Stroop O
Match-to-Sample O
’ O
task O
during O
fMRI O
acquisition O
using O
a O
clinical O
whole-body O
GE O
3 O
T O
scanner O
. O

Stimuli O
were O
presented O
through O
a O
rear-projection O
system O
and O
viewed O
via O
a O
mirror O
attached O
to O
the O
head O
coil O
. O

Alcohol O
and O
emotion O
priming O
- O
Stroop O
match-to-sample O
task O
The O
task O
containing O
color O
, O
word O
, O
and O
picture O
stimuli O
was O
presented O
with O
PsyScope O
software O
and O
synchronized O
with O
the O
MRI O
acquisition O
via O
the O
fORP O
system O
interface O
( O
www.curdes.com O
) O
. O

Stroop O
match-to-sample O
: O
Similar O
to O
previous O
versions O
of O
the O
Stroop O
Match-to-Sample O
task O
( O
e.g. O
, O
) O
, O
subjects O
were O
instructed O
to O
match O
the O
color O
of O
a O
sample O
stimulus O
displayed O
for O
700 O
ms O
in O
the O
center O
of O
the O
screen O
to O
the O
font O
color O
of O
a O
Stroop O
word O
stimulus O
that O
appeared O
for O
1100 O
ms O
thereafter O
( O
Fig O
. O

1a O
) O
. O

The O
color O
samples O
and O
Stroop O
word O
colors O
were O
red O
, O
green O
, O
or O
blue O
. O

The O
Stroop O
word O
was O
either O
congruent O
( O
word O
RED O
written O
in O
red O
font O
) O
or O
incongruent O
( O
word O
RED O
written O
in O
blue O
font O
) O
. O

The O
font O
color O
of O
the O
Stroop O
word O
either O
matched O
or O
did O
not O
match O
the O
sample O
color O
. O

For O
color O
matches O
, O
subjects O
pressed O
a O
YES-key O
and O
for O
non-color O
matches O
, O
a O
NO-key O
using O
their O
dominant O
hand O
, O
thereby O
providing O
measures O
of O
reaction O
time O
and O
accuracy O
for O
each O
trial O
. O

For O
incongruent-nonmatch O
color-Stroop O
conditions O
, O
the O
sample O
color O
always O
matched O
the O
word O
content O
( O
e.g. O
, O
blue O
sample O
, O
word O
BLUE O
written O
in O
red O
font O
color O
) O
. O

In O
contrast O
to O
previous O
task O
versions O
, O
a O
picture O
of O
an O
alcoholic O
beverage O
, O
an O
emotional O
face O
( O
angry O
, O
happy O
) O
( O
MacBrain O
Face O
Stimulus O
Set O
; O
www.macbrain.org/resources.htm O
) O
, O
or O
neutral O
gray O
patch O
was O
presented O
for O
700 O
ms O
between O
the O
color O
sample O
and O
the O
Stroop O
word O
( O
Fig O
. O

1 O
) O
. O

This O
task O
was O
designed O
to O
study O
cue O
reactivity O
( O
Fig O
. O

1b O
) O
and O
priming O
of O
an O
upcoming O
emotion O
and O
alcohol-related O
conflict O
( O
Fig O
. O

1c O
) O
by O
using O
pictures O
that O
validly O
predicted O
the O
word O
’ O
s O
content O
and O
to O
identify O
processing O
differences O
between O
ALC O
and O
controls O
. O

Cue O
reactivity O
: O
To O
test O
cue O
reactivity O
to O
emotional O
face O
and O
alcohol O
beverage O
picture O
trials O
( O
vs. O
neutral O
trials O
) O
, O
congruent O
non-conflicting O
Stroop O
words O
were O
used O
( O
Fig O
. O

1b O
) O
. O

Priming O
Stroop O
: O
To O
test O
the O
effect O
of O
priming O
emotion O
and O
alcohol-related O
conflict O
, O
Stroop O
words O
had O
an O
alcohol O
( O
e.g. O
, O
BEER O
, O
WINE O
, O
WHISKEY O
) O
, O
emotionally O
positive O
( O
e.g. O
, O
HAPPY O
, O
JOY O
, O
GLAD O
) O
, O
or O
negative O
content O
( O
e.g. O
, O
ANGRY O
, O
MAD O
, O
FURIOUS O
) O
; O
each O
word O
was O
printed O
in O
red O
, O
blue O
, O
or O
green O
font O
color O
( O
Fig O
. O

1 O
) O
. O

The O
content O
of O
the O
picture O
always O
primed O
the O
content O
of O
the O
Stroop O
word O
, O
e.g. O
, O
an O
angry O
face O
preceded O
the O
word O
ANGRY O
and O
a O
picture O
of O
a O
glass O
of O
wine O
preceded O
the O
word O
WINE O
. O

The O
task O
was O
to O
“ O
match O
colors O
” O
and O
, O
consequently O
, O
the O
picture O
prime O
and O
Stroop O
word O
content O
were O
not O
relevant O
for O
accurate O
performance O
. O

The O
Stroop O
word O
’ O
s O
content O
( O
incongruent O
color O
: O
; O
emotion O
: O
; O
reward-related O
: O
) O
is O
assumed O
to O
be O
processed O
automatically O
and O
to O
elicit O
prepotent O
responses O
that O
need O
to O
be O
inhibited O
to O
correctly O
and O
efficiently O
perform O
the O
color-matching O
task O
. O

Accordingly O
, O
Stroop O
effects O
to O
primed O
alcohol O
and O
emotion O
Stroop O
conditions O
are O
operationalized O
to O
test O
‘ O
current O
need O
or O
state O
, O
’ O
in O
ALC O
relative O
to O
controls O
, O
and O
to O
weigh O
against O
conditions O
of O
‘ O
neutral O
state O
’ O
( O
color O
) O
conditions O
. O

At O
the O
behavioral O
level O
, O
the O
Stroop O
effect O
( O
interference O
from O
the O
Stroop O
word O
’ O
s O
content O
) O
is O
defined O
as O
the O
difference O
in O
reaction O
time O
( O
RT O
) O
to O
incongruent O
and O
congruent O
color-word O
stimuli O
( O
Fig O
. O

1a O
) O
. O

Similarly O
, O
alcohol O
and O
emotion O
Stroop O
effects O
were O
defined O
as O
the O
difference O
in O
RT O
between O
alcohol/emotion O
words O
and O
congruent O
color-word O
stimuli O
( O
Fig O
. O

1c O
) O
, O
equivalent O
to O
previous O
reports O
. O

As O
in O
previous O
task O
versions O
, O
trials O
were O
presented O
in O
two O
block O
types O
: O
response O
repetition O
( O
RR O
) O
and O
response O
switching O
( O
RS O
) O
blocks O
. O

RR O
and O
RS O
blocks O
comprised O
the O
same O
96 O
match O
and O
nonmatch O
trials O
, O
only O
in O
a O
different O
order O
: O
In O
RS O
blocks O
, O
color O
match O
and O
nonmatch O
trials O
were O
presented O
in O
a O
pseudo-random O
order O
and O
required O
switching O
between O
YES O
( O
sample-target O
colors O
match O
) O
and O
NO O
responses O
( O
sample-target O
colors O
do O
not O
match O
) O
; O
in O
RR O
blocks O
, O
either O
color O
match O
( O
YES O
responses O
) O
or O
nonmatch O
trials O
( O
NO O
responses O
) O
were O
presented O
and O
did O
therefore O
not O
require O
response O
switches O
. O

This O
allowed O
testing O
the O
effect O
of O
repetitive O
behavior O
on O
cue O
reactivity O
and O
Stroop O
effects O
. O

To O
quantify O
Stroop O
effects O
within O
a O
block O
design O
, O
incongruent O
and O
congruent O
trials O
were O
never O
mixed O
within O
a O
block O
. O

Consistent O
with O
our O
experience O
with O
previous O
task O
versions O
of O
the O
Stroop O
Match-to-Sample O
task O
, O
subjects O
were O
not O
aware O
about O
the O
blocked O
trial O
design O
, O
as O
indicated O
in O
post-scan O
interviews O
. O

All O
study O
participants O
underwent O
two O
runs O
of O
the O
alcohol-emotion O
priming O
Stroop O
match-to-sample O
task O
within O
the O
same O
scan O
session O
; O
each O
run O
contained O
6 O
stimulation O
blocks O
for O
each O
condition O
: O
alcohol O
, O
positive O
and O
negative O
emotion O
, O
and O
color O
( O
block O
= O
8TRs O
; O
TR O
= O
2.2 O
s O
) O
. O

Total O
number O
of O
trials O
was O
192 O
. O

All O
subjects O
performed O
a O
practice O
session O
before O
entering O
the O
scanner O
, O
and O
test O
instructions O
were O
reviewed O
through O
the O
scanner O
’ O
s O
intercom O
system O
before O
each O
run O
. O

Magnetic O
resonance O
imaging O
( O
MRI O
) O
Data O
acquisition O
and O
analyses O
Subject O
motion O
was O
minimized O
by O
following O
standard O
practices O
for O
head O
fixation O
, O
such O
as O
additional O
padding O
of O
the O
neck O
and O
the O
sides O
of O
the O
head O
and O
use O
of O
a O
head O
strap O
. O

Whole-brain O
fMRI O
data O
were O
acquired O
with O
a O
T2 O
* O
-weighted O
gradient O
echo-planar O
pulse O
sequence O
( O
2D O
axial O
, O
TE O
= O
30 O
ms O
; O
TR O
= O
2200 O
ms O
; O
flip O
angle O
= O
90° O
; O
in O
plane O
resolution O
= O
3.75 O
× O
3.75mm2 O
; O
thick O
= O
5 O
mm O
; O
gap O
= O
0 O
mm O
; O
number O
of O
slices O
= O
36 O
; O
FOV O
= O
240×240mm2 O
; O
1 O
NEX O
) O
. O

A O
dual-echo O
fast O
spin O
echo O
( O
FSE O
) O
scan O
was O
acquired O
( O
2D O
axial O
; O
TR O
= O
5000 O
ms O
; O
TE O
= O
17/102 O
ms O
; O
thick O
= O
5 O
mm O
; O
gap O
= O
0 O
mm O
; O
xy O
matrix O
= O
256 O
× O
256 O
; O
flip O
angle O
= O
90° O
; O
number O
of O
slices O
= O
36 O
; O
FOV O
= O
240×240mm2 O
; O
1 O
NEX O
) O
and O
used O
for O
spatially O
registering O
the O
fMRI O
data O
. O

Image O
preprocessing O
and O
statistical O
analyses O
The O
fMRI O
analysis O
was O
done O
with O
the O
SPM8 O
software O
package O
( O
Wellcome O
Department O
of O
Cognitive O
Neurology O
, O
UK O
; O
http O
: O
//www.fil.ion.ucl.ac.uk/spm/ O
) O
and O
focused O
on O
the O
whole O
brain O
. O

The O
functional O
images O
were O
subjected O
to O
geometric O
distortion O
( O
field O
map O
) O
correction O
and O
the O
time-series O
were O
realigned O
to O
the O
first O
image O
as O
reference O
image O
to O
remove O
movement O
artifacts O
in O
fMRI O
. O

The O
FSE O
structural O
images O
were O
co-registered O
to O
the O
mean O
unwarped O
and O
motion-corrected O
functional O
image O
for O
each O
subject O
and O
segmented O
into O
gray O
and O
white O
matter O
images O
. O

Functional O
and O
structural O
gray O
matter O
images O
were O
normalized O
to O
Montreal O
Neurological O
Institute O
( O
MNI O
) O
space O
assuring O
that O
the O
fMRI O
signal O
was O
confined O
to O
gray O
matter O
. O

Functional O
volumes O
were O
smoothed O
with O
a O
Gaussian O
kernel O
of O
8 O
mm O
( O
FWHM O
) O
. O

Individual O
statistics O
were O
computed O
using O
a O
general O
linear O
model O
( O
GLM O
) O
approach O
as O
implemented O
in O
SPM8 O
and O
using O
the O
realignment O
parameters O
from O
each O
run O
as O
confounds O
. O

Statistical O
preprocessing O
consisted O
of O
high-pass O
filtering O
at O
70.4 O
s O
, O
low-pass O
filtering O
through O
convolution O
with O
the O
canonical O
hemodynamic O
response O
function O
, O
and O
global O
scaling O
. O

For O
first O
level O
analysis O
, O
one O
image O
per O
contrast O
was O
computed O
from O
a O
design O
matrix O
that O
included O
the O
task O
conditions O
as O
explanatory O
variables O
in O
addition O
to O
the O
estimated O
individual O
movement O
parameters O
as O
regressors O
. O

Cue O
reactivity O
contrasts O
of O
interest O
were O
derived O
at O
the O
individual O
analysis O
level O
for O
non-conflict O
trials O
( O
Fig O
. O

1b O
) O
: O
for O
Alcohol O
by O
contrasting O
alcohol O
beverage O
pictures O
to O
congruent O
( O
alcpic O
> O
con O
) O
conditions O
, O
for O
Positive-Emotion O
by O
contrasting O
happy O
face O
pictures O
to O
congruent O
( O
pospic O
> O
con O
) O
conditions O
, O
and O
for O
Negative-Emotion O
by O
contrasting O
angry O
face O
pictures O
to O
congruent O
( O
negpic O
> O
con O
) O
conditions O
. O

Priming O
Stroop O
conflict O
contrasts O
of O
interest O
were O
derived O
for O
alcohol O
and O
emotion O
word O
conflict O
trials O
( O
Fig O
. O

1c O
) O
: O
for O
Alcohol O
Stroop O
by O
contrasting O
alcohol O
to O
congruent O
( O
alc O
> O
con O
) O
conditions O
, O
for O
Positive-Emotion O
Stroop O
by O
contrasting O
positive O
emotion O
to O
congruent O
( O
pos O
> O
con O
) O
conditions O
, O
and O
for O
Negative-Emotion O
Stroop O
by O
contrasting O
positive O
emotion O
to O
congruent O
( O
neg O
> O
con O
) O
conditions O
. O

In O
addition O
, O
individual O
color O
Stroop O
contrasts O
, O
derived O
by O
contrasting O
incongruent O
to O
congruent O
color-word O
( O
inc O
> O
con O
) O
conditions O
( O
Fig O
. O

1a O
) O
, O
were O
added O
to O
the O
model O
for O
comparison O
( O
see O
also O
) O
. O

The O
individual O
contrast O
images O
were O
then O
subjected O
to O
random O
effects O
analyses O
for O
group O
averaging O
and O
population O
inference O
. O

The O
second O
level O
design O
matrix O
involved O
two O
factorial O
models O
, O
each O
with O
2 O
factors O
, O
which O
were O
for O
cue O
reactivity O
: O
group O
( O
ALC O
, O
CTL O
) O
and O
picture O
cue O
( O
alcohol O
beverage O
, O
happy O
faces O
, O
angry O
faces O
) O
, O
and O
for O
priming O
Stroop O
: O
group O
( O
ALC O
, O
CTL O
) O
and O
Stroop O
( O
color O
, O
alcohol O
, O
positive O
emotion O
, O
negative O
emotion O
) O
, O
and O
their O
interaction O
. O

Whole O
brain O
corrected O
p-thresholds O
for O
combined O
spatial O
extent O
and O
peak O
intensity O
( O
see O
also O
) O
were O
set O
at O
pcorrected O
< O
0.05 O
and O
calculated O
with O
3dClustSim O
( O
https O
: O
//afni.nimh.nih.gov/pub/dist/doc/program_help/3dClustSim.html O
) O
( O
see O
also O
) O
. O

Statistical O
analyses O
Data O
analysis O
of O
Stroop O
task O
performance O
was O
conducted O
with O
the O
statistical O
software O
package O
SPSS O
Statistics O
23.0 O
. O

Repeated O
measures O
analysis O
of O
variance O
( O
ANOVA O
) O
tested O
group O
effects O
( O
ALC O
, O
controls O
) O
for O
cue O
reactivity O
, O
color-word O
Stroop O
and O
primed O
alcohol-emotion O
Stroop O
. O

The O
alpha O
p O
level O
was O
set O
to O
0.05 O
. O

To O
test O
our O
directional O
hypothesis O
, O
where O
‘ O
current O
relevance O
or O
need O
’ O
in O
ALC O
( O
addiction O
severity O
, O
craving O
) O
would O
correlate O
with O
more O
cue O
reactivity O
and O
difficulty O
in O
executive O
control O
( O
greater O
Stroop O
conflict O
) O
, O
we O
used O
one-tailed O
Spearman O
Rho O
correlation O
( O
SPSS O
23.0 O
software O
package O
) O
. O

We O
extracted O
individual O
MR O
signal O
change O
from O
significant O
clusters O
in O
frontal O
, O
and O
midbrain-limbic-striatal O
regions O
( O
see O
Tables O
2–4 O
) O
using O
the O
matlab-based O
SPM-compatible O
MarsBar O
toolbox O
( O
http O
: O
//marsbar.sourceforge.net/marsbar.pdf O
) O
. O

These O
values O
were O
then O
read O
into O
SPSS O
to O
test O
our O
specific O
brain-behavior O
hypothesis O
that O
midbrain-limbic-striatal O
activity O
to O
emotion-and O
alcohol-related O
cues O
would O
be O
associated O
with O
craving O
intensity O
or O
addiction O
severity O
in O
ALC O
, O
and O
that O
frontal O
activity O
would O
be O
associated O
with O
the O
degree O
of O
interference O
from O
emotion- O
and O
alcohol-related O
stimulus O
content O
, O
i.e. O
, O
primed O
Stroop O
conflict O
, O
and O
extrastriate O
activation O
with O
less O
primed O
Stroop O
conflict O
. O

Significant O
voxel O
cluster O
of O
activation O
, O
specific O
to O
each O
contrast O
, O
were O
correlated O
with O
the O
respective O
behavioral O
effect O
( O
e.g. O
, O
for O
cue O
reactivity O
or O
primed O
Stroop O
effects O
) O
and O
mood O
scores O
( O
anxiety O
, O
BDI O
) O
, O
and O
in O
ALC O
with O
alcohol O
data O
( O
lifetime O
alcohol O
consumption O
, O
alcohol O
severity O
, O
craving O
) O
. O

Family-wise O
Bonferroni O
correction O
for O
6 O
comparisons O
required O
p O
levels O
between O
p O
≤ O
0.016 O
( O
for O
directed O
hypothesis O
, O
1-tailed O
) O
and O
p O
≤ O
.008 O
( O
2-tailed O
) O
. O

Comparison O
of O
large-scale O
human O
brain O
functional O
and O
anatomical O
networks O
in O
schizophrenia O
Schizophrenia O
is O
a O
disease O
with O
disruptions O
in O
thought O
, O
emotion O
, O
and O
behavior O
. O

The O
dysconnectivity O
hypothesis O
suggests O
these O
disruptions O
are O
due O
to O
aberrant O
brain O
connectivity O
. O

Many O
studies O
have O
identified O
connectivity O
differences O
but O
few O
have O
been O
able O
to O
unify O
gray O
and O
white O
matter O
findings O
into O
one O
model O
. O

Here O
we O
develop O
an O
extension O
of O
the O
Network-Based O
Statistic O
( O
NBS O
) O
called O
NBSm O
( O
Multimodal O
Network-based O
statistic O
) O
to O
compare O
functional O
and O
anatomical O
networks O
in O
schizophrenia O
. O

Structural O
, O
resting O
functional O
, O
and O
diffusion O
magnetic O
resonance O
imaging O
data O
were O
collected O
from O
29 O
chronic O
patients O
with O
schizophrenia O
and O
29 O
healthy O
controls O
. O

Images O
were O
preprocessed O
, O
and O
average O
time O
courses O
were O
extracted O
for O
90 O
regions O
of O
interest O
( O
ROI O
) O
. O

Functional O
connectivity O
matrices O
were O
estimated O
by O
pairwise O
correlations O
between O
wavelet O
coefficients O
of O
ROI O
time O
series O
. O

Following O
diffusion O
tractography O
, O
anatomical O
connectivity O
matrices O
were O
estimated O
by O
white O
matter O
streamline O
counts O
between O
each O
pair O
of O
ROIs O
. O

Global O
and O
regional O
strength O
were O
calculated O
for O
each O
modality O
. O

NBSm O
was O
used O
to O
find O
significant O
overlap O
between O
functional O
and O
anatomical O
components O
that O
distinguished O
health O
from O
schizophrenia O
. O

Global O
strength O
was O
decreased O
in O
patients O
in O
both O
functional O
and O
anatomical O
networks O
. O

Regional O
strength O
was O
decreased O
in O
all O
regions O
in O
functional O
networks O
and O
only O
one O
region O
in O
anatomical O
networks O
. O

NBSm O
identified O
a O
distinguishing O
functional O
component O
consisting O
of O
46 O
nodes O
with O
113 O
links O
( O
p O
< O
0.001 O
) O
, O
a O
distinguishing O
anatomical O
component O
with O
47 O
nodes O
and O
50 O
links O
( O
p O
= O
0.002 O
) O
, O
and O
a O
distinguishing O
intermodal O
component O
with O
26 O
nodes O
( O
p O
< O
0.001 O
) O
. O

NBSm O
is O
a O
powerful O
technique O
for O
understanding O
network-based O
group O
differences O
present O
in O
both O
anatomical O
and O
functional O
data O
. O

In O
light O
of O
the O
dysconnectivity O
hypothesis O
, O
these O
results O
provide O
compelling O
evidence O
for O
the O
presence O
of O
significant O
overlapping O
anatomical O
and O
functional O
disruption O
in O
people O
with O
schizophrenia O
. O

Highlights O
A O
novel O
method O
for O
the O
unified O
analysis O
of O
functional O
and O
anatomical O
networks O
in O
schizophrenia O
is O
proposed O
. O

The O
methodology O
extends O
existing O
networkbased O
analyses O
to O
test O
brain O
network O
differences O
across O
imaging O
modalities O
. O

A O
fundamental O
disrupted O
network O
was O
found O
in O
those O
with O
schizophrenia O
when O
compared O
to O
healthy O
, O
agematched O
controls O
. O

Methods O
and O
materials O
Participants O
Data O
from O
29 O
participants O
with O
chronic O
schizophrenia O
( O
11 O
females O
; O
age O
41.3 O
± O
9.3 O
( O
SD O
) O
; O
5 O
left-handed O
) O
and O
29 O
healthy O
participants O
( O
11 O
females O
; O
age O
41.1 O
± O
10.6 O
( O
SD O
) O
; O
2 O
left-handed O
) O
were O
included O
in O
this O
analysis O
. O

All O
participants O
provided O
written O
informed O
consent O
and O
received O
payment O
for O
the O
time O
they O
spent O
participating O
. O

The O
consent O
process O
and O
all O
procedures O
were O
reviewed O
and O
approved O
by O
the O
institutional O
review O
board O
( O
IRB O
) O
at O
the O
University O
of O
Minnesota O
prior O
to O
initiating O
studies O
. O

Schizophrenia O
patients O
were O
diagnosed O
with O
the O
Structured O
Clinical O
Interview O
for O
DSM-IV O
. O

Out O
of O
the O
29 O
chronic O
schizophrenia O
patients O
: O
16 O
were O
taking O
1 O
atypical O
antipsychotic O
, O
8 O
were O
taking O
2 O
atypical O
antipsychotics O
, O
1 O
was O
taking O
1 O
typical O
antipsychotic O
, O
1 O
was O
taking O
1 O
atypical O
and O
1 O
typical O
antipsychotic O
, O
1 O
was O
taking O
2 O
atypical O
and O
1 O
atypical O
antipsychotics O
, O
and O
2 O
were O
not O
taking O
any O
antipsychotic O
. O

Participants O
were O
excluded O
if O
they O
fulfilled O
the O
criteria O
for O
Alcohol O
or O
Substance O
Abuse O
or O
Dependence O
described O
in O
the O
Diagnostic O
and O
Statistical O
Manual O
of O
Mental O
Disorder O
, O
Fourth O
Edition O
within O
3 O
months O
prior O
to O
scanning O
, O
significant O
medical O
illness O
, O
or O
head O
injury O
resulting O
in O
loss O
of O
consciousness O
exceeding O
30 O
min O
. O

Education O
and O
occupational O
status O
were O
determined O
with O
the O
Socioeconomic O
Status O
questionnaire O
. O

See O
for O
a O
detailed O
breakdown O
of O
educational O
and O
socioeconomic O
status O
. O

Groups O
were O
matched O
by O
levels O
of O
education O
( O
t O
( O
55 O
) O
= O
0.06 O
, O
p O
= O
0.952 O
) O
and O
occupational O
status O
( O
t O
( O
55 O
) O
= O
1.191 O
, O
p O
= O
0.239 O
) O
of O
primary O
caregivers O
. O

Healthy O
participants O
, O
however O
, O
had O
significantly O
higher O
levels O
of O
education O
( O
t O
( O
55 O
) O
= O
5.01 O
, O
p O
< O
0.001 O
) O
and O
occupational O
status O
( O
t O
( O
55 O
) O
= O
5.78 O
, O
p O
< O
0.001 O
) O
. O

See O
for O
a O
detailed O
analysis O
of O
the O
whole-brain O
resting O
state O
connectivity O
in O
this O
population O
. O

Imaging O
Structural O
( O
sMRI O
) O
, O
functional O
( O
fMRI O
) O
, O
and O
diffusion O
weighted O
( O
DTI O
) O
magnetic O
resonance O
images O
were O
acquired O
for O
all O
participants O
on O
a O
Siemens O
3.0 O
T O
Trio O
scanner O
( O
Erlangen O
, O
Germany O
) O
. O

All O
images O
were O
acquired O
in O
a O
single O
scanning O
session O
. O

The O
resting O
state O
fMRI O
scan O
lasted O
for O
approximately O
6 O
min O
. O

Participants O
were O
given O
instructions O
to O
remain O
still O
, O
keep O
their O
eyes O
closed O
, O
and O
remain O
awake O
. O

The O
scan O
utilized O
a O
gradient-echo O
echo-planar O
imaging O
( O
EPI O
) O
sequence O
of O
180 O
volumes O
, O
a O
TR O
( O
repetition O
time O
) O
of O
2 O
s O
, O
TE O
( O
echo O
time O
) O
of O
30 O
ms O
, O
flip O
angle O
of O
90° O
and O
consisted O
of O
34 O
continuous O
AC-PC O
aligned O
axial O
slices O
with O
a O
voxel O
size O
of O
3.4 O
× O
3.4 O
× O
4.0 O
mm O
and O
an O
acquisition O
matrix O
size O
of O
64 O
× O
64 O
× O
34 O
. O

Participants O
were O
debriefed O
at O
the O
end O
of O
the O
scan O
to O
find O
out O
whether O
they O
fell O
asleep O
. O

DTI O
images O
were O
acquired O
axially O
using O
a O
dual O
spin O
echo O
, O
single-shot O
pulsed-gradient O
echo-planar O
imaging O
( O
EPI O
) O
technique O
. O

The O
sequence O
included O
a O
TR O
of O
8.3 O
s O
, O
TE O
of O
86 O
ms O
, O
b-value O
of O
1000 O
s/mm2 O
, O
2 O
averages O
, O
and O
consisted O
of O
64 O
slices O
with O
a O
voxel O
size O
of O
2 O
× O
2 O
× O
2 O
mm O
, O
a O
field O
of O
view O
of O
256 O
mm O
, O
a O
skip O
of O
0 O
mm O
, O
and O
30 O
non-collinear O
directions O
. O

To O
measure O
brain O
structure O
, O
we O
employed O
a O
high-res O
T1 O
weighted O
anatomical O
image O
that O
utilized O
a O
magnetization O
prepared O
rapid O
gradient-echo O
sequence O
. O

A O
field O
map O
was O
also O
generated O
and O
included O
a O
TR O
of O
300 O
ms O
, O
TE O
of O
1.91 O
ms/4.37 O
ms O
, O
a O
flip O
angle O
of O
55° O
, O
and O
a O
voxel O
size O
of O
3.4 O
× O
3.4 O
× O
4.0 O
mm O
. O

Pre-processing O
All O
images O
were O
pre-processed O
to O
reduce O
noise O
from O
motion O
and O
inhomogeneity O
in O
the O
magnetic O
field O
, O
and O
to O
produce O
connectivity O
matrices O
for O
later O
analysis O
. O

All O
fMRI O
and O
DTI O
images O
were O
registered O
to O
high O
resolution O
anatomical O
space O
. O

Careful O
attention O
was O
paid O
to O
motion O
correction O
since O
subtle O
movements O
have O
been O
shown O
to O
introduce O
spurious O
correlations O
between O
time O
series O
. O

Importantly O
, O
the O
two O
groups O
had O
similar O
mean O
root O
mean O
square O
( O
RMS O
) O
motion O
parameters O
for O
the O
fMRI O
acquisitions O
: O
two-sample O
t-tests O
of O
mean O
RMS O
translational O
and O
angular O
movement O
were O
not O
significant O
( O
p O
= O
0.14 O
and O
p O
= O
0.12 O
, O
respectively O
) O
. O

fMRI O
images O
were O
processed O
by O
removing O
the O
first O
3 O
volumes O
for O
magnetization O
stabilization O
, O
correcting O
motion O
artifacts O
using O
FSL O
, O
correcting O
for O
geometric O
distortion O
, O
correcting O
for O
slice-timing O
effects O
, O
and O
removing O
non-brain O
elements O
such O
as O
skull O
, O
meninges O
, O
and O
dura O
. O

Spatial O
