smoothing O
, O
using O
a O
6 O
mm O
full-width O
half-max O
kernel O
, O
grand O
mean O
and O
intensity O
normalization O
, O
and O
high-pass O
temporal O
filtering O
were O
also O
applied O
to O
images O
. O

fMRI O
images O
were O
denoised O
using O
probabilistic O
independent O
component O
analysis O
( O
PICA O
) O
using O
a O
tool O
in O
FSL O
( O
http O
: O
//www.fmrib.ox.ac.uk/fsl/ O
) O
, O
which O
was O
based O
on O
the O
procedure O
established O
by O
. O

The O
goal O
of O
this O
procedure O
was O
to O
remove O
noise O
components O
from O
head O
motion O
scanner O
artifacts O
, O
and O
physiological O
noise O
as O
described O
by O
and O
in O
the O
MELODIC O
manual O
( O
http O
: O
//www.fmrib.ox.ac.uk/fslcourse/lectures/melodic.pdf O
) O
. O

Linear O
regression O
was O
performed O
on O
each O
voxel O
to O
account O
for O
effects O
of O
individual O
subject O
motion O
by O
removing O
6 O
motion O
parameter O
time O
courses O
. O

After O
registration O
to O
high O
resolution O
anatomical O
space O
, O
fMRI O
images O
were O
then O
registered O
to O
Montreal O
Neurological O
Institute O
( O
MNI O
) O
standard O
space O
( O
MNI-152 O
brain O
) O
. O

Average O
time O
series O
were O
extracted O
for O
90 O
cortical O
and O
subcortical O
regions O
of O
interest O
( O
ROIs O
) O
based O
on O
the O
Automated O
Anatomical O
Labeling O
( O
AAL O
) O
atlas O
. O

ROIs O
from O
the O
cerebellum O
and O
vermis O
were O
not O
included O
in O
this O
analysis O
. O

We O
used O
a O
maximum O
overlap O
discrete O
wavelet O
transform O
to O
extract O
time O
series O
data O
from O
specific O
frequency O
bands O
. O

We O
chose O
the O
Daubechies O
4 O
wavelet O
and O
extracted O
level O
2 O
wavelet O
coefficients O
for O
each O
ROI O
, O
corresponding O
to O
a O
frequency O
range O
of O
0.060–0.125 O
Hz O
. O

We O
constructed O
a O
functional O
connectivity O
matrix O
by O
computing O
Pearson O
correlation O
coefficients O
for O
each O
pair O
of O
ROI O
time O
series O
. O

DTI O
images O
were O
corrected O
for O
distortion O
due O
to O
eddy O
currents O
and O
head O
motion O
( O
using O
a O
6 O
degrees O
of O
freedom O
linear O
registration O
) O
and O
were O
further O
corrected O
for O
geometric O
distortion O
using O
field O
maps O
generated O
during O
the O
structural O
scan O
. O

The O
AAL O
atlas O
was O
then O
transformed O
to O
native O
space O
for O
each O
subject O
using O
a O
non-linear O
registration O
( O
FNIRT O
; O
http O
: O
//www.fmrib.ox.ac.uk/fsl/fnirt O
) O
. O

White O
matter O
tractography O
files O
were O
generated O
by O
a O
FACT-based O
, O
DTI O
algorithm O
using O
the O
TrackVis O
Diffusion O
Toolkit O
( O
trackviz.org O
) O
; O
parameters O
included O
a O
35 O
degree O
angle O
threshold O
, O
0.1 O
step O
threshold O
, O
and O
voxel O
center O
seed O
location O
using O
one O
seed O
per O
voxel O
, O
with O
analysis O
applied O
to O
the O
whole O
brain O
. O

This O
algorithm O
was O
applied O
to O
the O
whole O
brain O
according O
to O
the O
TrackVis O
Diffusion O
Toolkit O
guidelines O
. O

We O
constructed O
an O
anatomical O
connectivity O
matrix O
by O
counting O
the O
number O
of O
white O
matter O
streamlines O
linking O
each O
pair O
of O
ROIs O
, O
in O
a O
similar O
manner O
to O
that O
reported O
in O
. O

Brain O
size O
analysis O
Structural O
T1 O
volumetric O
data O
were O
processed O
with O
FreeSurfer O
. O

Using O
the O
FreeSurfer O
BrainSegNotVent O
variable O
, O
we O
compared O
brain O
size O
between O
the O
two O
groups O
with O
age O
and O
gender O
as O
covariates O
. O

No O
significant O
group O
difference O
was O
found O
. O

Bivariate O
analysis O
As O
described O
above O
, O
for O
each O
data O
type O
a O
90 O
× O
90 O
( O
N O
× O
N O
) O
connectivity O
matrix O
was O
generated O
. O

This O
matrix O
describes O
the O
( O
functional O
or O
anatomical O
) O
connectivity O
between O
pairs O
of O
brain O
regions O
( O
4005 O
pairs O
in O
total O
) O
. O

We O
then O
calculated O
the O
average O
connectivity O
between O
each O
region O
and O
all O
89 O
other O
regions O
. O

This O
measure O
of O
connectivity O
is O
referred O
to O
as O
regional O
strength O
. O

Specifically O
, O
the O
strength O
of O
node O
( O
region O
) O
i O
is O
defined O
as O
the O
mean O
value O
of O
the O
ith O
column O
of O
the O
connectivity O
matrix O
. O

Overall O
brain O
connectivity O
, O
referred O
to O
as O
the O
global O
strength O
, O
was O
then O
calculated O
. O

Specifically O
, O
the O
global O
strength O
was O
calculated O
by O
averaging O
all O
regional O
strengths O
into O
one O
value O
. O

Group O
comparisons O
were O
made O
for O
both O
anatomical O
and O
functional O
data O
types O
and O
for O
both O
regional O
and O
global O
strength O
measures O
. O

Comparisons O
were O
calculated O
via O
an O
independent O
two O
sample O
t-statistic O
. O

This O
was O
calculated O
as O
the O
mean O
group O
difference O
divided O
by O
the O
pooled O
standard O
deviation O
. O

Significance O
was O
tested O
by O
permutation O
testing O
. O

Ten O
million O
random O
permutations O
were O
performed O
for O
regional O
and O
global O
strength O
for O
both O
anatomical O
and O
functional O
data O
. O

For O
each O
permutation O
, O
group O
labels O
were O
randomized O
and O
a O
t-statistic O
was O
calculated O
. O

This O
t-statistic O
extracted O
from O
the O
permuted O
data O
was O
then O
included O
as O
a O
member O
of O
the O
null O
distribution O
. O

The O
position O
of O
the O
true O
t-statistic O
was O
then O
located O
in O
the O
null O
distribution O
to O
determine O
a O
p-value O
. O

The O
p-value O
was O
calculated O
by O
dividing O
the O
count O
of O
null O
t-statistic O
values O
larger O
than O
the O
true O
t-statistic O
by O
the O
total O
number O
of O
permutations O
. O

Control O
for O
Type-I O
( O
false O
positive O
) O
errors O
that O
accompany O
multiple O
comparisons O
, O
specifically O
for O
the O
regional O
analysis O
, O
was O
then O
performed O
using O
a O
false O
discovery O
rate O
( O
FDR O
) O
correction O
. O

Network O
analysis O
Here O
we O
used O
the O
Network-Based O
Statistic O
( O
NBS O
) O
developed O
by O
to O
determine O
group O
differences O
in O
connectivity O
within O
each O
imaging O
modality O
. O

In O
a O
second-level O
analysis O
, O
we O
evaluated O
the O
overlap O
of O
significantly O
different O
, O
connected O
ROIs O
between O
modalities O
using O
a O
multimodal O
extension O
NBSm O
which O
we O
develop O
for O
this O
study O
. O

Intramodal O
differences O
( O
NBS O
) O
Subjects O
were O
labeled O
as O
proband O
or O
control O
and O
group O
differences O
between O
matrix O
elements O
were O
identified O
by O
generating O
a O
t-statistic O
for O
each O
element O
in O
the O
connectivity O
matrices O
. O

In O
this O
way O
, O
we O
constructed O
a O
t-matrix O
representing O
group O
differences O
in O
connection O
strengths O
for O
each O
modality O
. O

The O
t-matrix O
for O
each O
modality O
was O
thresholded O
to O
retain O
information O
only O
for O
matrix O
elements O
with O
the O
largest O
group O
differences O
. O

An O
initial O
data O
exploration O
was O
performed O
to O
find O
the O
t-threshold O
for O
each O
data O
modality O
. O

A O
distribution O
of O
node O
count O
( O
of O
the O
largest O
component O
) O
versus O
t-threshold O
was O
generated O
for O
each O
modality O
over O
a O
wide O
range O
of O
possible O
t-thresholds O
. O

Since O
the O
anatomical O
imaging O
had O
a O
lower O
distribution O
of O
t-thresholds O
it O
was O
used O
to O
choose O
a O
maximal O
node O
count O
provided O
by O
a O
t-threshold O
≥ O
2.00 O
( O
Fig O
. O

1 O
) O
and O
resulted O
in O
a O
t-threshold O
of O
2.10 O
. O

Based O
on O
node O
count O
this O
resulted O
in O
the O
selection O
of O
a O
functional O
t-threshold O
of O
5.00 O
. O

This O
method O
provided O
similarly O
sized O
components O
even O
within O
very O
different O
imaging O
modalities O
. O

Once O
a O
t-threshold O
was O
chosen O
for O
each O
modality O
, O
each O
t-matrix O
was O
thresholded O
and O
subnetworks O
were O
identified O
. O

The O
largest O
intramodal O
component O
was O
defined O
as O
the O
subnetwork O
of O
the O
modality-specific O
t-matrix O
with O
the O
largest O
total O
number O
of O
edges O
. O

In O
short O
, O
we O
use O
the O
size O
of O
the O
largest O
connected O
component O
as O
a O
statistic O
; O
noting O
that O
this O
sub-graph O
isolates O
significant O
network-based O
differences O
between O
the O
two O
groups O
. O

In O
other O
words O
, O
we O
are O
testing O
against O
the O
null O
hypothesis O
that O
the O
size O
of O
a O
sub-graph O
of O
group O
differences O
is O
larger O
than O
expected O
by O
chance O
. O

NBS O
significance O
testing O
The O
significance O
of O
intra-modal O
components O
was O
tested O
using O
a O
permutation O
testing O
technique O
( O
Fig O
. O

2 O
) O
. O

The O
intra-modal O
component O
generation O
process O
was O
repeated O
for O
each O
modality O
with O
random O
reassignment O
of O
subject O
labels O
but O
with O
maintenance O
of O
original O
group O
sizes O
. O

For O
each O
random O
permutation O
, O
the O
maximum O
component O
size O
was O
calculated O
and O
stored O
in O
a O
null O
intra-modal O
distribution O
. O

After O
10 O
million O
permutations O
, O
the O
size O
of O
the O
actual O
intra-modal O
components O
was O
compared O
to O
the O
null O
size O
distribution O
extracted O
from O
the O
permuted O
data O
sets O
. O

The O
p-value O
for O
significance O
in O
comparison O
to O
the O
null O
hypothesis O
was O
calculated O
by O
dividing O
the O
total O
number O
null O
model O
components O
larger O
than O
the O
actual O
component O
by O
the O
total O
number O
of O
permutations O
performed O
. O

Intermodal O
overlap O
( O
NBSm O
) O
After O
determining O
the O
intra-modal O
component O
for O
each O
modality O
, O
we O
investigated O
the O
anatomical O
locations O
of O
regions O
in O
each O
component O
separately O
and O
defined O
an O
“ O
intermodal O
overlap O
” O
set O
to O
be O
the O
subset O
of O
nodes O
present O
in O
both O
intra-modal O
components O
. O

NBSm O
significance O
testing O
The O
significance O
of O
the O
intermodal O
set O
was O
determined O
using O
a O
set O
membership O
procedure O
. O

With O
each O
permutation O
, O
the O
number O
of O
overlapping O
ROIs O
( O
i.e. O
, O
those O
nodes O
present O
in O
both O
intra-modal O
components O
) O
was O
determined O
. O

The O
size O
of O
the O
intermodal O
overlap O
set O
and O
identity O
of O
the O
ROIs O
in O
this O
group O
were O
recorded O
. O

A O
p-value O
for O
the O
significance O
of O
the O
size O
of O
the O
intermodal O
overlap O
set O
was O
generated O
by O
counting O
the O
number O
of O
permuted O
data O
sets O
in O
which O
the O
size O
of O
the O
intermodal O
overlap O
set O
was O
larger O
than O
the O
actual O
size O
and O
dividing O
this O
number O
by O
the O
number O
of O
permutations O
. O

A O
p-value O
for O
the O
significance O
of O
the O
presence O
of O
each O
ROI O
in O
the O
intermodal O
overlap O
set O
was O
determined O
by O
counting O
the O
number O
of O
permutations O
in O
which O
the O
ROI O
was O
identified O
as O
a O
member O
of O
the O
intermodal O
overlap O
set O
and O
dividing O
this O
number O
by O
the O
number O
of O
permutations O
. O

Eveningness O
among O
late O
adolescent O
males O
predicts O
neural O
reactivity O
to O
reward O
and O
alcohol O
dependence O
two O
years O
later O
Eveningness O
, O
a O
preference O
for O
later O
sleep-wake O
timing O
, O
is O
linked O
to O
altered O
reward O
function O
, O
which O
may O
explain O
a O
consistent O
association O
with O
substance O
abuse O
. O

Notably O
, O
the O
extant O
literature O
rests O
largely O
on O
cross-sectional O
data O
, O
yet O
both O
eveningness O
and O
reward O
function O
show O
developmental O
changes O
. O

We O
examined O
whether O
circadian O
preference O
during O
late O
adolescence O
predicted O
the O
neural O
response O
to O
reward O
two O
years O
later O
. O

A O
sample O
of O
93 O
males O
reported O
circadian O
preference O
and O
completed O
a O
monetary O
reward O
fMRI O
paradigm O
at O
ages O
20 O
and O
22 O
. O

Primary O
analyses O
examined O
longitudinal O
paths O
from O
circadian O
preference O
to O
medial O
prefrontal O
cortex O
( O
mPFC O
) O
and O
ventral O
striatal O
( O
VS O
) O
reward O
responses O
. O

We O
also O
explored O
whether O
reward O
responses O
mediated O
longitudinal O
associations O
between O
circadian O
preference O
and O
alcohol O
dependence O
, O
frequency O
of O
alcohol O
use O
, O
and/or O
frequency O
of O
cannabis O
use O
. O

Age O
20 O
eveningness O
was O
positively O
associated O
with O
age O
22 O
mPFC O
and O
VS O
responses O
to O
win O
, O
but O
not O
associated O
with O
age O
22 O
reactivity O
to O
reward O
anticipation O
. O

Age O
20 O
eveningness O
was O
indirectly O
related O
to O
age O
22 O
alcohol O
dependence O
via O
age O
22 O
mPFC O
response O
to O
win O
. O

Our O
findings O
provide O
novel O
evidence O
that O
altered O
reward-related O
brain O
function O
could O
underlie O
associations O
between O
eveningness O
and O
alcohol O
use O
problems O
. O

Eveningness O
may O
be O
an O
under-recognized O
but O
modifiable O
risk O
factor O
for O
reward-related O
problems O
such O
as O
mood O
and O
substance O
use O
disorders O
. O

2 O
. O

METHODS O
AND O
MATERIALS O
2.1 O
Participants O
Participants O
were O
drawn O
from O
the O
Pitt O
Mother O
& O
Child O
Project O
( O
PMCP O
) O
, O
an O
ongoing O
longitudinal O
study O
examining O
vulnerability O
and O
resilience O
in O
low-income O
boys O
. O

The O
initial O
sample O
consisted O
of O
310 O
boys O
and O
their O
families O
, O
recruited O
when O
boys O
were O
6 O
to O
17 O
months O
old O
through O
Women O
, O
Infants O
, O
and O
Children O
Nutritional O
Supplement O
( O
WIC O
) O
programs O
serving O
low-income O
families O
in O
the O
Pittsburgh O
metropolitan O
area O
( O
see O
. O

The O
current O
study O
utilizes O
data O
from O
subsequent O
laboratory O
visits O
when O
participants O
were O
20 O
and O
22 O
years O
of O
age O
. O

These O
visits O
each O
included O
a O
clinical O
interview O
, O
self-report O
measures O
, O
and O
an O
fMRI O
scan O
. O

Written O
informed O
consent O
was O
obtained O
for O
all O
participants O
. O

The O
study O
was O
approved O
by O
the O
Institutional O
Review O
Board O
of O
the O
University O
of O
Pittsburgh O
. O

Participants O
were O
asked O
to O
refrain O
from O
using O
any O
illegal O
substances O
starting O
48 O
h O
prior O
to O
their O
fMRI O
scan O
and O
all O
participants O
were O
approved O
for O
the O
scan O
by O
a O
registered O
nurse O
. O

A O
combination O
of O
breathalyzer O
, O
saliva O
drug O
screen O
, O
self-report O
, O
and O
clinical O
judgment O
were O
used O
to O
determine O
which O
participants O
were O
approved O
to O
scan O
. O

A O
total O
of O
106 O
participants O
had O
circadian O
preference O
data O
at O
both O
age O
20 O
and O
22 O
. O

Of O
these O
, O
a O
total O
of O
93 O
participants O
had O
valid O
reward O
task O
fMRI O
data O
at O
both O
ages O
( O
5 O
were O
excluded O
because O
of O
scheduling O
limitations O
, O
2 O
were O
excluded O
because O
of O
claustrophobia O
, O
2 O
were O
excluded O
because O
of O
metal/bullet O
fragments O
, O
2 O
were O
excluded O
because O
of O
inadequate O
coverage O
of O
the O
ventral O
striatum O
, O
1 O
was O
excluded O
because O
of O
misunderstanding O
the O
task O
, O
and O
1 O
refused O
the O
scan O
) O
. O

2.2 O
Clinical O
measures O
Circadian O
preference O
We O
used O
the O
Composite O
Scale O
of O
Morningness O
to O
assess O
circadian O
preference O
at O
the O
age O
20 O
and O
22 O
assessments O
( O
age O
20 O
α=0.63 O
; O
age O
22 O
α=0.65 O
) O
. O

The O
score O
is O
obtained O
by O
the O
sum O
of O
13 O
Likert-type O
items O
, O
and O
ranges O
from O
13 O
( O
extreme O
eveningness O
) O
to O
55 O
( O
extreme O
morningness O
) O
. O

Although O
we O
used O
the O
CSM O
score O
as O
a O
continuous O
measure O
for O
the O
primary O
analyses O
, O
for O
descriptive O
purposes O
we O
also O
classified O
participants O
by O
type O
using O
the O
scoring O
thresholds O
suggested O
by O
Natale O
and O
Alzani O
: O
13–26=evening-type O
; O
27–41=intermediate-type O
; O
42–55=morning-type O
. O

Alcohol O
dependence O
We O
used O
the O
age O
22 O
administration O
of O
the O
Alcohol O
Dependence O
Scale O
( O
ADS O
) O
, O
a O
25-item O
questionnaire O
to O
assess O
self-reported O
alcohol O
withdrawal O
symptoms O
, O
impaired O
control O
over O
drinking O
, O
awareness O
of O
a O
compulsion O
to O
drink O
, O
increased O
tolerance O
to O
alcohol O
, O
and O
salience O
of O
drink-seeking O
behavior O
in O
the O
past O
year O
. O

A O
score O
of O
9 O
or O
more O
is O
highly O
indicative O
of O
current O
diagnosis O
of O
alcohol O
abuse O
or O
dependence O
( O
α=0.78 O
for O
sample O
) O
. O

Because O
the O
ADS O
was O
administered O
only O
to O
participants O
reporting O
current O
alcohol O
use O
at O
age O
20 O
( O
n=70 O
in O
the O
present O
sample O
) O
, O
we O
elected O
to O
focus O
only O
on O
age O
22 O
ADS O
scores O
in O
the O
primary O
analyses O
. O

Alcohol O
use O
We O
assessed O
frequency O
of O
alcohol O
use O
via O
the O
age O
20 O
and O
22 O
administrations O
of O
the O
Lifetime O
Drinking O
History O
, O
a O
structured O
interview O
designed O
to O
quantify O
lifetime O
patterns O
of O
the O
use O
of O
alcohol O
. O

Participants O
reported O
on O
past O
year O
frequency O
of O
alcohol O
( O
days O
per O
month O
) O
. O

Based O
on O
the O
skewed O
distribution O
of O
alcohol O
use O
data O
, O
we O
used O
a O
square-root O
transformation O
. O

Cannabis O
use O
Although O
we O
did O
not O
have O
a O
measure O
of O
cannabis O
problems O
parallel O
to O
the O
ADS O
, O
we O
assessed O
frequency O
of O
cannabis O
use O
via O
the O
age O
20 O
and O
22 O
administrations O
of O
the O
Lifetime O
Drug O
Use O
History O
, O
a O
structured O
interview O
designed O
to O
quantify O
lifetime O
patterns O
of O
the O
use O
of O
various O
substances O
. O

Participants O
reported O
on O
past O
year O
frequency O
of O
cannabis O
use O
( O
days O
per O
month O
) O
. O

Based O
on O
the O
bimodal O
distribution O
of O
the O
cannabis O
use O
data O
, O
we O
created O
an O
ordinal O
version O
of O
the O
variable O
( O
0=no O
days O
per O
month O
, O
1=1–19 O
days O
per O
month O
, O
3=20+ O
days O
per O
month O
) O
with O
a O
unimodal O
distribution O
( O
n O
= O
39 O
, O
37 O
, O
and O
13 O
, O
respectively O
) O
for O
use O
in O
the O
analyses O
. O

Tobacco O
use O
We O
also O
assessed O
daily O
tobacco O
use O
given O
because O
it O
is O
associated O
with O
decreased O
reward-related O
brain O
function O
. O

We O
used O
the O
8-point O
Likert-scale O
tobacco O
use O
item O
from O
the O
age O
22 O
administration O
of O
the O
Alcohol O
and O
Drug O
Consumption O
Questionnaire O
, O
dichotomizing O
the O
item O
into O
no O
daily O
use O
( O
scores O
= O
0–7 O
) O
and O
daily O
use O
( O
score=8 O
) O
. O

Depressive O
symptoms O
We O
used O
the O
Beck O
Depression O
Inventory O
( O
BDI O
) O
to O
assess O
depressive O
symptomatology O
at O
age O
20 O
and O
22 O
, O
given O
prior O
reports O
that O
depression O
is O
associated O
with O
both O
eveningness O
and O
altered O
reward-related O
brain O
function O
. O

Psychopathology O
Finally O
, O
at O
age O
22 O
, O
we O
assessed O
current O
and O
past O
Axis O
I O
clinical O
disorders O
using O
the O
SCID O
with O
a O
clinically O
trained O
staff O
person O
trained O
to O
reliability O
with O
a O
licensed O
clinical O
psychologist O
. O

For O
descriptive O
purposes O
, O
we O
provide O
information O
on O
Major O
Depressive O
Disorder O
, O
Dysthymia O
, O
Bipolar O
Disorder O
, O
Alcohol O
Dependence O
, O
Substance O
Dependence O
, O
and O
Antisocial O
Personality O
Disorder O
given O
their O
relevance O
to O
reward O
function O
. O

At O
age O
22 O
, O
11 O
% O
had O
a O
history O
of O
Major O
Depressive O
Disorder O
, O
1 O
% O
had O
a O
history O
of O
Bipolar O
Disorder O
, O
5 O
% O
had O
a O
history O
of O
Dysthmia O
, O
2 O
% O
had O
a O
history O
of O
Alcohol O
Dependence O
, O
2 O
% O
had O
a O
history O
of O
non-alcohol O
Substance O
Dependence O
, O
and O
7 O
% O
had O
a O
history O
of O
Antisocial O
Personality O
Disorder O
. O

2.3 O
Reward O
processing O
task O
We O
employed O
a O
slow O
event-related O
fMRI O
card-guessing O
paradigm O
designed O
to O
examine O
neural O
reactivity O
to O
anticipation O
and O
receipt O
of O
monetary O
reward O
and O
loss O
see O
) O
. O

Trials O
were O
presented O
in O
a O
pseudorandom O
order O
with O
predetermined O
outcomes O
. O

Each O
20-s O
trial O
consisted O
of O
a O
4-s O
decision O
phase O
when O
participants O
guessed O
whether O
the O
value O
of O
a O
visually O
presented O
card O
with O
a O
possible O
value O
of O
1–9 O
was O
higher O
or O
lower O
than O
5 O
, O
a O
6-s O
anticipation O
period O
when O
the O
trial O
type O
( O
possible-reward O
or O
possible-loss O
) O
was O
displayed O
, O
a O
1–s O
outcome O
period O
the O
numerical O
value O
of O
the O
card O
and O
then O
outcome O
feedback O
( O
win O
, O
loss O
, O
or O
no-change O
) O
were O
presented O
, O
and O
a O
9-s O
interstimulus O
interval O
. O

In O
reward O
trials O
participants O
would O
win O
$ O
1 O
if O
their O
guess O
was O
correct O
and O
there O
would O
be O
no-change O
in O
earnings O
if O
their O
guess O
was O
incorrect O
. O

In O
loss O
trials O
participants O
would O
lose O
50 O
cents O
if O
their O
guess O
was O
incorrect O
and O
there O
would O
be O
no-change O
in O
earnings O
if O
their O
guess O
was O
correct O
. O

Twenty-four O
trials O
were O
presented O
in O
one O
run O
with O
12 O
reward-anticipation O
and O
12 O
loss-anticipation O
trials O
. O

Within O
reward-anticipation O
trials O
there O
were O
a O
balanced O
number O
of O
win-outcome O
and O
no-change O
outcome O
trials O
. O

In O
the O
present O
study O
we O
focus O
on O
the O
anticipation O
and O
outcome O
phases O
of O
the O
reward O
trials O
, O
based O
on O
evidence O
that O
circadian O
preference O
is O
more O
strongly O
related O
to O
reward O
, O
appetitive O
motivation O
, O
and O
positive O
affect O
than O
to O
negative O
affect O
processes O
, O
and O
specifically O
used O
the O
reward O
anticipation O
> O
baseline O
and O
reward O
win O
> O
baseline O
contrasts O
, O
in O
which O
baseline O
was O
defined O
as O
the O
last O
3 O
s O
of O
the O
interstimulus O
interval O
. O

Outcome O
probabilities O
were O
fixed O
trial-wise O
to O
ensure O
an O
identical O
win/loss O
time O
series O
modeling O
and O
pattern O
of O
outcome O
experiences O
for O
every O
participant O
. O

Each O
participant O
was O
given O
$ O
10 O
in O
earnings O
. O

Participants O
were O
unaware O
of O
the O
fixed O
outcome O
probabilities O
in O
the O
paradigm O
, O
and O
were O
led O
to O
believe O
their O
performance O
would O
determine O
net O
monetary O
gain O
. O

Neuroimaging O
data O
were O
collected O
using O
a O
3.0 O
T O
Siemens O
Trio O
MRI O
scanner O
at O
the O
University O
of O
Pittsburgh O
. O

Structural O
3D O
axial O
MPRAGE O
images O
were O
acquired O
in O
the O
same O
session O
( O
TE=3.29 O
ms O
; O
TR=2200 O
ms O
; O
Flip O
Angle=9° O
; O
Field O
of O
View=256 O
× O
192 O
mm2 O
; O
Slice-Thickness=1 O
mm O
; O
Matrix O
: O
256 O
× O
256 O
; O
192 O
continuous O
slices O
) O
. O

Mean O
blood-oxygenation-level-dependent O
( O
BOLD O
) O
images O
were O
then O
acquired O
with O
a O
gradient O
echo O
EPI O
sequence O
during O
13-min O
covering O
39 O
axial O
slices O
( O
3.1 O
mm O
thick O
; O
TR/TE=2000/28 O
ms O
; O
FOV=205×205 O
mm O
; O
matrix O
64 O
× O
64 O
; O
Flip O
Angle O
90° O
) O
. O

2.4 O
fMRI O
preprocessing O
and O
initial O
analyses O
Neuroimaging O
data O
were O
preprocessed O
and O
analyzed O
with O
Statistical O
Parametric O
Mapping O
software O
, O
Version-8 O
( O
SPM8 O
; O
http O
: O
//www.fil.ion.ucl.ac.uk/spm O
) O
. O

Data O
for O
each O
participant O
were O
realigned O
to O
the O
first O
volume O
in O
the O
time O
series O
to O
correct O
for O
head O
motion O
. O

Data O
sets O
were O
then O
selected O
for O
quality O
based O
on O
our O
standard O
small-motion O
correction O
( O
< O
2 O
mm O
on O
average O
across O
all O
frames O
) O
and O
adequate O
coverage O
of O
the O
ventral O
striatum O
( O
> O
80 O
% O
) O
. O

Realigned O
images O
were O
then O
coregistered O
with O
the O
subject O
’ O
s O
anatomical O
image O
, O
segmented O
to O
restrict O
analyses O
to O
gray O
matter O
, O
normalized O
to O
standard O
Montreal O
Neurological O
Institute O
( O
MNI O
) O
template O
, O
and O
spatially O
smoothed O
with O
a O
Gaussian O
kernel O
of O
6 O
mm O
full-width O
at O
half-maximum O
. O

A O
first-level O
fixed-effect O
model O
was O
constructed O
for O
each O
participant O
and O
scan O
and O
predetermined O
condition O
effects O
at O
each O
voxel O
were O
calculated O
using O
a O
t-statistic O
, O
producing O
a O
statistical O
image O
for O
the O
reward-anticipation- O
minus-baseline O
and O
win-outcome-after-reward-anticipation-minus-baseline O
contrast O
. O

First-level O
contrast O
images O
were O
then O
included O
in O
second-level O
whole-brain O
and O
region O
of O
interest O
( O
ROI O
) O
analyses O
. O

The O
VS O
ROI O
was O
constructed O
using O
the O
WFU O
Pickatlas O
Tool O
( O
v1.04 O
) O
and O
defined O
as O
a O
sphere O
20mm O
in O
radius O
, O
centered O
on O
the O
ventral O
striatum O
using O
Talairach O
coordinates O
x=0 O
, O
y=10 O
, O
and O
z=−10 O
, O
and O
encompassing O
the O
head O
of O
the O
caudate O
nucleus O
and O
ventral O
areas O
. O

The O
mPFC O
ROI O
was O
constructed O
using O
the O
PickAtlas O
and O
defined O
as O
a O
5393-voxel O
sphere O
including O
medial O
Brodmann O
Area O
( O
BA O
) O
10 O
and O
BA32 O
, O
key O
projection O
targets O
of O
midbrain O
dopamine O
neurons O
, O
which O
demonstrate O
connectivity O
with O
the O
ventral O
striatum O
, O
and O
which O
have O
been O
implicated O
in O
evaluating O
the O
relative O
value O
of O
rewards O
and O
reward-directed O
behavior O
. O

At O
the O
second O
level O
, O
we O
used O
1-sample O
t-tests O
in O
the O
age O
20 O
sample O
to O
ascertain O
the O
main O
effect O
of O
task O
( O
anticipation-baseline O
and O
win-baseline O
contrasts O
) O
in O
each O
ROI O
, O
using O
a O
height O
threshold O
of O
p O
< O
0.001 O
and O
a O
cluster-level O
threshold O
of O
pFWE O
< O
0.05 O
. O

A O
single O
cluster O
was O
identified O
in O
each O
of O
the O
VS O
and O
mPFC O
ROIs O
. O

To O
focus O
on O
voxels O
within O
each O
ROI O
responsive O
to O
the O
reward O
task O
, O
we O
created O
functional O
masks O
based O
on O
these O
VS O
and O
mPFC O
clusters O
( O
see O
Figures O
S1 O
and O
S2 O
in O
the O
Supplement O
) O
, O
and O
then O
employed O
the O
Marsbar O
toolbox O
to O
extract O
the O
mean O
activation O
across O
each O
functional O
cluster O
in O
both O
the O
age O
20 O
and O
age O
22 O
datasets O
. O

These O
mean O
activations O
across O
VS O
and O
mPFC O
were O
subsequently O
used O
in O
all O
remaining O
analyses O
. O

We O
examined O
the O
distribution O
of O
the O
extracted O
ROI O
data O
, O
excluding O
4 O
participants O
with O
values O
greater O
than O
3SD O
from O
the O
mean O
, O
resulting O
in O
a O
sample O
of O
89 O
participants O
. O

Also O
, O
based O
on O
prior O
evidence O
of O
circadian O
rhythms O
in O
reward O
processes O
, O
including O
reward-related O
brain O
activation O
( O
, O
) O
, O
we O
explored O
correlations O
between O
the O
extracted O
ROI O
data O
and O
the O
time O
of O
scan O
( O
which O
ranged O
from O
9AM–4PM O
) O
. O

There O
were O
no O
significant O
correlations O
between O
extracted O
ROI O
data O
and O
the O
time O
of O
scan O
, O
and O
thus O
time O
of O
scan O
was O
not O
used O
as O
a O
covariate O
in O
subsequent O
analyses O
. O

2.5 O
Main O
data O
analyses O
Changes O
in O
circadian O
preference O
, O
substance O
outcomes O
, O
and O
reward-related O
brain O
function O
were O
examined O
via O
paired-sample O
t-tests O
or O
the O
Wilcoxon O
Signed O
Ranks O
Test O
( O
cannabis O
use O
only O
) O
. O

Fisher O
’ O
s O
Exact O
Test O
( O
FET O
) O
was O
used O
to O
examine O
changes O
in O
distribution O
of O
circadian O
preference O
types O
. O

Hypothesized O
associations O
between O
circadian O
preference O
, O
reward-related O
brain O
function O
, O
and O
substance O
use O
were O
initially O
examined O
via O
bivariate O
Pearson O
’ O
s O
correlations O
in O
SPSS O
22 O
( O
IBM O
Corporation O
, O
2013 O
) O
. O

Significant O
relationships O
were O
subsequently O
evaluated O
using O
cross-lag O
panel O
and O
mediation O
analyses O
in O
Mplus O
7 O
. O

Cross-lag O
panel O
analyses O
with O
maximum O
likelihood O
estimation O
tested O
whether O
circadian O
preference O
at O
age O
20 O
predicted O
reward-related O
brain O
function O
in O
the O
mPFC O
and O
VS O
at O
age O
22 O
after O
adjusting O
for O
reward-related O
brain O
function O
at O
age O
20 O
and O
circadian O
preference O
at O
age O
22 O
. O

Analyses O
were O
performed O
separately O
for O
reward O
anticipation O
and O
win O
outcome O
responses O
. O

Given O
prior O
reports O
that O
depressive O
symptoms O
are O
associated O
with O
both O
eveningness O
and O
reward-related O
brain O
function O
, O
we O
initially O
added O
BDI O
scores O
at O
age O
20 O
and O
22 O
to O
the O
cross-lag O
models O
. O

Parameter O
estimates O
were O
generated O
for O
autocorrelations O
( O
e.g. O
, O
longitudinal O
path O
of O
one O
variable O
on O
itself O
) O
, O
cross-lag O
relationships O
( O
e.g. O
, O
longitudinal O
path O
of O
one O
variable O
on O
another O
variable O
) O
, O
and O
concurrent O
correlations O
between O
variables O
at O
each O
assessment O
point O
. O

This O
model O
resulted O
in O
zero O
degrees O
of O
freedom O
( O
a O
just-identified O
model O
) O
, O
therefore O
, O
goodness-of-fit O
could O
not O
be O
evaluated O
. O

Mediation O
analyses O
tested O
whether O
associations O
between O
circadian O
preference O
at O
age O
20 O
and O
substance O
involvement O
at O
age O
22 O
were O
mediated O
through O
reward-related O
brain O
function O
in O
the O
mPFC O
and O
VS O
at O
age O
22 O
. O

Analyses O
were O
performed O
separately O
for O
alcohol O
dependence O
, O
frequency O
of O
alcohol O
use O
, O
and O
frequency O
of O
cannabis O
use O
. O

Parameter O
estimates O
were O
generated O
for O
autocorrelations O
; O
cross-lag O
relationships O
of O
endogenous O
age O
22 O
variables O
on O
age O
20 O
circadian O
preference O
; O
concurrent O
correlations O
between O
mPFC O
and O
VS O
response O
at O
ages O
20 O
and O
22 O
; O
concurrent O
correlations O
between O
circadian O
preference O
and O
substance O
involvement O
at O
age O
22 O
; O
and O
regressions O
of O
age O
22 O
substance O
involvement O
on O
concurrent O
mPFC O
and O
VS O
response O
. O

Model O
goodness-of-fit O
was O
evaluated O
using O
absolute O
indices O
( O
i.e. O
, O
χ2 O
, O
RMSEA O
, O
SRMR O
) O
and O
comparative O
indices O
( O
i.e. O
, O
CFI O
, O
TLI O
) O
. O

Indirect O
effects O
were O
calculated O
using O
95 O
% O
two-tailed O
, O
bias-corrected O
bootstrap O
confidence O
intervals O
. O

In O
addition O
, O
because O
smoking O
on O
the O
day O
of O
the O
scan O
may O
affect O
brain O
blood O
flow O
and O
is O
associated O
with O
other O
substance O
use O
, O
we O
performed O
supplemental O
analyses O
that O
included O
a O
dichotomous O
indicator O
of O
daily O
smoking O
( O
yes O
, O
no O
) O
as O
a O
covariate O
in O
mediation O
analyses O
. O

Including O
the O
daily O
smoking O
covariate O
did O
not O
substantially O
alter O
the O
results O
of O
mediation O
analyses O
( O
see O
Figures O
S3 O
and O
S4 O
of O
the O
Supplement O
) O
; O
results O
without O
the O
daily O
smoking O
covariate O
are O
reported O
here O
. O

Attenuated O
neural O
response O
to O
emotional O
cues O
in O
cocaine-dependence O
: O
a O
preliminary O
analysis O
of O
gender O
differences O
Background O
Cocaine O
users O
often O
report O
a O
loss O
of O
arousal O
for O
nondrug-related O
stimuli O
, O
which O
may O
contribute O
to O
their O
response O
to O
drug-related O
rewards O
. O

However O
, O
little O
is O
known O
about O
users O
’ O
neural O
reactivity O
to O
emotional O
nondrug-related O
stimuli O
and O
the O
potential O
influence O
of O
gender O
. O

Objectives O
Test O
the O
hypotheses O
that O
cocaine-dependent O
individuals O
have O
an O
attenuated O
neural O
response O
to O
arousing O
stimuli O
relative O
to O
controls O
and O
that O
this O
difference O
is O
amplified O
in O
women O
. O

Methods O
The O
brain O
response O
to O
typically O
arousing O
positive O
and O
negative O
images O
as O
well O
as O
neutral O
images O
from O
the O
International O
Affective O
Picture O
System O
was O
measured O
in O
40 O
individuals O
( O
20 O
non-treatment O
seeking O
cocaine-dependent O
and O
20 O
age- O
and O
gender-matched O
control O
participants O
; O
50 O
% O
of O
whom O
were O
women O
) O
. O

Images O
were O
displayed O
for O
4 O
s O
each O
in O
blocks O
of O
five O
across O
two O
270-second O
runs O
. O

General O
linear O
models O
assessed O
within O
and O
between O
group O
activation O
differences O
for O
the O
emotional O
images O
. O

Results O
Cocaine-dependent O
individuals O
had O
a O
significantly O
lower O
response O
to O
typically O
arousing O
positive O
and O
negative O
images O
than O
controls O
, O
with O
attenuated O
neural O
activity O
present O
in O
the O
medial O
prefrontal O
cortex O
( O
mPFC O
) O
and O
anterior O
cingulate O
cortex O
( O
ACC O
) O
. O

Analyses O
by O
gender O
revealed O
less O
mPFC/ACC O
activation O
among O
female O
users O
, O
but O
not O
males O
, O
for O
both O
positive O
and O
negative O
images O
. O

Conclusion O
The O
dampened O
neural O
response O
to O
typically O
arousing O
stimuli O
among O
cocaine-dependent O
polydrug O
users O
suggests O
decreased O
salience O
processing O
for O
nondrug O
stimuli O
, O
particularly O
among O
female O
users O
. O

This O
decreased O
responding O
is O
consistent O
with O
data O
from O
other O
substance O
using O
populations O
and O
suggests O
that O
this O
may O
be O
a O
general O
feature O
of O
addiction O
. O

Amplifying O
the O
neural O
response O
to O
naturally O
arousing O
nondrug-related O
reinforcers O
may O
present O
an O
opportunity O
for O
unique O
behavioral O
and O
brain O
stimulation O
therapies O
. O

Methods O
Participants O
The O
study O
was O
approved O
by O
the O
Institutional O
Review O
Board O
and O
all O
participants O
provided O
written O
informed O
consent O
. O

Forty O
individuals O
completed O
this O
study O
and O
were O
entered O
into O
the O
final O
data O
analysis O
: O
20 O
non-treatment O
seeking O
cocaine-dependent O
individuals O
and O
20 O
individuals O
with O
no O
lifetime O
history O
of O
drug O
or O
alcohol O
dependence O
( O
see O
Supplementary O
Material O
for O
more O
details O
in O
exclusion O
criteria O
) O
. O

The O
mean O
age O
was O
35.55 O
for O
drug O
users O
and O
34.85 O
for O
controls O
, O
and O
it O
did O
not O
differ O
by O
user O
status O
or O
gender O
. O

The O
control O
group O
had O
less O
cigarette O
smokers O
( O
controls O
= O
3 O
, O
users O
= O
17 O
, O
p O
< O
.05 O
) O
, O
more O
years O
of O
education O
( O
controls O
= O
16.15 O
, O
users O
= O
12.85 O
; O
t O
= O
4.20 O
, O
p O
< O
.001 O
) O
, O
lower O
BDI-II O
scores O
( O
controls O
= O
.85 O
, O
users O
= O
5.75 O
; O
t O
= O
3.89 O
, O
p O
< O
.01 O
) O
, O
and O
lower O
state O
anxiety O
( O
controls O
= O
21.8 O
, O
users O
= O
28.6 O
, O
t O
= O
3.19 O
, O
p O
< O
.01 O
) O
than O
the O
user O
group O
. O

There O
were O
no O
significant O
gender O
differences O
between O
each O
group O
. O

See O
Table O
1 O
for O
breakdown O
by O
gender O
and O
user O
group O
. O

Cocaine O
users O
had O
a O
mean O
age O
of O
first O
use O
of O
20.05 O
( O
SD O
= O
3.50 O
) O
years O
old O
and O
had O
been O
using O
for O
a O
mean O
of O
15.5 O
( O
SD O
= O
8.02 O
) O
years O
, O
and O
did O
not O
differ O
by O
gender O
. O

Procedure O
During O
the O
fMRI O
scanning O
session O
, O
participants O
were O
presented O
with O
blocks O
of O
highly O
arousing O
positive O
and O
negative O
and O
emotionally O
neutral O
standardized O
images O
selected O
from O
the O
International O
Affective O
Picture O
System O
. O

The O
stimuli O
included O
: O
30 O
positive O
( O
valence O
M O
= O
6.87 O
, O
SD O
= O
.52 O
) O
, O
30 O
negative O
( O
valence O
M O
= O
2.27 O
, O
SD O
= O
.52 O
) O
, O
and O
30 O
neutral O
images O
( O
valence O
M O
= O
4.91 O
, O
SD O
= O
.67 O
) O
. O

Participants O
passively O
viewed O
the O
images O
and O
were O
instructed O
to O
allow O
themselves O
to O
feel O
whatever O
comes O
naturally O
when O
viewing O
the O
pictures O
. O

Because O
of O
the O
interest O
in O
comparing O
alterations O
in O
emotional O
response O
among O
male O
and O
female O
cocaine O
users O
, O
images O
were O
selected O
to O
be O
matched O
on O
arousal O
within O
each O
block O
among O
men O
and O
women O
based O
on O
standardized O
scores O
( O
no O
significant O
gender O
difference O
) O
. O

Arousal O
ratings O
by O
gender O
and O
by O
condition O
were O
as O
follows O
: O
positive O
( O
men O
M O
= O
6.15 O
, O
SD O
= O
.67 O
; O
women O
: O
M O
= O
5.94 O
, O
SD O
= O
.39 O
) O
; O
negative O
( O
men O
: O
M O
= O
5.97 O
, O
SD O
= O
.60 O
; O
women O
: O
M O
= O
6.42 O
, O
SD O
= O
.68 O
) O
; O
and O
neutral O
( O
men O
: O
M O
= O
3.50 O
, O
SD O
= O
.63 O
; O
women O
: O
M O
= O
3.45 O
, O
SD O
= O
.66 O
) O
. O

To O
control O
for O
potential O
differences O
in O
social O
responding O
among O
conditions O
, O
all O
images O
contained O
at O
least O
one O
person O
, O
and O
each O
category O
of O
images O
contained O
individuals O
from O
different O
racial O
and O
ethnic O
backgrounds O
. O

Images O
were O
presented O
in O
two O
functional O
runs O
lasting O
270s O
each O
. O

Each O
run O
consisted O
of O
nine O
20s O
blocks O
: O
three O
each O
of O
positive O
, O
negative O
, O
and O
neutral O
images O
. O

Each O
affective O
block O
contained O
five O
images O
presented O
for O
4 O
s O
each O
. O

Each O
image O
block O
was O
separated O
by O
a O
10-s O
rest O
block O
( O
cross O
hair O
) O
. O

Image O
order O
was O
pseudorandom O
within O
each O
block O
, O
and O
images O
were O
presented O
only O
once O
across O
the O
two O
runs O
. O

Following O
the O
fMRI O
scanning O
session O
, O
the O
participants O
completed O
a O
task O
to O
assess O
image O
recognition O
and O
ensure O
that O
participants O
did O
not O
fall O
asleep O
during O
image O
presentation O
. O

Each O
of O
the O
90 O
previously O
presented O
stimuli O
, O
along O
with O
90 O
( O
30 O
per O
condition O
) O
never O
seen O
stimuli O
, O
were O
presented O
randomly O
on O
a O
computer O
screen O
. O

Images O
were O
presented O
for O
an O
unlimited O
duration O
, O
until O
a O
key O
was O
pressed O
to O
indicate O
whether O
the O
image O
was O
previously O
seen O
during O
the O
fMRI O
session O
or O
not O
( O
k O
= O
yes O
; O
l O
= O
no O
) O
. O

The O
number O
of O
hits O
( O
correctly O
identifying O
a O
seen O
image O
) O
and O
false O
alarms O
( O
incorrectly O
identifying O
an O
unseen O
image O
as O
seen O
) O
were O
counted O
for O
each O
stimulus O
type O
. O

To O
measure O
recognition O
, O
a O
sensitivity O
index O
( O
d′ O
= O
Zhits O
− O
Zfalse O
alarms O
) O
was O
then O
calculated O
to O
measure O
the O
ability O
to O
distinguish O
between O
seen O
and O
never O
seen O
images O
. O

The O
effect O
of O
user O
status O
and O
gender O
on O
sensitivity O
was O
examined O
with O
independent O
samples O
t-tests O
. O

Image O
acquisition O
and O
analysis O
Scanning O
was O
performed O
using O
a O
3-Tesla O
MRI O
Trio O
( O
Siemens O
Medical O
, O
Erlangen O
, O
Germany O
) O
. O

High-resolution O
T1-weighted O
structural O
images O
were O
first O
acquired O
and O
used O
during O
co-registration O
and O
normalization O
of O
the O
functional O
scans O
[ O
repetition O
time O
( O
TR O
) O
= O
1750 O
ms O
, O
echo O
time O
( O
TE O
) O
= O
4 O
ms O
, O
voxel O
dimensions O
1.0 O
× O
1.0 O
× O
1.0 O
mm O
, O
and O
160 O
slices O
] O
. O

Functional O
scans O
were O
acquired O
using O
a O
standard O
multislice O
single-shot O
gradient O
echo-planar O
imaging O
sequence O
( O
TR O
= O
2200 O
ms O
, O
TE O
= O
30 O
ms O
, O
voxel O
dimensions O
3.0 O
× O
3.0 O
× O
3.0 O
mm O
, O
and O
64 O
× O
64 O
matrix O
) O
. O

Preprocessing O
and O
whole O
brain O
image O
analysis O
were O
conducted O
with O
SPM8 O
( O
Wellcome O
Department O
of O
Cognitive O
Neurology O
, O
London O
, O
UK O
) O
, O
implemented O
in O
Matlab O
7.14 O
( O
MathWorks O
, O
Natick O
, O
MA O
) O
. O

Preprocessing O
steps O
are O
as O
follows O
: O
realignment O
to O
the O
mean O
image O
, O
co-registration O
of O
the O
T1-weighted O
structural O
scan O
and O
the O
mean O
realigned O
image O
, O
normalization O
to O
standard O
space O
( O
Montreal O
Neurological O
Institute O
template O
) O
, O
and O
smoothing O
with O
an O
8-mm O
Gaussian O
kernel O
. O

Functional O
images O
were O
modeled O
with O
a O
boxcar O
function O
convolved O
with O
the O
hemodynamic O
response O
function O
over O
task O
blocks O
( O
positive O
, O
negative O
, O
and O
neutral O
images O
) O
using O
the O
general O
linear O
model O
. O

First-level O
, O
fixed-effects O
contrasts O
were O
created O
for O
positive O
> O
neutral O
and O
negative O
> O
neutral O
for O
each O
participant O
. O

Group-level O
differences O
( O
user O
status O
) O
were O
calculated O
using O
second-level O
, O
random-effects O
analyses O
of O
the O
first-level O
contrasts O
for O
the O
entire O
sample O
( O
primary O
analysis O
) O
, O
and O
separately O
for O
men O
and O
women O
( O
secondary O
analysis O
) O
. O

The O
primary O
analysis O
examining O
the O
effect O
of O
user O
group O
and O
whether O
group O
status O
differentially O
affected O
response O
to O
positive O
and O
negative O
images O
was O
assessed O
with O
a O
2 O
( O
user O
group O
) O
× O
2 O
( O
valence O
) O
analysis O
of O
variance O
( O
ANOVA O
) O
. O

T-tests O
further O
examined O
the O
differential O
response O
among O
cocaine O
users O
and O
controls O
for O
positive O
and O
negative O
images O
. O

Gender-based O
analyses O
were O
conducted O
with O
one-sample O
( O
within O
group O
) O
and O
two-sample O
( O
between O
group O
) O
t-tests O
. O

The O
examination O
of O
potential O
contributing O
factors O
was O
conducted O
by O
adding O
covariates O
( O
depression O
symptomatology O
, O
education O
, O
state O
anxiety O
, O
and O
cigarettes O
per O
day O
) O
to O
the O
model O
or O
directly O
comparing O
groups O
( O
marijuana O
dependence O
) O
. O

All O
reported O
results O
met O
significance O
at O
p O
< O
.05 O
corrected O
for O
multiple O
comparisons O
( O
determined O
by O
Monte O
Carlo O
simulation O
; O
voxel-level O
threshold O
of O
p O
< O
.005 O
for O
at O
least O
48 O
contiguous O
voxels O
; O
AlphaSim O
in O
REST O
toolbox O
) O
. O

A O
joint O
time-frequency O
analysis O
of O
resting-state O
functional O
connectivity O
reveals O
novel O
patterns O
of O
connectivity O
shared O
between O
or O
unique O
to O
schizophrenia O
patients O
and O
healthy O
controls O
Functional O
connectivity O
of O
the O
resting-state O
( O
RS O
) O
brain O
is O
a O
vehicle O
to O
study O
brain O
dysconnectivity O
aspects O
of O
diseases O
such O
as O
schizophrenia O
and O
bipolar O
. O

Methods O
that O
are O
developed O
to O
measure O
functional O
connectivity O
are O
based O
on O
the O
underlying O
hypotheses O
regarding O
the O
actual O
nature O
of O
RS-connectivity O
including O
evidence O
of O
temporally O
dynamic O
versus O
static O
RS-connectivity O
and O
evidence O
of O
frequency-specific O
versus O
hemodynamically-driven O
connectivity O
over O
a O
wide O
frequency O
range O
. O

This O
study O
is O
derived O
by O
these O
observations O
of O
variation O
of O
RS-connectivity O
in O
temporal O
and O
frequency O
domains O
and O
evaluates O
such O
characteristics O
of O
RS-connectivity O
in O
clinical O
population O
and O
jointly O
in O
temporal O
and O
frequency O
domains O
( O
the O
spectro-temporal O
domain O
) O
. O

We O
base O
this O
study O
on O
the O
hypothesis O
that O
by O
studying O
functional O
connectivity O
of O
schizophrenia O
patients O
and O
comparing O
it O
to O
the O
one O
of O
healthy O
controls O
in O
the O
spectro-temporal O
domain O
we O
might O
be O
able O
to O
make O
new O
observations O
regarding O
the O
differences O
and O
similarities O
between O
diseased O
and O
healthy O
brain O
connectivity O
and O
such O
observations O
could O
be O
obscured O
by O
studies O
which O
investigate O
such O
characteristics O
separately O
. O

Interestingly O
, O
our O
results O
include O
, O
but O
are O
not O
limited O
to O
, O
a O
spectrally O
localized O
( O
mostly O
mid-range O
frequencies O
) O
modular O
dynamic O
connectivity O
pattern O
in O
which O
sensory O
motor O
networks O
are O
anti-correlated O
with O
visual O
, O
auditory O
and O
sub-cortical O
networks O
in O
schizophrenia O
, O
as O
well O
as O
evidence O
of O
lagged O
dependence O
between O
default-mode O
and O
sensory O
networks O
in O
schizophrenia O
. O

These O
observations O
are O
unique O
to O
the O
proposed O
augmented O
domain O
of O
connectivity O
analysis O
. O

We O
conclude O
this O
study O
by O
arguing O
not O
only O
resting-state O
connectivity O
has O
structured O
spectro-temporal O
variability O
, O
but O
also O
that O
studying O
properties O
of O
connectivity O
in O
this O
joint O
domain O
reveals O
distinctive O
group-based O
differences O
and O
similarities O
between O
clinical O
and O
healthy O
populations O
. O

Highlights O
RS-connectivity O
of O
Schizophrenia O
and O
healthy O
is O
studied O
in O
domain O
of O
time O
and O
frequency O
. O

Dynamic O
connectivity O
is O
now O
superposition O
of O
connectivities O
with O
unique O
frequencies O
. O

Augmented O
domain O
reveals O
novel O
connectivity O
patterns O
unique O
to O
schizophrenia/healthy O
. O

Materials O
and O
method O
Participants O
, O
image O
acquisition O
and O
pre-processing O
Subjects O
include O
163 O
healthy O
controls O
( O
46 O
females O
) O
with O
average O
age O
of O
36.9 O
and O
151 O
( O
37 O
females O
) O
patients O
diagnosed O
with O
schizophrenia O
with O
average O
age O
of O
37.8 O
. O

In O
accordance O
with O
the O
internal O
review O
boards O
of O
corresponding O
institutes O
, O
informed O
consent O
was O
obtained O
from O
all O
the O
subjects O
. O

Details O
on O
the O
image O
acquisition O
and O
the O
pre-processing O
are O
provided O
in O
Supplementary O
Material O
A. O
Group-ICA O
and O
post-processing O
We O
study O
connectivity O
between O
anatomically O
and O
functionally O
meaningful O
regions O
in O
the O
brain O
. O

We O
choose O
group O
spatial O
independent O
component O
analysis O
( O
gsICA O
) O
as O
the O
data-driven O
approach O
to O
define O
these O
regions O
with O
no O
need O
for O
prior O
knowledge O
of O
the O
regions O
or O
a O
task-design O
. O

It O
is O
achieved O
by O
linearly O
decomposing O
voxel-level O
time O
series O
into O
maximally O
independent O
spatial O
maps O
with O
corresponding O
time-courses O
per-subject O
. O

The O
GIFT O
toolbox O
implementation O
of O
gsICA O
is O
used O
. O

More O
details O
on O
implementation O
of O
gsICA O
in O
GIFT O
are O
provided O
in O
Supplementary O
Material O
B. O
Temporally-dynamic O
and O
frequency-specific O
connectivity O
states O
To O
estimate O
connectivity O
, O
in O
the O
spectro-temporal O
domain O
, O
we O
first O
, O
decompose O
each O
subject-specific O
network O
time-courses O
into O
a O
time-frequency O
domain O
by O
leveraging O
a O
wavelet O
decomposition O
by O
convolving O
each O
time-course O
with O
complex O
Morlet O
wavelet O
as O
our O
choice O
of O
wavelet O
kernel O
. O

The O
complex O
Morlet O
kernel O
has O
the O
following O
formulation O
, O
which O
has O
both O
real O
and O
imaginary O
parts O
: O
The O
kernel O
has O
a O
Gaussian-shaped O
frequency O
spectrum O
whose O
fc O
is O
center O

, O

Next O

, O

Research O
of O
Hubs O
Location O
Method O
for O
Weighted O
Brain O
Network O
Based O
on O
NoS-FA O
As O
a O
complex O
network O
of O
many O
interlinked O
brain O
regions O
, O
there O
are O
some O
central O
hub O
regions O
which O
play O
key O

in O
the O
structural O
human O

network O
based O
on O
T1 O
and O
diffusion O
tensor O
imaging O
( O
DTI O
) O
technology O
. O

Since O
most O
studies O
about O
hubs O
location O
method O
in O
the O
whole O
human O
brain O
network O
are O
mainly O
concerned O
with O
the O
local O
properties O
of O
each O

node O
but O
not O
the O
global O
properties O
of O
all O
the O

location O
method O
based O
on O
global O
importance O
contribution O
evaluation O
index O
is O
proposed O
in O
this O
study O
. O

The O
number O
of O
streamlines O
( O

) O
is O
fused O
with O
normalized O
fractional O
anisotropy O
( O

) O
for O
more O

brain O
bioinformation O
. O

The O
brain O
region O
importance O
contribution O
matrix O
and O
information O
transfer O
efficiency O
value O
are O
constructed O
, O
respectively O
, O
and O
then O
by O
combining O
these O
two O
factors O
together O
we O
can O
calculate O
the O
importance O
value O
of O
each O
node O
and O
locate O
the O
hubs O
. O

Profiting O
from O
both O
local O
and O
global O
features O
of O
the O
nodes O
and O
the O

of O
human O

show O
that O
this O
method O
can O
detect O

reasonably O

. O

in O

of O

of O

and O

the O
importance O
of O

be O
affected O
by O
all O

connections O
which O
it O
has O
. O

That O
means O
when O

with O

one O
node O
, O

will O

to O

. O

The O

with O

have O
very O

influence O
on O
the O

of O
a O
node O
, O

not O

to O
describe O

of O
topological O
relation O
only O

of O

. O

On O

of O

. O

In O

Effectiveness O
Analysis O
of O
the O
Algorithm O
We O
use O
both O
the O
weighted O
betweenness O
hubs O
location O
method O
which O
is O
the O
most O
popular O
method O
in O
evaluating O
brain O
hubs O
and O
proposed O
hubs O
location O
method O
to O
calculate O
the O
importance O
value O
of O
each O
brain O
region O
for O
the O
same O
healthy O
people O
's O
brain O
network O
, O
and O
the O
results O
were O
shown O
in O
Figure O
3 O
. O

There O
are O
three O
improvements O
when O
using O
the O
proposed O
method O
. O

Firstly O
, O
from O
the O
results O
, O
we O
can O
see O
when O
using O
the O
region O
evaluation O
method O
with O
weighted O
betweenness O
that O
there O
exist O
some O
nodes O
that O
have O
the O
same O
importance O
value O
. O

While O
in O
the O
results O
based O
on O
the O
proposed O
method O
every O
region O
has O
different O
value O
of O
importance O
, O
so O
our O
method O
is O
more O
accurate O
for O
evaluating O
the O
importance O
of O
brain O
regions O
. O

In O
addition O
, O
it O
can O
be O
seen O
clearly O
in O

region O

results O
with O
weighted O
betweenness O
method O
that O

have O
the O

of O

, O
but O

is O

for O

to O

in O

network O
. O

While O

of O
proposed O
method O
even O

last O
one O
also O
has O
a O
no-zero O
importance O
value O
, O
so O
our O
method O
is O
more O
reasonable O
for O
evaluating O
the O
importance O
of O
brain O
regions O
. O

Finally O
in O

region O
evaluation O
results O

weighted O

method O
, O
the O
distribution O
of O
importance O
value O
is O
more O
even O
and O
the O

in O
different O
regions O
are O
closed O
to O
each O
other O
. O

While O
in O

proposed O
method O

distribution O
looks O
sharper O
, O
the O
difference O
between O

and O

noncore O
nodes O
in O

is O

. O

For O

, O

in O

; O

that O

the O

, O

and O

of O
the O
organization O
, O
including O

, O
parietal O

, O

, O

, O

4.2 O
. O

Algorithm O
Vulnerability O
Analysis O
and O
Comparison O
In O
order O
to O
verify O
the O
actual O
importance O
of O
the O
hubs O
, O
which O
are O
located O
by O
the O
proposed O
algorithm O
, O
the O
vulnerability O
analysis O
experiment O
is O
presented O
in O
our O
work O
. O

When O
a O
node O
in O
the O
network O
is O
removed O
, O
the O
global O
property O
of O
the O
network O
will O
be O
changed O
. O

Usually O
the O
ratio O
of O
the O
change O
of O
network O
property O
to O
the O
network O
property O
before O
the O
removal O
is O
defined O
as O
the O
vulnerability O
. O

The O
greater O
vulnerability O
a O
node O
has O
, O
the O
higher O
damage O
will O
be O
put O
on O
the O
entire O
network O
, O
and O
the O
role O
of O
this O
node O
is O
more O
important O
. O

It O
needs O
to O
be O
emphasized O
that O
, O
in O
the O
experiment O
, O
when O
one O
node O
is O
removed O
, O
all O
the O
white O
matter O
fibers O
, O
which O
are O
connected O
with O
this O
brain O
regions O
, O
are O
invalid O
and O
the O
NoS O
weight O
of O
related O
edges O
in O
the O
network O
will O
be O
zero O
. O

Therefore O
, O
the O
vulnerability O
of O
brain O
region O
i O
is O
defined O
as O
Here O
PropValue O
represents O
one O
kind O
of O
network O
properties O
value O
before O
a O
node O
is O
removed O
, O
and O
PropValue′ O
represents O
this O
property O
value O
after O
the O
removal O
. O

In O
this O
research O
, O
the O
network O
properties O
of O
global O
efficiency O
and O
network O
density O
are O
taken O
as O
the O
vulnerability O
analysis O
parameters O
, O
respectively O
, O
which O
are O
shown O
as O
The O
network O
density O
reflects O
the O
ratio O
of O
the O
actual O
number O
of O
edges O
and O
the O
maximum O
number O
of O
edges O
the O
network O
may O
have O
, O
and O
it O
is O
an O
important O
attribute O
to O
test O
the O
network O
size O
. O

The O
global O
efficiency O
reflects O
the O
information O
transmission O
capability O
of O
a O
network O
. O

To O
compare O
the O
influence O
that O
a O
hub O
may O
have O
on O
the O
entire O
brain O
network O
, O
three O
cases O
are O
considered O
in O
this O
experiment O
: O
brain O
hubs O
are O

and O
chosen O
with O
our O
proposed O
method O
, O
with O
weighted O
betweenness O
method O
or O
at O
random O
. O

The O
vulnerability O
change O
curves O
of O
three O
methods O
are O
given O
and O
compared O
as O
shown O
in O
Figure O
5 O
. O

It O
can O
be O
seen O
that O

of O

the O

proposed O

the O

on O

of O

Because O

Nicotine O
deprivation O
elevates O
neural O
representation O
of O
smoking-related O
cues O
in O
object-sensitive O
visual O
cortex O
: O
a O
proof O
of O
concept O
study O
Objective O
In O
the O
current O
study O
, O
we O
use O
functional O
magnetic O
resonance O
imaging O
( O
fMRI O
) O
and O
multi-voxel O
pattern O
analysis O
( O
MVPA O
) O
to O
investigate O
whether O
tobacco O
addiction O
biases O
basic O
visual O
processing O
in O
favour O
of O
smoking-related O
images O
. O

We O
hypothesize O
that O
the O
neural O
representation O
of O
smoking-related O
stimuli O
in O
the O
lateral O
occipital O
complex O
( O
LOC O
) O
is O
elevated O
after O
a O
period O
of O
nicotine O
deprivation O
compared O
to O
a O
satiated O
state O
, O
but O
that O
this O
is O
not O
the O
case O
for O
object O
categories O
unrelated O
to O
smoking O
. O

Methods O
Current O
smokers O
( O
≥10 O
cigarettes O
a O
day O
) O
underwent O
two O
fMRI O
scanning O
sessions O
: O
one O
after O
10 O
h O
of O
nicotine O
abstinence O
and O
the O
other O
one O
after O
smoking O
ad O
libitum O
. O

Regional O
blood O
oxygenated O
level-dependent O
( O
BOLD O
) O
response O
was O
measured O
while O
participants O
were O
presented O
with O
24 O
blocks O
of O
8 O
colour-matched O
pictures O
of O
cigarettes O
, O
pencils O
or O
chairs O
. O

The O
functional O
data O
of O
10 O
participants O
were O
analysed O
through O
a O
pattern O
classification O
approach O
. O

Results O
In O
bilateral O
LOC O
clusters O
, O
the O
classifier O
was O
able O
to O
discriminate O
between O
patterns O
of O
activity O
elicited O
by O
visually O
similar O
smoking-related O
( O
cigarettes O
) O
and O
neutral O
objects O
( O
pencils O
) O
above O
empirically O
estimated O
chance O
levels O
only O
during O
deprivation O
( O
mean O
= O
61.0 O
% O
, O
chance O
( O
permutations O
) O
= O
50.0 O
% O
, O
p O
= O
.01 O
) O
but O
not O
during O
satiation O
( O
mean O
= O
53.5 O
% O
, O
chance O
( O
permutations O
) O
= O
49.9 O
% O
, O
ns O
. O
) O
. O

For O
all O
other O
stimulus O
contrasts O
, O
there O
was O
no O
difference O
in O
discriminability O
between O
the O
deprived O
and O
satiated O
conditions O
. O

Conclusion O
The O
discriminability O
between O
smoking O
and O
non-smoking O
visual O
objects O
was O
elevated O
in O
object-selective O
brain O
region O
LOC O
after O
a O
period O
of O
nicotine O
abstinence O
. O

This O
indicates O
that O
attention O
bias O
likely O
affects O
basic O
visual O
object O
processing O
. O

Methods O
Participants O
Fourteen O
right-handed O
, O
current O
smokers O
( O
6 O
males O
, O
mean O
age O
25.21 O
years O
) O
participated O
in O
this O
study O
. O

Individuals O
who O
reported O
smoking O
a O
minimum O
of O
10 O
cigarettes O
a O
day O
on O
average O
for O
at O
least O
1 O
year O
were O
included O
. O

Exclusion O
criteria O
were O
history O
of O
physical O
or O
mental O
illness O
, O
use O
of O
psychotropic O
medication O
, O
history O
of O
drug O
or O
alcohol O
abuse O
, O
and O
contraindications O
for O
the O
MRI O
scanner O
. O

Participants O
received O
financial O
compensation O
for O
their O
participation O
and O
travel O
costs O
. O

The O
study O
was O
approved O
by O
the O
Ethical O
Review O
Committee O
Psychology O
and O
Neuroscience O
of O
Maastricht O
University O
, O
and O

. O

Procedure O
Participants O
were O
scanned O
on O
two O
occasions O
. O

On O
one O
occasion O
, O
they O
were O
instructed O
to O
refrain O
from O
smoking O
for O
at O
least O
10 O
h O
before O
the O
experiment O
. O

On O
the O
other O
occasion O
, O
participants O
were O
allowed O
to O
smoke O
ad O
libitum O
and O
were O
specifically O
asked O
to O
smoke O
a O
cigarette O
just O
before O
entering O
the O
lab O
in O
order O
to O
achieve O
maximal O
satiation O
. O

The O
order O
of O
the O
sessions O
was O
randomized O
across O
subjects O
. O

Upon O
entering O
the O
lab O
, O
smoking O
status O
was O
verified O
by O
exhaled O
carbon O
monoxide O
measurement O
. O

In O
addition O
, O
participants O
reported O
at O
what O
time O
they O
had O
smoked O
their O
most O
recent O
cigarette O
. O

Furthermore O
, O
they O
filled O
out O
the O
Fagerström O
Test O
for O
Nicotine O
Dependence O
( O
FTND O
) O
( O
Heatherton O
et O
al O
. O

) O
, O
the O
Minnesota O
Nicotine O
Withdrawal O
Scale O
( O
MNWS O
) O
( O
Cappelleri O
et O
al O
. O
) O

and O
an O
MRI O
eligibility O
check O
. O

Localizer O
run O
An O
independent O
functional O
localizer O
run O
preceded O
the O
experiment O
to O
localize O
object-sensitive O
regions O
of O
the O
brain O
. O

Participants O
were O
presented O
with O
12 O
blocks O
of O
10-Gy-scale O
pictures O
of O
common O
objects O
and O
12 O
blocks O
of O
scrambled O
versions O
of O
the O
same O
pictures O
, O
all O
equalized O
for O
luminance O
. O

All O
pictures O
were O
presented O
for O
1200 O
ms O
with O
an O
inter-stimulus O
interval O
of O
600 O
ms O
. O

Stimulus O
blocks O
were O
presented O
in O
random O
order O
and O
interleaved O
with O
fixation O
blocks O
of O
12,600 O
ms O
. O

Experimental O
run O
Stimuli O
for O
this O
run O
consisted O
of O
coloured O
pictures O
of O
cigarettes O
, O
pencils O
and O
chairs O
in O
similar O
colours O
, O
presented O
centrally O
on O
a O
white O
background O
. O

Participants O
were O
presented O
with O
three O
runs O
, O
consisting O
of O
eight O
blocks O
of O
eight O
pictures O
of O
either O
cigarettes O
or O
pencils O
or O
chairs O
. O

Pictures O
were O
presented O
for O
1500 O
ms O
with O
a O
50-ms O
inter-stimulus O
interval O
. O

Stimulus O
blocks O
were O
presented O
in O
random O
order O
and O
interchanged O
with O
intervals O
of O
10 O
, O
12 O
or O
14 O
s O
of O
rest O
( O
see O
Fig O
. O

1 O
) O
. O

These O
intervals O
allowed O
the O
blood O
oxygenated O
level-dependent O
( O
BOLD O
) O
response O
elicited O
by O
the O
previous O
stimulus O
block O
to O
return O
back O
to O
baseline O
before O
the O
onset O
of O
the O
adjacent O
block O
. O

To O
ensure O
attention O
to O
the O
pictures O
, O
participants O
had O
to O
respond O
to O
catch O
trials O
in O
which O
presentation O
of O
the O
preceding O
picture O
was O
repeated O
. O

Imaging O
data O
acquisition O
Functional O
and O
anatomical O
images O
were O
acquired O
in O
a O
3-T O
Siemens O
Prisma O
Scanner O
( O
Siemens O
Medical O
Solutions O
, O
Germany O
) O
using O
a O
64-channel O
head O
coil O
. O

For O
the O
localizer O
run O
, O
functional O
images O
were O
obtained O
for O
33 O
contiguous O
axial O
slices O
( O
voxel O
size O
= O
3 O
× O
3 O
× O
3 O
mm O
) O
using O
a O
standard O
gradient O
echo O
planar O
imaging O
( O
EPI O
) O
sequence O
( O
repetition O
time O
[ O
TR O
] O
= O
1800 O
ms O
, O
echo O
time O
[ O
TE O
] O
= O
30 O
ms O
, O
matrix O
size O
= O
72 O
× O
72 O
, O
flip O
angle O
[ O
FA O
] O
= O
77° O
) O
. O

Functional O
images O
for O
the O
experimental O
runs O
were O
also O
acquired O
with O
an O
EPI O
sequence O
( O
TR O
= O
2000 O
ms O
, O
TE O
= O
30 O
ms O
, O
matrix O
size O
= O
72 O
× O
72 O
, O
FA O
= O
77° O
) O
, O
but O
for O
36 O
contiguous O
axial O
slices O
( O
voxel O
size O
= O
3 O
× O
3 O
× O
3 O
mm O
) O
. O

Both O
functional O
measurements O
covered O
as O
much O
as O
possible O
the O
entire O
cortical O
volume O
. O

Whole O
brain O
structural O
images O
were O
acquired O
using O
a O
1 O
× O
1 O
× O
1 O
mm O
resolution O
T1-weighted O
MPRAGE O
sequence O
( O
[ O
TR O
] O
= O
2250 O
ms O
, O
[ O
TE O
] O
= O
2.21 O
ms O
, O
[ O
FA O
] O
= O
9° O
) O
. O

The O
first O
two O
volumes O
of O
all O
functional O
runs O
were O
discarded O
because O
of O
possible O
T1 O
saturation O
. O

Participants O
were O
placed O
in O
supine O
position O
on O
the O
scanner O
bed O
, O
and O
their O
heads O
were O
fixated O
with O
foam O
pads O
. O

Stimuli O
were O
projected O
on O
a O
screen O
at O
the O
back O
of O
the O
scanner O
bore O
, O
and O
were O
visible O
to O
the O
participants O
through O
a O
mirror O
attached O
to O
the O
head O
coil O
. O

Responses O
were O
made O
with O
a O
hand-held O
button O
box O
. O

Stimulus O
presentation O
was O
accomplished O
with O
Presentation O
software O
( O
Neurobehavioral O
Systems O
Inc. O
, O
Albany O
, O
CA O
) O
for O
the O
localizer O
run O
and O
E-Prime® O
( O
Psychology O
Software O
Tools O
, O
Inc. O
Sharpsburg O
, O
PA O
) O
for O
the O
experimental O
runs O
and O
was O
synchronized O
to O
the O
MR O
data O
acquisition O
. O

Analyses O
Imaging O
data O
was O
pre-processed O
and O
analysed O
using O
BrainVoyager O
QX O
version O
2.8 O
( O
Brain O
Innovation O
, O
Maastricht O
, O
The O
Netherlands O
) O
and O
Matlab O
R2014b O
( O
MathWorks O
Inc. O
, O
Natick O
, O
MA O
) O
. O

First O
, O
functional O
images O
were O
corrected O
for O
possible O
susceptibility-induced O
EPI O
distortions O
by O
using O
B0 O
fieldmaps O
and O
the O
BrainVoyager O
QX O
plugin O
anatabacus O
( O
Breman O
et O
al O
. O
) O
. O

The O
functional O
data O
were O
then O
corrected O
for O
slice O
scan-time O
differences O
and O
3D O
head O
motion O
( O
six O
parameters O
) O
. O

In O
order O
to O
enhance O
the O
subsequent O
alignment O
of O
the O
functional O
images O
to O
the O
anatomical O
volume O
, O
the O
first O
and O
third O
runs O
were O
corrected O
with O
the O
second O
run O
as O
intra-session O
reference O
, O
as O
the O
acquisition O
of O
this O
run O
was O
temporally O
adjacent O
to O
the O
anatomical O
scan O
. O

Subsequently O
, O
linear O
trends O
and O
low-frequency O
temporal O
drifts O
were O
removed O
from O
the O
data O
using O
a O
high-pass O
filter O
, O
removing O
temporal O
frequencies O
below O
6 O
cycles O
per O
run O
. O

The O
resulting O
functional O
data O
were O
co-registered O
to O
the O
anatomical O
volume O
and O
transformed O
to O
Talairach O
space O
. O

To O
further O
reduce O
the O
effects O
of O
motion-related O
variability O
( O
‘ O
spikes O
’ O
) O
, O
a O
custom O
Matlab O
algorithm O
was O
applied O
that O
for O
each O
volume O
computed O
the O
percentage O
of O
voxels O
exceeded O
the O
voxel O
mean O
intensity O
by O
more O
than O
4 O
standard O
deviations O
. O

Volumes O
with O
more O
than O
2 O
% O
extreme O
voxels O
were O
labelled O
as O
affected O
by O
‘ O
excessive O
’ O
motion O
. O

These O
volumes O
were O
replaced O
by O
new O
values O
derived O
from O
a O
voxel-wise O
spline O
interpolation O
between O
the O
volumes O
that O
temporally O
bordered O
the O
removed O
volumes O
. O

In O
case O
the O
excessive O
volumes O
were O
at O
the O
beginning O
or O
end O
of O
the O
run O
, O
the O
volumes O
were O
simply O
removed O
. O

A O
standard O
whole O
brain O
univariate O
random O
effects O
GLM O
analysis O
was O
performed O
to O
localize O
bilateral O
LOC O
clusters O
for O
each O
subject O
. O

The O
locations O
of O
the O
object O
selective O
regions O
of O
interest O
( O
ROIs O
) O
were O
determined O
based O
on O
a O
conjunction O
contrast O
and O
anatomical O
criteria O
. O

We O
selected O
voxels O
within O
the O
bilateral O
ventral O
occipito-temporal O
cortex O
that O
showed O
a O
significant O
response O
( O
Bonferroni O
corrected O
) O
in O
the O
conjunction O
analysis O
between O
an O
object-responsive O
contrast O
( O
objects O
> O
scrambled O
objects O
) O
and O
an O
object-positive O
contrast O
( O
objects O
> O
baseline O
) O
. O

The O
experimental O
runs O
were O
analysed O
through O
a O
pattern O
classification O
approach O
( O
Cox O
and O
Savoy O
) O
using O
custom O
written O
code O
in O
Matlab O
. O

The O
pseudocode O
of O
this O
analysis O
is O
provided O
as O
a O
supplement O
. O

This O
analysis O
was O
confined O
to O
the O
resulting O
voxels O
from O
the O
analysis O
of O
the O
localizer O
run O
. O

First O
, O
for O
each O
voxel O
within O
the O
region O
of O
interest O
, O
individual O
responses O
to O
the O
experimental O
blocks O
were O
estimated O
by O
fitting O
a O
double-gamma O
haemodynamic O
response O
function O
( O
HRF O
) O
to O
the O
voxel O
’ O
s O
time O
course O
, O
using O
the O
resulting O
beta O
as O
block O
estimate O
. O

For O
each O
ROI O
and O
each O
condition O
, O
this O
resulted O
in O
a O
matrix O
with O
dimensions O
V O
× O
B O
, O
where O
V O
represents O
the O
number O
of O
voxels O
, O
and O
B O
stands O
for O
the O
number O
of O
blocks O
. O

These O
matrices O
capture O
the O
fine-grained O
neural O
information O
about O
the O
conditions O
that O
may O
be O
apparent O
in O
the O
response O
patterns O
. O

The O
blocks O
were O
labelled O
according O
to O
their O
corresponding O
condition O
( O
cigarette O
, O
pencil O
, O
chair O
) O
and O
normalized O
( O
z-scored O
) O
so O
as O
to O
obtain O
a O
mean O
response O
of O
0 O
and O
standard O
deviation O
of O
1 O
across O
all O
voxels O
within O
our O
region O
of O
interest O
. O

The O
analysis O
was O
run O
using O
a O
leave-1-run-out O
cross-validation O
. O

This O
entails O
that O
the O
classification O
algorithm O
was O
trained O
on O
two O
out O
of O
three O
runs O
, O
and O
its O
generalization O
performance O
tested O
on O
the O
run O
that O
was O
left O
out O
. O

This O
procedure O
is O
repeated O
three O
times O
, O
ensuring O
that O
each O
run O
is O
once O
used O
for O
testing O
, O
after O
which O
the O
three O
prediction O
accuracies O
are O
averaged O
. O

First O
, O
for O
the O
cigarette O
and O
pencil O
conditions O
, O
the O
dataset O
was O
split O
into O
a O
training O
set O
consisting O
of O
two O
runs O
( O
i.e O
. O

16 O
examples O
) O
per O
condition O
and O
a O
test O
set O
consisting O
of O
one O
run O
( O
i.e O
. O

8 O
examples O
) O
per O
condition O
. O

The O
labelled O
training O
trials O
were O
submitted O
to O
a O
linear O
support O
vector O
machine O
classifier O
( O
C O
= O
1 O
) O
( O
Cortes O
and O
Vapnik O
; O
Mourão-Miranda O
et O
al O
. O

; O
Formisano O
et O
al O
. O

) O
, O
which O
performs O
binary O
classification O
on O
a O
dataset O
by O
placing O
all O
cases O
in O
a O
multidimensional O
space O
. O

Each O
individual O
block O
( O
or O
example O
) O
is O
expressed O
as O
a O
vector O
of O
N O
features O
( O
voxels O
) O
in O
the O
N-dimensional O
space O
. O

This O
creates O
two O
‘ O
clouds O
’ O
of O
block O
vectors O
in O
the O
multidimensional O
space O
, O
one O
for O
each O
condition O
tested O
. O

The O
algorithm O
then O
attempts O
to O
define O
an O
optimal O
separation O
boundary O
, O
or O
hyperplane O
, O
between O
the O
two O
classes O
, O
given O
the O
training O
data O
. O

The O
generalizability O
of O
the O
trained O
classifier O
is O
then O
subsequently O
assessed O
by O
feeding O
the O
independent O
and O
unlabelled O
test O
blocks O
from O
the O
left-out O
run O
to O
the O
algorithm O
. O

The O
accuracy O
at O
which O
the O
classifier O
is O
able O
to O
determine O
the O
correct O
labels O
from O
these O
trials O
given O
only O
the O
response O
patterns O
is O
an O
indication O
of O
successful O
learning O
of O
the O
algorithm O
. O

This O
, O
in O
turn O
, O
reflects O
a O
meaningful O
difference O
in O
spatial O
patterns O
of O
neural O
activity O
elicited O
by O
the O
two O
conditions O
. O

In O
order O
to O
statistically O
quantify O
the O
prediction O
results O
, O
we O
empirically O
estimated O
the O
distribution O
of O
prediction O
accuracies O
under O
the O
null O
hypothesis O
by O
a O
bootstrapping O
approach O
: O
instead O
of O
training O
the O
classifier O
on O
voxel O
patterns O
and O
corresponding O
class O
labels O
, O
we O
pseudo O
randomly O
assigned O
the O
labels O
to O
the O
patterns O
( O
randomization O
of O
labels O
per O
run O
) O
. O

The O
classifier O
then O
learned O
the O
arbitrary O
relationship O
between O
patterns O
and O
classes O
. O

By O
feeding O
the O
test O
trials O
to O
the O
model O
, O
we O
obtained O
a O
prediction O
accuracy O
under O
the O
null O
hypothesis O
. O

Repeating O
this O
1000 O
times O
yields O
the O
distribution O
of O
prediction O
accuracies O
under O
the O
null O
hypothesis O
. O

This O
entire O
analysis O
was O
repeated O
for O
the O
cigarette O
and O
chair O
, O
and O
pencil O
and O
chair O
classes O
. O

Finally O
, O
a O
non-parametric O
Wilcoxon O
signed-rank O
test O
( O
Wilcoxon O
) O
was O
performed O
to O
statistically O
test O
the O
mean O
prediction O
accuracies O
against O
the O
permutations O
, O
and O
to O
test O
the O
difference O
between O
the O
deprivation O
and O
satiation O
sessions O
. O

Resulting O
p O
values O
were O
corrected O
for O
multiple O
comparisons O
by O
computing O
the O
false O
discovery O
rate O
( O
FDR O
) O
using O
q O
= O
0.05 O
. O

In O
order O
to O
test O
the O
variables O
for O
possible O
interaction O
effects O
, O
we O
computed O
the O
two-way O
F-statistic O
using O
a O
repeated-measures O
ANOVA O
with O
the O
factors O
deprivation O
state O
( O
2 O
) O
× O
stimulus O
type O
( O
3 O
) O
. O

Then O
, O
we O
permuted O
the O
2 O
× O
3 O
condition O
labels O
across O
participants O
and O
recomputed O
the O
F-statistic O
in O
10,000 O
iterations O
, O
creating O
the O
distribution O
of O
F O
under O
the O
null O
hypothesis O
( O
Suckling O
and O
Bullmore O
) O
. O

The O
probability O
of O
finding O
the O
true O
interaction O
F-statistic O
under O
the O
assumption O
that O
the O
H0 O
is O
true O
was O
subsequently O
derived O
from O
the O
permuted O
F-distribution O
. O

A O
priori O
planned O
comparisons O
between O
the O
satiated O
and O
deprived O
conditions O
were O
made O
for O
each O
stimulus O
category O
, O
regardless O
of O
the O
outcome O
of O
the O
corresponding O
overall O
interaction O
test O
. O

This O
is O
a O
legitimate O
procedure O
if O
the O
comparisons O
are O
suggested O
by O
the O
theoretical O
basis O
of O
the O
experiment O
( O
Winer O
) O
. O

Access O
to O
the O
Matlab O
codes O
used O
in O
this O
study O
will O
be O
provided O
upon O
individual O
request O
. O

Insular O
and O
Cingulate O
Attenuation O
during O
Decision O
Making O
is O
associated O
with O
Future O
Transition O
to O
Stimulant O
Use O
Disorder O
Aims O
To O
understand O
processes O
placing O
individuals O
at O
risk O
for O
stimulant O
( O
amphetamine O
and O
cocaine O
) O
use O
disorder O
. O

Design O
Longitudinal O
study O
. O

Setting O
University O
of O
California O
, O
San O
Diego O
Department O
of O
Psychiatry O
, O
USA O
. O

Participants O
Occasional O
stimulant O
users O
( O
OSU O
; O
n=184 O
) O
underwent O
a O
baseline O
clinical O
interview O
and O
a O
functional O
magnetic O
resonance O
imaging O
( O
fMRI O
) O
session O
. O

On O
the O
basis O
of O
a O
follow-up O
clinical O
interview O
completed O
three O
years O
later O
, O
OSU O
( O
n=147 O
) O
were O
then O
categorized O
as O
problem O
stimulant O
users O
( O
PSU O
: O
n=36 O
; O
those O
who O
developed O
stimulant O
use O
disorders O
in O
the O
interim O
) O
or O
desisted O
stimulant O
users O
( O
DSU O
: O
n=74 O
; O
those O
who O
stopped O
using O
) O
. O

OSU O
who O
did O
not O
meet O
criteria O
for O
PSU O
or O
DSU O
( O
n=37 O
) O
were O
included O
in O
dimensional O
analyses O
. O

Measurements O
fMRI O
blood-oxygen-level O
dependent O
( O
BOLD O
) O
contrast O
percent O
signal O
change O
from O
baseline O
collected O
during O
a O
Paper-Scissors-Rock O
task O
was O
examined O
during O
three O
decision O
making O
conditions O
, O
those O
resulting O
in O
: O
( O
1 O
) O
wins O
, O
( O
2 O
) O
ties O
, O
and O
( O
3 O
) O
losses O
. O

These O
data O
were O
used O
as O
dependent O
variables O
in O
categorical O
analyses O
comparing O
PSU O
and O
DSU O
as O
well O
as O
dimensional O
analyses O
including O
interim O
drug O
use O
as O
predictors O
, O
controlling O
for O
baseline O
drug O
use O
. O

Findings O
PSU O
exhibited O
lower O
anterior O
cingulate O
, O
middle O
insula O
, O
superior O
temporal O
, O
inferior O
parietal O
, O
precuneus O
and O
cerebellum O
activation O
than O
DSU O
across O
all O
three O
conditions O
( O
significant O
brain O
clusters O
required O
> O
19 O
neighboring O
voxels O
to O
exceed O
F O
( O
1,108 O
) O
=5.58 O
, O
p O
< O
.01 O
two-tailed O
; O
all O
Cohen O
’ O
s O
d O
> O
.83 O
) O
. O

Higher O
interim O
marijuana O
use O
was O
linked O
to O
lower O
precentral O
and O
superior O
temporal O
activation O
during O
choices O
resulting O
in O
wins O
( O
> O
19 O
neighboring O
voxels O
to O
exceed O
t=2.61 O
, O
p O
< O
.01 O
two-tailed O
; O
R2 O
change O
> O
.11 O
) O
. O

Conclusions O
Individuals O
who O
transition O
from O
stimulant O
use O
to O
stimulant O
use O
disorder O
appear O
to O
show O
alterations O
in O
neural O
processing O
of O
stimulus O
valuation O
and O
outcome O
monitoring O
, O
patterns O
also O
evident O
in O
chronic O
stimulant O
use O
disorder O
. O

Attenuated O
anterior O
cingulate O
and O
insular O
processing O
may O
constitute O
a O
high-risk O
neural O
processing O
profile O
, O
which O
could O
be O
used O
to O
calculate O
risk O
scores O
for O
individuals O
experimenting O
with O
stimulants O
. O

Methods O
Design O
Figure O
1 O
illustrates O
the O
longitudinal O
study O
design O
: O
( O
1 O
) O
at O
baseline O
, O
OSU O
completed O
an O
interview O
to O
evaluate O
clinical O
diagnoses O
and O
determine O
initial O
drug O
use O
patterns O
, O
and O
a O
neuroimaging O
session O
; O
and O
( O
2 O
) O
three O
years O
later O
, O
OSU O
completed O
a O
follow-up O
interview O
to O
determine O
changes O
in O
clinical O
status O
and O
patterns O
of O
drug O
use O
. O

Participants O
The O
study O
protocol O
was O
approved O
by O
the O
University O
of O
California O
, O
San O
Diego O
institutional O
review O
board O
and O
complied O
with O
the O
Declaration O
of O
Helsinki O
. O

Students O
at O
local O
universities O
were O
recruited O
via O
internet O
ads O
, O
newspapers O
, O
and O
flyers O
; O
OSU O
who O
met O
study O
criteria O
provided O
written O
informed O
consent O
to O
participate O
. O

OSU O
endorsed O
: O
( O
a O
) O
> O
2 O
off-prescription O
uses O
of O
cocaine O
and/or O
pharmaceutical O
stimulants O
( O
amphetamines O
and/or O
methylphenidate O
) O
in O
the O
past O
six O
months O
; O
( O
b O
) O
no O
lifetime O
stimulant O
dependence O
; O
and O
( O
c O
) O
no O
interest O
in O
drug O
treatment O
. O

Baseline O
Interview O
Session O
Lifetime O
DSM-IV O
Axis O
I O
diagnoses O
and O
Axis O
II O
antisocial O
personality O
disorder O
( O
ASPD O
) O
were O
assessed O
by O
the O
Semi-Structured O
Assessment O
for O
the O
Genetics O
of O
Alcoholism O
II O
( O
SSAGA O
II O
) O
( O
see O
for O
participant O
exclusion O
criteria O
) O
. O

Subjects O
also O
completed O
a O
measure O
of O
verbal O
intelligence O
( O
IQ O
) O
as O
well O
as O
the O
Barratt O
Impulsiveness O
Scale O
( O
BIS-11 O
) O
, O
Sensation O
Seeking O
Scale O
( O

) O
, O
and O
Beck O
Depression O
Inventory O
( O
