) O
, O
measures O
indexing O
impulsivity O
, O
sensation O
seeking O
, O
and O
depression O
, O
respectively O
. O

Baseline O
Neuroimaging O
Session O
Overview O
Participants O
were O
instructed O
to O
abstain O
from O
illicit O
substance O
use O
≥ O
72 O
h O
prior O
( O
abstinence O
was O
determined O
by O
urine O
toxicology O
screen O
) O
. O

Subjects O
then O
completed O
the O
PSR O
task O
during O
fMRI O
recording O
after O
engaging O
in O
a O
practice O
version O
of O
the O
task O
outside O
of O
the O
scanner O
. O

PSR O
paradigm O
This O
task O
examines O
how O
individuals O
acquire O
the O
ability O
to O
make O
decisions O
associated O
with O
advantageous O
outcomes O
, O
wherein O
: O
( O
1 O
) O
rock O
beats O
scissors O
; O
( O
2 O
) O
paper O
beats O
rock O
; O
( O
3 O
) O
scissors O
beat O
paper O
. O

Subjects O
were O
instructed O
to O
play O
against O
the O
computer O
and O
attempt O
to O
maximize O
points O
( O
1 O
for O
a O
win O
, O
0 O
for O
a O
tie O
, O
and O
−1 O
for O
a O
loss O
) O
, O
as O
they O
would O
receive O
additional O
payment O
according O
to O
their O
cumulative O
point O
total O
( O
each O
point O
was O
worth O
$ O
1 O
) O
. O

Unknown O
to O
the O
subject O
, O
probability O
of O
beating O
the O
computer O
and O
thus O
being O
reinforced O
( O
e.g. O
, O
subject O
chooses O
scissors O
, O
computer O
selects O
paper O
, O
scissors O
beats O
paper O
, O
subject O
gains O
1 O
point O
) O
was O
predetermined O
. O

A O
total O
of O
120 O
trials O
were O
presented O
( O
six O
blocks O
containing O
20 O
trials O
) O
. O

Within O
each O
block O
, O
the O
three O
possible O
selections O
had O
pre-determined O
probabilities O
of O
having O
a O
winning O
, O
tying O
, O
or O
losing O
outcome O
. O

The O
“ O
preferred O
response O
” O
won O
on O
90 O
% O
of O
trials O
, O
the O
“ O
even O
response O
” O
won O
50 O
% O
of O
the O
time O
, O
and O
the O
“ O
worst O
response O
” O
won O
on O
10 O
% O
of O
trials O
. O

Preferred O
, O
even O
, O
and O
worst O
responses O
were O
switched O
for O
each O
of O
the O
six O
blocks O
. O

Figure O
2A O
illustrates O
an O
example O
of O
one O
trial O
. O

After O
an O
initial O
fixation O
lasting O
2 O
s O
, O
subjects O
saw O
a O
hand O
forming O
paper O
, O
scissors O
, O
and O
rock O
on O
a O
screen O
for O
1 O
s O
and O
heard O
the O
instruction O
“ O
one O
, O
two O
, O
three O
” O
over O
headphones O
. O

At O
3 O
s O
into O
the O
trial O
, O
subjects O
were O
then O
presented O
with O
a O
“ O
Go O
” O
sign O
, O
providing O
the O
cue O
to O
select O
paper O
, O
scissors O
, O
or O
rock O
. O

Subjects O
had O
3.5 O
s O
to O
respond O
, O
after O
which O
the O
trial O
timed O
out O
. O

Upon O
responding O
, O
the O
outcome O
was O
presented O
, O
wherein O
the O
subject O
saw O
the O
computer O
’ O
s O
response O
, O
and O
heard O
“ O
you O
win O
, O
” O
“ O
you O
lose O
, O
” O
or O
“ O
a O
tie O
” O
. O

Nine O
null O
trials O
were O
interspersed O
at O
the O
beginning O
( O
three O
prior O
to O
any O
relevant O
trials O
) O
, O
middle O
( O
three O
prior O
to O
the O
fourth O
block O
) O
, O
and O
end O
of O
the O
task O
( O
three O
after O
all O
relevant O
trials O
were O
completed O
) O
as O
a O
temporal O
jitter O
. O

fMRI O
image O
acquisition O
One O
run O
indexing O
blood O
oxygenation O
level-dependent O
( O
BOLD O
) O
contrast O
was O
collected O
( O
randomized O
fast-event O
related O
design O
) O
using O
a O
Signa O
EXCITE O
( O
GE O
Healthcare O
, O
Milwaukee O
, O
Wisconsin O
) O
3.0 O
Tesla O
scanner O
( O
T2 O
* O
-weighted O
EPI O
scans O
, O
TR=2000 O
ms O
, O
TE=32 O
ms O
, O
FOV=230mm3 O
, O
64×64 O
matrix O
, O
30 O
2.6mm O
axial O
slices O
[ O
1.4 O
mm O
gap O
] O
, O
flip O
angle=90° O
, O
290 O
whole-brain O
TRs O
) O
. O

fMRI O
volume O
acquisitions O
were O
time-locked O
to O
task O
onset O
. O

A O
high-resolution O
T1-weighted O
anatomical O
image O
was O
obtained O
[ O
spoiled O
gradient O
recalled O
( O
SPGR O
) O
, O
TI=450 O
, O
TR=8 O
ms O
, O
TE=3 O
ms O
, O
flip O
angle=12° O
, O
FOV=250mm3 O
, O
192×256 O
matrix O
, O
172 O
sagittally O
acquired O
slices O
with O
1mm O
thickness O
] O
. O

Analysis O
pathway O
specifications O
including O
slice O
timing O
correction O
, O
outlier O
estimation/removal O
, O
and O
motion O
estimation/correction O
are O
detailed O
in O
. O

Multiple O
regressor O
analyses O
A O
deconvolution O
model O
was O
created O
in O
Analysis O
of O
Functional O
Neuroimages O
( O
AFNI O
) O
, O
individualized O
for O
each O
participant O
, O
comparing O
decision-making O
between O
preferred O
, O
even O
, O
and O
worst O
response O
selections O
. O

Each O
subject O
’ O
s O
behavioral O
performance O
determined O
three O
regressors O
of O
interest O
for O
trials O
in O
which O
the O
participant O
selected O
: O
( O
a O
) O
the O
preferred O
response O
, O
( O
b O
) O
the O
tied O
response O
, O
and O
( O
c O
) O
the O
worst O
response O
( O
Figure O
2B O
depicts O
an O
example O
of O
one O
participant O
’ O
s O
performance O
) O
. O

The O
baseline O
for O
this O
model O
consisted O
of O
the O
inter-trial O
interval O
and O
null O
trials O
interspersed O
between O
trial O
blocks O
. O

Regressors O
of O
interest O
were O
generated O
to O
delineate O
conditions O
for O
this O
model O
, O
wherein O
a O
0–1 O
reference O
function O
for O
each O
condition O
was O
convolved O
with O
a O
gamma O
variate O
function O
modeling O
a O
prototypical O
hemodynamic O
response O
( O
6–8 O
s O
delay O
) O
. O

Three O
normalized O
decision-making O
predictors O
( O
brain O
activation O
from O
trial O
onset O
to O
each O
participant O
’ O
s O
behavioral O
selection O
of O
the O
preferred O
, O
even O
, O
and O
worst O
response O
designated O
for O
each O
block O
) O
were O
included O
in O
the O
AFNI O
program O
3dDeconvolve O
, O
controlling O
for O
motion O
as O
well O
as O
baseline O
and O
linear O
drift O
, O
to O
estimate O
goodness O
of O
fit O
between O
model O
estimates O
and O
BOLD O
responses O
for O
each O
subject O
. O

Voxels O
were O
resampled O
into O
4×4×4mm3 O
space O
and O
whole-brain O
voxel-wise O
normalized O
percent O
signal O
change O
( O
PSC O
) O
, O
the O
main O
dependent O
measure O
, O
was O
determined O
by O
dividing O
the O
beta O
coefficient O
for O
each O
of O
the O
predictors O
of O
interest O
( O
preferred O
, O
even O
, O
and O
worst O
responses O
) O
by O
the O
beta O
coefficient O
for O
the O
baseline O
regressor O
and O
multiplying O
by O
100 O
. O

A O
Gaussian O
spatial O
filter O
( O
4mm O
full O
width O
half O
maximum O
; O
FWHM O
) O
was O
used O
to O
spatially O
blur O
PSC O
values O
to O
account O
for O
anatomical O
differences O
and O
this O
output O
was O
then O
normalized O
to O
Talairach O
coordinates O
( O
40×48×38 O
voxel O
coverage O
) O
as O
defined O
by O
AFNI O
’ O
s O
built-in O
atlases O
. O

Individual O
subject O
PSC-scaled O
beta O
weight O
values O
for O
preferred O
, O
even O
, O
and O
worst O
responses O
for O
each O
voxel O
included O
in O
a O
whole-brain O
mask O
( O
comprised O
of O
23775 O
voxels O
) O
was O
extracted O
for O
further O
categorical O
and O
dimensional O
statistical O
analyses O
outlined O
below O
. O

Individual O
voxels O
meeting O
a O
p O
< O
.01 O
significance O
criterion O
as O
a O
result O
of O
these O
statistical O
tests O
( O
linear O
mixed O
models O
and O
regressions O
) O
were O
further O
evaluated O
to O
determine O
whether O
they O
comprised O
a O
significant O
brain O
cluster O
after O
correction O
for O
multiple O
comparisons O
( O
given O
all O
voxels O
included O
in O
the O
whole-brain O
mask O
) O
. O

Leading O
neuroimaging O
programs O
have O
recently O
been O
criticized O
for O
underestimation O
of O
spatial O
autocorrelation O
in O
fMRI O
data O
, O
resulting O
in O
inadequate O
implementation O
of O
correction O
for O
multiple O
comparisons O
when O
determining O
how O
many O
voxels O
are O
required O
to O
comprise O
a O
significant O
brain O
cluster O
. O

As O
a O
consequence O
of O
this O
critique O
, O
we O
revised O
our O
laboratory O
’ O
s O
clustering O
procedure O
. O

First O
, O
the O
updated O
AFNI O
3dFWHMx O
program O
was O
used O
to O
more O
reliably O
estimate O
the O
actual O
autocorrelation O
in O
fMRI O
data O
across O
participants O
( O
.44 O
, O
1.71 O
, O
and O
10.36 O
) O
as O
well O
as O
the O
actual O
smoothness O
present O
in O
the O
data O
after O
blurring O
( O
4.99 O
mm O
) O
. O

Second O
, O
we O
then O
ran O
an O
updated O
version O
of O
AFNI O
’ O
s O
3dClustSim O
that O
takes O
these O
autocorrelation O
values O
into O
account O
given O
our O
voxel O
size O
, O
whole O
brain O
mask O
size O
, O
10,000 O
Monte O
Carlo O
simulations O
, O
and O
two-sided O
thresholding O
with O
an O
overall O
voxel O
p O
statistical O
threshold O
of O
.01 O
and O
a O
corrected O
clusterwise O
alpha O
value O
of O
.01 O
. O

Given O
this O
input O
, O
3dClustSim O
determined O
that O
: O
( O
1 O
) O
our O
data O
smoothness O
approached O
6.20mm O
; O
and O
( O
2 O
) O
> O
19 O
neighboring O
voxels O
( O
or O
> O
1216μL O
) O
were O
required O
to O
comprise O
a O
significant O
brain O
cluster O
; O
this O
voxelwise O
cutoff O
more O
than O
doubles O
the O
size O
of O
the O
cluster O
required O
for O
significance O
given O
similar O
blurring O
parameters O
in O
our O
prior O
work O
( O
8 O
voxels O
) O
. O

Three O
Year O
Follow-Up O
Interview O
Session O
OSU O
were O
contacted O
three O
years O
after O
their O
baseline O
assessment O
( O
Figure O
1 O
) O
. O

Each O
participant O
underwent O
a O
standardized O
interview O
( O
phone O
or O
in-person O
) O
to O
examine O
extent O
of O
drug O
use O
in O
the O
three-year O
interim O
since O
the O
baseline O
interview O
, O
thereby O
allowing O
us O
to O
identify O
subjects O
meeting O
criteria O
for O
new O
stimulant O
user O
groups O
: O
PSU O
or O
DSU O
. O

PSU O
were O
a O
priori O
defined O
by O
: O
( O
1 O
) O
continued O
stimulant O
use O
during O
the O
three-year O
interim O
( O
see O
Table O
1 O
) O
; O
and O
( O
2 O
) O
endorsement O
of O
2+ O
symptoms O
of O
DSM-IV O
amphetamine O
and/or O
cocaine O
abuse O
or O
dependence O
criteria O
occurring O
together O
≥ O
6 O
contiguous O
months O
since O
the O
initial O
visit O
( O
M=4.17 O
symptoms O
; O
SD=2.32 O
; O
range O
: O
2–9 O
) O
. O

Percentage O
of O
PSU O
subjects O
who O
met O
criteria O
for O
stimulant O
use O
disorders O
were O
the O
following O
: O
53 O
% O
cocaine O
abuse O
, O
22 O
% O
cocaine O
dependence O
, O
42 O
% O
amphetamine O
abuse O
, O
and O
19 O
% O
amphetamine O
dependence O
( O
n=3 O
met O
criteria O
for O
2 O
symptoms O
of O
dependence O
, O
1 O
criterion O
short O
to O
obtain O
a O
diagnosis O
; O
n=20 O
met O
criteria O
for O
1 O
diagnosis O
; O
n=10 O
met O
criteria O
for O
2 O
diagnoses O
; O
and O
n=3 O
met O
criteria O
for O
3 O
diagnoses O
) O
. O

In O
comparison O
, O
DSU O
were O
defined O
as O
having O
: O
( O
1 O
) O
no O
6-month O
periods O
of O
3+ O
stimulant O
uses O
; O
and O
( O
2 O
) O
no O
interim O
stimulant O
use O
disorder O
symptoms O
. O

Figure O
1 O
illustrates O
that O
categorical O
analyses O
compared O
PSU O
and O
DSU O
on O
fMRI O
data O
, O
whereas O
dimensional O
analyses O
included O
all O
OSU O
with O
usable O
fMRI O
and O
follow-up O
data O
, O
even O
those O
who O
did O
not O
meet O
PSU O
or O
DSU O
group O
criteria O
. O

Categorical O
Analyses O
Self-report O
Group O
differences O
in O
age O
, O
verbal O
IQ O
, O
education O
, O
drug O
use O
sessions O
, O
impulsivity O
, O
and O
sensation O
seeking O
were O
evaluated O
using O
IBM O
SPSS O
Statistics O
for O
Windows O
Version O
22 O
( O
Armonk O
, O
NY O
) O
independent O
sample O
t-tests O
. O

Group O
differences O
in O
gender O
, O
handedness O
, O
race/ethnicity O
, O
depression O
( O
BDI O
scores O
0–9 O
= O
no O
depression O
; O
BDI O
scores O
10–14 O
= O
mild O
depression O
) O
and O
drug O
use O
recency O
were O
explored O
using O
SPSS O
chi-square O
tests O
. O

Neuroimaging O
For O
each O
voxel O
, O
a O
linear O
mixed O
effects O
( O
LME O
) O
model O
in O
R O
was O
calculated O
on O
PSC O
values O
with O
group O
( O
PSU O
, O
DSU O
) O
and O
decision O
condition O
( O
preferred O
, O
even O
, O
and O
worst O
choices O
) O
modeled O
as O
fixed O
factors O
, O
and O
subject O
modeled O
as O
a O
random O
factor O
. O

For O
each O
voxel O
, O
degrees O
of O
freedom O
, O
F O
, O
and O
p O
values O
were O
obtained O
for O
each O
main O
effect O
and O
interaction O
. O

Only O
individual O
voxels O
meeting O
p O
< O
.01 O
significance O
for O
the O
F O
test O
were O
considered O
for O
inclusion O
in O
brain O
clustering O
, O
correcting O
for O
multiple O
comparisons O
. O

Cohen O
’ O
s O
d O
was O
calculated O
to O
determine O
effect O
sizes O
. O

All O
fMRI O
results O
were O
whole-brain O
extractions O
. O

Dimensional O
Analyses O
Figure O
1 O
illustrates O
that O
across O
all O
OSU O
with O
usable O
follow-up O
data O
, O
regardless O
of O
group O
status O
, O
cumulative O
stimulant O
and O
marijuana O
uses O
at O
baseline O
as O
well O
as O
interim O
stimulant O
and O
marijuana O
uses O
reported O
at O
follow-up O
were O
log O
transformed O
due O
to O
skew O
, O
standardized O
, O
and O
entered O
as O
predictors O
in O
multivariate O
regressions O
for O
self-report O
and O
neuroimaging O
data O
. O

Self-report O
Multivariate O
linear O
regressions O
were O
computed O
in O
IBM O
SPSS O
Statistics O
for O
the O
following O
dependent O
variables O
: O
age O
, O
verbal O
IQ O
, O
education O
, O
impulsivity O
and O
sensation O
seeking O
. O

A O
multivariate O
logistic O
regression O
was O
computed O
for O
depression O
status O
. O

Neuroimaging O
A O
total O
of O
three O
multivariate O
linear O
regressions O
were O
computed O
in O
R O
( O
https O
: O
//cran.r-project.org/package=rlm O
) O
for O
each O
voxel O
in O
the O
whole-brain O
mask O
. O

Dependent O
variables O
were O
PSC O
for O
preferred O
, O
even O
, O
and O
worst O
decision O
trials O
. O

DRD2 O
co-expression O
network O
and O
a O
related O
polygenic O
index O
predict O
imaging O
, O
behavioral O
and O
clinical O
phenotypes O
linked O
to O
schizophrenia O
Genetic O
risk O
for O
schizophrenia O
( O
SCZ O
) O
is O
determined O
by O
many O
genetic O
loci O
whose O
compound O
biological O
effects O
are O
difficult O
to O
determine O
. O

We O
hypothesized O
that O
co-expression O
pathways O
of O
SCZ O
risk O
genes O
are O
associated O
with O
system-level O
brain O
function O
and O
clinical O
phenotypes O
of O
SCZ O
. O

We O
examined O
genetic O
variants O
related O
to O
the O
dopamine O
D2 O
receptor O
gene O
DRD2 O
co-expression O
pathway O
and O
associated O
them O
with O
working O
memory O
( O
WM O
) O
behavior O
, O
the O
related O
brain O
activity O
and O
treatment O
response O
. O

Using O
two O
independent O
post-mortem O
prefrontal O
messenger O
RNA O
( O
mRNA O
) O
data O
sets O
( O
total O
N=249 O
) O
, O
we O
identified O
a O
DRD2 O
co-expression O
pathway O
enriched O
for O
SCZ O
risk O
genes O
. O

Next O
, O
we O
identified O
non-coding O
single-nucleotide O
polymorphisms O
( O
SNPs O
) O
associated O
with O
co-expression O
of O
this O
pathway O
. O

These O
SNPs O
were O
associated O
with O
regulatory O
genetic O
loci O
in O
the O
dorsolateral O
prefrontal O
cortex O
( O
P O
< O
0.05 O
) O
. O

We O
summarized O
their O
compound O
effect O
on O
co-expression O
into O
a O
Polygenic O
Co-expression O
Index O
( O
PCI O
) O
, O
which O
predicted O
DRD2 O
pathway O
co-expression O
in O
both O
mRNA O
data O
sets O
( O
all O
P O
< O
0.05 O
) O
. O

We O
associated O
the O
PCI O
with O
brain O
activity O
during O
WM O
performance O
in O
two O
independent O
samples O
of O
healthy O
individuals O
( O
total O
N=368 O
) O
and O
29 O
patients O
with O
SCZ O
who O
performed O
the O
n-back O
task O
. O

Greater O
predicted O
DRD2 O
pathway O
prefrontal O
co-expression O
was O
associated O
with O
greater O
prefrontal O
activity O
and O
longer O
WM O
reaction O
times O
( O
all O
corrected O
P O
< O
0.05 O
) O
, O
thus O
indicating O
inefficient O
WM O
processing O
. O

Blind O
prediction O
of O
treatment O
response O
to O
antipsychotics O
in O
two O
independent O
samples O
of O
patients O
with O
SCZ O
suggested O
better O
clinical O
course O
of O
patientswith O
greater O
PCI O
( O
total O
N=87 O
; O
P O
< O
0.05 O
) O
. O

The O
findings O
on O
this O
DRD2 O
co-expression O
pathway O
are O
a O
proof O
of O
concept O
that O
gene O
co-expression O
can O
parse O
SCZ O
risk O
genes O
into O
biological O
pathways O
associated O
with O
intermediate O
phenotypes O
as O
well O
as O
with O
clinically O
meaningful O
information O
. O

Materials O
and O
methods O
Participants O
Table O
1 O
summarizes O
the O

data O
of O

subjects O
included O
in O
all O
experiments O
. O

After O

a O
complete O

of O

in O
the O

and O
the O

consent O
following O
the O
guidelines O
of O
the O
Declaration O
of O
Helsinki O
. O

Protocols O
and O
procedures O
were O
approved O
by O
the O

committee O
of O
the O
University O
of O

and O
by O
the O

review O

of O

Network O
identification O
We O
used O
the O
publicly O
available O
Braincloud O
data O
set O
( O
http O
: O
//braincloud.jhmi.edu/ O
) O
for O
a O
genome-wide O
Weighted O
Genes O
Co-expression O
Network O
Analysis O
. O

The O
sample O
included O
199 O
observations O
( O
demographics O
in O
Table O
1 O
) O
. O

We O
preprocessed O
the O
gene O
expression O
matrix O
to O
factor O
out O
confounding O
variables O
, O
including O
demographics O
. O

The O
first O
principal O
component O
of O
the O
DRD2 O
gene O
set O
( O
module O
eigengene O
, O
ME O
) O
served O
to O
track O
the O
simultaneous O
variation O
of O
the O
whole O
gene O
set O
. O

We O
correlated O
this O
co-expression O
measure O
with O
DRD2 O
expression O
levels O
. O

To O
investigate O
the O
biological O
functions O
that O
may O
be O
subserved O
by O
this O
ensemble O
of O
co-expressed O
genes O
, O
we O
computed O
gene O
ontology O
enrichment O
analysis O
using O
AmiGO2 O
( O
http O
: O
//amigo.geneontology.org/amigo/landing O
) O
. O

Finally O
, O
we O
assessed O
enrichment O
of O
the O
gene O
set O
for O
the O
loci O
associated O
with O
SCZ O
risk O
by O
the O
Psychiatric O
Genomic O
Consortium O
( O
PGC O
with O
a O
hypergeometric O
test O
( O
SI O
Materials O
and O
Methods O
) O
. O

SNP O
association O
study O
We O
performed O
a O
gene O
set-wide O
association O
study O
of O
SNPs O
with O
the O
ME O
. O

The O
sample O
size O
of O
our O
post-mortem O
data O
set O
is O
probably O
small O
for O
a O
genetic O
association O
study O
, O
and O
co-expression O
is O
most O
likely O
a O
phenotypic O
trait O
with O
complex O
heritability O
, O
much O
like O
SCZ O
. O

Power O
calculations O
in O
genetic O
association O
studies O
have O
been O
shown O
to O
depend O
on O
many O
factors O
, O
including O
heritability O
of O
the O
trait O
, O
the O
proportion O
of O
variance O
explained O
by O
the O
genotyped O
SNPs O
, O
the O
total O
number O
of O
SNPs O
, O
the O
proportion O
of O
SNPs O
with O
no O
effect O
on O
the O
trait O
, O
the O
total O
sample O
size O
and O
the O
P-value O
threshold O
for O
SNP O
selection O
. O

The O
heritability O
of O
expression O
quantitative O
trait O
loci O
( O
eQTLs O
) O
is O
extremely O
variable O
and O
appears O
to O
be O
comparable O
between O
cis- O
and O
trans-eQTLs O
( O
co-eQTLs O
fall O
in O
the O
latter O
category O
) O
. O

Nevertheless O
, O
there O
is O
evidence O
of O
high O
replicability O
of O
eQTLs O
both O
with O
stringent O
and O
more O
lenient O
thresholds O
of O
significance O
. O

These O
findings O
suggest O
that O
, O
beside O
statistical O
significance O
, O
genetic O
signals O
in O
the O
study O
of O
gene O
expression O
may O
be O
found O
beyond O
the O
threshold O
for O
corrected O
or O
nominal O
significance O
, O
as O
is O
also O
the O
case O
of O
complex O
clinical O
traits O
. O

Based O
on O
these O
considerations O
, O
we O
first O
tested O
for O
co-eQTLs O
that O
would O
survive O
stringent O
Bonferroni O
correction O
; O
then O
, O
we O
employed O
more O
permissive O
statistics O
for O
our O
association O
to O
minimize O
false-negative O
findings O
and O
performed O
internal O
cross-validations O
and O
independent O
replication O
to O
minimize O
type O
I O
errors O
. O

Through O
this O
procedure O
, O
we O
aimed O
at O
identifying O
an O
ensemble O
of O
SNPs O
that O
, O
together O
, O
predict O
co-expression O
. O

We O
used O
eight O
SNPs O
associated O
with O
the O
first O
principal O
component O
of O
gene O
set O
co-expression O
with O
P O
< O
0.005 O
to O
compute O
the O
PCI O
. O

As O
a O
common O
method O
to O
select O
SNPs O
for O
subsequent O
inclusion O
in O
polygenic O
scores O
consists O
in O
increasing O
the O
number O
of O
SNPs O
until O
the O
proportion O
of O
variance O
plateaus O
, O
we O
also O
tested O
whether O
such O
an O
approach O
selected O
the O
same O
set O
of O
eight O
SNPs O
with O
P O
< O
0.005 O
( O
SI O
Materials O
and O
Methods O
) O
. O

We O
interrogated O
Haploreg O
v4.1 O
( O
http O
: O
//archive.broadinstitute.org/mammals/haploreg/haploreg.php O
) O
to O
gain O
information O
on O
the O
possible O
regulatory O
functions O
of O
these O
SNPs O
. O

Then O
, O
we O
computed O
the O
PCI O
by O
assigning O
a O
weight O
to O
each O
genotype O
of O
each O
SNP O
based O
on O
the O
expression O
profile O
within O
different O
genotypic O
groups O
. O

The O
greater O
the O
PCI O
, O
the O
greater O
is O
the O
messenger O
RNA O
expression O
level O
of O
that O
individual O
. O

We O
cross-validated O
the O
PCI O
and O
assessed O
ethnicity O
and O
population O
stratification O
effects O
, O
as O
well O
as O
age O
effects O
( O
SI O
Materials O
and O
Methods O
) O
. O

We O
used O
the O
publicly O
available O
BrainEAC O
data O
set O
to O
replicate O
the O
association O
of O
the O
PCI O
with O
D2L O
co-expression O
in O
the O
frontal O
cortex O
. O

From O
this O
data O
set O
, O
we O
selected O
the O
probes O
of O
all O
genes O
included O
in O
the O
D2L O
co-expression O
pathway O
and O
preprocessed O
the O
data O
as O
above O
reported O
. O

The O
sample O
included O
50 O
Caucasian O
participants O
. O

We O
computed O
the O
PCI O
of O
each O
individual O
and O
associated O
it O
with O
the O
ME O
using O
Pearson O
’ O

. O

Imaging O
study O
We O

124 O

from O

for O

. O

We O
used O
the O
n-back O
task O
to O
probe O
WM O
. O

Stimuli O
consisted O
of O
numbers O
( O
1–4 O
) O
shown O
in O
random O
sequence O
and O
displayed O
at O
the O
points O
of O
a O
diamond-shaped O
box O
. O

There O
was O
a O
non-memory-guided O
control O
condition O
( O
0-back O
) O
that O
required O
subjects O
to O
identify O
the O
stimulus O
currently O
seen O
. O

As O

load O
increased O
, O
the O
task O
required O
the O
recollection O
of O
a O
stimulus O
seen O
one O
( O
1-back O
) O
or O
two O
( O
2-back O
) O
stimuli O
before O
, O
while O
keeping O
on O

stimuli O
( O

Materials O
and O
Methods O
) O
. O

We O
tested O

of O
the O
PCI O
with O
brain O
activation O
using O
repeated O
measures O
analysis O
of O
covariance O
( O

factor O
: O
LOAD O
( O
1-back O
, O
2-back O
) O
; O
covariates O
: O
age O
, O
gender O
and O
handedness O
; O
whole-brain O
topological O
false O
discovery O
rate-corrected O
α=0.05 O
; O
extent O
threshold=6 O
, O
that O
is O
, O
> O
300 O
mm3 O
) O
. O

We O

sample O
of O
244 O
Caucasian O

as O

The O
effect O
of O
the O
PCI O
on O

was O
tested O
using O
robust O
linear O
models O
with O

, O

We O

using O
as O

the O

( O

We O

, O
that O
is O
, O

of O

, O
and O

times O
with O

: O

( O

Pharmacogenetics O
The O
first O
clinical O
cohort O
in O
the O
pharmacogenetic O
study O
included O
47 O
Caucasian O
patients O
with O
SCZ O
( O
Structured O
Clinical O
Interview O
for O
DSM O
( O
SCID O
) O
diagnosis O
) O
recruited O
from O
the O
region O
of O
Apulia O
, O
Italy O
( O
Table O
1 O
) O
. O

Treatment O
response O
was O
computed O
as O
the O
difference O
in O
the O
total O
Positive O
And O
Negative O
Syndrome O
Scale O
( O
PANSS O
) O
core O
between O
baseline O
and O
treatment O
end O
. O

The O
second O
cohort O
consisted O
of O
40 O
patients O
with O
SCZ O
with O
history O
of O
inadequate O
treatment O
response O
recruited O
at O
the O
Clinical O
Brain O
Disorders O
Branch O
SCZ O
inpatient O
research O
unit O
at O
the O
National O
Institutes O
of O
Health O
Clinical O
Center O
, O
Bethesda O
, O
MD O
, O
USA O
. O

Treatment O
response O
was O
defined O
as O
the O
difference O
between O
symptoms O
severity O
at O
the O
end O
of O
placebo O
treatment O
and O
severity O
at O
the O
end O
of O
drug O
treatment O
. O

The O
clinical O
protocols O
used O
in O
the O
pharmacogenetic O
study O
for O
both O
samples O
have O
been O
described O
in O
detail O
previously O
( O
see O
Supplementary O
Table O
2 O
for O
clinical O
data O
) O
. O

We O
first O
performed O
an O
association O
study O
to O
investigate O
the O
direction O
of O
the O
PCI O
treatment O
response O
relationship O
using O
Spearman O
’ O
s O
Rho O
; O
then O
, O
we O
assessed O
the O
potency O
of O
the O
PCI O
as O
predictor O
of O
treatment O
response O
in O
comparison O
with O
pharmacological O
doses O
and O
off-medication O
symptom O
severity O
using O
Receiver O
Operating O
Characteristic O
curves O
( O
SI O
Materials O
and O
Methods O
) O
. O

Brain O
connectivity O
changes O
occurring O
following O
cognitive O
behavioural O
therapy O
for O
psychosis O
predict O
long-term O
recovery O
Little O
is O
known O
about O
the O
psychobiological O
mechanisms O
of O
cognitive O
behavioural O
therapy O
for O
psychosis O
( O
CBTp O
) O
and O
which O
specific O
processes O
are O
key O
in O
predicting O
favourable O
long-term O
outcomes O
. O

Following O
theoretical O
models O
of O
psychosis O
, O
this O
proof-of-concept O
study O
investigated O
whether O
the O
long-term O
recovery O
path O
of O
CBTp O
completers O
can O
be O
predicted O
by O
the O
neural O
changes O
in O
threat-based O
social O
affective O
processing O
that O
occur O
during O
CBTp O
. O

We O
followed O
up O
22 O
participants O
who O
had O
undergone O
a O
social O
affective O
processing O
task O
during O
functional O
magnetic O
resonance O
imaging O
along O
with O
self-report O
and O
clinician-administered O
symptom O
measures O
, O
before O
and O
after O
receiving O
CBTp O
. O

Monthly O
ratings O
of O
psychotic O
and O
affective O
symptoms O
were O
obtained O
retrospectively O
across O
8 O
years O
since O
receiving O
CBTp O
, O
plus O
self-reported O
recovery O
at O
final O
follow-up O
. O

We O
investigated O
whether O
these O
long-term O
outcomes O
were O
predicted O
by O
CBTp-led O
changes O
in O
functional O
connections O
with O
dorsal O
prefrontal O
cortical O
and O
amygdala O
during O
the O
processing O
of O
threatening O
and O
prosocial O
facial O
affect O
. O

Although O
long-term O
psychotic O
symptoms O
were O
predicted O
by O
changes O
in O
prefrontal O
connections O
during O
prosocial O
facial O
affective O
processing O
, O
long-term O
affective O
symptoms O
were O
predicted O
by O
threat-related O
amygdalo-inferior O
parietal O
lobule O
connectivity O
. O

Greater O
increases O
in O
dorsolateral O
prefrontal O
cortex O
connectivity O
with O
amygdala O
following O
CBTp O
also O
predicted O
higher O
subjective O
ratings O
of O
recovery O
at O
long-term O
follow-up O
. O

These O
findings O
show O
that O
reorganisation O
occurring O
at O
the O
neural O
level O
following O
psychological O
therapy O
can O
predict O
the O
subsequent O
recovery O
path O
of O
people O
with O
psychosis O
across O
8 O
years O
. O

This O
novel O
methodology O
shows O
promise O
for O
further O
studies O
with O
larger O
sample O
size O
, O
which O
are O
needed O
to O
better O
examine O
the O
sensitivity O
of O
psychobiological O
processes O
, O
in O
comparison O
to O
existing O
clinical O
measures O
, O
in O
predicting O
long-term O
outcomes O
. O

Materials O
and O
Methods O
Participants O
and O
design O
Participants O
were O
22 O
outpatients O
with O
a O
confirmed O
diagnosis O
of O
paranoid O
schizophrenia O
( O
final O
N=15 O
; O
see O
Table O
1 O
) O
who O
had O
taken O
part O
in O
our O
earlier O
studies O
. O

These O
participants O
had O
completed O
an O
fMRI O
implicit O
facial O
affective O
processing O
task O
and O
a O
battery O
of O
clinical O
measures O
on O
two O
occasions O
, O
pre O
( O
T1 O
) O
and O
post O
( O
T2 O
) O
receiving O
6 O
months O
of O
CBTp O
. O

Sixteen O
outpatients O
receiving O
treatment-as-usual O
were O
also O
scanned O
at O
these O
time O
points O
( O
data O
not O
analysed O
as O
part O
of O
the O
present O
study O
) O
. O

Procedure O
We O
retrospectively O
followed O
up O
these O
participants O
as O
their O
final O
fMRI O
scan O
( O
at O
T2 O
) O
, O
an O
average O
of O
8 O
years O
( O
range O
7–9 O
years O
) O
before O
the O
current O
study O
( O
T3 O
) O
. O

We O
obtained O
objective O
clinical O
outcomes O
for O
this O
entire O
period O
through O
case O
note O
review O
( O
T2 O
to O
T3 O
; O
see O
Longitudinal O
Clinician O
Ratings O
) O
as O
well O
as O
current O
subjective O
ratings O
of O
recovery O
and O
well-being O
( O
at O
T3 O
; O
see O
Outcome O
Measures O
) O
. O

Consent O
was O
obtained O
by O
seeking O
current O
contact O
details O
from O
consultant O
clinicians O
in O
the O
services O
providing O
care O
for O
the O
previously O
recruited O
participants O
. O

Participants O
were O
then O
contacted O
by O
phone O
and O
those O
expressing O
an O
interest O
received O
information O
about O
the O
study O
, O
a O
consent O
form O
for O
accessing O
their O
electronic O
clinic O
records O
, O
self-report O
questionnaires O
assessing O
well-being O
and O
recovery O
and O
a O
prepaid O
envelope O
. O

The O
final O
sample O
of O
participants O
who O
consented O
and O
returned O
the O
questionnaires O
were O
reimbursed O
£10 O
for O
their O
time O
. O

Ethical O
approval O
was O
granted O
by O
the O
National O
Health O
Service O
research O
ethics O
committee O
( O
reference O
: O
14/LO/0325 O
) O
. O

Functional O
neuroimaging O
procedure O
As O
described O
in O
earlier O
reports O
, O
participants O
were O
presented O
with O
monochrome O
faces O
depicting O
fear O
, O
anger O
, O
happiness O
or O
neutral O
expressions O
, O
and O
had O
to O
indicate O
the O
sex O
of O
the O
face O
with O
a O
button O
press O
response O
. O

These O
were O
repeated O
in O
four O
blocks O
per O
condition O
, O
with O
counterbalancing O
across O
16 O
blocks O
( O
see O
Mason O
et O
al O
. O

and O
Supplementary O
Material O
for O
further O
details O
of O
the O
scanning O
protocol O
) O
. O

Changes O
in O
functional O
connectivity O
from O
T1 O
to O
T2 O
were O
quantified O
during O
social O
threat O
( O
angry O
faces O
) O
and O
prosocial O
social O
affect O
( O
happy O
faces O
) O
using O
the O
psychophysiological O
interaction O
approach O
. O

Seeds O
were O
left O
amygdala O
and O
right O
DLPFC O
; O
whereas O
bilateral O
activation O
was O
found O
, O
we O
selected O
the O
regions O
of O
maximum O
task O
activation O
that O
were O
reported O
previously O
. O

Seeds O
were O
defined O
functionally O
from O
the O
group-level O
maxima O
, O
with O
spheres O
around O
these O
maxima O
( O
3 O
and O
4 O
mm O
radius O
for O
amygdala O
and O
DLPFC O
, O
respectively O
) O
. O

These O
were O
additionally O
constrained O
within O
anatomical O
masks O
for O
these O
regions O
as O
defined O
by O
the O
PickAtlas O
toolbox O
. O

Significant O
connectivity O
changes O
following O
CBTp O
were O
tested O
by O
examining O
the O
interaction O
of O
group O
( O
CBTp O
vs O
treatment-as-usual O
) O
by O
time O
( O
T1 O
vs O
T2 O
) O
. O

There O
were O
exclusively O
increases O
in O
connectivity O
in O
the O
CBTp O
group O
across O
functional O
connections O
with O
amygdala O
and O
DLPFC O
. O

For O
the O
present O
study O
, O
we O
focused O
our O
analyses O
on O
the O
change O
in O
DLPFC-amygdala O
connectivity O
that O
occurred O
during O
social O
threat O
processing O
, O
because O
of O
the O
strong O
theoretical O
link O
with O
cognitive O
regulation O
of O
affect O
and O
in O
turn O
the O
relevance O
to O
cognitive O
behavioural O
models O
of O
positive O
symptoms O
of O
psychosis O
. O

We O
also O
included O
the O
two O
connectivity O
changes O
that O
previously O
correlated O
with O
improvement O
in O
positive O
psychotic O
symptoms O
: O
amygdala-IPL O
and O
DLPFC-postcentral O
gyrus O
, O
which O
had O
occurred O
for O
the O
processing O
of O
threat O
and O
prosocial O
facial O
affect O
, O
respectively O
. O

Cross-sectional O
clinical O
measures O
The O
following O
clinician-administered O
and O
self-report O
measures O
had O
previously O
been O
administered O
pre- O
and O
post- O
CBTp O
( O
T1 O
and O
T2 O
) O
. O

The O
Positive O
and O
Negative O
Syndrome O
Schedule O
( O
PANSS O
) O
; O
is O
a O
clinician-administered O
rating O
of O
positive O
, O
negative O
and O
general O
psychopathology O
symptoms O
. O

Affective O
symptoms O
were O
measured O
from O
the O
Beck O
Depression O
Inventory O
, O
second O
edition O
. O

We O
acquired O
additional O
measures O
at O
long-term O
follow-up O
( O
T3 O
) O
. O

We O
assessed O
subjective O
recovery O
using O
the O
Questionnaire O
about O
the O
Process O
of O
Recovery O
( O
QPR O
, O
) O
, O
a O
service-user O
led O
instrument O
that O
follows O
theoretical O
models O
of O
recovery O
and O
provides O
a O
measure O
of O
constructs O
such O
as O
hope O
, O
empowerment O
, O
confidence O
, O
connectedness O
to O
others O
. O

This O
was O
our O
primary O
measure O
as O
it O
has O
one O
of O
the O
best O
psychometric O
properties O
of O
recovery O
measures O
and O
can O
be O
expected O
to O
be O
relatively O
robust O
to O
fluctuations O
in O
clinical O
state O
, O
making O
it O
well O
suited O
to O
use O
a O
cross-sectional O
measurement O
of O
long-term O
outcome O
. O

Additional O
measures O
for O
well-being O
, O
satisfaction O
and O
functioning O
were O
acquired O
( O
Supplementary O
Materials O
) O
but O
were O
not O
included O
in O
analyses O
because O
of O
missing O
observations O
, O
a O
high O
correlation O
with O
self-reported O
recovery O
and O
to O
reduce O
the O
number O
of O
analyses O
reported O
. O

These O
data O
are O
available O
on O
request O
from O
the O
first O
author O
. O

Longitudinal O
clinician O
ratings O
of O
symptoms O
: O
We O
retrospectively O
determined O
symptoms O
and O
functioning O
from O
electronic O
case O
note O
data O
held O
by O
local O
National O
Health O
Service O
trusts O
in O
South O
London O
. O

This O
covered O
the O
entire O
period O
between O
participants O
’ O
final O
fMRI O
measurements O
( O
T2 O
; O
circa O
2007 O
) O
and O
January O
2015 O
( O
T3 O
) O
. O

Two O
raters O
followed O
validated O
operationalised O
criteria O
to O
infer O
presence O
of O
positive O
psychotic O
symptoms O
for O
each O
month O
independently O
, O
based O
on O
clinical O
note O
entries O
made O
by O
mental O
health O
professionals O
. O

Participants O
were O
rated O
as O
being O
in O
‘ O
full O
remission O
’ O
( O
no O
symptoms O
present O
) O
, O
‘ O
partial O
remission O
’ O
( O
symptoms O
of O
low O
intensity O
or O
frequency O
with O
clinicians O
noting O
at O
least O
partial O
insight O
) O
, O
or O
‘ O
no O
remission O
’ O
( O
moderate O
symptoms O
; O
see O
Bebbington O
et O
al O
. O

for O
fully O
detailed O
criteria O
) O
. O

Ratings O
of O
affective O
symptoms O
were O
based O
on O
both O
the O
intensity O
and O
frequency O
of O
affective O
disturbance O
as O
follows O
. O

Affective O
symptoms O
were O
rated O
as O
‘ O
low O
’ O
when O
there O
was O
no O
indication O
of O
distress O
or O
only O
brief O
periods O
( O
< O
3 O
days O
, O
maximum O
of O
two O
separate O
instances O
for O
that O
month O
) O
of O
mild-to-moderate O
severity O
( O
without O
expression O
of O
suicidality O
and O
that O
did O
not O
require O
intervention O
by O
mental O
health O
professionals O
) O
. O

‘ O
Moderate O
’ O
affective O
symptoms O
was O
rated O
where O
there O
was O
any O
period O
of O
distress O
lasting O
more O
than O
3 O
days O
, O
where O
there O
was O
expression O
of O
suicidality O
not O
requiring O
severe O
management O
, O
or O
where O
there O
were O
three O
or O
more O
instances O
of O
‘ O
low O
’ O
affective O
symptoms O
present O
for O
that O
month O
. O

‘ O
Severe O
’ O
was O
rated O
for O
any O
month O
in O
which O
there O
was O
severe O
distress O
and O
suicidality O
requiring O
severe O
management O
, O
including O
hospitalisation O
or O
home O
treatment O
care O
. O

This O
method O
was O
shown O
to O
have O
high O
reliability O
and O
clinical O
validity O
, O
with O
strong O
associations O
between O
the O
ratings O
of O
symptoms O
made O
by O
case O
note O
ratings O
and O
PANSS O
in O
the O
same O
participants O
. O

We O
confirmed O
that O
reliability O
was O
also O
high O
for O
ratings O
made O
in O
the O
present O
study O
, O
with O
inter-rater O
agreement O
ranging O
from O
‘ O
moderate O
’ O
to O
‘ O
almost O
perfect O
’ O
( O
Supplementary O
Materials O
) O
. O

In O
addition O
to O
these O
symptom O
ratings O
, O
we O
also O
rated O
level O
of O
care O
needed O
( O
categories O
: O
care O
of O
general O
practitioner O
only O
; O
outpatient O
appointments O
in O
secondary O
care O
; O
daily O
home O
treatment O
; O
hospital O
treatment O
) O
and O
occupational O
functioning O
( O
paid O
employment O
; O
voluntary O
work O
or O
training O
course O
; O
unemployed O
) O
, O
as O
a O
mean O
of O
validating O
the O
clinical O
ratings O
( O
Supplementary O
Table O
1 O
) O
. O

There O
were O
significant O
positive O
associations O
between O
the O
non-remission O
measure O
and O
amount O
of O
severe O
care O
( O
hospitalisation O
and O
home O
treatment O
; O
see O
Supplementary O
Table O
2 O
) O
. O

Data O
analysis O
Prediction O
of O
long-term O
outcomes O
from O
functional O
connectivity O
changes O
Multivariate O
analysis O
of O
variance O
( O
MANOVA O
, O
Wilk O
’ O
s O
Lambda O
) O
was O
used O
to O
relate O
the O
longitudinal O
, O
month-by-month O
clinician O
ratings O
of O
psychotic O
and O
affective O
symptoms O
( O
T2 O
to O
T3 O
) O
as O
well O
as O
subjective O
recovery O
( O
T3 O
) O
, O
to O
the O
functional O
connectivity O
changes O
( O
T1 O
to O
T2 O
) O
as O
follows O
. O

All O
tests O
were O
performed O
one-tailed O
. O

Percentage O
of O
months O
spent O
in O
each O
of O
the O
three O
symptom O
states O
was O
computed O
for O
positive O
psychotic O
symptoms O
( O
full O
, O
partial O
or O
non-remission O
) O
and O
for O
affective O
symptoms O
( O
low O
, O
moderate O
or O
severe O
) O
. O

To O
simplify O
the O
analyses O
and O
to O
reduce O
model O
over-fitting O
, O
we O
computed O
a O
single O
residualised O
variable O
for O
each O
symptom O
domain O
( O
see O
Supplementary O
Materials O
for O
details O
) O
. O

The O
effect O
of O
psychotic O
and O
affective O
symptom O
domains O
was O
tested O
separately O
, O
by O
entering O
the O
respective O
symptom O
variable O
as O
a O
regressor O
within O
MANOVA O
, O
along O
with O
our O
hypothesised O
changes O
in O
connectivity O
as O
dependent O
variables O
. O

Bonferroni O
correction O
was O
applied O
for O
multiple O
tests O
( O
p/2 O
) O
across O
the O
two O
symptom O
domains O
and O
significant O
effects O
were O
followed O
up O
using O
correlation O
tests O
( O
Spearman O
; O
rρ O
) O
to O
clarify O
the O
direction O
of O
associations O
. O

We O
also O
performed O
an O
exploratory O
analysis O
to O
address O
the O
hypothesis O
that O
the O
therapeutic O
effects O
of O
CBTp O
would O
be O
better O
captured O
by O
changes O
to O
core O
threat O
processes O
than O
by O
short-term O
symptom O
reduction O
. O

Because O
of O
the O
exploratory O
nature O
, O
this O
analysis O
is O
reported O
as O
Supplementary O
Material O
. O

Finally O
, O
we O
separately O
tested O
the O
relationship O
between O
the O
functional O
connectivity O
changes O
and O
long-term O
subjective O
recovery O
, O
the O
total O
score O
of O
which O
was O
entered O
as O
a O
regressor O
into O
MANOVA O
with O
the O
functional O
connectivity O
changes O
as O
dependent O
variables O
. O

Functional O
neuroimaging O
effects O
of O
recently O
discovered O
genetic O
risk O
loci O
for O
schizophrenia O
and O
polygenic O
risk O
profile O
in O
five O
RDoC O
subdomains O
Recently O
, O
125 O
loci O
with O
genome-wide O
support O
for O
association O
with O
schizophrenia O
were O
identified O
. O

We O
investigated O
the O
impact O
of O
these O
variants O
and O
their O
accumulated O
genetic O
risk O
on O
brain O
activation O
in O
five O
neurocognitive O
domains O
of O
the O
Research O
Domain O
Criteria O
( O
working O
memory O
, O
reward O
processing O
, O
episodic O
memory O
, O
social O
cognition O
and O
emotion O
processing O
) O
. O

In O
578 O
healthy O
subjects O
we O
tested O
for O
association O
( O
i O
) O
of O
a O
polygenic O
risk O
profile O
score O
( O
RPS O
) O
including O
all O
single-nucleotide O
polymorphisms O
( O
SNPs O
) O
reaching O
genome-wide O
significance O
in O
the O
recent O
genome-wide O
association O
studies O
( O
GWAS O
) O
meta-analysis O
and O
( O
ii O
) O
of O
all O
independent O
genome-wide O
significant O
loci O
separately O
that O
showed O
sufficient O
distribution O
of O
all O
allelic O
groups O
in O
our O
sample O
( O
105 O
SNPs O
) O
. O

The O
RPS O
was O
nominally O
associated O
with O
perigenual O
anterior O
cingulate O
and O
posterior O
cingulate/precuneus O
activation O
during O
episodic O
memory O
( O
PFWE O
( O
ROI O
) O
=0.047 O
) O
and O
social O
cognition O
( O
PFWE O
( O
ROI O
) O
=0.025 O
) O
, O
respectively O
. O

Single O
SNP O
analyses O
revealed O
that O
rs9607782 O
, O
located O
near O
EP300 O
, O
was O
significantly O
associated O
with O
amygdala O
recruitment O
during O
emotion O
processing O
( O
PFWE O
( O
ROI O
) O
=1.63 O
× O
10−4 O
, O
surpassing O
Bonferroni O
correction O
for O
the O
number O
of O
SNPs O
) O
. O

Importantly O
, O
this O
association O
was O
replicable O
in O
an O
independent O
sample O
( O
N=150 O
; O
PFWE O
( O
ROI O
) O
< O
0.025 O
) O
. O

Other O
SNP O
effects O
previously O
associated O
with O
imaging O
phenotypes O
were O
nominally O
significant O
, O
but O
did O
not O
withstand O
correction O
for O
the O
number O
of O
SNPs O
tested O
. O

To O
assess O
whether O
there O
was O
true O
signal O
within O
our O
data O
, O
we O
repeated O
single O
SNP O
analyses O
with O
105 O
randomly O
chosen O
non-schizophrenia-associated O
variants O
, O
observing O
fewer O
significant O
results O
and O
lower O
association O
probabilities O
. O

Applying O
stringent O
methodological O
procedures O
, O
we O
found O
preliminary O
evidence O
for O
the O
notion O
that O
genetic O
risk O
for O
schizophrenia O
conferred O
by O
rs9607782 O
may O
be O
mediated O
by O
amygdala O
function O
. O

We O
critically O
evaluate O
the O
potential O
caveats O
of O
the O
methodological O
approaches O
employed O
and O
offer O
suggestions O
for O
future O
studies O
. O

Materials O
and O
methods O
Subjects O
A O
total O
of O
578 O
German O
volunteers O
who O
never O
suffered O
from O
psychiatric O
disorder O
( O
evidenced O
by O
SCID-I O
) O
were O
recruited O
at O
Mannheim O
, O
Berlin O
and O
Bonn O
as O
part O
of O
an O
ongoing O
study O
on O
neurogenetic O
mechanisms O
of O
unipolar O
depression O
, O
bipolar O
disorder O
and O
schizophrenia O
( O
http O
: O
//www.ngfn.de/en/ O
schizophrenie.html O
; O
http O
: O
//www.sys-med.de/en/consortia/integrament/ O
) O
. O

N=333 O
participants O
had O
no O
lifetime O
family O
history O
of O
schizophrenia O
or O
an O
affective O
disorder O
, O
and O
n=245 O
subjects O
had O
at O
least O
one O
first-degree O
relative O
affected O
by O
schizophrenia O
( O
n=72 O
) O
, O
bipolar O
disorder O
( O
n=71 O
) O
or O
depression O
( O
n=102 O
) O
. O

Affected O
index O
patients O
did O
not O
suffer O
from O
any O
other O
psychotic O
or O
affective O
disorder O
, O
and O
the O
investigated O
relatives O
had O
no O
family O
history O
of O
multiple O
different O
psychiatric O
diagnoses O
( O
for O
example O
, O
cases O
of O
both O
, O
affective O
and O
psychotic O
disorders O
) O
. O

All O
subjects O
had O
grandparents O
of O
European O
origin O
. O

Following O
application O
of O
exclusion O
criteria O
n=472–509 O
subjects O
were O
included O
in O
the O
analyses O
of O
the O
respective O
tasks O
( O
see O
Supplementary O
Material O
for O
details O
) O
. O

N=150 O
controls O
recruited O
as O
part O
of O
a O
study O
on O
the O
neurogenetic O
mechanisms O
of O
alcohol O
dependence O
in O
Berlin O
and O
Bonn O
( O
http O
: O
//www.ngfn.de/en/alkoholabh__ngigkeit.html O
) O
served O
as O
replication O
sample O
. O

All O
participants O
never O
suffered O
from O
psychiatric O
disorder O
according O
to O
the O
Structured O
Clinical O
Interview O
of O
the O
Diagnostic O
and O
Statistical O
Manual O
of O
Mental O
Disorders O
( O
DSM-IV O
) O
Axis-I O
Disorders O
( O

) O
. O

Demographic O
characteristics O
of O

by O

of O

of O

, O

DNA O
extraction O
and O
genotyping O
Ethylenediaminetetraacetic O
acid O
anticoagulated O
venous O
blood O
samples O
were O
collected O
from O
all O
individuals O
. O

Lymphocyte O
DNA O
was O
isolated O
using O
the O
Chemagic O
Magnetic O
Separation O
Module O
I O
( O
Chemagen O
, O
Baesweiler O
, O
Germany O
) O
according O
to O
the O
manufacturer O
’ O
s O
recommendations O
. O

A O
genome-wide O
data O
set O
was O
generated O
at O
the O
Department O
of O
Genomics O
, O
Life O
& O
Brain O
Center O
, O
University O
of O
Bonn O
using O

Human610Quad O
, O

and O
Infinium O
PsychArray-24 O
BeadChips O
( O

, O
San O

, O
CA O
, O
USA O
) O
. O

and O

parameters O
used O
by O
the O
Psychiatric O
Genetics O
Consortium O
( O
PGC O
) O
Statistical O
Analyses O
Group O
and O

were O

. O

( O

Functional O
imaging O
tasks O
During O
functional O
magnetic O
resonance O
imaging O
( O
fMRI O
) O
subjects O
completed O
an O
associative O
episodic O
memory O
( O
EM O
) O
task O
requiring O
encoding O
, O
recall O
and O
recognition O
of O
face-profession O
pairs O
. O

The O
WM O
n-back O
task O
required O
continuous O
updating O
and O
retrieval O
of O
elements O
held O
in O
short-time O
memory O
. O

The O
RP O
monetary O
incentive O
delay O
task O
allowed O
the O
study O
of O
anticipation O
of O
monetary O
gains O
or O
losses O
. O

The O
Theory O
of O
Mind O
( O
ToM O
) O
task O
consisted O
of O
cartoon O
stories O
requiring O
subjects O
to O
take O
the O
protagonist O
’ O
s O
perspective O
and O
judge O
changes O
in O
his/her O
affective O
states O
. O

The O
face-matching O
task O
( O
FMT O
) O
operationalized O
subjects O
’ O
implicit O
processing O
of O
negative O
emotions O
while O
viewing O
faces O
showing O
either O
fearful O
or O
angry O
expressions O
( O
for O
detailed O
descriptions O
see O
refs O
and O
Supplementary O
Material O
) O
. O

All O
tasks O
were O
previously O
shown O
to O
robustly O
activate O
target O
structures O
and O
to O
possess O
excellent O
test–retest O
reliability O
in O
between-group O
designs O
. O

Imaging O
parameters O
Blood-oxygen-level O
dependent O
fMRI O
was O
performed O
on O
three O
Siemens O
Trio O
3 O
T O
MR-Tomographs O
at O
the O
Life O
and O
Brain O
Center O
of O
the O
University O
of O
Bonn O
, O
the O
Central O
Institute O
of O
Mental O
Health O
Mannheim O
, O
and O
the O
Charité-Universitätsmedizin O
Berlin O
. O

At O
all O
sites O
, O
identical O
sequences O
and O
scanner O
protocols O
were O
employed O
( O
EM O
: O
33 O
slices O
, O
axially O
tilted O
( O
−30° O
) O
, O
slice O
thickness O
2.4 O
mm+0.6 O
mm O
gap O
, O
field O
of O
view O
( O
FOV O
) O
192 O
mm O
, O
repetition O
time O
( O
TR O
) O
1.96 O
s O
, O
echo O
time O
( O
TE O
) O
30 O
ms O
, O
flip O
angle O
80° O
, O
all O
other O
fMRI O
tasks O
: O
28 O
slices O
, O
slice O
thickness O
4 O
mm+1 O
mm O
gap O
, O
FOV O
192 O
mm O
, O
TR O
2 O
s O
, O
TE O
30 O
ms O
, O
flip O
angle O
80° O
) O
. O

Quality-control O
measurements O
were O
conducted O
at O
all O
sites O
on O
every O
day O
of O
data O
collection O
according O
to O
a O
multicenter O
quality-assurance O
protocol O
, O
revealing O
stable O
parameters O
over O
time O
. O

To O
account O
for O
any O
variance O
related O
to O
differences O
across O
sites O
, O
the O
site O
was O
used O
as O
a O
covariate O
for O
all O
statistical O
analyses O
. O

Functional O
image O
processing O
Image O
processing O
and O
statistical O
analyses O
were O
conducted O
using O
statistical O
parametric O
mapping O
methods O
as O
implemented O
in O
SPM8 O
( O
http O
: O
//www.fil.ion.ucl.ac.uk/spm/software/spm8/ O
) O
. O

Scans O
were O
subjected O
to O
a O
strict O
quality O
assessment O
before O
inclusion O
into O
further O
analyses O
. O

Following O
data-quality O
assessment O
and O
application O
of O
general O
exclusion O
criteria O
( O
see O
above O
) O
n=472–509 O
subjects O
were O
included O
in O
the O
respective O
analyses O
( O
see O
Supplementary O
Figure O
1 O
and O
Supplementary O
Methods O
for O
details O
) O
. O

During O
pre-processing O
, O
images O
were O
realigned O
to O
a O
mean O
image O
( O
movement O
parameters O
confined O
to O
< O
3 O
mm O
translation O
and O
< O
1.7° O
rotation O
between O
volumes O
) O
, O
slice-time-corrected O
, O
spatially O
normalized O
to O
a O
standard O
stereotactic O
space O
( O
a O
brain O
template O
created O
by O
the O
Montreal O
Neurological O
Institute O
) O
with O
a O
voxel O
size O
of O
3 O
× O
3 O
× O
3 O
mm O
and O
smoothed O
with O
a O
9 O
mm O
full O
width O
at O
half O
maximum O
Gaussian O
filter O
. O

A O
first-level O
fixed-effects O
model O
was O
computed O
for O
each O
participant O
and O
task O
. O

Regressors O
were O
created O
from O
the O
time O
course O
of O
the O
experimental O
conditions O
of O
interest O
per O
task O
and O
convolved O
with O
a O
canonical O
hemodynamic O
response O
function O
. O

Movement O
parameters O
, O
and O
for O
the O
ToM O
task O
also O
instructions O
and O
button O
presses O
, O
were O
included O
in O
the O
first-level O
models O
as O
covariates O
of O
no O
interest O
. O

For O
each O
subject O
, O
individual O
contrast O
images O
of O
the O
task O
effect O
( O
WM O
: O
2-back O
> O
0-back O
; O
EM O
: O
memory O
> O
control O
; O
RP O
: O
anticipation O
of O
monetary O
win/loss O
> O
anticipation O
of O
neutral O
outcomes O
; O
ToM O
: O
mentalizing O
> O
control O
; O
FMT O
: O
faces O
> O
shapes O
) O
were O
subsequently O
entered O
into O
group O
statistics O
. O

Statistical O
group O
analyses O
RPS O
: O
To O
test O
for O
genetic O
association O
with O
the O
intermediate O
phenotypes O
, O
the O
respective O
individual O
contrast O
images O
were O
analyzed O
using O
second-level O
multiple O
regression O
models O
for O
each O
task O
, O
including O
the O
RPS O
as O
regressor O
of O
interest O
, O
and O
age O
, O
sex O
, O
site O
, O
subgroup O
( O
no O
familial O
liability O
for O
psychiatric O
disorders O
, O
affected O
first-degree O
relative O
of O
patients O
with O
schizophrenia O
, O
bipolar O
disorder O
or O
depression O
) O
, O
chip O
used O
for O
genotyping O
and O
the O
first O
three O
principal O
components O
( O
derived O
from O
a O
statistically O
independent O
set O
of O
common O
SNPs O
representing O
potential O
population O
stratification O
) O
as O
nuisance O
covariates O
. O

Effects O
of O
RPS O
on O
predefined O
regions O
of O
interest O
( O
ROIs O
) O
were O
assessed O
determining O
the O
familywise O
error O
( O
FWE O
) O
-corrected O
significance O
values O
of O
the O
maximally O
activated O
voxel O
within O
each O
ROI O
using O
undirected O
tests O
. O

For O
the O
WM O
, O
EM O
and O
FMT O
tasks O
, O
ROIs O
were O
defined O
a O
priori O
using O
anatomical O
labels O
provided O
by O
the O
Wake O
Forest O
University O
Pick O
Atlas O
( O
www.fmri.wfubmc.edu/downloads O
) O
. O

These O
were O
the O
bilateral O
dorsolateral O
prefrontal O
cortex O
( O
BA46 O
and O
BA9 O
with O
subtraction O
of O
medial O
voxels O
of O
BA9 O
, O
see O
Esslinger O
et O
al O
. O

for O
details O
) O
for O
the O
WM O
task O
, O
the O
left O
and O
right O
hippocampus O
and O
perigenual O
anterior O
cingulate O
cortex O
( O
pgACC O
) O
for O
EM O
tasks O
and O
the O
bilateral O
amygdala O
, O
as O
well O
as O
the O
pgACC O
for O
the O
FMT O
( O
Supplementary O
Figure O
S2 O
) O
. O

As O
the O
AAL O
atlas O
does O
not O
provide O
anatomical O
labels O
for O
the O
ventral O
striatum O
, O
a O
spherical O
ROI O
was O
created O
for O
the O
RP O
task O
using O
a O
voxel O
located O
in O
the O
center O
of O
the O
ventral O
striatum O
( O
x=±9 O
, O
y=11 O
, O
z=−8 O
) O
surrounded O
by O
a O
sphere O
of O
10 O
mm O
. O

For O
the O
ToM O
task O
, O
four O
functional O
ROIs O
were O
created O
for O
those O
regions O
previously O
shown O
to O
be O
aberrantly O
activated O
in O
patients O
with O
schizophrenia O
( O
for O
example O
, O
Sugranyes O
et O
al O
. O

; O
Walter O
et O
al O
. O
) O

and O
to O
be O
genetically O
modulated O
. O

As O
these O
regions O
were O
not O
covered O
by O
specific O
AAL O
ROIs O
, O
masks O
for O
the O
medial O
prefrontal O
cortex O
, O
bilateral O
temporal O
parietal O
junction O
( O
TPJ O
) O
and O
posterior O
cingulate O
cortex/precuneus O
( O
PCC/Pcu O
) O
were O
created O
based O
on O
coordinates O
reported O
by O
a O
meta-analysis O
on O
brain O
areas O
involved O
in O
ToM O
using O
the O
toolbox O
TWURoi O
( O
see O
Supplementary O
Material O
for O
details O
) O
. O

Single O
SNP O
fMRI O
analyses O
Comparable O
to O
RPS O
analyses O
, O
second-level O
multiple O
regression O
models O
were O
computed O
for O
each O
SNP O
and O
each O
task O
with O
number O
of O
minor O
alleles O
as O
regressor O
of O
interest O
, O
and O
age O
, O
sex O
, O
site O
, O
subgroup O
, O
genotyping O
chip O
and O
the O
first O
three O
principal O
components O
of O
potential O
population O
stratification O
as O
nuisance O
covariates O
. O

We O
excluded O
SNPs O
with O
less O
than O
10 O
subjects O
in O
one O
allelic O
group O
, O
resulting O
in O
105 O
independent O
analyses O
. O

Similar O
to O
RPS O
analyses O
, O
we O
extracted O
FWE-corrected O
P-values O
of O
the O
maximally O
activated O
voxel O
within O
each O
ROI O
for O
each O
SNP O
from O
an O
undirected O
test O
. O

These O
significance O
values O
were O
then O
Bonferroni-corrected O
for O
the O
number O
of O
autosomal O
SNPs O
tested O
, O
that O
is O
, O
105 O
( O
P O
< O
4.76 O
× O
10−4 O
) O
. O

We O
used O
an O
undirected O
F-test O
in O
all O
analyses O
, O
as O
, O
for O
the O
investigated O
RPS O
and O
the O
vast O
majority O
of O
SNPs O
, O
we O
had O
no O
hypotheses O
about O
the O
directionality O
of O
effects O
. O

Associations O
with O
the O
intermediate O
phenotype O
could O
be O
represented O
by O
reduced O
or O
increased O
activation O
, O
being O
either O
indicative O
of O
dysfunction O
, O
inefficiency O
or O
compensatory O
resilience O
mechanisms O
. O

Auditory O
verbal O
hallucinations O
related O
to O
altered O
long-range O
synchrony O
of O
gamma-band O
oscillations O
Our O
understanding O
of O
the O
neural O
correlates O
of O
auditory-verbal-hallucinations O
( O
AVH O
) O
has O
substantially O
increased O
during O
the O
last O
few O
years O
, O
but O
is O
far O
from O
sufficient O
. O

One O
current O
hypothesis O
, O
the O
interhemispheric O
miscommunication O
theory O
, O
is O
based O
on O
findings O
from O
fMRI O
, O
DTI O
and O
EEG O
, O
but O
there O
is O
only O
limited O
evidence O
so O
far O
concerning O
underlying O
functional O
coupling O
mechanisms O
. O

Here O
we O
report O
a O
64-channel O
EEG O
study O
using O
lagged O
phase O
synchronization O
analysis O
and O
eLORETA O
source O
estimation O
to O
examine O
the O
functional O
connectivity O
between O
bilateral O
auditory O
cortices O
in O
the O
gamma-band O
in O
26 O
schizophrenia O
patients O
( O
13 O
with O
and O
13 O
without O
AVH O
) O
and O
26 O
matched O
healthy O
controls O
( O
HC O
) O
while O
performing O
a O
dichotic O
listening O
task O
. O

We O
found O
a O
significantly O
reduced O
right-ear-advantage O
( O
REA O
) O
in O
AVH O
but O
not O
in O
non-AVH O
patients O
compared O
to O
HC O
. O

The O
major O
finding O
was O
significantly O
stronger O
gamma-band O
connectivity O
between O
bilateral O
auditory O
cortices O
during O
conscious O
perception O
of O
left O
( O
versus O
right O
) O
ear O
syllables O
in O
patients O
with O
AVH O
compared O
to O
HC O
and O
patients O
without O
AVH O
. O

A O
significant O
positive O
correlation O
was O
found O
between O
this O
connectivity O
alteration O
and O
the O
AVH O
symptom O
score O
in O
schizophrenia O
patients O
. O

These O
findings O
provide O
further O
support O
for O
the O
interhemispheric O
miscommunication O
hypothesis O
of O
AVH O
pathophysiology O
by O
indicating O
that O
aberrant O
gamma-band O
coupling O
between O
auditory O
cortices O
is O
related O
to O
the O
emergence O
of O
AVH O
in O
schizophrenia O
. O

Methods O
Participants O
This O
study O
included O
26 O
patients O
who O
met O
the O
DSM-IV O
criteria O
for O
SCZ O
and O
26 O
healthy O
controls O
( O
HC O
) O
matched O
for O
age O
, O
sex O
, O
and O
education O
. O

Inclusion O
criteria O
were O
German O
as O
a O
native O
language O
, O
right-handedness O
, O
no O
current O
presence O
and/or O
history O
of O
co-morbidities O
with O
axis O
I O
and O
II O
disorders O
of O
the O
DSM O
, O
no O
neurological O
disorders O
, O
no O
history O
of O
alcohol/drug O
dependence O
or O
abuse O
within O
three O
months O
, O
an O
IQ O
of O
≥70 O
, O
and O
no O
hearing O
damage O
or O
tinnitus O
. O

Most O
patients O
were O
taking O
antipsychotic O
medications O
, O
but O
there O
was O
no O
medication O
that O
would O
have O
interfered O
with O
EEG O
, O
neurological O
or O
cognitive O
functions O
( O
e.g O
. O

Clozapine O
; O
Table O
1 O
) O
. O

Psychopathologic O
symptoms O
were O
assessed O
using O
the O
Positive O
and O
Negative O
Syndrome O
Scale O
( O
PANSS O
) O
, O
which O
was O
evaluated O
according O
to O
Gaag O
et O
al O
.. O

The O
individual O
mental O
state O
was O
examined O
using O
the O
subjective O
well-being O
under O
neuroleptic O
scale O
( O
SWN-K O
) O
. O

The O
patients O
were O
carefully O
assigned O
according O
to O
the O
current O
history O
of O
AVH O
using O
the O
positive O
PANSS O
item O
“ O
P3 O
” O
into O
two O
groups O
( O
AVH O
vs. O
non-AVH O
patients O
) O
. O

The O
Psychotic O
Symptom O
Rating O
Scales O
( O
PSYRATS O
) O
was O
used O
to O
document O
the O
phenomenological O
features O
of O
the O
voices O
. O

The O
group O
of O
healthy O
subjects O
partly O
overlapped O
with O
the O
sample O
of O
our O
previous O
study O
( O
4 O
new O
subjects O
were O
recruited O
for O
matching O
) O
. O

This O
study O
was O
approved O
by O
the O
ethical O
committee O
of O
Medical O
Association O
Hamburg O
and O
was O
consistent O
with O
the O
principles O
outlined O
in O
an O
internationally O
recognized O
standard O
for O
ethical O
conduct O
in O
human O
research O
. O

After O
participants O
received O
a O
complete O
description O
of O
the O
experimental O
procedures O
, O
written O
informed O
consent O
was O
obtained O
according O
to O
the O
Declaration O
of O
Helsinki O
. O

Paradigm O
The O
DL O
task O
used O
was O
the O
same O
as O
in O
our O
previous O
study O
( O
for O
detailed O
description O
see O
ref O
. O

and O
Fig O
. O

1 O
) O
. O

In O
brief O
, O
six O
different O
consonant-vocal O
syllables O
( O
/ba/ O
, O
/da/ O
, O
/ka/ O
, O
/ga/ O
, O
/pa/ O
, O
/ta/ O
) O
were O
paired O
and O
presented O
simultaneously O
: O
one O
syllable O
to O
each O
ear O
, O
resulting O
in O
12 O
different O
combinations O
. O

Participants O
were O
instructed O
to O
report O
after O
each O
trial O
which O
syllable O
was O
perceived O
best O
. O

The O
response O
was O
given O
via O
button O
press O
with O
the O
right O
( O
dominant O
) O
hand O
, O
while O
a O
response O
screen O
, O
which O
appeared O
right O
after O
hearing O
the O
syllable O
pair O
, O
showed O
all O
six O
syllables O
presented O
in O
a O
circular O
formation O
. O

By O
clicking O
with O
the O
index O
finger O
the O
left O
mouse O
button O
it O
was O
possible O
to O
navigate O
through O
the O
six O
answer O
alternatives O
and O
by O
clicking O
with O
the O
ring O
finger O
the O
right O
mouse O
button O
the O
selection O
was O
confirmed O
. O

In O
order O
to O
assess O
the O
magnitude O
of O
the O
ear O
effect O
, O
a O
behavioral O
laterality O
index O
( O
LI O
) O
was O
calculated O
for O
every O
subject O
according O
to O
the O
formula O
: O
LI O
= O
100 O
* O
( O
RE O
− O
LE O
) O
/ O
( O
RE O
+ O
LE O
) O
, O
where O
RE O
= O
number O
of O
correct O
right O
ear O
reports O
and O
LE O
= O
number O
of O
correct O
left O
ear O
reports O
. O

The O
scale O
varies O
between O
−100 O
and O
+100 O
, O
with O
negative O
values O
indicating O
a O
left-ear O
advantage O
( O
LEA O
) O
and O
positive O
values O
indicating O
a O
REA O
. O

EEG O
recording O
and O
functional O
connectivity O
analysis O
The O
recording O
took O
place O
in O
a O
sound-proof O
and O
electrically O
shielded O
cabin O
, O
while O
participants O
listened O
through O
closed O
system O
headphones O
( O
Sennheiser O
, O
HAD O
200 O
) O
to O
the O
randomly O
presented O
240 O
syllable O
pairs O
at O
approximately O
75 O
dB O
. O

The O
EEG O
recordings O
were O
conducted O
with O
64 O
Ag/AgCl O
electrodes O
mounted O
on O
an O
elastic O
cap O
( O
ActiCaps O
, O
Brain O
Products O
, O
Munich O
, O
Germany O
) O
, O
including O
four O
EOG O
channels O
to O
monitor O
eye O
movements O
, O
using O
the O
Brain O
Vision O
Recorder O
1.10 O
( O
Brain O
Products O
, O
Munich O
, O
Germany O
) O
. O

Data O
were O
recorded O
with O
a O
bandpass O
( O
0.1 O
to O
1000 O
Hz O
) O
and O
digitized O
at O
a O
sampling O
rate O
of O
1000 O
Hz O
. O

Impedances O
were O
kept O
below O
5 O
KΩ O
. O

Offline O
processing O
was O
carried O
out O
using O
Brain O
Vision O
Analyzer O
2.0 O
( O
Brain O
Products O
, O
Munich O
, O
Germany O
) O
. O

The O
data O
was O
Butterworth O
zero O
phase O
bandpass O
filtered O
from O
20 O
to O
120 O
Hz O
( O
IIR O
, O
12 O
dB/octave O
) O
and O
down-sampled O
to O
500 O
Hz O
All O
channels O
were O
re-referenced O
to O
common O
average O
and O
FCz O
was O
recovered O
as O
a O
regular O
channel O
. O

Epochs O
with O
muscle O
artifacts O
in O
any O
channel O
were O
identified O
by O
visual O
inspection O
and O
rejected O
from O
further O
analysis O
. O

Independent O
component O
analysis O
( O
ICA O
) O
was O
applied O
to O
identify O
and O
remove O
blink O
, O
horizontal O
eye O
movements O
, O
electrocardiographic O
, O
muscle O
and O
saccadic O
spike O
potential O
( O
SP O
) O
artifacts O
based O
on O
their O
characteristic O
topographies O
, O
time-courses O
, O
and O
frequency O
distributions O
. O

To O
control O
for O
saccadic O
SPs O
in O
the O
gamma O
frequency O
range O
an O
additional O
“ O
radial O
electro-oculogram O
channel O
” O
( O
REOG O
) O
was O
derived O
following O
the O
procedure O
described O
by O
Keren O
et O
al O
.. O

Subsequently O
, O
the O
artifact-free O
data O
was O
segmented O
in O
epochs O
ranging O
from O
−200 O
to O
1848 O
ms O
regarding O
the O
stimulus O
onset O
and O
sorted O
as O
RE O
or O
LE O
reports O
. O

Finally O
, O
the O
number O
of O
correct-response O
epochs O
were O
exported O
for O
further O
analysis O
and O
balanced O
between O
LE O
and O
RE O
reports O
for O
every O
subject O
( O
matched O
number O
of O
trials O
for O
AVH O
: O
68.23 O
± O
19.43 O
; O
non-AVH O
: O
68.76 O
± O
14.79 O
and O
HC O
: O
71.19 O
± O
12.93 O
) O
, O
with O
no O
significant O
difference O
in O
the O
number O
of O
trials O
between O
the O
three O
groups O
[ O
F O
( O
1,51 O
) O
= O
0.208 O
, O
p O
= O
0.81 O
] O
. O

Similar O
to O
our O
previous O
studies O
, O
all O
further O
analyses O
were O
executed O
with O
the O
LORETA O
KEY O
software O
package O
investigating O
functional O
connectivity O
computed O
as O
“ O
lagged O
phase O
synchronization O
” O
( O
LPS O
) O
. O

LPS O
was O
assessed O
within O
two O
a O
priori O
defined O
regions-of-interests O
( O
ROIs O
) O
, O
which O
have O
been O
identified O
as O
essential O
nodes O
in O
the O
AVH O
network O
: O
right O
and O
left O
primary O
auditory O
cortices O
( O
PACs/BA41 O
) O
known O
to O
support O
any O
type O
of O
sound O
processing O
, O
and O
right O
and O
left O
secondary O
auditory O
cortices O
( O
SACs/BA42 O
) O
known O
to O
be O
involved O
in O
the O
processing O
of O
complex O
sounds O
and O
speech O
sounds O
. O

The O
ROIs O
were O
defined O
using O
the O
anatomical O
definitions O
provided O
by O
the O
eLORETA O
software O
based O
on O
the O
Talairach O
Daemon O
( O
see O
Figure O
S1 O
) O
. O

Based O
on O
our O
previous O
work O
, O
where O
we O
did O
not O
find O
LPS O
differences O
in O
any O
of O
the O
other O
frequencies O
( O
delta O
, O
theta O
, O
alpha O
, O
beta O
) O
as O
well O
as O
an O
effect O
in O
all O
gamma O
subbands O
( O
30–50 O
Hz O
, O
50–90 O
Hz O
) O
, O
analysis O
was O
focused O
on O
the O
whole O
gamma-band O
range O
( O
30–100 O
Hz O
) O
and O
the O
two O
conditions O
: O
LE O
and O
RE O
report O
. O

LPS O
across O
all O
the O
voxels O
included O
in O
the O
ROIs O
was O
based O
on O
the O
average O
of O
all O
LPS O
values O
, O
which O
were O
calculated O
for O
the O
connectivity O
between O
every O
voxel O
of O
ROI O
A O
and O
every O
voxel O
of O
ROI O
B O
. O

For O
all O
single O
trials O
, O
time-varying O
frequency O
analysis O
was O
done O
using O
a O
short O
time O
Fourier O
transform O
( O
sliding O
Bartlett-Hann O
window O
function O
) O
with O
a O
window O
width O
of O
100 O
ms. O
LPS O
was O
calculated O
using O
cross O
spectra O
derived O
from O
that O
transformation O
. O

In O
a O
time O
frame O
from O
0 O
to O
900 O
ms O
after O
stimulus O
presentation O
results O
were O
extracted O
every O
100 O
ms O
. O

Details O
of O
EEG O
electrode O
placement O
, O
the O
computation O
methods O
and O
its O
advantages O
have O
been O
provided O
previously O
and O
can O
be O
found O
also O
in O
supplementary O
material O
. O

Statistics O
First O
, O
the O
patient O
groups O
were O
compared O
by O
means O
of O
independent O
t-tests O
or O
Mann-Whitney-U O
tests O
( O
depending O
on O
normal O
distribution O
and O
corrected O
for O
multiple O
testing O
) O
for O
clinical O
data O
using O
SPSS O
21 O
. O

In O
order O
to O
compare O
demographic O
and O
behavioural O
data O
across O
the O
three O
groups O
( O
HC O
, O
AVH O
, O
and O
non-AVH O
) O
one-way O
ANOVA O
was O
used O
with O
follow-up O
Bonferroni O
post-hoc O
analysis O
. O

Effect O
sizes O
were O
calculated O
as O
r O
( O
for O
Mann-Whitney-U O
tests O
) O
or O
partial O
Eta-squared O
( O
η O
2/for O
one-way O
ANOVA O
) O
. O

The O
effects O
of O
group O
, O
ROIs O
, O
condition O
, O
and O
time O
on O
gamma O
synchrony O
were O
assessed O
with O
a O
linear O
mixed-effects O
model O
. O

Linear O
mixed O
models O
have O
several O
advantages O
over O
traditional O
repeated-measures O
designs O
, O
as O
they O
can O
accommodate O
departures O
from O
the O
assumptions O
of O
homogeneity O
of O
regression O
slopes O
and O
independence O
, O
and O
thus O
are O
better O
suited O
to O
model O
interindividual O
variability O
. O

This O
model O
has O
also O
been O
successfully O
implemented O
by O
researchers O
to O
analyse O
EEG O
data O
. O

In O
this O
study O
, O
the O
model O
included O
Group O
( O
3 O
levels O
: O
HC O
, O
AVH O
, O
non-AVH O
) O
, O
Time O
( O
10 O
levels O
: O
from O
0 O
to O
900 O
ms O
in O
100 O
ms O
steps O
) O
, O
Condition O
( O
2 O
levels O
: O
LE O
and O
RE O
reports O
) O
, O
and O
ROIs O
( O
2 O
levels O
: O
BA41 O
, O
BA42 O
) O
as O
the O
fixed-effects O
factors O
, O
Subject O
as O
a O
random-effects O
factor O
, O
and O
Gamma O
Synchrony O
as O
the O
dependent O
variable O
. O

The O
Spearman O
’ O
s O
correlation O
coefficient O
( O
two-tailed O
, O
p O
< O
0.05 O
) O
was O
used O
to O
investigate O
the O
relation O
between O
gamma O
synchrony O
( O
LPS O
difference O
between O
LE O
and O
RE O
reports O
at O
600ms O
) O
, O
PANSS O
hallucination O
item O
“ O
P3 O
” O
, O
and O
medication O
dosage O
in O
CPZ O
equivalents O
, O
without O
applying O
correction O
for O
multiple O
testing O
as O
the O
analysis O
was O
considered O
exploratory O
. O

Bootstrapping O
was O
used O
to O
calculate O
95 O
% O
confidence O
intervals O
( O
CI O
) O
around O
each O
significant O
correlation O
. O

Disrupted O
Olfactory O
Integration O
in O
Schizophrenia O
: O
Functional O
Connectivity O
Study O
Abstract O
Background O
Evidence O
for O
olfactory O
dysfunction O
in O
schizophrenia O
has O
been O
firmly O
established O
. O

However O
, O
in O
the O
typical O
understanding O
of O
schizophrenia O
, O
olfaction O
is O
not O
recognized O
to O
contribute O
to O
or O
interact O
with O
the O
illness O
. O

Despite O
the O
solid O
presence O
of O
olfactory O
dysfunction O
in O
schizophrenia O
, O
its O
relation O
to O
the O
rest O
of O
the O
illness O
remains O
largely O
unclear O
. O

Here O
, O
we O
aimed O
to O
examine O
functional O
connectivity O
of O
the O
olfactory O
bulb O
, O
olfactory O
tract O
, O
and O
piriform O
cortices O
and O
isolate O
the O
network O
that O
would O
account O
for O
the O
altered O
olfaction O
in O
schizophrenia O
. O

Methods O
We O
examined O
the O
functional O
connectivity O
of O
these O
specific O
olfactory O
regions O
in O
order O
to O
isolate O
other O
brain O
regions O
associated O
with O
olfactory O
processing O
in O
schizophrenia O
. O

Using O
the O
resting O
state O
functional O
MRI O
data O
from O
the O
Center O
for O
Biomedical O
Research O
Excellence O
in O
Brain O
Function O
and O
Mental O
Illness O
, O
we O
compared O
84 O
patients O
of O
schizophrenia O
and O
90 O
individuals O
without O
schizophrenia O
. O

Results O
The O
schizophrenia O
group O
showed O
disconnectivity O
between O
the O
anterior O
piriform O
cortex O
and O
the O
nucleus O
accumbens O
, O
between O
the O
posterior O
piriform O
cortex O
and O
the O
middle O
frontal O
gyrus O
, O
and O
between O
the O
olfactory O
tract O
and O
the O
visual O
cortices O
. O

Conclusions O
The O
current O
results O
suggest O
functional O
disconnectivity O
of O
olfactory O
regions O
in O
schizophrenia O
, O
which O
may O
account O
for O
olfactory O
dysfunction O
and O
disrupted O
integration O
with O
other O
sensory O
modalities O
in O
schizophrenia O
. O

Materials O
and O
Methods O
Data O
Acquisition O
The O
MRI O
images O
, O
the O
clinical O
data O
, O
and O
the O
demographic O
data O
from O
the O
Center O
for O
Biomedical O
Research O
Excellence O
in O
Brain O
Function O
and O
Mental O
Illness O
were O
obtained O
from O
Collaborative O
Informatics O
and O
Neuroimaging O
Suite O
( O
http O
: O
//coins.mrn.org/ O
) O
. O

This O
data O
subset O
consisted O
of O
183 O
individuals O
for O
whom O
both O
resting O
state O
and O
structural O
data O
were O
available O
. O

Among O
these O
individuals O
, O
84 O
had O
a O
diagnosis O
of O
schizophrenia O
or O
schizoaffective O
disorder O
( O
hereafter O
SZ O
group O
, O
36.85±14.09 O
years O
old O
) O
based O
on O
the O
Structural O
Clinical O
Interview O
for O
DSM-IV O
for O
Axis O
I O
DSM-IV O
Disorders O
, O
and O
90 O
were O
nonpsychiatric O
age-matched O
controls O
( O
control O
group O
, O
37.5±11.40 O
years O
old O
) O
. O

Nine O
individuals O
who O
had O
a O
diagnosis O
of O
bipolar O
disorder O
were O
excluded O
from O
further O
analysis O
. O

Resting O
state O
echo O
planner O
image O
( O
EPI O
) O
volumes O
had O
32 O
slices O
of O
4 O
mm O
64x64 O
matrix O
with O
4-mm O
thickness O
( O
voxel O
size O
= O
3x3x4 O
mm O
) O
, O
with O
repetition O
time O
( O
TR O
) O
of O
2000 O
milliseconds O
and O
echo O
time O
( O
TE O
) O
of O
29 O
milliseconds O
. O

A O
total O
of O
150 O
volumes O
( O
5 O
minutes O
) O
were O
used O
in O
the O
analysis O
. O

High-resolution O
structural O
T1 O
volume O
was O
acquired O
as O
176 O
sagittal O
slices O
of O
256 O
mm O
x O
256 O
mm O
with O
1-mm O
thickness O
( O
voxel O
size O
= O
1x1x1 O
mm O
, O
TR=2530 O
milliseconds O
and O
TE=3.25 O
milliseconds O
) O
. O

Data O
Processing O
Data O
preprocessing O
and O
statistical O
analyses O
were O
conducted O
using O
FMRIB O
Software O
Library O
( O
FSL O
) O
as O
well O
as O
Analysis O
of O
Functional O
NeuroImages O
. O

The O
anatomical O
volume O
for O
each O
subject O
was O
skull O
stripped O
, O
segmented O
( O
gray O
matter O
, O
white O
matter O
, O
and O
CSF O
) O
, O
and O
registered O
to O
the O
MNI O
2-mm O
standard O
brain O
. O

The O
first O
4 O
EPI O
volumes O
were O
removed O
. O

Transient O
signal O
spikes O
were O
removed O
by O
despiking O
interpolation O
. O

To O
correct O
head O
motion O
, O
the O
volumes O
were O
linearly O
registered O
to O
the O
then-first O
volume O
, O
through O
which O
6 O
motion O
parameters O
and O
displacement O
distance O
between O
2 O
consecutive O
volumes O
were O
estimated O
. O

Each O
of O
the O
resting O
state O
volumes O
was O
regressed O
by O
white O
matter O
and O
cerebrospinal O
fluid O
signal O
fluctuations O
as O
well O
as O
the O
6 O
motion O
parameters O
. O

After O
smoothing O
with O
a O
6-mm O
FWHM O
Gaussian O
kernel O
, O
the O
volumes O
were O
resampled O
, O
spatially O
transformed O
, O
and O
aligned O
to O
the O
MNI O
2-mm O
standard O
brain O
space O
. O

Through O
this O
registration O
, O
12 O
affine O
parameters O
were O
created O
between O
rs-fMRI O
volume O
and O
MNI152 O
2-mm O
space O
, O
so O
that O
a O
seed O
ROI O
can O
later O
be O
registered O
to O
each O
individual O
rs-fMRI O
space O
. O

To O
perform O
scrubbing O
where O
the O
volumes O
with O
excess O
motion O
are O
removed O
, O
as O
a O
displacement O
distance O
between O
2 O
EPI O
volumes O
, O
the O
root O
mean O
square O
deviation O
was O
calculated O
from O
motion O
correction O
parameters O
, O
at O
an O
r=40-mm O
spherical O
surface O
using O
FSL O
’ O
s O
rmsdiff O
tool O
. O

Volumes O
whose O
displacement O
distance O
exceeded O
the O
threshold O
( O
0.3 O
mm O
) O
were O
removed O
( O
scrubbed O
) O
from O
further O
statistical O
analyses O
. O

The O
olfactory O
bulb O
, O
olfactory O
tract O
, O
anterior O
piriform O
cortex O
, O
and O
posterior O
piriform O
cortex O
were O
manually O
segmented O
in O
the O
MNI O
2-mm O
space O
( O
Figure O
1 O
) O
following O
anatomical O
descriptions O
in O
the O
literature O
. O

For O
each O
ROI O
, O
voxel-wise O
connectivity O
analysis O
was O
conducted O
. O

The O
time O
course O
was O
spatially O
averaged O
within O
the O
ROI O
that O
was O
registered O
to O
the O
EPI O
space O
so O
that O
correlations O
can O
be O
tested O
between O
the O
ROI O
and O
each O
individual O
voxel O
across O
the O
brain O
. O

The O
Z-scores O
representing O
the O
correlations O
between O
the O
ROI O
and O
a O
voxel O
were O
used O
for O
group-level O
analysis O
after O
registration O
to O
the O
MNI O
2-mm O
brain O
space O
. O

The O
SZ O
and O
control O
groups O
were O
compared O
by O
randomise O
script O
in O
FSL O
. O

Z-statistic O
images O
were O
estimated O
where O
clusters O
were O
determined O
by O
the O
statistical O
threshold O
of O
Z O
> O
2.326 O
with O
a O
family-wise O
error-corrected O
cluster O
significance O
threshold O
, O
assuming O
a O
Gaussian O
random O
field O
for O
the O
Z-statistics O
. O

The O
peak O
voxels O
within O
a O
cluster O
were O
calculated O
by O
using O
voxelwise O
family-wise O
error O
corrected O
t O
test O
images O
. O

Nucleus O
Accumbens O
Functional O
Connectivity O
at O
Age O
20 O
is O
Associated O
with O
Trajectory O
of O
Adolescent O
Cannabis O
Use O
and O
Predicts O
Psychosocial O
Functioning O
in O
Young O
Adulthood O
Aims O
1 O
) O
To O
identify O
trajectories O
of O
cannabis O
use O
across O
adolescence O
, O
2 O
) O
to O
measure O
the O
influence O
of O
cannabis O
use O
characteristics O
on O
functional O
connectivity O
of O
the O
nucleus O
accumbens O
( O
NAcc O
) O
, O
and O
3 O
) O
to O
assess O
whether O
patterns O
of O
functional O
connectivity O
related O
to O
cannabis O
use O
are O
associated O
with O
psychosocial O
functioning O
2 O
years O
later O
. O

Design O
The O
Pitt O
Mother O
& O
Child O
Project O
( O
PMCP O
) O
is O
a O
prospective O
, O
longitudinal O
study O
of O
male O
youth O
at O
high O
risk O
for O
psychopathology O
based O
on O
family O
income O
and O
gender O
. O

Setting O
Participants O
were O
recruited O
between O
age O
6–17 O
months O
from O
the O
Women O
, O
Infants O
, O
and O
Children O
Nutritional O
Supplement O
program O
( O
WIC O
) O
in O
the O
Pittsburgh O
, O
Pennsylvania O
area O
. O

Participants O
N=158 O
PMCP O
young O
men O
contributed O
fMRI O
and O
substance O
use O
data O
at O
age O
20 O
. O

Measurements O
Latent O
class O
growth O
analysis O
was O
used O
to O
determine O
trajectories O
of O
cannabis O
use O
frequency O
from O
age O
14–19 O
. O

Psychophysiological O
interaction O
( O
PPI O
) O
analysis O
was O
used O
to O
measure O
functional O
connectivity O
between O
the O
NAcc O
and O
prefrontal O
cortex O
( O
PFC O
) O
. O

Adolescent O
cannabis O
use O
trajectory O
, O
recent O
frequency O
of O
use O
, O
and O
age O
of O
initiation O
were O
considered O
as O
developmental O
factors O
. O

We O
also O
tested O
whether O
functional O
connectivity O
was O
associated O
with O
depressive O
symptoms O
, O
anhedonia O
, O
and O
educational O
attainment O
at O
age O
22 O
. O

Findings O
We O
identified O
three O
distinct O
trajectories O
of O
adolescent O
cannabis O
use O
, O
characterized O
by O
stable O
high O
, O
escalating O
, O
or O
stable O
low O
use O
. O

Cannabis O
use O
trajectory O
group O
had O
a O
significant O
effect O
on O
NAcc O
functional O
connectivity O
to O
the O
medial O
PFC O
( O
F=11.32 O
, O
Z=4.04 O
, O
pFWE-corr=.000 O
) O
. O

The O
escalating O
trajectory O
group O
displayed O
a O
pattern O
of O
negative O
NAcc-mPFC O
connectivity O
that O
was O
linked O
to O
higher O
levels O
of O
depressive O
symptoms O
( O
r=−.17 O
, O
p=.041 O
) O
, O
anhedonia O
( O
r=−.19 O
, O
p=.028 O
) O
, O
and O
lower O
educational O
attainment O
( O
t=−2.77 O
, O
p=.006 O
) O
at O
age O
22 O
. O

Conclusions O
Pattern O
of O
cannabis O
use O
frequency O
across O
adolescence O
in O
US O
youth O
could O
have O
consequences O
for O
mood O
symptoms O
and O
educational O
attainment O
in O
early O
adulthood O
via O
altered O
function O
in O
neural O
reward O
circuitry O
. O

Methods O
Design O
The O
Pitt O
Mother O
& O
Child O
Project O
( O
PMCP O
) O
is O
a O
prospective O
, O
longitudinal O
study O
of O
risk O
and O
resiliency O
among O
low-income O
male O
participants O
recruited O
from O
the O
Pittsburgh O
, O
Pennsylvania O
area O
. O

This O
study O
was O
initiated O
in O
1991 O
and O
a O
total O
of O
N=310 O
families O
were O
recruited O
from O
Women O
, O
Infant O
, O
and O
Children O
Nutritional O
Supplement O
Program O
( O
WIC O
) O
Clinics O
when O
participants O
were O
6–17 O
months O
old O
. O

Participants O
completed O
in-person O
assessments O
at O
age O
1.5 O
, O
2 O
, O
3.5 O
, O
5 O
, O
5.5 O
, O
6 O
, O
8 O
, O
10 O
, O
11 O
, O
12 O
, O
15 O
, O
17 O
, O
20 O
, O
and O
22 O
. O

This O
study O
has O
the O
strength O
of O
allowing O
for O
concurrent O
examination O
of O
the O
relative O
influence O
of O
adolescent O
trajectory O
of O
cannabis O
use O
, O
recent O
