frequency O
of O
use O
, O
and O
age O
of O
onset O
. O

Because O
subjects O
were O
recruited O
in O
infancy O
and O
followed O
prospectively O
, O
it O
was O
not O
possible O
to O
control O
the O
number O
of O
participants O
that O
would O
ultimately O
go O
on O
to O
engage O
in O
cannabis O
use O
. O

Rather O
, O
we O
took O
a O
data-driven O
approach O
to O
determine O
the O
different O
trajectories O
of O
cannabis O
use O
that O
were O
present O
among O
PMCP O
participants O
, O
and O
to O
use O
these O
trajectory O
groups O
as O
the O
basis O
for O
our O
functional O
connectivity O
analyses O
. O

Participants O
Participants O
were O
n=158 O
PMCP O
participants O
who O
completed O
an O
fMRI O
scan O
and O
substance O
use O
measures O
at O
age O
20 O
. O

All O
subjects O
were O
eligible O
to O
participate O
in O
the O
imaging O
study O
unless O
they O
reported O
any O
standard O
MRI O
contraindications O
. O

Procedures O
were O
approved O
by O
the O
University O
of O
Pittsburgh O
Institutional O
Review O
Board O
. O

All O
participants O
provided O
written O
informed O
consent O
to O
study O
procedures O
and O
were O
compensated O
for O
their O
participation O
. O

Measures O
Cannabis O
Use O
Cannabis O
use O
characteristics O
were O
assessed O
at O
age O
20 O
using O
the O
Lifetime O
History O
of O
Drug O
Use O
and O
Drug O
Consumption O
, O
a O
psychometrically O
sound O
, O
semi-structured O
interview O
. O

This O
was O
the O
first O
visit O
at O
which O
participants O
were O
asked O
about O
their O
frequency O
and O
quantity O
of O
use O
across O
development O
. O

For O
each O
year O
since O
their O
first O
use O
, O
participants O
reported O
their O
average O
days/month O
of O
cannabis O
use O
, O
average O
quantity O
, O
maximum O
quantity O
, O
and O
maximum O
number O
of O
days O
using O
their O
maximum O
quantity O
of O
cannabis O
. O

Retrospective O
report O
of O
cannabis O
use O
is O
valid O
, O
and O
may O
sometimes O
be O
more O
accurate O
than O
concurrent O
report O
because O
adolescents O
may O
under-report O
their O
current O
use O
because O
of O
concerns O
about O
legal O
consequences O
. O

The O
current O
analyses O
focused O
on O
average O
frequency O
of O
use O
for O
each O
year O
and O
age O
of O
initiation O
. O

Alcohol O
Use O
Annual O
alcohol O
use O
frequency O
( O
days/month O
) O
and O
quantity O
( O
average O
number O
of O
drinks/occasion O
) O
for O
each O
year O
since O
participants O
’ O
first O
alcohol O
use O
were O
assessed O
at O
age O
20 O
using O
the O
Lifetime O
Drinking O
History O
. O

The O
product O
of O
alcohol O
use O
frequency O
and O
quantity O
was O
calculated O
for O
each O
year O
and O
average O
alcohol O
exposure O
from O
age O
10 O
to O
19 O
was O
included O
as O
a O
covariate O
in O
all O
functional O
connectivity O
analyses O
. O

Age O
22 O
Psychosocial O
Outcomes O
Depression O
Participants O
completed O
the O
Beck O
Depression O
Inventory O
( O
BDI O
; O
44 O
) O
at O
age O
20 O
and O
22 O
, O
a O
widely O
used O
, O
21-item O
self-report O
questionnaire O
that O
had O
adequate O
reliability O
in O
this O
sample O
( O
α=.89 O
) O
. O

BDI O
scores O
did O
not O
change O
significantly O
from O
age O
20 O
to O
22 O
( O
F O
( O
302,1 O
) O
=.803 O
, O
p=.371 O
) O
. O

Anhedonia O
At O
age O
22 O
only O
, O
participants O
completed O
the O
Snaith-Hamilton O
Pleasure O
Scale O
, O
a O
psychometrically O
sound O
, O
14-item O
questionnaire O
appropriate O
for O
measuring O
anhedonia O
in O
typical O
and O
clinical O
samples O
. O

Reliability O
was O
adequate O
in O
this O
sample O
( O
α=.851 O
) O
. O

Educational O
Attainment O
Participants O
reported O
their O
highest O
level O
of O
school O
completed O
on O
a O
13-point O
scale O
( O
“ O
below O
grade O
9 O
” O
to O
“ O
completion O
of O
graduate O
degree O
” O
) O
. O

For O
the O
current O
analyses O
, O
participants O
were O
classified O
as O
having O
either O
obtained O
“ O
high O
school O
diploma O
( O
or O
GED O
) O
or O
less O
” O
or O
“ O
some O
higher O
education O
or O
more O
” O
( O
39.9 O
% O
at O
age O
20 O
; O
52 O
% O
at O
22 O
) O
. O

Educational O
attainment O
increased O
from O
age O
20 O
to O
age O
22 O
( O
X2=57.85 O
, O
p=.00 O
) O
. O

Functional O
Connectivity O
Analysis O
fMRI O
Acquisition O
Procedure O
Participants O
( O
n=186 O
) O
underwent O
functional O
imaging O
on O
a O
Siemens O
TIM O
Trio O
3T O
scanner O
using O
a O
gradient O
echo O
planar O
imaging O
( O
EPI O
) O
sequence O
with O
34 O
axial O
slices O
( O
3.1mm O
thick O
; O
TR/TE=2000/28ms O
, O
FOV=20cm O
, O
matrix=64×64 O
) O
, O
as O
reported O
previously O
. O

A O
reference O
EPI O
scan O
was O
acquired O
and O
inspected O
for O
artifacts O
and O
signal O
. O

Twenty-eight O
participants O
were O
excluded O
because O
of O
intoxication O
( O
n=4 O
) O
, O
psychosis O
( O
n=1 O
) O
, O
< O
75 O
% O
response O
rate O
( O
n=13 O
) O
, O
poor O
coverage O
( O
n=8 O
) O
, O
or O
unusable O
data O
( O
n=2 O
) O
, O
resulting O
in O
the O
final O
sample O
of O
n=158 O
included O
in O
the O
current O
analyses O
. O

All O
participants O
had O
< O
2mm O
mean O
movement O
in O
any O
direction O
. O

The O
fMRI O
paradigm O
was O
an O
8-min O
, O
24-trial O
, O
slow O
event-related O
card-guessing O
game O
that O
assesses O
response O
to O
anticipation O
and O
receipt O
of O
monetary O
reward O
( O
see O
for O
task O
details O
) O
. O

Participants O
guessed O
whether O
a O
card O
was O
high O
or O
low O
, O
anticipated O
win O
or O
loss O
, O
and O
received O
feedback O
and O
monetary O
outcome O
. O

Trials O
were O
presented O
in O
a O
fixed O
, O
pseudorandom O
order O
, O
with O
participants O
unaware O
of O
fixed O
outcomes O
. O

This O
task O
robustly O
activates O
reward O
circuitry O
, O
including O
the O
NAcc O
( O
see O
Supplemental O
Figure O
1 O
for O
task O
main O
effects O
) O
. O

fMRI O
Functional O
Connectivity O
Analysis O
We O
conducted O
preprocessing O
and O
analysis O
using O
SPM8 O
( O
http O
: O
//www.fil.ion.ucl.ac.uk/spm O
) O
. O

Imaging O
data O
were O
realigned O
, O
unwarped O
, O
co-registered O
to O
segmented O
structural O
images O
, O
spatially O
normalized O
into O
standard O
stereotactic O
space O
( O
Montreal O
Neurological O
Institute O
) O
using O
a O
12-parameter O
affine O
model O
, O
and O
smoothed O
with O
a O
6mm O
FWHM O
Gaussian O
filter O
. O

Voxel-wise O
signal O
intensities O
were O
ratio O
normalized O
to O
the O
whole-brain O
global O
mean O
. O

Functional O
connectivity O
analyses O
of O
win O
anticipation O
> O
loss O
anticipation O
and O
win O
outcome O
> O
loss O
outcome O
were O
conducted O
using O
psychophysiological O
interaction O
( O
gPPI O
) O
( O
for O
description O
of O
PPI O
, O
please O
see O
) O
. O

These O
contrasts O
were O
chosen O
because O
PPI O
analyses O
require O
the O
contrast O
of O
2 O
active O
task O
conditions O
( O
rather O
than O
1 O
active O
condition O
and O
1 O
baseline O
condition O
) O
. O

The O
bilateral O
NAcc O
, O
defined O
anatomically O
using O
WFU O
PickAtlas O
( O
v. O
3.0.4 O
) O
, O
was O
the O
seed O
region O
because O
of O
its O
critical O
role O
in O
reward O
processing O
and O
association O
with O
substance O
use O
. O

Functional O
connectivity O
was O
examined O
between O
the O
NAcc O
and O
a O
region O
of O
interest O
including O
the O
PFC O
and O
ACC O
, O
defined O
anatomically O
using O
WFU O
PickAtlas O
( O
v. O
3.0.4 O
) O
to O
include O
Brodmann O
Areas O
9–12 O
, O
24–25 O
, O
32–33 O
, O
and O
44–47 O
( O
see O
supplemental O
Figure O
2 O
) O
. O

Data O
Analyses O
Aim O
1 O
: O
Developmental O
Trajectory O
of O
Adolescent O
Cannabis O
Use O
Trajectory O
group O
analyses O
used O
frequency O
of O
cannabis O
use O
from O
age O
14–19 O
years O
. O

This O
range O
covers O
a O
large O
portion O
of O
adolescence O
, O
includes O
the O
typical O
age O
of O
initiation O
, O
and O
included O
past-year O
use O
because O
assessments O
occurred O
on O
or O
around O
participants O
’ O
20th O
birthdays O
. O

We O
used O
a O
latent O
class O
growth O
analyses O
in O
MPlus O
, O
which O
identifies O
clusters O
of O
people O
in O
common O
developmental O
pathways O
. O

Models O
with O
1–4 O
groups O
were O
tested O
( O
Supplementary O
Table O
1 O
) O
. O

We O
followed O
recommendations O
that O
the O
smallest O
group O
contain O
at O
least O
5 O
% O
of O
the O
sample O
. O

Aim O
2 O
: O
Influence O
of O
Cannabis O
Use O
Characteristics O
on O
Age O
20 O
Functional O
Connectivity O
One-way O
ANOVA O
was O
used O
to O
test O
the O
effect O
of O
trajectory O
group O
on O
NAcc O
functional O
connectivity O
. O

Clusters O
demonstrating O
significant O
effects O
of O
trajectory O
group O
were O
used O
as O
a O
mask O
for O
post-hoc O
pairwise O
t-tests O
. O

Regression O
was O
used O
to O
test O
the O
effect O
of O
recent O
frequency O
of O
cannabis O
use O
and O
age O
of O
initiation O
on O
NAcc O
functional O
connectivity O
. O

Daily O
nicotine O
use O
, O
antisocial O
personality O
disorder O
( O
present/absent O
) O
, O
lifetime O
alcohol O
exposure O
, O
and O
SES O
were O
covariates O
because O
of O
their O
influence O
on O
reward O
circuitry O
or O
association O
with O
trajectory O
group O
. O

Functional O
connectivity O
with O
the O
PFC O
was O
tested O
at O
p O
< O
.005 O
and O
correction O
for O
multiple O
comparisons O
used O
a O
cluster-level O
FWE-corrected O
p O
< O
.05 O
threshold O
. O

This O
threshold O
was O
selected O
to O
balance O
risk O
for O
Type O
I O
and O
Type O
II O
error O
, O
based O
on O
current O
recommendations O
in O
the O
field O
. O

Carter O
et O
al O
. O

calculated O
power O
curves O
to O
illustrate O
sample O
sizes O
necessary O
to O
detect O
moderate O
effects O
at O
various O
statistical O
thresholds O
. O

Based O
on O
their O
calculations O
, O
a O
threshold O
of O
p O
< O
.001 O
would O
be O
likely O
to O
obscure O
meaningful O
effects O
in O
on O
our O
current O
sample O
size O
, O
whereas O
a O
threshold O
of O
p O
< O
.005 O
would O
allow O
us O
to O
detect O
a O
moderate O
effect O
. O

Aim O
3 O
: O
Relation O
between O
Age O
20 O
Functional O
Connectivity O
and O
Age O
22 O
Psychosocial O
Outcomes O
Pearson O
bivariate O
correlation O
analyses O
tested O
whether O
functional O
connectivity O
related O
to O
adolescent O
cannabis O
use O
was O
associated O
with O
depression O
, O
anhedonia O
, O
or O
educational O
attainment O
at O
age O
22 O
. O

Unseen O
scars O
: O
Cocaine O
patients O
with O
prior O
trauma O
evidence O
heightened O
resting O
state O
functional O
connectivity O
( O
RSFC O
) O
between O
the O
amygdala O
and O
limbic-striatal O
regions O
Background O
Substance O
use O
disorder O
( O
SUD O
) O
patients O
with O
a O
history O
of O
trauma O
exhibit O
poorer O
treatment O
outcome O
, O
greater O
functional O
impairment O
and O
higher O
risk O
for O
relapse O
. O

Endorsement O
of O
prior O
trauma O
has O
, O
in O
several O
SUD O
populations O
, O
been O
linked O
to O
abnormal O
functional O
connectivity O
( O
FC O
) O
during O
task-based O
studies O
. O

We O
examined O
amygdala O
FC O
in O
the O
resting O
state O
( O
RS O
) O
, O
testing O
for O
differences O
between O
cocaine O
patients O
with O
and O
without O
prior O
trauma O
. O

Methods O
Patients O
with O
cocaine O
use O
disorder O
( O
CUD O
; O
n=34 O
) O
were O
stabilized O
in O
an O
inpatient O
setting O
prior O
to O
a O
BOLD O
fMRI O
scan O
. O

Responses O
to O
Addiction O
Severity O
Index O
and O
the O
Mini-International O
Neuropsychiatric O
Interview O
were O
used O
to O
characterize O
the O
No-Trauma O
( O
n=16 O
) O
and O
Trauma O
( O
n=18 O
) O
groups O
. O

Seed-based O
RSFC O
was O
conducted O
using O
the O
right O
and O
left O
amygdala O
as O
regions O
of O
interest O
. O

Examination O
of O
amygdala O
RSFC O
was O
restricted O
to O
an O
a O
priori O
anatomical O
mask O
that O
incorporated O
nodes O
of O
the O
limbic-striatal O
motivational O
network O
. O

Results O
RSFC O
was O
compared O
for O
the O
Trauma O
versus O
No-Trauma O
groups O
. O

The O
Trauma O
group O
evidenced O
greater O
connectivity O
between O
the O
amygdala O
and O
the O
a O
priori O
limbic-striatal O
mask O
. O

Peaks O
within O
the O
statistically O
significant O
limbic-striatal O
mask O
included O
the O
amygdala O
, O
putamen O
, O
pallidum O
, O
caudate O
, O
thalamus O
, O
insula O
, O
hippocampus/parahippocampus O
, O
and O
brain O
stem O
. O

Conclusions O
Results O
suggest O
that O
cocaine O
patients O
with O
prior O
trauma O
( O
versus O
without O
) O
have O
heightened O
communication O
within O
nodes O
of O
the O
motivational O
network O
, O
even O
at O
rest O
. O

To O
our O
knowledge O
, O
this O
is O
the O
first O
fMRI O
study O
to O
examine O
amygdala O
RSFC O
among O
those O
with O
CUD O
and O
trauma O
history O
. O

Heightened O
RSFC O
intralimbic O
connectivity O
for O
the O
Trauma O
group O
may O
reflect O
a O
relapse-relevant O
brain O
vulnerability O
and O
a O
novel O
treatment O
target O
for O
this O
clinically-challenging O
population O
. O

2 O
. O

Methods O
2.1 O
Participants O
Participants O
were O
34 O
treatment-seeking O
, O
cocaine-dependent O
men O
, O
between O
34 O
and O
60 O
years O
of O
age O
, O
who O
met O
DSM-IV O
criteria O
for O
cocaine O
dependence O
, O
described O
smoking O
as O
their O
primary O
route O
of O
cocaine-crack O
administration O
, O
and O
reported O
using O
cocaine O
on O
at O
least O
8 O
of O
the O
30 O
days O
before O
screening O
( O
See O
Table O
1 O
for O
demographics O
) O
. O

Participants O
were O
recruited O
through O
advertisements O
in O
local O
media O
and O
were O
part O
of O
a O
larger O
study O
examining O
brain O
and O
behavioral O
vulnerabilities O
associated O
with O
addiction O
. O

After O
completing O
a O
detailed O
telephone O
screen O
, O
participants O
provided O
informed O
consent O
, O
were O
medically O
screened O
, O
and O
completed O
psychological O
assessment O
measures O
. O

Exclusion O
criteria O
included O
: O
contraindications O
for O
fMRI O
( O
e.g. O
, O
metal O
in O
the O
body O
, O
claustrophobia O
) O
, O
use O
of O
medications O
affecting O
central O
dopaminergic O
neurotransmission O
, O
history O
of O
psychosis O
, O
seizures O
, O
or O
organic O
brain O
syndrome O
unrelated O
to O
cocaine O
use O
, O
clinically O
significant O
cardiovascular O
, O
hematologic O
, O
hepatic O
, O
renal O
, O
neurological O
, O
or O
endocrine O
abnormalities O
, O
history O
of O
head O
trauma O
or O
loss O
of O
consciousness O
for O
more O
than O
3 O
minutes O
. O

Psychiatric O
diagnoses O
were O
based O
on O
the O
Mini O
International O
Neuropsychiatric O
Interview O
( O
MINI O
) O
and O
those O
diagnosed O
with O
comorbid O
Axis O
I O
disorders O
were O
excluded O
, O
with O
exception O
for O
dependence O
on O
nicotine O
, O
marijuana O
, O
or O
alcohol O
not O
requiring O
medical O
detoxification O
. O

Participants O
meeting O
diagnostic O
criteria O
for O
depression O
were O
not O
excluded O
if O
their O
diagnosis O
was O
linked O
solely O
to O
periods O
of O
cocaine O
use/cessation O
. O

This O
study O
adhered O
to O
the O
Declaration O
of O
Helsinki O
and O
was O
approved O
by O
the O
University O
of O
Pennsylvania O
Institutional O
Review O
Board O
. O

2.2 O
. O

Study O
Design O
Participants O
were O
stabilized O
in O
a O
supervised O
drug-free O
residential O
stabilization O
unit O
for O
7–10 O
days O
prior O
to O
participating O
in O
a O
one-hour O
fMRI O
scanning O
session O
involving O
several O
experimental O
tasks O
including O
a O
BOLD O
resting O
state O
scan O
, O
which O
preceded O
the O
behavioral O
tasks O
. O

This O
controlled O
setting O
eliminates O
the O
impact O
of O
cocaine O
intoxication O
and O
minimizes O
the O
contribution O
of O
cessation O
symptoms O
to O
study O
measures O
. O

2.3 O
. O

Measures O
Cocaine O
and O
other O
illicit O
drug O
use O
for O
the O
past O
30 O
days O
were O
assessed O
with O
the O
Addiction O
Severity O
Index O
( O
ASI O
) O
and O
the O
Timeline O
Followback O
interview O
( O
TLFB O
) O
. O

Presence O
of O
psychiatric O
diagnosis O
was O
based O
on O
results O
from O
the O
MINI O
. O

To O
assess O
for O
recent O
anxiety O
and O
depression O
, O
additional O
measures O
included O
the O
Beck O
Anxiety O
Inventory O
( O
BAI O
) O
, O
the O
Beck O
Depression O
Inventory O
( O
BDI O
) O
, O
and O
the O
clinician O
administered O
, O
Hamilton O
Rating O
Scale O
for O
Depression O
( O
HAM-D O
) O
. O

The O
PTSD O
Checklist O
for O
Civilians O
( O
PCL-C O
) O
was O
also O
administered O
to O
characterize O
symptoms O
that O
may O
accompany O
trauma O
exposure O
as O
a O
potential O
clinical O
validator O
for O
the O
Trauma O
subgroup O
. O

Participants O
completed O
measures O
during O
their O
initial O
screening O
assessment O
( O
PCL-C O
, O
MINI O
, O
ASI O
) O
and O
their O
baseline O
visit O
( O
BAI O
, O
BDI O
, O
HAM-D O
, O
TLFB O
) O
. O

2.4. O
fMRI O
Acquisition O
Functional O
MR O
imaging O
was O
conducted O
on O
a O
3-T O
whole-body O
scanner O
( O
Siemens O
Tim O
Trio O
, O
Erlangen O
, O
Germany O
) O
. O

High-resolution O
structural O
images O
were O
acquired O
for O
spatial O
brain O
normalization O
using O
a O
3D O
magnetization O
prepared O
rapid O
gradient O
echo O
( O
MPRAGE O
) O
sequence O
( O
TR/TE/TI O
= O
1620/3/950ms O
) O
. O

Images O
for O
the O
resting-scan O
were O
acquired O
during O
a O
6-min O
scan O
using O
a O
gradient-echo O
echo-planar-imaging O
sequence O
( O
TR/TE O
= O
2s/30ms O
, O
FOV O
= O
220x220 O
mm2 O
, O
matrix O
= O
64x64 O
, O
slice O
thickness O
= O
4.5 O
mm O
, O
150 O
images O
were O
acquired O
) O
. O

Participants O
were O
asked O
to O
remain O
still O
with O
their O
eyes O
open O
and O
to O
not O
think O
about O
anything O
in O
particular O
during O
this O
scan O
. O

Data O
preprocessing O
was O
carried O
out O
using O
Data O
Processing O
Assistant O
for O
Resting-State O
fMRI O
Basic O
Edition O
( O
DPARSF O
) O
and O
Data O
Processing O
and O
Analysis O
of O
Brain O
Imaging O
( O
REST O
) O
toolbox O
, O
based O
on O
SPM8 O
( O
http O
: O
//www.fil.ion.ucl.ac.uk/spm O
) O
run O
under O
Matlab O
R2015 O
environment O
. O

In O
this O
paper O
, O
we O
followed O
the O
standard O
preprocessing O
pipeline O
still O
accounting O
for O
motion O
related O
artifacts O
. O

Each O
participants O
’ O
images O
were O
slice-time O
corrected O
, O
realigned O
, O
coregistered O
to O
high-resolution O
structural O
images O
, O
and O
subsequently O
normalized O
to O
MNI O
standard O
space O
and O
smoothed O
with O
the O
FWHM O
kernel O
of O
6mm O
. O

Summary O
motion O
statistics O
for O
each O
subject O
were O
examined O
and O
confirmed O
the O
motion O
was O
below O
2mm O
in O
both O
directions O
. O

In O
addressing O
the O
head O
motion O
concerns O
, O
we O
regressed O
out O
Friston O
24 O
head O
motion O
parameters O
which O
includes O
six O
head O
motion O
estimates O
from O
current O
time O
point O
( O
Rt O
= O
[ O
X O
Y O
Z O
pitch O
roll O
yaw O
] O
) O
, O
six O
head O
motion O
parameters O
from O
immediately O
preceding O
time O
point O
( O
Rt-1 O
) O
and O
their O
corresponding O
squares O
( O
Rt O
2 O
, O
Rt-1 O
2 O
) O
. O

Given O
the O
concerns O
of O
the O
field O
about O
the O
impact O
of O
micro O
motion O
( O
as O
small O
as O
0.2 O
mm O
) O
on O
resting O
functional O
connectivity O
, O
we O
additionally O
calculated O
mean O
Frame-by-Frame O
head O
displacement O
( O
FD O
) O
to O
compare O
the O
two O
groups O
and O
for O
subsequent O
use O
as O
a O
nuisance O
covariate O
at O
the O
second O
level O
analysis O
( O
see O
below O
) O
. O

Images O
were O
then O
detrended O
to O
remove O
linear O
trends O
due O
to O
scanner O
drift O
; O
band-pass O
filtered O
( O
0.01–0.1Hz O
) O
to O
remove O
scanner O
and O
cardio-respiratory O
noise O
. O

Tissue O
based O
signals O
such O
as O
white O
matter O
, O
CSF O
and O
global O
signal O
were O
used O
as O
nuisance O
regressors O
to O
remove O
the O
sources O
of O
spurious O
variance O
and O
their O
temporal O
derivatives O
were O
also O
removed O
from O
the O
data O
through O
linear O
regression O
. O

Smoothed O
normalized O
images O
were O
entered O
into O
seed-based O
region O
of O
interest O
( O
ROI O
) O
analysis O
with O
amygdalae O
as O
seeds O
. O

A O
cross-correlation O
map O
was O
constructed O
by O
doing O
voxel-wise O
correlation O
between O
the O
temporal O
signals O
from O
both O
the O
right O
and O
left O
amygdala O
and O
each O
voxel O
in O
the O
brain O
. O

The O
right O
and O
left O
amygdalae O
were O
selected O
as O
ROIs O
( O
AAL O
atlas O
) O
based O
on O
prior O
work O
implicating O
their O
involvement O
in O
the O
pathophysiology O
of O
stress O
, O
trauma O
exposure O
, O
and O
addiction O
. O

We O
examined O
connectivity O
for O
each O
side O
of O
the O
amygdala O
separately O
, O
as O
the O
human O
literature O
has O
documented O
differences O
in O
anatomical O
connections O
for O
the O
left O
and O
right O
amygdala O
. O

The O
resulting O
correlation O
map O
from O
each O
participant O
was O
converted O
to O
Z O
map O
using O
Fisher O
’ O
s O
r-to-z O
transformation O
in O
order O
to O
improve O
the O
normality O
of O
the O
correlation O
coefficients O
. O

The O
Z O
maps O
were O
then O
analyzed O
in O
a O
random-effects O
model O
in O
SPM8 O
to O
reveal O
any O
differences O
in O
RSFC O
between O
the O
Trauma O
and O
No-Trauma O
subgroups O
( O
see O
below O
for O
trauma-status O
determination O
) O
. O

In O
all O
the O
group O
analysis O
, O
mean O
FD O
was O
entered O
as O
a O
nuisance O
variable O
to O
control O
for O
participants O
’ O
head O
motion O
. O

Based O
on O
prior O
work O
, O
we O
further O
constrained O
the O
voxels O
that O
we O
queried O
in O
relation O
to O
the O
amygdala O
, O
based O
on O
a O
mask O
that O
includes O
mesolimbic O
regions O
( O
amygdala O
, O
ventral O
tegmental O
area/midbrain O
, O
ventral O
striatum O
, O
caudal O
orbitofrontal O
cortex O
) O
, O
and O
three O
other O
addiction-relevant O
regions O
including O
the O
insula O
, O
dorsal O
striatum O
, O
and O
thalamus O
. O

The O
mask O
including O
our O
a O
priori O
ROIs O
, O
was O
created O
using O
Harvard-Oxford O
Cortical O
Structural O
Atlas O
( O
FMRI O
of O
the O
Brain O
[ O
FMRIB O
] O
Software O
Library O
, O
Oxford O
Centre O
for O
FMIRB O
) O
with O
a O
probability O
threshold O
ranging O
between O
10–25 O
% O
. O

For O
the O
purposes O
of O
the O
current O
paper O
, O
this O
limbic O
mask O
is O
treated O
as O
the O
unit O
of O
analysis O
( O
a O
single O
region O
of O
interest O
) O
. O

Individual O
sub-group O
maps O
were O
thresholded O
at O
FWE O
corrected O
, O
p O
< O
0.05 O
, O
and O
the O
group O
contrast O
maps O
are O
cluster O
corrected O
at O
p O
< O
0.05 O
with O
425 O
contiguous O
voxels O
based O
on O
the O
recently O
debugged O
version O
of O
3dClustSim O
using O
autocorrelation O
function O
( O
ACF O
) O
option O
in O
AFNI_17.2.05 O
. O

ACF O
was O
calculated O
by O
running O
3dFWHMx O
on O
the O
residual O
image O
at O
group O
level O
. O

2.5 O
Trauma O
Versus O
No-Trauma O
Subgroups O
Of O
the O
34 O
participants O
, O
18 O
were O
designated O
to O
the O
“ O
Trauma O
” O
group O
while O
16 O
were O
designated O
as O
the O
“ O
No-Trauma O
” O
group O
. O

Determination O
of O
trauma O
status O
was O
based O
on O
participants O
’ O
response O
to O
two O
measures O
. O

The O
first O
was O
the O
ASI O
supplement O
– O
PTSD O
questionnaire O
, O
which O
probes O
whether O
one O
has O
‘ O
ever O
experienced O
something O
so O
frightening O
, O
horrible O
, O
or O
upsetting O
that O
others O
rarely O
go O
through O
’ O
. O

Prior O
studies O
have O
used O
the O
ASI O
to O
measure O
trauma O
exposure O
. O

Trauma O
status O
was O
further O
queried O
by O
participants O
’ O
responses O
to O
the O
clinician O
administered O
MINI O
, O
which O
assesses O
for O
trauma O
exposure O
as O
a O
preliminary O
criterion O
for O
PTSD O
diagnosis O
. O

All O
participants O
in O
the O
Trauma O
group O
endorsed O
trauma O
exposure O
on O
both O
the O
MINI O
and O
ASI O
. O

It O
is O
worth O
noting O
that O
, O
while O
the O
parent O
study O
excluded O
Axis-I O
diagnosis O
including O
PTSD O
, O
Trauma O
participants O
in O
this O
study O
endorsed O
trauma O
exposure O
but O
did O
not O
meet O
criteria O
for O
PTSD O
. O

Increased O
BOLD O
Signals O
Elicited O
by O
High O
Gamma O
Auditory O
Stimulation O
of O
the O
Left O
Auditory O
Cortex O
in O
Acute O
State O
Schizophrenia O
Recent O
MRI O
studies O
have O
shown O
that O
schizophrenia O
is O
characterized O
by O
reductions O
in O
brain O
gray O
matter O
, O
which O
progress O
in O
the O
acute O
state O
of O
the O
disease O
. O

Cortical O
circuitry O
abnormalities O
in O
gamma O
oscillations O
, O
such O
as O
deficits O
in O
the O
auditory O
steady O
state O
response O
( O
ASSR O
) O
to O
gamma O
frequency O
( O
> O
30-Hz O
) O
stimulation O
, O
have O
also O
been O
reported O
in O
schizophrenia O
patients O
. O

In O
the O
current O
study O
, O
we O
investigated O
neural O
responses O
during O
click O
stimulation O
by O
BOLD O
signals O
. O

We O
acquired O
BOLD O
responses O
elicited O
by O
click O
trains O
of O
20 O
, O
30 O
, O
40 O
and O
80-Hz O
frequencies O
from O
15 O
patients O
with O
acute O
episode O
schizophrenia O
( O
AESZ O
) O
, O
14 O
symptom-severity-matched O
patients O
with O
non-acute O
episode O
schizophrenia O
( O
NASZ O
) O
, O
and O
24 O
healthy O
controls O
( O
HC O
) O
, O
assessed O
via O
a O
standard O
general O
linear-model-based O
analysis O
. O

The O
AESZ O
group O
showed O
significantly O
increased O
ASSR-BOLD O
signals O
to O
80-Hz O
stimuli O
in O
the O
left O
auditory O
cortex O
compared O
with O
the O
HC O
and O
NASZ O
groups O
. O

In O
addition O
, O
enhanced O
80-Hz O
ASSR-BOLD O
signals O
were O
associated O
with O
more O
severe O
auditory O
hallucination O
experiences O
in O
AESZ O
participants O
. O

The O
present O
results O
indicate O
that O
neural O
over O
activation O
occurs O
during O
80-Hz O
auditory O
stimulation O
of O
the O
left O
auditory O
cortex O
in O
individuals O
with O
acute O
state O
schizophrenia O
. O

Given O
the O
possible O
association O
between O
abnormal O
gamma O
activity O
and O
increased O
glutamate O
levels O
, O
our O
data O
may O
reflect O
glutamate O
toxicity O
in O
the O
auditory O
cortex O
in O
the O
acute O
state O
of O
schizophrenia O
, O
which O
might O
lead O
to O
progressive O
changes O
in O
the O
left O
transverse O
temporal O
gyrus O
. O

Highlights O
We O
investigated O
neural O
responses O
during O
click O
stimulation O
by O
BOLD O
signals O
. O

We O
evaluated O
patients O
with O
acute O
and O
non-acute O
schizophrenia O
, O
and O
healthy O
controls O
. O

80-Hz O
auditory O
stimulation O
activated O
the O
left O
auditory O
cortex O
in O
acute O
schizophrenia O
. O

Our O
data O
may O
reflect O
left O
auditory O
cortex O
glutamate O
toxicity O
in O
acute O
schizophrenia O
. O

Recent O
MRI O
studies O
show O
that O
schizophrenia O
is O
characterized O
by O
reduced O
brain O
gray O
matter O
, O
which O
deteriorates O
in O
the O
acute O
state O
of O
the O
disease O
. O

Periodic O
auditory O
click O
trains O
elicit O
auditory O
steady-state O
responses O
( O
ASSRs O
) O
, O
and O
ASSR O
abnormalities O
are O
reported O
in O
schizophrenia O
. O

We O
investigated O
neural O
responses O
during O
click O
stimulation O
using O
BOLD O
signals O
, O
which O
may O
reflect O
glutamate O
toxicity O
. O

Compared O
with O
non-acute O
schizophrenia O
patients O
and O
healthy O
controls O
, O
acute O
episode O
schizophrenia O
patients O
showed O
significantly O
increased O
ASSR-BOLD O
to O
80-Hz O
stimuli O
in O
the O
left O
auditory O
cortex O
. O

Our O
data O
demonstrate O
neuronal O
over O
activation O
in O
terms O
of O
the O
BOLD O
pattern O
in O
acute O
state O
schizophrenia O
, O
which O
might O
reflect O
progressive O
volume O
reduction O
in O
the O
left O
superior O
temporal O
cortex O
by O
glutamate O
toxicity O
during O
the O
acute O
phase O
of O
schizophrenia O
. O

Materials O
& O
Methods O
Participants O
Demographic O
and O
clinical O
data O
are O
shown O
in O
Table O
1 O
. O

The O
sample O
consisted O
of O
24 O
HC O
, O
15 O
AESZ O
, O
and O
14 O
symptom-severity-matched O
NASZ O
subjects O
. O

All O
subjects O
had O
normal O
hearing O
, O
were O
between O
25 O
and O
59 O
years O
of O
age O
, O
and O
were O
right-handed O
. O

After O
receiving O
a O
complete O
description O
of O
the O
study O
, O
all O
participants O
signed O
an O
informed O
consent O
form O
according O
to O
the O
regulations O
of O
the O
Ethics O
Committee O
of O
the O
National O
Hospital O
Organization O
Hizen O
Psychiatric O
Center O
. O

Healthy O
controls O
were O
screened O
using O
the O
Structured O
Clinical O
Interview O
( O
SCID O
) O
-non-patient O
edition O
. O

No O
healthy O
controls O
or O
their O
first-degree O
relatives O
had O
an O
Axis-I O
psychiatric O
disorder O
. O

The O
exclusion O
criteria O
were O
: O
1 O
) O
neurological O
illness O
or O
major O
head O
trauma O
, O
2 O
) O
previous O
treatment O
with O
electroconvulsive O
therapy O
, O
3 O
) O
alcohol O
or O
drug O
dependence O
, O
4 O
) O
alcohol O
or O
drug O
abuse O
within O
the O
past O
5 O
years O
, O
and O
5 O
) O
a O
verbal O
intelligence O
quotient O
below O
75 O
. O

All O
patients O
were O
recruited O
from O
National O
Hospital O
Organization O
Hizen O
Psychiatric O
Center O
and O
were O
diagnosed O
based O
on O
the O
SCID-DSM O
IV-TR O
, O
Research O
Version O
and O
information O
from O
patient O
medical O
records O
. O

Based O
on O
previous O
studies O
, O
we O
operationally O
defined O
an O
acute O
exacerbation O
episode O
as O
that O
occurring O
within O
4 O
weeks O
of O
psychiatric O
hospitalization O
, O
and O
a O
non-acute O
phase O
as O
that O
occurring O
at O
least O
4 O
weeks O
after O
psychiatric O
hospitalization O
. O

All O
AESZ O
and O
11 O
NASZ O
participants O
were O
inpatients O
, O
and O
3 O
NASZ O
participants O
were O
outpatients O
. O

The O
patients O
were O
assessed O
using O
the O
Positive O
and O
Negative O
Syndrome O
Scale O
( O
PANSS O
) O
and O
the O
Brief O
Psychiatric O
Rating O
Scale O
( O
BPRS O
) O
. O

Stimuli O
and O
Procedure O
Following O
a O
hearing O
test O
, O
participants O
were O
asked O
to O
lay O
supine O
inside O
an O
MRI O
scanner O
while O
wearing O
head-phones O
. O

The O
head O
of O
each O
participant O
was O
restrained O
via O
padding O
behind O
the O
neck O
and O
between O
the O
head O
and O
the O
coil O
. O

Participants O
were O
asked O
to O
keep O
their O
head O
still O
inside O
the O
scanner O
and O
to O
focus O
on O
a O
fixation O
cross O
presented O
on O
a O
screen O
. O

All O
auditory O
stimuli O
were O
delivered O
binaurally O
through O
the O
head-phones O
. O

We O
presented O
auditory O
stimulation O
using O
a O
4-min-block-design O
paradigm O
with O
8 O
blocks O
of O
15 O
s O
of O
rest O
( O
stimulation O
OFF O
) O
and O
15 O
s O
of O
stimulation O
including O
15 O
click O
trains O
( O
stimulation O
ON O
) O
. O

In O
total O
, O
we O
presented O
120 O
click O
trains O
for O
each O
fMRI O
session O
. O

We O
conducted O
four O
fMRI O
sessions O
with O
different O
sound O
stimuli O
for O
each O
subject O
. O

The O
stimuli O
were O
1-ms O
clicks O
, O
presented O
binaurally O
as O
trains O
of O
clicks O
for O
each O
frequency O
( O
20 O
, O
30 O
, O
40 O
, O
and O
80-Hz O
) O
. O

Both O
the O
duration O
of O
the O
click O
trains O
and O
the O
inter-train O
interval O
were O
500 O
ms O
, O
and O
the O
click O
trains O
were O
presented O
with O
an O
intensity O
of O
80-dB O
sound O
pressure O
level O
. O

The O
order O
of O
sessions O
was O
counterbalanced O
across O
subjects O
. O

Data O
Acquisition O
We O
conducted O
MRI O
using O
a O
1.5-T O
Philips O
scanner O
with O
a O
standard O
head O
coil O
, O
located O
at O
the O
National O
Hospital O
Organization O
Hizen O
Psychiatric O
Center O
. O

We O
used O
standard O
sequence O
parameters O
to O
obtain O
functional O
images O
, O
as O
follows O
: O
gradient-echo O
echo-planar O
imaging O
( O
EPI O
) O
; O
repetition O
time O
( O
TR O
) O
= O
3000 O
ms O
; O
echo O
time O
( O
TE O
) O
= O
45 O
ms O
; O
flip O
angle O
= O
90° O
; O
field O
of O
view O
( O
FOV O
) O
= O
230 O
× O
230 O
mm O
; O
matrix O
= O
64 O
× O
64 O
; O
60 O
axial O
slices O
with O
a O
slice O
thickness O
of O
4 O
mm O
with O
no O
slice O
gap O
. O

We O
acquired O
a O
high-resolution O
T1-weighted O
3D O
anatomical O
image O
for O
each O
participant O
between O
the O
functional O
data O
trials O
. O

Image O
Processing O
Raw O
image O
DICOM O
files O
were O
converted O
to O
the O
NIFTI O
format O
using O
MRIConvert O
( O
Version O
2.0 O
, O
Lewis O
Center O
for O
Neuroimaging O
, O
Oregon O
) O
. O

Image O
processing O
and O
statistical O
analyses O
were O
performed O
using O
the O
statistical O
parametric O
mapping O
software O
SPM8 O
( O
Wellcome O
Department O
of O
Cognitive O
Neurology O
, O
London O
, O
United O
Kingdom O
) O
with O
Matlab O
R2014a O
( O
The O
Math O
Works O
Inc. O
, O
Natick O
, O
MA O
) O
. O

The O
first O
five O
volumes O
of O
each O
EPI O
image O
run O
were O
excluded O
to O
allow O
the O
MR O
signal O
to O
reach O
a O
state O
of O
equilibrium O
. O

All O
volumes O
of O
functional O
EPI O
images O
were O
realigned O
to O
the O
first O
volume O
of O
each O
session O
to O
correct O
for O
subject O
motion O
, O
and O
the O
mean O
functional O
EPI O
image O
was O
then O
spatially O
co-registered O
with O
the O
anatomical O
T1 O
images O
. O

Each O
co-registered O
T1-weighted O
anatomical O
image O
was O
normalized O
into O
a O
standard O
T1 O
template O
image O
( O
ICBM O
152 O
) O
, O
which O
defined O
the O
Montreal O
Neurological O
Institute O
( O
MNI O
) O
space O
. O

The O
parameters O
from O
this O
normalization O
process O
were O
then O
applied O
to O
each O
functional O
image O
. O

The O
normalized O
functional O
images O
were O
smoothed O
with O
a O
3D O
8-mm O
full-width O
half-maximum O
( O
FWHM O
) O
Gaussian O
Kernel O
. O

Time O
series O
data O
at O
each O
voxel O
were O
temporally O
filtered O
using O
a O
high O
pass O
filter O
with O
a O
cutoff O
of O
128 O
s. O
Statistical O
Analysis O
We O
used O
one-way O
analyses O
of O
variance O
( O
ANOVA O
) O
, O
chi-squared O
tests O
, O
and O
t-tests O
to O
assess O
group O
differences O
in O
the O
demographic O
variables O
. O

We O
performed O
fMRI O
statistical O
analysis O
on O
the O
preprocessed O
EPIs O
with O
the O
general O
linear O
model O
( O
GLM O
) O
using O
a O
two-level O
approach O
. O

The O
model O
consisted O
of O
boxcar O
functions O
convolved O
with O
the O
canonical O
hemodynamic O
response O
function O
, O
and O
then O
used O
as O
the O
regressors O
for O
the O
regression O
analysis O
. O

The O
six O
head O
motion O
parameters O
, O
derived O
from O
the O
realignment O
processing O
, O
were O
also O
used O
as O
regressors O
to O
reduce O
the O
motion O
related O
artifacts O
. O

On O
the O
first O
level O
of O
analysis O
, O
individual O
contrast O
images O
for O
each O
stimulus O
versus O
rest O
were O
computed O
and O
taken O
to O
the O
second O
level O
for O
random-effects O
inference O
. O

On O
the O
second O
level O
, O
contrast O
images O
for O
stimuli O
as O
the O
within-subject O
factors O
were O
submitted O
to O
three O
groups O
( O
HC O
, O
NASZ O
, O
AESZ O
) O
as O
the O
between-subject O
factors O
full-factorial O
ANOVA O
. O

All O
fMRI O
results O
are O
reported O
at O
a O
significance O
level O
of O
p O
< O
0.05 O
, O
family-wise O
error O
( O
FWE O
) O
-corrected O
( O
voxel-level O
corrected O
) O
, O
or O
p O
< O
0.05 O
, O
FWE O
cluster-corrected O
across O
the O
whole O
brain O
with O
the O
initial O
voxel O
threshold O
at O
p O
< O
0.001 O
, O
uncorrected O
. O

To O
determine O
the O
direction O
of O
the O
frequency-by-group O
interaction O
, O
we O
extracted O
contrast O
values O
by O
identifying O
the O
primary O
auditory O
cortex O
and O
Brodmann O
areas O
41 O
and O
42 O
as O
regions O
of O
interest O
( O
ROI O
) O
s O
using O
MarsBar O
( O
http O
: O
//marsbar.sourceforge.net O
) O
. O

We O
chose O
these O
areas O
because O
the O
ASSR O
is O
reportedly O
evoked O
in O
or O
near O
the O
primary O
auditory O
cortex O
. O

The O
resulting O
contrast O
values O
were O
subjected O
to O
ANOVA O
in O
SPSS O
with O
the O
three O
groups O
( O
HC O
, O
NASZ O
, O
AESZ O
) O
for O
each O
ROI O
, O
and O
we O
used O
Bonferroni O
post-hoc O
tests O
to O
test O
the O
differences O
between O
the O
groups O
. O

To O
visualize O
the O
time-course O
of O
the O
responses O
in O
each O
ROI O
, O
we O
fitted O
a O
finite O
impulse O
response O
( O
FIR O
) O
model O
in O
MarsBar O
to O
the O
data O
. O

This O
involved O
using O
a O
linear O
model O
to O
provide O
unbiased O
estimates O
of O
the O
average O
signal O
intensity O
at O
each O
time O
point O
without O
making O
a O
priori O
assumptions O
about O
the O
shape O
of O
the O
hemodynamic O
response O
( O
HDR O
) O
. O

We O
modeled O
seven O
time-windows O
of O
every O
3 O
s O
( O
corresponding O
to O
the O
TR O
) O
, O
time-locked O
to O
the O
onset O
of O
the O
first O
auditory O
stimulation O
. O

The O
average O
signal O
used O
in O
this O
calculation O
is O
based O
on O
frequency O
and O
is O
identified O
as O
the O
value O
of O
percent O
signal O
change O
for O
the O
mean O
column O
of O
the O
SPM O
regression O
analysis O
. O

We O
performed O
a O
repeated-measures O
ANOVA O
with O
time O
window O
( O
0–3 O
, O
3–6 O
, O
6–9 O
, O
9–12 O
, O
12–15 O
, O
15–18 O
, O
and O
18–21 O
s O
) O
as O
a O
within-subjects O
factor O
and O
group O
( O
HC O
, O
NASZ O
, O
AESZ O
) O
as O
a O
between-subjects O
factor O
. O

The O
resulting O
percent O
signal O
change O
values O
were O
subjected O
to O
a O
three O
group O
( O
HC O
, O
NASZ O
, O
AESZ O
) O
ANOVA O
in O
SPSS O
, O
and O
we O
used O
Bonferroni O
post-hoc O
tests O
to O
assess O
the O
differences O
between O
groups O
. O

We O
applied O
the O
Greenhouse–Geisser O
correction O
for O
inhomogeneity O
of O
variance O
for O
factors O
with O
> O
2 O
levels O
, O
as O
reflected O
in O
the O
reported O
p O
values O
. O

For O
the O
period O
with O
the O
largest O
main O
effect O
of O
group O
during O
auditory O
stimulation O
, O
we O
performed O
correlational O
analyses O
between O
hallucination O
scores O
in O
the O
PANSS O
( O
all O
AESZ O
patients O
had O
auditory O
hallucinations O
) O
and O
BOLD O
percent O
signal O
changes O
. O

Effect O
sizes O
are O
expressed O
as O
Cohen O
's O
d. O
The O
Spearman O
's O
rho O
was O
used O
for O
correlational O
analysis O
. O

For O
all O
statistical O
tests O
, O
α O
was O
0.05 O
. O

Identifying O
functional O
network O
changing O
patterns O
in O
individuals O
at O
clinical O
high-risk O
for O
psychosis O
and O
patients O
with O
early O
illness O
schizophrenia O
: O
A O
group O
ICA O
study O
Although O
individuals O
at O
clinical O
high O
risk O
( O
CHR O
) O
for O
psychosis O
exhibit O
a O
psychosis-risk O
syndrome O
involving O
attenuated O
forms O
of O
the O
positive O
symptoms O
typical O
of O
schizophrenia O
( O
SZ O
) O
, O
it O
remains O
unclear O
whether O
their O
resting-state O
brain O
intrinsic O
functional O
networks O
( O
INs O
) O
show O
attenuated O
or O
qualitatively O
distinct O
patterns O
of O
functional O
dysconnectivity O
relative O
to O
SZ O
patients O
. O

Based O
on O
resting-state O
functional O
magnetic O
imaging O
data O
from O
70 O
healthy O
controls O
( O
HCs O
) O
, O
53 O
CHR O
individuals O
( O
among O
which O
41 O
subjects O
were O
antipsychotic O
medication-naive O
) O
, O
and O
58 O
early O
illness O
SZ O
( O
ESZ O
) O
patients O
( O
among O
which O
53 O
patients O
took O
antipsychotic O
medication O
) O
within O
five O
years O
of O
illness O
onset O
, O
we O
estimated O
subject-specific O
INs O
using O
a O
novel O
group O
information O
guided O
independent O
component O
analysis O
( O
GIG-ICA O
) O
and O
investigated O
group O
differences O
in O
INs O
. O

We O
found O
that O
when O
compared O
to O
HCs O
, O
both O
CHR O
and O
ESZ O
groups O
showed O
significant O
differences O
, O
primarily O
in O
default O
mode O
, O
salience O
, O
auditory-related O
, O
visuospatial O
, O
sensory-motor O
, O
and O
parietal O
INs O
. O

Our O
findings O
suggest O
that O
widespread O
INs O
were O
diversely O
impacted O
. O

More O
than O
25 O
% O
of O
voxels O
in O
the O
identified O
significant O
discriminative O
regions O
( O
obtained O
using O
all O
19 O
possible O
changing O
patterns O
excepting O
the O
no-difference O
pattern O
) O
from O
six O
of O
the O
15 O
interrogated O
INs O
exhibited O
monotonically O
decreasing O
Z-scores O
( O
in O
INs O
) O
from O
the O
HC O
to O
CHR O
to O
ESZ O
, O
and O
the O
related O
regions O
included O
the O
left O
lingual O
gyrus O
of O
two O
vision-related O
networks O
, O
the O
right O
postcentral O
cortex O
of O
the O
visuospatial O
network O
, O
the O
left O
thalamus O
region O
of O
the O
salience O
network O
, O
the O
left O
calcarine O
region O
of O
the O
fronto-occipital O
network O
and O
fronto-parieto-occipital O
network O
. O

Compared O
to O
HCs O
and O
CHR O
individuals O
, O
ESZ O
patients O
showed O
both O
increasing O
and O
decreasing O
connectivity O
, O
mainly O
hypo-connectivity O
involving O
15 O
% O
of O
the O
altered O
voxels O
from O
four O
INs O
. O

The O
left O
supplementary O
motor O
area O
from O
the O
sensory-motor O
network O
and O
the O
right O
inferior O
occipital O
gyrus O
in O
the O
vision-related O
network O
showed O
a O
common O
abnormality O
in O
CHR O
and O
ESZ O
groups O
. O

Some O
brain O
regions O
also O
showed O
a O
CHR-unique O
alteration O
( O
primarily O
the O
CHR-increasing O
connectivity O
) O
. O

In O
summary O
, O
CHR O
individuals O
generally O
showed O
intermediate O
connectivity O
between O
HCs O
and O
ESZ O
patients O
across O
multiple O
INs O
, O
suggesting O
that O
some O
dysconnectivity O
patterns O
evident O
in O
ESZ O
predate O
psychosis O
in O
attenuated O
form O
during O
the O
psychosis O
risk O
stage O
. O

Hence O
, O
these O
connectivity O
measures O
may O
serve O
as O
possible O
biomarkers O
to O
predict O
schizophrenia O
progression O
. O

Highlights O
This O
is O
the O
first O
study O
exploring O
functional O
networks O
in O
clinical O
high O
risk O
for O
psychosis O
using O
ICA O
. O

Novel O
group O
information O
guided O
ICA O
was O
applied O
to O
accurately O
estimate O
networks O
. O

Multiple O
networks O
altered O
in O
early O
schizophrenia O
and O
clinical O
high O
risk O
groups O
. O

Some O
regions O
showed O
step-wise O
worsening O
of O
dysconnectivity O
from O
healthy O
condition O
to O
psychosis O
risk O
to O
schizophrenia O
. O

Early O
schizophrenia O
and O
psychosis O
risk O
groups O
also O
showed O
common O
abnormalities O
. O

Materials O
and O
methods O
Subjects O
We O
analyzed O
resting-state O
fMRI O
data O
from O
70 O
HCs O
, O
53 O
CHR O
individuals O
, O
and O
58 O
ESZ O
patients O
. O

Subject O
demographic O
and O
clinical O
information O
are O
presented O
in O
Table O
1 O
. O

There O
were O
no O
significant O
differences O
among O
the O
three O
groups O
in O
age O
or O
gender O
( O
see O
Table O
1 O
) O
. O

CHR O
individuals O
were O
recruited O
from O
a O
psychosis-risk O
research O
clinic O
at O
the O
University O
of O
California O
, O
San O
Francisco O
( O
UCSF O
) O
. O

Individuals O
recruited O
to O
the O
CHR O
group O
met O
the O
Criteria O
of O
Prodromal O
Syndromes O
( O
COPS O
) O
based O
on O
a O
Structured O
Interview O
for O
Prodromal O
Syndromes O
( O
SIPS O
) O
administered O
by O
trained O
clinicians O
. O

The O
COPS O
comprises O
three O
non-mutually O
exclusive O
syndromes O
: O
Attenuated O
Positive O
Symptom O
Syndrome O
( O
APSS O
) O
, O
Brief O
Intermittent O
Psychotic O
Syndrome O
( O
BIPS O
) O
, O
and/or O
Genetic O
Risk O
and O
Deterioration O
Syndrome O
( O
GRD O
) O
. O

In O
our O
study O
, O
the O
majority O
( O
49/53 O
, O
92.5 O
% O
) O
of O
CHR O
subjects O
met O
COPS O
criteria O
for O
APSS O
. O

Supplementary O
Table O
S1 O
shows O
the O
number O
and O
percentage O
of O
CHR O
subjects O
with O
each O
syndrome O
. O

Ratings O
of O
symptom O
severity O
in O
CHR O
individuals O
were O
obtained O
using O
the O
Scale O
of O
Prodromal O
Symptoms O
( O
SOPS O
) O
, O
an O
embedded O
scale O
within O
the O
SIPS O
. O

Most O
of O
the O
CHR O
subjects O
( O
41/53 O
; O
77 O
% O
) O
were O
antipsychotic O
medication-naive O
at O
the O
time O
of O
scanning O
. O

ESZ O
patients O
within O
five O
( O
mean O
± O
standard O
deviation O
= O
2.08 O
± O
1.37 O
) O
years O
of O
illness O
onset O
were O
recruited O
from O
an O
early O
psychosis O
clinic O
at O
UCSF O
and O
from O
community O
clinics O
. O

Diagnosis O
of O
schizophrenia O
or O
schizoaffective O
disorder O
in O
ESZ O
subjects O
was O
verified O
using O
the O
Structured O
Clinical O
Interview O
for O
DSM-IV O
( O
SCID O
) O
and O
symptom O
severity O
was O
assessed O
using O
the O
Positive O
and O
Negative O
Syndrome O
Scale O
( O
PANSS O
) O
. O

Most O
of O
the O
ESZ O
patients O
( O
53/58 O
; O
91 O
% O
) O
were O
taking O
antipsychotic O
medication O
at O
the O
time O
of O
testing O
. O

HC O
subjects O
were O
recruited O
from O
the O
community O
and O
did O
not O
meet O
current O
or O
lifetime O
criteria O
for O
major O
Axis O
I O
psychiatric O
disorders O
based O
on O
the O
SCID O
. O

The O
same O
data O
were O
analyzed O
using O
dynamic O
connectivity O
analysis O
in O
our O
previous O
study O
. O

MRI O
scan O
acquisition O
All O
brain O
images O
were O
acquired O
on O
a O
3 O
T O
Siemens O
TIM O
Trio O
scanner O
at O
the O
UCSF O
Neuroimaging O
Center O
. O

Resting-state O
scans O
were O
acquired O
using O
whole-brain O
echo-planar O
imaging O
( O
EPI O
) O
sequences O
. O

Rest O
scans O
lasted O
6 O
min O
, O
during O
which O
180 O
functional O
images O
were O
obtained O
( O
32 O
axial O
slices O
, O
3.5 O
mm O
slice O
thickness O
, O
1.05 O
mm O
inter-slice O
gap O
, O
TR O
= O
2 O
s O
, O
TE O
= O
29 O
ms O
, O
flip O
angle O
= O
75° O
, O
FOV O
= O
24 O
cm O
, O
64 O
× O
64 O
matrix O
) O
. O

Subjects O
were O
instructed O
to O
rest O
with O
their O
eyes O
closed O
and O
to O
stay O
awake O
. O

MRI O
data O
preprocessing O
FMRI O
data O
from O
each O
subject O
were O
preprocessed O
using O
Statistical O
Parametric O
Mapping O
( O
SPM8 O
) O
( O
http O
: O
//www.fil.ion.ucl.ac.uk/spm O
) O
. O

The O
first O
ten O
volumes O
were O
discarded O
to O
allow O
for O
T1 O
equilibration O
effects O
, O
and O
the O
remaining O
volumes O
in O
the O
run O
were O
then O
slice-time O
corrected O
and O
realigned O
to O
the O
first O
volume O
to O
correct O
for O
head O
motion O
. O

In O
terms O
of O
head O
motion O
, O
translations O
were O
< O
4 O
mm O
and O
rotations O
did O
not O
exceed O
4° O
in O
all O
axes O
over O
the O
entire O
fMRI O
run O
for O
all O
included O
subjects O
. O

There O
were O
no O
significant O
group O
differences O
( O
p O
> O
0.05 O
, O
tested O
by O
analysis O
of O
variance O
) O
in O
the O
motion O
parameters O
displayed O
in O
Table O
1 O
. O

Subsequently O
, O
the O
images O
were O
spatially O
normalized O
to O
the O
Montreal O
Neurological O
Institute O
( O
MNI O
) O
EPI O
template O
, O
resliced O
to O
3 O
mm O
× O
3 O
mm O
× O
3 O
mm O
voxels O
, O
and O
smoothed O
with O
a O
Gaussian O
kernel O
with O
a O
full-width O
at O
half-maximum O
( O
FWHM O
) O
of O
6 O
mm O
. O

Estimating O
intrinsic O
functional O
networks O
using O
GIG-ICA O
We O
applied O
GIG-ICA O
to O
the O
preprocessed O
fMRI O
data O
of O
all O
subjects O
to O
estimate O
each O
subject O
's O
INs O
, O
resulting O
in O
INs O
with O
correspondence O
across O
subjects O
while O
also O
retaining O
subject-specific O
network O
features O
. O

Our O
method O
primarily O
involved O
the O
following O
three O
steps O
. O

First O
, O
based O
on O
the O
temporally-concatenated O
fMRI O
data O
of O
181 O
subjects O
, O
ICA O
with O
the O
Infomax O
algorithm O
was O
used O
to O
estimate O
the O
group-level O
ICs O
. O

In O
order O
to O
decrease O
the O
influence O
of O
random O
initializations O
, O
we O
performed O
ICASSO O
with O
20 O
ICA O
runs O
followed O
by O
selection O
of O
the O
most O
reliable O
ICA O
run O
to O
obtain O
reliable O
group-level O
ICs O
. O

Before O
the O
group-level O
ICA O
, O
subject-level O
and O
group-level O
PCAs O
were O
applied O
to O
reduce O
the O
dimensionality O
of O
the O
fMRI O
data O
. O

In O
this O
study O
, O
the O
number O
of O
ICs O
was O
set O
to O
30 O
based O
on O
previous O
work O
, O
and O
the O
number O
of O
principle O
components O
used O
in O
the O
subject-level O
PCAs O
was O
specified O
as O
a O
greater O
number O
( O
i.e. O
, O
60 O
) O
as O
recommended O
. O

Thus O
, O
30 O
group O
-level O
ICs O
were O
obtained O
and O
Z-scored O
. O

It O
is O
worth O
noting O
that O
the O
sign O
of O
each O
resulting O
group-level O
IC O
is O
arbitrary O
. O

In O
our O
study O
, O
we O
computed O
the O
skewness O
of O
each O
IC O
and O
flipped O
the O
IC O
if O
its O
skewness O
was O
negative O
. O

Consequently O
, O
the O
positive O
Z-scores O
in O
each O
IC O
represented O
the O
voxels O
contributing O
the O
most O
to O
the O
associated O
network O
. O

Second O
, O
we O
manually O
identified O
the O
meaningful O
group-level O
networks O
after O
carefully O
inspecting O
all O
group-level O
ICs O
' O
spatial O
maps O
. O

If O
the O
primary O
activation O
of O
one O
IC O
's O
spatial O
map O
is O
located O
in O
gray O
matter O
, O
smooth O
and O
continuous O
, O
we O
preferred O
to O
regard O
it O
as O
an O
interesting O
functional O
network O
. O

Also O
, O
we O
referred O
to O
networks O
reported O
in O
previous O
studies O
to O
further O
confirm O
. O

The O
removed O
noise-related O
group-level O
ICs O
reflected O
head O
motion O
, O
physiological O
noise O
, O
and O
influence O
of O
scanner O
. O

Third O
, O
the O
remaining O
meaningful O
group-level O
ICs O
were O
characterized O
as O
the O
group-level O
INs O
and O
then O
used O
to O
calculate O
the O
subject-specific O
INs O
based O
on O
a O
multi-objective O
function O
optimization O
algorithm O
. O

GIG-ICA O
automatically O
yields O
Z-scored O
the O
subject-specific O
INs O
. O

Finally O
, O
a O
regression O
model O
was O
utilized O
to O
estimate O
the O
corresponding O
time O
courses O
( O
reflecting O
fluctuations O
) O
of O
the O
individual O
INs O
for O
each O
subject O
's O
fMRI O
data O
. O

It O
is O
known O
that O
for O
each O
voxel O
in O
a O
given O
individual O
IN O
, O
a O
positive O
Z-score O
indicates O
that O
the O
time O
series O
( O
after O
preprocessing O
) O
in O
the O
voxel O
has O
a O
positive O
correlation O
with O
the O
time O
course O
of O
the O
IN O
; O
in O
contrast O
a O
negative O
Z-score O
represents O
that O
the O
time O
series O
in O
the O
voxel O
has O
a O
negative O
correlation O
with O
the O
time O
course O
of O
the O
IN O
. O

Therefore O
, O
for O
one O
specific O
IN O
, O
a O
region O
containing O
voxels O
with O
high O
positive O
Z-scores O
( O
taking O
a O
region O
only O
including O
two O
voxels O
as O
an O
example O
, O
Z-scores O
of O
two O
voxels O
= O
10 O
and O
9 O
) O
tends O
to O
have O
stronger O
co-activation O
( O
i.e. O
, O
positive O
correlation O
) O
within O
the O
IN O
compared O
to O
a O
region O
containing O
voxels O
with O
low O
positive O
Z-scores O
( O
e.g. O
, O
Z-scores O
of O
two O
voxels O
= O
2 O
and O
1 O
) O
. O

In O
such O
case O
, O
the O
mean O
of O
the O
Z-scores O
in O
one O
region O
can O
reflect O
the O
co-activation O
extent O
of O
the O
region O
. O

In O
fact O
, O
if O
a O
region O
contains O
voxels O
with O
greater O
negative O
Z-scores O
( O
e.g. O
, O
Z-scores O
of O
two O
voxels O
= O
− O
10 O
and O
− O
9 O
) O
relative O
to O
the O
other O
region O
( O
e.g. O
, O
Z-scores O
of O
two O
voxels O
= O
− O
2 O
and O
− O
1 O
) O
, O
the O
former O
also O
tends O
to O
have O
stronger O
co-activation O
than O
the O
later O
. O

In O
this O
study O
, O
considering O
that O
the O
positive O
Z-scores O
contributing O
the O
most O
include O
important O
spatial O
maps O
in O
each O
IN O
, O
we O
focused O
on O
investigating O
group O
differences O
in O
voxels O
primarily O
associated O
with O
positive O
Z-scores O
to O
simplify O
the O
subsequent O
analyses O
. O

It O
is O
also O
worth O
pointing O
out O
that O
if O
one O
region O
includes O
both O
higher O
and O
lower O
positive O
Z-scores O
( O
e.g. O
, O
Z-scores O
of O
two O
voxels O
= O
10 O
and O
1 O
) O
compared O
to O
the O
other O
region O
( O
e.g. O
, O
Z-scores O
of O
two O
voxels O
= O
2 O
and O
8 O
) O
, O
we O
can O
not O
determine O
which O
region O
has O
greater O
co-activation O
using O
Z-scores O
. O

Therefore O
, O
in O
this O
work O
, O
we O
applied O
two-sample O
t-tests O
( O
rather O
than O
analysis O
of O
variance O
) O
to O
identify O
brain O
regions O
including O
voxels O
with O
consistent O
changing O
patterns O
between O
groups O
. O

Identifying O
significant O
discriminative O
regions O
in O
intrinsic O
functional O
networks O
Based O
on O
the O
estimated O
subject-specific O
INs O
, O
we O
investigated O
differences O
in O
each O
corresponding O
IN O
across O
the O
three O
groups O
in O
order O
to O
examine O
the O
network O
abnormalities O
of O
the O
ESZ O
and O
CHR O
group O
relative O
to O
each O
other O
and O
to O
the O
HC O
group O
. O

For O
each O
IN O
, O
we O
performed O
three O
analysis O
steps O
that O
include O
( O
1 O
) O
extracting O
important O
voxels O
positively O
contributing O
to O
the O
network O
( O
i.e. O
, O
voxels O
primarily O
involving O
positive O
Z-scores O
) O
and O
generating O
a O
network O
mask O
, O
( O
2 O
) O
identifying O
regions O
based O
on O
all O
possible O
19 O
inter-group O
changing O
patterns O
in O
the O
network O
mask O
, O
and O
( O
3 O
) O
investigating O
group O
differences O
in O
the O
co-activation O
of O
each O
significant O
discriminative O
region O
. O

We O
describe O
the O
detailed O
processing O
on O
each O
IC O
as O
follows O
. O

In O
the O
first O
step O
, O
for O
each O
voxel O
, O
a O
right-tailed O
one-sample O
t-test O
( O
p O
< O
0.01 O
with O
Bonferroni O
correction O
, O
i.e. O
, O
p O
< O
0.01/the O
number O
of O
voxels O
in O
a O
brain O
mask O
= O
0.01/69078 O
= O
1.45e O
− O
7 O
) O
was O
applied O
to O
the O
voxel O
's O
Z-scores O
from O
the O
corresponding O
subject-specific O
INs O
of O
all O
181 O
subjects O
to O
identify O
voxels O
whose O
Z-scores O
were O
positive O
in O
most O
of O
the O
subjects O
, O
resulting O
a O
network O
mask O
. O

The O
subsequent O
second O
and O
third O
steps O
were O
performed O
on O
the O
voxels O
in O
the O
network O
mask O
. O

Additionally O
, O
we O
tested O
if O
our O
strategy O
may O
fail O
to O
find O
group O
differences O
in O
some O
important O
voxels O
( O
or O
regions O
) O
showing O
positive O
Z-scores O
in O
one O
group O
( O
e.g. O
, O
HC O
) O
but O
not O
showing O
positive O
Z-scores O
in O
other O
groups O
( O
e.g. O
, O
CHR O
and O
ESZ O
) O
. O

So O
, O
we O
examined O
whether O
performing O
one-sample O
t-tests O
on O
each O
group O
separately O
may O
generate O
significantly O
different O
network O
masks O
compared O
to O
performing O
one-sample O
t-tests O
on O
all O
the O
three O
groups O
. O

For O
each O
group O
( O
e.g. O
, O
HC O
) O
, O
voxel-wise O
right-tailed O
one-sample O
t-tests O
were O
applied O
on O
the O
corresponding O
individual-subject O
's O
networks O
. O

The O
parameter O
( O
p O
< O
0.01 O
with O
Bonferroni O
correction O
, O
i.e. O
, O
p O
< O
0.01/the O
number O
of O
voxels O
in O
brain O
mask O
= O
0.01/69078 O
= O
1.45e O
− O
7 O
) O
used O
in O
one-sample O
t-tests O
on O
each O
group O
's O
subjects O
was O
as O
same O
as O
the O
parameter O
of O
one-sample O
t-tests O
on O
all O
subjects O
of O
three O
groups O
. O

We O
then O
combined O
the O
three O
masks O
obtained O
separately O
from O
the O
three O
groups O
in O
order O
to O
compare O
them O
with O
the O
mask O
obtained O
using O
the O
whole O
dataset O
. O

In O
the O
second O
step O
, O
we O
defined O
19 O
non-overlapping O
patterns O
( O
see O
Fig O
. O

1 O
) O
that O
reflect O
all O
possible O
significant O
differences O
among O
the O
three O
groups O
based O
on O
statistical O
analysis O
results O
from O
two-tailed O
two-sample O
t-tests O
, O
and O
then O
identified O
regions O
including O
voxels O
coinciding O
with O
each O
pattern O
. O

Specifically O
, O
for O
each O
significant O
voxel O
in O
the O
network O
mask O
identified O
, O
we O
performed O
two-tailed O
two-sample O
t-tests O
( O
p O
< O
0.05 O
) O
on O
its O
Z-score O
for O
three O
pairs O
of O
groups O
( O
HC O
vs. O
CHR O
, O
CHR O
vs. O
ESZ O
, O
and O
HC O
vs. O
ESZ O
) O
and O
then O
examined O
whether O
its O
Z-score O
exhibited O
one O
of O
19 O
characteristic O
patterns O
. O

Among O
the O
19 O
patterns O
, O
two O
patterns O
( O
Fig O
. O

1A–B O
) O
corresponded O
to O
strictly O
decreasing O
and O
strictly O
increasing O
Z-scores O
from O
HC O
to O
CHR O
to O
ESZ O
. O

For O
example O
, O
for O
the O
strictly O
decreasing O
pattern O
, O
t-value O
> O
0 O
was O
required O
for O
both O
the O
HC O
vs. O
CHR O
test O
and O
the O
CHR O
vs. O
ESZ O
test O
, O
reflecting O
significant O
decreases O
in O
Z-scores O
from O
the O
healthy O
condition O
to O
the O
psychosis-risk O
state O
and O
from O
the O
risk-state O
to O
full-blown O
schizophrenia O
. O

Four O
patterns O
( O
Fig O
. O

1C–F O
) O
involved O
situations O
where O
the O
ESZ O
or O
HC O
group O
was O
significantly O
lower O
or O
significantly O
higher O
than O
the O
other O
two O
groups O
. O

For O
example O
, O
in O
the O
ESZ-decreasing O
pattern O
, O
t-value O
> O
0 O
was O
required O
for O
both O
the O
HC O
vs. O
ESZ O
and O
CHR O
vs. O
ESZ O
comparisons O
, O
with O
no O
significant O
difference O
between O
the O
HC O
and O
CHR O
groups O
. O

Six O
additional O
patterns O
( O
Fig O
. O

2G–L O
) O
were O
CHR-unique O
alteration O
related O
patterns O
in O
which O
the O
CHR O
group O
had O
significantly O
lower O
or O
higher O
Z-scores O
than O
the O
other O
two O
groups O
. O

For O
example O
, O
in O
terms O
of O
the O
CHR-decreasing O
pattern O
1 O
( O
Fig O
. O

2G O
) O
, O
we O
required O
t-value O
> O
0 O
for O
the O
HC O
vs. O
CHR O
comparison O
as O
well O
as O
t-value O
< O
0 O
for O
the O
CHR O
vs. O
ESZ O
comparison O
, O
with O
no O
significant O
difference O
between O
the O
ESZ O
and O
HC O
groups O
. O

There O
were O
also O
six O
patterns O
( O
Fig O
. O

1M–R O
) O
in O
which O
only O
one O
pair O
of O
groups O
showed O
a O
group O
difference O
. O

Taking O
the O
HC O
> O
ESZ O
pattern O
for O
an O
example O
, O
t-value O
> O
0 O
for O
the O
HC O
vs. O
ESZ O
comparison O
and O
no O
group O
differences O
for O
other O
comparisons O
were O
required O
. O

Finally O
, O
a O
no-difference O
pattern O
( O
Fig O
. O

2S O
) O
was O
possible O
, O
where O
all O
three O
groups O
showed O
no O
significant O
differences O
( O
i.e. O
, O
p O
> O
0.05 O
for O
all O
comparisons O
) O
. O

Regarding O
each O
pattern O
, O
the O
associated O
voxels O
were O
identified O
and O
then O
corrected O
( O
p O
< O
0.05 O
) O
for O
multiple O
comparisons O
using O
Monte O
Carlo O
simulation O
( O
N O
= O
1000 O
) O
to O
obtain O
regions O
each O
of O
which O
were O
spatially O
continuous O
. O

Thus O
, O
each O
remaining O
region O
was O
required O
to O
have O
a O
size O
greater O
than O
a O
given O
voxel O
number O
that O
was O
determined O
by O
the O
threshold O
p O
< O
0.05 O
and O
the O
network O
mask O
from O
the O
voxel-wise O
one-sample O
t-tests O
using O
1000 O
Monte O
Carlo O
simulations O
. O

Except O
for O
the O
last O
pattern O
representing O
no O
significant O
difference O
across O
groups O
, O
we O
named O
the O
identified O
regions O
as O
significant O
discriminative O
regions O
( O
SDRs O
) O
within O
the O
associated O
INs O
. O

In O
our O
work O
, O
we O
applied O
two-tailed O
two-sample O
t-tests O
to O
define O
the O
changing O
patterns O
because O
we O
can O
not O
make O
a O
hypothesis O
that O
one O
group O
( O
e.g. O
, O
HC O
) O
shows O
higher O
( O
or O
lower O
) O
Z-scores O
in O
network O
than O
the O
other O
group O
( O
e.g. O
, O
CHR O
) O
. O

We O
are O
testing O
for O
the O
possibility O
of O
the O
relationship O
in O
both O
directions O
( O
i.e. O
, O
the O
possibility O
of O
one O
group O
shows O
higher O
and O
lower O
Z-scores O
than O
the O
other O
group O
) O
. O

In O
the O
third O
step O
, O
for O
each O
SDR O
including O
voxels O
with O
the O
same O
pattern O
in O
a O
specific O
IN O
, O
we O
tested O
whether O
its O
co-activation O
differed O
significantly O
among O
the O
HC O
, O
CHR O
and O
ESZ O
groups O
. O

Based O
on O
the O
results O
from O
the O
above O
mentioned O
voxel-wise O
two-sample O
t-tests O
of O
different O
voxels O
in O
one O
SDR O
, O
we O
applied O
a O
Fisher O
's O
combined O
probability O
test O
to O
measure O
the O
group O
difference O
of O
each O
SDR O
's O
co-activation O
, O
resulting O
in O
a O
combined O
p-value O
for O
any O
comparison O
between O
two O
groups O
( O
e.g. O
, O
HC O
vs. O
CHR O
) O
. O

Since O
Fisher O
's O
combined O
probability O
test O
was O
proposed O
originally O
under O
an O
assumption O
of O
independence O
among O
separate O
tests O
, O
we O
also O
performed O
a O
non-parametric O
combination O
method O
including O
10,000 O
permutations O
as O
a O
supplement O
. O

The O
non-parametric O
combination O
procedure O
works O
even O
when O
independence O
is O
untenable O
. O

The O
detailed O
steps O
for O
the O
non-parametric O
combination O
method O
are O
described O
in O
the O
Supplementary O
materials O
. O

If O
the O
combined O
p-value O
of O
one O
comparison O
between O
two O
groups O
was O
smaller O
than O
0.05/3 O
, O
we O
regarded O
the O
co-activation O
in O
SDR O
significantly O
different O
between O
the O
two O
groups O
. O

Additionally O
, O
since O
the O
mean O
Z-score O
within O
voxels O
of O
each O
SDR O
can O
be O
used O
to O
reflect O
co-activation O
strength O
in O
the O
SDR O
, O
we O
calculated O
the O
Pearson O
correlation O
between O
the O
co-activation O
strengths O
of O
each O
SDR O
within O
one O
specific O
IN O
and O
the O
symptom O
severity O
ratings O
( O
in O
Table O
1 O
) O
for O
the O
CHR O
group O
and O
the O
ESZ O
group O
to O
explore O
the O
association O
between O
network O
measures O
and O
symptoms O
. O

The O
significance O
level O
was O
set O
to O
p O
< O
0.05 O
for O
the O
correlation O
analyses O
. O

The O
whole O
analysis O
framework O
is O
shown O
in O
Fig O
. O

2 O
. O

We O
also O
tested O
if O
medication O
has O
significant O
effects O
on O
the O
identified O
measures O
showing O
group O
differences O
. O

First O
, O
we O
converted O
all O
anti-psychotic O
data O
to O
their O
respective O
chlorpromazine O
( O
CPZ O
) O
dosage O
equivalents O
for O
ESZ O
patients O
with O
available O
dose-level O
medication O
data O
. O

Only O
one O
ESZ O
patient O
had O
no O
CPZ O
data O
. O

We O
then O
used O
a O
non-parametric O
Spearman O
's O
rank O
correlation O
method O
to O
evaluate O
the O
association O
between O
the O
CPZ O
equivalent O
and O
the O
co-activation O
( O
reflected O
by O
the O
mean O
Z-score O
) O
of O
each O
SDR O
( O
p O
< O
0.05 O
with O
Bonferroni O
correction O
, O
i.e. O
, O
p-value O
threshold O
= O
0.05/the O
number O
of O
all O
SDRs O
) O
for O
ESZ O
patients O
. O

Spearman O
's O
rank O
correlation O
analysis O
was O
applied O
due O
to O
the O
non-normality O
of O
the O
CPZ O
variable O
. O

For O
CHR O
subjects O
, O
we O
did O
not O
perform O
correlation O
analysis O
on O
the O
CPZ O
equivalents O
due O
to O
the O
small O
number O
of O
the O
medicated O
CHR O
subjects O
and O
the O
relatively O
noisy O
property O
of O
CPZ O
equivalents O
. O

Instead O
, O
we O
examined O
difference O
in O
the O
co-activation O
of O
each O
SDR O
between O
the O
CHR O
individuals O
without O
medication O
treatment O
and O
the O
CHR O
individuals O
taking O
medication O
using O
a O
two-tailed O
two-sample O
t-test O
( O
p O
< O
0.05 O
with O
Bonferroni O
correction O
, O
i.e. O
, O
p-value O
threshold O
= O
0.05/the O
number O
of O
all O
SDRs O
) O
. O

Reduced O
interhemispheric O
executive O
control O
network O
coupling O
in O
men O
during O
early O
cocaine O
abstinence O
: O
A O
pilot O
study O
Background O
Individuals O
who O
use O
cocaine O
have O
fewer O
cognitive O
resources O
needed O
to O
maintain O
abstinence O
. O

This O
is O
evidenced O
by O
blunted O
brain O
function O
during O
cognitive O
control O
tasks O
and O
reduced O
communication O
between O
brain O
regions O
associated O
with O
cognitive O
function O
. O

For O
instance O
, O
relapse O
vulnerability O
is O
heightened O
in O
individuals O
with O
less O
communication O
between O
the O
right O
and O
left O
frontoparietal O
executive O
control O
network O
( O
ECN O
) O
. O

Given O
that O
recent O
cocaine O
use O
enhances O
such O
communication O
, O
it O
is O
plausible O
that O
recency O
of O
cocaine O
use O
influences O
interhemispheric O
ECN O
communication O
. O

However O
, O
it O
is O
unclear O
whether O
ECN O
communication O
weakens O
over O
the O
course O
of O
early O
cocaine O
abstinence O
, O
which O
may O
then O
enhance O
relapse O
risk O
. O

Methods O
In O
ten O
men O
with O
cocaine O
use O
disorder O
, O
we O
conducted O
a O
preliminary O
assessment O
of O
the O
relationship O
between O
the O
number O
of O
days O
since O
last O
cocaine O
use O
( O
1–3 O
days O
) O
and O
interhemispheric O
ECN O
coupling O
using O
resting O
state O
functional O
magnetic O
resonance O
imaging O
( O
fMRI O
) O
. O

Results O
Reduced O
interhemispheric O
ECN O
coupling O
was O
associated O
with O
increasing O
days O
since O
last O
cocaine O
use O
; O
weaker O
coupling O
was O
also O
associated O
with O
lower O
urine O
cocaine O
metabolite O
concentrations O
. O

This O
association O
was O
more O
prominent O
in O
prefrontal O
than O
parietal O
ECN-subregions O
. O

Conclusions O
Preliminary O
results O
indicate O
that O
resting O
state O
interhemispheric O
ECN O
coupling O
weakens O
within O
the O
first O
few O
days O
following O
last O
cocaine O
use O
. O

Because O
of O
the O
known O
link O
between O
reduced O
ECN O
interhemispheric O
coupling O
and O
relapse O
vulnerability O
, O
these O
results O
suggest O
that O
relapse O
risk O
may O
increase O
the O
longer O
an O
individual O
abstains O
during O
an O
early O
quit O
attempt O
. O

Treatments O
focused O
on O
reversing O
this O
coupling O
deficit O
may O
facilitate O
abstinence O
. O

2 O
. O

Material O
and O
Methods O
2.1 O
Participants O
Participants O
were O
ten O
treatment-seeking O
cocaine-using O
men O
who O
had O
a O
history O
of O
using O
cocaine O
via O
the O
smoked O
and O
intranasal O
routes O
. O

Eligibility O
criteria O
included O
current O
cocaine O
abuse O
or O
dependence O
per O
the O
Mini O
International O
Neuropsychiatric O
Interview O
( O
MINI O
) O
and O
DSM-IV-TR O
criteria O
, O
having O
used O
cocaine O
at O
least O
four O
times O
in O
the O
past O
month O
, O
and O
a O
urine O
sample O
positive O
for O
benzoylecgonine O
( O
BE O
; O
> O
300 O
ng/mL O
; O
Alere O
iScreen O
DX O
CLIA O
Waived O
12 O
Panel O
Instant O
Drug O
Test O
Dip O
Card O
) O
to O
verify O
recent O
cocaine O
use O
. O

Positive O
urine O
screens O
were O
then O
quantified O
for O
BE O
metabolite O
concentration O
( O
Quest O
Diagnostics O
, O
Cambridge O
, O
MA O
) O
; O
one O
data O
point O
was O
missing O
due O
to O
sample O
leakage O
during O
transit O
. O

Exclusion O
criteria O
included O
current O
DSM-IV-TR O
psychotic O
disorder O
or O
drug O
dependence O
( O
except O
cocaine O
, O
nicotine O
, O
marijuana O
, O
and O
alcohol O
) O
, O
magnetic O
resonance O
contraindications O
, O
head O
injury O
with O
cognitive O
impairments O
, O
and O
seizure O
or O
other O
neurological O
disorders O
. O

Participants O
provided O
informed O
consent O
for O
the O
study O
, O
and O
procedures O
were O
approved O
by O
the O
Partners O
Human O
Research O
Committee O
. O

2.2 O
Functional O
Magnetic O
Resonance O
Imaging O
( O
fMRI O
) O
Parameters O
Brain O
imaging O
data O
were O
collected O
on O
a O
Siemens O
3 O
Tesla O
TIM O
Trio O
MR O
imaging O
system O
( O
Erlangen O
, O
Germany O
) O
with O
a O
32-channel O
phased-array O
radio O
frequency O
head O
coil O
. O

High-resolution O
, O
multiecho O
multiplanar O
rapidly O
acquired O
gradient-echo O
( O
ME-MPRAGE O
) O
anatomical O
scans O
were O
collected O
with O
a O
T1-weighted O
scan O
with O
TR=2.1 O
sec O
, O
TE=3.3 O
msec O
, O
matrix O
size O
: O
256 O
× O
256 O
mm O
, O
flip O
angle O
: O
7° O
, O
128 O
slices O
, O
and O
1.0 O
× O
1.0 O
× O
1.33 O
mm O
voxels O
. O

Resting O
state O
fMRI O
scans O
were O
collected O
using O
multiband O
echo O
planar O
imaging O
with O
TR=0.72 O
sec O
, O
TE=32 O
msec O
, O
matrix O
size O
: O
85 O
× O
85 O
mm O
, O
flip O
angle O
: O
66° O
, O
64 O
slices O
, O
and O
2.5 O
mm3 O
voxels O
. O

Transversal O
interleaved O
slices O
were O
aligned O
to O
the O
anterior O
and O
posterior O
commissures O
with O
phase O
encoding O
from O
posterior O
to O
anterior O
to O
avoid O
prefrontal O
signal O
loss O
. O

During O
the O
6-minute O
fMRI O
scans O
, O
participants O
were O
instructed O
to O
keep O
their O
eyes O
open O
, O
look O
at O
a O
fixation O
cross O
on O
a O
screen O
, O
and O
remain O
as O
still O
as O
possible O
. O

2.3 O
fMRI O
Pre-processing O
and O
Denoising O
Data O
analysis O
was O
conducted O
using O
the O
Functional O
Magnetic O
Resonance O
Imaging O
of O
the O
Brain O
( O
FMRIB O
) O
Software O
Library O
( O
FSL O
; O
www.fmrib.ox.ac.uk/fsl O
) O
. O

Functional O
data O
preprocessing O
included O
deleting O
the O
first O
10 O
volumes O
, O
motion O
correction O
( O
MCFLIRT O
) O
, O
brain O
extraction O
( O
BET O
) O
, O
slice O
timing O
correction O
, O
spatial O
smoothing O
( O
Gaussian O
kernel O
of O
6 O
mm O
full-width O
half-maximum O
) O
, O
and O
Gaussian-weighted O
least-squares O
straight O
line O
fitting O
high-pass O
temporal O
filter O
( O
100 O
sec O
) O
. O

Denoising O
involved O
identifying O
and O
removing O
motion O
and O
other O
artifactual O
components O
from O
each O
participant O
’ O
s O
resting O
state O
data O
using O
Multivariate O
Exploratory O
Linear O
Decomposition O
into O
Independent O
Components O
( O
MELODIC O
) O
. O

After O
all O
independent O
components O
were O
identified O
in O
each O
participant O
, O
components O
were O
visually O
inspected O
for O
noise O
, O
and O
noise O
components O
were O
regressed O
out O
of O
the O
resting O
state O
data O
using O
fsl_regfilt O
. O

Individual O
participant O
data O
were O
affine-registered O
to O
standard O
space O
at O
2 O
× O
2 O
× O
2 O
mm O
resolution O
( O
MNI152 O
2 O
mm3 O
; O
Montreal O
Neurological O
Institute O
, O
Montreal O
, O
QC O
, O
Canada O
) O
using O
FLIRT O
. O

2.4 O
Interhemispheric O
Coupling O
The O
average O
time O
courses O
for O
each O
participant O
were O
extracted O
using O
fslmeants O
for O
each O
bilateral O
region O
of O
interest O
( O
ROIs O
) O
. O

The O
right O
and O
left O
ECN O
were O
defined O
using O
the O
frontoparietal O
ROIs O
in O
, O
Fig O
. O

1 O
. O
) O
. O

The O
lateralized O
masks O
were O
further O
divided O
to O
separately O
examine O
the O
ECN-subregions O
: O
PFC O
and O
PPC O
, O
which O
did O
not O
include O
overlap O
with O
the O
opposite O
hemisphere O
. O

For O
each O
ROI O
, O
the O
average O
time O
course O
was O
demeaned O
, O
detrended O
, O
and O
Hamming O
windowed O
. O

The O
time O
courses O
for O
the O
right O
and O
left O
ROIs O
were O
then O
time-lagged O
cross-correlated O
to O
establish O
one O
maximum O
correlation O
value O
( O
r O
) O
for O
each O
participant O
, O
which O
was O
exported O
to O
SPSS O
24 O
for O
further O
analysis O
. O

2.5 O
Measures O
and O
Data O
Analyses O
Participants O
completed O
demographics O
and O
substance O
use O
history O
questionnaires O
, O
and O
the O
Cocaine O
Craving O
Questionnaire O
– O
Brief O
. O

Two-tailed O
Spearman O
’ O
s O
rank O
order O
correlations O
were O
conducted O
to O
assess O
the O
a O
priori O
relationship O
between O
reduced O
interhemispheric O
ECN O
coupling O
and O
the O
number O
of O
days O
since O
last O
cocaine O
use O
. O

Relationships O
between O
recency O
of O
cocaine O
use O
and O
interhemispheric O
coupling O
were O
then O
examined O
separately O
for O
each O
ECN-subregion O
( O
PFC O
, O
PPC O
) O
. O

Aberrant O
perfusion O
and O
its O
connectivity O
within O
default O
mode O
network O
of O
first-episode O
drug-naïve O
schizophrenia O
patients O
and O
their O
unaffected O
first-degree O
relatives O
Neural O
substrates O
behind O
schizophrenia O
( O
SZ O
) O
and O
its O
heritability O
mediated O
by O
brain O
function O
are O
largely O
unknown O
. O

Cerebral O
blood O
flow O
( O
CBF O
) O
, O
as O
a O
biomarker O
of O
activation O
in O
the O
brain O
, O
reflects O
the O
neuronal O
metabolism O
, O
and O
is O
promisingly O
used O
to O
detect O
cerebral O
alteration O
thereby O
shedding O
light O
on O
the O
features O
of O
individuals O
at O
high O
genetic O
risk O
. O

We O
performed O
a O
cross-sectional O
functional O
magnetic O
resonance O
imaging O
( O
MRI O
) O
study O
enrolling O
45 O
first-episode O
drug-naïve O
patients O
with O
SZ O
, O
32 O
unaffected O
first-degree O
relatives O
of O
these O
patients O
, O
and O
51 O
healthy O
controls O
( O
HCs O
) O
. O

We O
examined O
CBF O
, O
CBF O
connectivity O
, O
and O
CBF O
topological O
properties O
. O

SZ O
patients O
showed O
increased O
CBF O
in O
the O
left O
medial O
superior O
frontal O
gyrus O
and O
right O
precuneus O
compared O
with O
HCs O
, O
and O
decreased O
CBF O
in O
the O
left O
middle O
temporal O
gyrus O
compared O
with O
their O
relatives O
. O

Furthermore O
, O
unaffected O
relatives O
revealed O
higher O
level O
of O
CBF O
pronounced O
in O
regions O
within O
default O
mode O
network O
( O
DMN O
) O
. O

Both O
SZ O
patients O
and O
their O
relatives O
exhibited O
dysconnectivity O
patterns O
. O

Notably O
, O
as O
for O
the O
network O
properties O
, O
unaffected O
relatives O
were O
with O
an O
intermediate O
level O
between O
SZ O
patients O
and O
HCs O
in O
the O
local O
efficiency O
and O
global O
efficiency O
. O

Our O
findings O
demonstrate O
the O
aberrant O
CBF O
of O
areas O
within O
DMN O
and O
the O
CBF O
connectivity O
pattern O
might O
be O
a O
familial O
feature O
in O
the O
brain O
of O
first-episode O
SZ O
patients O
and O
their O
relatives O
. O

Methods O
Participants O
This O
study O
was O
approved O
by O
the O
ethical O
committee O
of O
Xijing O
Hospital O
, O
and O
all O
participants O
provided O
written O
informed O
consent O
after O
complete O
description O
of O
the O
study O
. O

All O
experiments O
were O
performed O
in O
accordance O
with O
relevant O
guidelines O
and O
regulations O
. O

A O
total O
of O
demographically O
matched O
51 O
first-episode O
drug-naïve O
SZ O
patients O
, O
33 O
unaffected O
first-degree O
relatives O
of O
these O
SZ O
patients O
, O
and O
53 O
HCs O
were O
included O
in O
the O
experiment O
. O

In O
the O
subsequent O
analysis O
, O
six O
patients O
, O
one O
relative O
, O
and O
two O
HCs O
with O
excessive O
head O
motion O
( O
> O
3 O
mm O
translation O
and/or O
> O
3.0° O
rotation O
) O
were O
detected O
and O
then O
excluded O
from O
the O
current O
study O
. O

Subjects O
from O
our O
inpatient O
department O
or O
outpatient O
clinic O
were O
assessed O
according O
to O
the O
Diagnostic O
and O
Statistical O
Manual O
of O
Mental O
Disorders O
, O
Fourth O
Edition O
, O
Text O
Revision O
( O
DSM-IV-TR O
) O
criteria O
and O
consensus O
diagnoses O
of O
SZ O
were O
made O
using O
all O
the O
available O
information O
. O

This O
was O
based O
on O
the O
scores O
of O
the O
Positive O
And O
Negative O
Syndrome O
Scale O
( O
PANSS O
) O
( O
score O
≥ O
60 O
) O
at O
the O
time O
of O
scanning O
. O

The O
following O
exclusion O
criteria O
applied O
to O
all O
groups O
: O
history O
of O
significant O
neurological O
or O
systematic O
illness O
, O
diagnosis O
of O
substance O
abuse O
in O
the O
prior O
30 O
days O
or O
substance O
dependence O
in O
the O
prior O
6 O
months O
, O
another O
axis O
I O
or O
II O
psychiatric O
disorder O
, O
receiving O
antipsychotics O
and/or O
intervention O
using O
transcranial O
direct O
current O
stimulation O
, O
transcranial O
magnetic O
stimulation O
, O
electroconvulsive O
therapy O
or O
behavioral O
therapy O
, O
and O
pregnancy O
or O
MRI O
contraindications O
. O

The O
Prodromal O
Questionnaire O
was O
used O
to O
confirm O
the O
absence O
of O
any O
psychotic O
syndromes O
in O
relatives O
and O
HCs O
. O

Image O
acquisition O
As O
described O
previously O
, O
scanning O
was O
performed O
on O
a O
Siemens O
( O
Erlangen O
, O
Germany O
) O
3.0 O
T O
Trio O
MR O
scanner O
using O
the O
body O
coil O
for O
transmission O
and O
an O
eight O
channel O
head O
coil O
for O
reception O
. O

A O
10-min O
magnetization-prepared O
, O
rapid O
acquisition O
gradient O
echo O
( O
MPRAGE O
: O
192 O
slices O
, O
voxel O
size O
= O
1 O
× O
1 O
× O
1 O
mm3 O
, O
matrix O
= O
256 O
× O
256 O
, O
slice O
thickness O
= O
1 O
mm O
, O
gap O
= O
0 O
mm O
, O
FOV O
= O
256 O
× O
256 O
, O
repetition O
time O
= O
2530 O
ms O
, O
echo O
time O
= O
3.5 O
ms O
) O
image O
was O
first O
acquired O
. O

The O
resting-state O
perfusion O
imaging O
was O
performed O
using O
a O
pASL O
sequence O
( O
repetition O
time O
= O
2805 O
ms O
, O
echo O
time O
= O
13 O
ms O
, O
post-label O
delay O
= O
1800 O
ms O
, O
flip O
angle O
= O
90° O
; O
field O
of O
view O
= O
256 O
mm O
× O
256 O
mm O
; O
reconstruction O
matrix O
= O
256 O
× O
256 O
; O
slice O
thickness O
= O
3 O
mm O
, O
gap O
= O
0.75 O
mm O
; O
31 O
axial O
slices O
) O
. O

The O
acquisition O
time O
was O
4 O
min O
and O
20 O
s O
for O
the O
resting O
state O
ASL O
scan O
. O

During O
the O
ASL O
scan O
, O
all O
subjects O
were O
instructed O
to O
keep O
their O
eyes O
closed O
, O
relax O
and O
move O
as O
little O
as O
possible O
, O
think O
of O
nothing O
in O
particular O
, O
and O
not O
fall O
asleep O
. O

In O
order O
to O
avoid O
excessive O
head O
motion O
, O
we O
used O
a O
custom-built O
head O
cushion O
, O
reducing O
motion O
artifacts O
during O
acquisition O
. O

Thereafter O
, O
subjects O
with O
excessive O
head O
motion O
( O
> O
3 O
mm O
translation O
and/or O
3.0° O
rotation O
during O
scanning O
, O
as O
mentioned O
above O
) O
were O
excluded O
from O
the O
current O
study O
in O
order O
to O
control O
its O
potential O
confound O
effect O
. O

Additionally O
, O
we O
carefully O
checked O
images O
of O
each O
subject O
before O
further O
analysis O
, O
thereby O
ensuring O
the O
quality O
of O
data O
. O

CBF O
calculation O
As O
we O
performed O
recently O
, O
data O
analysis O
was O
implemented O
in O
Arterial O
Spin O
Labeling O
Perfusion O
MRI O
Signal O
Processing O
Toolbox O
( O
ASLtbx O
; O
http O
: O
//cfn.upenn.edu/~wangze/ASLtbx.php O
) O
in O
accordance O
with O
reports O
by O
Wang O
et O
al O
.. O

The O
detailed O
procedures O
, O
partly O
based O
on O
SPM12 O
( O
http O
: O
//www.fil.ion.ucl.ac.uk/spm/ O
) O
, O
included O
image O
reorientation O
, O
motion O
correction O
, O
coregistering O
to O
