each O
subject O
’ O
s O
anatomical O
image O
then O
to O
PET-perfusion O
templates O
and O
finally O
to O
Montreal O
Neurological O
Institute O
( O
MNI O
) O
space O
by O
means O
of O
Affine O
transformation O
, O
spatial O
smoothing O
using O
a O
6 O
mm O
full-width O
at O
half-maximum O
( O
FWHM O
) O
Gaussian O
kernel O
, O
removing O
non-brain O
tissue O
, O
as O
well O
as O
CBF O
quantification O
. O

CBF O
connectivity O
analysis O
CBF O
matrix O
computation O
, O
connectivity O
matrix O
construction O
, O
and O
graph O
analysis O
were O
performed O
in O
the O
experiment O
using O
the O
method O
by O
Melie-Garcia O
et O
al. O
, O
in O
which O
a O
full O
description O
of O
this O
approach O
is O
available O
. O

First O
, O
parcellation O
, O
with O
90 O
anatomical O
structures O
using O
the O
automated O
anatomical O
labeling O
( O
AAL O
) O
atlas O
, O
was O
conducted O
to O
the O
preceding O
preprocessed O
CBF O
images O
for O
all O
the O
participants O
, O
yielding O
a O
matrix O
with O
“ O
n O
” O
( O
number O
of O
participants O
) O
rows O
by O
90 O
columns O
. O

Second O
, O
we O
defined O
a O
connection O
as O
statistical O
associations O
in O
CBF O
between O
brain O
regions O
for O
a O
particular O
parcellation O
and O
then O
constructed O
CBF O
connectivity O
matrix O
. O

We O
also O
calculated O
the O
sparsity/density O
of O
these O
matrices O
. O

The O
sparsity O
or O
density O
of O
a O
network O
is O
a O
fraction O
of O
the O
number O
of O
edges O
to O
the O
possible O
number O
of O
edges O
when O
the O
network O
is O
fully O
connected O
. O

Finally O
, O
we O
estimated O
global O
network O
properties O
, O
including O
clustering O
index O
, O
characteristic O
path O
length O
, O
and O
local O
and O
global O
efficiencies O
, O
to O
characterize O
brain O
CBF O
network O
. O

Statistical O
analysis O
The O
group O
differences O
in O
CBF O
were O
compared O
in O
a O
voxel-wise O
manner O
using O
a O
one-way O
analysis O
of O
variance O
( O
ANOVA O
) O
and O
two-sample O
t-test O
. O

Multiple O
comparisons O
were O
corrected O
using O
an O
AlphaSim O
correction O
with O
a O
threshold O
of O
P O
< O
0.005 O
( O
cluster O
> O
27 O
) O
according O
to O
the O
Correction O
Thresholds O
by O
AlphaSim O
module O
of O
Resting-State O
fMRI O
Data O
Analysis O
Toolkit O
V1.8 O
( O
http O
: O
//www.restfmri.net/forum/REST_V1.8 O
) O
. O

For O
two-sample O
t-tests O
, O
we O
used O
a O
higher O
level O
of O
threshold O
, O
i.e. O
, O
P O
< O
0.005/3 O
( O
AlphaSim O
correction O
, O
cluster O
> O
27 O
) O
, O
due O
to O
comparisons O
for O
three O
times O
. O

For O
each O
subject O
, O
Pearson O
correlation O
coefficients O
between O
brain O
function O
measures O
of O
each O
cluster O
with O
a O
significant O
group O
difference O
and O
the O
severity O
of O
symptoms O
( O
PANSS O
scores O
) O
were O
separately O
computed O
for O
SZ O
patient O
group O
. O

Correlation O
analyses O
were O
performed O
with O
SPSS O
software O
( O
version O
13.0 O
, O
SPSS O
, O
Inc. O
) O
. O

Significance O
was O
set O
at O
P O
< O
0.05 O
. O

For O
CBF O
connectivity O
, O
Fisher O
’ O
s O
z O
test O
was O
then O
used O
to O
compare O
correlations O
between O
two O
groups O
( O
http O
: O
//www.fon.hum.uva.nl/Service/Statistics/Two_Correlations.html O
) O
. O

Graph-based O
analysis O
of O
brain O
connectivity O
in O
schizophrenia O
The O
present O
study O
evaluated O
brain O
connectivity O
using O
electroencephalography O
( O
EEG O
) O
data O
from O
14 O
patients O
with O
schizophrenia O
and O
14 O
healthy O
controls O
. O

Phase-Locking O
Value O
( O
PLV O
) O
, O
Phase-Lag O
Index O
( O
PLI O
) O
and O
Directed O
Transfer O
Function O
( O
DTF O
) O
were O
calculated O
for O
the O
original O
EEG O
data O
and O
following O
current O
source O
density O
( O
CSD O
) O
transformation O
, O
re-referencing O
using O
the O
average O
reference O
electrode O
( O
AVERAGE O
) O
and O
reference O
electrode O
standardization O
techniques O
( O
REST O
) O
. O

The O
statistical O
analysis O
of O
adjacency O
matrices O
was O
carried O
out O
using O
indices O
based O
on O
graph O
theory O
. O

Both O
CSD O
and O
REST O
reduced O
the O
influence O
of O
volume O
conducted O
currents O
. O

The O
largest O
group O
differences O
in O
connectivity O
were O
observed O
for O
the O
alpha O
band O
. O

Schizophrenic O
patients O
showed O
reduced O
connectivity O
strength O
, O
as O
well O
as O
a O
lower O
clustering O
coefficient O
and O
shorter O
characteristic O
path O
length O
for O
both O
measures O
of O
phase O
synchronization O
following O
CSD O
transformation O
or O
REST O
re-referencing O
. O

Reduced O
synchronization O
was O
accompanied O
by O
increased O
directional O
flow O
from O
the O
occipital O
region O
for O
the O
alpha O
band O
. O

Following O
the O
REST O
re-referencing O
, O
the O
sources O
of O
alpha O
activity O
were O
located O
at O
parietal O
rather O
than O
occipital O
derivations O
. O

The O
results O
of O
PLV O
and O
DTF O
demonstrated O
group O
differences O
in O
fronto-posterior O
asymmetry O
following O
CSD O
transformation O
, O
while O
for O
PLI O
the O
differences O
were O
significant O
only O
using O
REST O
. O

The O
only O
analysis O
that O
identified O
group O
differences O
in O
inter-hemispheric O
asymmetry O
was O
DTF O
calculated O
for O
REST O
. O

Our O
results O
suggest O
that O
a O
comparison O
of O
different O
connectivity O
measures O
using O
graph-based O
indices O
for O
each O
frequency O
band O
, O
separately O
, O
may O
be O
a O
useful O
tool O
in O
the O
study O
of O
disconnectivity O
disorders O
such O
as O
schizophrenia O
. O

Materials O
and O
methods O
Participant O
recruitment O
The O
study O
comprised O
of O
14 O
patients O
( O
7 O
males O
: O
27.9 O
± O
3.3 O
years O
, O
7 O
females O
: O
28.3 O
± O
4.1 O
years O
) O
with O
paranoid O
schizophrenia O
, O
who O
were O
hospitalized O
at O
the O
Institute O
of O
Psychiatry O
and O
Neurology O
in O
Warsaw O
, O
Poland O
, O
and O
14 O
healthy O
controls O
( O
7 O
males O
: O
26.8 O
± O
2.9 O
, O
7 O
females O
: O
28.7 O
± O
3.4 O
years O
) O
. O

The O
patients O
met O
International O
Classification O
of O
Diseases O
ICD–10 O
criteria O
for O
paranoid O
schizophrenia O
( O
category O
F20.0 O
) O
. O

Study O
protocol O
was O
approved O
by O
the O
Ethics O
Committee O
of O
the O
Institute O
of O
Psychiatry O
and O
Neurology O
in O
Warsaw O
. O

All O
participants O
received O
a O
written O
description O
of O
the O
protocol O
and O
provided O
written O
consent O
to O
take O
part O
in O
this O
study O
. O

Inclusion O
criteria O
were O
: O
a O
minimum O
age O
of O
18 O
, O
ICD-10 O
diagnosis O
F20.0 O
, O
and O
medication O
washout O
period O
of O
a O
minimum O
of O
seven O
days O
. O

Exclusion O
criteria O
were O
: O
pregnancy O
, O
organic O
brain O
pathology O
, O
severe O
neurological O
diseases O
( O
e.g O
. O

epilepsy O
, O
Alzheimer O
’ O
s O
, O
or O
Parkinson O
disease O
) O
, O
presence O
of O
a O
general O
medical O
condition O
, O
and O
very O
early O
stage O
of O
schizophrenia O
, O
i.e. O
, O
first O
episode O
of O
schizophrenia O
. O

The O
control O
group O
was O
matched O
in O
gender O
and O
age O
to O
the O
14 O
patients O
completing O
the O
study O
. O

EEG O
recording O
and O
preprocessing O
Fifteen O
minutes O
of O
EEG O
data O
were O
recorded O
in O
all O
subjects O
during O
an O
eyes-closed O
resting O
state O
condition O
. O

Data O
were O
acquired O
with O
the O
sampling O
frequency O
of O
250 O
Hz O
using O
the O
standard O
10–20 O
EEG O
montage O
with O
19 O
EEG O
channels O
: O
Fp1 O
, O
Fp2 O
, O
F7 O
, O
F3 O
, O
Fz O
, O
F4 O
, O
F8 O
, O
T3 O
, O
C3 O
, O
Cz O
, O
C4 O
, O
T4 O
, O
T5 O
, O
P3 O
, O
Pz O
, O
P4 O
, O
T6 O
, O
O1 O
, O
O2 O
. O

The O
reference O
electrode O
was O
placed O
at O
FCz O
. O

EEG O
analysis O
was O
carried O
out O
using O
thirty O
second O
segments O
without O
artefacts O
( O
i.e O
. O

eye O
movements O
, O
cardiac O
activity O
, O
muscle O
contractions O
) O
. O

Then O
, O
the O
signals O
of O
each O
EEG O
channel O
were O
filtered O
using O
a O
Butterworth O
filter O
of O
order O
2 O
in O
the O
following O
physiological O
frequency O
bands O
: O
2–4 O
Hz O
( O
delta O
) O
, O
4.5–7.5 O
Hz O
( O
theta O
) O
, O
8–12.5 O
Hz O
( O
alpha O
) O
, O
13–30 O
Hz O
( O
beta O
) O
, O
30–45 O
Hz O
( O
gamma O
) O
. O

EEG O
analysis O
was O
carried O
out O
using O
the O
raw O
EEG O
data O
, O
as O
well O
as O
the O
re-referenced O
data O
relative O
to O
scalp O
surface O
Laplacian O
estimators O
( O
commonly O
referred O
to O
as O
current O
source O
density O
( O
CSD O
) O
) O
, O
the O
average O
reference O
electrode O
( O
AVERAGE O
) O
, O
and O
the O
reference O
electrode O
standardization O
techniques O
( O
REST O
) O
. O

This O
permitted O
us O
to O
examine O
the O
potential O
effect O
of O
reference O
electrode O
choice O
on O
connectivity O
results O
. O

CSD O
transformation O
was O
calculated O
using O
the O
CSD O
Toolbox O
, O
which O
allows O
for O
estimation O
of O
surface O
potentials O
using O
a O
spherical O
spline O
algorithm O
. O

REST O
was O
carried O
out O
using O
the O
REST O
Toolbox O
( O
http O
: O
//www.neuro.uestc.edu.cn/rest/ O
) O
. O

REST O
is O
a O
method O
that O
allows O
for O
the O
transformation O
of O
original O
EEG O
data—with O
the O
reference O
electrode O
placed O
at O
an O
arbitrary O
point O
on O
the O
head—to O
a O
new O
dataset O
with O
the O
reference O
at O
infinity O
and O
the O
potential O
at O
zero O
or O
a O
constant O
. O

The O
procedure O
is O
based O
on O
the O
calculation O
of O
the O
leadfield O
matrix O
for O
the O
canonical O
concentric-three-spheres O
head O
model O
. O

The O
current O
widely O
recommended O
reference O
is O
the O
REST O
. O

It O
was O
shown O
that O
the O
relative O
error O
of O
REST O
is O
always O
smaller O
than O
AVERAGE O
and O
it O
decreases O
by O
increasing O
the O
number O
of O
channels O
in O
contrast O
to O
the O
error O
of O
AVERAGE O
. O

Moreover O
, O
considering O
that O
the O
CSD O
transform O
is O
free O
from O
reference O
effects O
, O
we O
expected O
a O
greater O
correlation O
between O
CSD O
and O
REST O
than O
between O
CSD O
and O
another O
reference O
electrode O
. O

Connectivity O
measures O
EEG O
data O
were O
analyzed O
using O
three O
connectivity O
methods O
: O
Phase-Locking O
Value O
, O
Phase-Lag O
Index O
, O
and O
Directed O
Transfer O
Function O
, O
as O
well O
as O
indices O
based O
on O
graph O
theory O
. O

Below O
, O
is O
the O
brief O
theoretical O
basis O
for O
each O
method O
. O

Phase-locking O
value O
The O
amplitude O
A O
( O
t O
) O
and O
the O
instantaneous O
phase O
Ф O
( O
t O
) O
of O
a O
signal O
s O
( O
t O
) O
can O
be O
estimated O
using O
the O
Hilbert O
transform O
H O
{ O
· O
} O
: O
The O
analytic O
signal O
z O
( O
t O
) O
can O
be O
understood O
as O
an O
embedding O
of O
the O
one O
dimensional O
time-series O
in O
the O
two O
dimensional O
complex O
plane O
. O

The O
phase O
is O
computed O
by O
the O
following O
expression O
: O
The O
phase O
synchronization O
is O
defined O
as O
the O
locking O
of O
phases O
of O
two O
oscillators O
: O
where O
Φ1 O
( O
t O
) O
and O
Φ2 O
( O
t O
) O
denote O
the O
phases O
of O
the O
oscillators O
, O
and O
Φ12 O
( O
t O
) O
is O
defined O
as O
their O
relative O
phase O
. O

The O
phase-locking O
value O
( O
PLV O
) O
is O
defined O
as O
: O
where O
i–imaginary O
unit O
; O
N–the O
total O
number O
of O
samples O
; O
Φ12 O
–the O
relative O
phase O
of O
two O
signals O
; O
Δt–time O
between O
the O
successive O
samples O
j O
from O
1 O
to O
N-1 O
. O

The O
value O
of O
PLV O
is O
bounded O
between O
zero O
and O
one O
with O
zero O
indicating O
unsynchronized O
phases O
and O
one O
indicating O
when O
the O
phase O
difference O
is O
constant O
, O
i.e O
. O

the O
synchronization O
of O
signals O
is O
perfect O
. O

A O
decrease O
of O
the O
phase-locking O
value O
between O
two O
signals O
indicates O
a O
loss O
of O
synchronization O
between O
them O
. O

Phase-Lag O
Index O
Phase-Lag O
Index O
( O
PLI O
) O
was O
introduced O
to O
reduce O
the O
impact O
of O
common O
sources O
( O
e.g. O
, O
volume O
conduction O
and/or O
active O
reference O
electrodes O
in O
the O
case O
of O
EEG O
) O
in O
the O
estimation O
of O
phase O
synchronization O
. O

An O
asymmetry O
index O
for O
the O
distribution O
of O
phase O
differences O
centered O
around O
0 O
mod O
π O
, O
is O
defined O
as O
: O
where–π O
< O
ΔΦ O
( O
tn O
) O
≤ O
π O
, O
n O
= O
1…N O
is O
a O
time O
series O
of O
phase O
differences O
. O

The O
PLI O
ranges O
between O
zero O
and O
one O
, O
with O
zero O
indicating O
either O
no O
coupling O
or O
coupling O
with O
a O
phase O
difference O
centered O
around O
0 O
mod O
π O
, O
and O
one O
indicating O
perfect O
phase O
locking O
at O
a O
value O
of O
ΔΦ O
different O
from O
0 O
mod O
π O
. O

Directed O
Transfer O
Function O
Directed O
Transfer O
Function O
( O
DTF O
) O
is O
a O
measure O
based O
on O
Granger O
Causality O
, O
but O
defined O
in O
the O
frequency O
domain O
: O
For O
a O
multivariate O
k-channel O
process O
: O
X O
( O
t O
) O
= O
( O
X1 O
( O
t O
) O
, O
X2 O
( O
t O
) O
, O
… O
, O
Xk O
( O
t O
) O
) O
, O
the O
multivariate O
autoregressive O
model O
takes O
the O
form O
: O
where O
E O
( O
t O
) O
is O
a O
k–dimensional O
vector O
, O
is O
a O
square O
k O
x O
k O
matrix O
. O

Transforming O
the O
multivariate O
autoregressive O
model O
to O
the O
frequency O
domain O
we O
obtain O
: O
The O
matrix O
of O
coefficients O
H O
is O
called O
the O
transfer O
matrix O
. O

The O
Directed O
Transfer O
Function O
is O
defined O
as O
a O
normalized O
version O
of O
the O
transfer O
matrix O
: O
The O
following O
relation O
should O
be O
satisfied O
to O
guarantee O
the O
quality O
of O
fitting O
of O
the O
model O
: O
where O
N O
is O
the O
window O
length O
; O
d O
is O
the O
model O
order O
; O
and O
k O
is O
the O
number O
of O
EEG O
channels O
. O

The O
model O
order O
was O
estimated O
using O
the O
Akaike O
information O
criterion O
. O

In O
this O
paper O
the O
model O
order O
d O
was O
set O
to O
10 O
. O

Graph O
analysis O
All O
of O
the O
measures O
( O
PLV O
, O
PLI O
, O
DTF O
) O
were O
calculated O
from O
30-second O
EEG O
epochs O
subdivided O
into O
three O
consecutive O
10-second O
trials O
. O

For O
each O
connectivity O
measure O
, O
matrices O
of O
significant O
connections O
( O
the O
so-called O
adjacency O
matrices O
) O
were O
produced O
for O
each O
frequency O
band O
separately O
, O
as O
well O
as O
for O
whole O
spectrum O
, O
and O
used O
as O
weighted O
adjacency O
matrices O
. O

To O
assure O
the O
correct O
estimation O
of O
the O
autoregressive O
model O
, O
the O
DTF O
was O
calculated O
in O
the O
whole O
frequency O
band O
, O
and O
then O
the O
adjacency O
matrices O
were O
identified O
for O
individual O
frequency O
bands O
separately O
. O

The O
adjacency O
matrices O
were O
analyzed O
using O
indices O
based O
on O
graph O
theory O
. O

In O
graph O
theory O
, O
the O
brain O
is O
modeled O
as O
a O
graph O
composed O
of O
nodes O
, O
representing O
brain O
regions O
or O
EEG O
channels O
, O
and O
undirected O
or O
directed O
links O
between O
them O
, O
representing O
functional O
connections O
determined O
by O
PLV O
, O
PLI O
and O
DTF O
. O

The O
connectivity O
measures O
were O
calculated O
using O
algorithms O
included O
in O
the O
MATLAB O
Toolbox—HERMES O
( O
http O
: O
//hermes.ctb.upm.es O
) O
, O
while O
the O
graph-based O
indices O
were O
calculated O
using O
MATLAB O
functions O
embedded O
in O
the O
Brain O
Connectivity O
Toolbox O
( O
http O
: O
//www.brain-connectivity-toolbox.net O
) O
. O

For O
each O
of O
the O
obtained O
graphs O
, O
the O
following O
indices O
were O
calculated O
: O
( O
1 O
) O
basic O
measures O
( O
i.e. O
, O
density O
, O
degree O
, O
and O
strength O
) O
; O
( O
2 O
) O
measure O
of O
integration O
( O
i.e. O
, O
characteristic O
path O
length O
) O
; O
( O
3 O
) O
measure O
of O
segregation O
( O
i.e. O
, O
clustering O
coefficient O
) O
. O

Additionally O
, O
measures O
of O
asymmetry O
( O
i.e. O
, O
DFP O
, O
IFP O
, O
DLR O
, O
ILR O
) O
were O
calculated O
. O

The O
degree O
of O
an O
individual O
node O
is O
equal O
to O
the O
number O
of O
links O
connected O
to O
that O
node O
, O
which O
, O
in O
practice O
, O
is O
also O
equal O
to O
the O
number O
of O
neighbors O
of O
the O
node O
. O

Individual O
values O
of O
the O
degree O
therefore O
reflect O
the O
relative O
importance O
of O
a O
node O
in O
the O
network O
. O

The O
mean O
network O
degree O
is O
commonly O
used O
as O
a O
measure O
of O
the O
graph O
density O
, O
or O
of O
the O
total O
“ O
wiring O
cost O
” O
of O
the O
network O
. O

The O
directed O
variant O
of O
the O
degree O
distinguishes O
the O
number O
of O
inward O
links O
from O
the O
number O
of O
outward O
links O
, O
while O
the O
weighted O
variant O
of O
the O
degree O
, O
termed O
the O
strength O
, O
is O
defined O
as O
the O
sum O
of O
all O
neighboring O
link O
weights O
. O

Measures O
of O
integration O
estimate O
the O
ease O
of O
communication O
between O
distributed O
nodes O
. O

Specifically O
, O
the O
characteristic O
path O
length O
is O
defined O
as O
the O
average O
shortest O
path O
length O
between O
all O
pairs O
of O
nodes O
in O
the O
network O
. O

Measures O
of O
segregation O
characterize O
the O
ability O
for O
specialized O
processing O
within O
densely O
interconnected O
groups O
of O
nodes O
( O
clusters O
or O
modules O
) O
. O

The O
clustering O
coefficient O
is O
defined O
as O
the O
fraction O
of O
the O
node O
's O
neighbors O
that O
are O
also O
neighbors O
of O
each O
other O
. O

Displacement O
and O
influence O
were O
introduced O
to O
analyze O
asymmetry O
between O
frontal O
and O
posterior O
parts O
of O
brain O
, O
as O
well O
as O
between O
left O
and O
right O
hemispheres O
. O

These O
measures O
are O
defined O
as O
follows O
: O
where O
D–displacement O
; O
I–influence O
; O
k–number O
of O
all O
EEG O
channels O
, O
i.e O
. O

the O
number O
of O
rows O
or O
columns O
in O
the O
connectivity O
matrix O
; O
kF−number O
of O
connections O
within O
the O
frontal O
half O
of O
the O
brain O
( O
the O
first O
k/2 O
rows O
and O
the O
first O
k/2 O
columns O
of O
connectivity O
matrix O
) O
; O
kP−number O
of O
connections O
within O
the O
posterior O
half O
of O
the O
brain O
( O
the O
last O
k/2 O
rows O
and O
the O
last O
k/2 O
columns O
) O
; O
kP→F−number O
of O
connections O
from O
posterior O
to O
frontal O
areas O
of O
the O
brain O
( O
the O
first O
k/2 O
rows O
and O
the O
last O
k/2 O
columns O
of O
connectivity O
matrix O
) O
; O
kF→P−number O
of O
connections O
from O
frontal O
to O
posterior O
areas O
of O
the O
brain O
( O
the O
last O
k/2 O
rows O
and O
the O
first O
k/2 O
columns O
of O
connectivity O
matrix O
) O
. O

By O
analogy O
, O
the O
measures O
of O
asymmetry O
between O
the O
left O
and O
right O
hemispheres O
( O
DLR O
, O
ILR O
) O
are O
defined O
. O

Statistical O
analysis O
In O
the O
adjacency O
matrix O
, O
only O
the O
connectivity O
values O
above O
a O
significance O
threshold O
of O
0.05 O
were O
considered O
, O
while O
all O
non-significant O
values O
were O
set O
to O
zero O
. O

The O
significance O
of O
the O
connectivity O
values O
was O
determined O
by O
surrogate O
data O
analysis O
. O

The O
surrogate O
data O
method O
involves O
maintaining O
the O
amplitudes O
while O
destroying O
the O
phase O
relationship O
between O
the O
original O
signals O
by O
randomly O
shuffling O
the O
data O
in O
the O
frequency O
domain O
and O
then O
transforming O
them O
back O
to O
the O
time O
domain O
. O

The O
significance O
was O
tested O
by O
comparing O
values O
from O
the O
original O
data O
to O
values O
obtained O
from O
surrogate O
data O
. O

The O
number O
of O
surrogates O
, O
which O
were O
calculated O
for O
each O
signal O
, O
was O
100 O
. O

To O
evidence O
different O
connectivity O
patterns O
between O
the O
two O
groups O
( O
i.e. O
, O
healthy O
persons O
and O
patients O
with O
schizophrenia O
) O
a O
three-way O
ANOVA O
model O
was O
separately O
applied O
to O
the O
following O
indices O
for O
each O
metric O
: O
degree O
and O
strength O
. O

The O
ANOVA O
had O
the O
following O
factors O
: O
Group O
, O
Band O
( O
delta O
; O
theta O
; O
alpha O
; O
beta O
; O
gamma O
) O
, O
and O
EEG O
channels O
( O
system O
of O
19 O
channels O
: O
Fp1 O
, O
Fp2 O
, O
F7 O
, O
F3 O
, O
Fz O
, O
F4 O
, O
F8 O
, O
T3 O
, O
C3 O
, O
Cz O
, O
C4 O
, O
T4 O
, O
T5 O
, O
P3 O
, O
Pz O
, O
P4 O
, O
T6 O
, O
O1 O
, O
and O
O2 O
) O
. O

Moreover O
, O
a O
two-way O
ANOVA O
model O
with O
variables O
: O
Group O
and O
EEG O
channels O
, O
was O
analyzed O
for O
the O
same O
indices O
in O
each O
band O
separately O
. O

A O
two-way O
ANOVA O
model O
with O
variables O
: O
Group O
and O
Band O
, O
was O
analyzed O
for O
density O
, O
characteristic O
path O
length O
, O
clustering O
coefficient O
, O
displacement O
and O
influence O
. O

In O
case O
of O
significant O
effects O
, O
post O
hoc O
tests O
( O
Bonferroni O
correction O
) O
were O
performed O
. O

The O
statistical O
threshold O
was O
set O
at O
p O
< O
0.05 O
, O
with O
correction O
for O
multiple O
comparisons O
by O
controlling O
the O
family O
wise O
error O
( O
FWE O
) O
. O

Altered O
intrinsic O
and O
extrinsic O
connectivity O
in O
schizophrenia O
Schizophrenia O
is O
a O
disorder O
characterized O
by O
functional O
dysconnectivity O
among O
distributed O
brain O
regions O
. O

However O
, O
it O
is O
unclear O
how O
causal O
influences O
among O
large-scale O
brain O
networks O
are O
disrupted O
in O
schizophrenia O
. O

In O
this O
study O
, O
we O
used O
dynamic O
causal O
modeling O
( O
DCM O
) O
to O
assess O
the O
hypothesis O
that O
there O
is O
aberrant O
directed O
( O
effective O
) O
connectivity O
within O
and O
between O
three O
key O
large-scale O
brain O
networks O
( O
the O
dorsal O
attention O
network O
, O
the O
salience O
network O
and O
the O
default O
mode O
network O
) O
in O
schizophrenia O
during O
a O
working O
memory O
task O
. O

Functional O
MRI O
data O
during O
an O
n-back O
task O
from O
40 O
patients O
with O
schizophrenia O
and O
62 O
healthy O
controls O
were O
analyzed O
. O

Using O
hierarchical O
modeling O
of O
between-subject O
effects O
in O
DCM O
with O
Parametric O
Empirical O
Bayes O
, O
we O
found O
that O
intrinsic O
( O
within-region O
) O
and O
extrinsic O
( O
between-region O
) O
effective O
connectivity O
involving O
prefrontal O
regions O
were O
abnormal O
in O
schizophrenia O
. O

Specifically O
, O
in O
patients O
( O
i O
) O
inhibitory O
self-connections O
in O
prefrontal O
regions O
of O
the O
dorsal O
attention O
network O
were O
decreased O
across O
task O
conditions O
; O
( O
ii O
) O
extrinsic O
connectivity O
between O
regions O
of O
the O
default O
mode O
network O
was O
increased O
; O
specifically O
, O
from O
posterior O
cingulate O
cortex O
to O
the O
medial O
prefrontal O
cortex O
; O
( O
iii O
) O
between-network O
extrinsic O
connections O
involving O
the O
prefrontal O
cortex O
were O
altered O
; O
( O
iv O
) O
connections O
within O
networks O
and O
between O
networks O
were O
correlated O
with O
the O
severity O
of O
clinical O
symptoms O
and O
impaired O
cognition O
beyond O
working O
memory O
. O

In O
short O
, O
this O
study O
revealed O
the O
predominance O
of O
reduced O
synaptic O
efficacy O
of O
prefrontal O
efferents O
and O
afferents O
in O
the O
pathophysiology O
of O
schizophrenia O
. O

Highlights O
A O
first O
use O
of O
hierarchical O
modeling O
of O
effective O
connectivity O
to O
characterize O
large-scale O
networks O
in O
schizophrenia O
. O

Intrinsic O
and O
extrinsic O
effective O
connectivity O
involving O
prefrontal O
regions O
were O
abnormal O
in O
schizophrenia O
. O

Diagnostic O
connections O
could O
predict O
the O
severity O
of O
clinical O
symptoms O
and O
cognition O
in O
schizophrenia O
. O

Materials O
and O
methods O
Participants O
Patients O
with O
schizophrenia O
were O
recruited O
from O
the O
Department O
of O
Psychiatry O
, O
Renmin O
Hospital O
of O
Wuhan O
University O
( O
Wuhan O
, O
China O
) O
. O

The O
Structured O
Clinical O
Interview O
for O
the O
Diagnostic O
and O
Statistical O
Manual O
of O
Mental O
Disorder O
, O
4th O
edition O
( O
DSM-IV O
) O
( O
SCID O
) O
was O
administered O
, O
to O
confirm O
diagnosis O
. O

The O
patients O
also O
met O
the O
following O
inclusion O
criteria O
: O
( O
1 O
) O
the O
total O
score O
of O
Positive O
and O
Negative O
Syndrome O
Scale O
( O
PANSS O
) O
was O
over O
60 O
, O
( O
2 O
) O
duration O
of O
illness O
was O
< O
5 O
years O
, O
( O
3 O
) O
18–45 O
years O
of O
age O
, O
( O
4 O
) O
at O
least O
9 O
years O
of O
education O
, O
( O
5 O
) O
right-handed O
, O
and O
( O
6 O
) O
Han O
Chinese O
. O

Patients O
were O
excluded O
if O
they O
met O
the O
diagnosis O
criteria O
of O
any O
other O
DSM O
Axis-I O
disorders O
, O
had O
severe O
physical O
illness O
including O
cardiovascular O
disease O
, O
had O
received O
electroconvulsive O
therapy O
six O
months O
prior O
to O
recruitment O
, O
or O
had O
structural O
changes O
in O
the O
brain O
( O
such O
as O
a O
white O
matter O
lesion O
) O
diagnosed O
by O
a O
radiologist O
. O

Healthy O
controls O
were O
recruited O
by O
word O
of O
mouth O
and O
bulletin O
board O
postings O
both O
in O
the O
hospital O
and O
nearby O
communities O
. O

The O
healthy O
controls O
, O
who O
matched O
the O
patients O
on O
age O
, O
gender O
and O
educational O
level O
, O
had O
the O
same O
inclusion O
and O
exclusion O
criteria O
; O
except O
that O
healthy O
controls O
were O
excluded O
if O
they O
or O
their O
first-relatives O
met O
any O
diagnosis O
of O
a O
psychiatric O
disorder O
according O
to O
the O
DSM-IV O
criteria O
. O

Fifty-one O
patients O
and O
66 O
healthy O
controls O
were O
recruited O
. O

All O
the O
patients O
were O
receiving O
antipsychotic O
medications O
, O
which O
were O
converted O
to O
their O
chlorpromazine O
equivalents O
. O

Six O
patients O
and O
4 O
healthy O
controls O
were O
excluded O
from O
the O
data O
analyses O
due O
to O
severe O
head O
motion O
during O
scanning O
( O
x O
, O
y O
, O
z O
translation O
> O
3 O
mm O
or O
x O
, O
y O
, O
z O
rotation O
> O
3° O
) O
, O
3 O
patients O
were O
excluded O
due O
to O
extremely O
high O
values O
in O
the O
mean O
frame O
displacement O
( O
FD O
) O
value O
and O
2 O
patients O
were O
excluded O
due O
to O
extreme O
low O
scores O
in O
the O
0-back O
performance O
( O
see O
details O
in O
Methodology O
) O
. O

Finally O
, O
40 O
patients O
and O
62 O
normal O
controls O
were O
included O
in O
the O
following O
data O
analyses O
. O

Each O
participant O
or O
at O
least O
one O
first-degree O
relative O
for O
each O
patient O
provided O
informed O
consent O
before O
participation O
. O

The O
Ethics O
Committee O
of O
Renmin O
Hospital O
of O
Wuhan O
University O
and O
the O
Institutional O
Review O
Board O
of O
the O
Institute O
of O
Psychology O
, O
Chinese O
Academy O
of O
Sciences O
approved O
the O
study O
. O

Experimental O
design O
and O
task O
The O
WM O
paradigm O
used O
a O
blocked O
design O
, O
numeric O
n-back O
task O
, O
with O
numbers O
0–9 O
as O
stimuli O
, O
which O
has O
been O
used O
in O
previous O
studies O
. O

The O
paradigm O
alternated O
between O
rest O
and O
task O
. O

Rest O
periods O
, O
in O
which O
subjects O
were O
instructed O
to O
fixate O
on O
a O
cross O
at O
the O
centre O
of O
the O
screen O
, O
lasted O
for O
5 O
scans O
( O
i.e O
. O

10 O
s O
) O
. O

The O
task O
consisted O
of O
two O
conditions O
, O
0-back O
( O
baseline O
) O
and O
2-back O
( O
WM O
load O
condition O
) O
, O
arranged O
as O
0-2-0-0-2-2-2-0-0-2-2-0 O
, O
each O
with O
duration O
of O
12 O
scans O
( O
i.e O
. O

24 O
s O
) O
. O

Before O
each O
block O
a O
visual O
cue O
of O
one O
scan O
( O
i.e O
. O

2 O
s O
) O
was O
presented O
, O
indicating O
the O
condition O
of O
the O
subsequent O
block O
. O

Each O
block O
comprised O
12 O
stimuli O
, O
three O
of O
which O
were O
targets O
, O
each O
presented O
for O
1000 O
ms O
with O
a O
1000 O
ms O
interstimulus O
interval O
. O

Subjects O
were O
instructed O
to O
match O
the O
current O
number O
to O
a O
target O
, O
either O
the O
number O
9 O
( O
0-back O
) O
or O
the O
number O
presented O
two O
trials O
earlier O
( O
2-back O
) O
. O

In O
order O
to O
ensure O
compliance O
during O
the O
subsequent O
acquisition O
, O
a O
training O
session O
was O
conducted O
prior O
to O
scanning O
. O

The O
training O
procedure O
was O
the O
same O
as O
that O
used O
in O
our O
previous O
study O
. O

In O
brief O
, O
the O
training O
task O
was O
similar O
to O
the O
formal O
task O
, O
though O
only O
one O
0-back O
and O
one O
2-back O
trial O
were O
included O
. O

Accuracy O
was O
displayed O
on O
the O
monitor O
at O
the O
end O
of O
the O
practice O
task O
, O
and O
patients O
were O
provided O
with O
further O
practice O
opportunities O
, O
until O
they O
clearly O
understood O
the O
task O
. O

Cognition O
assessments O
Several O
cognitive O
assessments O
were O
conducted O
outside O
of O
scanning O
. O

These O
included O
the O
Digit O
Symbol O
Coding O
task O
, O
Digit O
Span O
( O
forward O
and O
backward O
) O
and O
Category O
Fluency O
test O
. O

The O
Digit O
Symbol O
Coding O
task O
assesses O
information O
processing O
speed O
and O
is O
known O
to O
detect O
impairments O
in O
schizophrenia O
reliably O
. O

The O
Category O
Fluency O
test O
is O
the O
cognitive O
assessment O
with O
the O
second O
largest O
effect O
size O
, O
followed O
by O
the O
Digit O
Symbol O
Coding O
task O
. O

The O
Digit O
Span O
( O
forward O
and O
backward O
) O
is O
a O
general O
assessment O
of O
attention O
and O
working O
memory O
capacity O
. O

MRI O
data O
acquisition O
and O
preprocessing O
MRI O
data O
were O
acquired O
from O
the O
Radiology O
Department O
of O
Renmin O
Hospital O
of O
Wuhan O
University O
with O
a O
General O
Electric O
HDxt O
3.0T O
Scanner O
. O

Whole-brain O
functional O
scans O
were O
collected O
in O
32 O
axial O
slices O
using O
an O
echo-planar O
imaging O
( O
EPI O
) O
sequence O
( O
repetition O
time O
= O
2000 O
ms O
, O
echo O
time O
= O
30 O
ms O
; O
flip O
angle O
= O
90° O
; O
matrix O
= O
64 O
× O
64 O
; O
field O
of O
view O
= O
220 O
mm O
× O
220 O
mm O
; O
slice O
thickness O
= O
4 O
mm O
; O
and O
slice O
gap O
= O
0.6 O
mm O
) O
. O

Anatomical O
images O
were O
acquired O
using O
a O
high-resolution O
T1-weighted O
sequence O
( O
repetition O
time O
= O
7.8 O
ms O
; O
echo O
time O
= O
3.0 O
ms O
; O
flip O
angle O
= O
7° O
; O
matrix O
= O
256 O
× O
256 O
; O
field O
of O
view O
= O
256 O
× O
256 O
mm2 O
; O
slice O
thickness O
= O
1 O
mm O
) O
composed O
of O
188 O
slices O
in O
a O
sagittal O
orientation O
. O

Initial O
image O
preprocessing O
was O
performed O
using O
Statistical O
Parametric O
Mapping O
( O
SPM12 O
) O
( O
http O
: O
//www.fil.ion.ucl.ac.uk/spm/ O
) O
and O
included O
slice O
timing O
correction O
, O
motion O
correction O
, O
structural O
and O
functional O
image O
co-registration O
, O
segmentation O
, O
normalization O
( O
based O
on O
each O
participant O
's O
structural O
image O
) O
to O
the O
Montreal O
Neurological O
Institute O
( O
MNI O
) O
152 O
template O
, O
and O
smoothing O
using O
a O
kernel O
with O
a O
full-width O
half O
maximum O
of O
6 O
mm O
. O

The O
normalized O
images O
were O
interpolated O
to O
a O
resolution O
of O
3 O
× O
3 O
× O
3 O
mm3 O
. O

Furthermore O
, O
based O
on O
the O
head O
motion O
parameters O
obtained O
after O
realignment O
, O
we O
computed O
the O
volume-based O
frame-wise O
displacement O
( O
FD O
) O
to O
quantify O
head O
motion O
. O

Behavioral O
analysis O
To O
assess O
behavioral O
performance O
of O
the O
n-back O
task O
, O
the O
sensitivity O
index O
, O
d′ O
from O
signal O
detection O
theory O
was O
used O
. O

The O
score O
d′ O
describes O
sensitivity O
; O
i.e. O
, O
the O
ability O
to O
separate O
signal O
( O
“ O
true O
” O
events O
) O
and O
noise O
( O
“ O
false O
” O
events O
) O
. O

The O
score O
was O
computed O
separately O
for O
0-back O
condition O
and O
2-back O
condition O
( O
d′0 O
and O
d′2 O
) O
for O
each O
participant O
. O

A O
repeated O
measures O
ANOVA O
with O
conditions O
as O
within-group O
factor O
and O
diagnosis O
as O
between-group O
factor O
was O
conducted O
using O
SPSS O
20.0 O
. O

Two O
sample O
t-tests O
were O
used O
to O
assess O
group O
differences O
in O
the O
Digit O
Symbol O
Coding O
task O
, O
Digit O
Span O
task O
and O
Category O
Fluency O
task O
. O

GLM O
analysis O
A O
general O
linear O
model O
( O
GLM O
) O
was O
constructed O
with O
regressors O
for O
each O
of O
the O
two O
task O
conditions O
( O
0-back O
and O
2-back O
) O
as O
well O
as O
the O
instruction O
cues O
for O
the O
task O
blocks O
. O

To O
regress O
out O
motion O
and O
physiological O
noise O
( O
e.g. O
, O
of O
cardiac O
and O
respiratory O
origin O
) O
, O
additional O
covariates O
were O
included O
to O
model O
: O
( O
1 O
) O
six O
head O
motion O
parameters O
obtained O
by O
rigid O
body O
head O
motion O
correction O
and O
( O
2 O
) O
five O
principal O
components O
from O
an O
anatomically O
defined O
noise O
VOI O
( O
composed O
of O
white O
matter O
and O
cerebrospinal O
fluid O
) O
, O
an O
approach O
that O
has O
been O
shown O
to O
accurately O
describe O
physiological O
noise O
in O
grey O
matter O
. O

Finally O
, O
a O
highpass O
filter O
with O
a O
cutoff O
of O
250 O
s O
( O
0.004 O
Hz O
) O
was O
implemented O
to O
remove O
low O
frequency O
drifts O
while O
retaining O
most O
task-related O
frequencies O
. O

At O
the O
group O
level O
, O
random-effects O
group O
analyses O
were O
conducted O
using O
an O
ANOVA O
, O
with O
diagnosis O
as O
a O
between-group O
factor O
and O
task O
condition O
as O
a O
within-group O
factor O
. O

If O
not O
mentioned O
otherwise O
, O
significant O
effects O
in O
fMRI O
analyses O
were O
defined O
by O
a O
corrected O
voxel-level O
family-wise O
error O
( O
FWE O
) O
threshold O
of O
p O
< O
0.05 O
. O

Dynamic O
causal O
modeling O
VOI O
selections O
Regions O
that O
showed O
differential O
activation O
between O
the O
patients O
and O
control O
groups O
in O
the O
context O
of O
WM O
( O
i.e. O
, O
a O
significant O
interaction O
between O
diagnosis O
and O
task O
) O
or O
activation/deactivation O
in O
association O
with O
the O
task O
( O
i.e. O
, O
a O
significant O
main O
effect O
of O
task O
) O
were O
considered O
as O
volumes O
of O
interest O
( O
VOI O
) O
for O
use O
in O
subsequent O
DCM O
analysis O
. O

Furthermore O
, O
in O
order O
to O
focus O
on O
the O
three O
networks O
of O
interest O
, O
i.e. O
, O
dorsal O
attention O
network O
( O
DAN O
) O
, O
salience O
network O
( O
SN O
) O
, O
and O
default-mode O
network O
( O
DMN O
) O
, O
preexisting O
templates O
were O
used O
as O
masks O
to O
identify O
peak O
voxels O
in O
the O
core O
regions O
in O
each O
of O
the O
three O
networks O
. O

This O
procedure O
defined O
four O
nodes O
for O
the O
DAN O
: O
the O
bilateral O
frontal O
eye O
field O
( O
FEF O
) O
and O
the O
bilateral O
superior O
parietal O
lobule O
( O
SPL O
) O
; O
three O
nodes O
for O
the O
SN O
: O
the O
SMA/ACC O
, O
the O
left O
anterior O
insula O
( O
AI O
) O
and O
the O
right O
AI O
; O
two O
nodes O
for O
the O
DMN O
: O
the O
medial O
prefrontal O
cortex O
( O
MPFC O
) O
and O
the O
posterior O
cingulate O
cortex O
( O
PCC O
) O
. O

The O
group-level O
VOI O
locations O
are O
listed O
in O
Table O
2 O
. O

These O
were O
obtained O
by O
intersecting O
functional O
defined O
templates O
with O
regions O
showing O
a O
significant O
interaction O
between O
diagnosis O
and O
task O
or O
main O
effect O
of O
task O
at O
a O
lesser O
conservative O
threshold O
of O
cluster-level O
FWE O
p O
< O
0.05 O
( O
cluster-defining O
threshold O
p O
= O
0.001 O
) O
. O

We O
then O
searched O
for O
the O
local O
maximum O
within O
the O
group-level O
VOI O
and O
summarized O
the O
regional O
response O
with O
the O
first O
eigenvariate O
of O
( O
confound-corrected O
) O
voxels O
within O
a O
6 O
mm O
radius O
. O

For O
the O
participants O
in O
which O
no O
supra-threshold O
voxels O
were O
identified O
, O
the O
first O
eigenvariate O
was O
extracted O
from O
a O
6 O
mm O
sphere O
centered O
at O
the O
group-level O
maximum O
. O

Individual O
level O
DCM O
specification O
and O
inversion O
DCM O
is O
a O
framework O
for O
specifying O
, O
estimating O
and O
comparing O
generative O
models O
of O
imaging O
time O
series O
. O

Here O
we O
used O
the O
basic O
( O
deterministic O
) O
model O
for O
fMRI O
, O
in O
which O
a O
vector O
z O
∈ O
ℝn O
represents O
mass O
neural O
activity O
of O
each O
brain O
region O
at O
a O
given O
time O
. O

The O
derivative O
of O
z O
with O
respect O
to O
time O
can O
be O
written O
as O
: O
where O
u O
is O
the O
experimental O
input O
and O
θn O
are O
neuronal O
coupling O
parameters O
that O
determine O
the O
strength O
of O
connections O
within O
and O
between O
brain O
regions O
. O

This O
function O
is O
approximated O
using O
: O
where O
parameter O
matrix O
A O
∈ O
ℝn O
× O
n O
represents O
the O
connectivity O
within O
and O
between O
each O
of O
the O
n O
regions O
( O
which O
in O
this O
study O
is O
the O
average O
connectivity O
of O
0-back O
and O
2-back O
conditions O
) O
, O
B O
( O
j O
) O
∈ O
ℝn O
× O
n O
is O
the O
modulatory O
effect O
of O
experimental O
manipulation O
j O
on O
each O
connection O
and O
C O
∈ O
ℝn O
× O
J O
is O
the O
direct O
driving O
influence O
of O
each O
of O
the O
J O
experimental O
conditions O
on O
each O
region O
. O

The O
predicted O
neuronal O
activity O
enters O
a O
haemodynamic O
model O
that O
incorporates O
a O
model O
of O
neurovascular O
coupling O
and O
the O
subsequent O
BOLD O
response O
. O

This O
provides O
the O
predicted O
fMRI O
time O
series O
that O
one O
would O
expect O
to O
measure O
, O
given O
the O
connectivity O
parameters O
θn O
= O
( O
A O
, O
B O
, O
C O
) O
. O

We O
specified O
a O
DCM O
for O
each O
participant O
. O

Model O
specification O
involved O
setting O
prior O
variances O
on O
the O
parameters O
in O
matrices O
A O
, O
B O
and O
C O
, O
where O
a O
prior O
variance O
of O
zero O
‘ O
switches O
off O
’ O
a O
connection O
and O
a O
non-zero O
prior O
variance O
‘ O
switches O
on O
’ O
a O
connection O
– O
so O
that O
it O
can O
be O
informed O
by O
data O
. O

Here O
, O
there O
were O
two O
experimental O
inputs O
( O
J O
= O
2 O
) O
: O
the O
main O
effect O
of O
task O
( O
all O
0-back O
and O
2-back O
events O
) O
and O
working O
memory O
load O
( O
contrasting O
0-back O
with O
2-back O
) O
. O

Task O
entered O
the O
model O
as O
a O
driving O
input O
( O
by O
setting O
the O
appropriate O
priors O
in O
matrix O
C O
) O
. O

Working O
memory O
load O
entered O
the O
model O
as O
a O
modulatory O
input O
on O
each O
region O
's O
self-connection O
( O
i.e. O
, O
intrinsic O
connection O
) O
by O
setting O
the O
appropriate O
priors O
on O
matrix O
B O
. O

The O
self-connections O
regulate O
a O
region O
's O
response O
to O
its O
inputs O
; O
i.e. O
, O
they O
provide O
gain O
control O
in O
the O
model O
, O
akin O
to O
inhibitory O
inter-neurons O
– O
and O
consequent O
excitation-inhibition O
balance O
– O
in O
the O
brain O
. O

Thus O
, O
we O
modeled O
working O
memory O
load O
as O
modifying O
the O
sensitivity O
of O
each O
region O
to O
input O
from O
the O
rest O
of O
the O
network O
. O

Each O
subject O
's O
model O
was O
inverted O
, O
providing O
estimates O
of O
the O
connection O
strength O
parameters O
θ O
( O
n O
) O
which O
best O
explained O
the O
observed O
data O
. O

The O
resulting O
posterior O
densities O
were O
normally O
distributed O
, O
with O
expected O
values O
and O
covariance O
( O
uncertainty O
) O
. O

Model O
estimation O
additionally O
provided O
the O
free O
energy O
approximation O
to O
log O
model O
evidence O
F O
, O
which O
scores O
the O
quality O
of O
each O
model O
in O
terms O
of O
accuracy O
and O
complexity O
: O
where O
y O
is O
the O
data O
and O
m O
is O
the O
model O
. O

One O
uses O
the O
free O
energy O
F O
to O
compare O
competing O
models O
, O
in O
order O
to O
find O
the O
least O
complex O
model O
of O
the O
data O
that O
accurately O
explains O
the O
most O
variance O
. O

Empirical O
Bayes O
for O
group O
DCM O
Having O
fitted O
each O
subject O
's O
DCM O
to O
their O
data O
, O
we O
next O
performed O
a O
second O
level O
analysis O
to O
estimate O
the O
group O
mean O
and O
the O
effect O
of O
diagnosis O
for O
each O
connection O
. O

This O
used O
recently O
developed O
routines O
for O
modeling O
connectivity O
at O
the O
group O
level O
( O
Parametric O
Empirical O
Bayes O
) O
in O
the O
context O
of O
DCM O
. O

Parametric O
Empirical O
Bayes O
( O
PEB O
) O
is O
a O
between-subject O
hierarchical O
or O
empirical O
Bayesian O
model O
over O
parameters O
that O
models O
how O
individual O
( O
within-subject O
) O
connections O
relate O
to O
group O
or O
condition O
means O
. O

This O
hierarchical O
approach O
treats O
each O
connection O
as O
a O
random O
( O
between-subject O
) O
effect O
, O
which O
is O
modeled O
by O
adding O
a O
random O
Gaussian O
variation O
to O
subject-specific O
predictions O
, O
based O
upon O
the O
group O
mean O
connectivity O
as O
well O
as O
between-subject O
effects O
such O
as O
diagnosis O
or O
age O
. O

This O
parametric O
random O
effects O
modeling O
is O
important O
because O
, O
unlike O
a O
classical O
test O
( O
e.g O
. O

t-test O
) O
, O
it O
uses O
the O
full O
posterior O
density O
over O
the O
parameters O
from O
each O
subject O
's O
DCM O
– O
both O
the O
expected O
strength O
of O
each O
connection O
and O
the O
associated O
uncertainty O
( O
i.e O
. O

posterior O
covariance O
) O
– O
to O
inform O
the O
group-level O
result O
( O
i.e. O
, O
group O
differences O
) O
. O

A O
PEB O
model O
has O
the O
following O
form O
: O
Starting O
with O
the O
last O
line O
, O
the O
observed O
fMRI O
data O
yi O
for O
subject O
i O
is O
generated O
by O
function O
Γi O
( O
1 O
) O
, O
which O
here O
is O
the O
subject O
's O
DCM O
, O
with O
parameters O
θ O
( O
1 O
) O
and O
observation O
noise O
ϵi O
( O
1 O
) O
. O

The O
contribution O
of O
the O
PEB O
framework O
is O
that O
the O
DCM O
parameters O
θ O
( O
1 O
) O
are O
themselves O
represented O
by O
a O
group O
or O
second-level O
model O
, O
written O
on O
the O
second O
line O
of O
the O
equation O
. O

The O
second O
level O
function O
Γ O
( O
2 O
) O
has O
parameters O
( O
e.g. O
, O
average O
connection O
strengths O
) O
θ O
( O
2 O
) O
, O
plus O
between-subject O
variability O
ϵ O
( O
2 O
) O
. O

Finally O
, O
these O
second O
level O
parameters O
have O
priors O
, O
with O
mean O
η O
, O
as O
specified O
on O
the O
first O
line O
of O
the O
equation O
. O

In O
this O
study O
, O
the O
first O
( O
within-subject O
) O
level O
of O
the O
model O
is O
the O
standard O
deterministic O
DCM O
for O
fMRI O
, O
where O
the O
parameters O
correspond O
to O
effective O
connectivity O
( O
please O
see O
above O
) O
. O

The O
second O
( O
between-subject O
) O
level O
model O
Γ O
( O
2 O
) O
is O
simply O
a O
GLM O
with O
the O
form O
: O
where O
X O
∈ O
ℝS O
× O
C O
is O
the O
design O
matrix O
( O
S O
is O
the O
number O
of O
subjects O
, O
C O
is O
the O
number O
of O
covariates O
) O
, O
IP O
is O
the O
identity O
matrix O
of O
dimension O
P O
( O
where O
P O
is O
the O
number O
of O
connection O
parameters O
in O
the O
DCM O
) O
and O
the O
operator O
⊗ O
is O
the O
Kronecker O
product O
that O
duplicates O
each O
element O
of O
the O
design O
matrix O
for O
each O
DCM O
parameter O
. O

In O
other O
words O
, O
this O
model O
allows O
for O
every O
between O
subject-effect O
to O
be O
expressed O
at O
every O
within-subject O
effect O
. O

The O
parameters O
of O
the O
GLM O
are O
β O
⊂ O
θ O
( O
2 O
) O
. O

Thus O
, O
we O
had O
one O
β O
parameter O
representing O
the O
effect O
of O
each O
( O
between-subject O
) O
covariate O
on O
each O
DCM O
connection O
. O

The O
priors O
on O
these O
second O
level O
parameters O
were O
set O
to O
match O
the O
priors O
of O
the O
first O
level O
parameters O
. O

In O
order O
to O
identify O
differences O
between O
patients O
with O
schizophrenia O
and O
normal O
controls O
, O
we O
included O
two O
covariates O
of O
interest O
in O
the O
design O
matrix O
X O
: O
the O
group O
mean O
and O
diagnosis O
. O

We O
also O
included O
the O
working O
memory O
performance O
indexed O
by O
the O
ratio O
between O
d′2 O
score O
and O
d′0 O
score O
and O
the O
interaction O
between O
diagnosis O
and O
performance O
as O
nuisance O
covariates O
, O
in O
order O
to O
exclude O
the O
potential O
influence O
of O
performance O
components O
on O
the O
group O
mean O
and O
diagnosis O
effect O
. O

The O
between-subject O
variability O
ϵ O
( O
2 O
) O
with O
precision O
Π O
( O
2 O
) O
was O
parameterized O
using O
a O
single O
precision O
parameter O
γ O
: O
where O
Q0 O
is O
the O
lower O
bound O
on O
precision O
, O
which O
takes O
on O
a O
small O
positive O
value O
, O
and O
the O
precision O
parameter O
γ O
⊂ O
θ O
( O
2 O
) O
scales O
a O
precision O
component O
Q1 O
. O

Here O
, O
we O
used O
the O
defaults O
in O
SPM O
, O
which O
sets O
Q1 O
to O
, O
where O
pC O
is O
the O
prior O
covariance O
matrix O
of O
a O
single O
subject O
's O
DCM O
parameters O
and O
β O
= O
16 O
. O

To O
summarize O
, O
the O
PEB O
model O
estimates O
the O
effect O
of O
each O
covariate O
on O
each O
connection O
( O
both O
the O
group O
mean O
and O
any O
group O
differences O
) O
, O
as O
well O
as O
estimating O
the O
between-subject O
variability O
. O

The O
parameters O
of O
the O
PEB O
model O
were O
estimated O
using O
a O
standard O
variational O
Laplace O
procedure O
, O
as O
is O
usually O
applied O
in O
DCM O
. O

Bayesian O
model O
reduction O
To O
evaluate O
how O
the O
connectivity O
of O
patients O
with O
schizophrenia O
differs O
from O
that O
of O
normal O
controls O
, O
we O
used O
Bayesian O
model O
comparison O
to O
explore O
the O
space O
of O
possible O
hypotheses O
( O
models O
) O
, O
where O
each O
hypothesis O
or O
model O
assumes O
that O
a O
different O
combination O
of O
the O
connections O
could O
exist O
across O
participants O
or O
show O
phenotypic O
variance O
. O

Candidate O
PEB O
models O
were O
obtained O
by O
removing O
one O
or O
more O
( O
second O
level O
) O
parameters O
from O
the O
full O
PEB O
model O
( O
described O
above O
) O
to O
produce O
reduced O
forms O
of O
the O
full O
model O
that O
differed O
only O
in O
their O
priors O
. O

We O
did O
this O
using O
Bayesian O
model O
reduction O
( O
BMR O
) O
that O
enables O
the O
evidence O
and O
parameters O
of O
nested O
( O
reduced O
) O
models O
to O
be O
derived O
directly O
from O
a O
full O
model O
. O

This O
provides O
an O
efficient O
search O
of O
the O
model O
space O
by O
scoring O
each O
reduced O
model O
, O
based O
on O
its O
log O
model-evidence O
or O
free O
energy O
; O
for O
details O
, O
see O
. O

The O
( O
greedy O
) O
search O
algorithm O
used O
BMR O
to O
iteratively O
prune O
connection O
parameters O
from O
the O
full O
PEB O
model O
, O
until O
model-evidence O
started O
to O
decrease O
. O

The O
parameters O
of O
the O
best O
256 O
pruned O
models O
were O
then O
averaged O
, O
weighted O
by O
their O
evidence O
( O
Bayesian O
Model O
Averaging O
) O
. O

To O
summarize O
the O
DCM O
analysis O
pipeline O
, O
we O
first O
specified O
a O
DCM O
for O
each O
subject O
and O
fitted O
it O
to O
their O
data O
, O
providing O
estimates O
of O
the O
connectivity O
parameters O
. O

These O
subject-specific O
estimates O
( O
expected O
values O
and O
covariance O
) O
were O
taken O
to O
the O
group O
level O
and O
modeled O
using O
a O
Bayesian O
GLM O
( O
i.e. O
, O
a O
PEB O
model O
) O
. O

The O
parameters O
of O
the O
GLM O
represent O
the O
group O
average O
of O
each O
connectivity O
parameter O
, O
as O
well O
as O
any O
group O
differences O
between O
patients O
and O
controls O
. O

We O
than O
used O
Bayesian O
model O
reduction O
to O
search O
over O
hundreds O
of O
reduced O
PEB O
models O
with O
different O
combinations O
of O
connections O
( O
and O
group O
differences O
) O
. O

The O
best O
models O
from O
this O
search O
were O
combined O
using O
Bayesian O
model O
averaging O
. O

We O
report O
these O
averages O
in O
the O
Results O
section O
. O

Clinical O
correlates O
of O
differentiated O
connections O
Having O
identified O
the O
connections O
that O
differed O
between O
patients O
and O
controls O
in O
the O
working O
memory O
task O
, O
we O
next O
asked O
whether O
the O
strength O
of O
these O
connections O
correlated O
with O
the O
severity O
of O
symptoms O
in O
patients O
. O

As O
we O
had O
a O
large O
number O
of O
variables O
, O
we O
did O
not O
include O
these O
in O
the O
PEB O
model O
directly O
; O
instead O
, O
we O
used O
a O
( O
post O
hoc O
) O
canonical O
variates O
analysis O
( O
CVA O
) O
to O
identify O
linear O
relationships O
between O
the O
two O
sets O
of O
measures O
( O
strength O
of O
effective O
connectivity O
and O
clinical O
symptoms O
) O
. O

This O
resulted O
in O
pairs O
of O
significantly O
correlated O
canonical O
variables O
( O
i.e. O
, O
latent O
connectivity O
and O
symptom O
profiles O
) O
. O

Using O
the O
same O
analysis O
, O
we O
asked O
whether O
our O
cognitive O
scores O
could O
be O
predicted O
by O
the O
effective O
connectivity O
. O

Effect O
of O
antipsychotic O
medication O
In O
order O
to O
ameliorate O
the O
confounding O
effect O
of O
antipsychotic O
medication O
on O
group O
differences O
, O
we O
included O
the O
chlorpromazine O
equivalents O
of O
antipsychotic O
medication O
as O
a O
nuisance O
covariate O
– O
in O
addition O
to O
the O
nuisance O
covariates O
above O
( O
working O
memory O
performance O
and O
interaction O
between O
diagnosis O
and O
performance O
) O
– O
in O
the O
between O
subject O
design O
matrix O
. O

The O
main O
effects O
of O
group O
were O
unchanged O
when O
including O
antipsychotic O
medication O
as O
a O
between O
subject O
effect O
. O

We O
present O
the O
effect O
of O
the O
antipsychotic O
medication O
and O
other O
nuisance O
covariates O
on O
effective O
connectivity O
in O
the O
supplementary O
materials O
( O
Fig O
. O

S1 O
) O
. O

We O
also O
include O
the O
chlorpromazine O
equivalents O
of O
antipsychotic O
medication O
into O
the O
CVA O
models O
while O
exploring O
the O
clinical O
correlates O
of O
differentiate O
connections O
. O

Real-time O
motion O
analytics O
during O
brain O
MRI O
improve O
data O
quality O
and O
reduce O
costs O
Head O
motion O
systematically O
distorts O
clinical O
and O
research O
MRI O
data O
. O

Motion O
artifacts O
have O
biased O
findings O
from O
many O
structural O
and O
functional O
brain O
MRI O
studies O
. O

An O
effective O
way O
to O
remove O
motion O
artifacts O
is O
to O
exclude O
MRI O
data O
frames O
affected O
by O
head O
motion O
. O

However O
, O
such O
post-hoc O
frame O
censoring O
can O
lead O
to O
data O
loss O
rates O
of O
50 O
% O
or O
more O
in O
our O
pediatric O
patient O
cohorts O
. O

Hence O
, O
many O
scanner O
operators O
collect O
additional O
‘ O
buffer O
data O
’ O
, O
an O
expensive O
practice O
that O
, O
by O
itself O
, O
does O
not O
guarantee O
sufficient O
high-quality O
MRI O
data O
for O
a O
given O
participant O
. O

Therefore O
, O
we O
developed O
an O
easy-to-setup O
, O
easy-to-use O
Framewise O
Integrated O
Real-time O
MRI O
Monitoring O
( O
FIRMM O
) O
software O
suite O
that O
provides O
scanner O
operators O
with O
head O
motion O
analytics O
in O
real-time O
, O
allowing O
them O
to O
scan O
each O
subject O
until O
the O
desired O
amount O
of O
low-movement O
data O
has O
been O
collected O
. O

Our O
analyses O
show O
that O
using O
FIRMM O
to O
identify O
the O
ideal O
scan O
time O
for O
each O
person O
can O
reduce O
total O
brain O
MRI O
scan O
times O
and O
associated O
costs O
by O
50 O
% O
or O
more O
. O

2 O
. O

Materials O
and O
methods O
2.1 O
. O

FIRMM O
software O
suite O
FIRMM O
is O
built O
using O
several O
software O
packages O
, O
each O
with O
a O
specific O
purpose O
, O
to O
make O
installation O
and O
usage O
easier O
and O
more O
reliable O
. O

Installation O
requires O
a O
Docker-capable O
Linux O
system O
. O

Operation O
on O
Ubuntu O
14.04 O
and O
CentOS O
7 O
operating O
systems O
have O
both O
been O
tested O
and O
work O
well O
. O

Installation O
is O
accomplished O
via O
a O
downloadable O
shell O
script O
which O
retrieves O
and O
installs O
FIRMM O
’ O
s O
components O
. O

After O
installation O
FIRMM O
is O
launched O
with O
a O
shell O
script O
tailored O
to O
use O
a O
pre-built O
Docker O
image O
. O

FIRMM O
’ O
s O
components O
are O
the O
compiled O
MATLAB O
( O
R2016b O
) O
binary O
backend O
which O
only O
requires O
an O
included O
MATLAB O
compiler O
runtime O
to O
run O
, O
shell O
scripts O
for O
image O
processing O
, O
a O
Docker O
image O
containing O
image O
processing O
software O
dependencies O
, O
and O
a O
Django O
web O
application O
front O
end O
. O

The O
compiled O
MATLAB O
binary O
backend O
monitors O
an O
incoming O
folder O
waiting O
for O
a O
new O
subfolder O
that O
has O
the O
current O
date O
and O
contains O
images O
created O
within O
the O
last O
few O
minutes O
. O

The O
backend O
does O
shell O
script O
image O
processing O
only O
on O
new O
functional O
images O
. O

The O
required O
image O
processing O
software O
is O
already O
installed O
and O
configured O
inside O
the O
Docker O
image O
. O

Results O
are O
visually O
displayed O
in O
the O
Django O
web O
application O
frontend O
as O
plots O
and O
tables O
in O
a O
Chromium O
web O
browser O
. O

2.2 O
. O

Real-time O
processing O
of O
DICOM O
images O
As O
soon O
as O
each O
frame/volume O
of O
EPI O
( O
echo O
planar O
imaging O
) O
data O
is O
acquired O
and O
reconstructed O
into O
DICOM O
format O
, O
it O
is O
transferred O
to O
a O
pre-designated O
folder O
that O
the O
FIRMM O
software O
monitors O
for O
new O
images O
. O

On O
Siemens O
scanners O
, O
rapid O
DICOM O
transfer O
can O
be O
achieved O
by O
selecting O
the O
‘ O
send O
IMA O
’ O
option O
in O
the O
ideacmdtool O
utility O
( O
requires O
‘ O
advanced O
user O
’ O
mode O
) O
. O

On O
Siemens O
scanners O
one O
can O
also O
use O
an O
MS-DOS O
batch O
script O
to O
add O
start O
‘ O
FIRMM O
’ O
and O
stop O
‘ O
FIRMM O
’ O
buttons O
to O
the O
scanner O
operating O
system O
. O

This O
package O
is O
a O
standalone O
script O
that O
can O
be O
downloaded O
with O
FIRMM O
. O

FIRMM O
reads O
the O
DICOM O
headers O
and O
uses O
the O
header O
information O
to O
enter O
data O
sequentially O
into O
a O
job O
queuing O
system O
. O

DICOMs O
are O
processed O
in O
the O
temporal O
order O
they O
were O
acquired O
. O

FIRMM O
converts O
DICOMs O
into O
4dfp O
format O
prior O
to O
any O
further O
processing O
. O

FIRMM O
realigns O
EPI O
data O
using O
the O
4dfp O
cross_realign3d_4dfp O
algorithm O
. O

The O
cross_realign3d_4dfp O
algorithm O
run O
by O
FIRMM O
has O
been O
optimized O
for O
computational O
speed O
, O
thus O
frame-to-frame O
image O
intensity O
normalization O
has O
been O
disabled O
and O
the O
realigned O
data O
are O
not O
written O
out O
, O
only O
the O
alignment O
parameters O
. O

Alternative O
alignment O
algorithms O
operating O
on O
NIfTI O
format O
data O
can O
also O
be O
utilized O
and O
will O
be O
made O
available O
in O
future O
releases O
. O

The O
EPI O
images O
do O
not O
undergo O
pre-processing O
steps O
typically O
utilized O
in O
offline O
data O
analyses O
. O

For O
EPI O
images O
with O
a O
spatial O
resolution O
smaller O
than O
4 O
mm3 O
, O
data O
are O
down-sampled O
to O
4 O
mm3 O
prior O
to O
realignment O
to O
increase O
processing O
speed O
. O

2.3 O
. O

Estimation O
of O
head O
realignments O
Each O
data O
frame O
( O
volume O
) O
is O
aligned O
to O
the O
first O
frame O
of O
the O
run O
through O
a O
series O
of O
rigid O
body O
transforms O
, O
Ti O
, O
where O
i O
indexes O
the O
spatial O
registration O
of O
frame O
i O
to O
a O
reference O
of O
frame O
1 O
, O
starting O
with O
the O
second O
frame O
. O

Each O
transform O
is O
calculated O
by O
minimizing O
the O
registration O
error O
: O
such O
that O
I O
( O
x⃗ O
) O
is O
the O
image O
intensity O
at O
locus O
x⃗ O
and O
s O
is O
a O
scalar O
factor O
that O
compensates O
for O
fluctuations O
in O
mean O
signal O
intensity O
, O
spatially O
averaged O
over O
the O
whole O
brain O
( O
angle O
brackets O
) O
. O

Each O
transform O
is O
represented O
by O
a O
combination O
of O
rotations O
and O
displacements O
. O

Therefore O
, O
with O
Ri O
representing O
the O
3 O
× O
3 O
matrix O
of O
rotations O
and O
ḋi O
representing O
the O
3 O
× O
1 O
column O
vector O
of O
displacements O
. O

Ri O
consists O
of O
the O
three O
elementary O
rotations O
at O
each O
of O
the O
three O
axes O
. O

Hence O
, O
Ri O
= O
RiαRiβRiγ O
and O
2.4 O
. O

Computation O
of O
framewise O
displacement O
( O
FD O
) O
Calculating O
head O
realignment O
parameters O
across O
frames O
starting O
with O
the O
second O
frame O
generates O
six O
displacement O
vectors O
of O
head O
motion O
. O

We O
convert O
head O
motion O
to O
a O
scalar O
quantity O
with O
the O
formula O
, O
Displacementi O
= O
|Δdix| O
+ O
|Δdiy| O
+ O
|Δdiz| O
+ O
|Δαi| O
+ O
|Δβi| O
+ O
|Δγi| O
, O
where O
Δdix O
= O
d O
( O
i−1 O
) O
x O
− O
dix O
, O
Δdiy O
= O
d O
( O
i−1 O
) O
y O
− O
diy O
, O
Δdiz O
= O
d O
( O
i−1 O
) O
z O
− O
diz O
, O
and O
so O
forth O
. O

Rotational O
displacements O
are O
converted O
from O
degrees O
to O
millimeters O
by O
computing O
displacement O
on O
the O
surface O
of O
a O
sphere O
of O
radius O
50 O
mm O
, O
which O
is O
approximately O
the O
mean O
distance O
from O
the O
cerebral O
cortex O
to O
the O
center O
of O
the O
head O
for O
a O
healthy O
young O
adult O
. O

Since O
we O
realign O
each O
data O
frame O
to O
the O
first O
frame O
, O
FD O
is O
calculated O
by O
subtracting O
Displacementi−1 O
( O
for O
the O
previous O
frame O
) O
from O
Displacementi O
( O
for O
the O
current O
frame O
) O
. O

2.5 O
. O

Model O
for O
predicting O
framewise O
displacement O
( O
FD O
) O
The O
head O
motion O
( O
FD O
) O
prediction O
algorithm O
is O
a O
linear O
model O
that O
updates O
with O
each O
new O
data O
frame O
( O
y O
= O
mx O
+ O
b O
) O
, O
where O
y O
is O
the O
predicted O
number O
of O
low-movement O
frames O
below O
a O
certain O
FD O
cutoff O
at O
the O
end O
of O
the O
scan O
or O
experiment O
, O
x O
is O
the O
consecutive O
frame O
count O
, O
and O
m O
and O
b O
are O
estimated O
for O
each O
participant O
in O
real O
time O
. O

A O
given O
frame O
is O
labeled O
as O
usable O
if O
the O
relative O
object O
displacement O
is O
less O
than O
a O
given O
FD O
threshold O
( O
in O
mm O
) O
, O
using O
as O
reference O
the O
object O
’ O
s O
position O
in O
the O
previous O
frame O
. O

The O
prediction O
algorithm O
is O
implemented O
in O
Python O
using O
the O
scikit-learn O
package O
( O
http O
: O
//scikit-learn.org O
) O
. O

The O
prediction O
algorithm O
outputs O
are O
displayed O
inside O
the O
‘ O
Predicted O
Duration O
to O
Scan O
Criteria O
’ O
box O
in O
FIRMM O
’ O
s O
graphical O
user O
interface O
( O
GUI O
) O
, O
as O
minutes O
until O
the O
user-specified O
data O
criterion O
is O
reached O
. O

FIRMM O
users O
can O
select O
three O
FD O
thresholds O
( O
in O
mm O
) O
and O
the O
desired O
amount O
of O
low-movement O
data O
( O
in O
min O
. O
) O

using O
a O
simple O
settings O
file O
. O

2.6 O
. O

Visualization O
of O
framewise O
displacement O
( O
FD O
) O
in O
real O
time O
FIRMM O
uses O
a O
GUI O
designed O
with O
Django O
( O
https O
: O
//www.djangoproject.com/ O
) O
and O
Chart.js O
( O
http O
: O
//www.chartjs.org/ O
) O
to O
display O
FD O
traces O
and O
summary O
counts O
of O
data O
quality O
in O
real O
time O
. O

FIRMM O
continuously O
updates O
summary O
counts O
about O
the O
number O
of O
‘ O
high-quality O
’ O
low-movement O
frames O
already O
acquired O
( O
FD O
cutoff O
presets O
are O
0.2 O
mm O
, O
0.3 O
mm O
and O
0.4 O
mm O
) O
in O
table O
format O
and O
as O
a O
color-coded O
bar O
graph O
. O

At O
the O
end O
of O
each O
data O
acquisition O
epoch O
( O
run O
) O
the O
summary O
counts O
for O
that O
run O
are O
displayed O
in O
a O
list O
that O
tabulates O
the O
summary O
head O
motion O
data O
for O
each O
run O
separately O
and O
for O
the O
sum O
of O
all O
the O
data O
acquired O
thus O
far O
in O
the O
active O
scanning O
session O
. O

FIRMM O
also O
displays O
predictions O
about O
how O
much O
longer O
a O
given O
subject O
will O
likely O
have O
to O
be O
scanned O
until O
the O
preset O
time-to-criterion O
( O
minutes O
of O
low-movement O
FD O
data O
) O
has O
been O
acquired O
. O

There O
is O
also O
a O
graph O
of O
the O
actual O
amount O
of O
time O
( O
in O
min O
and O
s O
) O
one O
has O
scanned O
‘ O
low-movement O
’ O
frames O
toward O
a O
preset O
criterion O
amount O
of O
time O
. O

Users O
are O
able O
to O
customize O
the O
FD O
cutoffs O
and O
data O
amount O
criterion O
by O
opening O
FIRMM O
in O
the O
settings O
mode O
( O
FIRMM O
-s O
) O
. O

FIRMM O
can O
be O
run O
in O
the O
help O
mode O
by O
typing O
FIRMM O
-h. O
2.7 O
. O

FIRMM O
monitoring O
: O
scanner O
requirements O
FIRMM O
requires O
an O
MRI O
scanner O
enabled O
to O
rapidly O
reconstruct O
and O
transfer O
BOLD O
images O
. O

FIRMM O
currently O
expects O
an O
EPI O
mosaic O
as O
provided O
by O
Siemens O
, O
but O
is O
customizable O
to O
work O
with O
non-mosaic O
formats O
( O
i.e O
. O

GE O
and O
Philips O
) O
. O

FIRMM O
monitoring O
was O
developed O
and O
tested O
on O
Siemens O
3T O
Tim O
Trio O
and O
Siemens O
3T O
Prisma O
scanners O
at O
Washington O
University O
School O
of O
Medicine O
( O
WUSM O
) O
and O
Oregon O
Health O
& O
Science O
University O
( O
OHSU O
) O
. O

Additional O
beta O
testing O
has O
been O
conducted O
as O
part O
of O
the O
Adolescent O
Brain O
Cognitive O
Development O
( O
ABCD O
) O
project O
at O
several O
MRI O
sites O
and O
is O
now O
being O
implemented O
as O
a O
core O
advancement O
for O
this O
national O
study O
of O
10,000 O
children O
who O
will O
be O
scanned O
biannually O
over O
the O
next O
10 O
years O
( O
http O
: O
//www.ABCDstudy.org O
) O
. O

FIRMM O
was O
expressly O
designed O
to O
also O
be O
compatible O
with O
General O
Electric O
( O
GE O
) O
and O
Philips O
MRI O
scanners O
and O
dedicated O
GE O
and O
Philips O
versions O
are O
under O
development O
. O

On O
Siemens O
scanners O
FIRMM O
monitoring O
can O
utilize O
the O
ideacmdtool O
SendIMA O
option O
with O
buffering O
disabled O
. O

Alternatively O
, O
rapid O
DICOM O
forwarding O
can O
also O
be O
built O
directly O
into O
Siemens O
sequences O
, O
or O
an O
MS-DOS O
batch O
can O
be O
used O
to O
insert O
FIRMM O
‘ O
start O
’ O
and O
‘ O
stop O
’ O
buttons O
into O
the O
operating O
system O
( O
stand-alone O
software O
that O
can O
be O
downloaded O
with O
FIRMM O
) O
. O

2.8 O
. O

FIRMM O
works O
with O
a O
wide O
range O
of O
sequences O
and O
EPI O
image O
types O
Today O
’ O
s O
MRI O
data O
acquisition O
landscape O
is O
changing O
rapidly O
. O

With O
multiband O
imaging O
, O
EPI O
data O
for O
sequences O
such O
as O
BOLD O
can O
now O
be O
collected O
every O
few O
hundred O
milliseconds O
and O
at O
spatial O
resolutions O
as O
low O
as O
2 O
mm O
isotropic O
. O

While O
our O
estimations O
of O
FIRMM-driven O
time O
savings O
and O
the O
initial O
live O
testing O
of O
FIRMM O
were O
conducted O
on O
single-band O
EPI O
data O
with O
TRs O
of O
2.0–2.5 O
s O
, O
we O
have O
since O
verified O
that O
FIRMM O
works O
equally O
well O
with O
multiband O
EPI O
data O
acquired O
at O
spatial O
resolutions O
as O
low O
as O
2 O
mm O
isotropic O
and O
with O
TRs O
as O
short O
as O
700 O
ms. O
For O
BOLD O
data O
with O
high O
multiband O
factors O
, O
small O
voxel O
sizes O
and O
short O
TRs O
, O
the O
rate-limiting O
step O
is O
image O
reconstruction O
from O
k-space O
data O
, O
not O
FIRMM O
’ O
s O
FD O
calculations O
and O
predictions O
. O

While O
image O
reconstruction O
can O
take O
longer O
for O
these O
types O
of O
acquisition O
parameters O
, O
vendor O
software O
platforms O
are O
becoming O
faster O
. O

Siemens O
image O
reconstruction O
as O
implemented O
in O
VE11B O
and O
VE11C O
is O
fast O
enough O
for O
FIRMM O
FD O
calculations O
to O
keep O
up O
with O
the O
speed O
of O
data O
acquisition O
at O
TRs O
of O
700 O
ms O
. O

In O
addition O
, O
we O
simulated O
even O
faster O
image O
acquisition O
rates O
( O
TRs O
down O
to O
500 O
ms O
) O
and O
FIRMM O
was O
still O
able O
to O
keep O
up O
and O
deliver O
accurate O
real-time O
FD O
calculations O
. O

In O
addition O
to O
providing O
real-time O
head O
motion O
information O
during O
EPI O
imaging O
( O
rs-fcMRI O
, O
fMRI O
) O
at O
various O
resolutions O
and O
TRs O
, O
FIRMM O
can O
also O
be O
used O
to O
calculate O
FD O
on O
the O
EPI O
motion O
marker O
or O
navigator O
images O
collected O
as O
part O
of O
novel O
motion-correcting O
structural O
sequences O
. O

Such O
navigator O
images O
are O
similar O
enough O
to O
other O
EPI O
images O
that O
FIRMM O
can O
monitor O
head O
motion O
as O
long O
as O
it O
receives O
the O
EPI O
navigator O
images O
in O
real O
time O
. O

This O
use O
case O
is O
planned O
for O
development O
in O
a O
later O
release O
. O

2.9 O
. O

FIRMM O
computer O
requirements O
The O
only O
hardware O
requirement O
for O
running O
FIRMM O
is O
a O
Docker-capable O
Linux O
computer O
networked O
to O
the O
computer O
running O
the O
scanner O
operating O
system O
, O
which O
is O
already O
part O
of O
the O
typical O
setup O
for O
MRI O
scanners O
used O
in O
research O
. O

The O
FIRMM O
software O
is O
self-contained O
in O
a O
Docker O
image O
and O
does O
not O
require O
licenses O
or O
the O
installation O
of O
other O
software O
packages O
. O

FIRMM O
has O
been O
most O
extensively O
used O
with O
a O
self-built O
computer O
running O
Linux O
( O
Ubuntu O
14.04 O
LTS O
) O
and O
the O
following O
hardware O
specifications O
: O
Intel O
Core O
i7 O
4790 O
K O
4.0 O
GHz O
processor O
, O
16 O
GB O
DDR3 O
memory O
, O
Samsung O
850 O
EVO O
120 O
GB O
SSD O
and O
NVIDIA O
GTX O
960 O
GPU O
. O

2.10 O
. O

FIRMM O
code O
availability O
We O
are O
making O
the O
FIRMM O
software O
and O
manuals O
available O
on O
our O
website O
( O
http O
: O
//www.firmm.us O
) O
and O
on O
the O
Neuroimaging O
Informatics O
Tools O
and O
Resources O
Clearinghouse O
( O
https O
: O
//www.nitrc.org O
) O
. O

Installation O
instructions O
for O
FIRMM O
can O
be O
found O
at O
: O
http O
: O
//www.firmm.us O
. O

Detailed O
documentation O
is O
included O
with O
the O
software O
download O
. O

2.11 O
. O

Using O
FIRMM O
We O
focused O
on O
making O
FIRMM O
as O
easy O
to O
launch O
as O
possible O
to O
minimize O
the O
time O
interval O
between O
subject O
arrival O
and O
starting O
the O
first O
run O
, O
which O
can O
reduce O
costs O
and O
increase O
the O
chance O
of O
getting O
through O
the O
entire O
protocol O
for O
longer O
scanning O
sessions O
, O
especially O
in O
special O
populations O
. O

In O
its O
current O
version O
, O
scanner O
operators O
open O
the O
FIRMM O
monitoring O
GUI O
by O
typing O
‘ O
FIRMM O
’ O
into O
the O
command O
line O
. O

To O
start O
monitoring O
head O
movement O
in O
real O
time O
the O
scanner O
operator O
must O
open O
FIRMM O
and O
then O
click O
the O
‘ O
Start O
FIRMM O
’ O
button O
which O
will O
begin O
monitoring O
the O
backend O
JSON O
file O
for O
updates O
. O

Once O
launched O
, O
FIRMM O
requires O
no O
additional O
inputs O
because O
it O
automatically O
detects O
the O
active O
MRI O
scanning O
session O
folder O
and O
monitors O
for O
new O
incoming O
EPI O
acquisitions O
, O
separating O
images O
into O
distinct O
runs O
. O

Should O
the O
scanner O
operator O
forget O
to O
launch O
FIRMM O
at O
the O
beginning O
of O
the O
scanning O
session O
, O
he O
or O
she O
can O
launch O
FIRMM O
at O
any O
point O
during O
the O
study O
and O
FIRMM O
will O
process O
all O
EPI O
images O
associated O
with O
the O
current O
session O
in O
the O
correct O
order O
until O
it O
catches O
up O
to O
ongoing O
image O
acquisition O
. O

FIRMM O
automatically O
saves O
a O
log O
file O
for O
each O
run O
during O
a O
scanning O
session O
. O

Shutting O
down O
FIRMM O
only O
requires O
closing O
the O
FIRMM O
GUI O
window O
. O

All O
synced O
dicoms O
are O
automatically O
deleted O
from O
the O
host O
computer O
after O
48 O
h. O
2.12 O
. O

FIRMM O
outputs O
FIRMM O
saves O
a O
temporary O
processing O
folder O
per O
study O
using O
the O
DICOM O
header O
information O
. O

In O
that O
folder O
, O
FIRMM O
saves O
the O
head O
motion O
parameters O
and O
FD O
values O
associated O
with O
each O
data O
frame O
. O

FIRMM O
also O
generates O
and O
saves O
a O
JSON O
file O
of O
the O
full O
information O
displayed O
in O
the O
GUI O
at O
the O
conclusion O
of O
the O
scanning O
session O
. O

By O
loading O
the O
JSONs O
of O
completed O
scans O
, O
users O
are O
able O
to O
recreate O
the O
final O
FIRMM O
display O
of O
previous O
scan O
session O
. O

For O
each O
scanning O
session O
FIRMM O
also O
writes O
out O
a O
simple O
text O
log O
( O
.csv O
) O
containing O
each O
data O
frame O
’ O
s O
FD O
value O
and O
the O
six O
underlying O
motion O
parameters O
. O

FIRMM O
users O
interested O
in O
using O
FIRMM O
’ O
s O
motion O
numbers O
for O
data O
processing O
and O
denoising O
can O
either O
import O
them O
from O
the O
log O
files O
, O
or O
from O
the O
JSON O
files O
using O
the O
JQ O
command-line O
JSON O
processor O
( O
https O
: O
//stedolan.github.io/jq/ O
) O
. O

2.13 O
. O

Future O
upgrades O
to O
FIRMM O
As O
noted O
above O
, O
the O
current O
version O
of O
FIRMM O
is O
part O
of O
the O
standard O
acquisition O
protocol O
for O
the O
21-site O
ABCD O
study O
that O
will O
collect O
MRI O
data O
( O
structural O
, O
task O
fMRI O
, O
and O
rs-fcMRI O
) O
from O
10,000 O
children O
biannually O
over O
the O
span O
of O
10 O
years O
, O
starting O
at O
the O
age O
of O
9 O
. O

We O
expect O
the O
ABCD O
study O
to O
provide O
a O
great O
deal O
of O
valuable O
feedback O
to O
further O
improve O
FIRMM O
’ O
s O
utility O
. O

ABCD O
functional O
( O
fMRI O
, O
rs-fcMRI O
) O
and O
structural O
( O
motion-correcting O
T1 O
, O
motion-correcting O
T2 O
) O
data O
should O
allow O
us O
to O
further O
improve O
the O
accuracy O
of O
our O
head O
motion O
prediction O
algorithm O
in O
the O
age O
range O
under O
investigation O
. O

FIRMM O
upgrades O
already O
under O
development O
are O
aimed O
at O
making O
it O
even O
easier O
to O
use O
and O
to O
broaden O
its O
capabilities O
. O

Hence O
, O
we O
are O
currently O
testing O
a O
version O
of O
FIRMM O
with O
interactive O
graphics O
that O
would O
further O
simplify O
its O
use O
by O
allowing O
the O
selection O
and O
deselection O
of O
specific O
individual O
scans O
for O
inclusion O
in O
the O
actual O
and O
predicted O
amount O
of O
low-movement O
data O
. O

Planned O
future O
versions O
of O
FIRMM O
should O
also O
allow O
users O
to O
display O
DVAR O
( O
D O
for O
derivative O
of O
timeseries O
, O
VAR O
for O
RMS O
variance O
across O
voxels O
) O
as O
an O
additional O
EPI O
data O
quality O
metric O
. O

DVAR O
measures O
how O
much O
the O
whole O
brain O
signal O
intensity O
varies O
from O
each O
data O
frame O
to O
the O
next O
, O
independent O
of O
the O
source O
of O
signal O
change O
. O

DVAR O
traces O
are O
very O
sensitive O
to O
frame-to-frame O
head O
motion O
but O
in O
principle O
can O
also O
detect O
EPI O
signal O
aberrancies O
from O
sources O
other O
than O
head O
motion O
. O

In O
addition O
to O
the O
4dfp O
alignment O
algorithm O
currently O
implemented O
by O
FIRMM O
, O
future O
versions O
will O
allow O
scanner O
operators O
to O
choose O
between O
similar O
, O
but O
slightly O
different O
, O
EPI O
image O
registration O
methods O
for O
calculating O
FD O
( O
FSL O
, O
AFNI O
, O
SPM O
) O
. O

Options O
for O
feeding O
information O
about O
head O
motion O
back O
to O
the O
subject O
, O
post-run O
and/or O
in O
real O
time O
are O
undergoing O
testing O
. O

Those O
feedback O
approaches O
most O
effective O
at O
reducing O
head O
motion O
will O
also O
be O
built O
into O
future O
versions O
of O
FIRMM O
. O

2.14 O
. O

Validation O
data O
sets O
For O
this O
study O
, O
extant O

data O
( O

) O
from O

total O
of O

of O

, O

and O
young O

( O

female O

) O
with O

of O
12.4 O
years O
( O
range O
= O
7.2–19.6 O
years O
) O
, O
were O
utilized O
to O
compare O
FIRMM O
’ O
s O
FD O
calculations O
to O
standard O
offline O
methods O
( O
WashU O

) O
and O
to O
estimate O
the O
scanning O
cost O
reductions O
had O
FIRMM O
been O
available O
at O
the O
time O
of O
scanning O
. O

These O
data O
came O
from O
two O
different O
data O
sets O
that O
were O
pooled O
for O
the O
purpose O
of O
this O

. O

The O

were O
also O
used O
to O
validate O
FIRMM O
’ O
s O
head O

algorithm O
. O

cohorts O
with O

deficit O

disorder O
( O

: O
425 O

female O
) O
, O

2.14.1 O
. O

ADHD O
, O
ASD O
, O
neurotypical O
controls O
( O
dataset O
1 O
) O
The O
ADHD O
and O
ASD O
cohorts O
, O
alongside O
age-matched O
neurotypical O
controls O
, O
were O
recruited O
as O
part O
of O
two O
ongoing O
longitudinal O
studies O
in O
the O
Fair O
and O
Nigg O
laboratories O
. O

For O
neurotypical O
and O
ADHD O
participants O
, O
children O
were O
recruited O
from O
families O
who O
volunteered O
in O
response O
to O
mass O
mailings O
in O
the O
community O
. O

Their O
diagnostic O
grouping O
was O
carefully O
evaluated O
in O
best-estimate O
, O
multi-stage O
case O
finding O
procedure O
. O

Children O
were O
excluded O
if O
they O
did O
not O
meet O
criteria O
for O
ADHD O
or O
non-ADHD O
groups O
. O

Exclusion O
criteria O
were O
tic O
disorder O
, O
psychotic O
disorder O
, O
bipolar O
disorder O
, O
autism O
spectrum O
disorder O
, O
conduct O
disorder O
, O
major O
depressive O
disorder O
, O
intellectual O
disability O
, O
neurological O
illness O
, O
chronic O
medical O
problems O
, O
sensorimotor O
disability O
, O
significant O
head O
trauma O
( O
with O
loss O
of O
consciousness O
) O
; O
or O
if O
they O
were O
taking O
psychotropic O
medications O
other O
than O
psychostimulants O
. O

Children O
were O
also O
excluded O
if O
they O
had O
contra-indications O
to O
MRI O
. O

Only O
right-handed O
children O
were O
included O
in O
the O
study O
. O

Children O
prescribed O
psychostimulant O
medications O
were O
scanned O
after O
a O
minimum O
washout O
period O
of O
five O
half-lives O
( O
i.e O
. O

24–48 O
h O
depending O
on O
the O
preparation O
) O
. O

For O
ASD O
participants O
, O
diagnosis O
was O
determined O
by O
a O
multi-disciplinary O
clinical O
team O
that O
utilized O
the O
ADOS O
. O

All O
children O
also O
met O
ASD O
criteria O
on O
the O
ADI-R O
, O
using O
DSM-IV O
criteria O
. O

Children O
with O
ASD O
were O
also O
assessed O
for O
ADHD O
by O
the O
same O
research O
methods O
noted O
above O
. O

As O
above O
, O
children O
with O
ASD O
who O
were O
taking O
psychostimulant O
medications O
were O
allowed O
in O
but O
were O
washed O
out O
for O
a O
minimum O
of O
24–48 O
h O
( O
depending O
on O
formulation O
) O
or O
at O
least O
7 O
half-lives O
of O
the O
formulation O
( O
i.e O
. O

the O
period O
of O
time O
it O
takes O
the O
body O
to O
metabolize/excrete O
half O
of O
the O
dose O
of O
the O
medication O
) O
prior O
to O
neuroimaging O
. O

Children O
taking O
non-stimulant O
psychoactive O
medications O
( O
e.g O
. O

tricyclic O
antidepressants O
, O
SSRIs O
, O
MAO O
inhibitors O
, O
or O
antipsychotic O
medication O
and O
atomoxetine O
) O
were O
excluded O
from O
the O
study O
. O

2.14.2 O
. O

Family O
history O
of O

, O

controls O
( O

) O
Participants O
, O

. O

of O

( O

) O

were O
part O
of O

and O
matched O
for O

to O
family O
history O
negative O
participants O
( O
neurotypical O

) O
. O

To O
determine O

were O

with O
the O

and O
one O

[ O

: O

of O

, O

( O
i.e O
. O

schizophrenia O
or O

I O
) O
, O

of O
a O

[ O

for O

, O

] O
, O

( O
> O
10 O

of O

) O
[ O

] O
, O

, O

( O

of O

> O
2 O
min O
) O
, O

, O

disability O
or O

, O

to O

, O

[ O

( O

. O

sequence O
was O

( O

= O
1 O
× O
1 O
× O
1.1 O
mm O
) O
. O

( O

) O

* O
-weighted O

( O

= O
2500 O
ms O
, O

= O

= O

, O

= O
240 O
mm2 O
, O
36 O

, O

= O

mm O
, O
resolution O
= O
3.75 O
× O
3.75 O
× O
3.8 O
mm O
) O
. O

Three O
runs O
of O
5 O
min O
of O
resting O
state O
BOLD O
data O
were O
acquired O
, O

3 O

Siemens O
Tim O
Trio O
3.0 O
T O
Magnetom O
system O
( O
Siemens O
Medical O
Solutions O
, O
Erlangen O
, O

, O

WU O
’ O

East O
Building O
Imaging O
Center O

A O

T1-weighted O
MPRAGE O
sequence O
was O
acquired O
( O
resolution O
= O
1 O
× O
1 O
× O
1 O
mm O
) O
. O

images O
were O

using O
a O
BOLD O
contrast-sensitive O
echoplanar O
sequence O
( O
TE O
= O
27 O
ms O
, O
flip O
angle O
= O

, O

resolution O
4 O
× O

mm O
; O
volume O
TR O
= O
2.5 O
s O

, O

about O
