. O

2.17 O
. O

Analyses O
comparing O
FIRMM O
and O
offline O
FD O
values O
For O
all O
1134 O
scan O
sessions O
FD O
values O
were O
calculated O
using O
FIRMM O
( O
see O
sections O
2.2 O
, O
2.3 O
, O
2.4 O
) O
as O
well O
as O
using O
a O
previously O
published O
Offline O
method O
. O

The O
differences O
between O
the O
FIRMM O
and O
Offline O
FD O
values O
are O
1 O
) O
that O
the O
FIRMM O
FD O
values O
are O
calculated O
on O
the O
‘ O
raw O
’ O
BOLD O
images O
, O
prior O
to O
de-banding O
and O
slice-time-correction O
, O
and O
2 O
) O
that O
the O
FIRMM O
FD O
values O
are O
computed O
from O
BOLD O
image O
alignments O
relative O
to O
the O
first O
data O
frame O
instead O
of O
the O
run O
’ O
s O
middle O
frame O
( O
Offline O
) O
. O

All O
other O
steps O
such O
as O
the O
estimation O
of O
head O
realignment O
( O
section O
2.3 O
) O
and O
the O
formula O
for O
calculating O
FD O
( O
section O
2.4 O
) O
are O
the O
same O
for O
the O
FIRMM O
and O
Offline O
methods O
. O

For O
both O
FD O
calculation O
methods O
( O
FIRMM O
, O
Offline O
) O
the O
number O
of O
usable O
low O
movement O
frames O
were O
calculated O
for O
three O
commonly O
used O
stringent O
thresholds O
( O
FD O
< O
0.2 O
mm O
, O
FD O
< O
0.3 O
mm O
, O
FD O
< O
0.4 O
mm O
) O
. O

For O
the O
whole O
sample O
of O
1134 O
scans O
the O
correlation O
in O
the O
percentage O
of O
usable O
low O
movement O
frames O
between O
FIRMM O
and O
Offline O
was O
calculated O
for O
each O
frame O
censoring O
threshold O
( O
Fig O
. O

3 O
, O
Supplementary O
Fig O
. O

2 O
. O

2.18 O
. O

Analyses O
estimating O
time O
savings O
generated O
by O
FIRMM O
To O
estimate O
how O
much O
scan O
time O
could O
have O
been O
saved O
by O
using O
FIRMM O
to O
scan O
until O
each O
subject O
had O
acquired O
the O
desired O
number O
of O
frames O
below O
the O
FD O
cutoff O
( O
scanning-to-criterion O
) O
, O
we O
generated O
low O
movement O
data O
( O
FD O
< O
0.2 O
mm O
) O
accumulation O
plots O
for O
all O
1134 O
scan O
session O
. O

These O
plots O
show O
the O
accumulation O
of O
low O
movement O
data O
( O
min. O
, O
y-axis O
) O
relative O
to O
the O
time O
spent O
scanning O
( O
min O
. O

; O
x-axis O
) O
( O
Fig O
. O

5a O
) O
. O

We O
then O
generated O
low O
movement O
data O
accumulation O
plots O
for O
each O
of O
our O
cohorts O
( O
ASD O
, O
ADHD O
, O
FHA O
, O
Control O
) O
( O
Fig O
. O

5b O
) O
. O

In O
these O
plots O
the O
area O
under O
the O
curve O
represents O
the O
relative O
scan O
time O
savings O
( O
percent O
) O
when O
scanning-to-criterion O
instead O
of O
scanning O
all O
participants O
for O
20 O
min O
. O

For O
those O
scan O
sessions O
with O
< O
20 O
min O
of O
collected O
data O
, O
we O
linearly O
extrapolated O
the O
accumulation O
of O
usable O
frames O
from O
the O
existing O
data O
( O
Fig O
. O

5b O
) O
. O

We O
also O
used O
the O
1134 O
individual O
low O
movement O
data O
accumulation O
plots O
to O
calculate O
the O
time O
difference O
in O
time-to-criterion O
between O
the O
FIRMM O
and O
Offline O
methods O
( O
Supplementary O
Fig O
. O

4 O
) O
. O

Affinity O
States O
of O
Striatal O
Dopamine O
D2 O
Receptors O
in O
Antipsychotic-Free O
Patients O
with O
Schizophrenia O
Abstract O
Background O
Dopamine O
D2 O
receptors O
are O
reported O
to O
have O
high-affinity O
( O
D2High O
) O
and O
low-affinity O
( O
D2Low O
) O
states O
. O

Although O
an O
increased O
proportion O
of O
D2High O
has O
been O
demonstrated O
in O
animal O
models O
of O
schizophrenia O
, O
few O
clinical O
studies O
have O
investigated O
this O
alteration O
of O
D2High O
in O
schizophrenia O
in O
vivo O
. O

Methods O
Eleven O
patients O
with O
schizophrenia O
, O
including O
10 O
antipsychotic-naive O
and O
1 O
antipsychotic-free O
individuals O
, O
and O
17 O
healthy O
controls O
were O
investigated O
. O

Psychopathology O
was O
assessed O
by O
Positive O
and O
Negative O
Syndrome O
Scale O
, O
and O
a O
5-factor O
model O
was O
used O
. O

Two O
radioligands O
, O
[ O
11C O
] O
raclopride O
and O
[ O
11C O
] O
MNPA O
, O
were O
employed O
to O
quantify O
total O
dopamine O
D2 O
receptor O
and O
D2High O
, O
respectively O
, O
in O
the O
striatum O
by O
measuring O
their O
binding O
potentials O
. O

Binding O
potential O
values O
of O
[ O
11C O
] O
raclopride O
and O
[ O
11C O
] O
MNPA O
and O
the O
binding O
potential O
ratio O
of O
[ O
11C O
] O
MNPA O
to O
[ O
11C O
] O
raclopride O
in O
the O
striatal O
subregions O
were O
statistically O
compared O
between O
the O
2 O
diagnostic O
groups O
using O
multivariate O
analysis O
of O
covariance O
controlling O
for O
age O
, O
gender O
, O
and O
smoking O
. O

Correlations O
between O
binding O
potential O
and O
Positive O
and O
Negative O
Syndrome O
Scale O
scores O
were O
also O
examined O
. O

Results O
Multivariate O
analysis O
of O
covariance O
demonstrated O
a O
significant O
effect O
of O
diagnosis O
( O
schizophrenia O
and O
control O
) O
on O
the O
binding O
potential O
ratio O
( O
P=.018 O
) O
, O
although O
the O
effects O
of O
diagnosis O
on O
binding O
potential O
values O
obtained O
with O
either O
[ O
11C O
] O
raclopride O
or O
[ O
11C O
] O
MNPA O
were O
nonsignificant O
. O

Posthoc O
test O
showed O
that O
the O
binding O
potential O
ratio O
was O
significantly O
higher O
in O
the O
putamen O
of O
patients O
( O
P=.017 O
) O
. O

The O
Positive O
and O
Negative O
Syndrome O
Scale O
“ O
depressed O
” O
factor O
in O
patients O
was O
positively O
correlated O
with O
binding O
potential O
values O
of O
both O
ligands O
in O
the O
caudate O
. O

Conclusions O
The O
present O
study O
indicates O
the O
possibilities O
of O
: O
( O
1 O
) O
a O
higher O
proportion O
of O
D2High O
in O
the O
putamen O
despite O
unaltered O
amounts O
of O
total O
dopamine O
D2 O
receptors O
; O
and O
( O
2 O
) O
associations O
between O
depressive O
symptoms O
and O
amounts O
of O
caudate O
dopamine O
D2 O
receptors O
in O
patients O
with O
schizophrenia O
. O

Methods O
Participants O
A O
total O
of O
11 O
patients O
with O
schizophrenia O
( O
4 O
men O
and O
7 O
women O
) O
were O
recruited O
from O
affiliated O
hospitals O
or O
clinics O
. O

Seventeen O
healthy O
controls O
( O
8 O
men O
and O
9 O
women O
) O
were O
recruited O
by O
the O
National O
Institute O
of O
Radiological O
Sciences O
, O
Chiba O
, O
Japan O
, O
for O
participation O
in O
this O
study O
. O

The O
patient O
group O
was O
comprised O
of O
10 O
antipsychotic-naive O
patients O
( O
one O
had O
taken O
benzodiazepines O
the O
night O
before O
her O
PET O
scans O
) O
and O
1 O
patient O
who O
had O
been O
antipsychotic-free O
for O
2 O
years O
after O
1-year O
treatment O
with O
aripiprazole O
. O

All O
patients O
fulfilled O
the O
diagnostic O
criteria O
for O
schizophrenia O
according O
to O
DSM-IV O
. O

None O
of O
the O
patients O
were O
comorbid O
with O
other O
neuropsychiatric O
disorders O
or O
had O
substance O
abuse O
. O

Psychopathology O
was O
assessed O
using O
the O
Positive O
and O
Negative O
Syndrome O
Scale O
( O
PANSS O
) O
, O
and O
a O
5-factor O
model O
was O
used O
to O
calculate O
PANSS O
subscale O
scores O
( O
positive O
, O
negative O
, O
disorganized/concrete O
, O
excited O
, O
and O
depressed O
factors O
) O
. O

The O
healthy O
control O
volunteers O
were O
recruited O
by O
public O
notices O
. O

They O
had O
no O
history O
of O
psychiatric O
disease O
, O
neurological O
injury O
or O
disease O
, O
severe O
medical O
diseases O
, O
substance O
abuse O
that O
may O
affect O
brain O
functions O
, O
or O
first-degree O
relatives O
suffering O
from O
psychotic O
episodes O
. O

All O
the O
diagnostic O
interviews O
and O
PANSS O
ratings O
were O
conducted O
by O
trained O
psychiatrists O
. O

Table O
1 O
presents O
the O
participants O
’ O
demographic O
information O
. O

This O
study O
was O
approved O
by O
the O
Radiation O
Drug O
Safety O
Committee O
and O
the O
Institutional O
Review O
Board O
of O
the O
National O
Institute O
of O
Radiological O
Sciences O
, O
Japan O
, O
and O
was O
carried O
out O
in O
accordance O
with O
the O
Code O
of O
Ethics O
of O
the O
World O
Medical O
Association O
. O

After O
complete O
description O
of O
the O
study O
, O
written O
informed O
consent O
was O
obtained O
from O
all O
participants O
. O

Data O
were O
collected O
between O
April O
2008 O
and O
October O
2016 O
. O

PET O
Procedures O
All O
subjects O
underwent O
2 O
PET O
scans O
on O
the O
same O
day O
, O
one O
with O
[ O
11C O
] O
raclopride O
and O
the O
other O
with O
[ O
11C O
] O
MNPA O
, O
except O
1 O
control O
subject O
who O
took O
the O
2 O
scans O
on O
separate O
days O
due O
to O
technical O
trouble O
. O

[ O
11C O
] O
MNPA-PET O
preceded O
[ O
11C O
] O
raclopride-PET O
in O
10 O
patients O
and O
11 O
controls O
, O
and O
[ O
11C O
] O
raclopride-PET O
was O
followed O
by O
[ O
11C O
] O
MNPA-PET O
in O
1 O
patient O
and O
6 O
controls O
. O

After O
i.v O
. O

rapid O
bolus O
injection O
of O
[ O
11C O
] O
raclopride O
, O
a O
PET O
scan O
was O
performed O
for O
60 O
minutes O
. O

Similarly O
, O
after O
i.v O
. O

rapid O
bolus O
injection O
of O
[ O
11C O
] O
MNPA O
, O
a O
PET O
scan O
was O
performed O
for O
90 O
minutes O
. O

The O
time O
interval O
between O
initiations O
of O
the O
first O
and O
second O
PET O
scans O
was O
120 O
minutes O
or O
longer O
. O

For O
both O
PET O
scans O
, O
3-dimensional O
dynamic O
PET O
data O
were O
acquired O
with O
a O
Siemens O
ECAT O
Exact O
HR+ O
system O
( O
CTI/Siemens O
) O
, O
which O
provides O
63 O
sections O
with O
an O
axial O
field O
of O
view O
of O
15.5 O
cm O
. O

PET O
images O
were O
reconstructed O
with O
a O
filtered O
back-projection O
method O
with O
corrections O
for O
attenuation O
and O
scatter O
. O

The O
reconstructed O
in-plane O
resolution O
was O
7.5 O
mm O
full-width O
at O
half-maximum O
. O

A O
10-minute O
transmission O
scan O
using O
a O
68Ge/68Ga O
line O
source O
was O
performed O
before O
each O
PET O
scan O
for O
attenuation O
correction O
. O

A O
thermoplastic O
head O
fixation O
device O
was O
used O
to O
minimize O
head O
movement O
during O
PET O
scanning O
. O

The O
dynamic O
scans O
consisted O
of O
twelve O
20-second O
frames O
, O
sixteen O
60-second O
frames O
, O
and O
ten O
240-second O
frames O
for O
[ O
11C O
] O
raclopride O
, O
and O
nine O
20-second O
frames O
, O
five O
60-second O
frames O
, O
four O
120-second O
frames O
, O
eleven O
240-second O
frames O
, O
and O
six O
300-second O
frames O
for O
[ O
11C O
] O
MNPA O
. O

MRI O
Procedures O
Because O
of O
replacements O
of O
MRI O
machines O
during O
this O
study O
, O
3 O
types O
of O
MRI O
devices O
were O
used O
depending O
on O
the O
time O
of O
participant O
recruitment O
. O

For O
the O
initial O
4 O
patients O
and O
7 O
controls O
, O
MR O
images O
were O
acquired O
with O
a O
1.5-T O
MR O
scanner O
( O
Intera O
, O
Philips O
Medical O
Systems O
) O
. O

3D O
volumetric O
acquisition O
of O
a O
T1-weighted O
gradient O
echo O
sequence O
produced O
a O
gapless O
series O
of O
thin O
transverse O
sections O
( O
TE O
9.2 O
ms O
, O
TR O
21 O
ms O
, O
flip O
angle O
30° O
, O
field O
of O
view O
256 O
mm O
, O
acquisition O
matrix O
256 O
× O
256 O
, O
slice O
thickness O
1 O
mm O
) O
. O

Then O
, O
for O
the O
next O
6 O
patients O
, O
a O
3-T O
MR O
scanner O
( O
Sigma O
HDx O
, O
General O
Electric O
) O
was O
used O
. O

3D O
volumetric O
acquisition O
of O
a O
T1-weighted O
3-dimensional O
fast O
spoiled O
gradient-recalled O
acquisition O
in O
the O
steady-state O
sequence O
produced O
a O
gapless O
series O
of O
thin O
transverse O
sections O
( O
TE O
2.8 O
ms O
, O
TR O
7.0 O
ms O
, O
flip O
angle O
8° O
, O
field O
of O
view O
260 O
mm O
, O
acquisition O
matrix O
256 O
× O
256 O
, O
slice O
thickness O
1 O
mm O
) O
. O

Finally O
, O
for O
1 O
patient O
and O
10 O
controls O
, O
T1-weighted O
MR O
images O
were O
obtained O
with O
another O
3-T O
MR O
scanner O
( O
MAGNETOM O
Verio O
, O
Siemens O
) O
. O

3D O
volumetric O
acquisition O
of O
a O
T1-weighted O
gradient O
echo O
sequence O
produced O
a O
gapless O
series O
of O
thin O
sagittal O
sections O
( O
TE O
1.95 O
ms O
, O
TR O
2300 O
ms O
, O
TI O
900 O
ms O
, O
flip O
angle O
9° O
, O
field O
of O
view O
250 O
mm O
, O
acquisition O
matrix O
256×256 O
, O
slice O
thickness O
1 O
mm O
) O
. O

Region O
of O
Interest O
( O
ROI O
) O
Definition O
All O
ROIs O
used O
in O
our O
analyses O
were O
initially O
defined O
on O
a O
standard O
anatomic O
orientation O
( O
MNI O
standard O
space O
; O
Montreal O
Neurological O
Institute O
) O
. O

Striatum O
ROIs O
( O
caudate O
, O
putamen O
, O
and O
ventral O
striata O
) O
were O
defined O
using O
a O
striatum O
anatomical O
atlas O
. O

A O
cerebellum O
ROI O
was O
defined O
with O
a O
probabilistic O
cerebellar O
atlas O
, O
excluding O
the O
vermis O
. O

These O
ROIs O
were O
transformed O
into O
individual O
MR O
spaces O
with O
transformation O
matrices O
calculated O
with O
the O
“ O
normalize O
” O
function O
of O
statistical O
parametric O
mapping O
software O
( O
SPM12 O
; O
Wellcome O
Department O
of O
Imaging O
Neuroscience O
) O
and O
were O
thresholded O
using O
FreeSurfer O
’ O
s O
automated O
anatomical O
segmentation O
to O
exclude O
neighboring O
white O
matter O
, O
ventricles O
, O
and O
non-brain O
regions O
. O

Time-activity O
curves O
for O
each O
ROI O
were O
extracted O
by O
applying O
these O
ROIs O
to O
individual O
dynamic O
PET O
images O
based O
on O
the O
transformation O
parameters O
for O
the O
coregistration O
of O
MR O
images O
to O
the O
PET O
spaces O
using O
PMOD O
software O
ver O
. O

3.7 O
( O
PMOD O
Technologies O
Ltd O
) O
. O

Quantification O
of O
Total O
D2R O
and O
D2High O
Availabilities O
in O
the O
Striatum O
Availabilities O
of O
striatal O
total O
D2R O
and O
D2High O
were O
quantified O
as O
binding O
potentials O
relative O
to O
the O
nondisplaceable O
tissue O
( O
BPND O
) O
of O
[ O
11C O
] O
raclopride O
and O
[ O
11C O
] O
MNPA O
, O
respectively O
. O

[ O
11C O
] O
raclopride O
BPND O
and O
[ O
11C O
] O
MNPA O
BPND O
were O
calculated O
for O
each O
ROI O
using O
a O
3-parameter O
simplified O
reference O
tissue O
model O
and O
cerebellar O
cortex O
as O
reference O
tissue O
, O
which O
has O
negligible O
density O
of O
D2R O
. O

BPND O
was O
defined O
as O
follows O
: O
where O
fND O
is O
the O
free O
fraction O
of O
radioligand O
in O
the O
nondisplaceable O
tissue O
compartment O
and O
Bavail O
indicates O
the O
neuroreceptor O
density O
. O

All O
kinetic O
analyses O
were O
performed O
using O
PMOD O
software O
ver O
. O

3.7 O
. O

Statistical O
Analysis O
Statistical O
analyses O
were O
conducted O
with O
SPSS O
23.0 O
( O
SPSS O
Inc O
) O
. O

First O
, O
MANCOVA O
was O
applied O
to O
examine O
group O
differences O
in O
: O
( O
1 O
) O
BPND O
of O
[ O
11C O
] O
raclopride O
; O
( O
2 O
) O
BPND O
of O
[ O
11C O
] O
MNPA O
; O
and O
( O
3 O
) O
the O
BPND O
ratio O
( O
ratio O
of O
[ O
11C O
] O
MNPA O
BPND O
to O
[ O
11C O
] O
raclopride O
BPND O
) O
in O
3 O
striatal O
ROIs O
( O
caudate O
, O
putamen O
, O
and O
ventral O
striata O
) O
, O
separately O
. O

A O
fixed O
factor O
was O
diagnosis O
( O
patients O
= O
1 O
, O
controls O
= O
0 O
) O
. O

Nuisance O
covariates O
were O
defined O
as O
age O
, O
gender O
, O
and O
smoking O
state O
( O
smoker O
= O
1 O
, O
nonsmoker O
= O
0 O
) O
to O
control O
for O
their O
potential O
effects O
on O
D2Rs O
. O

Statistical O
significance O
threshold O
was O
defined O
as O
P O
< O
.05 O
( O
2-tailed O
) O
. O

Second O
, O
correlational O
analyses O
were O
performed O
between O
the O
BPND O
values O
mentioned O
above O
and O
each O
of O
the O
PANSS O
factor O
scores O
( O
positive O
, O
negative O
, O
disorganized/concrete O
, O
excited O
, O
and O
depressed O
factors O
) O
in O
patients O
. O

The O
statistical O
threshold O
was O
set O
at O
P O
< O
.05 O
with O
Bonferroni O
correction O
for O
the O
3 O
striatal O
subregions O
( O
caudate O
, O
putamen O
, O
and O
ventral O
striata O
) O
, O
as O
in O
previous O
studies O
. O

Because O
of O
the O
small O
sample O
size O
and O
exploratory O
nature O
of O
this O
study O
, O
corrections O
were O
not O
applied O
for O
multiple O
comparisons O
of O
the O
5 O
PANSS O
factor O
scores O
and O
the O
3 O
binding O
parameters O
( O
[ O
11C O
] O
raclopride O
BPND O
, O
[ O
11C O
] O
MNPA O
BPND O
, O
and O
their O
ratio O
) O
. O

In O
case O
significant O
correlations O
were O
found O
, O
partial O
correlation O
analyses O
were O
also O
performed O
, O
controlling O
for O
age O
, O
gender O
, O
smoking O
state O
, O
or O
duration O
of O
illness O
. O

Statistical O
significance O
threshold O
was O
defined O
as O
P O
< O
.05 O
( O
2-tailed O
) O
. O

Altered O
anterior O
cingulate O
cortex O
to O
hippocampus O
effective O
connectivity O
in O
response O
to O
drug O
cues O
in O
men O
with O
cocaine O
use O
disorder O
Drug-related O
attentional O
bias O
may O
have O
significant O
implications O
for O
the O
treatment O
of O
cocaine O
use O
disorder O
( O
CocUD O
) O
. O

However O
, O
the O
neurobiology O
of O
attentional O
bias O
is O
not O
completely O
understood O
. O

This O
study O
employed O
dynamic O
causal O
modeling O
( O
DCM O
) O
to O
conduct O
an O
analysis O
of O
effective O
( O
directional O
) O
connectivity O
involved O
in O
drug-related O
attentional O
bias O
in O
treatment-seeking O
CocUD O
subjects O
. O

The O
DCM O
analysis O
was O
conducted O
based O
on O
functional O
magnetic O
resonance O
imaging O
( O
fMRI O
) O
data O
acquired O
from O
fifteen O
CocUD O
subjects O
while O
performing O
a O
cocaine-word O
Stroop O
task O
, O
during O
which O
blocks O
of O
Cocaine O
Words O
( O
CW O
) O
and O
Neutral O
Words O
( O
NW O
) O
alternated O
. O

There O
was O
no O
significant O
attentional O
bias O
at O
group O
level O
. O

Although O
no O
significant O
brain O
activation O
was O
found O
, O
the O
DCM O
analysis O
found O
that O
, O
relative O
to O
the O
NW O
, O
the O
CW O
caused O
a O
significant O
increase O
in O
the O
strength O
of O
the O
right O
( O
R O
) O
anterior O
cingulate O
cortex O
( O
ACC O
) O
to O
R O
hippocampus O
effective O
connectivity O
. O

Greater O
increase O
of O
this O
connectivity O
was O
associated O
with O
greater O
CW O
reaction O
time O
( O
relative O
to O
NW O
reaction O
time O
) O
. O

The O
increased O
strength O
of O
R O
ACC O
to O
R O
hippocampus O
connectivity O
may O
reflect O
ACC O
activation O
of O
hippocampal O
memories O
related O
to O
drug O
use O
, O
which O
was O
triggered O
by O
the O
drug O
cues O
. O

This O
circuit O
could O
be O
a O
potential O
target O
for O
therapeutics O
in O
CocUD O
patients O
. O

No O
significant O
change O
was O
found O
in O
the O
other O
modeled O
connectivities O
. O

2 O
. O

METHODS O
2.1 O
Subjects O
The O
study O
was O
officially O
approved O
by O
the O
local O
Institutional O
Review O
Board O
, O
and O
was O
performed O
in O
accordance O
with O
the O
Code O
of O
Ethics O
of O
the O
World O
Medical O
Association O
( O
Declaration O
of O
Helsinki O
) O
. O

Informed O
consent O
was O
obtained O
from O
each O
subject O
. O

The O
CocUD O
subjects O
were O
from O
a O
treatment O
study O
, O
in O
which O
the O
majority O
of O
the O
participants O
were O
male O
. O

All O
MRI O
scans O
took O
place O
prior O
to O
the O
initiation O
of O
medication O
treatment O
. O

All O
subjects O
were O
screened O
using O
the O
Structured O
Clinical O
Interview O
for O
DSM-IV O
( O
SCID O
) O
and O
underwent O
physical O
examination O
and O
medical O
history O
. O

The O
Addiction O
Severity O
Index O
was O
obtained O
to O
document O
lifetime O
drug O
and O
alcohol O
use O
. O

Female O
subjects O
were O
screened O
with O
a O
urine O
pregnancy O
test O
immediately O
prior O
to O
MRI O
scanning O
. O

Each O
subject O
’ O
s O
urine O
was O
screened O
for O
tetrahydrocannabinol O
( O
THC O
) O
, O
opiates O
, O
cocaine O
, O
amphetamines O
, O
and O
benzodiazepines O
( O
Syva O
Company O
, O
Deerfield O
, O
IL O
) O
, O
and O
each O
subject O
was O
screened O
for O
alcohol O
with O
an O
Intoximeter O
Alco-Sensor O
III O
breathalyzer O
( O
Intoximeters O
, O
Inc. O
, O
St. O
Louis O
, O
MO O
) O
immediately O
prior O
to O
MRI O
scanning O
. O

Subject O
inclusion O
criteria O
were O
: O
( O
1 O
) O
18–55 O
years O
old O
; O
( O
2 O
) O
right-handed O
; O
( O
3 O
) O
free O
of O
alcohol O
at O
the O
time O
of O
MRI O
scanning O
; O
( O
4 O
) O
met O
Diagnostic O
and O
Statistical O
Manual O
Fourth O
Edition O
( O
DSM-IV O
) O
criteria O
for O
current O
cocaine O
dependence O
based O
on O
the O
Structured O
Clinical O
Interview O
for O
DSM-IV O
. O

Exclusion O
criteria O
were O
: O
( O
1 O
) O
subjects O
who O
met O
current O
or O
past O
DSM-IV O
Axis O
I O
disorder O
other O
than O
substance O
abuse O
or O
substance O
dependence O
; O
( O
2 O
) O
medical O
disorders O
or O
taking O
medication O
that O
may O
affect O
the O
central O
nervous O
system O
; O
( O
3 O
) O
claustrophobia O
experienced O
during O
MRI O
or O
MRI O
simulator O
sessions O
; O
( O
4 O
) O
any O
definite O
or O
suspected O
clinically O
significant O
abnormalities O
of O
the O
brain O
on O
Fluid O
Attenuated O
Inversion O
Recovery O
( O
FLAIR O
) O
MRI O
scans O
; O
( O
5 O
) O
positive O
pregnancy O
test O
result O
. O

Based O
on O
above O
criteria O
, O
fifteen O
CocUD O
subjects O
, O
among O
the O
26 O
CocUD O
subjects O
who O
were O
scanned O
, O
were O
included O
for O
final O
analysis O
. O

See O
Table O
1 O
for O
the O
demographics O
and O
drug-use O
information O
of O
these O
subjects O
. O

This O
is O
a O
free-standing O
study O
; O
all O
the O
CocUD O
subjects O
( O
n=26 O
) O
who O
were O
scanned O
were O
considered O
. O

Eleven O
CocUD O
subjects O
were O
excuded O
because O
of O
either O
missing O
behavioral O
performance O
data O
( O
n=1 O
) O
; O
excessive O
head O
motion O
during O
the O
fMRI O
scan O
( O
n=2 O
) O
; O
clinically O
significant O
abnormal O
results O
on O
FLAIR O
scan O
of O
the O
brain O
( O
n=4 O
) O
; O
subject O
’ O
s O
request O
to O
terminate O
the O
scanning O
( O
n=2 O
) O
; O
or O
current O
alcohol O
dependence O
( O
n=2 O
) O
. O

The O
majority O
of O
the O
participants O
were O
male O
. O

The O
one O
female O
subject O
who O
was O
scanned O
was O
excluded O
because O
of O
excessive O
head O
motion O
. O

2.2 O
Cocaine-word O
Stroop O
fMRI O
Task O
The O
subject O
was O
presented O
with O
ten O
cocaine O
words O
( O
CW O
) O
and O
ten O
neutral O
words O
( O
NW O
) O
, O
one O
word O
at O
a O
time O
. O

The O
CW O
and O
NW O
were O
matched O
in O
letter O
length O
. O

Both O
CW O
( O
e.g. O
, O
“ O
cocaine O
” O
, O
“ O
crack O
” O
) O
and O
NW O
( O
e.g. O
, O
“ O
kitchen O
” O
, O
“ O
table O
” O
) O
were O
frequently O
used O
words O
in O
the O
English O
language O
. O

Each O
word O
when O
presented O
was O
randomly O
printed O
in O
one O
of O
three O
different O
colors O
( O
blue O
, O
green O
, O
or O
red O
) O
. O

The O
subject O
was O
instructed O
to O
ignore O
the O
meaning O
of O
the O
word O
and O
to O
press O
the O
appropriate O
button O
to O
denote O
the O
color O
in O
which O
the O
word O
was O
printed O
. O

Each O
word O
was O
shown O
for O
a O
maximum O
duration O
of O
1800 O
ms O
( O
if O
no O
response O
) O
, O
but O
the O
display O
of O
the O
word O
was O
terminated O
by O
a O
response O
, O
after O
which O
a O
blank O
screen O
was O
shown O
for O
the O
remainder O
of O
the O
trial O
up O
to O
1900 O
ms O
. O

The O
next O
trial O
immediately O
began O
with O
the O
presentation O
of O
the O
next O
word O
. O

Four O
CW O
blocks O
and O
four O
NW O
blocks O
alternated O
with O
a O
12 O
s O
pause O
between O
blocks O
. O

Within O
each O
block O
( O
58 O
s O
per O
block O
) O
, O
thirty O
words O
were O
presented O
. O

The O
effect O
of O
drug O
cues O
on O
the O
reaction O
times O
( O
ΔRT O
) O
was O
measured O
by O
the O
mean O
reaction O
time O
during O
all O
the O
CW O
blocks O
minus O
that O
during O
all O
of O
the O
NW O
blocks O
, O
i.e. O
, O
ΔRT O
= O
RT O
( O
CW O
) O
minus O
RT O
( O
NW O
) O
. O

Only O
the O
correct-response O
trials O
were O
included O
when O
calculating O
the O
mean O
reaction O
times O
. O

ΔRT O
was O
treated O
as O
a O
measure O
of O
attentional O
bias O
at O
the O
behavioral O
level O
in O
the O
present O
study O
. O

2.3 O
fMRI O
Data O
Acquisition O
MRI O
data O
were O
acquired O
on O
a O
Philips O
3.0 O
T O
Intera O
system O
with O
an O
eight O
channel O
receive O
head O
coil O
( O
Philips O
Medical O
Systems O
, O
Best O
, O
Netherlands O
) O
. O

Single O
shot O
spin O
echo O
echoplanar O
imaging O
( O
EPI O
) O
was O
used O
for O
acquiring O
fMRI O
data O
. O

The O
fMRI O
acquisition O
parameters O
were O
: O
SENSE O
acceleration O
factor O
2.0 O
, O
repetition O
time O
2500 O
ms O
, O
echo O
time O
75 O
ms O
, O
flip O
angle O
90 O
degrees O
, O
field O
of O
view O
240 O
mm O
× O
240 O
mm O
, O
in-plane O
resolution O
3.75 O
mm O
× O
3.75 O
mm O
, O
25 O
axial O
slices O
, O
slice O
thickness O
3.75 O
mm O
, O
interslice O
gap O
1.25 O
mm O
, O
224 O
repetitions O
per O
run O
after O
10 O
dummy O
acquisitions O
, O
total O
duration O
per O
run O
was O
10 O
min O
40 O
s. O
2.4 O
fMRI O
Preprocessing O
During O
an O
fMRI O
run O
, O
individual O
scans O
in O
which O
the O
fMRI O
signal O
exceeded O
plus O
or O
minus O
four O
standard O
deviations O
from O
the O
mean O
were O
considered O
to O
be O
outliers O
and O
were O
replaced O
by O
the O
mean O
of O
the O
two O
nearest O
neighbors O
using O
the O
Analysis O
of O
Functional O
NeuroImages O
( O
AFNI O
) O
software O
command O
“ O
3dDespike O
” O
( O
http O
: O
//afni.nimh.nih.gov/afni/ O
) O
. O

All O
subsequent O
preprocessing O
used O
Statistical O
Parametric O
Mapping O
12 O
( O
SPM12 O
) O
software O
( O
http O
: O
//www.fil.ion.ucl.ac.uk/spm/ O
) O
implemented O
in O
Matlab O
R2007b O
( O
Mathworks O
Inc. O
Sherborn O
MA O
, O
USA O
) O
. O

After O
slice O
timing O
correction O
, O
the O
fMRI O
series O
was O
realigned O
to O
the O
first O
image O
to O
correct O
for O
head O
motion O
. O

Runs O
with O
head O
motion O
greater O
than O
1 O
voxel O
( O
3.75 O
mm O
translation O
on O
any O
axis O
) O
or O
rotation O
greater O
than O
3.75 O
degrees O
were O
removed O
from O
the O
analysis O
. O

The O
anatomical O
image O
was O
coregistered O
to O
the O
fMRI O
images O
and O
spatially O
transformed O
to O
Montreal O
Neurological O
Institute O
( O
MNI O
) O
standard O
atlas O
coordinates O
using O
the O
SPM12 O
Normalise O
module O
with O
the O
SPM12 O
T1 O
MNI O
template O
image O
. O

The O
transformation O
parameters O
were O
applied O
to O
the O
fMRI O
images O
, O
which O
were O
resliced O
to O
2 O
mm O
isotropic O
resolution O
and O
spatially O
smoothed O
with O
a O
Gaussian O
filter O
of O
8 O
mm O
isotropic O
full O
width O
at O
half O
maximum O
. O

2.5 O
SPM O
univariate O
analysis O
First O
level O
univariate O
statistical O
analysis O
of O
the O
fMRI O
data O
was O
conducted O
using O
SPM12 O
. O

CW O
and O
NW O
blocks O
( O
conditions O
) O
were O
modeled O
by O
boxcar O
functions O
convolved O
with O
the O
SPM12 O
canonical O
hemodynamic O
response O
function O
. O

The O
parameters O
for O
each O
condition O
were O
estimated O
using O
the O
General O
Linear O
Model O
at O
each O
voxel O
without O
global O
normalization O
. O

The O
fMRI O
time O
series O
was O
high-pass O
filtered O
with O
an O
optimized O
cut-off O
period O
of O
188 O
s O
determined O
by O
the O
Fourier O
transformation O
of O
each O
condition O
’ O
s O
time O
model O
. O

Attentional O
bias O
activation O
was O
defined O
as O
the O
contrast O
at O
each O
voxel O
of O
the O
parameter O
estimate O
for O
CW O
blocks O
minus O
the O
parameter O
estimate O
for O
NW O
blocks O
( O
CW O
minus O
NW O
contrast O
) O
. O

The O
resulting O
set O
of O
voxel O
values O
for O
this O
contrast O
constitutes O
a O
statistical O
parametric O
map O
for O
that O
contrast O
. O

The O
CW O
minus O
NW O
contrast O
image O
( O
one O
per O
subject O
) O
was O
then O
entered O
at O
the O
SPM12 O
second O
level O
( O
i.e. O
, O
random O
effects O
) O
group O
analysis O
. O

To O
determine O
the O
group O
level O
blood-oxygen-level O
dependent O
( O
BOLD O
) O
activation O
, O
a O
SPM12 O
second O
level O
Random O
Effects O
one-sample O
t-test O
was O
conducted O
voxel-wise O
throughout O
the O
whole O
brain O
for O
the O
contrast O
image O
( O
CW O
minus O
NW O
) O
. O

Statistical O
significance O
was O
defined O
as O
family-wise O
error O
( O
FWE O
) O
corrected O
cluster O
probability O
( O
p O
) O
less O
than O
0.05 O
( O
two O
tail O
) O
. O

The O
brain O
activations O
found O
by O
this O
analysis O
were O
used O
for O
DCM O
nodes O
( O
regions O
of O
interest O
) O
selection O
, O
but O
the O
statistical O
significance O
was O
defined O
as O
uncorrected O
cluster O
p O
less O
than O
0.05 O
( O
two O
tail O
) O
. O

It O
is O
commonly O
accepted O
to O
use O
uncorrected O
cluster O
p O
less O
than O
0.05 O
( O
two O
tail O
) O
for O
determining O
DCM O
nodes O
. O

For O
all O
SPM12 O
second O
level O
analyses O
, O
the O
cluster-defining O
threshold O
was O
t O
= O
2.4 O
. O

Anatomical O
labels O
for O
regions O
of O
activation O
were O
determined O
using O
the O
Anatomical O
Automatic O
Labeling O
( O
AAL O
) O
toolbox O
. O

2.6 O
Dynamic O
causal O
modeling O
FMRI-based O
DCM O
is O
a O
biophysical O
model O
of O
the O
underlying O
neuronal O
connectivity O
and O
of O
how O
the O
neuronal O
connectivity O
generates O
the O
observed O
BOLD O
signal O
. O

DCM O
with O
stochastic O
option O
, O
as O
implemented O
in O
SPM12 O
( O
Revision O
6906 O
) O
, O
was O
used O
for O
effective O
connectivity O
analysis O
. O

DCM O
has O
been O
described O
elsewhere O
. O

In O
brief O
, O
the O
mathematical O
model O
of O
the O
underlying O
neuronal O
connectivity O
among O
an O
a O
priori O
selected O
set O
of O
brain O
regions O
is O
a O
system O
of O
bilinear O
differential O
state O
equations O
with O
coefficients O
specified O
by O
three O
matrices O
( O
A O
matrix O
, O
B O
matrix O
and O
C O
matrix O
) O
. O

In O
this O
model O
, O
the O
experimental O
conditions O
( O
i.e. O
, O
CW O
and O
NW O
) O
can O
serve O
as O
inputs O
to O
the O
model O
as O
either O
driving O
inputs O
, O
or O
modulatory O
inputs O
, O
or O
both O
. O

The O
DCM O
analysis O
determines O
which O
particular O
nodes O
in O
the O
model O
exhibit O
effective O
connectivity O
with O
other O
specific O
nodes O
in O
the O
model O
, O
which O
nodes O
receive O
driving O
inputs O
from O
experimental O
conditions O
into O
the O
model O
, O
and O
which O
specific O
connectivities O
between O
nodes O
in O
the O
model O
are O
modulated O
( O
i.e. O
, O
changed O
in O
connectivity O
strength O
, O
in O
units O
of O
Hz O
) O
under O
experimental O
conditions O
. O

A O
node O
( O
driving O
input O
location O
) O
in O
the O
model O
that O
receives O
driving O
inputs O
, O
as O
quantified O
by O
the O
C O
matrix O
parameters O
, O
is O
the O
brain O
region O
among O
the O
nodes O
in O
the O
model O
which O
first O
experiences O
a O
change O
in O
neuronal O
activity O
. O

The O
node O
that O
receives O
the O
driving O
input O
then O
influences O
( O
“ O
drives O
” O
) O
the O
connectivity O
to O
other O
nodes O
in O
the O
model O
. O

The O
endogenous O
( O
or O
fixed O
) O
connectivity O
in O
DCM O
is O
quantified O
by O
the O
A O
matrix O
parameters O
, O
which O
measure O
the O
effective O
connectivity O
strengths O
( O
in O
units O
of O
Hz O
) O
between O
nodes O
, O
regardless O
of O
the O
moment-to-moment O
switching O
on O
and O
off O
of O
inputs O
. O

Experimental O
conditions O
( O
CW O
and O
NW O
) O
can O
modulate O
the O
endogenous O
connectivity O
among O
nodes O
. O

These O
modulation O
effects O
are O
quantified O
by O
the O
B O
matrix O
parameters O
as O
increased O
or O
decreased O
connectivity O
strength O
compared O
to O
the O
endogenous O
connectivity O
at O
different O
times O
in O
the O
experiment O
that O
are O
related O
to O
the O
timing O
of O
changes O
in O
the O
particular O
experimental O
conditions O
. O

2.6.1 O
DCM O
nodes O
DCM O
node O
selection O
criteria O
were O
: O
( O
1 O
) O
the O
brain O
activations O
found O
in O
this O
study O
, O
( O
2 O
) O
previous O
fMRI O
studies O
using O
cocaine O
stimulus O
Stroop O
tasks O
( O
e.g. O
, O
) O
, O
and O
( O
3 O
) O
theories O
about O
attentional O
bias O
( O
e.g. O
, O
) O
. O

Based O
on O
meeting O
the O
combined O
presence O
of O
all O
of O
the O
above O
three O
criteria O
, O
the O
following O
five O
regions O
served O
as O
nodes O
for O
the O
DCM O
analysis O
: O
( O
1 O
) O
left O
( O
L O
) O
anterior O
cingulate O
cortex O
( O
ACC O
) O
( O
x= O
−8 O
, O
y=46 O
, O
z= O
−4 O
) O
; O
( O
2 O
) O
R O
ACC O
( O
x=10 O
, O
y=26 O
, O
z=24 O
) O
; O
( O
3 O
) O
right O
( O
R O
) O
insula O
( O
x=42 O
, O
y= O
−10 O
, O
z= O
−6 O
) O
; O
( O
4 O
) O
R O
hippocampus O
( O
x=36 O
, O
y= O
−18 O
, O
z= O
−14 O
) O
; O
and O
( O
5 O
) O
L O
caudate O
( O
x= O
−18 O
, O
y= O
−8 O
, O
z=22 O
) O
. O

The O
x O
, O
y O
, O
z O
values O
are O
the O
MNI O
coordinates O
of O
the O
center O
of O
each O
node O
, O
which O
were O
defined O
as O
a O
sphere O
with O
5 O
mm O
radius O
and O
centered O
at O
local O
maximum O
of O
the O
regional O
fMRI O
activation O
corresponding O
to O
that O
node O
. O

For O
each O
node O
, O
the O
functional O
activation O
BOLD O
time-series O
, O
which O
was O
used O
for O
DCM O
analysis O
, O
was O
extracted O
using O
the O
methods O
described O
in O
. O

2.6.2 O
Driving O
input O
and O
modulatory O
input O
The O
CW O
and O
NW O
experimental O
conditions O
were O
not O
directly O
used O
as O
inputs O
. O

Following O
and O
, O
we O
created O
a O
parametric O
regressor O
for O
“ O
All O
Words O
” O
contrast O
, O
and O
another O
parametric O
regressor O
for O
CW O
minus O
NW O
contrast O
. O

The O
method O
of O
constructing O
these O
regressors O
can O
be O
found O
online O
( O
https O
: O
//github.com/HaukeHillebrandt/SPM_connectome O
) O
. O

The O
“ O
All O
Words O
” O
contrast O
, O
which O
reflects O
the O
common O
features O
of O
the O
CW O
and O
NW O
, O
was O
used O
as O
a O
single O
input O
to O
the O
DCM O
( O
driving O
input O
) O
. O

The O
CW O
minus O
NW O
contrast O
, O
which O
reflects O
the O
special O
effect O
of O
CW O
over O
NW O
, O
was O
used O
as O
a O
putative O
modulator O
( O
modulatory O
input O
) O
of O
effective O
connectivity O
( O
the O
factor O
causing O
changes O
in O
the O
effective O
connectivities O
) O
. O

In O
the O
present O
study O
, O
the O
changes O
of O
effective O
connectivities O
( O
relative O
to O
the O
endogenous O
connectivities O
) O
caused O
by O
the O
CW O
minus O
NW O
modulator O
are O
termed O
as O
modulatory O
changes O
. O

By O
definition O
, O
a O
modulatory O
change O
reflects O
the O
change O
in O
an O
effective O
connectivity O
caused O
by O
the O
CW O
minus O
the O
change O
in O
this O
effective O
connectivity O
caused O
by O
the O
NW O
. O

Thus O
the O
effects O
of O
drug O
cues O
( O
CW O
) O
on O
the O
behavioral O
performance O
( O
reaction O
time O
) O
, O
brain O
activation O
, O
and O
effective O
connectivity O
were O
all O
assessed O
relative O
to O
NW O
in O
the O
present O
study O
. O

2.6.3 O
DCM O
inference O
Given O
the O
nodes O
of O
the O
model O
, O
a O
DCM O
post-hoc O
optimization O
analysis O
was O
used O
for O
model O
structure O
inference O
. O

Starting O
from O
a O
fully-connected O
model O
, O
the O
post O
hoc O
optimization O
analysis O
systematically O
searches O
for O
an O
optimal O
“ O
sparse O
” O
model O
that O
determines O
which O
particular O
nodes O
exhibit O
effective O
connectivity O
with O
other O
nodes O
( O
i.e. O
, O
endogenous O
connectivity O
) O
, O
which O
nodes O
first O
experience O
a O
change O
in O
neuronal O
activity O
associated O
with O
the O
“ O
All O
Words O
” O
input O
( O
i.e. O
, O
driving O
input O
effects O
) O
, O
and O
which O
effective O
connectivities O
showed O
modulatory O
changes O
associated O
with O
the O
CW O
minus O
NW O
modulator O
. O

Based O
on O
the O
results O
of O
the O
post O
hoc O
optimization O
analysis O
, O
a O
Bayesian O
model O
averaging O
( O
BMA O
) O
analysis O
was O
conducted O
for O
DCM O
parameter O
inference O
, O
with O
a O
model O
space O
consisting O
of O
the O
fully-connected O
model O
and O
the O
optimal O
sparse O
model O
. O

BMA O
averages O
each O
DCM O
parameter O
across O
models O
( O
and O
across O
subjects O
) O
such O
that O
the O
contribution O
of O
each O
model O
( O
of O
each O
subject O
) O
for O
that O
parameter O
was O
weighted O
by O
the O
model O
’ O
s O
posterior O
probability O
. O

Multimodal O
Fusion O
with O
Reference O
: O
Searching O
for O
Joint O
Neuromarkers O
of O
Working O
Memory O
Deficits O
in O
Schizophrenia O
Multimodal O
fusion O
is O
an O
effective O
approach O
to O
take O
advantage O
of O
cross-information O
among O
multiple O
imaging O
data O
to O
better O
understand O
brain O
diseases O
. O

However O
, O
most O
current O
fusion O
approaches O
are O
blind O
, O
without O
adopting O
any O
prior O
information O
. O

To O
date O
, O
there O
is O
increasing O
interest O
to O
uncover O
the O
neurocognitive O
mapping O
of O
specific O
behavioral O
measurement O
on O
enriched O
brain O
imaging O
data O
; O
hence O
, O
a O
supervised O
, O
goal-directed O
model O
that O
enables O
a O
priori O
information O
as O
a O
reference O
to O
guide O
multimodal O
data O
fusion O
is O
in O
need O
and O
a O
natural O
option O
. O

Here O
we O
proposed O
a O
fusion O
with O
reference O
model O
, O
called O
“ O
multi-site O
canonical O
correlation O
analysis O
with O
reference O
plus O
joint O
independent O
component O
analysis O
” O
( O
MCCAR+jICA O
) O
, O
which O
can O
precisely O
identify O
co-varying O
multimodal O
imaging O
patterns O
closely O
related O
to O
reference O
information O
, O
such O
as O
cognitive O
scores O
. O

In O
a O
3-way O
fusion O
simulation O
, O
the O
proposed O
method O
was O
compared O
with O
its O
alternatives O
on O
estimation O
accuracy O
of O
both O
target O
component O
decomposition O
and O
modality O
linkage O
detection O
. O

MCCAR+jICA O
outperforms O
others O
with O
higher O
precision O
. O

In O
human O
imaging O
data O
, O
working O
memory O
performance O
was O
utilized O
as O
a O
reference O
to O
investigate O
the O
covarying O
functional O
and O
structural O
brain O
patterns O
among O
3 O
modalities O
and O
how O
they O
are O
impaired O
in O
schizophrenia O
. O

Two O
independent O
cohorts O
( O
294 O
and O
83 O
subjects O
respectively O
) O
were O
used O
. O

Interestingly O
, O
similar O
brain O
maps O
were O
identified O
between O
the O
two O
cohorts O
, O
with O
substantial O
overlap O
in O
the O
executive O
control O
networks O
in O
fMRI O
, O
salience O
network O
in O
sMRI O
, O
and O
major O
white O
matter O
tracts O
in O
dMRI O
. O

These O
regions O
have O
been O
linked O
with O
working O
memory O
deficits O
in O
schizophrenia O
in O
multiple O
reports O
, O
while O
MCCAR+jICA O
further O
verified O
them O
in O
a O
repeatable O
, O
joint O
manner O
, O
demonstrating O
the O
potential O
of O
such O
results O
to O
identify O
potential O
neuromarkers O
for O
mental O
disorders O
. O

II O
. O

Methods O
and O
Materials O
The O
main O
idea O
of O
MCCAR+jICA O
is O
straightforward O
: O
while O
maintaining O
the O
performance O
of O
MCCA+jICA O
, O
we O
hope O
to O
optimize O
specific O
subject-level O
correlations O
with O
a O
reference O
. O

To O
do O
this O
, O
a O
prior O
reference O
such O
as O
a O
cognitive O
score O
is O
incorporated O
to O
guide O
joint O
source O
separation O
, O
as O
shown O
in O
Figure O
1 O
. O

A. O
MCCAR O
Assume O
that O
there O
are O
n O
multimodal O
datasets O
Xk O
, O
k O
= O
1,2 O
, O
… O
, O
n O
, O
each O
is O
a O
linear O
mixture O
of O
components O
Ck O
with O
a O
nonsingular O
mixing O
matrix O
Ak O
, O
k O
denotes O
modality O
. O

where O
Xk O
is O
a O
subjects-by-voxels O
feature O
matrix O
, O
Ak O
is O
in O
dimension O
of O
subjects O
by O
number O
of O
components O
M. O
MCCA O
with O
reference O
( O
MCCAR O
) O
imposes O
an O
additional O
constraint O
upon O
the O
MCCA O
framework O
to O
maximize O
not O
only O
the O
covariations O
among O
mixing O
matrices O
of O
each O
modality O
, O
but O
also O
the O
top O
column-wise O
correlations O
between O
Ak O
and O
the O
reference O
signal O
, O
as O
shown O
in O
Figure O
1 O
( O
c O
) O
and O
equation O
( O
2 O
) O
. O

where O
corr O
( O
Ak O
, O
Aj O
) O
is O
the O
column-wise O
correlations O
between O
Ak O
and O
Aj O
, O
k O
, O
j O
= O
{ O
1,2,3 O
… O
n O
} O
, O
k O
≠ O
j O
. O

The O
basic O
strategy O
of O
MCCAR O
is O
as O
follows O
: O
consider O
that O
there O
are O
N O
subjects O
, O
dimension O
reduction O
is O
first O
performed O
on O
Xk O
, O
thus O
the O
signal O
subspace O
given O
by O
Yk O
= O
XkEk O
are O
determined O
. O

MCCAR O
is O
thus O
performed O
on O
Yk O
, O
generating O
the O
canonical O
variants O
Ak O
by O
maximizing O
the O
sum O
of O
squared O
correlations O
( O
SSQCOR O
) O
among O
canonical O
variants O
( O
CVs O
) O
as O
well O
as O
the O
SSQCOR O
between O
each O
CVs O
and O
the O
reference O
signal O
. O

We O
can O
summarize O
the O
optimization O
procedure O
of O
MCCAR O
as O
below O
. O

Consider O
that O
the O
CVs O
Ak O
given O
by O
Ak O
= O
Ykwk O
were O
jointly O
decomposed O
into O
M O
components O
, O
then O
the O
canonical O
coefficient O
vectors O
wk O
are O
updated O
by O
two O
stages O
: O
Stage O
1 O
: O
Stage O
2 O
: O
for O
i O
= O
2 O
: O
M O
end O
where O
is O
the O
ith O
column O
of O
the O
w O
matrices O
, O
is O
the O
correlation O
between O
the O
ith O
column O
of O
Ak O
and O
Aj O
, O
is O
the O
correlation O
between O
the O
ith O
column O
of O
Ak O
and O
the O
reference O
signal O
, O
which O
has O
the O
same O
length O
of O
subject O
numbers O
. O

λ O
is O
the O
regularization O
parameter O
balancing O
the O
weight O
of O
two O
objective O
functions O
: O
and O
and O
controls O
the O
convergence O
of O
the O
optimization O
. O

Stage O
1 O
is O
solved O
by O
first O
calculating O
the O
partial O
derivative O
function O
of O
the O
SSQCOR O
cost O
with O
respect O
to O
each O
and O
equating O
it O
to O
zero O
to O
find O
the O
stationary O
point O
. O

Since O
the O
SSQCOR O
cost O
is O
a O
quadratic O
function O
of O
each O
, O
the O
partial O
derivative O
is O
a O
linear O
function O
of O
and O
hence O
, O
the O
closed O
form O
solution O
can O
be O
derived O
. O

Stage O
2 O
and O
higher O
stages O
are O
solved O
in O
a O
similar O
manner O
with O
the O
cost O
function O
replaced O
by O
a O
Lagrangian O
multiplier O
incorporating O
the O
orthogonality O
constraints O
on O
the O
canonical O
coefficient O
vectors O
. O

In O
Figure O
1 O
, O
k O
≠ O
j O
, O
k O
, O
j O
= O
1,2,3 O
, O
an O
example O
is O
when O
M O
= O
5 O
, O
as O
shown O
in O
Figure O
1 O
( O
b O
) O
and O
( O
c O
) O
, O
based O
on O
the O
above O
optimization O
, O
we O
can O
obtain O
A1 O
, O
A2 O
, O
A3 O
simultaneously O
as O
shown O
in O
Figure O
1 O
( O
d O
) O
, O
which O
satisfies O
: O
k O
≠ O
j O
, O
k O
, O
j O
∈ O
{ O
1,2,3 O
} O
; O
i.e. O
, O
the O
covariation O
of O
Ak O
will O
be O
a O
diagonal O
matrix O
. O

In O
addition O
, O
one O
or O
more O
joint O
components O
, O
here O
the O
3rd O
joint O
component O
, O
will O
be O
the O
target O
component O
that O
has O
significant O
correlations O
with O
the O
reference O
. O

B. O
MCCAR+jICA O
Due O
to O
the O
potential O
marginally O
significant O
correlations O
between O
ROI O
and O
reference O
in O
each O
modality O
, O
applying O
correlation O
with O
reference O
within O
each O
dataset O
may O
introduce O
ambiguity O
in O
feature O
matching O
. O

While O
MCCA O
focus O
only O
on O
maximizing O
inter-modality O
covariance O
as O
shown O
in O
Fig O
. O

1 O
( O
b O
) O
; O
therefore O
, O
the O
proposed O
MCCAR O
solves O
two O
problems O
in O
one O
processing O
, O
resulting O
in O
unique O
and O
robust O
cross-modality O
correspondence O
as O
well O
as O
a O
CV O
that O
is O
highly O
correlated O
with O
reference O
in O
each O
modality O
. O

Although O
MCCAR O
can O
provide O
a O
useful O
decomposition O
in O
many O
cases O
, O
the O
associated O
maps O
Ck O
may O
still O
not O
be O
unique O
in O
some O
cases O
. O

In O
order O
to O
keep O
the O
joint O
target O
component O
and O
maximize O
the O
spatial O
independence O
, O
we O
further O
apply O
jICA O
on O
the O
concatenated O
maps O
[ O
C1 O
, O
C2 O
, O
… O
, O
Cn O
] O
to O
obtain O
the O
final O
independent O
components O
( O
ICs O
) O
Sk O
, O
as O
well O
as O
their O
corresponding O
mixing O
matrices O
Dk O
: O
Combined O
with O
equation O
( O
1 O
) O
, O
Therefore O
, O
compared O
to O
blind O
N-way O
decomposition O
, O
MCCAR+jICA O
ensures O
both O
spatial O
independence O
and O
better O
correspondence O
with O
the O
reference O
in O
the O
mixing O
profile O
. O

This O
means O
in O
human O
brain O
imaging O
applications O
, O
we O
could O
simultaneously O
explore O
interested O
multimodal O
covariation O
and O
associate O
it O
with O
specific O
clinical O
measures O
. O

C. O
Simulated O
Data O
We O
next O
simulated O
multimodal O
MRI O
data O
to O
compare O
the O
proposed O
method O
with O
its O
alternatives O
for O
its O
capability O
to O
extract O
accurate O
spatial O
maps O
and O
correspondence O
between O
multiple O
modalities O
and O
with O
the O
reference O
. O

Eight O
brain O
networks O
were O
simulated O
using O
the O
simTB O
for O
fMRI O
and O
sMRI O
. O

DMRI O
was O
generated O
using O
the O
Johns O
Hopkins O
University O
( O
JHU O
) O
white O
matter O
atlas O
in O
which O
we O
selected O
8 O
typical O
fiber O
bundles O
, O
as O
shown O
in O
Figure O
2 O
( O
the O
red O
boxed O
source O
maps O
are O
designed O
to O
be O
correlated O
with O
reference O
) O
. O

Loading O
matrices O
for O
each O
modality O
, O
A1 O
, O
A2 O
, O
A3 O
were O
constructed O
in O
size O
of O
300×8 O
, O
resulting O
in O
300 O
samples O
with O
21025 O
, O
40000 O
and O
65536 O
voxels O
for O
fMRI O
, O
dMRI O
and O
sMRI O
feature O
matrices O
respectively O
by O
linear O
combination O
. O

Here O
, O
we O
used O
a O
real O
cognitive O
score O
of O
300 O
subjects O
as O
a O
reference O
and O
carefully O
designed O
one O
component O
for O
each O
modality O
( O
in O
different O
order O
, O
7th O
, O
4th O
, O
1st O
for O
fMRI O
, O
sMRI O
and O
dMRI O
respectively O
) O
to O
be O
significantly O
correlated O
with O
the O
reference O
, O
as O
shown O
in O
Supplementary O
Table O
I O
. O

We O
then O
applied O
MCCAR+jICA O
to O
the O
simulated O
datasets O
and O
compared O
its O
performance O
with O
4 O
alternative O
methods O
under O
16 O
noise O
levels O
. O

The O
noise O
levels O
were O
simulated O
with O
peak O
signal-to-noise O
ratio O
( O
PSNR O
) O
ranges O
from O
1 O
dB O
to O
34dB O
. O

Typical O
PSNR O
value O
for O
the O
acceptable O
image O
quality O
is O
about O
30 O
dB O
; O
the O
lower O
the O
value O
, O
the O
more O
degraded O
the O
image O
. O

D. O
Human O
Brain O
Data O
In O
this O
study O
, O
we O
used O
two O
independent O
data O
cohorts O
. O

One O
is O
recruited O
from O
the O
Function O
Biomedical O
Informatics O
Research O
Network O
( O
FBIRN O
) O
phase O
III O
datasets O
including O
147 O
SZs O
( O
39.5 O
± O
11.7 O
) O
and O
147 O
HCs O
( O
37.4 O
± O
11 O
) O
that O
were O
matched O
for O
age O
, O
gender O
, O
handedness O
, O
and O
race O
distributions O
. O

Demographics O
of O
all O
subjects O
are O
shown O
in O
Supplementary O
Table O
II O
. O

All O
subjects O
were O
collected O
from O
seven O
FBIRN O
consortium O
sites O
( O
University O
of O
California O
Irvine O
, O

of O

Los O
Angeles O
, O
University O
of O
California O
San O
Francisco O
, O
Duke O
University O
, O
University O
of O
North O
Carolina O
, O
University O
of O
New O
Mexico O
, O
University O
of O
Iowa O
, O
and O
University O
of O
Minnesota O
) O
. O

Each O
dataset O
including O
diagnosis O
, O
age O
at O
time O
of O
scan O
, O
gender O
, O
illness O
duration O
, O
symptom O
scores O
, O
and O
current O
medications O
when O
available O
, O
were O
shared O
by O
each O
research O
group O
according O
to O
their O
site O
’ O
s O
protocols O
. O

Inclusion O
criteria O
required O
all O
participants O
to O
be O
adults O
between O
the O
ages O
of O
18 O
and O
65 O
years O
. O

Diagnosis O
of O
schizophrenia O
was O
confirmed O
by O
trained O
raters O
using O
the O
Structured O
Clinical O
Interview O
for O
DSM-IV O
( O
SCID O
) O
. O

All O
patients O
were O
on O
a O
stable O
dose O
of O
antipsychotic O
medication O
either O
typical O
, O
atypical O
, O
or O
a O
combination O
for O
at O
least O
2 O
months O
. O

Current O
symptom O
severity O
was O
rated O
using O
the O
Positive O
and O
Negative O
Syndrome O
Scale O
( O
PANSS O
) O
. O

All O
SZs O
were O
clinically O
stable O
at O
the O
time O
of O
scanning O
. O

In O
addition O
, O
HC O
participants O
were O
excluded O
for O
current O
or O
past O
psychiatric O
illness O
based O
on O
SCID O
assessment O
or O
for O
having O
a O
first-degree O
relative O
with O
a O
diagnosis O
of O
an O
Axis-I O
psychotic O
disorder O
. O

Written O
informed O
consent O
was O
obtained O
from O
all O
study O
participants O
under O
protocols O
approved O
by O
the O
Institutional O
Review O
Boards O
at O
each O
study O
site O
. O

Demographic O
information O
for O
subjects O
of O
each O
sites O
are O
provided O
in O
Supplementary O
Table O
III O
. O

Another O
cohort O
consisting O
of O
39 O
SZs O
( O
35.6±13.1 O
) O
and O
44 O
HCs O
( O
36.3±12.5 O
) O
were O
collected O
from O
the O
University O
of O
New O
Mexico O
( O
UNM O
) O
. O

Details O
of O
the O
demographic O
information O
, O
inclusion O
and O
exclusion O
criteria O
could O
be O
found O
in O
Supplementary O
Table O
IV O
. O

1 O
) O
Image O
Parameters O
and O
Preprocessing O
The O
resting O
state O
fMRI O
data O
were O
collected O
on O
six O
3T O
Siemens O
TIM O
Trio O
scanners O
and O
one O
3T O
MR750 O
General O
Electric O
( O
GE O
) O
scanner O
. O

The O
imaging O
protocol O
for O
the O
resting O
state O
scans O
at O
all O
sites O
was O
a O
T2 O
* O
-weighted O
AC-PC O
aligned O
echo O
planar O
imaging O
sequence O
( O
TR/TE O
2 O
s/30 O
ms O
, O
flip O
angle O
77 O
degrees O
, O
32 O
slices O
collected O
sequentially O
from O
superior O
to O
inferior O
, O
3.4 O
× O
3.4 O
× O
4 O
mm O
with O
1 O
mm O
gap O
, O
162 O
frames O
, O
5:38 O
min O
) O
. O

For O
the O
resting O
scan O
, O
subjects O
were O
instructed O
to O
lie O
still O
with O
eyes O
closed O
. O

DMRI O
were O
acquired O
on O
six O
3T O
Siemens O
Tim O
Trio O
System O
and O
one O
3T O
GE O
Discovery O
MR750 O
scanner O
. O

All O
parameters O
for O
these O
two O
scanners O
were O
the O
same O
except O
for O
TE O
( O
Siemens O
84ms/GE O
81.7ms O
) O
. O

The O
rest O
of O
the O
parameters O
for O
both O
Siemens O
and O
GE O
were O
as O
follows O
: O
TR O
= O
9000ms O
; O
acquisition O
matrix O
= O
128 O
× O
128 O
; O
field O
of O
view O
( O
FOV O
) O
= O
256×256 O
mm O
; O
slice O
thickness O
= O
2 O
mm O
; O
number O
of O
slices O
= O
72 O
; O
slice O
gap=2 O
mm O
; O
voxel O
resolution O
2×2×2 O
mm O
; O
flip O
angle O
= O
90 O
; O
number O
of O
diffusion O
gradient O
directions O
= O
30 O
, O
b O
= O
800 O
seconds/mm2 O
, O
and O
5 O
measurements O
with O
b O
= O
0 O
; O
number O
of O
excitations O
( O
NEX O
) O
=1 O
. O

All O
images O
were O
registered O
to O
the O
first O
b O
= O
0 O
image O
by O
FMRIB O
Linear O
Image O
Registration O
Tool O
( O
FLIRT O
: O
http O
: O
//fsl.fmrib.ox.ac.uk/fsl/fslwiki/FLIRT O
) O
. O

High-resolution O
structural O
brain O
scans O
were O
also O
acquired O
on O
six O
3T O
Siemens O
Tim O
Trio O
System O
and O
one O
3T O
GE O
Discovery O
MR750 O
scanner O
using O
standardized O
sequences O
. O

Siemens O
MP-RAGE O
scan O
parameters O
were O
: O
TR/TE/TI=2300/2.94/1100 O
ms O
, O
flip O
angle=9° O
, O
resolution O
=256×256×160 O
. O

GE O
IR_SPGR O
scan O
parameters O
were O
: O
TR/TE/TI=5.95/1.99/45 O
ms O
, O
flip O
angle O
=12° O
, O
resolution O
=256×256×166 O
. O

All O
scans O
covered O
the O
entire O
brain O
with O
FOV=220 O
mm2 O
, O
voxel O
size= O
0.86×0.86×1.2 O
mm3 O
, O
sagittal O
scan O
plane O
, O
GRAPPA/ASSET O
acceleration O
factor=2 O
, O
and O
NEX=1 O
. O

The O
fMRI O
data O
was O
preprocessed O
using O
the O
automated O
analysis O
pipeline O
, O
whose O
steps O
are O
conducted O
in O
SPM O
5 O
( O
http O
: O
//www.fil.ion.ucl.ac.uk/spm O
) O
as O
follows O
: O
Motion O
correction O
to O
the O
first O
image O
using O
INRIalign O
; O
slice O
timing O
corrected O
to O
the O
middle O
slice O
; O
and O
normalization O
to O
MNI O
space O
, O
including O
reslicing O
to O
3 O
× O
3 O
× O
3 O
mm O
voxels O
. O

We O
further O
regressed O
out O
six O
motion O
parameters O
, O
white O
matter O
, O
and O
cerebrospinal O
fluid O
in O
denoising O
. O

Data O
were O
then O
spatially O
smoothed O
with O
an O
8 O
mm O
full O
width O
half O
max O
( O
FWHM O
) O
Gaussian O
filter O
. O

To O
calculate O
fractional O
amplitude O
of O
low O
frequency O
fluctuations O
( O
fALFF O
) O
, O
the O
sum O
of O
the O
amplitude O
values O
in O
the O
0.01 O
to O
0.08Hz O
low-frequency O
power O
range O
was O
divided O
by O
the O
sum O
of O
the O
amplitudes O
over O
the O
entire O
detectable O
power O
spectrum O
( O
range O
: O
0–0.25Hz O
) O
[ O
see O
more O
details O
in O
] O
. O

DMRI O
data O
were O
preprocessed O
using O
the O
FMRIB O
Software O
Library O
( O
www.fmrib.ox.ac.uk/fsl O
) O
and O
consisted O
of O
the O
following O
steps O
: O
1 O
) O
quality O
check O
with O
any O
gradient O
directions O
with O
excessive O
motion O
or O
vibration O
artifacts O
identified O
and O
removed O
; O
2 O
) O
motion O
and O
eddy O
current O
correction O
; O
3 O
) O
correction O
of O
gradient O
directions O
for O
any O
image O
rotation O
done O
during O
the O
previous O
motion O
correction O
step O
; O
and O
4 O
) O
calculation O
of O
diffusion O
tensor O
and O
scalar O
measures O
such O
as O
fractional O
anisotropy O
( O
FA O
) O
, O
which O
were O
then O
smoothed O
using O
8 O
mm O
FWHM O
Gaussian O
filter O
. O

Using O
the O
unified O
segmentation O
methods O
of O
SPM5 O
, O
the O
sMRI O
was O
normalized O
to O
MNI O
space O
, O
resliced O
to O
3 O
× O
3 O
× O
3 O
mm O
, O
and O
segmented O
into O
gray O
matter O
( O
GM O
) O
, O
white O
matter O
, O
and O
cerebral O
spinal O
fluid O
( O
CSF O
) O
. O

Then O
, O
the O
GM O
images O
were O
smoothed O
with O
a O
FWHM O
of O
8 O
mm O
Gaussian O
filter O
. O

Subject O
outlier O
detection O
was O
further O
performed O
using O
a O
spatial O
Pearson O
correlation O
with O
the O
template O
image O
to O
ensure O
that O
all O
subjects O
were O
properly O
segmented O
[ O
details O
can O
be O
found O
in O
] O
. O

2 O
) O
Normalization O
and O
Site O
Effect O
Correction O
After O
preprocessing O
, O
the O
three-dimensional O
brain O
images O
of O
each O
subject O
were O
reshaped O
into O
a O
one-dimensional O
vector O
and O
stacked O
, O
forming O
a O
matrix O
( O
Nsubj×Nvoxel O
) O
for O
each O
of O
the O
three O
modalities O
. O

These O
three O
matrices O
were O
then O
normalized O
to O
have O
the O
same O
average O
sum O
of O
squares O
( O
computed O
across O
all O
subjects O
and O
all O
voxels O
for O
each O
modality O
) O
to O
ensure O
all O
modalities O
had O
the O
same O
ranges O
. O

Multivariate O
analysis O
of O
covariance O
( O
MANCOVA O
) O
was O
performed O
on O
the O
normalized O
feature O
matrices O
. O

Gender O
, O
age O
and O
site O
were O
set O
as O
covariates O
, O
along O
with O
their O
interactions O
were O
all O
regressed O
out O
from O
fALFF O
, O
FA O
and O
GM O
matrices O
respectively O
, O
to O
minimize O
their O
potential O
impact O
on O
the O
imaging O
data O
, O
the O
resulting O
data O
were O
then O
ready O
for O
fusion O
analysis O
. O

3 O
) O
The O
Working O
Memory O
Scores O
We O
use O
one O
cognitive O
domain O
measure O
, O
working O
memory O
( O
WM O
) O
score O
, O
as O
the O
reference O
for O
supervised O
multimodal O
MRI O
fusion O
. O

For O
fBIRN O
data O
, O
the O
WM O
score O
was O
measured O
by O
the O
Computerized O
Multiphasic O
Interactive O
Neuro-cognitive O
System O
( O
CMINDS O
) O
. O

As O
listed O
in O
Supplementary O
Table O
II O
, O
CMINDS O
involves O
6 O
domains O
, O
i.e. O
, O
speed O
of O
processing O
, O
attention/vigilance O
, O
working O
memory O
, O
verbal O
learning O
, O
visual O
learning O
and O
reasoning/problem O
solving O
. O

For O
the O
validated O
data O
cohort O
from O
UNM O
, O
working O
memory O
score O
is O
measured O
by O
the O
MATRICS O
Consensus O
Cognitive O
Battery O
( O
MCCB O
) O
system O
, O
which O
is O
launched O
by O
the O
National O
Institute O
of O
Mental O
Health O
and O
contain O
one O
more O
domain O
, O
social O
cognition O
than O
CMINDS O
, O
see O
supplementary O
Table O
IV O
. O

Both O
cognitive O
measurement O
systems O
include O
computerized O
neuropsychological O
tasks O
that O
are O
structurally O
and O
functionally O
similar O
, O
and O
the O
neurocognitive O
domain O
z-scores O
were O
computed O
from O
these O
tests O
. O

As O
reported O
by O
, O
CMINDS O
is O
very O
similar O
to O
MATRICS O
on O
measuring O
cognitive O
deficits O
in O
schizophrenia O
. O

Brain O
substrates O
of O
early O
( O
4 O
h O
) O
cigarette O
abstinence O
: O
Identification O
of O
treatment O
targets O
Introduction O
Research O
indicates O
that O
overnight O
nicotine O
abstinence O
disrupts O
neural O
activity O
in O
the O
mesocorticolimbic O
reward O
network O
; O
however O
, O
less O
is O
known O
about O
the O
time O
course O
of O
abstinence-induced O
brain O
changes O
. O

To O
examine O
the O
potential O
neural O
effects O
of O
early O
abstinence O
, O
we O
used O
arterial O
spin O
labeling O
perfusion O
fMRI O
, O
to O
measure O
regional O
cerebral O
blood O
flow O
( O
rCBF O
) O
changes O
in O
the O
resting O
brain O
induced O
by O
4 O
h O
of O
nicotine O
abstinence O
. O

Methods O
In O
a O
repeated O
measures O
design O
, O
5 O
min O
of O
resting O
perfusion O
fMRI O
data O
were O
acquired O
in O
awake O
nicotine-dependent O
individuals O
( O
eyes O
open O
) O
during O
‘ O
smoking O
as O
usual O
’ O
( O
SMK O
) O
and O
following O
4 O
h O
of O
monitored O
nicotine O
abstinence O
( O
ABS O
) O
conditions O
( O
N O
= O
20 O
) O
. O

Conditions O
were O
compared O
using O
a O
paired O
t O
test O
in O
SPM8 O
. O

Craving O
was O
assessed O
prior O
to O
each O
condition O
. O

Results O
Compared O
to O
SMK O
, O
ABS O
significantly O
increased O
craving O
and O
reduced O
rCBF O
in O
select O
regions O
, O
including O
the O
hippocampus O
and O
ventral O
striatum O
( O
cluster O
corr O
, O
α O
= O
0.01 O
, O
943 O
contiguous O
voxels O
) O
. O

The O
magnitude O
of O
the O
abstinence-induced O
change O
in O
rCBF O
correlated O
with O
the O
magnitude O
of O
the O
change O
in O
craving O
across O
conditions O
in O
select O
regions O
, O
including O
the O
medial O
and O
lateral O
orbitofrontal O
cortices O
and O
the O
anterior O
ventral O
insula O
( O
r O
values O
ranging O
from O
0.59–0.74 O
) O
. O

Conclusions O
Results O
show O
that O
as O
few O
as O
4 O
h O
of O
abstinence O
can O
reduce O
resting O
rCBF O
in O
multiple O
nodes O
of O
the O
brain O
’ O
s O
mesocorticolimbic O
network O
, O
disrupting O
neural O
processing O
. O

Identifying O
early O
withdrawal O
treatment O
targets O
has O
far-reaching O
implications O
, O
which O
include O
thwarting O
relapse O
proclivities O
. O

Results O
parallel O
those O
of O
the O
extant O
human O
literature O
and O
are O
in O
agreement O
with O
an O
extensive O
preclinical O
literature O
showing O
compromised O
mesolimbic O
dopaminergic O
function O
and O
impairments O
in O
reward O
function O
during O
nicotine O
withdrawal O
. O

2 O
. O

Methods O
2.1 O
. O

Participants O
The O
study O
was O
conducted O
at O
the O
University O
of O
Pennsylvania O
Perelman O
School O
of O
Medicine O
. O

All O
procedures O
were O
approved O
and O
monitored O
by O
the O
Institutional O
Review O
Board O
, O
and O
adhered O
to O
the O
Declaration O
of O
Helsinki O
. O

Participants O
received O
compensation O
ranging O
from O
$ O
235 O
to O
$ O
250 O
for O
participating O
in O
the O
study O
. O

Eligible O
participants O
were O
non-treatment-seeking O
smokers O
( O
18–60 O
years O
of O
age O
) O
who O
reported O
smoking O
at O
least O
10 O
cigarettes O
per O
day O
for O
the O
past O
3 O
years O
and O
had O
baseline O
carbon O
monoxide O
( O
CO O
) O
levels O
greater O
than O
10 O
ppm O
. O

Ten O
CPD O
was O
chosen O
as O
the O
smoking O
criteria O
to O
study O
the O
effects O
of O
4 O
h O
of O
abstinence O
because O
1 O
) O
10 O
CPD O
represents O
the O
average O
smoker O
in O
the O
current O
climate O
, O
wherein O
smoking O
is O
largely O
prohibited O
in O
the O
work O
place O
and O
most O
other O
public O
places O
in O
the O
U.S O
; O
2 O
) O
a O
10 O
CPD O
individual O
scores O
in O
the O
range O
of O
moderate O
nicotine O
dependence O
on O
the O
FTND O
; O
and O
3 O
) O
ten O
CPD O
corresponds O
to O
approximately O
a O
little O
over O
1 O
cigarette O
over O
the O
course O
of O
two O
hours O
in O
a O
16 O
h O
day O
( O
assuming O
8 O
h O
are O
spent O
sleeping O
) O
, O
thus O
such O
an O
individual O
is O
likely O
to O
experience O
some O
symptoms O
of O
withdrawal O
in O
the O
absence O
of O
nicotine O
over O
a O
4-h O
period O
. O

Participants O
were O
screened O
, O
tested O
on O
study O
knowledge O
, O
and O
consented O
prior O
to O
study O
participation O
. O

Severity O
of O
nicotine O
dependence O
was O
determined O
from O
the O
Fagerström O
Test O
for O
Nicotine O
Dependence O
( O
FTND O
) O
. O

Exclusion O
criteria O
included O
current O
substance O
use O
disorder O
, O
positive O
urine O
drug O
screen O
for O
illicit O
drugs O
( O
tested O
at O
screening O
and O
prior O
to O
MRI O
sessions O
) O
, O
seeking O
treatment O
for O
cigarette/nicotine O
dependence O
or O
attempting O
to O
quit O
smoking O
, O
having O
an O
acute O
, O
chronic O
or O
debilitating O
medical O
condition O
, O
psychiatric O
disorders O
as O
determined O
by O
The O
MINI O
International O
Neuropsychiatric O
Interview O
, O
a O
history O
of O
head O
trauma O
or O
other O
injury O
resulting O
in O
loss O
of O
consciousness O
lasting O
greater O
than O
three O
minutes O
or O
associated O
with O
skull O
fracture O
or O
intra-cranial O
bleeding O
, O
and O
other O
contraindications O
for O
MRI O
, O
and O
head O
movement O
of O
more O
than O
1.5 O
mm O
over O
the O
course O
of O
the O
resting O
baseline O
acquisition O
. O

Following O
MRI O
acquisition O
, O
participants O
with O
abnormal O
structural O

were O
excluded O
( O
N O
= O
2 O
) O
, O
leaving O
20 O
eligible O
participants O
. O

Eligible O
participants O
were O
50 O
% O
male O
and O
the O

( O

% O

were O
White O
. O

Other O
races O
included O
1 O

, O
2 O

1 O

. O

Participants O
were O
29.1 O
± O
2.13 O
years O
of O
age O
, O
having O
14.75 O
± O
0.52 O
years O
of O

. O

Participants O
smoked O
15 O
. O

± O
1.13 O
cigarettes O
per O

for O

± O

years O
( O

) O
. O

2.2 O
. O

Experimental O
design O
Participants O
participated O
in O
two O
scanning O
sessions O
that O
occurred O
on O
separate O
days O
at O
least O
3 O
or O
more O
days O
apart O
. O

The O
abstinent O
scan O
was O
conducted O
following O
4 O
h O
of O
staff- O
and O
CO-monitored O
nicotine O
abstinence O
. O

Prior O
to O
the O
monitored O
abstinence O
( O
ABS O
) O
regimen O
, O
participants O
smoked O
a O
cigarette O
to O
satiety O
to O
standardize O
time O
since O
last O
smoked O
( O
i.e. O
, O
∼ O
4 O
h O
prior O
to O
MRI O
data O
acquisition O
) O
In O
the O
‘ O
smoking O
as O
usual O
’ O
( O
SMK O
) O
condition O
, O
participants O
smoked O
throughout O
the O
day O
ad O
lib O
, O
were O
monitored O
for O
2 O
h O
prior O
to O
scanning O
while O
continuing O
to O
smoke O
ad O
lib O
, O
and O
smoked O
to O
satiety O
20–25 O
min O
prior O
to O
acquisition O
of O
the O
resting O
baseline O
CBF O
data O
to O
standardize O
time O
since O
last O
smoked O
and O
ensure O
dissipation O
of O
the O
acute O
cardiovascular O
effects O
of O
smoking O
. O

During O

period O
, O
participants O
were O
occupied O
similarly O
, O
filling O
out O
questionnaires O
and O
participating O
in O

tasks O
. O

Subjective O
reports O
of O
cigarette O
craving O
and O

were O

prior O
to O
each O
condition O
using O

and O

( O

) O
and O
, O

a O

of O

Shiffman-Jarvik O
Scale O
was O

acquired O
( O
n O
= O
14 O
; O

to O

, O

from O
one O
or O

in O

. O

Sessions O
were O
counterbalanced O
such O
that O

the O

. O

For O

was O

first O
, O

by O
the O
resting O
pseudo O
continuous O
arterial O
spin O
labeled O
( O

) O
perfusion O

scan O
. O

Although O
not O
the O
focus O
of O

current O

subsequently O
. O

Throughout O

Wakefulness O
was O

with O

( O

Systems O
; O

: O
//www.mrc-systems.de O
) O
. O

2.3 O
. O

Siemens O
3.0 O

( O

, O

array O

. O

High-resolution O

images O
were O
obtained O
for O

using O
a O
standard O
3-dimensional O
( O
3D O
) O
Magnetization O
Prepared O
Rapid O

Gradient O
Echo O
( O

) O

with O

= O
1620 O
ms O
, O

( O

) O
= O
950 O
ms O
, O

time O
( O

3 O
ms O
, O

= O
15° O
, O
160 O
contiguous O

, O
1 O
× O
1 O
× O
1 O

. O

The O

was O
5 O

in O

. O

Following O

, O

, O

, O

of O

( O

) O
= O
and O
220 O
× O
220 O
mm2 O
, O
matrix O
= O
64 O
× O
64 O
, O

, O

mm O
. O

The O
ASL O
resting O

scan O
was O
5 O
min O
in O
length O
, O
providing O
45 O
acquisitions O
. O

2.4 O
. O

Data O
analyses O
Imaging O
data O

were O

using O

Parametric O
Mapping O
software O
( O

; O
Wellcome O

of O

R2013a O
( O

, O

) O
. O

For O
each O
subject O
, O
functional O
images O
were O
realigned O
to O
correct O
for O
head O
motion O
and O
co-registered O
with O
each O
individual O
’ O
s O
anatomical O
image O
. O

Perfusion O
weighted O
image O
series O
were O
then O
generated O
by O
pairwise O

of O
the O
label O
and O
control O
images O

followed O
by O
conversion O
to O
absolute O
CBF O
image O
series O
based O
on O
a O

model O
. O

For O
each O

, O
one O

was O

, O
normalized O
to O
the O
Montreal O
Neurological O
Institute O
( O

) O
template O
, O
smoothed O
with O
a O
3-D O
9 O
mm O
Full O
Width O
Half O
Maximum O
( O

) O
isotropic O
Gaussian O
kernel O
, O
and O
then O
entered O
into O
the O
whole O
brain O
voxel-wise O
analysis O
using O
the O
general O
linear O
model O
( O
GLM O
) O
. O

Age O
and O
sex O
were O
included O
as O
covariates O
in O
all O
analyses O
. O

A O
paired O
t-test O
was O
conducted O
to O
compare O
rCBF O
between O
SMK O
and O
ABS O
conditions O
using O
a O
cluster O
forming O
height O
threshold O
of O
p O
< O
0.001 O
. O

To O
control O
for O
Type O
I O
error O
, O
the O
most O
updated O
and O
accurate O
correction O
method O
for O
controlling O
for O
false O
positives O
provided O
by O
AFNI O
, O
3dttest+ O
+ O
, O
was O
used O
( O
AFNI_17.1.07 O
) O
, O
resulting O
in O
a O
5 O
% O
probability O
of O
a O
cluster O
surviving O
due O
to O
chance O
( O
α O
= O
0.01 O
, O
943 O
contiguous O
voxels O
) O
. O

All O
listed O
coordinates O
are O
in O
MNI O
space O
. O

To O
explore O
associations O
between O
brain O
and O
relevant O
smoking O
behavioral O
measures O
, O
simple O
regression O
analyses O
were O
conducted O
in O

on O
the O
change O
in O
rCBF O
from O
SMK O
to O
ABS O
conditions O
, O
using O
the O
change O
in O

scores O
from O

to O

( O
Item O
3 O
of O
the O
CWQ O
) O
and O
FTND O
scores O
as O
covariates O
of O
interest O
. O

The O
same O
corrections O
used O
for O
rCBF O
contrasts O
were O
applied O
prior O
to O
extracting O
significant O
rCBF O
values O
from O
each O
of O
the O
functionally-identified O
clusters O
within O
each O
subject O
using O
MarsBaR O
and O

were O

in O
SPSS O
version O
22 O
. O

Similarly O
, O
an O
