post O
hoc O
analysis O
was O
conducted O
on O
the O
change O
in O
rCBF O
from O
SMK O
to O
ABS O
conditions O
using O
the O
focus/attention O
item O
of O
the O
Shiffman-Jarvik O
Withdrawal O
Scale O
as O
a O
covariate O
of O
interest O
. O

Continuous O
demographic O
variables O
and O
FTND O
scores O
were O
summarized O
by O
calculating O
means O
and O
standard O
error O
measurements O
( O
X O
± O
SEMs O
) O
. O

A O
paired O
t-test O
was O
used O
to O
assess O
differences O
across O
conditions O
in O
CWQ O
items O
and O
the O
focus/attention O
item O
of O
the O
Shiffman-Jarvik O
Scale O
( O
post O
hoc O
) O
. O

Statistical O
analyses O
were O
conducted O
in O
SPSS O
version O
22.0 O
. O

Family O
history O
of O
alcoholism O
and O
the O
human O
brain O
response O
to O
oral O
sucrose O
A O
heightened O
hedonic O
response O
to O
sweet O
tastes O
has O
been O
associated O
with O
increased O
alcohol O
preference O
and O
alcohol O
consumption O
in O
both O
humans O
and O
animals O
. O

The O
principal O
goal O
of O
this O
study O
was O
to O
examine O
blood O
oxygenation O
level O
dependent O
( O
BOLD O
) O
activation O
to O
high- O
and O
low-concentration O
sweet O
solutions O
in O
subjects O
who O
are O
either O
positive O
( O
FHP O
) O
or O
negative O
( O
FHN O
) O
for O
a O
family O
history O
of O
alcoholism O
. O

Seventy-four O
non-treatment O
seeking O
, O
community-recruited O
, O
healthy O
volunteers O
( O
22.8 O
± O
1.6 O
SD O
years O
; O
43 O
% O
men O
) O
rated O
a O
range O
of O
sucrose O
concentrations O
in O
a O
taste O
test O
and O
underwent O
functional O
magnetic O
resonance O
imaging O
( O
fMRI O
) O
during O
oral O
delivery O
of O
water O
, O
0.83 O
M O
, O
and O
0.10 O
M O
sucrose O
. O

Sucrose O
compared O
to O
water O
produced O
robust O
activation O
in O
primary O
gustatory O
cortex O
, O
ventral O
insula O
, O
amygdala O
, O
and O
ventral O
striatum O
. O

FHP O
subjects O
displayed O
greater O
bilateral O
amygdala O
activation O
than O
FHN O
subjects O
in O
the O
low O
sucrose O
concentration O
( O
0.10 O
M O
) O
. O

In O
secondary O
analyses O
, O
the O
right O
amygdala O
response O
to O
the O
0.10 O
M O
sucrose O
was O
greatest O
in O
FHP O
women O
. O

When O
accounting O
for O
group O
differences O
in O
drinks O
per O
week O
, O
the O
family O
history O
groups O
remained O
significantly O
different O
in O
their O
right O
amygdala O
response O
to O
0.10 O
M O
sucrose O
. O

Our O
findings O
suggest O
that O
the O
brain O
response O
to O
oral O
sucrose O
differs O
with O
a O
family O
history O
of O
alcoholism O
, O
and O
that O
this O
response O
to O
a O
mildly O
reinforcing O
primary O
reward O
might O
be O
an O
endophenotypic O
marker O
of O
alcoholism O
risk O
. O

Highlights O
Studies O
in O
humans O
and O
animals O
have O
suggested O
sweet O
tastes O
as O
a O
trait O
correlate O
of O
alcohol O
risk O
. O

Oral O
sucrose O
resulted O
in O
robust O
BOLD O
activation O
of O
gustatory O
and O
limbic O
areas O
. O

Amygdala O
responses O
to O
0.10 O
M O
sucrose O
were O
greatest O
in O
drinkers O
with O
family O
histories O
of O
alcoholism O
. O

This O
study O
is O
first O
to O
suggest O
endophenotypic O
brain O
responses O
to O
sucrose O
in O
familial O
alcoholism O
. O

Materials O
and O
methods O
Subjects O
Seventy-four O
healthy O
, O
right-handed O
volunteers O
( O
42 O
women O
) O
were O
recruited O
( O
Table O
1 O
) O
and O
evaluated O
using O
the O
Semi-Structured O
Assessment O
for O
the O
Genetics O
of O
Alcoholism O
( O
SSAGA O
) O
, O
a O
35-day O
version O
of O
the O
Timeline O
Followback O
interview O
for O
habitual O
drinking O
, O
and O
the O
Alcohol O
Use O
Disorders O
Identification O
Test O
( O
AUDIT O
) O
. O

The O
sample O
consisted O
of O
37 O
FHP O
( O
defined O
as O
having O
at O
least O
one O
first-degree O
relative O
using O
SSAGA O
FHA O
Individual O
Assessment O
Module O
) O
and O
37 O
FHN O
subjects O
. O

Subjects O
were O
excluded O
for O
histories O
of O
central O
neurological O
disease O
, O
head O
injury O
with O
loss O
of O
consciousness O
, O
and O
any O
DSM-IV O
Axis O
I O
diagnosis O
. O

Subjects O
were O
not O
, O
however O
, O
excluded O
for O
prior O
histories O
of O
depression O
and/or O
anxiety O
if O
not O
currently O
taking O
medication O
( O
n O
= O
8 O
; O
2 O
FHP-M O
, O
5 O
FHP-F O
, O
1 O
FHN-F O
) O
. O

None O
of O
the O
subjects O
expressed O
interest O
in O
treatment O
for O
alcohol O
abuse O
, O
none O
reported O
any O
disorders O
of O
smell O
or O
taste O
, O
and O
all O
passed O
an O
olfactory O
screen O
( O
Pocket O
Smell O
Test O
, O
American O
Version O
; O
Sensonics O
, O
Inc. O
) O
. O

Nineteen O
subjects O
( O
26 O
% O
; O
9 O
FHP-M O
, O
4 O
FHP-F O
, O
4 O
FHN-M O
, O
2 O
FHN-F O
) O
reported O
nicotine O
use O
within O
six O
weeks O
of O
testing O
( O
3.74 O
± O
2.15 O
units/day O
) O
, O
68 O
% O
( O
n O
= O
13 O
) O
of O
whom O
were O
family O
history O
positive O
. O

Nicotine O
use O
was O
not O
related O
to O
drinking O
patterns O
. O

Subjects O
consented O
to O
a O
urine O
screen O
( O
Andwin O
Scientific O
) O
for O
commonly O
abused O
drugs O
[ O
amphetamine O
, O
secobarbital O
, O
buprenorphine O
, O
oxazepam O
, O
cocaine O
, O
methylenedioxymethamphetamine O
, O
methamphetamine O
, O
morphine O
, O
methadone O
, O
opiate O
, O
oxycodone O
, O
phencyclidine O
, O
propoxyphene O
, O
and O
cannabinoids O
] O
; O
however O
, O
given O
its O
high O
comorbidity O
with O
alcohol O
, O
we O
did O
not O
exclude O
the O
one O
male O
FHN O
subject O
testing O
positive O
for O
marijuana O
use O
, O
who O
showed O
no O
evidence O
of O
acute O
intoxication O
, O
and O
whose O
last O
reported O
dose O
was O
two O
weeks O
prior O
to O
study O
. O

There O
was O
no O
significant O
difference O
in O
the O
brain O
imaging O
results O
with O
this O
subject O
removed O
. O

Experiments O
occurred O
only O
after O
each O
subject O
's O
written O
consent O
, O
as O
per O
the O
Indiana O
University O
Intuitional O
Review O
Board O
. O

Procedures O
Subjects O
arrived O
at O
~ O
7:00 O
am O
, O
having O
fasted O
since O
11:00 O
pm O
the O
previous O
evening O
. O

Height O
and O
weight O
were O
recorded O
, O
urine O
was O
collected O
for O
drug O
screening O
, O
and O
subjects O
were O
fed O
a O
standardized O
breakfast O
between O
7:30–8:15 O
am O
. O

The O
imaging O
session O
began O
at O
approximately O
11:00 O
am O
, O
with O
imaging O
of O
sucrose O
stimulation O
starting O
at O
~ O
12:00 O
pm O
( O
prior O
to O
which O
, O
subjects O
were O
imaged O
while O
performing O
one O
run O
of O
a O
monetary O
incentive O
delay O
task O
; O
data O
to O
be O
reported O
elsewhere O
) O
. O

Taste O
test O
Prior O
to O
imaging O
, O
subjects O
tasted O
and O
rated O
different O
molar O
( O
M O
) O
concentrations O
of O
sucrose O
as O
used O
in O
similar O
studies O
( O
0.05 O
, O
0.10 O
, O
0.21 O
, O
0.42 O
, O
0.83 O
M O
) O
, O
prepared O
by O
dissolving O
table O
sugar O
in O
100 O
ml O
of O
deionized O
water O
. O

Administered O
in O
three O
blocks O
, O
each O
of O
the O
five O
solutions O
was O
presented O
once O
per O
block O
in O
a O
randomized O
fashion O
. O

Subjects O
sampled O
15 O
ml O
of O
each O
solution O
, O
“ O
swished O
” O
for O
5 O
s O
in O
the O
mouth O
, O
and O
spit O
without O
swallowing O
. O

Subjects O
rated O
the O
intensity O
of O
sweetness O
and O
their O
subjective O
“ O
liking O
” O
. O

After O
rating O
each O
sample O
, O
subjects O
cleansed O
their O
palates O
using O
~ O
10 O
ml O
of O
deionized O
water O
. O

Gustatory O
stimulus O
paradigm O
Fig O
. O

1 O
visually O
depicts O
the O
gustatory O
stimulus O
paradigm O
. O

During O
imaging O
, O
gustatory O
stimuli O
were O
delivered O
using O
a O
computer O
controlled O
, O
five-channel O
gustometer O
in O
which O
gear O
pumps O
deliver O
solutions O
through O
a O
spray O
nozzle O
. O

Each O
delivery O
lightly O
covered O
the O
tongue O
with O
either O
0.75 O
ml O
of O
a O
sucrose O
solution O
( O
0.83 O
M O
or O
0.10 O
M O
) O
or O
a O
control O
stimulus O
of O
water O
with O
a O
tasteless O
thickening O
agent O
( O
ThickenUp O
Clear® O
, O
Nestlē O
Health O
Sciences O
, O
Vevey O
, O
Switzerland O
) O
to O
approximate O
the O
viscosity O
of O
the O
sucrose O
solution O
. O

Both O
sucrose O
and O
water O
controls O
were O
followed O
by O
0.75 O
ml O
of O
thickened O
water O
( O
which O
in O
sucrose O
trials O
, O
purged O
the O
nozzle O
of O
residual O
sucrose O
) O
. O

Each O
subject O
underwent O
one O
imaging O
session O
in O
which O
each O
sucrose O
concentration O
was O
presented O
in O
three O
separate O
functional O
scanning O
runs O
, O
for O
a O
total O
of O
six O
functional O
scans O
per O
subject O
( O
three O
0.83 O
M O
sucrose O
and O
three O
0.10 O
M O
scans O
, O
done O
in O
an O
alternating O
order O
within O
individuals O
, O
with O
the O
starting O
concentration O
counterbalanced O
across O
individuals O
) O
. O

Within O
each O
sucrose O
functional O
scan O
, O
there O
were O
24 O
trials O
( O
7 O
sucrose O
, O
17 O
water O
; O
pseudorandomized O
order O
for O
each O
sucrose O
concentration O
) O
. O

This O
resulted O
in O
21 O
sucrose O
and O
51 O
water O
trials O
for O
each O
concentration O
. O

Subjects O
were O
alerted O
to O
impending O
spray O
delivery O
by O
the O
text O
“ O
READY O
” O
as O
projected O
onto O
a O
screen O
at O
the O
rear O
of O
the O
scanner O
, O
with O
“ O
SPRAY O
” O
being O
displayed O
while O
the O
solution O
was O
presented O
. O

Subjects O
were O
asked O
to O
hold O
the O
solution O
in O
their O
mouth O
until O
prompted O
to O
swallow O
by O
the O
visual O
command O
“ O
SWALLOW O
” O
( O
jittered O
1–3 O
s O
after O
sprays O
) O
. O

To O
maximize O
taste O
contrast O
, O
only O
water O
controls O
that O
immediately O
followed O
a O
preceding O
water O
trial O
were O
used O
for O
the O
[ O
Sucrose O
> O
Water O
] O
contrast O
, O
resulting O
in O
comparisons O
of O
21 O
trials O
of O
each O
sucrose O
concentration O
and O
33 O
water O
trials O
for O
each O
subject O
. O

Following O
each O
scan O
, O
1.5 O
ml O
( O
or O
more O
as O
chosen O
by O
the O
subject O
) O
of O
thickened O
water O
was O
delivered O
to O
the O
subject O
to O
rinse O
the O
mouth O
, O
with O
the O
opportunity O
to O
administer O
further O
rinses O
as O
needed O
by O
subjects O
individually O
. O

Intra-MRI O
assessment O
Prior O
to O
the O
first O
sucrose O
scan O
, O
subjects O
rated O
baseline O
hunger O
, O
thirst O
, O
and O
sweet O
and O
salt O
craving O
. O

Following O
the O
first O
two O
and O
final O
two O
functional O
scans O
, O
subjects O
rated O
hunger O
, O
thirst O
, O
sweet O
and O
salt O
cravings O
, O
perceived O
sweetness O
, O
liking O
of O
the O
sucrose O
solution O
in O
the O
prior O
scan O
, O
and O
desire O
to O
increase O
or O
decrease O
solution O
sweetness O
. O

Subjects O
made O
rated O
the O
sucrose O
solutions O
following O
the O
first O
and O
last O
pair O
of O
high/low O
concentration O
scans O
so O
as O
to O
bracket O
all O
sucrose O
functional O
scans O
, O
and O
to O
avoid O
“ O
rating O
fatigue O
” O
from O
repeated O
questioning O
. O

Image O
acquisition O
Subjects O
were O
imaged O
on O
a O
Siemens O
3 O
T O
Magnetom O
Prisma O
( O
Erlangen O
, O
Germany O
) O
scanner O
using O
a O
64-channel O
head O
coil O
array O
. O

A O
high-resolution O
anatomic O
volume O
( O
1.05 O
× O
1.05 O
× O
1.2 O
mm3 O
voxels O
, O
3D O
magnetization O
prepared O
rapid O
gradient O
echo O
; O
MPRAGE O
) O
was O
used O
to O
position O
functional O
, O
blood O
oxygenation O
level O
dependent O
( O
BOLD O
) O
contrast O
sensitive O
data O
acquisition O
( O
gradient O
echo O
, O
echo-planar O
imaging O
[ O
EPI O
] O
, O
164 O
measurements O
, O
repetition/echo O
time O
TR/TE O
= O
2110/29 O
ms O
, O
flip O
angle O
78° O
, O
field-of-view O
220 O
× O
220 O
mm O
, O
matrix O
80 O
× O
80 O
, O
39 O
interleaved O
3 O
mm O
thick O
slices O
, O
2.75 O
× O
2.75 O
× O
3.0 O
mm3 O
voxels O
, O
GRAPPA O
acceleration O
factor O
2 O
) O
. O

The O
total O
duration O
of O
functional O
imaging O
was O
50–55 O
min O
, O
which O
included O
brief O
instructions O
, O
six O
BOLD O
scans O
, O
intra-MRI O
assessment O
questions O
, O
and O
time O
for O
post-scan O
water O
spray O
delivery O
and O
subjective O
ratings O
after O
BOLD O
scans O
. O

A O
gradient O
echo O
field O
mapping O
scan O
( O
TR O
= O
355 O
ms O
, O
TE1/TE2 O
= O
3.86/6.32 O
ms O
) O
with O
an O
imaging O
volume O
and O
voxel O
size O
identical O
to O
BOLD O
EPI O
was O
acquired O
prior O
to O
the O
first O
BOLD O
scan O
. O

This O
59 O
s O
scan O
with O
an O
advanced O
B0 O
shim O
mode O
adjustment O
optimized O
the O
field O
homogeneity O
and O
facilitated O
the O
BOLD O
EPI O
volume O
distortion O
evaluation O
and O
unwarping O
. O

This O
procedure O
yielded O
improved O
localization O
across O
the O
brain O
, O
most O
notably O
in O
the O
ventral O
striatal O
and O
frontal O
areas O
. O

Subjects O
' O
head O
movement O
and O
motion-related O
artifacts O
were O
minimized O
using O
foam O
pads O
and O
real O
time O
prospective O
acquisition O
motion O
correction O
, O
with O
additional O
steps O
accounting O
for O
head O
motion O
detailed O
in O
the O
image O
analysis O
below O
. O

Image O
analysis O
Image O
preprocessing O
included O
BOLD O
volume O
unwarping O
using O
topup/applytopup O
( O
Oxford O
Center O
for O
Functional O
MRI O
of O
the O
Brain O
Software O
Library O
; O
FSL O
, O
) O
, O
with O
slice-time O
acquisition O
correction O
, O
rigid-body O
realignment O
, O
and O
co-registration O
implemented O
in O
SPM8 O
( O
Wellcome O
Department O
of O
Imaging O
Neuroscience O
, O
University O
College O
, O
London O
, O
UK O
) O
. O

Each O
subject O
's O
MPRAGE O
image O
was O
segmented O
with O
SPM8 O
and O
parameters O
from O
this O
nonlinear O
transformation O
were O
used O
to O
convert O
the O
subject O
's O
structural O
MRI O
and O
realigned O
, O
co-registered O
BOLD O
volumes O
into O
Montreal O
Neurological O
Institute O
( O
MNI O
) O
stereotactic O
space O
. O

The O
resulting O
volumes O
were O
interpolated O
to O
2 O
mm/side O
isotropic O
voxels O
and O
smoothed O
by O
a O
6 O
mm O
full-width O
at O
half-maximum O
isotropic O
Gaussian O
kernel O
. O

Within-subject O
fixed O
effects O
of O
the O
BOLD O
response O
to O
stimulus O
trials O
were O
estimated O
using O
SPM O
's O
canonical O
hemodynamic O
response O
function O
with O
time O
and O
dispersion O
derivatives O
. O

Sucrose O
and O
water O
trial O
conditions O
were O
modeled O
to O
an O
onset O
coinciding O
with O
gustometer O
pump O
activation O
and O
durations O
of O
3 O
s. O
Swallowing O
was O
a O
condition O
of O
no O
interest O
, O
with O
onsets O
given O
by O
the O
visual O
cue O
appearance O
. O

We O
included O
, O
as O
multiple O
regressors O
, O
six O
head O
motion O
parameters O
from O
the O
SPM8 O
realignment O
and O
two O
FSL-derived O
metrics O
( O
frame O
displacement O
and O
DVARS O
from O
fsl_motion_outliers O
) O
recommended O
for O
tagging O
outlier O
BOLD O
volumes O
corrupted O
by O
large O
motion O
. O

A O
mixed O
linear O
model O
found O
no O
difference O
in O
outliers O
within O
any O
factor O
. O

An O
autoregressive O
AR O
( O
1 O
) O
model O
accounted O
for O
serial O
correlations O
, O
while O
a O
high-pass O
filter O
was O
set O
( O
1/128 O
Hz O
) O
to O
remove O
low-frequency O
noise O
. O

Statistical O
analysis O
The O
contrasts O
of O
[ O
0.83 O
M O
Sucrose O
> O
Water O
] O
and O
[ O
0.10 O
M O
Sucrose O
> O
Water O
] O
were O
estimated O
across O
all O
three O
scans O
of O
each O
concentration O
and O
entered O
into O
an O
SPM8 O
group O
random O
effects O
factorial O
model O
, O
Family O
History O
( O
FHP O
, O
FHN O
) O
× O
Sex O
( O
Men O
, O
Women O
) O
× O
Sucrose O
Concentration O
( O
high O
, O
low O
) O
, O
permitting O
secondary O
analyses O
of O
any O
effects O
from O
sex O
. O

We O
also O
examined O
an O
SPM O
factorial O
model O
that O
included O
drinks/week O
as O
normalized O
by O
total O
body O
water O
to O
account O
for O
differences O
in O
body O
size O
in O
sex O
, O
and O
thus O
alcohol O
exposure O
. O

In O
addition O
, O
the O
covariates O
of O
both O
drinks/week O
and O
drinks/drinking O
day O
( O
normalized O
by O
total O
body O
water O
) O
were O
tested O
for O
any O
associations O
with O
BOLD O
responses O
to O
determine O
if O
the O
preliminary O
effects O
we O
previously O
identified O
could O
be O
replicated O
. O

For O
ease O
of O
interpretation O
, O
however O
, O
we O
also O
present O
drinking O
data O
that O
are O
unadjusted O
by O
total O
body O
water O
( O
see O
Table O
1 O
) O
. O

To O
identify O
only O
those O
gustatory O
areas O
present O
in O
the O
current O
data O
set O
, O
we O
made O
statistical O
inferences O
for O
the O
main O
effect O
of O
sucrose O
( O
collapsed O
across O
Family O
History O
, O
Sex O
, O
and O
Concentration O
) O
at O
the O
voxel-wise O
height O
threshold O
pFWE O
< O
0.05 O
, O
correcting O
for O
family-wise O
error O
( O
FWE O
) O
from O
multiple O
comparisons O
across O
the O
whole O
brain O
volume O
. O

This O
was O
the O
only O
contrast O
assessed O
across O
the O
whole O
brain O
volume O
, O
and O
solely O
to O
demonstrate O
that O
the O
paradigm O
activated O
the O
gustatory O
system O
overall O
( O
positive O
control O
) O
. O

To O
test O
for O
effects O
related O
to O
family O
history O
, O
we O
created O
a O
mask O
from O
regions O
previously O
defined O
by O
work O
published O
elsewhere O
( O
i.e. O
, O
the O
current O
data O
were O
not O
used O
to O
generate O
the O
mask O
) O
. O

This O
9792 O
mm3 O
( O
1224 O
voxels O
) O
conjoint O
binary O
mask O
( O
Fig O
. O

S1 O
) O
used O
for O
family O
wise O
error O
correction O
comprised O
of O
a O
priori O
hypothesized O
bilateral O
ROIs O
covering O
: O
( O
a O
) O
gustatory O
regions O
of O
“ O
area-G O
” O
( O
insula/parietal O
junction O
) O
and O
peri-Rolandic O
parietal O
areas O
identified O
by O
, O
( O
b O
) O
amygdala O
as O
identified O
by O
the O
MarsBar O
utility O
( O
AAL O
Atlas O
) O
, O
( O
c O
) O
posterior O
orbitofrontal O
areas O
identified O
by O
the O
meta-analysis O
as O
responding O
to O
primary O
reinforcers O
, O
and O
( O
d O
) O
previously O
described O
ventral O

regions O
. O

All O
subsequent O
analyses O
of O
BOLD O
response O
( O
i.e. O
, O
all O
those O
beyond O
the O
main O
effect O
of O
sucrose O
stimulation O
, O
described O
above O
) O
were O
conducted O
using O
this O
independent O
conjoint O
mask O
for O
small O
volume O
correction O
with O
a O
height O
threshold O
of O
pFWE O
< O
0.05 O
. O

Finally O
, O
we O
used O
voxel-wise O
linear O
regression O
to O
test O
for O
associations O
between O
rated O
sucrose O
liking O
and O
brain O
activation O
. O

Subject O
group O
demographic O
data O
were O
analyzed O
using O
Family O
History O
( O
2 O
) O
× O
Sex O
( O
2 O
) O
general O
linear O
models O
. O

Taste O
test O
data O
outside O
the O
scanner O
were O
analyzed O
by O
a O
Family O
History O
( O
2 O
) O
× O
Sex O
( O
2 O
) O
× O
Concentration O
( O
5 O
) O
× O
Block O
( O
3 O
) O
mixed O
linear O
model O
, O
with O
concentration O
and O
block O
being O
repeated O
measures O
. O

Additional O
models O
including O
drinks/week O
and O
drinks/drinking O
day O
( O
each O
corrected O
by O
total O
body O
water O
) O
covariates O
were O
also O
used O
to O
test O
for O
the O
covariate O
effects O
. O

Intra-MRI O
ratings O
of O
hunger O
, O
thirst O
, O
craving O
for O
sweet O
and O
salty O
tastes O
, O
and O
desire O
to O
change O
sweetness O
were O
analyzed O
using O
a O
Family O
History O
( O
FHP O
, O
FHN O
) O
× O
Sex O
( O
Men O
, O
Women O
) O
× O
Time O
( O
Baseline O
, O
First O
Scan O
, O
Last O
Scan O
) O
× O
Concentration O
( O
pre-exposure O
, O
0.10 O
M O
, O
0.83 O
M O
) O
mixed O
linear O
model O
, O
with O
Time O
and O
Concentration O
being O
repeated O
measures O
. O

Perceived O
sweetness O
and O
sweet O
liking O
were O
analyzed O
with O
Family O
History O
( O
FHP O
, O
FHN O
) O
× O
Sex O
( O
Men O
, O
Women O
) O
× O
Time O
( O
First O
Scan O
, O
Last O
Scan O
) O
× O
Concentration O
( O
0.10 O
M O
, O
0.83 O
M O
) O
mixed O
linear O
models O
. O

To O
test O
for O
associations O
between O
drinking O
and O
rated O
liking O
of O
the O
sweet O
solutions O
inside O
the O
scanner O
, O
the O
covariates O
of O
drinks/week O
and O
drinks/drinking O
day O
( O
both O
adjusted O
for O
total O
body O
water O
) O
were O
also O
used O
. O

When O
examining O
these O
covariates O
, O
and O
for O
ease O
of O
interpretation O
, O
the O
models O
were O
simplified O
by O
removing O
the O
Concentration O
factor O
, O
with O
two O
different O
models O
for O
each O
concentration O
( O
0.10 O
M O
, O
0.83 O
M O
) O
. O

The O
neural O
correlates O
of O
the O
unified O
percept O
of O
alcohol-related O
craving O
: O
a O
fMRI O
and O
EEG O
study O
Alcohol O
addiction O
is O
accompanied O
by O
aberrant O
neural O
activity O
. O

Previously O
, O
task-based O
fMRI O
and O
resting-state O
EEG O
studies O
have O
revealed O
that O
craving O
, O
a O
critical O
component O
of O
addiction O
, O
is O
linked O
to O
abnormal O
activity O
in O
cortical O
regions O
including O
the O
dorsal O
anterior O
cingulate O
cortex O
( O
dACC O
) O
, O
nucleus O
accumbens O
( O
NAcc O
) O
, O
posterior O
cingulate O
cortex O
( O
PCC O
) O
and O
pregenual O
anterior O
cingulate O
cortex O
( O
pgACC O
) O
, O
etc O
. O

In O
this O
study O
, O
we O
combine O
these O
two O
imaging O
techniques O
to O
investigate O
a O
group O
of O
alcohol-addicted O
patients O
and O
provide O
convergent O
evidence O
for O
the O
neural O
correlates O
of O
craving O
not O
only O
in O
alcohol O
but O
substance O
abuse O
in O
general O
. O

We O
observe O
abnormal O
BOLD O
signal O
levels O
in O
the O
dACC O
, O
NAcc O
, O
pgACC O
, O
PCC O
, O
amygdala O
, O
and O
parahippocampus O
( O
PHC O
) O
in O
a O
cue-reactivity O
fMRI O
experiment O
. O

These O
findings O
are O
consistent O
with O
increased O
beta-band O
activity O
in O
the O
dACC O
and O
pgACC O
in O
resting-state O
EEG O
. O

We O
further O
observe O
desynchronization O
characterized O
by O
decreased O
functional O
connectivity O
in O
cue-based O
fMRI O
and O
hypersynchronization O
characterized O
by O
increased O
functional O
connectivity O
between O
these O
regions O
in O
the O
theta O
frequency O
band O
. O

The O
results O
of O
our O
study O
show O
a O
consistent O
pattern O
of O
alcohol O
craving O
elicited O
by O
external O
cues O
and O
internal O
desires O
. O

Given O
the O
advantage O
of O
superior O
spatial O
and O
temporal O
resolution O
, O
we O
hypothesize O
a O
“ O
central O
craving O
network O
” O
that O
integrates O
the O
different O
aspects O
of O
alcohol O
addiction O
into O
a O
unified O
percept O
. O

Materials O
and O
Methods O
Patient O
demographics O
Eleven O
patients O
( O
N O
= O
11 O
; O
8 O
males O
and O
3 O
females O
) O
with O
a O
mean O
age O
of O
48.12 O
years O
( O
sd O
= O
8.54 O
) O
were O
included O
in O
the O
study O
. O

The O
mean O
score O
on O
the O
NRS O
( O
numeric O
rating O
scale O
) O
for O
the O
desire O
of O
alcohol O
was O
8.32 O
( O
sd O
= O
1.87 O
) O
and O
the O
mean O
Audit O
( O
Alcohol O
Use O
Disorders O
Identification O
test O
) O
score O
was O
36.21 O
( O
sd O
= O
5.89 O
) O
. O

An O
Audit O
( O
Alcohol O
Use O
Disorders O
Identification O
test O
) O
score O
of O
20 O
or O
above O
clinically O
warrants O
further O
diagnostic O
evaluation O
for O
alcohol O
dependence O
. O

All O
patients O
were O
first O
screened O
by O
a O
psychiatric O
consultation O
. O

Following O
that O
an O
EEG O
was O
performed O
, O
as O
well O
as O
an O
fMRI O
using O
images O
of O
alcoholic O
and O
non-alcoholic O
beverages O
as O
cues O
. O

All O
patients O
reported O
that O
they O
had O
undergone O
multiple O
treatments O
with O
only O
temporary O
success O
, O
due O
to O
major O
craving O
and O
an O
obsessive-compulsive O
focus O
on O
alcohol O
, O
presented O
with O
a O
relapsing O
clinical O
picture O
. O

All O
patients O
were O
resistant O
to O
acamprosate O
and O
naltrexone O
. O

Patients O
reported O
that O
during O
relapses O
they O
engaged O
in O
binge O
drinking O
associated O
with O
aggression O
with O
amnesia O
, O
mood O
and O
sleep O
problems O
followed O
by O
withdrawal O
symptoms O
upon O
arresting O
alcohol O
intake O
. O

Behavioral O
treatment O
in O
outpatient O
individualized O
sessions O
, O
group O
sessions O
, O
and O
inpatient O
treatment O
in O
a O
general O
hospital O
as O
well O
as O
a O
specialized O
addiction O
hospital O
all O
yielded O
only O
temporary O
success O
. O

See O
Table O
1 O
for O
Table O
demographics O
, O
anthropometric O
and O
laboratory O
measures O
. O

Participants O
were O
requested O
to O
refrain O
from O
alcohol O
consumption O
24 O
hours O
prior O
to O
recording O
and O
from O
caffeinated O
beverage O
consumption O
on O
the O
day O
of O
recording O
. O

This O
study O
was O
approved O
by O
the O
local O
ethical O
committee O
( O
Antwerp O
University O
Hospital O
) O
and O
was O
in O
accordance O
with O
the O
declaration O
of O
Helsinki O
. O

Written O
informed O
consent O
was O
obtained O
from O
all O
patients O
. O

Functional O
Magnetic O
Resonance O
Imaging O
Data O
Acquisition O
The O
patients O
underwent O
three O
fMRI O
sessions O
at O
different O
time O
points O
on O
a O
3 O
T O
MRI O
scanner O
( O
ACHIEVA O
, O
Philips O
Medical O
Systems O
, O
Best O
, O
The O
Netherlands O
) O
. O

Alcohol O
addicted O
patients O
performed O
a O
visual O
cue O
stimulation O
experiment O
using O
a O
blocked O
designed O
paradigm O
. O

During O
the O
experiment O
, O
the O
fMRI O
was O
performed O
to O
map O
out O
BOLD O
signals O
in O
different O
cortical O
areas O
. O

Each O
patient O
had O
four O
sessions O
and O
each O
session O
contained O
120 O
scans O
( O
EPI O
; O
120 O
dynamic O
scans O
, O
repetition O
time O
( O
TR O
) O
= O
3000 O
ms O
; O
echo O
time O
( O
TE O
) O
= O
33 O
ms O
; O
voxel O
size O
= O
2.9 O
× O
2.9 O
× O
4.0 O
mm O
; O
field O
of O
view O
( O
FOV O
) O
= O
230 O
× O
230 O
mm O
; O
flip O
angle O
( O
FA O
) O
= O
90 O
) O
. O

Within O
and O
between O
sessions O
balance O
was O
included O
in O
the O
experimental O
design O
. O

In O
each O
session O
, O
120 O
images O
were O
divided O
into O
24 O
blocks O
and O
4 O
conditions O
. O

Each O
block O
contained O
5 O
images O
within O
the O
same O
condition O
and O
each O
image O
lasted O
3 O
s. O
The O
four O
conditions O
were O
( O
a O
) O
alcohol O
condition O
( O
images O
of O
alcohol O
beverages O
) O
, O
( O
b O
) O
beverage O
condition O
( O
images O
of O
non-alcoholic O
beverages O
) O
, O
( O
c O
) O
control O
condition O
( O
unidentifiably O
scrambled O
images O
of O
alcoholic O
and O
non-alcoholic O
beverages O
) O
, O
and O
( O
d O
) O
fix O
condition O
( O
image O
of O
a O
fixation O
cross O
) O
. O

Patients O
were O
instructed O
to O
focus O
on O
the O
visually O
presented O
stimuli O
throughout O
the O
entire O
experiment O
in O
the O
MRI O
machine O
. O

Numerous O
studies O
have O
used O
a O
cue-reactivity O
paradigm O
, O
which O
exposes O
subjects O
to O
drug-related O
stimuli O
, O
while O
monitoring O
their O
physiological O
responses O
to O
investigate O
addictive O
behavior O
. O

A O
meta-analysis O
of O
the O
cue-reactivity O
paradigm O
suggests O
it O
can O
generate O
a O
stable O
profile O
of O
significant O
addict-related O
effects O
. O

To O
improve O
our O
understanding O
of O
alcohol O
addictive O
behavior O
, O
establish O
treatment O
for O
active O
alcohol O
users O
, O
and O
prevent O
relapse O
, O
it O
is O
important O
to O
understand O
the O
neurobiological O
mechanism O
that O
underpins O
alcohol-related O
behavior O
. O

Data O
analysis O
The O
fMRI O
data O
were O
analyzed O
using O
Statistical O
Parametric O
Mapping O
8 O
( O
SPM8 O
) O
( O
The O
Wellcome O
Trust O
Center O
for O
Neuroimaging O
, O
London O
, O
UK O
) O
( O
http O
: O
//www.fil.ion.ucl.ac.uk/spm O
) O
. O

The O
structural O
T1 O
image O
( O
retaining O
the O
gray O
matter O
, O
white O
matter O
, O
and O
CSF O
) O
was O
first O
skull-stripped O
. O

The O
functional O
images O
were O
realigned O
to O
the O
first O
scan O
to O
correct O
for O
head O
movement O
. O

The O
high-resolution O
skull-stripped O
T1 O
image O
was O
then O
co-registered O
to O
the O
mean O
realigned O
functional O
image O
and O
subsequently O
normalized O
to O
the O
Montreal O
Neurological O
Institute O
( O
MNI O
) O
coordinates O
. O

Finally O
, O
spatial O
smoothing O
was O
applied O
using O
a O
6 O
× O
6 O
× O
6 O
mm O
full-width O
at O
half O
maximum O
( O
FWHM O
) O
of O
the O
Gaussian O
smoothing O
kernel O
. O

The O
functional O
activation O
was O
analyzed O
using O
a O
standard O
general O
linear O
model O
( O
GLM O
) O
. O

A O
boxcar O
reference O
function O
was O
convolved O
with O
the O
hemodynamic O
function O
to O
represent O
the O
time O
course O
of O
the O
expected O
signal O
during O
the O
experiment O
. O

The O
first O
blood O
oxygenation O
level-dependent O
( O
BOLD O
) O
signal O
was O
generated O
by O
a O
one-sample O
t-test O
specified O
to O
a O
contrast O
between O
seeing O
images O
of O
alcoholic O
beverages O
versus O
images O
of O
non-alcoholic O
beverages O
in O
the O
patient O
group O
. O

The O
second O
blood O
oxygenation O
level-dependent O
( O
BOLD O
) O
signal O
was O
generated O
by O
a O
conjunction O
analysis O
assessing O
a O
comparison O
of O
viewing O
images O
of O
alcoholic O
beverages O
to O
control O
images O
versus O
a O
comparison O
of O
viewing O
images O
of O
non-alcoholic O
beverages O
to O
control O
images O
across O
all O
patients O
. O

The O
one-sample O
t-test O
and O
conjunction O
analysis O
were O
both O
conducted O
at O
voxel O
level O
and O
a O
threshold O
for O
significant O
functional O
activation O
at O
p O
< O
0.01 O
uncorrected O
for O
the O
one-sample O
t-test O
and O
p O
< O
0.001 O
uncorrected O
for O
the O
conjunction O
analysis O
. O

The O
set O
of O
cluster O
size O
was O
larger O
than O
60 O
voxels O
in O
the O
one-sample O
t-test O
and O
larger O
than O
50 O
voxels O
in O
the O
conjunction O
analysis O
. O

Functional O
connectivity O
The O
average O
beta O
values O
for O
every O
condition O
at O
the O
peak O
activation O
voxel O
of O
all O
regions O
of O
interest O
were O
extracted O
from O
each O
individual O
and O
activity O
of O
all O
regions O
of O
interest O
were O
correlated O
with O
one O
another O
to O
create O
a O
co-activation O
matrix O
. O

This O
co-activation O
matrix O
was O
the O
measure O
of O
functional O
connectivity O
in O
the O
cue-based O
fMRI O
paradigm O
. O

The O
functional O
connectivity O
matrix O
in O
the O
alcoholic O
beverage O
and O
non-alcoholic O
beverage O
conditions O
were O
compared O
using O
Fischer O
’ O
s O
Z O
and O
p O
< O
0.05 O
. O

Electroencephalography O
EEG O
Data O
collection O
EEG O
data O
were O
obtained O
as O
a O
standard O
procedure O
. O

Recordings O
were O
obtained O
in O
a O
fully O
lighted O
room O
with O
each O
participant O
sitting O
upright O
on O
a O
small O
but O
comfortable O
chair O
. O

The O
actual O
recording O
lasted O
approximately O
five O
minutes O
. O

The O
EEG O
was O
sampled O
using O
Mitsar-201 O
amplifiers O
( O
NovaTech O
http O
: O
//www.novatecheeg.com/ O
) O
with O
19 O
electrodes O
placed O
according O
to O
the O
standard O
10–20 O
International O
placement O
( O
Fp1 O
, O
Fp2 O
, O
F7 O
, O
F3 O
, O
Fz O
, O
F4 O
, O
F8 O
, O
T7 O
, O
C3 O
, O
Cz O
, O
C4 O
, O
T8 O
, O
P7 O
, O
P3 O
, O
Pz O
, O
P4 O
, O
P8 O
, O
O1 O
, O
O2 O
) O
. O

Participants O
abstained O
from O
alcohol O
consumption O
24 O
hours O
prior O
to O
EEG O
recording O
and O
from O
caffeinated O
beverages O
on O
the O
day O
of O
recording O
to O
avoid O
alcohol-induced O
changes O
in O
EEG O
or O
a O
caffeine-induced O
alpha O
power O
decrease O
. O

The O
vigilance O
of O
participants O
was O
monitored O
by O
EEG O
parameters O
such O
as O
the O
slowing O
of O
alpha O
rhythm O
or O
the O
appearance O
of O
spindles O
as O
drowsiness O
that O
is O
reflected O
in O
enhanced O
theta O
power O
. O

Impedances O
were O
checked O
to O
remain O
below O
5 O
kΩ O
. O

Data O
was O
collected O
eyes-closed O
( O
sampling O
rate O
= O
500 O
Hz O
, O
band O
passed O
0.15–200 O
Hz O
) O
. O

Off-line O
data O
were O
resampled O
to O
128 O
Hz O
, O
band-pass O
filtered O
in O
the O
range O
2–44 O
Hz O
and O
subsequently O
transposed O
into O
Eureka O
! O

software O
, O
plotted O
and O
carefully O
inspected O
for O
manual O
artifact-rejection O
. O

All O
episodic O
artifacts O
including O
eye O
blinks O
, O
eye O
movements O
, O
teeth O
clenching O
, O
body O
movement O
, O
and O
other O
ECG O
artifacts O
were O
removed O
from O
the O
stream O
of O
the O
EEG O
. O

In O
addition O
, O
an O
independent O
component O
analysis O
( O
ICA O
) O
was O
conducted O
to O
further O
verify O
if O
all O
artifacts O
had O
been O
excluded O
. O

To O
investigate O
the O
effect O
of O
possible O
ICA O
component O
rejection O
, O
we O
compared O
the O
power O
spectra O
with O
two O
approaches O
: O
( O
1 O
) O
after O
visual O
artifact O
rejection O
only O
and O
( O
2 O
) O
after O
additional O
ICA O
component O
rejection O
. O

The O
mean O
power O
in O
the O
delta O
( O
2–3.5 O
Hz O
) O
, O
theta O
( O
4–7.5 O
Hz O
) O
, O
alpha1 O
( O
8–10 O
Hz O
) O
, O
alpha2 O
( O
10–12 O
Hz O
) O
, O
beta1 O
( O
13–18 O
Hz O
) O
, O
beta2 O
( O
18.5–21 O
Hz O
) O
, O
beta3 O
( O
21.5–30 O
Hz O
) O
, O
and O
gamma O
( O
30.5–44 O
Hz O
) O
bands O
did O
not O
show O
a O
statistically O
significant O
difference O
between O
the O
two O
approaches O
. O

Average O
Fourier O
cross-spectral O
matrices O
were O
computed O
for O
all O
eight O
bands O
. O

Normative O
database O
A O
normative O
database O
was O
used O
. O

Exclusion O
criteria O
were O
known O
psychiatric O
or O
neurological O
illness O
, O
psychiatric O
history O
of O
drug/alcohol O
abuse O
in O
a O
participant O
or O
any O
relative O
, O
current O
psychotropic/CNS O
active O
medications O
, O
history O
of O
head O
injury O
( O
with O
loss O
of O
consciousness O
) O
or O
seizures O
, O
headache O
, O
and O
physical O
disability O
. O

About O
3–5 O
min O
of O
EEG O
was O
continuously O
recorded O
while O
participant O
sat O
with O
their O
eyes O
closed O
on O
a O
comfortable O
chair O
in O
a O
quiet O
and O
dimly O
lit O
room O
. O

EEG O
data O
were O
acquired O
at O
the O
19 O
standard O
leads O
prescribed O
by O
the O
10–20 O
international O
system O
( O
FP1 O
, O
FP2 O
, O
F7 O
, O
F3 O
, O
FZ O
, O
F4 O
, O
F8 O
, O
T3 O
, O
C3 O
, O
CZ O
, O
C4 O
, O
T4 O
, O
T5 O
, O
P3 O
, O
PZ O
, O
P4 O
, O
T6 O
, O
O1 O
, O
O2 O
) O
using O
both O
earlobes O
as O
reference O
and O
enabling O
a O
60 O
Hz O
notch O
filter O
to O
suppress O
power O
line O
contamination O
. O

The O
resistance O
of O
all O
electrodes O
was O
kept O
below O
5 O
kΩ O
. O

Data O
of O
the O
BRL O
database O
were O
acquired O
using O
the O
12-bit O
A/D O
BSA O
acquisition O
system O
( O
Neurometrics O
, O
Inc. O
, O
New O
York O
, O
NY O
) O
and O
sampled O
at O
100 O
Hz O
. O

For O
consistency O
, O
we O
subsequently O
up-sampled O
the O
BRL O
database O
to O
128 O
Hz O
using O
a O
natural O
cubic O
spline O
interpolation O
routine O
( O
Congedo O
et O
al. O
, O
2002 O
) O
. O

We O
removed O
from O
all O
data O
biological O
, O
instrumental O
and O
environmental O
artifacts O
, O
paying O
attention O
to O
biological O
artifacts O
generated O
by O
the O
eyes O
, O
the O
heart O
and O
the O
muscles O
of O
the O
neck O
, O
face O
and O
jaw O
. O

EEG O
recordings O
were O
visually O
inspected O
on O
a O
high-resolution O
screen O
and O
epochs O
containing O
visible O
artifacts O
were O
marked O
and O
ignored O
for O
ensuing O
analysis O
. O

Source O
localization O
Standardized O
low-resolution O
brain O
electromagnetic O
tomography O
( O
sLORETA O
) O
was O
used O
to O
estimate O
the O
intracerebral O
electrical O
sources O
. O

As O
a O
standard O
procedure O
, O
a O
common O
average O
reference O
transformation O
was O
performed O
before O
applying O
the O
sLORETA O
algorithm O
. O

sLORETA O
computes O
electric O
neuronal O
activity O
as O
current O
density O
( O
A/m2 O
) O
without O
assuming O
a O
predefined O
number O
of O
active O
sources O
. O

The O
solution O
space O
used O
in O
this O
study O
and O
associated O
lead-field O
matrix O
are O
those O
implemented O
in O
the O
LORETA-Key O
software O
( O
freely O
available O
at O
http O
: O
//www.uzh.ch/keyinst/loreta.htm O
) O
. O

This O
software O
implements O
revisited O
realistic O
electrode O
coordinates O
( O
Jurcak O
et O
al O
. O

2007 O
) O
and O
the O
lead O
field O
produced O
by O
Fuchs O
et O
al O
. O

by O
applying O
the O
boundary O
element O
method O
on O
the O
MNI-152 O
( O
Montreal O
neurological O
institute O
, O
Canada O
) O
template O
of O
Mazziotta O
et O
al O
.. O

The O
sLORETA-key O
anatomical O
template O
divides O
and O
labels O
the O
neocortical O
( O
including O
hippocampus O
and O
anterior O
cingulate O
cortex O
) O
MNI-152 O
volume O
in O
6,239 O
voxels O
of O
dimension O
5 O
mm3 O
, O
based O
on O
probabilities O
returned O
by O
the O
Demon O
Atlas O
. O

Lagged O
phase O
coherence O
Coherence O
and O
phase O
synchronization O
between O
time O
series O
corresponding O
to O
different O
spatial O
locations O
are O
usually O
interpreted O
as O
indicators O
of O
“ O
connectivity O
” O
. O

However O
, O
any O
measure O
of O
dependence O
is O
highly O
contaminated O
with O
an O
instantaneous O
, O
non-physiological O
contribution O
due O
to O
volume O
conduction O
. O

However O
, O
Pascual-Marqui O
, O
introduced O
new O
measures O
of O
coherence O
and O
phase O
synchronization O
taking O
into O
account O
only O
non-instantaneous O
( O
lagged O
) O
connectivity O
, O
effectively O
removing O
the O
confounding O
factor O
of O
volume O
conduction O
. O

Such O
“ O
lagged O
phase O
coherence O
” O
between O
two O
sources O
can O
be O
interpreted O
as O
the O
amount O
of O
cross-talk O
between O
the O
regions O
contributing O
to O
the O
source O
activity O
. O

Since O
the O
two O
components O
oscillate O
coherently O
with O
a O
phase O
lag O
, O
the O
cross-talk O
can O
be O
interpreted O
as O
information O
sharing O
by O
axonal O
transmission O
. O

More O
precisely O
, O
the O
discrete O
Fourier O
transform O
decomposes O
the O
signal O
in O
a O
finite O
series O
of O
cosine O
and O
sine O
waves O
at O
the O
Fourier O
frequencies O
( O
Bloomfield O
2000 O
) O
. O

The O
lag O
of O
the O
cosine O
waves O
with O
respect O
to O
their O
sine O
counterparts O
is O
inversely O
proportional O
to O
their O
frequency O
and O
amounts O
to O
a O
quarter O
of O
the O
period O
; O
for O
example O
, O
the O
period O
of O
a O
sinusoidal O
wave O
at O
10 O
Hz O
is O
100 O
ms O
. O

The O
sine O
is O
shifted O
a O
quarter O
of O
a O
cycle O
( O
25 O
ms O
) O
with O
the O
respect O
to O
the O
cosine O
. O

Then O
the O
lagged O
phase O
coherence O
at O
10 O
Hz O
indicates O
coherent O
oscillations O
with O
a O
25 O
ms O
delay O
, O
while O
at O
20 O
Hz O
the O
delay O
is O
12.5 O
ms O
, O
etc O
. O

The O
threshold O
of O
significance O
for O
a O
given O
lagged O
phase O
coherence O
value O
according O
to O
asymptotic O
results O
can O
be O
found O
as O
described O
by O
Pascual-Marqui O
( O
2007 O
) O
, O
where O
the O
definition O
of O
lagged O
phase O
coherence O
can O
be O
found O
as O
well O
. O

As O
such O
, O
this O
measure O
of O
dependence O
can O
be O
applied O
to O
any O
number O
of O
brain O
areas O
jointly O
, O
i.e. O
, O
distributed O
cortical O
networks O
, O
whose O
activity O
can O
be O
estimated O
with O
sLORETA O
. O

Measures O
of O
linear O
dependence O
( O
coherence O
) O
between O
the O
multivariate O
time O
series O
are O
defined O
. O

The O
measures O
are O
non-negative O
, O
and O
take O
the O
value O
zero O
only O
when O
there O
is O
independence O
and O
are O
defined O
in O
the O
frequency O
domain O
: O
delta O
( O
2–3.5 O
Hz O
) O
, O
theta O
( O
4–7.5 O
Hz O
) O
, O
alpha1 O
( O
8–10 O
Hz O
) O
, O
alpha2 O
( O
10–12 O
Hz O
) O
, O
beta1 O
( O
13–18 O
Hz O
) O
, O
beta2 O
( O
18.5–21 O
Hz O
) O
, O
beta3 O
( O
21.5–30 O
Hz O
) O
and O
gamma O
( O
30.5–44 O
Hz O
) O
. O

Based O
on O
this O
principle O
, O
lagged O
linear O
connectivity O
was O
calculated O
. O

Time-series O
of O
current O
density O
were O
extracted O
for O
different O
regions O
of O
interests O
using O
sLORETA O
. O

Power O
in O
all O
6,239 O
voxels O
was O
normalized O
to O
a O
power O
of O
1 O
and O
log O
transformed O
at O
each O
time O
point O
. O

Region O
of O
interest O
values O
thus O
reflect O
the O
log-transformed O
fraction O
of O
total O
power O
across O
all O
voxels O
, O
separately O
for O
specific O
frequencies O
. O

Regions O
of O
interest O
selected O
were O
based O
on O
the O
activity O
findings O
of O
both O
EEG O
and O
fMRI O
- O
left O
and O
right O
orbitofrontal O
cortex O
, O
the O
pregenual O
anterior O
cingulate O
cortex O
, O
the O
dorsal O
anterior O
cingulate O
cortex O
, O
the O
posterior O
cingulate O
cortex O
, O
the O
left O
and O
right O
inferior O
frontal O
gyrus O
, O
the O
left O
and O
right O
insula O
, O
the O
left O
parahippocampus O
. O

Statistical O
analyses O
The O
methodology O
used O
is O
a O
non-parametric O
permutation O
test O
. O

It O
is O
based O
on O
estimating O
, O
via O
randomization O
, O
the O
empirical O
probability O
distribution O
for O
the O
max-statistic O
, O
under O
the O
null O
hypothesis O
comparisons O
. O

This O
methodology O
corrects O
for O
multiple O
testing O
( O
i.e O
. O

for O
the O
collection O
of O
tests O
performed O
for O
all O
voxels O
, O
and O
for O
all O
frequency O
bands O
) O
. O

Due O
to O
the O
non-parametric O
nature O
of O
this O
method O
, O
its O
validity O
does O
not O
rely O
on O
any O
assumption O
of O
Gaussianity O
. O

The O
significance O
threshold O
for O
all O
tests O
was O
based O
on O
a O
permutation O
test O
with O
5000 O
permutations O
. O

Comparisons O
were O
made O
between O
the O
healthy O
controls O
versus O
patients O
with O
an O
alcohol O
addiction O
. O

These O
comparisons O
were O
performed O
on O
a O
whole O
brain O
by O
sLORETA O
statistical O
contrast O
maps O
through O
multiple O
voxel-by-voxel O
comparisons O
in O
a O
logarithm O
of O
t-ratio O
. O

Data O
availability O
statement O
The O
datasets O
generated O
during O
and/or O
analyzed O
during O
the O
current O
study O
are O
available O
from O
the O
corresponding O
author O
on O
reasonable O
request O
. O

Yuefeng O
Huang O
and O
Anusha O
Mohan O
contributed O
equally O
to O
this O
work O
. O

Publisher O
's O
note O
: O
Springer O
Nature O
remains O
neutral O
with O
regard O
to O
jurisdictional O
claims O
in O
published O
maps O
and O
institutional O
affiliations O
. O

Combining O
multi-modality O
data O
for O
searching O
biomarkers O
in O
schizophrenia O
Identification O
of O
imaging O
biomarkers O
for O
schizophrenia O
is O
an O
important O
but O
still O
challenging O
problem O
. O

Even O
though O
considerable O
efforts O
have O
been O
made O
over O
the O
past O
decades O
, O
quantitative O
alterations O
between O
patients O
and O
healthy O
subjects O
have O
not O
yet O
provided O
a O
diagnostic O
measure O
with O
sufficient O
high O
sensitivity O
and O
specificity O
. O

One O
of O
the O
most O
important O
reasons O
is O
the O
lack O
of O
consistent O
findings O
, O
which O
is O
in O
part O
due O
to O
single-mode O
study O
, O
which O
only O
detects O
single O
dimensional O
information O
by O
each O
modality O
, O
and O
thus O
misses O
the O
most O
crucial O
differences O
between O
groups O
. O

Here O
, O
we O
hypothesize O
that O
multimodal O
integration O
of O
functional O
MRI O
( O
fMRI O
) O
, O
structural O
MRI O
( O
sMRI O
) O
, O
and O
diffusion O
tensor O
imaging O
( O
DTI O
) O
might O
yield O
more O
power O
for O
the O
diagnosis O
of O
schizophrenia O
. O

A O
novel O
multivariate O
data O
fusion O
method O
for O
combining O
these O
modalities O
is O
introduced O
without O
reducing O
the O
dimension O
or O
using O
the O
priors O
from O
161 O
schizophrenia O
patients O
and O
168 O
matched O
healthy O
controls O
. O

The O
multi-index O
feature O
for O
each O
ROI O
is O
constructed O
and O
summarized O
with O
Wilk O
's O
lambda O
by O
performing O
multivariate O
analysis O
of O
variance O
to O
calculate O
the O
significant O
difference O
between O
different O
groups O
. O

Our O
results O
show O
that O
, O
among O
these O
modalities O
, O
fMRI O
has O
the O
most O
significant O
featureby O
calculating O
the O
Jaccard O
similarity O
coefficient O
( O
0.7416 O
) O
and O
Kappa O
index O
( O
0.4833 O
) O
. O

Furthermore O
, O
fusion O
of O
these O
modalities O
provides O
the O
most O
plentiful O
information O
and O
the O
highest O
predictive O
accuracy O
of O
86.52 O
% O
. O

This O
work O
indicates O
that O
multimodal O
integration O
can O
improve O
the O
ability O
of O
distinguishing O
differences O
between O
groups O
and O
might O
be O
assisting O
in O
further O
diagnosis O
of O
schizophrenia O
. O

Methods O
Subjects O
One O
hundred O
and O
sixty-one O
patients O
with O
chronic O
schizophrenia O
( O
66 O
males O
and O
95 O
females O
) O
were O
recruited O
for O
this O
study O
and O
they O
were O
identified O
according O
to O
the O
DSM-IV O
diagnostic O
criteria O
by O
qualified O
psychiatrists O
at O
the O
Taipei O
Veterans O
General O
Hospital O
. O

Exclusion O
criteria O
included O
the O
presence O
of O
DSM-IV O
Axis O
I O
diagnoses O
of O
other O
disorders O
such O
as O
bipolar O
disorder O
, O
history O
of O
any O
substance O
dependence O
or O
history O
of O
clinically O
significant O
head O
trauma O
. O

Illness O
durations O
ranged O
from O
several O
months O
to O
52 O
years O
( O
mean±SD O
: O
17.86±11.1 O
years O
) O
. O

All O
patients O
were O
being O
treated O
with O
a O
range O
of O
antipsychotics O
. O

Their O
average O
age O
was O
44.99±11.5years O
and O
they O
had O
a O
mean O
education O
duration O
of O
12.33±3.66 O
years O
. O

Symptom O
severity O
was O
measured O
using O
the O
Positive O
and O
Negative O
Syndrome O
Scale O
( O
PANSS O
) O
assessment O
which O
was O
given O
to O
all O
schizophrenic O
participants O
either O
one O
week O
before O
the O
MRI O
scan O
or O
one O
week O
after O
it O
. O

All O
patients O
complete O
their O
PANSS O
assessment O
as O
listed O
in O
Table O
1 O
. O

One O
hundred O
sixty O
eight O
( O
72 O
male O
and O
96 O
female O
) O
healthy O
control O
subjects O
were O
also O
recruited O
. O

Their O
average O
age O
was O
43.17±10.8 O
years O
, O
and O
their O
mean O
education O
duration O
was O
15.8±3.5 O
years O
. O

All O
of O
the O
controls O
were O
assessed O
in O
accordance O
with O
DSM-IV O
criteria O
as O
being O
free O
of O
schizophrenia O
and O
other O
Axis O
I O
disorders O
. O

None O
of O
them O
had O
any O
neurological O
diseases O
or O
suffered O
from O
clinically O
significant O
head O
trauma O
and O
none O
had O
a O
history O
of O
any O
substance O
dependence O
. O

The O
patient O
and O
control O
groups O
were O
well O
matched O
by O
gender O
( O
χ2 O
= O
1.2 O
, O
p O
= O
0.73 O
) O
and O
age O
( O
t O
= O
1.48 O
, O
p O
= O
0.14 O
) O
although O
the O
controls O
had O
a O
slightly O
longer O
education O
duration O
( O
t O
= O
-8.8 O
, O
p O
< O
0.001 O
) O
. O

Patient O
and O
healthy O
control O
demographics O
are O
shown O
in O
Table O
1 O
. O

All O
of O
the O
patients O
were O
diagnosed O
according O
to O
the O
Diagnostic O
and O
Statistical O
Manual O
of O
Mental O
Disorders-IV O
criteria O
, O
then O
administered O
a O
diagnostic O
structured O
Mini- O
International O
Neuropsychiatric O
Interview O
( O
MINI O
) O
, O
Mini-Mental O
State O
Examination O
( O
MMSE O
) O
Chinese O
version O
. O

The O
cognitive O
functioning O
of O
the O
participants O
was O
evaluated O
using O
the O
MMSE O
for O
general O
cognitive O
status O
and O
the O
Wechsler O
Digit O
Span O
subtest O
for O
verbal O
working O
memory O
abilities O
. O

All O
participants O
exhibited O
sufficient O
visual O
and O
auditory O
acuity O
to O
undergo O
cognitive O
testing O
. O

This O
study O
was O
conducted O
in O
accordance O
with O
the O
Declaration O
of O
Helsinki O
and O
approved O
by O
the O
Institutional O
Review O
Board O
of O
Taipei O
Veterans O
General O
Hospital O
. O

Written O
informed O
consent O
was O
obtained O
from O
all O
participants O
ensuring O
adequate O
understanding O
of O
the O
study O
. O

Any O
participants O
with O
the O
presence O
of O
possible O
dementia O
or O
illiteracy O
were O
excluded O
. O

Imaging O
acquisitions O
and O
data O
preprocessing O
Imaging O
parameters O
All O
images O
were O
acquired O
using O
a O
3T O
MR O
system O
( O
Siemens O
Magnetom O
Tim O
Trio O
, O
Erlangen O
, O
German O
) O
at O
National O
Yang-Ming O
University O
, O
equipped O
with O
a O
high-resolution O
12-channel O
head O
array O
coil O
. O

To O
minimize O
the O
head O
motion O
during O
the O
scan O
, O
each O
subject O
’ O
s O
head O
was O
immobilized O
with O
cushions O
inside O
the O
coil O
during O
the O
scan O
. O

A O
high-resolution O
anatomical O
T1-weighted O
image O
was O
acquired O
with O
sagittal O
3D O
magnetization-prepared O
rapid O
gradient O
echo O
( O
MPRAGE O
) O
sequence O
: O
repetition O
time O
( O
TR O
) O
= O
3500 O
ms O
, O
echo O
time O
( O
TE O
) O
= O
3.5 O
ms O
, O
inversion O
time O
= O
1100 O
ms O
, O
flip O
angle O
= O
7° O
, O
field O
of O
view O
( O
FOV O
) O
= O
256 O
× O
256 O
mm2 O
, O
192 O
slices O
, O
slice O
thickness O
= O
1 O
mm O
, O
voxel O
size O
= O
1×1×1 O
mm3 O
. O

The O
diffusion O
images O
gradient O
encoding O
schemes O
include O
30 O
non-collinear O
directions O
( O
according O
to O
the O
minimal O
energy O
arrangement O
of O
electron O
distribution O
( O
http O
: O
//www2.research.att.com/~njas/electrons/dim3 O
) O
with O
b-value O
1000 O
s/mm2 O
, O
number O
of O
excitations O
: O
3 O
) O
and O
3 O
non-diffusion O
weighted O
image O
volume O
. O

With O
the O
consideration O
of O
total O
brain O
coverage O
, O
each O
volume O
consisted O
of O
70 O
contiguous O
axial O
slice O
( O
thickness O
: O
2 O
mm O
) O
acquired O
using O
a O
single O
shot O
spin-echo O
planar O
imaging O
( O
EPI O
) O
sequence O
( O
TR O
: O
11,000ms O
, O
TE O
: O
104ms O
, O
NEX O
: O
6 O
, O
Matrix O
size O
: O
128×128 O
, O
voxel O
size O
: O
2×2×2 O
mm3 O
, O
matrix O
size O
: O
128×128 O
) O
. O

For O
resting O
state O
fMRI O
: O
T2-weighted O
images O
with O
BOLD O
contrast O
were O
measured O
using O
a O
gradient O
echo- O
planar O
imaging O
( O
EPI O
) O
sequence O
( O
repetition O
time O
, O
TR O
: O
2,500 O
ms O
, O
echo O
time O
, O
TE O
: O
27 O
ms O
, O
field O
of O
view O
, O
FoV O
: O
220 O
mm O
, O
flip O
angle O
: O
77 O
degree O
, O
matrix O
size O
: O
64×64 O
, O
and O
voxel O
size O
: O
3.44×3.44×3.40 O
mm3 O
) O
, O
participants O
were O
instructed O
to O
relax O
with O
their O
eyes O
closed O
, O
without O
falling O
asleep O
during O
the O
total O
8min O
scan O
time O
. O

For O
each O
run O
, O
200 O
EPI O
volume O
images O
were O
acquired O
along O
the O
anterior O
and O
posterior O
commissure O
( O
AC–PC O
) O
plane O
. O

After O
the O
resting O
state O
experiment O
, O
participants O
were O
asked O
whether O
they O
fell O
asleep O
during O
the O
resting O
state O
scan O
session O
, O
and O
the O
participants O
were O
rescanned O
if O
they O
slept O
during O
the O
resting O
state O
scan O
. O

fMRI O
preprocessing O
fMRI O
data O
preprocessing O
was O
then O
conducted O
by O
SPM8 O
( O
University O
College O
London O
, O
UK O
; O
http O
: O
//www.fil.ion.ucl.ac.uk/spm O
) O
and O
DPARSF O
( O
Data O
Processing O
Assistant O
for O
resting-state O
fMRI O
) O
. O

Briefly O
, O
the O
remaining O
functional O
scans O
were O
first O
corrected O
for O
within-scan O
acquisition O
time O
differences O
between O
slices O
, O
and O
then O
realigned O
to O
the O
middle O
volume O
to O
correct O
for O
interscan O
head O
motions O
. O

Subsequently O
, O
the O
functional O
scans O
were O
spatially O
normalized O
to O
a O
standard O
template O
( O
Montreal O
Neurological O
Institute O
) O
and O
resampled O
to O
3×3×3mm3 O
. O

After O
normalization O
, O
the O
Blood O
Oxygenation O
Level O
Dependent O
( O
BOLD O
) O
signal O
of O
each O
voxel O
was O
first O
detrended O
to O
abandon O
linear O
trend O
and O
then O
passed O
through O
a O
bandpass O
filter O
( O
0.01–0.08 O
Hz O
) O
to O
reduce O
low-frequency O
drift O
and O
high-frequency O
physiological O
noise O
. O

Finally O
, O
nuisance O
covariates O
including O
head O
motion O
parameters O
, O
global O
mean O
signals O
, O
white O
matter O
signals O
and O
cerebrospinal O
fluid O
signals O
were O
regressed O
out O
from O
the O
Blood O
Oxygenation O
Level O
Dependent O
signals O
. O

sMRI O
preprocessing O
All O
T1-weighted O
structural O
data O
were O
pre-processed O
using O
the O
Diffeomorphic O
Anatomical O
Registration O
using O
Exponentiated O
Lie O
algebra O
( O
DARTEL O
) O
toolbox O
in O
SPM8 O
software O
( O
http O
: O
//www.fil.ion.ucl.ac.uk/spm O
) O
running O
under O
Matlab O
( O
MathWorks O
, O
USA O
) O
. O

This O
procedure O
involves O
the O
creation O
of O
a O
study-specific O
template O
and O
the O
segmentation O
of O
each O
individual O
image O
using O
said O
template O
, O
with O
the O
aim O
of O
maximizing O
accuracy O
and O
sensitivity O
. O

After O
modulate O
normalizing O
, O
the O
images O
were O
segmented O
into O
gray O
matter O
, O
white O
matter O
and O
the O
cerebrospinal O
fluid O
. O

These O
segmented O
images O
were O
smoothed O
using O
a O
12-mm O
full O
width O
at O
half O
maximum O
( O
FWHM O
) O
Gaussian O
kernel O
. O

DTI O
preprocessing O
Before O
image O
data O
processing O
, O
one O
author O
( O
Chu-Chung O
Huang O
, O
an O
experienced O
radiological O
technician O
) O
received O
all O
of O
the O
MRI O
scans O
to O
confirm O
that O
the O
participants O
were O
free O
of O
any O
morphological O
abnormalities O
and O
apparent O
WM O
lesions O
. O

Eddy O
current O
correction O
and O
brain O
tissue O
extraction O
of O
DTI O
dataset O
were O
pre-processed O
using O
FSL O
5.0.9 O
( O
Functional O
Magnetic O
Resonance O
Imaging O
of O
the O
Brain O
Software O
Library O
; O
http O
: O
//www.fmrib.ox.ac.uk/fsl O
) O
. O

Eddy O
current O
correction O
involved O
registering O
the O
diffusion-weighted O
images O
to O
the O
non-diffusion O
weighted O
image O
through O
affine O
transformations O
. O

It O
was O
done O
not O
only O
to O
minimize O
image O
distortion O
derived O
from O
eddy O
currents O
induced O
by O
fast-switching O
gradient O
coils O
, O
but O
also O
to O
reduce O
the O
simple O
head O
motion O
. O

Subsequently O
, O
the O
Brain O
Extraction O
Tool O
( O
BET O
) O
compiled O
in O
FSL O
was O
applied O
to O
remove O
the O
non-brain O
tissue O
and O
background O
noise O
from O
the O
images O
. O

After O
DTI O
preprocessing O
, O
parameter O
maps O
include O
FA O
( O
relative O
ratio O
of O
axial O
to O
radial O
diffusivities O
) O
, O
RD O
( O
radial O
diffusivity O
, O
( O
λ2+λ3 O
) O
/2 O
and O
MD O
( O
mean O
diffusivity O
, O
( O
λ1+λ2+λ3 O
) O
/3 O
) O
were O
calculated O
by O
fitting O
Baser O
’ O
s O
DTI O
tensor O
model O
at O
each O
voxel O
using O
in-house O
software O
. O

The O
definitions O
of O
λ1 O
, O
λ2 O
, O
λ3 O
are O
given O
in O
Supplemental O
Materials O
. O

Construction O
of O
multi-index O
vector O
for O
each O
ROI O
After O
preprocessing O
, O
each O
modality O
is O
first O
reduced O
to O
a O
“ O
feature O
” O
for O
each O
subject O
, O
which O
tends O
to O
be O
more O
tractable O
than O
working O
with O
the O
large-scale O
original O
data O
and O
provides O
a O
simpler O
space O
to O
link O
the O
data O
. O

In O
this O
paper O
, O
an O
automated O
anatomical O
labeling O
atlas O
was O
used O
to O
parcellate O
the O
brain O
into O
90 O
regions O
of O
interest O
( O
ROIs O
) O
( O
45 O
in O
each O
hemisphere O
) O
and O
the O
“ O
feature O
” O
is O
obtained O
for O
each O
ROI O
. O

The O
names O
of O
the O
ROIs O
and O
their O
corresponding O
abbreviations O
are O
listed O
in O
S1 O
Table O
. O

For O
fMRI O
, O
the O
time O
series O
were O
firstly O
extracted O
in O
each O
ROI O
by O
averaging O
the O
signals O
of O
all O
voxels O
within O
that O
region O
. O

Secondly O
, O
ordinary O
Pearson O
correlation O
coefficients O
with O
all O
other O
89 O
different O
ROIs O
were O
calculated O
for O
each O
ROI O
. O

A O
Fisher O
’ O
s O
r-to-z O
transformation O
was O
utilized O
to O
convert O
each O
correlation O
coefficient O
rij O
into O
Zij O
to O
improve O
the O
normality O
. O

A O
vector O
consisting O
of O
all O
these O
89 O
functional O
connectivity O
( O
FC O
) O
coefficients O
( O
Zij O
) O
was O
constructed O
as O
the O
functional O
measure O
( O
fMRI O
) O
for O
each O
ROI O
. O

For O
sMRI O
, O
the O
volume O
of O
grey O
matter O
( O
GM O
) O
and O
white O
matter O
( O
WM O
) O
was O
extracted O
as O
the O
structural O
feature O
for O
each O
ROI O
. O

For O
DTI O
, O
the O
fractional O
anisotropy O
( O
FA O
) O
, O
radial O
diffusivity O
( O
RD O
) O
and O
mean O
diffusivity O
( O
MD O
) O
were O
extracted O
as O
the O
DTI O
features O
for O
each O
ROI O
. O

By O
combining O
with O
the O
functional O
, O
structural O
and O
DTI O
features O
, O
a O
vector O
consisting O
of O
94 O
variables O
( O
89 O
fMRI O
features O
, O
2 O
sMRI O
features O
, O
and O
3 O
DTI O
features O
) O
was O
constructed O
as O
multi-index O
vector O
for O
each O
ROI O
. O

To O
avoid O
being O
overly O
biased O
by O
data O
scaling O
, O
the O
combined O
data O
was O
normalized O
by O
subtracting O
the O
mean O
and O
dividing O
by O
the O
standard O
deviation O
. O

The O
flowchart O
of O
the O
fusion O
data O
is O
shown O
in O
Fig O
1 O
. O

Multivariate O
analysis O
of O
variance O
Multivariate O
analysis O
of O
variance O
( O
MANOVA O
) O
is O
one O
of O
the O
multivariate O
approaches O
. O

It O
is O
a O
statistical O
test O
procedure O
for O
comparing O
multivariate O
( O
population O
) O
means O
of O
several O
groups O
. O

The O
multivariate O
approach O
has O
been O
adapted O
for O
single-mode O
fMRI O
data O
, O
sMRI O
data O
and O
DTI O
data O
in O
earlier O
studies O
. O

Suppose O
there O
are O
G O
different O
groups O
( O
patient O
, O
healthy O
control O
, O
etc O
) O
with O
ng O
individuals O
in O
the O
g-th O
group O
. O

For O
each O
individual O
k O
in O
the O
g-th O
group O
, O
there O
are O
m O
measures O
to O
form O
a O
measurement O
vector O
where O
is O
the O
i-th O
measurement O
of O
the O
k-th O
sample O
on O
the O
g-th O
group O
. O

We O
assume O
that O
Xgk O
follows O
a O
multivariate O
normal O
distribution O
Xg O
∼ O
Nm O
( O
μg O
, O
∑ O
) O
, O
g O
= O
1,2 O
, O
… O
, O
G O
In O
order O
to O
test O
the O
ability O
of O
each O
ROI O
to O
distinguish O
the O
different O
groups O
, O
we O
define O
the O
following O
measures O
: O
the O
within-group O
dispersion O
matrix O
W O
= O
[ O
wij O
] O
m×m O
, O
the O
between-group O
dispersion O
matrix O
B O
= O
[ O
bij O
] O
m×m O
and O
the O
total O
dispersion O
matrix O
T O
= O
[ O
Tij O
] O
m×m O
, O
where O
The O
ordinary O
Wilk O
's O
Lambda O
statistic O
was O
defined O
as O
follows O
: O
The O
smaller O
the O
value O
of O
λ O
is O
, O
the O
bigger O
the O
difference O
of O
different O
groups O
are O
. O

In O
order O
to O
calculate O
the O
p O
value O
of O
each O
Wilk O
’ O
s O
Lambda O
statistics O
, O
we O
transform O
it O
to O
a O
chi-square O
distribution O
with O
the O
following O
formulation O
: O
Bartlett O
showed O
that O
if O
H0 O
: O
μ1 O
= O
μ2 O
= O
… O
= O
μG O
is O
true O
and O
n O
is O
large O
, O
λ O
has O
approximately O
a O
chi-square O
distribution O
with O
m× O
( O
G−1 O
) O
degrees O
of O
freedom O
Support O
vector O
machine O
( O
SVM O
) O
classifier O
The O
SVM O
is O
a O
machine O
learning O
approach O
for O
a O
two-class O
classification O
problem O
. O

Since O
first O
proposed O
by O
Vapnik O
as O
a O
logistical O
extension O
of O
statistical O
learning O
theory O
, O
SVM O
has O
become O
widely O
used O
in O
many O
areas O
because O
of O
their O
ability O
to O
handle O
very O
high-dimensional O
data O
, O
and O
their O
accuracy O
in O
classification O
and O
prediction O
. O

SVM O
has O
become O
increasingly O
used O
in O
studies O
of O
psychiatric O
and O
neurological O
disorders O
, O
the O
rationale O
for O
which O
is O
that O
it O
is O
able O
to O
account O
for O
the O
inter-relationship O
between O
different O
within-modality O
measures O
for O
each O
subject O
by O
considering O
them O
simultaneously O
. O

SVM O
conceptually O
implements O
the O
idea O
that O
vectors O
are O
non-linearly O
mapped O
to O
a O
very O
high O
dimensional O
feature O
space O
. O

In O
the O
feature O
space O
, O
a O
linear O
separation O
surface O
is O
created O
to O
separate O
the O
training O
data O
by O
maximizing O
the O
margin O
between O
the O
vectors O
of O
the O
two O
classes O
. O

The O
training O
ends O
with O
the O
definition O
of O
a O
decision O
surface O
that O
divides O
the O
space O
into O
two O
sub-spaces O
. O

Each O
sub-space O
corresponds O
to O
one O
class O
of O
the O
training O
data O
. O

Once O
the O
training O
is O
completed O
, O
the O
test O
data O
are O
mapped O
to O
the O
feature O
space O
. O

A O
class O
is O
then O
assigned O
to O
the O
test O
data O
depending O
on O
which O
sub-space O
they O
are O
mapped O
to O
. O

In O
this O
paper O
, O
a O
SVM O
toolkit O
named O
libsvm O
written O
by O
Chih-Jen O
Lin O
from O
Taiwan O
university O
( O
http O
: O
//www.csie.ntu.edu.tw/~cjlin/libsvm/ O
) O
is O
used O
. O

Specifically O
, O
the O
whole O
brain O
single-modal O
or O
multi-modal O
features O
are O
applied O
to O
the O
raw O
input O
matrix O
. O

Statistically O
significant O
features O
( O
p-value O
of O
two-sample O
t-test O
being O
smaller O
than O
a O
threshold O
) O
are O
selected O
. O

Different O
kernel O
types O
( O
linear O
, O
t O
= O
0 O
; O
polynomial O
, O
t O
= O
1 O
; O
radial O
basis O
function O
, O
t O
= O
2 O
) O
and O
different O
trade-off O
parameter O
C O
( O
0.001 O
, O
0.01 O
, O
0.1 O
, O
1 O
, O
10 O
, O
100 O
, O
1000 O
, O
10000 O
) O
is O
tried O
to O
obtain O
the O
highest O
accuracy O
rate O
. O

To O
measure O
the O
test O
performance O
and O
to O
validate O
the O
classifier O
, O
we O
implement O
10-fold O
cross-validation O
with O
three O
levels O
of O
nesting O
for O
tuning O
and O
validating O
our O
model O
. O

That O
is O
, O
for O
each O
iteration O
, O
eight O
folds O
of O
the O
subjects O
are O
used O
for O
training O
, O
one O
fold O
is O
used O
to O
optimize O
the O
parameters O
and O
another O
fold O
for O
testing O
. O

The O
procedure O
is O
iterated O
for O
100 O
times O
, O
and O
the O
meandiscrimination O
accuracy O
, O
sensitivity O
and O
specificity O
are O
reported O
with O
the O
best O
parameter O
setting O
. O

The O
features O
are O
selected O
in O
each O
cross-validation O
run O
and O
the O
features O
with O
high O
weights O
during O
the O
100 O
iterations O
are O
the O
optimized O
features O
for O
each O
classifier O
. O

Choosing O
the O
generalization O
rate O
as O
the O
statistic O
, O
permutation O
tests O
are O
employed O
to O
estimate O
the O
statistical O
significance O
of O
the O
observed O
classification O
accuracy O
. O

In O
permutation O
testing O
, O
the O
class O
labels O
of O
the O
training O
data O
are O
randomly O
permuted O
prior O
to O
training O
. O

Cross-validation O
is O
then O
performed O
on O
the O
permuted O
training O
set O
, O
and O
the O
permutation O
is O
repeated O
100 O
times O
. O

The O
p-value O
represents O
the O
probability O
of O
observing O
a O
classification O
prediction O
rate O
in O
a O
permutation O
testing O
no O
less O
than O
the O
discrimination O
accuracy O
. O

If O
the O
p-value O
is O
smaller O
than O
the O
significant O
level O
, O
we O
reject O
the O
null O
hypothesis O
that O
the O
classifier O
could O
not O
learn O
the O
relationship O
between O
the O
data O
and O
the O
labels O
reliably O
and O
declare O
that O
the O
classifier O
learns O
the O
relationship O
with O
a O
probability O
of O
being O
wrong O
of O
at O
most O
p.The O
flowchart O
of O
the O
pattern O
recognition O
is O
shown O
in O
S1 O
Fig O
. O

Diversity O
of O
individual O
modalities O
in O
classification O
As O
mentioned O
earlier O
, O
a O
lot O
of O
studies O
have O
indicated O
that O
different O
modalities O
contain O
complementary O
information O
for O
discrimination O
. O

In O
order O
to O
quantitatively O
measure O
the O
discrimination O
similarity O
and O
diversity O
between O
any O
two O
different O
modalities O
, O
we O
use O
Jaccard O
similarity O
coefficient O
and O
Kappa O
index O
to O
achieve O
these O
goals O
. O

The O
Jaccard O
coefficient O
measures O
similarity O
between O
finite O
sample O
sets O
, O
and O
is O
defined O
as O
the O
size O
of O
the O
intersection O
divided O
by O
the O
size O
of O
the O
union O
of O
the O
sample O
sets O
. O

Cohen O
's O
kappa O
measures O
the O
agreement O
between O
two O
raters O
who O
each O
classify O
N O
items O
into O
C O
mutually O
exclusive O
categories O
. O

The O
equation O
for O
kappa O
is O
: O
Where O
Pr O
( O
a O
) O
is O
the O
relative O
observed O
agreement O
among O
raters O
, O
and O
Pr O
( O
e O
) O
is O
the O
hypothetical O
probability O
of O
chance O
agreement O
, O
using O
the O
observed O
data O
to O
calculate O
the O
probabilities O
of O
each O
observer O
randomly O
staying O
each O
category O
. O

Contribution O
of O
different O
modalities O
When O
scanning O
the O
same O
subject O
, O
we O
can O
obtain O
fMRI O
, O
sMRI O
and O
DTI O
at O
the O
same O
time O
. O

The O
multi-modal O
data O
provides O
a O
different O
perspective O
on O
the O
study O
of O
brain O
function O
and O
structure O
. O

In O
order O
to O
investigate O
which O
kind O
of O
modality O
is O
more O
powerful O
, O
we O
intend O
to O
study O
the O
contribution O
of O
each O
modality O
to O
the O
fusion O
data O
. O

Suppose O
Xi O
is O
the O
features O
for O
subject O
i O
. O

Then O
we O
use O
the O
following O
logistic O
regression O
to O
model O
the O
probability O
, O
pi O
, O
for O
the O
i-th O
subject O
to O
be O
a O
patient O
: O
In O
order O
to O
assess O
the O
contribution O
of O
different O
modalities O
, O
we O
use O
R2 O
indices O
, O
defined O
by O
Cox O
and O
Snell O
to O
describe O
how O
well O
the O
features O
Xi O
fit O
a O
set O
of O
observations O
( O
i.e. O
, O
goodness O
of O
fit O
) O
. O

We O
denote O
, O
, O
, O
as O
the O
R2 O
indices O
of O
four O
different O
models O
when O
we O
use O
fusion O
, O
fMRI O
, O
sMRI O
, O
and O
DTI O
features O
as O
independent O
, O
respectively O
. O

We O
define O
the O
contribution O
of O
different O
modality O
to O
fusion O
data O
as O
the O
ratio O
of O
R2 O
of O
each O
modality O
to O
R2 O
of O
fusion O
data O
. O

For O
example O
, O
the O
ratio O
is O
the O
contribution O
of O
fMRI O
data O
. O

Social O
affective O
context O
reveals O
altered O
network O
dynamics O
in O
schizophrenia O
patients O
Impairments O
in O
social O
cognition O
and O
interactions O
are O
core O
psychopathologies O
in O
schizophrenia O
, O
often O
manifesting O
as O
an O
inability O
to O
appropriately O
relate O
to O
the O
intentions O
and O
feelings O
of O
others O
. O

Neuroimaging O
has O
helped O
to O
demarcate O
the O
dynamics O
of O
two O
distinct O
functional O
connectivity O
circuits O
underlying O
the O
social-affective O
processes O
related O
to O
mentalization O
( O
known O
as O
Theory O
of O
Mind O
, O
ToM O
) O
and O
somatic-affiliation O
( O
known O
as O
Embodied O
Simulation O
, O
ES O
) O
. O

While O
evidence O
points O
to O
abnormal O
activation O
patterns O
within O
these O
networks O
among O
those O
suffering O
from O
schizophrenia O
, O
it O
is O
yet O
unclear O
however O
, O
if O
these O
patients O
exhibit O
this O
abnormal O
functional O
connectivity O
in O
the O
context O
of O
social-affective O
experiences O
. O

The O
current O
fMRI O
study O
, O
investigated O
functional O
connectivity O
dynamics O
within O
ToM O
and O
ES O
networks O
as O
subjects O
experienced O
evolving O
cinematic O
portrayals O
of O
fear O
. O

During O
scanning O
, O
schizophrenia O
patients O
and O
healthy O
controls O
passively O
watched O
a O
cinematic O
scene O
in O
which O
a O
mother O
and O
her O
son O
face O
various O
threatening O
events O
. O

Participants O
then O
provided O
a O
continuous O
and O
retrospective O
report O
of O
their O
fear O
intensity O
during O
a O
second O
viewing O
outside O
the O
scanner O
. O

Using O
network O
cohesion O
index O
( O
NCI O
) O
analysis O
, O
we O
examined O
modulations O
of O
ES-related O
and O
ToM-related O
functional O
connectivity O
dynamics O
and O
their O
relation O
to O
symptom O
severity O
and O
the O
continuous O
emotional O
ratings O
of O
the O
induced O
cinematic O
fear O
. O

Compared O
to O
patients O
, O
healthy O
controls O
showed O
higher O
ES-NCI O
and O
marginally O
lower O
ToM-NCI O
during O
emotional O
peaks O
. O

Cross-correlation O
analysis O
revealed O
an O
intriguing O
dynamic O
between O
NCI O
and O
the O
inter-group O
difference O
of O
reported O
fear O
. O

Schizophrenia O
patients O
rated O
their O
fear O
as O
lower O
relative O
to O
healthy O
controls O
, O
shortly O
after O
exhibiting O
lower O
ES O
connectivity O
. O

This O
increased O
difference O
in O
rating O
was O
also O
followed O
by O
higher O
ToM O
connectivity O
among O
schizophrenia O
patients O
. O

The O
clinical O
relevance O
of O
these O
findings O
is O
further O
highlighted O
by O
the O
following O
two O
results O
: O
( O
a O
) O
ToM-NCI O
was O
found O
to O
have O
a O
strong O
correlation O
with O
the O
severity O
of O
general O
symptoms O
during O
one O
of O
the O
two O
main O
emotional O
peaks O
( O
Spearman O
R O
= O
0.77 O
) O
; O
and O
( O
b O
) O
k-mean O
clustering O
demonstrated O
that O
the O
networks O
’ O
NCI O
dynamic O
during O
the O
social-affective O
context O
reliably O
differentiated O
between O
patients O
and O
controls O
. O

Together O
, O
these O
findings O
point O
to O
a O
possible O
neural O
marker O
for O
abnormal O
social-affective O
processing O
in O
schizophrenia O
, O
manifested O
as O
the O
disturbed O
balance O
between O
two O
functional O
networks O
involved O
in O
social-affective O
affiliation O
. O

This O
in O
turn O
suggests O
that O
exaggerated O
mentalization O
over O
somatic-affiliative O
processing O
, O
in O
response O
to O
another O
’ O
s O
’ O
distress O
may O
underlie O
social-affective O
deficits O
in O
schizophrenia O
. O

Materials O
and O
methods O
Subjects O
The O
study O
groups O
included O
30 O
inpatients O
( O
13 O
women O
; O
mean O
age O
25 O
, O
range O
: O
18–40 O
years O
) O
recruited O
by O
a O
senior O
psychiatrists O
at O
one O
of O
three O
Mental O
Health O
Centers O
: O
Beer O
Yaakov O
Mental O
Health O
Center O
, O
Mazra O
Mental O
Health O
Center O
and O
Lev-Hasharon O
Mental O
Health O
Center O
. O

Patients O
were O
diagnosed O
based O
on O
the O
structured O
clinical O
interview O
for O
DSM-IV O
Axis-I O
disorders O
, O
Patient O
Edition O
, O
SCID-I/P O
( O
First O
, O
1994 O
) O
, O
while O
hospitalized O
. O

Those O
with O
major O
affective O
or O
neurological O
disorders O
, O
or O
drug-induced O
or O
alcohol-induced O
psychoses O
were O
not O
included O
. O

Medical O
and O
neurological O
illnesses O
were O
ruled O
out O
by O
physical O
and O
neurological O
examinations O
, O
routine O
laboratory O
investigations O
, O
reports O
from O
the O
patients O
’ O
family O
physicians O
and O
the O
hospital O
medical O
records O
. O

Severity O
of O
schizophrenia O
symptoms O
were O
assessed O
with O
the O
Positive O
and O
Negative O
Syndrome O
Scale O
( O
PANSS O
) O
( O
Table O
S1 O
) O
. O

Twenty-three O
healthy O
individuals O
without O
any O
known O
psychiatric O
or O
neurologic O
disorder O
( O
12 O
women O
; O
mean O
age O
26 O
, O
22–39 O
years O
) O
were O
recruited O
through O
public O
advertisement O
( O
Table O
S1 O
) O
. O

Patients O
and O
healthy O
controls O
were O
matched O
for O
age O
and O
gender O
. O

All O
participants O
were O
native O
Hebrew O
speakers O
with O
adequate O
language O
comprehension O
. O

After O
drop-out O
, O
due O
to O
motion O
artifacts O
( O
see O
below O
) O
, O
our O
final O
sample O
included O
27 O
patients O
( O
10 O
women O
; O
mean O
age O
25 O
, O
range O
: O
18–40 O
years O
) O
and O
22 O
healthy O
controls O
( O
11 O
female O
, O
mean O
age O
: O
26 O
, O
range O
: O
22–39 O
) O
. O

There O
is O
no O
standard O
way O
to O
perform O
power O
analyses O
for O
non-parametric O
analyses O
, O
such O
as O
those O
that O
are O
employed O
in O
this O
work O
. O

The O
estimated O
power O
of O
a O
corresponding O
parametric O
t-test O
with O
the O
same O
number O
of O
participants O
as O
in O
the O
selected O
sample O
is O
0.77 O
for O
ToM O
NCI O
, O
and O
0.99 O
for O
ES O
NCI O
. O

These O
values O
were O
estimated O
based O
on O
data O
from O
the O
time O
window O
of O
the O
highest O
mean O
difference O
between O
these O
the O
group O
NCIs O
( O
following O
ref O
. O

) O
. O

The O
study O
was O
approved O
by O
the O
Institutional O
Review O
Boards O
in O
each O
of O
the O
mental O
health O
centers O
. O

All O
participants O
gave O
written O
informed O
consent O
after O
receiving O
a O
full O
explanation O
of O
the O
study O
protocol O
. O

Task O
The O
cinematic O
stimulus O
was O
selected O
due O
to O
its O
high O
ecological O
validity O
and O
the O
efficiency O
of O
movies O
as O
inducers O
of O
emotion O
. O

Participants O
passively O
watched O
a O
clip O
from O
the O
movie O
“ O
The O
Ring O
2 O
” O
( O
8:15 O
min O
) O
with O
Hebrew O
subtitles O
while O
in O
the O
scanner O
. O

The O
clip O
included O
two O
dramatic O
emotional O
peaks O
: O
a O
mother O
looking O
for O
her O
son O
while O
experiencing O
a O
frightful O
delirium O
in O
the O
amusement O
park O
restroom O
( O
~2 O
min O
) O
, O
and O
a O
deer O
attacking O
the O
mother O
and O
son O
( O
2 O
min O
) O
. O

Participants O
passively O
viewed O
a O
blank O
screen O
for O
1 O
min O
before O
and O
after O
the O
film O
was O
presented O
. O

Continuous O
fear O
rating O
Due O
to O
technical O
issues O
valid O
post-scanning O
continuous O
fear O
rating O
were O
obtained O
from O
24 O
schizophrenia O
patients O
( O
9 O
females O
, O
mean O
age O
: O
27.2 O
, O
range O
: O
19–40 O
) O
and O
only O
10 O
of O
the O
healthy O
controls O
( O
1 O
female O
, O
mean O
age O
: O
26 O
, O
range O
: O
22–39 O
) O
. O

To O
improve O
the O
estimation O
of O
the O
rating O
pattern O
of O
the O
healthy O
population O
, O
we O
included O
data O
from O
77 O
additional O
healthy O
volunteers O
. O

Thus O
, O
in O
total O
, O
the O
group O
included O
87 O
healthy O
controls O
( O
33 O
females O
, O
mean O
age O
: O
25.6 O
, O
range O
: O
20–40 O
) O
. O

It O
should O
be O
noted O
that O
the O
median O
ratings O
of O
the O
smaller O
and O
later O
expanded O
healthy O
control O
groups O
were O
highly O
correlated O
( O
Spearman O
R O
= O
0.98 O
, O
p O
< O
5 O
× O
10−102 O
) O
. O

In O
the O
post-scan O
session O
, O
the O
participants O
watched O
the O
movie O
clip O
for O
a O
second O
time O
while O
continuously O
and O
retrospectively O
rating O
the O
fear O
intensity O
they O
recalled O
feeling O
during O
the O
first O
viewing O
in O
the O
scanner O
. O

The O
rating O
was O
performed O
retrospectively O
to O
avoid O
the O
confounding O
effect O
of O
rating O
while O
being O
in O
the O
scanner O
for O
the O
first O
time O
. O

Fear O
was O
the O
targeted O
emotion O
because O
it O
can O
be O
considered O
an O
“ O
empathic O
emotion O
” O
inducer O
, O
since O
a O
threat O
is O
being O
posed O
to O
a O
cinematic O
character O
rather O
than O
to O
the O
subject O
themselves O
. O

The O
rating O
was O
sampled O
at O
10 O
Hz O
using O
in-house O
software O
. O

The O
participants O
used O
a O
vertical O
scale O
indicating O
7 O
levels O
of O
fear—from O
neutral O
to O
very O
deep O
( O
each O
containing O
3° O
of O
shift O
; O
21° O
in O
total O
) O
. O

fMRI O
data O
acquisition O
and O
preprocessing O
fMRI O
scanning O
was O
performed O
using O
a O
GE O
3 O
T O
Signa O
Excite O
echo O
speed O
scanner O
with O
an O
eight-channel O
head O
coil O
located O
at O
the O
Tel-Aviv O
Sourasky O
Medical O
Center O
. O

Structural O
scans O
included O
a O
T1-weighted O
3D O
axial O
spoiled O
gradient O
echo O
( O
SPGR O
) O
pulse O
sequence O
( O
TR/TE O
= O
8.94/3.48 O
ms O
, O
slice O
thickness O
= O
1 O
mm O
, O
flip O
angle O
= O
13° O
, O
pixel O
size O
= O
1 O
mm O
, O
FOV O
= O
256 O
× O
256 O
mm O
) O
. O

Functional O
whole-brain O
scans O
were O
performed O
in O
interleaved O
order O
with O
a O
T2 O
* O
-weighted O
gradient O
echo O
planar O
imaging O
pulse O
sequence O
( O
time O
repetition O
[ O
TR O
] O
/TE O
= O
3000/35 O
ms O
, O
flip O
angle O
= O
90° O
, O
pixel O
size O
= O
1.56 O
mm O
, O
FOV O
= O
200 O
× O
200 O
mm O
, O
slice O
thickness O
= O
3 O
mm O
, O
39 O
slices O
per O
volume O
) O
. O

Active O
noise O
canceling O
headphones O
( O
Optoacoustics O
) O
were O
used O
. O

Brain O
Voyager O
QX O
2.4 O
was O
used O
for O
preprocessing O
and O
co-registration O
of O
the O
standardized O
anatomical O
and O
functional O
data O
. O

Head O
motions O
were O
detected O
and O
corrected O
using O
trilinear O
and O
sinc O
interpolations O
respectively O
, O
applying O
rigid O
body O
transformations O
with O
three O
translation O
and O
three O
rotation O
parameters O
. O

The O
data O
were O
high-pass O
filtered O
at O
0.008 O
Hz O
and O
spatial O
smoothed O
with O
a O
6 O
mm O
FWHM O
kernel O
. O

To O
avoid O
the O
confounding O
effects O
of O
fluctuations O
in O
the O
whole-brain O
BOLD O
signal O
, O
for O
each O
TR O
, O
each O
voxel O
was O
scaled O
by O
the O
global O
mean O
at O
that O
time O
point O
. O

Due O
to O
head O
movements O
( O
deviations O
higher O
than O
1.5°/1.5 O
mm O
relative O
to O
the O
reference O
) O
three O
patients O
and O
one O
healthy O
control O
were O
excluded O
from O
the O
study O
. O

Finally O
, O
we O
trimmed O
the O
functional O
data O
to O
improve O
the O
specificity O
of O
our O
analysis O
. O

The O
onset O
of O
the O
cinematic O
stimulus O
after O
a O
minute O
of O
rest O
may O
evoke O
emotional O
response O
regardless O
of O
the O
content O
of O
the O
film O
. O

Since O
we O
were O
not O
interested O
in O
this O
psychological O
effect O
, O
we O
removed O
a O
segment O
of O
five O
TRs O
from O
the O
functional O
data O
that O
were O
collected O
during O
the O
film O
viewing O
. O

The O
size O
of O
this O
segment O
was O
set O
to O
five O
TRs O
to O
discard O
the O
hemodynamic O
response O
to O
the O
film O
onset O
, O
as O
this O
response O
typically O
lasts O
12–16 O
s. O
A O
segment O
including O
the O
five O
first O
time O
points O
was O
removed O
from O
the O
rating O
as O
well O
so O
that O
these O
signals O
could O
be O
comparable O
. O

Defining O
networks O
of O
interest O
The O
anatomical O
definition O
of O
social O
cognition-related O
networks O
relied O
on O
two O
relevant O
meta-analyses O
of O
ES O
and O
ToM O
neuroimaging O
studies O
( O
Fig O
. O

1a O
, O
Table O
S2 O
) O
. O

Both O
networks O
were O
used O
in O
a O
previous O
analysis O
of O
network O
cohesion O
applied O
to O
data O
collected O
