during O
the O
viewing O
of O
two O
additional O
cinematic O
contents O
used O
in O
our O
lab O
. O

The O
statistical O
maps O
were O
kindly O
provided O
by O
the O
authors O
of O
refs O
. O

and O
, O
respectively O
. O

The O
defined O
ES O
network O
was O
based O
on O
a O
meta-analysis O
of O
studies O
on O
vicarious O
pain O
experiences O
and O
included O
regions O
that O
were O
activated O
both O
during O
first-hand O
experiences O
of O
pain O
and O
while O
observing O
the O
pain O
of O
another O
. O

The O
defined O
ToM O
network O
was O
based O
on O
a O
meta-analysis O
of O
studies O
that O
involved O
taking O
the O
cognitive O
perspective O
of O
another O
’ O
s O
mental O
state O
. O

Seven O
regions O
were O
selected O
from O
the O
meta-analytical O
statistical O
map O
, O
and O
based O
on O
further O
evidence O
from O
another O
study O
as O
being O
the O
only O
regions O
reliability O
activated O
across O
various O
ToM O
tasks O
. O

NCI O
analysis O
All O
NCI O
analyses O
were O
performed O
using O
a O
designated O
Matlab O
code O
, O
which O
will O
be O
made O
available O
upon O
request O
. O

In O
short O
, O
NCI O
analysis O
( O
Fig O
. O

1b O
) O
is O
a O
sliding-window O
method O
to O
estimate O
the O
functional O
connectivity O
dynamics O
between O
and O
within O
networks O
during O
continuous O
paradigms O
. O

NCI O
is O
a O
t-statistic O
based O
on O
the O
pairwise O
correlations O
of O
network O
nodes O
. O

It O
is O
sensitive O
to O
both O
the O
magnitude O
and O
variance O
of O
connectivity O
within O
the O
network O
, O
thus O
depicting O
cohesion O
between O
nodes O
. O

In O
previous O
works O
, O
NCI O
of O
specific O
networks O
of O
interest O
were O
found O
to O
covary O
with O
empathy O
and O
emotion O
reactivity O
indices O
, O
pointing O
to O
their O
capacity O
to O
affect O
network O
dynamics O
. O

To O
compute O
NCI O
, O
we O
first O
extracted O
the O
signal O
for O
each O
of O
the O
network O
nodes O
. O

The O
node O
’ O
s O
signal O
was O
defined O
as O
the O
average O
signal O
of O
the O
voxel O
clusters O
reported O
by O
the O
relevant O
meta-analysis O
. O

For O
each O
network O
, O
time-window O
, O
and O
participant O
, O
the O
set O
of O
all O
pairwise O
Pearson O
correlations O
within O
the O
network O
was O
computed O
. O

The O
time-windows O
spanned O
over O
30 O
s O
( O
10 O
TRs O
) O
according O
to O
previous O
evidence O
for O
the O
validity O
of O
using O
windows O
of O
this O
length O
. O

We O
examined O
successive O
time O
windows O
with O
90 O
% O
overlap O
. O

NCI O
was O
computed O
as O
the O
t-statistic O
of O
a O
Student O
’ O
s O
t-test O
with O
a O
null O
hypothesis O
of O
µR O
= O
0 O
, O
performed O
on O
the O
Fisher O
z O
transformed O
coefficients O
for O
each O
participant O
, O
network O
, O
and O
time-window O
. O

In O
this O
test O
, O
the O
t-statistic O
serves O
as O
a O
probe O
for O
the O
connectivity O
within O
the O
network O
, O
with O
elevated O
values O
when O
the O
mean O
correlation O
is O
high O
and O
variance O
is O
low O
. O

Correlation O
of O
NCI O
with O
fear O
rating O
group O
difference O
We O
next O
investigated O
whether O
the O
difference O
between O
the O
fear O
ratings O
of O
schizophrenia O
patients O
and O
healthy O
controls O
were O
related O
to O
the O
corresponding O
inter-group O
difference O
in O
the O
connectivity O
of O
the O
ES O
and O
ToM O
networks O
. O

To O
examine O
the O
temporal O
relations O
between O
these O
parameters O
, O
we O
computed O
cross-correlations O
between O
NCI O
and O
the O
difference O
in O
rating O
indices O
, O
while O
displacing O
one O
time O
series O
relative O
to O
the O
other O
. O

To O
fit O
the O
rating O
index O
with O
the O
sliding-window O
format O
used O
for O
NCI O
analysis O
, O
the O
data O
was O
first O
down-sampled O
to O
30 O
s O
windows O
. O

In O
each O
time-window O
we O
performed O
a O
non-parametric O
Wilcoxon O
test O
to O
compare O
the O
median O
rating O
of O
the O
schizophrenia O
and O
healthy O
control O
groups O
. O

A O
corresponding O
index O
for O
the O
inter-group O
NCI O
difference O
was O
similarly O
computed O
via O
a O
Wilcoxon O
test O
for O
the O
ES O
and O
ToM O
networks O
. O

The O
resulting O
Z-statistic O
time O
series O
were O
cross-correlated O
, O
as O
the O
NCI O
time-series O
were O
displaced O
relative O
to O
the O
rating O
difference O
series O
in O
a O
range O
of O
±one O
time O
window O
with O
a O
single O
time O
point O
( O
one O
TR O
) O
lag O
( O
i.e. O
, O
the O
NCI O
signal O
was O
shifted O
in O
up O
to O
±10 O
TRs O
relative O
to O
the O
rating O
; O
see O
Fig O
. O

S1 O
) O
. O

This O
procedure O
yielded O
21 O
NCI O
time O
courses O
( O
the O
non-shifted O
time O
series O
+ O
10 O
backward O
and O
forward O
shifted O
time O
courses O
) O
with O
131 O
time-points O
each O
according O
to O
the O
following O
calculation O
( O
see O
Fig O
. O

S1 O
for O
visualization O
) O
: O
The O
duration O
of O
the O
movie O
clip O
was O
165 O
TRs O
. O

As O
mentioned O
above O
, O
five O
TRs O
were O
discarded O
from O
the O
data O
to O
avoid O
the O
film O
onset O
effect O
. O

For O
the O
time O
series O
of O
160 O
TRs O
that O
were O
left O
after O
this O
trimming O
, O
we O
calculated O
151 O
sliding O
NCI/rating O
time O
windows O
( O
10 O
TRs O
each O
) O
. O

From O
this O
NCI O
time O
series O
of O
151 O
TRs O
we O
then O
derived O
time O
series O
shifted O
in O
up O
to O
±10 O
TRs O
. O

These O
shifted O
time O
series O
were O
generated O
in O
an O
identical O
size O
to O
allow O
proper O
comparison O
. O

Under O
these O
constrains O
, O
the O
maximal O
size O
of O
the O
shifted O
time O
series O
was O
131 O
TRs O
. O

Spearman O
’ O
s O
correlation O
coefficients O
were O
computed O
for O
each O
of O
the O
lagged O
data O
sets O
; O
for O
21 O
inter-group O
NCI O
and O
rating O
duplets O
with O
131 O
time-points O
each O
. O

We O
determined O
the O
significance O
of O
the O
correlations O
by O
applying O
a O
bootstrapping O
procedure O
that O
included O
phase O
randomization O
for O
each O
Fourier O
component O
of O
the O
individual O
NCI O
time O
series O
and O
then O
the O
inverse O
Fourier O
transformation O
. O

To O
control O
for O
21 O
comparisons O
for O
each O
of O
the O
two O
main O
hypotheses O
( O
ToM-NCI O
rating O
and O
ES-NCI O
rating O
associations O
) O
, O
we O
applied O
false O
discovery O
rate O
( O
FDR O
) O
for O
independent O
or O
positively O
dependent O
tests O
. O

Comparing O
NCI O
between O
groups O
We O
further O
examined O
whether O
significant O
NCI O
differences O
between O
schizophrenia O
patients O
and O
healthy O
controls O
can O
be O
found O
at O
specific O
time-windows O
during O
the O
movie O
. O

To O
compare O
network O
connectivity O
between O
the O
groups O
, O
a O
two-sided O
Wilcoxon O
test O
was O
performed O
on O
the O
two O
distributions O
of O
individual O
NCI O
values O
for O
each O
of O
the O
networks O
. O

This O
test O
was O
repeated O
for O
each O
of O
the O
time-windows O
. O

To O
control O
for O
multiple O
comparisons O
, O
FDR O
correction O
was O
applied O
considering O
the O
total O
number O
of O
comparisons O
for O
each O
network O
( O
131 O
comparisons O
) O
. O

We O
further O
examined O
whether O
differences O
between O
the O
groups O
are O
specifically O
related O
to O
the O
network O
connectivity O
or O
could O
also O
be O
found O
when O
comparing O
the O
time O
series O
of O
the O
BOLD O
amplitudes O
of O
these O
networks O
. O

Thus O
, O
we O
averaged O
the O
Z-scored O
signals O
obtained O
for O
all O
of O
the O
network O
nodes O
, O
averaged O
the O
signals O
again O
using O
a O
sliding O
windows O
of O
10 O
TRs O
and O
compared O
the O
resulting O
time O
series O
between O
the O
groups O
using O
a O
two-sided O
Wilcoxon O
test O
. O

Correlating O
NCIs O
with O
schizophrenia O
symptoms O
We O
next O
examined O
the O
co-variation O
between O
the O
network O
connectivity O
indices O
and O
the O
severity O
of O
schizophrenia O
symptoms O
. O

We O
computed O
a O
Spearman O
correlation O
between O
the O
empathy-related O
NCIs O
and O
the O
positive O
, O
negative O
, O
and O
general O
Positive O
and O
Negative O
Syndrome O
Scale O
( O
PANSS O
) O
scores O
for O
each O
time-window O
throughout O
the O
movie O
. O

FDR O
correction O
was O
applied O
to O
control O
for O
the O
total O
number O
of O
comparisons O
( O
131 O
comparisons O
) O
for O
each O
of O
the O
six O
main O
hypotheses O
( O
association O
between O
ES/ToM O
NCI O
and O
the O
positive O
, O
negative O
or O
general O
symptoms O
) O
. O

Classification O
based O
on O
ToM O
and O
ES O
NCI O
In O
order O
to O
classify O
participants O
into O
their O
respective O
groups O
( O
Schizophrenia O
patients O
and O
healthy O
controls O
) O
we O
applied O
the O
k-nearest O
neighbor O
( O
KNN O
) O
classifier O
, O
which O
is O
a O
widely O
used O
machine O
learning O
classification O
algorithm O
based O
on O
the O
closest O
training O
examples O
in O
the O
feature O
space O
. O

We O
used O
k O
= O
10 O
, O
and O
classification O
was O
carried O
out O
in O
the O
Matlab O
Classification O
Learner O
application O
( O
The O
MathWorks O
Inc. O
, O
Natick O
, O
MA O
, O
USA O
) O
. O

The O
NCI O
values O
per O
time O
point O
per O
network O
( O
simulation O
and O
ToM O
) O
were O
used O
as O
predictors O
( O
total O
of O
302 O
features O
) O
. O

We O
then O
assessed O
generalization O
through O
five-fold O
cross-validation O
. O

The O
overall O
accuracy O
, O
sensitivity O
, O
specificity O
, O
and O
positive O
predictive O
value O
( O
PPV O
) O
was O
computed O
for O
each O
classifier O
; O
overall O
accuracy O
was O
the O
number O
of O
true O
classifications O
to O
total O
cohort O
; O
sensitivity O
was O
the O
number O
of O
true O
positives O
( O
i.e O
. O

patients O
correctly O
classified O
) O
for O
the O
total O
number O
of O
patients O
; O
specificity O
was O
the O
number O
of O
true O
negatives O
( O
i.e O
. O

healthy O
controls O
correctly O
classified O
) O
for O
the O
total O
number O
of O
healthy O
controls O
; O
positive O
predictive O
value O
( O
PPV O
) O
was O
the O
ratio O
of O
the O
true O
positives O
for O
all O
positive O
classifications O
( O
i.e O
. O

true O
and O
false O
positives O
) O
. O

Statistics O
were O
derived O
from O
the O
mean O
and O
standard O
deviation O
of O
all O
1000 O
classifiers O
. O

For O
additional O
statistical O
significance O
assessment O
of O
the O
classification O
accuracy O
we O
conducted O
a O
bootstrapping O
procedure O
of O
permutation O
tests O
. O

The O
class O
labels O
of O
the O
original O
dataset O
were O
randomly O
permuted O
and O
then O
classified O
using O
the O
identical O
aforementioned O
KNN O
analysis O
procedure O
( O
using O
five-fold O
cross-validation O
and O
1000 O
repetitions O
) O
. O

This O
procedure O
was O
again O
repeated O
1000 O
times O
. O

The O
p-value O
of O
the O
permutation O
test O
was O
defined O
as O
the O
fraction O
of O
the O
number O
of O
permuted O
classifiers O
that O
obtained O
better O
classification O
accuracy O
than O
the O
original O
dataset O
, O
given O
aswhere O
k O
is O
the O
number O
of O
permutation O
tests O
( O
k O
= O
1000 O
) O
. O

Prospective O
Changes O
in O
Neural O
Alcohol O
Cue O
Reactivity O
in O
At-Risk O
Adolescents O
Introduction O
Adolescence O
represents O
an O
ideal O
time O
for O
elucidating O
the O
etiology O
of O
cue O
reactivity O
profiles O
. O

This O
study O
examined O
the O
influence O
of O
three O
risk O
factors O
consistently O
associated O
with O
heavy O
adolescent O
drinking O
on O
alcohol O
cue O
reactivity O
. O

Methods O
Youth O
were O
first O
assessed O
while O
still O
naïve O
to O
alcohol O
( O
12–14 O
years O
old O
) O
and O
followed O
after O
transitioning O
into O
alcohol O
use O
( O
17–21 O
years O
old O
) O
. O

The O
effects O
of O
family O
history O
of O
substance O
use O
disorder O
, O
sex O
, O
and O
history O
of O
early O
of O
dating O
( O
i.e. O
, O
before O
14 O
years O
of O
age O
) O
on O
BOLD O
response O
contrast O
to O
alcohol O
picture O
cues O
were O
examined O
in O
a O
linear O
mixed O
model O
, O
controlling O
for O
age O
and O
alcohol O
use O
patterns O
at O
follow-up O
. O

Result O
Activation O
to O
alcohol O
picture O
cues O
differed O
as O
a O
function O
of O
risk O
factor O
and O
time O
. O

At O
baseline O
, O
family O
history O
positive O
youth O
showed O
greater O
activation O
to O
alcohol O
cues O
than O
family O
history O
negative O
peers O
in O
the O
right O
middle O
occipital O
and O
anterior O
cingulate O
gyri O
. O

Youth O
with O
a O
history O
of O
early-dating O
showed O
greater O
activation O
to O
alcohol O
cues O
, O
compared O
to O
non-early O
daters O
, O
in O
the O
left O
anterior O
cingulate/white O
matter O
region O
. O

Girls O
showed O
greater O
activation O
to O
alcohol O
than O
boys O
at O
baseline O
in O
left O
middle O
frontal O
gyrus O
. O

At O
follow-up O
, O
after O
drinking O
started O
, O
patterns O
reversed O
for O
each O
risk O
factor O
. O

Discussion O
These O
results O
indicate O
that O
even O
prior O
to O
initiating O
alcohol O
use O
, O
adolescents O
showed O
differences O
in O
activation O
to O
alcohol O
cues O
based O
on O
their O
family O
history O
, O
dating O
history O
, O
and O
sex O
. O

Methods O
Participants O
This O
study O
used O
data O
from O
a O
larger O
ongoing O
longitudinal O
substance O
use O
and O
neuroimaging O
project O
( O
R01 O
AA13419 O
) O
, O
a O
protocol O
that O
was O
approved O
by O
the O
University O
of O
California O
San O
Diego O
Human O
Research O
Protections O
Program O
. O

Participants O
between O
12 O
to O
14 O
years O
old O
were O
recruited O
from O
San O
Diego O
public O
middle O
schools O
. O

Eligible O
youth O
( O
N O
= O
295 O
) O
were O
administered O
a O
comprehensive O
interview O
assessing O
substance O
use O
and O
demographic O
information O
( O
e.g. O
, O
age O
, O
ethnicity O
) O
and O
completed O
an O
MRI O
scan O
at O
baseline O
( O
project O
entry O
) O
. O

In O
the O
parent O
study O
, O
potential O
participants O
were O
excluded O
for O
psychiatric O
diagnoses O
, O
neurodevelopmental O
disorders O
, O
and O
use O
that O
exceeded O
minimal O
exposure O
to O
alcohol O
and O
other O
substances O
. O

Participants O
were O
followed-up O
each O
year O
by O
phone O
to O
obtain O
data O
about O
alcohol O
consumption O
and O
other O
drug O
use O
habits O
and O
psychosocial O
changes O
( O
e.g. O
, O
grade O
in O
school O
) O
. O

Individuals O
who O
transitioned O
into O
drinking O
were O
brought O
back O
into O
the O
laboratory O
for O
a O
repeat O
MRI O
scan O
at O
follow-up O
. O

Not O
all O
participants O
in O
the O
parent O
study O
received O
the O
Alcohol O
Pictures O
Cue O
Reactivity O
task O
, O
as O
it O
was O
added O
later O
during O
the O
project O
. O

The O
sample O
for O
the O
current O
study O
included O
only O
those O
participants O
in O
the O
parent O
study O
who O
were O
administered O
this O
task O
at O
baseline O
and O
follow-up O
. O

To O
account O
for O
possible O
effects O
of O
prior O
alcohol O
and O
other O
substance O
use O
on O
cue O
reactivity O
at O
baseline O
, O
participants O
in O
the O
parent O
study O
who O
reported O
having O
any O
experience O
with O
alcohol O
greater O
than O
several O
sips O
and O
any O
history O
of O
other O
substance O
use O
at O
project O
intake O
were O
excluded O
from O
analysis O
. O

Likewise O
, O
to O
examine O
the O
effects O
of O
initiation O
of O
alcohol O
use O
on O
alcohol O
cue O
reactivity O
, O
participants O
who O
had O
not O
initiated O
alcohol O
use O
at O
follow-up O
( O
i.e. O
, O
have O
not O
had O
at O
least O
one O
standard O
drink O
) O
were O
also O
excluded O
from O
analysis O
. O

In O
total O
, O
51 O
participants O
met O
criteria O
for O
inclusions O
in O
the O
current O
set O
of O
analyses O
. O

Measures O
Structured O
clinical O
interview O
The O
Structured O
Clinical O
Interview O
was O
administered O
to O
youth O
at O
baseline O
and O
follow-up O
to O
assess O
general O
psychosocial O
functioning O
such O
as O
academic O
functioning O
( O
e.g. O
, O
grade O
point O
average O
) O
and O
peer O
relations O
and O
attitudes O
towards O
substance O
use O
, O
and O
major O
medical O
illnesses O
. O

Dating O
status O
was O
defined O
dichotomously O
with O
the O
question O
“ O
Do O
you O
date O
” O
at O
baseline O
. O

Answer O
choices O
were O
“ O
no O
, O
never O
dated O
” O
, O
“ O
no O
, O
not O
now O
” O
, O
“ O
yes O
, O
only O
in O
group O
activities O
” O
, O
“ O
yes O
, O
rarely O
” O
, O
“ O
yes O
, O
occasionally O
” O
, O
“ O
yes O
, O
regularly O
” O
, O
“ O
yes O
, O
steady O
partner O
” O
, O
or O
“ O
I O
am O
married. O
” O
At O
baseline O
, O
youth O
were O
coded O
as O
either O
1 O
) O
non-early O
daters O
( O
i.e. O
, O
no O
history O
of O
dating O
) O
if O
they O
answered O
“ O
no O
, O
never O
dated O
” O
, O
or O
2 O
) O
early O
daters O
( O
i.e. O
, O
have O
a O
history O
of O
any O
, O
or O
are O
currently O
, O
dating O
) O
if O
answered O
otherwise O
. O

All O
but O
one O
participant O
reported O
having O
dated O
at O
least O
once O
at O
follow-up O
. O

Substance O
use O
The O
Customary O
Drinking O
and O
Drug O
Use O
Record O
was O
administered O
at O
baseline O
and O
follow-up O
years O
to O
assess O
onset O
, O
frequency O
, O
quantity O
, O
and O
sequelae O
of O
alcohol O
and O
other O
substance O
use O
. O

Participants O
were O
asked O
to O
abstain O
from O
alcohol O
and O
recreational O
drug O
use O
for O
72 O
hours O
prior O
to O
scan O
sessions O
. O

Breathalyzer O
and O
urine O
toxicology O
screens O
were O
administered O
in O
the O
laboratory O
to O
confirm O
recent O
abstinence O
. O

Family O
history O
The O
Family O
History O
Assessment O
Module O
was O
administered O
to O
youth O
and O
both O
parents O
, O
or O
one O
parent O
and O
another O
family O
member O
, O
to O
assess O
familial O
density O
of O
alcohol O
and O
other O
substance O
use O
disorders O
( O
SUD O
) O
. O

Family O
history O
negative O
( O
FHN O
) O
was O
defined O
as O
having O
no O
first- O
or O
second-degree O
relative O
with O
history O
of O
SUD O
, O
family O
history O
positive O
( O
FHP O
) O
as O
having O
one O
or O
more O
first- O
or O
second-degree O
relative O
with O
history O
of O
SUD O
. O

Socioeconomic O
status O
The O
Hollingshead O
Index O
of O
Social O
Position O
score O
( O
Hollingshead O
1965 O
) O
, O
an O
index O
of O
socioeconomic O
status O
( O
SES O
) O
, O
was O
calculated O
for O
each O
subject O
using O
parental O
socioeconomic O
background O
information O
( O
i.e. O
, O
educational O
attainment O
, O
occupation O
, O
and O
salary O
of O
each O
parent O
) O
to O
characterize O
the O
youth O
’ O
s O
home O
environment O
. O

Higher O
values O
indicate O
lower O
SES O
. O

Imaging O
Imaging O
data O
were O
collected O
using O
a O
3.0 O
Tesla O
General O
Electric O
( O
3T O
GE O
) O
short O
bore O
Excite-2 O
system O
with O
an O
eight-channel O
phase-array O
head O
coil O
. O

Eight O
high-bandwidth O
receivers O
for O
ultra-short O
repetition O
time O
( O
TR O
) O
reduced O
signal O
distortions O
and O
dropout O
. O

High-resolution O
T1- O
weighted O
sequence O
using O
a O
sagittally O
acquired O
spoiled O
gradient O
recalled O
sequence O
( O
field O
of O
view O
[ O
FOV O
] O
24cm O
, O
256 O
× O
256 O
× O
192 O
matrix O
, O
.94 O
× O
.94 O
× O
1mm O
voxels O
, O
176 O
slices O
, O
repetition O
time=20ms O
, O
echo O
time=4.8ms O
; O
flip O
angle O
12° O
, O
7:26 O
minutes O
) O
. O

Field O
maps O
were O
acquired O
to O
assess O
field O
inhomogeneities O
and O
signal O
dropout O
with O
two O
different O
echo O
times O
, O
which O
was O
then O
applied O
to O
the O
BOLD O
signal O
to O
minimize O
warping O
and O
signal O
dropouts O
. O

BOLD O
signal O
was O
measured O
with O
T2 O
* O
-weighted O
axially O
acquired O
echo-planar O
images O
( O
FOV=24cm O
, O
64 O
× O
64 O
matrix O
, O
3.75 O
× O
3.75 O
× O
3.8mm O
voxels O
, O
32 O
slices O
, O
echo O
time=30ms O
, O
repetition O
time=2,000ms O
, O
flip O
angle O
90° O
, O
task O
time O
: O
8:32 O
) O
. O

Task O
stimuli O
were O
back-projected O
from O
a O
laptop O
to O
a O
screen O
at O
the O
foot O
of O
the O
scanner O
using O
an O
angled O
mirror O
attached O
to O
the O
head O
coil O
. O

Task O
accuracy O
and O
reaction O
times O
were O
logged O
with O
a O
MRI O
compatible O
fiber-optic O
response O
box O
( O
Current O
Designs O
, O
Pittsburgh O
, O
PA O
) O
. O

Task O
The O
Alcohol O
Cue O
Reactivity O
Task O
consisted O
of O
four O
conditions O
: O
alcoholic O
beverages O
, O
non-alcoholic O
beverage O
( O
i.e. O
, O
neutral O
cues O
) O
, O
active O
control O
conditions O
( O
i.e. O
, O
pixilated O
versions O
of O
the O
beverage O
images O
) O
, O
and O
fixation O
( O
rest O
) O
periods O
. O

Each O
of O
the O
4 O
conditions O
consisted O
of O
22 O
stimuli O
each O
presented O
four O
times O
on O
a O
laptop O
using O
E-Prime O
( O
Pittsburgh O
, O
PA O
) O
. O

Stimuli O
in O
this O
event-related O
task O
were O
presented O
sequentially O
in O
pseudo-randomized O
order O
, O
each O
for O
750 O
ms O
with O
a O
1250 O
ms O
inter-stimulus O
interval O
, O
resulting O
in O
a O
task O
duration O
of O
8 O
minutes O
and O
32 O
seconds O
( O
Figure O
1 O
) O
. O

Alcohol O
and O
non-alcohol O
beverage O
stimuli O
were O
previously O
standardized O
with O
a O
non-drinking O
youth O
sample O
to O
ascertain O
adequate O
identification O
, O
and O
comparable O
valence O
, O
arousal O
, O
and O
visual O
characteristics O
between O
the O
two O
conditions O
. O

Standardized O
instructions O
and O
a O
practice O
version O
of O
the O
task O
were O
administrated O
outside O
the O
scanner O
. O

In O
the O
scanner O
, O
participants O
were O
instructed O
to O
indicate O
the O
valence O
( O
i.e. O
, O
dislike O
, O
neutral O
, O
like O
) O
of O
each O
stimulus O
with O
their O
fingers O
using O
a O
button O
box O
. O

Participants O
’ O
responses O
and O
reaction O
times O
were O
logged O
while O
completing O
the O
task O
inside O
the O
scanner O
. O

BOLD O
response O
signal O
change O
during O
viewing O
of O
the O
alcohol O
picture O
cues O
minus O
neutral O
picture O
cues O
served O
as O
the O
outcome O
measure O
of O
interest O
. O

A O
positive O
BOLD O
response O
contrast O
was O
interpreted O
as O
greater O
activation O
to O
alcoholic O
beverage O
cues O
vs. O
neutral O
cues O
; O
a O
negative O
BOLD O
response O
contrast O
was O
interpreted O
as O
greater O
activation O
to O
neutral O
cues O
vs. O
alcoholic O
beverage O
cues O
. O

Image O
Processing O
Imaging O
data O
was O
analyzed O
using O
the O
Analysis O
of O
Functional O
NeuroImages O
( O
AFNI O
) O
software O
. O

Artifacts O
and O
abnormal O
signals O
were O
removed O
and O
time O
series O
data O
were O
temporally O
aligned O
and O
co-registered O
to O
a O
maximally O
stable O
base O
volume O
with O
an O
iterated O
least O
squares O
algorithm O
. O

Each O
individual O
’ O
s O
functional O
and O
anatomical O
data O
sets O
were O
co-registered O
and O
warped O
to O
standardized O
Talairach O
space O
to O
reduce O
effects O
of O
anatomical O
variability O
. O

Functional O
data O
were O
resampled O
into O
isotropic O
voxels O
( O
3 O
mm3 O
) O
, O
and O
spatial O
smoothing O
was O
applied O
using O
a O
Gaussian O
filter O
( O
full-width O
half O
maximum O
5 O
mm O
) O
. O

Motion O
( O
i.e. O
, O
three O
rotational O
and O
three O
linear O
displacement O
parameters O
) O
was O
estimated O
for O
each O
participant O
and O
used O
to O
control O
for O
task-related O
analyses O
. O

An O
automated O
program O
detected O
outliers O
in O
the O
six O
motion O
parameters O
; O
time-series O
data O
with O
significant O
outliers O
were O
despiked O
or O
censored O
( O
i.e. O
, O
removed O
from O
further O
processing O
) O
. O

No O
participant O
had O
15 O
% O
or O
more O
of O
repetitions O
censored O
. O

Deconvolution O
was O
conducted O
on O
time-series O
data O
with O
a O
reference O
function O
that O
convolved O
the O
behavioral O
stimuli O
response O
time O
with O
an O
ideal O
hemodynamic O
response O
model O
, O
covarying O
for O
linear O
trends O
and O
motion O
correction O
parameters O
. O

Results O
of O
the O
general O
linear O
model O
included O
, O
for O
each O
voxel O
, O
1 O
) O
a O
fit O
coefficient O
that O
represented O
change O
in O
signal O
between O
alcohol O
beverage O
pictures O
minus O
active O
control O
, O
2 O
) O
percentage O
signal O
change O
( O
i.e. O
, O
contrast O
between O
alcohol O
and O
neutral O
picture O
cue O
trials O
) O
and O
3 O
) O
threshold O
statistics O
. O

Statistical O
Analysis O
fMRI O
BOLD O
To O
test O
the O
dual O
hypotheses O
that O
1 O
) O
no O
differences O
in O
BOLD O
activation O
to O
alcohol O
vs. O
neutral O
picture O
cues O
would O
be O
detected O
between O
risk O
groups O
at O
baseline O
and O
2 O
) O
high-risk O
participants O
would O
exhibit O
increased O
activation O
to O
alcohol O
vs. O
neutral O
picture O
cues O
after O
transitioning O
into O
alcohol O
use O
at O
follow-up O
, O
a O
single O
whole-brain O
group-level O
linear O
mixed O
effects O
model O
was O
conducted O
in O
AFNI O
( O
3dLME O
) O
. O

The O
model O
included O
two O
covariates O
( O
age O
and O
total O
number O
of O
drinks O
consumed O
in O
the O
past O
year O
) O
, O
one O
random O
factor O
( O
participants O
) O
, O
one O
fixed-effect O
within-subject O
predictor O
( O
time O
: O
baseline O
and O
follow-up O
) O
, O
three O
dichotomous O
fixed-effects O
between-subjects O
predictors O
( O
family O
history O
, O
sex O
, O
early-dating O
history O
) O
, O
and O
interactions O
among O
the O
four O
predictors O
. O

Mean O
activations O
from O
functional O
clusters O
that O
showed O
significant O
interaction O
effects O
were O
extract O
( O
3dROIstats O
) O
for O
each O
time O
point O
( O
i.e. O
, O
at O
baseline O
and O
follow-up O
) O
and O
group O
( O
e.g. O
, O
FHN O
and O
FHP O
) O
and O
graphed O
using O
Microsoft O
Excel O
. O

Graphs O
were O
visually O
inspected O
for O
qualitative O
description O
of O
signage O
( O
i.e. O
, O
positive O
or O
negative O
activation O
) O
directionality O
( O
e.g. O
, O
increased O
or O
decreased O
over O
time O
) O
. O

To O
control O
for O
multiple O
comparisons O
and O
Type O
I O
error O
, O
noise O
smoothness O
in O
the O
x O
, O
y O
, O
and O
z O
dimensions O
was O
first O
estimated O
( O
3dFWHMx O
) O
with O
a O
Gaussian O
and O
mono-spherical O
autocorrelation O
function O
( O
acf O
) O
. O

Parameters O
from O
this O
model O
were O
then O
entered O
into O
Monte O
Carlo O
simulations O
( O
3dClustSim O
) O
that O
accounted O
for O
the O
estimated O
smoothing O
to O
determine O
cluster O
size O
thresholds O
that O
met O
the O
following O
criteria O
: O
bi-sided O
thresholding O
, O
first-nearest O
neighbor O
clustering O
, O
uncorrected O
( O
per-voxel O
) O
p O
< O
.001 O
, O
and O
corrected O
( O
whole O
volume O
) O
α O
=.05 O
. O

Only O
regions O
with O
11 O
or O
more O
contiguous O
voxels O
were O
retained O
for O
interpretation O
. O

Alcohol O
Consumption O
Differences O
in O
past-year O
total O
drinking O
and O
binge-drinking O
days O
at O
follow-up O
by O
family O
history O
, O
sex O
, O
and O
early-dating O
history O
were O
tested O
in O
Wilcoxon-Mann-Whitney O
tests O
with O
the O
proc O
nparlway O
wilcoxon O
command O
in O
the O
SAS O
Studio O
software O
( O
SAS O
Institute O
Inc. O
, O
Cary O
, O
NC O
, O
USA O
; O
Version O
3.5 O
) O
. O

Wilcoxon-Mann-Whitney O
tests O
were O
conducted O
to O
reflect O
the O
non-normal O
distribution O
of O
the O
two O
indices O
of O
alcohol O
use O
of O
interest O
. O

Six O
models O
were O
tested O
in O
total O
; O
one O
for O
each O
group O
( O
i.e. O
, O
FHP O
vs. O
FHN O
; O
male O
vs. O
female O
; O
early-dating O
history O
vs. O
non-early O
dating O
history O
) O
and O
alcohol O
use O
index O
( O
i.e. O
, O
past-year O
total O
drinking O
days O
, O
past-year O
binge O
drinking O
days O
) O
. O

The O
relationship O
between O
recent O
( O
i.e. O
, O
past O
year O
) O
alcohol O
consumption O
at O
follow-up O
and O
alcohol-cue O
reactivity O
was O
examined O
in O
two O
linear O
regressions O
( O
3dMEMA O
) O
. O

To O
examine O
the O
effect O
of O
overall O
drinking O
quantity O
on O
alcohol O
cue O
reactivity O
, O
the O
first O
linear O
regression O
model O
used O
the O
total O
number O
of O
standard O
drinks O
consumed O
in O
the O
past O
year O
as O
the O
predictor O
( O
i.e. O
, O
independent O
) O
variable O
of O
interest O
. O

To O
examine O
the O
effect O
of O
risky O
drinking O
behavior O
on O
activation O
to O
alcohol O
picture O
cues O
, O
the O
number O
of O
binge O
drinking O
episodes O
in O
the O
past O
year O
( O
defined O
as O
4 O
or O
more O
drinks O
per O
drinking O
occasion O
for O
females O
and O
5 O
or O
more O
drinks O
per O
drinking O
occasion O
for O
males O
) O
served O
as O
the O
predictor O
of O
interest O
in O
the O
second O
linear O
regression O
model O
. O

In O
both O
regression O
models O
, O
whole-brain O
BOLD O
fMRI O
response O
to O
alcohol O
vs. O
neutral O
picture O
cues O
at O
follow-up O
served O
as O
the O
outcome O
( O
i.e. O
, O
dependent O
) O
variable O
of O
interest O
. O

The O
same O
procedure O
for O
multiple O
comparisons O
corrections O
as O
above O
was O
followed O
( O
uncorrected O
p O
< O
.001 O
, O
corrected O
α O
=.05 O
, O
≥ O
11 O
contiguous O
voxels O
) O
. O

Naltrexone O
ameliorates O
functional O
network O
abnormalities O
in O
alcohol‐dependent O
individuals O
Abstract O
Naltrexone O
, O
an O
opioid O
receptor O
antagonist O
, O
is O
commonly O
used O
as O
a O
relapse O
prevention O
medication O
in O
alcohol O
and O
opiate O
addiction O
, O
but O
its O
efficacy O
and O
the O
mechanisms O
underpinning O
its O
clinical O
usefulness O
are O
not O
well O
characterized O
. O

In O
the O
current O
study O
, O
we O
examined O
the O
effects O
of O
50‐mg O
naltrexone O
compared O
with O
placebo O
on O
neural O
network O
changes O
associated O
with O
substance O
dependence O
in O
21 O
alcohol O
and O
36 O
poly‐drug‐dependent O
individuals O
compared O
with O
36 O
healthy O
volunteers O
. O

Graph O
theoretic O
and O
network‐based O
statistical O
analysis O
of O
resting‐state O
functional O
magnetic O
resonance O
imaging O
( O
MRI O
) O
data O
revealed O
that O
alcohol‐dependent O
subjects O
had O
reduced O
functional O
connectivity O
of O
a O
dispersed O
network O
compared O
with O
both O
poly‐drug‐dependent O
and O
healthy O
subjects O
. O

Higher O
local O
efficiency O
was O
observed O
in O
both O
patient O
groups O
, O
indicating O
clustered O
and O
segregated O
network O
topology O
and O
information O
processing O
. O

Naltrexone O
normalized O
heightened O
local O
efficiency O
of O
the O
neural O
network O
in O
alcohol‐dependent O
individuals O
, O
to O
the O
same O
levels O
as O
healthy O
volunteers O
. O

Naltrexone O
failed O
to O
have O
an O
effect O
on O
the O
local O
efficiency O
in O
abstinent O
poly‐substance‐dependent O
individuals O
. O

Across O
groups O
, O
local O
efficiency O
was O
associated O
with O
substance O
, O
but O
no O
alcohol O
exposure O
implicating O
local O
efficiency O
as O
a O
potential O
premorbid O
risk O
factor O
in O
alcohol O
use O
disorders O
that O
can O
be O
ameliorated O
by O
naltrexone O
. O

These O
findings O
suggest O
one O
possible O
mechanism O
for O
the O
clinical O
effects O
of O
naltrexone O
, O
namely O
, O
the O
amelioration O
of O
disrupted O
network O
topology O
. O

Materials O
and O
Methods O
Participants O
Details O
of O
study O
design O
and O
procedures O
are O
reported O
elsewhere O
( O
Paterson O
et O
al O
. O

2015 O
) O
. O

Inclusion O
criteria O
included O
individuals O
who O
met O
DSM‐IV O
criteria O
for O
current O
or O
prior O
AD O
, O
or O
another O
substance O
of O
dependence O
( O
e.g O
. O

amphetamines O
, O
benzodiazepines O
, O
cocaine O
and O
opiates O
) O
( O
poly‐drug O
SD O
) O
. O

Participants O
were O
abstinent O
, O
and O
there O
was O
no O
upper O
limit O
for O
abstinence O
. O

Abstinence O
was O
determined O
through O
clinical O
interviews O
during O
the O
baseline O
session O
and O
by O
using O
urine O
and O
alcohol O
breath O
test O
on O
each O
day O
of O
testing O
. O

Participants O
were O
not O
undergoing O
pharmacological O
treatment O
. O

All O
participants O
were O
aged O
21 O
to O
64 O
years O
. O

The O
healthy O
control O
group O
had O
no O
previous O
history O
of O
substance O
abuse O
, O
as O
assessed O
using O
the O
Alcohol O
, O
Smoking O
and O
Substance O
Involvement O
Screening O
Test O
( O
ASSIST O
) O
( O
Group O
WAW O
2002 O
) O
and O
timeline O
follow‐back O
. O

The O
healthy O
control O
group O
was O
matched O
for O
age O
, O
gender O
and O
smoking O
status O
where O
possible O
. O

All O
participants O
were O
required O
to O
provide O
a O
negative O
breath O
alcohol O
test O
and O
a O
negative O
urine O
sample O
( O
screening O
for O
the O
presence O
of O
amphetamines O
, O
benzodiazepines O
, O
cocaine O
and O
opiates O
) O
on O
experimental O
days O
. O

Participants O
were O
asked O
to O
refrain O
from O
cannabis O
use O
for O
the O
7 O
days O
prior O
to O
testing O
. O

Positive O
results O
for O
cannabinoids O
were O
accepted O
; O
however O
, O
because O
of O
the O
long O
half‐life O
of O
metabolites O
, O
so O
long O
as O
the O
participant O
was O
not O
under O
intoxication O
or O
withdrawal O
. O

For O
the O
alcohol O
group O
, O
prior O
dependence O
on O
any O
other O
substance O
was O
exclusionary O
. O

Exclusion O
criteria O
included O
are O
as O
follows O
: O
current O
use O
of O
regular O
prescription O
or O
non‐prescription O
medication O
that O
would O
interfere O
with O
study O
integrity O
or O
subject O
safety O
; O
current O
primary O
axis O
I O
diagnosis O
; O
current O
or O
past O
history O
of O
enduring O
severe O
mental O
illness O
; O
current O
or O
past O
psychiatric O
history O
that O
contraindicated O
participation O
; O
history O
or O
current O
significant O
neurological O
diagnosis O
that O
may O
have O
influenced O
analysis O
or O
results O
; O
claustrophobia O
or O
unable O
to O
lie O
in O
the O
MRI O
scanner O
for O
90 O
minutes O
; O
a O
cardiac O
pacemaker O
, O
other O
electronic O
device O
or O
other O
MRI O
contraindication O
, O
including O
pregnancy O
, O
as O
assessed O
by O
a O
standard O
pre‐MRI O
questionnaire O
. O

Secondary O
or O
lifetime O
history O
of O
depression O
or O
anxiety O
was O
permitted O
in O
both O
SD O
and O
healthy O
volunteers O
, O
as O
these O
are O
common O
comorbidities O
in O
the O
former O
. O

Procedure O
All O
participants O
underwent O
a O
baseline O
session O
followed O
by O
two O
study O
sessions O
in O
which O
clinical O
, O
cognitive O
and O
neuroimaging O
tests O
were O
completed O
under O
either O
placebo O
or O
naltrexone O
, O
in O
counterbalanced O
order O
. O

The O
drug O
was O
administered O
2 O
hours O
before O
each O
scan O
. O

A O
50‐mg O
oral O
dose O
of O
naltrexone O
( O
manufactured O
by O
Bristol‐Myers O
Squibb O
Pharmaceutical O
Limited O
, O
UK O
) O
provided O
as O
per O
the O
British O
National O
Formulary O
was O
administered O
per O
participant O
. O

Subjects O
participated O
in O
resting O
state O
functional O
MRI O
, O
which O
was O
always O
first O
, O
and O
followed O
by O
three O
task‐based O
functional O
MRI O
scans O
. O

We O
examined O
individuals O
who O
completed O
both O
study O
sessions O
, O
which O
were O
counterbalanced O
, O
and O
there O
were O
no O
participant O
dropouts O
between O
these O
sessions O
( O
36 O
healthy O
volunteers O
[ O
17 O
placebo O
first O
, O
Imperial/Cambridge/Manchester O
( O
ICM O
) O
= O
13/12/11 O
] O
; O
36 O
poly‐drug O
SD O
( O
19 O
placebo O
first O
, O
ICM O
= O
12/13/11 O
) O
; O
21 O
AD O
( O
12 O
placebo O
first O
, O
ICM O
= O
10/6/5 O
) O
) O
. O

Please O
see O
Supporting O
Information O
for O
further O
details O
of O
procedure O
and O
assessments O
taken O
. O

Resting O
State O
Functional O
MRI O
Acquisition O
and O
Processing O
Data O
acquisition O
procedures O
are O
reported O
elsewhere O
( O
McGonigle O
et O
al O
. O

2016 O
) O
. O

Briefly O
, O
data O
were O
collected O
from O
three O
centres O
in O
the O
United O
Kingdom O
( O
Imperial O
College O
London O
and O
University O
of O
Cambridge O
with O
3T O
Siemens O
Tim O
Trio O
with O
a O
Siemens O
32 O
channel O
head O
coil O
, O
and O
Salford O
Royal O
NHS O
Foundation O
Trust O
, O
Manchester O
using O
3T O
Philips O
Achieva O
with O
an O
eight‐element O
SENSE O
head O
coil O
) O
. O

A O
recent O
report O
( O
McGonigle O
et O
al O
. O

2016 O
) O
demonstrated O
no O
differences O
between O
centres O
for O
neuroimaging O
results O
during O
task O
performance O
, O
using O
the O
exact O
same O
data O
acquisition O
sequences O
and O
processing O
in O
healthy O
volunteers O
. O

Please O
see O
Supporting O
Information O
for O
further O
details O
. O

Resting O
state O
functional O
MRI O
data O
were O
collected O
for O
360 O
seconds O
from O
all O
participants O
with O
eyes O
closed O
. O

Participants O
were O
asked O
to O
think O
of O
nothing O
in O
particular O
. O

Data O
were O
pre‐processed O
using O
speedypp.py O
as O
part O
of O
the O
fMRI O
signal O
processing O
toolbox O
v1.0 O
, O
which O
draws O
upon O
modules O
from O
afni O
toolbox O
( O
http O
: O
//afni.nimh.nih.gov O
) O
. O

As O
motion O
significantly O
affects O
connectivity O
measures O
during O
resting O
state O
fMRI O
, O
motion O
parameters O
and O
derivatives O
and O
signal O
from O
cerebrospinal O
fluid O
were O
regressed O
out O
. O

Signals O
with O
high O
change O
in O
BOLD O
signal O
from O
volume O
to O
volume O
, O
i.e O
. O

dvars O
> O
2 O
, O
may O
not O
have O
been O
sufficiently O
corrected O
for O
motion O
( O
Power O
et O
al O
. O

2012 O
) O
, O
and O
these O
subjects O
were O
removed O
in O
a O
secondary O
, O
more O
stringent O
analysis O
, O
resulting O
in O
removal O
of O
three O
AD O
, O
10 O
poly‐drug O
SD O
and O
eight O
HV O
participants O
. O

Dvars O
were O
not O
significantly O
different O
between O
groups O
( O
P O
> O
0.05 O
) O
. O

Data O
were O
zero‐padded O
, O
despiked O
and O
slice‐time O
corrected O
. O

Anatomical O
and O
functional O
images O
were O
co‐registered O
and O
normalized O
to O
a O
Montreal O
Neurological O
Institute O
( O
MNI152 O
) O
template O
. O

Graph O
Theory O
Analysis O
We O
extracted O
regional O
mean O
fMRI O
time O
series O
for O
90 O
regions O
of O
interest O
( O
ROI O
) O
in O
the O
Anatomical O
Automatic O
Labeling O
template O
( O
Tzourio‐Mazoyer O
et O
al O
. O

2002 O
) O
for O
each O
individual O
. O

Each O
regional O
mean O
time O
series O
was O
decomposed O
into O
wavelet O
coefficients O
at O
four O
scales O
using O
the O
maximum O
overlap O
discrete O
wavelet O
transform O
, O
a O
time‐frequency O
transformation O
. O

We O
used O
the O
scale O
2 O
wavelet O
correlation O
matrices O
, O
which O
represent O
functionally O
relevant O
signals O
in O
the O
frequency O
range O
of O
0.061~0.125 O
Hz O
, O
in O
line O
with O
previous O
reports O
assessing O
network O
efficiency O
measures O
( O
Achard O
& O
Bullmore O
2007 O
) O
. O

We O
constructed O
a O
whole O
brain O
ROI‐to‐ROI O
correlation O
matrix O
using O
pairwise O
region‐to‐region O
correlations O
between O
coefficients O
, O
as O
described O
in O
a O
previous O
study O
( O
Achard O
& O
Bullmore O
2007 O
) O
. O

The O
functional O
connectivity O
weights O
were O
binarized O
with O
the O
density O
threshold O
of O
5 O
percent O
to O
control O
network O
density O
between O
subjects O
( O
Achard O
& O
Bullmore O
2007 O
) O
and O
reduce O
the O
possibility O
of O
spurious O
connections O
, O
thus O
being O
the O
most O
parsimonious O
threshold O
generating O
the O
core O
connectivity O
of O
the O
network O
. O

Whole O
Brain O
Network O
Characteristics O
Local O
and O
global O
efficiency O
in O
the O
binarized O
graph O
were O
computed O
as O
described O
in O
previous O
literature O
( O
Meunier O
et O
al O
. O

2009 O
; O
Rubinov O
& O
Sporns O
2010 O
) O
. O

Local O
and O
global O
efficiency O
measures O
were O
entered O
into O
repeated O
measures O
ANOVA O
assessing O
group O
as O
a O
between‐subject O
factor O
and O
drug O
as O
a O
within‐subject O
factor O
. O

Comparisons O
were O
made O
using O
placebo O
, O
as O
a O
drug‐control O
session O
; O
however O
, O
the O
baseline O
session O
was O
additionally O
assessed O
to O
examine O
variability O
across O
sessions O
for O
each O
subject O
group O
. O

The O
AD O
and O
poly‐drug O
SD O
groups O
were O
then O
separately O
compared O
with O
the O
HV O
group O
. O

Local O
and O
global O
efficiency O
were O
correlated O
with O
drug O
and O
alcohol O
exposure O
using O
Pearson O
's O
correlation O
. O

Outcomes O
of O
P O
< O
0.05 O
were O
considered O
significant O
. O

Nodal O
efficiency O
was O
examined O
on O
an O
exploratory O
basis O
for O
significant O
main O
findings O
. O

Network‐based O
Statistics O
Group O
comparisons O
in O
region‐to‐region O
connectivity O
were O
assessed O
using O
NBS O
Toolbox O
( O
Zalesky O
et O
al O
. O

2010 O
) O
, O
for O
MATLAB O
( O
The O
MathWorks O
, O
Inc. O
, O
Natick O
, O
Massachusetts O
, O
United O
States O
) O
. O

Group O
differences O
are O
tested O
at O
every O
connection O
within O
the O
connectivity O
matrices O
( O
inter‐regional O
correlation O
in O
BOLD O
activity O
) O
using O
an O
initial O
threshold O
of O
T O
> O
3 O
as O
described O
in O
the O
work O
of O
Zalesky O
et O
al O
( O
2010 O
) O
. O

NBS O
identified O
the O
interconnected O
subnetwork O
consisting O
of O
suprathreshold O
edges O
( O
T O
> O
3 O
in O
group O
difference O
) O
. O

The O
size O
of O
the O
interconnected O
subnetwork O
( O
i.e O
. O

the O
number O
of O
interconnected O
suprathreshold O
edges O
) O
was O
used O
to O
calculate O
a O
family‐wise O
error O
corrected O
P‐value O
using O
10 O
000 O
permutation O
tests O
( O
P O
< O
0.05 O
, O
family‐wise O
error O
corrected O
) O
. O

In O
other O
words O
, O
NBS O
identified O
an O
interconnected O
subnetwork O
of O
altered O
connectivity O
with O
a O
cluster‐level O
corrected O
P‐values O
using O
network O
cluster O
size O
( O
the O
number O
of O
interconnected O
suprathreshold O
edges O
) O
. O

AD O
and O
poly‐drug O
SD O
were O
separately O
compared O
with O
HV O
. O

AD O
and O
poly‐drug O
SD O
were O
compared O
with O
each O
other O
on O
an O
exploratory O
basis O
. O

Motivational O
Deficits O
in O
Schizophrenia O
Are O
Associated O
with O
Reduced O
Differentiation O
between O
Gain O
and O
Loss-Avoidance O
Feedback O
in O
the O
Striatum O
Background O
The O
current O
study O
was O
designed O
to O
test O
the O
hypothesis O
that O
motivational O
deficits O
in O
schizophrenia O
( O
SZ O
) O
are O
tied O
to O
a O
reduced O
ability O
to O
differentially O
signal O
gains O
and O
instances O
of O
loss-avoidance O
in O
the O
brain O
, O
leading O
to O
reduced O
ability O
to O
form O
adaptive O
representations O
of O
expected O
value O
. O

Methods O
We O
administered O
a O
reinforcement O
learning O
paradigm O
to O
27 O
medicated O
SZ O
patients O
and O
27 O
controls O
, O
in O
which O
participants O
learned O
three O
probabilistic O
discriminations O
. O

In O
regions O
of O
interest O
in O
reward O
networks O
identified O
a O
priori O
, O
we O
examined O
contrasts O
between O
trial-types O
with O
different O
expected O
values O
( O
Expected O
Gain O
– O
Non-monetary O
, O
e.g O
. O

) O
, O
and O
between O
outcomes O
with O
the O
same O
prediction O
error O
valence O
but O
different O
experienced O
values O
( O
Gain O
– O
Loss-avoidance O
outcome O
, O
Miss O
– O
Loss O
outcome O
, O
e.g O
. O
) O
. O

Results O
Both O
whole-brain O
and O
regions-of-interest O
analyses O
revealed O
that O
schizophrenia O
patients O
showed O
reduced O
differentiation O
between O
Gain O
and O
Loss-avoidance O
outcomes O
in O
dorsal O
anterior O
cingulate O
cortex O
and O
bilateral O
anterior O
insula O
. O

That O
is O
, O
SZ O
patients O
showed O
reduced O
contrasts O
between O
positive O
prediction O
errors O
of O
different O
objective O
values O
in O
these O
areas O
. O

Furthermore O
, O
we O
observed O
significant O
correlations O
between O
[ O
Gain O
– O
Loss-avoidance O
outcome O
] O
contrasts O
in O
ventral O
striatum O
and O
ratings O
for O
Avolition/Anhedonia O
, O
and O
between O
[ O
Expected O
Gain O
– O
Non-monetary O
] O
contrasts O
in O
ventral O
striatum O
and O
ventromedial O
prefrontal O
cortex O
. O

Conclusions O
These O
results O
provide O
further O
evidence O
for O
intact O
prediction O
error O
signaling O
in O
medicated O
schizophrenia O
patients O
, O
especially O
with O
regard O
to O
loss-avoidance O
. O

By O
contrast O
components O
of O
frontostriatal O
circuits O
appear O
to O
show O
reduced O
sensitivity O
to O
the O
absolute O
valence O
of O
expected O
and O
experienced O
outcomes O
, O
suggesting O
a O
mechanism O
by O
which O
motivational O
deficits O
may O
emerge O
. O

Methods O
and O
Materials O
General O
Procedures O
Twenty-nine O
SZ O
patients O
and O
28 O
healthy O
volunteers O
, O
matched O
on O
demographic O
characteristics O
and O
smoking O
status O
, O
successfully O
completed O
an O
RL O
task O
in O
the O
MRI O
scanner O
( O
see O
Supplementary O
Methods O
for O
details O
of O
screening O
procedures O
) O
. O

All O
patients O
except O
one O
were O
medicated O
with O
antipsychotic O
drugs O
, O
with O
all O
those O
medicated O
being O
on O
stable O
antipsychotic O
medication O
regimens O
( O
no O
changes O
for O
four O
weeks O
) O
. O

Outside O
of O
the O
MRI O
scanner O
, O
cognitive O
function O
was O
assessed O
using O
three O
standard O
measures O
: O
the O
Wechsler O
Abbreviated O
Scale O
of O
Intelligence O
( O
WASI O
; O
23 O
) O
, O
the O
Wechsler O
Test O
of O
Adult O
Reading O
( O
WTAR O
; O
24 O
) O
, O
and O
the O
MATRICS O
battery O
. O

Standard O
symptom O
ratings O
were O
obtained O
for O
all O
patients O
using O
the O
Scale O
for O
the O
Assessment O
of O
Negative O
Symptoms O
( O
SANS O
; O
26 O
) O
, O
the O
Brief O
Psychiatric O
Rating O
Scale O
( O
BPRS O
; O
27 O
) O
, O
and O
the O
Calgary O
Depression O
Scale O
( O
CDS O
; O
28 O
) O
. O

Acquisition O
of O
behavioral O
and O
neuroimaging O
data O
Participants O
performed O
240 O
trials O
( O
average O
length O
: O
6 O
s O
) O
of O
a O
version O
of O
the O
Gain O
vs. O
Loss-avoidance O
probabilistic O
RL O
task O
similar O
to O
that O
used O
in O
our O
prior O
work O
( O
19 O
; O
Table O
1 O
) O
. O

Functional O
MRI O
data O
were O
acquired O
simultaneous O
with O
task O
performance O
, O
in O
four O
EPI O
scanning O
runs O
, O
each O
lasting O
≈7 O
minutes O
( O
with O
lead O
time O
) O
and O
involving O
the O
acquisition O
of O
191 O
whole-brain O
functional O
EPI O
images O
( O
for O
measurement O
of O
T2 O
* O
-weighted O
BOLD O
effects O
) O
using O
a O
3-T O
Siemens O
Trio O
scanner O
( O
Erlangen O
, O
Germany O
; O
81 O
2-mm O
axial O
slices O
; O
128 O
× O
128 O
matrix O
; O
FOV O
= O
22 O
× O
22 O
cm O
; O
TR O
= O
2 O
s O
; O
see O
Supplementary O
Methods O
for O
additional O
scanning O
parameters O
) O
. O

Also O
, O
in O
each O
session O
, O
we O
acquired O
a O
whole-brain O
T1-weighted O
structural O
image O
( O
MPRAGE O
) O
for O
anatomical O
reference O
( O
1-mm3 O
isotropic O
voxels O
) O
. O

Two O
patients O
were O
removed O
from O
subsequent O
analyses O
due O
to O
head O
motion O
sufficient O
to O
produce O
phase-instability O
in O
the O
functional O
images O
( O
resulting O
in O
the O
loss O
of O
entire O
runs O
to O
artifact O
) O
. O

One O
control O
was O
excluded O
from O
subsequent O
analyses O
, O
due O
to O
a O
lack O
of O
task-engagement O
( O
evidenced O
by O
random O
button-pressing O
and O
no O
attempt O
to O
learn O
) O
. O

Analysis O
of O
Behavioral O
and O
Characterizing O
Data O
Groups O
did O
not O
differ O
in O
age O
, O
gender O
, O
race O
, O
and O
parental O
education O
( O
Table O
1 O
) O
. O

As O
expected O
, O
significant O
between-group O
differences O
were O
observed O
for O
participant O
educational O
attainment O
and O
multiple O
measures O
of O
overall O
intellectual O
functioning O
. O

Behavioral O
data O
were O
analyzed O
for O
the O
proportion O
of O
trials O
on O
which O
participants O
chose O
the O
optimal O
( O
more-frequently-reinforced O
) O
stimulus O
from O
a O
pair O
, O
as O
well O
as O
“ O
win-stay O
” O
and O
“ O
lose-shift O
” O
rates O
( O
see O
Supplementary O
Methods O
for O
details O
) O
. O

Finally O
, O
we O
used O
a O
computational O
model O
, O
similar O
to O
those O
previously O
used O
by O
our O
group O
, O
in O
order O
to O
estimate O
action O
values O
and O
prediction O
errors O
on O
a O
trial-wise O
basis O
. O

Comparison O
of O
multiple O
models O
revealed O
that O
a O
Q-learning O
model O
with O
separate O
learning O
rates O
for O
positive O
and O
negative O
RPEs O
fit O
the O
behavioral O
data O
the O
best O
( O
see O
Supplementary O
Materials O
for O
details O
) O
. O

Analyses O
of O
Event-related O
fMRI O
Data O
Single-subject O
Analyses O
We O
performed O
two O
sets O
of O
regression O
analyses O
( O
general O
linear O
models O
, O
or O
GLMs O
) O
of O
single-subject O
voxel-wise O
time O
series O
, O
one O
with O
binary O
regressors O
corresponding O
to O
the O
six O
different O
trial O
types O
( O
three O
different O
pairs O
x O
two O
possible O
outcomes O
) O
, O
and O
one O
using O
parametric O
regressors O
( O
see O
Supplementary O
Methods O
for O
details O
) O
. O

Binary O
regressors O
were O
3-second O
boxcar O
functions O
, O
time-locked O
to O
the O
onset O
of O
individual O
trials O
and O
convolved O
with O
a O
model O
hemodynamic O
response O
function O
. O

Parametric O
regressors O
were O
derived O
from O
the O
results O
of O
computational O
modeling O
of O
individual O
behavior O
, O
which O
allowed O
for O
the O
estimation O
of O
prediction O
errors O
on O
a O
trial-wise O
basis O
. O

Whole-brain O
Group-level O
Analyses O
To O
test O
for O
significant O
activations O
within O
groups O
, O
as O
well O
as O
for O
significant O
between-group O
differences O
in O
BOLD O
signal O
activations O
associated O
with O
parametric O
RPE O
regressors O
, O
we O
used O
whole-brain O
t-tests O
( O
AFNI O
3dttest++ O
command O
) O
. O

To O
test O
for O
significant O
within-group O
effects O
of O
outcome O
valence O
, O
we O
used O
whole-brain O
paired O
t-tests O
( O
AFNI O
3dttest++ O
command O
) O
. O

To O
test O
for O
significant O
between-group O
differences O
in O
BOLD O
signal O
contrasts O
with O
regard O
to O
experienced O
value O
and O
expected O
value O
, O
we O
used O
whole-brain O
multivariate O
models O
( O
AFNI O
3dMVM O
command O
) O
, O
with O
factors O
of O
group O
and O
value O
( O
6 O
levels O
of O
experienced O
value O
, O
3 O
levels O
of O
expected O
value O
) O
. O

For O
whole-brain O
analyses O
, O
we O
used O
a O
voxel-wise O
threshold O
of O
p=0.001 O
and O
a O
cluster-size O
threshold O
of O
95 O
voxels O
, O
determined O
by O
Monte O
Carlo O
simulations O
. O

Analyses O
of O
event-related O
neural O
responses O
in O
regions-of-interest O
( O
ROIs O
) O
Based O
on O
the O
prior O
literature O
, O
we O
looked O
for O
effects O
of O
expected O
value O
valence O
, O
RPE O
valence O
, O
and O
outcome O
valence O
in O
VS O
( O
bilaterally O
) O
, O
vmPFC/mOFC O
, O
dorsal O
anterior O
cingulate O
cortex O
( O
dACC O
) O
, O
right O
anterior O
insula O
( O
R O
AI O
) O
, O
and O
left O
anterior O
insula O
( O
L O
AI O
; O
see O
Figure O
2A–C O
for O
specific O
coordinates O
of O
ROIs O
; O
see O
Supplementary O
Materials O
for O
justification O
of O
coordinates O
chosen O
) O
. O

For O
the O
VS O
, O
we O
centered O
spheres O
of O
5-mm O
radius O
on O
( O
±10 O
, O
8 O
, O
−4 O
) O
to O
form O
a O
single O
, O
bilateral O
ROI O
. O

All O
ROIs O
in O
PFC O
consisted O
of O
spheres O
of O
10-mm O
radius O
. O

Our O
primary O
focus O
was O
on O
contrasts O
between O
outcomes O
of O
different O
objective O
values O
for O
the O
same O
RPE O
valence O
( O
e.g. O
, O
Gain O
vs. O
Loss-avoidance O
, O
Miss O
vs. O
Loss O
) O
. O

Exploratory O
analyses O
examined O
contrasts O
between O
expected O
outcomes O
, O
corresponding O
to O
condition O
( O
e.g. O
, O
Gain/Miss O
vs. O
Loss/Loss-avoidance O
) O
. O

For O
each O
of O
these O
contrasts O
, O
we O
performed O
the O
following O
tests O
: O
1 O
) O
a O
repeated-measures O
ANOVA O
, O
within O
the O
control O
group O
, O
with O
ROI O
as O
a O
factor O
, O
in O
order O
to O
determine O
if O
the O
contrast O
differed O
from O
zero O
in O
the O
control O
group O
, O
without O
respect O
to O
ROI O
, O
and O
if O
the O
contrast O
differed O
as O
a O
function O
of O
ROI O
; O
2 O
) O
a O
repeated-measures O
ANOVA O
, O
across O
the O
entire O
sample O
, O
with O
group O
and O
ROI O
as O
factors O
, O
in O
order O
to O
determine O
if O
there O
was O
a O
between-group O
difference O
in O
the O
contrast O
, O
without O
respect O
to O
ROI O
, O
or O
a O
significant O
group O
x O
ROI O
interaction O
; O
3 O
) O
Spearman O
correlation O
analyses O
, O
between O
MRI O
contrasts O
in O
ROIs O
and O
RL O
performance O
measures O
in O
controls O
; O
and O
4 O
) O
Spearman O
correlation O
analyses O
, O
between O
MRI O
contrasts O
in O
ROIs O
and O
measures O
of O
motivational O
deficits O
in O
patients O
. O

In O
order O
to O
quantify O
motivational O
deficits O
in O
patients O
, O
we O
computed O
an O
avolition/anhedonia O
factor O
score O
by O
averaging O
item O
scores O
from O
the O
avolition/role-functioning O
and O
anhedonia/asociality O
subscales O
of O
the O
SANS O
. O

In O
order O
to O
determine O
whether O
measures O
of O
motivational O
deficits O
in O
patients O
were O
related O
specifically O
to O
negative O
symptoms O
, O
rather O
than O
measures O
in O
multiple O
symptom O
classes O
, O
as O
well O
as O
cognitive O
domains O
, O
we O
also O
performed O
Spearman O
correlation O
analyses O
, O
between O
MRI O
contrasts O
in O
ROIs O
and O
1 O
) O
individual O
psychosis O
scores O
, O
by O
averaging O
ratings O
from O
individual O
psychosis O
items O
on O
the O
BPRS O
( O
Suspiciousness O
, O
Grandiosity O
, O
Hallucinations O
, O
and O
Unusual O
Thought O
Content O
) O
, O
2 O
) O
individual O
IQ O
estimates O
, O
as O
well O
as O
several O
measures O
of O
intellectual O
function O
from O
the O
MATRICS O
battery O
, O
and O
3 O
) O
standardized O
APD O
doses O
for O
SZ O
patients O
( O
see O
Supplementary O
Materials O
for O
conversions O
and O
results O
of O
correlation O
analyses O
) O
. O

Linked O
functional O
network O
abnormalities O
during O
intrinsic O
and O
extrinsic O
activity O
in O
schizophrenia O
as O
revealed O
by O
a O
data-fusion O
approach O
Abnormalities O
in O
functional O
brain O
networks O
in O
schizophrenia O
have O
been O
studied O
by O
examining O
intrinsic O
and O
extrinsic O
brain O
activity O
under O
various O
experimental O
paradigms O
. O

However O
, O
the O
identified O
patterns O
of O
abnormal O
functional O
connectivity O
( O
FC O
) O
vary O
depending O
on O
the O
adopted O
paradigms O
. O

Thus O
, O
it O
is O
unclear O
whether O
and O
how O
these O
patterns O
are O
inter-related O
. O

In O
order O
to O
assess O
relationships O
between O
abnormal O
patterns O
of O
FC O
during O
intrinsic O
activity O
and O
those O
during O
extrinsic O
activity O
, O
we O
adopted O
a O
data-fusion O
approach O
and O
applied O
partial O
least O
square O
( O
PLS O
) O
analyses O
to O
FC O
datasets O
from O
25 O
patients O
with O
chronic O
schizophrenia O
and O
25 O
age- O
and O
sex-matched O
normal O
controls O
. O

For O
the O
input O
to O
the O
PLS O
analyses O
, O
we O
generated O
a O
pair O
of O
FC O
maps O
during O
the O
resting O
state O
( O
REST O
) O
and O
the O
auditory O
deviance O
response O
( O
ADR O
) O
from O
each O
participant O
using O
the O
common O
seed O
region O
in O
the O
left O
middle O
temporal O
gyrus O
, O
which O
is O
a O
focus O
of O
activity O
associated O
with O
auditory O
verbal O
hallucinations O
( O
AVHs O
) O
. O

PLS O
correlation O
( O
PLS-C O
) O
analysis O
revealed O
that O
patients O
with O
schizophrenia O
have O
significantly O
lower O
loadings O
of O
a O
component O
containing O
positive O
FCs O
in O
default-mode O
network O
regions O
during O
REST O
and O
a O
component O
containing O
positive O
FCs O
in O
the O
auditory O
and O
attention-related O
networks O
during O
ADR O
. O

Specifically O
, O
loadings O
of O
the O
REST O
component O
were O
significantly O
correlated O
with O
the O
severities O
of O
positive O
symptoms O
and O
AVH O
in O
patients O
with O
schizophrenia O
. O

The O
co-occurrence O
of O
such O
altered O
FC O
patterns O
during O
REST O
and O
ADR O
was O
replicated O
using O
PLS O
regression O
, O
wherein O
FC O
patterns O
during O
REST O
are O
modeled O
to O
predict O
patterns O
during O
ADR O
. O

These O
findings O
provide O
an O
integrative O
understanding O
of O
altered O
FCs O
during O
intrinsic O
and O
extrinsic O
activity O
underlying O
core O
schizophrenia O
symptoms O
. O

Highlights O
A O
new O
fMRI O
analysis O
method O
for O
data O
fusion O
was O
applied O
to O
schizophrenia O
fMRI O
data O
. O

Multiple O
patterns O
of O
abnormal O
functional O
connectivity O
were O
linked O
in O
schizophrenia O
. O

Abnormal O
networks O
included O
the O
auditory O
language O
and O
saliency O
networks O
and O
DMN O
. O

The O
identified O
patterns O
of O
connectivity O
abnormalities O
were O
correlated O
with O
symptoms O
. O

Materials O
and O
methods O
Participants O
Twenty-five O
patients O
with O
SCZ O
and O
25 O
age- O
and O
sex-matched O
HCs O
participated O
in O
this O
study O
. O

The O
patients O
were O
recruited O
at O
Karasuyama O
Hospital O
at O
the O
Showa O
University O
School O
of O
Medicine O
in O
Tokyo O
, O
Japan O
. O

Diagnoses O
were O
made O
by O
2 O
experienced O
psychiatrists O
, O
based O
on O
the O
Structured O
Clinical O
Interview O
for O
the O
Diagnostic O
and O
Statistical O
Manual O
of O
Mental O
Disorders O
, O
Fourth O
Edition O
. O

Patients O
were O
excluded O
if O
they O
had O
other O
major O
psychiatric O
or O
neurological O
disease O
, O
severe O
somatic O
disorders O
, O
alcohol O
intake O
within O
24 O
h O
of O
the O
examination O
, O
or O
current O
or O
past O
alcohol O
abuse O
. O

Psychiatric O
symptoms O
were O
assessed O
using O
the O
Positive O
and O
Negative O
Syndrome O
Scale O
( O
PANSS O
) O
, O
and O
the O
severities O
of O
the O
auditory O
hallucinations O
were O
rated O
using O
the O
Auditory O
Hallucination O
Rating O
Scale O
( O
AHRS O
) O
. O

None O
of O
the O
HCs O
reported O
any O
severe O
medical O
problems O
or O
neurological O
or O
psychiatric O
histories O
, O
and O
none O
satisfied O
the O
diagnostic O
criteria O
for O
any O
psychiatric O
disorder O
. O

Written O
informed O
consent O
was O
obtained O
from O
all O
participants O
. O

Handedness O
of O
each O
participant O
was O
assessed O
using O
the O
Edinburgh O
Handedness O
Inventory O
. O

The O
patient O
's O
premorbid O
intelligence O
was O
estimated O
using O
the O
Japanese O
version O
of O
the O
National O
Adult O
Reading O
Test O
. O

Demographic O
data O
for O
the O
SCZ O
and O
HC O
groups O
are O
shown O
in O
Table O
1 O
. O

This O
study O
was O
conducted O
in O
accordance O
with O
the O
principles O
of O
the O
Declaration O
of O
Helsinki O
and O
was O
approved O
by O
the O
Ethics O
Committee O
of O
the O
Faculty O
of O
Medicine O
of O
Showa O
University O
. O

The O
patients O
' O
primary O
physicians O
determined O
the O
patients O
' O
ability O
to O
provide O
informed O
consent O
before O
recruitment O
. O

Data O
acquisition O
All O
MRI O
data O
were O
acquired O
using O
a O
1.5-T O
GE O
Signa O
system O
( O
General O
Electric O
; O
Milwaukee O
, O
WI O
, O
USA O
) O
with O
a O
phased-array O
whole-head O
coil O
. O

Every O
participant O
underwent O
the O
two O
functional O
imaging O
runs O
for O
the O
REST O
and O
ADR O
paradigms O
in O
a O
single O
fMRI O
session O
. O

The O
functional O
images O
were O
acquired O
using O
a O
gradient O
echo-planar O
imaging O
sequence O
. O

Except O
for O
parameters O
of O
slice O
thickness O
and O
the O
number O
of O
volumes O
, O
the O
following O
parameters O
were O
the O
same O
between O
the O
two O
fMRI O
runs O
: O
in-plane O
resolution O
= O
3.4375 O
× O
3.4375 O
mm2 O
, O
echo O
time O
( O
TE O
) O
= O
40 O
ms O
, O
repetition O
time O
( O
TR O
) O
= O
2000 O
ms O
, O
flip O
angle O
= O
90° O
, O
matrix O
size O
: O
64 O
× O
64 O
, O
and O
27 O
axial O
slices O
. O

Slice O
thickness O
was O
4 O
mm O
with O
a O
1-mm O
slice O
gap O
for O
REST O
and O
4 O
mm O
without O
a O
gap O
for O
ADR O
. O

In O
each O
fMRI O
run O
, O
the O
first O
four O
volumes O
were O
discarded O
to O
allow O
for O
equilibration O
effects O
. O

At O
the O
end O
of O
the O
MRI O
session O
, O
a O
high-resolution O
T1-weighted O
spoiled O
gradient O
recalled O
three-dimensional O
MRI O
image O
was O
acquired O
( O
in-plane O
resolution O
: O
0.9375 O
× O
0.9375 O
mm2 O
, O
1.4 O
mm O
slice O
thickness O
, O
TR O
: O
25 O
ms O
, O
TE O
: O
9.2 O
ms O
, O
matrix O
size O
: O
256 O
× O
256 O
, O
128 O
sagittal O
slices O
) O
. O

Task O
For O
the O
REST O
run O
, O
the O
participants O
were O
instructed O
to O
lie O
in O
the O
supine O
position O
in O
the O
scanner O
, O
to O
remain O
as O
still O
as O
possible O
, O
and O
to O
keep O
their O
eyes O
closed O
, O
but O
stay O
awake O
in O
the O
dim O
scanner O
room O
. O

In O
total O
, O
204 O
volumes O
were O
acquired O
over O
6 O
min O
48 O
s. O
For O
the O
ADR O
run O
, O
we O
adopted O
an O
auditory O
oddball O
paradigm O
originally O
used O
in O
a O
previous O
study O
wherein O
the O
neural O
sources O
of O
ADR O
were O
identified O
. O

In O
this O
paradigm O
, O
sequences O
consisting O
of O
two O
types O
of O
tones O
were O
presented O
: O
Tone O
1 O
( O
TN1 O
) O
was O
a O
400-Hz O
tone O
and O
Tone O
2 O
( O
TN2 O
) O
was O
a O
500-Hz O
tone O
. O

Both O
tones O
had O
durations O
of O
100 O
ms. O
Each O
run O
consisted O
of O
alternating O
“ O
standard O
” O
blocks O
( O
24 O
s O
per O
block O
) O
and O
“ O
deviant O
” O
blocks O
( O
24 O
s O
per O
block O
) O
, O
with O
intervening O
rest O
blocks O
( O
24 O
s O
per O
block O
) O
. O

The O
standard O
blocks O
consisted O
of O
two O
tones O
alternating O
in O
a O
regular O
fashion O
( O
i.e. O
, O
TN1 O
, O
TN2 O
, O
TN1 O
, O
TN2 O
, O
TN1 O
, O
TN2 O
… O
) O
. O

In O
the O
deviant O
blocks O
, O
the O
two O
tones O
were O
presented O
in O
a O
pseudo-random O
order O
( O
e.g. O
, O
TN1 O
, O
TN2 O
, O
TN2 O
, O
TN1 O
, O
TN1 O
, O
TN1 O
, O
TN2 O
… O
) O
. O

The O
tones O
were O
presented O
with O
an O
inter-stimulus O
interval O
of O
400 O
ms O
. O

The O
single O
run O
consisted O
of O
6 O
standard O
blocks O
and O
6 O
deviant O
blocks O
, O
with O
rest O
blocks O
without O
auditory O
stimulation O
interposed O
in O
between O
. O

The O
number O
of O
volumes O
was O
291 O
( O
9 O
min O
42 O
s O
) O
. O

During O
the O
run O
, O
a O
gray O
checkerboard O
( O
a O
visual O
distractor O
) O
appeared O
on O
the O
screen O
at O
irregular O
intervals O
. O

The O
participants O
were O
instructed O
to O
pay O
attention O
to O
the O
screen O
and O
to O
press O
a O
button O
whenever O
the O
checkerboard O
appeared O
on O
the O
screen O
. O

They O
were O
also O
instructed O
that O
their O
task O
was O
to O
respond O
to O
the O
checkerboard O
and O
that O
the O
auditory O
tones O
were O
irrelevant O
to O
the O
task O
. O

The O
frequency O
of O
the O
appearance O
of O
the O
checkerboard O
was O
balanced O
over O
the O
“ O
standard O
, O
” O
“ O
deviant O
, O
” O
and O
rest O
blocks O
. O

The O
participants O
wore O
MRI-compatible O
headsets O
( O
Serene O
Sound O
; O
Resonance O
Technology O
; O
Northridge O
, O
CA O
, O
USA O
) O
. O

During O
the O
ADR O
run O
, O
participant O
responses O
( O
response O
time O
and O
accuracy O
) O
were O
collected O
via O
a O
fiber-optic O
response O
pad O
connected O
to O
a O
PC O
interface O
( O
Current O
Designs O
; O
Philadelphia O
, O
PA O
, O
USA O
) O
. O

Stimulus O
presentation O
and O
response O
collection O
were O
controlled O
using O
Neurobehavioral O
Systems O
Presentation O
software O
( O
Neurobehavioral O
Systems O
; O
Albany O
, O
CA O
, O
USA O
) O
. O

fMRI O
Data O
analyses O
Preprocessing O
For O
each O
of O
the O
REST O
and O
ADR O
runs O
, O
we O
first O
applied O
a O
series O
of O
preprocessing O
steps O
and O
then O
performed O
seed-based O
FC O
analyses O
for O
each O
subject O
before O
the O
PLS O
data-fusion O
step O
. O

The O
same O
preprocessing O
steps O
were O
used O
for O
the O
REST O
and O
ADR O
paradigms O
as O
follows O
: O
[ O
1 O
] O
slice-timing O
correction O
, O
[ O
2 O
] O
head O
motion O
correction O
, O
[ O
3 O
] O
normalization O
and O
resampling O
to O
a O
resolution O
of O
2 O
× O
2 O
× O
2 O
mm3 O
, O
and O
[ O
4 O
] O
spatial O
smoothing O
using O
a O
Gaussian O
kernel O
( O
6-mm O
full O
width O
at O
half-maximum O
) O
. O

All O
of O
these O
preprocessing O
steps O
were O
performed O
using O
Statistical O
Parametric O
Mapping O
software O
( O
SPM8 O
; O
Wellcome O
Department O
of O
Cognitive O
Neurology O
; O
London O
, O
UK O
) O
. O

We O
also O
generated O
a O
task-specific O
brain O
mask O
by O
including O
voxels O
that O
were O
present O
in O
all O
of O
the O
participants O
and O
survived O
at O
a O
25 O
% O
gray O
matter O
( O
GM O
) O
probability O
mask O
used O
to O
restrict O
the O
FC O
analyses O
within O
the O
GM O
volume O
. O

To O
remove O
artefactual O
components O
from O
the O
time-series O
in O
each O
voxel O
during O
the O
REST O
run O
, O
we O
performed O
multiple O
linear O
regression O
analyses O
using O
the O
following O
confound O
regressors O
: O
[ O
1 O
] O
six O
head O
motion O
parameters O
and O
their O
temporal O
derivatives O
, O
[ O
2 O
] O
a O
mean O
signal O
from O
white O
matter O
voxels O
, O
and O
[ O
3 O
] O
a O
mean O
signal O
from O
cerebrospinal O
fluid O
voxels O
. O

We O
did O
not O
remove O
the O
global O
signal O
in O
order O
to O
avoid O
the O
risk O
of O
yielding O
spurious O
negative O
correlations O
. O

A O
band-pass O
filter O
( O
0.01–0.1 O
Hz O
) O
was O
applied O
to O
reduce O
the O
effects O
of O
low-frequency O
drift O
and O
physiological O
noise O
. O

Furthermore O
, O
to O
reduce O
spurious O
changes O
in O
FC O
due O
to O
head O
motion O
, O
we O
used O
a O
scrubbing O
method O
adopted O
from O
a O
previous O
study O
. O

Specifically O
, O
we O
calculated O
a O
frame-wise O
displacement O
( O
FD O
) O
at O
each O
time O
point O
using O
the O
six O
motion O
parameters O
. O

We O
then O
flagged O
volumes O
with O
FDs O
larger O
than O
0.5 O
mm O
and O
removed O
these O
volumes O
along O
with O
the O
previous O
and O
subsequent O
two O
volumes O
from O
the O
correlation O
analysis O
. O

There O
were O
no O
significant O
differences O
between O
the O
two O
groups O
either O
in O
the O
mean O
FD O
( O
HCs O
: O
0.11 O
± O
0.03 O
mm O
; O
patients O
with O
SCZ O
: O
0.11 O
± O
0.04 O
mm O
; O
t O
= O
− O
0.41 O
, O
p O
= O
0.68 O
) O
or O
the O
number O
of O
frames O
with O
FDs O
larger O
than O
0.5 O
mm O
( O
HCs O
: O
1.8 O
± O
0.70 O
; O
patient O
with O
SCZ O
: O
3.04 O
± O
0.70 O
; O
t O
= O
1.25 O
, O
p O
= O
0.22 O
) O
. O

For O
the O
ADR O
run O
, O
we O
also O
confirmed O
that O
there O
were O
no O
significant O
differences O
between O
the O
two O
groups O
either O
in O
the O
mean O
FD O
( O
HCs O
: O
0.097 O
± O
0.007 O
mm O
; O
patients O
with O
SCZ O
: O
0.120 O
± O
0.011 O
mm O
; O
t O
= O
1.75 O
, O
p O
= O
0.09 O
) O
or O
in O
the O
number O
of O
frames O
with O
FDs O
larger O
than O
0.5 O
mm O
( O
HCs O
: O
2.96 O
± O
1.11 O
; O
patients O
with O
SCZ O
: O
4.28 O
± O
1.11 O
; O
t O
= O
0.84 O
, O
p O
= O
0.40 O
) O
. O

Generation O
of O
FC O
maps O
for O
the O
REST O
and O
ADR O
runs O
The O
first O
step O
in O
the O
preparation O
for O
PLS O
analyses O
was O
to O
generate O
pairs O
of O
fMRI O
FC O
maps O
for O
REST O
and O
ADR O
between O
which O
critical O
latent O
patterns O
of O
FC O
features O
are O
expected O
. O

Hence O
, O
we O
determined O
a O
common O
seed-region O
for O
REST O
and O
ADR O
and O
generated O
a O
pair O
of O
seed-based O
FC O
maps O
for O
each O
subject O
( O
25 O
patients O
with O
SCZ O
and O
25 O
matched O
HCs O
) O
. O

Based O
on O
numerous O
previous O
studies O
showing O
that O
auditory O
and O
speech-related O
areas O
underlie O
various O
schizophrenia O
symptoms O
, O
particularly O
AVH O
, O
we O
focused O
on O
the O
left O
lateral O
temporal O
cortex O
as O
the O
primary O
candidate O
for O
the O
common O
seed O
for O
REST O
and O
ADR O
. O

Based O
on O
a O
previous O
meta-analysis O
that O
revealed O
a O
significant O
association O
between O
AVH O
and O
abnormal O
activation O
, O
we O
determined O
a O
6-mm O
sphere O
centered O
at O
the O
Montreal O
Neurological O
Institute O
coordinate O
[ O
-56 O
-30 O
-2 O
] O
in O
the O
left O
middle O
temporal O
gyrus O
( O
MTG O
) O
as O
the O
seed O
. O

Because O
this O
location O
was O
near O
the O
superior O
temporal O
sulcus O
( O
STS O
) O
, O
we O
named O
the O
seed O
location O
the O
left O
MTG/STS O
. O

An O
FC O
map O
of O
the O
REST O
run O
in O
each O
subject O
was O
generated O
by O
assessing O
correlations O
between O
the O
time-series O
data O
at O
the O
seed O
location O
and O
data O
from O
each O
voxel O
in O
the O
GM O
volume O
. O

Finally O
, O
an O
FC O
map O
was O
generated O
for O
each O
participant O
by O
computing O
Pearson O
's O
correlation O
coefficients O
between O
time O
courses O
extracted O
from O
the O
seed O
location O
and O
those O
of O
all O
other O
voxels O
. O

The O
seed O
time-course O
was O
extracted O
from O
an O
area O
within O
a O
6-mm O
radius O
of O
the O
aforementioned O
coordinate O
. O

The O
correlation O
coefficients O
were O
converted O
to O
z-scores O
using O
Fisher O
's O
r-to-z O
transform O
. O

The O
resulting O
z-maps O
were O
fed O
into O
the O
PLS O
. O

In O
the O
calculation O
of O
FC O
maps O
for O
ADR O
, O
the O
effects O
of O
the O
auditory O
oddball O
( O
i.e. O
, O
ADR O
) O
on O
FCs O
were O
estimated O
using O
Psychophysiological O
Interaction O
( O
PPI O
) O
analysis O
in O
SPM8 O
. O

The O
PPI O
analysis O
consisted O
of O
a O
first O
regressor O
representing O
the O
seed O
fMRI O
time-series O
data O
extracted O
from O
the O
seed O
location O
that O
was O
deconvolved O
with O
a O
hemodynamic O
response O
function O
, O
a O
second O
regressor O
representing O
the O
psychological O
variable O
of O
Deviant O
- O
Standard O
blocks O
, O
and O
a O
third O
regressor O
representing O
the O
interaction O
between O
these O
two O
factors O
. O

The O
seed O
fMRI O
time-series O
was O
extracted O
from O
a O
sphere O
with O
a O
6-mm O
radius O
centered O
at O
the O
seed O
coordinate O
. O

The O
six O
parameters O
for O
head O
motion O
were O
also O
used O
as O
nuisance O
regressors O
. O

We O
generated O
a O
contrast O
map O
for O
the O
third O
regressor O
for O
each O
individual O
. O

This O
map O
was O
then O
fed O
into O
the O
PLS O
analyses O
. O

Group O
comparisons O
of O
REST O
and O
ADR O
FC O
maps O
In O
a O
separate O
analysis O
from O
the O
PLS O
, O
we O
performed O
two-sample O
t-tests O
to O
compare O
z-maps O
during O
the O
REST O
run O
between O
HCs O
and O
patients O
with O
SCZ O
. O

The O
statistical O
threshold O
was O
set O
to O
p O
< O
0.001 O
at O
the O
voxel O
level O
and O
the O
spatial O
extent O
threshold O
was O
set O
to O
k O
> O
250 O
voxels O
, O
as O
determined O
using O
3dFWHMx O
and O
3dClustSim O
to O
achieve O
a O
corrected O
p O
< O
0.05 O
at O
the O
cluster O
level O
. O

For O
the O
ADR O
run O
, O
we O
performed O
group O
comparisons O
using O
the O
contrast O
maps O
for O
the O
regressor O
for O
the O
psychophysiological O
interaction O
. O

The O
voxel-level O
threshold O
of O
p O
< O
0.001 O
and O
the O
spatial O
extent O
threshold O
of O
k O
> O
86 O
were O
used O
to O
achieve O
a O
cluster-level O
corrected O
p O
< O
0.05 O
, O
as O
determined O
using O
3dFWHMx O
and O
3dClustSim O
. O

Data O
fusion O
: O
PLS O
PLS O
correlation O
( O
PLS-C O
) O
is O
a O
multivariate O
statistical O
technique O
used O
to O
investigate O
statistical O
associations O
between O
two O
sets O
of O
variables O
by O
identifying O
latent O
components O
in O
one O
variable O
set O
( O
i.e. O
, O
REST O
) O
that O
maximally O
co-vary O
with O
those O
in O
another O
set O
( O
i.e. O
, O
ADR O
) O
across O
participants O
. O

The O
procedure O
is O
illustrated O
in O
Fig O
. O

1 O
. O

A O
pair O
of O
FC O
maps O
, O
REST O
and O
ADR O
, O
generated O
by O
seeding O
the O
left O
MTG/STS O
in O
each O
individual O
were O
separately O
flattened O
into O
two O
rows O
, O
which O
were O
then O
fed O
into O
row O
vectors O
in O
X O
and O
Y O
data O
matrices O
, O
respectively O
. O

Therefore O
, O
the O
X O
and O
Y O
matrices O
had O
50 O
rows O
and O
their O
number O
of O
columns O
corresponded O
to O
the O
number O
of O
voxels O
in O
the O
FC O
maps O
of O
REST O
and O
ADR O
. O

A O
standard O
approach O
for O
solving O
the O
PLS-C O
problem O
is O
to O
apply O
singular O
value O
decomposition O
( O
SVD O
) O
to O
the O
covariance O
matrix O
XTY O
, O
which O
represents O
the O
covariance O
of O
all O
of O
the O
pairs O
of O
a O
voxel O
in O
one O
condition O
( O
i.e. O
, O
REST O
) O
and O
those O
in O
another O
condition O
( O
i.e. O
, O
ADR O
) O
across O
participants O
. O

Briefly O
, O
SVD O
generates O
a O
set O
of O
mutually O
orthogonal O
composite O
components O
by O
decomposing O
XTY O
into O
UΔVT O
, O
wherein O
U O
and O
V O
are O
matrices O
of O
left O
and O
right O
singular O
vectors O
and O
Δ O
is O
a O
diagonal O
matrix O
with O
singular O
values O
along O
the O
diagonal O
. O

Here O
, O
the O
ith O
composite O
component O
consists O
of O
the O
ith O
column O
vectors O
of O
matrices O
U O
and O
V O
and O
the O
ith O
singular O
value O
in O
matrix O
Δ O
. O

The O
number O
of O
composite O
components O
was O
46 O
, O
which O
was O
equal O
to O
the O
full O
rank O
of O
the O
covariance O
matrix O
XTY O
. O

The O
ith O
column O
vectors O
of O
U O
and O
V O
represent O
voxel O
values O
in O
FC O
maps O
of O
the O
REST O
and O
ADR O
runs O
. O

More O
specifically O
, O
before O
being O
fed O
into O
SVD O
, O
the O
effects O
of O
age O
, O
handedness O
, O
and O
sex O
from O
each O
column O
in O
the O
X O
and O
Y O
matrices O
were O
regressed O
out O
, O
as O
these O
factors O
might O
impact O
the O
results O
of O
PLS O
. O

The O
X O
and O
Y O
data O
matrices O
were O
then O
standardized O
to O
each O
column O
. O

The O
application O
of O
SVD O
to O
the O
covariance O
matrix O
( O
i.e. O
, O
XTY O
) O
is O
computationally O
expensive O
because O
of O
the O
high O
dimensionality O
of O
the O
matrix O
( O
i.e. O
, O
the O
number O
of O
voxels O
in O
REST O
and O
ADR O
) O
. O

In O
this O
study O
, O
we O
used O
an O
alternative O
computationally O
efficient O
method O
proposed O
in O
a O
previous O
study O
. O

Briefly O
, O
during O
the O
decomposition O
of O
XTY O
into O
UΔVT O
, O
XTYYTX O
may O
be O
represented O
as O
UΔ2UT O
and O
is O
related O
to O
eigenvalue O
decomposition O
. O

In O
addition O
, O
YYT O
, O
which O
is O
in O
the O
middle O
of O
XTYYTX O
, O
is O
an O
N O
x O
N O
positive O
semi-definite O
matrix O
. O

Based O
on O
the O
properties O
of O
positive O
semi-definite O
matrices O
, O
YYT O
may O
be O
replaced O
by O
ZTZ O
, O
where O
Z O
is O
a O
square O
matrix O
that O
satisfies O
YYT O
= O
ZTZ O
. O

XTYYTX O
can O
then O
be O
rewritten O
as O
( O
ZX O
) O
T O
( O
ZX O
) O
. O

Based O
on O
the O
fact O
that O
eig O
( O
ATA O
) O
is O
equivalent O
to O
eig O
( O
AAT O
) O
, O
we O
can O
calculate O
matrices O
U O
, O
V O
, O
and O
Δ O
using O
a O
substantially O
reduced O
number O
of O
dimensions O
( O
i.e. O
, O
46 O
× O
46 O
) O
. O

When O
the O
SVD O
is O
applied O
, O
the O
ith O
column O
vectors O
of O
U O
and O
V O
represent O
voxel O
values O
in O
FC O
maps O
of O
the O
REST O
and O
ADR O
runs O
such O
that O
the O
two O
maps O
maximally O
co-vary O
with O
each O
other O
across O
participants O
. O

Therefore O
, O
the O
column O
vectors O
of O
U O
and O
V O
may O
be O
interpreted O
as O
optimal O
combinations O
of O
FC O
patterns O
during O
the O
two O
conditions O
. O

Each O
combination O
of O
the O
two O
FC O
patterns O
is O
associated O
with O
a O
scalar O
singular O
value O
represented O
in O
the O
diagonal O
of O
matrix O
Δ O
, O
which O
reflects O
the O
covariance O
between O
the O
two O
original O
FC O
maps O
and O
is O
explained O
by O
the O
composite O
component O
. O

See O
Appendix O
B O
for O
further O
details O
of O
PLS-C. O
To O
assess O
the O
statistical O
significance O
of O
each O
of O
the O
composite O
components O
, O
we O
performed O
permutation O
tests O
for O
the O
top O
10 O
composite O
components O
, O
which O
accounted O
for O
42.6 O
% O
of O
the O
total O
covariance O
. O

In O
each O
cycle O
of O
permutation O
, O
we O
randomly O
reordered O
the O
rows O
of O
data O
matrix O
X O
, O
such O
that O
the O
original O
link O
between O
X O
and O
Y O
was O
destroyed O
. O

The O
permutation O
was O
repeated O
10,000 O
times O
to O
obtain O
a O
null O
distribution O
of O
singular O
values O
at O
each O
component O
. O

Measured O
values O
falling O
outside O
the O
95 O
% O
probability O
of O
the O
null O
distribution O
were O
regarded O
as O
significant O
components O
( O
p O
< O
0.05 O
) O
. O

For O
statistically O
significant O
components O
, O
we O
used O
a O
two-sample O
t-test O
to O
determine O
whether O
there O
were O
significant O
group O
differences O
between O
HCs O
and O
patients O
with O
SCZ O
in O
individual O
component O
loadings O
. O

In O
the O
composite O
component O
maps O
, O
contribution O
and O
reliability O
( O
statistical O
significance O
) O
of O
FC O
strength O
at O
each O
voxel O
was O
estimated O
by O
bootstrap O
resampling O
for O
cross-validation O
of O
the O
derived O
pattern O
of O
FC O
. O

Bootstrapping O
was O
performed O
by O
randomly O
resampling O
50 O
participants O
with O
replacement O
( O
rows O
of O
data O
matrices O
X O
and O
Y O
) O
. O

The O
resampled O
data O
were O
subjected O
to O
SVD O
to O
generate O
sampling O
distributions O
for O
each O
voxel O
in O
the O
singular O
vectors O
. O

The O
bootstrap O
distribution O
was O
used O
to O
estimate O
the O
standard O
error O
for O
each O
voxel O
. O

Finally O
, O
bootstrap O
ratios O
were O
calculated O
for O
each O
voxel O
in O
U O
and O
V O
by O
dividing O
the O
voxel O
values O
from O
the O
singular O
vector O
by O
their O
bootstrap-estimated O
standard O
error O
. O

We O
used O
a O
statistical O
threshold O
of O
p O
< O
0.05 O
for O
both O
positive O
and O
negative O
values O
( O
| O
z O
| O
> O
2.0 O
) O
. O

In O
order O
to O
further O
examine O
whether O
and O
how O
the O
identified O
composite O
components O
are O
influenced O
by O
a O
particular O
model O
within O
the O
PLS O
framework O
, O
we O
also O
performed O
PLS O
Regression O
( O
PLS-R O
) O
, O
which O
is O
another O
PLS O
model O
with O
the O
assumption O
that O
the O
FC O
patterns O
during O
one O
condition O
contain O
components O
that O
are O
predictive O
of O
the O
FC O
patterns O
during O
another O
condition O
. O

In O
contrast O
to O
PLS-C O
, O
where O
X O
and O
Y O
are O
