interchangeable O
, O
PLS-R O
aims O
to O
build O
a O
model O
that O
predicts O
Y O
( O
ADR O
) O
from O
X O
( O
REST O
) O
while O
avoiding O
the O
multicollinearity O
of O
variables O
. O

Here O
, O
X O
and O
Y O
are O
modeled O
to O
be O
decomposed O
into O
TPT O
and O
UQT O
, O
respectively O
, O
where O
P O
and O
Q O
are O
composite O
FC O
maps O
for O
X O
and O
Y O
, O
respectively O
, O
and O
T O
and O
U O
are O
matrices O
of O
latent O
variables O
for O
X O
and O
Y O
, O
respectively O
. O

This O
is O
because O
we O
assume O
that O
U O
can O
be O
predicted O
by O
T O
, O
U O
= O
TB O
, O
where O
B O
is O
the O
diagonal O
matrix O
. O

Formally O
, O
this O
yields O
the O
prediction O
model O
as O
follows O
: O
Y O
= O
TBQT O
= O
XWPLS O
, O
with O
WPLS O
= O
PT O
+ O
BQT O
, O
where O
PT O
+ O
is O
the O
Moore-Penrose O
pseudo-inverse O
of O
PT O
. O

We O
estimated O
the O
parameters O
T O
, O
B O
, O
U O
, O
Q O
, O
and O
WPLS O
using O
non-linear O
iterative O
partial O
least O
squares O
( O
NIPALS O
) O
, O
as O
proposed O
by O
. O

See O
Appendix O
B O
for O
further O
details O
of O
PLS-R O
. O

The O
number O
of O
latent O
components O
is O
determined O
based O
on O
Krzanowski O
's O
W O
criterion O
with O
leave-one-out O
cross-validation O
( O
LOOCV O
) O
. O

Krzanowski O
's O
W O
is O
calculated O
as O
follows O
: O
where O
The O
Predicted O
Estimated O
Sum O
of O
Squares O
was O
used O
as O
the O
measure O
of O
the O
quality O
of O
the O
prediction O
. O

In O
the O
equation O
above O
, O
is O
the O
predicted O
value O
of O
y O
from O
N-1 O
samples O
and O
N O
is O
the O
number O
of O
participants O
. O

k O
was O
the O
optimal O
number O
of O
latent O
components O
when O
Wk O
had O
a O
maximum O
value O
within O
the O
set O
of O
Wk O
values O
> O
1 O
. O

The O
optimal O
number O
of O
composite O
components O
was O
4 O
, O
as O
determined O
using O
Krzanowski O
's O
W O
with O
LOOCV O
. O

As O
in O
PLS-C O
, O
bootstrapping O
was O
used O
to O
estimate O
the O
contribution O
and O
reliability O
( O
statistical O
significance O
) O
of O
FC O
strength O
at O
each O
voxel O
of O
the O
identified O
component O
maps O
. O

Bootstrapping O
was O
performed O
by O
randomly O
resampling O
50 O
participants O
with O
replacement O
. O

The O
resampled O
data O
were O
subjected O
to O
NIPALS O
to O
generate O
a O
sampling O
distribution O
for O
each O
voxel O
in O
the O
composite O
components O
. O

The O
bootstrap O
distribution O
was O
used O
to O
estimate O
the O
standard O
error O
for O
each O
voxel O
. O

Finally O
, O
the O
bootstrap O
ratio O
was O
calculated O
for O
each O
voxel O
in O
P O
and O
Q O
by O
dividing O
the O
voxel O
values O
from O
the O
singular O
vector O
by O
their O
bootstrap-estimated O
standard O
error O
. O

We O
used O
a O
statistical O
threshold O
of O
p O
< O
0.05 O
for O
both O
positive O
and O
negative O
values O
( O
| O
z O
| O
> O
2.0 O
) O
. O

Post-hoc O
correlation O
analyses O
using O
clinical O
scores O
The O
PLS-C O
and O
PLS-R O
analyses O
identified O
composite O
component O
maps O
with O
significant O
group O
differences O
for O
REST O
and O
ADR O
. O

In O
order O
to O
identify O
brain O
regions O
in O
the O
composite O
component O
maps O
whose O
altered O
FCs O
are O
specifically O
associated O
with O
the O
severities O
of O
clinical O
symptoms O
, O
we O
performed O
post-hoc O
voxel-wise O
correlation O
analyses O
using O
the O
individual O
FC O
maps O
( O
seed O
: O
left O
MTG/STS O
) O
and O
clinical O
scores O
on O
either O
PANSS O
( O
P O
) O
or O
AHRS O
. O

Correlation O
analyses O
were O
performed O
separately O
for O
REST O
and O
ADR O
. O

In O
order O
to O
restrict O
the O
analyses O
into O
voxels O
identified O
by O
the O
PLS O
analyses O
, O
we O
generated O
a O
binary O
inclusive O
mask O
for O
both O
REST O
and O
ADR O
. O

For O
the O
inclusive O
mask O
for O
REST O
, O
we O
generated O
a O
binary O
map O
for O
supra-threshold O
voxels O
of O
the O
REST O
component O
map O
identified O
using O
PLS-C O
, O
and O
a O
binary O
map O
for O
the O
REST O
component O
map O
identified O
using O
PLS-R. O
We O
then O
generated O
a O
binary O
image O
by O
combining O
the O
two O
binary O
maps O
. O

The O
voxel-level O
threshold O
was O
set O
to O
p O
< O
0.001 O
. O

In O
order O
to O
achieve O
a O
cluster-level O
corrected O
p O
< O
0.05 O
, O
we O
determined O
the O
spatial O
extent O
threshold O
using O
3dFWHMx O
and O
3dClustSim O
. O

The O
spatial O
extent O
thresholds O
were O
determined O
to O
be O
78 O
and O
69 O
for O
correlation O
with O
PANSS O
( O
P O
) O
and O
AHRS O
, O
respectively O
. O

The O
same O
procedures O
were O
used O
for O
ADR O
. O

Using O
3dFWHMx O
and O
3dClustSim O
, O
we O
found O
spatial O
extent O
thresholds O
of O
51 O
and O
47 O
for O
correlation O
with O
PANSS O
( O
P O
) O
and O
AHRS O
, O
respectively O
. O

Hallucination- O
and O
speech-specific O
hypercoupling O
in O
frontotemporal O
auditory O
and O
language O
networks O
in O
schizophrenia O
using O
combined O
task-based O
fMRI O
data O
: O
an O
fBIRN O
study O
Hypercoupling O
of O
activity O
in O
speech-perception-specific O
brain O
networks O
has O
been O
proposed O
to O
play O
a O
role O
in O
the O
generation O
of O
auditory-verbal O
hallucinations O
( O
AVHs O
) O
in O
schizophrenia O
; O
however O
, O
it O
is O
unclear O
whether O
this O
hypercoupling O
extends O
to O
non-verbal O
auditory O
perception O
. O

We O
investigated O
this O
by O
comparing O
schizophrenia O
patients O
with O
and O
without O
AVHs O
, O
and O
healthy O
controls O
, O
on O
task-based O
functional O
magnetic O
resonance O
imaging O
( O
fMRI O
) O
data O
combining O
verbal O
speech O
perception O
( O
SP O
) O
, O
inner O
verbal O
thought O
generation O
( O
VTG O
) O
, O
and O
non-verbal O
auditory O
oddball O
detection O
( O
AO O
) O
. O

Data O
from O
two O
previously-published O
fMRI O
studies O
were O
simultaneously O
analyzed O
using O
group O
constrained O
principal O
component O
analysis O
for O
fMRI O
( O
group O
fMRI-CPCA O
) O
, O
which O
allowed O
for O
comparison O
of O
task-related O
functional O
brain O
networks O
across O
groups O
and O
tasks O
while O
holding O
the O
brain O
networks O
under O
study O
constant O
, O
leading O
to O
determination O
of O
the O
degree O
to O
which O
networks O
are O
common O
to O
verbal O
and O
non-verbal O
perception O
conditions O
, O
and O
which O
show O
coordinated O
hyperactivity O
in O
hallucinations O
. O

Three O
functional O
brain O
networks O
emerged O
: O
( O
1 O
) O
auditory-motor O
, O
( O
2 O
) O
language O
processing O
, O
and O
( O
3 O
) O
default-mode O
( O
DMN O
) O
networks O
. O

Combining O
the O
AO O
and O
sentence O
tasks O
allowed O
the O
auditory-motor O
and O
language O
networks O
to O
separately O
emerge O
, O
whereas O
they O
were O
aggregated O
when O
individual O
tasks O
were O
analyzed O
. O

AVH O
patients O
showed O
greater O
coordinated O
activity O
( O
deactivity O
for O
DMN O
regions O
) O
than O
non-AVH O
patients O
during O
SP O
in O
all O
networks O
, O
but O
this O
did O
not O
extend O
to O
VTG O
or O
AO O
. O

This O
suggests O
that O
the O
hypercoupling O
in O
AVH O
patients O
in O
speech-perception-related O
brain O
networks O
is O
specific O
to O
perceived O
speech O
, O
and O
does O
not O
extend O
to O
perceived O
non-speech O
or O
inner O
verbal O
thought O
generation O
. O

Methods O
Participants O
Participants O
were O
schizophrenia O
patients O
and O
healthy O
controls O
from O
two O
functional O
magnetic O
resonance O
imaging O
( O
fMRI O
) O
datasets O
. O

The O
first O
dataset O
consisted O
of O
27 O
healthy O
controls O
, O
11 O
non-AVH O
, O
and O
12 O
AVH O
schizophrenia O
patients O
who O
performed O
a O
verbal O
sentence O
task O
including O
speech O
perception O
and O
inner O
verbal O
thought O
generation O
conditions O
. O

Mean O
illness O
duration O
was O
14.05 O
years O
( O
SD O
= O
10.14 O
) O
, O
and O
all O
but O
one O
patient O
was O
currently O
taking O
antipsychotic O
medication O
. O

Nineteen O
patients O
were O
taking O
an O
atypical O
antipsychotic O
, O
and O
two O
were O
taking O
a O
typical O
antipsychotic O
, O
as O
their O
primary O
medication O
. O

Fourteen O
patients O
were O
also O
taking O
a O
second O
antipsychotic O
medication O
( O
2 O
typical O
, O
12 O
atypical O
) O
, O
and O
four O
were O
taking O
a O
third O
atypical O
medication O
( O
1 O
missing O
data O
) O
. O

Chlorpromazine O
equivalent O
dosages O
were O
available O
for O
14 O
patients O
: O
mean O
= O
1018.57 O
; O
SD O
= O
2402.92 O
. O

Symptoms O
were O
assessed O
using O
the O
Signs O
of O
Symptoms O
of O
Psychotic O
Illness O
( O
SSPI O
) O
, O
which O
is O
scored O
on O
a O
5-point O
scale O
corresponding O
to O
severity O
of O
hallucinations O
( O
0 O
= O
absent O
, O
1 O
= O
vague O
descriptions O
of O
hallucinations O
, O
2 O
= O
hallucinations O
that O
the O
patient O
accepts O
as O
arising O
from O
within O
his/her O
own O
mind O
, O
3 O
= O
definite O
hallucinations O
occurring O
occasionally O
[ O
e.g. O
, O
< O
once/day O
] O
, O
4 O
= O
definite O
hallucinations O
that O
are O
frequent O
and/or O
influence O
observable O
behaviour O
) O
. O

Patients O
scoring O
greater O
than O
2 O
on O
the O
hallucinations O
item O
were O
included O
in O
the O
AVH O
group O
. O

All O
patients O
experienced O
AVHs O
( O
i.e. O
, O
voices O
) O
, O
though O
two O
also O
experienced O
other O
auditory O
hallucinations O
, O
such O
as O
auditory O
distortions O
, O
simple O
noises O
, O
and O
music O
. O

Six O
patients O
also O
experienced O
multimodal O
hallucinations O
( O
6 O
tactile O
, O
3 O
visual O
, O
1 O
olfactory O
) O
. O

All O
participants O
were O
screened O
for O
MRI O
compatibility O
and O
gave O
written O
informed O
consent O
prior O
to O
participation O
. O

Experimental O
procedures O
were O
approved O
as O
part O
of O
a O
larger O
study O
by O
the O
University O
of O
British O
Columbia O
clinical O
research O
ethics O
board O
. O

The O
second O
dataset O
was O
acquired O
from O
the O
publicly O
available O
fBIRN O
phase O
II O
multisite O
study O
, O
which O
consists O
of O
data O
collected O
at O
six O
sites O
across O
the O
United O
States O
of O
America O
: O
Duke/UNC O
, O
Brigham O
and O
Women O
’ O
s O
Hospital O
, O
Massachusetts O
General O
Hospital O
, O
University O
of O
California O
– O
Irvine O
, O
University O
of O
New O
Mexico O
, O
and O
Yale O
. O

Data O
were O
downloaded O
from O
the O
fBIRN O
Data O
Repository O
, O
Project O
Accession O
Number O
2007-BDR-6UHZ1 O
. O

The O
quality-controlled O
data O
set O
( O
see O
) O
included O
50 O
healthy O
controls O
, O
23 O
non-AVH O
, O
and O
35 O
AVH O
patients O
diagnosed O
with O
schizophrenia O
or O
schizoaffective O
disorder O
who O
completed O
an O
auditory O
oddball O
task O
. O

Patients O
’ O
symptoms O
were O
assessed O
using O
the O
Scale O
for O
the O
Assessment O
of O
Positive O
Symptoms O
( O
SAPS O
) O
, O
which O
is O
scored O
on O
a O
six-point O
scale O
from O
0 O
to O
5 O
in O
increasing O
severity O
: O
0 O
= O
none O
; O
1 O
= O
questionable O
; O
2 O
= O
mild O
( O
noises O
or O
single O
words O
, O
which O
only O
appear O
occasionally O
) O
; O
3 O
= O
moderate O
( O
clear O
evidence O
of O
voices O
occurring O
at O
least O
weekly O
) O
; O
4 O
= O
marked O
( O
clear O
evidence O
of O
voices O
occurring O
almost O
daily O
) O
; O
5 O
= O
severe O
( O
voices O
occur O
often O
daily O
) O
. O

As O
with O
the O
sentence O
task O
sample O
, O
patients O
scoring O
greater O
than O
2 O
on O
the O
hallucinations O
item O
were O
included O
in O
the O
AVH O
group O
. O

Observation O
of O
scores O
on O
the O
SAPS O
items O
Voices O
Commenting O
and O
Voices O
Conversing O
confirmed O
that O
most O
hallucinating O
patients O
experienced O
AVHs O
; O
however O
, O
the O
presence O
of O
AVHs O
could O
not O
be O
confirmed O
in O
eight O
patients O
who O
reported O
auditory O
hallucinations O
, O
as O
the O
AVH-specific O
items O
were O
not O
endorsed O
or O
were O
scored O
below O
the O
same O
cut-off O
value O
of O
2 O
. O

Nineteen O
patients O
also O
reported O
multimodal O
hallucinations O
( O
10 O
somatic-tactile O
, O
6 O
olfactory O
, O
13 O
visual O
) O
. O

All O
patients O
were O
stable O
and O
had O
no O
changes O
in O
their O
medications O
in O
the O
two O
months O
prior O
to O
testing O
; O
however O
, O
additional O
information O
regarding O
medication O
and O
illness O
history O
was O
not O
available O
, O
which O
precluded O
us O
from O
comparing O
the O
two O
samples O
on O
these O
measures O
. O

All O
fBIRN O
sites O
received O
local O
Institutional O
Review O
Board O
approval O
. O

Table O
1 O
shows O
demographic O
information O
for O
each O
group O
, O
for O
the O
auditory O
oddball O
and O
sentence O
tasks O
separately O
. O

There O
were O
no O
significant O
differences O
between O
groups O
on O
age O
, O
gender O
or O
handedness O
for O
either O
task O
. O

Experimental O
Design O
Sentence O
Task O
Participants O
were O
presented O
with O
a O
noun O
( O
object O
) O
and O
its O
corresponding O
image O
( O
e.g. O
, O
Table O
) O
and O
instructed O
to O
either O
listen O
to O
( O
speech O
perception O
condition O
; O
SP O
) O
or O
mentally O
generate O
( O
inner O
verbal O
thought O
generation O
condition O
; O
VTG O
) O
a O
simple O
definition O
of O
the O
word O
( O
e.g. O
, O
“ O
Something O
you O
eat O
dinner O
on O
” O
; O
see O
Figures O
1A O
and O
1B O
, O
respectively O
) O
. O

The O
SP O
and O
VTG O
conditions O
were O
presented O
in O
blocks O
consisting O
of O
15 O
trials O
each O
( O
30 O
trials O
total O
for O
each O
condition O
across O
two O
runs O
) O
, O
with O
an O
inter-trial O
interval O
( O
ITI O
) O
between O
stimuli O
, O
and O
a O
60s O
rest O
break O
between O
the O
two O
conditions O
. O

The O
ITI O
was O
exponential O
to O
optimize O
deconvolution O
of O
the O
blood O
oxygenation O
level O
dependent O
( O
BOLD O
) O
signal O
, O
and O
lasted O
from O
2 O
to O
20s O
( O
mean O
= O
4.46s O
) O
. O

Stimuli O
were O
randomly O
assigned O
to O
each O
condition O
for O
each O
participant O
separately O
. O

The O
conditions O
were O
cued O
with O
the O
words O
“ O
listen… O
” O
and O
“ O
something O
you… O
” O
presented O
under O
the O
images O
in O
the O
SP O
and O
VTG O
conditions O
, O
respectively O
, O
in O
order O
to O
ensure O
that O
at O
least O
some O
words O
were O
mentally O
generated O
on O
every O
trial O
, O
and O
to O
minimize O
any O
interpretational O
confounds O
between O
conditions O
. O

Following O
the O
experiment O
, O
participants O
were O
asked O
whether O
or O
not O
they O
experienced O
hallucinations O
during O
the O
scanning O
session O
. O

One O
patient O
reported O
active O
AVHs O
during O
the O
speech O
perception O
trials O
, O
and O
one O
patient O
reported O
tactile O
hallucinations O
during O
the O
thought O
generation O
trials O
( O
data O
were O
missing O
for O
two O
subjects O
) O
. O

fBIRN O
Auditory O
Oddball O
Task O
The O
two-tone O
AO O
task O
( O
Figure O
1C O
) O
involved O
listening O
to O
a O
series O
of O
tones O
and O
indicating O
with O
a O
button O
press O
when O
a O
target O
tone O
( O
i.e. O
, O
a O
tone O
deviating O
in O
frequency O
) O
was O
presented O
. O

Four O
runs O
of O
the O
auditory O
oddball O
task O
were O
completed O
in O
each O
of O
two O
sessions O
, O
leading O
to O
a O
total O
of O
eight O
runs O
per O
subject O
that O
each O
lasted O
280s O
. O

Each O
run O
began O
with O
15s O
of O
silence O
, O
followed O
by O
a O
series O
of O
tones O
lasting O
100ms O
each O
, O
with O
500ms O
interstimulus O
intervals O
between O
them O
; O
a O
15s O
period O
of O
silence O
indicated O
the O
end O
of O
each O
run O
. O

The O
majority O
of O
the O
tones O
( O
standard O
tones O
; O
95 O
% O
occurrence O
) O
were O
presented O
at O
a O
frequency O
of O
1000Hz O
and O
the O
remaining O
tones O
( O
target O
tones O
; O
5 O
% O
occurrence O
) O
were O
presented O
at O
a O
frequency O
of O
1200Hz O
. O

The O
latency O
between O
two O
target O
tones O
varied O
between O
6s O
and O
15s O
, O
allowing O
for O
deconvolution O
of O
the O
BOLD O
signal O
. O

Auditory O
stimuli O
were O
presented O
binaurally O
through O
headphones O
. O

Prior O
to O
the O
functional O
scan O
, O
participants O
adjusted O
right O
and O
left O
ear O
volumes O
to O
a O
test O
stimulus O
to O
ensure O
the O
tones O
could O
be O
heard O
over O
scanner O
noise O
. O

Participants O
were O
instructed O
to O
focus O
on O
a O
black O
fixation O
cross O
displayed O
on O
a O
grey O
screen O
throughout O
the O
run O
, O
and O
to O
respond O
with O
a O
button O
press O
when O
they O
heard O
the O
target O
tone O
. O

Stimuli O
were O
presented O
using O
E-Prime O
software O
( O
http O
: O
//www.pstnet.com/products/e-prime/ O
) O
. O

After O
the O
experiment O
, O
patients O
were O
asked O
whether O
they O
experienced O
hallucinations O
during O
the O
scanning O
session O
, O
with O
one O
patient O
reporting O
AVHs O
“ O
almost O
constantly O
” O
, O
one O
“ O
occasionally O
” O
, O
and O
one O
reporting O
visual O
hallucinations O
occasionally O
( O
data O
were O
missing O
for O
11 O
subjects O
) O
. O

Image O
Acquisition O
and O
Processing O
Imaging O
for O
the O
sentence O
task O
data O
was O
performed O
at O
the O
University O
of O
British O
Columbia O
MRI O
Research O
Centre O
using O
a O
Philips O
Achieva O
3.0 O
Tesla O
( O
T O
) O
MRI O
scanner O
with O
quasar O
dual O
gradients O
( O
maximum O
gradient O
amplitude O
, O
80mT/m O
; O
maximum O
slew O
rate O
, O
200 O
mT/m/s O
) O
. O

The O
participant O
’ O
s O
head O
was O
firmly O
secured O
using O
a O
customized O
head O
holder O
. O

Functional O
image O
volumes O
were O
collected O
using O
a O
T2 O
* O
-weighted O
gradient-echo O
spin O
pulse O
sequence O
with O
36 O
axial O
slices O
; O
thickness/gap O
, O
3/1 O
mm O
; O
matrix O
, O
80×80 O
; O
repetition O
time O
( O
TR O
) O
, O
2500 O
ms O
; O
echo O
time O
( O
TE O
) O
, O
30 O
ms O
; O
flip O
angle O
( O
FA O
) O
, O
90° O
, O
field O
of O
view O
( O
FOV O
) O
, O
240×240 O
mm O
, O
effectively O
covering O
the O
whole O
brain O
. O

352 O
images O
were O
acquired O
over O
two O
runs O
of O
approximately O
7 O
min O
and O
30 O
s O
each O
. O

Imaging O
for O
the O
fBIRN O
data O
was O
performed O
at O
five O
sites O
( O
one O
site O
was O
excluded O
during O
quality O
control O
) O
across O
the O
United O
States O
of O
America O
, O
for O
which O
imaging O
parameters O
were O
matched O
as O
closely O
as O
possible O
based O
on O
preliminary O
testing O
: O
27 O
slices O
if O
possible O
; O
thickness/gap O
= O
4mm/1mm O
; O
matrix O
= O
64×64 O
; O
repetition O
time O
( O
TR O
) O
= O
2000 O
ms O
; O
echo O
time O
( O
TE O
) O
= O
30ms O
( O
3T O
) O
/40ms O
( O
1.5T O
) O
; O
flip O
angle O
( O
FA O
) O
= O
90° O
; O
field O
of O
view O
( O
FOV O
) O
= O
22cm O
; O
voxel O
dimensions O
= O
3.4375 O
× O
3.4375 O
× O
4 O
mm O
) O
. O

One O
site O
( O
Duke/UNC O
) O
employed O
a O
spiral O
echo O
sequence O
, O
while O
all O
other O
sites O
used O
a O
single-shot O
EPI O
sequence O
. O

140 O
volumes O
were O
collected O
in O
each O
run O
lasting O
280s O
. O

Functional O
volumes O
for O
both O
datasets O
were O
pre-processed O
using O
Statistical O
Parametric O
Mapping O
8 O
( O
SPM8 O
; O
Wellcome O
Trust O
Centre O
for O
Neuroimaging O
, O
UK O
) O
. O

For O
each O
participant O
, O
each O
functional O
run O
was O
realigned O
, O
normalized O
to O
the O
Montreal O
Neurological O
Institute O
( O
MNI O
) O
EPI O
brain O
template O
( O
voxel O
size O
= O
2 O
mm3 O
) O
, O
and O
spatially O
smoothed O
with O
an O
8mm O
full O
width O
at O
half O
maximum O
Gaussian O
filter O
. O

Following O
preprocessing O
, O
the O
SPM O
realignment O
parameters O
were O
examined O
, O
and O
any O
runs O
exceeding O
3mm O
translation O
or O
3° O
rotation O
were O
excluded O
from O
further O
analysis O
. O

This O
led O
to O
the O
removal O
of O
29 O
runs O
in O
the O
fBIRN O
sample O
. O

Additional O
quality O
control O
procedures O
for O
the O
fBIRN O
sample O
included O
removing O
runs O
for O
images O
that O
showed O
artifacts O
and/or O
led O
to O
errors O
during O
preprocessing O
, O
and O
for O
runs O
in O
which O
there O
were O
few O
responses O
or O
a O
high O
false O
positive O
rate O
, O
suggesting O
participants O
were O
not O
engaged O
in O
the O
task O
. O

Further O
information O
on O
this O
quality O
control O
can O
be O
found O
in O
previous O
work O
. O

Data O
Analysis O
Group O
fMRI-CPCA O
fMRI O
data O
analysis O
was O
carried O
out O
using O
constrained O
principal O
component O
analysis O
for O
fMRI O
to O
compare O
groups O
( O
group O
fMRI-CPCA O
) O
with O
orthogonal O
rotation O
( O
; O
) O
. O

The O
theory O
and O
proofs O
for O
CPCA O
are O
detailed O
in O
previously O
published O
work O
. O

The O
fMRI-CPCA O
application O
is O
available O
on-line O
, O
free O
of O
charge O
( O
www.nitrc.org/projects/fmricpca O
) O
. O

fMRI-CPCA O
computes O
( O
via O
PCA O
) O
components O
representing O
functional O
brain O
networks O
on O
blood-oxygen O
level-dependent O
( O
BOLD O
) O
signal O
for O
which O
variance O
has O
been O
constrained O
( O
via O
multivariate O
multiple O
regression O
) O
to O
that O
predictable O
from O
task O
timing O
, O
and O
provides O
both O
spatial O
( O
dominant O
brain O
regions O
) O
and O
temporal O
( O
hemodynamic O
response O
shapes O
) O
information O
for O
each O
task-based O
functional O
brain O
network O
. O

When O
applied O
to O
multiple O
datasets O
, O
group O
fMRI-CPCA O
allows O
for O
visualization O
of O
task-common O
and O
task-specific O
networks O
, O
through O
observation O
of O
spatial O
and O
temporal O
replication O
across O
tasks O
within O
each O
network O
. O

Group O
fMRI-CPCA O
involved O
the O
preparation O
of O
two O
matrices O
: O
( O
1 O
) O
a O
data O
matrix O
( O
Z O
) O
, O
containing O
the O
BOLD O
time O
series O
of O
each O
voxel O
, O
with O
one O
column O
per O
voxel O
and O
one O
row O
per O
whole O
brain O
scan O
; O
and O
( O
2 O
) O
the O
design O
matrix O
( O
G O
) O
, O
containing O
finite O
impulse O
response O
( O
FIR O
) O
models O
of O
the O
expected O
BOLD O
response O
to O
the O
timing O
onsets O
of O
stimulus O
presentations O
( O
i.e. O
, O
pictures O
for O
the O
sentence O
task O
, O
target O
tones O
for O
the O
oddball O
task O
) O
. O

In O
order O
to O
compare O
functional O
brain O
networks O
across O
experiments O
, O
data O
from O
all O
tasks O
( O
SP O
, O
VTG O
, O
AO O
) O
were O
included O
in O
Z O
, O
leading O
to O
a O
matrix O
of O
115040 O
rows O
( O
158 O
subjects O
× O
up O
to O
11 O
runs O
× O
up O
to O
176 O
volumes O
) O
and O
585,930 O
columns O
( O
voxels O
in O
2mm3 O
resolution O
) O
. O

Each O
column O
contained O
normalized O
and O
smoothed O
activations O
over O
all O
scans O
, O
with O
subjects O
, O
runs O
, O
and O
scans O
stacked O
vertically O
to O
produce O
Z O
. O

In O
G O
, O
a O
value O
1 O
was O
placed O
in O
rows O
for O
which O
BOLD O
signal O
amplitude O
was O
to O
be O
estimated O
, O
and O
the O
value O
0 O
in O
all O
other O
rows O
, O
creating O
“ O
mini O
boxcar O
” O
functions O
. O

The O
columns O
of O
G O
code O
7 O
poststimulus O
time O
points O
for O
each O
condition O
( O
SP O
, O
VTG O
, O
AO O
) O
for O
each O
of O
the O
( O
combined O
) O
158 O
subjects O
, O
totaling O
3318 O
columns O
( O
7 O
× O
3 O
× O
158 O
= O
3318 O
) O
. O

These O
time O
points O
reflect O
different O
poststimulus O
time O
points O
in O
each O
study O
due O
to O
the O
difference O
in O
TR O
across O
studies O
, O
and O
are O
converted O
to O
seconds O
in O
the O
figures O
and O
results O
section O
to O
facilitate O
interpretation O
. O

Group O
fMRI-CPCA O
proceeds O
in O
two O
steps O
. O

First O
, O
the O
data O
matrix O
, O
Z O
, O
is O
regressed O
onto O
the O
design O
matrix O
, O
G O
, O
which O
partitions O
the O
overall O
variance O
into O
predicted O
and O
residual O
scores O
. O

The O
matrix O
predicted O
scores O
, O
which O
reflects O
variance O
in O
BOLD O
signal O
that O
is O
predictable O
from O
task O
timing O
, O
is O
then O
submitted O
to O
a O
principal O
component O
analysis O
( O
PCA O
) O
, O
resulting O
in O
task-specific O
functional O
brain O
networks O
. O

Relation O
to O
Experimental O
Conditions O
Group O
fMRI-CPCA O
produces O
predictor O
weights O
for O
each O
combination O
of O
subject O
, O
task O
condition O
, O
and O
poststimulus O
time O
. O

These O
predictor O
weights O
, O
which O
provide O
estimates O
of O
the O
engagement O
of O
functional O
networks O
, O
can O
be O
analyzed O
statistically O
to O
determine O
whether O
or O
not O
they O
reflect O
reliable O
and O
biologically O
plausible O
HDR O
shapes O
, O
and O
whether O
differences O
between O
groups O
and/or O
task O
conditions O
exist O
within O
each O
network O
. O

These O
analyses O
were O
carried O
out O
for O
each O
task O
condition O
separately O
as O
three O
3 O
× O
7 O
× O
3 O
mixed-model O
ANOVAs O
( O
one O
each O
for O
SP O
, O
VTG O
, O
and O
AO O
) O
, O
with O
the O
within-subjects O
factors O
of O
Component O
( O
3 O
components O
were O
extracted O
) O
and O
Poststimulus O
Time O
( O
7 O
whole O
brain O
scans O
after O
stimulus O
onset O
) O
, O
and O
the O
between-subjects O
factor O
of O
Group O
( O
control O
, O
non-AVH O
, O
AVH O
) O
. O

Significant O
three-way O
interactions O
were O
followed O
up O
with O
separate O
7 O
× O
3 O
ANOVAs O
for O
each O
component O
, O
and O
significant O
two-way O
interactions O
were O
followed O
up O
with O
simple O
contrasts O
comparing O
each O
Group O
pair O
at O
each O
level O
of O
Poststimulus O
Time O
. O

Tests O
of O
sphericity O
were O
carried O
out O
, O
and O
Greenhouse-Geisser O
adjustment O
in O
degrees O
of O
freedom O
for O
any O
analyses O
in O
which O
the O
assumption O
was O
violated O
did O
not O
affect O
interpretation O
of O
the O
results O
; O
therefore O
, O
the O
original O
degrees O
of O
free O
are O
reported O
below O
. O

Effect O
sizes O
( O
partial O
eta O
squared O
, O
η2p O
) O
are O
displayed O
. O

NICOTINE O
ABSTINENCE O
INFLUENCES O
THE O
CALCULATION O
OF O
SALIENCE O
IN O
DISCRETE O
INSULAR O
CIRCUITS O
Background O
Insular O
subdivisions O
show O
distinct O
patterns O
of O
resting O
state O
functional O
connectivity O
( O
rsFC O
) O
with O
specific O
brain O
regions O
, O
each O
with O
different O
functional O
significance O
. O

Seeds O
in O
these O
subdivisions O
are O
employed O
to O
characterize O
the O
effects O
of O
acute O
nicotine O
abstinence O
on O
rsFC O
between O
insula O
subdivisions O
and O
brain O
networks O
implicated O
in O
addiction O
and O
attentional O
control O
. O

Methods O
In O
a O
within O
subjects O
design O
, O
resting-state O
BOLD O
data O
were O
collected O
from O
treatment-seeking O
smokers O
( O
n=20 O
) O
following O
smoking O
satiety O
and O
again O
following O
48 O
hours O
of O
nicotine O
abstinence O
. O

Three O
right O
hemisphere O
insular O
regions O
of O
interest O
( O
dorsal O
, O
ventral O
, O
and O
posterior O
) O
served O
as O
seeds O
for O
analyses O
. O

Indices O
of O
both O
static O
and O
dynamic O
rsFC O
were O
obtained O
and O
correlated O
with O
indices O
of O
subjective O
withdrawal O
and O
behavioral O
performance O
. O

Results O
Abstinence-induced O
physiological O
, O
subjective O
, O
and O
cognitive O
differences O
were O
observed O
. O

Overall O
dynamic O
rsFC O
was O
reduced O
during O
abstinence O
, O
and O
circuits O
containing O
each O
insular O
seed O
showed O
changes O
in O
rsFC O
as O
a O
function O
of O
nicotine O
abstinence O
. O

Specifically O
, O
dorsal O
and O
posterior O
insular O
connections O
to O
the O
default O
mode O
and O
salience O
networks O
were O
enhanced O
, O
while O
a O
previously O
undescribed O
ventral O
insular O
connection O
to O
the O
executive O
control O
network O
was O
reduced O
. O

Further O
, O
static O
rsFC O
was O
significantly O
correlated O
with O
subjective O
ratings O
of O
aversive O
affect O
and O
withdrawal O
in O
the O
modified O
ventral O
and O
posterior O
insular-seeded O
circuits O
. O

Conclusions O
As O
predicted O
, O
divergent O
connections O
between O
insula O
subdivisions O
and O
anticorrelated O
resting O
brain O
networks O
were O
observed O
during O
abstinence O
. O

These O
changes O
reflect O
an O
attentional O
bias O
toward O
aversive O
affective O
processing O
and O
not O
directly O
away O
from O
exogenous O
cognitive O
processing O
, O
suggesting O
a O
coordinated O
modulation O
of O
circuits O
associated O
with O
interoceptive O
and O
affective O
processing O
that O
instantiates O
an O
aversive O
state O
during O
nicotine O
abstinence O
. O

METHODS O
Participants O
Twenty O
smoking O
cessation O
treatment-seeking O
participants O
completed O
all O
experimental O
procedures O
. O

Participants O
were O
required O
to O
be O
right-handed O
, O
18–60 O
years O
of O
age O
, O
free O
of O
active O
drug O
or O
alcohol O
abuse/dependence O
( O
other O
than O
nicotine O
) O
, O
report O
no O
current O
psychiatric O
or O
neurological O
disorders O
, O
and O
have O
no O
contraindications O
for O
magnetic O
resonance O
imaging O
( O
MRI O
) O
( O
Table O
1 O
) O
. O

Written O
informed O
consent O
was O
obtained O
in O
accordance O
with O
the O
NIDA-IRP O
Institutional O
Review O
Board O
. O

Experimental O
Design O
In O
this O
longitudinal O
, O
within-subjects O
design O
, O
each O
participant O
completed O
two O
MR O
scanning O
sessions O
, O
one O
during O
ad O
lib O
sated O
smoking O
, O
followed O
by O
an O
acute O
abstinence O
scan O
with O
last O
cigarette O
~48 O
hours O
prior O
to O
scan O
. O

As O
participants O
were O
enrolled O
in O
a O
smoking O
cessation O
protocol O
, O
the O
order O
of O
the O
two O
scans O
was O
fixed O
, O
with O
the O
sated O
scan O
preceding O
the O
abstinent O
scan O
by O
an O
average O
of O
67 O
days O
( O
median O
28 O
days O
) O
. O

( O
See O
supplement O
for O
general O
procedures O
) O
Behavioral O
task O
measure O
Following O
brief O
medical O
assessment O
, O
participants O
completed O
a O
12-minute O
rapid O
visual O
information O
processing O
( O
RVIP O
) O
task O
administered O
at O
a O
computer O
outside O
the O
MRI O
scanner O
to O
assess O
sustained O
attention O
processing O
( O
See O
supplement O
for O
task O
details O
) O
. O

Subjective O
withdrawal O
measure O
Directly O
before O
each O
scanning O
session O
( O
sated O
and O
abstinent O
) O
, O
subjective O
ratings O
of O
withdrawal-related O
symptoms O
were O
assessed O
via O
the O
Wisconsin O
Smoking O
Withdrawal O
Scale O
( O
WSWS O
) O
, O
a O
28 O
item O
self-report O
test O
comprised O
of O
7 O
subscales O
( O
Anger O
, O
Anxiety O
, O
Concentration O
, O
Craving O
, O
Hunger O
, O
Sadness O
, O
Sleep O
) O
, O
and O
TOTAL O
score O
. O

As O
pre-scan O
procedures O
generally O
took O
up O
to O
120 O
min O
, O
participants O
were O
given O
a O
< O
10 O
min O
smoking O
break O
immediately O
prior O
to O
the O
withdrawal O
assessment O
and O
MRI O
scan O
during O
the O
sated O
scan O
session O
only O
. O

MRI O
Scanning O
Following O
WSWS O
administration O
, O
participants O
immediately O
entered O
the O
scanner O
and O
completed O
an O
8-min O
, O
eyes O
open O
resting O
scan O
at O
onset O
of O
a O
longer O
scan O
session O
which O
also O
included O
several O
cognitive O
tasks O
( O
see O
) O
. O

( O
See O
supplement O
for O
MRI O
data O
acquisition O
and O
preprocessing O
parameters O
) O
Abstinence-Specific O
Procedures O
Upon O
completion O
of O
the O
sated O
scan O
session O
, O
participants O
began O
weekly O
meetings O
with O
a O
cessation O
counselor O
who O
, O
together O
with O
the O
participant O
, O
set O
a O
target O
quit O
date O
and O
time O
for O
completion O
of O
the O
48-hour O
abstinence O
period O
and O
scan O
session O
. O

DATA O
ANALYSIS O
Behavioral O
data O
RVIP O
task O
performance O
was O
assessed O
via O
sensitivity O
index O
, O
d′=Z O
( O
hit O
rate O
) O
-Z O
( O
false O
alarm O
rate O
) O
. O

SESSION O
( O
abstinence O
( O
− O
) O
sated O
) O
effects O
were O
calculated O
via O
paired O
t-test O
of O
RVIP O
d′ O
values O
. O

Subjective O
Ratings O
Withdrawal O
was O
assessed O
via O
WSWS O
scores O
for O
each O
scanning O
session O
. O

SESSION O
( O
abstinence O
( O
− O
) O
sated O
) O
effects O
were O
calculated O
via O
paired O
t-test O
, O
corrected O
for O
multiple O
comparisons O
based O
on O
the O
7 O
subscales O
and O
total O
score O
assessed O
( O
p-corrected O
< O
0.05/8 O
= O
0.00625 O
) O
. O

Resting-State O
Functional O
Connectivity O
Single-subject O
analysis O
For O
each O
subject O
, O
correlation O
coefficient O
( O
CC O
) O
images O
were O
computed O
by O
correlating O
each O
voxel O
’ O
s O
motion-censored O
time O
course O
with O
a O
reference O
time O
course O
from O
the O
3 O
right O
insula O
seeds O
( O
Dorsal O
( O
DOR O
) O
, O
Ventral O
( O
VEN O
) O
, O
and O
Posterior O
( O
POS O
) O
) O
defined O
via O
probabilistic O
voxel O
maps O
created O
by O
Chang O
et O
al O
.. O
Any O
voxel O
with O
> O
85 O
% O
inclusion O
probability O
in O
each O
insular O
subdivision O
was O
included O
in O
the O
mask O
for O
that O
subdivision O
, O
resulting O
in O
three O
non-overlapping O
insular O
subdivision O
seeds O
. O

( O
Fig O
1 O
, O
Table O
S1 O
) O
The O
resulting O
subject-level O
CC O
images O
were O
Fisher O
’ O
s O
Z-transformed O
( O
) O
to O
better O
approximate O
a O
normal O
distribution O
. O

In O
addition O
, O
as O
a O
post O
hoc O
test O
for O
potential O
hemispheric O
differences O
, O
right O
insula O
seed O
masks O
were O
reflected O
across O
the O
midline O
to O
left O
insula O
( O
Fig O
S2a O
) O
and O
similar O
subject-level O
CC O
images O
were O
computed O
. O

rsFC O
target O
network O
identification O
Seed O
based O
analyses O
were O
a O
priori O
constrained O
to O
voxels O
within O
each O
of O
the O
three O
functionally O
generated O
masks O
of O
large-scale O
brain O
networks O
consistently O
shown O
relevant O
to O
nicotine O
addiction O
: O
DMN O
, O
ECN O
, O
and O
SN O
. O

These O
brain O
network O
masks O
were O
identified O
via O
group-level O
independent O
component O
analysis O
( O
gICA O
) O
, O
resulting O
in O
voxel O
masks O
for O
each O
network O
( O
Fig O
1 O
, O
See O
Supplemental O
materials O
for O
gICA O
method O
details O
) O
. O

For O
each O
gICA-identified O
network O
, O
an O
individual O
mask O
of O
resultant O
voxels O
( O
Fig O
1 O
) O
was O
used O
in O
s-rsFC O
and O
d-rsFC O
analyses O
. O

Static O
rsFC O
analysis O
Paired O
t-tests O
of O
SESSION O
difference O
in O
s-rsFC O
strength O
between O
each O
of O
the O
3 O
insular O
seeds O
and O
voxels O
within O
each O
of O
the O
3 O
large-scale O
network O
masks O
were O
performed O
( O
i.e O
. O

seed-ECN O
voxels O
; O
seed-SN O
voxels O
; O
seed-DMN O
voxels O
) O
with O
correction O
for O
multiple O
comparisons O
( O
3 O
seeds O
* O
3 O
target O
networks O
, O
1 O
sided O
tests O
for O
DMN O
and O
ECN O
rsFC O
, O
2 O
sided O
tests O
for O
SN O
rsFC O
) O
and O
cluster-correction O
applied O
( O
p-voxel O
< O
0.0167 O
, O
p-corrected O
< O
0.05/9 O
= O
0.0056 O
for O
each O
test O
) O
. O

Post O
hoc O
tests O
for O
hemispheric O
differences O
employing O
left O
insula O
seeds O
were O
conducted O
with O
identical O
statistical O
corrections O
( O
p-voxel O
< O
0.0167 O
, O
p-corrected O
< O
0.0056 O
) O
. O

Dynamic O
rsFC O
analysis O
The O
three O
right O
insular O
seeds O
( O
DOR O
, O
VEN O
, O
POS O
) O
and O
the O
three O
brain O
network O
masks O
( O
ECN O
, O
DMN O
, O
SN O
) O
were O
resampled O
to O
4×4×4 O
mm O
voxel O
size O
to O
reduce O
computational O
load O
. O

Mean O
time O
series O
from O
insular O
seeds O
were O
extracted O
and O
used O
as O
seed O
time O
courses O
. O

D-rsFC O
between O
the O
3 O
insula O
seeds O
and O
3 O
brain O
network O
targets O
were O
estimated O
using O
a O
sliding O
window O
method O
. O

By O
sliding O
a O
Hamming O
window O
with O
window O
width O
of O
22 O
TRs O
( O
44 O
secs O
) O
and O
sliding O
steps O
of O
1 O
TR O
, O
correlation O
matrices O
between O
each O
insula O
seed O
time O
course O
and O
the O
time O
series O
of O
each O
voxel O
in O
each O
of O
the O
3 O
brain O
network O
masks O
within O
each O
time O
window O
were O
computed O
. O

These O
windowed O
correlation O
matrices O
were O
then O
transformed O
using O
Fisher O
’ O
s O
Z-transformation O
and O
concatenated O
to O
form O
a O
3D O
matrix O
, O
sized O
3×5510×209 O
for O
each O
subject O
and O
session O
. O

To O
assess O
the O
structure O
of O
reoccurring O
connectivity O
patterns O
, O
k-means O
clustering O
algorithm O
was O
applied O
to O
windowed O
correlation O
matrices O
and O
repeated O
500 O
times O
with O
random O
initialization O
of O
centroid O
positions O
to O
avoid O
converging O
into O
local O
minima O
. O

The O
resulting O
centroid O
of O
each O
cluster O
( O
n=6 O
based O
on O
the O
silhouette O
criterion O
; O
Fig O
S1 O
) O
was O
recognized O
as O
a O
state O
. O

After O
clustering O
, O
each O
windowed O
correlation O
matrix O
was O
assigned O
to O
one O
of O
the O
6 O
identified O
states O
. O

For O
each O
subject O
in O
each O
session O
, O
a O
state O
transition O
process O
was O
described O
using O
a O
Markov O
matrix O
. O

SESSION O
effects O
were O
assessed O
via O
a O
paired O
t-test O
( O
P O
( O
remain O
in O
current O
state O
) O
) O
—defined O
as O
sum O
of O
the O
diagonal O
of O
the O
Markov O
matrix O
. O

Correlation O
analyses O
Measures O
of O
static O
and O
dynamic O
rsFC O
showing O
a O
significant O
SESSION O
effect O
were O
extracted O
for O
both O
the O
abstinent O
and O
sated O
conditions O
for O
each O
participant O
, O
with O
the O
magnitude O
of O
rsFC O
SESSION O
effect O
correlated O
with O
the O
magnitude O
of O
SESSION O
effects O
on O
both O
RVIP O
d′ O
and O
WSWS O
subscale O
subjective O
ratings O
. O

These O
correlations O
were O
corrected O
for O
multiple O
comparisons O
based O
on O
the O
number O
of O
rsFC O
measures O
tested O
( O
n=5 O
: O
4 O
s-rsFC O
circuits O
identified O
, O
1 O
d-rsFC O
measure O
) O
* O
state O
measures O
tested O
( O
n=6 O
: O
RVIP O
d′ O
, O
WSWS O
subscales O
) O
( O
p-corrected O
< O
0.05/30 O
= O
0.00167 O
) O
. O

Finally O
, O
post O
hoc O
correlations O
between O
rsFC O
measures O
and O
cognitive O
and O
subjective O
withdrawal O
measures O
were O
calculated O
at O
both O
abstinence O
and O
satiety O
individually O
. O

In O
each O
case O
, O
state-specific O
correlations O
were O
only O
evaluated O
for O
those O
insular-seeded O
rsFC O
circuits O
that O
showed O
a O
SESSION O
effect O
. O

As O
above O
, O
these O
follow-up O
tests O
were O
corrected O
for O
multiple O
comparisons O
based O
on O
the O
number O
of O
rsFC O
measures O
( O
n=5 O
) O
, O
subjective O
measures O
( O
n=6 O
) O
, O
and O
states O
( O
n=2 O
) O
tested O
( O
p-corrected O
< O
0.05/60 O
= O
0.00083 O
) O
. O

The O
human O
cortex O
possesses O
a O
reconfigurable O
dynamic O
network O
architecture O
that O
is O
disrupted O
in O
psychosis O
Higher-order O
cognition O
emerges O
through O
the O
flexible O
interactions O
of O
large-scale O
brain O
networks O
, O
an O
aspect O
of O
temporal O
coordination O
that O
may O
be O
impaired O
in O
psychosis O
. O

Here O
, O
we O
map O
the O
dynamic O
functional O
architecture O
of O
the O
cerebral O
cortex O
in O
healthy O
young O
adults O
, O
leveraging O
this O
atlas O
of O
transient O
network O
configurations O
( O
states O
) O
, O
to O
identify O
state- O
and O
network-specific O
disruptions O
in O
patients O
with O
schizophrenia O
and O
psychotic O
bipolar O
disorder O
. O

We O
demonstrate O
that O
dynamic O
connectivity O
profiles O
are O
reliable O
within O
participants O
, O
and O
can O
act O
as O
a O
fingerprint O
, O
identifying O
specific O
individuals O
within O
a O
larger O
group O
. O

Patients O
with O
psychotic O
illness O
exhibit O
intermittent O
disruptions O
within O
cortical O
networks O
previously O
associated O
with O
the O
disease O
, O
and O
the O
individual O
connectivity O
profiles O
within O
specific O
brain O
states O
predict O
the O
presence O
of O
active O
psychotic O
symptoms O
. O

Taken O
together O
, O
these O
results O
provide O
evidence O
for O
a O
reconfigurable O
dynamic O
architecture O
in O
the O
general O
population O
and O
suggest O
that O
prior O
reports O
of O
network O
disruptions O
in O
psychosis O
may O
reflect O
symptom-relevant O
transient O
abnormalities O
, O
rather O
than O
a O
time-invariant O
global O
deficit O
. O

Temporal O
changes O
in O
brain O
dynamics O
are O
linked O
with O
cognitive O
abilities O
, O
but O
neither O
their O
stability O
nor O
relationship O
to O
psychosis O
is O
clear O
. O

Here O
, O
authors O
describe O
the O
dynamic O
neural O
architecture O
in O
healthy O
controls O
and O
patients O
with O
psychosis O
and O
find O
that O
they O
are O
stable O
over O
time O
and O
can O
predict O
psychotic O
symptoms O
. O

Methods O
Data O
acquisition O
Native O
English-speaking O
young O
adults O
( O
aged O
18–35 O
) O
with O
normal O
or O
corrected-to-normal O
vision O
were O
recruited O
from O
Harvard O
University O
, O
Massachusetts O
General O
Hospital O
, O
and O
the O
surrounding O
Boston O
communities O
through O
an O
ongoing O
large-scale O
study O
of O
brain O
imaging O
and O
genetics O
( O
n O
= O
1919 O
; O
age O
: O
21.35 O
± O
3.20 O
; O
female O
: O
56.53 O
% O
; O
right O
handed O
: O
92.40 O
% O
) O
. O

History O
of O
psychiatric O
illness O
and O
medication O
usage O
was O
assessed O
through O
a O
structured O
phone O
screen O
. O

On O
the O
day O
of O
MRI O
data O
collection O
, O
participants O
completed O
additional O
questionnaires O
concerning O
their O
physical O
health O
, O
past O
and O
present O
history O
of O
psychiatric O
illness O
, O
and O
medication O
usage O
. O

Exclusion O
criteria O
included O
a O
history O
of O
head O
trauma O
, O
current O
or O
past O
Axis O
I O
pathology O
, O
neurological O
disorders O
, O
current O
or O
past O
psychotropic O
medication O
use O
, O
current O
physical O
illness O
, O
and O
current O
or O
past O
loss O
of O
consciousness O
. O

Participants O
provided O
written O
informed O
consent O
in O
accordance O
with O
guidelines O
set O
by O
the O
Partners O
Health O
Care O
Institutional O
Review O
Board O
and O
the O
Harvard O
University O
Committee O
on O
the O
Use O
of O
Human O
Subjects O
in O
Research O
. O

For O
the O
present O
study O
, O
we O
assessed O
the O
extent O
to O
which O
the O
dynamic O
network O
architecture O
of O
the O
cortex O
is O
reliable O
within O
and O
across O
visits O
. O

To O
accomplish O
this O
, O
an O
additional O
data O
set O
( O
n O
= O
79 O
; O
age O
at O
the O
first O
scan O
: O
20.99 O
± O
2.93 O
; O
female O
: O
45.56 O
% O
; O
right O
handed O
: O
89.87 O
% O
) O
was O
acquired O
over O
the O
course O
of O
the O
primary O
collection O
effort O
. O

Data O
were O
collected O
on O
2 O
independent O
days O
( O
mean O
= O
63.35 O
± O
48.10 O
days O
apart O
; O
min O
= O
2 O
; O
max O
= O
151 O
) O
. O

Patients O
with O
psychotic O
illness O
were O
recruited O
from O
clinical O
services O
at O
McLean O
Hospital O
( O
n O
= O
170 O
; O
age O
: O
32.08 O
± O
11.64 O
; O
female O
: O
66.47 O
% O
; O
right O
handed O
: O
84.71 O
% O
) O
, O
including O
41 O
patients O
diagnosed O
with O
schizoaffective O
disorder O
, O
56 O
with O
schizophrenia O
, O
and O
73 O
with O
psychotic O
bipolar O
disorder O
. O

Study O
procedures O
are O
detailed O
in O
Baker O
et O
al O
. O

2014 O
. O

Briefly O
, O
exclusion O
criteria O
included O
neurological O
illness O
, O
positive O
pregnancy O
test O
, O
electroconvulsive O
therapy O
in O
the O
last O
3 O
months O
, O
and O
history O
of O
head O
trauma O
. O

Reflecting O
the O
severity O
of O
the O
present O
sample O
, O
the O
majority O
of O
patients O
( O
82 O
% O
) O
reported O
experiencing O
active O
psychotic O
symptoms O
at O
the O
time O
of O
their O
clinical O
assessment O
, O
as O
assessed O
through O
DSM-IV O
( O
SCID O
) O
clinician-rated O
symptomatic O
diagnostic O
criteria O
, O
indicating O
the O
presence O
of O
delusions O
and/or O
hallucinations O
in O
the O
past O
month O
. O

All O
patients O
were O
assessed O
for O
active O
symptoms O
within O
24 O
h O
of O
scan O
using O
the O
Positive O
and O
Negative O
Syndrome O
Scale O
( O
PANSS O
; O
positive O
scale O
: O
18.46 O
± O
6.51 O
; O
negative O
scale O
: O
13.48 O
± O
7.47 O
; O
general O
psychopathology O
scale O
: O
30.82 O
± O
7.95 O
) O
. O

A O
demographically O
matched O
healthy O
comparison O
sample O
was O
recruited O
from O
the O
surrounding O
Boston O
communities O
( O
n O
= O
369 O
; O
age O
: O
37.16 O
± O
14.65 O
; O
female O
: O
62.06 O
% O
; O
right O
handed O
: O
91.33 O
% O
) O
. O

The O
McLean O
Hospital O
Institutional O
Review O
Board O
approved O
the O
study O
, O
and O
all O
participants O
provided O
written O
informed O
consent O
. O

The O
control O
group O
was O
significantly O
older O
than O
the O
patient O
group O
( O
t O
= O
–3.98 O
, O
p O
≤ O
0.001 O
) O
. O

No O
significant O
group O
differences O
were O
identified O
in O
sex O
, O
handedness O
, O
or O
education O
( O
ps O
≥ O
0.07 O
) O
. O

The O
comparison O
sample O
was O
explicitly O
selected O
to O
match O
on O
the O
basis O
data O
quality O
. O

The O
BOLD O
runs O
for O
the O
patient O
and O
comparison O
groups O
did O
not O
differ O
in O
terms O
of O
slice-based O
temporal O
signal-to-noise O
ratio O
( O
comparison O
: O
161.17 O
± O
46.05 O
; O
patient O
: O
158.35 O
± O
71.53 O
) O
or O
the O
number O
of O
relative O
translations O
in O
3D O
space O
≥0.1 O
mm O
( O
comparison O
: O
31.05 O
± O
29.15 O
; O
patient O
: O
32.29 O
± O
29.66 O
; O
ps O
≥ O
0.58 O
) O
. O

The O
slice-based O
signal-to-noise O
ratio O
was O
calculated O
as O
the O
weighted O
mean O
of O
each O
slice O
’ O
s O
mean O
intensity O
over O
time O
( O
weighted O
by O
the O
size O
of O
the O
slice O
) O
. O

All O
imaging O
data O
were O
collected O
on O
3-T O
Tim O
Trio O
scanners O
( O
Siemens O
) O
with O
a O
12-channel O
phased-array O
head O
coil O
at O
Harvard O
University O
, O
Massachusetts O
General O
Hospital O
, O
or O
McLean O
Hospital O
. O

Structural O
data O
included O
a O
high-resolution O
multi-echo O
T1-weighted O
magnetization-prepared O
gradient-echo O
image O
( O
TR O
= O
2200 O
ms O
, O
TI O
= O
1100 O
ms O
, O
TE O
= O
1.54 O
ms O
for O
image O
1–7.01 O
ms O
for O
image O
4 O
, O
FA O
= O
7° O
, O
1.2 O
× O
1.2 O
× O
1.2 O
mm O
, O
and O
FOV O
= O
230 O
) O
. O

Functional O
data O
were O
acquired O
using O
a O
gradient-echo O
echoplanar O
imaging O
sequence O
sensitive O
to O
blood O
oxygenation O
level-dependent O
contrast O
with O
the O
following O
parameters O
: O
124 O
time O
points O
; O
repetition O
time O
= O
3000 O
ms O
; O
echo O
time O
= O
30 O
ms O
; O
flip O
angle O
= O
85° O
; O
3 O
× O
3 O
× O
3-mm O
voxels O
; O
FOV O
= O
216 O
; O
and O
47 O
axial O
sections O
collected O
with O
interleaved O
acquisition O
and O
no O
gap O
. O

Participants O
were O
instructed O
to O
remain O
still O
, O
stay O
awake O
, O
and O
keep O
their O
eyes O
open O
. O

Although O
no O
fixation O
image O
was O
used O
, O
participants O
with O
psychotic O
illness O
were O
monitored O
via O
eye-tracking O
video O
to O
ensure O
compliance O
during O
functional O
scans O
. O

One O
to O
two O
runs O
were O
acquired O
for O
each O
participant O
( O
70.89 O
% O
of O
the O
main O
sample O
, O
69.41 O
% O
of O
patient O
participants O
, O
and O
46.88 O
% O
of O
the O
matched O
comparison O
received O
a O
second O
run O
) O
. O

Software O
upgrades O
( O
VB13 O
, O
VB15 O
, O
and O
VB17 O
) O
occurred O
during O
data O
collection O
. O

Reported O
results O
are O
after O
partialing O
out O
variance O
associated O
with O
scanner O
and O
software O
upgrade O
. O

Data O
preprocessing O
Data O
were O
processed O
with O
a O
series O
of O
steps O
common O
to O
intrinsic O
connectivity O
analyses O
. O

Preprocessing O
included O
discarding O
the O
first O
four O
volumes O
of O
each O
run O
to O
allow O
for O
T1-equilibration O
effects O
, O
compensating O
for O
slice O
acquisition-dependent O
time O
shifts O
per O
volume O
, O
and O
correcting O
for O
head O
motion O
using O
rigid O
body O
translation O
and O
rotation O
. O

Additional O
steps O
included O
the O
removal O
of O
constant O
offset O
and O
linear O
trends O
over O
each O
run O
, O
and O
the O
application O
of O
a O
temporal O
filter O
to O
retain O
frequencies O
below O
0.08 O
Hz O
. O

Sources O
of O
spurious O
variance O
, O
along O
with O
their O
temporal O
derivatives O
, O
were O
removed O
through O
linear O
regression O
. O

These O
included O
six O
parameters O
obtained O
by O
correction O
for O
rigid O
body O
head O
motion O
, O
the O
signal O
averaged O
over O
the O
whole O
brain O
, O
the O
signal O
averaged O
over O
the O
ventricles O
, O
and O
the O
signal O
averaged O
over O
the O
deep O
cerebral O
white O
matter O
. O

Structural O
data O
and O
functional O
data O
were O
aligned O
as O
described O
in O
Yeo O
et O
al O
. O

and O
Buckner O
et O
al O
. O

using O
the O
FreeSurfer O
software O
package O
. O

This O
method O
yields O
a O
surface O
mesh O
representation O
of O
each O
participant O
’ O
s O
cortex O
, O
which O
is O
then O
registered O
to O
a O
common O
spherical O
coordinate O
system O
. O

Images O
were O
aligned O
with O
boundary-based O
registration O
from O
the O
FsFast O
software O
. O

Functional O
and O
structural O
images O
were O
then O
aligned O
to O
the O
common O
coordinate O
system O
by O
sampling O
from O
the O
middle O
of O
the O
cortical O
ribbon O
in O
a O
single O
interpolation O
step O
to O
reduce O
blurring O
of O
the O
functional O
signal O
across O
sulci O
and O
gyri O
. O

A O
6-mm O
smoothing O
kernel O
was O
applied O
to O
the O
functional O
data O
in O
the O
surface O
space O
, O
and O
data O
were O
downsampled O
to O
a O
4-mm O
mesh O
. O

Additional O
details O
on O
the O
preprocessing O
procedures O
are O
detailed O
in O
Holmes O
et O
al O
. O

and O
Yeo O
et O
al O
.. O

Dynamic O
connectivity O
sliding-window O
analysis O
Cortical O
functional O
coupling O
matrices O
were O
computed O
for O
each O
participant O
, O
across O
all O
available O
parcels O
within O
the O
17-network O
functional O
atlas O
of O
Yeo O
et O
al O
.. O
We O
defined O
114 O
regions O
( O
57 O
per O
hemisphere O
) O
that O
surveyed O
all O
17 O
networks O
. O

Correlation O
matrices O
were O
constructed O
to O
include O
all O
region O
pairs O
arranged O
by O
network O
membership O
. O

Connectivity O
across O
time O
was O
analyzed O
using O
a O
sliding-window O
approach O
( O
width O
= O
33 O
s O
) O
. O

Prior O
work O
suggests O
that O
a O
sliding-window O
range O
of O
30–60 O
s O
is O
appropriate O
for O
dynamic O
connectivity O
analyses O
. O

Pilot O
analyses O
( O
available O
upon O
request O
) O
revealed O
consistent O
state O
solution O
stability O
across O
varying O
sliding-window O
sizes O
of O
33–63 O
s. O
Thirty-three-second O
windows O
were O
chosen O
in O
order O
to O
maximize O
signal O
estimates O
, O
while O
still O
capturing O
properties O
of O
transient O
functional O
connectivity O
. O

A O
time O
series O
for O
each O
participant O
was O
extracted O
for O
the O
57 O
regions O
in O
each O
hemisphere O
. O

Time-course O
correlations O
across O
110 O
windows O
per O
bold O
run O
for O
each O
participant O
( O
220 O
windows O
if O
the O
participant O
had O
two O
runs O
) O
were O
calculated O
for O
each O
114 O
× O
114 O
region O
pair O
. O

To O
limit O
the O
redundancy O
across O
matrices O
and O
to O
reduce O
computational O
load O
, O
clustering O
was O
applied O
to O
a O
subsample O
of O
available O
windowed O
covariance O
matrices O
( O
1/10 O
windows O
) O
. O

Results O
were O
consistent O
with O
the O
alternate O
approach O
of O
subsampling O
along O
the O
temporal O
dimension O
to O
identify O
windowed O
covariance O
matrices O
with O
local O
maxima O
in O
functional O
connectivity O
variance O
. O

The O
resulting O
correlation O
matrices O
were O
then O
aggregated O
and O
z-transformed O
prior O
to O
running O
the O
clustering O
analyses O
. O

The O
clustering O
analysis O
was O
iteratively O
applied O
to O
define O
distinct O
state O
solutions O
for O
2 O
through O
20 O
brain O
states O
. O

Additional O
details O
on O
the O
selected O
clustering O
approach O
are O
provided O
in O
Yeo O
et O
al O
. O

As O
we O
did O
not O
have O
a O
priori O
hypotheses O
regarding O
the O
number O
of O
functional O
connectivity O
states O
, O
we O
assessed O
the O
stability O
of O
clustering O
solutions O
for O
all O
states O
2–20 O
. O

To O
do O
so O
, O
we O
examined O
the O
stability O
of O
the O
clustering O
analyses O
by O
iteratively O
and O
randomly O
splitting O
our O
data O
on O
two O
dimensions O
( O
sliding O
windows O
and O
pairwise O
connectivity O
) O
and O
rerunning O
the O
clustering O
solution O
30 O
times O
. O

The O
results O
were O
then O
compared O
using O
a O
Hungarian O
matching O
algorithm O
, O
as O
described O
in O
the O
next O
section O
. O

Greater O
instability O
was O
quantified O
as O
a O
greater O
summation O
of O
deviation O
between O
the O
two O
cluster O
solutions O
( O
Supplementary O
Figure O
1 O
) O
. O

Hierarchy O
analysis O
To O
examine O
the O
relations O
linking O
each O
state O
in O
solution O
S O
with O
the O
states O
in O
solution O
S O
+ O
1 O
, O
we O
used O
a O
Hungarian O
matching O
technique O
. O

Every O
possible O
combination O
of O
states O
in O
state O
solution O
S O
+ O
1 O
was O
compared O
to O
each O
state O
in O
solution O
S. O
To O
illustrate O
this O
point O
, O
take O
the O
comparison O
of O
states O
in O
the O
three- O
and O
four-state O
solutions O
. O

Each O
possible O
combination O
in O
the O
four-state O
solution O
is O
established O
( O
A4B4 O
, O
A4C4 O
, O
A4D4 O
, O
B4C4 O
, O
B4D4 O
, O
and O
C4D4 O
) O
by O
calculating O
the O
mean O
of O
each O
cell O
in O
the O
114 O
× O
114 O
× O
n O
( O
here O
, O
n O
= O
4 O
) O
connectivity O
matrix O
across O
the O
combined O
states O
to O
create O
hybrid O
states O
. O

Next O
, O
each O
hybrid O
state O
is O
grouped O
along O
with O
the O
other O
states O
in O
the O
four-state O
solution O
and O
compared O
to O
the O
three-state O
solution O
( O
A4 O
+ O
B4/C4/D4 O
, O
then O
A4 O
+ O
C4/B4/D4 O
, O
then O
A4 O
+ O
D4/B4/C4 O
, O
etc O
. O
) O
. O

Hungarian O
matching O
is O
used O
to O
determine O
which O
of O
the O
hybrid O
combinations O
in O
the O
four-state O
solution O
most O
closely O
approximates O
each O
state O
in O
the O
three-state O
solution O
( O
so O
, O
in O
the O
first O
example O
, O
the O
hybrid O
four-state O
solution O
comprised O
of O
A4 O
+ O
B4/C4/D4 O
is O
matched O
to O
states O
A3 O
, O
B3 O
, O
and O
C3 O
in O
the O
three-state O
solution O
) O
. O

This O
comparison O
is O
repeated O
until O
the O
match O
with O
the O
minimal O
cost O
is O
identified O
( O
Supplementary O
Figure O
2 O
) O
. O

Identifying O
variability O
across O
defined O
state O
solutions O
To O
determine O
the O
extent O
of O
network O
variability O
across O
brain O
states O
, O
we O
examined O
the O
variance O
of O
mean O
network O
connectivity O
in O
state O
solutions O
2–8 O
( O
see O
Supplementary O
Figure O
3 O
for O
variance O
with O
the O
four-state O
solution O
) O
. O

We O
used O
ANOVA O
to O
assess O
between-state O
variability O
( O
coefficient O
of O
variance O
) O
with O
state O
solutions O
treated O
as O
repeated O
measures O
. O

The O
results O
confirmed O
that O
variance O
differed O
across O
the O
networks O
( O
F15 O
= O
44.11 O
, O
p O
≤ O
0.001 O
) O
. O

Post O
hoc O
tests O
revealed O
increased O
cross-state O
variability O
within O
default O
A O
and O
B O
relative O
to O
the O
default O
D O
, O
control O
A O
and O
C O
, O
limbic O
, O
somatomotor O
A O
, O
and O
visual O
B O
networks O
( O
Bonferroni-corrected O
ps O
≤ O
0.05 O
, O
all O
other O
ps O
≥ O
0.5 O
) O
. O

Control O
B O
demonstrated O
greater O
variance O
relative O
to O
default O
C O
and O
D O
, O
control O
A O
and O
C O
, O
limbic O
, O
somatomotor O
, O
and O
visual O
networks O
( O
ps O
≤ O
0.05 O
; O
all O
other O
ps O
≥ O
0.5 O
) O
. O

The O
salience/ventral O
attention O
and O
dorsal O
attention O
A O
networks O
exhibited O
increased O
variance O
relative O
to O
default O
C O
and O
D O
, O
control O
A O
and O
C O
, O
limbic O
, O
somatomotor O
, O
and O
visual O
networks O
( O
ps O
≤ O
0.05 O
, O
all O
other O
ps O
≥ O
0.5 O
) O
. O

Individual O
identification O
analyses O
To O
examine O
the O
extent O
to O
which O
the O
observed O
dynamic O
connectivity O
profiles O
are O
reliably O
expressed O
across O
scans O
and O

, O
we O
first O
selected O
participants O
with O
two O
bold O
runs O
( O
n O
= O
1361 O
) O
. O

Next O
, O
we O
examined O
the O
79 O
participants O
, O
set O
aside O
from O
the O
original O
cohort O
, O
who O
had O
two O
separate O
study O
visits O
within O
6 O
months O
of O
each O
other O
. O

To O
test O
the O
relations O
within O
each O
individual O
’ O
s O
profile O
of O
network O
dynamics O
for O
the O
two O
bold O
runs O
within O
the O
same O
visit O
, O
and O
then O
for O
the O
individuals O
with O
more O
than O
one O
visit O
, O
we O
implemented O
the O
following O
analysis O
: O
First O
, O
we O
obtained O
each O
participant O
’ O
s O
state O
expression O
across O
time O
. O

To O
accomplish O
this O
, O
we O
used O
a O
Hungarian O
matching O
algorithm O
, O
assigning O
each O
time O
point O
in O
a O
participant O
’ O
s O
windowed O
time-course O
data O
to O
individual O
states O
in O
the O
desired O
population-level O
state O
solution O
. O

For O
instance O
, O
in O
the O
four-state O
solution O
, O
we O
found O
the O
best O
fit O
for O
each O
window O
in O
the O
participant O
’ O
s O
data O
and O
classified O
it O
as O
state O
A4 O
, O
B4 O
, O
C4 O
, O
or O
D4 O
. O

This O
yielded O
a O
vector O
of O
states O
for O
each O
participant O
, O
representing O
the O
participant O
’ O
s O
state O
expression O
over O
the O
course O
of O
the O
scan O
. O

Following O
this O
, O
we O
took O
the O
average O
correlation O
matrix O
for O
each O
window O
within O
a O
state O
. O

So O
, O
for O
participant O
1 O
, O
we O
collapsed O
across O
all O
of O
the O
state O
A4 O
windows O
, O
and O
generated O
a O
mean O
for O
state O
A4 O
, O
creating O
a O
114 O
× O
114 O
× O
S O
average O
state O
matrix O
for O
each O
participant O
. O

Participant O
matrices O
were O
vectorized O
, O
and O
Pearson O
correlations O
were O
run O
across O
every O
participant O
in O
two O
analyses O
for O
( O
1 O
) O
bold O
1 O
and O
bold O
2 O
; O
and O
every O
participant O
for O
( O
2 O
) O
visit O
1 O
and O
visit O
2 O
. O

Analyses O
indicated O
a O
significant O
level O
of O
consistency O
in O
within-individual O
connectivity O
profiles O
across O
bold O
runs O
and O
visits O
( O
Supplementary O
Figure O
4 O
) O
. O

For O
each O
state O
solution O
, O
we O
ran O
a O
t-test O
for O
within-participant O
rho O
values O
and O
between-participant O
rho O
values O
. O

All O
tests O
revealed O
increased O
rho O
values O
within O
, O
rather O
than O
between O
, O
participants O
( O
all O
ps O
≤ O
0.001 O
) O
. O

Permutation O
tests O
were O
performed O
in O
a O
manner O
consistent O
with O
prior O
studies O
examining O
functional O
connectome O
fingerprinting O
. O

For O
these O
analyses O
, O
we O
considered O
participants O
with O
multiple O
study O
visits O
( O
n O
= O
79 O
) O
and O
utilized O
the O
state- O
and O

connectivity O
vectors O
described O
above O
. O

A O
Pearson O
correlation O
was O
calculated O
across O
an O
ordered O
list O
for O
every O
participant O
’ O
s O
connectivity O
vector O
from O
visit O
1 O
compared O
to O
every O
other O
participant O
’ O
s O
vector O
from O
visit O
2 O
. O

We O
first O
established O
a O
comparison O
distribution O
from O
chance O
. O

For O
each O
state O
, O
the O
participant O
vector O
from O
visit O
1 O
was O
compared O
to O
a O
randomly O
permuted O
list O
of O
participants O
from O
visit O
2 O
, O
a O
Pearson O
correlation O
was O
calculated O
, O
a O
matching O
rank O
was O
assigned O
, O
and O
the O
identification O
rate O
was O
calculated O
. O

A O
“ O
correct O
” O
identification O
was O
defined O
in O
cases O
where O
the O
highest-ranked O
rho O
value O
was O
within O
a O
participant O
( O
visit O
1–visit O
2 O
) O
relative O
to O
other O
participants O
( O
for O

results O
, O
see O
Fig O
. O

4 O
, O
main O
text O
) O
. O

This O
was O
repeated O
1000 O
times O
, O
and O
a O
t-test O
was O
performed O
comparing O
the O
number O
of O
identifications O
of O
the O
actual O
order O
participants O
relative O
to O
the O
distribution O
of O
the O
number O
of O
identifications O
in O
the O
permuted O
order O
of O
the O
participant O
list O
. O

Noise O
constraints O
To O
assess O
the O
extent O
to O
which O
data O
quality O
might O
influence O
on O
our O
findings O
, O
we O
conducted O
a O
series O
of O
analyses O
aimed O
at O
detecting O
the O
differences O
in O
motion O
across O
state O
solutions O
. O

To O
obtain O
motion O
estimates O
by O
a O
participant O
for O
each O
window O
, O
we O
extracted O
the O
mean O
of O
the O
root O
mean O
square O
of O
relative O
motion O
for O
each O
participant O
across O
each O
window O
. O

We O
used O
the O
Hungarian O
matched O
state O
vector O
to O
classify O
relative O
motion O
within O
each O
TR O
to O
a O
state-specific O
window O
. O

We O
averaged O
motion O
values O
within O
states O
for O
each O
state O
solution O
. O

Although O
the O
relations O
linking O
state O
expression O
and O
motion O
were O
limited O
in O
size O
( O
ηp2s O
≤ O
0.006 O
) O
, O
state O
A O
associated O
with O
the O
most O
motion O
for O
state O
solutions O
2 O
, O
3 O
, O
and O
4 O
( O
all O
ps O
≤ O
0.05 O
; O
Supplementary O
Figure O
5 O
) O
. O

State O
A O
showed O
a O
muted O
increase O
in O
motion O
relative O
to O
other O
states O
in O
solutions O
5 O
through O
7 O
( O
five-state O
solution O
: O
ps O
≤ O
0.001 O
for O
state O
A5 O
relative O
to O
C5 O
and O
E5 O
, O
p O
≤ O
0.05 O
; O
p O
≥ O
0.59 O
for O
B5 O
and O
D5 O
; O
six-state O
solution O
: O
ps O
≤ O
0.01 O
for O
state O
A6 O
relative O
to O
E6 O
and O
F6 O
, O
ps O
≥ O
0.38 O
for O
B6 O
, O
C6 O
, O
and O
D6 O
; O
seven-state O
solution O
: O
ps O
≤ O
0.001 O
for O
state O
A7 O
relative O
to O
E7 O
and O
F7 O
; O
p O
= O
0.07 O
for O
C7 O
, O
p O
= O
0.06 O
for O
G7 O
, O
and O
p O
≥ O
0.61 O
for O
B7 O
and O
D7 O
) O
. O

In O
state O
solution O
8 O
, O
we O
found O
that O
state O
H8 O
, O
a O
state O
that O
our O
hierarchy O
analyses O
identified O
as O
architecturally O
related O
to O
state O
A O
in O
solutions O
2–7 O
, O
was O
associated O
with O
more O
motion O
than O
all O
other O
states O
( O
ps O
≤ O
0.001 O
) O
. O

Next O
, O
we O
examined O
the O
consistency O
of O
state O
stability O
in O
participants O
falling O
within O
the O
first O
and O
fourth O
quartiles O
of O
the O
distribution O
for O
motion O
( O
low O
motion O
: O
n O
= O
424 O
; O
high O
motion O
: O
n O
= O
398 O
) O
. O

No O
group O
differences O
were O
identified O
in O
age O
, O
sex O
, O
or O
handedness O
( O
ps O
≥ O
0.59 O
) O
. O

To O
determine O
the O
stability O
of O
our O
state-clustering O
approach O
, O
we O
applied O
iterative O
k-means O
clustering O
to O
each O
group O
for O
each O
population-level O
stable O
state O
solution O
( O
2 O
, O
4 O
, O
5 O
, O
and O
8 O
states O
) O
. O

To O
estimate O
the O
viability O
of O
the O
resulting O
solutions O
, O
data O
were O
resampled O
across O
sliding O
windows O
as O
described O
previously O
( O
Fig O
. O

1 O
, O
main O
text O
) O
. O

A O
t-test O
was O
performed O
to O
assess O
the O
differences O
in O
the O
consistency O
sampling O
from O
the O
high O
and O
low O
motion O
groups O
. O

No O
differences O
in O
consistency O
were O
observed O
across O
groups O
( O
Supplementary O
Figure O
6 O
; O
all O
ps O
≥ O
0.43 O
) O
. O

Prediction O
of O
active O
psychotic O
symptoms O
Here O
, O
we O
demonstrate O
that O
the O
strength O
of O
functional O
brain O
networks O
within O
specific O
brain O
states O
predicts O
the O
presence O
of O
active O
psychosis O
in O
previously O
unseen O
individuals O
. O

Elastic O
net O
logistic O
regression O
analyses O
were O
conducted O
with O
custom O
R O
code O
( O
elasticnet O
by O
Hui O
Zou O
, O
Trevor O
Hastie O
, O
and O
Robert O
Tibshirani O
) O
. O

Elastic O
net O
regularization O
is O
a O
cross-validated O
regularized O
log-linear O
regression O
procedure O
that O
combines O
LASSO O
( O
least O
absolute O
shrinkage O
and O
selection O
operator O
) O
regularization O
and O
Tikhonov O
( O
ridge O
) O
regularization O
The O
resulting O
log-linear O
regression O
weights O
were O
applied O
to O
the O
edges O
( O
ROI O
to O
ROI O
correlations O
) O
of O
each O
network O
configuration O
within O
the O
four-state O
solution O
and O
the O
associated O
covariates O
. O

All O
results O
were O
cross O
validated O
. O

Model O
development O
and O
validation O
consisted O
of O
four O
steps O
. O

First O
, O
model O
features O
were O
selected O
. O

Pearson O
correlation O
between O
each O
edge O
of O
the O
kth O
( O
e.g. O
, O
k O
= O
A4 O
, O
B4 O
, O
C4 O
, O
and O
D4 O
) O
dynamic O
brain O
state O
and O
clinical O
status O
was O
performed O
in O
the O
training O
set O
. O

Note O
that O
regarding O
dichotomous O
outcomes O
, O
a O
mass-univariate O
t-test O
would O
provide O
similar O
results O
as O
the O
Pearson O
correlation O
test O
concerning O
feature O
selection O
. O

Here O
, O
we O
used O
the O
Pearson O
correlation O
approach O
to O
be O
consistent O
with O
previous O
literature O
. O

The O
resulting O
edges O
were O
separated O
into O
positive O
and O
negative O
groups O
, O
and O
thresholded O
on O
the O
basis O
of O
the O
statistical O
significance O
( O
p O
≤ O
0.05 O
) O
and O
signs O
of O
correlation O
. O

Second O
, O
in O
the O
model O
development O
procedure O
, O
we O
first O
aggregated O
the O
values O
of O
edges O
in O
each O
feature O
set O
as O
a O
summary O
statistics O
, O
, O
or O
“ O
network O
strength O
” O
of O
the O
kth O
brain O
state O
, O
for O
. O

The O
network O
strength O
and O
covariates O
( O
e.g. O
, O
sex O
, O
age O
) O
were O
then O
entered O
into O
the O
model O
, O
yielding O
a O
scalar O
value O
, O
the O
predicated O
conditional O
probability O
of O
active O
psychotic O
symptoms O
. O

Formally O
, O
for O
subject O
i O
, O
, O
we O
definewhere O
denotes O
the O
predicted O
probability O
that O
subject O
i O
has O
active O
psychosis O
, O
given O
their O
observed O
network O
strength O
during O
brain O
state O
k O
, O
and O
covariates O
, O
a O
vector O
consisting O
of O
all O
observed O
covariates O
for O
subject O
i. O
and O
are O
estimated O
weights O
for O
brain O
state O
k O
from O
the O
elastic O
net O
logistic O
regression O
, O
where O
is O
a O
vector O
consisting O
of O
the O
estimates O
for O
each O
covariate O
in O
. O

Alternatively O
, O
we O
could O
model O
the O
predicted O
probability O
that O
subject O
i O
does O
not O
have O
psychosis O
as O
Probability O
estimation O
was O
iteratively O
performed O
using O
leave-one-subject-out O
cross-validation O
procedure O
. O

During O
each O
iteration O
, O
the O
weights O
were O
estimated O
using O
data O
from O
( O
n–1 O
, O
n O
= O
91 O
) O
participants O
and O
were O
used O
to O
predict O
the O
probability O
of O
the O
remaining O
participant O
having O
active O
psychotic O
symptoms O
. O

Each O
individual O
was O
left O
out O
once O
; O
hence O
, O
the O
procedure O
yielded O
n-predicted O
probability O
scores O
. O

To O
evaluate O
the O
estimation O
performance O
, O
we O
measured O
the O
area O
under O
the O
receiver-operating O
characteristic O
( O
ROC O
) O
curve O
( O
AUC O
) O
, O
estimated O
directly O
by O
conducting O
numerical O
integration O
of O
the O
ROC O
under O
all O
thresholds O
that O
yielded O
unique O
sensitivity/specificity O
values O
, O
wherein O
0.5 O
indicates O
chance O
, O
and O
1 O
is O
perfect O
discrimination O
. O

The O
model O
development O
and O
parameter O
estimation O
were O
conducted O
only O
using O
the O
training O
data O
. O

To O
evaluate O
the O
reproducibility O
, O
we O
applied O
the O
model O
obtained O
from O
the O
training O
data O
, O
without O
further O
fitting O
or O
modification O
, O
to O
39 O
previously O
unseen O
participants O
. O

To O
access O
the O
specificity O
of O
the O
model O
in O
detecting O
positive O
symptoms O
, O
we O
examined O
the O
positive O
, O
negative O
, O
and O
general O
psychopathology O
subscales O
of O
the O
PANSS O
in O
the O
held-out O
sample O
. O

PANSS O
scores O
were O
binarized O
as O
low O
( O
less O
than O
one O
standard O
deviation O
below O
the O
mean O
) O
or O
high O
( O
greater O
than O
one O
standard O
deviation O
below O
the O
mean O
) O
for O
each O
subscale O
( O
positive O
scale O
: O
18.46 O
± O
6.51 O
, O
cutoff O
= O
11.95 O
; O
negative O
scale O
: O
13.48 O
± O
7.47 O
, O
cutoff O
= O
6.01 O
; O
general O
psychopathology O
scale O
: O
30.82 O
± O
7.95 O
, O
cutoff O
= O
22.86 O
) O
. O

Due O
to O
the O
large O
variance O
in O
PANSS O
negative O
scores O
, O
to O
thoroughly O
explore O
potential O
relations O
with O
this O
subscale O
, O
we O
additionally O
examined O
alternative O
thresholds O
of O
< O
15 O
and O
of O
< O
12 O
selecting O
the O
optimal O
result O
( O
< O
12 O
) O
for O
comparison O
with O
the O
PANSS O
positive O
scale O
. O

To O
assess O
the O
statistical O
significance O
of O
the O
sensitivity O
and O
specificity O
analyses O
, O
we O
performed O
nonparametric O
permutation O
testing O
. O

During O
each O
test O
, O
we O
first O
randomly O
permuted O
the O
active O
psychotic O
symptoms O
status O
or O
PANSS O
labels O
. O

Next O
, O
model O
fitting O
was O
carried O
out O
using O
the O
correct O
dynamic O
signatures O
and O
covariates O
and O
permuted O
( O
incorrect O
) O
labels O
. O

For O
each O
permutation O
, O
an O
AUC O
value O
was O
calculated O
. O

The O
permutation O
tests O
were O
performed O
5000 O
times O
for O
the O
training O
and O
testing O
data O
, O
respectively O
. O

The O
null O
AUC O
values O
should O
be O
symmetrically O
distributed O
around O
0.5 O
if O
the O
procedure O
is O
unbiased O
. O

Data O
availability O
The O
data O
summary O
statistics O
that O
support O
the O
findings O
of O
this O
study O
are O
available O
from O
the O
corresponding O
author O
on O
request O
. O

As O
detailed O
in O
Holmes O
et O
al. O
, O
the O
Brain O
Genomics O
Superstruct O
Project O
( O
GSP O
) O
initial O
release O
data O
set O
of O
structural O
, O
functional O
, O
and O
behavioral O
measures O
is O
available O
for O
download O
( O
http O
: O
//neuroinformatics.harvard.edu/gsp/ O
) O
. O

Step-by-step O
instructions O
detailing O
how O
to O
access O
the O
release O
data O
set O
are O
available O
online O
in O
the O
“ O
Request O
Access O
” O
page O
( O
http O
: O
//neuroinformatics.harvard.edu/gsp/get O
) O
. O

The O
patient O
data O
are O
not O
publicly O
available O
due O
to O
information O
that O
could O
compromise O
research O
participant O
privacy/consent O
. O

Presumed O
Structural O
and O
Functional O
Neural O
Recovery O
after O
Long-Term O
Abstinence O
from O
Cocaine O
in O
Male O
Military O
Veterans O
Cumulative O
evidence O
suggests O
that O
cocaine O
use O
could O
alter O
the O
structure O
and O
function O
of O
different O
brain O
systems O
. O

However O
, O
the O
extent O
to O
which O
the O
altered O
brain O
structure O
and O
function O
possibly O
recover O
over O
time O
after O
cocaine O
abstinence O
remains O
less O
clear O
. O

The O
present O
study O
examines O
39 O
male O
military O
veterans O
with O
different O
stages O
of O
cocaine O
addiction O
and O
long-term O
abstinence O
( O
from O
1 O
year O
up O
to O
30 O
years O
) O
and O
evaluates O
plausible O
changes O
in O
brain O
structure O
and O
function O
of O
specific O
brain O
regions O
that O
sub-serve O
addictions O
. O

These O
include O
the O
striatum O
that O
is O
involved O
in O
cocaine O
reward O
; O
the O
lateral O
prefrontal O
cortex O
( O
especially O
the O
dorsolateral O
PFC O
) O
that O
plays O
a O
major O
role O
in O
inhibitory O
control O
; O
the O
insula O
, O
which O
has O
been O
implicated O
in O
craving O
; O
and O
the O
medial O
orbitofrontal O
( O
OFC O
) O
and O
ventromedial O
prefrontal O
cortex O
( O
VMPFC O
) O
shown O
to O
play O
key O
roles O
in O
foresight O
and O
decision-making O
. O

The O
results O
suggest O
that O
there O
are O
differences O
in O
both O
brain O
structure O
( O
gray O
matter O
volume O
, O
GMV O
) O
and O
function O
between O
cocaine O
USERS O
and O
CONTROLS O
, O
with O
USERS O
showing O
plausible O
relative O
strengthening O
in O
neural O
systems O
for O
processing O
reward O
and O
craving O
, O
and O
relative O
weakening O
in O
neural O
systems O
involved O
in O
inhibitory O
control O
and O
decision-making O
. O

Examination O
of O
possible O
neural O
changes O
after O
abstinence O
suggests O
that O
presumed O
recovery O
occurs O
mostly O
in O
neural O
systems O
related O
to O
reward O
, O
craving O
, O
and O
inhibitory O
control O
, O
but O
to O
a O
lesser O
extent O
in O
neural O
systems O
related O
to O
decision-making O
. O

Given O
the O
limitations O
of O
the O
data O
in O
terms O
of O
a O
small O
sample O
size O
, O
as O
well O
as O
the O
lack O
of O
certainty O
about O
occasional O
use O
in O
the O
abstinent O
group O
, O
these O
results O
may O
be O
considered O
as O
preliminary O
. O

However O
, O
they O
are O
compelling O
in O
that O
they O
suggest O
that O
male O
military O
veterans O
cocaine O
USERS O
are O
indefinitely O
at O
a O
higher O
risk O
for O
making O
lapses O
in O
judgment O
and O
decision-making O
leading O
to O
possible O
relapse O
, O
if O
reward O
salience O
and O
craving O
become O
more O
intense O
. O

Understanding O
the O
neurobiology O
of O
long-term O
cocaine O
abstinence O
in O
vulnerable O
populations O
and O
beyond O
could O
help O
devising O
better O
therapeutic O
strategies O
that O
prevent O
relapse O
. O

Materials O
and O
Methods O
Participants O
Thirty-nine O
males O
( O
32 O
cases O
and O
7 O
controls O
) O
from O
the O
greater O
Los O
Angeles O
area O
were O
recruited O
to O
participant O
in O
this O
study O
. O

These O
participants O
were O
a O
subsample O
of O
a O
long-term O
cohort O
study O
investigating O
the O
longitudinal O
patterns O
and O
consequences O
of O
cocaine O
use O
and O
addiction O
. O

Cocaine-dependent O
patients O
were O
screened O
and O
recruited O
from O
the O
original O
321 O
male O
military O
veterans O
who O
met O
dependence O
criteria O
for O
cocaine O
and O
were O
admitted O
to O
cocaine O
treatment O
in O
1988–1989 O
. O

Follow-up O
interviews O
were O
conducted O
in O
1990–1991 O
, O
1991–1992 O
, O
and O
2002–2003 O
. O

The O
normal O
control O
subjects O
were O
of O
similar O
ages O
and O
ethnicity/race O
; O
they O
responded O
to O
flyers O
posted O
in O
local O
Veterans O
Affairs O
facilities O
. O

A O
screening O
process O
was O
conducted O
to O
exclude O
candidates O
who O
: O
1 O
) O
are O
suffering O
from O
Axis O
1 O
psychiatric O
conditions O
including O
PTSD O
and O
alcohol O
dependence O
; O
2 O
) O
have O
medical O
conditions O
that O
might O
interfere O
with O
safe O
study O
participation O
; O
and/or O
3 O
) O
are O
currently O
taking O
medications O
for O
psychiatric O
or O
medical O
conditions O
. O

A O
urine O
testing O
was O
also O
conducted O
to O
verify O
recent O
self-reported O
cocaine O
use O
or O
abstinence O
. O

The O
mean O
age O
for O
these O
participants O
was O
56.5 O
± O
5.4 O
years O
. O

They O
were O
in O
different O
stages O
of O
cocaine O
abstinence O
without O
treatment O
. O

While O
twelve O
were O
found O
to O
use O
cocaine O
in O
the O
last O
year O
( O
USERS O
) O
, O
20 O
were O
at O
different O
stages O
of O
addiction O
abstinence O
( O
ABSTINENCE O
) O
[ O
five O
with O
1-5 O
years O
of O
abstinence O
( O
ABS1 O
) O
, O
five O
with O
6-10 O
years O
of O
abstinence O
( O
ABS2 O
) O
, O
and O
10 O
with O
over O
10 O
years O
of O
abstinence O
( O
ABS3 O
) O
] O
. O

The O
remaining O
seven O
subjects O
were O
controls O
( O
CONTROLS O
) O
; O
they O
had O
matched O
age O
, O
sex O
, O
years O
of O
education O
, O
and O
race O
, O
to O
the O
case O
subjects O
. O

The O
controls O
never O
tried O
cocaine O
but O
lived O
in O
the O
same O
neighborhood O
. O

They O
were O
carefully O
screened O
for O
any O
neurological O
and O
psychiatric O
disorders O
( O
e.g. O
, O
current O
psychoses O
, O
anxiety O
, O
or O
bipolar O
disorders O
) O
and O
use O
of O
medications O
that O
impact O
the O
central O
nervous O
system O
; O
no O
exclusions O
based O
on O
these O
criteria O
were O
made O
. O

All O
participants O
had O
normal O
or O
corrected-to-normal O
vision O
. O

All O
participants O
gave O
informed O
consent O
to O
the O
study O
procedures O
, O
which O
were O
approved O
by O
Institutional O
Review O
Boards O
of O
the O
University O
of O
Southern O
California O
and O
the O
University O
of O
California O
, O
Los O
Angeles O
. O

Procedures O
Participants O
were O
asked O
to O
come O
to O
a O
Cognitive O
Neuroscience O
Imaging O
Center O
to O
sign O
a O
consent O
form O
, O
complete O
a O
behavioral O
interview O
and O
go O
through O
an O
MRI O
scan O
. O

Prior O
to O
the O
MRI O
scan O
, O
they O
provided O
a O
urine O
sample O
. O

The O
MRI O
scan O
took O
about O
30 O
minutes O
. O

During O
the O
scan O
, O
images O
for O
one O
high-resolution O
structural O
scan O
and O
one O
session O
of O
cue O
task O
were O
acquired O
, O
with O
a O
short O
resting O
period O
in O
between O
. O

Behavior O
Interviews O
Measures O
included O
natural O
history O
of O
drug O
use O
, O
alcohol O
and O
tobacco O
use O
, O
mental O
health O
( O
e.g. O
, O
Beck O
Depression O
, O
SCL-58 O
) O
, O
quality O
of O
health O
( O
e.g. O
, O
SF36 O
) O
, O
sensation-seeking O
, O
and O
self-efficacy O
. O

It O
captured O
up-to-date O
drug O
use O
and O
abstinence O
( O
e.g. O
, O
years O
of O
cocaine O
abstinence O
) O
and O
other O
measures O
( O
e.g. O
, O
current O
health O
and O
mental O
health O
) O
. O

Urine O
samples O
were O
used O
to O
reasonably O
confirm O
participants O
’ O
abstinence O
. O

fMRI O
Protocol O
MRI O
images O
were O
acquired O
using O
a O
3T O
Siemens O
MAGNETOM O
Tim/Trio O
scanner O
at O
the O
Dana O
and O
David O
Dornsife O
Cognitive O
Neuroscience O
Imaging O
Center O
at O
the O
University O
of O
Southern O
California O
. O

Participants O
lay O
in O
the O
supine O
position O
on O
the O
scanner O
bed O
. O

Foam O
pads O
were O
used O
to O
minimize O
head O
motion O
. O

They O
were O
instructed O
to O
rest O
and O
keep O
their O
head O
very O
still O
during O
the O
structural O
scan O
. O

During O
the O
fMRI O
scan O
, O
the O
task O
was O
back-projected O
onto O
a O
screen O
through O
a O
mirror O
attached O
to O
the O
head O
coil O
. O

Stimulus O
presentation O
and O
timing O
of O
all O
stimuli O
and O
response O
events O
were O
operationalized O
with O
Matlab O
( O
Mathworks O
) O
and O
Psychtoolbox O
( O
www.psychtoolbox.org O
) O
on O
an O
IBM-compatible O
PC O
. O

Participants O
’ O
responses O
were O
collected O
online O
