using O
an O
MRI-compatible O
button O
box O
. O

The O
structural O
image O
was O
obtained O
with O
T1-weighted O
3D-Magnetization O
Prepared O
Rapid O
Gradient O
Echo O
( O
MPRAGE O
) O
sequence O
, O
covering O
the O
whole O
brain O
with O
the O
following O
scanning O
parameters O
: O
TR/TE O
= O
2530/3.39 O
ms O
, O
flip O
angel O
= O
7° O
, O
matrix O
= O
256 O
× O
256 O
, O
number O
of O
slices O
= O
128 O
, O
and O
slice O
thickness O
= O
1.33 O
mm O
. O

Functional O
MRI O
images O
were O
acquired O
with O
blood O
oxygen O
level O
dependent O
( O
BOLD O
) O
scan O
using O
a O
z-shim O
gradient O
echo O
EPI O
( O
echo O
planer O
imaging O
) O
sequence O
with O
PACE O
( O
prospective O
acquisition O
correction O
) O
. O

This O
specific O
sequence O
is O
designed O
to O
reduce O
signal O
loss O
in O
the O
prefrontal O
and O
orbitofrontal O
areas O
. O

The O
PACE O
option O
can O
help O
reducing O
the O
impact O
of O
head O
motion O
during O
data O
acquisition O
. O

The O
scanning O
parameters O
were O
: O
TR/TE O
= O
2000/25 O
ms O
; O
flip O
angle O
= O
90° O
; O
64 O
× O
64 O
matrix O
size O
with O
resolution O
3 O
× O
3 O
mm2 O
. O

Thirty-one O
3.5-mm O
axial O
slices O
were O
used O
to O
cover O
the O
whole O
cerebral O
cortex O
and O
most O
of O
the O
cerebellum O
with O
no O
gaps O
. O

The O
slices O
were O
tilted O
about O
30° O
clockwise O
along O
the O
AC-PC O
plane O
to O
obtain O
better O
signals O
in O
the O
orbitofrontal O
cortex O
. O

fMRI O
Cue O
Task O
Participants O
performed O
a O
cue O
task O
in O
the O
scanner O
to O
measure O
their O
brain O
activity O
when O
watching O
two O
categories O
of O
stimuli O
: O
cocaine-related O
pictures O
and O
natural O
scene O
pictures O
( O
see O
example O
stimuli O
in O
Figure O
1 O
) O
. O

The O
fMRI O
task O
used O
a O
block O
design O
and O
participants O
were O
asked O
to O
passively O
view O
the O
images O
. O

MRI-compatible O
eye-tracking O
system O
was O
used O
to O
monitor O
participants O
’ O
pupils O
to O
ensure O
they O
are O
awake O
during O
the O
fMRI O
task O
. O

No O
exclusions O
based O
on O
this O
were O
made O
. O

Within O
each O
24 O
second O
block O
, O
8 O
pictures O
were O
presented O
for O
2.5 O
second O
each O
with O
an O
inter-trial O
interval O
of O
0.5 O
seconds O
. O

There O
was O
a O
12 O
second O
resting O
period O
between O
blocks O
of O
stimuli O
. O

There O
were O
16 O
cocaine-related O
pictures O
and O
16 O
natural O
scene O
pictures O
. O

These O
pictures O
were O
selected O
based O
on O
a O
pilot O
study O
. O

Each O
participant O
viewed O
8 O
blocks O
of O
each O
stimuli O
type O
and O
the O
order O
of O
different O
stimuli O
presentation O
was O
counterbalanced O
across O
participants O
using O
either O
ABBABAAB O
or O
BAABABBA O
sequence O
. O

There O
was O
a O
12 O
second O
resting O
period O
both O
at O
the O
beginning O
and O
the O
end O
of O
the O
task O
. O

The O
total O
scanning O
time O
for O
the O
cue O
task O
was O
about O
10 O
minutes O
. O

Statistical O
Analysis O
Similar O
analysis O
procedures O
were O
applied O
to O
the O
structural O
and O
functional O
scans O
. O

First O
, O
participants O
were O
divided O
into O
three O
major O
groups O
: O
USERS O
( O
those O
who O
have O
used O
cocaine O
within O
the O
last O
year O
, O
n O
= O
12 O
) O
, O
ABSTINENCE O
( O
those O
who O
were O
at O
different O
stages O
of O
cocaine O
abstinence O
, O
n O
= O
20 O
) O
and O
CONTROLS O
( O
matched O
controls O
that O
have O
never O
used O
cocaine O
, O
n O
= O
7 O
) O
. O

The O
first O
analysis O
focused O
on O
group O
differences O
between O
1 O
) O
USERS O
and O
CONTROLS O
, O
2 O
) O
USERS O
and O
ABSTINENCE O
, O
3 O
) O
ABSTINENCE O
and O
CONTROLS O
. O

Since O
the O
number O
of O
participants O
in O
the O
CONTROL O
group O
was O
relatively O
small O
, O
we O
first O
examined O
group O
difference O
between O
three O
groups O
as O
a O
means O
to O
preliminarily O
search O
for O
brain O
regions O
that O
may O
present O
differences O
. O

These O
differences O
were O
further O
refined O
by O
dividing O
the O
ABSTINENCE O
group O
into O
three O
subgroups O
: O
ABS1 O
( O
1–5 O
years O
of O
abstinence O
, O
n O
= O
5 O
) O
, O
ABS2 O
( O
6–10 O
years O
of O
abstinence O
, O
n O
= O
5 O
) O
, O
and O
ABS3 O
( O
abstinent O
for O
over O
10 O
years O
, O
n O
= O
10 O
) O
. O

This O
division O
was O
chosen O
based O
on O
how O
prior O
research O
has O
treated O
short O
meaningful O
abstinence O
, O
medium O
duration O
abstinence O
, O
and O
long-term O
abstinence O
. O

A O
second O
analysis O
was O
performed O
to O
shed O
more O
light O
on O
possible O
differences O
associated O
with O
abstinence O
. O

It O
included O
two O
inter-group O
comparisons O
between O
: O
1 O
) O
USERS O
and O
ABS1 O
( O
examining O
the O
differences O
between O
current O
users O
and O
recently O
abstinent O
) O
; O
and O
2 O
) O
CONTROL O
and O
ABS3 O
( O
examining O
the O
differences O
between O
controls O
and O
long O
term O
abstinent O
) O
. O

A O
third O
analysis O
included O
the O
calculation O
of O
years O
of O
abstinence O
for O
the O
ABSTINENCE O
group O
( O
N O
= O
20 O
) O
. O

These O
data O
and O
their O
log10 O
transformation O
were O
then O
correlated O
with O
whole-brain O
imaging O
data O
. O

This O
was O
done O
to O
reveal O
association O
between O
abstinence O
duration O
and O
brain O
function O
and O
structure O
. O

The O
last O
( O
fourth O
) O
analysis O
supplemented O
the O
previous O
one O
by O
extracting O
region O
of O
interest O
( O
ROI O
) O
volumes O
and O
activations O
. O

These O
data O
were O
used O
for O
subgroup O
comparisons O
. O

For O
all O
correlational O
analysis O
, O
robust O
regression O
was O
used O
to O
minimize O
the O
impact O
of O
outliers O
in O
the O
behavioral O
data O
, O
using O
iteratively O
reweighted O
least O
squares O
implemented O
in O
the O
robustfit O
command O
in O
the O
MATLAB O
Statistics O
Toolbox O
. O

Reported O
r-values O
reflect O
( O
non-robust O
) O
Pearson O
product-moment O
correlation O
values O
, O
whereas O
the O
reported O
p-values O
and O
regression O
lines O
are O
based O
on O
the O
robust O
regression O
results O
. O

Because O
the O
sample O
size O
was O
relatively O
small O
, O
the O
effect O
sizes O
as O
well O
as O
their O
95 O
% O
confidence O
intervals O
were O
reported O
where O
available O
, O
following O
methods O
by O
. O

Voxel-Based O
Morphometry O
( O
VBM O
) O
Analysis O
Structural O
MRI O
data O
were O
analyzed O
with O
FSL-VBM O
, O
an O
optimized O
voxel-based O
morphometry O
analysis O
toolbox O
implemented O
in O
FSL O
. O

This O
approach O
requires O
no O
prior O
information O
about O
the O
location O
of O
possible O
differences O
in O
gray O
matter O
, O
and O
has O
been O
proven O
to O
be O
operator-independent O
. O

First O
, O
structural O
images O
were O
extracted O
using O
BET O
. O

Next O
, O
tissue-type O
segmentation O
was O
performed O
using O
FAST4 O
. O

The O
resulting O
gray-matter O
partial O
volume O
images O
were O
then O
aligned O
to O
the O
gray-matter O
template O
in O
the O
MNI152 O
standard O
space O
using O
the O
affine O
registration O
tool O
FLIRT O
, O
followed O
by O
nonlinear O
registration O
using O
FNIRT O
, O
which O
used O
a O
b-spline O
representation O
of O
the O
registration O
warp O
field O
. O

The O
spatially O
normalized O
images O
were O
then O
averaged O
to O
create O
a O
study-specific O
template O
, O
to O
which O
the O
native O
gray O
matter O
images O
were O
registered O
again O
using O
both O
linear O
and O
nonlinear O
algorithms O
as O
described O
above O
. O

The O
registered O
partial O
volume O
images O
were O
then O
modulated O
by O
dividing O
them O
with O
the O
Jacobian O
of O
the O
warp O
field O
to O
correct O
for O
local O
expansion O
or O
contraction O
. O

The O
modulated O
segmented O
images O
, O
which O
represent O
the O
GMV O
, O
were O
then O
smoothed O
with O
an O
isotropic O
Gaussian O
kernel O
with O
a O
3 O
mm O
standard O
deviation O
. O

Finally O
, O
voxel-wise O
general O
linear O
models O
were O
used O
to O
examine O
correlations O
between O
brain O
data O
, O
group O
affiliation O
and O
years O
of O
abstinence O
. O

Non-parametric O
permutation O
methods O
( O
Randomise O
v2.1 O
in O
FSL O
) O
were O
used O
for O
inference O
on O
statistic O
maps O
. O

The O
null O
distribution O
at O
each O
voxel O
was O
constructed O
using O
10,000 O
random O
permutations O
of O
the O
data O
. O

Threshold-free O
cluster O
enhancement O
( O
TFCE O
) O
was O
used O
to O
correct O
for O
multiple O
comparisons O
across O
the O
whole O
brain O
. O

The O
mean O
GMV O
in O
each O
significant O
cluster O
was O
then O
extracted O
for O
each O
individual O
. O

fMRI O
Analysis O
Functional O
MRI O
image O
preprocessing O
and O
statistical O
analyses O
were O
carried O
out O
using O
the O
FSL O
package O
( O
www.fmrib.ox.ac.uk/fsl O
) O
. O

fMRI O
images O
were O
realigned O
to O
compensate O
for O
small O
residual O
head O
movements O
that O
were O
not O
captured O
by O
the O
PACE O
sequence O
. O

Translational O
movement O
parameters O
never O
exceeded O
1 O
voxel O
in O
any O
direction O
for O
any O
participant O
. O

Data O
were O
spatially O
smoothed O
using O
a O
5-mm O
full-width-half-maximum O
( O
FWHM O
) O
Gaussian O
kernel O
. O

The O
data O
were O
filtered O
using O
a O
nonlinear O
high O
pass O
filter O
with O
a O
100-second O
cut-off O
. O

A O
two-step O
registration O
procedure O
was O
used O
whereby O
EPI O
images O
were O
first O
registered O
to O
the O
MPRAGE O
structural O
image O
, O
and O
then O
into O
standard O
MNI O
space O
, O
using O
affine O
transformations O
. O

Registration O
from O
MPRAGE O
structural O
image O
to O
standard O
space O
was O
further O
refined O
using O
FNIRT O
nonlinear O
registration O
. O

Statistical O
analyses O
were O
performed O
in O
the O
native O
image O
space O
, O
with O
the O
statistical O
maps O
normalized O
to O
the O
standard O
space O
prior O
to O
higher-level O
analyses O
. O

The O
data O
were O
modeled O
at O
the O
first O
level O
using O
a O
general O
linear O
model O
( O
GLM O
) O
within O
FSL O
’ O
s O
FILM O
module O
. O

Brain O
activations O
for O
both O
cocaine-related O
pictures O
and O
natural O
scene O
pictures O
were O
modeled O
in O
the O
single O
subject O
level O
. O

The O
boxcar O
response O
was O
convolved O
with O
the O
canonical O
hemodynamic O
response O
function O
( O
HRF O
, O
double-gamma O
) O
to O
generate O
regressors O
used O
in O
the O
GLM O
. O

Temporal O
derivatives O
were O
included O
as O
covariates O
of O
no O
interest O
to O
improve O
statistical O
sensitivity O
. O

Resting O
periods O
were O
not O
explicitly O
modeled O
, O
and O
therefore O
constituted O
an O
implicit O
baseline O
. O

The O
six O
movement O
parameters O
were O
also O
included O
as O
covariates O
in O
the O
model O
. O

Higher O
level O
random-effects O
models O
were O
tested O
for O
group O
analyses O
using O
FMRIB O
’ O
s O
Local O
Analysis O
of O
Mixed O
Effect O
stage O
1 O
only O
with O
automatic O
outlier O
detection O
. O

Group O
images O
were O
evaluated O
with O
a O
height O
threshold O
of O
Z O
> O
3 O
and O
a O
cluster O
probability O
of O
p O
< O
0.05 O
, O
corrected O
for O
whole-brain O
multiple O
comparisons O
based O
on O
Gaussian O
random O
field O
theory O
. O

Regions O
of O
interests O
( O
ROI O
) O
were O
created O
from O
clusters O
of O
voxels O
with O
significant O
activation O
in O
the O
voxel-wise O
analyses O
. O

Analyses O
were O
performed O
by O
extracting O
parameter O
estimates O
( O
betas O
) O
of O
each O
type O
of O
stimuli O
from O
the O
fitted O
model O
and O
averaging O
across O
all O
voxels O
in O
the O
cluster O
for O
each O
participant O
. O

Percent O
signal O
changes O
were O
calculated O
using O
a O
method O
suggested O
by O
Mumford O
( O
http O
: O
//mumford.fmripower.org/perchange_guide.pdf O
) O
. O

Functional O
Connectivity O
Analysis O
To O
better O
understand O
key O
brain O
networks O
associated O
with O
long-term O
cocaine O
abstinence O
, O
the O
time O
courses O
of O
the O
following O
four O
seed O
regions O
revealed O
in O
the O
fMRI O
results O
were O
extracted O
: O
( O
1 O
) O
the O
right O
striatum O
( O
MNI O
coordinates O
: O
10 O
, O
14 O
, O
0 O
) O
; O
( O
2 O
) O
the O
left O
insula O
( O
MNI O
coordinates O
: O
-40 O
, O
6 O
, O
-10 O
) O
; O
( O
3 O
) O
the O
right O
Lateral O
Frontal O
Pole O
( O
LFP O
; O
MNI O
coordinates O
: O
24 O
, O
44 O
, O
42 O
) O
; O
( O
4 O
) O
the O
left O
VMPFC O
( O
MNI O
coordinates O
: O
-14 O
, O
56 O
, O
14 O
) O
. O

These O
ROIs O
were O
defined O
as O
6 O
mm O
spheres O
centered O
on O
the O
MNI O
coordinates O
mentioned O
above O
. O

Pearson O
product-moment O
correlational O
analysis O
was O
performed O
between O
the O
time O
courses O
of O
each O
pair O
of O
ROIs O
for O
each O
subject O
separately O
. O

Between-group O
differences O
and O
correlations O
with O
years O
of O
abstinence O
were O
then O
assessed O
. O

Altered O
resting-state O
functional O
connectivity O
of O
the O
cerebellum O
in O
schizophrenia O
Structural O
and O
functional O
abnormalities O
of O
the O
cerebellum O
in O
schizophrenia O
have O
been O
reported O
. O

Most O
previous O
studies O
investigating O
resting-state O
functional O
connectivity O
( O
rsFC O
) O
have O
relied O
on O
a O
priori O
restrictions O
on O
seed O
regions O
or O
specific O
networks O
, O
which O
may O
bias O
observations O
. O

In O
this O
study O
, O
we O
aimed O
to O
elicit O
the O
connectivity O
alterations O
of O
the O
cerebellum O
in O
schizophrenia O
in O
a O
hypothesis-free O
approach O
. O

Ninety-five O
schizophrenia O
patients O
and O
93 O
sex- O
and O
age-matched O
healthy O
controls O
underwent O
resting-state O
functional O
magnetic O
resonance O
imaging O
( O
fMRI O
) O
. O

A O
voxel-wise O
data-driven O
method O
, O
resting-state O
functional O
connectivity O
density O
( O
rsFCD O
) O
, O
was O
used O
to O
investigate O
cerebellar O
connectivity O
changes O
in O
schizophrenia O
patients O
. O

Regions O
with O
altered O
rsFCD O
were O
chosen O
as O
seeds O
to O
perform O
seed-based O
resting-state O
functional O
connectivity O
( O
rsFC O
) O
analyses O
. O

We O
found O
that O
schizophrenia O
patients O
exhibited O
decreased O
rsFCD O
in O
the O
right O
hemispheric O
VI O
; O
moreover O
, O
this O
cerebellar O
region O
showed O
increased O
rsFC O
with O
the O
prefrontal O
cortex O
and O
subcortical O
nuclei O
and O
decreased O
rsFC O
with O
the O
visual O
cortex O
and O
sensorimotor O
cortex O
. O

In O
addition O
, O
some O
rsFC O
changes O
were O
associated O
with O
positive O
symptoms O
. O

These O
findings O
suggest O
that O
abnormalities O
of O
the O
cerebellar O
hub O
and O
cerebellar-subcortical-cortical O
loop O
may O
be O
the O
underlying O
mechanisms O
of O
schizophrenia O
. O

Materials O
and O
methods O
Subjects O
Two O
hundred O
right-handed O
individuals O
were O
enrolled O
in O
this O
study O
, O
including O
98 O
schizophrenia O
patients O
and O
102 O
healthy O
controls O
. O

The O
Medical O
Research O
Ethics O
Committee O
of O
Tianjin O
Medical O
University O
General O
Hospital O
approved O
this O
study O
. O

After O
a O
complete O
description O
of O
the O
study O
, O
written O
informed O
consent O
was O
obtained O
from O
each O
subject O
. O

The O
diagnosis O
of O
schizophrenia O
was O
determined O
by O
the O
consensus O
of O
two O
experienced O
clinical O
psychiatrists O
using O
the O
Structured O
Interview O
for O
DSM-IV O
Axis O
I O
Disorders O
, O
Patient O
Edition O
( O
SCID-P O
) O
. O

Healthy O
controls O
were O
recruited O
from O
the O
local O
community O
via O
advertisements O
. O

All O
healthy O
controls O
were O
screened O
using O
the O
non-patient O
edition O
of O
the O
SCID O
( O
SCID-NP O
) O
to O
confirm O
a O
lifetime O
absence O
of O
psychiatric O
illnesses O
. O

In O
addition O
, O
all O
of O
the O
healthy O
controls O
were O
interviewed O
to O
exclude O
individuals O
with O
a O
known O
history O
of O
psychiatric O
illness O
in O
first-degree O
relatives O
. O

The O
exclusion O
criteria O
for O
all O
subjects O
were O
MRI O
contraindications O
, O
a O
history O
of O
head O
trauma O
with O
consciousness O
disturbances O
lasting O
more O
than O
five O
minutes O
, O
a O
history O
of O
drug O
or O
alcohol O
abuse O
, O
pregnancy O
, O
and O
any O
physical O
illness O
such O
as O
cardiovascular O
disease O
or O
neurological O
disorders O
, O
as O
diagnosed O
by O
an O
interview O
and O
medical O
records O
review O
. O

A O
professional O
radiologist O
assessed O
the O
image O
quality O
slice-by-slice O
, O
and O
three O
patients O
and O
9 O
healthy O
controls O
with O
poor O
image O
quality O
were O
excluded O
. O

Consequently O
, O
95 O
schizophrenia O
patients O
and O
93 O
healthy O
controls O
were O
included O
in O
the O
statistical O
analysis O
. O

The O
clinical O
symptoms O
of O
psychosis O
were O
quantified O
using O
the O
Positive O
and O
Negative O
Syndrome O
Scale O
( O
PANSS O
) O
. O

The O
antipsychotic O
dosages O
are O
reported O
as O
the O
chlorpromazine O
equivalents O
calculated O
based O
on O
clinically O
equivalent O
dosing O
estimates O
( O
Gardner O
et O
al O
. O
) O
. O

For O
each O
schizophrenia O
patient O
, O
the O
chlorpromazine O
equivalent O
was O
estimated O
according O
to O
the O
antipsychotic O
drugs O
and O
dosages O
used O
in O
the O
latest O
week O
before O
MRI O
. O

MRI O
data O
acquisition O
MRI O
data O
were O
acquired O
using O
a O
3.0-Tesla O
MR O
system O
( O
Discovery O
MR750 O
, O
General O
Electric O
, O
Milwaukee O
, O
WI O
, O
USA O
) O
. O

Tight O
but O
comfortable O
foam O
padding O
was O
used O
to O
minimize O
head O
motion O
, O
and O
earplugs O
were O
used O
to O
reduce O
scanner O
noise O
. O

Sagittal O
3D O
T1-weighted O
images O
were O
acquired O
using O
a O
brain O
volume O
sequence O
and O
the O
following O
parameters O
: O
repetition O
time O
( O
TR O
) O
= O
8.2 O
ms O
; O
echo O
time O
( O
TE O
) O
= O
3.2 O
ms O
; O
inversion O
time O
( O
TI O
) O
= O
450 O
ms O
; O
flip O
angle O
( O
FA O
) O
= O
12° O
; O
field O
of O
view O
( O
FOV O
) O
= O
256 O
mm O
× O
256 O
mm O
; O
matrix O
=256 O
× O
256 O
; O
slice O
thickness O
= O
1 O
mm O
, O
no O
gap O
; O
and O
188 O
sagittal O
slices O
. O

Resting-state O
fMRI O
data O
were O
acquired O
using O
a O
gradient-echo O
single-short O
echo O
planar O
imaging O
sequence O
with O
the O
following O
parameters O
: O
TR/TE O
= O
2000/45 O
ms O
; O
FOV O
= O
220 O
mm O
× O
220 O
mm O
; O
matrix O
=64 O
× O
64 O
; O
FA O
= O
90° O
; O
slice O
thickness O
= O
4 O
mm O
; O
gap O
=0.5 O
mm O
; O
32 O
interleaved O
transverse O
slices O
; O
and O
180 O
volumes O
. O

All O
subjects O
were O
instructed O
to O
keep O
their O
eyes O
closed O
, O
relax O
, O
move O
as O
little O
as O
possible O
, O
think O
of O
nothing O
in O
particular O
, O
and O
not O
fall O
asleep O
during O
the O
fMRI O
scans O
. O

fMRI O
data O
preprocessing O
Resting-state O
fMRI O
data O
were O
preprocessed O
using O
SPM8 O
( O
http O
: O
//www.fil.ion.ucl.ac.uk/spm O
) O
. O

The O
first O
10 O
volumes O
for O
each O
subject O
were O
discarded O
to O
allow O
the O
signal O
to O
reach O
equilibrium O
and O
the O
participants O
to O
adapt O
to O
the O
scanning O
noise O
. O

The O
remaining O
volumes O
were O
corrected O
for O
the O
acquisition O
time O
delay O
between O
slices O
. O

Next O
, O
realignment O
was O
performed O
to O
correct O
the O
motion O
between O
time O
points O
. O

All O
of O
the O
subjects O
’ O
fMRI O
data O
were O
within O
the O
defined O
motion O
thresholds O
( O
i.e. O
, O
translational O
or O
rotational O
motion O
parameters O
less O
than O
2 O
mm O
or O
2° O
) O
. O

We O
also O
calculated O
frame-wise O
displacement O
( O
FD O
) O
, O
which O
indexes O
the O
volume-to-volume O
changes O
in O
head O
position O
. O

There O
were O
no O
significant O
group O
differences O
in O
FD O
( O
t O
= O
0.56 O
, O
P O
= O
0.58 O
) O
between O
the O
patients O
( O
0.117 O
± O
0.007 O
) O
and O
controls O
( O
0.113 O
± O
0.006 O
) O
. O

Several O
nuisance O
covariates O
( O
six O
motion O
parameters O
, O
their O
first-time O
derivations O
, O
and O
average O
BOLD O
signals O
of O
the O
ventricular O
and O
white O
matter O
) O
were O
regressed O
out O
from O
the O
data O
. O

Recent O
studies O
have O
reported O
that O
the O
signal O
spike O
caused O
by O
head O
motion O
significantly O
contaminated O
the O
final O
resting-state O
fMRI O
results O
even O
after O
regressing O
out O
the O
linear O
motion O
parameters O
( O
Power O
et O
al O
. O
) O
. O

Therefore O
, O
we O
further O
regressed O
out O
spike O
volumes O
when O
the O
FD O
of O
the O
specific O
volume O
exceeded O
0.5 O
. O

The O
datasets O
were O
then O
band-pass O
filtered O
in O
a O
frequency O
range O
of O
0.01 O
to O
0.08 O
Hz O
. O

In O
the O
normalization O
step O
, O
individual O
structural O
images O
were O
linearly O
co-registered O
with O
the O
mean O
functional O
image O
; O
the O
transformed O
structural O
images O
were O
segmented O
into O
gray O
matter O
, O
white O
matter O
, O
and O
cerebrospinal O
fluid O
. O

The O
gray O
matter O
maps O
were O
non-linearly O
transformed O
to O
the O
tissue O
probability O
maps O
in O
the O
Montreal O
Neurological O
Institute O
( O
MNI O
) O
space O
. O

Finally O
, O
each O
filtered O
functional O
volume O
was O
spatially O
normalized O
to O
the O
MNI O
space O
using O
the O
parameters O
estimated O
during O
the O
non-linear O
transformation O
and O
resampled O
into O
a O
3-mm O
cubic O
voxel O
. O

rsFCD O
calculation O
and O
analysis O
The O
rsFCD O
of O
each O
voxel O
was O
calculated O
using O
an O
in-house O
script O
that O
was O
written O
in O
the O
Linux O
platform O
according O
to O
the O
method O
described O
by O
Tomasi O
and O
Volkow O
( O
Tomasi O
and O
Volkow O
) O
. O

Pearson O
’ O
s O
linear O
correlation O
evaluated O
the O
strength O
of O
the O
functional O
connectivity O
between O
every O
pair O
of O
voxels O
in O
the O
entire O
brain O
. O

Two O
voxels O
with O
a O
correlation O
coefficient O
, O
which O
was O
larger O
than O
a O
predefined O
threshold O
, O
were O
considered O
to O
be O
significantly O
connected O
. O

To O
obtain O
reliable O
and O
robust O
results O
, O
we O
used O
multiple O
threshold O
levels O
( O
R O
= O
0.4 O
, O
0.6 O
and O
0.8 O
) O
to O
compute O
the O
rsFCD O
. O

The O
rsFCD O
calculation O
was O
restricted O
to O
a O
whole O
brain O
mask O
including O
the O
cerebellum O
. O

The O
rsFCD O
at O
a O
given O
voxel O
x0 O
was O
computed O
as O
the O
total O
functional O
connectivity O
, O
k O
( O
x0 O
) O
, O
between O
x0 O
and O
all O
other O
voxels O
. O

This O
calculation O
was O
repeated O
for O
all O
voxels O
within O
the O
whole O
brain O
mask O
. O

To O
increase O
the O
normality O
of O
the O
distribution O
, O
grand O
mean O
scaling O
was O
performed O
by O
dividing O
the O
rsFCD O
of O
each O
voxel O
by O
the O
mean O
value O
of O
the O
whole O
brain O
. O

Finally O
, O
the O
rsFCD O
maps O
were O
spatially O
smoothed O
using O
a O
6 O
mm O
× O
6 O
mm O
× O
6 O
mm O
full-width O
at O
half O
maximum O
( O
FWHM O
) O
Gaussian O
kernel O
. O

Inter-group O
differences O
in O
rsFCD O
were O
voxel-wisely O
compared O
within O
a O
cerebellar O
mask O
using O
a O
general O
linear O
model O
with O
age O
and O
sex O
as O
nuisance O
variables O
. O

Correction O
for O
multiple O
comparisons O
was O
performed O
using O
the O
voxel-level O
false O
discovery O
rate O
( O
FDR O
) O
method O
with O
a O
corrected O
threshold O
of O
P O
< O
0.05 O
. O

The O
significant O
regions O
in O
3 O
comparisons O
( O
corresponding O
to O
the O
three O
thresholds O
) O
were O
overlapped O
. O

The O
overlapping O
areas O
were O
identified O
as O
the O
regions O
of O
interest O
( O
ROIs O
) O
for O
the O
correlation O
analyses O
and O
were O
defined O
as O
seed O
regions O
for O
the O
subsequent O
rsFC O
analyses O
. O

The O
ROI-based O
correlation O
analyses O
with O
the O
clinical O
variables O
, O
including O
antipsychotic O
dosages O
of O
chlorpromazine O
equivalents O
, O
illness O
duration O
and O
PANSS O
scores O
, O
were O
performed O
for O
the O
patient O
group O
using O
partial O
correlation O
analysis O
with O
age O
and O
sex O
as O
the O
nuisance O
covariates O
. O

For O
these O
correlation O
analyses O
, O
a O
significant O
threshold O
was O
set O
at O
P O
< O
0.05. O
rsFC O
analysis O
Most O
of O
the O
data O
preprocessing O
steps O
for O
the O
rsFC O
analysis O
were O
the O
same O
as O
the O
preprocessing O
steps O
for O
the O
rsFCD O
calculation O
. O

The O
only O
difference O
was O
that O
functional O
images O
were O
smoothed O
using O
a O
Gaussian O
kernel O
of O
6 O
mm O
× O
6 O
mm O
× O
6 O
mm O
FWHM O
after O
normalization O
. O

For O
each O
subject O
, O
Pearson O
’ O
s O
correlation O
coefficients O
between O
the O
mean O
time O
series O
of O
the O
seed O
region O
and O
that O
of O
each O
voxel O
in O
the O
whole O
brain O
was O
computed O
and O
converted O
to O
z-values O
using O
Fisher O
’ O
s O
r-to-z O
transformation O
to O
improve O
the O
normality O
. O

Next O
, O
the O
individual O
’ O
s O
z-values O
were O
entered O
into O
a O
random-effects O
one-sample O
t-test O
in O
a O
voxel-wise O
manner O
using O
SPM8 O
. O

FDR O
correction O
with O
P O
< O
0.05 O
was O
used O
to O
identify O
brain O
regions O
that O
showed O
significant O
positive O
correlations O
with O
the O
seed O
region O
. O

Next O
, O
a O
two-sample O
t-test O
was O
performed O
within O
the O
positive O
rs-FC O
mask O
to O
quantitatively O
compare O
the O
differences O
in O
rsFC O
of O
the O
seed O
region O
between O
schizophrenia O
patients O
and O
healthy O
controls O
. O

Multiple O
comparisons O
were O
corrected O
using O
the O
FDR O
method O
with O
a O
corrected O
threshold O
of O
P O
< O
0.05 O
. O

To O
test O
the O
association O
between O
rsFC O
and O
the O
clinical O
variables O
, O
voxel-wise O
multiple O
regression O
analysis O
was O
performed O
for O
the O
patient O
group O
within O
a O
mask O
constructed O
from O
the O
group O
differences O
between O
patients O
and O
controls O
. O

A O
threshold O
of O
P O
< O
0.01 O
was O
considered O
significant O
. O

The O
P1 O
Visual-Evoked O
Potential O
, O
Red O
Light O
, O
and O
Transdiagnostic O
Psychiatric O
Symptoms O
A O
reduced O
P1 O
visual-evoked O
potential O
amplitude O
has O
been O
reported O
across O
several O
psychiatric O
disorders O
, O
including O
schizophrenia-spectrum O
, O
bipolar O
, O
and O
depressive O
disorders O
. O

In O
addition O
, O
a O
difference O
in O
P1 O
amplitude O
change O
to O
a O
red O
background O
compared O
to O
its O
opponent O
color O
, O
green O
, O
has O
been O
found O
in O
schizophrenia-spectrum O
samples O
. O

The O
current O
study O
examined O
whether O
specific O
psychiatric O
symptoms O
that O
related O
to O
these O
P1 O
abnormalities O
in O
earlier O
studies O
would O
be O
replicated O
when O
using O
a O
broad O
transdiagnostic O
sample O
. O

The O
final O
sample O
consisted O
of O
135 O
participants O
: O
26 O
with O
bipolar O
disorders O
, O
25 O
with O
schizophrenia-spectrum O
disorders O
, O
19 O
with O
unipolar O
depression O
, O
62 O
with O
no O
current O
psychiatric O
disorder O
, O
and O
3 O
with O
disorders O
in O
other O
categories O
. O

Low O
( O
8 O
% O
) O
and O
high O
( O
64 O
% O
) O
contrast O
check O
arrays O
were O
presented O
on O
gray O
, O
green O
, O
and O
red O
background O
conditions O
during O
electroencephalogram O
, O
while O
an O
eye O
tracker O
monitored O
visual O
fixation O
on O
the O
stimuli O
. O

Linear O
regressions O
across O
the O
entire O
sample O
( O
N O
= O
135 O
) O
found O
that O
greater O
severity O
of O
both O
clinician-rated O
and O
self-reported O
delusions/magical O
thinking O
correlated O
with O
a O
reduced O
P1 O
amplitude O
on O
the O
low O
contrast O
gray O
( O
neutral O
) O
background O
condition O
. O

In O
addition O
, O
across O
the O
entire O
sample O
, O
higher O
self-reported O
constricted O
affect O
was O
associated O
with O
a O
larger O
decrease O
in O
P1 O
amplitude O
( O
averaged O
across O
contrast O
conditions O
) O
to O
the O
red O
, O
compared O
to O
green O
, O
background O
. O

All O
relationships O
remained O
statistically O
significant O
after O
covarying O
for O
diagnostic O
class O
, O
suggesting O
that O
they O
are O
relatively O
transdiagnostic O
in O
nature O
. O

These O
findings O
indicate O
that O
early O
visual O
processing O
abnormalities O
may O
be O
more O
directly O
related O
to O
specific O
transdiagnostic O
symptoms O
such O
as O
delusions O
and O
constricted O
affect O
rather O
than O
specific O
psychiatric O
diagnoses O
or O
broad O
symptom O
factor O
scales O
. O

4 O
. O

Methods O
4.1 O
. O

Participants O
This O
study O
was O
approved O
by O
the O
Institutional O
Review O
Board O
of O
the O
University O
of O
Central O
Florida O
and O
follows O
the O
ethical O
guidelines O
described O
in O
the O
Declaration O
of O
Helsinki O
. O

We O
recruited O
participants O
using O
two O
different O
types O
of O
advertisements O
. O

One O
mentioned O
that O
we O
were O
looking O
for O
individuals O
with O
a O
diagnosis O
of O
schizophrenia O
, O
schizoaffective O
disorder O
, O
or O
bipolar O
disorder O
, O
while O
the O
other O
mentioned O
that O
we O
were O
looking O
for O
adults O
between O
the O
ages O
of O
21 O
and O
55 O
. O

These O
advertisements O
were O
placed O
in O
a O
variety O
of O
locations O
including O
local O
psychiatric O
facilities O
, O
local O
newspapers O
, O
and O
the O
Craigslist O
website O
. O

For O
the O
psychiatric O
group O
, O
inclusion O
criteria O
included O
having O
any O
psychiatric O
diagnosis O
, O
even O
though O
advertisements O
were O
targeting O
particular O
ones O
. O

For O
the O
nonpsychiatric O
group O
, O
the O
presence O
of O
any O
current O
psychiatric O
disorder O
was O
an O
exclusion O
criteria O
, O
as O
was O
having O
a O
biological O
relative O
with O
a O
psychotic O
disorder O
or O
bipolar O
disorder O
. O

For O
both O
groups O
, O
inclusion O
criteria O
included O
being O
between O
the O
ages O
of O
21 O
and O
55 O
, O
and O
further O
exclusion O
criteria O
included O
: O
history O
of O
a O
neurological O
disorder O
, O
seizures O
, O
or O
head O
injury O
resulting O
in O
loss O
of O
consciousness O
for O
more O
than O
15 O
minutes O
, O
substance O
abuse O
or O
dependence O
in O
the O
last O
six O
months O
( O
per O
diagnostic O
interview O
) O
, O
heavy O
alcohol O
use O
or O
any O
drug O
use O
in O
the O
72 O
hours O
prior O
to O
each O
session O
( O
per O
self-report O
) O
, O
estimated O
full O
scale O
IQ O
< O
70 O
, O
visual O
acuity O
worse O
than O
20/50 O
( O
allowing O
for O
corrective O
lenses O
) O
, O
and O
indication O
of O
color O
blindness O
. O

Following O
a O
phone O
screening O
, O
eligible O
participants O
were O
invited O
to O
the O
first O
of O
two O
sessions O
. O

Participants O
were O
provided O
a O
monetary O
stipend O
at O
the O
end O
of O
each O
session O
. O

Following O
recruitment O
attempts O
, O
we O
assessed O
178 O
participants O
in O
the O
first O
of O
the O
two O
sessions O
. O

Of O
these O
, O
43 O
individuals O
were O
not O
eligible O
for O
use O
in O
the O
final O
analyses O
for O
the O
following O
reasons O
: O
22 O
not O
able O
or O
willing O
to O
return O
to O
the O
second O
session O
, O
5 O
had O
substance O
dependence O
or O
abuse O
during O
past O
six O
months O
, O
6 O
EEG O
problems O
, O
3 O
problems O
calibrating O
the O
eye O
tracker O
, O
3 O
visual O
acuity O
worse O
than O
20/50 O
, O
2 O
excessive O
drowsiness O
during O
EEG O
recording O
, O
1 O
color O
blindness O
, O
and O
1 O
estimated O
IQ O
< O
70 O
. O

This O
resulted O
in O
135 O
participants O
included O
in O
the O
final O
analyses O
. O

While O
sample O
diagnoses O
are O
similar O
to O
our O
previously O
published O
study O
on O
visual-evoked O
potentials O
, O
only O
five O
of O
those O
individuals O
participated O
in O
the O
current O
study O
. O

See O
Table O
1 O
for O
demographic O
and O
clinical O
characteristics O
. O

Diagnoses O
by O
broad O
classes O
included O
: O
1 O
) O
no O
current O
psychiatric O
disorder O
( O
N O
= O
62 O
[ O
46 O
% O
] O
) O
; O
2 O
) O
bipolar O
disorders O
( O
N O
= O
26 O
[ O
19 O
% O
] O
; O
24 O
bipolar O
I O
disorder O
[ O
7 O
with O
psychotic O
features O
] O
and O
2 O
bipolar O
disorder O
not O
otherwise O
specified O
) O
; O
3 O
) O
schizophrenia O
spectrum O
disorder O
( O
N O
= O
25 O
[ O
19 O
% O
] O
; O
15 O
schizophrenia O
, O
4 O
schizoaffective O
disorder O
, O
2 O
delusional O
disorder O
, O
and O
3 O
schizotypal O
and O
1 O
paranoid O
personality O
disorder O
) O
; O
and O
4 O
) O
recurrent O
or O
current O
unipolar O
depressive O
disorders O
( O
N O
= O
19 O
[ O
14 O
% O
] O
; O
14 O
major O
depressive O
disorder O
, O
recurrent O
[ O
2 O
with O
psychotic O
features O
] O
, O
2 O
major O
depressive O
disorder O
, O
single O
episode O
[ O
current O
] O
, O
2 O
dysthymic O
disorder O
, O
and O
1 O
depressive O
disorder O
not O
otherwise O
specified O
) O
. O

Transdiagnostic O
analyses O
also O
included O
three O
participants O
with O
other O
current O
psychiatric O
disorders O
: O
1 O
adjustment O
disorder O
with O
anxiety O
, O
1 O
social O
phobia O
, O
and O
1 O
obsessive O
compulsive O
disorder O
. O

The O
four O
diagnostic O
class O
groups O
did O
not O
differ O
on O
age O
, O
F O
( O
3,131 O
) O
= O
0.26 O
, O
p O
= O
.85 O
, O
η2 O
= O
.006 O
, O
sex O
, O
χ2 O
( O
3 O
, O
N O
= O
135 O
) O
= O
2.21 O
, O
p O
= O
.53 O
, O
race O
, O
χ2 O
( O
9 O
, O
N O
= O
135 O
) O
= O
13.54 O
, O
p O
= O
.14 O
, O
or O
Hispanic/Latino O
( O
a O
) O
ethnicity O
χ2 O
( O
3 O
, O
N O
= O
135 O
) O
= O
1.75 O
, O
p O
= O
.63 O
. O

However O
, O
level O
of O
education O
differed O
between O
the O
four O
groups O
( O
see O
Table O
1 O
) O
, O
F O
( O
3,131 O
) O
= O
6.95 O
, O
p O
< O
.001 O
, O
η2 O
= O
.14 O
. O

The O
no O
current O
psychiatric O
disorder O
group O
had O
a O
significantly O
higher O
level O
of O
education O
as O
compared O
to O
the O
depressive O
, O
F O
( O
1,82 O
) O
= O
7.41 O
, O
p O
= O
.01 O
, O
η2 O
= O
.08 O
, O
and O
schizophrenia O
spectrum O
, O
F O
( O
1,88 O
) O
= O
9.86 O
, O
p O
= O
.002 O
, O
η2 O
= O
.10 O
, O
disorder O
groups O
, O
who O
did O
not O
differ O
from O
each O
other O
, O
F O
( O
1,42 O
) O
= O
0.01 O
, O
p O
= O
.95 O
, O
η2 O
< O
.001 O
. O

The O
bipolar O
disorders O
group O
had O
a O
significantly O
higher O
level O
of O
education O
than O
the O
depressive O
, O
F O
( O
1,43 O
) O
= O
9.34 O
, O
p O
= O
.004 O
, O
η2 O
= O
.18 O
, O
and O
schizophrenia O
spectrum O
, O
F O
( O
1,49 O
) O
= O
12.11 O
, O
p O
= O
.001 O
, O
η2 O
= O
.20 O
, O
disorder O
groups O
, O
but O
did O
not O
differ O
from O
the O
no O
current O
disorder O
group O
, O
F O
( O
1,89 O
) O
= O
2.25 O
, O
p O
= O
.14 O
, O
η2 O
= O
.03 O
. O

4.2 O
. O

Procedures O
Due O
to O
the O
length O
of O
the O
procedures O
, O
the O
study O
was O
administered O
over O
two O
meetings O
of O
approximately O
two O
to O
three O
hours O
, O
which O
were O
19.76 O
days O
apart O
on O
average O
, O
with O
six O
participants O
completing O
both O
sessions O
on O
the O
same O
day O
. O

In O
cases O
in O
which O
more O
than O
a O
month O
elapsed O
between O
sessions O
( O
N O
= O
26 O
) O
, O
the O
clinician-administered O
diagnostic O
interviews O
and O
symptom O
measures O
were O
re-administered O
to O
reflect O
any O
changes O
. O

4.2.1 O
. O

Session O
# O
1 O
Procedures O
After O
an O
informed O
consent O
procedure O
, O
participants O
completed O
the O
Colenbrander O
Mixed O
Contrast O
Card O
Set O
( O
Precision O
Vision O
, O
La O
Salle O
, O
IL O
) O
to O
estimate O
visual O
acuity O
. O

Participants O
with O
a O
corrected O
visual O
acuity O
worse O
than O
20/50 O
at O
an O
intermediate O
distance O
were O
excluded O
, O
as O
were O
participants O
exhibiting O
color O
blindness O
using O
Ishihara O
's O
Tests O
for O
Colour O
Deficiency O
( O
Kanehara O
Trading O
Inc. O
, O
Tokyo O
, O
Japan O
) O
. O

Participants O
completed O
the O
Wide O
Range O
Achievement O
Test O
– O
4th O
edition O
( O
WRAT-4 O
) O
Reading O
subtest O
to O
estimate O
full O
scale O
IQ O
, O
and O
were O
excluded O
if O
the O
standardized O
score O
was O
less O
than O
70 O
. O

A O
trained O
clinical O
psychology O
doctoral O
student O
administered O
the O
Structured O
Clinical O
Interview O
for O
DSM-IV O
Axis O
I O
Disorders O
, O
the O
schizotypal O
, O
paranoid O
, O
and O
avoidant O
personality O
disorder O
( O
i.e. O
, O
schizophrenia-spectrum O
) O
sections O
of O
the O
Structured O
Clinical O
Interview O
for O
DSM-IV O
Axis O
II O
Disorders O
, O
and O
the O
Structured O
Interview O
for O
Positive O
and O
Negative O
Syndromes O
of O
Schizophrenia O
( O
PANSS O
) O
. O

Final O
diagnoses O
were O
determined O
through O
case O
presentations O
with O
a O
licensed O
psychologist O
( O
author O
JSB O
) O
. O

Participants O
also O
completed O
the O
Schizotypal O
Personality O
Questionnaire O
– O
Brief O
Revised O
( O
SPQ-BR O
) O
, O
and O
the O
Anticipatory O
and O
Consummatory O
Interpersonal O
Pleasure O
Scale O
( O
ACIPS O
) O
. O

Participants O
were O
invited O
to O
Session O
# O
2 O
if O
they O
passed O
the O
exclusion O
criteria O
listed O
above O
, O
and O
did O
not O
meet O
diagnostic O
criteria O
for O
a O
substance O
use O
disorder O
in O
the O
past O
six O
months O
. O

4.2.2 O
. O

Session O
# O
2 O
Procedures O
After O
an O
informed O
consent O
procedure O
, O
participants O
completed O
the O
visual O
evoked O
potential O
task O
. O

Stimuli O
consisted O
of O
8 O
× O
8 O
arrays O
of O
checks O
, O
as O
used O
in O
several O
other O
transient O
VEP O
publications O
. O

E-Prime O
2.0 O
Professional O
was O
used O
for O
stimuli O
presentation O
. O

The O
array O
of O
gray O
checks O
appeared O
in O
the O
center O
of O
the O
monitor O
screen O
( O
see O
Figure O
5 O
) O
, O
subtending O
a O
visual O
angle O
of O
6.67 O
× O
6.67 O
degrees O
. O

The O
checks O
were O
presented O
on O
three O
different O
backgrounds O
of O
gray O
, O
green O
, O
and O
red O
, O
which O
surrounded O
the O
checks O
and O
the O
rest O
of O
the O
screen O
, O
subtending O
a O
visual O
angle O
of O
32.48 O
× O
18.53 O
degrees O
. O

The O
gray O
background O
was O
chosen O
as O
the O
primary O
baseline O
color O
to O
allow O
for O
comparison O
to O
VEP O
studies O
from O
other O
labs O
. O

We O
also O
had O
specific O
interest O
in O
the O
effect O
of O
the O
red O
background O
, O
so O
green O
was O
included O
for O
that O
comparison O
as O
it O
is O
the O
opponent O
color O
of O
red O
. O

The O
background O
colors O
were O
approximately O
matched O
for O
a O
physical O
luminance O
of O
30 O
cd/m2 O
, O
using O
a O
spot O
photometer O
placed O
at O
the O
center O
of O
the O
screen O
. O

The O
gray O
checks O
were O
brighter O
than O
the O
background O
to O
create O
low O
( O
8 O
% O
) O
and O
high O
( O
64 O
% O
) O
contrast O
stimuli O
for O
each O
of O
the O
three O
color O
backgrounds O
. O

The O
ambient O
light O
in O
the O
room O
was O
dim O
( O
approximately O
0.23 O
cd/m2 O
) O
. O

The O
three O
color O
backgrounds O
cycled O
in O
blocks O
, O
with O
participants O
randomly O
assigned O
to O
the O
order O
of O
green–gray–red O
or O
red–gray–green O
. O

Each O
of O
these O
sequences O
contained O
a O
20 O
second O
countdown O
rest O
period O
on O
a O
black O
background O
following O
each O
color O
block O
. O

Each O
color O
block O
contained O
50 O
trials O
of O
each O
of O
the O
two O
contrasts O
presented O
in O
a O
random O
order O
. O

The O
color O
blocks O
cycled O
five O
times O
, O
resulting O
in O
250 O
trials O
of O
each O
contrast O
by O
color O
condition O
. O

In O
addition O
, O
line O
drawings O
of O
four O
different O
animals O
were O
presented O
during O
26 O
random O
trials O
within O
each O
color O
block O
, O
with O
13 O
of O
those O
trials O
representing O
a O
target O
animal O
for O
which O
the O
participant O
was O
asked O
to O
press O
a O
button O
on O
a O
game O
controller O
. O

These O
animal O
stimuli O
were O
included O
to O
help O
participants O
engage O
and O
attend O
to O
the O
passive O
task O
– O
consistent O
with O
past O
studies O
using O
check O
arrays O
. O

Each O
stimulus O
was O
presented O
for O
60 O
ms O
followed O
by O
a O
blank O
screen O
of O
the O
same O
color O
background O
for O
an O
interstimulus O
interval O
( O
ISI O
) O
that O
varied O
randomly O
between O
540 O
– O
1,340 O
ms O
for O
the O
majority O
of O
the O
trials O
, O
although O
it O
could O
remain O
up O
to O
5,840 O
ms O
if O
the O
eye O
tracker O
did O
not O
detect O
a O
fixation O
near O
center O
of O
the O
screen O
( O
details O
provided O
below O
) O
. O

The O
duration O
of O
the O
entire O
task O
was O
approximately O
50 O
minutes O
. O

A O
graphic O
representation O
of O
task O
flow O
is O
provided O
in O
Figure O
6 O
. O

EEG O
was O
recorded O
using O
a O
64 O
channel O
Neuroscan O
Synamps2 O
system O
, O
with O
DC O
recording O
digitized O
at O
1,000 O
Hz O
, O
with O
a O
200 O
Hz O
low O
pass O
filter O
, O
no O
high-pass O
filter O
, O
and O
impedance O
of O
less O
than O
10 O
kOhms O
at O
each O
electrode O
. O

The O
average O
from O
unlinked O
bilateral O
mastoid O
electrodes O
were O
used O
as O
the O
active O
reference O
, O
and O
vertical O
and O
horizontal O
ocular O
electrodes O
were O
used O
to O
estimate O
blinks O
and O
large O
eye O
movements O
. O

Eye O
movements O
were O
recorded O
monocularly O
from O
the O
right O
eye O
using O
an O
EyeLink O
1000 O
remote O
eye O
tracker O
( O
SR O
Research O
Ltd. O
, O
Mississsauga O
, O
Ontario O
, O
Canada O
) O
, O
sampling O
at O
500 O
Hz O
. O

The O
task O
began O
with O
a O
five-point O
calibration O
routine O
to O
set O
the O
average O
and O
maximum O
calibration O
error O
at O
less O
than O
0.5° O
and O
1.0° O
of O
visual O
angle O
respectively O
. O

Following O
each O
stimulus O
and O
an O
initial O
randomly O
selected O
ISI O
of O
40 O
to O
840 O
ms O
, O
the O
eye O
tracker O
monitored O
for O
a O
fixation O
of O
at O
least O
500 O
ms O
in O
the O
center O
of O
the O
screen O
( O
7° O
× O
7° O
visual O
angle O
) O
, O
which O
would O
then O
trigger O
the O
presentation O
of O
the O
next O
stimulus O
. O

This O
helped O
ensure O
that O
participants O
had O
their O
eyes O
open O
and O
fixated O
near O
the O
center O
of O
the O
screen O
immediately O
prior O
to O
the O
presentation O
of O
each O
stimulus O
. O

If O
a O
sufficiently O
long O
central O
fixation O
was O
not O
detected O
within O
5,000 O
ms O
, O
the O
eye O
tracker O
recorded O
that O
the O
ISI O
had O
timed O
out O
and O
proceeded O
to O
the O
next O
trial O
. O

This O
procedure O
resulted O
in O
a O
total O
possible O
ISI O
duration O
of O
540 O
-5,840 O
ms. O
4.2.3 O
. O

VEP O
Measurement O
Procedures O
The O
VEP O
data O
was O
analyzed O
using O
Brain O
Vision O
Analyzer O
2.1.2 O
software O
and O
was O
filtered O
offline O
using O
a O
high O
pass O
filter O
of O
0.10 O
Hz O
and O
low O
pass O
filter O
of O
45 O
Hz O
, O
both O
using O
a O
roll O
off O
of O
48 O
db/oct O
. O

The O
data O
was O
segmented O
from O
-100 O
to O
500 O
ms O
based O
on O
the O
onset O
of O
the O
check O
stimuli O
( O
stimulus-locked O
) O
, O
and O
was O
then O
corrected O
for O
blinks O
and O
large O
eye O
movements O
using O
independent O
component O
analysis O
on O
the O
ocular O
electrodes O
. O

Data O
were O
down-sampled O
to O
500 O
Hz O
, O
re-referenced O
to O
the O
common O
average O
, O
and O
baseline O
corrected O
from O
-100 O
to O
0 O
ms. O
Artifact O
rejection O
removed O
segments O
from O
particular O
electrodes O
containing O
more O
than O
a O
+/- O
100 O
μV O
deflection O
. O

We O
then O
segmented O
the O
data O
based O
on O
the O
contrast O
and O
color O
condition O
and O
averaged O
the O
segments O
within O
each O
condition O
using O
individual O
channel O
mode O
. O

Brain O
electric O
source O
analysis O
( O
BESA O
) O
The O
basic O
premise O
of O
source O
modeling O
is O
that O
a O
component O
can O
be O
defined O
as O
the O
part O
of O
the O
scalp O
waveform O
that O
results O
from O
the O
compound O
local O
activity O
of O
a O
circumscribed O
brain O
region O
. O

BESA O
employs O
a O
least O
squares O
fitting O
algorithm O
, O
over O
which O
the O
user O
has O
interactive O
control O
. O

Source O
localization O
proceeds O
by O
a O
search O
within O
the O
head O
model O
for O
a O
location O
where O
the O
sources O
can O
explain O
a O
maximal O
amount O
of O
variance O
. O

Here O
, O
we O
assumed O
bilateral O
symmetrical O
sources O
. O

An O
assumption O
of O
spatial O
symmetry O
considerably O
reduces O
the O
number O
of O
independent O
parameters O
to O
be O
determined O
and O
is O
consistent O
with O
the O
known O
generators O
of O
P1 O
. O

The O
inverse O
leadfield O
matrix O
( O
i.e. O
, O
the O
matrix O
of O
coefficients O
that O
maps O
current O
sources O
to O
surface O
potentials O
) O
was O
then O
used O
to O
project O
the O
modeled O
dipolar O
activity O
back O
onto O
the O
scalp O
surface O
in O
order O
to O
select O
the O
optimal O
channels O
used O
for O
the O
ERP O
analysis O
of O
the O
P1 O
component O
. O

Source O
modeling O
resulted O
in O
dipoles O
localized O
to O
generators O
in O
dorsal O
extrastriate O
cortex O
of O
the O
middle O
occipital O
gyrus O
consistent O
with O
previous O
studies O
. O

The O
model O
produced O
a O
goodness-of-fit O
value O
of O
96.4 O
% O
( O
residual O
variance O
= O
3.6 O
% O
) O
across O
the O
modeled O
epoch O
of O
80 O
– O
116 O
ms O
( O
see O
Figure O
7 O
a O
, O
b O
) O
. O

Based O
on O
the O
distribution O
of O
the O
dipolar O
surface O
projection O
, O
we O
chose O
to O
measure O
P1 O
from O
the O
average O
of O
six O
electrodes O
from O
each O
hemisphere O
: O
TP7/8 O
, O
CP5/6 O
, O
CP3/4 O
, O
P7/8 O
, O
P5/6 O
, O
and O
P3/4 O
, O
generating O
one O
analysis O
region O
of O
interest O
( O
ROI O
) O
on O
each O
hemisphere O
( O
see O
Figure O
7c O
) O
. O

We O
measured O
P1 O
separately O
for O
each O
ROI O
, O
using O
the O
largest O
positive O
peak O
appearing O
in O
the O
time O
window O
of O
60 O
to O
195 O
ms O
. O

The O
average O
amplitude O
of O
this O
peak O
was O
measured O
using O
a O
20 O
ms O
window O
centered O
on O
the O
peak O
from O
the O
averaged O
waveform O
for O
each O
hemisphere O
and O
condition O
within O
each O
participant O
. O

See O
Figure O
8 O
for O
a O
depiction O
of O
the O
grand O
average O
waveforms O
by O
color O
and O
contrast O
across O
all O
participants O
. O

4.3 O
. O

Statistical O
Analyses O
Prior O
to O
examining O
symptom O
relationships O
, O
we O
examined O
P1 O
amplitude O
across O
the O
entire O
sample O
using O
repeated-measures O
ANCOVAs O
to O
assess O
the O
general O
effects O
of O
contrast O
and O
hemisphere O
. O

For O
examination O
of O
symptom O
relationships O
with O
the O
P1 O
amplitude O
, O
we O
conducted O
linear O
regressions O
, O
with O
hypothesized O
symptoms O
entered O
simultaneously O
. O

As O
there O
was O
substantial O
shared O
variance O
between O
clinician-rated O
and O
self-reported O
symptoms O
, O
we O
ran O
separate O
regressions O
for O
each O
type O
of O
assessment O
modality O
. O

Analyses O
with O
the O
gray O
background O
included O
the O
two O
hypothesized O
clinician-rated O
PANSS O
symptoms O
of O
Delusions O
( O
P1 O
) O
and O
Conceptual O
Disorganization O
( O
P2 O
) O
, O
along O
with O
two O
other O
symptoms O
found O
in O
a O
single O
past O
study O
- O
Suspiciousness/Persecution O
( O
P6 O
) O
, O
and O
Emotional O
Withdrawal O
( O
N2 O
) O
, O
and O
corresponding O
self-reported O
symptoms O
from O
the O
SPQ-BR O
subscales O
of O
: O
Magical O
Thinking O
, O
Eccentric O
Behavior O
, O
Odd O
Speech O
, O
and O
Suspiciousness O
( O
sum O
of O
the O
three O
items O
; O
excluding O
Ideas O
of O
Reference O
items O
) O
. O

Analyses O
examining O
the O
change O
from O
the O
green O
to O
red O
background O
included O
the O
two O
hypothesized O
PANSS O
symptoms O
of O
Blunted O
Affect O
( O
N1 O
) O
and O
Passive/Apathetic O
Social O
Withdrawal O
( O
N4 O
) O
, O
and O
related O
self-report O
scales O
of O
SPQ-BR O
Constricted O
Affect O
( O
sum O
of O
the O
three O
items O
; O
excluding O
No O
Close O
Friends O
items O
) O
, O
SPQ-BR O
Social O
Anxiety O
, O
and O
the O
ACIPS O
total O
score O
. O

We O
also O
added O
SPQ-BR O
Ideas O
of O
Reference O
( O
sum O
of O
the O
three O
items O
; O
excluding O
Suspiciousness O
items O
) O
and O
the O
corresponding O
PANSS O
Delusions O
item O
to O
analyses O
as O
one O
past O
study O
using O
the O
full O
original O
SPQ O
found O
this O
association O
. O

Any O
statistically O
significant O
regressions O
were O
then O
repeated O
with O
the O
addition O
of O
covarying O
for O
diagnostic O
class O
in O
order O
to O
examine O
the O
relative O
influence O
of O
that O
variable O
. O

The O
three O
individuals O
with O
disorders O
outside O
of O
the O
classes O
of O
interest O
were O
combined O
with O
the O
nonpsychiatric O
controls O
for O
these O
post O
hoc O
analyses O
. O

All O
regressions O
were O
examined O
for O
multicollinearity O
( O
Variance O
Inflation O
Factor O
> O
4 O
or O
Condition O
Index O
> O
30 O
) O
and O
statistical O
outliers O
( O
defined O
by O
combination O
of O
Studentized O
residual O
> O
3.0 O
and O
Cook O
's O
d O
> O
.03 O
) O
. O

Any O
deviations O
from O
these O
parameters O
are O
reported O
in O
the O
results O
. O

This O
is O
a O
PDF O
file O
of O
an O
unedited O
manuscript O
that O
has O
been O
accepted O
for O
publication O
. O

As O
a O
service O
to O
our O
customers O
we O
are O
providing O
this O
early O
version O
of O
the O
manuscript O
. O

The O
manuscript O
will O
undergo O
copyediting O
, O
typesetting O
, O
and O
review O
of O
the O
resulting O
proof O
before O
it O
is O
published O
in O
its O
final O
citable O
form O
. O

Please O
note O
that O
during O
the O
production O
process O
errors O
may O
be O
discovered O
which O
could O
affect O
the O
content O
, O
and O
all O
legal O
disclaimers O
that O
apply O
to O
the O
journal O
pertain O
. O

Highlights O
Delusion O
severity O
negatively O
related O
to O
amplitude O
of O
P1 O
visual-evoked O
potential O
Constricted O
affect O
negatively O
related O
to O
change O
in O
P1 O
amplitude O
to O
red O
background O
Participants O
with O
schizophrenia O
showed O
reduced O
P1 O
amplitude O
compared O
to O
controls O

Hippocampal O
network O
modularity O
is O
associated O
with O
relational O
memory O
dysfunction O
in O
schizophrenia O
Background O
Functional O
dysconnectivity O
has O
been O
proposed O
as O
a O
major O
pathophysiological O
mechanism O
for O
cognitive O
dysfunction O
in O
schizophrenia O
. O

The O
hippocampus O
is O
a O
focal O
point O
of O
dysconnectivity O
in O
schizophrenia O
, O
with O
decreased O
hippocampal O
functional O
connectivity O
contributing O
to O
the O
marked O
memory O
deficits O
observed O
in O
patients O
. O

Normal O
memory O
function O
relies O
on O
the O
interaction O
of O
complex O
cortico-hippocampal O
networks O
. O

However O
, O
only O
recent O
technological O
advances O
have O
enabled O
the O
large-scale O
exploration O
of O
functional O
networks O
with O
accuracy O
and O
precision O
. O

Methods O
We O
investigated O
the O
modularity O
of O
hippocampal O
resting-state O
functional O
networks O
in O
a O
sample O
of O
45 O
patients O
with O
schizophrenia O
spectrum O
disorders O
and O
38 O
healthy O
control O
subjects O
. O

Modularity O
was O
calculated O
for O
two O
distinct O
functional O
networks O
: O
a O
core O
hippocampal-medial O
temporal O
lobe O
cortex O
( O
MTLC O
) O
network O
; O
and O
an O
extended O
hippocampalcortical O
network O
. O

As O
hippocampal O
function O
differs O
along O
its O
longitudinal O
axis O
, O
follow-up O
analyses O
examined O
anterior O
and O
posterior O
networks O
separately O
. O

To O
explore O
effects O
of O
resting O
network O
function O
on O
behavior O
, O
we O
tested O
associations O
between O
modularity O
and O
relational O
memory O
ability O
. O

Age O
, O
sex O
, O
handedness O
, O
and O
parental O
education O
were O
similar O
between O
groups O
. O

Results O
Network O
modularity O
was O
lower O
in O
schizophrenia O
patients O
, O
especially O
in O
the O
posterior O
hippocampal O
network O
. O

Schizophrenia O
patients O
also O
showed O
markedly O
lower O
relational O
memory O
ability O
compared O
to O
control O
subjects O
. O

We O
found O
a O
distinct O
brain-behavior O
relationship O
in O
schizophrenia O
that O
differed O
from O
control O
subjects O
by O
network O
and O
anterior/posterior O
division—while O
relational O
memory O
in O
control O
subjects O
was O
associated O
with O
anterior O
hippocampal-cortical O
modularity O
, O
schizophrenia O
patients O
showed O
an O
association O
with O
posterior O
hippocampal-MTLC O
network O
modularity O
. O

Conclusions O
Our O
findings O
support O
a O
model O
of O
abnormal O
resting-state O
cortico-hippocampal O
network O
coherence O
in O
schizophrenia O
, O
which O
may O
contribute O
to O
relational O
memory O
deficits O
. O

METHODS O
AND O
MATERIAL O
Participants O
We O
studied O
45 O
patients O
with O
schizophrenia O
spectrum O
disorder O
( O
i.e. O
, O
schizophreniform O
disorder O
, O
schizophrenia O
, O
schizoaffective O
disorder O
) O
and O
38 O
healthy O
control O
subjects O
( O
Table O
1 O
) O
. O

Patients O
were O
recruited O
from O
the O
inpatient O
units O
and O
outpatient O
clinics O
of O
the O
Vanderbilt O
Psychiatric O
Hospital O
into O
a O
registered O
neuroimaging O
repository O
from O
2008 O
through O
2013 O
( O
clinicaltrials.gov O
; O
NCT00762866 O
) O
. O

All O
participants O
were O
assessed O
by O
a O
trained O
rater O
using O
the O
Structured O
Clinical O
Interview O
for O
the O
DSM-IV O
( O
SCID O
I-P O
) O
, O
and O
diagnoses O
were O
confirmed O
by O
a O
senior O
clinician O
( O
S.H O
. O
) O

through O
patient O
interview O
, O
consensus O
conference O
, O
and O
available O
hospital O
records O
. O

At O
the O
time O
of O
participation O
, O
19 O
patients O
were O
diagnosed O
with O
schizophreniform O
disorder O
. O

Follow-up O
diagnoses O
were O
available O
for O
14 O
of O
these O
patients O
: O
13 O
patients O
converted O
to O
schizophrenia O
and O
1 O
patient O
converted O
to O
schizoaffective O
disorder O
. O

Healthy O
control O
subjects O
were O
recruited O
from O
the O
surrounding O
community O
. O

Participants O
were O
assessed O
for O
current O
mood O
, O
psychotic O
symptom O
severity O
, O
and O
intellectual O
function O
( O
see O
Supplementary O
Methods O
) O
. O

There O
were O
no O
significant O
differences O
in O
age O
, O
sex O
, O
handedness O
, O
and O
years O
of O
parental O
education O
by O
group O
( O
Table O
1 O
) O
. O

Participants O
were O
selected O
for O
this O
analysis O
based O
on O
the O
following O
criteria O
: O
1 O
) O
successful O
completion O
of O
an O
eye O
tracking O
memory O
study O
; O
and O
2 O
) O
completion O
of O
a O
high-quality O
resting-state O
functional O
connectivity O
scan O
( O
see O
quality O
methods O
below O
) O
. O

Twenty-eight O
of O
the O
38 O
healthy O
control O
subjects O
and O
23 O
of O
the O
45 O
schizophrenia O
patients O
had O
been O
included O
in O
a O
previous O
behavioral O
study O
. O

Exclusion O
criteria O
were O
age O
less O
than O
16 O
or O
greater O
than O
65 O
, O
a O
history O
of O
significant O
head O
injury O
, O
major O
medical O
( O
i.e. O
, O
HIV O
, O
cancer O
) O
or O
neurological O
illness O
, O
any O
contraindication O
for O
MRI O
scanning O
( O
e.g. O
, O
pregnancy O
, O
metal O
implants O
, O
claustrophobia O
) O
, O
current O
alcohol O
or O
substance O
abuse O
within O
the O
past O
3 O
months O
, O
and O
uncorrected O
vision O
deficits O
( O
see O
Supplementary O
Methods O
for O
full O
repository O
sample O
details O
) O
. O

Healthy O
control O
subjects O
were O
excluded O
for O
any O
history O
of O
Axis O
I O
disorders O
or O
prior O
psychotropic O
medication O
use O
, O
or O
a O
first-degree O
relative O
with O
a O
psychotic O
illness O
. O

Participants O
in O
both O
groups O
were O
predominantly O
white O
( O
69 O
% O
) O
, O
although O
groups O
differed O
by O
racial O
composition O
( O
X2 O
= O
7.86 O
, O
p O
= O
.005 O
) O
. O

Secondary O
analyses O
were O
performed O
to O
test O
for O
potential O
effects O
of O
race O
on O
modularity O
results O
. O

This O
study O
was O
conducted O
in O
accordance O
with O
the O
Vanderbilt O
Human O
Research O
Protection O
Program O
and O
all O
participants O
provided O
written O
informed O
consent O
prior O
to O
study O
procedures O
. O

Participants O
received O
financial O
compensation O
for O
their O
time O
. O

Relational O
memory O
behavior O
Eye O
movements O
were O
recorded O
to O
assess O
memory O
performance O
during O
a O
face-scene O
pair O
task O
. O

During O
testing O
, O
participants O
were O
shown O
three O
previously-seen O
faces O
superimposed O
over O
a O
previously-seen O
background O
scene O
. O

One O
of O
the O
three O
overlaid O
faces O
( O
Match O
face O
) O
had O
been O
previously O
paired O
with O
the O
background O
scene O
( O
for O
further O
details O
see O
Supplementary O
Methods O
) O
. O

During O
the O
first O
2 O
s O
of O
test O
trials O
, O
schizophrenia O
patients O
spent O
less O
time O
fixating O
on O
faces O
and O
scenes O
compared O
to O
control O
subjects O
( O
Schizophrenia O
mean O
= O
1.24 O
s O
, O
SD O
= O
.16 O
s O
; O
Control O
mean O
=1.48 O
s O
, O
SD O
= O
.22 O
s O
; O
F O
= O
29.46 O
, O
p O
< O
.001 O
) O
, O
suggesting O
more O
time O
spent O
on O
blinks O
or O
looking O
away O
from O
the O
monitor O
; O
therefore O
, O
element O
viewing O
times O
were O
corrected O
for O
total O
viewing O
time O
. O

Previous O
findings O
have O
shown O
that O
preferential O
viewing O
associated O
with O
hippocampal O
function O
occurs O
within O
the O
first O
2 O
s O
of O
face-scene O
test O
viewing O
. O

Therefore O
, O
relational O
memory O
performance O
was O
characterized O
as O
the O
change O
in O
the O
proportion O
of O
time O
spent O
viewing O
the O
Match O
face O
( O
slope O
) O
during O
the O
first O
2 O
s O
of O
each O
Match O
trial O
. O

Slopes O
were O
corrected O
for O
between-subject O
differences O
in O
initial O
eye O
position O
( O
first O
250 O
ms O
) O
following O
face O
presentation O
. O

Imaging O
data O
acquisition O
and O
pre-processing O
Imaging O
data O
were O
collected O
on O
two O
identical O
3T O
Philips O
Intera O
Achieva O
magnetic O
resonance O
imaging O
( O
MRI O
) O
scanners O
located O
in O
the O
Vanderbilt O
University O
Institute O
for O
Imaging O
Science O
. O

A O
high-resolution O
T1-weighted O
fast O
field O
echo O
( O
FFE O
) O
structural O
scan O
( O
Supplementary O
Methods O
) O
and O
a O
7-minute O
echo-planar O
imaging O
resting-state O
functional O
scan O
( O
rs-fMRI O
) O
were O
collected O
for O
each O
subject O
. O

The O
rs-fMRI O
was O
collected O
with O
the O
following O
parameters O
, O
which O
provided O
whole-brain O
coverage O
: O
28 O
axial O
slices O
; O
FOV O
= O
240 O
mm O
; O
matrix O
= O
80 O
× O
80 O
, O
3 O
mm O
× O
3 O
mm O
in-plane O
resolution O
, O
slice O
thickness O
= O
4 O
mm O
; O
volumes O
= O
203 O
; O
TR O
= O
2 O
s O
; O
TE O
= O
35 O
ms O
; O
SENSE O
= O
1.8 O
. O

Participants O
were O
instructed O
to O
relax O
and O
close O
their O
eyes O
and O
to O
remain O
awake O
during O
the O
scan O
. O

The O
rs-fMRI O
was O
acquired O
following O
the O
structural O
scan O
and O
was O
not O
preceded O
by O
any O
cognitive O
tasks O
. O

Resting-state O
data O
were O
motion O
corrected O
, O
coregistered O
to O
the O
subject O
’ O
s O
structural O
image O
, O
and O
normalized O
to O
an O
MNI O
T1 O
template O
image O
in O
SPM8 O
( O
http O
: O
//www.fil.ion.ucl.ac.uk/spm O
) O
( O
Supplementary O
Methods O
) O
. O

Functional O
quality O
measures O
were O
computed O
using O
an O
in-house O
quality O
assurance O
toolbox O
; O
data O
with O
motion O
greater O
than O
2 O
mm O
translation O
or O
2° O
rotation O
, O
or O
with O
median O
framewise O
displacement O
( O
FD O
) O
greater O
than O
0.6 O
mm O
were O
not O
selected O
for O
analysis O
. O

Overall O
, O
motion O
was O
low O
( O
translation O
[ O
max O
] O
= O
.82 O
mm O
, O
rotation O
[ O
max O
] O
= O
1.27° O
, O
median O
FD O
[ O
max O
] O
= O
.55 O
) O
across O
subjects O
and O
similar O
between O
groups O
( O
all O
p O
’ O
s O
> O
.2 O
) O
. O

Functional O
connectivity O
and O
network O
modularity O
analysis O
Network O
connectivity O
was O
calculated O
at O
two O
levels O
: O
the O
hippocampal-medial O
temporal O
lobe O
cortex O
( O
MTLC O
) O
network O
, O
a O
core O
hippocampal O
network O
comprised O
of O
proximal O
connections O
central O
to O
memory O
function O
, O
including O
the O
hippocampal O
formation O
and O
adjacent O
entorhinal O
, O
perirhinal O
, O
and O
parahippocampal O
cortices O
; O
and O
the O
hippocampal-cortical O
network O
, O
a O
broader O
network O
including O
prefrontal O
, O
temporal O
, O
and O
parietal O
cortical O
regions O
that O
support O
memory O
function O
( O
Figure O
1 O
) O
. O

Because O
memory O
function O
and O
connectivity O
vary O
along O
the O
longitudinal O
axis O
of O
the O
hippocampus O
, O
follow-up O
analyses O
were O
conducted O
for O
the O
anterior O
and O
posterior O
hippocampus O
separately O
. O

To O
capture O
individual O
variation O
of O
hippocampal O
structure O
, O
hippocampus O
region O
of O
interest O
( O
ROI O
) O
masks O
were O
created O
for O
each O
participant O
using O
in-house O
multi-atlas O
segmentation O
techniques O
. O

Each O
ROI O
was O
manually O
segmented O
into O
an O
anterior O
and O
posterior O
mask O
by O
a O
trained O
rater O
( O
S.A. O
) O
. O

The O
anterior O
lateral O
and O
posterior O
medial O
entorhinal O
cortex O
were O
delineated O
by O
high-resolution O
functionally-derived O
masks O
. O

For O
the O
remaining O
cortical O
ROIs O
, O
a O
regular O
12 O
mm O
grid O
containing O
1068 O
spheres O
was O
overlaid O
on O
each O
subject O
’ O
s O
anatomically-segmented O
brain O
. O

Using O
anatomical O
atlases O
, O
spheres O
were O
selected O
within O
the O
perirhinal O
cortex O
( O
n O
= O
2 O
, O
bilateral O
) O
and O
parahippocampal O
cortex O
( O
n O
= O
4 O
, O
bilateral O
) O
. O

The O
remaining O
cortical O
spheres O
were O
chosen O
based O
on O
coordinates O
from O
an O
independent O
sample O
that O
show O
resting-state O
functional O
connectivity O
with O
the O
hippocampus O
( O
see O
Supplementary O
Table O
S1 O
for O
sphere O
coordinates O
) O
. O

In O
total O
, O
the O
hippocampal-cortical O
network O
consisted O
72 O
nodes O
( O
ROIs O
) O
and O
2,556 O
possible O
edges O
( O
connections O
) O
, O
while O
the O
core O
hippocampal-MTLC O
network O
consisted O
of O
20 O
nodes O
and O
190 O
possible O
edges O
. O

Connectivity O
analyses O
were O
performed O
in O
the O
Functional O
Connectivity O
( O
CONN O
) O
toolbox O
v16.a O
( O
www.nitrc.org/projects/conn O
) O
. O

Connectivity O
matrices O
( O
Supplementary O
Methods O
) O
were O
calculated O
for O
each O
subject O
and O
connections O
were O
analyzed O
for O
laterality O
differences O
. O

Connectivity O
strength O
was O
similar O
across O
hemispheres O
; O
therefore O
, O
left O
and O
right O
hemisphere O
connectivity O
values O
were O
averaged O
. O

To O
enhance O
contrast O
between O
relevant O
( O
strong O
) O
and O
irrelevant O
( O
weak O
) O
networks O
, O
graph O
matrices O
were O
thresholded O
to O
include O
only O
moderate O
to O
strong O
connections O
( O
|r| O
≥.5 O
) O
. O

The O
number O
of O
retained O
connections O
( O
edges O
) O
was O
similar O
between O
groups O
( O
sparsity O
~2 O
% O
, O
p O
= O
.74 O
) O
( O
Supplementary O
Methods O
) O
. O

Thresholded O
functional O
connectivity O
matrices O
are O
displayed O
in O
Supplementary O
Figure O
S1 O
. O

To O
explore O
the O
stability O
of O
networks O
over O
different O
levels O
of O
sparsity O
, O
graph O
matrices O
were O
also O
thresholded O
at O
values O
ranging O
from O
mild O
to O
strong O
connectivity O
( O
r O
= O
.3 O
, O
.4 O
, O
.6 O
, O
.7 O
) O
, O
corresponding O
to O
network O
sparsity O
of O
~13 O
% O
, O
6 O
% O
, O
1 O
% O
, O
and O
.5 O
% O
( O
Supplementary O
Figure O
S2 O
) O
. O

Connection O
matrices O
were O
binarized O
for O
each O
participant O
to O
create O
unweighted O
networks O
. O

Secondary O
analyses O
using O
only O
the O
positive O
connectivity O
network O
were O
also O
conducted O
to O
determine O
stability O
of O
findings O
. O

Connection O
matrices O
were O
collapsed O
by O
anatomical O
region O
for O
the O
purposes O
of O
visual O
display O
( O
Figure O
1 O
) O
. O

Modularity O
( O
Q O
) O
was O
calculated O
for O
a O
priori O
hippocampal O
networks O
( O
Figure O
1 O
) O
according O
to O
Newman O
’ O
s O
metric O
. O

Modularity O
can O
be O
described O
as O
the O
quality O
of O
the O
partition O
of O
the O
network O
, O
or O
the O
fraction O
of O
connections O
that O
fall O
within O
the O
network O
minus O
the O
expected O
fraction O
if O
connections O
were O
distributed O
at O
random O
. O

Higher O
modularity O
values O
indicate O
a O
tightly O
knit O
community O
( O
modules O
) O
with O
dense O
inter-connections O
, O
while O
a O
modularity O
value O
of O
zero O
indicates O
no O
greater O
community O
structure O
than O
would O
be O
expected O
by O
chance O
. O

Hippocampal O
asymmetry O
scores O
were O
calculated O
to O
examine O
the O
relationship O
between O
anterior O
and O
posterior O
networks O
. O

Modularity O
values O
were O
converted O
to O
z-scores O
( O
mean O
= O
100 O
, O
SD O
= O
25 O
) O
and O
asymmetry O
was O
calculated O
as O
the O
difference O
in O
modularity O
between O
anterior O
and O
posterior O
networks O
, O
with O
higher O
scores O
indicating O
an O
anterior O
> O
posterior O
asymmetry O
in O
modularity O
strength O
. O

Anterior O
and O
posterior O
hippocampal O
functional O
connectivity O
may O
be O
differentially O
affected O
by O
age O
; O
therefore O
, O
all O
within-group O
asymmetry O
analyses O
were O
corrected O
for O
potential O
age O
effects O
. O

Modularity O
calculations O
were O
conducted O
using O
Matlab O
R2016b O
( O
The O
MathWorks O
Inc. O
, O
Natick O
, O
MA O
) O
. O

Statistical O
analysis O
One-way O
analysis O
of O
variance O
( O
ANOVA O
) O
tested O
for O
between-group O
comparisons O
of O
hippocampal O
network O
modularity O
( O
p O
= O
.05 O
) O
. O

Properties O
of O
the O
functional O
connectivity O
matrix O
were O
calculated O
to O
describe O
patterns O
contributing O
to O
modularity O
; O
means O
and O
standard O
deviations O
are O
presented O
for O
descriptive O
data O
. O

To O
assess O
whether O
memory O
network O
modularity O
was O
associated O
with O
relational O
memory O
function O
, O
Spearman O
correlations O
between O
modularity O
and O
relational O
memory O
slope O
were O
examined O
( O
p O
= O
.05 O
) O
. O

Spearman O
correlations O
do O
not O
assume O
a O
linear O
relationship O
, O
but O
rather O
measure O
the O
monotonic O
relationship O
between O
variables O
, O
including O
non-linear O
relationships O
. O

A O
priori O
follow-up O
comparisons O
of O
individual O
anterior O
and O
posterior O
networks O
were O
Bonferroni-corrected O
( O
p O
= O
.025 O
) O
. O

To O
ensure O
modularity O
distributions O
did O
not O
influence O
findings O
, O
all O
between-group O
results O
were O
confirmed O
using O
non-parametric O
tests O
. O

Statistical O
analyses O
were O
performed O
using O
SAS O
software O
v9.4 O
( O
SAS O
Institute O
Inc. O
, O
Cary O
, O
NC O
) O
. O

The O
Effects O
of O
Music O
Intervention O
on O
Functional O
Connectivity O
Strength O
of O
the O
Brain O
in O
Schizophrenia O
Schizophrenia O
is O
often O
associated O
with O
behavior O
abnormality O
in O
the O
cognitive O
and O
affective O
domain O
. O

Music O
intervention O
is O
used O
as O
a O
complementary O
treatment O
for O
improving O
symptoms O
in O
patients O
with O
schizophrenia O
. O

However O
, O
the O
neurophysiological O
correlates O
of O
these O
remissions O
remain O
poorly O
understood O
. O

Here O
, O
we O
investigated O
the O
effects O
of O
music O
intervention O
in O
neural O
circuits O
through O
functional O
magnetic O
resonance O
imaging O
( O
fMRI O
) O
study O
in O
schizophrenic O
subjects O
. O

Under O
the O
standard O
care O
, O
patients O
were O
randomly O
assigned O
to O
music O
and O
non-music O
interventions O
( O
MTSZ O
, O
UMTSZ O
) O
for O
1 O
month O
. O

Resting-state O
fMRI O
were O
acquired O
over O
three O
time O
points O
( O
baseline O
, O
1 O
month O
, O
and O
6 O
months O
later O
) O
in O
patients O
and O
analyzed O
using O
functional O
connectivity O
strength O
( O
FCS O
) O
and O
seed-based O
functional O
connection O
( O
FC O
) O
approaches O
. O

At O
baseline O
, O
compared O
with O
healthy O
controls O
, O
decreased O
FCS O
in O
the O
right O
middle O
temporal O
gyrus O
( O
MTG O
) O
was O
observed O
in O
patients O
. O

However O
, O
after O
music O
intervention O
, O
the O
functional O
circuitry O
of O
the O
right O
MTG O
, O
which O
was O
related O
with O
the O
function O
of O
emotion O
and O
sensorimotor O
, O
was O
improved O
in O
MTSZ O
. O

Furthermore O
, O
the O
FC O
increments O
were O
significantly O
correlated O
with O
the O
improvement O
of O
symptoms O
, O
while O
vanishing O
6 O
months O
later O
. O

Together O
, O
these O
findings O
provided O
evidence O
that O
music O
intervention O
might O
positively O
modulate O
the O
functional O
connectivity O
of O
MTG O
in O
patients O
with O
schizophrenia O
; O
such O
changes O
might O
be O
associated O
with O
the O
observed O
therapeutic O
effects O
of O
music O
intervention O
on O
neurocognitive O
function O
. O

This O
trial O
is O
registered O
with O
ChiCTR-OPC-14005339 O
. O

2 O
. O

Material O
and O
Methods O
2.1 O
. O

Subjects O
The O
participants O
in O
this O
study O
are O
the O
same O
with O
our O
previous O
study O
including O
fifty-six O
schizophrenic O
subjects O
( O
male O
: O
10 O
; O
female O
: O
26 O
) O
and O
nineteen O
healthy O
controls O
( O
HC O
) O
( O
male O
: O
7 O
; O
female O
: O
12 O
) O
. O

All O
subjects O
were O
recruited O
from O
the O
clinical O
hospital O
of O
the O
Chengdu O
Brain O
Science O
Institute O
( O
CBSI O
) O
. O

The O
detail O
fundamental O
information O
of O
schizophrenic O
subjects O
and O
HC O
could O
be O
referred O
to O
our O
previous O
article O
. O

2.2 O
. O

Design O
To O
measure O
the O
effect O
of O
music O
intervention O
on O
schizophrenic O
subjects O
, O
a O
quasirandomized O
controlled O
trial O
was O
conducted O
in O
this O
study O
. O

Twenty-two O
patients O
with O
schizophrenia O
, O
who O
were O
randomly O
selected O
from O
patients O
, O
received O
group O
music O
intervention O
( O
MTSZ O
: O
music O
intervention O
patients O
with O
schizophrenia O
) O
. O

Controlled O
patients O
( O
UMTSZ O
: O
non-music O
intervention O
patients O
with O
schizophrenia O
, O
remaining O
twenty-three O
patients O
) O
received O
standard O
care O
only O
. O

Three O
time O
point O
tests O
were O
included O
: O
a O
baseline O
test O
, O
a O
1-month O
follow-up O
, O
and O
a O
6-month O
follow-up O
. O

The O
blinded O
assessments O
and O
assignment O
were O
performed O
in O
schizophrenic O
subjects O
. O

The O
design O
of O
music O
intervention O
in O
this O
study O
was O
the O
same O
with O
our O
previous O
work O
. O

The O
detailed O
information O
could O
be O
referred O
from O
the O
previous O
article O
. O

2.3 O
. O

Content O
of O
Music O
Intervention O
One O
professional O
music O
therapist O
participated O
in O
this O
study O
. O

Mozart O
's O
sonata O
K.448 O
music O
listening O
was O
performed O
in O
the O
MTSZ O
group O
( O
30 O
minutes O
per O
day O
, O
30 O
days O
) O
. O

MTSZ O
patients O
peacefully O
listened O
to O
the O
music O
in O
a O
quiet O
room O
during O
each O
session O
. O

The O
music O
therapist O
introduced O
the O
background O
of O
the O
music O
to O
schizophrenic O
patients O
at O
the O
beginning O
. O

The O
UMTSZ O
was O
treated O
solely O
with O
antipsychotic O
drugs O
. O

The O
content O
of O
the O
music O
intervention O
was O
also O
the O
same O
with O
our O
previous O
study O
. O

The O
detailed O
information O
could O
be O
referred O
from O
the O
previous O
article O
. O

2.4 O
. O

Psychiatric O
and O
Neuropsychological O
Assessment O
Three O
evaluators O
of O
the O
neuropsychological O
assessments O
and O
one O
psychiatrist O
assessed O
the O
patients O
with O
schizophrenia O
. O

The O
psychiatric O
symptoms O
of O
the O
schizophrenic O
patients O
were O
assessed O
by O
a O
psychiatrist O
using O
the O
Positive O
and O
Negative O
Symptom O
Scale O
( O
PANSS O
) O
. O

In O
the O
neuropsychological O
assessment O
( O
Block O
Design O
Test O
( O
BDT O
) O
, O
BVRT O
, O
and O
Spatial O
Maze O
Test O
) O
, O
the O
evaluators O
were O
trained O
to O
achieve O
a O
high O
interrater O
reliability O
before O
the O
start O
of O
the O
study O
. O

Detailed O
information O
can O
be O
found O
in O
Section O
1 O
of O
the O
Supplemental O
Information O
) O
. O

2.5 O
. O

Data O
Acquisition O
Experiments O
were O
performed O
on O
a O
3 O
T O
MRI O
scanner O
( O
GE O
Discovery O
MR750 O
) O
. O

A O
detailed O
description O
of O
the O
data O
collection O
can O
be O
found O
in O
Section O
2 O
of O
the O
Supplemental O
Information O
. O

Functional O
image O
preprocessing O
was O
performed O
using O
SPM8 O
( O
Statistical O
Parametric O
Mapping O
, O
http O
: O
//www.fil.ion.ucl.ac.uk/spm/ O
) O
according O
to O
a O
standard O
pipeline O
. O

Slice O
timing O
correction O
and O
head O
motion O
correction O
were O
carried O
out O
. O

Then O
, O
the O
functional O
scans O
were O
normalized O
to O
the O
Montreal O
Neurological O
Institute O
( O
MNI O
) O
EPI O
template O
and O
resampled O
to O
3 O
× O
3 O
× O
3 O
mm3 O
voxels O
. O

The O
general O
processing O
procedures O
of O
spatial O
smoothing O
( O
Gaussian O
kernel O
of O
a O
full O
width O
at O
half O
maximum O
( O
FWHM O
) O
of O
6 O
mm O
) O
was O
not O
included O
for O
the O
FCS O
analysis O
but O
was O
included O
for O
the O
FC O
analysis O
. O

Then O
, O
nuisance O
signals O
were O
then O
removed O
from O
the O
data O
through O
linear O
regression O
( O
white O
matter O
( O
WM O
) O
, O
cerebrospinal O
fluid O
( O
CSF O
) O
, O
and O
six O
motion O
parameters O
) O
, O
except O
the O
global O
signal O
due O
to O
recent O
excellent O
studies O
. O

Finally O
, O
fMRI O
data O
were O
temporally O
filtered O
in O
band-pass O
0.01–0.08 O
Hz O
. O

Recent O
studies O
demonstrated O
that O
head O
motion O
had O
a O
substantial O
impact O
on O
FC O
. O

Thus O
, O
any O
subjects O
who O
had O
a O
maximum O
translation O
in O
any O
of O
the O
cardinal O
directions O
larger O
than O
2.0 O
mm O
or O
a O
maximum O
rotation O
larger O
than O
2.0 O
degrees O
were O
excluded O
. O

Besides O
, O
we O
also O
assessed O
framewise O
displacement O
( O
FD O
) O
in O
three O
groups O
as O
suggested O
by O
Power O
et O
al O
. O

using O
the O
following O
formula O
: O
where O
M O
is O
the O
length O
of O
the O
time O
courses O
( O
M O
= O
250 O
in O
this O
study O
) O
; O
x O
i O
, O
y O
i O
, O
and O
z O
i O
are O
translations/rotations O
at O
the O
ith O
time O
point O
in O
the O
x O
, O
y O
, O
and O
z O
directions O
, O
respectively O
; O
Δt O
represents O
the O
framewise O
displacement O
translation O
; O
and O
Δd O
represents O
the O
framewise O
displacement O
rotation O
. O

Δd O
xi O
= O
x O
i O
− O
x O
i−1 O
and O
similar O
for O
d O
yiandd O
zi O
. O

Structural O
images O
were O
processed O
using O
SPM8 O
toolbox O
. O

Spatial O
normalization O
to O
MNI-space O
was O
performed O
using O
a O
diffeomorphic O
anatomical O
registration O
through O
exponentiated O
lie O
algebra O
and O
segmented O
into O
gray O
matter O
( O
GM O
) O
, O
WM O
, O
and O
CSF O
. O

The O
segmented O
GM O
and O
WM O
were O
modulated O
using O
nonlinear O
deformation O
. O

Total O
Intracranial O
Volume O
( O
TIV O
) O
and O
GM O
volume O
and O
were O
calculated O
. O

Then O
, O
the O
normalization O
analysis O
was O
performed O
: O
the O
GM O
volume O
was O
divided O
by O
the O
TIV O
score O
. O

The O
schizophrenic O
patients O
' O
and O
HC O
's O
normalized O
GM O
at O
baseline O
were O
entered O
as O
a O
global O
variable O
to O
correct O
for O
the O
global O
GM O
volume O
of O
different O
subjects O
in O
the O
statistical O
analysis O
. O

2.6 O
. O

Functional O
Connectivity O
Strength O
Analysis O
Whole-brain O
FC O
analysis O
was O
performed O
as O
follows O
. O

First O
, O
to O
exclude O
artefactual O
correlations O
from O
non-gray O
matter O
, O
the O
GM O
mask O
was O
generated O
by O
thresholding O
( O
cutoff O
= O
0.2 O
) O
the O
average O
of O
GM O
probability O
map O
involving O
all O
subjects O
. O

The O
time O
series O
from O
each O
voxel O
within O
the O
GM O
mask O
was O
extracted O
, O
and O
Pearson O
's O
correlations O
between O
any O
pair O
of O
voxels O
were O
calculated O
for O
each O
subject O
. O

To O
improve O
normality O
, O
we O
then O
transformed O
individual O
correlation O
matrices O
to O
a O
z-score O
matrix O
using O
a O
Fisher O
r-to-z O
transformation O
. O

Then O
, O
for O
a O
given O
voxel O
( O
node O
) O
, O
nodal O
FCS O
was O
computed O
as O
the O
sum O
of O
weights O
of O
its O
connections O
with O
other O
voxels O
. O

We O
conservatively O
restricted O
our O
analysis O
to O
positive O
correlations O
above O
the O
threshold O
of O
r O
= O
0.2 O
, O
which O
was O
chosen O
to O
eliminate O
the O
voxels O
with O
weak O
correlations O
attributable O
to O
signal O
noise O
. O

Before O
group-level O
statistical O
analysis O
, O
an O
individual O
voxel-wise O
FCS O
map O
was O
standardized O
to O
z-scores O
and O
further O
spatially O
smoothed O
( O
FWHM O
= O
6 O
mm O
) O
. O

2.7 O
. O

Functional O
Connectivity O
Analysis O
We O
examined O
FC O
by O
taking O
the O
brain O
region O
that O
had O
showed O
different O
FCS O
( O
pursuant O
to O
the O
FCS O
statistical O
test O
) O
as O
the O
seed O
. O

FC O
analysis O
was O
performed O
between O
the O
seed O
and O
all O
voxels O
in O
the O
brain O
. O

To O
improve O
normality O
, O
we O
then O
transformed O
individual O
correlation O
matrices O
to O
a O
z-score O
matrix O
using O
a O
Fisher O
r-to-z O
transformation O
. O

In O
this O
manner O
, O
FC O
maps O
of O
these O
seeds O
were O
produced O
for O
each O
subject O
. O

2.8 O
. O

Statistical O
Analysis O
2.8.1 O
. O

Participant O
Fundamental O
Information O
Statistics O
Age O
, O
years O
of O
education O
, O
and O
FD O
among O
the O
three O
groups O
were O
compared O
using O
one-way O
ANOVA O
. O

Chi-square O
test O
was O
used O
to O
compare O
gender O
distributions O
. O

A O
two-sample O
t-test O
was O
used O
to O
compare O
the O
psychiatric O
symptoms O
( O
illness O
duration O
, O
medication O
dosage O
in O
chlorpromazine O
( O
CPZ O
) O
equivalents O
( O
mg O
) O
, O
and O
PANSS O
scores O
) O
between O
two O
groups O
of O
patients O
at O
baseline O
. O

Repeated O
measure O
ANOVA O
were O
performed O
to O
determine O
the O
music O
intervention∗time O
interaction O
, O
main O
effects O
of O
music O
intervention O
and O
time O
on O
neuropsychological O
measurements O
, O
and O
PANSS O
scores O
. O

2.8.2 O
. O
