Baseline O
Brain O
Connectivity O
Analyses O
between O
Patients O
and O
HC O
Firstly O
, O
we O
established O
baseline O
abnormalities O
between O
HCs O
and O
schizophrenic O
patients O
through O
two-sample O
t-test O
in O
FCS O
and O
seed-based O
FC O
, O
respectively O
, O
with O
age O
, O
gender O
, O
years O
of O
education O
, O
and O
GM O
as O
covariates O
. O

The O
comparison O
, O
for O
the O
FCS O
statistical O
test O
, O
was O
constrained O
within O
the O
GM O
mask O
. O

The O
seed-based O
FC O
statistical O
test O
was O
performed O
within O
the O
mask O
that O
resulted O
from O
the O
union O
set O
of O
the O
one-sample O
t-test O
of O
the O
two O
groups O
( O
p O
< O
0.005 O
with O
cluster-level O
false O
discovery O
rate O
corrected O
, O
p O
< O
0.05 O
) O
. O

Due O
to O
the O
quantity O
of O
patients O
being O
greater O
than O
the O
amount O
of O
HC O
, O
the O
HC O
and O
the O
same O
number O
of O
patients O
who O
were O
randomly O
selected O
from O
the O
whole O
sample O
of O
patients O
were O
entered O
into O
the O
statistical O
comparisons O
. O

These O
steps O
were O
repeatedly O
performed O
200 O
times O
. O

A O
total O
of O
200 O
comparison O
results O
were O
obtained O
. O

Then O
, O
we O
calculated O
the O
probability O
map O
where O
the O
voxels O
exhibited O
significant O
differences O
( O
p O
< O
0.005 O
with O
cluster-level O
false O
discovery O
rate O
corrected O
, O
p O
< O
0.05 O
) O
across O
the O
200 O
comparisons O
. O

Furthermore O
, O
we O
also O
established O
the O
difference O
between O
MTSZ O
and O
UMTSZ O
at O
baseline O
through O
a O
two-sample O
t-test O
in O
FCS O
and O
seed-based O
FC O
, O
respectively O
, O
with O
gender O
, O
years O
of O
education O
, O
GM O
, O
and O
age O
as O
covariates O
. O

The O
significance O
threshold O
of O
the O
group O
difference O
was O
set O
to O
p O
< O
0.05 O
. O

2.8.3 O
. O

Longitudinal O
Analysis O
of O
Functional O
Connectivity O
in O
Patients O
After O
tests O
of O
normality O
, O
homogeneity O
of O
variance O
, O
and O
Mauchly O
's O
test O
of O
sphericity O
, O
the O
repeated-measure O
ANOVA O
and O
post O
hoc O
analyses O
were O
performed O
on O
the O
schizophrenic O
subjects O
from O
baseline O
and O
1-month O
follow-up O
to O
determine O
the O
music O
intervention∗time O
interaction O
, O
main O
effects O
of O
music O
intervention O
, O
and O
time O
on O
FCS O
and O
seed-based O
FC O
, O
respectively O
. O

The O
age O
, O
gender O
, O
illness O
duration O
, O
education O
characteristics O
, O
GM O
, O
and O
the O
medication O
dosage O
were O
used O
as O
covariates O
. O

The O
significance O
threshold O
for O
ANOVA O
was O
set O
to O
p O
< O
0.005 O
with O
cluster-level O
false O
discovery O
rate O
corrected O
( O
p O
< O
0.05 O
) O
. O

For O
the O
region O
with O
difference O
resulted O
from O
repeated-measure O
ANOVA O
, O
a O
further O
two-sample O
t-test O
was O
performed O
between O
HC O
and O
patients O
( O
MTSZ O
and O
UMTSZ O
from O
1-month O
follow-up O
) O
to O
assess O
the O
effect O
of O
the O
1-month O
music O
intervention O
on O
patients O
relative O
to O
HC O
. O

At O
last O
, O
the O
data O
with O
the O
6-month O
follow-up O
was O
used O
to O
evaluate O
the O
long-term O
effect O
of O
music O
intervention O
through O
the O
comparison O
to O
data O
from O
the O
1-month O
follow-up O
in O
schizophrenic O
subjects O
. O

2.9 O
. O

The O
Relationship O
between O
FC O
and O
Patients O
' O
Variables O
To O
investigate O
the O
underlying O
relationship O
between O
the O
changes O
of O
functional O
measurements O
( O
i.e. O
, O
FCS O
and O
seed-based O
FC O
) O
and O
the O
changes O
of O
neuropsychological O
measurements O
, O
as O
well O
as O
PANSS O
in O
the O
MTSZ O
and O
UMTSZ O
groups O
, O
we O
used O
partial O
correlation O
analysis O
in O
this O
study O
. O

We O
extracted O
the O
mean O
z-score O
of O
the O
region O
that O
showed O
significant O
difference O
of O
FCS O
and O
FC O
. O

Then O
, O
the O
partial O
correlations O
between O
the O
mean O
changes O
( O
1-month O
later O
minus O
baseline O
) O
and O
the O
percentage O
change O
scores O
( O
1 O
− O
[ O
score O
at O
1-month/score O
at O
baseline O
] O
) O
of O
neuropsychological O
measurements O
were O
performed O
, O
as O
well O
as O
the O
percentage O
change O
scores O
of O
PANSS O
, O
with O
age O
, O
gender O
, O
illness O
duration O
, O
education O
characteristics O
, O
GM O
, O
and O
medication O
dosage O
as O
covariates O
. O

The O
partial O
correlation O
analysis O
was O
also O
performed O
between O
the O
mean O
changes O
( O
6 O
months O
later O
minus O
baseline O
) O
and O
the O
percentage O
change O
scores O
( O
1 O
− O
[ O
score O
at O
6 O
months/score O
at O
baseline O
] O
) O
of O
neuropsychological O
and O
PANSS O
scores O
. O

Connectivity-enhanced O
diffusion O
analysis O
reveals O
white O
matter O
density O
disruptions O
in O
first O
episode O
and O
chronic O
schizophrenia O
Reduced O
fractional O
anisotropy O
( O
FA O
) O
is O
a O
well-established O
correlate O
of O
schizophrenia O
, O
but O
it O
remains O
unclear O
whether O
these O
tensor-based O
differences O
are O
the O
result O
of O
axon O
damage O
and/or O
organizational O
changes O
and O
whether O
the O
changes O
are O
progressive O
in O
the O
adult O
course O
of O
illness O
. O

Diffusion O
MRI O
data O
were O
collected O
in O
81 O
schizophrenia O
patients O
( O
54 O
first O
episode O
and O
27 O
chronic O
) O
and O
64 O
controls O
. O

Analysis O
of O
FA O
was O
combined O
with O
“ O
fixel-based O
” O
analysis O
, O
the O
latter O
of O
which O
leverages O
connectivity O
and O
crossing-fiber O
information O
to O
assess O
both O
fiber O
bundle O
density O
and O
organizational O
complexity O
( O
i.e. O
, O
presence O
and O
magnitude O
of O
off-axis O
diffusion O
signal O
) O
. O

Compared O
with O
controls O
, O
patients O
with O
schizophrenia O
displayed O
clusters O
of O
significantly O
lower O
FA O
in O
the O
bilateral O
frontal O
lobes O
, O
right O
dorsal O
centrum O
semiovale O
, O
and O
the O
left O
anterior O
limb O
of O
the O
internal O
capsule O
. O

All O
FA-based O
group O
differences O
overlapped O
substantially O
with O
regions O
containing O
complex O
fiber O
architecture O
. O

FA O
within O
these O
clusters O
was O
positively O
correlated O
with O
principal O
axis O
fiber O
density O
, O
but O
inversely O
correlated O
with O
both O
secondary/tertiary O
axis O
fiber O
density O
and O
voxel-wise O
fiber O
complexity O
. O

Crossing O
fiber O
complexity O
had O
the O
strongest O
( O
inverse O
) O
association O
with O
FA O
( O
r O
= O
−0.82 O
) O
. O

When O
crossing O
fiber O
structure O
was O
modeled O
in O
the O
MRtrix O
fixel-based O
analysis O
pipeline O
, O
patients O
exhibited O
significantly O
lower O
fiber O
density O
compared O
to O
controls O
in O
the O
dorsal O
and O
posterior O
corpus O
callosum O
( O
central O
, O
postcentral O
, O
and O
forceps O
major O
) O
. O

Findings O
of O
lower O
FA O
in O
patients O
with O
schizophrenia O
likely O
reflect O
two O
inversely O
related O
signals O
: O
reduced O
density O
of O
principal O
axis O
fiber O
tracts O
and O
increased O
off-axis O
diffusion O
sources O
. O

Whereas O
the O
former O
confirms O
at O
least O
some O
regions O
where O
myelin O
and O
or/axon O
count O
are O
lower O
in O
schizophrenia O
, O
the O
latter O
indicates O
that O
the O
FA O
signal O
from O
principal O
axis O
fiber O
coherence O
is O
broadly O
contaminated O
by O
macrostructural O
complexity O
, O
and O
therefore O
does O
not O
necessarily O
reflect O
microstructural O
group O
differences O
. O

These O
results O
underline O
the O
need O
to O
move O
beyond O
tensor-based O
models O
in O
favor O
of O
acquisition O
and O
analysis O
techniques O
that O
can O
help O
disambiguate O
different O
sources O
of O
white O
matter O
disruptions O
associated O
with O
schizophrenia O
. O

Graphical O
abstract O
Highlights O
MRtrix3 O
's O
fixel-based O
analysis O
pipeline O
performs O
crossing-fiber O
modeling O
and O
anatomically O
precise O
whole-brain O
white O
matter O
registration O
Axon O
bundle O
density O
and O
organizational O
complexity O
appear O
to O
underlie O
white O
matter O
alterations O
in O
first O
episode O
and O
chronic O
schizophrenia O
Results O
underline O
the O
need O
to O
incorporate O
techniques O
that O
can O
help O
disambiguate O
sources O
of O
white O
matter O
alterations O
Methods O
and O
materials O
Sample O
recruitment O
and O
demographics O
All O
participants O
were O
recruited O
as O
part O
of O
the O
Center O
for O
Neurocognition O
and O
Emotion O
in O
Schizophrenia O
research O
. O

The O
study O
protocol O
and O
consent O
form O
were O
approved O
by O
the O
institutional O
review O
boards O
of O
the O
University O
of O
California O
, O
Los O
Angeles O
( O
UCLA O
) O
and O
Yale O
University O
, O
and O
all O
participants O
provided O
written O
informed O
consent O
. O

The O
present O
sample O
included O
individuals O
who O
had O
recently O
experienced O
their O
first O
episode O
( O
FE O
) O
of O
schizophrenia O
( O
within O
two O
years O
prior O
to O
recruitment O
) O
, O
individuals O
with O
chronic O
schizophrenia O
, O
and O
matched O
healthy O
controls O
. O

Schizophrenia O
diagnosis O
was O
determined O
using O
the O
Structured O
Clinical O
Interview O
for O
DSM-IV O
Axis O
I O
disorders O
( O
SCID-I O
) O
. O

Patients O
were O
excluded O
on O
the O
basis O
of O
drug O
induced O
psychosis O
, O
substance O
dependence O
within O
the O
last O
6 O
months O
, O
or O
history O
of O
traumatic O
brain O
injury O
or O
neurological O
disorder O
. O

Patients O
were O
recruited O
from O
public O
and O
private O
clinics O
and O
hospitals O
in O
the O
Los O
Angeles O
area O
, O
and O
all O
FE O
patients O
were O
under O
the O
care O
of O
the O
UCLA O
Aftercare O
Research O
Program O
. O

All O
FE O
patients O
were O
clinically O
stabilized O
at O
the O
time O
of O
test O
( O
61 O
% O
Risperidone O
, O
19 O
% O
Olanzapine O
, O
6 O
% O
Aripiprazole O
, O
8 O
% O
Other O
antipsychotic O
, O
6 O
% O
missing O
; O
missing O
data O
were O
due O
to O
computer O
error O
) O
. O

Chronic O
patients O
were O
drawn O
from O
a O
sample O
of O
patients O
previously O
recruited O
and O
treated O
as O
FE O
patients O
through O
the O
Aftercare O
program O
, O
but O
whose O
initial O
psychotic O
episode O
occurred O
5 O
years O
or O
more O
prior O
to O
the O
imaging O
assessment O
. O

The O
medication O
profile O
of O
the O
Chronic O
patient O
subset O
was O
somewhat O
more O
diverse O
: O
33 O
% O
Risperidone O
, O
20 O
% O
Aripiprazole O
, O
11 O
% O
Haldol O
, O
30 O
% O
other O
antipsychotic O
, O
6 O
% O
no O
current O
antipsychotic O
medication O
. O

Healthy O
control O
participants O
were O
recruited O
through O
local O
advertisements O
( O
newspapers O
and O
posters O
) O
. O

Control O
participants O
were O
excluded O
based O
on O
the O
following O
criteria O
: O
history O
of O
any O
major O
DSM-IV O
Axis O
I O
disorder O
, O
neurological O
disorder O
, O
traumatic O
brain O
injury O
, O
or O
drug O
dependence O
or O
recent O
abuse O
( O
as O
assessed O
by O
the O
SCID-I O
) O
. O

Potential O
control O
participants O
were O
also O
excluded O
if O
they O
had O
a O
first-degree O
relative O
with O
psychosis O
, O
or O
if O
they O
were O
currently O
pregnant O
. O

The O
initial O
MRI O
sample O
comprised O
163 O
patients O
and O
controls O
aged O
18–40 O
. O

Following O
visual O
inspection O
for O
scan O
quality O
, O
18 O
scans O
were O
removed O
: O
15 O
based O
on O
Field O
of O
View O
errors O
( O
7 O
controls O
) O
and O
3 O
based O
on O
overt O
MR O
artifacts O
, O
such O
as O
blurring O
or O
warping O
( O
2 O
controls O
) O
. O

The O
final O
sample O
included O
81 O
patients O
( O
54 O
FE O
and O
27 O
Chronic O
) O
and O
64 O
age-matched O
controls O
. O

Patients O
and O
controls O
did O
not O
differ O
significantly O
in O
age O
( O
t O
( O
139 O
) O
= O
1.56 O
, O
p O
= O
0.12 O
) O
or O
sex O
( O
X2 O
= O
0.39 O
, O
p O
= O
0.53 O
) O
. O

Sample O
demographics O
are O
presented O
in O
Table O
1 O
. O

Neuroimaging O
data O
acquisition O
& O
preprocessing O
Imaging O
was O
performed O
on O
a O
3T O
Siemens O
Trio O
Scanner O
using O
a O
12-channel O
head O
coil O
at O
the O
Staglin O
Center O
for O
Cognitive O
Neuroscience O
at O
UCLA O
. O

The O
diffusion O
image O
was O
acquired O
as O
a O
single-shot O
spin-echo O
echo O
planar O
imaging O
pulse O
sequence O
, O
with O
64 O
diffusion O
sensitized O
gradients O
( O
b O
= O
1000 O
) O
and O
seven O
b O
= O
0 O
volumes O
collected O
( O
b O
= O
0 O
images O
stacked O
at O
the O
beginning O
of O
the O
sequence O
) O
. O

Repetition O
time O
( O
TR O
) O
/echo O
time O
( O
TE O
) O
was O
7000 O
ms/93 O
ms O
, O
voxel O
size O
= O
1.98 O
× O
1.98 O
× O
3.00 O
, O
matrix O
= O
96 O
× O
96 O
× O
50 O
, O
and O
acquisition O
time O
was O
8 O
min O
, O
24 O
s. O
In O
order O
to O
approximate O
and O
control O
for O
subtle O
effects O
of O
motion O
, O
data O
were O
processed O
using O
FSL O
's O
EDDY O
tool O
, O
which O
provides O
estimates O
of O
relative O
volume-to-volume O
motion O
for O
each O
participant O
, O
adjusted O
for O
translation O
in O
the O
Phase O
Encoding O
direction O
. O

Patients O
had O
higher O
mean O
relative O
motion O
compared O
to O
controls O
( O
Patient O
mean O
= O
0.20 O
( O
0.12 O
) O
, O
Control O
mean O
= O
0.16 O
( O
0.08 O
) O
, O
t O
( O
143 O
) O
= O
−2.26 O
, O
p O
< O
0.05 O
) O
. O

To O
account O
for O
motion O
effects O
, O
mean O
relative O
motion O
was O
included O
as O
a O
covariate O
in O
all O
analyses O
. O

In O
addition O
, O
we O
formed O
matched O
groups O
of O
patients O
and O
controls O
( O
whereby O
each O
control O
was O
matched O
with O
one O
or O
more O
patients O
based O
on O
the O
mean O
relative O
motion O
parameter O
, O
excluding O
any O
patients O
for O
whom O
motion O
was O
unmatched O
with O
a O
control O
subject O
) O
and O
tested O
whether O
the O
primary O
results O
held O
when O
motion O
was O
perfectly O
balanced O
between O
diagnostic O
groups O
. O

This O
motion-matched O
subset O
consisted O
of O
64 O
patients O
( O
mean O
motion O
= O
0.16 O
( O
0.05 O
) O
) O
and O
64 O
controls O
( O
mean O
motion O
= O
0.16 O
( O
0.08 O
) O
) O
; O
t O
( O
126 O
) O
= O
0.30 O
, O
p O
= O
0.76 O
. O

Since O
signal-to-noise O
ratio O
( O
SNR O
) O
of O
diffusion-weighted O
images O
may O
have O
important O
implications O
for O
diffusion O
metric O
estimation O
, O
we O
also O
calculated O
SNR O
using O
the O
tools O
outlined O
in O
. O

Mean O
SNR O
across O
the O
whole O
sample O
was O
7.79 O
( O
0.70 O
) O
, O
which O
indicates O
good-to-excellent O
SNR O
across O
the O
sample O
. O

Patients O
had O
slightly O
lower O
SNR O
compared O
to O
controls O
( O
t O
( O
143 O
) O
= O
2.03 O
, O
p O
< O
0.05 O
) O
, O
but O
this O
difference O
was O
explained O
entirely O
by O
the O
high O
correlation O
between O
relative O
motion O
and O
SNR O
( O
r O
( O
143 O
) O
= O
−0.83 O
, O
p O
< O
0.001 O
) O
. O

Tract O
based O
spatial O
statistics O
Dicom O
files O
were O
converted O
to O
nifti O
using O
dcm2nii O
( O
http O
: O
//www.mccauslandcenter.sc.edu/mricro/mricron/dcm2nii.html O
) O
. O

The O
preprocessing O
steps O
and O
all O
analyses O
were O
completed O
using O
tools O
in O
FMRIB O
Software O
Library O
( O
FSL O
5.0.3 O
; O
http O
: O
//www.fmrib.ox.ac.uk/fsl O
) O
. O

All O
images O
were O
corrected O
for O
motion O
and O
eddy O
current O
distortions O
using O
EDDY O
, O
which O
also O
outputs O
corrected O
bvecs O
files O
for O
use O
in O
subsequent O
tensor-fitting O
steps O
. O

Brain O
extractions O
were O
completed O
using O
the O
FSL O
brain O
extraction O
tool O
( O
bet O
) O
, O
and O
dtifit O
was O
used O
to O
calculate O
diffusion O
parameters O
using O
the O
adjusted O
bvecs O
files O
. O

FA O
images O
were O
normalized O
to O
an O
FA O
template O
in O
Montreal O
Neurological O
Institute O
( O
MNI O
) O
space O
using O
the O
non-linear O
registration O
algorithm O
FNIRT O
. O

A O
mean O
FA O
image O
was O
calculated O
from O
the O
spatially O
normalized O
images O
of O
all O
subjects O
. O

This O
image O
was O
then O
“ O
skeletonized O
” O
to O
allow O
for O
the O
comparison O
of O
FA O
values O
across O
spatially O
matched O
tract O
structures O
across O
all O
subjects O
. O

FA O
values O
of O
each O
subject O
were O
projected O
on O
the O
mean O
sample-based O
FA O
skeleton O
for O
use O
in O
regression O
analyses O
. O

Voxel-wise O
whole-brain O
statistical O
analyses O
were O
performed O
using O
the O
“ O
randomise O
” O
command O
in O
FSL O
. O

Randomise O
uses O
the O
general O
linear O
model O
in O
conjunction O
with O
5000 O
non-parametric O
permutation O
tests O
to O
generate O
test O
statistics O
. O

Threshold-free O
cluster O
enhancement O
( O
TFCE O
) O
was O
used O
because O
it O
avoids O
an O
arbitrarily O
predefined O
T-threshold O
or O
cluster O
threshold O
. O

Whole-brain O
family O
wise O
error O
( O
FWE O
) O
corrected O
p-maps O
were O
thresholded O
at O
an O
FWE O
of O
0.05 O
. O

All O
reported O
coordinates O
are O
in O
MNI_152 O
space O
, O
and O
results O
are O
reported O
using O
the O
JHU-White-Matter O
Tractography O
Atlas O
and O
the O
JHU O
ICBM-DTI-81 O
White O
Matter O
Labels O
Atlases O
. O

Per O
the O
FSL O
GLM O
recommendation O
, O
all O
continuous O
variables O
were O
mean O
centered O
prior O
to O
being O
entered O
into O
regression O
. O

Using O
FSL O
's O
GLM O
tool O
, O
the O
main O
effect O
model O
of O
interest O
in O
the O
present O
study O
was O
set O
up O
to O
test O
for O
group O
differences O
in O
FA O
between O
patients O
and O
controls O
, O
covarying O
for O
age O
, O
sex O
, O
and O
mean O
relative O
head O
motion O
. O

Secondary O
analyses O
were O
conducted O
to O
determine O
whether O
there O
was O
an O
interaction O
effect O
between O
age O
and O
diagnosis O
( O
all O
interaction O
effects O
were O
tested O
in O
separate O
models O
, O
and O
the O
interaction O
terms O
were O
never O
included O
in O
models O
from O
which O
main O
effects O
are O
reported O
) O
. O

Fixel-based O
processing O
and O
analysis O
All O
fixel-based O
processing O
steps O
were O
carried O
out O
using O
MRtrix3 O
version O
RC2 O
, O
according O
to O
the O
procedures O
outlined O
in O
the O
MRtrix3 O
documentation O
( O
www.MRtrix.readthedocs.io O
) O
. O

The O
processing O
steps O
are O
summarized O
briefly O
here O
( O
see O
Supplemental O
Materials O
for O
further O
details O
) O
. O

Following O
dcm2nii O
conversion O
, O
data O
were O
converted O
from O
nifti O
format O
to O
MRtrix3 O
format O
( O
“ O
.mif O
” O
) O
using O
mrconvert O
and O
preprocessed O
according O
to O
the O
MRtrix3 O
fixel-based O
workflow O
. O

All O
images O
were O
denoised O
( O
; O
see O
supplemental O
methods O
for O
more O
detail O
) O
preprocessed O
via O
FSL O
's O
EDDY O
, O
and O
bias O
field O
corrected O
. O

In O
order O
to O
adjust O
for O
free O
water O
compartment O
influences O
, O
tissue-specific O
( O
CSF O
and O
white O
matter O
) O
response O
functions O
were O
then O
generated O
for O
each O
subject O
and O
then O
averaged O
to O
create O
sample-specific O
response O
functions O
for O
white O
matter O
and O
CSF O
, O
respectively O
. O

B O
= O
0 O
images O
can O
be O
leveraged O
as O
a O
second O
“ O
shell O
” O
from O
which O
CSF-specific O
response O
functions O
can O
be O
estimated O
in O
each O
participant O
. O

Modeling O
the O
distinct O
response O
functions O
for O
white O
matter O
and O
CSF O
in O
this O
way O
makes O
it O
possible O
to O
apply O
multi-shell O
, O
multi-tissue O
deconvolution O
in O
single-shell O
data O
, O
thereby O
enhancing O
the O
signal O
from O
white O
matter O
relative O
to O
CSF O
. O

This O
strategy O
is O
technically O
referred O
to O
as O
“ O
single O
shell O
, O
multi O
tissue O
” O
constrained O
spherical O
deconvolution O
( O
SSMT-CSD O
) O
, O
and O
is O
useful O
because O
the O
better O
signal-to-noise O
ratio O
ameliorates O
the O
problem O
of O
white O
matter O
volume O
overestimation O
that O
can O
arise O
from O
the O
standard O
“ O
single O
shell O
, O
single O
tissue O
” O
approach O
. O

The O
SSMT-CSD O
technique O
has O
been O
successfully O
applied O
in O
a O
recent O
study O
of O
optic O
neuritis O
in O
multiple O
sclerosis O
. O

In O
order O
to O
demonstrate O
that O
algorithm O
can O
appropriately O
identify O
white O
matter O
vs. O
CSF O
voxels O
in O
our O
single-shell O
data O
, O
we O
randomly O
selected O
6 O
participants O
and O
included O
the O
graphical O
output O
of O
the O
voxel O
selection O
procedure O
in O
the O
Supplemental O
Material O
( O
Supplemental O
Fig O
. O

4 O
) O
. O

Multi-shell O
, O
multi-tissue O
constrained O
spherical O
deconvolution O
was O
performed O
for O
white O
matter O
and O
CSF O
, O
respectively O
, O
using O
the O
previously O
estimated O
response O
functions O
, O
and O
the O
resulting O
white O
matter O
Fiber O
Orientation O
Distribution O
( O
FOD O
) O
images O
were O
fed O
forward O
into O
all O
subsequent O
analysis O
steps O
. O

The O
mtnormalise O
command O
was O
used O
to O
correct O
for O
intensity O
inhomogeneities O
across O
subjects O
, O
and O
the O
normalized O
white O
matter O
FOD O
images O
were O
then O
coregisistered O
to O
create O
a O
sample-specific O
FOD O
template O
. O

Peak O
FOD O
amplitudes O
at O
each O
fixel O
in O
this O
template O
were O
calculated O
and O
thresholded O
( O
at O
0.30 O
) O
to O
remove O
fixels O
containing O
residual O
gray O
matter O
peaks O
. O

This O
thresholded O
image O
was O
then O
used O
to O
create O
an O
“ O
analysis O
fixel O
mask O
” O
and O
an O
“ O
analysis O
voxel O
mask O
” O
, O
which O
represent O
the O
coregistered O
fixel- O
and O
voxel-space O
in O
white O
matter O
across O
all O
subjects O
in O
the O
sample O
. O

Individual O
subjects O
' O
FOD O
images O
were O
then O
transformed O
into O
a O
sample-specific O
FOD O
template O
space O
, O
segmented O
into O
fiber O
density-based O
( O
FD O
) O
fixels O
within O
each O
voxel O
, O
and O
reoriented O
to O
the O
template O
space O
. O

The O
final O
FD O
images O
for O
each O
subject O
were O
computed O
by O
taking O
each O
fixel O
in O
reoriented O
subject O
space O
and O
assigning O
it O
to O
the O
corresponding O
fixel O
in O
template O
space O
. O

Fiber O
cross-section O
( O
FC O
) O
is O
then O
computed O
based O
on O
the O
deformation O
fields O
of O
the O
warps O
generated O
during O
registration O
, O
allowing O
for O
some O
measure O
of O
the O
macroscopic O
diameter O
of O
fiber O
bundles O
spanning O
multiple O
voxels O
( O
see O
Fig O
. O

1 O
) O
. O

Because O
connectivity-based O
fixel O
enhancement O
( O
CFE O
) O
capitalizes O
on O
tractography-based O
connectivity O
information O
to O
inform O
the O
spatial O
extent O
of O
clustering O
in O
fixel-wise O
analyses O
, O
whole O
brain O
tractography O
was O
performed O
on O
the O
unbiased O
FOD O
sample-specific O
FOD O
template O
, O
and O
the O
resulting O
20-million O
streamline O
tractogram O
was O
reduced O
using O
SIFT O
to O
contain O
2 O
million O
streamlines O
for O
use O
in O
analyses O
. O

Finally O
, O
the O
fixelcfestats O
command O
, O
which O
uses O
GLM O
in O
concert O
with O
non-parametric O
permutation O
testing O
( O
5000 O
permutations O
) O
was O
used O
to O
perform O
whole-brain O
fixel O
analyses O
for O
fiber O
density O
and O
cross-section O
, O
respectively O
. O

In O
order O
to O
verify O
the O
spatial O
extent O
of O
FA O
group O
differences O
from O
TBSS O
, O
we O
also O
performed O
FA O
analysis O
using O
MRtrix O
tools O
. O

Starting O
with O
native O
space O
images O
that O
were O
processed O
with O
EDDY O
, O
the O
tensor O
model O
was O
fit O
at O
each O
voxel O
using O
dwi2tensor O
, O
and O
FA O
images O
were O
created O
using O
the O
tensor2metric O
command O
. O

To O
ensure O
robust O
registration O
based O
on O
underlying O
fiber O
architecture O
, O
MRtrix-derived O
FA O
images O
were O
transformed O
to O
the O
same O
template O
space O
used O
in O
fixel-based O
analyses O
. O

In O
addition O
, O
a O
complexity O
metric O
was O
computed O
across O
each O
subject O
's O
template-space O
fixel O
image O
and O
stored O
at O
the O
voxel O
level O
. O

The O
complexity O
metric O
ranges O
from O
zero O
to O
one O
( O
where O
zero O
represents O
a O
voxel O
with O
a O
single O
fixel O
) O
, O
and O
nears O
one O
when O
multiple O
fixels O
within O
a O
voxel O
have O
the O
same O
fiber O
density O
. O

Since O
small O
densities O
may O
be O
spurious O
, O
complexity O
was O
computed O
based O
on O
both O
the O
raw O
fixel O
images O
, O
and O
then O
again O
on O
fixel O
images O
that O
were O
thresholded O
to O
remove O
small O
densities O
( O
< O
0.1 O
) O
. O

For O
voxel-wise O
analyses O
, O
both O
complexity O
and O
FA O
images O
were O
then O
smoothed O
at O
FWHM O
= O
3 O
and O
entered O
into O
regression O
models O
using O
MRtrix3 O
's O
mrclusterstats O
. O

The O
mrclusterstats O
command O
is O
similar O
to O
FSL O
's O
randomise O
in O
that O
it O
uses O
Threshold-free O
cluster O
enhancement O
, O
and O
performs O
FWE O
correction O
using O
non-parametric O
bootstrapping O
( O
5000 O
permutations O
) O
. O

All O
mrclusterstats O
and O
fixelcfestats O
regression O
models O
included O
sex O
, O
age O
, O
and O
mean O
relative O
subject O
motion O
as O
covariates O
. O

Reported O
results O
from O
TBSS O
and O
MRtrix O
analyses O
are O
Family O
Wise O
Error O
( O
FWE O
) O
corrected O
. O

Extracted O
region-of-interest O
based O
metrics O
were O
analyzed O
using O
R O
statistical O
software O
. O

The O
relationship O
between O
interleukin-6 O
and O
functional O
connectivity O
in O
methamphetamine O
users O
Methamphetamine O
( O
MA O
) O
causes O
an O
increase O
in O
pro-inflammatory O
cytokines O
in O
animal O
models O
and O
in O
humans O
. O

Resulting O
activation O
of O
microglia O
and O
neuro-inflammation O
could O
, O
via O
effects O
on O
reward O
networks O
, O
mediate O
behavioral O
characteristics O
of O
addiction O
. O

We O
examined O
the O
relationship O
between O
interleukin-6 O
( O
IL-6 O
) O
and O
corticolimbic O
and O
striatolimbic O
resting-state O
functional O
connectivity O
( O
RSFC O
) O
. O

Thirty O
adults O
diagnosed O
with O
MA O
dependence O
and O
20 O
control O
subjects O
underwent O
a O
resting-state O
functional O
magnetic O
resonance O
imaging O
( O
fMRI O
) O
scan O
and O
gave O
a O
blood O
sample O
for O
determination O
of O
plasma O
IL-6 O
levels O
. O

Seed-based O
RSFC O
analyses O
were O
performed O
to O
examine O
the O
interactive O
effect O
of O
group O
and O
IL-6 O
on O
ventral O
striatal O
and O
prefrontal O
connectivity O
. O

Within O
the O
MA O
group O
, O
IL-6 O
levels O
were O
positively O
related O
to O
striatolimbic O
RSFC O
but O
negatively O
related O
to O
corticostriatal O
RSFC O
. O

Our O
findings O
with O
IL-6 O
support O
the O
idea O
that O
inflammation O
may O
at O
least O
partly O
mediate O
the O
link O
among O
MA O
use O
disorder O
, O
RSFC O
, O
and O
behavior O
, O
possibly O
via O
effects O
on O
mesolimbic O
and O
mesocortical O
dopaminergic O
systems O
. O

2 O
. O

Materials O
and O
methods O
2.1 O
. O

Participants O
Thirty O
volunteers O
diagnosed O
with O
MA O
dependence O
and O
20 O
healthy O
controls O
provided O
written O
informed O
consent O
, O
as O
approved O
by O
the O
Veterans O
Affairs O
Portland O
Health O
Care O
System O
( O
VAPORHCS O
) O
and O
Oregon O
Health O
& O
Science O
University O
Institutional O
Review O
Boards O
( O
IRBs O
) O
. O

The O
work O
was O
carried O
out O
in O
accordance O
with O
The O
Code O
of O
Ethics O
of O
the O
World O
Medical O
Association O
( O
Declaration O
of O
Helsinki O
) O
. O

Participants O
in O
the O
MA O
group O
were O
recruited O
through O
word O
of O
mouth O
, O
IRB-approved O
advertisements O
, O
and O
referrals O
from O
VAPORHCS O
, O
the O
community O
, O
and O
from O
addiction O
treatment O
centers O
. O

Control O
participants O
were O
recruited O
by O
advertisement O
from O
the O
general O
public O
and O
from O
friends O
and O
families O
of O
those O
who O
attended O
the O
clinics O
associated O
with O
the O
study O
. O

Exclusion O
criteria O
for O
both O
groups O
, O
determined O
by O
medical O
history O
and O
laboratory O
blood O
tests O
were O
: O
systemic O
, O
neurological O
, O
cardiovascular O
, O
or O
pulmonary O
disease O
, O
head O
trauma O
with O
loss O
of O
consciousness O
, O
magnetic O
resonance O
imaging O
( O
MRI O
) O
contraindications O
, O
use O
of O
medications O
known O
to O
have O
dopaminergic O
mechanisms O
( O
e.g. O
, O
antipsychotics O
, O
antidepressants O
, O
antiparkinsonian O
agents O
) O
, O
sedative-hypnotics O
( O
barbiturates O
, O
benzodiazepines O
, O
zolpidem O
) O
or O
anticholinergics O
. O

Past O
or O
Current O
Axis O
I O
diagnoses O
, O
other O
than O
depression O
, O
posttraumatic O
stress O
disorder O
or O
nicotine O
dependence O
for O
either O
group O
, O
assessed O
with O
the O
the O
Mini-International O
Neuropsychiatric O
Interview O
( O
M.I.N.I O
. O

) O
, O
and O
alcohol O
use O
> O
7 O
standard O
drinks O
per O
week O
for O
women O
and O
> O
14 O
drinks O
per O
week O
for O
men O
were O
exclusionary O
. O

For O
inclusion O
in O
the O
MA O
group O
, O
participants O
met O
DSM-IV O
criteria O
for O
MA O
dependence O
and O
had O
been O
abstinent O
from O
MA O
for O
> O
1 O
month O
and O
< O
6 O
months O
( O
Note O
: O
Although O
the O
currently O
accepted O
terminology O
is O
methamphetamine O
use O
disorder O
, O
as O
per O
the O
DSM-5 O
, O
the O
diagnostic O
category O
was O
previously O
termed O
MA O
dependence O
, O
and O
this O
term O
is O
used O
when O
referring O
to O
the O
research O
participants O
described O
in O
this O
paper O
) O
. O

Urine O
testing O
on O
day O
of O
MRI O
scan O
verified O
abstinence O
from O
cocaine O
, O
methamphetamine O
, O
benzodiazepines O
, O
and O
opiates O
. O

2.2 O
. O

Blood O
sample O
collection O
and O
processing O
Blood O
was O
drawn O
from O
non-fasting O
participants O
at O
rest O
by O
one-time O
venipuncture O
. O

Samples O
were O
collected O
in O
cell O
preparation O
tubes O
( O
BD O
Vacutainer O
Systems O
, O
Franklin O
Lakes O
, O
NJ O
, O
USA O
) O
containing O
1 O
mL O
of O
0.1M O
sodium O
citrate O
solution O
. O

The O
blood O
was O
then O
centrifuged O
at O
1500 O
RCF O
for O
20 O
minutes O
at O
room O
temperature O
( O
22–25° O
C O
) O
. O

Plasma O
was O
separated O
, O
collected O
and O
immediately O
aliquoted O
in O
polypropylene O
tubes O
( O
Phenix O
Research O
Products O
, O
Hayward O
, O
CA O
, O
USA O
) O
and O
frozen O
at O
−80° O
C O
until O
assayed O
. O

Every O
effort O
was O
made O
to O
collect O
samples O
between O
11 O
AM O
and O
1 O
PM O
( O
average O
collection O
time O
was O
11:36 O
AM O
) O
; O
mean O
blood O
collection O
times O
by O
study O
group O
were O
as O
follows O
: O
Control O
group O
= O
11:28 O
AM O
and O
MA O
group O
= O
12:05 O
PM O
. O

2.3 O
. O

Multiplex O
immunoassay O
Human O
plasma O
samples O
were O
analyzed O
in O
duplicate O
using O
a O
customized O
, O
high-sensitivity O
multiplex O
polystyrene O
bead-based O
immunoassay O
[ O
Luminex O
Performance O
Assay O
( O
cat O
. O

no O
. O

FCST09-03 O
) O
; O
R O
& O
D O
Systems O
, O
Minneapolis O
, O
MN O
, O
USA O
] O
to O
measure O
peripheral O
immune O
biomarkers O
associated O
with O
inflammation O
, O
specifically O
IL-6 O
and O
IL-1β O
, O
and O
the O
anti-inflammatory O
cytokine O
, O
IL-10 O
. O

The O
manufacturer-reported O
lower O
detection O
limits O
were O
0.31 O
pg/ml O
for O
IL-6 O
, O
0.18 O
pg/ml O
for O
IL-1β O
, O
and O
0.24 O
pg/ml O
for O
IL-10 O
, O
but O
for O
a O
number O
of O
samples O
we O
were O
able O
to O
estimate O
values O
for O
samples O
below O
these O
limits O
. O

Our O
assay O
detection O
limits O
were O
0.06 O
– O
3,719 O
pg/ml O
for O
IL-6 O
, O
0.04 O
– O
1,612 O
pg/ml O
for O
IL-1β O
, O
and O
0.09 O
– O
2,488 O
pg/ml O
for O
IL-10 O
. O

In O
order O
to O
assess O
the O
reliability O
of O
the O
cytokine O
measurements O
, O
we O
calculated O
the O
intra- O
and O
inter-assay O
coefficients O
of O
variations O
( O
CVs O
) O
as O
indices O
of O
within- O
and O
between-assay O
precision O
, O
respectively O
. O

The O
average O
intra-assay O
% O
CVs O
for O
the O
cytokine O
measures O
were O
8.8 O
% O
for O
IL-6 O
, O
11.4 O
% O
for O
IL-1β O
, O
and O
9.9 O
% O
for O
IL-10 O
, O
which O
are O
comparable O
to O
, O
or O
lower O
than O
, O
similar O
multiplexed O
cytokine O
analysis O
. O

The O
inter-assay O
% O
CVs O
( O
indices O
of O
plate-to-plate O
consistency O
) O
were O
calculated O
for O
low O
and O
high O
control O
samples O
with O
known O
cytokine O
concentrations O
. O

The O
average O
of O
the O
low O
and O
high O
% O
CVs O
were O
14.5 O
% O
for O
IL-6 O
, O
27.0 O
% O
for O
IL-1β O
, O
and O
8.2 O
% O
for O
IL-10 O
. O

This O
variation O
is O
comparable O
to O
previously O
reported O
inter-assay O
CVs O
using O
this O
method O
. O

2.4 O
. O

MRI O
imaging O
acquisition O
Imaging O
was O
performed O
on O
a O
3 O
Tesla O
Siemens O
TIM O
Trio O
MRI O
scanner O
. O

A O
localizer O
scan O
was O
acquired O
in O
order O
to O
guide O
slice O
alignment O
during O
anatomical O
and O
functional O
scans O
. O

A O
T2 O
* O
- O
weighted O
echo-planar O
image O
( O
EPI O
) O
was O
acquired O
( O
24 O
slices O
, O
4 O
mm O
thick O
, O
gap O
width O
= O
1 O
mm O
, O
TR/TE/α O
= O
2,000 O
ms/40 O
ms/80° O
, O
matrix O
= O
128 O
× O
128 O
, O
FOV O
= O
240 O
mm2 O
, O
170 O
volumes O
, O
in-plane O
pixel O
size O
of O
1.875 O
mm2 O
) O
while O
subjects O
stared O
at O
a O
white O
cross O
on O
a O
black O
screen O
. O

One O
high-resolution O
T1-weighted O
anatomical O
magnetically O
prepared O
rapid O
acquisition O
gradient O
echo O
( O
MPRAGE O
; O
144 O
slices O
1 O
mm O
thick O
, O
TR/TE/TI/α O
= O
2,300 O
ms/4.38 O
ms/1,200 O
ms/12° O
, O
FOV O
= O
208 O
× O
256 O
mm2 O
) O
was O
acquired O
for O
co-registration O
with O
functional O
images O
and O
statistical O
overlay O
. O

2.5 O
. O

Resting-state O
fMRI O
analysis O
Three O
participants O
in O
the O
MA O
group O
were O
excluded O
for O
incomplete O
scan O
acquisition O
due O
to O
technical O
difficulties O
. O

On O
the O
remaining O
subject O
data O
, O
image O
analysis O
was O
performed O
using O
FSL O
5.0.2.1 O
( O
www.fmrib.ox.ac.uk/fsl O
) O
. O

Images O
were O
realigned O
to O
compensate O
for O
motion O
, O
and O
high-pass O
temporal O
filtering O
( O
100 O
s O
) O
was O
applied O
. O

Data O
were O
skull-stripped O
and O
spatially O
smoothed O
( O
5-mm O
FWHM O
Gaussian O
kernel O
) O
. O

Images O
were O
further O
pre-processed O
to O
include O
additional O
nuisance O
regressors O
: O
average O
signal O
of O
cerebrospinal O
fluid O
, O
average O
signal O
from O
white-matter O
, O
and O
two O
metrics O
of O
motion-related O
artifact O
, O
specifically O
motion O
scrubbing O
with O
frame-wise O
displacement O
and O
a O
combination O
of O
the O
temporal O
derivative O
of O
the O
time O
series O
and O
root-mean-squared O
variance O
over O
all O
voxels O
. O

Global O
signal O
regression O
was O
not O
applied O
. O

The O
EPI O
images O
were O
registered O
to O
the O
high-resolution O
MPRAGE O
image O
and O
then O
into O
standard O
Montreal O
Neurological O
Institute O
space O
, O
using O
a O
12-parameter O
affine O
transformation O
. O

An O
anatomically-defined O
region O
of O
interest O
from O
the O
Harvard-Oxford O
Subcortical O
atlas O
of O
the O
ventral O
striatum O
and O
a O
spherical O
ROI O
of O
the O
DLPFC O
( O
Montreal O
Neurological O
Institute O
coordinates O
: O
x O
= O
30 O
, O
y O
= O
36 O
, O
z O
= O
20 O
) O
were O
used O
as O
seeds O
in O
two O
separate O
analyses O
. O

The O
seeds O
were O
transformed O
into O
each O
subject O
’ O
s O
native O
space O
by O
applying O
the O
inverted O
transformation O
matrix O
of O
EPI O
to O
MPRAGE O
to O
standard O
space O
. O

In O
separate O
whole-brain O
, O
voxel-wise O
resting-state O
analyses O
, O
the O
mean O
time O
series O
across O
all O
voxels O
within O
the O
striatum O
seed O
and O
within O
the O
DLPFC O
seed O
from O
pre-processed O
images O
were O
entered O
as O
covariates O
. O

For O
IL O
markers O
that O
showed O
significant O
group O
differences O
, O
between-group O
mixed-effects O
analyses O
were O
conducted O
with O
IL O
concentrations O
as O
regressors O
to O
test O
group O
interactions O
in O
whole-brain O
voxel-wise O
regression O
of O
striatum O
and O
DLPFC O
RSFC O
( O
see O
Section O
2.6. O
for O
further O
description O
of O
statistical O
analyses O
) O
. O

All O
whole-brain O
fMRI O
statistics O
were O
corrected O
for O
multiple O
comparisons O
by O
using O
cluster-correction O
with O
voxel O
height O
threshold O
of O
Z O
> O
2.3 O
and O
cluster O
significance O
of O
P O
< O
0.05 O
. O

2.6 O
. O

Statistical O
analysis O
Student O
’ O
s O
t-tests O
and O
chi-squared O
( O
χ2 O
) O
tests O
were O
used O
to O
compare O
groups O
in O
demographic O
and O
substance O
use O
variables O
. O

A O
linear O
regression O
was O
used O
to O
test O
for O
the O
main O
effects O
of O
group O
, O
age O
, O
and O
sex O
on O
differences O
in O
IL-6 O
, O
IL-1β O
and O
IL-10 O
concentrations O
. O

In O
addition O
, O
given O
the O
non-normal O
distribution O
of O
IL-10 O
concentrations O
, O
a O
nonparametric O
Mann-Whitney O
test O
was O
conducted O
. O

Statistical O
analysis O
was O
conducted O
using O
SPSS O
24 O
( O
Armonk O
, O
NY O
: O
IBM O
Corp O
) O
. O

Weak O
dorsolateral O
prefrontal O
response O
to O
social O
criticism O
predicts O
worsened O
mood O
and O
symptoms O
following O
social O
conflict O
in O
people O
at O
familial O
risk O
for O
schizophrenia O
Understanding O
the O
specific O
mechanisms O
that O
explain O
why O
people O
who O
have O
relatives O
with O
schizophrenia O
( O
i.e. O
, O
people O
at O
familial O
high O
risk O
; O
FHR O
) O
are O
more O
likely O
to O
develop O
the O
disorder O
is O
crucial O
for O
prevention O
. O

We O
investigated O
a O
diathesis-stress O
model O
of O
familial O
risk O
by O
testing O
whether O
FHR O
individuals O
under-recruit O
brain O
regions O
central O
to O
emotion O
regulation O
when O
exposed O
to O
social O
conflict O
, O
resulting O
in O
worse O
mood O
and O
symptoms O
following O
conflict O
. O

FHR O
and O
non-FHR O
participants O
listened O
to O
critical O
, O
neutral O
, O
and O
praising O
comments O
in O
an O
fMRI O
scanner O
before O
completing O
4 O
weeks O
of O
daily-diary O
records O
. O

Compared O
to O
non-FHR O
individuals O
, O
FHR O
individuals O
under-recruited O
the O
bilateral O
dorsolateral O
prefrontal O
cortex O
( O
DLPFC O
) O
—a O
region O
strongly O
implicated O
in O
cognitive O
emotion O
regulation—following O
criticism O
. O

Furthermore O
, O
within O
FHR O
participants O
, O
weak O
DLPFC O
response O
to O
criticism O
in O
the O
laboratory O
task O
was O
associated O
with O
elevated O
negative O
mood O
and O
positive O
symptoms O
on O
days O
with O
distressing O
social O
conflicts O
in O
daily-diary O
assessments O
. O

Results O
extend O
diathesis-stress O
models O
of O
schizophrenia O
by O
clarifying O
neural O
and O
environmental O
pathways O
to O
dysregulation O
in O
FHR O
individuals O
. O

Highlights O
People O
at O
familial O
risk O
for O
schizophrenia O
showed O
reduced O
DLPFC O
activity O
following O
criticism O
. O

Reduced O
DLPFC O
activity O
following O
criticism O
predicted O
worse O
responses O
to O
actual O
social O
conflicts O
. O

Weak O
neural O
regulation O
of O
emotion O
combined O
with O
social O
conflict O
may O
promote O
symptom O
development O
in O
at-risk O
individuals O
. O

Material O
and O
methods O
Participants O
Twenty-one O
FHR O
and O
20 O
non-FHR O
individuals O
enrolled O
in O
the O
study O
and O
completed O
the O
fMRI O
task O
. O

We O
excluded O
1 O
non-FHR O
participant O
due O
to O
excessive O
motion O
. O

All O
non-FHR O
participants O
and O
17 O
FHR O
participants O
then O
completed O
4 O
weeks O
of O
daily-diary O
questionnaires O
. O

Consequently O
, O
for O
fMRI O
analyses O
, O
NFHR O
= O
21 O
and O
Nnon-FHR O
= O
19 O
. O

For O
daily-diary O
analyses O
, O
NFHR O
= O
17 O
and O
Nnon-FHR O
= O
19 O
( O
see O
Table O
1 O
for O
participant O
details O
) O
. O

FHR O
participants O
were O
required O
to O
be O
between O
15 O
and O
32 O
years O
of O
age O
and O
have O
a O
relative O
or O
relatives O
diagnosed O
with O
psychotic O
disorders O
. O

All O
FHR O
participants O
had O
at O
least O
one O
first-degree O
relative O
with O
schizophrenia O
or O
schizoaffective O
disorder O
, O
and O
all O
but O
2 O
had O
a O
second O
first-degree O
relative O
with O
one O
of O
these O
disorders O
. O

Non-FHR O
participants O
had O
no O
family O
history O
of O
psychotic O
disorders O
, O
psychiatric O
hospitalization O
, O
or O
suicide O
. O

Exclusion O
criteria O
for O
both O
FHR O
and O
non-FHR O
participants O
included O
past/current O
treatment O
with O
anti-psychotics O
or O
mood O
stabilizers O
, O
IQ O
< O
70 O
, O
being O
a O
non-native O
English O
speaker O
, O
fMRI O
contraindication O
, O
and O
past O
or O
current O
DSM-IV O
Axis-I O
psychotic O
disorders O
( O
i.e. O
, O
schizophrenia O
, O
schizoaffective O
disorder O
, O
psychosis-NOS O
, O
substance-induced O
psychosis O
, O
or O
bipolar/major O
depressive O
disorder O
with O
psychotic O
features O
) O
. O

Neither O
FHR O
nor O
non-FHR O
participants O
were O
excluded O
for O
other O
Axis-I O
disorders O
. O

This O
maintained O
the O
representativeness O
and O
external O
validity O
of O
our O
sample O
, O
as O
these O
conditions O
have O
been O
found O
to O
be O
more O
prevalent O
in O
FHR O
individuals O
than O
the O
general O
population O
. O

We O
used O
the O
Diagnostic O
Interview O
for O
Genetic O
Studies O
( O
DIGS O
) O
and O
Family O
Interview O
for O
Genetic O
Studies O
( O
FIGS O
) O
to O
assess O
personal O
and O
family O
history O
of O
psychopathology O
. O

Participants O
' O
prodromal O
psychotic O
symptoms O
were O
measured O
with O
the O
Structured O
Interview O
for O
Prodromal O
Syndromes O
( O
SIPS O
) O
. O

IQ O
was O
assessed O
with O
the O
Wechsler O
Abbreviated O
Scale O
of O
Intelligence O
( O
WASI O
) O
. O

The O
Beck O
Depression O
Inventory O
( O
BDI-II O
) O
and O
State–Trait O
Anxiety O
Inventory O
( O
STAI O
) O
assessed O
depression O
and O
anxiety O
, O
respectively O
. O

Expressed O
emotion O
task O
Following O
the O
procedure O
developed O
by O
Hooley O
and O
colleagues O
, O
participants O
listened O
to O
audio O
recordings O
of O
critical O
, O
neutral O
, O
and O
praising O
comments O
spoken O
in O
the O
third O
person O
presented O
via O
fMRI-compatible O
headphones O
. O

Participants O
listened O
to O
comments O
for O
20 O
s O
, O
freely O
processed O
and O
reflected O
on O
comments O
for O
a O
6-s O
pause O
period O
, O
and O
then O
had O
4 O
s O
to O
rate O
how O
positive O
or O
negative O
they O
felt O
after O
each O
comment O
( O
see O
Fig O
. O

1a O
for O
task O
details O
) O
. O

Participants O
imagined O
that O
each O
comment O
was O
about O
them O
to O
simulate O
the O
experience O
of O
being O
criticized O
, O
neutrally O
commented O
on O
, O
and O
praised O
( O
see O
Fig O
. O

1b O
for O
example O
comments O
) O
, O
and O
ratings O
were O
made O
on O
a O
5-point O
scale O
( O
1 O
= O
very O
positive O
, O
5 O
= O
very O
negative O
) O
. O

The O
task O
included O
4 O
trials O
of O
each O
condition O
, O
evenly O
split O
into O
two O
runs O
. O

Trial O
order O
was O
pseudo-randomized O
. O

We O
analyzed O
participants O
' O
average O
mood O
ratings O
within O
each O
condition O
using O
a O
2 O
Group O
[ O
FHR O
vs. O
non-FHR O
] O
× O
3 O
Condition O
[ O
critical O
vs. O
neutral O
vs. O
praising O
] O
ANOVA O
. O

fMRI O
data O
acquisition O
and O
processing O
Structural O
and O
functional O
MRI O
data O
were O
collected O
on O
a O
3-Tesla O
Siemens O
scanner O
using O
a O
12-channel O
head O
coil O
. O

T1-weighted O
structural O
images O
were O
acquired O
using O
multi-echo O
MPRAGE O
sequences O
( O
176 O
sagittal O
slices O
, O
1 O
mm O
slice O
thickness O
) O
. O

Whole-brain O
functional O
scans O
consisted O
of O
interleaved O
echo-planar O
images O
acquired O
in O
the O
oblique-axial O
plane O
( O
40 O
slices O
, O
3 O
mm O
isomorphic O
voxels O
, O
TE O
= O
30 O
ms O
, O
TR O
= O
2560 O
ms O
, O
flip O
angle O
= O
85 O
, O
FOV O
= O
216 O
mm O
× O
216 O
mm O
, O
matrix O
size O
= O
72 O
× O
72 O
) O
. O

The O
first O
four O
volumes O
of O
each O
run O
were O
discarded O
to O
stabilize O
signal O
. O

Data O
were O
preprocessed O
using O
SPM8 O
( O
Wellcome O
Department O
of O
Cognitive O
Neurology O
, O
London O
, O
UK O
) O
, O
including O
correction O
for O
slice O
time O
and O
head O
motion O
. O

Functional O
volumes O
were O
realigned O
to O
the O
anatomical O
image O
, O
spatially O
normalized O
to O
the O
Montreal O
Neurological O
Institute O
( O
MNI O
) O
template O
, O
and O
smoothed O
with O
a O
6 O
mm O
Gaussian O
kernel O
. O

fMRI O
analyses O
Analyses O
were O
conducted O
in O
Neuroelf O
( O
www.neuroelf.net O
) O
using O
general O
linear O
models O
( O
GLMs O
) O
in O
which O
events O
were O
convolved O
with O
canonical O
hemodynamic O
response O
functions O
. O

We O
included O
motion O
parameters O
and O
a O
high-pass O
filter O
of O
128 O
s O
as O
regressors O
of O
no O
interest O
to O
statistically O
remove O
head O
motion O
from O
measures O
of O
brain O
activity O
. O

Analyses O
focused O
on O
the O
6-s O
pause O
period O
between O
listening O
and O
rating O
to O
assess O
neural O
activity O
following O
periods O
of O
critical O
, O
neutral O
, O
or O
praising O
social O
experiences O
( O
i.e. O
, O
the O
time O
at O
which O
participants O
would O
be O
processing O
the O
emotions O
aroused O
during O
the O
listening O
period O
) O
. O

GLMs O
included O
listening O
periods O
split O
by O
condition O
and O
rating O
periods O
as O
regressors O
of O
no O
interest O
to O
ensure O
that O
only O
the O
inter-trial O
interval O
was O
treated O
as O
baseline O
. O

Our O
primary O
fMRI O
analysis O
examined O
group O
differences O
in O
neural O
activity O
following O
critical O
comments O
compared O
to O
neutral O
comments O
[ O
i.e. O
, O
critical O
> O
neutral O
( O
non-FHR O
> O
FHR O
) O
] O
. O

This O
contrast O
examined O
neural O
activity O
while O
participants O
processed O
emotions O
aroused O
by O
critical O
comments O
and O
used O
the O
neutral O
condition O
to O
control O
for O
low-level O
task O
features O
. O

Given O
that O
previous O
research O
establishes O
that O
the O
DLPFC O
plays O
a O
critical O
role O
in O
emotion O
regulation O
and O
that O
DLPFC O
activity O
is O
atypical O
in O
FHR O
individuals O
, O
we O
had O
an O
a O
priori O
interest O
in O
exploring O
group O
differences O
in O
this O
region O
. O

Hence O
, O
we O
corrected O
fMRI O
analyses O
for O
multiple O
comparisons O
using O
an O
independently O
defined O
bilateral O
DLPFC O
mask O
from O
. O

We O
applied O
small-volume O
correction O
within O
this O
bilateral O
DLPFC O
mask O
to O
ensure O
that O
significant O
clusters O
within O
the O
DLPFC O
met O
a O
corrected O
threshold O
of O
p O
< O
.05 O
. O

For O
completeness O
, O
we O
also O
report O
regions O
from O
whole-brain O
contrasts O
that O
occurred O
outside O
the O
DLPFC O
. O

To O
correct O
for O
multiple O
comparisons O
outside O
of O
the O
DLPFC O
, O
we O
used O
a O
Monte O
Carlo O
simulation O
implemented O
via O
Neuroelf O
's O
Alphasim O
function O
to O
determine O
the O
minimum O
cluster O
size O
that O
would O
be O
required O
to O
meet O
a O
corrected O
threshold O
of O
p O
< O
.05 O
. O

The O
Alphasim O
simulation O
concluded O
that O
a O
minimum O
of O
39 O
contiguous O
voxels O
at O
a O
voxel-wise O
threshold O
of O
p O
< O
.001 O
met O
this O
corrected O
threshold O
. O

Hence O
, O
we O
report O
clusters O
that O
meet O
a O
p O
< O
.05 O
threshold O
, O
either O
corrected O
using O
small-volume O
correction O
( O
within O
the O
DLPFC O
) O
or O
Alphasim O
correction O
( O
outside O
the O
DLPFC O
) O
. O

Independently O
defined O
region-of-interest O
( O
ROI O
) O
analyses O
can O
provide O
corroborating O
evidence O
for O
whole-brain O
analyses O
and O
can O
further O
establish O
that O
specific O
regions O
are O
implicated O
in O
certain O
psychological O
processes O
. O

Thus O
, O
as O
in O
this O
prior O
work O
, O
we O
used O
Neurosynth O
to O
identify O
brain O
regions O
from O
the O
neuroimaging O
literature O
that O
show O
a O
significant O
meta-analytic O
association O
with O
the O
phrase O
“ O
emotion O
regulation O
” O
. O

A O
meta-analysis O
of O
134 O
neuroimaging O
studies O
returned O
significant1 O
clusters O
in O
the O
left O
DLPFC O
( O
MNI O
coordinates O
= O
[ O
−40 O
, O
16 O
, O
44 O
] O
; O
k O
= O
192 O
) O
and O
right O
DLPFC O
( O
coordinates O
= O
[ O
36 O
, O
24 O
, O
46 O
] O
; O
k O
= O
50 O
) O
. O

We O
extracted O
beta O
estimates O
of O
activity O
in O
these O
clusters O
during O
the O
expressed O
emotion O
task O
and O
computed O
critical O
> O
neutral O
difference O
scores O
for O
each O
participant O
. O

We O
tested O
for O
group O
differences O
in O
these O
independently O
defined O
ROIs O
using O
t-tests O
. O

This O
ROI O
analysis O
buttressed O
conclusions O
from O
the O
small-volume O
corrected O
whole-brain O
analysis O
discussed O
above O
and O
ensured O
that O
the O
specific O
portion O
of O
the O
DLPFC O
we O
analyzed O
was O
associated O
with O
emotion O
regulation O
in O
prior O
studies O
. O

Daily-diary O
measures O
Participants O
completed O
an O
online O
questionnaire O
each O
evening O
before O
bed O
for O
28 O
days O
following O
the O
MRI O
scan O
( O
see O
Table O
2 O
for O
daily-diary O
questions O
, O
Cronbach O
's O
αs O
, O
descriptive O
statistics O
, O
and O
group O
comparisons O
) O
. O

Each O
day O
, O
participants O
indicated O
how O
much O
they O
felt O
a O
series O
of O
emotions O
( O
e.g. O
, O
anxious O
, O
sad O
, O
hopeless O
, O
cheerful O
, O
happy O
, O
or O
content O
) O
on O
5-point O
scales O
( O
1 O
= O
not O
at O
all O
, O
5 O
= O
extremely O
) O
. O

We O
averaged O
negative O
and O
positive O
emotion O
ratings O
to O
produce O
daily O
measures O
of O
negative O
and O
positive O
mood O
. O

Participants O
also O
indicated O
whether O
or O
not O
they O
had O
experienced O
7 O
forms O
of O
interpersonal O
conflict O
that O
day O
( O
e.g. O
, O
“ O
I O
felt O
that O
someone O
else O
was O
hostile O
towards O
me O
” O
) O
, O
and O
they O
rated O
how O
distressing O
they O
found O
each O
conflict O
( O
1 O
= O
not O
at O
all O
, O
5 O
= O
extremely O
) O
. O

We O
computed O
the O
maximum O
conflict O
distress O
for O
each O
day O
( O
0 O
if O
no O
conflicts O
that O
day O
) O
. O

Finally O
, O
participants O
completed O
a O
set O
of O
questions O
that O
measured O
each O
day O
's O
level O
of O
negative O
symptoms O
( O
e.g. O
, O
“ O
I O
felt O
like O
I O
did O
n't O
care O
about O
anything O
” O
) O
, O
positive O
symptoms O
( O
e.g. O
, O
“ O
I O
felt O
as O
if O
someone O
else O
could O
read O
my O
thoughts O
and O
feelings O
” O
) O
, O
and O
disorganized O
symptoms O
( O
e.g. O
, O
“ O
I O
felt O
like O
my O
thoughts O
were O
jumbled O
” O
) O
again O
on O
5-point O
scales O
( O
1 O
= O
not O
at O
all O
, O
5 O
= O
extremely O
) O
. O

We O
computed O
each O
day O
's O
average O
rating O
of O
each O
symptom O
type O
. O

Because O
reliability O
for O
our O
measure O
of O
disorganized O
symptoms O
was O
unsatisfactory O
, O
Cronbach O
's O
α O
= O
.48 O
, O
we O
excluded O
it O
from O
further O
analyses O
. O

We O
also O
excluded O
diary O
entries O
that O
were O
incomplete O
or O
were O
completed O
the O
following O
morning O
. O

Daily-diary O
analyses O
We O
first O
investigated O
whether O
participants O
' O
neural O
responses O
to O
critical O
comments O
predicted O
their O
mood O
and O
symptoms O
on O
days O
with O
distressing O
social O
conflicts O
. O

Following O
previous O
work O
, O
we O
extracted O
beta O
estimates O
of O
neural O
activity O
in O
the O
expressed O
emotion O
task O
and O
examined O
whether O
this O
interacted O
with O
FHR O
status O
and/or O
real-world O
social O
conflict O
to O
predict O
daily O
mood O
and O
symptoms O
in O
a O
series O
of O
mixed-effects O
models O
. O

We O
used O
neural O
activity O
from O
the O
Neurosynth O
ROIs O
in O
these O
analyses—rather O
than O
activity O
in O
clusters O
identified O
in O
the O
whole-brain O
analysis—to O
avoid O
using O
data O
that O
had O
been O
selected O
based O
on O
group O
differences O
. O

Because O
DLPFC O
betas O
from O
the O
left O
and O
right O
ROIs O
were O
strongly O
correlated O
, O
r O
= O
0.52 O
, O
p O
= O
.001 O
, O
we O
averaged O
these O
into O
a O
single O
bilateral O
DLPFC O
estimate O
for O
each O
participant O
. O

We O
used O
two O
sets O
of O
mixed-effects O
models O
to O
test O
the O
hypothesis O
that O
weaker O
DLPFC O
responses O
to O
criticism O
in O
FHR O
individuals O
were O
associated O
with O
increased O
negative O
mood O
and O
psychotic-like O
symptoms O
following O
real-world O
social O
conflict O
. O

The O
first O
set O
of O
models O
examined O
how O
DLPFC O
activity O
, O
FHR O
status O
, O
same-day O
conflict O
distress O
, O
and O
interactions O
between O
these O
factors O
related O
to O
our O
4 O
dependent O
variables O
of O
interest O
( O
negative O
mood O
, O
positive O
mood O
, O
negative O
symptoms O
, O
and O
positive O
symptoms O
) O
. O

By O
“ O
same-day O
conflict O
distress O
” O
we O
mean O
the O
maximum O
distress O
rating O
for O
conflicts O
experienced O
on O
the O
same O
day O
as O
dependent O
variable O
ratings O
. O

We O
hypothesized O
three-way O
interactions O
for O
these O
models O
such O
that O
the O
combination O
of O
distressing O
social O
conflicts O
and O
weak O
DLPFC O
activity O
would O
be O
associated O
with O
exacerbated O
mood O
and O
symptom O
disturbance O
specifically O
in O
FHR O
individuals O
. O

A O
second O
set O
of O
analyses O
examined O
whether O
DLPFC O
activity O
, O
FHR O
status O
, O
and O
social O
conflict O
impacted O
dependent O
variables O
on O
the O
day O
following O
conflicts O
. O

We O
refer O
to O
these O
analyses O
as O
“ O
following-day O
analyses. O
” O
These O
analyses O
included O
DLPFC O
activity O
, O
FHR O
status O
, O
previous-day O
conflict O
distress O
, O
and O
their O
interactions O
as O
fixed O
effects O
. O

By O
“ O
previous-day O
conflict O
distress O
, O
” O
we O
mean O
the O
maximum O
conflict O
distress O
experienced O
on O
the O
day O
before O
dependent O
variable O
ratings O
. O

These O
analyses O
let O
us O
( O
i O
) O
examine O
whether O
social O
conflict O
impacted O
participants O
even O
the O
day O
after O
a O
conflict O
and O
( O
ii O
) O
establish O
whether O
social O
conflict O
temporally O
preceded O
changes O
in O
dependent O
variables O
. O

We O
again O
hypothesized O
three-way O
interactions O
such O
that O
weak O
DLPFC O
activity O
and O
FHR O
status O
would O
be O
specifically O
associated O
with O
exacerbated O
mood O
and O
symptom O
disturbance O
on O
days O
following O
distressing O
social O
conflicts O
. O

For O
both O
same-day O
and O
following-day O
analyses O
, O
each O
dependent O
variable O
( O
i.e. O
, O
negative O
mood O
, O
positive O
mood O
, O
negative O
symptoms O
, O
and O
positive O
symptoms O
) O
was O
modeled O
at O
the O
daily O
level O
in O
a O
separate O
mixed-effects O
model O
. O

Fixed-effect O
predictors O
of O
interest O
included O
group O
( O
FHR O
vs. O
non-FHR O
) O
, O
conflict O
distress O
( O
0–5 O
maximum O
distress O
due O
to O
conflict O
either O
that O
day O
or O
the O
previous O
day O
) O
, O
neural O
response O
to O
criticism O
( O
bilateral O
DLPFC O
beta O
) O
, O
and O
the O
interactions O
between O
these O
three O
predictors O
. O

Note O
that O
each O
participant O
's O
daily O
conflict O
distress O
and O
overall O
neural O
response O
to O
criticism O
were O
input O
as O
continuous O
measures O
: O
These O
variables O
were O
not O
split O
into O
categories O
even O
though O
predicted O
values O
for O
extreme O
groups O
are O
presented O
in O
figures O
to O
illustrate O
the O
interactions O
. O

Models O
controlled O
for O
diary O
day O
and O
the O
previous O
day O
's O
level O
of O
each O
dependent O
variable O
. O

Controlling O
for O
the O
previous-day O
rating O
of O
dependent O
variables O
effectively O
means O
we O
modeled O
the O
change O
in O
the O
dependent O
variable O
from O
the O
previous O
day O
. O

We O
“ O
nested O
” O
days O
within O
participants O
by O
modeling O
participants O
as O
a O
random O
effect O
. O

Diary O
day O
was O
allowed O
to O
have O
a O
random O
slope O
across O
participants O
. O

All O
continuous O
predictors O
were O
centered O
. O

We O
unpacked O
significant O
interactions O
between O
conflict O
distress O
and O
DLPFC O
activity O
using O
simple O
slopes O
analyses O
. O

These O
analyses O
dissect O
interactions O
and O
uncover O
which O
combinations O
of O
group O
status O
, O
DLPFC O
activity O
, O
and O
conflict O
distress O
were O
associated O
with O
outcomes O
. O

These O
analyses O
specifically O
tested O
whether O
DLPFC O
activity O
was O
associated O
with O
mood O
or O
symptom O
levels O
within O
both O
FHR O
and O
non-FHR O
groups O
on O
days O
with O
high O
or O
low O
conflict O
distress O
. O

Such O
piecewise O
analyses O
clarify O
which O
group O
and O
level O
of O
conflict O
distress O
drove O
interactions O
, O
thereby O
testing O
whether O
interactions O
were O
due O
to O
the O
hypothesized O
pattern O
of O
results O
( O
i.e. O
, O
weak O
DLPFC O
activity O
is O
associated O
with O
elevated O
mood O
and O
symptom O
expression O
in O
FHR O
participants O
following O
distressing O
conflicts O
) O
. O

For O
each O
group O
, O
simple O
slope O
analyses O
assessed O
whether O
high O
or O
low O
DLPFC O
activity O
( O
1 O
SD O
from O
each O
group O
's O
mean O
) O
was O
significantly O
associated O
with O
each O
dependent O
variable O
on O
days O
with O
no O
( O
0 O
= O
conflict O
absent O
) O
or O
maximal O
( O
5 O
= O
extremely O
distressing O
) O
conflict O
distress O
. O

We O
tested O
the O
significance O
of O
simple O
slopes O
in O
R O
using O
the O
pbkrtest O
package O
, O
which O
conducts O
an O
F-test O
using O
Kenward-Roger-approximated O
degrees O
of O
freedom O
. O

Correction O
for O
multiple O
comparisons O
Although O
mixed-effect O
model O
analyses O
were O
planned O
a O
priori O
, O
these O
analyses O
involved O
a O
large O
number O
of O
comparisons O
. O

Hence O
, O
we O
implemented O
the O
method O
to O
facilitate O
interpretation O
of O
which O
results O
survived O
correction O
for O
multiple O
comparisons O
. O

Each O
predictor O
across O
all O
8 O
analyses O
was O
considered O
a O
separate O
test O
. O

We O
report O
results O
that O
persist O
following O
this O
correction O
in O
Table O
3 O
. O

Follow-up O
control O
analyses O
including O
covariates O
We O
conducted O
a O
series O
of O
follow-up O
control O
analyses O
to O
verify O
that O
age O
, O
gender O
, O
depressive O
symptoms O
( O
assessed O
by O
the O
BDI-II O
) O
, O
and O
having O
a O
diagnosis O
of O
substance O
abuse O
did O
not O
confound O
our O
results O
. O

To O
test O
whether O
primary O
results O
existed O
even O
after O
controlling O
for O
these O
variables O
, O
we O
added O
these O
variables O
as O
simultaneous O
covariates O
in O
a O
set O
of O
secondary O
analyses O
. O

We O
report O
results O
of O
these O
control O
analyses O
in O
the O
results O
sections O
below O
. O

Note O
that O
these O
analyses O
included O
only O
a O
subset O
of O
participants O
because O
data O
regarding O
Axis-I O
diagnoses O
were O
not O
available O
for O
5 O
participants O
and O
BDI-II O
scores O
were O
not O
available O
for O
2 O
additional O
participants O
. O

Demonstrating O
that O
results O
remain O
after O
controlling O
for O
these O
variables O
increases O
confidence O
in O
the O
study O
's O
findings O
and O
suggests O
they O
are O
not O
explained O
by O
any O
of O
these O
potentially O
confounding O
variables O
. O

Disrupted O
modular O
organization O
of O
primary O
sensory O
brain O
areas O
in O
schizophrenia O
Abnormal O
brain O
resting-state O
functional O
connectivity O
has O
been O
consistently O
observed O
in O
patients O
affected O
by O
schizophrenia O
( O
SCZ O
) O
using O
functional O
MRI O
and O
other O
neuroimaging O
techniques O
. O

Graph O
theoretical O
methods O
provide O
a O
framework O
to O
investigate O
these O
defective O
functional O
interactions O
and O
their O
effects O
on O
the O
organization O
of O
brain O
connectivity O
networks O
. O

A O
few O
studies O
have O
shown O
altered O
distribution O
of O
connectivity O
within O
and O
between O
functional O
modules O
in O
SCZ O
patients O
, O
an O
indication O
of O
imbalanced O
functional O
segregation O
ad O
integration O
. O

However O
, O
no O
major O
alterations O
of O
modular O
organization O
have O
been O
reported O
in O
patients O
, O
and O
unambiguous O
identification O
of O
the O
neural O
substrates O
affected O
remains O
elusive O
. O

Recently O
, O
it O
has O
been O
demonstrated O
that O
current O
modularity O
analysis O
methods O
suffer O
from O
a O
fundamental O
and O
severe O
resolution O
limit O
, O
as O
they O
fail O
to O
detect O
features O
that O
are O
smaller O
than O
a O
scale O
determined O
by O
the O
size O
of O
the O
entire O
connectivity O
network O
. O

This O
resolution O
limit O
is O
likely O
to O
have O
hampered O
the O
ability O
to O
resolve O
differences O
between O
patients O
and O
controls O
in O
previous O
studies O
. O

Here O
, O
we O
apply O
Surprise O
, O
a O
novel O
resolution O
limit-free O
approach O
, O
to O
study O
the O
modular O
organization O
of O
resting O
state O
functional O
connectivity O
networks O
in O
a O
large O
cohort O
of O
SCZ O
patients O
and O
in O
matched O
healthy O
controls O
. O

Leveraging O
these O
important O
methodological O
advances O
we O
find O
new O
evidence O
of O
substantial O
fragmentation O
and O
reorganization O
involving O
primary O
sensory O
, O
auditory O
and O
visual O
areas O
in O
SCZ O
patients O
. O

Conversely O
, O
frontal O
and O
prefrontal O
areas O
, O
typically O
associated O
with O
higher O
cognitive O
functions O
, O
appear O
to O
be O
largely O
unaffected O
, O
with O
changes O
selectively O
involving O
language O
and O
speech O
processing O
areas O
. O

Our O
findings O
support O
the O
hypothesis O
that O
cognitive O
dysfunction O
in O
SCZ O
may O
involve O
deficits O
occurring O
already O
at O
early O
stages O
of O
sensory O
processing O
. O

Materials O
and O
methods O
Participants O
MRI O
data O
from O
78 O
patients O
with O
schizophrenia O
strict O
diagnosis O
( O
DSM O
IV O
) O
SCZ O
and O
91 O
healthy O
controls O
( O
CON O
) O
were O
downloaded O
from O
the O
open O
COBRE O
database O
( O
http O
: O
//fcon_1000.projects.nitrc.org/indi/retro/cobre.html O
) O
. O

Age O
ranged O
from O
18 O
to O
65 O
years O
in O
both O
groups O
. O

There O
was O
no O
significant O
mean O
age O
difference O
between O
the O
two O
populations O
( O
t-test O
, O
p-value O
= O
0.52 O
) O
. O

28 O
% O
of O
patients O
were O
scanned O
within O
a O
year O
from O
diagnosis O
, O
54 O
% O
between O
1 O
and O
5 O
years O
, O
the O
remaining O
ones O
after O
5 O
years O
. O

Participant O
demographics O
are O
reported O
in O
Table O
1 O
. O

All O
subjects O
in O
the O
COBRE O
were O
screened O
and O
excluded O
if O
they O
had O
history O
of O
neurological O
disorder O
, O
history O
of O
mental O
retardation O
, O
history O
of O
severe O
head O
trauma O
with O
> O
5 O
minutes O
loss O
of O
consciousness O
, O
history O
of O
substance O
abuse O
or O
dependence O
within O
the O
last O
12 O
months O
. O

Ethical O
statements O
are O
contained O
in O
the O
original O
publication O
of O
this O
dataset O
: O
informed O
consent O
was O
obtained O
from O
all O
subjects O
according O
to O
institutional O
guidelines O
at O
the O
University O
of O
New O
Mexico O
Human O
Research O
Protections O
Office O
, O
and O
all O
data O
were O
anonymized O
prior O
to O
group O
analysis O
. O

Patients O
were O
treated O
with O
one O
of O
the O
three O
atypical O
antipsychotics O
, O
olanzapine O
, O
risperidone O
or O
ziprasidone O
, O
and O
had O
retrospective O
and O
prospective O
clinical O
stability O
. O

None O
of O
the O
patients O
was O
under O
mood O
stabilizing O
treatment O
at O
the O
time O
of O
study O
. O

fMRI O
acquisition O
and O
pre-processing O
Images O
were O
acquired O
with O
a O
Siemens O
MIND O
TRIO O
3 O
T O
scanner O
equipped O
for O
echo-planar O
imaging O
( O
EPI O
) O
. O

Echo-planar O
imaging O
was O
used O
for O
resting O
state O
fMRI O
data O
collection O
with O
( O
Repetition O
Time O
) O
TR O
= O
2 O
s O
, O
( O
Echo O
Time O
) O
TE O
= O
29 O
ms O
, O
matrix O
size O
: O
64 O
× O
64 O
, O
slices O
= O
33 O
, O
voxel O
size O
= O
3 O
× O
3 O
× O
4 O
mm3 O
( O
for O
more O
details O
see O
) O
. O

A O
total O
of O
150 O
volumes O
of O
functional O
images O
were O
obtained O
for O
all O
subjects O
except O
one O
( O
this O
subject O
was O
excluded O
from O
the O
present O
study O
) O
. O

The O
data O
were O
pre-processed O
using O
SPM8 O
( O
Wellcome O
Trust O
Centre O
for O
Neuroimaging O
, O
London O
, O
UK O
) O
. O

After O
discarding O
the O
four O
initial O
volumes O
, O
the O
remaining O
volumes O
were O
corrected O
for O
slice O
timing O
, O
head-motion O
realigned O
( O
translational O
displacement O
and O
rotation O
along O
and O
around O
X O
, O
Y O
and O
Z O
axes O
) O
and O
normalized O
to O
the O
standard O
MNI O
EPI O
template O
space O
( O
voxel-size O
re-sampled O
to O
3 O
× O
3 O
× O
3 O
mm3 O
) O
. O

Means O
and O
standard O
deviations O
of O
motion O
parameters O
extracted O
with O
SPM O
for O
each O
subject O
included O
in O
this O
study O
are O
shown O
in O
the O
Supplementary O
information O
section O
( O
Fig O
. O

S5 O
) O
. O

Given O
the O
impact O
of O
motion O
on O
functional O
connectivity O
measures O
, O
and O
the O
potential O
confounds O
arising O
from O
differential O
motion O
across O
experimental O
groups O
, O
we O
assessed O
the O
effects O
of O
movement O
for O
each O
subject O
in O
the O
SZ O
and O
healthy O
control O
groups O
. O

Analysis O
of O
motion O
parameters O
did O
not O
show O
any O
significant O
difference O
between O
groups O
( O
z O
translation O
: O
p O
= O
0.265 O
; O
y O
translation O
: O
p O
= O
0.525 O
; O
x O
translation O
: O
p O
= O
0.2446 O
; O
x O
rotation O
: O
p O
= O
0.245 O
; O
y O
rotation O
: O
p O
= O
0.652 O
; O
z O
rotation O
: O
p O
= O
0.194 O
) O
. O

Additionally O
, O
Framewise O
Displacement O
( O
FD O
) O
and O
DVARS O
, O
two O
indices O
of O
data O
quality O
, O
were O
computed O
following O
. O

FD O
is O
a O
measure O
of O
head O
motion O
between O
subsequent O
volumes O
, O
whereas O
DVARS O
is O
an O
index O
of O
signal O
intensity O
changes O
across O
volumes O
. O

No O
outliers O
were O
identified O
in O
either O
group O
, O
nor O
significant O
between-group O
differences O
were O
observed O
in O
these O
metrics O
, O
and O
in O
the O
number O
and O
extent O
of O
motion-related O
spikes O
( O
Table O
S1 O
in O
the O
Supplementary O
information O
section O
) O
. O

In O
the O
light O
of O
this O
analysis O
we O
did O
not O
apply O
frame O
censoring O
to O
avoid O
loss O
of O
information O
and O
decrease O
of O
temporal O
degrees O
of O
freedom O
. O

However O
, O
we O
performed O
community O
detection O
in O
a O
subgroup O
of O
patients O
( O
61 O
) O
selected O
by O
stricter O
motion O
criteria O
( O
i.e O
. O

removing O
subjects O
with O
relative O
movement O
> O
0.5 O
mm O
) O
to O
further O
rule O
out O
effects O
of O
differential O
motion O
( O
see O
Discussion O
and O
Supplementary O
information O
section O
) O
. O

Comparisons O
of O
motion O
parameters O
, O
DVARS O
and O
FD O
for O
the O
experimental O
groups O
are O
reported O
in O
the O
Supplementary O
materials O
section O
. O

Adjacency O
matrices O
and O
connectivity O
parameters O
For O
each O
participant O
, O
638 O
regional O
mean O
time O
series O
were O
computed O
by O
averaging O
the O
voxel O
time O
series O
within O
each O
of O
the O
parcellized O
areas O
of O
the O
template O
described O
in O
. O

After O
regressing O
movement O
parameters O
, O
we O
estimated O
the O
connectivity O
matrix O
by O
computing O
pairwise O
inter-regional O
correlation O
for O
each O
individual O
. O

In O
order O
to O
compute O
group-level O
connectivity O
matrices O
, O
individual O
correlation O
matrices O
were O
Fisher-transformed O
and O
averaged O
by O
group O
. O

Several O
critiques O
of O
correlation O
as O
a O
measure O
of O
functional O
connectivity O
have O
been O
proposed O
, O
but O
this O
definition O
is O
the O
most O
widely O
accepted O
choice O
, O
and O
we O
have O
adopted O
it O
to O
ensure O
comparability O
of O
our O
results O
with O
previous O
studies O
. O

From O
the O
adjacency O
matrix O
, O
we O
extracted O
the O
distribution O
of O
z-score O
( O
corresponding O
to O
the O
weighted O
edges O
of O
our O
network O
) O
, O
and O
we O
computed O
nodal O
and O
global O
measures O
of O
connectivity O
to O
compare O
this O
dataset O
with O
those O
used O
in O
previous O
studies O
. O

The O
degree O
of O
a O
node O
represents O
the O
number O
of O
connections O
towards O
the O
other O
nodes O
. O

The O
network O
density O
indicates O
the O
ratio O
between O
the O
connections O
in O
the O
matrix O
and O
all O
possible O
connection O
. O

Global O
efficiency O
represents O
the O
average O
of O
the O
inverse O
shortest O
weighted O
path O
lengths O
connecting O
every O
pair O
of O
nodes O
, O
and O
is O
inversely O
related O
to O
the O
network O
characteristic O
path O
length O
. O

The O
weighted O
global O
efficiency O
can O
be O
written O
as O
: O
where O
dijw O
is O
the O
weighted O
shortest-path O
length O
between O
node O
i O
and O
node O
j O
of O
a O
graph O
with O
n O
nodes O
. O

Weighted O
local O
efficiency O
quantifies O
a O
network O
's O
resistance O
to O
failure O
on O
a O
local O
scale O
. O

The O
definition O
of O
weighted O
local O
efficiency O
used O
in O
this O
manuscript O
is O
the O
one O
given O
by O
. O

Asymptotical O
Surprise O
The O
quality O
function O
that O
we O
chose O
to O
determine O
community O
structure O
in O
this O
study O
is O
Asymptotical O
Surprise O
, O
a O
recently O
developed O
approach O
rooted O
in O
information O
theory O
that O
aims O
to O
encode O
the O
relative O
entropy O
between O
the O
observed O
intracluster O
density O
and O
its O
expected O
value O
as O
on O
the O
basis O
of O
a O
null O
model O
. O

Asymptotical O
Surprise O
was O
recently O
shown O
to O
be O
quasi-resolution-limit O
free O
, O
and O
to O
provide O
improved O
means O
to O
resolve O
the O
modular O
structure O
of O
complex O
networks O
of O
brain O
functional O
connectivity O
. O

Asymptotical O
Surprise O
is O
defined O
as O
: O
where O
m O
is O
the O
sum O
of O
all O
edge O
weights O
, O
mζ O
is O
the O
sum O
of O
intracluster O
edge O
weights O
, O
p O
is O
the O
total O
number O
of O
possible O
links O
, O
pζ O
is O
the O
total O
sum O
of O
possible O
intracluster O
links O
. O

Optimization O
of O
Asymptotical O
Surprise O
was O
carried O
out O
by O
means O
of O
PACO O
( O
PArtitioning O
Cost O
Optimization O
) O
, O
an O
iterative O
agglomerative O
algorithm O
built O
on O
a O
variation O
of O
the O
Kruskal O
algorithm O
for O
minimum O
spanning O
trees O
. O

We O
have O
recently O
shown O
that O
maximization O
of O
Asymptotical O
Surprise O
enables O
detection O
of O
heterogeneously O
distributed O
communities O
, O
thus O
making O
it O
possible O
to O
resolve O
differences O
in O
the O
modular O
organization O
of O
different O
networks O
representing O
functional O
connectivity O
in O
different O
subjects O
or O
experimental O
groups O
. O

A O
MATLAB O
toolbox O
including O
binary O
and O
weighted O
versions O
of O
Surprise O
optimization O
is O
available O
upon O
request O
at O
http O
: O
//forms.iit.it/view.php O
? O
id=68447 O
. O

PACO O
is O
a O
non-deterministic O
heuristic O
, O
like O
many O
other O
methods O
used O
to O
maximize O
quality O
functions O
for O
community O
detection O
. O

This O
means O
that O
multiple O
runs O
of O
PACO O
on O
the O
same O
graph O
may O
yield O
slightly O
different O
resulting O
partitions O
. O

In O
this O
study O
, O
we O
used O
1000 O
runs O
and O
picked O
the O
partition O
with O
the O
highest O
value O
of O
Asymptotical O
Surprise O
. O

As O
shown O
in O
, O
Asymptotical O
Surprise O
does O
not O
suffer O
from O
degeneracy O
of O
nearly O
optimal O
solutions O
, O
and O
is O
characterized O
by O
a O
sharply O
distinct O
global O
optimum O
. O

Hence O
, O
there O
is O
no O
need O
to O
determine O
a O
consensus O
solution O
over O
an O
ensemble O
of O
different O
nearly O
optimal O
partitions O
with O
similarly O
large O
values O
of O
the O
fitness O
function O
, O
and O
the O
solutions O
with O
the O
highest O
value O
of O
Asymptotical O
Surprise O
were O
selected O
. O

All O
visual O
representations O
of O
the O
anatomical O
distribution O
of O
modules O
and O
topological O
parameters O
were O
produced O
using O
the O
BrainNet O
viewer O
toolbox O
. O

Percolation O
analysis O
In O
weighted O
networks O
, O
sparsification O
procedures O
are O
often O
applied O
to O
remove O
the O
weakest O
edges O
, O
which O
are O
the O
most O
affected O
by O
experimental O
noise O
, O
and O
to O
reduce O
the O
density O
of O
the O
graph O
, O
thus O
making O
it O
theoretically O
and O
computationally O
more O
tractable O
. O

To O
this O
end O
, O
we O
used O
a O
percolation O
analysis O
approach O
. O

This O
method O
, O
grounded O
in O
statistical O
physics O
, O
was O
first O
demonstrated O
in O
brain O
networks O
by O
, O
and O
previously O
applied O
to O
study O
phase O
transitions O
of O
connected O
subgraphs O
in O
random O
networks O
. O

In O
brief O
, O
percolation O
analysis O
measures O
the O
size O
of O
the O
largest O
connected O
component O
of O
the O
network O
upon O
iterative O
removal O
of O
the O
weakest O
edges O
and O
enables O
data-driven O
determination O
of O
the O
optimal O
sparsification O
threshold O
that O
preserves O
network O
structure O
and O
connectedness O
while O
removing O
potentially O
spurious O
correlations O
. O

In O
random O
graphs O
, O
the O
size O
of O
the O
largest O
connected O
component O
shows O
a O
sharp O
transition O
at O
some O
threshold O
value O
. O

Brain O
networks O
can O
exhibit O
multiple O
drops O
with O
increasing O
threshold O
, O
revealing O
a O
hierarchy O
of O
clusters O
. O

The O
steeper O
the O
percolation O
curve O
, O
the O
more O
susceptible O
is O
the O
graph O
to O
break O
apart O
into O
subcomponents O
upon O
removal O
of O
weaker O
edges O
. O

Based O
on O
these O
observations O
, O
we O
have O
recently O
demonstrated O
that O
a O
threshold O
just O
above O
the O
onset O
of O
fragmentation O
of O
the O
largest O
connected O
component O
strikes O
the O
optimal O
balance O
between O
removal O
of O
noise-induced O
spurious O
correlations O
and O
loss O
of O
information O
that O
may O
be O
contained O
in O
the O
discarded O
, O
weaker O
links O
. O

Specifically O
, O
the O
percolation O
threshold O
maximizes O
information O
that O
can O
be O
extracted O
about O
the O
network O
's O
modular O
organization O
, O
simultaneously O
maximizing O
sensitivity O
and O
specificity O
in O
the O
assignment O
of O
nodes O
to O
different O
modules O
, O
as O
shown O
in O
synthetic O
networks O
endowed O
with O
a O
ground-truth O
community O
structure O
and O
in O
human O
resting O
state O
functional O
connectivity O
networks O
. O

Thresholding O
by O
percolation O
analysis O
has O
been O
previously O
applied O
in O
human O
and O
animal O
functional O
connectivity O
studies O
. O

Percolation O
analysis O
was O
performed O
independently O
in O
the O
two O
groups O
prior O
to O
community O
detection O
by O
Asymptotical O
Surprise O
maximization O
. O

This O
is O
an O
important O
conceptual O
step O
, O
as O
it O
overcomes O
a O
conundrum O
in O
the O
comparison O
between O
groups O
characterized O
by O
different O
connectivity O
strengths O
. O

In O
many O
previous O
studies O
, O
thresholds O
were O
determined O
by O
fixing O
the O
same O
edge O
densities O
in O
the O
connectivity O
graphs O
of O
the O
groups O
to O
be O
compared O
. O

However O
, O
constant O
edge O
density O
may O
bias O
group O
comparisons O
when O
the O
experimental O
groups O
exhibit O
intrinsic O
differences O
in O
connectivity O
strength O
, O
like O
in O
the O
present O
case O
. O

Imposing O
equal O
densities O
for O
graphs O
describing O
connectivity O
in O
patients O
and O
controls O
may O
lead O
to O
the O
inclusion O
of O
a O
greater O
number O
of O
potentially O
spurious O
links O
in O
the O
group O
with O
weaker O
connectivity O
, O
and O
to O
the O
exclusion O
of O
topologically O
relevant O
links O
in O
the O
group O
with O
stronger O
connectivity O
. O

A O
higher O
proportion O
of O
spurious O
connection O
results O
in O
a O
more O
random O
network O
topology O
, O
and O
intergroup O
differences O
may O
just O
reflect O
different O
levels O
of O
noise O
, O
rather O
than O
genuine O
topological O
differences O
. O

Identification O
of O
optimal O
thresholds O
that O
maximize O
information O
about O
the O
modular O
organization O
of O
each O
group O
enables O
unbiased O
comparison O
of O
the O
two O
community O
structures O
. O

It O
should O
be O
noted O
that O
modules O
are O
defined O
in O
terms O
of O
node O
membership O
and O
do O
not O
dependent O
on O
the O
total O
density O
of O
edges O
, O
but O
rather O
on O
the O
balance O
between O
inwards O
and O
outwards O
edges O
. O

Community O
detection O
was O
performed O
on O
the O
thresholded O
group-level O
graphs O
maintaining O
the O
weight O
distribution O
above O
percolation O
threshold O
. O

In O
other O
words O
, O
graphs O
were O
not O
binarized O
after O
thresholding O
, O
as O
optimization O
of O
Asymptotical O
Surprise O
by O
PACO O
enables O
community O
detection O
in O
weighted O
graphs O
. O

Hence O
, O
the O
percolation O
threshold O
was O
applied O
solely O
for O
graph O
sparsification O
and O
removal O
of O
the O
noisiest O
edges O
. O

A O
total O
of O
8207 O
and O
17,171 O
edges O
were O
retained O
after O
thresholding O
in O
the O
patient O
and O
control O
groups O
, O
respectively O
, O
corresponding O
to O
graph O
densities O
of O
0.0404 O
and O
0.0845 O
. O

Group O
level O
comparison O
After O
community O
detection O
by O
Asymptotical O
Surprise O
in O
the O
two O
populations O
( O
SCZ O
and O
CON O
) O
, O
we O
computed O
the O
similarity O
between O
the O
extracted O
modular O
partitions O
in O
terms O
of O
normalized O
mutual O
information O
( O
NMI O
) O
, O
and O
used O
an O
approach O
proposed O
by O
to O
test O
for O
statistical O
differences O
. O

This O
method O
is O
based O
on O
the O
idea O
that O
if O
variance O
in O
the O
community O
structure O
data O
is O
reliably O
explained O
by O
group O
membership O
, O
then O
the O
mean O
NMI O
between O
all O
possible O
pairs O
of O
participants O
within O
an O
experimental O
group O
should O
be O
higher O
than O
the O
mean O
NMI O
of O
pairs O
of O
participants O
from O
random O
