groups O
. O

As O
the O
underlying O
distribution O
of O
group O
means O
NMI O
is O
unknown O
, O
a O
null-distribution O
is O
generated O
through O
a O
permutation O
method O
between O
the O
two O
experimental O
groups O
( O
10,000 O
permutations O
) O
. O

This O
approach O
was O
also O
applied O
to O
test O
for O
between-group O
differences O
in O
sub-networks O
defined O
by O
individual O
modules O
in O
the O
CON O
group O
partition O
. O

Participation O
coefficient O
To O
complete O
the O
investigation O
at O
the O
node O
level O
, O
we O
considered O
the O
alteration O
in O
node O
role O
between O
the O
two O
populations O
based O
on O
the O
differences O
in O
modular O
organization O
revealed O
by O
Asymptotical O
Surprise O
. O

To O
this O
end O
, O
we O
adopted O
Guimera O
and O
Amaral O
classification O
scheme O
, O
whereby O
nodes O
are O
classified O
by O
their O
within-community O
degree O
z O
( O
a O
measure O
of O
how O
well O
connected O
a O
node O
is O
to O
other O
nodes O
in O
the O
same O
community O
) O
and O
their O
participation O
coefficient O
P O
, O
a O
parameter O
that O
reflects O
the O
extent O
to O
which O
a O
node O
is O
connected O
to O
nodes O
in O
other O
modules O
. O

P O
can O
be O
written O
as O
: O
where O
kic O
is O
the O
number O
of O
links O
of O
node O
i O
to O
nodes O
in O
module O
c O
, O
and O
ki O
is O
the O
total O
degree O
of O
node O
i O
. O

To O
assess O
statistical O
differences O
, O
we O
computed O
the O
P O
index O
of O
each O
node O
for O
each O
subjects O
and O
ran O
a O
t-test O
between O
groups O
, O
Bonferroni O
corrected O
. O

Node-wise O
statistical O
significance O
was O
parametrically O
mapped O
on O
the O
MRI O
template O
. O

Cognitive O
scores O
We O
selected O
three O
tests O
probing O
different O
cognitive O
domains O
and O
available O
in O
the O
COBRE O
database O
for O
all O
patients O
included O
in O
this O
study O
: O
the O
Brief O
Assessment O
of O
Cognition O
in O
Schizophrenia O
( O
BACS O
) O
, O
the O
Mazes O
test O
from O
the O
Neuropsychological O
Assessment O
Battery O
( O
NAB O
) O
, O
and O
the O
Brief O
Visuospatial O
Memory O
Test O
( O
BVMT O
) O
. O

The O
BACS O
includes O
assessments O
of O
verbal O
memory O
, O
working O
memory O
, O
verbal O
fluency O
, O
attention O
and O
executive O
function O
. O

The O
NAB-Mazes O
test O
measures O
aspects O
of O
executive O
function O
often O
impaired O
in O
SZ O
patients O
. O

The O
BVMT O
measures O
visuospatial O
learning O
performance O
; O
processing O
speed O
has O
been O
shown O
to O
be O
a O
predictor O
of O
performance O
in O
the O
BVMT O
. O

We O
performed O
multiple O
regression O
analysis O
of O
subject-wise O
Global O
Efficiency O
and O
slope O
of O
the O
correlation O
curve O
( O
extracted O
by O
fitting O
a O
psychometric O
function O
) O
against O
the O
aggregated O
scores O
of O
these O
three O
tests O
. O

These O
parameters O
reflect O
the O
efficiency O
in O
information O
exchange O
across O
the O
network O
, O
and O
the O
“ O
fragility O
” O
of O
its O
modular O
organization O
upon O
edge O
removal O
, O
respectively O
. O

Dynamic O
network O
dysfunction O
in O
cocaine O
dependence O
: O
Graph O
theoretical O
metrics O
and O
stop O
signal O
reaction O
time O
Graphic O
theoretical O
metrics O
have O
become O
increasingly O
popular O
in O
characterizing O
functional O
connectivity O
of O
neural O
networks O
and O
how O
network O
connectivity O
is O
compromised O
in O
neuropsychiatric O
illnesses O
. O

Here O
, O
we O
add O
to O
this O
literature O
by O
describing O
dynamic O
network O
connectivities O
of O
78 O
cocaine O
dependent O
( O
CD O
) O
and O
85 O
non-drug O
using O
healthy O
control O
( O
HC O
) O
participants O
who O
underwent O
fMRI O
during O
performance O
of O
a O
stop O
signal O
task O
( O
SST O
) O
. O

Compared O
to O
HC O
, O
CD O
showed O
prolonged O
stop O
signal O
reaction O
time O
( O
SSRT O
) O
, O
consistent O
with O
deficits O
in O
response O
inhibition O
. O

In O
graph O
theoretical O
analysis O
of O
dynamic O
functional O
connectivity O
, O
we O
examined O
temporal O
flexibility O
and O
spatiotemporal O
diversity O
of O
14 O
networks O
covering O
the O
whole O
brain O
. O

Temporal O
flexibility O
quantifies O
how O
frequently O
a O
brain O
region O
interacts O
with O
regions O
of O
other O
communities O
across O
time O
, O
with O
high O
temporal O
flexibility O
indicating O
that O
a O
region O
interacts O
predominantly O
with O
regions O
outside O
its O
own O
community O
. O

Spatiotemporal O
diversity O
quantifies O
how O
uniformly O
a O
brain O
region O
interacts O
with O
regions O
in O
other O
communities O
over O
time O
, O
with O
high O
spatiotemporal O
diversity O
indicating O
that O
the O
interactions O
are O
more O
evenly O
distributed O
across O
communities O
. O

Compared O
to O
HC O
, O
CD O
exhibited O
decreased O
temporal O
flexibility O
and O
increased O
spatiotemporal O
diversity O
in O
the O
great O
majority O
of O
neural O
networks O
. O

The O
graph O
metric O
measures O
of O
the O
default O
mode O
network O
negatively O
correlated O
with O
SSRT O
in O
CD O
but O
not O
HC O
. O

The O
findings O
are O
consistent O
with O
diminished O
temporal O
flexibility O
and O
a O
compensatory O
increase O
in O
spatiotemporal O
diversity O
, O
in O
association O
with O
impairment O
of O
a O
critical O
executive O
function O
, O
in O
cocaine O
addiction O
. O

More O
broadly O
, O
the O
findings O
suggest O
that O
graph O
theoretical O
metrics O
provide O
new O
insights O
for O
connectivity O
analyses O
to O
elucidate O
network O
dysfunction O
that O
may O
elude O
conventional O
measures O
. O

Highlights O
Cocaine O
addiction O
( O
CA O
) O
is O
associated O
with O
prolonged O
stop O
signal O
reaction O
time O
( O
SSRT O
) O
. O

CA O
is O
associated O
with O
decreased O
temporal O
flexibility O
( O
TF O
) O
of O
neural O
networks O
. O

CA O
is O
associated O
with O
increased O
spatial O
temporal O
diversity O
( O
STD O
) O
of O
neural O
networks O
. O

The O
TF O
and O
STD O
of O
default O
mode O
network O
correlated O
negatively O
with O
SSRT O
in O
CA O
. O

Dynamic O
connectivity O
captures O
network O
dysfunction O
in O
link O
with O
inhibition O
deficits O
in O
CA O
. O

Materials O
and O
methods O
Subjects O
and O
behavioral O
task O
Eighty-five O
healthy O
control O
( O
HC O
) O
and O
78 O
cocaine O
dependent O
( O
CD O
) O
adults O
participated O
in O
this O
study O
. O

CD O
resided O
in O
an O
inpatient O
treatment O
unit O
and O
was O
abstinent O
between O
1 O
and O
2 O
weeks O
before O
fMRI O
scan O
was O
conducted O
. O

All O
participants O
reported O
no O
major O
medical O
, O
neurological O
, O
or O
other O
psychiatric O
illnesses O
( O
except O
nicotine O
use O
disorder O
) O
, O
denied O
use O
of O
other O
illicit O
substances O
and O
tested O
negative O
for O
cannabis O
, O
opioids O
, O
amphetamine O
, O
methamphetamine O
, O
phencyclidine O
, O
benzodiazepine O
, O
and O
barbiturate O
on O
the O
day O
of O
fMRI O
. O

All O
participants O
signed O
a O
written O
, O
informed O
consent O
in O
accordance O
with O
a O
protocol O
approved O
by O
the O
Yale O
Human O
Investigation O
Committee O
. O

Participants O
performed O
a O
stop O
signal O
task O
or O
SST O
, O
which O
was O
described O
in O
details O
in O
our O
previous O
studies O
. O

Briefly O
, O
a O
“ O
go O
” O
signal O
set O
up O
a O
pre-potent O
response O
tendency O
in O
go O
trials O
( O
~75 O
% O
) O
, O
and O
an O
additional O
, O
less O
frequent O
“ O
stop O
” O
signal O
instructed O
subjects O
to O
withhold O
their O
response O
in O
stop O
trials O
( O
~25 O
% O
) O
. O

Go O
and O
stop O
trials O
were O
randomized O
in O
presentation O
, O
with O
an O
inter-trial-interval O
of O
2 O
s. O
The O
time O
delay O
between O
go O
and O
stop O
signal O
– O
stop O
signal O
delay O
( O
SSD O
) O
– O
was O
staircased O
, O
increasing O
and O
decreasing O
by O
67 O
ms O
each O
following O
a O
stop O
success O
and O
error O
trial O
. O

Participants O
were O
instructed O
to O
respond O
as O
quickly O
as O
they O
could O
to O
“ O
go O
” O
signal O
, O
while O
watching O
out O
for O
the O
“ O
stop O
” O
signal O
. O

In O
the O
scanner O
, O
participants O
completed O
four O
10-minute O
runs O
of O
the O
SST O
, O
with O
approximately O
100 O
trials O
in O
each O
run O
. O

With O
the O
staircase O
procedure O
, O
participants O
succeeded O
in O
stopping O
approximately O
half O
of O
time O
. O

The O
stop O
signal O
reaction O
time O
( O
SSRT O
) O
– O
the O
time O
needed O
for O
one O
to O
stop O
the O
response O
half O
of O
the O
time O
, O
was O
estimated O
on O
the O
basis O
of O
a O
race O
model O
. O

Briefly O
, O
in O
the O
race O
model O
, O
go O
and O
stop O
processes O
independently O
race O
toward O
a O
finish O
line O
and O
whichever O
finishes O
first O
determines O
the O
trial O
outcome O
. O

With O
the O
race O
model O
, O
the O
SSRT O
can O
be O
estimated O
by O
subtracting O
a O
critical O
SSD O
( O
where O
subjects O
would O
succeed O
in O
stopping O
half O
of O
the O
time O
) O
from O
the O
mean O
go O
trial O
RT O
. O

The O
SSRT O
indexes O
the O
capacity O
of O
response O
inhibition O
, O
with O
shorter O
SSRT O
reflecting O
better O
ability O
of O
inhibitory O
control O
. O

Imaging O
protocol O
Conventional O
T1-weighted O
spin-echo O
sagittal O
anatomical O
images O
were O
acquired O
for O
slice O
localization O
using O
a O
3-T O
scanner O
( O
Siemens O
Trio O
, O
Erlangen O
, O
Germany O
) O
. O

Anatomical O
images O
of O
the O
functional O
slice O
locations O
were O
obtained O
with O
spin-echo O
imaging O
in O
the O
axial O
plane O
parallel O
to O
the O
anterior O
commissure–posterior O
commissure O
( O
AC–PC O
) O
line O
with O
TR O
= O
300 O
ms O
, O
TE O
= O
2.5 O
ms O
, O
bandwidth O
= O
300 O
Hz/pixel O
, O
flip O
angle O
= O
60° O
, O
field O
of O
view O
= O
220 O
× O
220 O
mm O
, O
matrix O
= O
256 O
× O
256 O
, O
32 O
slices O
with O
slice O
thickness O
= O
4 O
mm O
and O
no O
gap O
. O

A O
single O
high-resolution O
T1-weighted O
gradient-echo O
scan O
was O
obtained O
. O

One O
hundred O
seventy-six O
slices O
parallel O
to O
the O
AC–PC O
line O
covering O
the O
whole O
brain O
were O
acquired O
with O
TR O
= O
2530 O
ms O
, O
TE O
= O
3.66 O
ms O
, O
bandwidth O
= O
181 O
Hz/pixel O
, O
flip O
angle O
= O
7° O
, O
field O
of O
view O
= O
256 O
× O
256 O
mm O
, O
matrix O
= O
256 O
× O
256 O
, O
1 O
mm3 O
isotropic O
voxels O
. O

Functional O
scans O
were O
conducted O
with O
the O
SST O
. O

Blood O
oxygenation O
level O
dependent O
( O
BOLD O
) O
signals O
were O
acquired O
with O
a O
single-shot O
gradient-echo O
echo-planar O
imaging O
( O
EPI O
) O
sequence O
. O

Thirty-two O
axial O
slices O
parallel O
to O
the O
AC–PC O
line O
covering O
the O
whole O
brain O
were O
acquired O
with O
TR O
= O
2000 O
ms O
, O
TE O
= O
25 O
ms O
, O
bandwidth O
= O
2004 O
Hz/pixel O
, O
flip O
angle O
= O
85° O
, O
field O
of O
view O
= O
220 O
× O
220 O
mm O
, O
matrix O
= O
64 O
× O
64 O
, O
32 O
slices O
with O
slice O
thickness O
= O
4 O
mm O
and O
no O
gap O
. O

There O
were O
10 O
min O
( O
three O
hundred O
images O
) O
in O
each O
run O
for O
a O
total O
of O
four O
runs O
of O
the O
SST O
. O

Data O
pre-processing O
All O
data O
were O
first O
analyzed O
with O
Statistical O
Parametric O
Mapping O
( O
SPM O
, O
Wellcome O
Department O
of O
Imaging O
Neuroscience O
, O
University O
College O
London O
, O
U.K. O
) O
. O

In O
the O
pre-processing O
of O
BOLD O
data O
, O
images O
of O
each O
participant O
were O
realigned O
( O
motion-corrected O
) O
and O
corrected O
for O
slice O
timing O
. O

A O
mean O
functional O
image O
volume O
was O
constructed O
for O
each O
participant O
for O
each O
run O
from O
the O
realigned O
image O
volumes O
. O

These O
mean O
images O
were O
co-registered O
with O
the O
high O
resolution O
structural O
image O
and O
then O
segmented O
for O
normalization O
to O
a O
Montreal O
Neurological O
Institute O
EPI O
template O
with O
affine O
registration O
followed O
by O
nonlinear O
transformation O
. O

Images O
were O
then O
smoothed O
with O
a O
Gaussian O
kernel O
of O
8 O
mm O
at O
full O
width O
at O
half O
maximum O
. O

A O
multiple O
linear O
regression O
with O
12 O
realignment O
parameters O
( O
3 O
translations O
, O
3 O
rotations O
, O
and O
their O
first O
temporal O
derivatives O
) O
was O
applied O
to O
the O
smoothed O
data O
. O

Averaged O
signals O
from O
predefined O
white O
matter O
and O
cerebrospinal O
fluid O
masks O
were O
computed O
, O
detrended O
, O
and O
regressed O
out O
of O
the O
preprocessed O
data O
. O

The O
first O
5 O
frames O
of O
BOLD O
data O
were O
discarded O
to O
enable O
the O
signal O
to O
achieve O
steady-state O
equilibrium O
between O
radio O
frequency O
pulsing O
and O
relaxation O
. O

Finally O
, O
for O
each O
subject O
, O
data O
were O
concatenated O
across O
the O
four O
runs O
of O
SST O
for O
analyses O
. O

Graph O
model O
metrics O
We O
largely O
followed O
in O
the O
computation O
of O
graph O
metrics O
. O

The O
workflow O
is O
summarized O
in O
Fig O
. O

1 O
. O

Node O
definition O
Nodes O
were O
defined O
from O
Power O
's O
atlas O
with O
264 O
brain O
regions O
. O

The O
264 O
nodes O
were O
grouped O
to O
form O
14 O
large O
scale O
networks O
, O
including O
the O
salience O
network O
( O
SN O
) O
, O
cingulo-opercular O
task O
control O
network O
( O
CON O
) O
, O
fronto-parietal O
task O
control O
network O
( O
FPN O
) O
, O
dorsal O
attention O
network O
( O
DAN O
) O
, O
ventral O
attention O
network O
( O
VAN O
) O
, O
subcortical O
network O
, O
default O
mode O
network O
( O
DMN O
) O
, O
memory O
retrieval O
network O
, O
visual O
network O
, O
auditory O
network O
, O
sensory-motor O
networks O
as O
well O
as O
the O
cerebellum O
network O
. O

Voxel O
signals O
were O
extracted O
, O
detrended O
and O
averaged O
for O
each O
node O
. O

A O
band-pass O
filter O
( O
0.008 O
Hz O
< O
f O
< O
0.25 O
Hz O
) O
was O
applied O
to O
remove O
low-frequency O
signal O
drifts O
and O
increase O
the O
signal O
noise O
ratio O
. O

Time O
varying O
functional O
connectivity O
A O
sliding O
window O
with O
no O
gap O
or O
overlap O
between O
windows O
was O
applied O
to O
the O
time O
series O
to O
obtain O
dynamic O
functional O
connectivity O
between O
nodes O
. O

Exponentially O
decaying O
weights O
were O
applied O
to O
each O
time O
point O
within O
a O
window O
. O

The O
exponentially O
decaying O
weights O
were O
computed O
as O
: O
where O
w0 O
= O
( O
1 O
− O
e−1/θ O
) O
/ O
( O
1 O
− O
e−T/θ O
) O
, O
t O
is O
the O
tth O
time O
point O
within O
the O
sliding O
window O
, O
T O
is O
the O
window O
length O
( O
= O
40 O
s O
) O
, O
and O
the O
exponent O
θ O
controls O
the O
influence O
from O
distant O
time O
points O
, O
set O
to O
a O
third O
of O
the O
window O
length O
. O

Connectivity O
matrix O
for O
each O
time O
window O
was O
obtained O
by O
computing O
the O
weighted O
Pearson O
correlation O
between O
the O
time-series O
of O
any O
two O
nodes O
xt O
and O
yt O
as O
: O
where O
and O
. O

The O
resulting O
connectivity O
matrix O
for O
each O
window O
was O
z-transformed O
within O
the O
subject O
for O
subsequent O
analysis O
. O

Modularity O
Modularity O
was O
used O
to O
determine O
the O
optimal O
community O
structure O
within O
the O
unthresholded O
connectivity O
matrix O
by O
grouping O
nodes O
into O
non-overlapping O
communities O
or O
modules O
that O
maximize O
intra-modular O
connectivity O
and O
minimize O
inter-modular O
connectivity O
. O

Louvain O
community O
detection O
algorithm O
from O
the O
Brain O
Connectivity O
Toolbox O
was O
employed O
to O
identify O
community O
structure O
in O
both O
static O
and O
time-varying O
connectivity O
matrices O
. O

The O
algorithm O
optimizes O
a O
quality O
function O
Q O
, O
defined O
as O
the O
difference O
between O
the O
observed O
intra-modular O
and O
inter-modular O
connectivity O
, O
while O
penalizing O
assignment O
of O
nodes O
with O
negative O
correlations O
to O
the O
same O
community O
. O

The O
algorithm O
was O
repeated O
100 O
times O
and O
the O
results O
with O
the O
highest O
Q O
was O
extracted O
as O
the O
optimal O
community O
structure O
, O
for O
the O
computation O
of O
group O
static O
matrix O
and O
each O
subject O
's O
temporal O
co-occurrence O
matrix O
. O

Temporal O
co-occurrence O
matrix O
To O
investigate O
dynamic O
interactions O
between O
nodes O
, O
temporal O
co-occurrence O
matrices O
were O
computed O
based O
on O
subject O
's O
optimal O
community O
structures O
as O
obtained O
from O
the O
time-varying O
connectivity O
matrix O
. O

The O
community O
structure O
within O
each O
sliding O
window O
was O
used O
to O
construct O
an O
adjacency O
matrix O
Aijtk O
, O
such O
that O
Aijtk O
= O
1 O
if O
node O
i O
and O
node O
j O
are O
in O
the O
same O
community O
within O
time O
window O
t O
for O
participantk O
, O
otherwise O
Aijtk O
= O
0 O
. O

The O
temporal O
co-occurrence O
matrix O
was O
thus O
computed O
as O
the O
temporal O
mean O
of O
the O
adjacency O
matrix O
. O

Each O
element O
measures O
the O
proportion O
of O
times O
that O
two O
nodes O
are O
part O
of O
the O
same O
community O
. O

A O
higher O
value O
indicates O
that O
the O
two O
corresponding O
nodes O
participate O
in O
the O
same O
community O
more O
frequently O
. O

Group O
static O
functional O
connectivity O
Two O
levels O
of O
static O
functional O
connectivity O
were O
defined O
and O
computed O
. O

At O
the O
first O
level O
, O
for O
each O
individual O
, O
the O
static O
connectivity O
between O
nodes O
was O
computed O
by O
applying O
Pearson O
correlations O
on O
the O
nodes O
' O
time-series O
. O

At O
the O
second O
level O
, O
the O
resulting O
correlation O
matrices O
from O
individual O
subjects O
were O
z-transformed O
and O
averaged O
to O
form O
a O
group O
averaged O
connectivity O
matrix O
. O

Modularity O
analysis O
was O
performed O
with O
random O
initialization O
for O
100 O
times O
on O
group O
averaged O
connectivity O
matrix O
to O
determine O
the O
optimal O
static O
community O
structure O
, O
to O
be O
used O
for O
the O
computation O
of O
node-level O
metrics O
. O

Node-level O
metrics O
With O
the O
temporal O
co-occurrence O
matrix O
Cijk O
and O
the O
group O
static O
community O
, O
we O
characterized O
the O
dynamic O
spatiotemporal O
properties O
of O
each O
node O
using O
two O
measures O
: O
temporal O
flexibility O
and O
spatiotemporal O
diversity O
. O

The O
temporal O
flexibility O
of O
node O
i O
and O
participant O
k O
was O
computed O
as O
: O
where O
Cijk O
is O
the O
temporal O
co-occurrence O
matrix O
for O
individual O
k O
, O
ui O
is O
the O
community O
to O
which O
node O
i O
belongs O
, O
and O
∑j∉uiCijk O
measures O
the O
total O
frequency O
with O
which O
node O
i O
interacts O
with O
nodes O
outside O
its O
native O
community O
. O

Temporal O
flexibility O
of O
the O
node O
captures O
the O
tendency O
of O
deviation O
from O
its O
own O
native O
community O
and O
interaction O
with O
nodes O
from O
other O
community O
. O

The O
spatiotemporal O
diversity O
of O
node O
i O
and O
participant O
k O
was O
computed O
as O
: O
where O
, O
sik O
is O
the O
degree/strength O
of O
node O
i O
among O
all O
communities O
for O
participant O
k O
, O
sik O
( O
u O
) O
is O
the O
degree/strength O
of O
node O
i O
in O
community O
u O
for O
participant O
k O
, O
m O
is O
the O
total O
number O
of O
communities O
, O
and O
M O
is O
the O
set O
of O
communities O
. O

Nodes O
with O
high O
spatiotemporal O
diversity O
scores O
are O
those O
that O
have O
relatively O
spatially O
varied O
distribution O
of O
time-varying O
interactions O
with O
all O
communities O
and O
are O
putative O
loci O
for O
integrating O
information O
between O
communities O
. O

Correlation O
with O
behavioral O
performance O
We O
used O
both O
Pearson O
correlation O
to O
examine O
the O
relationship O
between O
graph O
metrics O
and O
the O
stop O
signal O
reaction O
time O
( O
SSRT O
) O
, O
the O
primary O
outcome O
measure O
of O
the O
SST O
. O

We O
focused O
on O
four O
networks O
that O
are O
known O
to O
be O
associated O
with O
inhibitory O
control O
– O
the O
saliency O
network O
, O
default O
mode O
network O
( O
DMN O
) O
, O
cingulo-opercular O
network O
( O
CON O
) O
, O
and O
fronto-parietal O
network O
( O
FPN O
) O
– O
in O
Pearson O
regression O
with O
the O
two O
connectivity O
metrics O
– O
temporal O
flexibility O
and O
spatiotemporal O
diversity O
. O

A O
corrected O
p O
value O
of O
0.05/8 O
= O
0.0063 O
was O
used O
to O
examine O
the O
correlation O
results O
. O

Ventral O
striatal O
dysfunction O
in O
cocaine O
dependence O
– O
difference O
mapping O
for O
subregional O
resting O
state O
functional O
connectivity O
Research O
of O
dopaminergic O
deficits O
has O
focused O
on O
the O
ventral O
striatum O
( O
VS O
) O
with O
many O
studies O
elucidating O
altered O
resting O
state O
functional O
connectivity O
( O
rsFC O
) O
in O
individuals O
with O
cocaine O
dependence O
( O
CD O
) O
. O

The O
VS O
comprises O
functional O
subregions O
and O
delineation O
of O
subregional O
changes O
in O
rsFC O
requires O
careful O
consideration O
of O
the O
differences O
between O
addicted O
and O
healthy O
populations O
. O

In O
the O
current O
study O
, O
we O
parcellated O
the O
VS O
using O
whole-brain O
rsFC O
differences O
between O
CD O
and O
non-drug-using O
controls O
( O
HC O
) O
. O

Voxels O
with O
similar O
rsFC O
changes O
formed O
functional O
clusters O
. O

The O
results O
showed O
that O
the O
VS O
was O
divided O
into O
3 O
subclusters O
, O
in O
the O
area O
of O
the O
dorsal-anterior O
VS O
( O
daVS O
) O
, O
dorsal O
posterior O
VS O
( O
dpVS O
) O
, O
and O
ventral O
VS O
( O
vVS O
) O
, O
each O
in O
association O
with O
different O
patterns O
of O
rsFC O
. O

The O
three O
subregions O
shared O
reduced O
rsFC O
with O
bilateral O
hippocampal/parahippocampal O
gyri O
( O
HG/PHG O
) O
but O
also O
showed O
distinct O
changes O
, O
including O
reduced O
vVS O
rsFC O
with O
ventromedial O
prefrontal O
cortex O
( O
vmPFC O
) O
and O
increased O
daVS O
rsFC O
with O
visual O
cortex O
in O
CD O
as O
compared O
to O
HC O
. O

Across O
CD O
, O
daVS O
visual O
cortical O
connectivity O
was O
positively O
correlated O
with O
amount O
of O
prior-month O
cocaine O
use O
and O
cocaine O
craving O
, O
and O
vVS O
vmPFC O
connectivity O
was O
negatively O
correlated O
with O
the O
extent O
of O
depression O
and O
anxiety O
. O

These O
findings O
suggest O
a O
distinct O
pattern O
of O
altered O
VS O
subregional O
rsFC O
in O
cocaine O
dependence O
, O
and O
some O
of O
the O
changes O
have O
eluded O
analyses O
using O
the O
whole O
VS O
as O
a O
seed O
region O
. O

The O
findings O
may O
provide O
new O
insight O
to O
delineating O
VS O
circuit O
deficits O
in O
cocaine O
dependence O
and O
provide O
an O
alternative O
analytical O
framework O
to O
address O
functional O
dysconnectivity O
in O
other O
mental O
illnesses O
. O

Materials O
and O
methods O
Subjects O
, O
informed O
consent O
, O
and O
assessment O
Sixty-six O
recently O
abstinent O
participants O
( O
44 O
men O
) O
with O
cocaine O
dependence O
( O
CD O
) O
and O
66 O
age- O
and O
gender-matched O
healthy O
control O
( O
HC O
) O
subjects O
( O
36 O
men O
) O
participated O
in O
the O
study O
( O
Supplementary O
Table O
1 O
) O
. O

CD O
met O
criteria O
for O
current O
cocaine O
dependence O
, O
as O
diagnosed O
by O
the O
Structured O
Clinical O
Interview O
for O
DSM-IV O
. O

Recent O
cocaine O
use O
was O
confirmed O
by O
urine O
toxicology O
screens O
. O

CD O
were O
drug-free O
while O
staying O
in O
an O
inpatient O
unit O
prior O
to O
the O
current O
fMRI O
study O
. O

All O
subjects O
were O
physically O
healthy O
with O
no O
major O
medical O
illnesses O
or O
current O
use O
of O
prescription O
medications O
. O

None O
reported O
having O
a O
history O
of O
head O
injury O
or O
neurological O
illness O
. O

Other O
exclusion O
criteria O
included O
dependence O
on O
another O
psychoactive O
substance O
( O
except O
nicotine O
) O
and O
current O
or O
past O
history O
of O
psychotic O
disorders O
. O

Individuals O
with O
current O
depressive O
or O
anxiety O
symptoms O
requiring O
treatment O
or O
currently O
being O
treated O
for O
these O
symptoms O
were O
excluded O
as O
well O
. O

The O
Human O
Investigation O
committee O
at O
Yale O
University O
School O
of O
Medicine O
approved O
all O
study O
procedures O
, O
and O
all O
subjects O
signed O
an O
informed O
consent O
prior O
to O
study O
participation O
. O

CD O
’ O
s O
were O
assessed O
with O
the O
Beck O
Depression O
Inventory O
and O
the O
State-Trait O
Anxiety O
Inventory O
at O
admission O
. O

The O
mean O
( O
± O
SD O
) O
BDI O
( O
9.5 O
± O
8.1 O
) O
and O
STAI O
state O
( O
33.8 O
± O
11.0 O
) O
and O
trait O
( O
38.3 O
± O
9.8 O
) O
scores O
were O
within O
the O
range O
reported O
previously O
for O
individuals O
with O
cocaine O
dependence O
. O

Cocaine O
craving O
was O
assessed O
with O
the O
cocaine O
craving O
questionnaire O
, O
brief O
version O
( O
CCQ-Brief O
) O
, O
for O
all O
participants O
every O
two O
to O
three O
days O
. O

The O
CCQ-Brief O
is O
a O
10-item O
questionnaire O
, O
abbreviated O
from O
the O
CCQ-Now O
. O

It O
is O
highly O
correlated O
with O
the O
CCQ-Now O
and O
other O
cocaine O
craving O
measures O
. O

Each O
item O
was O
rated O
on O
a O
scale O
from O
1 O
to O
7 O
, O
with O
a O
higher O
total O
score O
( O
ranging O
from O
10 O
to O
70 O
) O
indicating O
greater O
craving O
. O

CD O
showed O
a O
CCQ O
score O
of O
23.8 O
± O
10.4 O
across O
all O
assessments O
. O

Imaging O
protocol O
Conventional O
T1-weighted O
spin O
echo O
sagittal O
anatomical O
images O
were O
acquired O
for O
slice O
localization O
using O
a O
3 O
T O
scanner O
( O
Siemens O
Trio O
) O
. O

Anatomical O
images O
of O
the O
functional O
slice O
locations O
were O
next O
obtained O
with O
spin O
echo O
imaging O
in O
the O
axial O
plane O
parallel O
to O
the O
AC–PC O
line O
with O
TR O
= O
300 O
ms O
, O
TE O
= O
2.5 O
ms O
, O
bandwidth O
= O
300 O
Hz/pixel O
, O
flip O
angle O
= O
60° O
, O
field O
of O
view O
= O
220 O
× O
220 O
mm O
, O
matrix O
= O
256 O
× O
256 O
, O
32 O
slices O
with O
slice O
thickness O
= O
4 O
mm O
and O
no O
gap O
. O

Functional O
, O
blood O
oxygenation O
level-dependent O
( O
BOLD O
) O
signals O
were O
then O
acquired O
with O
a O
single-shot O
gradient O
echo O
echoplanar O
imaging O
( O
EPI O
) O
sequence O
during O
a O
resting O
state O
( O
one O
scan O
per O
participant O
; O
duration O
: O
10 O
minutes O
; O
eyes O
closed O
) O
. O

Thirty-two O
axial O
slices O
parallel O
to O
the O
AC–PC O
line O
covering O
the O
whole O
brain O
were O
acquired O
with O
TR O
= O
2000 O
ms O
, O
TE O
= O
25 O
ms O
, O
bandwidth O
= O
2004 O
Hz/pixel O
, O
flip O
angle O
= O
85° O
, O
field O
of O
view O
= O
220 O
× O
220 O
mm O
, O
matrix O
= O
64 O
× O
64 O
, O
32 O
slices O
with O
slice O
thickness O
= O
4 O
mm O
and O
no O
gap O
. O

Imaging O
data O
preprocessing O
Figure O
1a O
illustrates O
the O
step O
by O
step O
procedures O
in O
data O
analysis O
. O

The O
data O
were O
processed O
with O
Statistical O
Parametric O
Mapping O
( O
SPM8 O
, O
Wellcome O
Department O
of O
Imaging O
Neuroscience O
, O
University O
College O
London O
, O
U.K. O
) O
. O

Images O
from O
the O
first O
five O
TRs O
at O
the O
beginning O
of O
each O
session O
were O
discarded O
. O

Images O
of O
each O
individual O
subject O
were O
first O
realigned O
( O
motion O
corrected O
) O
and O
corrected O
for O
slice O
timing O
. O

A O
mean O
functional O
image O
volume O
was O
constructed O
from O
the O
realigned O
image O
volumes O
. O

These O
mean O
images O
were O
co-registered O
with O
the O
high-resolution O
structural O
image O
and O
segmented O
for O
normalization O
with O
affine O
registration O
followed O
by O
nonlinear O
transformation O
. O

The O
normalization O
parameters O
determined O
for O
the O
structure O
volume O
were O
then O
applied O
to O
the O
corresponding O
functional O
image O
volumes O
for O
each O
subject O
. O

Finally O
, O
the O
images O
were O
smoothed O
with O
a O
Gaussian O
kernel O
of O
4 O
mm O
at O
Full O
Width O
at O
Half O
Maximum O
. O

Additional O
preprocessing O
was O
applied O
to O
reduce O
spurious O
BOLD O
variances O
that O
were O
unlikely O
to O
reflect O
neuronal O
activity O
. O

The O
sources O
of O
spurious O
variance O
were O
removed O
through O
linear O
regression O
by O
including O
the O
signal O
from O
the O
ventricular O
system O
, O
white O
matter O
, O
and O
whole O
brain O
, O
in O
addition O
to O
the O
six O
parameters O
obtained O
by O
rigid O
body O
head O
motion O
correction O
. O

First-order O
derivatives O
of O
the O
whole O
brain O
, O
ventricular O
and O
white O
matter O
signals O
were O
also O
included O
in O
the O
regression O
. O

Cordes O
and O
colleagues O
suggested O
that O
BOLD O
fluctuations O
below O
a O
frequency O
of O
0.1 O
Hz O
contribute O
to O
regionally O
specific O
BOLD O
correlations O
. O

Thus O
, O
we O
applied O
a O
temporal O
band-pass O
filter O
( O
0.009 O
Hz O
< O
f O
< O
0.08 O
Hz O
) O
to O
the O
time O
course O
in O
order O
to O
obtain O
low-frequency O
fluctuations O
, O
as O
in O
previous O
studies O
. O

Head O
motion O
As O
extensively O
investigated O
in O
previous O
study O
, O
micro O
head O
motion O
( O
> O
0.1 O
mm O
) O
is O
an O
important O
source O
of O
spurious O
correlations O
in O
resting O
state O
functional O
connectivity O
analysis O
. O

Therefore O
, O
we O
applied O
a O
“ O
scrubbing O
” O
method O
proposed O
by O
Power O
and O
colleagues O
and O
successfully O
applied O
in O
previous O
studies O
to O
remove O
time O
points O
affected O
by O
head O
motions O
, O
prior O
to O
temporal O
band-pass O
filtering O
. O

Briefly O
, O
for O
every O
time O
point O
t O
, O
we O
computed O
the O
framewise O
displacement O
given O
by O
, O
where O
( O
dx O
, O
dy O
, O
dz O
) O
and O
( O
α O
, O
β O
, O
γ O
) O
are O
the O
translational O
and O
rotational O
movements O
, O
respectively O
. O

The O
second O
head O
movement O
metric O
was O
the O
root O
mean O
square O
variance O
( O
DVARS O
) O
of O
the O
differences O
in O
% O
BOLD O
intensity O
I O
( O
t O
) O
between O
consecutive O
time O
points O
across O
brain O
voxels O
, O
computed O
as O
: O
, O
where O
the O
brackets O
indicate O
the O
mean O
across O
brain O
voxels O
. O

Finally O
, O
to O
compute O
each O
subject O
’ O
s O
correlation O
map O
, O
we O
removed O
every O
time O
point O
with O
FD O
( O
t O
) O
> O
0.5 O
mm O
or O
DVARS O
( O
t O
) O
> O
0.5 O
% O
. O

On O
average O
, O
1 O
% O
of O
the O
time O
points O
were O
removed O
across O
subjects O
. O

CD O
and O
HC O
did O
not O
differ O
in O
either O
the O
mean O
FD O
( O
p O
= O
0.76 O
) O
or O
DVARS O
( O
p O
= O
0.57 O
) O
. O

Parcelation O
of O
the O
VS O
based O
on O
functional O
connectivity O
differences O
between O
CD O
and O
HC O
As O
with O
our O
previous O
studies O
, O
we O
used O
a O
ventral O
striatum O
( O
VS O
) O
mask O
( O
Fig O
. O

1b O
) O
generated O
by O
cytoarchitectonic O
and O
topographical O
criteria O
. O

We O
employed O
116 O
anatomical O
masks O
from O
the O
Automated O
Anatomical O
Labeling O
or O
AAL O
Atlas O
based O
on O
a O
Montreal O
Neurological O
Institute O
( O
MNI O
) O
template O
. O

We O
averaged O
the O
BOLD O
time O
courses O
of O
voxels O
within O
each O
of O
the O
116 O
regions O
and O
computed O
the O
correlation O
coefficient O
between O
the O
averaged O
time O
course O
of O
each O
AAL O
region O
and O
the O
time O
courses O
of O
each O
individual O
voxel O
of O
the O
VS O
for O
individual O
subjects O
. O

To O
assess O
and O
compare O
the O
resting O
state O
“ O
correlograms O
( O
correlation O
matrices O
) O
, O
” O
we O
converted O
these O
correlation O
matrices O
, O
which O
were O
not O
normally O
distributed O
, O
to O
z O
score O
maps O
by O
Fisher O
’ O
s O
z O
transform O
: O
. O

The O
z O
maps O
were O
used O
in O
group O
, O
random O
effect O
analyses O
. O

A O
two-sample O
t O
test O
was O
first O
applied O
to O
the O
“ O
z O
maps O
” O
to O
compare O
66 O
CD O
with O
66 O
HC O
for O
each O
of O
the O
116 O
correlograms O
. O

Voxels O
within O
the O
VS O
mask O
were O
subject O
to O
rsFC O
based O
segmentation O
, O
with O
each O
voxel O
represented O
by O
116 O
t O
values O
of O
the O
two-sample O
t O
test O
. O

A O
K-means O
algorithm O
was O
applied O
to O
cluster O
the O
voxels O
within O
the O
VS O
on O
the O
bases O
of O
the O
116 O
t O
values O
. O

Placing O
K O
points O
into O
the O
space O
represented O
by O
the O
objects O
that O
are O
being O
clustered O
. O

These O
points O
represent O
initial O
group O
centroids O
. O

Assigning O
each O
object O
to O
the O
group O
that O
has O
the O
closest O
centroid O
. O

Recalculating O
the O
positions O
of O
the O
K O
centroids O
, O
when O
all O
objects O
have O
been O
assigned O
. O

Repeating O
Steps O
2 O
and O
3 O
until O
the O
centroids O
no O
longer O
move O
. O

This O
produces O
a O
separation O
of O
the O
objects O
into O
groups O
from O
which O
the O
metric O
to O
be O
minimized O
can O
be O
calculated O
. O

As O
an O
unsupervised O
learning O
algorithm O
, O
K-means O
clustering O
classifies O
a O
given O
data O
set O
into O
an O
a-priori O
set O
of O
K O
clusters O
by O
minimizing O
an O
objective O
squared O
error O
function O
as O
shown O
in O
Eq O
. O

( O
1 O
) O
: O
.where O
is O
a O
distance O
measure O
between O
a O
data O
point O
and O
the O
cluster O
center O
. O

The O
algorithm O
was O
executed O
by O
: O
In O
order O
to O
determine O
the O
optimal O
number O
of O
clusters O
that O
best O
described O
the O
data O
set O
, O
we O
used O
the O
Bayesian O
Information O
Criterion O
( O
BIC O
) O
, O
which O
is O
widely O
used O
for O
model O
identification O
in O
time O
series O
and O
linear O
regression O
: O
where O
n O
is O
the O
number O
of O
observations O
( O
=116 O
) O
; O
k O
is O
the O
number O
of O
class O
; O
RSS O
is O
the O
residual O
sum O
of O
squares O
from O
the O
K-means O
model O
. O

Given O
any O
two O
clustering O
number O
k O
’ O
s O
, O
the O
one O
with O
lower O
BIC O
value O
was O
preferred O
. O

Furthermore O
, O
because O
the O
K-means O
algorithm O
is O
sensitive O
to O
the O
initial O
, O
randomly O
selected O
cluster O
centers O
, O
we O
repeated O
this O
algorithm O
1,000 O
times O
to O
alleviate O
the O
effect O
of O
the O
initial O
conditions O
. O

K O
was O
tested O
for O
values O
from O
2 O
to O
20 O
. O

For O
VS O
subregions O
as O
well O
as O
the O
whole O
VS O
, O
we O
computed O
the O
whole-brain O
connectivity O
maps O
each O
for O
CD O
and O
HC O
, O
and O
converted O
to O
z O
score O
maps O
. O

In O
second O
level O
analysis O
, O
we O
performed O
one-sample O
t O
test O
each O
on O
the O
Z O
maps O
of O
those O
seeds O
for O
CD O
and O
HC O
groups O
and O
two-sample O
t O
test O
with O
age O
as O
covariate O
comparing O
the O
two O
groups O
. O

In O
addition O
, O
the O
VS O
and O
hypothalamus O
are O
reciprocally O
connected O
. O

Both O
the O
VS O
and O
hypothalamus O
receive O
projections O
from O
the O
dopaminergic O
midbrain O
and O
are O
implicated O
in O
processing O
of O
reward-related O
stimuli O
, O
including O
those O
associated O
with O
drugs O
of O
abuse O
. O

Examining O
the O
VS O
hypothalamus O
connectivity O
may O
provide O
useful O
information O
as O
to O
how O
this O
understudied O
circuit O
is O
impacted O
by O
cocaine O
addiction O
. O

Thus O
, O
we O
also O
conducted O
a O
region O
of O
interest O
analysis O
, O
using O
small O
volume O
correction O
for O
a O
hypothalamus O
mask O
. O

Temptations O
of O
friends O
: O
adolescents O
’ O
neural O
and O
behavioral O
responses O
to O
best O
friends O
predict O
risky O
behavior O
Abstract O
Adolescents O
are O
notorious O
for O
engaging O
in O
risky O
, O
reward-motivated O
behavior O
, O
and O
this O
behavior O
occurs O
most O
often O
in O
response O
to O
social O
reward O
, O
typically O
in O
the O
form O
of O
peer O
contexts O
involving O
intense O
positive O
affect O
. O

A O
combination O
of O
greater O
neural O
and O
behavioral O
sensitivity O
to O
peer O
positive O
affect O
may O
characterize O
adolescents O
who O
are O
especially O
likely O
to O
engage O
in O
risky O
behaviors O
. O

To O
test O
this O
hypothesis O
, O
we O
examined O
50 O
adolescents O
’ O
reciprocal O
positive O
affect O
and O
neural O
response O
to O
a O
personally O
relevant O
, O
ecologically O
valid O
pleasant O
stimulus O
: O
positive O
affect O
expressed O
by O
their O
best O
friend O
during O
a O
conversation O
about O
past O
and O
future O
rewarding O
mutual O
experiences O
. O

Participants O
were O
typically O
developing O
community O
adolescents O
( O
age O
14–18 O
years O
, O
48.6 O
% O
female O
) O
, O
and O
risky O
behavior O
was O
defined O
as O
a O
factor O
including O
domains O
such O
as O
substance O
use O
, O
sexual O
behavior O
and O
suicidality O
. O

Adolescents O
who O
engaged O
in O
more O
real-life O
risk-taking O
behavior O
exhibited O
either O
a O
combination O
of O
high O
reciprocal O
positive O
affect O
behavior O
and O
high O
response O
in O
the O
left O
ventrolateral O
prefrontal O
cortex—a O
region O
associated O
with O
impulsive O
sensation-seeking—or O
the O
opposite O
combination O
. O

Behavioral O
and O
neural O
sensitivity O
to O
peer O
influence O
could O
combine O
to O
contribute O
to O
pathways O
from O
peer O
influence O
to O
risky O
behavior O
, O
with O
implications O
for O
healthy O
development O
. O

Materials O
and O
methods O
Participants O
and O
protocol O
Participants O
were O
50 O
typically O
developing O
community O
adolescents O
with O
no O
history O
of O
psychiatric O
disorder O
or O
serious O
health O
problems O
. O

Participants O
were O
ages O
14–18 O
( O
M O
= O
16.22 O
, O
s.d O
. O

= O
1.4 O
) O
, O
48.6 O
% O
female O
, O
and O
68 O
% O
European O
American O
, O
27 O
% O
African O
American O
and O
5 O
% O
mixed O
race O
. O

Of O
the O
original O
70 O
participants O
in O
the O
study O
, O
7 O
did O
not O
complete O
the O
fMRI O
scan O
, O
due O
to O
ineligibility O
( O
recent O

, O
n O
= O

; O
claustrophobia O
, O

= O
2 O
; O
mental O
health O
history O
, O
n O
= O
2 O
) O
, O
3 O
were O
unable O
to O
be O
contacted O
after O
the O
initial O
visit O
and O
2 O
refused O
the O
scan O
. O

Of O
the O

who O
completed O
the O
entire O
assessment O
, O

did O
not O
complete O
the O
fMRI O
task O
because O
of O
technical O
problems O
, O
1 O
had O

of O
the O

( O
≤80 O
% O
) O

had O

( O
> O

of O

over O

in O
any O

and O
3 O
had O
missing O
behavior O
data O
because O
of O
coding O
error O
. O

All O
50 O
participants O
had O
adequate O
coverage O
in O
ventral O
brain O
areas O
and O
< O
2 O
mm O
movement O
in O
any O
direction O
. O

All O
participants O
identified O
a O
same-gender O
best O
friend O
who O
attended O
the O
lab O
visit O
to O
complete O
the O
peer O
interaction O
task O
( O
M O
= O
15.82 O
years O
, O
s.d O
. O

= O
1.2 O
; O
race O
: O
38 O
% O
African O
American O
, O
62 O
% O
European O
American O
; O
demographic O
data O
on O

were O
missing O
for O

participants O
) O
. O

Participants O
completed O
a O
lab O
visit O
with O
self-report O
measures O
and O
an O
MRI O
scan O
. O

Most O
participants O
( O
57 O
% O
) O
were O
scanned O
within O
1 O
month O
of O
their O
lab O
visit O
( O
median O
= O
27.5 O
days O
, O
s.d O
. O

= O
54.8 O
) O
. O

The O
University O
of O
Pittsburgh O
Institutional O
Review O
Board O
approved O
all O
research O
procedures O
, O
and O
written O
informed O
consent O
was O
obtained O
from O
each O
participant O
and O
a O
parent/guardian O
. O

Risky O
behavior O
Participants O
completed O
the O
standard O
high O
school O
version O
of O
the O
Youth O
Risk O
Behavior O
Survey O
[ O
YRBS O
; O
Center O
for O
Disease O
Control O
and O
Prevention O
( O
CDC O
) O
, O
] O
, O
an O
89-item O
self-report O
instrument O
developed O
for O
epidemiologic O
research O
on O
high O
school O
students O
’ O
engagement O
in O
6 O
domains O
of O
health-risk O
behaviors O
. O

These O
are O
( O
i O
) O
behaviors O
contributing O
to O
injury O
and O
violence O
, O
( O
ii O
) O
sexual O
behaviors O
related O
to O
negative O
outcomes O
, O
( O
iii O
) O
alcohol O
and O
drug O
use O
, O
( O
iv O
) O
tobacco O
use O
, O
( O
v O
) O
unhealthy O
dietary O
behaviors O
, O
and O
( O
vi O
) O
inadequate O
physical O
activity O
. O

These O
behaviors O
are O
considered O
risky O
based O
on O
their O
potential O
to O
compromise O
physical O
health O
( O
e.g O
. O

obtaining O
sexually O
transmitted O
infections O
from O
intercourse O
without O
condom O
use O
) O
or O
mental O
health O
( O
e.g O
. O

developing O
addiction O
from O
frequent O
use O
of O
illicit O
drugs O
) O
. O

Thus O
, O
the O
YRBS O
does O
not O
include O
reward-seeking O
behaviors O
that O
are O
adaptive O
or O
that O
have O
only O
minor O
direct O
consequences O
for O
health O
and O
wellbeing O
( O
e.g O
. O

initiating O
a O
new O
romantic O
relationship O
, O
raising O
one O
’ O
s O
hand O
in O
class O
) O
. O

Scores O
for O
risky O
behavior O
were O
computed O
based O
on O
a O
single O
factor O
created O
by O
from O
10 O
YRBS O
items O
selected O
to O
represent O
a O
broad O
range O
of O
risky O
behaviors O
, O
including O
substance O
use O
, O
seat O
belt O
use O
, O
sexual O
behavior O
and O
suicidality O
. O

Items O
in O
the O
factor O
include O
daily O
cigarette O
smoking O
, O
seat O
belt O
use O
while O
riding O
in O
a O
car O
, O
number O
of O
lifetime O
sexual O
partners O
, O
and O
having O
gotten O
into O
a O
physical O
fight O
( O
see O
Supplementary O
Table O
S1 O
for O
all O
items O
) O
. O

The O
factor O
was O
tested O
with O
confirmatory O
factor O
analysis O
in O
a O
sample O
of O
174 O
community O
adolescents O
and O
then O
replicated O
in O
a O
sample O
of O
4135 O
16-year-old O
adolescents O
from O
the O
2009 O
CDC O
Youth O
Risk O
Behavior O
Surveillance O
Survey O
, O
with O
good O
fit O
and O
a O
unidimensional O
factor O
structure O
in O
both O
samples O
( O
see O
for O
factor O
loadings O
in O
both O
samples O
) O
. O

All O
10 O
items O
in O
the O
factor O
were O
included O
in O
this O
study O
, O
as O
in O
previous O
work O
. O

Raw O
scores O
were O
used O
in O
analyses O
, O
as O
they O
were O
highly O
correlated O
with O
scores O
adjusted O
for O
factor O
loadings O
. O

Risky O
behavior O
scores O
were O
normally O
distributed O
, O
with O
higher O
scores O
indicating O
higher O
levels O
of O
general O
risky O
( O
M O
= O
15.51 O
, O
s.d O
. O

=5.57 O
, O
range O
= O
8-27 O
) O
. O

Reciprocal O
positive O
affect O
behavior O
Each O
adolescent O
( O
target O
) O
and O
her O
or O
his O
best O
friend O
were O
video O
recorded O
as O
they O
engaged O
in O
a O
10-min O
conversation O
, O
with O
5 O
min O
devoted O
to O
‘ O
the O
most O
fun O
you O
’ O
ve O
ever O
had O
together O
’ O
and O
5 O
min O
devoted O
to O
‘ O
a O
fun O
or O
exciting O
event O
you O
’ O
d O
like O
to O
plan O
together. O
’ O
Topics O
were O
chosen O
based O
on O
participants O
’ O
responses O
to O
a O
list O
of O
pleasant O
events O
, O
with O
examples O
including O
high O
school O
graduation O
, O
visiting O
a O
local O
amusement O
park O
, O
soccer O
camp O
and O
weekend O
parties O
with O
alcohol O
and O
drug O
use O
. O

Similar O
tasks O
have O
been O
used O
successfully O
in O
families O
of O
healthy O
and O
depressed O
adolescents O
. O

Affective O
behavior O
from O
the O
conversation O
was O
coded O
from O
video O
for O
two O
purposes O
, O
in O
two O
ways O
, O
by O
separate O
coding O
teams O
: O
( O
i O
) O
using O
the O
LIFE O
coding O
system O
to O
obtain O
detailed O
measurement O
of O
reciprocal O
positive O
affect O
, O
which O
was O
the O
main O
regressor O
in O
our O
models O
; O
and O
( O
ii O
) O
using O
ratings O
of O
participant O
and O
friend O
positive O
and O
neutral O
affect O
to O
select O
segments O
to O
create O
stimuli O
in O
the O
fMRI O
task O
( O
see O
below O
) O
. O

For O
LIFE O
coding O
to O
obtain O
reciprocal O
positive O
affect O
, O
trained O
observers O
blind O
to O
hypotheses O
coded O
adolescents O
’ O
affect O
expression O
and O
verbal O
content O
from O
video O
in O
real O
time O
. O

Four O
constructs—aggressive O
, O
positive O
, O
dysphoric O
and O
other—were O
derived O
from O
the O
individual O
codes O
. O

These O
constructs O
are O
based O
on O
the O
theoretical O
rationale O
of O
the O
LIFE O
system O
, O
which O
was O
developed O
to O
examine O
the O
function O
of O
emotions O
in O
social O
contexts O
. O

The O
positive O
affect O
construct O
, O
which O
was O
the O
focus O
of O
our O
analyses O
, O
captures O
happy O
, O
caring O
and O
facilitative O
behavior O
codes O
. O

Reciprocal O
positive O
affect—to O
examine O
the O
tendency O
to O
respond O
to O
a O
close O
friend O
’ O
s O
positive O
affect O
in O
kind O
, O
rather O
than O
a O
general O
tendency O
toward O
positive O
affective O
behavior—was O
then O
computed O
from O
the O
positive O
affect O
construct O
of O
LIFE O
codes O
. O

This O
variable O
was O
computed O
using O
the O
Generalized O
Sequential O
Querier O
Program O
. O

Conditional O
lagged O
probabilities O
for O
positive O
affect O
were O
computed O
for O
participants O
’ O
behavior O
given O
friends O
’ O
behavior O
, O
by O
considering O
participants O
’ O
behaviors O
occurring O
from O
1 O
s O
after O
the O
onset O
until O
1 O
s O
after O
the O
offset O
of O
each O
observation O
of O
friends O
’ O
positive O
affect O
( O
i.e O
. O

instances O
in O
which O
the O
target O
participant O
expressed O
positive O
affect O
during O
or O
after O
the O
best O
friend O
’ O
s O
expression O
of O
positive O
affect O
) O
. O

This O
resulted O
in O
a O
2×2 O
contingency O
table O
for O
each O
dyad O
, O
reflecting O
the O
probability O
of O
the O
consequent O
( O
participant O
positive O
affect O
) O
given O
the O
antecedent O
( O
friend O
positive O
affect O
) O
, O
as O
compared O
to O
the O
probability O
of O
the O
consequent O
given O
all O
other O
peer O
behavior O
antecedents O
and O
the O
probability O
of O
all O
other O
participant O
affective O
behaviors O
given O
friend O
positive O
affect O
. O

From O
these O
tabled O
values O
of O
joint O
probability O
, O
adjusted O
residuals O
were O
computed O
for O
analyses O
. O

These O
values O
reflected O
associations O
greater O
than O
expected O
by O
chance O
( O
i.e O
. O

positive O
values O
) O
or O
lower O
than O
expected O
by O
chance O
( O
i.e O
. O

negative O
values O
) O
( O
M O
= O
13.70 O
, O
s.d O
. O

= O
8.06 O
, O
range O
= O
−2.95 O
to O
33 O
) O
and O
were O
distributed O
approximately O
normally O
, O
with O
a O
mean O
of O
0 O
and O
a O
variance O
equal O
to O
1 O
. O

We O
note O
that O
reciprocal O
positive O
affect O
is O
intended O
to O
capture O
a O
behavioral O
tendency O
during O
the O
entire O
interaction O
and O
is O
not O
meaningful O
across O
smaller O
time O
segments O
. O

Neural O
response O
to O
friend O
positive O
affect O
Best O
Friend O
fMRI O
task O
This O
novel O
task O
, O
personalized O
for O
each O
participant O
, O
contained O
six O
video O
clips O
of O
the O
participant O
’ O
s O
best O
friend O
and O
six O
video O
clips O
of O
an O
unfamiliar O
, O
same-gender O
, O
control O
adolescent O
presented O
in O
a O
block O
design O
with O
10-s O
fixation O
displays O
between O
blocks O
. O

Blocks O
were O
presented O
in O
a O
predetermined O
, O
pseudorandom O
order O
so O
that O
positive O
and O
neutral O
affect O
blocks O
alternated O
and O
clips O
with O
the O
friend O
or O
unfamiliar O
peer O
alternated O
( O
Figure O
1 O
) O
. O

During O
the O
task O
, O
participants O
were O
instructed O
to O
attend O
to O
each O
video O
and O
to O
press O
a O
button O
at O
the O
onset O
of O
each O
, O
to O
ensure O
that O
they O
were O
awake O
and O
engaged O
. O

Affective O
behavior O
from O
the O
conversation O
was O
coded O
from O
video O
to O
create O
task O
stimuli O
. O

Lab O
conversation O
videos O
were O
coded O

by O
a O
team O
of O
trained O
observers O
using O
an O
adaptation O
of O
the O
AFFEX O
coding O
system O
. O

This O
was O
conducted O
separately O
from O
the O
coding O
to O
compute O
reciprocal O
positive O
affect O
behavior O
. O

Specifically O
, O
videos O
were O
coded O
for O
friends O
’ O
positive O
and O
neutral O
affect O
during O
the O
lab O
conversation O
( O
i.e O
. O

not O
target O
participants O
’ O
affect O
or O
dyadic O
affect O
) O
, O
and O
coding O
data O
were O
used O
to O
determine O
each O
participant O
’ O

stimulus O
segments O
for O
the O
friend O
positive O
and O
friend O

conditions O
of O
the O
fMRI O
task O
. O

Positive O
affect O
was O
coded O
with O
a O
score O
of O
0–2 O
for O
its O
presence O
and O
intensity O
and O
neutral O
affect O
was O
coded O
with O
a O
score O
of O
0 O
or O
1 O
for O
its O
presence O
only O
. O

Approximately O
25 O
% O
of O
the O
videotapes O
were O
additionally O
coded O
by O
an O
extensively O
trained O
master O
coder O
for O
reliability O
( O
mean O
ICC O
for O
PA O
= O
0.93 O
, O
range O
= O
0.86–0.96 O
; O
mean O
ICC O
for O
neutral O
affect O
= O
0.92 O
; O
range O
= O
0.89–0.94 O
) O
. O

The O
master O
coder O
selected O
20-s O
segments O
based O
on O
predominance O
of O
positive O
or O
neutral O
affect O
. O

As O
intended O
, O
the O
best-friend O
positive O
affect O
stimuli O
included O
higher O
levels O
of O

affect O
than O

[ O
( O

; O
s.d O
. O

= O

) O
and O
( O

= O
0.08 O
; O

) O
; O
t O
( O

) O
= O
−40.24 O
, O
P O
= O

] O
, O

of O

than O

[ O
( O

) O

; O

. O

) O

Stimuli O
included O
the O
head O
and O

of O
the O

friend O
( O
i.e O
. O

not O
a O

of O

) O
and O

of O
both O
adolescents O
. O

We O
made O
efforts O
to O
ensure O
that O
video O
clips O
were O
equivalent O
in O

, O
camera O
angle O
, O

and O

of O
affect O
. O

Stimuli O
included O
segments O
drawn O
from O
both O
past- O
and O

of O
the O
lab O
conversation O
, O

to O
be O
from O

( O

) O
and O

to O

from O

( O

) O
. O

Similar O
to O
methods O
used O
in O
and O
, O
and O
to O
avoid O

’ O

with O

, O

for O

and O

were O

from O
video O
segments O
of O

of O

from O

, O

. O

These O
adolescents O
’ O
training O
allowed O
them O
to O
convincingly O
portray O
a O
conversation O
with O
a O
close O
friend O
. O

Control O
stimuli O
were O
selected O
using O
the O

procedures O
used O
for O
the O
best-friend O
stimuli O
. O

As O

for O

than O

[ O
( O
M O
= O
1.71 O
; O

. O

; O
s.d O
. O

= O

) O
, O
respectively O
; O

( O

) O

−13.19 O
, O

] O
, O

[ O
( O

; O

) O
, O

Control O
stimuli O
were O
presented O
to O
each O
participant O
to O
match O
the O
participant O
’ O
s O
gender O
and O
approximate O
age O
. O

Because O
our O
focus O
was O
positive O
affect O
within O
a O
familiar O
peer O
context O
( O
e.g O
. O

rather O
than O
positive O
affect O
from O
a O
familiar O
vs O
unfamiliar O
