) O
, O
the O
contrast O
generated O
for O
analyses O
was O
friend O
positive O
affect O
> O
friend O
neutral O
affect O
. O

This O
contrast O
allowed O
assessment O
of O
neural O
response O
to O
a O
type O
of O
social O
reward O
that O
is O
relevant O
to O
adolescents O
’ O
risky O
behavior O
. O

The O
contrast O
was O
defined O
across O
all O
three O
20-s O
blocks O
of O
friend O
positive O
affect O
stimuli O
and O
all O
three O
20-s O
blocks O
of O
friend O
neutral O
affect O
stimuli O
. O

The O
onset O
and O
duration O
of O
each O
condition O
was O
based O
on O
all O
20-s O
segments O
of O
best O
friends O
’ O
behavior O
selected O
for O
inclusion O
as O
stimuli O
based O
on O
AFFEX O
coding O
. O

Thus O
, O
the O
two O
conditions O
had O
an O
identical O
duration O
of O
data O
analyzed O
. O

fMRI O
acquisition O
and O
preprocessing O
Each O
participant O
was O
scanned O
using O
a O
Siemens O
3-T O
TIM O
Trio O
scanner O
. O

Structural O
images O
were O
acquired O
using O
MPRAGE O
160 O
axial O
slices O
, O
1.2-mm O
thick O
( O
TR/TE O
= O
2300/2.98 O
ms O
, O
FOV O
= O
256×240 O
cm2 O
, O
matrix O
= O
256 O
× O
240 O
, O
flip O
angle O
= O
9° O
) O
. O

BOLD O
functional O
images O
for O
the O
friend O
task O
were O
acquired O
in O
a O
single O
run O
, O
with O
a O
gradient O
echo O
planar O
imaging O
sequence O
and O
covered O
39 O
axial O
slices O
, O
3.1-mm O
thick O
, O
beginning O
at O
the O
cerebral O
vertex O
and O
encompassing O
the O
entire O
cerebrum O
( O
TR/TE O
= O
2000/28 O
ms O
, O
FOV= O
20×20 O
cm2 O
, O
matrix O
= O
64 O
× O
64 O
, O
flip O
angle O
= O
90° O
) O
. O

Preprocessing O
and O
analysis O
of O
fMRI O
data O
were O
completed O
using O
SPM8 O
( O
http O
: O
//www.fil.ion.ucl.ac.uk/spm O
) O
. O

Structural O
images O
for O
each O
participant O
were O
segmented O
to O
focus O
on O
gray O
matter O
. O

For O
each O
functional O
scan O
, O
data O
were O
realigned O
to O
correct O
for O
head O
motion O
. O

Volumes O
with O
excess O
motion O
( O
> O
3 O
s.d O
. O

from O
the O
subject O
’ O
s O
mean O
, O
> O
0.5 O
mm O
scan-to-scan O
translation O
, O
or O
> O
0.01 O
degrees O
of O
scan-to-scan O
rotation O
) O
were O
identified O
using O
Artifact O
Detection O
Toolbox O
( O
ART O
; O
http O
: O
//www.nitrc.org/projects/artifact_detect/ O
) O
software O
. O

Preprocessed O
data O
were O
inspected O
prior O
to O
first-level O
analysis O
to O
ensure O
that O
all O
participants O
had O
fewer O
than O
25 O
% O
of O
volumes O
with O
excessive O
movement O
detected O
by O
ART O
. O

Images O
were O
then O
spatially O
normalized O
into O
standard O
stereotactic O
space O
( O
Montreal O
Neurological O
Institute O
template O
) O
using O
a O
12-parameter O
affine O
model O
and O
smoothed O
with O
a O
6 O
mm O
full-width O
at O
half-maximum O
Gaussian O
filter O
. O

Voxel-wise O
signal O
intensities O
were O
ratio O
normalized O
to O
the O
whole-brain O
global O
mean O
. O

Voxels O
were O
resampled O
during O
preprocessing O
to O
2 O
mm3 O
. O

Data O
analyses O
First-level O
tests O
for O
effect O
of O
task O
within O
each O
participant O
were O
calculated O
at O
each O
voxel O
using O
paired O
t-tests O
for O
friend O
positive O
affect O
> O
friend O
neutral O
affect O
. O

In O
addition O
, O
exploratory O
analyses O
to O
address O
the O
specificity O
of O
effects O
examined O
the O
contrasts O
unfamiliar-peer O
positive O
affect O
> O
unfamiliar-peer O
neutral O
affect O
and O
( O
friend O
positive O
affect O
> O
friend O
neutral O
affect O
) O
> O
( O
unfamiliar-peer O
positive O
affect O
> O
unfamiliar-peer O
neutral O
affect O
) O
( O
see O
below O
) O
. O

Second-level O
analysis O
was O
conducted O
using O
a O
within-sample O
t-test O
masked O
for O
regions O
that O
respond O
to O
fMRI O
paradigms O
focusing O
on O
social O
stimuli O
. O

The O
mask O
was O
obtained O
from O
the O
Neurosynth O
platform O
( O
neurosynth.org O
) O
, O
which O
provides O
meta-analytic O
findings O
across O
fMRI O
studies O
measuring O
specific O
constructs O
. O

Given O
our O
focus O
on O
social O
reward O
, O
we O
selected O
the O
search O
term O
social O
, O
which O
, O
at O
the O
time O
of O
analysis O
, O
yielded O
a O
map O
of O
results O
from O
exactly O
1000 O
studies O
of O
social O
stimuli O
. O

The O
map O
included O
the O
following O
regions O
: O
dorsomedial O
, O
ventromedial O
and O
ventrolateral O
PFC O
; O
precuneus O
; O
temporoparietal O
junction O
( O
including O
right O
superior O
temporal O
gyrus O
) O
; O
temporal O
pole O
; O
amygdala O
; O
and O
ventral O
striatum O
( O
Supplementary O
Figure O
S1 O
) O
. O

Type O
I O
error O
for O
the O
within-sample O
t O
test O
was O
controlled O
by O
applying O
a O
voxel-wise O
height O
threshold O
of O
P O
< O
0.0001 O
and O
family-wise O
error O
correction O
at O
cluster O
level O
of O
P O
< O
0.05 O
, O
which O
is O
consistent O
with O
current O
recommendations O
for O
rigorous O
adjustment O
for O
multiple O
comparisons O
in O
fMRI O
research O
. O

Mean O
BOLD O
response O
for O
a O
sphere O
of O
2 O
mm O
around O
the O
peak O
voxel O
of O
each O
cluster O
resulting O
from O
the O
second-level O
analysis O
above O
was O
then O
extracted O
for O
moderation O
analyses O
. O

One O
moderation O
model O
was O
computed O
for O
each O
cluster O
. O

Additional O
analyses O
were O
performed O
extracting O
( O
i O
) O
the O
BOLD O
response O
within O
each O
of O
the O
significant O
clusters O
and O
( O
ii O
) O
the O
BOLD O
response O
within O
a O
priori O
anatomical O
masks O
of O
social O
reward O
regions O
significantly O
activated O
by O
the O
task O
using O
a O
small O
volume O
correction O
. O

Age O
and O
gender O
were O
included O
as O
covariates O
in O
t-tests O
to O
adjust O
for O
their O
potential O
role O
, O
even O
though O
participants O
’ O
risky O
behavior O
, O
affective O
behavior O
, O
and O
neural O
response O
to O
reward O
did O
not O
vary O
with O
gender O
, O
race O
or O
age O
( O
all O
Ps O
> O
0.07 O
) O
. O

Moderation O
analyses O
tested O
the O
hypothesis O
that O
behavioral×neural O
response O
to O
peer O
social O
reward O
predicts O
risky O
behavior O
. O

Analyses O
were O
conducted O
using O
the O
PROCESS O
macro O
for O
SPSS O
. O

In O
these O
analyses O
, O
which O
do O
not O
require O
significant O
association O
between O
independent O
variable O
and O
dependent O
variable O
to O
test O
moderation O
, O
reciprocal O
positive O
affect O
was O
entered O
as O
the O
independent O
variable O
, O
extracted O
BOLD O
variable O
for O
each O
region O
was O
entered O
as O
the O
moderating O
variable O
, O
and O
risky O
behavior O
was O
entered O
as O
the O
dependent O
variable O
. O

Type O
I O
error O
in O
moderation O
models O
was O
controlled O
using O
the O
sliding O
linear O
model O
( O
SLIM O
) O
, O
a O
method O
designed O
for O
data O
sets O
with O
dependence O
structure O
, O
as O
is O
the O
case O
for O
fMRI O
variables O
extracted O
from O
second-level O
model O
described O
above O
. O

Age O
and O
gender O
were O
not O
covaried O
in O
moderation O
analyses O
given O
that O
they O
were O
previously O
controlled O
for O
in O
the O
neuroimaging O
analyses O
. O

However O
, O
supplementary O
analyses O
revealed O
that O
the O
addition O
of O
age O
and O
gender O
as O
covariates O
did O
not O
affect O
the O
significance O
of O
the O
results O
. O

Abnormal O
degree O
centrality O
in O
chronic O
users O
of O
codeine-containing O
cough O
syrups O
: O
A O
resting-state O
functional O
magnetic O
resonance O
imaging O
study O
Codeine-containing O
cough O
syrups O
( O
CCS O
) O
have O
become O
one O
of O
the O
most O
popular O
drugs O
of O
abuse O
in O
young O
population O
worldwide O
. O

However O
, O
the O
neurobiological O
mechanisms O
underlying O
CCS-dependence O
are O
yet O
ill-defined O
. O

Therefore O
, O
understanding O
the O
brain O
abnormalities O
in O
chronic O
users O
of O
CCS O
is O
crucial O
for O
developing O
effective O
interventions O
. O

The O
present O
study O
depicted O
the O
intrinsic O
dysconnectivity O
pattern O
of O
whole-brain O
functional O
networks O
at O
the O
voxel O
level O
in O
chronic O
users O
of O
CCS O
. O

In O
addition O
, O
the O
degree O
centrality O
( O
DC O
) O
changes O
were O
correlated O
to O
the O
Barratt O
Impulsiveness O
Scale O
( O
BIS-11 O
) O
total O
score O
, O
dose O
, O
duration O
of O
CCS O
use O
, O
and O
the O
age O
at O
first O
use O
of O
cough O
syrups O
. O

The O
current O
study O
included O
38 O
chronic O
CCS O
users O
and O
34 O
matched O
control O
subjects O
. O

All O
patients O
were O
evaluated O
using O
the O
BIS-11 O
. O

Next O
, O
resting-state O
functional O
magnetic O
resonance O
imaging O
( O
rs-fMRI O
) O
datasets O
were O
acquired O
from O
these O
CCS O
users O
and O
controls O
. O

Whole-brain O
connectivity O
was O
analyzed O
using O
a O
graph O
theory O
approach O
: O
degree O
centrality O
( O
DC O
) O
. O

CCS-dependent O
individuals O
exhibited O
low O
DC O
values O
in O
the O
left O
inferior O
parietal O
lobule O
and O
the O
left O
middle O
temporal O
gyrus O
, O
while O
high O
DC O
values O
were O
noted O
in O
the O
right O
pallidum O
and O
the O
right O
hippocampus O
( O
P O
< O
0.01 O
, O
AlphaSim O
corrected O
) O
. O

Also O
, O
significant O
correlations O
were O
established O
between O
average O
DC O
value O
in O
the O
left O
inferior O
parietal O
lobule O
and O
attentional O
impulsivity O
scores O
and O
the O
age O
at O
first O
CCS O
use O
. O

The O
rs-fMRI O
study O
suggested O
that O
the O
abnormal O
intrinsic O
dysconnectivity O
pattern O
of O
whole-brain O
functional O
networks O
may O
provide O
an O
insight O
into O
the O
neural O
substrates O
of O
abnormalities O
in O
the O
cognitive O
control O
circuit O
, O
the O
reward O
circuit O
, O
and O
the O
learning O
and O
memory O
circuit O
in O
CCS-dependent O
individuals O
. O

Highlights O
The O
abuse O
of O
CCS O
has O
gained O
a O
severe O
foothold O
among O
young O
individuals O
worldwide O
. O

DC O
is O
one O
of O
the O
more O
reliable O
and O
compelling O
measures O
among O
several O
nodal O
network O
metrics O
. O

The O
present O
study O
depicted O
intrinsic O
dysconnectivity O
pattern O
of O
whole-brain O
functional O
networks O
in O
CCS-dependent O
individuals O
. O

CCS-dependent O
individuals O
showed O
altered O
DC O
in O
the O
right O
pallidum O
, O
right O
hippocampus O
, O
left O
IPL O
and O
left O
middle O
temporal O
gyrus O
. O

Significant O
correlations O
were O
established O
between O
average O
DC O
value O
in O
the O
left O
IPL O
and O
attentional O
impulsivity O
scores O
and O
the O
age O
at O
first O
CCS O
use O
. O

Materials O
and O
methods O
Participants O
This O
prospective O
study O
was O
approved O
by O
the O
Ethics O
Committee O
of O
Guangdong O
Second O
Provincial O
General O
Hospital O
. O

Written O
informed O
consent O
was O
obtained O
from O
all O
subjects O
. O

A O
total O
of O
72 O
right-handed O
participants O
, O
including O
34 O
control O
subjects O
and O
38 O
CCS-dependent O
individuals O
, O
were O
enrolled O
in O
this O
study O
. O

The O
CCS-dependent O
individuals O
were O
recruited O
from O
the O
patients O
seeking O
treatment O
at O
the O
Addiction O
Medicine O
Division O
of O
the O
Guangdong O
Second O
Provincial O
General O
Hospital O
. O

All O
the O
patients O
were O
screened O
based O
on O
the O
DSM-IV O
criteria O
from O
medical O
history O
and O
underwent O
a O
urine O
test O
and O
an O
interview O
on O
the O
same O
day O
. O

All O
participants O
regularly O
smoked O
cigarettes O
but O
did O
not O
use O
any O
type O
of O
psychotropic O
agents O
prior O
to O
the O
rs-fMRI O
scan O
. O

The O
exclusion O
criteria O
for O
all O
participants O
included O
central O
nervous O
system O
diseases O
, O
schizophrenia O
, O
bipolar O
disorder O
, O
prior O
significant O
head O
trauma O
, O
positive O
human O
immunodeficiency O
virus O
( O
HIV O
) O
status O
, O
diabetes O
, O
hepatitis O
C O
, O
other O
major O
medical O
illness O
, O
and O
left-handedness O
. O

The O
inclusion O
criteria O
for O
the O
control O
subjects O
was O
the O
absence O
of O
diagnosis O
of O
any O
type O
of O
substance O
abuse O
or O
dependence O
. O

Impulsivity O
assessment O
BIS-11 O
was O
used O
for O
assessing O
the O
impulsivity O
. O

This O
30-item O
self-rated O
scale O
has O
three O
oblique O
factors O
: O
attentional/cognitive O
that O
measures O
the O
toleration O
for O
cognitive O
complexity O
and O
persistence O
; O
motor O
that O
estimates O
the O
tendency O
to O
act O
on O
the O
spur O
of O
the O
moment O
; O
and O
non-planning O
impulsivity O
, O
which O
evaluates O
the O
lack O
of O
sense O
of O
the O
future O
. O

Items O
are O
rated O
from O
1 O
( O
rarely/never O
) O
to O
4 O
( O
almost O
always/always O
) O
. O

To O
determine O
the O
overall O
impulsiveness O
scores O
, O
all O
items O
are O
summed O
; O
high O
scores O
indicate O
remarkable O
impulsivity O
. O

BIS-11 O
is O
a O
valid O
and O
reliable O
instrument O
for O
healthy O
Chinese O
and O
psychiatric O
populations O
. O

Data O
acquisition O
All O
MRI O
datasets O
were O
obtained O
using O
a O
Philips O
Achieva O
1.5 O
T O
Nova O
dual O
MR O
scanner O
at O
the O
Department O
of O
Medical O
Imaging O
, O
Guangdong O
Second O
Provincial O
General O
Hospital O
. O

These O
datasets O
included O
rs-fMRI O
dataset O
and O
T1-weighted O
structural O
images O
. O

The O
rs-fMRI O
dataset O
[ O
22 O
axial O
slices O
, O
repetition O
time O
( O
TR O
) O
/echo O
time O
( O
TE O
) O
= O
2000 O
ms/50 O
ms O
, O
matrix O
= O
64 O
× O
64 O
, O
field O
of O
view O
( O
FOV O
) O
= O
230 O
× O
230 O
mm2 O
, O
slice O
thickness O
= O
4.5 O
mm O
without O
gap O
, O
flip O
angle O
= O
90° O
] O
was O
acquired O
using O
an O
echo O
planar O
imaging O
( O
EPI O
) O
sequence O
. O

Each O
functional O
run O
contained O
240 O
volumes O
( O
8 O
min O
) O
[ O
the O
slices O
were O
approximately O
along O
the O
anterior O
commissure-posterior O
commissure O
( O
AC-PC O
) O
line O
and O
covered O
approximately O
230 O
to O
60 O
in O
the O
inferosuperior O
direction O
] O
, O
and O
the O
subjects O
were O
asked O
to O
lie O
quietly O
with O
their O
eyes O
closed O
and O
avoid O
eye O
movement O
or O
thinking O
of O
anything O
specific O
or O
falling O
asleep O
while O
in O
the O
scanner O
, O
during O
the O
rs-fMRI O
data O
acquisition O
. O

Sagittal O
structural O
images O
( O
160 O
sagittal O
slices O
, O
TR/TE O
= O
25 O
ms/4.1 O
ms O
, O
thickness O
= O
1.0 O
mm O
, O
no O
gap O
, O
in-plane O
resolution O
= O
231 O
× O
232 O
, O
FOV O
= O
230 O
× O
230 O
mm O
, O
flip O
angle O
= O
30° O
) O
were O
acquired O
using O
a O
fast O
field O
echo O
( O
FFE O
) O
three-dimensional O
( O
3D O
) O
T1-weighted O
sequence O
. O

Data O
pre-processing O
and O
DC O
calculation O
Data O
Processing O
Assistant O
for O
Resting-State O
Functional O
MR O
Imaging O
toolbox O
( O
http O
: O
//www.restfmri.net.sci-hub.cc/forum/DPARSF O
, O
) O
was O
used O
for O
the O
post-processing O
of O
the O
imaging O
data O
. O

Before O
pre-processing O
, O
the O
first O
10 O
volumes O
were O
discarded O
for O
each O
subject O
so O
that O
magnetization O
reached O
a O
steady O
state O
and O
subjects O
adapted O
to O
the O
MRI O
scanning O
noise O
. O

Then O
, O
the O
remaining O
230 O
fMRI O
images O
were O
obtained O
with O
slice O
time O
correction O
for O
the O
acquisition O
time O
delay O
and O
realignment O
of O
the O
head O
motion O
correction O
. O

One O
patient O
and O
two O
control O
subjects O
, O
who O
showed O
head O
motion O
> O
1.5 O
mm O
or O
1.5° O
during O
image O
acquisition O
, O
were O
excluded O
in O
subsequent O
analysis O
. O

All O
realigned O
images O
were O
normalized O
to O
the O
standard O
Montreal O
Neurological O
Institute O
( O
MNI O
) O
template O
by O
applying O
the O
echo O
planar O
imaging O
( O
EPI O
) O
template O
at O
a O
3 O
× O
3 O
× O
3 O
mm3 O
resolution O
. O

The O
normalized O
functional O
image O
was O
subjected O
to O
spatial O
smoothing O
[ O
6 O
mm O
half O
high O
full-width O
( O
FWHM O
) O
Gaussian O
kernel O
] O
. O

Finally O
, O
the O
imaging O
data O
were O
processed O
to O
remove O
the O
linear O
trends O
and O
filtered O
using O
typical O
temporal O
bandpass O
( O
0.01–0.08 O
Hz O
) O
to O
reduce O
the O
low-frequency O
drift O
and O
high-frequency O
noise O
. O

For O
calculating O
the O
DC O
, O
we O
performed O
voxel-wise O
voxel-based O
whole-brain O
correlation O
analysis O
on O
the O
pre-processed O
fMRI O
data O
, O
as O
described O
previously O
. O

The O
time O
course O
of O
each O
voxel O
in O
each O
brain O
was O
correlated O
to O
every O
other O
voxel O
time O
course O
in O
the O
GM O
mask O
. O

Thus O
, O
we O
could O
acquire O
a O
n O
× O
n O
matrix O
of O
Pearson O
's O
correlation O
coefficients O
between O
any O
pair O
of O
voxels O
, O
where O
n O
is O
the O
voxel O
number O
of O
the O
GM O
mask O
. O

Next O
, O
we O
transformed O
the O
Pearson O
's O
correlation O
data O
into O
normally O
distributed O
Fisher O
Z-scores O
and O
constructed O
the O
whole-brain O
functional O
network O
by O
thresholding O
each O
correlation O
at O
r O
> O
0.25 O
. O

The O
threshold O
was O
the O
default O
setting O
while O
constructing O
the O
DC O
map O
. O

Only O
positive O
Pearson O
's O
correlation O
coefficients O
were O
considered O
in O
the O
present O
study O
. O

For O
a O
given O
voxel O
, O
the O
DC O
was O
calculated O
as O
the O
sum O
of O
the O
significant O
connections O
at O
the O
individual O
level O
. O

As O
described O
by O
previous O
studies O
, O
DC O
represents O
the O
number O
of O
direct O
connections O
for O
a O
given O
voxel O
in O
the O
voxel-based O
graphs O
. O

It O
has O
been O
widely O
used O
to O
represent O
the O
node O
characteristics O
of O
large-scale O
brain O
intrinsic O
connectivity O
networks O
. O

Statistical O
analysis O
The O
differences O
in O
age O
, O
education O
, O
and O
nicotine O
use O
between O
the O
CCS-dependent O
and O
control O
groups O
were O
assessed O
by O
two-sample O
two-tailed O
t-tests O
using O
SPSS O
statistical O
software O
. O

A O
two-tailed O
Pearson O
's O
chi-square O
test O
was O
performed O
to O
determine O
the O
differences O
in O
the O
gender O
between O
the O
two O
groups O
. O

To O
examine O
the O
between-group O
differences O
in O
the O
DC O
using O
zDC O
maps O
, O
a O
two-sample O
t-test O
was O
performed O
between O
the O
two O
groups O
using O
REST O
. O

A O
correction O
for O
multiple O
comparisons O
was O
performed O
by O
Monte O
Carlo O
simulation O
using O
the O
AlphaSim O
program O
, O
( O
http O
: O
//afni.nimh.nih.gov O
) O
. O

The O
AlphaSim O
program O
was O
implemented O
in O
the O
REST O
software O
by O
combining O
the O
height O
threshold O
of O
P O
< O
0.001 O
and O
an O
extent O
threshold O
of O
P O
< O
0.01 O
, O
which O
corresponded O
to O
a O
corrected O
P O
< O
0.01 O
. O

The O
average O
DC O
values O
of O
all O
voxels O
in O
the O
significantly O
different O
regions O
demonstrated O
by O
voxel-based O
analysis O
were O
extracted O
independently O
using O
the O
extract O
time O
series O
in O
REST O
and O
entered O
into O
SPSS O
. O

Then O
, O
a O
Pearson O
's O
correlation O
analysis O
was O
performed O
to O
clarify O
the O
relationships O
between O
abnormal O
DC O
values O
of O
significantly O
different O
regions O
and O
clinical O
characteristics O
in O
CCS-dependent O
patients O
, O
including O
the O
duration O
of O
CCS O
usage O
, O
age O
at O
first O
CCS O
use O
, O
and O
BIS-11 O
scores O
; O
the O
significance O
levels O
were O
set O
at O
P O
< O
0.05 O
( O
two-tailed O
) O
. O

Attenuated O
Resting-State O
Functional O
Connectivity O
in O
Patients O
with O
Childhood- O
and O
Adult-Onset O
Schizophrenia O
Background O
Childhood-onset O
schizophrenia O
( O
COS O
) O
is O
a O
rare O
, O
severe O
form O
of O
the O
adult-onset O
disorder O
( O
AOS O
) O
. O

Our O
previous O
resting-state O
fMRI O
study O
identified O
attenuated O
functional O
connectivity O
in O
COS O
compared O
with O
controls O
. O

Here O
, O
we O
ask O
whether O
COS O
and O
AOS O
patients O
and O
their O
siblings O
exhibit O
similar O
abnormalities O
of O
functional O
connectivity O
. O

Methods O
A O
whole-brain O
, O
data-driven O
approach O
was O
used O
to O
assess O
resting-state O
functional O
connectivity O
differences O
in O
COS O
( O
patients/siblings/controls O
, O
n O
: O
26/28/33 O
) O
and O
AOS O
( O
n O
: O
19/28/30 O
) O
. O

There O
were O
no O
significant O
differences O
in O
age O
, O
sex O
, O
or O
head O
motion O
across O
groups O
in O
each O
dataset O
and O
as O
designed O
, O
the O
COS O
dataset O
has O
a O
significantly O
lower O
age O
than O
the O
AOS O
. O

Results O
Both O
COS O
and O
AOS O
patients O
showed O
decreased O
functional O
connectivity O
relative O
to O
controls O
among O
a O
wide O
set O
of O
brain O
regions O
( O
P O
< O
0.05 O
, O
corrected O
) O
, O
but O
their O
siblings O
did O
not O
. O

Decreased O
connectivity O
in O
COS O
and O
AOS O
patients O
showed O
no O
amplitude O
differences O
and O
was O
not O
modulated O
by O
age-at-onset O
or O
medication O
doses O
. O

Cluster O
analysis O
revealed O
that O
these O
regions O
fell O
into O
two O
large-scale O
networks O
: O
one O
sensorimotor O
network O
and O
one O
centered O
on O
default-mode O
network O
regions O
, O
but O
including O
higher-order O
cognitive O
areas O
only O
in O
COS O
. O

Decreased O
connectivity O
between O
these O
two O
networks O
was O
notable O
( O
P O
< O
0.05 O
, O
corrected O
) O
for O
both O
patient O
groups O
. O

Conclusions O
A O
shared O
pattern O
of O
attenuated O
functional O
connectivity O
was O
found O
in O
COS O
and O
AOS O
, O
supporting O
the O
continuity O
of O
childhood-onset O
and O
adult-onset O
schizophrenia O
. O

Connections O
were O
altered O
between O
sensorimotor O
areas O
and O
default-mode O
areas O
in O
both O
COS O
and O
AOS O
, O
suggesting O
potential O
abnormalities O
in O
processes O
of O
self-monitoring O
and O
sensory O
prediction O
. O

The O
absence O
of O
substantial O
dysconnectivity O
in O
siblings O
indicates O
that O
attenuation O
is O
state-related O
. O

2 O
Methods O
2.1 O
Participants O
Twenty-six O
individuals O
with O
childhood-onset O
schizophrenia O
( O
COS O
) O
, O
28 O
nonpsychotic O
siblings O
of O
individuals O
with O
COS O
( O
COS_SIB O
) O
, O
and O
33 O
typically O
developing O
controls O
( O
COS_CON O
) O
participated O
in O
the O
COS O
study O
( O
Table O
1 O
) O
. O

Some O
of O
the O
included O
COS O
patients O
and O
siblings O
were O
related O
. O

Informed O
assent O
and O
consent O
were O
obtained O
from O
all O
participants O
and O
their O
parent/guardian O
as O
applicable O
in O
accordance O
with O
a O
National O
Institutes O
of O
Health O
Institutional O
Review O
Board O
approved O
protocol O
. O

COS O
participants O
were O
recruited O
nationwide O
and O
diagnosed O
after O
inpatient O
observation O
that O
included O
medication O
washout O
when O
clinically O
appropriate O
. O

Exclusionary O
criteria O
included O
medical O
or O
neurological O
illness O
, O
substance O
abuse O
, O
or O
full-scale O
IQ O
below O
70 O
prior O
to O
onset O
of O
psychotic O
symptoms O
( O
for O
further O
details O
, O
see O
McKenna O
et O
al O
. O
) O
. O

Control O
participants O
were O
free O
of O
lifetime O
medical O
or O
psychiatric O
disorders O
as O
determined O
by O
clinical O
examination O
and O
standardized O
interview O
, O
and O
none O
had O
psychiatric O
illness O
in O
a O
first-degree O
relative O
. O

All O
COS O
patients O
were O
rated O
by O
staff O
clinicians O
using O
the O
Scale O
for O
the O
Assessment O
of O
Positive O
Symptoms O
( O
SAPS O
) O
and O
Scale O
for O
the O
Assessment O
of O
Negative O
Symptoms O
( O
SANS O
) O
for O
quantification O
of O
symptom O
severity O
. O

All O
COS O
patients O
were O
receiving O
treatment O
with O
antipsychotic O
medication O
at O
the O
time O
of O
the O
study O
, O
typically O
clozapine O
, O
and O
had O
been O
stabilized O
for O
at O
least O
2 O
weeks O
. O

The O
participants O
for O
the O
AOS O
study O
( O
Table O
1 O
) O
were O
the O
same O
set O
as O
reported O
in O
Repovs O
et O
al O
. O

but O
12 O
participants O
were O
excluded O
to O
match O
groups O
for O
motion O
and O
age O
; O
see O
Supplemental O
Image O
Preprocessing O
for O
details O
. O

Sex O
and O
other O
demographic O
variables O
were O
still O
matched O
across O
groups O
. O

These O
participants O
were O
recruited O
through O
the O
Conte O
Center O
for O
the O
Neuroscience O
of O
Mental O
Disorders O
at O
Washington O
University O
School O
of O
Medicine O
in O
St. O
Louis O
and O
included O
: O
1 O
) O
19 O
individuals O
with O
DSM-IV O
schizophrenia O
( O
AOS O
) O
; O
2 O
) O
28 O
nonpsychotic O
siblings O
of O
individuals O
with O
schizophrenia O
( O
AOS_SIB O
) O
; O
3 O
) O
30 O
healthy O
control O
subjects O
( O
AOS_CON O
) O
. O

Some O
of O
the O
AOS O
patients O
and O
siblings O
were O
related O
. O

All O
participants O
gave O
written O
informed O
consent O
for O
participation O
. O

Subjects O
were O
diagnosed O
using O
a O
semi-structured O
interview O
and O
the O
Structured O
Clinical O
Interview O
for O
DSM-IV O
Axis O
I O
Disorders O
. O

Participants O
were O
excluded O
for O
substance O
dependence/abuse O
within O
the O
last O
6 O
months O
; O
medical O
illness O
; O
history O
of O
head O
injury O
; O
or O
mental O
retardation O
( O
diagnostic O
and O
exclusion O
details O
elsewhere O
) O
. O

The O
AOS O
patients O
were O
all O
outpatients O
and O
had O
been O
stabilized O
on O
antipsychotic O
medication O
for O
at O
least O
2 O
weeks O
. O

Control O
subjects O
had O
no O
lifetime O
history O
of O
Axis O
I O
psychotic O
or O
mood O
disorders O
and O
no O
first-degree O
relatives O
with O
a O
psychotic O
disorder O
. O

All O
patients O
were O
assessed O
using O
the O
SAPS O
and O
SANS O
by O
a O
master O
’ O
s-level O
research O
assistant O
who O
regularly O
participated O
in O
training O
and O
reliability O
sessions O
. O

2.2 O
Image O
Acquisition O
For O
each O
participant O
, O
resting O
state O
EPI O
( O
echo-planar-imaging O
) O
images O
were O
acquired O
; O
parameters O
varied O
between O
COS O
and O
AOS O
data O
, O
including O
make O
of O
scanner O
( O
see O
Table O
S1 O
for O
details O
) O
. O

T1-weighted O
anatomical O
images O
( O
MPRAGE O
) O
were O
obtained O
( O
voxel O
size O
= O
0.86×0.86×1.3 O
mm O
for O
COS O
data O
, O
1×1×1 O
mm O
for O
AOS O
) O
. O

2.3 O
Image O
Analyses O
Both O
COS O
and O
AOS O
fMRI O
images O
were O
analyzed O
as O
previously O
described O
by O
our O
group O
and O
as O
further O
detailed O
in O
Supplemental O
Methods O
. O

Briefly O
, O
preprocessing O
was O
done O
within O
AFNI O
using O
the O
basic O
ANATICOR O
approach O
and O
the O
cleaned O
, O
smoothed O
residual O
time O
series O
were O
spatially O
normalized O
to O
the O
Talairach O
and O
Tournoux O
anatomical O
template O
. O

Quality O
of O
these O
two O
datasets O
was O
compared O
using O
two O
measures O
, O
motion O
and O
global O
signal O
amplitude O
, O
which O
did O
not O
differ O
across O
groups O
( O
Table O
S2 O
) O
. O

After O
preprocessing O
, O
for O
both O
COS O
and O
AOS O
data O
, O
first O
we O
conducted O
a O
whole-brain O
, O
data-driven O
search O
as O
previously O
described O
to O
identify O
regions O
of O
interest O
showing O
connectivity O
differences O
, O
measured O
by O
“ O
connectedness O
” O
( O
the O
average O
Pearson O
correlation O
of O
each O
voxel O
with O
all O
others O
) O
of O
schizophrenia O
vs. O
controls O
and O
siblings O
vs. O
controls O
( O
see O
details O
in O
Supplemental O
Methods O
) O
. O

Second O
, O
these O
regions O
showing O
reduced O
connectedness O
were O
used O
as O
seeds O
to O
find O
the O
locations O
driving O
connectedness O
differences O
. O

Combining O
these O
two O
sets O
of O
regions O
resulted O
in O
one O
set O
of O
all O
regions O
that O
showed O
differences O
in O
functional O
connectivity O
between O
groups O
. O

Using O
K-Means O
cluster O
analysis O
on O
all O
pairwise O
correlations O
, O
these O
regions O
were O
organized O
into O
two O
clusters O
, O
the O
optimal O
number O
as O
determined O
by O
elbow O
plots O
and O
confirmed O
by O
silhouette O
values O
. O

We O
examined O
group O
differences O
of O
region-by-region O
correlations O
within- O
and O
across-clusters O
as O
well O
as O
their O
correlations O
with O
clinical O
measures O
( O
SAPS O
and O
SANS O
) O
. O

ANCOVA O
models O
were O
used O
to O
compare O
groups O
and O
examine O
modulation O
effects O
of O
age-at-onset O
, O
medication O
doses O
, O
and O
clinical O
measures O
. O

Age O
and O
transient O
Motion O
were O
co-varied O
as O
nuisance O
variables O
in O
all O
models O
and O
results O
were O
corrected O
using O
cluster O
size O
( O
AFNI O
’ O
s O
3dClustSim O
, O
family-wise O
Type O
I O
error O
( O
FWE O
) O
< O
.05 O
, O
employing O
AFNI O
’ O
s O
updated O
spatial O
auto-correlation O
function O
) O
for O
whole-brain O
comparisons O
and O
Bonferroni O
correction O
for O
the O
number O
of O
seeds O
tested O
. O

More O
details O
of O
data O
analyses O
are O
in O
Supplemental O
Methods O
. O

Hippocampal O
involvement O
in O
nonpathological O
déjà O
vu O
: O
Subfield O
vulnerability O
rather O
than O
temporal O
lobe O
epilepsy O
equivalent O
Abstract O
Introduction O
Morphological O
correlates O
of O
nonpathological O
déjà O
vu O
( O
DV O
) O
have O
been O
identified O
recently O
within O
the O
human O
brain O
. O

Significantly O
reduced O
gray O
matter O
volume O
( O
GMV O
) O
within O
a O
set O
of O
cortical O
and O
subcortical O
regions O
reported O
in O
subjects O
experiencing O
DV O
seems O
to O
mirror O
the O
distribution O
of O
GMV O
reduction O
in O
mesial O
temporal O
lobe O
epilepsy O
( O
MTLE O
) O
patients O
but O
vary O
in O
terms O
of O
the O
hippocampus O
. O

Another O
condition O
associated O
with O
hippocampal O
GMV O
reduction O
and O
DV O
alike O
disturbance O
in O
memory O
processing O
is O
schizophrenia O
( O
SCH O
) O
. O

Here O
, O
we O
tested O
the O
hypothesis O
that O
hippocampal O
involvement O
in O
nonpathological O
DV O
resembles O
more O
closely O
the O
pattern O
of O
GMV O
decrease O
observed O
in O
MTLE O
compared O
with O
that O
occurring O
in O
SCH O
. O

Methods O
Using O
automated O
segmentation O
of O
the O
MRI O
data O
we O
compared O
the O
medians O
of O
GMV O
within O
12 O
specific O
hippocampal O
subfields O
in O
healthy O
individuals O
that O
do O
( O
DV+ O
; O
N O
= O
87 O
) O
and O
do O
not O
report O
déjà O
vu O
experience O
( O
DV− O
; O
N O
= O
26 O
) O
, O
and O
patients O
with O
MTLE O
( O
N O
= O
47 O
) O
and O
SCH O
( O
N O
= O
29 O
) O
. O

By O
Pearson O
correlation O
, O
we O
then O
evaluated O
the O
similarity O
of O
MTLE O
and O
SCH O
groups O
to O
DV+ O
group O
with O
respect O
to O
spatial O
distribution O
of O
GMV O
deviation O
from O
DV− O
group O
. O

Results O
Significant O
GMV O
decrease O
was O
found O
in O
MTLE O
group O
in O
most O
of O
the O
subfields O
. O

There O
were O
just O
trends O
in O
the O
hippocampal O
GMV O
decrease O
found O
in O
DV+ O
or O
SCH O
groups O
. O

Concerning O
the O
spatial O
distribution O
of O
GMV O
decrease O
, O
we O
revealed O
statistically O
significant O
correlation O
for O
the O
left O
hippocampus O
for O
SCH O
vs O
DV+ O
. O

Otherwise O
there O
was O
no O
statistically O
significant O
correlation O
. O

Conclusions O
Our O
findings O
reveal O
structural O
features O
of O
hippocampal O
involvement O
in O
nonpathological O
DV O
, O
MTLE O
, O
and O
SCH O
. O

Despite O
our O
expectations O
, O
the O
pattern O
of O
GMV O
reduction O
in O
the O
DV+ O
relative O
to O
the O
DV− O
group O
does O
not O
resemble O
the O
pattern O
observed O
in O
MTLE O
any O
more O
than O
that O
observed O
in O
SCH O
. O

The O
highly O
similar O
patterns O
of O
the O
three O
clinical O
groups O
rather O
suggest O
an O
increased O
vulnerability O
of O
certain O
hippocampal O
subfields O
; O
namely O
, O
Cornu O
Ammonis O
( O
CA O
) O
4 O
, O
CA3 O
, O
dentate O
gyrus O
granular O
cell O
layer O
( O
GC‐DG O
) O
, O
hippocampal–amygdaloid O
transition O
area O
( O
HATA O
) O
and O
subiculum O
. O

METHODS O
Subjects O
Our O
sample O
comprised O
a O
total O
of O
189 O
subjects O
participated O
in O
the O
study O
. O

The O
MTLE O
group O
consisted O
of O
a O
left‐sided O
( O
L‐MTLE O
; O
N O
= O
27 O
; O
8M O
, O
19F O
; O
median O
age O
= O
40.2 O
years O
; O
range O
= O
17.7 O
– O
54.6 O
years O
) O
and O
right‐sided O
subgroup O
( O
R‐MTLE O
; O
N O
= O
20 O
; O
6M O
, O
14F O
; O
median O
age O
= O
38.2 O
years O
; O
range O
= O
24.8 O
– O
61.1 O
years O
) O
. O

For O
the O
L‐MTLE O
subgroup O
, O
the O
median O
age O
at O
the O
time O
of O
disease O
onset O
was O
3 O
years O
( O
range O
1 O
– O
35 O
years O
) O
, O
the O
median O
disease O
duration O
was O
32.5 O
years O
( O
range O
6 O
– O
54 O
years O
) O
, O
and O
the O
median O
seizure O
frequency O
was O
4 O
seizures O
per O
month O
( O
range O
2 O
– O
135 O
seizures O
) O
. O

For O
the O
R‐MTLE O
subgroup O
, O
the O
median O
age O
at O
the O
time O
of O
the O
disease O
onset O
was O
5.5 O
years O
( O
range O
8 O
months O
– O
40 O
years O
) O
, O
the O
median O
disease O
duration O
was O
29.5 O
years O
( O
range O
8 O
– O
55 O
years O
) O
, O
and O
the O
median O
seizure O
frequency O
was O
4.75 O
seizures O
per O
month O
( O
1 O
– O
13 O
) O
. O

At O
the O
time O
of O
testing O
, O
the O
subgroups O
did O
not O
differ O
significantly O
in O
age O
( O
p O
= O
.97 O
, O
T–test O
) O
, O
gender O
( O
p O
= O
.48 O
; O
T–test O
) O
, O
disease O
duration O
( O
p O
= O
.60 O
, O
T–test O
) O
or O
seizure O
frequency O
( O
p O
= O
.40 O
, O
T–test O
) O
. O

There O
was O
no O
significant O
variance O
between O
the O
subgroups O
in O
their O
positive O
history O
of O
febrile O
convulsions O
( O
seven O
in O
L‐MTLE O
and O
six O
in O
R‐MTLE O
; O
p O
= O
.74 O
, O
T–test O
) O
. O

Majority O
of O
the O
subjects O
had O
a O
history O
of O
complex O
partial O
seizures O
. O

Ten O
patients O
in O
the O
L‐MTLE O
subgroup O
and O
eight O
patients O
in O
the O
R‐MTLE O
subgroup O
also O
presented O
secondary O
generalized O
seizures O
. O

One O
patient O
with O
L‐MTLE O
and O
one O
with O
R‐MTLE O
had O
simple O
partial O
seizures O
. O

DV O
in O
the O
context O
of O
aura O
was O
reported O
solely O
by O
one O
patient O
. O

The O
only O
statistically O
significant O
divergence O
between O
the O
subgroups O
was O
in O
the O
number O
of O
prescribed O
antiepileptic O
drugs O
( O
number O
of O
types O
) O
: O
a O
mean O
of O
2.3 O
medications O
for O
the O
L‐MTLE O
subgroup O
, O
and O
a O
mean O
of O
1.8 O
medications O
for O
R‐MTLE O
subgroup O
( O
p O
= O
.03 O
, O
T‐test O
) O
. O

The O
diagnosis O
of O
unilateral O
MTLE O
was O
based O
on O
a O
consonance O
of O
history O
data O
, O
ictal O
and O
interictal O
EEG O
findings O
( O
long‐term O
semi‐invasive O
video‐EEG O
monitoring O
with O
sphenoidal O
electrodes O
) O
, O
ictal O
semiology O
, O
neuropsychology O
, O
neuroimaging O
findings O
, O
and O
fulfillment O
of O
the O
diagnostic O
criteria O
for O
MTLE O
according O
to O
the O
International O
League O
Against O
Epilepsy O
( O
ILAE O
) O
criteria O
( O
Commission O
on O
Classification O
and O
Terminology O
of O
ILAE O
, O
1989 O
) O
. O

As O
another O
inclusion O
criteria O
was O
set O
also O
hippocampal O
sclerosis O
, O
which O
is O
a O
substrate O
characterizing O
classical O
TLE O
( O
Hogan O
, O
2001 O
) O
. O

Unilateral O
hippocampal O
sclerosis O
MRI O
evidence O
concordant O
with O
the O
EEG O
lateralization O
of O
the O
epileptogenic O
zone O
was O
found O
in O
all O
subjects O
. O

None O
of O
the O
subjects O
revealed O
any O
other O
structural O
brain O
lesions O
on O
MRI O
scans O
, O
and O
none O
had O
undergone O
previous O
intracranial O
surgery O
. O

All O
subjects O
had O
been O
seizure O
free O
for O
24 O
hr O
prior O
to O
the O
MRI O
investigation O
. O

The O
SCH O
group O
comprised O
of O
29 O
subjects O
( O
23M O
, O
6F O
; O
median O
age O
= O
33 O
years O
; O
range O
= O
19.3 O
– O
45.1 O
years O
) O
with O
a O
median O
disease O
duration O
of O
4.5 O
years O
( O
range O
= O
1 O
‐ O
288 O
months O
) O
. O

The O
symptom O
severity O
in O
these O
patients O
was O
assessed O
with O
Positive O
and O
Negative O
Syndrome O
Scale O
( O
PANSS O
; O
Kay O
, O
Fiszbein O
, O
& O
Opler O
, O
1987 O
) O
. O

Patients O
scored O
a O
median O
of O
14 O
points O
( O
range O
= O
7 O
– O
20 O
points O
) O
on O
the O
positive O
scale O
, O
a O
median O
score O
of O
21 O
points O
( O
range O
= O
10 O
– O
29 O
points O
) O
on O
the O
negative O
scale O
, O
and O
a O
median O
of O
38 O
points O
( O
range O
= O
21 O
– O
53 O
points O
) O
on O
the O
general O
psychopathology O
scale O
. O

The O
median O
of O
experienced O
episodes O
was O
2 O
( O
range O
= O
1 O
‐ O
8 O
episodes O
) O
during O
the O
course O
of O
the O
disease O
, O
and O
all O
subjects O
were O
on O
stable O
antipsychotic O
medication O
with O
median O
of O
1 O
( O
range O
= O
1‐2 O
drugs O
, O
all O
atypical O
antipsychotics O
) O
. O

None O
of O
the O
subjects O
reported O
history O
of O
epilepsy O
or O
signs O
of O
hippocampal O
sclerosis O
on O
MRI O
. O

The O
DV+ O
group O
comprised O
of O
87 O
healthy O
volunteers O
( O
45M O
, O
42F O
; O
median O
age O
= O
24.1 O
years O
; O
range O
= O
19.1 O
– O
46.2 O
years O
) O
with O
no O
personal O
or O
family O
history O
of O
epilepsy O
or O
schizophrenia O
. O

All O
subjects O
completed O
the O
Inventory O
for O
Déjà O
vu O
Experiences O
Assessment O
( O
IDEA O
) O
—a O
questionnaire O
used O
widely O
in O
previous O
DV O
research O
( O
Sno O
, O
Schalken O
, O
de O
Jonghe O
, O
& O
Koeter O
, O
1994 O
) O
—and O
answered O
“ O
yes O
” O
to O
the O
question O
A1 O
: O
” O
Have O
you O
ever O
had O
the O
feeling O
of O
having O
experienced O
a O
sensation O
or O
situation O
before O
in O
exactly O
the O
same O
way O
when O
in O
fact O
you O
are O
experiencing O
it O
for O
the O
first O
time O
? O
” O
. O

The O
DV− O
group O
included O
26 O
healthy O
volunteers O
( O
14M O
, O
12F O
; O
median O
age O
= O
24.2 O
years O
; O
range O
= O
20.3 O
– O
49.5 O
years O
) O
with O
no O
personal O
or O
family O
history O
of O
epilepsy O
or O
schizophrenia O
. O

These O
individuals O
answered O
“ O
never O
” O
to O
question O
A1 O
of O
the O
IDEA O
questionnaire O
. O

Group O
factor O
testing O
reached O
statistical O
significance O
in O
the O
case O
of O
age O
( O
Kruskal‐Wallis O
test O
H O
[ O
4,189 O
] O
= O
59.6 O
, O
p O
< O
.001 O
) O
and O
gender O
( O
Pearson O
Chi‐square O
test O
, O
chi‐square O
= O
17.9 O
, O
p O
= O
.001 O
) O
. O

Written O
informed O
consent O
was O
obtained O
from O
each O
participant O
after O
all O
the O
procedures O
were O
explained O
in O
full O
. O

The O
study O
received O
the O
approval O
of O
the O
local O
ethics O
committee O
. O

MRI O
data O
acquisition O
We O
acquired O
a O
T1 O
MPRAGE O
high O
resolution O
MRI O
for O
each O
subject O
with O
a O
Siemens O
Symphony O
1.5T O
MR O
scanner O
( O
160 O
sagittal O
slices O
; O
matrix O
size O
256 O
× O
256 O
, O
resampled O
to O
512 O
× O
512 O
; O
TR O
= O
1,700 O
ms O
; O
TE O
= O
3.96 O
ms O
; O
FOV O
= O
246 O
mm O
; O
FA O
= O
15° O
; O
slice O
thickness O
= O
1.17 O
mm O
; O
native O
in O
plane O
resolution O
= O
0.96 O
mm O
) O
. O

Eight O
images O
were O
discarded O
due O
to O
severe O
motion O
artifacts O
identified O
by O
visual O
inspection O
. O

The O
resulting O
images O
comprised O
the O
data O
described O
above O
and O
analyzed O
as O
follows O
. O

MRI O
data O
preprocessing O
We O
used O
the O
Freesurfer O
6.0 O
toolbox O
for O
data O
preprocessing O
with O
additional O
tool O
for O
hippocampal O
subfields O
segmentation O
( O
recon‐all O
–all O
–hippocampal‐subfields‐T1 O
command O
) O
( O
Iglesias O
et O
al. O
, O
2015 O
) O
. O

The O
output O
of O
the O
preprocessing O
contained O
an O
information O
of O
the O
hippocampal O
subfields O
volumes O
, O
namely O
parasubiculum O
, O
presubiculum O
, O
subiculum O
, O
CA1 O
, O
CA3 O
, O
CA4 O
, O
GC‐DG O
, O
HATA O
, O
fimbria O
, O
molecular O
layer O
HP O
, O
fissure O
and O
tail O
as O
well O
as O
an O
estimate O
of O
the O
total O
intracranial O
volume O
( O
TIV O
) O
. O

The O
subfield O
volumes O
were O
corrected O
for O
age O
and O
gender O
effects O
using O
linear O
regression O
and O
for O
variability O
in O
head O
volume O
using O
normalization O
by O
TIV O
. O

We O
refer O
to O
these O
values O
as O
corrected O
subfield O
volumes O
( O
CSV O
) O
. O

Statistics O
The O
purpose O
of O
the O
study O
was O
to O
map O
GMV O
within O
distinctive O
hippocampal O
subfields O
, O
and O
to O
perform O
comparisons O
in O
these O
measures O
of O
GMV O
among O
the O
DV+ O
, O
DV− O
, O
SCH O
, O
and O
MTLE O
groups O
. O

We O
carried O
out O
two O
statistical O
tests O
with O
the O
STATISTICA O
12 O
( O
StatSoft O
, O
Inc. O
, O
USA O
) O
. O

Subfield O
specific O
GMV O
decrease O
To O
reveal O
subfield O
specific O
GMV O
change O
in O
DV+ O
, O
SCH O
, O
and O
MTLE O
group O
relative O
to O
the O
DV− O
group O
, O
we O
performed O
Mann‐Whitney O
tests O
on O
CSV O
for O
each O
subfield O
and O
group O
( O
DV+ O
, O
SCH O
and O
MTLE O
vs. O
DV− O
) O
. O

The O
significance O
level O
was O
set O
to O
p O
< O
.05 O
. O

Spatial O
distribution O
of O
GMV O
decrease O
We O
computed O
median O
of O
the O
CSV O
volumes O
( O
mCSV O
) O
across O
subjects O
for O
each O
group O
and O
subfield O
. O

To O
identify O
which O
patient O
group O
resembles O
more O
the O
DV+ O
group O
considering O
the O
spatial O
pattern O
of O
GMV O
deviations O
from O
DV− O
we O
further O
computed O
the O
deviation O
of O
mCSV O
between O
DV+/MTLE/SCH O
and O
DV− O
( O
dmSCV O
) O
. O

The O
dmCSV O
patterns O
were O
assessed O
using O
Pearson O
correlation O
coefficient O
, O
that O
is O
, O
we O
computed O
correlation O
coefficient O
based O
on O
dmSCV O
for O
DV+ O
vs O
MTLE O
in O
affected O
hippocampus O
and O
DV+ O
vs O
SCH O
in O
both‐sided O
hippocampi O
. O

The O
significance O
level O
of O
correlation O
coefficients O
was O
set O
to O
p O
< O
.05 O
. O

Identifying O
first-episode O
drug O
naïve O
patients O
with O
schizophrenia O
with O
or O
without O
auditory O
verbal O
hallucinations O
using O
whole-brain O
functional O
connectivity O
: O
A O
pattern O
analysis O
study O
Many O
studies O
have O
focused O
on O
patients O
with O
schizophrenia O
with O
or O
without O
auditory O
verbal O
hallucinations O
( O
AVHs O
) O
, O
but O
due O
to O
the O
complexity O
of O
schizophrenia O
, O
biologically O
based O
diagnosis O
of O
patients O
with O
schizophrenia O
remains O
unsolved O
. O

The O
objectives O
of O
this O
study O
are O
to O
classify O
between O
first-episode O
drug-naïve O
patients O
with O
schizophrenia O
and O
healthy O
controls O
, O
and O
to O
classify O
between O
patients O
with O
and O
without O
AVHs O
. O

Resting O
state O
fMRI O
data O
from O
41 O
patients O
with O
schizophrenia O
( O
22 O
with O
and O
19 O
without O
AVHs O
) O
and O
23 O
normal O
controls O
( O
NC O
) O
were O
included O
to O
compute O
functional O
connectivity O
between O
brain O
regions O
. O

Classifiers O
based O
on O
support O
vector O
machine O
( O
SVM O
) O
were O
developed O
to O
classify O
patients O
with O
schizophrenia O
from O
NC O
, O
as O
well O
as O
between O
the O
two O
subgroups O
of O
patients O
. O

The O
classification O
accuracy O
was O
evaluated O
with O
a O
leave-one-out O
cross-validation O
( O
LOOCV O
) O
strategy O
. O

The O
accuracy O
in O
discriminating O
both O
subgroups O
of O
patients O
from O
NC O
was O
81.3 O
% O
, O
with O
92.0 O
% O
( O
sensitivity O
) O
and O
65.2 O
% O
( O
specificity O
) O
for O
the O
patients O
and O
NC O
, O
respectively O
. O

The O
classification O
accuracy O
in O
discriminating O
patients O
with O
and O
without O
AVHs O
was O
75.6 O
% O
, O
with O
77.3 O
% O
( O
sensitivity O
) O
and O
73.9 O
% O
( O
specificity O
) O
for O
patients O
with O
and O
without O
AVHs O
, O
respectively O
. O

The O
results O
suggest O
that O
functional O
connectivity O
provided O
good O
discriminative O
power O
not O
only O
for O
identifying O
patients O
with O
schizophrenia O
among O
NC O
, O
but O
also O
in O
discriminating O
patients O
with O
schizophrenia O
with O
and O
without O
AVHs O
. O

Highlights O
Normal O
controls O
, O
schizophrenia O
patients O
with O
and O
without O
AVHs O
were O
successfully O
classified O
. O

Using O
LOOCV O
, O
the O
classifier O
achieved O
an O
accuracy O
of O
groups O
of O
81.3 O
% O
for O
all O
the O
three O
groups O
of O
subjects O
. O

Patients O
with O
AVHs O
were O
differentiated O
with O
those O
without O
AVHs O
with O
an O
accuracy O
of O
75.6 O
% O
. O

The O
proposed O
may O
help O
with O
the O
clinical O
diagnosis O
of O
schizophrenia O
patients O
. O

Materials O
and O
methods O
Participants O
45 O
first-episode O
drug O
naïve O
patients O
with O
schizophrenia O
, O
including O
untreated O
inpatients O
undergoing O
their O
first O
hospitalization O
or O
outpatients O
seeking O
help O
for O
the O
first O
time O
after O
the O
first O
onset O
of O
the O
disease O
, O
were O
assigned O
to O
two O
groups O
according O
to O
the O
presence O
of O
AVHs O
symptom O
. O

25 O
of O
them O
who O
reported O
AVHs O
at O
least O
once O
a O
day O
for O
the O
past O
four O
weeks O
were O
assigned O
to O
AVHs O
group O
. O

20 O
patients O
who O
have O
never O
experienced O
AVHs O
or O
have O
not O
experienced O
them O
within O
two O
years O
before O
recruitment O
were O
allocated O
to O
Non-AVHs O
group O
, O
with O
consensus O
diagnoses O
from O
two O
senior O
clinical O
psychiatrists O
according O
to O
the O
Structural O
Clinical O
Interview O
for O
Diagnostic O
Statistical O
and O
Manual O
of O
Mental O
disorders O
, O
Fourth O
Edition O
, O
Text O
Revision O
( O
DSM-IV-TR O
) O
. O

Demographically O
matched O
24 O
normal O
controls O
( O
NC O
group O
) O
were O
included O
in O
this O
study O
. O

They O
were O
all O
right-handed O
and O
native O
Chinese O
speakers O
. O

Five O
subjects O
were O
excluded O
from O
analysis O
because O
of O
excessive O
head O
motion O
during O
the O
MRI O
scan O
( O
> O
2.5 O
mm O
translation O
and O
> O
2.5° O
rotation O
) O
. O

The O
remaining O
41 O
patients O
( O
22 O
with O
AVHs O
, O
19 O
without O
AVHs O
, O
mean O
duration O
since O
a O
diagnosis O
of O
first-episode O
was O
9.2 O
months O
) O
and O
23 O
NC O
were O
included O
in O
the O
analysis O
. O

All O
participants O
gave O
their O
written O
informed O
consent O
prior O
to O
the O
study O
, O
which O
was O
in O
accordance O
with O
the O
Declaration O
of O
Helsinki O
and O
all O
experiments O
protocol O
were O
approved O
by O
ethics O
committee O
in O
Fourth O
Military O
Medical O
University O
( O
FMMU O
) O
. O

Clinical O
assessment O
Patients O
meeting O
diagnostic O
criteria O
for O
schizophrenia O
according O
to O
DSM-IV-TR O
were O
assessed O
by O
two O
senior O
clinical O
psychiatrists O
using O
the O
Positive O
and O
Negative O
Symptom O
Scale O
( O
PANSS O
total O
score O
≥ O
60 O
) O
. O

Further O
assessment O
of O
AVHs O
patients O
was O
based O
on O
the O
Hoffman O
Auditory O
Hallucination O
Rating O
Scale O
( O
HAHRS O
) O
. O

Magnetic O
resonance O
imaging O
Magnetic O
resonance O
imaging O
( O
MRI O
) O
was O
performed O
on O
a O
3 O
Tesla O
Magnetom O
Trio O
Tim O
scanner O
system O
( O
Siemens O
, O
Germany O
) O
at O
Xijing O
Hospital O
, O
FMMU O
. O

During O
the O
resting O
state O
scan O
, O
subjects O
were O
instructed O
to O
close O
their O
eyes O
, O
but O
remain O
awake O
. O

A O
standard O
birdcage O
head O
coil O
was O
used O
. O

Foam O
pads O
and O
headsets O
were O
used O
to O
reduce O
head O
motion O
and O
scanner O
noise O
. O

The O
fMRI O
images O
were O
collected O
using O
an O
echo-planar O
imaging O
( O
EPI O
) O
sequence O
. O

The O
parameters O
were O
: O
repetition O
time/echo O
time O
= O
2000/30 O
ms O
, O
thickness/gap O
= O
4/0.6 O
mm O
, O
field O
of O
view O
= O
220 O
× O
220 O
mm O
, O
flip O
angle O
= O
90° O
, O
matrix O
= O
64 O
× O
64 O
, O
number O
of O
slices O
= O
33 O
. O

Each O
resting O
state O
scan O
lasted O
about O
10 O
min O
and O
generated O
240 O
brain O
volumes O
. O

T1-weighted O
anatomical O
data O
were O
acquired O
using O
the O
3D O
MPRAGE O
sequence O
: O
repetition O
time/echo O
time O
= O
2530/3.5 O
ms O
, O
thickness/gap O
= O
1/0 O
mm O
, O
field O
of O
view O
= O
256 O
mm O
× O
256 O
mm O
, O
flip O
angle O
= O
7° O
, O
matrix O
= O
256 O
× O
256 O
, O
number O
of O
slices O
= O
192 O
, O
resolution O
= O
1 O
mm O
× O
1 O
mm O
× O
1 O
mm O
. O

Data O
preprocessing O
Using O
the O
DPARSF O
2.3 O
, O
preprocessing O
included O
several O
steps O
: O
( O
1 O
) O
For O
each O
subject O
, O
the O
first O
10 O
volumes O
of O
scanned O
data O
were O
discarded O
for O
magnetic O
saturation O
. O

( O
2 O
) O
The O
230 O
volumes O
were O
corrected O
by O
registering O
for O
head O
motion O
. O

( O
3 O
) O
The O
volumes O
were O
normalized O
by O
using O
T1 O
image O
segmentation O
. O

( O
4 O
) O
Temporal O
band-pass O
filtering O
( O
0.01 O
Hz O
< O
f O
< O
0.08 O
Hz O
) O
and O
spatial O
smoothing O
( O
8 O
mm O
full-width O
half-maximum O
kernel O
) O
were O
applied O
to O
the O
resulting O
images O
. O

( O
5 O
) O
Nuisance O
regressors O
, O
including O
6 O
motion O
parameters O
obtained O
by O
rigid-body O
head O
motion O
correction O
, O
global O
signal O
level O
, O
ventricular O
signal O
level O
, O
and O
white O
matter O
signals O
were O
regressed O
out O
. O

( O
6 O
) O
The O
automated O
anatomical O
labeling O
( O
AAL O
) O
atlas O
template O
with O
116 O
regions O
of O
interest O
( O
ROI O
) O
was O
used O
to O
extract O
time O
series O
of O
the O
BOLD O
time O
series O
. O

( O
7 O
) O
The O
correlation O
( O
Pearson O
's O
r O
coefficient O
) O
between O
each O
pair O
of O
ROI O
time O
series O
was O
computed O
to O
generate O
a O
correlation O
matrix O
( O
116 O
× O
116 O
) O
for O
each O
subject O
. O

The O
6670 O
upper O
triangle O
elements O
of O
the O
matrix O
, O
excluding O
the O
diagonal O
of O
the O
matrix O
, O
were O
used O
as O
features O
in O
all O
subsequent O
MPA O
. O

With O
regard O
to O
head O
motion O
, O
no O
significance O
difference O
was O
found O
among O
groups O
on O
Jenkinson O
's O
mean O
frame-wise O
displacement O
values O
( O
P O
= O
0.17 O
) O
. O

Feature O
selection O
and O
SVM O
SVM O
was O
proposed O
by O
Vapnik O
and O
has O
been O
applied O
in O
life O
sciences O
as O
a O
powerful O
tool O
for O
classification O
and O
prediction O
. O

Many O
studies O
have O
demonstrated O
that O
SVM O
is O
suitable O
for O
analyzing O
neuroimaging O
data O
. O

Due O
to O
the O
large O
number O
of O
features O
in O
our O
study O
, O
feature O
selection O
with O
high O
discriminative O
power O
is O
essential O
to O
achieve O
high O
classification O
accuracy O
. O

In O
this O
study O
, O
SVM O
was O
used O
to O
discriminate O
between O
subjects O
belonging O
to O
different O
classes O
( O
for O
example O
, O
NC O
and O
patients O
) O
. O

The O
Kendall O
tau O
rank O
correlation O
coefficient O
was O
used O
as O
the O
discriminative O
power O
indicator O
for O
each O
feature O
based O
on O
its O
relevance O
to O
classification O
. O

Programs O
written O
in O
Matlab O
R2010a O
were O
used O
to O
calculate O
the O
tau O
. O

For O
example O
, O
for O
the O
i-th O
feature O
, O
tau O
is O
computed O
by O
: O
where O
m O
and O
n O
are O
the O
number O
of O
samples O
in O
the O
two O
groups O
, O
and O
nc O
and O
nd O
are O
the O
number O
of O
concordant O
and O
discordant O
pairs O
between O
the O
two O
groups O
, O
respectively O
. O

For O
feature O
i O
, O
let O
xj O
and O
xk O
denote O
the O
functional O
connectivity O
of O
the O
j-th O
sample O
from O
the O
control O
group O
and O
k-th O
sample O
from O
the O
patient O
group O
. O

Let O
yj O
and O
yk O
denote O
the O
class O
labels O
of O
the O
groups O
( O
e. O
g. O
, O
+1 O
for O
controls O
and O
−1 O
for O
patients O
) O
. O

The O
pair O
is O
concordant O
if O
the O
connectivity O
difference O
and O
class O
label O
difference O
has O
the O
same O
sign O
: O
They O
are O
discordant O
if O
the O
signs O
are O
opposite O
: O
The O
discriminative O
power O
was O
defined O
as O
the O
absolute O
value O
of O
the O
tau O
. O

Features O
were O
ranked O
according O
to O
their O
discriminative O
powers O
and O
those O
above O
a O
certain O
threshold O
were O
included O
in O
the O
final O
features O
set O
in O
SVM O
classification O
. O

The O
threshold O
was O
chosen O
to O
give O
the O
best O
classification O
accuracy O
for O
the O
classifier O
. O

When O
the O
high O
discriminative O
power O
feature O
set O
was O
selected O
, O
LIBSVM O
3.18 O
( O
default O
setting O
C O
= O
1 O
, O
as O
suggested O
in O
, O
linear O
kernel O
) O
was O
used O
for O
classification O
. O

Due O
to O
the O
quantity O
of O
samples O
, O
LOOCV O
was O
conducted O
by O
iterating O
the O
procedure O
with O
each O
of O
the O
samples O
left O
out O
. O

Classification O
accuracy O
was O
computed O
from O
the O
average O
of O
all O
the O
iterations O
. O

The O
training O
features O
( O
functional O
connections O
) O
differed O
slightly O
from O
iteration O
to O
iteration O
of O
the O
LOOCV O
procedure O
. O

The O
common O
features O
, O
considered O
as O
consensus O
functional O
connectivity O
( O
CFC O
) O
, O
were O
selected O
as O
the O
final O
feature O
set O
through O
all O
the O
iterations O
. O

The O
occurrence O
number O
of O
each O
ROI O
in O
the O
CFC O
was O
calculated O
as O
the O
region O
weight O
as O
an O
indicator O
of O
the O
relative O
contribution O
to O
identification O
. O

The O
steps O
of O
the O
calculation O
are O
illustrated O
in O
Fig O
. O

1 O
. O

To O
evaluate O
the O
performance O
of O
the O
classifier O
, O
we O
did O
a O
permutation O
test O
. O

The O
test O
was O
repeated O
5000 O
times O
. O

For O
each O
permutation O
, O
the O
class O
labels O
of O
the O
training O
data O
were O
randomly O
permutated O
, O
and O
then O
an O
accuracy O
was O
obtained O
. O

The O
results O
were O
used O
as O
a O
baseline O
to O
gauge O
the O
statistical O
significance O
of O
the O
SVM O
procedure O
. O

The O
major O
depressive O
disorder O
GWAS-supported O
variant O
rs10514299 O
in O
TMEM161B-MEF2C O
predicts O
putamen O
activation O
during O
reward O
processing O
in O
alcohol O
dependence O
Alcohol O
dependence O
( O
AD O
) O
frequently O
co-occurs O
with O
major O
depressive O
disorder O
( O
MDD O
) O
. O

While O
this O
comorbidity O
is O
associated O
with O
an O
increase O
in O
disease O
burden O
, O
worse O
treatment O
outcomes O
, O
and O
greater O
economic O
costs O
, O
the O
underlying O
neurobiology O
remains O
poorly O
understood O
. O

A O
recent O
large-scale O
GWAS O
of O
MDD O
has O
identified O
a O
locus O
in O
the O
TMEM161B-MEF2C O
region O
( O
rs10514299 O
) O
as O
a O
novel O
risk O
variant O
; O
however O
, O
the O
biological O
relevance O
of O
this O
variant O
has O
not O
yet O
been O
studied O
. O

Given O
previous O
reports O
of O
disrupted O
reward O
processing O
in O
both O
AD O
and O
MDD O
, O
we O
hypothesized O
that O
rs10514299 O
would O
be O
associated O
with O
differences O
in O
striatal O
BOLD O
responses O
during O
reward/loss O
anticipation O
in O
AD O
. O

DNA O
samples O
from O
45 O
recently O
detoxified O
patients O
with O
AD O
and O
45 O
healthy O
controls O
( O
HC O
) O
were O
genotyped O
for O
rs10514299 O
. O

Participants O
performed O
the O
Monetary O
Incentive O
Delay O
task O
in O
a O
3-Tesla O
MRI O
scanner O
. O

Effects O
of O
rs10514299 O
on O
striatal O
activation O
during O
anticipation O
of O
high/low O
reward/loss O
were O
investigated O
. O

Furthermore O
, O
we O
examined O
associations O
between O
rs10514299 O
and O
lifetime O
AD O
diagnosis O
in O
two O
independent O
clinical O
samples O
[ O
NIAAA O
: O
n O
= O
1858 O
( O
1123 O
cases O
, O
735 O
controls O
) O
; O
SAGE O
: O
n O
= O
3838 O
( O
1848 O
cases O
, O
1990 O
controls O
) O
] O
, O
as O
well O
as O
its O
association O
with O
depression O
severity O
in O
a O
subsample O
of O
individuals O
with O
a O
lifetime O
AD O
diagnosis O
( O
n O
= O
953 O
) O
. O

Patients O
carrying O
the O
T O
allele O
showed O
significantly O
greater O
putamen O
activation O
during O
anticipation O
of O
high O
reward O
( O
p O
= O
0.014 O
) O
, O
low O
reward O
( O
at O
trend-level O
; O
p O
= O
0.081 O
) O
, O
high O
loss O
( O
p O
= O
0.024 O
) O
, O
and O
low O
loss O
( O
p O
= O
0.046 O
) O
compared O
to O
HCs O
. O

Association O
analyses O
in O
the O
NIAAA O
sample O
showed O
a O
trend-level O
relationship O
between O
rs10514299 O
and O
a O
lifetime O
AD O
diagnosis O
in O
the O
European O
American O
subgroup O
( O
odds O
ratio O
= O
0.82 O
, O
p O
= O
0.09 O
) O
. O

This O
finding O
was O
not O
replicated O
in O
the O
SAGE O
sample O
. O

In O
the O
NIAAA O
sample O
, O
the O
T O
allele O
was O
significantly O
associated O
with O
greater O
depression O
symptom O
severity O
in O
individuals O
with O
a O
lifetime O
AD O
diagnosis O
( O
β O
= O
1.25 O
, O
p O
= O
0.02 O
) O
; O
this O
association O
was O
driven O
by O
the O
African O
American O
ancestry O
subgroup O
( O
β O
= O
2.11 O
, O
p O
= O
0.008 O
) O
. O

We O
show O
for O
the O
first O
time O
that O
the O
previously O
identified O
MDD O
risk O
variant O
rs10514299 O
in O
TMEM161B-MEF2C O
predicts O
neuronal O
correlates O
of O
reward O
processing O
in O
an O
AD O
phenotype O
, O
possibly O
explaining O
part O
of O
the O
shared O
pathophysiology O
and O
comorbidity O
between O
the O
disorders O
. O

Materials O
and O
methods O
Participants O
The O
Neuroimaging O
Sample O
included O
90 O
participants O
( O
45 O
AD O
and O
45 O
HC O
) O
with O
a O
mean O
age O
of O
39.78 O
( O
SD O
= O
11.33 O
; O
see O
Table O
1 O
) O
. O

Prior O
to O
study O
participation O
, O
participants O
in O
the O
Neuroimaging O
and O
NIAAA O
Sample O
provided O
informed O
written O
consent O
in O
accordance O
with O
the O
Declaration O
of O
Helsinki O
and O
as O
approved O
by O
the O
National O
Institute O
on O
Alcohol O
Abuse O
and O
Alcoholism O
Review O
Board O
. O

All O
participants O
completed O
the O
Structured O
Clinical O
Interview O
for O
DSM-IV-TR O
Axis O
I O
Disorders O
( O
SCID-IV O
) O
. O

Given O
that O
DSM-5 O
criteria O
for O
alcohol O
use O
disorder O
are O
less O
stringent O
compared O
to O
DSM-IV O
criteria O
for O
AD O
, O
all O
individuals O
likely O
fall O
into O
the O
moderate/severe O
alcohol O
use O
disorder O
categories O
in O
DSM-5 O
. O

Exclusion O
criteria O
included O
left-handedness O
, O
contraindications O
for O
MRI O
( O
e.g. O
, O
claustrophobia O
or O
pregnancy O
) O
, O
and O
the O
presence O
of O
any O
significant O
medical O
or O
neurological O
diagnoses O
as O
assessed O
by O
a O
history O
and O
physical O
exam O
. O

Additional O
exclusion O
criteria O
for O
the O
HC O
group O
included O
DSM-IV-TR O
diagnoses O
of O
current/past O
AD O
, O
positive O
urine O
drug O
screens O
, O
and O
alcohol O
breathalyzer O
readings O
above O
zero O
. O

FMRI O
scans O
were O
obtained O
while O
participants O
completed O
a O
modified O
version O
of O
the O
MID O
task O
where O
approximately O
70 O
% O
of O
trials O
were O
successful O
. O

Participants O
were O
not O
on O
any O
psychotropic O
medications O
on O
the O
day O
of O
the O
scan O
and O
there O
were O
no O
alcohol O
abstainers O
among O
the O
HC O
group O
. O

DNA O
samples O
were O
obtained O
from O
all O
participants O
for O
genotyping O
. O

The O
NIAAA O
Sample O
consisted O
of O
1123 O
individuals O
with O
a O
DSM-IV-TR O
diagnosis O
of O

and O

who O
enrolled O
in O
research O
studies O
at O
the O
National O
Institute O
on O
Alcohol O
Abuse O
and O
Alcoholism O

the O

Institutes O
of O
Health O
Clinical O
Center O
in O
Bethesda O
, O
MD O
( O
see O
Table O

) O
. O

531 O
individuals O
with O
AD O
and O
411 O
controls O
were O
of O
European O
American O
( O
EA O
) O
descent O
. O

A O
total O
of O
507 O
individuals O
with O
AD O
and O

controls O
were O
of O
African O
American O
( O
AA O
) O
descent O
. O

All O
participants O
provided O
blood O
samples O
for O
genotyping O
. O

The O
SAGE O
was O
funded O
by O
the O
National O
Human O
Genome O
Research O
Institute O
as O
part O
of O
the O
Gene O
Environment O
Association O
Studies O
( O
GENEVA O
) O
that O
consisted O
of O
three O
major O
studies O
of O
addictive O
disorders O
: O
The O
Collaborative O
Study O
on O
the O
Genetics O
of O

( O
COGA O
) O
, O
the O
Family O
Study O
of O

Dependence O
( O
