this O
study O
. O

Neurocognitive O
and O
behavioral O
assessments O
MRI O
subjects O
underwent O
a O
detailed O
series O
of O
standardized O
neuropsychological O
tests O
, O
either O
on O
the O
same O
day O
or O
within O
7 O
days O
of O
MRI O
scans O
. O

This O
included O
( O
1 O
) O
the O
Montreal O
Cognitive O
Assessment O
( O
MoCA O
) O
to O
assess O
global O
cognitive O
ability O
, O
( O
2 O
) O
the O
Barratt O
Impulsiveness O
Scale O
( O
BIS-11 O
) O
to O
determine O
the O
level O
of O
impulsivity O
, O
( O
3 O
) O
the O
Iowa O
Gambling O
Task O
( O
IGT O
) O
to O
evaluate O
decision-making O
ability O
, O
and O
( O
4 O
) O
a O
visual O
analog O
scale O
to O
assess O
self-reported O
average O
heroin O
craving O
during O
the O
past O
week O
. O

Detailed O
descriptions O
of O
these O
assessments O
are O
available O
in O
the O
Supplementary O
Materials O
. O

MRI O
data O
acquisition O
and O
preprocessing O
MRI O
was O
performed O
using O
a O
1.5-T O
MR O
Signa O
HDxt O
imaging O
system O
( O
General O
Electric O
Medical O
System O
, O
Milwaukee O
, O
WI O
, O
USA O
) O
with O
a O
standard O
eight-channel O
head O
coil O
. O

Two O
experienced O
radiologists O
examined O
the O
T2 O
images O
, O
and O
no O
abnormalities O
were O
observed O
in O
the O
subjects O
. O

T1-weighted O
sagittal O
three-dimensional O
images O
were O
acquired O
with O
a O
spoiled O
gradient O
recalled O
echo O
sequence O
with O
coverage O
of O
the O
entire O
brain O
. O

For O
DTI O
, O
a O
total O
of O
28 O
image O
sets O
was O
acquired O
with O
56 O
axial O
slices O
( O
slice O
thickness O
: O
2.4 O
mm O
with O
no O
gap O
; O
repetition O
time/echo O
time O
: O
14.4 O
s/85 O
ms O
; O
3 O
b0 O
images O
without O
diffusion O
weighting O
; O
25 O
non-collinear O
diffusion-weighting O
gradients O
with O
b O
= O
1000 O
s/mm2 O
; O
acquisition O
matrix O
: O
128 O
× O
128 O
; O
field O
of O
view O
: O
256 O
× O
256 O
mm2 O
) O
. O

The O
DTI O
data O
were O
preprocessed O
using O
FSL5.0.7 O
( O
www.fmrib.ox.ac.uk/fsl/ O
; O
accessed O
6 O
September O
2017 O
) O
using O
the O
following O
steps O
: O
( O
1 O
) O
Eddy-current O
and O
head O
motion O
correction O
, O
estimation O
of O
the O
diffusion O
tensors O
, O
and O
calculation O
of O
functional O
anisotropy O
( O
FA O
) O
; O
( O
2 O
) O
co-registration O
of O
T1 O
scans O
with O
their O
corresponding O
DTI O
b0 O
image O
so O
that O
ROIs O
that O
were O
defined O
in O
the O
structural O
MRI O
space O
could O
be O
transformed O
into O
native O
diffusion O
space O
; O
( O
3 O
) O
the O
FA O
images O
were O
spatially O
normalized O
to O
the O
Montreal O
Neurological O
Institute O
( O
MNI O
) O
space O
using O
DARTEL O
of O
SPM8 O
, O
resampled O
to O
3 O
× O
3 O
× O
3 O
mm3 O
during O
the O
normalization O
, O
and O
smoothed O
with O
an O
6-mm O
full-width O
at O
half-maximum O
Gaussian O
kernel O
. O

Network O
construction O
The O
flow O
chart O
of O
network O
analysis O
was O
shown O
in O
Fig O
. O

S1 O
. O

Network O
nodes O
definition O
We O
defined O
the O
addiction O
reward-related O
brain O
regions O
( O
12 O
regions O
in O
each O
hemisphere O
) O
, O
which O
were O
both O
highly O
reported O
in O
our O
systematic O
literature O
review O
and O
involved O
in O
biological O
mechanism O
of O
heroin O
addiction O
, O
as O
the O
nodes O
of O
reward O
network O
. O

These O
involved O
the O
dlPFC O
, O
ACC O
, O
VTA O
, O
orbitofrontal O
cortex O
( O
OFC O
) O
, O
insula O
( O
INS O
) O
, O
ventral O
striatum O
( O
VStr O
) O
, O
caudate O
, O
amygdala O
( O
AMY O
) O
, O
hippocampus O
( O
HIP O
) O
, O
thalamus O
( O
THA O
) O
, O
putamen O
, O
and O
pallidum O
( O
definitions O
are O
indicated O
in O
Table O
S2 O
and O
Fig O
. O

1a O
) O
. O

Specifically O
, O
we O
defined O
the O
subnetworks O
based O
on O
authoritative O
reviews O
, O
the O
reward-driving O
subnetwork O
comprised O
the O
VTA O
, O
NAc O
, O
AMY O
, O
THA O
, O
and O
other O
subcortical O
regions O
that O
responded O
to O
impulsive O
motivation O
driving O
of O
substance O
reward O
( O
e.g. O
, O
craving O
) O
, O
and O
the O
reward-control O
subnetwork O
comprised O
the O
dlPFC O
, O
ACC O
together O
with O
OFC O
and O
INS O
that O
mainly O
exerted O
inhibitory O
control O
for O
substance O
reward O
. O

Network O
edge O
definition O
Between O
pairs O
of O
ROIs O
, O
structural O
connections O
were O
measured O
using O
the O
probabilistic O
fiber O
tracking O
method O
in O
FSL O
. O

This O
comprised O
of O
276 O
structural O
connections O
for O
each O
subject O
( O
a O
symmetrical O
24 O
× O
24 O
matrix O
) O
. O

Probabilistic O
fiber O
tracking O
was O
repeatedly O
sampled O
from O
the O
distributions O
of O
voxel-wise O
principal O
diffusion O
directions O
to O
generate O
a O
probabilistic O
streamline O
on O
the O
location O
of O
the O
true O
streamline O
and O
thereby O
build O
a O
connective O
value O
map O
in O
diffusion O
space O
. O

All O
the O
fibers O
were O
tracked O
with O
a O
curvature O
threshold O
of O
0.2 O
. O

Then O
, O
both O
the O
FA-value O
images O
and O
the O
probabilistic O
streamline O
images O
were O
warped O
from O
diffusion O
space O
into O
MNI O
space O
. O

The O
one-sample O
t-test O
was O
applied O
to O
the O
connective O
value O
maps O
of O
addiction O
subjects O
or O
HC O
subjects O
, O
respectively O
, O
to O
define O
streamline O
regions O
. O

The O
voxels O
were O
thresholded O
at O
p O
< O
0.05 O
compared O
to O
zero O
. O

The O
connective O
strength O
of O
each O
edge O
was O
defined O
as O
the O
average O
FA O
values O
of O
all O
voxels O
that O
were O
included O
in O
the O
streamline O
regions O
. O

Network O
analysis O
The O
average O
connective O
strength O
of O
each O
edge O
was O
measured O
for O
each O
subject O
independently O
, O
including O
connections O
within O
the O
reward-driving O
subnetwork O
( O
Driving O
) O
and O
reward-control O
subnetwork O
( O
Control O
) O
, O
connections O
between O
driving/control O
subnetworks O
( O
BTN-connections O
) O
, O
and O
connections O
with O
significant O
differences O
between O
HAs O
and O
HCs O
( O
Diff-connections O
) O
. O

DNA O
extraction O
and O
genetic O
variation O
detection O
Genomic O
DNA O
was O
isolated O
from O
peripheral O
blood O
lymphocytes O
using O
the O
QIAamp O
DNA O
Mini O
Kit O
( O
Qiagen O
, O
Valencia O
, O
CA O
, O
USA O
) O
. O

MassArray O
( O
Sequenom O
, O
San O
Diego O
, O
CA O
, O
USA O
) O
was O
used O
to O
genotype O
all O
markers O
using O
allele-specific O
Matrix-assisted O
laser O
desorption/ionization-time O
of O
flight O
mass O
spectrometry O
. O

Primers O
and O
multiplex O
reactions O
were O
designed O
using O
RealSNP.com O
website O
. O

None O
of O
the O
individual O
proportions O
significantly O
deviated O
from O
Hardy–Weinberg O
equilibrium O
( O
HWE O
) O
among O
HCs O
and O
HAs O
. O

The O
genotype O
call O
rate O
was O
> O
98 O
% O
for O
each O
SNP O
. O

Statistical O
analysis O
The O
statistical O
power O
of O
sample O
size O
computed O
by O
the O
Quanto O
soft O
( O
http O
: O
//biostats.usc.edu/Quanto.html O
) O
was O
higher O
than O
0.9 O
. O

The O
variances O
were O
similar O
between O
the O
groups O
that O
were O
being O
statistically O
compared O
. O

Two-sample O
t-test O
was O
used O
to O
determine O
differences O
in O
demographic O
and O
clinical O
characteristics O
using O
SPSS O
21.0 O
software O
. O

Each O
structural O
connection O
was O
compared O
between O
the O
HA O
and O
HC O
groups O
using O
10,000 O
non-parametric O
permutation O
tests O
based O
on O
two-sample O
t-test O
scores O
, O
with O
“ O
cigarettes O
smoked O
per O
day O
” O
and O
age O
as O
covariates O
. O

The O
threshold O
of O
Diff-connections O
was O
set O
at O
p O
< O
0.00018116 O
( O
0.05/276 O
) O
with O
multiple-comparison O
correction O
to O
identify O
statistically O
significant O
differences O
. O

The O
assessment O
of O
HWE O
was O
performed O
using O
the O
χ2 O
goodness-of-fit O
test O
. O

Additive O
linear O
regression O
was O
used O
for O
the O
association O
analysis O
of O
SNPs O
with O
structural O
connection O
, O
with O
“ O
cigarettes O
smoked O
per O
day O
” O
and O
age O
as O
covariates O
using O
PLINK O
. O

Linkage O
disequilibrium O
( O
LD O
) O
analyses O
were O
performed O
using O
Haploview O
4.1 O
( O
http O
: O
//www.broad.mit.edu/mpg/haploview/ O
) O
. O

The O
mediation O
analysis O
was O
performed O
using O
the O
model O
4 O
in O
PROCESS O
to O
bootstrap O
the O
sampling O
distribution O
of O
the O
indirect O
effect O
. O

An O
approach O
to O
directly O
link O
ICA O
and O
seed-based O
functional O
connectivity O
: O
application O
to O
schizophrenia O
Independent O
component O
analysis O
( O
ICA O
) O
and O
seed-based O
analyses O
are O
widely O
used O
techniques O
for O
studying O
intrinsic O
neuronal O
activity O
in O
task-based O
or O
resting O
scans O
. O

In O
this O
work O
, O
we O
show O
there O
is O
a O
direct O
link O
between O
the O
two O
, O
and O
show O
that O
there O
are O
some O
important O
differences O
between O
the O
two O
approaches O
in O
terms O
of O
what O
information O
they O
capture O
. O

We O
developed O
an O
enhanced O
connectivity-matrix O
independent O
component O
analysis O
( O
cmICA O
) O
for O
calculating O
whole O
brain O
voxel O
maps O
of O
functional O
connectivity O
, O
which O
reduces O
the O
computational O
complexity O
of O
voxel-based O
connectivity O
analysis O
on O
performing O
many O
temporal O
correlations O
. O

We O
also O
show O
there O
is O
a O
mathematical O
equivalency O
between O
parcellations O
on O
voxel-to-voxel O
functional O
connectivity O
and O
simplified O
cmICA O
. O

Next O
, O
we O
used O
this O
cost-efficient O
data-driven O
method O
to O
examine O
the O
resting O
state O
fMRI O
connectivity O
in O
schizophrenia O
patients O
( O
SZ O
) O
and O
healthy O
controls O
( O
HC O
) O
on O
a O
whole O
brain O
scale O
and O
further O
quantified O
the O
relationship O
between O
brain O
functional O
connectivity O
and O
cognitive O
performances O
measured O
by O
the O
Measurement O
and O
Treatment O
Research O
to O
Improve O
Cognition O
in O
Schizophrenia O
( O
MATRICS O
) O
battery O
. O

Current O
results O
suggest O
that O
SZ O
exhibit O
a O
wide-range O
abnormality O
, O
primarily O
a O
decrease O
, O
in O
functional O
connectivity O
both O
between O
networks O
and O
within O
different O
network O
hubs O
. O

Specific O
functional O
connectivity O
decreases O
were O
associated O
with O
MATRICS O
performance O
deficits O
. O

In O
addition O
, O
we O
found O
that O
resting O
state O
functional O
connectivity O
decreases O
was O
extensively O
associated O
with O
aging O
regardless O
of O
groups O
. O

In O
contrast O
, O
there O
was O
no O
relationship O
between O
positive O
and O
negative O
symptoms O
in O
the O
patients O
and O
functional O
connectivity O
. O

In O
sum O
, O
we O
have O
developed O
a O
novel O
mathematical O
relationship O
between O
ICA O
and O
seed-based O
connectivity O
that O
reduces O
computational O
complexity O
, O
which O
has O
broad O
applicability O
, O
and O
showed O
a O
specific O
application O
of O
this O
approach O
to O
characterize O
connectivity O
changes O
associated O
with O
cognitive O
scores O
in O
SZ O
. O

Methods O
1 O
. O

Theory O
We O
present O
a O
novel O
simplification O
of O
cmICA O
that O
is O
specifically O
applicable O
to O
fMRI O
data O
sets O
, O
when O
connectivity O
between O
two O
voxels O
is O
defined O
as O
the O
temporal O
cross-correlation O
between O
them O
. O

This O
simplification O
arises O
because O
the O
first O
step O
of O
ICA O
is O
principle O
component O
analysis O
( O
PCA O
) O
, O
and O
we O
show O
that O
PCA O
of O
a O
voxel-based O
connectivity O
map O
can O
be O
done O
directly O
based O
on O
the O
BOLD O
signal O
, O
without O
first O
calculating O
individual O
connectivity O
maps O
. O

Some O
of O
the O
advantages O
of O
cmICA O
and O
its O
meaning O
have O
been O
discussed O
previously O
in O
the O
context O
of O
diffusion O
imaging O
data O
, O
and O
these O
ideas O
apply O
here O
as O
well O
. O

Specifically O
, O
we O
will O
decompose O
each O
subject O
’ O
s O
voxel-wise O
brain O
connectivity O
matrix O
( O
C O
= O
ΣSkRk O
) O
into O
a O
sum O
of O
source O
regions O
( O
Sk O
) O
, O
and O
their O
respective O
connectivity O
maps O
( O
Rk O
) O
to O
the O
whole O
brain O
with O
that O
source O
. O

One O
limitation O
of O
the O
original O
cmICA O
algorithm O
is O
the O
high O
computational O
burden O
if O
employed O
on O
a O
voxel-wise O
basis O
for O
the O
whole O
brain O
, O
as O
it O
requires O
generating O
the O
entire O
connectivity O
matrix O
prior O
to O
the O
ICA O
decomposition O
as O
well O
as O
data O
reduction O
on O
a O
fairly O
large O
adjacency O
matrix O
for O
each O
subject O
. O

To O
calculate O
functional O
connectivity O
( O
temporal O
correlation O
) O
per O
voxel O
pairs O
from O
a O
standard O
3mm3 O
fMRI O
and O
store O
whole O
brain O
connectivity O
matrices O
would O
require O
1×109~2×109 O
times O
of O
correlation O
calculations O
and O
18~26GB O
of O
memory O
per O
subject O
, O
depending O
on O
the O
mask O
size O
. O

In O
practice O
, O
it O
is O
critical O
to O
optimize O
the O
algorithm O
in O
terms O
of O
calculation O
speed O
and O
memory O
cost O
. O

1 O
) O
Single O
subject O
optimization O
The O
original O
cmICA O
performed O
PCA/ICA O
directly O
on O
the O
brain O
connectivity O
matrix O
C O
, O
and O
parcellated O
it O
into O
spatially O
independent O
source O
maps O
S O
and O
corresponding O
connectivity O
profile O
maps O
R O
that O
define O
the O
connectivity O
of O
each O
source O
S O
to O
the O
whole O
brain O
, O
i.e. O
, O
C O
= O
RS O
. O

In O
the O
case O
of O
functional O
connectivity O
, O
each O
connectivity O
element O
in O
matrix O
C O
is O
carried O
out O
as O
a O
standard O
Pearson O
’ O
s O
correlation O
coefficient O
on O
temporal O
courses O
per O
voxel O
pair O
in O
fMRI O
BOLD O
signal O
. O

The O
connectivity O
matrix O
C O
( O
voxel×voxel O
) O
from O
BOLD O
data O
X O
( O
time×voxel O
) O
is O
where O
is O
the O
temporally O
normalized O
X O
for O
each O
voxel O
, O
where O
μx O
is O
the O
mean O
and O
σx O
is O
the O
standard O
deviation O
. O

A O
standard O
SVD/PCA O
analysis O
of O
gives O
( O
where O
U O
and O
V O
are O
the O
unitary O
matrices O
and O
Σ O
is O
the O
eigenvalue O
diagonal O
matrix O
) O
, O
which O
implies O
that O
. O

In O
other O
words O
PCA O
decomposition O
of O
C O
can O
be O
calculated O
from O
PCA O
of O
, O
importantly O
without O
calculating O
the O
connectivity O
matrix O
C. O
If O
W O
is O
ICA O
demixing O
matrix O
after O
ICA O
on O
the O
reduced O
dimension O
PCA O
output O
corresponding O
to O
U O
, O
then O
with O
C O
= O
RS O
, O
we O
have O
This O
clearly O
shows O
that O
an O
ICA O
decomposition O
of O
C O
can O
simply O
be O
derived O
from O
the O
PCA/ICA O
decomposition O
of O
without O
prior O
computation O
of O
functional O
connectivity O
matrix O
C O
( O
see O
in O
Appendix O
1 O
) O
. O

2 O
) O
Group O
level O
derivation O
The O
group-level O
cmICA O
adapts O
the O
same O
2-step O
PCA O
procedure O
as O
is O
typically O
used O
in O
group O
ICA O
, O
where O
it O
runs O
the O
standard O
1st O
PCA O
on O
individual O
subject O
, O
and O
concatenates O
the O
PCA O
results O
per O
subject O
to O
run O
the O
2nd O
PCA O
and O
ICA O
to O
compute O
the O
group O
maps O
. O

However O
, O
since O
the O
connectivity O
matrix O
C O
is O
not O
computed O
; O
the O
original O
group O
level O
cmICA O
’ O
s O
back-reconstruction O
has O
no O
individual O
input O
to O
project O
from O
. O

Therefore O
, O
it O
needs O
a O
new O
derivation O
accordingly O
. O

Here O
, O
we O
applied O
the O
similar O
GICA O
principle O
from O
previous O
work O
complemented O
by O
matching O
each O
subjects O
loadings/contributions O
to O
the O
final O
PCA/ICA O
, O
where O
it O
yielded O
. O

where O
is O
the O
reduced O
SVD/PCA O
result O
from O
single O
subject O
k O
, O
and O
is O
the O
reduced O
SVD/PCA O
result O
at O
concatenated O
group O
level O
where O
is O
the O
partition O
of O
for O
the O
subject O
k O
, O
and O
W O
is O
the O
demixing O
matrix O
in O
ICA O
decomposition O
. O

We O
chose O
GICA O
for O
back-reconstruction O
instead O
of O
other O
approaches O
, O
e.g. O
, O
dual O
regression O
, O
because O
it O
filters O
out O
the O
artifact O
( O
low O
PCA O
variance O
) O
contribution O
to O
the O
R O
maps O
Using O
this O
approach O
, O
cmICA O
for O
functional O
connectivity O
is O
now O
optimized O
to O
be O
to O
an O
execution O
of O
spatial O
ICA O
on O
normalized O
BOLD O
data O
, O
rather O
than O
on O
the O
original O
voxel-wise O
connectivity O
matrix O
. O

This O
eliminates O
the O
original O
limitation O
of O
high O
memory O
and O
computation O
costs O
. O

3 O
) O
cmICA O
maps O
as O
seeds O
for O
seed-based O
connectivity O
Seed-based O
approach O
for O
functional O
connectivity O
analysis O
requires O
creating O
seed O
regions O
first O
. O

The O
( O
average O
) O
time O
series O
of O
BOLD O
signal O
is O
extracted O
from O
the O
seed O
and O
the O
connectivity O
map O
is O
then O
computed O
by O
temporal O
correlating O
this O
reference O
time O
series O
with O
the O
time O
courses O
of O
all O
other O
brain O
voxels O
. O

However O
, O
there O
is O
no O
golden O
standard O
for O
seed O
selection O
and O
there O
are O
numerous O
options O
available O
. O

One O
option O
is O
to O
use O
the O
ICA O
source O
maps O
S O
as O
seeding O
regions O
or O
to O
use O
seed O
regions O
as O
constraints O
in O
a O
spatial O
ICA O
analysis O
. O

In O
optimized O
cmICA O
for O
functional O
connectivity O
analysis O
, O
the O
derived O
source O
maps O
S O
can O
be O
interpreted O
as O
“ O
seed O
” O
regions O
. O

Since O
in O
spatial O
ICA O
, O
the O
temporal O
component O
T O
represents O
each O
S O
map O
’ O
s O
common O
time O
course O
, O
the O
connectivity O
map O
for O
each O
seed O
region O
S O
can O
be O
computed O
as O
the O
temporal O
correlation O
between O
the O
representative O
time O
course O
T O
and O
all O
brain O
BOLD O
time O
series O
. O

i.e. O
, O
a O
seed-based O
correlation O
map O
is O
equivalent O
to O
a O
( O
normalized O
) O
connectivity O
map O
R O
in O
cmICA O
, O
using O
an O
ICA-defined O
source O
as O
seed O
. O

We O
revisit O
this O
topic O
in O
the O
Discussion O
. O

In O
cmICA O
, O
S O
and O
R O
maps O
represent O
two O
different O
spatial O
components O
, O
which O
has O
been O
interpreted O
in O
extensively O
. O

S O
maps O
define O
the O
spatial O
segregations O
of O
connectivity O
restricted O
by O
statistical O
independence O
, O
whose O
distributions O
are O
relatively O
sparse O
, O
( O
i.e. O
, O
super-Gaussian O
) O
. O

S O
are O
also O
more O
consistent O
across O
different O
individuals O
, O
mental O
status O
( O
task/rest O
) O
and O
disease O
states O
. O

R O
maps O
, O
the O
loadings O
in O
ICA O
, O
define O
the O
shared O
connectivity O
maps O
using O
the O
corresponding O
S O
regions O
as O
“ O
seeds O
” O
, O
without O
spatial O
independence O
or O
stationary O
constraints O
. O

Therefore O
, O
R O
maps O
are O
less O
sparse O
and O
may O
capture O
more O
inter-subject O
variability O
. O

An O
inter-subject O
variability O
test O
of O
S O
and O
R O
was O
conducted O
in O
Appendix O
2 O
. O

2 O
. O

Subjects O
Subjects O
were O
recruited O
via O
a O
Center O
of O
Biomedical O
Research O
Excellence O
( O
COBRE O
, O
http O
: O
//cobre.mrn.org O
) O
program O
at O
the O
Mind O
Research O
Network O
. O

In O
this O
paper O
, O
we O
used O
fMRI O
data O
from O
the O
same O
group O
of O
SZ O
subjects O
( O
n O
= O
60 O
, O
age O
= O
38.6 O
± O
3.4 O
years O
) O
and O
HC O
subjects O
( O
n O
= O
61 O
, O
age O
= O
35.0 O
± O
10.5 O
years O
) O
that O
we O
previously O
studied O
for O
diffusion O
imaging O
. O

Four O
SZ O
and O
three O
HC O
subjects O
were O
excluded O
( O
5 O
without O
fMRI O
collections O
and O

) O

COBRE O
data O
is O
also O
shared O
via O

COINS O
data O
exchange O
( O

//coins.mrn.org/dx O
) O

Each O

provided O

consent O
according O
to O
guidelines O
at O
the O
University O
of O
New O
Mexico O
and O
compensated O
for O

. O

Prior O
to O

the O

, O

to O
ensure O

( O

) O

) O
. O

Structural O
clinical O

for O

( O

) O
and O
case O
file O
reviews O
confirmed O
diagnosis O
of O

for O
the O
patients O
. O

The O
specific O
clinical O
screening O
protocol O
can O
be O
referred O
to O
our O
recent O
work O
, O
SZ O
and O

subject O
groups O
did O
not O
differ O
in O
age O
( O
p=0.11 O
) O
, O

( O

, O

( O

( O

) O

a O
less O
biased O

. O

1 O
provides O
demographic O

. O

3 O
. O

Cognitive O
and O
clinical O
assessment O
All O
assessments O
were O
performed O
within O
1 O
week O
of O
the O
scan O
date O
. O

Three O
cognitive O
assessments O
were O
collected O
in O
all O
subjects O
. O

1 O
) O
The O
WTAR O
was O
conducted O
to O
provide O
a O
measure O
of O
premorbid O
intelligence O
for O
neuropsychological O
evaluation O
. O

The O
age-standardized O
score O
was O
used O
for O
this O
study O
. O

2 O
) O
WASI-II O
battery O
was O
chosen O
for O
intelligence O
evaluation O
. O

The O
standardized O
full O
scale O
IQ O
, O
calculated O
from O
four O
subtests O
( O
vocabulary O
, O
similarities O
, O
block O
design O
and O
matrix O
reasoning O
) O
, O
was O
used O
for O
this O
current O
study O
. O

3 O
) O
MATRICS O
is O
a O
cognition O
measure O
specifically O
designed O
for O
patients O
diagnosed O
with O
schizophrenia O
and O
related O
disorders O
. O

The O
composite O
T-score O
, O
summarized O
from O
seven O
cognitive O
domains O
( O
speed O
of O
processing O
, O
attention/vigilance O
, O
working O
memory O
, O
verbal O
learning O
, O
visual O
learning O
, O
reasoning O
and O
problem O
solving O
, O
and O
social O
cognition O
) O
were O
used O
. O

All O
sub-category O
scores O
are O
provided O
in O
the O
Supplemental O
A O
. O

In O
addition O
, O
the O
Positive O
and O
Negative O
Syndrome O
Scale O
( O
PANSS O
) O
was O
collected O
for O
all O
SZ O
, O
with O
the O
positive O
, O
negative O
and O
general O
psychopathology O
subscales O
used O
in O
the O
current O
study O
. O

4 O
. O

Data O
acquisition O
and O
preprocessing O
All O
participants O
were O
scanned O
on O
a O
3Tesla O
Siemens O
TIM O
trio O
equipped O
with O
12-channel O
radio O
frequency O
coil O
at O
MRN O
. O

Subjects O
were O
instructed O
to O
fixate O
on O
a O
central O
cross O
hair O
presented O
with O
eyes O
open O
at O
rest O
. O

Resting O
state O
functional O
scans O
were O
collected O
by O
means O
of O
T2 O
* O
-weighted O
gradient O
echo O
planar O
imaging O
sequences O
at O
5 O
minutes O
long O
, O
150 O
volumes O
with O
the O
following O
parameters O
: O
repeat O
time O
( O
TR O
) O
= O
2s O
, O
echo O
time O
( O
TE O
) O
= O
29ms O
, O
field O
of O
view O
= O
240mm O
, O
acquisition O
matrix O
= O
64×64 O
, O
flip O
angle O
= O
75° O
, O
voxel O
size O
= O
3.75×3.75×4.55mm3 O
, O
gap O
= O
1.05mm O
, O
33 O
slices O
, O
ascending O
acquisition O
. O

A O
high-resolution O
structural O
anatomy O
was O
also O
acquired O
via O
a O
3D O
MPRAGE O
T1 O
sequence O
( O
sagittal O
; O
matrix O
, O
256×256 O
; O
FOV O
, O
256 O
mm O
; O
slice O
thickness O
, O
1 O
mm O
; O
no O
gap O
; O
in-plane O
voxel O
size O
, O
1 O
mm×1 O
mm O
; O
flip O
angle O
, O
7° O
; O
TR O
, O
2.53 O
s O
; O
TE O
, O
1.64 O
ms O
) O
to O
provide O
the O
anatomical O
reference O
for O
the O
functional O
scan O
. O

FMRI O
data O
were O
preprocessed O
using O
the O
software O
package O
SPM8 O
. O

The O
first O
five O
image O
volumes O
were O
removed O
to O
avoid O
T1 O
equilibration O
effects O
. O

Images O
were O
then O
realigned O
using O
INRI O
align O
– O
a O
motion O
correction O
algorithm O
unbiased O
by O
local O
signal O
changes O
. O

Slice O
timing O
was O
corrected O
using O
the O
middle O
slice O
as O
the O
reference O
frame O
. O

Next O
, O
data O
were O
spatially O
normalized O
into O
standard O
Montreal O
Neurological O
Institute O
space O
, O
spatially O
smoothed O
with O
a O
5mm O
full O
width O
at O
half-maximum O
Gaussian O
kernel O
and O
sub-sampled O
to O
3×3×3 O
mm O
, O
resulting O
in O
a O
total O
of O
53×63×46 O
voxels O
. O

The O
data O
were O
also O
detrended O
and O
temporal O
band-pass O
filtered O
from O
0.001 O
to O
0.15 O
Hz O
to O
remove O
non-spontaneous O
artefacts O
( O
scanner O
drift O
, O
slow O
vascular/metabolic O
oscillation O
) O
and O
other O
high O
frequency O
noises O
( O
motion O
, O
breathing O
, O
heartbeat O
) O
, O
and O
to O
be O
as O
close O
to O
the O
resting-state O
“ O
low O
frequency O
fluctuation O
” O
. O

The O
potential O
impact O
of O
temporal O
filtering O
on O
ICA O
results O
were O
investigated O
( O
see O
Supplemental O
B O
) O
. O

Last O
, O
voxel O
time O
courses O
were O
normalized O
for O
the O
purpose O
of O
the O
cmICA O
optimization O
. O

As O
temporal O
variance O
normalization O
minimizes O
the O
possible O
bias O
in O
subsequent O
data O
reduction O
, O
it O
is O
usually O
preferred O
for O
connectivity O
and/or O
temporal O
modulation O
analysis O
. O

5. O
cmICA O
model O
order O
selection O
In O
our O
original O
cmICA O
paper O
for O
diffusion O
connectivity O
, O
we O
explored O
both O
low O
( O
Nc O
= O
30 O
) O
and O
high O
( O
Nc O
= O
100 O
) O
model O
order O
, O
and O
found O
the O
low O
model O
order O
matched O
better O
with O
the O
JHU O
tract O
atlas O
. O

In O
this O
study O
, O
we O
chose O
a O
medium O
model O
order O
( O
Nc O
= O
50 O
) O
for O
cmICA O
after O
multiple O
tests O
and O
comparisons O
for O
the O
following O
reasons O
. O

First O
, O
functional O
data O
contains O
larger O
variance O
than O
structural O
data O
, O
in O
both O
noise O
level O
and O
physiological O
signal O
level O
. O

Second O
, O
structural O
connectivity O
from O
diffusion O
imaging O
( O
a O
very O
sparse O
matrix O
) O
is O
much O
more O
localized O
than O
functional O
connectivity O
( O
a O
non-sparse O
matrix O
) O
. O

Third O
, O
high/medium O
model O
order O
provides O
a O
finer-grained O
regional O
separation O
of O
sources O
in O
the O
cortical O
and O
subcortical O
compartments O
. O

We O
chose O
medium O
order O
over O
high O
order O
, O
70-100 O
typically O
used O
in O
fMRI O
spatial O
ICA O
literatures O
, O
because O
temporal O
filtering O
in O
the O
initial O
preprocessing O
removes O
considerable O
variance O
associated O
with O
the O
non- O
“ O
low-frequency O
fluctuation O
” O
( O
LFF O
) O
artefacts O
( O
see O
detailed O
model O
order O
estimation O
in O
Appendix O
3 O
) O
. O

To O
ensure O
the O
validity O
of O
model O
order O
selection O
on O
our O
dataset O
, O
ICASSO O
with O
20 O
re-runs O
and O
random O
initial O
conditions O
, O
was O
used O
to O
test O
the O
convergence O
during O
ICA O
training O
and O
the O
stability O
and O
the O
“ O
best O
run O
” O
was O
selected O
to O
provide O
a O
robust O
and O
replicable O
result O
using O
a O
minimum O
spanning O
tree O
( O
MST O
) O
method O
introduced O
in O
and O
implemented O
in O
the O
GIFT O
toolbox O
. O

After O
cmICA O
, O
data O
was O
decomposed O
into O
functional O
source O
maps O
S O
and O
corresponding O
connectivity O
maps O
R. O
The O
resulting O
50 O
independent O
source O
maps O
were O
manually O
evaluated O
using O
existing O
procedures O
with O
motion O
, O
imaging O
and O
physiological O
artefact O
removal O
( O
including O
mixed O
components O
consisting O
of O
artifact O
and O
RSN O
sources O
, O
see O
Supplemental O
F O
for O
details O
) O
, O
yielding O
28 O
resting O
state O
network O
( O
RSN O
) O
components O
for O
further O
study O
. O

6 O
. O

Connectivity O
group O
difference O
analysis O
As O
in O
, O
we O
observed O
that O
the O
cmICA O
back-reconstructed O
source O
S O
maps O
- O
the O
“ O
seeds O
” O
- O
were O
fairly O
stable O
among O
individuals O
while O
the O
dual O
connectivity O
R O
maps O
maintained O
more O
variability O
. O

This O
is O
mainly O
because O
of O
the O
spatial O
stationarity O
assumption O
on O
S O
across O
subjects O
on O
spatial O
ICA O
, O
whereas O
R O
maps O
, O
i.e. O
, O
the O
mixing O
matrix O
in O
ICA O
, O
have O
no O
explicit O
statistical/mathematical O
restrictions O
. O

Prior O
to O
statistical O
analysis O
, O
the O
normality O
tests O
( O
see O
Supplemental O
C O
) O
were O
performed O
on O
back-reconstructed O
maps O
to O
ensure O
the O
Student O
t-tests O
and/or O
linear O
regressions O
were O
the O
suitable O
statistical O
approach O
. O

We O
then O
examined O
S O
and O
R O
maps O
’ O
group O
differences O
between O
SZ O
and O
HC O
separately O
via O
simple O
two O
sample O
T-tests O
as O
a O
pre-screening O
step O
. O

We O
found O
that O
the O
S O
maps O
did O
not O
show O
any O
statistically O
significant O
differences O
at O
p O
* O
smaller O
than O
0.05 O
with O
FDR O
multiple O
comparison O
correction O
at O
whole O
brain O
level O
and O
cluster O
extent O
larger O
than O
20 O
voxels O
, O
while O
a O
greater O
proportion O
of O
cells O
in O
the O
R O
maps O
showed O
group O
differences O
. O

It O
is O
important O
to O
notice O
that O
the O
inter-subject O
variability O
on O
source O
maps O
S O
may O
still O
be O
detectable O
in O
many O
cases O
which O
have O
been O
explored O
extensively O
in O
, O
but O
in O
this O
study O
it O
didn O
’ O
t O
pass O
the O
significance O
test O
. O

Therefore O
, O
the O
following O
( O
demographic/cognitive/clinical O
) O
multivariate O
regression O
analyses O
were O
conducted O
on O
connectivity O
R O
maps O
( O
per O
voxel O
) O
only O
. O

This O
agrees O
with O
previous O
findings O
from O
, O
that O
independent O
S O
maps O
partial O
out O
the O
variances O
across O
subjects O
( O
or O
task O
conditions O
) O
significantly O
, O
whereas O
R O
maps O
( O
or O
seed O
based O
maps O
) O
would O
keep O
those O
variances O
. O

This O
results O
in O
S O
maps O
being O
less O
dependent O
on O
individual O
variabilities O
and O
external-induced O
co-activations O
( O
see O
Appendix O
2 O
) O
. O

Next O
, O
different O
demographic O
factors O
were O
investigated O
as O
covariates O
on O
functional O
connectivity O
R. O
Previous O
studies O
have O
indicated O
effects O
of O
age O
and O
gender O
on O
resting O
state O
functional O
connectivity O
. O

Age O
effects O
were O
also O
found O
in O
same O
set O
of O
subjects O
from O
our O
previous O
work O
in O
structural O
connectivity O
. O

In O
this O
study O
, O
we O
first O
used O
a O
backward O
multivariate O
model O
selection O
procedure O
to O
check O
the O
impact O
of O
different O
demographic O
factors O
by O
performing O
a O
multivariate O
analysis O
of O
covariance O
( O
MANCOVAN O
, O
http O
: O
//www.mathworks.com/matlabcentral/fileexchange/27014-mancovan O
) O
on O
effects O
of O
age O
, O
gender O
( O
male O
0 O
, O
female O
1 O
) O
, O
social O
economic O
status O
( O
SES O
, O
education O
, O
and O
parental O
education O
) O
and O
group O
label O
( O
SZ O
1 O
HC O
0 O
) O
, O
as O
well O
as O
their O
interactions O
to O
detect O
which O
predictor O
( O
s O
) O
in O
the O
design O
matrix O
showed O
variabilities O
in O
the O
response O
. O

In O
addition O
, O
potential O
motion O
effects O
on O
functional O
connectivity O
were O
also O
examined O
by O
including O
motion O
nuisance O
parameters O
( O
x O
, O
y O
, O
and O
z O
translations O
and O
pitch O
, O
roll O
, O
and O
yaw O
rotations O
) O
from O
SPM O
INRIalign O
motion O
estimations O
and O
by O
adding O
additional O
motion O
cleaning O
, O
e.g O
. O

data O
despiking O
. O

No O
significant O
motion O
effect O
was O
found O
in O
either O
case O
( O
see O
Supplemental O
D O
) O
. O

This O
is O
likely O
because O
the O
motion O
residuals O
are O
reduced O
via O
the O
initial O
temporal O
filtering O
and O
the O
removal O
of O
motion-related O
artifacts O
via O
spatial O
ICA O
, O
and O
because O
of O
the O
low O
correlations O
between O
motion O
parameters O
and O
regressors O
in O
design O
matrix O
. O

The O
final O
regressions O
were O
only O
performed O
on O
retained O
regressor O
( O
s O
) O
in O
order O
to O
decrease O
the O
degrees O
of O
freedom O
used O
in O
the O
MANCOVAN O
computation O
. O

7 O
. O

Multivariate O
analysis O
on O
cognition O
and O
clinical O
assessment O
During O
the O
regression O
analysis O
on O
various O
cognitive O
performances O
, O
we O
noticed O
a O
high O
multicollinearity O
( O
Tolerance O
< O
0.2 O
, O
variance O
inflation O
factor O
> O
5 O
) O
among O
WTAR O
, O
WASI O
and O
MATRICS O
due O
to O
the O
high O
correlations O
( O
r O
= O
0.59~0.7 O
) O
among O
these O
three O
variables O
. O

Without O
proper O
model O
selection O
, O
this O
may O
lead O
to O
invalid O
estimation O
in O
individual O
responses O
. O

To O
ensure O
prediction O
accuracy O
, O
we O
first O
tested O
effects O
on O
three O
cognitive O
scores O
without O
differentiating O
group O
types O
, O
searching O
for O
significant O
effects O
associated O
with O
function O
connectivity O
. O

We O
also O
tested O
effects O
on O
three O
group O
interaction O
terms O
( O
group×WTAR O
, O
group×WASI O
, O
and O
group×MATRICS O
) O
looking O
for O
disease-related O
regressor O
( O
s O
) O
associated O
with O
functional O
connectivity O
changes O
. O

The O
final O
regression O
was O
only O
performed O
on O
the O
most O
significant O
covariates O
and O
collinearity O
safe O
model O
( O
Variance O
inflation O
factor O
( O
VIF O
) O
< O
5 O
) O
M O
= O
( O
group O
, O
age O
, O
WTAR O
, O
WASI O
, O
and O
MATRICS O
) O
, O
OZP O
was O
removed O
due O
to O
no O
significant O
effects O
and O
no O
significant O
impacts O
on O
WTAR/WASI/MATRICS O
’ O
responses O
. O

Similarly O
, O
in O
symptom-based O
analysis O
, O
PANSS O
general O
psychopathology O
score O
were O
correlated O
with O
positive O
and O
negative O
scores O
( O
r O
= O
0.51 O
, O
0.35 O
) O
. O

The O
general O
score O
was O
removed O
in O
regression O
model O
due O
to O
the O
high O
multicollinearity O
( O
VIF O
> O
5 O
) O
, O
and O
the O
final O
regression O
model O
was O
M O
= O
[ O
group O
, O
age O
, O
PANSS O
POS O
, O
PANSS O
NEG O
, O
and O
OZP O
] O
. O

All O
tests O
are O
attached O
in O
Supplemental O
E. O
The O
detected O
regions O
were O
adjusted O
using O
the O
same O
significance O
test O
as O
before O
. O

In O
addition O
, O
we O
examined O
the O
impact O
of O
patients O
’ O
medication O
usage O
( O
using O
total O
OZP O
dose O
equivalence O
) O
on O
MATRICS O
and O
PANSS O
performances O
as O
well O
as O
on O
functional O
connectivity O
, O
since O
it O
has O
been O
reported O
that O
medications O
have O
large O
impact O
on O
symptoms O
and/or O
cognitions O
, O
which O
may O
potentially O
affect O
functional O
dysconnectivity O
associations O
. O

Multimodal O
neuromarkers O
in O
schizophrenia O
via O
cognition-guided O
MRI O
fusion O
Cognitive O
impairment O
is O
a O
feature O
of O
many O
psychiatric O
diseases O
, O
including O
schizophrenia O
. O

Here O
we O
aim O
to O
identify O
multimodal O
biomarkers O
for O
quantifying O
and O
predicting O
cognitive O
performance O
in O
individuals O
with O
schizophrenia O
and O
healthy O
controls O
. O

A O
supervised O
learning O
strategy O
is O
used O
to O
guide O
three-way O
multimodal O
magnetic O
resonance O
imaging O
( O
MRI O
) O
fusion O
in O
two O
independent O
cohorts O
including O
both O
healthy O
individuals O
and O
individuals O
with O
schizophrenia O
using O
multiple O
cognitive O
domain O
scores O
. O

Results O
highlight O
the O
salience O
network O
( O
gray O
matter O
, O
GM O
) O
, O
corpus O
callosum O
( O
fractional O
anisotropy O
, O
FA O
) O
, O
central O
executive O
and O
default-mode O
networks O
( O
fractional O
amplitude O
of O
low-frequency O
fluctuation O
, O
fALFF O
) O
as O
modality-specific O
biomarkers O
of O
generalized O
cognition O
. O

FALFF O
features O
are O
found O
to O
be O
more O
sensitive O
to O
cognitive O
domain O
differences O
, O
while O
the O
salience O
network O
in O
GM O
and O
corpus O
callosum O
in O
FA O
are O
highly O
consistent O
and O
predictive O
of O
multiple O
cognitive O
domains O
. O

These O
modality-specific O
brain O
regions O
define—in O
three O
separate O
cohorts—promising O
co-varying O
multimodal O
signatures O
that O
can O
be O
used O
as O
predictors O
of O
multi-domain O
cognition O
. O

Cognitive O
impairment O
is O
a O
feature O
of O
many O
psychiatric O
diseases O
. O

Here O
the O
authors O
aimed O
to O
identify O
multimodal O
neuromarkers O
that O
can O
be O
used O
to O
quantify O
and O
predict O
cognitive O
performance O
in O
individuals O
with O
schizophrenia O
using O
three O
different O
features O
of O
MRI O
and O
three O
independent O
cohorts O
. O

Methods O
Multimodal O
fusion O
with O
reference O
Based O
on O
supervised O
learning O
, O
we O
previously O
have O
developed O
a O
reference-guided O
fusion O
model O
called O
MCCAR O
+ O
jICA O
. O

Assume O
Xk O
represents O
multimodal O
dataset O
and O
each O
is O
a O
linear O
mixture O
of O
components O
Ck O
with O
a O
nonsingular O
mixing O
matrix O
Ak O
, O
k O
= O
1 O
, O
2 O
, O
3 O
, O
denoting O
the O
modality O
. O

Namely O
, O
Xk O
= O
AkCk O
, O
where O
Xk O
is O
a O
subjects-by-voxels O
feature O
matrix O
and O
Ak O
is O
a O
subjects O
by O
number O
of O
components O
( O
M O
) O
mixing O
matrix O
. O

MCCA O
with O
reference O
( O
MCCAR O
) O
imposes O
an O
additional O
constraint O
to O
maximize O
not O
only O
the O
covariations O
among O
loadings O
of O
each O
modality O
, O
but O
also O
the O
column-wise O
correlations O
between O
Ak O
and O
the O
reference O
signal O
, O
as O
shown O
in O
Eq O
. O

( O
3 O
) O
.where O
ref O
is O
an O
N O
× O
1 O
vector O
, O
denoting O
the O
referred O
measure O
, O
N O
is O
the O
subject O
number O
. O

corr O
( O
Ak O
, O
Aj O
) O
is O
the O
column-wise O
correlation O
between O
Ak O
and O
Aj O
, O
and O
corr O
( O
Ak O
, O
ref O
) O
is O
the O
column-wise O
correlation O
between O
Ak O
and O
ref O
. O

After O
optimization O
by O
MCCAR O
, O
we O
can O
obtain O
the O
potential O
target O
components O
Ci O
that O
are O
correlated O
with O
ref O
in O
each O
modality O
, O
as O
well O
as O
being O
most O
correlated O
across O
subjects O
between O
modalities O
. O

Then O
joint O
ICA O
is O
further O
applied O
to O
on O
the O
concatenated O
maps O
of O
[ O
C1 O
, O
… O
, O
CM O
] O
, O
in O
order O
to O
keep O
the O
modality O
linkage O
of O
the O
potential O
target O
components O
and O
maximize O
the O
spatial O
independence O
. O

The O
final O
independent O
components O
( O
ICs O
) O
Sk O
, O
along O
with O
their O
mixing O
matrices O
Dk O
are O
obtained O
by O
linear O
source O
decomposition.Among O
Sk O
, O
one O
or O
more O
joint O
independent O
components O
( O
ICs O
) O
that O
are O
specifically O
correlated O
with O
the O
ref O
will O
be O
identified O
as O
the O
target O
ICref O
. O

Therefore O
, O
by O
incorporating O
prior O
information O
, O
MCCAR O
+ O
jICA O
enables O
identification O
of O
a O
joint O
multimodal O
component O
( O
s O
) O
that O
has O
robust O
correlations O
within O
referred O
measures O
and O
amongst O
themselves O
( O
inter-modality O
correlations O
) O
, O
which O
may O
not O
be O
detected O
by O
a O
blind O
N-way O
multimodal O
fusion O
approach O
. O

For O
more O
details O
, O
please O
refer O
to O
our O
method O
paper O
on O
MCCAR O
+ O
jICA O
and O
λ O
tuning O
for O
Supplementary O
Note O
5 O
. O

Here O
the O
cognition-guided O
fusion O
analyses O
were O
implemented O
by O
feeding O
the O
preprocessed O
MRI O
features O
( O
i.e. O
, O
GM O
density O
from O
sMRI O
, O
FA O
from O
dMRI O
and O
fALFF O
from O
resting-state O
fMRI O
) O
into O
MCCAR O
+ O
jICA O
, O
as O
displayed O
in O
Fig O
. O

9a O
and O
b O
. O

We O
sought O
to O
investigate O
the O
target O
joint O
independent O
components O
( O
ICref O
) O
that O
are O
not O
only O
significantly O
correlated O
with O
referred O
cognitive O
scores O
, O
such O
as O
CMINDS O
composite O
, O
MCCB O
composite O
or O
CMINDS O
domain O
scores O
, O
but O
also O
indicated O
significant O
linked O
functional–anatomical–structural O
alterations O
between O
schizophrenia O
and O
controls O
, O
i.e. O
, O
group-discriminative O
. O

Predictive O
neuromarker O
extraction O
After O
identifying O
multimodal O
networks O
of O
four O
CMINDS O
cognitive O
domains O
from O
the O
FBIRN O
data O
( O
Fig O
. O

9c O
, O
d O
) O
, O
we O
extracted O
the O
brain O
regions O
which O
were O
consistently O
involved O
within O
each O
modality O
as O
potential O
neuromarkers O
. O

Take O
the O
feature O
extraction O
of O
GM O
as O
an O
example O
. O

After O
converting O
component O
GM_ICref O
into O
Z O
scores O
and O
thresholding O
at O
|Z| O
> O
= O
2 O
, O
masks O
of O
GM_ICref O
for O
each O
of O
the O
four O
cognitive O
domains O
( O
composite O
, O
attention O
, O
working O
memory O
and O
verbal O
learning O
) O
were O
generated O
. O

A O
map O
of O
regions O
included O
in O
each O
of O
these O
four O
GM O
masks O
reveals O
the O
common O
ROIs O
across O
the O
four O
cognitive O
domains O
. O

The O
final O
GM O
mask O
of O
GM_SAN O
is O
shown O
in O
Fig O
. O

7a O
. O

This O
mask O
of O
GM O
was O
then O
used O
to O
extract O
ROI O
features O
from O
every O
subject O
. O

The O
mean O
of O
the O
voxels O
within O
the O
obtained O
ROI O
was O
calculated O
for O
each O
subject O
, O
generating O
a O
N O
subj O
× O
1 O
feature O
vector O
for O
GM_SAN O
. O

The O
other O
modalities O
( O
dMRI O
and O
fMRI O
) O
were O
processed O
in O
the O
same O
way O
to O
get O
the O
FA_CC O
and O
fALFF_PFC O
feature O
vectors O
. O

The O
fourth O
fALFF_pDMN O
feature O
was O
extracted O
from O
fALFF_ICref_composite O
from O
the O
FBIRN O
data O
. O

The O
resulting O
regions O
were O
those O
included O
in O
the O
triple O
network O
hypothesis O
. O

Finally O
, O
we O
formed O
a O
feature O
matrix O
in O
dimension O
of O
N O
subj O
× O
4 O
for O
the O
FBIRN O
data O
. O

For O
the O
UNM O
and O
COBRE O
cohorts O
, O
the O
ROI O
features O
of O
each O
modality O
were O
extracted O
by O
applying O
the O
four O
masks O
generated O
from O
the O
FBIRN O
to O
the O
UNM O
and O
COBRE O
data O
. O

Following O
this O
, O
the O
mean O
of O
each O
ROI O
was O
calculated O
for O
each O
subject O
, O
resulting O
in O
a O
N O
subj O
× O
4 O
feature O
matrix O
for O
the O
UNM O
and O
COBRE O
cohorts O
, O
respectively O
. O

Multiple O
linear O
regression O
After O
neuromarker O
extraction O
, O
for O
the O
FBIRN O
data O
, O
each O
of O
the O
four O
neuromarker O
vector O
was O
normalized O
to O
mean O
= O
0 O
, O
std O
= O
1 O
. O

These O
vectors O
were O
then O
treated O
as O
the O
linear O
regressors O
and O
the O
corresponding O
cognitive O
scores O
were O
treated O
as O
the O
targeted O
measures O
; O
together O
, O
they O
were O
input O
into O
the O
multiple O
linear O
regression O
model O
to O
obtain O
a O
linear O
equation O
for O
an O
estimate O
of O
the O
target O
measures O
. O

The O
same O
regression O
model O
( O
beta O
weights O
) O
achieved O
from O
the O
FBIRN O
prediction O
was O
then O
applied O
to O
the O
regressors O
obtained O
from O
UNM O
and O
COBRE O
data O
. O

Pearson O
correlations O
between O
true O
and O
predicted O
cognitive O
scores O
of O
each O
domain O
were O
assessed O
, O
as O
seen O
in O
Figs O
. O

7 O
, O
8 O
and O
9e O
. O

Based O
on O
the O
CMINDS O
regression O
model O
obtained O
from O
FBIRN O
cohort O
, O
if O
the O
estimated O
MCCB O
scores O
of O
UNM O
and O
COBRE O
cohorts O
are O
significantly O
correlated O
with O
the O
true O
MCCB O
scores O
, O
the O
generalization O
of O
predictability O
of O
cognition O
based O
on O
the O
four O
selected O
neuromarkers O
can O
be O
recognized O
to O
some O
degree O
. O

The O
beta O
weights O
of O
linear O
regression O
models O
for O
each O
predicted O
cognitive O
domain O
are O
displayed O
in O
Fig O
. O

8 O
. O

Participants O

independent O
data O

were O
used O
in O
this O
study O
. O

One O
is O
recruited O
from O
FBIRN O
phase O

datasets O
including O
147 O

( O

× O

( O

× O
11 O
) O
that O
were O
matched O
for O
gender O
, O
age O
, O
handedness O
and O
race O
distributions O
. O

The O
demographic O
and O

information O
are O
summarized O
in O
Supplementary O
Table O
10 O
. O

All O
subjects O
were O

from O

( O

of O

, O

, O

of O

, O

of O

and O

. O

Each O
dataset O
included O
diagnosis O
, O

at O
time O
of O
scan O
, O
gender O
, O
illness O
duration O
, O

when O

, O
which O
were O
shared O
by O
each O

group O
according O
to O
their O
site O
’ O

protocols O
. O

Inclusion O
criteria O
required O
all O
participants O
to O
be O
adults O
between O
the O
ages O
of O
18 O
and O
65 O
years O
. O

of O

was O
confirmed O
by O
trained O
raters O
using O
the O
Structured O
Clinical O
Interview O
for O
DSM-IV O
( O

) O
. O

All O
patients O
were O
on O
a O
stable O
dose O
of O
antipsychotic O
medication O
either O
typical O
, O
atypical O
, O
or O
a O

for O
at O

2 O
months O
. O

Detailed O
medication O
information O
could O
be O

8 O
. O

Symptom O
severity O
was O
rated O
using O

. O

All O

were O
clinically O
stable O
at O
the O
time O
of O
scanning O
. O

In O
addition O
, O

participants O
were O
excluded O
for O
past O
or O
current O

illness O
based O
on O

or O

of O

. O
