Imaging O
parameters O
The O
resting-state O
fMRI O
data O
for O
the O
FBIRN O
cohort O
was O
collected O
on O
six O
3T O
Siemens O
and O
one O
3T O
General O
Electric O
( O
GE O
) O
scanner O
. O

The O
imaging O
protocol O
for O
the O
resting-state O
scans O
at O
all O
sites O
was O
the O
same O
: O
a O
T2∗-weighted O
AC-PC O
aligned O
echo O
planar O
imaging O
sequence O
( O
TR O
= O
2 O
s O
, O
TE O
= O
30 O
ms O
, O
flip O
angle O
= O
77° O
, O
3.4 O
× O
3.4 O
× O
4 O
mm O
with O
1 O
mm O
gap O
, O
162 O
frames O
, O
5:38 O
min O
) O
. O

For O
the O
resting O
scan O
, O
subjects O
were O
instructed O
to O
lie O
still O
with O
eyes O
closed O
. O

DMRI O
data O
for O
the O
FBIRN O
cohort O
were O
also O
acquired O
on O
six O
3T O
Siemens O
and O
one O
3T O
GE O
. O

All O
parameters O
for O
these O
two O
scanners O
were O
the O
same O
except O
for O
TE O
( O
Siemens O
: O
84 O
ms O
, O
GE O
: O
81.7 O
ms O
) O
. O

The O
rest O
of O
the O
parameters O
for O
both O
Siemens O
and O
GE O
were O
as O
follows O
: O
TR O
= O
9 O
s O
; O
field O
of O
view O
( O
FOV O
) O
= O
256 O
× O
256 O
mm O
; O
slice O
thickness O
= O
2 O
mm O
; O
number O
of O
slices O
= O
72 O
; O
slice O
gap O
= O
2 O
mm O
; O
voxel O
resolution O
2 O
× O
2 O
× O
2 O
mm O
; O
flip O
angle O
= O
90° O
; O
number O
of O
diffusion O
gradient O
directions O
= O
30 O
, O
b O
= O
800 O
seconds/mm2 O
, O
and O
5 O
measurements O
with O
b O
= O
0 O
. O

All O
images O
were O
registered O
to O
the O
first O
b O
= O
0 O
image O
by O
FMRIB O
Linear O
Image O
Registration O
Tool O
( O
FLIRT O
: O
http O
: O
//fsl.fmrib.ox.ac.uk/fsl/fslwiki/FLIRT O
) O
. O

High-resolution O
T1-weighted O
brain O
imaging O
data O
for O
the O
FBIRN O
cohort O
were O
also O
acquired O
on O
six O
3 O
T O
Siemens O
and O
one O
3T O
GE O
. O

Siemens O
scan O
parameters O
were O
TR O
= O
2.3 O
s O
, O
TE O
= O
2.94 O
ms O
, O
flip O
angle O
= O
9° O
, O
resolution O
= O
256 O
× O
256 O
× O
160 O
. O

GE O
scan O
parameters O
were O
TR O
= O
5.95 O
s O
, O
TE O
= O
1.99 O
ms O
, O
flip O
angle O
= O
12° O
, O
resolution O
= O
256 O
× O
256 O
× O
166 O
. O

All O
scans O
covered O
the O
entire O
brain O
with O
FOV O
= O
220 O
mm2 O
, O
voxel O
size O
= O
0.86 O
× O
186 O
× O
1.2 O
mm3 O
. O

Data O
preprocessing O
The O
fMRI O
data O
were O
preprocessed O
using O
the O
automated O
analysis O
pipeline O
in O
SPM8 O
( O
http O
: O
//www.fil.ion.ucl.ac.uk/spm O
) O
as O
following O
: O
motion O
correction O
, O
slice O
timing O
and O
normalization O
to O
MNI O
space O
, O
including O
reslicing O
to O
3 O
× O
3 O
× O
3 O
mm O
voxels O
. O

We O
removed O
subjects O
who O
had O
framewise O
displacements O
( O
FD O
) O
exceeding O
1.0 O
mm O
, O
and O
head O
motion O
exceeding O
2.0 O
mm O
of O
maximal O
translation O
( O
in O
any O
direction O
of O
x O
, O
y O
, O
or O
z O
) O
or O
1.0° O
of O
maximal O
rotation O
throughout O
the O
course O
of O
scanning O
. O

We O
also O
despiked O
the O
fMRI O
data O
, O
regressed O
out O
six O
head O
motion O
parameters O
, O
white O
matter O
, O
and O
cerebrospinal O
fluid O
in O
the O
denoising O
procedure O
. O

Results O
indicate O
FD O
( O
mean O
framewise O
displacements O
, O
mean O
of O
root O
of O
mean O
square O
frame-to-frame O
head O
motions O
assuming O
50 O
mm O
head O
radius O
) O
for O
all O
subjects O
were O
< O
0.3 O
mm O
at O
every O
time O
point O
. O

There O
is O
no O
significant O
difference O
between O
patients O
and O
controls O
on O
mean O
FDs O
; O
namely O
, O
UNM O
, O
HC O
: O
mean O
= O
0.22 O
± O
0.12 O
mm O
, O
SZ O
: O
0.21 O
± O
0.11 O
mm O
, O
two O
sample O
t-test O
: O
p O
= O
0.77 O
, O
FBIRN O
, O
HC O
: O
mean O
= O
0.25 O
± O
0.18 O
mm O
, O
SZ O
: O
0.27 O
± O
0.21 O
mm O
, O
two O
sample O
t-test O
: O
p O
= O
0.65 O
. O

No O
imaging O
voxels O
showed O
a O
significant O
correlation O
with O
mean O
FD O
after O
the O
FDR O
multiple O
comparison O
correction O
for O
any O
of O
the O
three O
modalities O
, O
and O
also O
no O
significant O
correlations O
between O
mean O
FD O
and O
cognition O
. O

Detailed O
head O
motion O
correction O
could O
be O
found O
in O
the O
Supplementary O
Note O
6 O
. O

Data O
were O
then O
spatially O
smoothed O
with O
an O
8 O
mm O
, O
full-width O
half-maximum O
( O
FWHM O
) O
Gaussian O
filter O
. O

The O
sum O
of O
the O
amplitude O
values O
in O
0.01 O
to O
0.08 O
Hz O
low-frequency O
range O
was O
divided O
by O
the O
sum O
of O
the O
amplitudes O
over O
the O
entire O
power O
spectrum O
to O
obtain O
fALFF O
. O

Finally O
, O
the O
fusion O
analysis O
was O
conducted O
on O
the O
spatial O
maps O
of O
fALFF O
. O

Considering O
there O
is O
no O
group O
difference O
in O
head O
motion O
, O
no O
significant O
correlations O
between O
mean O
FD O
and O
cognitive O
scores O
, O
and O
the O
correlations O
with O
cognitive O
scores O
are O
still O
significant O
after O
regressing O
out O
mean O
FD O
, O
we O
believe O
that O
micro-motion O
is O
not O
a O
major O
factor O
affecting O
the O
current O
results O
. O

The O
dMRI O
data O
were O
preprocessed O
using O
the O
FMRIB O
Software O
Library O
( O
www.fmrib.ox.ac.uk/fsl O
) O
and O
consisted O
of O
the O
following O
steps O
. O

Firstly O
, O
quality O
check O
and O
remove O
gradient O
directions O
with O
excessive O
motion O
or O
vibration O
artifact O
. O

Secondly O
, O
motion O
and O
eddy O
correction O
. O

Thirdly O
, O
correction O
of O
gradient O
directions O
for O
image O
rotation O
due O
to O
the O
motion O
correction O
procedure O
. O

Finally O
, O
FA O
was O
calculated O
and O
smoothed O
using O
an O
8 O
mm O
FWHM O
Gaussian O
filter O
. O

The O
sMRI O
data O
were O
spatially O
normalized O
to O
MNI O
space O
using O
the O
unified O
segmentation O
method O
in O
SPM8 O
, O
segmented O
into O
GM O
, O
white O
matter O
, O
and O
cerebral O
spinal O
fluid O
( O
CSF O
) O
. O

Then O
, O
the O
GM O
volume O
were O
smoothed O
with O
an O
FWHM O
of O
8 O
mm O
Gaussian O
filter O
. O

Subject O
outliers O
were O
further O
detected O
by O
spatial O
Pearson O
correlation O
with O
the O
template O
image O
to O
ensure O
that O
all O
subjects O
were O
segmented O
properly O
. O

Normalization O
and O
site O
effect O
correction O
After O
preprocessing O
, O
the O
three-dimensional O
brain O
images O
of O
each O
subject O
were O
reshaped O
into O
a O
one-dimensional O
vector O
and O
stacked O
, O
forming O
a O
matrix O
( O
Nsubj O
× O
Nvoxel O
) O
for O
each O
of O
the O
three O
modalities O
. O

These O
three O
matrices O
were O
then O
normalized O
to O
have O
the O
same O
average O
sum O
of O
squares O
( O
computed O
across O
all O
subjects O
and O
all O
voxels O
for O
each O
modality O
) O
to O
ensure O
all O
modalities O
had O
the O
same O
ranges O
. O

To O
ensure O
that O
each O
of O
the O
modality O
features O
were O
not O
confounded O
by O
site-related O
differences O
in O
subject O
recruitment O
criteria O
or O
by O
other O
unidentified O
variables O
, O
multivariate O
analysis O
of O
covariance O
( O
MANCOVA O
) O
was O
performed O
on O
all O
feature O
matrices O
. O

Site O
, O
gender O
, O
age O
, O
and O
their O
interactions O
were O
all O
regressed O
out O
from O
GM O
, O
fALFF O
, O
and O
FA O
features O
, O
respectively O
, O
to O
minimize O
their O
impact O
on O
the O
brain O
imaging O
data O
. O

Thus O
, O
the O
resulting O
data O
were O
then O
ready O
for O
fusion O
analysis O
. O

Data O
availability O
The O
code O
for O
the O
supervised O
fusion O
algorithm O
has O
been O
released O
and O
integrated O
in O
the O
Fusion O
ICA O
Toolbox O
( O
FIT O
, O
https O
: O
//mialab.mrn.org/software/fit O
) O
, O
which O
can O
be O
downloaded O
freely O
and O
used O
directly O
by O
users O
worldwide O
. O

The O
multimodal O
data O
used O
in O
the O
present O
study O
can O
be O
accessed O
upon O
request O
to O
the O
corresponding O
authors O
. O

Exploring O
the O
Neuroplastic O
Effects O
of O
Biofeedback O
Training O
on O
Smokers O
Smoking O
and O
stress O
cooccur O
in O
different O
stages O
of O
a O
nicotine O
addiction O
cycle O
, O
affecting O
brain O
function O
and O
showing O
additive O
impact O
on O
different O
physiological O
responses O
. O

Resting-state O
functional O
connectivity O
has O
shown O
potential O
in O
identifying O
these O
alterations O
. O

Nicotine O
addiction O
has O
been O
associated O
with O
detrimental O
effects O
on O
functional O
integrity O
of O
the O
central O
nervous O
system O
, O
including O
the O
organization O
of O
resting-state O
networks O
. O

Prolonged O
stress O
may O
result O
in O
enhanced O
activation O
of O
the O
default O
mode O
network O
( O
DMN O
) O
. O

Considering O
that O
biofeedback O
has O
shown O
promise O
in O
alleviating O
physiological O
manifestations O
of O
stress O
, O
we O
aimed O
to O
explore O
the O
possible O
neuroplastic O
effects O
of O
biofeedback O
training O
on O
smokers O
. O

Clinical O
, O
behavioral O
, O
and O
neurophysiological O
( O
resting-state O
EEG O
) O
data O
were O
collected O
from O
twenty-seven O
subjects O
before O
and O
after O
five O
sessions O
of O
skin O
temperature O
training O
. O

DMN O
functional O
cortical O
connectivity O
was O
investigated O
. O

While O
clinical O
status O
remained O
unaltered O
, O
the O
degree O
of O
nicotine O
dependence O
and O
psychiatric O
symptoms O
were O
significantly O
improved O
. O

Significant O
changes O
in O
DMN O
organization O
and O
network O
properties O
were O
not O
observed O
, O
except O
for O
a O
significant O
increase O
of O
information O
flow O
from O
the O
right O
ventrolateral O
prefrontal O
cortex O
and O
right O
temporal O
pole O
cortex O
towards O
other O
DMN O
components O
. O

Biofeedback O
aiming O
at O
stress O
alleviation O
in O
smokers O
could O
play O
a O
protective O
role O
against O
maladaptive O
plasticity O
of O
connectivity O
. O

Multiple O
sessions O
, O
individualized O
interventions O
and O
more O
suitable O
methods O
to O
promote O
brain O
plasticity O
, O
such O
as O
neurofeedback O
training O
, O
should O
be O
considered O
. O

2 O
. O

Materials O
and O
Methods O
2.1 O
. O

Participants O
We O
recruited O
twenty-seven O
smokers O
( O
male O
: O
female O
, O
9 O
: O
18 O
) O
with O
a O
mean O
age O
of O
50.52 O
years O
( O
range O
: O
24–75 O
, O
standard O
deviation O
( O
SD O
) O
: O
12.364 O
) O
. O

The O
participants O
were O
recruited O
in O
the O
context O
of O
the O
SmokeFreeBrain O
project O
following O
the O
inclusion O
and O
exclusion O
criteria O
of O
the O
neurofeedback O
clinical O
study O
protocol O
( O
https O
: O
//clinicaltrials.gov/ct2/show/NCT02991781 O
) O
. O

All O
subjects O
signed O
an O
informed O
consent O
form O
, O
prior O
to O
their O
inclusion O
, O
in O
compliance O
with O
the O
Code O
of O
Ethics O
of O
the O
World O
Medical O
Association O
( O
Declaration O
of O
Helsinki O
) O
. O

Inclusion O
criteria O
were O
the O
following O
: O
( O
1 O
) O
active O
smokers O
( O
more O
than O
ten O
cigarettes O
per O
day O
) O
, O
( O
2a O
) O
either O
being O
unemployed O
for O
at O
least O
three O
months O
and O
between O
eighteen O
to O
thirty-five O
years O
old O
, O
or O
( O
2b O
) O
being O
diagnosed O
with O
asthma O
or O
chronic O
obstructive O
pulmonary O
disease O
( O
COPD O
) O
with O
an O
age O
greater O
than O
thirty O
years O
old O
. O

Exclusion O
criteria O
included O
diagnosis O
of O
neurological O
, O
mental O
or O
psychiatric O
illness O
and O
drug-resistant O
epilepsy O
. O

Three O
( O
3 O
) O
out O
of O
27 O
participants O
were O
young O
and O
unemployed O
adults O
, O
sixteen O
( O
16 O
) O
out O
of O
27 O
were O
asthma O
patients O
, O
and O
eight O
( O
8 O
) O
out O
of O
27 O
were O
COPD O
patients O
. O

The O
study O
( O
design O
, O
methodology O
, O
and O
experimental O
protocol O
) O
was O
approved O
by O
the O
Bioethics O
Committee O
of O
the O
Medical O
School O
of O
the O
Aristotle O
University O
of O
Thessaloniki O
. O

2.2 O
. O

Experimental O
Design O
Each O
participant O
went O
through O
a O
detailed O
clinical O
examination O
, O
which O
is O
a O
prerequisite O
for O
the O
SmokeFreeBrain O
( O
SFB O
) O
project O
( O
http O
: O
//smokefreebrain.eu/ O
) O
. O

Specifically O
, O
each O
participant O
, O
after O
checking O
for O
eligibility O
criteria O
, O
underwent O
a O
baseline O
clinical O
evaluation O
( O
session O
1 O
, O
Figure O
1 O
) O
prior O
to O
which O
eligibility O
criteria O
were O
tested O
. O

Session O
1 O
took O
place O
either O
at O
the O
private O
practice O
of O
a O
collaborator O
physician O
or O
at O
the O
Respiratory O
Failure O
Unit O
of O
“ O
G O
. O

Papanikolaou O
” O
General O
Hospital O
. O

If O
a O
participant O
was O
eligible O
, O
demographic O
, O
medical O
, O
and O
behavioral O
data O
were O
collected O
. O

Demographics O
included O
age O
, O
years O
of O
education O
, O
gender O
, O
body O
mass O
index O
( O
BMI O
) O
, O
number O
of O
cigarettes O
per O
day O
, O
and O
cigarette O
dependence O
in O
months O
. O

Clinical O
evaluation O
included O
pulmonary O
function O
tests O
such O
as O
spirometry O
with O
parameters O
of O
forced O
expiratory O
flow O
in O
1 O
second O
( O
FEV1 O
) O
, O
forced O
vital O
capacity O
( O
FVC O
) O
, O
expiratory O
ratio O
( O
% O
FEV1/FVC O
) O
, O
forced O
expiratory O
flow O
at O
the O
middle O
half O
of O
the O
FVC O
( O
FEF25–75 O
% O
) O
, O
and O
measurement O
of O
exhaled O
carbon O
monoxide O
levels O
( O
CO O
) O
, O
as O
well O
as O
a O
blood O
sampling O
for O
the O
evaluation O
of O
total O
oxidative O
stress/total O
oxidative O
capacity O
( O
TOS/TOC O
) O
, O
and O
vitamin O
E. O
In O
the O
current O
study O
, O
we O
just O
analyzed O
TOS/TOC O
scores O
both O
before O
and O
after O
the O
intervention O
. O

Behavioral O
assessment O
was O
performed O
by O
administrating O
a O
battery O
of O
behavioral O
tests O
and O
questionnaires O
validated O
or O
adapted O
for O
the O
Greek O
population O
. O

These O
were O
the O
following O
: O
Fagerström O
Test O
for O
Nicotine O
Dependence O
, O
Motivation O
, O
The O
Contemplation O
Ladder O
, O
Minnesota O
Nicotine O
Withdrawal O
Scale O
, O
Beck O
Depression O
Inventory O
, O
State-Trait O
Anxiety O
Inventory O
, O
General O
Health O
Test O
, O
Rosenberg O
Self-Esteem O
Scale O
, O
and O
World O
Health O
Organization O
Quality O
of O
Life O
Instrument—Brief O
. O

In O
addition O
, O
the O
COPD O
patients O
completed O
the O
COPD O
Assessment O
Test O
score O
and O
the O
COPD O
and O
Asthma O
Sleep O
Impact O
Scale O
, O
while O
asthma O
patients O
answered O
the O
Asthma O
Control O
Test O
. O

In O
session O
2 O
( O
Figure O
1 O
) O
, O
a O
baseline O
neuropsychological O
evaluation O
was O
performed O
administrating O
the O
Stroop O
Test O
, O
Trail-Making O
Test O
A O
and O
B O
, O
and O
Digit O
Span O
Test O
, O
along O
with O
an O
electrophysiological O
assessment O
through O
electroencephalographic O
recordings O
( O
EEG O
) O
in O
different O
conditions O
. O

EEG O
recordings O
were O
performed O
with O
a O
Nihon O
Kohden O
128-channel O
EEG O
recording O
system O
and O
an O
active O
electrode O
cap O
( O
actiCAP O
128Ch O
, O
Brain O
Products O
) O
according O
to O
the O
high-resolution O
EEG O
10-5 O
international O
electrode O
system O
. O

Recordings O
took O
place O
inside O
the O
electromagnetically O
shielded O
and O
sound-attenuated O
room O
of O
the O
Medical O
Physics O
Laboratory O
, O
before O
and O
after O
the O
biofeedback O
training O
. O

They O
were O
performed O
at O
a O
sampling O
rate O
of O
1000 O
Hz O
, O
while O
electrode O
impedances O
of O
the O
brain O
signal O
, O
ground O
electrode O
, O
and O
references O
were O
kept O
lower O
than O
10 O
kΩ O
. O

EEG O
was O
recorded O
during O
four O
different O
conditions O
, O
including O
eyes O
open O
( O
EO O
) O
( O
5 O
minutes O
) O
, O
eyes O
fixated O
in O
a O
smoking-related O
image O
( O
EF O
) O
( O
1 O
minute O
) O
, O
eyes O
closed O
( O
EC O
) O
( O
5 O
minutes O
) O
, O
and O
a O
multifeature O
auditory O
mismatch O
negativity O
measurement O
according O
to O
the O
guidelines O
of O
Näätänen O
et O
al O
. O

( O
15 O
min O
in O
duration O
) O
. O

In O
the O
current O
manuscript O
, O
eyes-closed O
data O
were O
analyzed O
following O
the O
suggestions O
by O
Raichle O
et O
al. O
, O
where O
resting-state O
is O
defined O
as O
a O
task-free O
state O
in O
which O
the O
individuals O
rest O
quietly O
awake O
with O
eyes O
closed O
. O

The O
intervention O
phase O
( O
Figure O
1 O
) O
consisted O
of O
five O
30-minute O
sessions O
of O
skin O
temperature O
training O
. O

Each O
training O
session O
included O
, O
at O
the O
start O
, O
an O
introduction O
to O
stress-coping O
techniques O
of O
15-minute O
length O
and O
a O
one-minute O
baseline O
peripheral O
temperature O
recording O
. O

These O
were O
followed O
by O
30 O
minutes O
of O
skin O
temperature O
training O
as O
suggested O
by O
Peniston O
and O
Kulkosky O
. O

Participants O
sat O
comfortably O
on O
a O
reclined O
chair O
across O
a O
computer O
monitor O
resting O
their O
nondominant O
hand O
on O
the O
lap O
or O
a O
pillow O
. O

A O
sensitive O
thermistor O
was O
placed O
in O
the O
middle O
fingertip O
of O
their O
nondominant O
hand O
. O

The O
training O
goal O
at O
each O
session O
was O
to O
achieve O
temperature O
enhancement O
while O
receiving O
an O
audiovisual O
feedback O
. O

When O
the O
temperature O
exceeded O
an O
autoadjusted O
threshold O
, O
a O
puzzle O
was O
being O
formed O
accompanied O
by O
a O
pleasant O
auditory O
stimulus O
as O
described O
in O
. O

In O
the O
posttraining O
phase O
( O
sessions O
3 O
and O
4 O
) O
, O
the O
followed O
procedures O
were O
identical O
to O
the O
baseline O
. O

Additionally O
, O
in O
the O
posttraining O
clinical O
evaluation O
, O
urine O
samples O
were O
collected O
to O
assess O
cotinine O
levels O
in O
our O
participants O
apart O
from O
the O
procedures O
already O
described O
for O
the O
baseline O
screening O
. O

In O
later O
phases O
of O
the O
intervention O
, O
as O
part O
of O
the O
SmokeFreeBrain O
project O
, O
multiple O
sessions O
of O
alpha-theta O
neurofeedback O
training O
are O
introduced O
, O
but O
this O
is O
not O
discussed O
in O
the O
current O
study O
. O

2.3 O
. O

Total O
Oxidative O
Capacity/Total O
Oxidative O
Stress O
( O
TOC/TOS O
) O
After O
blood O
draw O
, O
blood O
samples O
were O
centrifuged O
for O
10 O
min O
at O
2000g O
and O
4°C O
, O
and O
serum O
samples O
( O
1 O
ml O
) O
, O
divided O
in O
two O
or O
three O
microcentrifuge O
tubes O
, O
were O
stored O
at O
−80°C O
. O

The O
average O
time O
lapse O
between O
sample O
collection O
and O
freezing O
was O
90 O
minutes O
. O

Determination O
of O
the O
peroxides O
was O
performed O
by O
the O
reaction O
of O
a O
peroxidase O
with O
peroxides O
in O
the O
sample O
followed O
by O
the O
conversion O
of O
tetramethyl O
benzidine O
to O
a O
colored O
product O
. O

After O
the O
addition O
of O
a O
stop O
solution O
, O
the O
samples O
were O
measured O
at O
450 O
nm O
in O
a O
microliter O
plate O
reader O
. O

The O
quantification O
was O
performed O
by O
the O
delivered O
calibrator O
. O

2.4 O
. O

Data O
Preprocessing O
and O
Resting-State O
Connectivity O
The O
Brain O
Electrical O
Source O
Analysis O
software O
( O
BESA O
research O
, O
version O
6.0 O
, O
Megis O
Software O
, O
Heidelberg O
, O
Germany O
) O
was O
used O
for O
the O
preprocessing O
of O
the O
EEG O
data O
in O
EC O
condition O
. O

Data O
were O
visually O
inspected O
to O
detect O
bad O
channels O
. O

Bad O
channels O
detected O
along O
with O
ground O
and O
reference O
electrodes O
( O
AFz O
and O
FCz O
, O
resp O
. O
) O

were O
interpolated O
via O
an O
interpolation O
algorithm O
of O
the O
BESA O
software O
. O

A O
high-pass O
filter O
with O
a O
cutoff O
frequency O
at O
1 O
Hz O
was O
chosen O
to O
remove O
low-frequency O
signals O
along O
with O
a O
low-pass O
filter O
with O
a O
cutoff O
frequency O
at O
30 O
Hz O
removing O
high-frequency O
signals O
. O

Furthermore O
, O
a O
notch O
filter O
was O
used O
at O
50 O
Hz O
in O
order O
to O
eliminate O
the O
industrial O
noise O
. O

Independent O
component O
analysis O
( O
ICA O
) O
decomposition O
was O
performed O
in O
the O
current O
screen O
of O
the O
EEG O
data O
( O
60 O
seconds O
) O
using O
the O
principal O
component O
analysis O
( O
PCA O
) O
technique O
. O

In O
more O
detail O
, O
the O
method O
underlying O
the O
ICA O
analysis O
is O
the O
extended O
ICA O
algorithm O
. O

The O
dimensionality O
of O
data O
was O
reduced O
by O
PCA O
before O
ICA O
by O
ignoring O
all O
PCA O
components O
that O
explain O
less O
than O
1 O
% O
of O
the O
variance O
. O

Linear O
drifts O
, O
heart O
modulation O
, O
muscle O
contamination O
, O
artifacts O
induced O
by O
the O
participant O
's O
movements O
, O
and O
high-frequency O
noise O
were O
characterized O
as O
artifactual O
sources O
and O
removed O
. O

After O
reconstructing O
the O
whole O
dataset O
excluding O
noisy O
ICA O
components O
, O
data O
were O
visually O
inspected O
. O

Ten O
random O
epochs O
of O
equal O
length O
( O
4 O
seconds O
) O
were O
extracted O
using O
ten O
random O
triggers O
and O
exporting O
an O
interval O
of O
4000 O
ms O
around O
the O
triggers O
( O
−2000 O
ms O
to O
+2000 O
ms O
) O
. O

An O
equal O
number O
of O
epochs O
( O
epochs O
= O
10 O
) O
was O
exported O
for O
both O
baseline O
and O
posttraining O
EEG O
recordings O
( O
EC O
) O
. O

Afterwards O
, O
the O
lead O
field O
matrix O
was O
obtained O
by O
the O
eConnectome O
toolbox O
relating O
2054 O
scalp O
triangles O
to O
7850 O
cortical O
dipoles O
. O

The O
lead O
field O
matrix O
is O
provided O
by O
means O
of O
a O
three-layer O
BEM O
model O
based O
on O
the O
Colin27 O
MNI O
brain O
. O

The O
dipoles O
were O
restricted O
to O
the O
gray O
matter O
with O
perpendicular O
orientations O
towards O
the O
local O
cortical O
surface O
. O

Minimum O
norm O
estimate O
( O
MNE O
) O
was O
performed O
to O
solve O
the O
inverse O
problem O
by O
minimizing O
the O
source O
space O
energy O
given O
that O
the O
source O
dipoles O
' O
power O
is O
constrained O
by O
the O
cortex O
physiology O
. O

Tikhonov O
regularization O
was O
applied O
through O
the O
Regularization O
Toolbox O
to O
find O
the O
MNE O
solution O
. O

Additionally O
, O
we O
created O
eighteen O
custom-defined O
ROIs O
representing O
important O
nodes O
of O
the O
default O
mode O
network O
( O
DMN O
) O
at O
the O
surface O
of O
the O
cortex O
cortical O
model O
, O
in O
order O
to O
proceed O
to O
the O
computation O
of O
connectivity O
( O
Figure O
2 O
) O
. O

The O
ROI O
time O
series O
signal O
was O
computed O
by O
averaging O
the O
signal O
of O
all O
included O
cortical O
current O
dipoles O
. O

ROI O
time O
series O
were O
computed O
for O
each O
node O
at O
each O
of O
the O
ten O
4-second O
epochs O
for O
each O
subject O
. O

The O
functional O
cortical O
connectivity O
between O
the O
18 O
custom-defined O
nodes O
of O
DMN O
was O
evaluated O
by O
means O
of O
the O
directed O
transfer O
function O
( O
DTF O
) O
metric O
with O
significance O
testing O
using O
surrogate O
data O
. O

DTF O
is O
a O
Granger O
causality O
measure O
that O
uses O
the O
multivariate O
autoregressive O
model O
( O
MVAR O
) O
and O
describes O
the O
information O
flow O
between O
the O
node O
j O
and O
the O
node O
i O
at O
frequency O
f O
, O
producing O
weighted O
directed O
graphs O
. O

The O
order O
of O
the O
MVAR O
model O
was O
set O
to O
ten O
, O
based O
on O
SBC O
and O
FPE O
criteria O
as O
computed O
by O
the O
eConnectome O
software O
. O

For O
our O
analysis O
, O
DTF O
networks O
were O
computed O
at O
the O
frequency O
band O
of O
alpha O
rhythm O
at O
8–12 O
Hz O
as O
alpha O
rhythm O
is O
the O
dominant O
brain O
rhythm O
at O
idling O
rest O
. O

DTF O
was O
computed O
between O
ROI O
time O
series O
of O
the O
network O
nodes O
at O
each O
of O
the O
ten O
4-second O
epochs O
for O
each O
subject O
, O
producing O
27∗10∗2 O
adjacency O
matrices O
( O
for O
the O
pre- O
and O
posttime O
conditions O
) O
. O

The O
DTF O
adjacency O
matrices O
, O
corresponding O
to O
resting-state O
connectivity O
networks O
, O
were O
then O
compared O
between O
pre- O
and O
posttime O
conditions O
, O
in O
order O
to O
identify O
significantly O
altered O
connections O
. O

For O
this O
, O
we O
tested O
by O
false O
discovery O
rate O
( O
FDR O
) O
with O
5000 O
permutations O
, O
using O
the O
NBS O
toolbox O
. O

Following O
the O
aforementioned O
analysis O
design O
, O
we O
further O
explored O
possible O
differences O
in O
resting-state O
networks O
depending O
on O
gender O
. O

2.5 O
. O

Network O
Analysis O
Network O
analysis O
was O
performed O
using O
the O
Brain O
Connectivity O
Toolbox O
( O
BCT O
) O
for O
alpha O
band O
networks O
. O

The O
topological O
properties O
of O
the O
connectivity O
adjacency O
matrices O
were O
calculated O
using O
graph O
network O
analysis O
at O
each O
epoch O
for O
each O
subject O
. O

The O
topological O
properties O
were O
then O
averaged O
across O
epochs O
for O
each O
subject O
, O
producing O
two O
average O
values O
of O
each O
property O
( O
detailed O
below O
) O
for O
the O
resting-state O
network O
of O
each O
subject O
, O
one O
at O
the O
pre- O
and O
one O
at O
the O
posttime O
condition O
. O

Characteristic O
path O
length O
( O
CPL O
) O
, O
mean O
clustering O
coefficient O
( O
CC O
) O
, O
and O
density O
( O
D O
) O
, O
as O
well O
as O
the O
small-world O
( O
SW O
) O
measures O
were O
computed O
. O

Moreover O
, O
the O
in- O
and O
out-strengths O
values O
for O
each O
of O
the O
18 O
nodes O
of O
the O
network O
were O
also O
calculated O
. O

Characteristic O
path O
length O
( O
CPL O
) O
is O
the O
average O
shortest O
distance O
between O
node O
i O
and O
all O
other O
nodes O
, O
and O
it O
is O
considered O
as O
measure O
of O
integration O
. O

Mean O
clustering O
coefficient O
( O
CC O
) O
, O
a O
measure O
of O
segregation O
, O
indicates O
the O
graph O
nodes O
' O
tendency O
to O
be O
organized O
in O
triangles O
. O

Density O
( O
D O
) O
is O
the O
number O
of O
actual O
connections O
among O
network O
nodes O
divided O
by O
the O
maximum O
possible O
connections O
. O

Small-world O
( O
SW O
) O
networks O
( O
small-world O
scalar O
is O
defined O
in O
) O
are O
characterized O
by O
a O
short O
path O
length O
that O
is O
indicative O
of O
communication O
efficiency O
along O
with O
a O
high O
clustering O
coefficient O
which O
represents O
a O
high O
suborganization O
. O

In O
our O
study O
, O
the O
comparison O
of O
CPL O
and O
CC O
in O
the O
SW O
metric O
was O
made O
against O
10,000 O
random O
networks O
with O
the O
same O
number O
of O
connections O
and O
density O
to O
connectivity O
networks O
. O

The O
in-strength O
metric O
for O
each O
node O
( O
IS O
) O
was O
defined O
as O
the O
sum O
of O
the O
weights O
of O
all O
incoming O
connections O
to O
that O
node O
. O

The O
out-strength O
metric O
for O
each O
node O
( O
OS O
) O
was O
calculated O
by O
adding O
the O
weights O
of O
outgoing O
connections O
from O
that O
node O
. O

2.6 O
. O

Statistical O
Analysis O
All O
statistical O
analyses O
were O
performed O
using O
the O
IBM O
SPSS O
( O
version O
23 O
) O
and O
the O
level O
at O
which O
the O
null O
hypothesis O
is O
rejected O
was O
set O
as O
5 O
out O
of O
100 O
( O
a O
= O
0.05 O
) O
. O

2.6.1 O
. O

Demographic O
Data O
Demographic O
data O
were O
tested O
for O
normality O
assumption O
by O
visual O
inspection O
of O
histograms O
, O
normal O
Q-Q O
plots O
, O
and O
boxplots O
, O
checking O
skewness O
and O
kurtosis O
parameters O
, O
and O
using O
formal O
normality O
tests O
( O
Shapiro-Wilk O
test O
and O
Kolmogorov-Smirnov O
test O
) O
in O
order O
to O
calculate O
the O
appropriate O
measures O
of O
centrality O
and O
variation O
. O

As O
the O
variables O
age O
, O
education O
years O
, O
BMI O
index O
, O
and O
smoking O
dependence O
in O
months O
were O
approximately O
normally O
distributed O
, O
mean O
and O
standard O
deviation O
were O
calculated O
while O
median O
and O
interquartile O
range O
were O
calculated O
for O
the O
number O
of O
daily O
cigarettes O
. O

Moreover O
, O
we O
investigated O
gender O
differences O
in O
demographic O
data O
. O

Normality O
assumption O
was O
tested O
for O
demographics O
between O
male O
and O
female O
participants O
. O

Depending O
on O
the O
normality O
assumption O
, O
either O
t-test O
for O
independent O
samples O
or O
the O
Mann–Whitney O
U O
test O
was O
performed O
. O

2.6.2 O
. O

Clinical O
Data O
Total O
oxidative O
stress/total O
oxidative O
capacity O
( O
TOS/TOC O
) O
was O
analyzed O
at O
the O
two O
time O
conditions O
in O
the O
twenty-two O
participants O
out O
of O
twenty-seven O
as O
the O
rest O
of O
the O
samples O
were O
not O
available O
. O

Differences O
in O
oxidative O
stress O
were O
initially O
explored O
using O
paired O
t-test O
, O
as O
they O
were O
continuous O
variables O
and O
approximately O
normally O
distributed O
. O

Exhaled O
CO O
levels O
were O
also O
compared O
both O
before O
and O
after O
biofeedback O
training O
using O
paired O
t-test O
. O

Additionally O
, O
we O
explored O
gender O
differences O
in O
clinical O
data O
. O

Using O
repeated O
measures O
analysis O
of O
variance O
, O
with O
gender O
as O
a O
covariate O
factor O
, O
could O
be O
an O
analysis O
of O
choice O
, O
but O
this O
was O
not O
followed O
because O
normality O
assumption O
was O
not O
met O
in O
every O
cell O
of O
the O
analysis O
. O

Thus O
, O
within-group O
changes O
in O
TOS O
and O
CO O
levels O
, O
respectively O
, O
were O
explored O
using O
the O
Wilcoxon O
Signed O
Ranks O
test O
or O
paired O
t-test O
after O
grouping O
by O
gender O
. O

Between-group O
differences O
of O
clinical O
data O
at O
the O
two O
time O
points O
were O
compared O
between O
male O
and O
female O
cohorts O
using O
the O
Mann–Whitney O
U O
test O
or O
independent O
samples O
t-test O
. O

2.6.3 O
. O

Behavioral O
Data O
Total O
scores O
collected O
by O
neuropsychological O
tests O
and O
questionnaires O
such O
as O
the O
Fagerström O
Test O
, O
Minnesota O
Nicotine O
Withdrawal O
Scale O
, O
Beck O
Depression O
Inventory O
II O
( O
BDI O
II O
) O
, O
State-Trait O
Anxiety O
Inventory O
I O
( O
STAI O
I O
) O
and O
II O
( O
STAI O
II O
) O
, O
General O
Health O
Test O
, O
Rosenberg O
Self-Esteem O
Scale O
, O
and O
Motivation O
test O
were O
analyzed O
in O
this O
study O
. O

More O
precisely O
, O
score O
differences O
both O
before O
and O
after O
biofeedback O
training O
were O
calculated O
for O
each O
test O
or O
questionnaire O
. O

Score O
differences O
were O
tested O
for O
normality O
assumption O
using O
the O
aforementioned O
methodology O
( O
Section O
2.6.1 O
) O
. O

Depending O
on O
normality O
assumption O
, O
different O
analyses O
were O
planned O
( O
paired O
t-tests O
or O
Wilcoxon O
Signed O
Ranks O
tests O
) O
. O

However O
, O
total O
scores O
of O
Fagerström O
Test O
at O
the O
two O
time O
points O
were O
also O
converted O
into O
ordinal O
variables O
using O
the O
following O
formula O
: O
( O
a O
) O
scores O
from O
0 O
to O
3 O
were O
coded O
as O
low O
dependent O
, O
( O
b O
) O
scores O
from O
4 O
to O
6 O
were O
coded O
as O
medium O
dependent O
, O
and O
( O
c O
) O
scores O
from O
7 O
to O
10 O
were O
coded O
as O
high O
dependent O
. O

In O
this O
case O
, O
differences O
between O
different O
levels O
of O
dependence O
at O
the O
two O
time O
points O
were O
investigated O
performing O
the O
McNemar-Bowker O
Test O
. O

In O
the O
case O
where O
differences O
between O
different O
levels O
of O
dependence O
reached O
statistical O
significance O
( O
p O
values O
< O
0.05 O
) O
, O
McNemar O
tests O
were O
performed O
by O
two O
. O

In O
this O
case O
, O
p O
values O
were O
corrected O
for O
multiple O
comparisons O
using O
Bonferroni O
correction O
. O

Gender O
differences O
were O
further O
explored O
in O
behavioral O
data O
. O

As O
data O
did O
not O
fit O
in O
the O
assumptions O
of O
repeated-measures O
ANOVA O
with O
a O
covariate O
, O
an O
alternative O
design O
was O
preferred O
. O

Score O
differences O
in O
neuropsychological O
tests O
and O
questionnaires O
were O
calculated O
and O
then O
tested O
for O
normality O
assumption O
between O
male O
and O
female O
participants O
. O

Depending O
on O
the O
normality O
assumption O
of O
score O
differences O
, O
within-group O
comparisons O
were O
performed O
using O
either O
paired O
t-test O
or O
the O
Wilcoxon O
Signed O
Ranks O
test O
after O
grouping O
data O
by O
gender O
. O

Independent O
samples O
t-test O
or O
the O
Mann–Whitney O
U O
tests O
were O
run O
for O
between-group O
comparisons O
. O

2.6.4 O
. O

Network O
Properties O
Network O
properties O
such O
as O
CPL O
, O
mean O
CC O
, O
D O
, O
and O
SW O
, O
as O
well O
as O
IS O
and O
OS O
were O
calculated O
for O
each O
participant O
at O
the O
two O
time O
points O
. O

Differences O
( O
posttraining O
values O
− O
pretraining O
values O
) O
were O
computed O
for O
each O
property O
at O
the O
two O
time O
conditions O
and O
then O
tested O
for O
normality O
assumption O
. O

Different O
analyses O
were O
performed O
, O
either O
paired O
t-tests O
or O
the O
Wilcoxon O
Signed O
Ranks O
tests O
, O
at O
each O
network O
property O
depending O
on O
normality O
assumption O
. O

Possible O
within- O
and O
between-group O
differences O
depending O
on O
gender O
were O
explored O
using O
the O
same O
methodology O
as O
the O
one O
used O
in O
clinical O
and O
behavioral O
data O
. O

Aberrant O
patterns O
of O
neural O
activity O
when O
perceiving O
emotion O
from O
biological O
motion O
in O
schizophrenia O
Social O
perceptual O
deficits O
in O
schizophrenia O
are O
well O
established O
. O

Recent O
work O
suggests O
that O
the O
ability O
to O
extract O
social O
information O
from O
bodily O
cues O
is O
reduced O
in O
patients O
. O

However O
, O
little O
is O
known O
about O
the O
neurobiological O
mechanisms O
underlying O
this O
deficit O
. O

In O
the O
current O
study O
, O
20 O
schizophrenia O
patients O
and O
16 O
controls O
completed O
two O
tasks O
using O
point-light O
animations O
during O
fMRI O
: O
a O
basic O
biological O
motion O
task O
and O
an O
emotion O
in O
biological O
motion O
task O
. O

The O
basic O
biological O
motion O
task O
was O
used O
to O
localize O
activity O
in O
posterior O
superior O
temporal O
sulcus O
( O
pSTS O
) O
, O
a O
critical O
region O
for O
biological O
motion O
perception O
. O

During O
the O
emotion O
in O
biological O
motion O
task O
, O
participants O
viewed O
brief O
videos O
depicting O
happiness O
, O
fear O
, O
anger O
, O
or O
neutral O
emotions O
and O
were O
asked O
to O
decide O
which O
emotion O
was O
portrayed O
. O

Activity O
in O
pSTS O
and O
amygdala O
was O
interrogated O
during O
this O
task O
. O

Results O
indicated O
that O
patients O
showed O
overall O
reduced O
activation O
compared O
to O
controls O
in O
pSTS O
and O
at O
a O
trend O
level O
in O
amygdala O
across O
emotions O
, O
despite O
similar O
task O
performance O
. O

Further O
, O
a O
functional O
connectivity O
analysis O
revealed O
that O
controls O
, O
but O
not O
patients O
, O
showed O
significant O
positive O
connectivity O
between O
pSTS O
and O
left O
frontal O
regions O
as O
well O
as O
bilateral O
angular O
gyrus O
during O
the O
emotion O
in O
biological O
motion O
task O
. O

These O
findings O
indicate O
that O
schizophrenia O
patients O
show O
aberrant O
neural O
activity O
and O
functional O
connectivity O
when O
extracting O
complex O
social O
information O
from O
simple O
motion O
stimuli O
, O
which O
may O
contribute O
to O
social O
perception O
deficits O
in O
this O
disorder O
. O

Highlights O
Perception O
of O
social O
information O
from O
bodily O
cues O
is O
impaired O
in O
schizophrenia O
. O

We O
examined O
neural O
correlates O
of O
perception O
of O
emotion O
from O
biological O
motion O
. O

Activity O
in O
amygdala O
and O
posterior O
superior O
temporal O
sulcus O
was O
reduced O
in O
patients O
. O

pSTS O
functional O
connectivity O
with O
frontal O
and O
parietal O
regions O
was O
reduced O
in O
patients O
. O

Aberrant O
neural O
responses O
may O
contribute O
to O
social O
perceptual O
deficits O
in O
schizophrenia O
. O

Methods O
Participants O
Twenty O
patients O
with O
schizophrenia O
( O
7 O
female O
) O
and O
16 O
healthy O
controls O
( O
5 O
female O
) O
completed O
the O
study O
. O

Patients O
were O
recruited O
from O
community O
outpatient O
treatment O
clinics O
and O
met O
diagnostic O
criteria O
for O
schizophrenia O
based O
on O
the O
Structured O
Clinical O
Interview O
for O
DSM-IV O
Axis O
I O
Disorders O
( O
SCID O
) O
. O

Controls O
were O
recruited O
through O
internet O
postings O
and O
interviewed O
with O
the O
SCID-I O
and O
portions O
of O
the O
Structured O
Clinical O
Interview O
for O
DSM-IV O
Axis O
II O
Disorders O
( O
SCID-II O
) O
. O

All O
participants O
were O
between O
18 O
and O
65 O
years O
of O
age O
, O
and O
were O
excluded O
from O
participation O
if O
they O
had O
: O
an O
identifiable O
neurological O
disorder O
, O
history O
of O
loss O
of O
consciousness O
for O
more O
than O
1 O
h O
, O
or O
were O
not O
sufficiently O
fluent O
in O
English O
to O
consent O
and O
understand O
procedures O
. O

Additional O
exclusion O
criteria O
for O
patients O
was O
self-reported O
substance O
abuse O
in O
the O
past O
month O
or O
dependence O
in O
the O
last O
six O
months O
, O
and O
indication O
of O
IQ O
< O
70 O
based O
on O
chart O
review O
. O

Additional O
exclusion O
criteria O
for O
controls O
was O
a O
first-degree O
relative O
with O
schizophrenia O
or O
another O
psychotic O
disorder O
, O
a O
personal O
history O
of O
schizophrenia O
or O
other O
psychotic O
disorder O
, O
bipolar O
disorder O
, O
or O
recurrent O
depression O
, O
a O
lifetime O
history O
of O
substance O
dependence O
or O
any O
substance O
abuse O
in O
the O
last O
6 O
months O
, O
and O
any O
of O
the O
following O
Axis O
II O
disorders O
: O
avoidant O
, O
paranoid O
, O
schizoid O
, O
or O
schizotypal O
. O

Clinical O
measures O
Psychiatric O
symptoms O
in O
patients O
were O
evaluated O
using O
the O
24-item O
version O
of O
the O
Brief O
Psychiatric O
Rating O
Scale O
( O
BPRS O
) O
and O
Scale O
for O
the O
Assessment O
of O
Negative O
Symptoms O
( O
SANS O
) O
. O

For O
the O
BPRS O
we O
report O
the O
total O
score O
and O
the O
mean O
for O
the O
positive O
symptom O
factor O
. O

For O
the O
SANS O
we O
report O
the O
sum O
of O
four O
global O
scales O
: O
Affective O
Flattening O
, O
Alogia O
, O
Avolition-Apathy O
, O
and O
Anhedonia-Asociality O
. O

Functional O
outcome O
was O
assessed O
with O
the O
Role O
Functioning O
Scale O
( O
RFS O
) O
. O

All O
clinical O
assessments O
were O
conducted O
by O
interviewers O
trained O
to O
reliability O
through O
the O
Treatment O
Unit O
of O
the O
Department O
of O
Veterans O
Affairs O
VISN O
22 O
Mental O
Illness O
Research O
, O
Education O
, O
and O
Clinical O
Center O
( O
MIRECC O
) O
based O
on O
established O
procedures O
. O

The O
study O
protocol O
was O
reviewed O
and O
approved O
by O
the O
Institutional O
Review O
Board O
of O
the O
University O
of O
California O
, O
Los O
Angeles O
. O

All O
participants O
provided O
written O
informed O
consent O
after O
procedures O
were O
fully O
explained O
. O

Procedures O
Activation O
paradigms O
Participants O
completed O
two O
tasks O
involving O
point-light O
animations O
during O
fMRI O
( O
Fig O
. O

1 O
) O
. O

The O
first O
was O
the O
Basic O
Biological O
Motion O
Task O
. O

The O
second O
task O
was O
the O
Emotion O
in O
Biological O
Motion O
Task O
. O

The O
tasks O
were O
generated O
using O
E-Prime O
version O
2.0 O
professional O
( O
Psychology O
Software O
Tools O
, O
USA O
) O
. O

Prior O
to O
the O
scan O
session O
, O
participants O
completed O
practice O
trials O
to O
become O
familiar O
with O
each O
task O
. O

Basic O
biological O
motion O
task O
( O
localizer O
) O
: O
Stimuli O
consisted O
of O
1 O
s O
animations O
of O
point-light O
walkers O
; O
each O
animation O
video O
was O
comprised O
of O
12 O
black O
dots O
presented O
on O
a O
white O
background O
at O
central O
fixation O
. O

The O
dots O
were O
arranged O
and O
animated O
in O
a O
manner O
that O
corresponded O
to O
human O
( O
e.g. O
, O
walking O
, O
jumping O
) O
or O
random O
movement O
( O
Fig O
. O

1A O
) O
. O

Participants O
viewed O
12 O
alternating O
blocks O
of O
human O
( O
0 O
% O
scrambled O
) O
and O
random O
( O
100 O
% O
scrambled O
) O
movement O
. O

Each O
block O
included O
7 O
animations O
with O
an O
inter-stimulus O
interval O
( O
ISI O
) O
of O
1 O
s. O
A O
1 O
s O
fixation O
cross O
was O
presented O
during O
each O
ISI O
. O

A O
4 O
s O
fixation O
cross O
was O
presented O
between O
each O
block O
. O

To O
maintain O
the O
participant O
's O
attention O
, O
each O
block O
required O
performance O
of O
a O
1-back O
task O
in O
which O
they O
were O
required O
to O
press O
a O
button O
whenever O
the O
current O
animation O
was O
identical O
to O
the O
one O
appearing O
immediately O
before O
it O
. O

Participants O
had O
2 O
s O
to O
make O
their O
response O
; O
they O
could O
respond O
at O
any O
time O
after O
stimulus O
onset O
and O
prior O
to O
the O
onset O
of O
the O
next O
video O
. O

Emotion O
in O
biological O
motion O
task O
( O
Emo O
Bio O
) O
: O
Stimuli O
consisted O
of O
20 O
animations O
of O
point-light O
walkers O
( O
average O
duration O
: O
8.05 O
s O
, O
standard O
deviation O
: O
6.7 O
s O
) O
; O
videos O
were O
comprised O
of O
12 O
white O
dots O
presented O
on O
a O
black O
background O
at O
central O
fixation O
. O

The O
dots O
were O
arranged O
and O
animated O
in O
a O
manner O
that O
depicted O
happiness O
, O
fear O
, O
anger O
, O
or O
neutral O
human O
emotion O
. O

A O
1 O
s O
fixation O
cross O
was O
presented O
prior O
to O
each O
animation O
. O

After O
stimulus O
offset O
, O
the O
screen O
prompted O
the O
participant O
to O
make O
their O
response O
. O

Participants O
were O
asked O
to O
decide O
which O
emotion O
was O
being O
portrayed O
by O
pressing O
a O
corresponding O
button O
on O
a O
4-button O
response O
box O
. O

Participants O
had O
4 O
s O
to O
make O
their O
response O
. O

Responses O
triggered O
progression O
to O
a O
blank O
screen O
for O
the O
remainder O
of O
the O
4 O
s O
response O
period O
. O

Each O
animation O
was O
followed O
by O
a O
“ O
null O
” O
trial O
consisting O
of O
a O
fixation O
cross O
( O
mean O
duration O
: O
4.25 O
s O
, O
range O
: O
2.5–7.5 O
s O
) O
. O

fMRI O
data O
acquisition O
and O
processing O
All O
scanning O
was O
performed O
using O
two O
identical O
3 O
T O
Siemens O
Tim O
Trio O
scanners O
running O
identical O
software O
at O
the O
UCLA O
Ahmanson-Lovelace O
Brain O
Mapping O
Center O
and O
the O
UCLA O
Staglin O
Center O
for O
Cognitive O
Neuroscience O
. O

Each O
scanner O
utilized O
the O
same O
quality O
assurance O
protocols O
daily O
to O
assess O
scanner O
performance O
. O

There O
was O
no O
difference O
between O
scanners O
in O
terms O
of O
number O
of O
subjects O
per O
group O
or O
signal-to-noise O
ratio O
( O
Supplementary O
Table O
1 O
) O
. O

Functional O
runs O
were O
acquired O
with O
T2 O
* O
-weighted O
blood O
oxygen O
level-dependent O
( O
BOLD O
) O
gradient O
echo O
planar O
imaging O
( O
EPI O
) O
sequences O
for O
each O
activation O
task O
( O
TR O
= O
2500 O
ms O
, O
TE O
= O
35 O
ms O
, O
flip O
angle O
= O
75° O
, O
38 O
interleaved O
slices O
, O
slice O
thickness O
= O
3.3 O
mm O
; O
matrix O
= O
64 O
× O
64 O
; O
FOV O
= O
192 O
mm O
; O
in-plane O
resolution O
= O
3x3mm O
) O
. O

Two O
sets O
of O
structural O
images O
were O
acquired O
from O
each O
subject O
for O
anatomical O
localization O
and O
registration O
of O
functional O
data O
: O
a O
high-resolution O
T1-weighted O
magnetization O
prepared O
rapid-acquisition O
gradient O
echo O
image O
( O
MPRAGE O
) O
[ O
TR O
= O
1900 O
ms O
; O
TE O
= O
3.43 O
ms O
; O
flip O
angle O
= O
9° O
; O
160 O
sagittal O
slices O
; O
slice O
thickness O
= O
1 O
mm O
; O
matrix O
= O
256 O
× O
256 O
; O
FOV O
= O
256 O
mm O
; O
voxel O
size O
= O
1x1x1mm O
] O
and O
a O
T2-weighted O
matched-bandwidth O
high-resolution O
scan O
with O
the O
same O
slice O
prescription O
as O
the O
EPI O
[ O
TR O
= O
6000 O
ms O
; O
TE O
= O
66 O
ms O
; O
flip O
angle O
= O
90° O
; O
38 O
slices O
; O
slice O
thickness O
= O
3.3 O
mm O
; O
matrix O
= O
128 O
× O
128 O
; O
FOV O
= O
192 O
mm O
; O
voxel O
size O
= O
1.5 O
× O
1.5 O
× O
3.3 O
mm O
] O
. O

Image O
preprocessing O
was O
carried O
out O
using O
the O
FMRIB O
Software O
Library O
( O
FSL O
v5.0.9 O
; O
Analysis O
Group O
, O
Oxford O
, O
UK O
) O
. O

Preprocessing O
steps O
included O
high-pass O
filtering O
( O
100 O
s O
cut-off O
) O
, O
spatial O
smoothing O
( O
5 O
mm O
FWHM O
) O
, O
skull O
stripping O
, O
and O
registration O
. O

Registration O
was O
carried O
out O
using O
FSL O
's O
FLIRT O
( O
FMRIB O
's O
Linear O
Image O
Registration O
Tool O
v6.0 O
) O
. O

Each O
run O
of O
individual O
EPI O
data O
was O
registered O
first O
to O
the O
co-planar O
matched-bandwidth O
T2-weighted O
image O
( O
affine O
transformation O
; O
6 O
degrees O
of O
freedom O
) O
, O
then O
to O
the O
T1-weighted O
MPRAGE O
( O
Boundary-Based O
Registration O
, O
BBR O
) O
and O
finally O
, O
to O
Montreal O
Neurological O
Institute O
( O
MNI O
) O
standard O
space O
( O
affine O
transformation O
, O
12 O
degrees O
of O
freedom O
) O
. O

We O
addressed O
potential O
motion O
artifacts O
in O
several O
ways O
. O

Motion O
estimates O
were O
inspected O
to O
ensure O
that O
relative O
mean O
displacement O
did O
not O
exceed O
0.5 O
mm O
for O
any O
participant O
. O

In O
addition O
, O
all O
images O
were O
realigned O
to O
the O
middle O
volume O
using O
MCFLIRT O
and O
movement O
parameters O
calculated O
by O
MCFLIRT O
were O
modeled O
as O
nuisance O
covariates O
. O

Finally O
, O
the O
FSL O
motion O
outliers O
tool O
was O
used O
to O
remove O
the O
effects O
of O
any O
time-points O
corrupted O
by O
motion O
beyond O
what O
realignment O
and O
linear O
motion O
parameter O
regression O
methods O
can O
fix O
. O

Behavioral O
analyses O
For O
the O
demographic O
data O
, O
independent O
samples O
t-tests O
and O
chi-square O
tests O
were O
used O
to O
assess O
group O
differences O
for O
continuous O
and O
categorical O
variables O
, O
respectively O
. O

For O
the O
localizer O
task O
, O
behavioral O
data O
were O
collected O
to O
ensure O
participants O
were O
attending O
to O
the O
task O
but O
these O
data O
were O
not O
analyzed O
as O
a O
primary O
outcome O
variable O
. O

For O
the O
Emo O
Bio O
task O
, O
separate O
independent O
samples O
t-tests O
were O
used O
to O
assess O
group O
differences O
in O
response O
time O
and O
accuracy O
across O
condition O
( O
emotion O
type O
) O
. O

Analyses O
measured O
significance O
at O
the O
0.05 O
level O
, O
two-tailed O
. O

Given O
our O
relatively O
small O
sample O
size O
, O
we O
also O
give O
weight O
to O
any O
findings O
with O
an O
effect O
size O
of O
medium O
or O
greater O
. O

fMRI O
analyses O
Analysis O
of O
fMRI O
data O
was O
performed O
separately O
for O
the O
two O
tasks O
. O

For O
both O
tasks O
, O
we O
used O
a O
general O
linear O
model O
( O
GLM O
) O
approach O
with O
FEAT O
( O
FMRI O
Expert O
Analysis O
Tool O
v6.0 O
) O
, O
and O
a O
timing O
model O
based O
on O
a O
double-gamma O
hemodynamic O
response O
function O
. O

In O
the O
first-level O
analysis O
, O
linear O
contrasts O
of O
trials O
by O
condition O
were O
created O
for O
each O
subject O
. O

The O
primary O
contrast O
of O
interest O
for O
the O
Basic O
Biological O
Motion O
Task O
was O
“ O
biological O
” O
> O
“ O
non-biological. O
” O
For O
the O
Emotion O
in O
Biological O
Motion O
Task O
, O
the O
primary O
contrasts O
of O
interest O
were O
each O
condition O
( O
“ O
happy O
, O
” O
“ O
afraid O
, O
” O
“ O
angry O
, O
” O
“ O
neutral O
” O
) O
versus O
baseline O
. O

Localizer O
task O
: O
The O
primary O
goal O
of O
the O
localizer O
task O
analyses O
was O
to O
identify O
voxels O
responsive O
to O
biological O
motion O
within O
bilateral O
pSTS O
. O

An O
anatomically O
constrained O
functional O
region O
of O
interest O
( O
ROI O
) O
for O
pSTS O
was O
created O
using O
a O
two-step O
procedure O
. O

First O
, O
a O
20 O
mm O
diameter O
spheres O
were O
created O
around O
peak O
coordinates O
in O
MNI O
standard O
space O
( O
x O
= O
±52 O
, O
y O
= O
−56 O
, O
z O
= O
6 O
) O
identified O
by O
a O
recent O
meta-analysis O
. O

Next O
, O
contiguous O
voxels O
within O
that O
anatomical O
region O
of O
cortex O
were O
identified O
that O
were O
significantly O
activated O
at O
the O
group O
level O
( O
all O
subjects O
combined O
) O
by O
biological O
motion O
relative O
to O
scrambled O
motion O
at O
a O
false O
discovery O
rate O
( O
FDR O
) O
of O
q O
< O
0.05 O
( O
Fig O
. O

2A O
) O
. O

Emo O
Bio O
task O
: O
Our O
primary O
analytic O
approach O
for O
the O
Emo O
Bio O
task O
was O
to O
use O
ROIs O
to O
focus O
on O
pSTS O
and O
amygdala O
. O

The O
bilateral O
pSTS O
ROI O
was O
defined O
as O
outlined O
above O
and O
transformed O
to O
each O
individual O
's O
native O
space O
. O

Bilateral O
anatomical O
amygdala O
ROIs O
were O
created O
in O
individual O
native O
space O
based O
on O
the O
HarvardOxford O
subcortical O
probability O
atlas O
at O
a O
25 O
% O
probability O
threshold O
( O
Fig O
. O

3A O
) O
. O

First O
, O
separate O
2 O
( O
Group O
) O
× O
2 O
( O
Condition O
: O
all O
emotions O

) O
rmANOVAs O
were O
conducted O
on O
parameter O
estimates O
( O
i.e. O
, O

) O
for O
each O

to O
compare O
within O

groups O

activity O

the O
task O
. O

Follow-up O
2 O
( O
Group O
) O
x O
3 O
( O
Condition O
: O
separate O
emotions O
) O
rmANOVAs O
were O
conducted O
for O
each O
ROI O
to O
explore O
ROI O
activity O
by O
emotion O
. O

A O
two-tailed O
significance O
threshold O
of O
p O
< O
.05 O
was O
applied O
, O
with O
additional O
weight O
given O
to O
any O
findings O
with O
an O
effect O
size O
of O
medium O
or O
greater O
. O

A O
secondary O
voxel-wise O
whole-brain O
analysis O
was O
conducted O
using O
FSL O
. O

Within- O
and O
between-group O
averages O
for O
contrasts O
of O
interest O
were O
compared O
using O
mixed O
effects O
analysis O
via O
the O
FLAME O
( O
FMRIB O
's O
Local O
Analysis O
of O
Mixed O
Effects O
) O
stage O
1 O
module O
. O

Variance O
estimates O
were O
calculated O
for O
each O
group O
separately O
. O

Clusters O
exceeding O
a O
height O
threshold O
of O
Z O
> O
2.3 O
and O
a O
cluster O
probability O
of O
p O
< O
.05 O
, O
corrected O
for O
whole-brain O
multiple O
comparisons O
are O
reported O
. O

We O
examined O
functional O
connectivity O
during O
the O
emotion O
conditions O
( O
excluding O
the O
neutral O
condition O
) O
between O
pSTS O
as O
a O
seed O
region O
and O
amygdala O
, O
and O
between O
pSTS O
and O
the O
rest O
of O
the O
brain O
. O

Individual O
subject O
time O
courses O
from O
the O
Emo O
Bio O
task O
were O
extracted O
from O
the O
preprocessed O
data O
for O
each O
subject O
's O
pSTS O
ROI O
. O

The O
time O
course O
was O
then O
entered O
into O
individual O
subject O
general O
linear O
models O
in O
FSL O
as O
a O
psychophysiological O
interaction O
with O
the O
combined O
emotion O
conditions O
. O

The O
neutral O
condition O
was O
entered O
as O
a O
separate O
regressor O
to O
account O
for O
variance O
associated O
with O
that O
condition O
. O

For O
the O
whole-brain O
voxel-wise O
connectivity O
analysis O
, O
within O
and O
between O
groups O
averages O
were O
compared O
using O
mixed O
effects O
analysis O
via O
FLAME O
stage O
1 O
module O
using O
the O
same O
significance O
thresholds O
as O
the O
whole-brain O
GLM O
analysis O
. O

Modeling O
subjective O
relevance O
in O
schizophrenia O
and O
its O
relation O
to O
aberrant O
salience O
In O
schizophrenia O
, O
increased O
aberrant O
salience O
to O
irrelevant O
events O
and O
reduced O
learning O
of O
relevant O
information O
may O
relate O
to O
an O
underlying O
deficit O
in O
relevance O
detection O
. O

So O
far O
, O
subjective O
estimates O
of O
relevance O
have O
not O
been O
probed O
in O
schizophrenia O
patients O
. O

The O
mechanisms O
underlying O
belief O
formation O
about O
relevance O
and O
their O
translation O
into O
decisions O
are O
unclear O
. O

Using O
novel O
computational O
methods O
, O
we O
investigated O
relevance O
detection O
during O
implicit O
learning O
in O
42 O
schizophrenia O
patients O
and O
42 O
healthy O
individuals O
. O

Participants O
underwent O
functional O
magnetic O
resonance O
imaging O
while O
detecting O
the O
outcomes O
in O
a O
learning O
task O
. O

These O
were O
preceded O
by O
cues O
differing O
in O
color O
and O
shape O
, O
which O
were O
either O
relevant O
or O
irrelevant O
for O
outcome O
prediction O
. O

We O
provided O
a O
novel O
definition O
of O
relevance O
based O
on O
Bayesian O
precision O
and O
modeled O
reaction O
times O
as O
a O
function O
of O
relevance O
weighted O
unsigned O
prediction O
errors O
( O
UPE O
) O
. O

For O
aberrant O
salience O
, O
we O
assessed O
responses O
to O
subjectively O
irrelevant O
cue O
manifestations O
. O

Participants O
learned O
the O
contingencies O
and O
slowed O
down O
their O
responses O
following O
unexpected O
events O
. O

Model O
selection O
revealed O
that O
individuals O
inferred O
the O
relevance O
of O
cue O
features O
and O
used O
it O
for O
behavioral O
adaption O
to O
the O
relevant O
cue O
feature O
. O

Relevance O
weighted O
UPEs O
correlated O
with O
dorsal O
anterior O
cingulate O
cortex O
activation O
and O
hippocampus O
deactivation O
. O

In O
patients O
, O
the O
aberrant O
salience O
bias O
to O
subjectively O
task-irrelevant O
information O
was O
increased O
and O
correlated O
with O
decreased O
striatal O
UPE O
activation O
and O
increased O
negative O
symptoms O
. O

This O
study O
shows O
that O
relevance O
estimates O
based O
on O
Bayesian O
precision O
can O
be O
inferred O
from O
observed O
behavior O
. O

This O
underscores O
the O
importance O
of O
relevance O
detection O
as O
an O
underlying O
mechanism O
for O
behavioral O
adaptation O
in O
complex O
environments O
and O
enhances O
the O
understanding O
of O
aberrant O
salience O
in O
schizophrenia O
. O

Author O
summary O
Schizophrenia O
patients O
display O
deficits O
in O
the O
appropriate O
attribution O
of O
meaningfulness O
to O
stimuli O
; O
such O
as O
aberrantly O
increased O
processing O
of O
irrelevant O
and O
insufficient O
processing O
of O
relevant O
information O
. O

We O
aimed O
to O
investigate O
the O
subjective O
nature O
of O
relevance O
detection O
and O
its O
deficit O
in O
schizophrenia O
and O
developed O
an O
implicit O
learning O
paradigm O
that O
allowed O
for O
parallel O
learning O
from O
relevant O
and O
irrelevant O
information O
. O

Based O
on O
the O
idea O
that O
subjective O
relevance O
might O
be O
captured O
by O
Bayesian O
precision O
we O
set O
up O
different O
computational O
models O
of O
how O
subjective O
relevance O
guides O
learning O
and O
behavioral O
adaptation O
. O

We O
found O
that O
subjects O
use O
Bayesian O
precision O
to O
estimate O
stimulus O
relevance O
in O
order O
to O
integrate O
multidimensional O
information O
and O
adapt O
more O
to O
the O
subjectively O
relevant O
stimuli O
. O

This O
relevance O
weighted O
adaptation O
correlated O
with O
brain O
activation O
within O
the O
salience O
network O
. O

Further O
, O
schizophrenia O
patients O
displayed O
an O
increased O
aberrant O
tendency O
to O
irrelevant O
events O
which O
related O
to O
decreased O
striatal O
coding O
of O
the O
relevant O
learning O
signal O
. O

To O
conclude O
, O
our O
findings O
demonstrate O
how O
individual O
beliefs O
about O
relevance O
can O
be O
inferred O
from O
computational O
models O
. O

Furthermore O
, O
we O
suggest O
that O
aberrant O
salience O
observed O
in O
patients O
with O
schizophrenia O
reflects O
an O
idiosyncratic O
bias O
in O
states O
of O
high O
subjective O
uncertainty O
. O

Materials O
and O
methods O
Ethics O
statement O
All O
participants O
gave O
written O
informed O
consent O
and O
received O
monetary O
compensation O
as O
well O
as O
the O
total O
wins O
of O
the O
task O
battery O
. O

The O
study O
was O
performed O
in O
accordance O
with O
the O
Declaration O
of O
Helsinki O
and O
was O
approved O
by O
the O
local O
ethics O
committee O
of O
Charité O
Universitätsmedizin O
. O

Participants O
In O
total O
, O
42 O
schizophrenia O
patients O
and O
a O
matched O
healthy O
control O
group O
of O
42 O
individuals O
participated O
in O
this O
study O
. O

Healthy O
individuals O
reported O
no O
past O
or O
present O
psychiatric O
disorder O
according O
to O
the O
SKID-I O
. O

Patients O
were O
diagnosed O
with O
schizophrenia O
according O
to O
the O
DSM-IV O
and O
ICD-10 O
. O

Psychopathology O
was O
assessed O
using O
the O
Positive O
and O
Negative O
Syndrome O
Scale O
( O
PANSS O
) O
as O
well O
as O
the O
subscale O
for O
delusions O
and O
anhedonia O
of O
the O
Scale O
for O
the O
Assessment O
of O
Positive O
( O
SAPS O
) O
and O
Negative O
Symptoms O
( O
SANS O
) O
, O
respectively O
( O
for O
information O
on O
demographics O
and O
psychopathology O
, O
see O
Table O
1 O
) O
. O

All O
patients O
were O
on O
antipsychotic O
medication O
( O
for O
more O
details O
, O
see O
Table O

in O

) O
. O

They O
were O

from O
the O

and O

of O

of O

Aberrant O
salience O
raw O
data O
scores O
of O
a O
partially O
overlapping O
sample O
( O
37 O
healthy O
controls O
and O
34 O

) O
were O
reported O
in O
a O
previous O
publication O
. O

Implicit O
salience O
paradigm O
( O
ISP O
) O
This O
paradigm O
was O
explicitly O
instructed O
like O
a O
target-detection O
task O
though O
implicitly O
being O
a O
learning O
paradigm O
where O
features O
of O
neutral O
stimuli O
predicted O
certain O
outcomes O
. O

It O
consisted O
of O
160 O
trials O
where O
subjects O
were O
told O
to O
discriminate O
the O
outcomes O
( O
10 O
Eurocent O
coin O
or O
blue O
circle O
) O
of O
each O
trial O
. O

Therefore O
, O
their O
only O
task O
was O
to O
press O
a O
respective O
button O
when O
they O
saw O
a O
coin O
, O
versus O
another O
button O
when O
they O
saw O
the O
blue O
circle O
. O

Subjects O
were O
told O
that O
they O
would O
receive O
the O
amount O
of O
money O
they O
had O
seen O
during O
the O
task O
irrespective O
of O
whether O
they O
had O
pressed O
a O
button O
or O
not O
, O
though O
they O
were O
encouraged O
by O
the O
experimenters O
not O
to O
miss O
too O
many O
trials O
because O
this O
would O
impede O
the O
analysis O
. O

The O
outcomes O
were O
preceded O
by O
conditioned O
stimuli O
that O
differed O
in O
color O
and O
shape O
: O
gray O
or O
colorful O
squares O
or O
triangles O
( O
see O
Fig O
1A O
and O
1B O
) O
. O

During O
the O
instructions O
, O
subjects O
were O
told O
not O
to O
pay O
attention O
to O
these O
stimuli O
preceding O
the O
outcomes O
. O

However O
, O
prior O
to O
scanning O
, O
participants O
were O
primed O
with O
the O
stimulus O
features O
while O
they O
were O
asked O
to O
name O
the O
color O
and O
the O
shape O
of O
each O
of O
the O
four O
conditioned O
stimuli O
. O

Then O
, O
they O
practiced O
the O
outcome O
detection O
for O
10 O
trials O
. O

In O
this O
practice O
session O
, O
all O
outcomes O
were O
preceded O
by O
a O
stimulus O
that O
was O
not O
presented O
during O
the O
main O
experiment O
in O
the O
scanner O
. O

In O
the O
main O
experiment O
, O
the O
conditioned O
stimuli O
predicted O
the O
outcome O
types O
in O
a O
probabilistic O
manner O
that O
reversed O
during O
the O
task O
. O

Importantly O
, O
only O
one O
stimulus O
feature O
reliably O
predicted O
the O
outcome O
( O
eg O
, O
shape O
) O
. O

For O
instance O
, O
80 O
% O
of O
all O
triangles O
were O
followed O
by O
the O
coin O
( O
20 O
% O
circle O
) O
, O
and O
80 O
% O
of O
all O
squares O
were O
followed O
by O
the O
blue O
circle O
( O
20 O
% O
coin O
) O
. O

Whether O
the O
square O
or O
the O
triangle O
predicted O
the O
coin O
reversed O
every O
20 O
trials O
. O

In O
the O
meantime O
, O
the O
color O
of O
the O
stimuli O
was O
irrelevant O
in O
predicting O
the O
outcome O
; O
colorful O
and O
gray O
stimuli O
were O
equally O
followed O
by O
coins O
and O
circles O
( O
50 O
% O
each O
) O
. O

After O
the O
first O
half O
of O
the O
experiment O
this O
was O
reversed O
, O
and O
then O
the O
formerly O
irrelevant O
feature O
( O
here O
: O
shape O
) O
predicted O
the O
outcome O
, O
whereas O
the O
other O
feature O
turned O
irrelevant O
( O
see O
Fig O
2 O
) O
. O

The O
relevant O
dimensions O
were O
counterbalanced O
across O
participants O
and O
coins O
and O
neutral O
outcomes O
were O
each O
displayed O
in O
50 O
% O
of O
all O
trials O
. O

In O
total O
, O
the O
experiment O
lasted O
15 O
minutes O
and O
took O
place O
during O
fMRI O
scanning O
. O

Participants O
received O
the O
amount O
of O
coins O
seen O
in O
the O
experiment O
( O
8 O
Euro O
) O
. O

Raw O
data O
analysis O
In O
our O
raw O
data O
analysis O
of O
reaction O
times O
, O
we O
focused O
on O
two O
aspects O
: O
( O
i O
) O
learning O
of O
the O
regularly O
reversing O
relevant O
feature O
and O
( O
ii O
) O
aberrant O
salience O
towards O
one O
manifestation O
of O
the O
irrelevant O
feature O
. O

Extreme O
reaction O
times O
( O
< O
150 O
ms O
and O
> O
1.5 O
s O
) O
were O
excluded O
. O

For O
analyses O
of O
potential O
learning O
, O
reaction O
times O
( O
in O
ms O
) O
were O
log O
transformed O
to O
achieve O
normal O
distribution O
required O
for O
variance O
analyses O
. O

First O
, O
we O
tested O
whether O
subjects O
learned O
the O
cue-outcome O
contingencies O
and O
slowed O
down O
their O
responses O
if O
the O
outcome O
could O
not O
be O
predicted O
based O
on O
the O
preceding O
cues O
and O
thus O
violated O
their O
expectation O
. O

For O
that O
, O
log O
reaction O
times O
were O
compared O
for O
expected O
( O
i.e O
. O

trials O
when O
the O
0.8 O
rewarded O
feature O
was O
followed O
by O
reward O
and O
trials O
when O
the O
0.8 O
non-rewarded O
feature O
was O
followed O
by O
a O
circle O
) O
versus O
unexpected O
events O
( O
i.e O
. O

trials O
when O
the O
0.8 O
rewarded O
feature O
was O
followed O
by O
the O
circle O
and O
trials O
when O
the O
0.8 O
non-rewarded O
feature O
was O
followed O
by O
a O
coin O
) O
of O
the O
relevant O
condition O
in O
a O
repeated-measures O
ANOVA O
with O
group O
as O
between-subject O
factor O
( O
HC O
versus O
patients O
) O
and O
event O
type O
as O
within O
factor O
( O
expected O
versus O
unexpected O
) O
. O

Second O
, O
a O
change O
in O
reaction O
times O
over O
time O
following O
contingency O
changes O
inside O
the O
relevant O
cue O
feature O
was O
tested O
using O
a O
repeated-measures O
ANOVA O
. O

For O
all O
eight O
blocks O
with O
20 O
trials O
each O
, O
log-reaction O
times O
of O
the O
16 O
expected O
events O
( O
ie O
, O
spanning O
those O
8 O
trials O
when O
the O
rewarded O
feature O
was O
followed O
by O
reward O
and O
the O
8 O
trials O
when O
the O
non-rewarded O
feature O
was O
followed O
by O
a O
circle O
) O
were O
grouped O
for O
rewarded O
versus O
neutral O
outcome O
trials O
( O
Condition O
factor O
) O
and O
combined O
into O
4 O
time O
bins O
each O
, O

of O
2 O

trials O
( O
Time O
factor O
) O
. O

For O
analyses O
targeting O
responses O
with O
regard O
to O
different O
cue O
features O
, O
please O
see O
the O
Supplement O
. O

For O
aberrant O
salience O
attribution O
, O
aberrant O
salience O
scores O
were O
calculated O
as O
in O
the O
previous O

, O
and O
reflected O
an O
individual O
bias O
towards O
one O
of O
the O
two O
irrelevant O
cue O
manifestations O
based O
on O
the O
ground O
truth O
contingencies O
. O

For O
that O
, O
the O
mean O
reaction O
times O
( O
in O
ms O
) O
to O
each O
of O
the O
four O
cue O
features O
when O
they O
were O
irrelevant O
to O
the O
task O
were O
calculated O
. O

Then O
, O
aberrant O
salience O
was O
calculated O
as O
the O
absolute O
difference O
in O
reaction O
times O
between O
both O
manifestations O
of O
each O
condition O
( O
eg O
, O
square O
over O
triangle O
when O
shape O
is O
irrelevant O
) O
. O

Then O
, O
these O
two O
scores O
were O
collapsed O
across O
test O
halves O
. O

Computational O
modeling O
of O
relevant O
and O
irrelevant O
predictions O
We O
used O
detailed O
computational O
modeling O
combined O
with O
model O
selection O
in O
order O
to O
assess O
the O
learning O
mechanisms O
driving O
the O
observed O
individual O
behavior O
. O

By O
that O
we O
tested O
if O
subjects O
learned O
the O
underlying O
cue-outcome O
associations O
and O
inferred O
the O
relevant O
cue O
feature O
. O

In O
keeping O
with O
our O
initial O
definition O
of O
relevance O
, O
a O
cue O
feature O
should O
be O
perceived O
as O
more O
relevant O
the O
more O
precisely O
it O
is O
believed O
to O
predict O
the O
outcome O
. O

In O
contrast O
, O
if O
the O
association O
between O
cue O
feature O
and O
outcome O
is O
very O
noisy O
, O
because O
the O
occurrence O
of O
reward O
and O
circle O
are O
equally O
probable O
this O
feature O
should O
be O
perceived O
as O
irrelevant O
. O

We O
set O
up O
novel O
response O
models O
that O
postulated O
slowing O
down O
of O
responses O
when O
the O
expectations O
were O
violated O
. O

Computationally O
, O
a O
violation O
was O
captured O
by O
the O
unsigned O
PE O
of O
each O
feature O
. O

In O
different O
models O
, O
we O
compared O
if O
unsigned O
PEs O
of O
the O
different O
cue O
features O
differentially O
affected O
behavior O
based O
on O
their O
current O
relevance O
. O

By O
the O
relevance O
weighted O
PE O
, O
we O
implemented O
increased O
adaptation O
to O
surprising O
events O
( O
unsigned O
PE O
) O
predicted O
by O
the O
most O
relevant O
cue O
feature O
as O
well O
as O
decreased O
adaptation O
to O
the O
irrelevant O
cue O
feature O
. O

Thereby O
, O
we O
tested O
if O
individuals O
adapted O
their O
behavior O
less O
to O
events O
when O
these O
had O
proven O
to O
be O
noisy O
and O
uninformative O
in O
the O
past O
. O

Instead O
, O
they O
would O
adapt O
their O
behavior O
to O
those O
unexpected O
events O
that O
were O
held O
to O
be O
informative O
because O
these O
may O
actually O
signal O
a O
real O
change O
in O
the O
environment O
( O
as O
the O
contingency O
changes O
in O
our O
task O
) O
. O

Our O
modeling O
analysis O
was O
guided O
by O
two O
aims O
: O
Modeling O
two O
parallel O
learning O
processes O
of O
predicting O
the O
relevant O
and O
the O
irrelevant O
cue O
feature O
in O
order O
to O
compute O
distinct O
prediction O
error O
trajectories O
[ O
for O
a O
comparable O
learning O
model O
, O
please O
see O
] O
. O

Here O
, O
it O
is O
crucial O
to O
determine O
a O
formal O
definition O
of O
“ O
relevance O
” O
since O
the O
participants O
had O
to O
dynamically O
infer O
which O
cue O
feature O
was O
relevant O
for O
predicting O
the O
outcome O
( O
even O
though O
this O
was O
not O
necessary O
to O
solve O
the O
task O
, O
that O
is O
, O
discriminating O
between O
a O
coin O
and O
a O
circle O
) O
. O

Describing O
the O
aberrant O
salience O
effect O
to O
an O
irrelevant O
feature O
as O
seen O
in O
previous O
analyses O
on O
a O
computational O
level O
by O
finding O
interindividual O
differences O
in O
model O
parameters O
capturing O
this O
effect O
. O

We O
modeled O
predictions O
for O
each O
of O
the O
two O
cue O
features O
, O
shape O
and O
color O
, O
in O
separate O
HGF O
learning O
models O
so O
that O
a O
trial-by-trial O
expectation O
was O
computed O
for O
each O
feature O
( O
learning O
model O
) O
. O

We O
did O
not O
model O
relevant O
and O
irrelevant O
conditions O
separately O
because O
of O
two O
reasons O
. O

First O
, O
the O
generative O
model O
was O
supposed O
to O
capture O
the O
subjects O
’ O
learning O
experience O
and O
they O
were O
not O
instructed O
about O
the O
task O
structure O
having O
relevant O
and O
irrelevant O
conditions O
. O

Instead O
they O
were O
only O
primed O
with O
the O
distinction O
by O
feature O
, O
color O
and O
shape O
, O
in O
the O
practice O
session O
. O

Second O
, O
after O
the O
first O
half O
of O
the O
experiment O
we O
switched O
the O
relevant O
dimension O
( O
e.g O
. O

shape O
to O
color O
) O
. O

Hence O
, O
modeling O
separately O
for O
relevance O
versus O
irrelevance O
would O
have O
introduced O
external O
information O
on O
the O
task O
structure O
that O
was O
not O
accessible O
to O
subjects O
and O
thus O
not O
generative O
. O

The O
resulting O
learning O
trajectories O
for O
shape O
and O
color O
were O
transformed O
into O
trial-by-trial O
predictors O
of O
reaction O
times O
( O
response O
model O
) O
. O

Hierarchical O
Gaussian O
filter O
[ O
HGF O
; O
] O
According O
to O
the O
‘ O
Bayesian O
brain O
’ O
hypothesis O
, O
an O
agent O
forms O
a O
generative O
model O
of O
the O
world O
in O
part O
by O
increasing O
the O
precision O
of O
predictions O
( O
μ O
) O
to O
successfully O
adapt O
one O
’ O
s O
behavior O
. O

The O
HGF O
offers O
a O
generic O
framework O
for O
Bayesian O
learning O
on O
multiple O
hierarchical O
levels O
. O

Crucially O
, O
the O
belief O
update O
at O
each O
level O
is O
comprised O
of O
a O
lower-level O
prediction O
error O
that O
is O
weighted O
according O
to O
a O
cross-level O
precision O
ratio O
( O
Eqs O
1 O
and O
2 O
; O
i O
for O
learning O
level O
, O
and O
k O
for O
trial O
number O
) O
. O

The O
precision O
of O
each O
level O
’ O
s O
prediction O
is O
defined O
as O
the O
inverse O
variance O
of O
the O
prediction O
. O

We O
used O
a O
“ O
two O
branches O
” O
version O
of O
the O
HGF O
for O
parallel O
learning O
of O
the O
shape O
and O
color O
associations O
with O
the O
outcome O
. O

In O
our O
modelling O
, O
we O
focused O
on O
the O
reliability O
and O
thus O
undirected O
beliefs O
about O
associations O
. O

Thus O
, O
the O
direction O
of O
the O
learning O
trajectories O
( O
association O
beliefs O
and O
prediction O
errors O
δ O
) O
did O
not O
reflect O
the O
reward O
value O
but O
an O
arbitrarily O
determined O
relationship O
between O
cue O
feature O
manifestations O
and O
outcomes O
. O

A O
more O
detailed O
description O
of O
the O
HGF O
and O
its O
levels O
can O
be O
found O
in O
the O
Supplement O
. O

A O
novel O
definition O
of O
relevance O
: O
First-level O
precision O
Since O
the O
core O
aim O
of O
this O
study O
was O
the O
dissociation O
between O
learning O
about O
relevant O
versus O
irrelevant O
cue O
features O
, O
the O
term O
relevance O
needs O
to O
be O
defined O
formally O
. O

In O
terms O
of O
the O
ISP O
, O
a O
cue O
feature O
should O
be O
perceived O
as O
more O
relevant O
the O
more O
precisely O
it O
is O
believed O
to O
predict O
the O
outcome O
. O

In O
contrast O
, O
if O
the O
belief O
of O
an O
association O
is O
0.5 O
it O
should O
be O
perceived O
as O
irrelevant O
for O
outcome O
prediction O
( O
because O
in O
this O
case O
reward O
and O
circle O
will O
occur O
with O
the O
same O
probability O
and O
can O
not O
be O
reliably O
predicted O
) O
. O

In O
the O
HGF O
framework O
, O
this O
interpretation O
of O
relevance O
is O
reflected O
in O
the O
estimated O
precision O
of O
prediction O
on O
the O
first O
level O
( O
see O
4 O
) O
. O

It O
is O
a O
function O
only O
of O
the O
first-level O
association O
prediction O
, O
which O
ranges O
between O
0 O
and O
1. O
has O
a O
minimum O
of O
4 O
for O
and O
increases O
symmetrically O
to O
infinity O
as O
approaches O
0 O
or O
1 O
. O

This O
relevance O
could O
affect O
how O
beliefs O
are O
updated O
( O
for O
this O
implementation O
( O
‘ O
precision O
feedback O
’ O
) O
, O
see O
the O
Supplement O
) O
and/or O
how O
learning O
signals O
affect O
behavior O
, O
which O
we O
implemented O
in O
four O
response O
models O
. O

Our O
learning O
model O
space O
contained O
2-level O
and O
3-level O
HGFs O
with O
and O
without O
precision O
feedback O
( O
see O
Supplement O
) O
, O
leading O
to O
four O
different O
hierarchical O
learning O
models O
: O
2HGF O
, O
2HGFprecfb O
, O
3HGF O
, O
and O
3HGFprecfb O
. O

Response O
models O
Prediction O
errors O
relating O
to O
the O
cue O
feature O
that O
is O
thought O
to O
be O
more O
relevant O
might O
translate O
more O
strongly O
into O
reaction O
times O
, O
and O
the O
aberrant O
salience O
effect O
found O
in O
the O
raw O
data O
may O
be O
explained O
as O
a O
bias O
towards O
one O
of O
the O
irrelevant O
features O
on O
a O
trial-by-trial O
basis O
. O

Both O
aspects O
were O
formalized O
in O
the O
following O
four O
response O
models O
. O

The O
baseline O
response O
model O
( O
see O
Eq O
4 O
) O
postulates O
that O
trial-by-trial O
reaction O
times O
are O
a O
linear O
function O
of O
the O
mean O
of O
the O
prediction O
errors O
of O
both O
features O
( O
4.1.1 O
) O
, O
a O
constant O
bias O
towards O
one O
feature O
manifestation O
( O
eg O
, O
triangles O
over O
squares O
) O
and O
the O
outcome O
( O
eg O
, O
slower O
for O
circles O
than O
for O
coin O
trials O
; O
4.2.1 O
) O
. O

The O
four O
cue O
manifestation O
vectors O
m O
reflect O
whether O
the O
respective O
manifestations O
were O
displayed O
for O
every O
trial O
( O
eg O
, O
1 O
for O
triangles O
and O
0 O
for O
squares O
in O
mtriangle O
) O
. O

This O
response O
model O
was O
modified O
in O
three O
ways O
. O

In O
a O
first O
modification O
( O
4.1.2 O
) O
, O
the O
absolute O
prediction O
errors O
of O
each O
feature O
were O
weighted O
according O
to O
their O
respective O
relevance O
weight O
( O
rel O
; O
5 O
) O
. O

The O
latter O
is O
formalized O
as O
the O
relative O
amount O
of O
each O
feature O
’ O
s O
precision O
given O
the O
overall O
precisions O
of O
both O
features O
. O

In O
a O
second O
modification O
and O
in O
line O
with O
the O
aberrant O
salience O
effect O
, O
the O
constant O
bias O
was O
weighted O
according O
to O
its O
feature O
’ O
s O
irrelevance O
( O
irrel O
; O
see O
Eq O
4.2.2 O
) O
. O

The O
irrelevance O
weight O
of O
one O
feature O
was O
defined O
as O
the O
relevance O
weight O
of O
the O
opposing O
feature O
( O
see O
Eq O
5 O
) O
. O

From O
the O
four O
cue O
feature O
parameters O
( O
β2 O
, O
… O
, O
β5 O
) O
one O
composite O
parameter O
was O
calculated O
in O
two O
steps O
. O

First O
, O
the O
individual O
absolute O
differences O
between O
the O
β2 O
and O
β3 O
for O
irrelevance O
weighted O
manifestations O
within O
color O
( O
and O
between O
the O
β4 O
and O
β5 O
for O
shape O
manifestations O
) O
were O
calculated O
. O

Then O
, O
they O
were O
collapsed O
across O
color O
and O
shape O
to O
achieve O
one O
parameter O
βirrelevance O
capturing O
the O
bias O
towards O
one O
cue O
feature O
manifestation O
that O
increased O
with O
subjective O
irrelevance O
. O

Thus O
, O
we O
compared O
four O
different O
response O
models O
: O
the O
baseline O
model O
( O
Eq O
4 O
) O
, O
the O
baseline O
model O
with O
relevance O
weighted O
absolute O
prediction O
errors O
( O
Eq O
4 O
with O
modification O
term O
4.1.2 O
; O
RelPE O
) O
, O
the O
baseline O
model O
with O
only O
the O
irrelevance O
bias O
( O
Eq O
4 O
with O
modification O
term O
4.2.2 O
; O
IrrelBias O
) O
, O
and O
a O
full O
model O
with O
both O
modifications O
( O
Eq O
4 O
with O
modification O
terms O
4.1.2 O
and O
4.2.2 O
; O
RelPE+IrrelBias O
) O
. O

This O
led O
to O
a O
total O
model O
space O
of O
16 O
model O
combinations O
( O
see O
Figure O
S1 O
) O
. O

Model O
fitting O
and O
Bayesian O
model O
comparison O
All O
models O
were O
fitted O
using O
the O
HGF O
toolbox O
4.15 O
as O
part O
of O
TNU O
Algorithms O
for O
Psychiatry-Advancing O
Science O
( O
TAPAS O
, O
http O
: O
//www.translationalneuromodeling.org/tapas/ O
) O
. O

For O
optimization O
, O
a O
quasi-Newton O
optimization O
algorithm O
was O
applied O
. O

We O
used O
random-effects O
Bayesian O
Model O
Selection O
[ O
BMS O
, O
spm_BMS O
in O
SPM12 O
, O
www.fil.ion.ucl.uk/spm O
; O
] O
for O
each O
subject O
’ O
s O
and O
each O
model O
’ O
s O
negative O
free O
energy O
( O
as O
an O
approximation O
to O
log-model O
evidence O
) O
in O
order O
to O
identify O
which O
of O
the O
competing O
models O
best O
explained O
the O
subjects O
’ O
response O
time O
data O
. O

BMS O
takes O
into O
account O
accuracy O
of O
each O
model O
and O
also O
penalizes O
for O
complexity O
. O

It O
accounts O
for O
heterogeneity O
across O
subjects O
and O
treats O
each O
model O
as O
a O
random O
variable O
in O
the O
population O
. O

We O
report O
protected O
exceedance O
probabilities O
for O
each O
model O
( O
PXP O
) O
and O
posterior O
probabilities O
( O
PP O
) O
as O
well O
as O
exceedance O
probabilities O
( O
XP O
) O
for O
model O
families O
( O
HGF O
vs. O
HGFprecfb O
; O
2HGF O
vs. O
3HGF O
; O
BL O
vs. O
RelPE O
vs. O
IrrelBias O
vs. O
RelPE+IrrelBias O
) O
. O

The O
XP O
describes O
the O
relative O
probability O
that O
the O
model O
would O
better O
replicate O
the O
data O
in O
comparison O
with O
the O
other O
models O
. O

The O
PXP O
that O
governed O
our O
model O
selection O
protects O
against O
the O
‘ O
null O
’ O
possibility O
that O
there O
are O
no O
differences O
in O
the O
likelihood O
of O
models O
across O
the O
population O
. O

Simulation O
analyses O
Based O
on O
the O
estimated O
individual O
parameters O
from O
the O
best-fitting O
model O
, O
we O
simulated O
trial-by-trial O
reaction O
time O
data O
. O

In O
addition O
to O
the O
Bayesian O
model O
comparison O
, O
we O
tested O
the O
model O
’ O
s O
credibility O
by O
carrying O
out O
the O
same O
analyses O
as O
in O
the O
raw O
data O
section O
on O
the O
simulated O
data O
( O
( O
1 O
) O
Expectedness O
* O
Group O
ANOVA O
, O
( O
2 O
) O
Condition O
* O
Time O
* O
Group O
ANOVA O
, O
( O
3 O
) O
‘ O
ground O
truth O
’ O
aberrant O
salience O
group O
differences O
) O
. O

Using O
this O
approach O
, O
we O
checked O
whether O
the O
model O
was O
capable O
of O
reproducing O
the O
meaningful O
effects O
and O
group O
differences O
that O
were O
evident O
in O
the O
data O
. O

Functional O
magnetic O
resonance O
imaging O
For O
single O
and O
group O
statistics O
, O
an O
event-related O
analysis O
was O
applied O
using O
the O
general O
linear O
model O
( O
GLM O
) O
approach O
as O
implemented O
in O
SPM12 O
( O
http O
: O
//www.fil.ion.ucl.ac.uk/spm/software/spm12/ O
) O
. O

On O
the O
single O
subject O
level O
, O
the O
outcome O
onsets O
were O
convolved O
with O
the O
hemodynamic O
response O
function O
and O
its O
temporal O
derivative O
. O

As O
parametric O
modulator O
, O
the O
mean O
of O
the O
relevance O
weighted O
absolute O
prediction O
errors O
of O
the O
best O
fitting O
model O
( O
2HGF-RelPe+IrrelBias O
) O
was O
introduced O
, O
representing O
how O
unexpected O
and O
salient O
the O
observed O
outcome O
was O
based O
on O
the O
subjects O
’ O
learned O
expectations O
about O
the O
two O
cue O
features O
. O

Regressors O
of O
no O
interest O
were O
no O
response O
trials O
, O
trials O
with O
reaction O
times O
> O
1.5 O
seconds O
and O
< O
150 O
milliseconds O
, O
