realignment O
parameters O
with O
their O
first O
temporal O
derivative O
of O
translational O
movement O
, O
and O
one O
regressor O
for O
scans O
with O
> O
1mm O
scan-to-scan O
movement O
. O

For O
random O
effects O
group-level O
analysis O
, O
the O
individual O
contrast O
images O
for O
mean O
relevance O
weighted O
PEs O
were O
used O
in O
a O
two-sample O
t-test O
for O
between-group O
comparisons O
( O
controls O
vs. O
patients O
) O
. O

Explorative O
analysis O
probed O
the O
association O
between O
model O
parameter O
βirrelevance O
and O
neural O
relevance O
weighted O
PE O
signals O
in O
schizophrenia O
patients O
. O

Hence O
, O
interindividual O
βirrelevance O
scores O
were O
introduced O
as O
a O
covariate O
in O
a O
one-sample O
t-test O
using O
the O
Mean O
relevance O
weighted O
PE O
contrast O
. O

Results O
are O
reported O
using O
FWE O
correction O
at O
the O
voxel O
level O
across O
the O
whole O
brain O
. O

Based O
on O
our O
hypothesis O
concerning O
activations O
in O
areas O
previously O
shown O
to O
code O
salience O
such O
as O
the O
ACC O
and O
insula O
, O
namely O
the O
so-called O
salience O
network O
, O
and O
the O
nucleus O
accumbens O
, O
we O
applied O
small O
volume O
correction O
at O
the O
voxel O
level O
for O
the O
respective O
bilateral O
anatomical O
masks O
derived O
from O
the O
WFU O
PickAtlas O
( O
http O
: O
//fmri.wfubmc.edu/software/pickatlas O
) O
. O

Thus O
, O
three O
VOIs O
were O
used O
for O
small O
volume O
correction O
at O
pFWE O
< O
0.05 O
and O
we O
indicate O
which O
results O
survive O
Bonferroni O
correction O
for O
three O
tests O
. O

Time‐dependent O
neuronal O
changes O
associated O
with O
craving O
in O
opioid O
dependence O
: O
an O
fMRI O
study O
Abstract O
Relapse O
after O
initially O
successful O
treatment O
is O
a O
significant O
problem O
facing O
the O
treatment O
of O
opioid O
dependence O
. O

Evidence O
suggests O
craving O
elicited O
by O
re‐exposure O
to O
drug O
cues O
may O
precipitate O
relapse O
. O

Attempts O
to O
identify O
neural O
biomarkers O
of O
cue‐elicited O
craving O
have O
yielded O
inconsistent O
findings O
. O

We O
aimed O
to O
apply O
a O
novel O
continuous O
functional O
magnetic O
resonance O
imaging O
technique O
to O
follow O
the O
minute‐to‐minute O
evolution O
of O
brain O
responses O
, O
which O
correlate O
with O
the O
waxing O
and O
waning O
of O
craving O
. O

Newly O
detoxified O
male O
opioid‐dependent O
patients O
and O
healthy O
control O
participants O
attended O
two O
separate O
, O
counterbalanced O
, O
functional O
magnetic O
resonance O
imaging O
scanning O
sessions O
during O
which O
they O
viewed O
a O
10‐minute O
video O
( O
drug O
cue O
or O
neutral O
cue O
) O
followed O
by O
5 O
minutes O
of O
fixation O
. O

Participants O
rated O
the O
intensity O
of O
their O
craving O
throughout O
each O
session O
. O

We O
hypothesized O
that O
subcortical/ventral O
prefrontal O
cortex O
( O
PFC O
) O
regions O
and O
dorsal O
PFC O
regions O
would O
show O
different O
associations O
with O
craving O
reflecting O
their O
putative O
roles O
in O
appetitive O
processing O
versus O
cognitive O
control O
. O

Compared O
with O
controls O
, O
drug O
cue O
( O
minus O
neutral O
cue O
) O
video O
recruited O
the O
left O
amygdala O
and O
was O
temporally O
correlated O
with O
craving O
. O

In O
contrast O
, O
dorsal O
anterior O
cingulate O
blood‐oxygen‐level‐dependent O
signal O
time O
course O
was O
higher O
than O
controls O
only O
during O
a O
period O
after O
cue O
exposure O
when O
craving O
levels O
were O
declining O
. O

Against O
expectations O
, O
neither O
the O
ventral O
striatum O
nor O
ventral O
PFC O
was O
significantly O
recruited O
by O
drug O
cue O
exposure O
. O

Findings O
suggest O
that O
the O
amygdala O
has O
a O
central O
role O
in O
craving O
, O
whereas O
the O
dorsal O
anterior O
cingulate O
may O
control O
craving O
in O
treatment‐seeking O
patients O
. O

Time O
course O
analysis O
yielded O
new O
insights O
into O
the O
neural O
substrates O
of O
craving O
that O
could O
objectively O
validate O
development O
of O
psychological O
and O
pharmacological O
approaches O
to O
sustained O
abstinence O
. O

Methods O
and O
Materials O
Participants O
Opioid‐dependent O
individuals O
( O
n O
= O
18 O
) O
This O
study O
was O
approved O
by O
the O
NHS O
Research O
Ethics O
Committee O
. O

Participants O
with O
OD O
were O
recruited O
from O
a O
residential O
detoxification O
unit O
within O
Greater O
Manchester O
( O
see O
Table O
1 O
for O
demographic O
information O
) O
. O

Treatment O
involved O
a O
4‐week O
residential O
stay O
with O
a O
10‐day O
methadone O
stabilization O
and O
reduction O
, O
followed O
by O
10 O
days O
of O
lofexidine O
treatment O
, O
an O
alpha‐2 O
adrenergic O
receptor O
agonist O
used O
to O
treat O
opioid O
withdrawal O
symptoms O
. O

Participants O
took O
part O
in O
the O
study O
during O
the O
last O
week O
of O
their O
residential O
stay O
when O
they O
were O
opioid O
free O
( O
confirmed O
by O
urine O
drug O
screen O
) O
. O

Lofexidine O
was O
extended O
at O
low O
doses O
for O
participants O
still O
experiencing O
withdrawal O
symptoms O
during O
this O
final O
week O
, O
and O
some O
ODs O
were O
receiving O
other O
psychoactive O
medications O
as O
indicated O
by O
Supporting O
Information O
Table O
S1 O
. O

The O
OD O
group O
was O
recruited O
according O
to O
the O
following O
inclusion O
criteria O
: O
male O
, O
aged O
18–55 O
; O
current O
DSM O
IV O
heroin O
dependence O
( O
the O
majority O
of O
patients O
also O
met O
criteria O
for O
current O
or O
past O
dependence O
on O
other O
substances O
; O
Table O
1 O
) O
; O
no O
history O
of O
serious O
psychiatric O
, O
neurological O
or O
physical O
illness O
; O
no O
contraindications O
for O
MRI O
; O
and O
IQ O
of O
≥85 O
[ O
determined O
using O
the O
Wechsler O
Test O
of O
Adult O
Reading O
( O
Holdnack O
2001 O
) O
] O
. O

Participants O
were O
identified O
and O
approached O
by O
members O
of O
the O
clinical O
team O
on O
the O
basis O
of O
detailed O
physical O
and O
mental O
health O
assessments O
on O
admission O
to O
the O
unit O
. O

All O
participants O
meeting O
the O
inclusion O
criteria O
were O
approached O
to O
take O
part O
in O
the O
study O
. O

A O
total O
of O
39 O
patients O
were O
enrolled O
in O
the O
craving O
study O
; O
however O
, O
19 O
were O
discharged O
from O
the O
unit O
before O
any O
testing O
could O
take O
place O
( O
mainly O
self‐discharge O
or O
early O
discharge O
due O
to O
use O
of O
prohibited O
substances O
) O
. O

Twenty O
patients O
were O
scanned O
as O
part O
of O
the O
study O
, O
although O
two O
were O
excluded O
from O
analysis O
because O
of O
excessive O
movement O
( O
see O
Preprocessing O
section O
for O
further O
details O
) O
, O
leaving O
n O
= O
18 O
who O
were O
included O
in O
analysis O
. O

Handedness O
was O
assessed O
with O
the O
Edinburgh O
Handedness O
Inventory O
( O
Oldfield O
1971 O
) O
. O

Healthy O
controls O
( O
n O
= O
20 O
) O
Healthy O
controls O
( O
HCs O
) O
were O
recruited O
who O
were O
familiar O
with O
graphic O
scenes O
of O
drug O
use O
because O
of O
occupational O
experience O
( O
e.g O
. O

drug O
treatment O
workers O
and O
other O
health O
professionals O
) O
. O

The O
HC O
group O
met O
the O
same O
inclusion O
criteria O
outlined O
previously O
and O
additionally O
had O
no O
current O
or O
past O
history O
of O
drug O
dependence O
or O
misuse O
( O
except O
nicotine O
) O
and O
had O
never O
used O
heroin O
in O
their O
lifetime O
. O

No O
healthy O
volunteers O
were O
receiving O
psychoactive O
medications O
. O

Participants O
were O
screened O
with O
the O
Mini O
International O
Neuropsychiatric O
Interview O
( O
Sheehan O
et O
al O
. O

1998 O
) O
, O
Wechsler O
Test O
of O
Adult O
Reading O
and O
Edinburgh O
Handedness O
Inventory O
. O

All O
participants O
provided O
written O
consent O
and O
were O
paid O
for O
their O
participation O
with O
vouchers O
. O

Procedures O
Participants O
attended O
two O
separate O
, O
counterbalanced O
sessions O
. O

Patients O
were O
scanned O
in O
the O
last O
week O
of O
their O
residential O
stay O
when O
they O
were O
opioid O
free O
. O

On O
each O
occasion O
, O
participants O
underwent O
fMRI O
, O
once O
whilst O
viewing O
a O
10‐minute O
heroin O
video O
( O
drug O
cue O
session O
) O
and O
once O
whilst O
viewing O
a O
10‐minute O
video O
containing O
scenes O
matched O
for O
visual O
complexity O
but O
lacking O
emotionally O
arousing O
content O
( O
neutral O
session O
) O
. O

Videos O
were O
preceded O
and O
followed O
by O
5 O
minutes O
of O
fixation O
( O
Fig O
. O

1 O
) O
. O

Images O
were O
presented O
using O
e‐prime O
( O
Psychology O
Software O
Tools O
, O
Inc O
, O
Sharpsburg O
, O
USA O
) O
( O
version O
2.0 O
) O
. O

Measures O
Participants O
were O
presented O
with O
Likert‐like O
subjective O
rating O
scales O
throughout O
the O
scanning O
session O
. O

Participants O
were O
prompted O
to O
respond O
by O
a O
screen O
displaying O
the O
following O
text O
‘ O
do O
you O
feel O
you O
are O
… O
’ O
, O
which O
was O
presented O
for O
3 O
seconds O
before O
slides O
stating O
‘ O
Craving O
? O
’ O
, O
‘ O
Withdrawing O
? O
’ O
, O
‘ O
Anxious O
? O
’ O
or O
‘ O
High O
? O
’ O
, O
were O
presented O
for O
4 O
seconds O
along O
with O
the O
following O
scale O
: O
1 O
( O
not O
all O
) O
, O
2 O
( O
slightly O
) O
, O
3 O
( O
moderately O
) O
and O
4 O
( O
extremely O
) O
. O

Participants O
responded O
via O
a O
button O
box O
. O

The O
scales O
were O
presented O
at O
3‐minute O
intervals O
in O
each O
session O
( O
Fig O
. O

1 O
) O
Behavioural O
data O
Mixed O
ANOVAs O
were O
carried O
out O
for O
each O
of O
the O
four O
subjective O
rating O
scales O
with O
time O
of O
rating O
( O
six O
levels O
including O
a O
pre‐video O
baseline O
rating O
, O
three O
during O
the O
video O
and O
two O
post‐video O
ratings O
) O
and O
session O
( O
drug O
cue O
, O
neutral O
) O
as O
within‐subject O
factors O
and O
group O
( O
HC O
, O
OD O
) O
as O
the O
between‐subject O
factor O
. O

Session O
order O
was O
included O
as O
a O
covariate O
. O

The O
pre‐video O
rating O
taken O
during O
the O
last O
minute O
of O
the O
baseline O
period O
( O
T0 O
) O
was O
used O
as O
the O
pre‐video O
baseline O
rating O
. O

A O
Greenhouse‐Geisser O
correction O
was O
applied O
when O
Mauchley O
's O
assumption O
of O
sphericity O
was O
violated O
. O

Ratings O
from O
one O
HC O
were O
not O
included O
as O
the O
participant O
could O
not O
see O
the O
rating O
scales O
. O

Scanning O
and O
analysis O
Whole O
brain O
T2 O
* O
weighted O
images O
were O
acquired O
on O
a O
3 O
Tesla O
Philips O
Achieva O
scanner O
with O
single O
shot O
, O
multi‐slice O
echo O
planar O
( O
EPI O
) O
pulse O
sequence O
. O

Each O
volume O
comprised O
34 O
contiguous O
axial O
slices O
( O
TR O
= O
2.5 O
s O
, O
TE O
= O
35 O
ms O
, O
96 O
× O
96 O
matrix O
, O
in‐plane O
voxel O
size O
3.0 O
mm O
× O
3.0 O
mm O
, O
slice O
thickness O
3.5 O
mm O
) O
. O

A O
high‐resolution O
T1‐weighted O
structural O
image O
was O
also O
acquired O
for O
each O
participant O
for O
coregistration O
during O
preprocessing O
and O
to O
exclude O
any O
structural O
abnormality O
. O

Preprocessing O
Functional O
data O
were O
analysed O
using O
statistical O
parametric O
mapping O
( O
SPM8 O
; O
The O
Wellcome O
Department O
of O
Cognitive O
Neurology O
, O
London O
, O
UK O
) O
running O
in O
MATLAB O
( O
Matlab O
, O
R2012a O
; O
Mathworks O
, O
Natick O
, O
Massachusetts O
, O
U.S.A. O
) O
. O

Functional O
images O
were O
realigned O
and O
coregistered O
with O
the O
T1 O
structural O
image O
before O
normalization O
of O
the O
functional O
images O
into O
standard O
space O
was O
carried O
out O
using O
the O
unified O
segmentation O
approach O
( O
Ashburner O
& O
Friston O
2005 O
) O
. O

Normalized O
images O
were O
smoothed O
using O
an O
8‐mm O
Gaussian O
kernel O
. O

The O
smoothed O
functional O
images O
of O
the O
participants O
who O
moved O
more O
than O
1 O
voxel O
were O
repaired O
by O
an O
interpolation O
method O
using O
the O
artefact O
repair O
toolbox O
( O
http O
: O
//cibsr.stanford.edu/tools/ArtRepair/ArtRepair.htm O
) O
. O

Two O
ODs O
with O
excessive O
movement O
were O
excluded O
( O
> O
10 O
percent O
volumes O
needing O
repairing O
) O
. O

Eighteen O
ODs O
and O
20 O
HCs O
were O
entered O
into O
subsequent O
analyses O
. O

First‐level O
analysis O
For O
both O
the O
drug O
cue O
and O
the O
neutral O
session O
, O
data O
were O
acquired O
continuously O
for O
20 O
minutes O
( O
5 O
minutes O
before O
the O
start O
of O
each O
video O
to O
allow O
participants O
to O
acclimatize O
to O
the O
scanner O
environment O
, O
10 O
minutes O
during O
presentation O
of O
the O
video O
and O
an O
additional O
5 O
minutes O
after O
the O
end O
of O
the O
video O
) O
( O
Fig O
. O

1 O
) O
. O

The O
resultant O
480 O
acquired O
scans O
were O
divided O
into O
1‐minute O
time‐bins O
( O
20 O
time‐bins O
in O
total O
) O
. O

The O
5th O
minute O
of O
the O
pre‐video O
baseline O
was O
treated O
as O
the O
baseline O
time‐bin O
T0 O
, O
with O
each O
subsequent O
time‐bin O
( O
T1–15 O
) O
compared O
with O
T0 O
using O
regression O
analysis O
within O
a O
general O
linear O
model O
framework O
. O

The O
exact O
shape O
of O
the O
signal O
of O
interest O
was O
unknown O
; O
therefore O
, O
no O
high‐pass O
filter O
was O
used O
. O

The O
neutral O
session O
averages O
were O
subtracted O
from O
the O
time O
equivalent O
drug O
cue O
session O
averages O
, O
resulting O
in O
‘ O
drug O
cue O
session–neutral O
session O
’ O
contrast O
images O
. O

Region‐of‐interest O
analysis O
A O
region‐of‐interest O
( O
ROI O
) O
approach O
was O
used O
to O
extract O
time O
course O
signals O
from O
key O
brain O
regions O
involved O
in O
drug O
cue O
reactivity O
based O
on O
recent O
meta‐analyses O
( O
Chase O
et O
al O
. O

2011 O
; O
Kuhn O
& O
Gallinat O
2011 O
) O
. O

These O
composed O
of O
spheres O
of O
7‐mm O
radius O
centred O
around O
the O
bilateral O
ventral O
striatum O
, O
amygdala O
and O
VmPFC O
, O
coordinates O
from O
Chase O
et O
al O
. O

( O
2011 O
) O
, O
and O
anterior O
cingulate O
cortex O
, O
coordinates O
from O
Kuhn O
& O
Gallinat O
( O
2011 O
) O
, O
as O
displayed O
in O
Fig O
. O

3 O
. O

Mean O
drug O
cue‐neutral O
session O
contrast O
estimates O
were O
extracted O
from O
each O
of O
the O
six O
ROIs O
using O
the O
Easy O
ROI O
toolbox O
implemented O
in O
SPM O
( O
http O
: O
//www.sbirc.ed.ac.uk/LCL/LCL_M1.html O
) O
and O
entered O
into O
mixed O
ANOVAs O
in O
SPSS O
( O
version O
20 O
) O
to O
investigate O
effects O
of O
time O
and O
group O
on O
drug O
cue‐neutral O
session O
BOLD O
signal O
. O

Investigations O
were O
carried O
out O
for O
the O
whole O
session O
( O
T0 O
to O
T15 O
) O
and O
for O
the O
video O
time‐bins O
( O
T1–T10 O
) O
and O
post‐video O
time‐bins O
separately O
( O
T11 O
to O
T15 O
) O
with O
session O
order O
included O
as O
a O
covariate O
. O

A O
Greenhouse‐Geisser O
correction O
was O
applied O
when O
Mauchley O
's O
assumption O
of O
sphericity O
was O
violated O
. O

A O
Bonferroni O
correction O
for O
the O
six O
separate O
ROIs O
results O
in O
a O
significance O
value O
of O
p O
< O
0.008 O
for O
this O
analysis O
. O

However O
, O
this O
is O
a O
conservative O
approach O
, O
which O
may O
result O
in O
false O
negatives O
. O

Results O
are O
therefore O
reported O
significant O
at O
p O
< O
0.05 O
with O
results O
surviving O
Bonferroni O
correction O
highlighted O
. O

ROI O
BOLD O
signal O
time O
course O
and O
subjective O
rating O
time O
course O
temporal O
correlation O
analysis O
In O
participants O
reporting O
a O
subjective O
rating O
change O
in O
response O
to O
the O
drug O
cue O
session O
, O
we O
investigated O
whether O
their O
subjective O
rating O
time O
course O
was O
temporally O
correlated O
with O
fMRI O
signal O
in O
the O
ROIs O
. O

Analyses O
were O
restricted O
to O
subjective O
ratings O
and O
ROI O
BOLD O
signal O
time O
courses O
, O
demonstrating O
significant O
effects O
in O
the O
ANOVAs O
. O

Before O
correlations O
were O
carried O
out O
, O
the O
pre‐video O
baseline O
subjective O
rating O
was O
subtracted O
from O
each O
video O
and O
post‐video O
rating O
for O
each O
session O
. O

The O
neutral O
session O
ratings O
were O
then O
subtracted O
from O
the O
drug O
cue O
session O
ratings O
. O

This O
was O
to O
ensure O
both O
the O
fMRI O
and O
subjective O
rating O
data O
reflected O
drug O
cue O
session O
changes O
from O
baseline O
minus O
neutral O
session O
changes O
from O
baseline O
( O
fMRI O
data O
already O
in O
this O
format O
after O
first‐level O
analysis O
) O
. O

Finally O
, O
the O
fMRI O
BOLD O
signal O
data O
were O
averaged O
over O
3‐minute O
intervals O
to O
reflect O
the O
3‐minute O
interval O
of O
subjective O
rating O
presentation O
during O
each O
session O
. O

Correlational O
analyses O
were O
carried O
out O
between O
each O
individual O
's O
subjective O
rating O
and O
ROI O
BOLD O
signal O
time O
courses O
using O
Pearson O
's O
product O
moment O
correlation O
coefficient O
. O

Resultant O
correlation O
coefficients O
were O
Fisher O
's O
z‐transformed O
and O
entered O
into O
one‐sample O
t‐tests O
to O
determine O
group O
level O
significance O
. O

Imaging O
resilience O
and O
recovery O
in O
alcohol O
dependence O
Background O
and O
aims O
Resilience O
and O
recovery O
are O
of O
increasing O
importance O
in O
the O
field O
of O
alcohol O
dependence O
( O
AD O
) O
. O

This O
paper O
describes O
how O
imaging O
studies O
in O
man O
can O
be O
used O
to O
assess O
the O
neurobiological O
correlates O
of O
resilience O
and O
, O
if O
longitudinal O
, O
of O
disease O
trajectories O
, O
progression O
rates O
and O
markers O
for O
recovery O
to O
inform O
treatment O
and O
prevention O
options O
. O

Methods O
Original O
articles O
on O
recovery O
and O
resilience O
in O
alcohol O
addiction O
and O
its O
neurobiological O
correlates O
were O
identified O
from O
‘ O
PubMed O
’ O
and O
have O
been O
analyzed O
and O
condensed O
within O
a O
systematic O
literature O
review O
. O

Results O
Findings O
deriving O
from O
( O
f O
) O
MRI O
and O
PET O
studies O
have O
identified O
links O
between O
increased O
resilience O
and O
less O
task-elicited O
neural O
activation O
within O
the O
basal O
ganglia O
, O
and O
benefits O
of O
heightened O
neural O
prefrontal O
cortex O
( O
PFC O
) O
engagement O
regarding O
resilience O
in O
a O
broader O
sense O
, O
namely O
resilience O
against O
relapse O
in O
early O
abstinence O
of O
AD O
. O

Furthermore O
, O
findings O
consistently O
propose O
at O
least O
partial O
recovery O
of O
brain O
glucose O
metabolism O
and O
executive O
and O
general O
cognitive O
functioning O
, O
as O
well O
as O
structural O
plasticity O
effects O
throughout O
the O
brain O
of O
alcohol-dependent O
patients O
during O
the O
course O
of O
short O
, O
medium O
and O
long-term O
abstinence O
, O
even O
when O
patients O
only O
lowered O
their O
alcohol O
consumption O
to O
a O
moderate O
level O
. O

Additionally O
, O
specific O
factors O
were O
found O
that O
appear O
to O
influence O
these O
observed O
brain O
recovery O
processes O
in O
AD O
, O
e.g O
. O

genotype-dependent O
neuronal O
( O
re O
) O
growth O
, O
gender-specific O
neural O
recovery O
effects O
, O
critical O
interfering O
effects O
of O
psychiatric O
comorbidities O
, O
additional O
smoking O
or O
marijuana O
influences O
, O
or O
adolescent O
alcohol O
abuse O
. O

Conclusions O
Neuroimaging O
research O
has O
uncovered O
neurobiological O
markers O
that O
appear O
to O
be O
linked O
to O
resilience O
and O
improved O
recovery O
capacities O
that O
are O
furthermore O
influenced O
by O
various O
factors O
such O
as O
gender O
or O
genetics O
. O

Consequently O
, O
future O
system-oriented O
approaches O
may O
help O
to O
establish O
a O
broad O
neuroscience-based O
research O
framework O
for O
alcohol O
dependence O
. O

Methods O
Search O
strategy O
We O
systematically O
reviewed O
the O
existing O
literature O
up O
to O
November O
2017 O
using O
PUBMED O
electronic O
database O
for O
the O
identification O
of O
neuroimaging O
studies O
investigating O
recovery O
and/or O
resilience O
in O
alcohol O
dependence O
or O
alcohol O
dependence O
in O
humans O
, O
respectively O
. O

We O
therefore O
used O
the O
following O
search O
terms O
: O
imaging O
, O
neuroimaging O
, O
addiction O
, O
dependence O
, O
alcohol O
* O
, O
substance O
use O
* O
, O
substance O
use O
disorder O
, O
recovery O
, O
resilience O
. O

Bibliographies O
of O
relevant O
articles O
were O
additionally O
screened O
for O
further O
relevant O
information O
. O

Study O
selection O
We O
included O
peer-reviewed O
original O
studies O
irrespective O
of O
when O
the O
study O
was O
conducted O
and O
excluded O
single O
case O
studies O
, O
reviews O
and O
meta-analyses O
. O

For O
the O
sake O
of O
parsimony O
, O
we O
further O
excluded O
neuroimaging O
studies O
using O
imaging O
techniques O
other O
than O
functional O
magnetic O
resonance O
imaging O
( O
fMRI O
) O
, O
structural O
MRI O
, O
diffusion O
tensor O
imaging O
( O
DTI O
) O
, O
or O
positron O
emission O
tomography O
( O
PET O
) O
. O

Additional O
exclusion O
criteria O
were O
: O
not O
in O
English O
, O
substances O
other O
than O
alcohol O
, O
neuropsychological O
studies O
without O
neuroimaging O
. O

Extraction O
and O
quality O
assessment O
One O
reviewer O
( O
KC O
) O
screened O
abstracts O
of O
articles O
identified O
for O
potential O
relevance O
. O

Then O
, O
two O
reviewers O
( O
AB O
and O
KC O
) O
independently O
extracted O
study O
data O
and O
further O
screened O
bibliographies O
of O
relevant O
articles O
. O

In O
the O
event O
of O
uncertainty O
or O
disagreement O
regarding O
criteria O
for O
eligibility O
between O
AB O
and O
KC O
, O
selected O
articles O
and O
manuscript O
draft O
were O
further O
discussed O
with O
the O
third O
and O
fourth O
reviewer O
( O
FWL O
and O
AH O
) O
. O

Decisions O
on O
study O
selection O
were O
documented O
by O
AR O
. O

Data-driven O
approaches O
for O
identifying O
links O
between O
brain O
structure O
and O
function O
in O
health O
and O
disease O
Brain O
imaging O
technology O
provides O
a O
powerful O
tool O
to O
visualize O
the O
living O
human O
brain O
, O
provide O
insights O
into O
disease O
mechanisms O
, O
and O
potentially O
provide O
a O
tool O
to O
assist O
clinical O
decision-making O
. O

The O
brain O
has O
a O
very O
specific O
structural O
substrate O
providing O
a O
foundation O
for O
functional O
information O
; O
however O
, O
most O
studies O
ignore O
the O
very O
interesting O
and O
complex O
relationships O
between O
brain O
structure O
and O
brain O
function O
. O

While O
a O
variety O
of O
approaches O
have O
been O
used O
to O
study O
how O
brain O
structure O
informs O
function O
, O
the O
study O
of O
such O
relationships O
in O
living O
humans O
in O
most O
cases O
is O
limited O
to O
noninvasive O
approaches O
at O
the O
macroscopic O
scale O
. O

The O
use O
of O
data-driven O
approaches O
to O
link O
structure O
and O
function O
provides O
a O
tool O
which O
is O
especially O
important O
at O
the O
macroscopic O
scale O
at O
which O
we O
can O
study O
the O
human O
brain O
. O

This O
paper O
reviews O
data-driven O
approaches O
, O
with O
a O
focus O
on O
independent O
component O
analysis O
approaches O
, O
which O
leverage O
higher O
order O
statistics O
to O
link O
together O
macroscopic O
structural O
and O
functional O
MRI O
data O
. O

Such O
approaches O
provide O
the O
benefit O
of O
allowing O
us O
to O
identify O
links O
which O
do O
not O
necessarily O
correspond O
spatially O
( O
eg O
, O
structural O
changes O
in O
one O
region O
related O
to O
functional O
changes O
in O
other O
regions O
) O
. O

They O
also O
provide O
a O
“ O
network O
level O
” O
perspective O
on O
the O
data O
, O
by O
enabling O
us O
to O
identify O
sets O
of O
brain O
regions O
that O
covary O
together O
. O

This O
also O
opens O
up O
the O
ability O
to O
evaluate O
both O
within O
and O
between O
network O
relationships O
. O

A O
variety O
of O
examples O
are O
presented O
, O
including O
several O
showing O
the O
potential O
of O
such O
approaches O
to O
inform O
us O
about O
mental O
illness O
, O
particularly O
about O
schizophrenia O
. O

Altered O
Small-World O
Networks O
in O
First-Episode O
Schizophrenia O
Patients O
during O
Cool O
Executive O
Function O
Task O
At O
present O
, O
little O
is O
known O
about O
brain O
functional O
connectivity O
and O
its O
small-world O
topologic O
properties O
in O
first-episode O
schizophrenia O
( O
SZ O
) O
patients O
during O
cool O
executive O
function O
task O
. O

In O
this O
paper O
, O
the O
Trail O
Making O
Test-B O
( O
TMT-B O
) O
task O
was O
used O
to O
evaluate O
the O
cool O
executive O
function O
of O
first-episode O
SZ O
patients O
and O
electroencephalography O
( O
EEG O
) O
data O
were O
recorded O
from O
14 O
first-episode O
SZ O
patients O
and O
14 O
healthy O
controls O
during O
this O
cool O
executive O
function O
task O
. O

Brain O
functional O
connectivity O
between O
all O
pairs O
of O
EEG O
channels O
was O
constructed O
based O
on O
mutual O
information O
( O
MI O
) O
analysis O
. O

The O
constructed O
brain O
functional O
networks O
were O
filtered O
by O
three O
thresholding O
schemes O
: O
absolute O
threshold O
, O
mean O
degree O
, O
and O
a O
novel O
data-driven O
scheme O
based O
on O
orthogonal O
minimal O
spanning O
trees O
( O
OMST O
) O
, O
and O
graph O
theory O
was O
then O
used O
to O
study O
the O
topographical O
characteristics O
of O
the O
filtered O
brain O
graphs O
. O

Results O
indicated O
that O
the O
graph O
theoretical O
measures O
of O
the O
theta O
band O
showed O
obvious O
difference O
between O
SZ O
patients O
and O
healthy O
controls O
. O

In O
the O
theta O
band O
, O
the O
characteristic O
path O
length O
was O
significantly O
longer O
and O
the O
cluster O
coefficient O
was O
significantly O
smaller O
in O
the O
SZ O
patients O
for O
a O
wide O
range O
of O
absolute O
threshold O
T. O
However O
, O
the O
cluster O
coefficient O
showed O
no O
significant O
changes O
, O
and O
the O
characteristic O
path O
length O
was O
still O
significantly O
longer O
in O
SZ O
patients O
when O
calculated O
as O
a O
function O
of O
mean O
degree O
K. O
Interestingly O
, O
we O
also O
found O
that O
only O
the O
characteristic O
path O
length O
was O
significantly O
longer O
in O
SZ O
patients O
compared O
with O
healthy O
controls O
after O
using O
the O
OMST O
scheme O
. O

Pearson O
correlation O
analysis O
showed O
that O
the O
characteristic O
path O
length O
was O
positively O
correlated O
with O
executive O
time O
of O
TMT-B O
for O
the O
combined O
SZ O
patients O
and O
healthy O
controls O
( O
r O
= O
0.507 O
, O
P O
= O
0.006 O
) O
, O
but O
not O
for O
SZ O
patients O
alone O
( O
r O
= O
0.072 O
, O
P O
= O
0.612 O
) O
. O

The O
above O
results O
suggested O
a O
less O
optimal O
organization O
of O
the O
brain O
network O
and O
could O
be O
useful O
for O
understanding O
the O
pathophysiologic O
mechanisms O
underlying O
cool O
executive O
dysfunction O
in O
first-episode O
SZ O
patients O
. O

2 O
. O

Materials O
and O
Methods O
2.1 O
. O

Subjects O
14 O
first-episode O
SZ O
patients O
( O
9 O
male O
and O
5 O
female O
) O
were O
recruited O
from O
the O
Henan O
Psychiatric O
Hospital O
of O
China O
according O
to O
the O
Structured O
Clinical O
Interview O
for O
DSM-IV O
, O
and O
any O
patients O
with O
a O
history O
of O
medication O
treatment O
, O
drug O
abuse/dependence O
, O
electroconvulsive O
therapy O
, O
or O
other O
psychiatric O
and O
neurological O
diseases O
were O
excluded O
. O

The O
mean O
age O
of O
the O
14 O
SZ O
patients O
was O
28.21 O
± O
6.94 O
years O
, O
the O
mean O
duration O
of O
illness O
was O
18.26 O
± O
7.03 O
months O
, O
and O
all O
patients O
are O
right-handed O
. O

For O
healthy O
controls O
, O
a O
group O
of O
14 O
subjects O
matched O
for O
sex O
, O
age O
, O
and O
dominant O
side O
was O
recruited O
( O
9 O
male O
and O
5 O
female O
; O
mean O
age O
: O
25.13 O
± O
3.75 O
; O
all O
right-handed O
) O
, O
and O
any O
healthy O
controls O
with O
a O
past O
or O
current O
psychiatric O
illness O
, O
drug O
dependence O
, O
neurological O
disorders O
, O
or O
severe O
somatic O
diseases O
were O
excluded O
. O

The O
study O
was O
approved O
by O
the O
ethics O
committee O
of O
Henan O
Psychiatric O
Hospital O
of O
China O
, O
and O
an O
informed O
consent O
form O
was O
signed O
by O
all O
participants O
before O
the O
experiment O
. O

2.2 O
. O

EEG O
Recordings O
and O
MI O
Computation O
The O
EEG O
data O
were O
recorded O
from O
all O
participants O
when O
they O
were O
performing O
a O
cool O
executive O
function O
task O
, O
that O
is O
, O
the O
TMT-B O
task O
. O

As O
for O
the O
TMT-B O
task O
that O
evaluates O
quick O
visual O
search O
, O
visual O
space O
sorting O
, O
and O
cognitive O
set O
transfer O
functions O
, O
the O
participants O
were O
asked O
to O
connect O
numbers O
( O
1–13 O
) O
and O
letters O
( O
A–M O
) O
using O
a O
pen O
on O
a O
paper O
according O
to O
an O
alternating O
sequence O
as O
fast O
as O
possible O
, O
and O
the O
pen O
tip O
can O
not O
leave O
the O
paper O
during O
this O
process O
. O

The O
execution O
time O
to O
complete O
this O
task O
and O
the O
error O
number O
that O
is O
the O
number O
of O
incorrectly O
linked O
numbers O
and O
letters O
were O
used O
to O
evaluate O
the O
task O
performance O
of O
the O
participants O
. O

The O
EEG O
data O
were O
recorded O
at O
a O
sampling O
rate O
of O
1000 O
Hz O
from O
24 O
channels O
( O
FP1 O
, O
FPz O
, O
FP2 O
, O
AF3 O
, O
AF4 O
, O
F7 O
, O
F5 O
, O
F3 O
, O
F1 O
, O
Fz O
, O
F2 O
, O
F4 O
, O
F6 O
, O
F8 O
, O
T7 O
, O
C3 O
, O
C4 O
, O
T8 O
, O
P7 O
, O
P3 O
, O
P4 O
, O
P8 O
, O
O1 O
, O
and O
O2 O
) O
that O
were O
mounted O
on O
the O
scalp O
with O
a O
64-channel O
EEG O
cap O
according O
to O
the O
10-20 O
standard O
system O
. O

And O
the O
impedance O
of O
all O
electrodes O
was O
below O
10 O
kΩ O
. O

Offline O
EEG O
preprocessing O
was O
carried O
out O
by O
using O
Matlab O
7.7.0 O
R2010a O
software O
( O
Mathworks O
Inc. O
, O
USA O
) O
equipped O
with O
the O
EEGLAB O
toolbox O
. O

Firstly O
, O
a O
0.5–30 O
Hz O
zero-phase O
bandpass O
filter O
was O
applied O
. O

Then O
, O
ocular O
and O
prominent O
muscle O
artifacts O
were O
removed O
by O
means O
of O
independent O
component O
analysis O
( O
ICA O
) O
, O
and O
the O
average O
number O
of O
artifactual O
independent O
components O
was O
3.1 O
± O
0.8 O
( O
mean O
± O
std O
) O
and O
3.4 O
± O
0.7 O
( O
mean O
± O
std O
) O
for O
healthy O
controls O
and O
SZ O
patients O
, O
respectively O
. O

Subsequently O
, O
the O
EEG O
data O
were O
divided O
into O
10-second O
epochs O
and O
recomputed O
against O
the O
average O
reference O
. O

Finally O
, O
the O
following O
4 O
frequency O
bands O
were O
obtained O
using O
a O
zero-phase O
bandpass O
filter O
: O
delta O
( O
0.5–3 O
Hz O
) O
, O
theta O
( O
4–7 O
Hz O
) O
, O
alpha O
( O
8–13 O
Hz O
) O
, O
and O
beta O
( O
13–30 O
Hz O
) O
. O

MI O
is O
based O
on O
information O
theory O
and O
can O
be O
used O
to O
measure O
the O
amount O
of O
information O
that O
can O
be O
obtained O
about O
one O
variable O
from O
the O
measurement O
of O
another O
. O

The O
main O
advantage O
of O
MI O
is O
that O
it O
takes O
account O
of O
both O
linear O
and O
nonlinear O
dependencies O
. O

The O
detailed O
calculation O
method O
of O
MI O
was O
described O
in O
some O
previously O
published O
literature O
. O

Briefly O
, O
given O
two O
random O
variables O
X O
and O
Y O
, O
the O
pairwise O
MI O
is O
defined O
as O
where O
PX O
( O
x O
) O
is O
the O
probability O
that O
x O
is O
drawn O
from O
X O
and O
PXY O
( O
x O
, O
y O
) O
is O
the O
joint O
probability O
density O
function O
for O
the O
measurements O
of O
X O
and O
Y O
that O
produce O
the O
values O
x O
and O
y. O
MI O
is O
estimated O
from O
a O
finite O
number O
of O
samples O
, O
and O
the O
probability O
densities O
, O
PX O
( O
x O
) O
and O
PXY O
( O
x O
, O
y O
) O
, O
are O
approximated O
by O
histogram O
( O
using O
bin O
size O
of O
100 O
) O
. O

For O
a O
fair O
comparison O
across O
subjects O
and O
frequency O
bands O
, O
here O
we O
computed O
the O
normalized O
MI O
as O
where O
H O
( O
X O
) O
and O
H O
( O
X O
) O
are O
the O
entropies O
and O
H O
( O
X O
) O
is O
defined O
as O
∑xPX O
( O
x O
) O
log2PX O
( O
x O
) O
. O

The O
normalized O
MI O
is O
in O
the O
range O
of O
[ O
0 O
, O
1 O
] O
. O

Here O
, O
the O
data O
are O
separated O
into O
10-second O
epochs O
for O
MI O
computation O
in O
order O
to O
increase O
the O
sample O
size O
as O
well O
as O
to O
enhance O
the O
stationarity O
and O
consistency O
of O
the O
MI O
computation O
. O

MI O
between O
all O
pairs O
of O
EEG O
channels O
was O
computed O
, O
resulting O
in O
a O
24 O
× O
24 O
matrix O
( O
24 O
is O
the O
number O
of O
EEG O
channels O
) O
. O

For O
each O
epoch O
, O
the O
MI O
matrix O
was O
computed O
, O
and O
an O
average O
MI O
matrix O
for O
each O
subject O
was O
obtained O
by O
averaging O
the O
MI O
matrixes O
calculated O
from O
all O
epochs O
. O

According O
to O
the O
above O
process O
, O
the O
MI O
matrixes O
for O
the O
above-mentioned O
four O
frequency O
bands O
( O
delta O
: O
0.5–3 O
Hz O
, O
theta O
: O
4–7 O
Hz O
, O
alpha O
: O
8–13 O
Hz O
, O
and O
beta O
: O
13–30 O
Hz O
) O
were O
computed O
. O

2.3 O
. O

Graph O
Theoretical O
Analysis O
In O
this O
paper O
, O
the O
MI O
matrix O
was O
converted O
into O
an O
undirected O
binary O
graph O
by O
applying O
three O
network O
filtering O
schemes O
: O
absolute O
threshold O
T O
, O
mean O
degree O
K O
, O
and O
OMST O
method O
. O

Because O
there O
is O
no O
optimal O
way O
to O
select O
T O
, O
here O
the O
range O
of O
0.15 O
< O
T O
< O
0.45 O
( O
in O
step O
of O
0.005 O
) O
was O
selected O
for O
the O
four O
bands O
. O

It O
is O
well-known O
that O
the O
edge O
number O
in O
a O
graph O
has O
a O
great O
relationship O
with O
the O
values O
of O
L O
and O
C O
, O
and O
the O
edge O
number O
in O
the O
2 O
graphs O
( O
SZ O
patients O
and O
healthy O
controls O
) O
will O
be O
different O
by O
applying O
a O
certain O
T. O
Therefore O
, O
in O
order O
to O
eliminate O
this O
effect O
, O
the O
L O
and O
C O
were O
calculated O
as O
a O
function O
of O
degree O
K O
( O
2 O
< O
K O
< O
8 O
, O
in O
step O
of O
0.1 O
) O
. O

Recently O
, O
Dimitriadis O
et O
al O
. O

proposed O
a O
novel O
data-driven O
topological O
filtering O
scheme O
based O
on O
OMST O
, O
which O
filters O
brain O
connectivity O
networks O
based O
on O
the O
optimization O
between O
the O
global O
efficiency O
of O
the O
network O
and O
the O
cost O
preserving O
its O
wiring O
. O

Here O
, O
we O
tried O
using O
the O
OMST O
method O
to O
filter O
the O
constructed O
brain O
networks O
and O
recomputed O
graph O
theoretical O
measures O
. O

After O
the O
MI O
matrix O
was O
converted O
into O
an O
undirected O
binary O
graph O
, O
the O
graph O
theoretical O
measures O
, O
such O
as O
characteristic O
path O
length O
L O
and O
cluster O
coefficient O
C O
, O
were O
computed O
. O

Detailed O
descriptions O
and O
calculation O
methods O
for O
L O
and O
C O
could O
be O
found O
in O
some O
previously O
published O
literature O
. O

The O
small-world O
network O
is O
characterized O
by O
a O
similar O
path O
length O
and O
higher O
cluster O
coefficient O
compared O
to O
a O
random O
network O
, O
that O
is O
, O
γ O
= O
Creal/Crandom O
> O
1 O
, O
λ O
= O
Lreal/Lrandom O
≈ O
1 O
. O

And O
the O
small-world O
index O
could O
be O
defined O
as O
σ O
= O
γ/λ O
. O

For O
the O
small-world O
network O
, O
the O
σ O
is O
greater O
than O
1 O
. O

Here O
, O
in O
order O
to O
compute O
small-world O
indexes O
of O
experimental O
networks O
( O
SZ O
patients O
and O
healthy O
controls O
) O
, O
after O
applying O
the O
OMST O
filtering O
scheme O
, O
300 O
random O
networks O
were O
generated O
for O
each O
experimental O
network O
by O
using O
the O
Markov-chain O
algorithm O
. O

As O
a O
result O
, O
the O
mean O
small-world O
index O
σ O
of O
experimental O
networks O
( O
SZ O
patients O
and O
healthy O
controls O
) O
was O
computed O
. O

2.4 O
. O

Statistical O
Analysis O
All O
statistical O
analyses O
were O
carried O
out O
using O
SPSS O
version O
21.0 O
software O
( O
SPSS O
Inc. O
, O
Chicago O
, O
IL O
) O
. O

The O
Shapiro-Wilk O
test O
was O
used O
to O
test O
for O
normality O
of O
distribution O
. O

Task O
performance O
, O
such O
as O
execution O
time O
and O
error O
number O
, O
was O
statistically O
compared O
between O
SZ O
patients O
and O
healthy O
controls O
by O
using O
independent O
sample O
t-test O
. O

The O
differences O
of O
C O
and O
L O
between O
SZ O
patients O
and O
healthy O
controls O
for O
each O
value O
over O
a O
range O
of O
T O
or O
degree O
K O
were O
compared O
by O
using O
the O
Mann–Whitney O
U O
test O
. O

In O
addition O
, O
Pearson O
correlation O
analysis O
was O
applied O
to O
explore O
whether O
there O
existed O
correlation O
between O
C O
or O
L O
and O
task O
performance O
. O

P O
< O
0.05 O
showed O
that O
a O
significant O
difference O
existed O
. O

Insight O
and O
emotion O
regulation O
in O
schizophrenia O
: O
A O
brain O
activation O
and O
functional O
connectivity O
study O
Background O
Insight O
is O
impaired O
in O
the O
majority O
of O
schizophrenia O
patients O
. O

The O
exact O
neural O
correlates O
of O
impaired O
insight O
remain O
unclear O
. O

We O
assume O
that O
the O
ability O
to O
regulate O
emotions O
contributes O
to O
having O
good O
clinical O
insight O
, O
as O
patients O
should O
be O
able O
to O
regulate O
their O
emotional O
state O
in O
such O
a O
way O
that O
they O
can O
adapt O
adequately O
in O
order O
to O
cope O
with O
impaired O
functioning O
and O
negative O
stigma O
associated O
with O
a O
diagnosis O
of O
schizophrenia O
. O

Numerous O
studies O
have O
shown O
emotional O
dysregulation O
in O
schizophrenia O
. O

We O
investigated O
the O
association O
between O
insight O
and O
brain O
activation O
and O
connectivity O
during O
emotion O
regulation O
. O

Methods O
Brain O
activation O
during O
emotion O
regulation O
was O
measured O
with O
functional O
MRI O
in O
30 O
individuals O
with O
schizophrenia O
. O

Two O
emotion O
regulation O
strategies O
were O
examined O
: O
cognitive O
reappraisal O
and O
expressive O
suppression O
. O

Clinical O
insight O
was O
measured O
with O
the O
Schedule O
for O
the O
Assessment O
of O
Insight O
– O
Expanded O
, O
and O
cognitive O
insight O
was O
measured O
with O
the O
Beck O
Cognitive O
Insight O
Scale O
. O

Whole O
brain O
random O
effects O
multiple O
regression O
analyses O
were O
conducted O
to O
assess O
the O
relation O
between O
brain O
activation O
during O
emotion O
regulation O
and O
insight O
. O

Generalized O
psychophysiological O
interaction O
( O
gPPI O
) O
was O
used O
to O
investigate O
the O
relation O
between O
task-related O
connectivity O
and O
insight O
. O

Results O
No O
significant O
associations O
were O
found O
between O
insight O
and O
neural O
correlates O
of O
cognitive O
reappraisal O
. O

For O
clinical O
insight O
and O
suppression O
, O
significant O
positive O
associations O
were O
found O
between O
symptom O
relabeling O
and O
activation O
in O
the O
left O
striatum O
, O
thalamus O
and O
insula O
, O
right O
insula O
and O
caudate O
, O
right O
pre- O
and O
postcentral O
gyrus O
, O
left O
superior O
occipital O
gyrus O
and O
cuneus O
and O
right O
middle O
and O
superior O
occipital O
gyrus O
and O
cuneus O
. O

Furthermore O
, O
reduced O
clinical O
insight O
was O
associated O
with O
more O
connectivity O
between O
midline O
medial O
frontal O
gyrus O
and O
right O
middle O
occipital O
gyrus O
. O

For O
cognitive O
insight O
and O
suppression O
, O
significant O
positive O
associations O
were O
found O
between O
self-reflectiveness O
and O
activation O
in O
pre- O
and O
postcentral O
gyrus O
and O
left O
middle O
cingulate O
gyrus O
. O

Conclusions O
Our O
results O
suggest O
an O
association O
between O
the O
capacity O
to O
relabel O
symptoms O
and O
activation O
of O
brain O
systems O
involved O
in O
cognitive-emotional O
control O
and O
visual O
processing O
of O
negative O
stimuli O
. O

Furthermore O
, O
poorer O
self-reflectiveness O
may O
be O
associated O
with O
brain O
systems O
subserving O
control O
and O
execution O
. O

Highlights O
We O
examined O
the O
association O
between O
emotion O
regulation O
and O
insight O
in O
schizophrenia O
. O

Patients O
with O
poorer O
insight O
engage O
different O
neural O
pathways O
during O
suppression O
. O

This O
finding O
was O
strengthened O
by O
connectivity O
measures O
of O
corresponding O
brain O
areas O
. O

No O
relationship O
between O
cognitive O
reappraisal O
and O
insight O
was O
found O
. O

Methods O
Participants O
35 O
individuals O
with O
schizophrenia O
( O
SZ O
; O
73 O
% O
men O
) O
and O
16 O
healthy O
controls O
( O
HC O
; O
67 O
% O
men O
) O
were O
included O
in O
this O
study O
. O

All O
patients O
were O
diagnosed O
with O
schizophrenia O
by O
a O
psychiatrist O
according O
to O
DSM-IV-TR O
and O
ICD-10 O
criteria O
, O
which O
was O
confirmed O
with O
the O
Mini O
International O
Neuropsychiatric O
Interview O
( O
MINI-plus O
) O
. O

Patients O
were O
recruited O
from O
several O
mental O
health O
institutions O
in O
the O
Netherlands O
in O
a O
consecutive O
manner O
. O

All O
healthy O
controls O
were O
assessed O
with O
the O
MINI-plus O
to O
confirm O
lack O
of O
personal O
history O
of O
psychiatric O
, O
somatic O
and O
neurological O
illnesses O
. O

They O
were O
matched O
to O
the O
patient O
group O
on O
age O
, O
handedness O
, O
sex O
and O
education O
. O

All O
participants O
were O
of O
ages O
18 O
and O
above O
and O
were O
able O
to O
give O
informed O
consent O
. O

Exclusion O
criteria O
for O
this O
study O
were O
having O
an O
acute O
psychosis O
, O
having O
a O
co-morbid O
psychiatric O
, O
somatic O
and/or O
neurological O
disorder O
, O
drug O
use O
, O
change O
of O
medication O
within O
the O
last O
week O
, O
use O
of O
a O
benzodiazepine O
equivalent O
to O
> O
3 O
mg O
lorazepam O
, O
electroconvulsive O
therapy O
within O
the O
last O
year O
and O
MRI O
contra-indications O
( O
i.e O
. O

metal O
implants O
, O
red O
ink O
tattoos O
, O
pregnancy O
or O
possibility O
thereof O
and O
claustrophobia O
) O
. O

All O
participants O
provided O
informed O
consent O
and O
received O
45 O
euros O
for O
participation O
. O

The O
study O
protocol O
was O
approved O
by O
the O
medical O
ethical O
board O
of O
the O
University O
Medical O
Center O
Groningen O
and O
was O
in O
accordance O
with O
the O
latest O
version O
of O
the O
Declaration O
of O
Helsinki O
. O

Five O
patients O
and O
one O
healthy O
individual O
were O
excluded O
from O
analyses O
for O
different O
reasons O
: O
lack O
of O
understanding O
of O
fMRI O
task O
( O
2 O
SZ O
) O
, O
MRI O
artefact O
( O
1 O
SZ O
) O
, O
lack O
of O
logging O
of O
onset O
times O
of O
different O
conditions O
fMRI O
task O
( O
1 O
SZ O
) O
and O
excessive O
head O
motion O
( O
1 O
SZ O
and O
1 O
HC O
) O
. O

This O
left O
a O
group O
of O
30 O
SZ O
patients O
and O
15 O
HC O
for O
analyses O
; O
their O
clinical O
and O
demographic O
characteristics O
can O
be O
seen O
in O
Table O
1 O
. O

Clinical O
measures O
Clinical O
characteristics O
Severity O
and O
frequency O
of O
last O
week O
's O
symptoms O
were O
assessed O
with O
the O
Positive O
and O
Negative O
Syndrome O
Scale O
( O
PANSS O
) O
, O
which O
is O
a O
semi-structured O
interview O
scored O
by O
a O
trained O
interviewer O
. O

The O
PANSS O
was O
used O
for O
the O
assessment O
of O
general O
psychopathology O
as O
well O
as O
positive O
and O
negative O
symptoms O
. O

Clinical O
insight O
Clinical O
insight O
was O
measured O
with O
the O
Schedule O
for O
the O
Assessment O
of O
Insight O
– O
Expanded O
( O
SAI-E O
) O
. O

The O
SAI-E O
is O
a O
12-item O
researcher-reported O
semi-structured O
interview O
measuring O
three O
subdimensions O
of O
insight O
: O
( O
1 O
) O
awareness O
of O
illness O
, O
( O
2 O
) O
relabeling O
of O
symptoms O
and O
( O
3 O
) O
awareness O
of O
need O
for O
treatment O
. O

Three O
subscale O
scores O
can O
be O
calculated O
, O
as O
well O
as O
a O
subtotal O
score O
( O
items O
1–9 O
) O
, O
with O
higher O
scores O
indicating O
better O
clinical O
insight O
. O

These O
subscales O
have O
been O
confirmed O
with O
factor O
analysis O
in O
several O
studies O
that O
found O
three O
similar O
factors O
. O

Subscale O
scores O
as O
well O
as O
SAI-E O
subtotal O
score O
were O
used O
for O
fMRI O
analyses O
. O

Cognitive O
insight O
Cognitive O
insight O
was O
measured O
with O
the O
Beck O
Cognitive O
Insight O
Scale O
( O
BCIS O
) O
. O

The O
BCIS O
is O
a O
self-report O
15-item O
questionnaire O
that O
consists O
of O
two O
subscales O
: O
( O
1 O
) O
self-reflection O
( O
SR O
; O
e.g. O
, O
‘ O
I O
am O
sometimes O
wrong O
about O
how O
people O
feel O
and O
think O
about O
me O
’ O
; O
9 O
items O
) O
and O
( O
2 O
) O
self-certainty O
( O
SC O
; O
e.g. O
, O
‘ O
my O
interpretations O
of O
my O
experiences O
are O
absolutely O
right O
’ O
; O
6 O
items O
) O
. O

These O
two O
factors O
have O
been O
confirmed O
by O
multiple O
studies O
. O

Two O
subscales O
scores O
and O
a O
composite O
index O
score O
( O
self-reflection O
score O
minus O
self-certainty O
score O
) O
were O
computed O
. O

All O
three O
scores O
were O
used O
for O
subsequent O
fMRI O
analyses O
. O

Poor O
cognitive O
insight O
is O
reflected O
by O
high O
scores O
on O
self-certainty O
, O
low O
scores O
on O
self-reflection O
and O
a O
low O
composite O
index O
score O
. O

Emotion O
regulation O
questionnaire O
Emotion O
regulation O
strategies O
were O
assessed O
with O
the O
Dutch O
version O
of O
the O
Emotion O
Regulation O
Questionnaire O
( O
ERQ O
) O
. O

This O
is O
a O
10-item O
self-report O
questionnaire O
that O
measures O
the O
use O
of O
reappraisal O
and O
suppression O
as O
emotion O
regulation O
strategies O
in O
daily O
life O
. O

This O
questionnaire O
consists O
of O
6 O
items O
measuring O
reappraisal O
( O
e.g O
. O

‘ O
I O
control O
my O
emotions O
by O
changing O
the O
way O
I O
think O
about O
the O
situation O
I O
am O
in O
’ O
) O
and O
4 O
items O
measuring O
suppression O
( O
e.g O
. O

‘ O
I O
control O
my O
emotions O
by O
not O
expressing O
them O
’ O
) O
. O

These O
subscales O
have O
been O
confirmed O
with O
factor O
analysis O
. O

All O
items O
were O
measured O
on O
a O
7-point O
scale O
( O
strongly O
disagree O
- O
strongly O
agree O
) O
. O

Subscale O
scores O
were O
calculated O
by O
dividing O
the O
total O
subscale O
score O
by O
the O
number O
of O
subscale O
items O
. O

Affect O
The O
Positive O
and O
Negative O
Affect O
Schedule O
( O
PANAS O
) O
is O
a O
20-item O
self-report O
measure O
assessing O
positive O
and O
negative O
affect O
at O
this O
moment O
. O

Responses O
were O
measured O
on O
a O
5-point O
scale O
( O
very O
slightly O
or O
not O
at O
all O
- O
extremely O
) O
. O

The O
PANAS O
has O
been O
shown O
to O
be O
a O
reliable O
and O
valid O
measure O
of O
affective O
state O
. O

Task O
and O
stimuli O
The O
emotion O
regulation O
task O
of O
event-related O
design O
that O
is O
used O
in O
this O
study O
is O
based O
on O
the O
theoretical O
framework O
of O
Gross O
, O
and O
was O
designed O
and O
published O
by O
. O

The O
task O
was O
programmed O
using O
E-Prime O
software O
version O
1.0.2 O
( O
Psychology O
Software O
Tools O
, O
Pittsburg O
, O
PA O
, O
USA O
) O
, O
run O
in O
Windows O
, O
which O
also O
recorded O
participants O
' O
responses O
. O

This O
task O
was O
validated O
in O
a O
previous O
study O
by O
our O
group O
examining O
healthy O
individuals O
, O
patients O
with O
schizophrenia O
and O
non-affected O
siblings O
. O

Before O
scanning O
, O
all O
participants O
received O
training O
to O
make O
sure O
they O
completely O
understood O
the O
task O
and O
what O
was O
asked O
of O
them O
. O

They O
told O
the O
researcher O
how O
they O
would O
regulate O
their O
emotions O
during O
the O
different O
conditions O
in O
order O
to O
practice O
all O
different O
emotion O
regulation O
strategies O
until O
complete O
understanding O
of O
the O
task O
. O

The O
emotional O
pictures O
, O
extracted O
from O
the O
International O
Affective O
Picture O
System O
( O
IAPS O
) O
, O
which O
were O
used O
as O
stimuli O
during O
training O
, O
were O
different O
from O
pictures O
used O
during O
the O
experiment O
. O

During O
the O
experiment O
, O
88 O
stimuli O
were O
shown O
in O
total O
, O
of O
which O
66 O
were O
negative O
( O
mean O
valence O
: O
2.6 O
; O
mean O
arousal O
: O
5.7 O
) O
and O
22 O
were O
neutral O
( O
mean O
valence O
: O
1.3 O
, O
mean O
arousal O
: O
1.9 O
) O
. O

Stimuli O
were O
selected O
in O
a O
randomized O
way O
. O

Each O
trial O
lasted O
15.5 O
s O
and O
consisted O
of O
six O
parts O
: O
( O
1 O
) O
view O
( O
2 O
s O
) O
, O
( O
2 O
) O
regulation O
( O
4 O
s O
) O
, O
( O
3 O
) O
lingering O
( O
2 O
s O
) O
, O
( O
4 O
) O
rating O
( O
3 O
s O
) O
, O
( O
5 O
) O
relax O
( O
4 O
s O
) O
and O
( O
6 O
) O
intertrial O
interval O
( O
0.5 O
s O
) O
( O
see O
Fig O
. O

3 O
) O
. O

Only O
the O
regulation O
part O
differed O
between O
trials O
, O
and O
could O
be O
one O
of O
five O
conditions O
: O
attend O
neutral O
, O
attend O
negative O
, O
reappraise O
, O
suppress O
and O
increase O
. O

During O
View O
, O
participants O
were O
shown O
the O
emotional O
picture O
with O
the O
instruction O
‘ O
view O
’ O
asking O
participants O
to O
look O
at O
the O
picture O
. O

After O
that O
, O
instructions O
were O
presented O
on O
the O
screen O
below O
the O
picture O
instructing O
the O
participants O
how O
to O
regulate O
their O
emotional O
reaction O
to O
the O
picture O
( O
Regulation O
: O
attend O
, O
reappraise O
, O
suppress O
or O
increase O
) O
. O

Instructions O
were O
in O
accordance O
with O
and O
, O
but O
translated O
into O
Dutch O
. O

During O
‘ O
attend O
’ O
the O
participants O
were O
asked O
to O
just O
look O
at O
the O
picture O
, O
while O
the O
participants O
were O
asked O
to O
regulate O
their O
emotions O
during O
‘ O
reappraise O
’ O
, O
‘ O
suppress O
’ O
and O
‘ O
increase O
’ O
. O

During O
‘ O
reappraisal O
’ O
the O
participant O
was O
instructed O
to O
reinterpret O
the O
picture O
in O
a O
way O
that O
decreases O
negative O
feelings O
. O

The O
instructions O
for O
‘ O
suppression O
’ O
asked O
the O
participant O
to O
suppress O
the O
expressive O
emotional O
reaction O
provoked O
by O
the O
picture O
. O

They O
were O
instructed O
that O
no O
one O
should O
be O
able O
to O
read O
their O
emotions O
from O
their O
face O
. O

The O
‘ O
increase O
’ O
condition O
entailed O
the O
opposite O
of O
the O
‘ O
reappraise O
’ O
condition O
, O
so O
participants O
had O
to O
increase O
the O
negative O
emotions O
caused O
by O
the O
stimulus O
. O

Stimuli O
were O
shown O
for O
6 O
s O
in O
total O
( O
during O
View O
and O
Regulation O
) O
. O

After O
the O
emotion O
regulation O
part O
of O
this O
task O
, O
the O
participants O
were O
asked O
to O
let O
their O
emotions O
linger O
while O
a O
black O
screen O
was O
shown O
to O
them O
( O
Lingering O
) O
. O

Consequently O
, O
participants O
had O
to O
rate O
how O
negatively O
they O
felt O
at O
that O
moment O
( O
Rating O
; O
score O
1–4 O
from O
‘ O
not O
negative O
’ O
to O
‘ O
very O
negative O
’ O
) O
. O

At O
last O
, O
the O
word O
‘ O
relax O
’ O
was O
presented O
and O
participants O
could O
relax O
for O
4 O
s O
( O
Relax O
) O
. O

The O
intertrial O
interval O
lasted O
0.5 O
s O
and O
consisted O
of O
a O
black O
screen O
to O
indicate O
start O
of O
a O
new O
trial O
. O

Each O
regulation O
condition O
occurred O
22 O
times O
; O
hence O
, O
the O
experimental O
paradigm O
consisted O
of O
110 O
trials O
( O
22 O
trials O
per O
condition O
) O
of O
15.5 O
s. O
After O
every O
tenth O
trial O
, O
a O
rest O
block O
was O
included O
in O
which O
a O
fixation O
cross O
was O
presented O
for O
20 O
s O
( O
Fixation O
; O
baseline O
) O
. O

Total O
fMRI O
scan O
duration O
for O
this O
task O
was O
around O
32 O
min O
and O
the O
task O
was O
scanned O
in O
two O
sessions O
to O
prevent O
fatigue O
. O

Image O
acquisition O
All O
scans O
were O
made O
in O
the O
Neuroimaging O
Center O
of O
the O
University O
Medical O
Center O
Groningen O
( O
UMCG O
) O
in O
Groningen O
. O

Scans O
were O
acquired O
using O
a O
3T O
Phillips O
Intera O
Quaser O
( O
Philips O
Intera O
, O
Best O
, O
the O
Netherlands O
) O
equipped O
with O
a O
synergy O
SENSE O
eight-channel O
head O
coil O
. O

Functional O
images O
were O
acquired O
using O
a O
T2 O
* O
-weighted O
echo-planar O
sequence O
producing O
37 O
interleaved O
axial O
slices O
tilted O
approximately O
30° O
, O
a O
thickness O
of O
3.5 O
mm O
and O
no O
slice O
gap O
to O
cover O
the O
entire O
cortex O
( O
TR O
= O
2 O
s O
; O
TE O
= O
30 O
ms O
; O
flip O
angle O
= O
70° O
; O
FOV O
= O
224 O
, O
129.5 O
, O
224 O
; O
64 O
× O
62 O
matrix O
of O
3.5 O
× O
3.5 O
× O
3.5 O
voxels O
) O
. O

In O
addition O
, O
a O
T1-weighted O
3D O
fast O
field O
echo O
( O
FFE O
) O
anatomical O
image O
( O
voxel O
size O
1 O
× O
1 O
× O
1 O
mm O
) O
containing O
170 O
slices O
( O
TR O
= O
9 O
ms O
; O
TE O
= O
3.54 O
ms O
; O
slice O
thickness O
= O
1 O
mm O
; O
256 O
× O
256 O
matrix O
; O
FOV O
232 O
, O
170 O
, O
256 O
mm O
) O
was O
acquired O
parallel O
to O
the O
bicommissural O
plane O
. O

Every O
run O
started O
with O
several O
dummy O
scans O
to O
ensure O
steady O
state O
magnetization O
before O
acquiring O
the O
data O
used O
for O
analyses O
. O

Method O
of O
analysis O
Demographic O
and O
clinical O
characteristics O
and O
insight O
SPSS O
20 O
( O
SPSS O
Inc. O
, O
Chicago O
, O
IL O
, O
USA O
) O
was O
used O
for O
all O
behavioral O
data O
analyses O
. O

Methods O
and O
results O
of O
group O
comparisons O
( O
SZ O
vs O
HC O
) O
as O
well O
as O
correlations O
between O
insight O
and O
demographic O
or O
clinical O
variables O
are O
described O
in O
Supplementary O
Materials O
1.1 O
and O
2.1.1 O
, O
respectively O
. O

Haloperidol O
equivalents O
were O
calculated O
based O
on O
antipsychotic O
dose O
. O

Haloperidol O
equivalents O
of O
pimozide O
were O
calculated O
by O
first O
converting O
to O
olanzapine O
according O
to O
, O
followed O
by O
conversion O
to O
haloperidol O
according O
to O
. O

Emotion O
regulation O
questionnaire O
We O
calculated O
Pearson O
correlations O
between O
a O
priori O
emotion O
regulation O
strategies O
and O
insight O
, O
results O
of O
which O
were O
evaluated O
at O
an O
FDR-corrected O
level O
corrected O
for O
4 O
tests O
. O

Methods O
and O
results O
of O
group O
comparisons O
are O
described O
in O
Supplementary O
Materials O
1.2 O
and O
2.1.2 O
, O
respectively O
. O

Affect O
Pearson O
correlations O
between O
a O
priori O
( O
negative O
and O
positive O
) O
affect O
and O
insight O
were O
calculated O
. O

A O
threshold O
of O
p O
< O
0.05 O
, O
two-tailed O
, O
was O
used O
as O
the O
standard O
for O
statistical O
significance O
and O
all O
correlations O
between O
PANAS O
subscales O
and O
insight O
were O
evaluated O
at O
an O
FDR-corrected O
level O
corrected O
for O
4 O
tests O
. O

Methods O
and O
results O
of O
group O
comparisons O
are O
described O
in O
Supplementary O
Materials O
1.3 O
and O
2.1.3 O
, O
respectively O
. O

Emotion O
regulation O
task O
Pearson O
correlations O
between O
negative O
affect O
ratings O
during O
the O
task O
and O
insight O
were O
calculated O
. O

A O
threshold O
of O
p O
< O
0.05 O
, O
two-tailed O
, O
was O
used O
as O
the O
standard O
for O
statistical O
significance O
and O
all O
correlations O
between O
negative O
affect O
ratings O
and O
RTs O
( O
after O
reappraise O
and O
suppress O
) O
and O
( O
clinical O
and O
cognitive O
) O
insight O
were O
evaluated O
at O
an O
FDR-corrected O
level O
corrected O
for O
8 O
tests O
. O

Methods O
and O
results O
of O
group O
comparisons O
are O
described O
in O
Supplementary O
Materials O
1.4 O
and O
2.1.4 O
, O
respectively O
. O

fMRI O
analyses O
We O
analyzed O
fMRI-data O
using O
Statistical O
Parametric O
Mapping O
( O
SPM12 O
– O
version O
r6223 O
) O
( O
www.fil.ion.ucl.ac.uk/spm O
) O
run O
in O
Matlab O
8.1 O
( O
The O
MathWorks O
Inc. O
, O
Natick O
, O
MA O
, O
USA O
) O
. O

First O
, O
all O
images O
were O
checked O
for O
artefacts O
( O
1 O
patient O
was O
excluded O
, O
as O
mentioned O
in O
2.1 O
Participants O
subsection O
) O
. O

Functional O
as O
well O
as O
anatomical O
images O
were O
reoriented O
parallel O
to O
the O
AC-PC O
plane O
. O

Functional O
images O
were O
corrected O
for O
slice O
timing O
( O
reference O
slice O
: O
middle O
slice O
) O
and O
realigned O
to O
the O
first O
volume O
of O
the O
first O
run O
. O

The O
details O
of O
the O
transformation O
were O
checked O
and O
participants O
who O
showed O
> O
6 O
mm O
movement O
across O
the O
session O
were O
dropped O
from O
analyses O
( O
1 O
HC O
and O
1 O
SZ O
, O
as O
mentioned O
in O
2.1 O
Participants O
subsection O
) O
. O

The O
mean O
functional O
scans O
created O
during O
realignment O
were O
coregistered O
to O
the O
anatomical O
scans O
( O
4th O
degree O
B-spline O
interpolation O
) O
. O

Functional O
images O
were O
spatially O
normalized O
based O
on O
the O
Montreal O
Neurological O
Image O
( O
MNI O
) O
T1 O
template O
and O
smoothed O
with O
a O
6 O
mm O
full-width O
half O
maximum O
( O
FWHM O
) O
Gaussian O
smoothing O
kernel O
. O

Smoothing O
was O
done O
with O
a O
6 O
mm O
kernel O
given O
our O
a O
priori O
interest O
in O
the O
amygdala O
. O

Coregistration O
and O
normalization O
were O
checked O
after O
coregistration O
and/or O
normalization O
and O
, O
if O
necessary O
, O
adjusted O
manually O
( O
adjustment O
after O
coregistration O
, O
n O
= O
31 O
; O
additional O
adjustment O
after O
normalization O
, O
n O
= O
21 O
) O
. O

In O
case O
of O
manual O
adjustment O
after O
normalization O
, O
functional O
images O
were O
resliced O
after O
this O
adjustment O
. O

At O
first O
level O
, O
a O
general O
linear O
model O
( O
GLM O
) O
was O
created O
which O
included O
14 O
condition-regressors O
( O
7 O
condition-regressors O
per O
session O
) O
modelled O
with O
a O
boxcar O
function O
convolved O
with O
a O
canonical O
hemodynamic O
response O
function O
( O
HRF O
) O
: O
( O
1 O
) O
view O
, O
( O
2 O
) O
attend O
neutral O
, O
( O
3 O
) O
attend O
negative O
, O
( O
4 O
) O
reappraisal O
, O
( O
5 O
) O
suppression O
, O
( O
6 O
) O
increase O
, O
( O
7 O
) O
after O
. O

The O
regressor O
‘ O
after O
’ O
included O
the O
Lingering O
, O
Rating O
and O
Relax O
parts O
of O
the O
task O
. O

Fixation O
crosses O
and O
intertrial O
intervals O
were O
seen O
as O
baseline O
brain O
activity O
. O

The O
six O
estimated O
motion O
parameters O
and O
their O
derivatives O
were O
added O
to O
the O
model O
to O
correct O
for O
motion O
effects O
. O

A O
high-pass O
filter O
cut-off O
of O
128 O
s O
was O
used O
, O
and O
serial O
correlations O
were O
accounted O
for O
using O
an O
autoregressive O
( O
AR O
( O
1 O
) O
) O
model O
during O
classical O
( O
ReML O
) O
parameter O
estimation O
. O

Three O
contrasts O
were O
defined O
for O
each O
participant O
: O
( O
1 O
) O
reappraise O
versus O
attend O
negative O
, O
( O
2 O
) O
suppress O
versus O
attend O
negative O
, O
and O
( O
3 O
) O
increase O
versus O
attend O
negative O
. O

These O
contrasts O
examine O
which O
brain O
regions O
are O
activated O
more O
during O
emotion O
regulation O
compared O
to O
attending O
to O
a O
negative O
picture O
, O
to O
isolate O
regions O
that O
are O
important O
for O
these O
emotion O
regulation O
strategies O
. O

The O
increase O
condition O
was O
not O
of O
our O
interest O
, O
but O
activation O
during O
this O
condition O
and O
differences O
between O
groups O
in O
activation O
during O
this O
condition O
will O
be O
described O
in O
Supplementary O
Materials O
2.2 O
and O
2.3 O
, O
respectively O
. O

At O
second O
level O
, O
first O
, O
main O
task O
effects O
were O
examined O
in O
all O
participants O
with O
one O
sample O
t-tests O
using O
contrasts O
reappraise O
> O
attend O
negative O
, O
suppress O
> O
attend O
negative O
and O
increase O
> O
attend O
negative O
. O

Second O
, O
between O
group O
differences O
were O
examined O
with O
two O
sample O
t-tests O
using O
the O
same O
contrasts O
. O

Between O
group O
analyses O
were O
conducted O
to O
examine O
whether O
patients O
engaged O
additional O
or O
different O
neural O
resources O
compared O
to O
HC O
. O

Third O
, O
second-level O
whole O
brain O
random O
effects O
multiple O
regression O
analyses O
were O
conducted O
to O
assess O
the O
relation O
between O
brain O
activation O
during O
emotion O
regulation O
and O
insight O
. O

Only O
patients O
were O
included O
in O
these O
analyses O
( O
n O
= O
30 O
) O
, O
and O
whole O
brain O
as O
well O
as O
region O
of O
interest O
( O
ROI O
) O
analyses O
were O
conducted O
. O

Contrasts O
reappraisal O
> O
attend O
negative O
and O
suppression O
> O
attend O
negative O
were O
used O
for O
further O
analyses O
, O
as O
there O
was O
no O
rationale O
for O
examining O
the O
association O
between O
insight O
and O
use O
of O
reappraisal O
to O
increase O
negative O
emotions O
. O

Thus O
, O
the O
contrast O
reappraisal O
> O
attend O
negative O
or O
suppression O
> O
attend O
negative O
was O
entered O
, O
with O
demeaned O
clinical O
insight O
scores O
( O
SAI-E O
subtotal O
score O
) O
or O
demeaned O
cognitive O
insight O
scores O
( O
BCIS O
composite O
index O
score O
) O
as O
covariate O
of O
interest O
. O

The O
same O
analysis O
was O
done O
for O
the O
subscale O
scores O
, O
with O
either O
the O
three O
demeaned O
SAI-E O
subscale O
scores O
as O
covariates O
of O
interest O
or O
the O
demeaned O
BCIS O
subscale O
scores O
as O
covariates O
of O
interest O
. O

All O
of O
these O
analyses O
were O
thresholded O
with O
family-wise O
error O
( O
FWE O
) O
cluster-level O
correction O
at O
p O
< O
0.05 O
( O
using O
an O
initial O
threshold O
of O
p O
< O
0.001 O
, O
uncorrected O
) O
. O

No O
extra O
correction O
was O
applied O
to O
correct O
for O
the O
number O
of O
contrasts O
tested O
. O

For O
the O
ROI O
random O
effects O
multiple O
regression O
analyses O
, O
masks O
of O
the O
IFG O
were O
made O
using O
Marsbar O
, O
based O
on O
group O
level O
activation O
during O
either O
reappraise O
> O
attend O
negative O
or O
suppress O
> O
attend O
negative O
. O

For O
reappraisal O
> O
attend O
negative O
, O
the O
mask O
included O
the O
right O
inferior O
frontal O
gyrus O
, O
insula O
and O
superior O
temporal O
gyrus O
. O

Two O
masks O
were O
made O
for O
suppression O
> O
attend O
negative O
; O
the O
first O
mask O
included O
the O
left O
inferior O
frontal O
gyrus O
and O
insula O
, O
while O
the O
second O
mask O
included O
the O
right O
inferior O
frontal O
gyrus O
and O
insula O
. O

Results O
of O
these O
ROI O
random O
effects O
multiple O
regression O
analyses O
were O
viewed O
with O
voxel-level O
pFWE O
< O
0.05 O
and O
small O
volume O
correction O
( O
SVC O
) O
. O

In O
order O
to O
investigate O
task-related O
connectivity O
, O
we O
used O
generalized O
psychophysiological O
interaction O
version O
13.1 O
( O
gPPI O
) O
. O

One O
seed O
region O
of O
interest O
, O
with O
a O
6 O
mm-radius O
, O
was O
defined O
functionally O
per O
contrast O
based O
on O
peak O
activation O
of O
the O
group O
: O
( O
1 O
) O
left O
IFG O
activated O
during O
reappraisal O
> O
attend O
negative O
( O
MNI O
coordinates O
-52 O
20 O
12 O
) O
and O
( O
2 O
) O
midline O
MFG O
activated O
during O
suppression O
> O
attend O
negative O
( O
MNI O
coordinates O
2 O
2 O
60 O
) O
. O

The O
seed O
ROIs O
were O
made O
using O
Marsbar O
. O

First O
, O
the O
time O
course O
representing O
activation O
in O
the O
seed O
region O
( O
first O
eigenvariate O
from O
the O
timeseries O
) O
was O
extracted O
from O
these O
seed O
regions O
for O
each O
subject O
, O
and O
neural O
activation O
in O
these O
seed O
regions O
was O
estimated O
by O
hemodynamic O
deconvolution O
( O
physiological O
term O
) O
. O

The O
estimated O
neural O
activation O
in O
these O
seed O
regions O
was O
multiplied O
with O
task O
vectors O
and O
reconvolved O
with O
a O
canonical O
HRF O
( O
PPI O
term O
) O
. O

The O
individual O
task O
vectors O
were O
also O
convolved O
with O
a O
canonical O
HRF O
( O
psychological O
term O
) O
. O

Separate O
task O
regressors O
were O
formed O
for O
each O
condition O
, O
and O
a O
separate O
interaction O
term O
was O
formed O
for O
each O
condition O
. O

For O
each O
seed O
region O
, O
a O
first O
level O
( O
individual O
) O
GLM O
analysis O
was O
performed O
with O
the O
PPI O
terms O
, O
the O
task O
regressors O
( O
psychological O
term O
) O
, O
the O
seed O
region O
timecourse O
( O
physiological O
term O
) O
and O
a O
constant O
. O

Two O
contrasts O
were O
created O
: O
reappraise O
versus O
attend O
negative O
and O
suppress O
versus O
attend O
negative O
. O

For O
each O
seed O
region O
, O
random O
effects O
multiple O
regression O
analyses O
with O
insight O
were O
computed O
at O
group O
level O
. O

Results O
were O
thresholded O
at O
FWE-corrected O
p O
< O
0.05 O
at O
cluster-level O
using O
an O
initial O
threshold O
of O
p O
< O
0.001 O
( O
uncorrected O
) O
. O

Expression O
of O
dopamine O
D2 O
and O
D3 O
receptors O
in O
the O
human O
retina O
revealed O
by O
positron O
emission O
tomography O
and O
targeted O
mass O
spectrometry O
Dopamine O
D2 O
receptors O
( O
D2R O
) O
are O
expressed O
in O
the O
human O
retina O
and O
play O
an O
important O
role O
in O
the O
modulation O
of O
neural O
responses O
to O
light-adaptation O
. O

However O
, O
it O
is O
unknown O
whether O
dopamine O
D3 O
receptors O
( O
D3R O
) O
are O
expressed O
in O
the O
human O
retina O
. O

Using O
positron O
emission O
tomography O
( O
PET O
) O
, O
we O
have O
observed O
significant O
uptake O
of O
the O
D3R-preferring O
agonist O
radiotracer O
[ O
11C O
] O
- O
( O
+ O
) O
-PHNO O
into O
the O
retina O
of O
humans O
in O
vivo O
. O

This O
led O
us O
to O
examine O
whether O
[ O
11C O
] O
- O
( O
+ O
) O
-PHNO O
binding O
in O
the O
retina O
was O
quantifiable O
using O
reference O
tissue O
methods O
and O
if O
D3R O
are O
expressed O
in O
human O
post-mortem O
retinal O
tissue O
. O

[ O
11C O
] O
- O
( O
+ O
) O
-PHNO O
data O
from O
49 O
healthy O
controls O
( O
mean O
age O
: O
39.96 O
± O
14.36 O
; O
16 O
female O
) O
and O
12 O
antipsychotic-naïve O
patients O
with O
schizophrenia O
( O
mean O
age O
: O
25.75 O
± O
6.25 O
; O
4 O
female O
) O
were O
analyzed O
. O

We O
observed O
no O
differences O
in O
[ O
11C O
] O
- O
( O
+ O
) O
-PHNO O
binding O
in O
the O
retina O
between O
first-episode O
, O
drug-naïve O
patients O
with O
schizophrenia O
and O
healthy O
controls O
. O

Post-mortem O
retinal O
tissues O
from O
four O
healthy O
persons O
( O
mean O
age O
: O
59.75 O
± O
9.11 O
; O
2 O
female O
) O
and O
four O
patients O
with O
schizophrenia O
( O
mean O
age O
: O
54 O
± O
17.11 O
; O
2 O
female O
) O
were O
analyzed O
using O
a O
targeted O
mass O
spectrometry O
technique O
: O
parallel O
reaction O
monitoring O
( O
PRM O
) O
analysis O
. O

Using O
targeted O
mass O
spectrometry O
, O
we O
confirmed O
that O
D3R O
are O
expressed O
in O
human O
retinal O
tissue O
ex O
vivo O
. O

Notably O
, O
there O
was O
far O
greater O
expression O
of O
D2R O
relative O
to O
D3R O
in O
the O
healthy O
human O
retina O
( O
~12:1 O
) O
. O

Moreover O
, O
PRM O
analysis O
revealed O
reduced O
D2R O
, O
but O
not O
D3R O
, O
expression O
in O
the O
retinas O
of O
non-first O
episode O
patients O
with O
schizophrenia O
compared O
to O
healthy O
controls O
. O

We O
confirm O
that O
D3R O
are O
expressed O
in O
the O
human O
retina O
. O

Future O
studies O
are O
needed O
to O
determine O
what O
proportion O
of O
the O
[ O
11C O
] O
- O
( O
+ O
) O
-PHNO O
signal O
in O
the O
human O
retina O
in O
vivo O
is O
due O
to O
binding O
to O
D3R O
versus O
D2R O
. O

Knowledge O
that O
both O
D2R O
and O
D3R O
are O
expressed O
in O
the O
human O
retina O
, O
and O
potentially O
quantifiable O
in O
vivo O
using O
[ O
11C O
] O
- O
( O
+ O
) O
-PHNO O
, O
poses O
new O
research O
avenues O
for O
better O
understanding O
the O
role O
of O
retinal O
dopamine O
in O
human O
vision O
. O

This O
work O
may O
have O
important O
implications O
for O
elucidating O
pathophysiological O
and O
antipsychotic O
induced O
visual O
deficits O
in O
schizophrenia O
. O

2 O
. O

Material O
and O
methods O
2.1 O
. O

[ O
11C O
] O
- O
( O
+ O
) O
-PHNO O
participants O
PET O
data O
from O
healthy O
persons O
and O
drug-naive O
persons O
with O
schizophrenia O
, O
previously O
reported O
in O
the O
literature O
, O
were O
re-analyzed O
for O
the O
current O
investigation O
. O

These O
studies O
were O
approved O
by O
the O
Research O
Ethics O
Board O
of O
the O
Centre O
for O
Addiction O
and O
Mental O
Health O
( O
CAMH O
) O
, O
Toronto O
. O

Healthy O
participants O
were O
right-handed O
adults O
free O
of O
any O
major O
medical O
or O
psychiatric O
disorders O
as O
determined O
by O
clinical O
interview O
, O
the O
Mini O
International O
Neuropsychiatric O
Interview-Plus O
( O
MINI-Plus O
) O
, O
basic O
clinical O
laboratory O
tests O
, O
and O
electrocardiography O
. O

Participants O
with O
schizophrenia O
were O
antipsychotic-naïve O
and O
met O
criteria O
for O
the O
diagnosis O
of O
schizophrenia O
or O
schizoaffective O
disorder O
based O
on O
the O
DSM-IV O
and O
the O
MINI-Plus O
. O

Participants O
were O
excluded O
if O
they O
had O
a O
current O
diagnosis O
of O
substance O
abuse O
or O
dependence O
, O
a O
history O
of O
clinically O
significant O
physical O
illness O
, O
or O
metal O
implants O
precluding O
the O
ability O
to O
be O
scanned O
with O
MRI O
. O

At O
inclusion O
and O
before O
the O
PET O
scan O
, O
participants O
were O
required O
to O
have O
a O
negative O
urine O
screen O
for O
drugs O
of O
abuse O
and/or O
pregnancy O
. O

All O
participants O
provided O
written O
informed O
consent O
. O

The O
average O
age O
of O
illness O
onset O
for O
the O
patient O
sample O
was O
24.42 O
± O
6.75 O
( O
range O
: O
17–42 O
) O
, O
with O
an O
average O
duration O
of O
illness O
of O
16.33 O
± O
14.74 O
( O
range O
: O
2–48 O
) O
months O
. O

2.2 O
. O

[ O
11C O
] O
- O
( O
+ O
) O
-PHNO O
synthesis O
& O
acquisition O
A O
full O
description O
of O
the O
radiosynthesis O
of O
[ O
11C O
] O
- O
( O
+ O
) O
-PHNO O
, O
as O
well O
as O
how O
PET O
images O
were O
acquired O
, O
can O
be O
found O
in O
previous O
publications O
. O

Briefly O
, O
[ O
11C O
] O
-propionyl O
chloride O
was O
reacted O
with O
9-hydroxynaph-thoxazine O
to O
generate O
a O
[ O
11C O
] O
-amide O
. O

This O
was O
subsequently O
reduced O
by O
lithium O
aluminium O
hydride O
. O

Purification O
by O
HPLC O
and O
formulation O
gave O
radio-chemically O
pure O
[ O
11C O
] O
- O
( O
+ O
) O
-PHNO O
as O
a O
sterile O
, O
pyrogen-free O
solution O
. O

PET O
images O
were O
acquired O
using O
a O
high-resolution O
head-dedicated O
PET O
camera O
system O
( O
CPS-HRRT O
; O
Siemens O
Molecular O
Imaging O
, O
USA O
) O
. O

The O
CPS-HRRT O
measures O
radioactivity O
in O
207 O
brain O
slices O
, O
each O
with O
a O
thickness O
of O
1.2 O
mm O
. O

The O
in-plane O
resolution O
was O
approximately O
2.8 O
mm O
full-width O
at O
half-maximum O
( O
FWHM O
) O
. O

Notably O
, O
significant O
[ O
11C O
] O
- O
( O
+ O
) O
-PHNO O
uptake O
into O
the O
retina O
could O
not O
be O
observed O
on O
scans O
collected O
using O
a O
high-resolution O
PET O
CT O
, O
Siemens-Biograph O
HiRez O
XVI O
( O
Siemens O
Molecular O
Imaging O
, O
Knoxville O
, O
TN O
, O
USA O
) O
operating O
in O
3D O
mode O
with O
an O
in-plane O
resolution O
of O
approximately O
4.6 O
mm O
FWHM O
( O
almost O
half O
the O
resolution O
of O
the O
CPS-HRRT O
) O
. O

Thus O
, O
PET O
camera O
systems O
of O
~2.8 O
mm O
FWHM O
or O
better O
are O
likely O
required O
to O
have O
the O
appropriate O
resolution O
to O
image O
[ O
11C O
] O
- O
( O
+ O
) O
-PHNO O
uptake O
into O
the O
retina O
. O

Transmission O
scans O
were O
acquired O
using O
a O
137Cs O
( O
T1/2=30.2 O
yr O
, O
E=662 O
KeV O
) O
single O
photon O
point O
source O
to O
provide O
attenuation O
correction O
, O
and O
the O
emission O
data O
were O
acquired O
in O
list O
mode O
. O

The O
raw O
data O
were O
reconstructed O
by O
filtered-back O
projection O
and O
the O
emission O
data O
were O
re-binned O
into O
a O
series O
of O
3D O
sonograms O
. O

Scanning O
time O
was O
90-min O
in O
length O
, O
wherein O
30 O
frames O
were O
defined O
: O
1 O
to O
15 O
of O
1-min O
duration O
and O
16 O
to O
30 O
of O
5-min O
duration O
. O

A O
custom-fitted O
thermoplastic O
mask O
( O
Tru-Scan O
Imaging O
, O
Annapolis O
) O
was O
created O
for O
each O
subject O
and O
used O
with O
a O
head O
fixation O
system O
during O
PET O
scans O
to O
reduce O
movement O
during O
the O
acquisition O
. O

[ O
11C O
] O
- O
( O
+ O
) O
-PHNO O
was O
injected O
as O
a O
bolus O
followed O
by O
a O
flush O
of O
2 O
mL O
saline O
into O
an O
intravenous O
line O
placed O
in O
an O
antecubital O
vein O
. O

The O
mean O
radioactivity O
dose O
was O
9.38 O
( O
±1.34 O
) O
mCi O
, O
with O
a O
specific O
activity O
of O
1160.82 O
( O
±401.58 O
) O
mCi/µmol O
, O
an O
injected O
mass O
of O
2.07 O
( O
±0.46 O
) O
µg O
, O
and O
an O
injected O
mass O
per O
kilogram O
of O
0.03 O
( O
±0.008 O
) O
µg/Kg O
. O

None O
of O
the O
participants O
included O
in O
this O
sample O
reported O
nausea O
associated O
with O
[ O
11C O
] O
- O
( O
+ O
) O
-PHNO O
injection O
. O

2.3 O
. O

imaging O
Subjects O
provided O
a O

image O
( O

, O

, O

, O

, O

, O

scanner O
( O
General O

, O

, O

) O
. O

These O

were O
used O
to O
enhance O
the O
analysis O
of O

scans O
, O
via O
co-registration O
( O

in O
detail O

, O

) O
. O

2.4 O
. O

[ O
11C O
] O
- O
( O
+ O
) O
-PHNO O
Image O
Analyses O
Two O
complementary O
approaches O
were O
employed O
for O
quantifying O
[ O
11C O
] O
- O
( O
+ O
) O
-PHNO O
binding O
in O
the O
retina O
. O

For O
the O
first O
approach O
( O
termed O
“ O
manual O
” O
) O
, O
retina O
ROIs O
were O
drawn O
manually O
on O
each O
subjects O
averaged O
dynamic O
[ O
11C O
] O
- O
( O
+ O
) O
-PHNO O
image O
in O
native-space O
( O
on O
every O
slice O
where O
the O
retina O
could O
be O
observed O
) O
, O
employing O
previous O
PET O
guidelines O
( O
See O
Fig O
. O

2 O
) O
. O

These O
manually O
drawn O
ROIs O
were O
then O
used O
to O
extract O
time O
activity O
curves O
from O
each O
subjects O
' O
dynamic O
PET O
image O
in O
native-space O
( O
See O
Fig O
. O

3 O
) O
. O

This O
was O
done O
with O
reference O
to O
each O
subjects O
co-registered O
T1-weighted O
MRI O
image O
, O
to O
confirm O
the O
placement O
of O
the O
retina O
ROIs O
. O

The O
co-registration O
of O
each O
subjects O
MRI O
to O
PET O
space O
was O
done O
using O
the O
normalized O
mutual O
information O
algorithm O
as O
implemented O
in O
SPM2 O
( O
SPM2 O
, O
Wellcome O
Department O
of O
Cognitive O
Neurology O
, O
London O
; O
http O
: O
//www.fil.ion.ucl.ac.uk/spm O
) O
. O

The O
TACs O
from O
the O
manually O
drawn O
retina O
ROIs O
were O
analyzed O
using O
both O
the O
Simplified O
Reference O
Tissue O
Method O
( O
SRTM O
) O
and O
Ichise O
's O
Multilinear O
Reference O
Tissue O
Model O
( O
MRTM O
) O
, O
both O
of O
which O
have O
been O
validated O
for O
use O
with O
[ O
11C O
] O
- O
( O
+ O
) O
-PHNO O
. O

For O
both O
models O
, O
the O
cerebellum O
was O
used O
as O
the O
reference O
region O
to O
derive O
a O
quantitative O
estimate O
of O
binding O
– O
binding O
potential O
relative O
to O
the O
non-displaceable O
compartment O
( O
BPND O
) O
– O
as O
defined O
by O
the O
consensus O
nomenclature O
for O
in O
vivo O
imaging O
of O
reversibly O
binding O
radioligands O
. O

It O
has O
been O
noted O
for O
in O
vivo O
human O
studies O
with O
[ O
11C O
] O
- O
( O
+ O
) O
-PHNO O
that O
there O
is O
a O
small O
displaceable O
signal O
in O
cerebellum O
( O
BPND=~0.4 O
) O
representing O
binding O
to O
D3R O
in O
cerebellar O
lobes O
IX O
and O
X O
. O

Thus O
, O
while O
we O
have O
done O
our O
best O
to O
exclude O
lobes O
IX O
and O
X O
in O
our O
cerebellar O
ROI O
, O
using O
the O
cerebellum O
as O
the O
reference O
region O
with O
[ O
11C O
] O
- O
( O
+ O
) O
-PHNO O
may O
result O
in O
some O
underestimation O
of O
BPND O
at O
D3R O
. O

Moreover O
, O
we O
recognize O
that O
use O
of O
the O
SRTM O
and O
MRTM O
is O
predicated O
on O
the O
assumption O
that O
blood O
flow O
into O
and O
out O
of O
the O
target O
and O
reference O
regions O
are O
similar O
. O

This O
assumption O
may O
not O
be O
true O
for O
both O
the O
blood-brain O
barrier O
( O
cerebellar O
reference O
region O
) O
and O
the O
retina-brain O
barrier O
( O
retina O
target O
region O
) O
, O
thus O
biasing O
our O
estimate O
of O
BPND O
. O

This O
poses O
a O
limitation O
in O
quantification O
which O
can O
only O
be O
avoided O
using O
arterial O
sampling O
of O
[ O
11C O
] O
- O
( O
+ O
) O
-PHNO O
, O
which O
is O
both O
invasive O
and O
costly O
. O

For O
the O
second O
approach O
( O
termed O
“ O
automated O
” O
) O
, O
the O
basis O
function O
implementation O
of O
the O
SRTM O
was O
applied O
to O
the O
dynamic O
PET O
images O
to O
generate O
parametric O
voxel-wise O
BPND O
maps O
using O
PMOD O
( O
v2.7 O
, O
PMOD O
Technologies O
, O
Zurich O
, O
Switzerland O
) O
. O

These O
images O
were O
spatially O
normalized O
into O
MNI O
brain O
space O
by O
Nearest O
Neighbour O
Interpolation O
with O
a O
voxel O
size O
fixed O
in O
2 O
× O
2 O
× O
2 O
mm3 O
using O
SPM2 O
. O

Regional O
BPND O
estimates O
were O
then O
derived O
from O
a O
manually O
drawn O
retina O
ROI O
defined O
in O
MNI O
space O
. O

The O
drawing O
of O
this O
ROI O
was O
aided O
by O
superimposing O
the O
average O
of O
the O
parametric O
voxel-wise O
BPND O
maps O
of O
all O
the O
subjects O
onto O
an O
MNI O
template O
. O

2.5 O
. O

Post-mortem O
retinal O
tissue O
samples O
Post-mortem O
retinal O
tissues O
from O
four O
patients O
with O

, O
and O
four O
age- O
and O

healthy O

, O
were O

from O

St. O
Michael O

Human O

( O

: O
//www.stmichaelshospital.com/eye-biobank/ O
; O
Toronto O
, O
Ontario O
, O

) O
( O
See O

3 O
) O
. O

Samples O
were O
formalin-fixed O
paraffin-embedded O
( O
FFPE O
) O
. O

2.6 O
. O

Sample O
preparation O
and O

reaction O
monitoring O
( O

) O
analyses O
Total O
sample O
homogenates O
( O
approx O
. O

2 O
µg O
) O
were O

to O
a O
modified O

( O

) O
protocol O
as O
previously O
described O
, O
with O
additional O
precipitation O
using O
an O
equal O
volume O
of O
2M O
KCL O
for O
depletion O
of O
residual O
detergents O
