Lys-C O
and O
tryptic O
peptides O
were O
combined O
and O
processed O
on O
Pierce O
C18 O
Tips O
reversed O
phase O
resin O
( O
Thermo O
Scientific O
) O
for O
desalting O
and O
concentration O
. O

High-resolution O
parallel O
reaction O
monitoring O
( O

) O
analyses O
were O
performed O
on O
a O
Q O
Exactive O
HF O
quadrupole–orbitrap O
mass O
spectrometer O
( O
Thermo O
Fisher O
Scientific O
) O
coupled O
to O
an O
EASY O
nanoflow O
liquid O
chromatography O
( O
EASY-nLC™ O
) O
system O
( O
Thermo O
Fisher O
Scientific O
) O
. O

Peptides O
were O
separated O
on O
a O
50 O
cm O
column O
( O
75 O
µm O
inner O
diameter O
) O
packed O
with O
PepMap®RSLC O
C18 O
resin O
at O
60 O
°C O
, O
using O
a O
flow O
rate O
of O
250 O
nl/min O
on O
a O
0 O
% O
–42 O
% O
acetonitrile O
( O
ACN O
) O
in O
0.1 O
% O
formic O
acid O
( O
FA O
) O
gradient O
and O
Buffer O
B O
( O
80 O
% O
ACN O
with O
0.1 O
% O
FA O
) O
over O
60 O
min O
. O

Column O
washes O
were O
performed O
on O
a O
30 O
% O
–90 O
% O
acetonitrile O
in O
0.1 O
% O
formic O
acid O
gradient O
for O
2 O
min O
. O

The O
IonMax O
electrospray O
ion O
source O
settings O
were O
: O
spray O
voltage O
, O
+1900 O
V O
and O
capillary O
temperature O
, O
+250 O
°C O
. O

In O
the O
PRM O
method O
, O
we O
only O
observed O
charge O
states O
as O
described O
in O
the O
inclusion O
list O
and O
skyline O
file O
. O

The O
targeted O
MS/MS O
was O
run O
at O
an O
Orbitrap O
resolution O
of O
30,000 O
at O
m/z O
200 O
, O
an O
AGC O
target O
value O
of O
2 O
× O
105 O
, O
and O
maximum O
fill O
times O
of O
100 O
ms O
. O

The O
targeted O
peptide O
was O
isolated O
using O
a O
0.8 O
m/z O
unit O
window O
. O

Fragmentation O
was O
performed O
with O
normalized O
collision O
energy O
( O
NCE O
) O
of O
32 O
eV O
. O

In O
the O
PRM O
method O
, O
we O
only O
observed O
charge O
states O
as O
described O
in O
the O
inclusion O
list O
and O
skyline O
file O
. O

Seven O
peptides O
and O
their O
corresponding O
heavy O
peptides O
( O
Table O
4 O
) O
were O
comprised O
in O
the O
inclusion O
list O
. O

Target O
peptides O
were O
selected O
based O
on O
in O
silico O
cleavage O
of O
the O
proteins O
using O
the O
Peptide O
Mass O
feature O
of O
ExPASy O
bioinformatics O
portal O
( O
http O
: O
//web.expasy.org/peptide_mass/ O
) O
. O

The O
following O
settings O
were O
used O
: O
enzyme O
( O
trypsin O
) O
; O
0 O
missed O
cleavage O
and O
display O
the O
peptides O
with O
a O
mass O
bigger O
than O
500 O
Da O
. O

2.7 O
. O

PRM O
data O
analysis O
Mass O
spectrometry O
analysis O
was O
performed O
at O
the O
SPARC O
Biocentre O
( O
The O
Hospital O
for O
Sick O
Children O
; O
SickKids O
, O
Toronto O
) O
. O

We O
attempted O
to O
quantify O
4 O
and O
3 O
unique O
peptides O
for O
D2R O
and O
D3R O
, O
respectively O
( O
see O
Table O
4 O
) O
. O

However O
, O
because O
of O
the O
relatively O
low O
protein O
yield O
in O
our O
FFPE O
slide O
samples O
, O
only O
a O
single O
unique O
peptide O
of O
either O
protein O
was O
detected O
and O
subsequently O
used O
for O
identification O
. O

Data O
analysis O
and O
quantification O
of O
PRM O
runs O
was O
performed O
using O
Skyline O
software O
. O

Relative O
quantification O
of O
D2R O
and O
D3R O
peptides O
from O
schizophrenia O
patient O
and O
control O
samples O
was O
based O
on O
the O
sum O
of O
the O
area O
under O
the O
curves O
( O
AUC O
) O
of O
the O
top O
three O
most O
intense O
peptide O
fragments O
. O

The O
use O
of O
a O
subset O
of O
three O
to O
six O
fragment O
ions O
( O
with O
acceptable O
peak O
purity O
) O
for O
peptide O
quantitation O
has O
been O
previously O
suggested O
to O
yield O
more O
accurate O
results O
than O
the O
entire O
set O
. O

Endogenous O
peptides O
were O
matched O
to O
heavy O
isotope O
peptides O
based O
on O
their O
similar O
retention O
times O
and O
transition O
patterns O
. O

2.8 O
. O

Statistical O
analyses O
Statistical O
analyses O
were O
performed O
using O
IBM O
SPSS O
( O
v.20 O
) O
and O
GraphPad O
( O
v.5.0 O
; O
GraphPad O
Software O
, O
La O
Jolla O
California O
) O
. O

Normality O
of O
variables O
was O
determined O
using O
the O
D'Agostino-Pearson O
test O
. O

The O
significance O
level O
for O
all O
tests O
was O
set O
at O
p O
< O
.05 O
( O
two-tailed O
) O
. O

Changes O
in O
Functional O
Brain O
Connectivity O
Highlight O
the O
Importance O
of O
a O
Baseline O
Measurement O
and O
Multiple O
Imaging O
Sessions O
for O
Cocaine O
Abstinence O
Studies O
Highlighted O
Research O
Paper O
: O

A O
Framework O
for O
Linking O
Resting-state O
Chronnectome/Genome O
Features O
in O
Schizophrenia O
: O
A O
Pilot O
Study O
Multimodal O
, O
imaging-genomics O
techniques O
offer O
a O
platform O
for O
understanding O
genetic O
influences O
on O
brain O
abnormalities O
in O
psychiatric O
disorders O
. O

Such O
approaches O
utilize O
the O
information O
available O
from O
both O
imaging O
and O
genomics O
data O
and O
identify O
their O
association O
. O

Particularly O
for O
complex O
disorders O
such O
as O
schizophrenia O
, O
the O
relationship O
between O
imaging O
and O
genomic O
features O
may O
be O
better O
understood O
by O
incorporating O
additional O
information O
provided O
by O
advanced O
multimodal O
modeling O
. O

In O
this O
study O
, O
we O
propose O
a O
novel O
framework O
to O
combine O
features O
corresponding O
to O
functional O
magnetic O
resonance O
imaging O
( O
functional O
) O
and O
single O
nucleotide O
polymorphism O
( O
SNP O
) O
data O
from O
61 O
schizophrenia O
( O
SZ O
) O
patients O
and O
87 O
healthy O
controls O
( O
HC O
) O
. O

In O
particular O
, O
the O
features O
for O
the O
functional O
and O
genetic O
modalities O
include O
dynamic O
( O
i.e. O
, O
time-varying O
) O
functional O
network O
connectivity O
( O
dFNC O
) O
features O
and O
the O
SNP O
data O
, O
respectively O
. O

The O
dFNC O
features O
are O
estimated O
from O
component O
time-courses O
, O
obtained O
using O
group O
independent O
component O
analysis O
( O
ICA O
) O
, O
by O
computing O
sliding-window O
functional O
network O
connectivity O
, O
and O
then O
estimating O
subject O
specific O
states O
from O
this O
dFNC O
data O
using O
a O
k-means O
clustering O
approach O
. O

For O
each O
subject O
, O
both O
the O
functional O
( O
dFNC O
states O
) O
and O
SNP O
data O
are O
selected O
as O
features O
for O
a O
parallel O
ICA O
( O
pICA O
) O
based O
imaging-genomic O
framework O
. O

This O
analysis O
identified O
a O
significant O
association O
between O
a O
SNP O
component O
( O
defined O
by O
large O
clusters O
of O
functionally O
related O
SNPs O
statistically O
correlated O
with O
phenotype O
components O
) O
and O
time-varying O
or O
dFNC O
component O
( O
defined O
by O
clusters O
of O
related O
connectivity O
links O
among O
distant O
brain O
regions O
distributed O
across O
discrete O
dynamic O
states O
, O
and O
statistically O
correlated O
with O
genomic O
components O
) O
in O
schizophrenia O
. O

Importantly O
, O
the O
polygenetic O
risk O
score O
( O
PRS O
) O
for O
SZ O
( O
computed O
as O
a O
linearly O
weighted O
sum O
of O
the O
genotype O
profiles O
with O
weights O
derived O
from O
the O
odds O
ratios O
of O
the O
psychiatric O
genomics O
consortium O
( O
PGC O
) O
) O
was O
negatively O
correlated O
with O
the O
significant O
dFNC O
component O
, O
which O
were O
mostly O
present O
within O
a O
state O
that O
exhibited O
a O
lower O
occupancy O
rate O
in O
individuals O
with O
SZ O
compared O
with O
HC O
, O
hence O
identifying O
a O
potential O
dFNC O
imaging O
biomarker O
for O
schizophrenia O
. O

Taken O
together O
, O
the O
current O
findings O
provide O
preliminary O
evidence O
for O
a O
link O
between O
dFNC O
measures O
and O
genetic O
risk O
, O
suggesting O
the O
application O
of O
dFNC O
patterns O
as O
biomarkers O
in O
imaging O
genetic O
association O
study O
. O

MATERIALS O
AND O
METHODS O
Participants O
We O
used O
resting-state O
functional O
magnetic O
resonance O
imaging O
( O
fMRI O
) O
data O
and O
single O
nucleotide O
polymorphism O
( O
SNP O
) O
data O
obtained O
from O
87 O
healthy O
controls O
( O
61 O
males O
, O
26 O
females O
; O
mean O
age O
36.83 O
) O
and O
61 O
age- O
and O
gender O
matched O
patients O
with O
SZ O
( O
52 O
males O
, O
9 O
females O
; O
mean O
age O
38.36 O
) O
during O
eyes O
closed O
condition O
as O
part O
of O
the O
multi-site O
fBIRN O
project O
. O

Informed O
consent O
was O
obtained O
from O
each O
participant O
prior O
to O
scanning O
in O
accordance O
with O
the O
Internal O
Review O
Boards O
of O
corresponding O
institutions O
. O

SNP O
Data O
Preprocessing O
and O
Feature O
Selection O
DNA O
was O
extracted O
from O
blood O
and O
saliva O
samples O
collected O
from O
the O
participants O
. O

No O
significant O
difference O
was O
noted O
in O
genotyping O
call O
rates O
between O
blood O
and O
saliva O
samples O
. O

DNA O
extraction O
was O
performed O
at O
the O
University O
of O
California O
at O
Irvine O
and O
genotyping O
was O
performed O
by O
Illumina O
( O
SD O
) O
using O
a O
custom O
made O
assay O
including O
the O
Infinium O
MEGAex O
chip O
as O
well O
all O
SNPs O
on O
the O
Psych O
chip O
. O

The O
SNP O
data O
went O
through O
quality O
control O
( O
QC O
) O
, O
imputation O
and O
post-imputation O
QC O
as O
described O
in O
, O
which O
is O
briefly O
summarized O
here O
. O

PLINK O
was O
employed O
for O
pre- O
and O
post-imputation O
QC O
, O
including O
: O
( O
a O
) O
gender O
consistency O
check O
, O
( O
b O
) O
sample O
relatedness O
( O
not O
closer O
than O
second O
degree O
relatives O
) O
, O
( O
c O
) O
genotyping O
call O
rate O
( O
> O
90 O
% O
at O
both O
the O
individual O
and O
SNP O
level O
) O
, O
( O
d O
) O
Hardy-Weinberg O
equilibrium O
in O
the O
control O
population O
( O
p O
< O
1 O
× O
10 O
−6 O
) O
, O
( O
e O
) O
minor O
allele O
frequency O
( O
MAF O
> O
0.05 O
) O
. O

Then O
imputation O
was O
conducted O
with O
SHAPEIT O
used O
for O
pre-phasing O
, O
IMPUTE2 O
for O
imputation O
, O
and O
the O
1000 O
Genomes O
data O
as O
the O
reference O
panel O
. O

Only O
markers O
with O
high O
imputation O
qualities O
( O
INFO O
score O
> O
0.95 O
) O
were O
retained O
. O

Missing O
calls O
were O
replaced O
using O
high O
linkage O
disequilibrium O
( O
LD O
) O
loci O
if O
available O
or O
otherwise O
removed O
. O

A O
total O
of O
977,242 O
SNP O
loci O
were O
obtained O
after O
post-imputation O
QC O
and O
LD O
pruning O
( O
r2 O
< O
0.9 O
) O
, O
and O
discrete O
numbers O
were O
then O
assigned O
to O
the O
categorical O
genotypes O
: O
0 O
( O
no O
minor O
allele O
) O
, O
1 O
( O
one O
minor O
allele O
) O
, O
and O
2 O
( O
two O
minor O
alleles O
) O
. O

Population O
structure O
was O
corrected O
with O
PCA O
. O

A O
pre-filtering O
( O
i.e. O
, O
pre-selection O
) O
step O
was O
conducted O
leveraging O
the O
Psychiatric O
Genomic O
Consortium O
SZ O
GWAS O
( O
Ripke O
et O
al. O
, O
2014 O
) O
based O
on O
SZ O
relevance O
( O
i.e. O
, O
the O
p- O
values O
reported O
by O
the O
PGC O
SZ O
GWAS O
) O
. O

This O
resulted O
in O
a O
total O
of O
pre-filtered O
1546 O
SNPs O
, O
discriminating O
patients O
from O
controls O
via O
a O
univariate O
SNP-wise O
test O
with O
p-values O
less O
than O
5× O
10−7 O
in O
the O
GWAS O
. O

Imaging O
data O
processing O
and O
feature O
selection O
fMRI O
Data O
Collection O
and O
Preprocessing O
Imaging O
data O
was O
collected O
on O
3T O
Siemens O
Tim O
Trio O
Systems O
( O
all O
but O
one O
site O
) O
or O
on O
a O
3T O
General O
Electric O
Discovery O
MR750 O
scanner O
. O

Resting O
state O
fMRI O
scans O
were O
acquired O
using O
a O
standard O
gradient-echo O
echo O
planar O
imaging O
paradigm O
: O
FOV O
of O
220 O
× O
220 O
mm O
( O
64 O
× O
64 O
matrix O
) O
, O
TR O
= O
2 O
s O
, O
TE O
= O
30 O
ms O
, O
FA O
= O
77° O
, O
162 O
volumes O
, O
32 O
sequential O
ascending O
axial O
slices O
of O
4 O
mm O
thickness O
and O
1 O
mm O
skip O
. O

Subjects O
had O
their O
eyes O
closed O
during O
the O
resting O
state O
scan O
. O

Data O
processing O
was O
performed O
using O
a O
combination O
of O
toolboxes O
( O
AFNI O
, O
SPM O
, O
GIFT O
) O
and O
custom O
code O
written O
in O
Matlab O
. O

We O
performed O
rigid O
body O
motion O
correction O
using O
the O
INRIAlign O
toolbox O
in O
SPM O
to O
correct O
for O
subject O
head O
motion O
followed O
by O
slice-timing O
correction O
to O
account O
for O
timing O
differences O
in O
slice O
acquisition O
. O

Then O
the O
fMRI O
data O
were O
despiked O
using O
AFNI O
’ O
s O
3dDespike O
algorithm O
to O
mitigate O
the O
impact O
of O
outliers O
. O

The O
fMRI O
data O
were O
subsequently O
warped O
to O
a O
Montreal O
Neurological O
Institute O
( O
MNI O
) O
template O
, O
and O
resampled O
to O
3 O
mm3 O
isotropic O
voxels O
. O

Instead O
of O
Gaussian O
smoothing O
, O
we O
smoothed O
the O
data O
to O
6 O
mm O
full O
width O
at O
half O
maximum O
( O
FWHM O
) O
using O
AFNI3s O
BlurToFWHM O
algorithm O
, O
which O
performs O
smoothing O
by O
a O
conservative O
finite O
difference O
approximation O
to O
the O
diffusion O
equation O
. O

This O
approach O
has O
been O
shown O
to O
reduce O
scanner O
specific O
variability O
in O
smoothness O
providing O
a O
“ O
smoothness O
equivalence O
” O
to O
data O
across O
sites O
. O

Each O
voxel O
time O
course O
was O
variance O
normalized O
by O
removing O
the O
mean O
and O
dividing O
by O
the O
standard O
deviation O
at O
each O
voxel O
prior O
to O
performing O
group O
independent O
component O
analysis O
as O
this O
has O
shown O
to O
better O
decompose O
subcortical O
sources O
in O
addition O
to O
cortical O
networks O
. O

Note O
that O
, O
no O
significant O
group O
difference O
in O
signal-to-noise O
ratio O
( O
SNR O
) O
was O
found O
( O
p=0.5 O
, O
Figure O
S4 O
) O
. O

Group O
ICA O
, O
Intrinsic O
Connectivity O
Network O
( O
ICN O
) O
Selection O
and O
Post O
processing O
After O
preprocessing O
the O
data O
, O
functional O
data O
from O
both O
control O
and O
patient O
groups O
were O
analyzed O
using O
spatial O
group O
independent O
component O
analysis O
( O
GICA O
) O
framework O
as O
implemented O
in O
the O
GIFT O
software O
. O

Spatial O
ICA O
decomposes O
the O
subject O
data O
into O
linear O
mixtures O
of O
spatially O
independent O
components O
that O
exhibit O
a O
unique O
time O
course O
profile O
. O

A O
subject- O
specific O
data O
reduction O
step O
was O
first O
used O
to O
reduce O
162 O
time O
point O
data O
into O
120 O
direction O
of O
maximal O
variability O
using O
principal O
component O
analysis O
. O

Then O
subject-reduced O
data O
were O
concatenated O
across O
time O
and O
a O
group O
data O
PCA O
step O
reduced O
this O
matrix O
further O
into O
100 O
components O
along O
directions O
of O
maximal O
group O
variability O
. O

Note O
that O
, O
group O
PCA O
on O
the O
entire O
dataset O
was O
performed O
to O
avoid O
biasing O
the O
solution O
to O
group O
differences O
. O

One O
hundred O
independent O
components O
were O
obtained O
from O
the O
group O
PCA O
reduced O
matrix O
using O
the O
infomax O
algorithm O
. O

To O
ensure O
stability O
of O
estimation O
, O
we O
repeated O
the O
ICA O
algorithm O
20 O
times O
in O
ICASSO O
, O
and O
aggregate O
spatial O
maps O
were O
estimated O
as O
the O
modes O
of O
component O
clusters O
. O

Subject O
specific O
spatial O
maps O
( O
SMs O
) O
and O
time O
courses O
( O
TCs O
) O
were O
obtained O
using O
the O
spatiotemporal O
regression O
back O
reconstruction O
approach O
implemented O
in O
the O
GIFT O
software O
. O

Subject O
specific O
SMs O
and O
TCs O
underwent O
post-processing O
as O
described O
in O
our O
earlier O
work O
( O
Allen O
et O
al. O
, O
2012 O
) O
. O

Briefly O
, O
we O
obtained O
one O
sample O
t-test O
maps O
for O
each O
SM O
across O
all O
subjects O
and O
thresholded O
these O
maps O
to O
obtain O
regions O
of O
peak O
activation O
clusters O
for O
that O
component O
; O
we O
also O
computed O
mean O
power O
spectra O
of O
the O
corresponding O
TCs O
. O

We O
visually O
inspected O
and O
identified O
a O
set O
of O
components O
as O
intrinsic O
connectivity O
networks O
( O
ICNs O
) O
if O
their O
peak O
activation O
clusters O
fell O
on O
GM O
( O
gray O
matter O
) O
and O
showed O
less O
overlap O
with O
known O
vascular O
, O
susceptibility O
, O
ventricular O
, O
and O
edge O
regions O
corresponding O
to O
head O
motion O
. O

We O
also O
ensured O
that O
the O
mean O
power O
spectra O
of O
the O
selected O
ICN O
time O
courses O
showed O
higher O
low O
frequency O
spectral O
power O
. O

This O
selection O
procedure O
resulted O
in O
47 O
ICNs O
out O
of O
the O
100 O
independent O
components O
obtained O
. O

The O
ICNs O
were O
assessed O
and O
distributed O
into O
sub-cortical O
( O
SC O
) O
, O
auditory O
( O
AUD O
) O
, O
visual O
( O
VIS O
) O
, O
sensorimotor O
( O
SM O
) O
, O
attention/cognitive O
control O
( O
CC O
) O
, O
default-mode O
( O
DMN O
) O
, O
and O
cerebellar O
( O
CB O
) O
network O
domains O
. O

Subject-specific O
TCs O
corresponding O
to O
the O
retained O
ICNs O
underwent O
additional O
post O
processing O
steps O
. O

The O
TCs O
were O
detrended O
to O
remove O
any O
existing O
linear O
, O
quadratic O
or O
cubic O
low O
frequency O
trends O
originating O
from O
scanner O
drift O
, O
orthogonalized O
with O
respect O
to O
estimated O
subject O
motion O
and O
realignment O
parameters O
, O
and O
despiked O
using O
AFNI O
’ O
s O
3dDespike O
function O
to O
replace O
outlier O
points O
with O
values O
estimated O
from O
third O
order O
spline O
fit O
to O
neighboring O
portions O
of O
the O
TCs O
. O

FC O
Estimation O
and O
Clustering O
Similar O
to O
our O
previous O
work O
time-varying O
FNC O
was O
estimated O
by O
sliding O
a O
window O
of O
length O
22 O
TRs O
( O
44 O
s O
) O
in O
steps O
of O
1 O
TR O
( O
2 O
s O
) O
. O

This O
sliding O
window O
analysis O
used O
a O
tapered O
window O
generated O
by O
convolving O
a O
rectangular O
window O
of O
length O
22 O
TRs O
( O
44 O
s O
) O
with O
a O
Gaussian O
window O
of O
standard O
deviation O
equal O
to O
3 O
TRs O
. O

To O
characterize O
the O
full O
covariance O
matrix O
, O
we O
estimated O
covariance O
from O
the O
regularized O
precision O
matrix O
or O
the O
inverse O
covariance O
matrix O
. O

Following O
the O
graphical O
LASSO O
method O
, O
we O
placed O
a O
penalty O
on O
the O
L1 O
norm O
of O
the O
precision O
matrix O
to O
promote O
sparsity O
. O

The O
regularization O
parameter O
lambda O
was O
optimized O
separately O
for O
each O
subject O
by O
evaluating O
the O
log-likelihood O
of O
unseen O
data O
( O
windowed O
covariance O
matrices O
from O
the O
same O
subject O
) O
in O
a O
cross-validation O
framework O
. O

Final O
dynamic O
FC O
estimates O
for O
each O
window O
, O
were O
concatenated O
to O
form O
a O
C O
x O
C O
x O
W O
array O
representing O
the O
changes O
in O
covariance O
( O
correlation O
) O
between O
components O
as O
a O
function O
of O
time O
. O

Next O
, O
we O
selected O
windows O
of O
higher O
variability O
as O
subject O
exemplars O
and O
used O
K-means O
clustering O
to O
obtain O
group O
centroids O
. O

We O
determined O
the O
number O
of O
clusters O
to O
be O
five O
using O
the O
elbow O
criterion O
of O
the O
cluster O
validity O
index O
, O
which O
is O
computed O
as O
the O
ratio O
between O
within-cluster O
distances O
to O
between-cluster O
distance O
. O

These O
centroids O
are O
then O
used O
as O
starting O
points O
to O
cluster O
all O
of O
the O
dynamic O
FNC O
data O
. O

Group- O
and O
subject- O
specific O
centroids O
were O
computed O
for O
further O
analyses O
. O

Proposed O
pICA O
framework O
Figure O
1 O
and O
Figure O
S5 O
provides O
an O
illustration O
of O
the O
proposed O
framework O
. O

pICA O
was O
performed O
through O
the O
Fusion O
ICA O
Toolbox O
( O
FIT O
, O
http O
: O
//mialab.mrn.org/software/fit O
) O
using O
the O
imaging O
( O
dynamic O
states O
) O
and O
genomic O
( O
SNP O
array O
) O
features O
. O

The O
algorithm O
was O
configured O
with O
a O
threshold O
of O
0.25 O
for O
constrained O
correlations O
to O
avoid O
false O
positive O
associations O
and O
to O
only O
constrain O
one O
pair O
of O
components O
. O

A O
SNP O
component O
is O
defined O
by O
large O
clusters O
of O
functionally O
related O
SNPs O
statistically O
correlated O
with O
phenotype O
components O
, O
whereas O
a O
dFNC O
component O
is O
defined O
by O
clusters O
of O
related O
connectivity O
links O
among O
distant O
brain O
regions O
distributed O
across O
5 O
discrete O
dynamic O
states O
, O
and O
statistically O
correlated O
with O
genomic O
components O
( O
Table O
S2 O
) O
. O

An O
endurance O
parameter O
was O
set O
to O
−5 O
× O
10−4 O
to O
control O
the O
decreasing O
slope O
of O
the O
entropy O
term O
and O
to O
mitigate O
against O
over O
fitting O
. O

For O
the O
fMRI O
modality O
( O
dFNC O
features O
) O
, O
the O
component O
number O
was O
predefined O
as O
15 O
, O
and O
for O
genomic O
modality O
( O
SNP O
data O
) O
the O
component O
number O
was O
predefined O
as O
25 O
based O
on O
pICA O
model O
stability O
, O
which O
was O
validated O
using O
the O
permutation O
test O
. O

The O
parallel O
ICA O
estimates O
components O
by O
maximizing O
component O
independence O
within O
each O
data O
modality O
, O
and O
maximizing O
the O
inter-modality O
association O
assessed O
based O
on O
component O
loadings O
from O
the O
two O
modalities O
. O

In O
the O
current O
work O
, O
parallel O
ICA O
extracted O
15 O
dFNC O
components O
and O
25 O
SNP O
components O
, O
which O
led O
to O
a O
total O
of O
375 O
SNP-dFNC O
pairs O
for O
which O
the O
associations O
were O
assessed O
. O

Significant O
SNP-dFNC O
associations O
were O
then O
identified O
based O
on O
Bonferroni O
correction O
( O
p O
< O
0.05/375 O
) O
. O

We O
performed O
a O
1000-run O
permutation O
test O
to O
assess O
the O
validity O
and O
stability O
of O
identified O
dFNC-SNP O
association O
by O
investigating O
the O
occurrences O
of O
inter-modality O
correlations O
by O
chance O
in O
permuted O
dFNC O
and O
SNP O
datasets O
. O

The O
null O
distribution O
was O
constructed O
with O
the O
top O
correlation O
obtained O
from O
each O
test O
run O
. O

We O
then O
counted O
the O
instances O
with O
correlations O
greater O
than O
that O
observed O
from O
the O
original O
data O
and O
calculated O
the O
two-tail O
probability O
as O
the O
significance O
level O
. O

Polygenic O
Risk O
Score O
Analysis O
Additionally O
, O
we O
computed O
the O
polygenic O
risk O
score O
( O
PRS O
) O
for O
SZ O
of O
the O
set O
of O
thresholded O
SNPs O
( O
i.e. O
, O
top O
SNPs O
after O
thresholding O
the O
SNP O
component O
) O
, O
which O
was O
a O
linearly O
weighted O
sum O
of O
the O
genotype O
profiles O
with O
weights O
derived O
from O
the O
odds O
ratios O
of O
the O
PGC O
SZ O
GWAS O
( O
; O
Ripke O
et O
al. O
, O
2014 O
) O
. O

The O
loading O
parameters O
from O
significant O
pICA O
paired O
components O
were O
then O
assessed O
for O
associations O
with O
PRS O
for O
SZ O
using O
Pearson O
’ O
s O
and O
Spearmann O
’ O
s O
rank O
order O
correlations O
. O

Partial O
Replication O
Study O
While O
an O
independent O
dataset O
with O
exact O
imaging O
and O
genomic O
features O
was O
unavailable O
for O
replication O
purpose O
, O
we O
implemented O
our O
proposed O
model O
on O
a O
separate O
, O
independent O
dataset O
for O
partial O
replication O
. O

The O
resting-state O
fMRI O
data O
were O
collected O
while O
the O
participants O
had O
their O
eyes O
open O
( O
as O
opposed O
to O
our O
main O
analyses O
where O
resting-state O
fMRI O
data O
were O
collected O
in O
eyes O
closed O
condition O
) O
. O

We O
used O
resting-state O
functional O
magnetic O
resonance O
imaging O
( O
fMRI O
) O
data O
and O
single O
nucleotide O
polymorphism O
( O
SNP O
) O
data O
obtained O
from O
a O
local O
COBRE O
( O
center O
of O
biomedical O
research O
excellence O
) O
study O
. O

After O
preprocessing O
, O
we O
obtained O
data O
from O
a O
total O
of O
135 O
participants O
( O
72 O
healthy O
controls O
and O
63 O
SZ O
patients O
matched O
for O
age O
) O
for O
which O
both O
fMRI O
and O
SNP O
data O
were O
collected O
. O

Using O
the O
same O
steps O
mentioned O
for O
our O
main O
analyses O
, O
we O
preprocessed O
both O
fMRI O
and O
SNP O
data O
. O

As O
the O
genomic O
features O
, O
we O
identified O
the O
same O
1546 O
pre-selected O
SNPs O
as O
our O
main O
analyses O
. O

In O
order O
to O
identify O
the O
similar O
imaging O
features O
( O
i.e. O
, O
dFNC O
states O
) O
, O
we O
implemented O
the O
following O
two-step O
replication O
: O
( O
i O
) O
using O
a O
spatially O
constrained O
ICA O
approach O
, O
we O
computed O
subject O
specific O
maps O
and O
timecourses O
for O
the O
49 O
ICNs O
and O
computed O
the O
sliding-window O
based O
dynamic O
connectivity O
matrices O
for O
each O
subject O
, O
and O
( O
ii O
) O
using O
k-means O
clustering O
approach O
while O
using O
the O
original O
dFNC O
states O
( O
i.e. O
, O
from O
our O
main O
study O
) O
as O
stating O
points O
for O
clusters O
, O
we O
identified O
5 O
cluster O
centroids/dFNC O
states O
for O
each O
subject O
. O

These O
dFNC O
states O
were O
then O
used O
as O
the O
imaging O
features O
for O
our O
proposed O
pICA O
framework O
. O

The O
proposed O
algorithm O
proceeds O
in O
two O
stages O
, O
consisting O
of O
independent O
component O
computation O
at O
group O
and O
subject O
levels O
, O
respectively O
. O

First O
, O
a O
group-level O
ICA O
is O
performed O
to O
extract O
information O
in O
the O
form O
of O
group O
ICs O
from O
preprocessed O
fMRI O
data O
of O
multiple O
subjects O
. O

Then O
the O
group O
information O
is O
used O
as O
guidance O
for O
the O
subject-level O
ICA O
, O
computed O
separately O
on O
the O
fMRI O
data O
of O
each O
subject O
. O

A O
list O
of O
key O
acronyms O
and O
definitions O
can O
be O
found O
in O
Tables O
S1 O
and O
S2 O
. O

Reduced O
higher-dimensional O
resting O
state O
fMRI O
dynamism O
in O
clinical O
high-risk O
individuals O
for O
schizophrenia O
identified O
by O
meta-state O
analysis O
New O
techniques O
to O
investigate O
functional O
network O
connectivity O
in O
resting O
state O
functional O
magnetic O
resonance O
imaging O
data O
have O
recently O
emerged O
. O

One O
novel O
approach O
, O
called O
meta-state O
analysis O
, O
goes O
beyond O
the O
mere O
cross-correlation O
of O
time O
courses O
of O
distinct O
brain O
areas O
and O
explores O
temporal O
dynamism O
in O
more O
detail O
, O
allowing O
for O
connectivity O
states O
to O
overlap O
in O
time O
and O
capturing O
global O
dynamic O
behavior O
. O

Previous O
studies O
have O
shown O
that O
patients O
with O
chronic O
schizophrenia O
exhibit O
reduced O
neural O
dynamism O
compared O
to O
healthy O
controls O
, O
but O
it O
is O
not O
known O
whether O
these O
alterations O
extend O
to O
earlier O
phases O
of O
the O
illness O
. O

In O
this O
study O
, O
we O
analyzed O
individuals O
at O
clinical O
high-risk O
( O
CHR O
, O
n= O
53 O
) O
for O
developing O
psychosis O
, O
patients O
in O
an O
early O
stage O
of O
schizophrenia O
( O
ESZ O
, O
n= O
58 O
) O
, O
and O
healthy O
controls O
( O
HC O
, O
n= O
70 O
) O
. O

ESZ O
individuals O
exhibit O
reduced O
neural O
dynamism O
across O
all O
domains O
compared O
to O
HC O
. O

CHR O
individuals O
also O
show O
reduced O
neural O
dynamism O
but O
only O
in O
2 O
out O
of O
4 O
domains O
investigated O
. O

Overall O
, O
meta-state O
analysis O
adds O
information O
about O
dynamic O
fluidity O
of O
functional O
connectivity O
. O

2 O
. O

Material O
and O
methods O
2.1 O
. O

Participants O
CHR O
individuals O
( O
n=53 O
) O
were O
recruited O
from O
University O
of O
California O
, O
San O
Francisco O
( O
UCSF O
) O
Early O
Psychosis O
Clinical O
Research O
Program O
, O
local O
clinics O
, O
and O
school O
counseling O
centers O
. O

The O
CHR O
for O
psychosis O
syndrome O
was O
diagnosed O
based O
on O
the O
Criteria O
of O
Prodromal O
Syndromes O
( O
COPS O
) O
as O
assessed O
using O
the O
Structured O
Interview O
for O
Prodromal O
Syndromes O
( O
SIPS O
) O
. O

Individuals O
met O
criteria O
for O
one O
or O
more O
of O
three O
non-mutually O
exclusive O
prodromal O
syndromes O
: O
Attenuated O
Psychotic O
Symptoms O
( O
92.5 O
% O
) O
, O
Brief O
Intermittent O
Psychotic O
Symptoms O
( O
1.9 O
% O
) O
, O
and O
Genetic O
Risk O
and O
Deterioration O
( O
7.5 O
% O
) O
. O

ESZ O
patients O
( O
n=58 O
) O
were O
recruited O
from O
the O
Early O
Psychosis O
Clinical O
Research O
Program O
at O
USCF O
and O
from O
local O
community O
clinics O
. O

ESZ O
patients O
met O
DSM-IV O
criteria O
for O
schizophrenia O
( O
n=63.8 O
% O
) O
, O
schizoaffective O
( O
n=27.6 O
% O
) O
or O
schizophreniform O
( O
n=6.9 O
% O
) O
disorder O
based O
on O
the O
Structured O
Clinical O
Interview O
for O
DSM-IV O
( O
SCID O
) O
administered O
by O
a O
trained O
interviewer O
. O

The O
mean O
illness O
duration O
for O
ESZ O
patients O
was O
2.09 O
years O
( O
standard O
deviation O
, O
SD O
, O
1.37 O
) O
. O

Symptom O
severity O
was O
assessed O
by O
trained O
clinical O
raters O
using O
the O
Scale O
of O
Prodromal O
Symptoms O
( O
SOPS O
) O
for O
CHR O
individuals O
and O
the O
Positive O
and O
Negative O
Syndrome O
Scale O
( O
PANSS O
) O
for O
ESZ O
patients O
. O

HC O
individuals O
( O
n=70 O
) O
were O
recruited O
from O
the O
community O
and O
did O
not O
meet O
criteria O
for O
any O
axis O
I O
diagnosis O
based O
on O
the O
SCID O
. O

For O
participants O
< O
16 O
years O
of O
age O
, O
the O
Schedule O
for O
Affective O
Disorders O
and O
Schizophrenia O
for O
School-Age O
Children O
( O
Kiddie-SADS O
) O
, O
Present O
and O
Lifetime O
Version O
was O
used O
in O
order O
to O
assess O
for O
Axis O
I O
diagnoses O
in O
younger O
teenagers O
. O

General O
exclusion O
criteria O
included O
DSM-IV O
substance O
dependence O
in O
the O
past O
year O
( O
except O
nicotine O
) O
, O
a O
history O
of O
head O
injury O
with O
loss O
of O
consciousness O
, O
neurological O
disorders O
, O
or O
a O
first-degree O
relative O
with O
a O
psychotic O
illness O
( O
for O
HC O
individuals O
only O
) O
. O

Written O
informed O
consent O
was O
obtained O
from O
participants O
, O
or O
from O
their O
parents/legal O
guardians O
in O
the O
case O
of O
minors O
( O
who O
also O
provided O
written O
assent O
) O
, O
under O
protocols O
approved O
by O
the O
institutional O
review O
board O
at O
UCSF O
. O

Demographic O
data O
are O
presented O
in O
Table O
1 O
. O

The O
final O
sample O
comprised O
70 O
HC O
, O
53 O
CHR O
, O
and O
58 O
ESZ O
individuals O
and O
groups O
did O
not O
differ O
significantly O
with O
regard O
to O
age O
and O
gender O
. O

12 O
CHR O
( O
22.6 O
% O
) O
and O
53 O
ESZ O
( O
91.4 O
% O
) O
individuals O
were O
medicated O
with O
antipsychotics O
( O
supplementary O
table O
1 O
) O
at O
the O
time O
of O
fMRI O
scanning O
. O

2.2 O
. O

Data O
acquisition O
Resting O
state O
fMRI O
data O
were O
collected O
at O
the O
UCSF O
Neuroimaging O
Center O
using O
a O
3T O
Siemens O
Trio O
( O
Erlangen O
, O
Germany O
) O
scanner O
. O

2.2.1 O
. O

Resting O
state O
fMRI O
pre-processing O
Participants O
were O
instructed O
to O
keep O
their O
eyes O
closed O
while O
scanning O
and O
to O
stay O
awake O
. O

Resting O
state O
scans O
were O
acquired O
using O
a O
high-speed O
whole O
brain O
echo O
planar O
imaging O
sequence O
( O
32 O
axial O
slices O
, O
thickness O
3.5mm O
, O
FOV O
24cm O
, O
TR O
2s O
, O
echo O
time O
29ms O
, O
flip O
angle O
75° O
) O
. O

Pre-processing O
was O
computed O
with O
SPM O
8 O
( O
http O
: O
//www.fil.ion.ucl.ac.uk/spm O
) O
and O
the O
Data O
Processing O
Assistant O
for O
Resting O
State O
fMRI O
( O
DPARSF O
) O
toolbox O
. O

The O
first O
10 O
images O
were O
discarded O
due O
to O
equilibration O
effects O
, O
leaving O
170 O
images O
for O
further O
analysis O
. O

Further O
pre-processing O
included O
slice O
time O
correction O
, O
realignment O
to O
the O
first O
volume O
, O
spatial O
normalization O
to O
a O
standard O
MNI O
template O
, O
reslicing O
to O
a O
voxel O
size O
of O
3×3×3mm O
, O
and O
smoothing O
with O
a O
6mm O
Gaussian O
kernel O
. O

Individuals O
included O
did O
not O
exceed O
4mm/4 O
degrees O
movement O
across O
volumes O
. O

2.3 O
. O

Functional O
network O
connectivity O
analysis O
The O
meta-state O
analysis O
is O
based O
on O
windowed O
FNC O
matrices O
. O

Therefore O
, O
we O
describe O
all O
FNC O
processing O
steps O
in O
detail O
below O
. O

2.3.1 O
. O

Group O
Independent O
Component O
Analysis O
( O
GICA O
) O
Figure O
1 O
depicts O
analysis O
steps O
for O
GICA O
and O
for O
the O
k-means O
meta-state O
approach O
. O

Spatial O
GICA O
decomposes O
the O
whole O
brain O
rs-fMRI O
data O
into O
linear O
mixtures O
of O
spatially O
independent O
components O
. O

GICA O
was O
performed O
using O
the O
Group O
ICA O
fMRI O
toolbox O
( O
GIFT O
) O
( O
http O
: O
//mialab.mrn.org/software/gift/index.html O
) O
with O
two O
data O
reduction O
steps O
using O
principal O
component O
analysis O
: O
1 O
) O
a O
subject-specific O
reduction O
of O
time O
points O
from O
170 O
time O
points O
to O
120 O
temporal O
principle O
components O
comprising O
weighted O
sums O
of O
time O
points O
, O
and O
2 O
) O
a O
group-wise O
reduction O
of O
the O
concatenated O
subject-reduced O
data O
to O
100 O
aggregate O
components O
each O
consisting O
of O
a O
spatial O
map O
and O
a O
corresponding O
time O
course O
using O
the O
expectation-maximization O
algorithm O
. O

Pre-processing O
in O
GIFT O
included O
z-scoring O
of O
time O
courses O
in O
order O
to O
normalize O
variance O
. O

ICA O
was O
repeated O
20 O
times O
in O
ICASSO O
using O
the O
infomax O
algorithm O
in O
order O
to O
ensure O
stability O
of O
estimation O
. O

We O
used O
spatial-temporal O
back O
reconstruction O
to O
estimate O
subject-specific O
time O
courses O
and O
spatial O
maps O
for O
each O
independent O
component O
. O

The O
resulting O
100 O
independent O
components O
were O
manually O
reviewed O
in O
order O
to O
identify O
meaningful O
ICNs O
based O
on O
the O
Automated O
Anatomic O
Labeling O
atlas O
. O

ICNs O
should O
show O
peak O
locations O
in O
gray O
matter O
with O
minimal O
overlap O
with O
white O
matter O
, O
ventricles O
, O
blood O
vessels O
, O
and O
non-brain O
structures O
. O

Further O
, O
spectral O
power O
of O
the O
time O
courses O
of O
meaningful O
ICNs O
should O
obey O
the O
power O
law O
, O
showing O
exponentially O
higher O
power O
at O
the O
lowest O
frequencies O
and O
lowest O
power O
at O
the O
highest O
frequencies O
. O

Inspection O
of O
the O
100 O
independent O
components O
yielded O
47 O
meaningful O
ICNs O
which O
were O
assigned O
to O
8 O
functional O
domains O
based O
on O
prior O
scientific O
literature O
( O
http O
: O
//neurosynth.org/ O
) O
: O
subcortical O
( O
SC O
) O
, O
salience O
( O
SAL O
) O
, O
auditory O
( O
AUD O
) O
, O
sensorimotor O
( O
SM O
) O
, O
visual O
( O
VIS O
) O
, O
cognitive O
control O
( O
CC O
) O
, O
default O
mode O
network O
( O
DMN O
) O
, O
and O
cerebellum O
( O
CB O
) O
. O

Supplementary O
figure O
1 O
shows O
all O
functional O
domains O
and O
supplementary O
table O
2 O
contains O
ICNs O
assigned O
to O
each O
domain O
. O

2.3.2 O
. O

Post-processing O
of O
time O
courses O
Post-processing O
of O
time O
courses O
included O
linear O
, O
quadratic O
, O
and O
cubic O
detrending O
and O
regression O
of O
motion O
parameters O
( O
in O
x- O
, O
y- O
, O
and O
z-direction O
as O
well O
as O
pitch O
, O
roll O
, O
and O
yaw O
) O
as O
well O
as O
their O
derivatives O
and O
squares O
, O
in O
a O
single O
multiple O
regression O
framework O
. O

Time O
courses O
were O
also O
despiked O
. O

Spikes O
were O
defined O
as O
time O
points O
with O
a O
root O
mean O
square O
of O
the O
frame-wise O
displacement O
> O
0.5mm O
. O

These O
were O
identified O
based O
on O
the O
3Ddespike O
algorithm O
as O
implemented O
in O
Analysis O
of O
Functional O
NeuroImages O
( O
AFNI O
) O
and O
interpolated O
using O
a O
3rd O
order O
spline O
fit O
to O
‘ O
clean O
’ O
neighboring O
data O
. O

Temporal O
filtering O
was O
applied O
with O
a O
bandpass O
5th O
order O
Butterworth O
filter O
( O
passband O
0.01 O
– O
0.15 O
Hz O
) O
. O

FNC O
was O
computed O
after O
post-processing O
and O
interpolation O
of O
time O
points O
identified O
as O
spikes O
. O

2.3.3 O
. O

Windowed O
functional O
network O
connectivity O
matrices O
As O
in O
earlier O
studies O
, O
we O
applied O
a O
sliding O
temporal O
window O
approach O
to O
rs-fMRI O
data O
in O
order O
to O
capture O
fluctuations O
of O
functional O
connectivity O
. O

A O
rectangular O
window O
( O
width O
22 O
TRs O
= O
44s O
) O
was O
convolved O
with O
a O
Gaussian O
of O
sigma O
3 O
TRs O
in O
order O
to O
obtain O
tapering O
along O
the O
edges O
of O
the O
window O
and O
slid O
in O
steps O
of O
1 O
TR O
across O
concatenated O
time O
courses O
. O

For O
each O
window O
, O
a O
separate O
FNC O
matrix O
consisting O
of O
cross-correlations O
of O
ICNs O
( O
size O
ICN O
x O
ICN O
) O
was O
calculated O
. O

2.3.4 O
Connectivity O
patterns O
( O
CP O
) O
and O
meta-states O
Unlike O
Miller O
et O
al. O
, O
we O
solely O
applied O
a O
k-means O
clustering O
algorithm O
to O
windowed O
FNC O
( O
wFNC O
) O
matrices O
( O
representing O
a O
connectivity O
pattern O
in O
an O
individual O
at O
a O
certain O
point O
in O
time O
) O
in O
order O
to O
make O
results O
between O
the O
dynamic O
FNC O
approach O
and O
the O
meta-states O
approach O
more O
comparable O
. O

Estimated O
wFNC O
matrices O
were O
clustered O
based O
on O
the O
k-means O
algorithm O
implemented O
in O
Matlab O
( O
7.12.0 O
( O
R2011a O
) O
, O
The O
MathWorks O
Inc. O
, O
Natick O
, O
MA O
) O
with O
squared O
Euclidean O
distance O
as O
similarity O
measure O
( O
150 O
iterations O
, O
5 O
replicates O
) O
. O

The O
optimal O
number O
of O
cluster O
centroids O
was O
estimated O
to O
be O
5 O
based O
on O
the O
elbow O
criterion O
( O
supplementary O
figure O
2 O
) O
. O

Supplementary O
figure O
3 O
shows O
the O
k-means O
clustering O
process O
in O
more O
detail O
. O

The O
resulting O
cluster O
centroids O
were O
used O
as O
main O
connectivity O
patterns O
( O
CPs O
) O
in O
order O
to O
generate O
distance O
vectors O
for O
each O
wFNC O
matrix O
. O

The O
distance O
was O
measured O
as O
squared O
Euclidean O
distance O
of O
each O
wFNC O
matrix O
to O
the O
five O
cluster O
centroids O
in O
the O
5-dimensional O
meta-state O
space O
resulting O
in O
a O
vector O
consisting O
of O
5 O
distances O
, O
see O
Figure O
1 O
. O

This O
distance O
vector O
is O
then O
parameterized O
by O
replacing O
each O
concrete O
distance O
value O
with O
the O
quartile O
this O
distance O
falls O
in O
based O
on O
the O
group O
’ O
s O
distance O
. O

These O
parameterized O
vectors O
are O
called O
meta-states O
. O

The O
following O
measures O
of O
dynamism O
can O
be O
calculated O
from O
the O
discretized O
distance O
vectors O
: O
The O
number O
of O
changes O
of O
meta-states O
, O
i.e. O
, O
how O
often O
does O
an O
individual O
switch O
between O
distinct O
meta-states O
; O
The O
number O
of O
distinct O
meta-states O
, O
i.e. O
, O
how O
many O
unique O
distance O
vectors O
are O
present O
in O
an O
individual O
; O
The O
span O
of O
meta-states O
, O
i.e. O
, O
the O
actual O
range O
of O
the O
5-dimensional O
meta-state O
space O
that O
one O
individual O
covers O
during O
the O
entire O
scan O
; O
The O
total O
distance O
traveled O
through O
the O
meta-state O
space O
. O

Using O
analysis O
of O
variance O
( O
ANOVA O
) O
, O
we O
tested O
for O
differences O
between O
groups O
separately O
for O
each O
measure O
of O
neural O
dynamism O
( O
significance O
level O
p O
< O
0.05 O
) O
. O

Significant O
results O
were O
followed O
up O
using O
the O
inbuilt O
Matlab O
( O
7.12.0 O
( O
R2011a O
) O
, O
The O
MathWorks O
Inc. O
, O
Natick O
, O
MA O
) O
function O
multcompare O
that O
uses O
Tukey O
’ O
s O
HSD O
tests O
in O
order O
to O
determine O
which O
groups O
differed O
. O

Tukey O
’ O
s O
HSD O
test O
was O
designed O
to O
control O
for O
type O
1 O
errors O
and O
corrects O
for O
multiple O
comparisons O
by O
itself O
. O

2.3.4.1 O
. O

Summary O
In O
the O
current O
study O
, O
a O
meta-state O
represents O
a O
whole O
brain O
connectivity O
pattern O
in O
time O
consisting O
of O
overlapping O
manifestations O
of O
5 O
main O
connectivity O
patterns O
. O

Thus O
, O
the O
term O
meta-state O
refers O
to O
a O
high-level O
summary O
of O
overlapping O
connectivity O
states O
. O

Meta-states O
are O
then O
used O
to O
calculate O
metrics O
reflecting O
dynamic O
properties O
of O
whole-brain O
connectivity O
, O
i.e. O
, O
number O
of O
meta-states O
changes O
, O
number O
of O
meta-states O
, O
span O
of O
meta-states O
, O
and O
total O
distance O
travelled O
in O
the O
5-dimensional O
meta-state O
space O
. O

2.3.5 O
. O

Association O
between O
neural O
dynamism O
and O
symptom O
severity O
In O
order O
to O
investigate O
possible O
associations O
between O
neural O
dynamism O
and O
symptom O
severity O
, O
we O
computed O
bivariate O
Pearson O
’ O
s O
correlations O
for O
CHR O
and O
ESZ O
groups O
and O
each O
dynamic O
measure O
. O

Positive O
and O
negative O
symptom O
scores O
based O
on O
SOPS O
for O
CHR O
individuals O
and O
PANSS O
for O
ESZ O
individuals O
were O
correlated O
with O
measures O
of O
neural O
dynamism O
. O

Results O
were O
considered O
significant O
when O
reaching O
a O
Bonferroni O
adjusted O
α-level O
of O
0.0031 O
( O
0.05/16 O
, O
i.e O
. O

nominal O
type O
I O
error/number O
of O
tests O
) O
. O

Clinical O
data O
were O
available O
for O
36 O
CHR O
and O
56 O
ESZ O
individuals O
for O
this O
analysis O
. O

2.3.6 O
Influence O
of O
antipsychotic O
medication O
on O
neural O
dynamism O
in O
CHR O
individuals O
In O
order O
to O
test O
medication O
effects O
, O
we O
compared O
measures O
of O
dynamism O
in O
unmedicated O
( O
N= O
41 O
, O
77.4 O
% O
) O
vs. O
medicated O
( O
N= O
12 O
, O
22.6 O
% O
) O
CHR O
individuals O
. O

Due O
to O
the O
unbalanced O
sample O
size O
, O
we O
computed O
non-parametric O
Wilcoxon O
rank O
sum O
tests O
. O

Since O
there O
were O
not O
enough O
ESZ O
patients O
without O
antipsychotic O
medication O
( O
n= O
5 O
, O
8.6 O
% O
) O
we O
could O
not O
apply O
the O
same O
approach O
to O
the O
ESZ O
sample O
. O

Aberrant O
Middle O
Prefrontal-Motor O
Cortex O
Connectivity O
Mediates O
Motor O
Inhibitory O
Biomarker O
in O
Schizophrenia O
Background O
: O
The O
inhibitory O
deficits O
in O
the O
motor O
cortex O
in O
schizophrenia O
have O
been O
well O
demonstrated O
using O
short-interval O
intracortical O
inhibition O
( O
SICI O
) O
by O
transcranial O
magnetic O
stimulation O
( O
TMS O
) O
. O

However O
, O
it O
remains O
unknown O
whether O
these O
deficits O
originate O
from O
dysfunction O
of O
motor O
cortex O
itself O
or O
reflect O
abnormal O
modulations O
of O
the O
motor O
cortex O
by O
other O
schizophrenia-related O
brain O
areas O
. O

Methods O
: O
Twenty-four O
patients O
with O
schizophrenia O
spectrum O
disorders O
and O
30 O
healthy O
controls O
completed O
the O
study O
. O

SICI O
was O
obtained O
by O
delivering O
TMS O
over O
the O
left O
motor O
cortex O
. O

Resting-state O
functional O
magnetic O
resonance O
imaging O
and O
diffusion O
tensor O
imaging O
fractional O
anisotropy O
were O
used O
to O
measure O
functional O
connectivity O
( O
FC O
) O
and O
white O
matter O
microstructures O
, O
respectively O
. O

Stimulation O
sites O
for O
SICI O
at O
the O
motor O
cortex O
were O
used O
as O
the O
seeds O
to O
obtain O
the O
whole-brain O
FC O
maps O
. O

The O
clinical O
symptoms O
were O
assessed O
with O
Brief O
Psychiatric O
Rating O
Scale O
( O
BPRS O
) O
. O

Results O
: O
In O
schizophrenia O
, O
left O
prefrontal O
cortex O
( O
PFC O
) O
– O
motor O
cortex O
FC O
was O
inversely O
associated O
with O
SICI O
but O
positively O
associated O
with O
the O
underlying O
white O
matter O
microstructure O
at O
the O
left O
corona O
radiata O
( O
CR O
) O
, O
and O
also O
associated O
with O
overall O
symptoms O
( O
all O
corrected O
p O
< O
0.05 O
) O
. O

Mediation O
analysis O
showed O
that O
the O
PFC-motor O
cortex O
FC O
significantly O
mediates O
the O
corona O
radiata O
white O
matter O
effects O
on O
SICI O
( O
p=0.007 O
) O
. O

Conclusions O
: O
Higher O
resting-state O
left O
PFC-motor O
cortex O
functional O
connectivity O
, O
accompanied O
by O
a O
higher O
FA O
of O
left O
corona O
radiata O
, O
predicts O
less O
inhibitory O
deficits O
, O
suggesting O
the O
inhibitory O
deficits O
in O
the O
motor O
cortex O
in O
schizophrenia O
may O
in O
part O
be O
mediated O
by O
a O
top-down O
prefrontal O
influence O
. O

SICI O
may O
serve O
as O
a O
robust O
biomarker O
indexing O
inhibitory O
dysfunction O
at O
anatomic O
as O
well O
as O
circuitry O
levels O
in O
schizophrenia O
. O

Materials O
and O
methods O
Participants O
Patients O
with O
schizophrenia O
spectrum O
disorders O
( O
n=24 O
) O
and O
healthy O
controls O
( O
n=30 O
) O
participated O
in O
the O
study O
( O
Table O
1 O
) O
. O

Patients O
were O
recruited O
from O
Maryland O
Psychiatric O
Research O
Center O
and O
neighboring O
mental O
health O
clinics O
in O
the O
Baltimore O
area O
. O

Controls O
were O
recruited O
from O
local O
media O
advertisement O
. O

The O
Structured O
Clinical O
Interview O
for O
DSM-IV O
was O
used O
to O
confirm O
the O
diagnoses O
of O
schizophrenia O
or O
schizoaffective O
disorder O
in O
patients O
and O
the O
absence O
of O
current O
DSM-IV O
Axis O
I O
diagnoses O
in O
controls O
. O

Exclusion O
criteria O
were O
major O
medical O
and O
neurological O
illnesses O
, O
history O
of O
head O
injury O
with O
loss O
of O
consciousness O
, O
substance O
abuse O
( O
except O
nicotine O
) O
and O
taking O
clozapine O
more O
than O
400mg/day O
. O

Four O
schizophrenia O
patients O
were O
not O
on O
antipsychotic O
medications O
, O
19 O
were O
on O
atypical O
, O
and O
2 O
were O
on O
typical O
including O
1 O
on O
both O
atypical O
and O
typical O
medications O
( O
Table O
1 O
) O
. O

No O
patients O
took O
benzodiazepines O
at O
the O
time O
of O
scanning O
. O

Brief O
Psychiatric O
Rating O
Scale O
( O
BPRS O
) O
was O
administered O
to O
patients O
for O
assessing O
their O
overall O
clinical O
symptoms O
( O
BPRS O
total O
score O
) O
. O

Motor O
retardation O
was O
represented O
by O
item O
13 O
in O
BPRS O
. O

All O
raters O
were O
master O
level O
clinicians O
and O
received O
training O
by O
a O
standing O
committee O
and O
must O
achieve O
intraclass O
correlation O
0.9 O
or O
above O
with O
the O
gold O
standard O
. O

All O
subjects O
gave O
their O
written O
informed O
consent O
approved O
by O
local O
Institutional O
Review O
Board O
. O

TMS O
and O
electromyography O
procedure O
A O
figure-of-eight O
coil O
with O
Magstim O
stimulators O
( O
Whitland O
, O
UK O
) O
was O
utilized O
to O
deliver O
the O
stimulations O
. O

Subject O
’ O
s O
structural O
images O
were O
used O
for O
precise O
positioning O
of O
the O
coil O
through O
Brainsight™ O
( O
Montreal O
, O
Canada O
) O
. O

The O
stimulus O
target O
was O
left O
motor O
cortex O
( O
M1 O
) O
where O
TMS O
induced O
the O
maximum O
response O
from O
right O
first O
dorsal O
interosseous O
muscle O
. O

Peak-to-peak O
amplitude O
of O
the O
motor-evoked O
potentials O
( O
MEP O
) O
was O
measured O
. O

Resting O
motor O
threshold O
( O
RMT O
) O
was O
defined O
as O
the O
minimum O
intensity O
needed O
to O
elicit O
a O
MEP O
of O
> O
50μV O
in O
at O
least O
5 O
out O
of O
10 O
consecutive O
stimuli O
. O

Paired-pulse O
TMS O
( O
ppTMS O
) O
with O
1 O
and O
3 O
ms O
ISIs O
were O
used O
to O
induce O
short-interval O
intracortical O
inhibition O
( O
SICI O
) O
. O

For O
each O
SICI O
trial O
, O
a O
subthreshold O
conditioning O
stimulus O
( O
80 O
% O
RMT O
) O
was O
followed O
by O
a O
suprathreshold O
stimulation O
( O
120 O
% O
RMT O
) O
. O

Single O
pulse O
at O
120 O
% O
RMT O
was O
the O
test O
stimulation O
( O
TS O
) O
that O
serves O
as O
a O
control O
. O

SICI O
was O
defined O
as O
the O
ratio O
between O
responses O
of O
ppTMS O
and O
TS O
alone O
. O

Ratios O
less O
than O
1 O
indicate O
inhibition O
and O
the O
smaller O
the O
ratio O
, O
the O
stronger O
the O
cortical O
inhibition O
. O

There O
were O
24 O
trials O
for O
SICI O
and O
24 O
trials O
for O
TS O
. O

Previous O
research O
demonstrated O
that O
SICI O
, O
but O
usually O
not O
RMT O
or O
MEP O
of O
TS O
alone O
, O
can O
robustly O
separate O
schizophrenia O
patients O
from O
healthy O
controls O
, O
supporting O
that O
the O
SICI O
deficit O
was O
likely O
inhibitory O
rather O
than O
deficit O
in O
motor O
responses O
. O

Imaging O
data O
acquisition O
Before O
the O
SICI O
session O
, O
we O
assessed O
structural O
, O
resting-state O
fMRI O
and O
diffusion O
tensor O
imaging O
( O
DTI O
) O
in O
a O
separate O
session O
. O

All O
imaging O
was O
performed O
using O
a O
Siemens O
3T O
TRIO O
MRI O
system O
( O
Erlangen O
, O
Germany O
) O
equipped O
with O
a O
32-channel O
head O
coil O
. O

Structural O
images O
were O
acquired O
using O
a O
fast O
spoiled O
gradient-recalled O
sequence O
( O
TR/TE=11.08/4.3ms O
, O
flip O
angle=45° O
, O
FOV=256mm O
, O
256×256 O
matrix O
, O
172 O
slices O
, O
1mm3 O
spatial O
resolution O
) O
. O

Resting-state O
functional O
T2 O
* O
-weighted O
images O
were O
obtained O
using O
a O
single-shot O
gradient-recalled O
, O
echo-planar O
pulse O
sequence O
( O
TR/TE O
=2s/27ms O
; O
flip O
angle=90° O
; O
FOV=220mm O
; O
64×64 O
matrix O
; O
1.7mm2 O
in-plane O
resolution O
; O
4mm O
slice O
thickness O
; O
37 O
axial O
slices O
, O
15 O
minutes O
scan O
for O
450 O
volumes O
) O
. O

Participants O
were O
asked O
to O
keep O
their O
eyes O
closed O
, O
relax O
and O
not O
to O
think O
about O
anything O
in O
particular O
. O

Post-scan O
questions O
confirmed O
that O
participants O
did O
not O
fall O
asleep O
during O
the O
scan O
. O

DTI O
data O
were O
collected O
using O
a O
single-shot O
, O
echo-planar O
, O
single O
refocusing O
spin-echo O
, O
T2-weighted O
sequence O
at O
1.7×1.7×3.0mm O
, O
TE/TR=87/8000ms O
, O
FOV=200mm O
, O
50 O
slices O
and O
no O
gaps O
, O
five O
b=0 O
images O
and O
64 O
isotropically O
distributed O
diffusion O
weighted O
directions O
with O
b=700s/mm2 O
. O

Imaging O
data O
preprocessing O
Standard O
resting-state O
functional O
MRI O
data O
processing O
was O
carried O
out O
using O
Analysis O
of O
Functional O
NeuroImages O
( O
AFNI O
) O
software O
( O
Version O
16.3.17 O
) O
. O

After O
discarding O
the O
first O
two O
TRs O
, O
the O
preprocessed O
data O
were O
spatially O
smoothed O
to O
a O
full O
width O
at O
half O
maximum O
of O
4mm O
. O

The O
linear O
trend O
, O
6 O
motion O
parameters O
( O
3 O
rotational O
and O
3 O
translational O
directions O
) O
, O
their O
6 O
temporal O
derivatives O
( O
rate O
of O
change O
in O
rotational O
and O
translational O
motion O
) O
and O
time O
courses O
from O
the O
white O
matter O
and O
cerebral O
spinal O
fluid O
( O
CSF O
) O
were O
removed O
as O
regressors O
of O
no O
interest O
. O

Time O
points O
with O
excessive O
motion O
( O
> O
0.2mm O
) O
and O
their O
neighboring O
time O
points O
were O
censored O
from O
statistical O
analysis O
( O
details O
in O
Supplementary O
material O
) O
. O

Finally O
, O
for O
group O
analysis O
, O
images O
were O
spatially O
normalized O
to O
the O
Talairach O
space O
. O

Individual O
statistical O
maps O
were O
then O
calculated O
using O
a O
seed-based O
correlation O
analysis O
to O
infer O
the O
functional O
connectivity O
of O
the O
seed O
with O
the O
rest O
of O
the O
brain O
. O

The O
seed O
region O
of O
interest O
( O
ROI O
) O
was O
left O
M1 O
defined O
based O
on O
TMS O
site O
of O
SICI O
for O
each O
subject O
. O

A O
10mm O
radius O
sphere O
was O
placed O
on O
each O
subject O
’ O
s O
structural O
images O
with O
individual O
SICI O
site O
as O
the O
center O
( O
Figure O
3A O
) O
. O

White O
matter O
and O
CSF O
were O
removed O
from O
the O
seed O
ROI O
using O
the O
masks O
obtained O
from O
FreeSurfer O
. O

Then O
, O
the O
mean O
time-series O
within O
seed O
ROI O
was O
correlated O
with O
the O
time O
course O
of O
each O
voxel O
in O
the O
brain O
for O
each O
subject O
. O

Pearson O
’ O
s O
correlation O
coefficients O
were O
converted O
to O
z O
values O
using O
Fisher O
’ O
s O
r-to-z O
transform O
. O

The O
details O
of O
DTI O
data O
preprocessing O
were O
described O
in O
Supplementary O
Material O
and O
our O
previous O
studies O
. O

Based O
on O
a O
tract-based O
spatial O
statistics O
method O
, O
fractional O
anisotropy O
( O
FA O
) O
images O
were O
obtained O
, O
spatially O
normalized O
to O
the O
JHU O
atlas O
which O
separated O
white O
matter O
into O
different O
tracts O
. O

The O
white O
matter O
directly O
under O
the O
left O
motor O
cortex O
and O
connecting O
motor O
cortex O
to O
the O
frontal O
area O
is O
the O
left O
corona O
radiata O
( O
CR O
) O
. O

In O
our O
previous O
research O
, O
by O
exploring O
SICI-related O
white O
matter O
tracts O
( O
25 O
tracts O
) O
, O
we O
found O
left O
CR O
was O
also O
the O
only O
tract O
whose O
association O
with O
SICI O
in O
schizophrenia O
survived O
Bonferroni O
correction O
. O

Therefore O
, O
we O
included O
only O
left O
CR O
in O
the O
study O
( O
Figure O
3A O
) O
. O

Some O
of O
the O
SICI O
and O
DTI O
data O
were O
reported O
in O
our O
previous O
work O
. O

None O
of O
the O
resting-state O
fMRI O
data O
were O
previously O
reported O
. O

Statistical O
analysis O
The O
demographic O
data O
were O
compared O
using O
independent-sample O
t O
tests O
for O
continuous O
values O
and O
Chi-squared O
test O
for O
categorical O
values O
. O

Although O
many O
demographic O
characters O
did O
not O
significantly O
differ O
between O
groups O
, O
their O
potential O
effects O
on O
the O
results O
were O
evaluated O
. O

Group-level O
brain-behavioral O
correlations O
were O
evaluated O
using O
Pearson O
’ O
s O
correlation O
with O
age O
as O
a O
covariate O
. O

Results O
were O
also O
evaluated O
by O
adding O
gender O
, O
education O
level O
, O
and O
chlorpromazine O
equivalent O
dose O
( O
CPZ O
) O
as O
extra O
covariates O
; O
only O
significant O
findings O
would O
be O
reported O
. O

The O
primary O
analysis O
was O
to O
test O
whether O
there O
are O
M1-seeded O
rsFC O
associated O
with O
both O
motor O
inhibition O
( O
i.e. O
, O
SICI O
) O
and O
overall O
symptoms O
of O
schizophrenia O
( O
i.e. O
, O
BPRS O
total O
score O
) O
. O

Brain-SICI O
correlation O
maps O
were O
calculated O
by O
correlating O
behavioral O
variables O
with O
z O
values O
in O
rsFC O
maps O
. O

We O
first O
identified O
regions O
showing O
significant O
M1 O
rsFC O
related O
to O
SICI O
in O
patients O
and O
controls O
separately O
, O
and O
schizophrenia O
symptoms O
in O
patients O
. O

The O
significant O
clusters O
were O
determined O
by O
estimating O
the O
cluster-size O
threshold O
( O
cluster O
size O
> O
202 O
voxels O
) O
using O
the O
updated O
3dClustSim O
with O
the O
Spatial O
AutoCorrelation O
Function O
to O
obtain O
corrected O
p O
< O
0.017 O
( O
0.05/3 O
; O
Bonferroni O
correction O
for O
3 O
comparisons O
) O
. O

We O
further O
used O
leave-one-out O
cross-validation O
( O
LOOCV O
) O
to O
evaluate O
the O
validities O
of O
clusters O
identified O
above O
( O
details O
in O
Supplementary O
material O
) O
. O

Clusters O
with O
validity O
of O
80 O
% O
or O
higher O
were O
considered O
as O
valid O
clusters O
. O

The O
same O
procedures O
were O
repeated O
for O
BPRS O
score O
. O

The O
overlapping O
region O
( O
s O
) O
of O
significant O
rsFC-SICI O
clusters O
and O
significant O
rsFC-BPRS O
clusters O
was O
extracted O
to O
represent O
M1 O
rsFC O
that O
were O
significantly O
related O
to O
both O
SICI O
and O
clinical O
symptoms O
of O
schizophrenia O
. O

The O
relationship O
between O
these O
clusters O
and O
motor O
retardation O
was O
examined O
to O
confirm O
their O
role O
in O
motor O
abnormality O
. O

The O
group-difference O
of O
rsFC O
was O
also O
assessed O
. O

The O
rsFC O
from O
those O
clusters O
was O
then O
used O
to O
examine O
for O
their O
mediation O
relationship O
with O
FA O
of O
left O
CR O
with O
age O
as O
a O
covariate O
using O
PROCESS O
in O
SPSS O
23.0 O
. O

Peripheral O
oxytocin O
and O
vasopressin O
modulates O
regional O
brain O
activity O
differently O
in O
men O
and O
women O
with O
schizophrenia O
Background O
Oxytocin O
( O
OT O
) O
and O
arginine O
vasopressin O
( O
AVP O
) O
exert O
sexually O
dimorphic O
effects O
on O
cognition O
and O
emotion O
processing O
. O

Abnormalities O
in O
these O
hormones O
are O
observed O
in O
schizophrenia O
and O
may O
contribute O
to O
multiple O
established O
sex O
differences O
associated O
with O
the O
disorder O
. O

Here O
we O
examined O
sex-dependent O
hormone O
associations O
with O
resting O
brain O
activity O
and O
their O
clinical O
associations O
in O
schizophrenia O
patients O
. O

Methods O
OT O
and O
AVP O
serum O
concentrations O
were O
assayed O
in O
35 O
individuals O
with O
schizophrenia O
( O
23 O
men O
) O
and O
60 O
controls O
( O
24 O
men O
) O
from O
the O
Chicago O
BSNIP O
study O
site O
. O

Regional O
cerebral O
function O
was O
assessed O
with O
resting O
state O
fMRI O
by O
measuring O
the O
amplitude O
of O
low-frequency O
fluctuations O
( O
ALFF O
) O
which O
are O
believed O
to O
reflect O
intrinsic O
spontaneous O
neuronal O
activity O
. O

Results O
In O
female O
patients O
, O
lower O
OT O
levels O
were O
associated O
with O
lower O
ALFF O
in O
frontal O
and O
cerebellar O
cortices O
( O
p O
’ O
s O
< O
0.05 O
) O
and O
in O
female O
controls O
AVP O
levels O
were O
inversely O
associated O
with O
ALFF O
in O
the O
frontal O
cortex O
( O
p=0.01 O
) O
. O

In O
male O
patients O
, O
lower O
OT O
levels O
were O
associated O
with O
lower O
ALFF O
in O
the O
posterior O
cingulate O
and O
lower O
AVP O
levels O
were O
associated O
with O
lower O
ALFF O
in O
frontal O
cortex O
( O
p O
’ O
s O
< O
0.05 O
) O
. O

In O
male O
controls O
, O
lower O
OT O
levels O
were O
associated O
with O
lower O
ALFF O
in O
frontal O
cortex O
and O
higher O
ALFF O
in O
the O
thalamus O
( O
p O
’ O
s O
< O
0.05 O
) O
. O

There O
were O
some O
inverse O
ALFF-behavior O
associations O
in O
patients O
. O

Conclusions O
Alterations O
in O
peripheral O
hormone O
levels O
are O
associated O
with O
resting O
brain O
physiology O
in O
a O
sex-dependent O
manner O
in O
schizophrenia O
. O

These O
effects O
may O
contribute O
to O
sex O
differences O
in O
psychiatric O
symptom O
severity O
and O
course O
of O
illness O
in O
schizophrenia O
. O

2 O
. O

Methods O
2.1 O
. O

Participants O
Participants O
included O
35 O
individuals O
with O
DSM-IV O
diagnoses O
of O
schizophrenia O
( O
12 O
women O
, O
23 O
men O
) O
and O
60 O
healthy O
individuals O
( O
36 O
women O
, O
24 O
men O
) O
from O
the O
Chicago O
site O
of O
the O
Bipolar O
and O
Schizophrenia O
Network O
on O
Intermediate O
Phenotypes O
( O
B-SNIP O
) O
consortium O
at O
which O
plasma O
for O
endocrine O
assays O
was O
obtained O
. O

Recruitment O
, O
diagnostic O
strategies O
and O
patient O
characteristics O
have O
been O
described O
previously O
( O
Table O
1 O
) O
. O

All O
participants O
provided O
written O
informed O
consent O
and O
the O
study O
was O
approved O
by O
the O
University O
of O
Illinois O
at O
Chicago O
Institutional O
Review O
Board O
. O

A O
diagnosis O
of O
schizophrenia O
was O
made O
at O
consensus O
meetings O
using O
all O
available O
information O
including O
findings O
from O
the O
Structured O
Clinical O
Interview O
for O
DSM-IV O
Axis O
I O
Disorders O
( O
SCID O
) O
. O

Healthy O
comparison O
subjects O
had O
no O
history O
of O
a O
psychotic O
disorder O
or O
recurrent O
depression O
, O
and O
no O
known O
immediate O
family O
history O
of O
these O
disorders O
. O

Exclusion O
criteria O
for O
all O
participants O
included O
: O
history O
of O
head O
injury O
with O
loss O
of O
consciousness O
> O
10 O
minutes O
; O
pregnancy O
; O
positive O
urine O
toxicology O
screen O
for O
common O
drugs O
of O
abuse O
on O
the O
day O
of O
testing O
; O
diagnosis O
of O
substance O
abuse O
in O
the O
past O
30 O
days O
or O
substance O
dependence O
in O
the O
past O
6 O
months O
; O
history O
of O
systemic O
medical O
or O
neurological O
disorder O
affecting O
mood O
or O
cognition O
; O
or O
age-corrected O
Wide-Range O
Achievement O
Test O
reading O
test O
standard O
score O
≤70 O
. O

2.2 O
Serum O
hormone O
assays O
Blood O
samples O
were O
drawn O
in O
the O
morning O
when O
possible O
( O
97 O
% O
blood O
draws O
before O
noon O
) O
. O

Samples O
were O
stored O
in O
plain O
tubes O
, O
spun O
at O
4°C O
, O
divided O
into O
aliquots O
( O
300ul O
) O
, O
and O
stored O
at O
−80°C O
. O

Samples O
were O
batched O
, O
diluted O
in O
an O
assay O
buffer O
to O
give O
reliable O
results O
within O
the O
linear O
portion O
of O
the O
standard O
curve O
( O
OT O
1:4 O
; O
AVP O
1:2 O
) O
, O
and O
completed O
in O
duplicate O
using O
unextracted O
plasma O
. O

EIA O
kits O
( O
Enzo O
Life O
Sciences/Assay O
Designs O
) O
were O
used O
to O
quantify O
OT O
and O
AVP O
and O
both O
hormones O
were O
assayed O
simultaneously O
. O

Samples O
were O
not O
extracted O
prior O
to O
performing O
the O
EIA O
as O
studies O
using O
mass O
spectrometry O
demonstrate O
high O
levels O
of O
OT O
in O
plasma O
and O
serum O
and O
indicate O
that O
methods O
involving O
extraction O
of O
samples O
removes O
much O
of O
this O
peptide O
. O

These O
EIAs O
are O
highly O
sensitive O
( O
minimal O
detection O
levels O
< O
12 O
pg/ml O
OT O
; O
4 O
pg/ml O
AVP O
) O
and O
cross-reactivity O
between O
OT O
and O
AVP O
is O
low O
( O
< O
0.04 O
% O
) O
. O

All O
OT O
values O
> O
2000 O
pg/ml O
and O
AVP O
values O
> O
400 O
pg/ml O
were O
re-run O
to O
confirm O
sample O
accuracy O
. O

This O
was O
only O
the O
case O
for O
OT O
level O
; O
no O
cases O
had O
AVP O
values O
> O
400pg/ml O
. O

For O
both O
assays O
, O
intra-assay O
coefficients O
of O
variation O
were O
< O
10.7 O
% O
. O

Hormone O
values O
were O
log O
transformed O
for O
statistical O
analysis O
. O

Mean O
daily O
chlorpromazine O
equivalent O
in O
patients O
was O
not O
associated O
with O
OT O
( O
r=−0.21 O
, O
p=0.33 O
) O
or O
AVP O
levels O
( O
r=−0.07 O
, O
p=0.74 O
) O
. O

Age O
was O
associated O
with O
OT O
( O
r=0.23 O
, O
p=0.03 O
) O
, O
but O
not O
AVP O
levels O
( O
r=0.13 O
, O
p=0.23 O
) O
. O

2.3 O
. O

Emotion O
processing O
and O
cognition O
From O
the O
Brief O
Assessment O
of O
Cognition O
in O
Schizophrenia O
( O
BACS O
) O
neuropsychological O
test O
battery O
, O
we O
selected O
three O
subtests O
including O
verbal O
learning O
( O
list O
learning O
) O
, O
verbal O
fluency O
( O
word O
generation O
) O
, O
and O
processing O
speed O
( O
symbol-coding O
) O
. O

The O
Penn O
Emotion O
Recognition O
( O
ER O
) O
-40 O
Test O
assessed O
the O
ability O
to O
accurately O
recognize O
facial O
emotions O
. O

These O
tests O
were O
selected O
based O
on O
previous O
research O
indicating O
that O
the O
tests O
demonstrate O
sex O
differences O
in O
the O
general O
population O
or O
if O
tests O
( O
verbal O
learning O
, O
processing O
speed O
) O
showed O
a O
sex O
difference O
in O
favor O
of O
women O
( O
p O
’ O
s O
< O
0.01 O
) O
in O
the O
large O
sample O
of O
healthy O
controls O
from O
the O
Bipolar O
and O
Schizophrenia O
Network O
on O
Intermediate O
Phenotypes O
study O
( O
N=304 O
, O
55 O
% O
women O
) O
. O

2.4 O
. O

Resting O
State O
Data O
Acquisition O
Participants O
underwent O
5 O
minutes O
of O
scanning O
using O
a O
GE O
Signa O
EXCITE O
3.0 O
Tesla O
MR O
imaging O
system O
and O
an O
8-channel O
phased O
array O
head O
coil O
. O

Participants O
fixated O
on O
a O
central O
crosshair O
for O
the O
duration O
of O
the O
scan O
. O

Video O
monitoring O
of O
participants O
eyes O
confirmed O
adherence O
to O
this O
instruction O
. O

Soft O
ear O
plugs O
were O
used O
to O
reduce O
scan O
noise O
, O
and O
head O
motion O
was O
minimized O
with O
head O
cushions O
. O

Echo-planar O
imaging O
sensitive O
to O
changes O
in O
BOLD O
signals O
( O
repetition O
time= O
1775msec O
, O
echo O
time= O
27msec O
, O
flip O
angle= O
60° O
) O
were O
obtained O
. O

The O
slice O
thickness O
was O
4 O
mm O
( O
1mm O
gap O
) O
with O
a O
matrix O
size O
of O
64×64 O
and O
a O
field O
of O
view O
of O
220×220 O
mm2 O
, O
resulting O
in O
a O
voxel O
size O
of O
3.44×3.44×5 O
mm3 O
. O

Each O
brain O
volume O
was O
comprised O
of O
29 O
axial O
slices O
, O
and O
each O
functional O
run O
contained O
210 O
image O
volumes O
. O

2.5 O
. O

Data O
Processing O
The O
first O
5 O
volumes O
were O
discarded O
to O
achieve O
steady-state O
longitudinal O
magnetization O
. O

Remaining O
data O
were O
preprocessed O
by O
Data O
Processing O
Assistant O
for O
Resting-State O
fMRI O
, O
version O
2.3 O
( O
http O
: O
//rfmri.org/DPARSF O
) O
software O
, O
implemented O
within O
the O
MATLAB O
toolbox O
, O
including O
slice O
timing O
and O
head O
motion O
correction O
, O
spatial O
normalization O
, O
and O
smoothing O
with O
a O
Gaussian O
kernel O
of O
6 O
mm3 O
full O
width O
at O
half O
maximum O
. O

fMRI O
images O
were O
spatially O
normalized O
to O
Montreal O
Neurological O
Institute O
space O
using O
the O
standard O
echo-planar O
imaging O
template O
after O
resampling O
the O
images O
to O
achieve O
a O
voxel O
resolution O
of O
3×3×3 O
mm O
. O

The O
measurement O
of O
ALFF O
ranged O
from O
0.01 O
to O
0.08 O
Hz O
, O
which O
is O
believed O
to O
reflect O
regional O
spontaneous O
neural O
activity O
. O

To O
achieve O
this O
, O
we O
set O
the O
bandpass O
filtering O
range O
as O
0.01–0.08 O
HZ O
and O
removed O
the O
linear O
trend O
. O

Then O
, O
using O
fast O
Fourier O
transformation O
( O
parameters O
: O
taper O
percentage=0 O
, O
fast O
Fourier O
transform O
length O
=shortest O
) O
, O
we O
transformed O
the O
time O
series O
to O
the O
frequency O
domain O
, O
and O
obtained O
the O
power O
spectrum O
. O

Next O
, O
power O
was O
square O
root O
transformed O
and O
then O
averaged O
across O
0.01–0.08 O
Hz O
to O
yield O
a O
measure O
of O
the O
ALFF O
from O
each O
voxel O
. O

Finally O
, O
the O
ALFF O
of O
each O
voxel O
was O
then O
divided O
by O
the O
global O
mean O
ALFF O
value O
of O
the O
individual O
to O
standardize O
data O
across O
subjects O
. O

2.6 O
. O

Statistical O
Analyses O
All O
statistical O
analytic O
processes O
were O
performed O
in O
REST O
software O
( O
Resting-State O
fMRI O
Data O
Analysis O
Toolkit O
V1.8 O
; O
http O
: O
//restfmri.net/forum/rest O
) O
. O

First O
, O
we O
calculated O
the O
voxel-wise O
correlations O
between O
ALFF O
and O
hormone O
data O
within O
the O
patient O
and O
control O
groups O
respectively O
, O
and O
within O
male O
and O
female O
participants O
in O
each O
group O
, O
with O
age O
treated O
as O
a O
covariate O
. O

To O
detect O
differences O
in O
hormone-brain O
activity O
correlations O
between O
groups O
, O
voxel-based O
comparison O
of O
correlation O
maps O
was O
performed O
in O
SPM8 O
( O
http O
: O
//www.fil.ion.ecl.ac.uk/spm O
) O
. O

Primary O
analyses O
compared O
male O
patients O
and O
controls O
, O
and O
female O
patients O
and O
controls O
. O

The O
average O
correlation O
coefficient O
of O
brain O
regions O
( O
clusters O
of O
voxels O
) O
showing O
significant O
differences O
in O
hormone O
– O
brain O
physiology O
correlations O
were O
extracted O
, O
compared O
across O
groups O
, O
and O
correlated O
with O
clinical O
and O
demographic O
characteristics O
using O
cocor O
software O
( O
comparing O
correlations O
; O
http O
: O
//comparingcorrelations.org O
) O
. O

Primary O
correlational O
analyses O
investigated O
relations O
between O
hormones O
and O
brain O
physiology O
, O
and O
between O
brain O
physiology O
and O
behavior O
. O

A O
series O
of O
multivariable O
linear O
regressions O
were O
then O
conducted O
to O
determine O
whether O
brain O
physiology O
mediated O
hormone-behavior O
associations O
. O

In O
all O
image O
analyses O
, O
we O
used O
Monte O
Carlo O
simulations O
and O
AlphSim O
software O
to O
correct O
for O
multiple O
comparisons O
when O
testing O
for O
statistical O
significance O
. O

The O
probability O
of O
a O
false-positive O
detection O
for O
the O
study O
was O
set O
to O
p O
< O
0.05 O
using O
a O
minimum O
cluster O
size O
of O
5 O
contiguous O
voxels O
significant O
individually O
at O
a O
threshold O
of O
p O
< O
0.05 O
( O
http O
: O
//afni.nimh.nih.gov/pub/dist/doc/manual/AlphaSim.pdf O
) O
. O

The O
AlphSim O
calculation O
was O
conducted O
using O
REST O
software O
( O
http O
: O
//restfmri.net/forum/index.php O
) O
, O
which O
integrated O
the O
true O
smoothness O
kernel O
estimated O
based O
on O
the O
statistical O
map O
and O
mask O
file O
. O

Classifying O
and O
Characterizing O
Nicotine O
Use O
Disorder O
with O
High O
Accuracy O
Using O
Machine O
Learning O
and O
Resting-State O
fMRI O
Cigarette O
smoking O
continues O
to O
be O
a O
leading O
cause O
of O
preventable O
morbidity O
and O
mortality O
. O

Although O
the O
majority O
of O
smokers O
report O
making O
a O
quit O
attempt O
in O
the O
past O
year O
, O
smoking O
cessation O
rates O
remain O
modest O
. O

Thus O
, O
developing O
accurate O
, O
data-driven O
methods O
that O
can O
classify O
and O
characterize O
the O
neural O
features O
of O
nicotine O
use O
disorder O
( O
NUD O
) O
would O
be O
a O
powerful O
clinical O
tool O
that O
could O
aid O
in O
optimizing O
treatment O
development O
and O
guide O
treatment O
modifications O
. O

This O
investigation O
applied O
support-vector O
machine-based O
classification O
to O
resting-state O
functional O
connectivity O
( O
rsFC O
) O
data O
from O
individuals O
diagnosed O
with O
NUD O
( O
n=108 O
; O
63 O
males O
) O
and O
matched O
nonsmoking O
controls O
( O
n=108 O
; O
63 O
males O
) O
and O
multidimensional O
scaling O
( O
MDS O
) O
to O
visualize O
the O
heterogeneity O
of O
NUD O
in O
individual O
smokers O
based O
on O
rsFC O
measures O
. O

Machine-based O
learning O
models O
identified O
five O
resting O
state O
networks O
( O
RSNs O
) O
that O
played O
a O
role O
in O
distinguishing O
smokers O
from O
controls O
: O
the O
posterior O
and O
anterior O
default O
mode O
networks O
, O
the O
sensorimotor O
network O
, O
the O
salience O
network O
, O
and O
the O
right O
executive O
control O
network O
. O

The O
classification O
method O
constructed O
classifiers O
with O
an O
average O
correct O
classification O
rate O
of O
88.1 O
% O
and O
an O
average O
area O
under O
the O
curve O
of O
0.93 O
. O

Compared O
to O
controls O
, O
individuals O
with O
NUD O
had O
weaker O
functional O
connectivity O
measures O
within O
these O
networks O
( O
p O
< O
0.05 O
, O
false O
discovery O
rate O
corrected O
) O
. O

Further O
, O
MDS O
visualization O
demonstrated O
that O
controls O
were O
similar O
to O
each O
other O
; O
whereas O
, O
individuals O
with O
NUD O
had O
less O
similarity O
to O
controls O
and O
to O
other O
individuals O
with O
NUD O
. O

Our O
findings O
build O
upon O
previous O
literature O
demonstrating O
that O
machine-learning O
based O
approaches O
to O
classifying O
rsFC O
data O
offer O
a O
valuable O
technique O
to O
understanding O
network-level O
differences O
in O
nicotine-related O
neurobiology O
and O
extend O
previous O
findings O
by O
improving O
classification O
accuracy O
and O
demonstrating O
the O
heterogeneity O
in O
RSNs O
of O
individuals O
with O
NUD O
. O

METHODS O
Participants O
Participants O
were O
selected O
from O
a O
larger O
cohort O
of O
individuals O
with O
NUD O
and O
non-smoking O
controls O
based O
on O
demographic O
characteristics O
( O
for O
matching O
purposes O
) O
and O
head O
motion O
and O
included O
108 O
individuals O
with O
NUD O
( O
63 O
males O
) O
and O
108 O
demographically O
and O
motion O
matched O
non-smoking O
controls O
( O
63 O
males O
) O
. O

All O
participants O
completed O
an O
initial O
telephone O
screen O
followed O
by O
an O
in-person O
screening O
and O
informed O
consent O
session O
. O

Individuals O
with O
a O
current O
DSM-IV O
Axis O
I O
diagnoses O
( O
other O
than O
NUD O
in O
smokers O
) O
, O
lifetime O
history O
of O
head O
injury O
with O
loss O
of O
consciousness O
for O
more O
than O
3 O
minutes O
, O
contraindications O
for O
MRI O
, O
and O
clinically O
significant O
medical O
conditions O
were O
excluded O
. O

The O
study O
protocol O
was O
executed O
in O
accordance O
with O
the O
standards O
of O
the O
Declaration O
of O
Helsinki O
and O
approved O
by O
the O
University O
of O
Pennsylvania O
Institutional O
Review O
Board O
. O

Measures O
A O
general O
demographics O
questionnaire O
assessed O
participant O
’ O
s O
biological O
sex O
, O
age O
, O
race O
, O
and O
years O
of O
education O
( O
Table O
1 O
) O
. O

The O
Mini-International O
Neuropsychiatric O
Interview O
assessed O
current O
DSM-IV O
diagnosis O
of O
substance O
dependence O
other O
than O
nicotine O
and O
current O
psychiatric O
symptoms O
. O

The O
Fagerström O
Test O
for O
Nicotine O
Dependence O
( O
FTND O
) O
measured O
severity O
of O
nicotine O
dependence O
among O
individuals O
with O
NUD O
. O

Individuals O
with O
NUD O
also O
reported O
on O
the O
number O
of O
cigarettes O
smoked O
per O
day O
( O
CPD O
) O
, O
number O
of O
years O
of O
smoking O
, O
and O
any O
other O
substance O
use O
over O
the O
past O
30 O
days O
. O

Urine O
drug O
screens O
verified O
the O
absence O
of O
illicit O
drugs O
in O
all O
subjects O
and O
the O
absence O
of O
nicotine O
and O
its O
major O
metabolite O
, O
cotinine O
, O
in O
controls O
. O

Procedures O
Image O
acquisition O
High-resolution O
structural O
and O
resting-state O
blood O
oxygen O
level-dependent O
( O
BOLD O
) O
functional O
magnetic O
resonance O
imaging O
( O
fMRI O
) O
data O
were O
collected O
at O
the O
University O
of O
Pennsylvania O
Center O
for O
Functional O
Neuroimaging O
on O
a O
Siemens O
3 O
Tesla O
Trio O
whole-body O
scanner O
( O
Erlangen O
, O
Germany O
) O
. O

NUDs O
smoked O
‘ O
as O
usual O
’ O
on O
the O
day O
of O
the O
scanning O
session O
, O
and O
all O
NUDs O
smoked O
a O
cigarette O
to O
satiety O
approximately O
25 O
minutes O
prior O
to O
the O
scan O
session O
. O

Participants O
were O
placed O
on O
the O
scanner O
table O
, O
and O
the O
head O
was O
stabilized O
within O
the O
head O
coil O
using O
foam O
to O
minimize O
head O
motion O
. O

Scan O
sessions O
involved O
a O
10-second O
localizer O
scan O
to O
ensure O
good O
head O
placement O
and O
slice O
selection O
covering O
the O
whole O
brain O
, O
followed O
by O
a O
high-resolution O
T1-weighted O
three-dimensional O
( O
3D O
) O
magnetization O
prepared O
rapid O
acquisition O
gradient O
echo O
( O
MPRAGE O
) O
scan O
( O
field O
of O
view O
( O
FOV O
) O
=250mm O
, O
256×256×192 O
matrix O
, O
slice O
thickness=1 O
mm O
, O
repetition O
time O
( O
TR O
) O
=1620ms O
, O
echo O
time O
( O
TE O
) O
=3ms O
) O
. O

Resting-state O
BOLD O
fMRI O
data O
were O
acquired O
using O
a O
gradient O
echo O
echo-planar O
imaging O
sequence O
( O
FOV=220mm O
, O
64×64×64 O
matrix O
, O
slice O
thickness=4mm O
, O
TR=2s O
, O
TE=24ms O
, O
150 O
volumes O
with O
no O
inter-slice O
gap O
) O
. O

Participants O
were O
instructed O
to O
lie O
still O
in O
the O
scanner O
and O
keep O
their O
eyes O
open O
. O

An O
eye-camera O
outside O
of O
the O
scanner O
monitored O
participants O
’ O
eyes O
to O
ensure O
that O
they O
remained O
awake O
during O
the O
scan O
session O
. O

All O
participants O
remained O
awake O
throughout O
the O
scan O
session O
. O

Data O
Analysis O
Each O
participant O
’ O
s O
rsfMRI O
data O
were O
pre-processed O
using O
Statistical O
Parametric O
Mapping O
( O
SPM8 O
, O
Wellcome O
Department O
of O
Cognitive O
Neurology O
, O
London O
, O
UK O
) O
and O
AFNI O
( O
https O
: O
//afni.nimh.nih.gov/ O
) O
software O
packages O
. O

Specifically O
, O
the O
first O
6 O
volumes O
were O
discarded O
to O
allow O
magnetization O
equilibration O
. O

De-spiking O
was O
applied O
to O
the O
remaining O
volumes O
using O
3dDespike O
, O
followed O
by O
slice-time O
correction O
using O
3dTshift O
. O

For O
head O
motion O
correction O
, O
the O
rsfMRI O
volumes O
were O
realigned O
to O
the O
mean O
volume O
obtained O
by O
two-pass O
averaging O
using O
3dvolreg O
. O

Head O
motion O
of O
each O
participant O
’ O
s O
rsfMRI O
data O
was O
measured O
by O
root O
mean O
square O
of O
framewise O
displacement O
( O
RMSFD O
) O
. O

The O
rsfMRI O
data O
of O
each O
subject O
were O
intensity O
scaled O
to O
yield O
a O
whole O
brain O
mean O
value O
of O
1,000 O
. O

The O
rsfMRI O
signals O
of O
the O
white O
matter O
and O
cerebrospinal O
fluid O
, O
as O
well O
as O
6 O
rigid O
head O
motion O
parameters O
, O
were O
regressed O
out O
of O
the O
data O
using O
a O
general O
linear O
model O
. O

Temporal O
band-pass O
filtering O
( O
0.01 O
< O
f O
< O
0.08 O
Hz O
) O
was O
then O
performed O
to O
reduce O
the O
effects O
of O
low-frequency O
drift O
and O
high-frequency O
noise O
. O

Finally O
, O
SPM8 O
’ O
s O
DARTEL O
toolbox O
was O
used O
to O
spatially O
normalize O
individual O
subject O
images O
to O
a O
group O
template O
and O
then O
normalized O
to O
the O
Montreal O
Neurological O
Institute O
( O
MNI O
) O
space O
with O
an O
affine O
transformation O
, O
resampled O
to O
3 O
mm O
× O
3 O
mm O
× O
3 O
mm O
voxels O
, O
and O
smoothed O
with O
a O
Gaussian O
kernel O
with O
a O
full-width O
at O
half-maximum O
( O
FWHM O
) O
of O
6 O
mm O
. O

Statistical O
Analysis O
Independent-sample O
t-tests O
or O
chi-square O
tests O
( O
for O
dichotomous O
variables O
) O
compared O
differences O
between O
groups O
( O
Table O
1 O
) O
. O

Resting O
state O
network O
computation O
and O
identification O
Group O
information O
guided O
independent O
components O
analysis O
( O
GIG-ICA O
) O
was O
used O
to O
compute O
subject O
specific O
resting O
state O
networks O
, O
and O
resting O
state O
networks O
at O
a O
group O
level O
were O
used O
as O
references O
to O
achieve O
inter-individual O
comparability O
of O
the O
subject O
specific O
resting O
state O
networks O
. O

Specifically O
, O
FSL O
Melodic O
, O
with O
its O
default O
setting O
, O
was O
used O
to O
compute O
independent O
components O
( O
ICs O
) O
at O
a O
group O
level O
with O
the O
number O
of O
ICs O
automatically O
estimated O
using O
Akaike O
Information O
Criterion O
. O

The O
number O
of O
components O
was O
10 O
, O
and O
these O
group O
level O
ICs O
were O
then O
used O
as O
guidance O
information O
to O
compute O
subject O
specific O
ICs O
and O
their O
associated O
time O
courses O
using O
the O
GIG-ICA O
. O

The O
ICs O
are O
referred O
to O
as O
resting O
state O
functional O
networks O
( O
RSNs O
) O
hereafter O
. O

To O
identify O
RSNs O
altered O
by O
NUD O
, O
we O
adopted O
a O
Grassmann O
manifold O
learning O
method O
to O
build O
