classification O
models O
based O
on O
RSNs O
that O
were O
selected O
to O
optimize O
the O
classification O
performance O
for O
distinguishing O
NUD O
subjects O
from O
controls O
by O
the O
pattern O
classification O
algorithm O
. O

Rather O
than O
analyzing O
each O
RSN O
encoded O
by O
a O
spatial O
independent O
component O
separately O
, O
the O
10 O
RSNs O
from O
each O
individual O
were O
used O
as O
bases O
for O
a O
linear O
subspace O
. O

Similarity O
measures O
between O
subjects O
RSNs O
were O
computed O
on O
the O
Grassmann O
manifold O
by O
adopting O
a O
principal O
angle O
based O
Riemannian O
distance O
. O

These O
similarity O
measures O
were O
used O
in O
the O
support O
vector O
machine O
( O
SVM O
) O
classification O
. O

In O
conjunction O
with O
a O
support O
vector O
machine O
( O
SVM O
) O
classifier O
, O
a O
forward O
component O
selection O
technique O
was O
adopted O
to O
select O
RSNs O
for O
constructing O
the O
most O
discriminative O
set O
of O
RSNs O
. O

To O
select O
the O
most O
discriminative O
components O
, O
the O
forward O
component O
selection O
algorithm O
first O
built O
a O
classifier O
upon O
each O
individual O
RSN O
, O
the O
classifier O
’ O
s O
performance O
was O
then O
estimated O
with O
a O
ten-fold O
cross-validation O
so O
that O
each O
RSN O
could O
be O
evaluated O
for O
its O
classification O
performance O
, O
and O
finally O
the O
component O
with O
the O
best O
classification O
performance O
was O
selected O
to O
be O
included O
in O
the O
classification O
. O

By O
combining O
the O
first O
selected O
component O
and O
one O
of O
the O
other O
components O
, O
a O
classifier O
could O
be O
built O
upon O
2 O
components O
. O

All O
classifiers O
built O
upon O
2 O
components O
were O
then O
evaluated O
using O
the O
same O
cross-validation O
, O
and O
the O
components O
with O
the O
best O
classification O
performance O
were O
selected O
to O
be O
included O
in O
the O
classification O
. O

This O
procedure O
was O
repeated O
to O
include O
more O
components O
in O
the O
classification O
one O
by O
one O
until O
one O
single O
classifier O
was O
built O
upon O
all O
available O
components O
and O
a O
function O
of O
classification O
performance O
of O
different O
numbers O
of O
components O
was O
obtained O
. O

Finally O
, O
across O
all O
the O
best O
classifiers O
with O
different O
numbers O
of O
components O
, O
the O
combination O
of O
components O
with O
the O
overall O
best O
classification O
performance O
was O
identified O
to O
be O
included O
in O
the O
final O
classification O
. O

The O
component O
selection O
and O
the O
classifier O
construction O
were O
carried O
out O
based O
on O
only O
training O
data O
. O

Specifically O
, O
we O
used O
a O
10-fold O
cross-validation O
strategy O
to O
build O
classifiers O
and O
evaluate O
their O
performance O
. O

The O
cross-validation O
procedure O
carried O
out O
a O
total O
of O
10 O
training O
and O
testing O
runs O
. O

In O
each O
run O
, O
one O
tenth O
of O
the O
subjects O
were O
selected O
as O
the O
testing O
sample O
, O
and O
a O
classifier O
was O
built O
upon O
data O
of O
all O
remaining O
subjects O
and O
tested O
based O
on O
the O
left-out O
testing O
subject O
. O

The O
training O
and O
testing O
run O
was O
repeated O
until O
all O
subjects O
had O
been O
selected O
as O
testing O
samples O
. O

Finally O
, O
the O
overall O
classification O
performance O
was O
evaluated O
based O
on O
the O
10 O
training O
and O
testing O
runs O
. O

In O
each O
training O
and O
testing O
run O
, O
a O
classifier O
with O
the O
best O
discriminative O
performance O
given O
the O
training O
dataset O
was O
identified O
. O

That O
is O
, O
for O
RSNs O
of O
the O
training O
subjects O
, O
we O
used O
a O
nested O
10-fold O
cross-validation O
procedure O
to O
select O
the O
best O
set O
of O
RSNs O
and O
build O
a O
SVM O
classifier O
by O
tuning O
its O
parameters O
to O
achieve O
the O
best O
classification O
rate O
. O

Within O
each O
run O
of O
the O
cross-validation O
, O
another O
10-fold O
cross-validation O
was O
performed O
to O
select O
RSNs O
and O
optimize O
the O
classification O
parameters O
based O
on O
the O
training O
data O
. O

With O
this O
nested O
10-fold O
cross-validation O
strategy O
, O
we O
built O
classifiers O
and O
estimated O
the O
statistical O
significance O
of O
our O
classification O
results O
using O
10e5 O
permutation O
tests O
by O
building O
classifiers O
on O
data O
with O
randomly O
assigned O
class O
labels O
. O

In O
addition O
to O
classification O
accuracy O
, O
receiver O
operating O
characteristic O
curves O
( O
ROCs O
) O
and O
the O
area O
under O
an O
ROC O
curve O
( O
AUROC O
) O
were O
also O
computed O
based O
on O
the O
classification O
scores O
of O
testing O
subjects O
. O

An O
ROC O
curve O
provides O
visualization O
of O
sensitivity O
and O
specificity O
of O
a O
classifier O
at O
different O
classification O
thresholds O
; O
whereas O
, O
an O
AUROC O
provides O
a O
summary O
number O
of O
an O
ROC O
curve O
. O

A O
larger O
AUROC O
indicates O
a O
better O
classification O
performance O
. O

Due O
to O
inter-subject O
variability O
, O
the O
best O
set O
of O
RSNs O
for O
differentiating O
patients O
from O
HC O
subjects O
varied O
across O
training O
and O
testing O
runs O
. O

Therefore O
, O
we O
computed O
the O
frequency O
of O
RSNs O
selected O
into O
the O
best O
set O
of O
discriminative O
RSNs O
in O
all O
runs O
. O

The O
most O
frequently O
selected O
RSNs O
are O
the O
most O
different O
RSNs O
between O
NUDs O
and O
non-smoking O
controls O
. O

A O
flowchart O
of O
the O
nested O
10-fold O
cross-validation O
is O
shown O
in O
Figure O
1 O
. O

The O
nested O
10-fold O
cross-validation O
classification O
experiment O
was O
repeated O
10 O
times O
with O
random O
splits O
of O
training O
and O
testing O
subjects O
for O
obtaining O
a O
robust O
estimation O
of O
the O
classification O
performance O
. O

Visualization O
of O
the O
heterogeneity O
of O
NUD O
in O
individual O
smokers O
A O
Grassmann O
manifold O
distance O
metric O
measured O
similarity O
between O
participants O
based O
on O
their O
RSNs O
that O
are O
most O
different O
between O
NUDs O
and O
non-smoking O
controls O
. O

Specifically O
, O
distance O
to O
each O
control O
was O
calculated O
and O
then O
averaged O
for O
a O
smoker O
or O
a O
control O
subject O
. O

The O
distance O
between O
the O
same O
subjects O
was O
zero O
, O
indicating O
that O
our O
manifold O
distance O
metric O
satisfies O
“ O
identity O
of O
indiscernibles O
” O
. O

Multidimensional O
scaling O
( O
MDS O
) O
was O
adopted O
to O
visualize O
the O
level O
of O
similarity O
of O
individual O
subjects O
in O
2D O
space O
( O
mdscale O
, O
MATLAB O
2014a O
) O
. O

Based O
on O
the O
similarity O
measure O
, O
, O
between O
two O
participants O
computed O
using O
the O
Grassmann O
manifold O
distance O
metric O
, O
functional O
distance O
between O
them O
was O
simple O
calculated O
as O
. O

The O
average O
functional O
distance O
between O
controls O
and O
each O
individual O
participant O
measured O
the O
difference O
between O
individuals O
with O
NUD O
and O
controls O
. O

Voxelwise O
FC O
measures O
of O
individual O
RSNs O
Each O
voxelwise O
FC O
measure O
of O
one O
RSN O
was O
computed O
as O
Pearson O
correlation O
coefficients O
between O
the O
time O
course O
of O
the O
voxel O
under O
consideration O
and O
the O
time O
course O
of O
the O
RSN O
and O
transferred O
to O
z-scores O
for O
every O
participant O
. O

Then O
, O
the O
FC O
measures O
were O
compared O
between O
individuals O
with O
NUD O
and O
non-smoking O
controls O
. O

The O
statistical O
threshold O
was O
two O
sample O
t-tests O
, O
p=0.05 O
, O
FDR O
( O
false O
discovery O
rate O
) O
corrected O
. O

Resting-state O
network O
connectivity O
and O
metastability O
predict O
clinical O
symptoms O
in O
schizophrenia O
Background O
: O
The O
functional O
architecture O
of O
resting-state O
networks O
( O
RSNs O
) O
is O
defined O
by O
their O
connectivity O
and O
metastability O
. O

Disrupted O
RSN O
connectivity O
has O
been O
amply O
demonstrated O
in O
schizophrenia O
while O
the O
role O
of O
metastability O
remains O
poorly O
defined O
. O

Here O
, O
we O
undertake O
a O
comprehensive O
characterisation O
of O
RSN O
organization O
in O
schizophrenia O
and O
test O
its O
contribution O
to O
the O
clinical O
profile O
of O
this O
disorder O
. O

Methods O
: O
We O
extracted O
RSNs O
representing O
the O
default O
mode O
( O
DMN O
) O
, O
central O
executive O
( O
CEN O
) O
, O
salience O
( O
SAL O
) O
, O
language O
( O
LAN O
) O
, O
sensorimotor O
( O
SMN O
) O
, O
auditory O
( O
AN O
) O
and O
visual O
( O
VN O
) O
networks O
from O
resting-state O
functional O
magnetic O
resonance O
imaging O
data O
obtained O
from O
patients O
with O
schizophrenia O
( O
n O
= O
85 O
) O
and O
healthy O
individuals O
( O
n O
= O
48 O
) O
. O

For O
each O
network O
, O
we O
computed O
its O
functional O
cohesiveness O
and O
integration O
and O
used O
the O
Kuramoto O
order O
parameter O
to O
compute O
metastability O
. O

We O
used O
stepwise O
multiple O
regression O
analyses O
to O
test O
these O
RSN O
features O
as O
predictors O
of O
symptom O
severity O
in O
patients O
. O

Results O
: O
RSN O
features O
respectively O
explained O
14 O
% O
, O
17 O
% O
, O
12 O
% O
and O
5 O
% O
of O
the O
variance O
in O
positive O
, O
negative O
, O
anxious/ O
depressive O
and O
agitation/disorganization O
symptoms O
. O

Lower O
functional O
integration O
between O
the O
DMN O
, O
CEN O
and O
SMN O
primarily O
contributed O
to O
positive O
symptoms O
. O

The O
functional O
properties O
of O
the O
SAL O
network O
were O
key O
predictors O
of O
all O
other O
symptom O
dimensions O
; O
specifically O
, O
lower O
cohesiveness O
of O
the O
SAL O
, O
lower O
integration O
of O
this O
network O
with O
the O
LAN O
and O
higher O
integration O
with O
the O
CEN O
respectively O
contributed O
to O
negative O
, O
anxious/depressive O
and O
disorganization O
symptoms O
. O

Increased O
SAL O
metastability O
was O
associated O
with O
negative O
symptoms O
. O

Conclusions O
: O
These O
results O
confirm O
the O
primacy O
of O
the O
SAL O
network O
for O
schizophrenia O
and O
demonstrate O
that O
abnormalities O
in O
RSN O
connectivity O
and O
metastability O
are O
significant O
predictors O
of O
schizophrenia-related O
psychopathology O
. O

Materials O
and O
methods O
Participants O
The O
study O
sample O
comprised O
93 O
patients O
with O
recent O
onset O
schizophrenia O
( O
illness O
duration O
< O
5 O
years O
) O
and O
50 O
healthy O
individuals O
( O
Table O
1 O
) O
. O

Patients O
fulfilled O
criteria O
for O
schizophrenia O
as O
defined O
by O
the O
fifth O
edition O
of O
the O
Diagnostic O
and O
Statistical O
Manual O
of O
Mental O
Disorders O
( O
DSM-5 O
) O
and O
were O
recruited O
via O
clinician O
referrals O
from O
the O
psychiatric O
services O
of O
the O
Mount O
Sinai O
Health O
System O
, O
New O
York O
. O

Healthy O
individuals O
were O
recruited O
via O
advertisements O
in O
the O
local O
press O
. O

All O
participants O
were O
screened O
to O
exclude O
those O
with O
IQ O
< O
70 O
, O
medical O
or O
neurological O
disorders O
, O
history O
of O
significant O
head O
trauma O
, O
and O
lifetime O
history O
of O
DSM-5 O
substance O
use O
disorder O
. O

The O
diagnostic O
status O
of O
all O
participants O
was O
determined O
using O
the O
research O
version O
of O
the O
Structured O
Clinical O
interview O
for O
DSM-5 O
supplemented O
by O
information O
from O
medical O
records O
in O
the O
case O
of O
patients O
. O

The O
presence O
and O
severity O
of O
psychopathology O
were O
assessed O
in O
all O
participants O
using O
the O
expanded O
24-item O
Brief O
Psychotic O
Rating O
Scale O
( O
BPRS O
) O
which O
allows O
decomposition O
of O
the O
clinical O
profile O
of O
psychosis O
into O
four O
dimensions O
comprising O
positive O
symptoms O
, O
negative O
symptoms O
, O
anxiety/depression O
and O
agitation/disorganization O
. O

An O
estimate O
of O
IQ O
was O
obtained O
from O
all O
participants O
using O
the O
Wechsler O
Abbreviated O
Scale O
of O
Intelligence O
, O
2nd O
Edition O
( O
WASI-II O
) O
. O

Medication O
type O
and O
dose O
was O
recorded O
in O
all O
patients O
and O
the O
daily O
antipsychotic O
dose O
was O
converted O
to O
chlorpromazine O
equivalents O
( O
CPZE O
) O
. O

The O
study O
was O
approved O
by O
the O
Institutional O
Review O
Board O
of O
the O
Icahn O
School O
of O
Medicine O
at O
Mount O
Sinai O
( O
ISMMS O
) O
. O

All O
participants O
provided O
written O
informed O
consent O
. O

Neuroimaging O
data O
acquisition O
and O
quality O
assurance O
Anatomical O
and O
resting-state O
fMRI O
( O
eyes O
open O
) O
data O
were O
acquired O
on O
a O
Siemens O
Skyra O
3 O
T O
scanner O
( O
Erlangen O
, O
Germany O
) O
at O
the O
ISMMS O
( O
details O
in O
Supplementary O
Material O
) O
. O

Data O
from O
the O
participants O
were O
preprocessed O
using O
established O
procedures O
implemented O
in O
Statistical O
Parametric O
Mapping O
software O
( O
SPM12 O
; O
http O
: O
//www.fil.ion.ucl.ac.uk/spm/software/spm12 O
) O
and O
the O
Data O
Processing O
Assistant O
for O
Resting-State O
fMRI O
software O
( O
DPARSF O
) O
available O
in O
the O
Data O
Processing O
and O
Analysis O
for O
Brain O
Imaging O
( O
DPABI O
) O
Toolbox O
( O
details O
in O
Supplementary O
Material O
) O
. O

Two O
healthy O
individuals O
and O
8 O
patients O
with O
schizophrenia O
were O
excluded O
because O
of O
excessive O
head O
motion O
( O
linear O
shift O
> O
3 O
mm O
or O
rotation O
> O
1° O
across O
the O
run O
and O
on O
a O
frame-to-frame O
basis O
) O
. O

After O
removal O
of O
these O
datasets O
, O
comparison O
between O
groups O
( O
patients O
, O
healthy O
volunteers O
) O
on O
multiple O
head O
motion O
parameters O
( O
i.e. O
, O
mean O
and O
maximum O
scan-to-scan O
head O
motion O
and O
framewise O
displacement O
) O
did O
not O
yield O
significant O
difference O
( O
all O
p O
> O
0.05 O
; O
details O
in O
Supplementary O
Material O
) O
. O

Computation O
of O
RSN O
functional O
connectivity O
In O
each O
individual O
resting-state O
fMRI O
dataset O
, O
we O
defined O
seven O
major O
RSNs O
comprising O
the O
default O
mode O
network O
( O
DMN O
) O
, O
the O
central O
executive O
network O
( O
CEN O
) O
, O
the O
salience O
network O
( O
SAL O
) O
, O
the O
sensorimotor O
network O
( O
SMN O
) O
, O
the O
visual O
network O
( O
VN O
) O
, O
the O
auditory O
network O
( O
AN O
) O
, O
and O
the O
language O
network O
( O
LAN O
) O
. O

These O
RSNs O
were O
defined O
using O
validated O
network O
masks O
that O
are O
publicly O
available O
through O
the O
Functional O
Imaging O
of O
Neuropsychiatric O
Disorders O
( O
FIND O
) O
Lab O
, O
Stanford O
University O
( O
http O
: O
//findlab.stanford.edu/functional_ROIs.html O
) O
. O

Each O
of O
the O
7 O
RSN O
masks O
comprises O
its O
corresponding O
functional O
regions-of-interest O
( O
ROIs O
) O
( O
Fig O
. O

1A O
; O
Supplemental O
Table O
S1 O
) O
. O

We O
chose O
functionally O
defined O
RSN O
masks O
because O
they O
offer O
great O
cogency O
and O
reproducibility O
. O

We O
have O
previously O
demonstrated O
the O
reproducibility O
of O
the O
FIND O
Lab O
masks O
using O
data O
from O
the O
Human O
Connectome O
Project O
( O
detailed O
in O
Supplemental O
Material O
and O
in O
) O
. O

The O
median O
overlap O
between O
functionally O
defined O
RSN O
masks O
and O
data-driven O
RSNs O
was O
91 O
% O
. O

We O
assessed O
the O
cohesiveness O
and O
integration O
of O
each O
RSN O
by O
computing O
their O
within-and O
between-network O
functional O
connectivity O
. O

Within-network O
functional O
connectivity O
was O
estimated O
by O
averaging O
the O
fMRI O
time O
series O
over O
all O
the O
voxels O
within O
each O
network O
region O
and O
then O
calculating O
all O
possible O
pairwise O
Pearson O
’ O
s O
correlation O
between O
the O
network O
regions O
. O

Between-network O
functional O
connectivity O
was O
estimated O
by O
computing O
pairwise O
Pearson O
’ O
s O
correlation O
between O
the O
networks O
’ O
average O
time O
series O
. O

All O
correlation O
coefficients O
were O
transformed O
into O
Fisher O
’ O
s O
z-score O
prior O
to O
further O
analyses O
. O

These O
computations O
resulted O
in O
28 O
connectivity O
measures O
per O
subject O
which O
were O
used O
in O
further O
analyses O
. O

No O
correlation O
was O
found O
between O
any O
of O
these O
measures O
and O
framewise O
displacement O
( O
FD O
) O
even O
at O
p O
< O
0.05 O
, O
uncorrected O
( O
detailed O
in O
Supplementary O
Material O
) O
. O

Computation O
of O
network O
synchrony O
and O
metastability O
The O
voxel-wise O
BOLD O
data O
for O
each O
RSN O
were O
filtered O
to O
extract O
frequency-band O
fMRI O
signals O
using O
the O
maximal O
overlap O
discrete O
wavelet O
transform O
( O
MODWT O
) O
. O

Because O
the O
repetition O
time O
of O
the O
fMRI O
data O
acquisition O
was O
1 O
s O
, O
the O
frequency O
bands O
extracted O
were O
: O
scale O
1 O
= O
0.25–0.5 O
Hz O
; O
scale O
2 O
= O
0.13–0.25 O
Hz O
; O
scale O
3 O
= O
0.06–0.13 O
Hz O
; O
scale O
4 O
= O
0.03–0.06 O
Hz O
; O
scale O
5 O
= O
0.015–0.03 O
Hz O
. O

We O
used O
a O
wavelet O
filter O
of O
Daubechies O
Least O
Asymmetric O
with O
a O
wavelet O
length O
of O
8 O
. O

We O
focused O
on O
scale O
4 O
wavelet O
coefficients O
, O
because O
the O
most O
relevant O
information O
for O
resting-state O
fMRI O
data O
is O
mainly O
contained O
within O
this O
scale O
. O

We O
then O
extracted O
the O
phases O
of O
the O
fMRI O
time O
series O
for O
each O
RSN O
in O
each O
participant O
by O
applying O
the O
Hilbert O
transform O
to O
the O
wavelet-filtered O
fMRI O
BOLD O
signals O
to O
obtain O
the O
associated O
analytical O
signals O
. O

The O
analytic O
signal O
represents O
a O
narrowband O
signal O
, O
s O
( O
t O
) O
, O
in O
the O
time O
domain O
as O
a O
rotating O
vector O
with O
an O
instantaneous O
phase O
, O
φ O
( O
t O
) O
, O
and O
an O
instantaneous O
amplitude O
, O
A O
( O
t O
) O
, O
i.e. O
, O
s O
( O
t O
) O
= O
A O
( O
t O
) O
cos O
( O
φ O
( O
t O
) O
) O
. O

The O
phase O
and O
the O
amplitude O
are O
given O
by O
the O
argument O
and O
the O
modulus O
, O
respectively O
, O
of O
the O
complex O
signal O
z O
( O
t O
) O
, O
given O
by O
z O
( O
t O
) O
= O
s O
( O
t O
) O
+ O
iH O
[ O
s O
( O
t O
) O
] O
, O
where O
i O
is O
the O
imaginary O
unit O
and O
H O
[ O
s O
( O
t O
) O
] O
is O
the O
Hilbert O
transform O
of O
s O
( O
t O
) O
. O

Subsequently O
, O
the O
first O
and O
last O
10 O
time O
steps O
were O
discarded O
to O
avoid O
border O
effect O
inherent O
to O
the O
Hilbert O
transform O
. O

To O
evaluate O
the O
dynamic O
properties O
of O
each O
RSN O
, O
we O
computed O
the O
Kuramoto O
order O
parameter O
R O
( O
t O
) O
, O
defined O
as O
where O
N O
is O
the O
total O
number O
of O
voxels O
within O
each O
RSN O
and O
φn O
( O
t O
) O
is O
the O
instantaneous O
phase O
of O
each O
fMRI O
BOLD O
signal O
at O
voxel O
n O
of O
each O
RSN O
. O

This O
parameter O
measures O
the O
level O
of O
synchronization O
between O
brain O
regions O
across O
time O
( O
Fig O
. O

1B O
) O
. O

For O
each O
network O
, O
synchrony O
( O
mean O
synchronization O
) O
and O
metastability O
( O
the O
variation O
in O
synchronization O
over O
time O
) O
were O
defined O
as O
the O
mean O
and O
the O
standard O
deviation O
of O
the O
Kuramoto O
order O
parameter O
over O
time O
, O
respectively O
. O

These O
computations O
resulted O
in O
14 O
measures O
per O
subject O
that O
were O
used O
in O
further O
analyses O
. O

Statistical O
analysis O
Group O
differences O
in O
demographic O
characteristics O
and O
IQ O
were O
examined O
using O
t- O
and O
χ2 O
tests O
as O
appropriate O
. O

We O
detected O
an O
effect O
of O
group O
for O
sex O
and O
IQ O
and O
we O
therefore O
conducted O
collinearity O
diagnostics O
using O
regression O
models O
. O

These O
variables O
were O
not O
collinear O
as O
their O
variance O
inflation O
factor O
( O
VIF O
) O
ranged O
between O
1 O
and O
1.4 O
which O
is O
below O
the O
traditional O
threshold O
of O
2 O
for O
collinearity O
. O

We O
performed O
three O
multivariate O
analyses O
of O
covariance O
( O
MANOVAs O
) O
to O
examine O
the O
effect O
of O
diagnosis O
separately O
on O
measures O
of O
network O
dynamics O
( O
synchrony O
and O
metastability O
) O
, O
measures O
of O
within-network O
functional O
connectivity O
and O
measures O
of O
between-network O
functional O
connectivity O
. O

Sex O
and O
IQ O
were O
entered O
as O
covariates O
in O
all O
analyses O
. O

For O
each O
MANOVA O
, O
when O
the O
overall O
model O
was O
significant O
at O
p O
< O
0.05 O
, O
we O
conducted O
post-hoc O
pairwise O
comparisons O
for O
which O
the O
threshold O
of O
statistical O
significance O
was O
adjusted O
using O
Bonferroni O
correction O
based O
on O
the O
number O
of O
variables O
included O
in O
each O
model O
. O

In O
addition O
, O
the O
effect O
size O
of O
case-control O
differences O
in O
neuroimaging O
measures O
was O
calculated O
using O
the O
Cohen O
’ O
s O
d. O
The O
predictive O
value O
of O
the O
neuroimaging O
variables O
for O
clinical O
symptoms O
was O
only O
tested O
in O
the O
patient O
group O
. O

The O
four O
BPRS O
symptom O
scores O
were O
not O
collinear O
( O
|r| O
< O
0.4 O
) O
and O
were O
used O
as O
dependent O
factors O
in O
separate O
stepwise O
regression O
analyses O
. O

This O
approach O
operates O
by O
successively O
adding O
and O
removing O
predictor O
variables O
based O
on O
their O
squared O
t-statistic O
to O
select O
the O
best O
grouping O
of O
predictor O
variables O
that O
accounts O
for O
most O
of O
the O
variance O
( O
R2 O
) O
in O
the O
outcome O
. O

The O
assumptions O
, O
advantages O
and O
limitations O
of O
this O
approach O
are O
well O
understood O
( O
e.g O
. O
) O
. O

Stepwise O
regression O
models O
allow O
a O
principled O
and O
data-driven O
selection O
of O
predictor O
variables O
, O
that O
is O
largely O
independent O
of O
sample O
size O
, O
and O
are O
best O
suited O
for O
testing O
prespecified O
hypotheses O
about O
the O
predictor O
and O
outcome O
variables O
. O

This O
is O
the O
case O
here O
as O
our O
aim O
was O
to O
test O
the O
predictive O
value O
of O
predefined O
connectivity O
features O
for O
symptom O
severity O
in O
schizophrenia O
. O

Stepwise O
regression O
analyses O
are O
prone O
to O
R2 O
values O
inflation O
and O
are O
sensitive O
to O
the O
presence O
of O
collinearity O
amongst O
the O
predictor O
variables O
. O

To O
address O
these O
concerns O
, O
we O
undertook O
the O
following O
three O
steps O
: O
( O
a O
) O
Curve O
estimation O
and O
collinearity O
assessments O
were O
conducted O
to O
select O
the O
neuroimaging O
variables O
entered O
as O
independent O
predictors O
. O

Variables O
were O
considered O
co-linear O
if O
their O
pairwise O
correlation O
was O
|r| O
> O
0.4 O
. O

The O
synchrony O
and O
metastability O
of O
each O
network O
were O
the O
only O
highly O
correlated O
( O
r O
values O
ranged O
between O
0.63 O
and O
0.72 O
) O
neuroimaging O
variables O
and O
therefore O
only O
metastability O
was O
entered O
in O
the O
regression O
analyses O
. O

( O
b O
) O
We O
confirmed O
that O
none O
of O
the O
regression O
results O
showed O
collinearity O
based O
on O
VIF O
< O
2 O
and O
tolerance O
> O
0.2 O
. O

( O
c O
) O
We O
examined O
the O
reliability O
of O
the O
R2 O
values O
of O
the O
regression O
models O
using O
a O
leave-one-out O
method O
that O
enables O
testing O
the O
reliability O
of O
these O
values O
while O
preserving O
statistical O
power O
. O

Reading O
the O
( O
functional O
) O
writing O
on O
the O
( O
structural O
) O
wall O
: O
multimodal O
fusion O
of O
brain O
structural O
and O
function O
via O
a O
deep O
neural O
network O
based O
translation O
approach O
reveals O
novel O
impairments O
in O
schizophrenia O
This O
work O
presents O
a O
novel O
approach O
using O
a O
deep O
neural O
network O
for O
finding O
linkage/association O
between O
multimodal O
brain O
imaging O
data O
, O
such O
as O
structural O
MRI O
( O
sMRI O
) O
and O
functional O
MRI O
( O
fMRI O
) O
. O

Motivated O
by O
the O
machine O
translation O
domain O
, O
we O
consider O
two O
different O
imaging O
views O
of O
the O
same O
brain O
like O
two O
different O
languages O
conveying O
some O
common O
facts O
that O
enables O
finding O
linkages O
between O
two O
modalities O
. O

The O
proposed O
translation O
based O
fusion O
model O
contains O
a O
computing O
layer O
that O
learns O
“ O
alignments O
” O
( O
or O
links O
) O
between O
dynamic O
connectivity O
features O
from O
fMRI O
data O
and O
static O
gray O
matter O
patterns O
from O
sMRI O
data O
. O

The O
approach O
is O
evaluated O
on O
a O
multi-site O
dataset O
consisting O
of O
eye-closed O
resting O
state O
imaging O
data O
collected O
from O
298 O
subjects O
( O
age- O
and O
gender O
matched O
154 O
healthy O
controls O
and O
144 O
patients O
with O
schizophrenia O
) O
. O

We O
used O
dynamic O
functional O
connectivity O
( O
dFNC O
) O
states O
as O
the O
functional O
features O
and O
ICA-based O
sources O
from O
gray O
matter O
densities O
as O
the O
structural O
features O
. O

The O
dFNC O
states O
characterized O
by O
weakly O
correlated O
intrinsic O
connectivity O
networks O
( O
ICNs O
) O
were O
found O
to O
have O
stronger O
association O
with O
putamen O
and O
insular O
gray O
matter O
pattern O
, O
while O
the O
dFNC O
states O
of O
profuse O
strongly O
correlated O
ICNs O
exhibited O
stronger O
links O
with O
the O
gray O
matter O
pattern O
in O
precuneus O
, O
posterior O
cingulate O
cortex O
( O
PCC O
) O
, O
and O
temporal O
cortex O
. O

Further O
investigation O
with O
the O
estimated O
link O
strength O
( O
or O
alignment O
score O
) O
showed O
significant O
group O
differences O
between O
healthy O
controls O
and O
patients O
with O
schizophrenia O
in O
several O
key O
regions O
including O
temporal O
lobe O
, O
and O
linked O
these O
to O
connectivity O
states O
showing O
less O
occupancy O
in O
healthy O
controls O
. O

Moreover O
, O
this O
novel O
approach O
revealed O
significant O
correlation O
between O
a O
cognitive O
score O
( O
attention/vigilance O
) O
and O
the O
function/structure O
alignment O
score O
that O
was O
not O
detected O
when O
data O
modalities O
were O
considered O
separately O
. O

Materials O
and O
Methods O
We O
first O
briefly O
describe O
about O
data O
collection O
and O
preprocessing O
, O
and O
then O
the O
translation-based O
fusion O
model O
is O
explained O
in O
this O
section O
. O

Participants O
In O
this O
work O
, O
we O
perform O
analysis O
on O
two O
modalities O
of O
data O
, O
T1-weighted O
structural O
images O
and O
T2 O
* O
-weighted O
functional O
images O
. O

The O
resting O
state O
fMRI O
data O
were O
collected O
from O
154 O
healthy O
controls O
( O
110 O
males O
, O
44 O
females O
; O
mean O
age O
37 O
) O
and O
144 O
schizophrenic O
patients O
( O
110 O
males O
, O
34 O
females O
; O
mean O
age O
38 O
) O
during O
eye O
closed O
condition O
at O
seven O
different O
scanning O
sites O
. O

A O
total O
of O
162 O
volumes O
of O
echo O
planar O
imaging O
BOLD O
fMRI O
data O
were O
collected O
with O
a O
TR O
of O
2 O
s O
on O
3T O
scanners O
. O

For O
the O
same O
subjects O
, O
T1-weighted O
structural O
images O
were O
collected O
as O
well O
. O

Full O
details O
on O
the O
participants O
and O
data O
collection O
can O
be O
found O
in O
and O
a O
summary O
of O
demographics O
are O
provided O
in O
. O

Data O
collection O
MR O
images O
were O
collected O
on O
a O
3-Tesla O
Siemens O
Trio O
scanner O
at O
six O
sites O
and O
on O
a O
3T O
General O
Electric O
Discovery O
MR750 O
scanner O
at O
one O
site O
. O

High-resolution O
T1-weighted O
structural O
images O
were O
acquired O
with O
a O
turbo-flash O
sequence O
( O
TE O
= O
2.94 O
ms O
, O
TR O
= O
2.3 O
s O
, O
flip O
angle O
= O
9° O
, O
number O
of O
excitations O
= O
1 O
, O
slice O
thickness O
= O
1.2 O
mm O
, O
field O
of O
view O
= O
256 O
mm O
, O
resolution O
= O
256 O
× O
256 O
) O
resulting O
in O
0.86 O
× O
0.86 O
× O
1.2 O
mm3 O
voxels O
. O

T2 O
* O
-weighted O
functional O
images O
were O
acquired O
using O
a O
gradient-echo O
EPI O
sequence O
( O
TR/TE O
2s/30ms O
, O
flip O
angle O
77 O
degrees O
, O
32 O
slices O
collected O
sequentially O
from O
superior O
to O
inferior O
, O
3.4 O
× O
3.4 O
× O
4 O
mm3 O
with O
1 O
mm O
gap O
, O
162 O
frames O
, O
5:38 O
min O
) O
. O

Participants O
were O
instructed O
to O
keep O
their O
eyes O
closed O
during O
the O
scan O
. O

Data O
preprocessing O
Structural O
data O
: O
T1-weighted O
images O
were O
normalized O
to O
MNI O
space O
, O
resliced O
to O
2 O
× O
2 O
× O
2 O
mm O
, O
and O
segmented O
into O
gray O
, O
white O
, O
and O
CSF O
images O
using O
the O
unified O
segmentation O
methods O
of O
SPM5 O
. O

Data O
quality O
was O
checked O
by O
correlations O
against O
the O
segmented O
templates O
; O
if O
the O
subject O
’ O
s O
segmented O
gray O
matter O
data O
did O
not O
correlate O
at O
0.9 O
or O
higher O
with O
the O
template O
across O
all O
voxels O
, O
it O
was O
removed O
from O
consideration O
. O

Gray O
matter O
segmentations O
were O
finally O
smoothed O
by O
a O
Gaussian O
filter O
of O
10 O
mm O
Full O
Width O
Half O
Maximum O
( O
FWHM O
) O
. O

We O
analyzed O
gray O
matter O
density O
( O
GMD O
) O
with O
independent O
component O
analysis O
( O
ICA O
) O
to O
extract O
features O
as O
relationships O
among O
GMD O
regions O
, O
which O
is O
called O
source-based O
morphometry O
( O
SBM O
) O
. O

The O
ICA O
was O
performed O
using O
the O
group O
ICA O
of O
fMRI O
( O
GIFT O
) O
toolbox1 O
and O
50 O
components O
were O
estimated O
. O

After O
analyzing O
stability O
of O
the O
components O
and O
visual O
inspection O
, O
23 O
components O
were O
selected O
, O
and O
hereafter O
they O
are O
referred O
to O
as O
structural O
components O
. O

Functional O
data O
: O
We O
used O
resting O
state O
fMRI O
data O
and O
performed O
rigid O
body O
motion O
correction O
using O
the O
INRIAlign O
toolbox O
in O
SPM O
to O
correct O
for O
subject O
head O
motion O
followed O
by O
slice-timing O
correction O
to O
account O
for O
timing O
differences O
in O
slice O
acquisition O
. O

Then O
the O
fMRI O
data O
were O
despiked O
using O
AFNI O
’ O
s O
3dDespike O
algorithm O
to O
mitigate O
the O
impact O
of O
outliers O
. O

The O
fMRI O
data O
were O
subsequently O
warped O
to O
a O
Montreal O
Neurological O
Institute O
( O
MNI O
) O
template O
and O
resampled O
to O
3 O
mm3 O
isotropic O
voxels O
. O

Instead O
of O
Gaussian O
smoothing O
, O
we O
smoothed O
the O
data O
to O
6 O
mm O
full O
width O
at O
half O
maximum O
( O
FWHM O
) O
using O
AFNI O
’ O
s O
BlurToFWHM O
algorithm O
which O
performs O
smoothing O
by O
a O
conservative O
finite O
difference O
approximation O
to O
the O
diffusion O
equation O
. O

This O
approach O
has O
been O
shown O
to O
reduce O
scanner O
specific O
variability O
in O
smoothness O
providing O
“ O
smoothness O
equivalence O
” O
to O
data O
across O
sites O
. O

Each O
voxel O
time O
course O
was O
variance O
normalized O
prior O
to O
performing O
group O
independent O
component O
analysis O
. O

These O
processed O
data O
were O
then O
decomposed O
into O
components O
using O
spatial O
group O
independent O
component O
analysis O
( O
GICA O
) O
implemented O
in O
the O
GIFT O
toolbox O
. O

Each O
component O
can O
be O
regarded O
as O
temporally O
coherent O
intrinsic O
connectivity O
networks O
( O
ICN O
) O
, O
and O
47 O
such O
networks O
were O
selected O
as O
in O
. O

For O
feature O
representation O
, O
pairwise O
correlation O
between O
ICN O
time O
courses O
were O
computed O
yielding O
a O
correlation O
matrix O
of O
size O
47 O
× O
47 O
. O

In O
order O
to O
capture O
dynamics O
, O
correlation O
was O
estimated O
using O
a O
sliding O
window O
approach O
with O
a O
window O
size O
of O
22 O
TR O
( O
44 O
s O
) O
in O
steps O
of O
1 O
TR O
( O
2 O
s O
) O
[ O
see O
for O
details O
] O
. O

We O
refer O
to O
this O
windowed O
correlation O
matrix O
as O
dynamic O
functional O
network O
connectivity O
( O
dFNC O
) O
. O

However O
, O
in O
order O
to O
reduce O
the O
total O
time O
steps O
for O
our O
translation O
model O
, O
we O
took O
average O
of O
every O
4 O
consecutive O
correlation O
matrices O
. O

Finally O
, O
a O
discrete O
sequence O
of O
dFNC O
states O
were O
obtained O
using O
k-means O
clustering O
algorithm O
on O
the O
dFNC O
matrices O
, O
with O
a O
setting O
of O
k O
= O
5 O
using O
the O
elbow O
criterion O
. O

Translation-based O
multimodal O
fusion O
model O
Machine O
translation O
models O
that O
produce O
sentences O
in O
one O
language O
from O
another O
are O
common O
in O
the O
natural O
language O
processing O
discipline O
. O

Essentially O
, O
different O
languages O
convey O
common O
concept O
or O
fact O
in O
different O
ways O
with O
their O
own O
constructs O
. O

We O
can O
consider O
sMRI O
and O
fMRI O
as O
two O
different O
views O
of O
the O
same O
brain O
, O
and O
take O
an O
approach O
from O
the O
machine O
translation O
discipline O
to O
deal O
with O
multimodal O
neuroimaging O
data O
. O

A O
recently O
proposed O
neural O
machine O
translation O
model O
has O
shown O
state-of-the-art O
performance O
with O
its O
novel O
attention O
mechanism O
. O

The O
main O
feature O
of O
the O
attention O
module O
is O
to O
learn O
alignment O
between O
phrases O
of O
two O
different O
languages O
for O
improving O
translation O
performance O
. O

We O
exploit O
this O
idea O
of O
attention O
mechanism O
to O
learn O
alignment O
( O
linkage O
) O
between O
dFNC O
states O
and O
brain O
structural O
components O
. O

However O
, O
unlike O
the O
sequence O
to O
sequence O
matching O
in O
the O
language O
translation O
, O
input O
in O
our O
case O
is O
an O
unordered O
set O
of O
sMRI O
component O
loadings O
and O
output O
are O
temporally O
ordered O
dFNC O
states O
. O

To O
tackle O
this O
problem O
, O
we O
propose O
a O
simple O
modification O
in O
the O
attention O
network O
in O
our O
translation O
model O
. O

Figure O
1 O
depicts O
the O
different O
parts O
of O
our O
translation O
model O
in O
the O
context O
of O

. O

The O
model O
stacks O
several O
neural-network O
layers O
( O
six O
layers O
in O
total O
) O
which O
we O
describe O
below O
. O

As O
shown O
in O
Fig O
. O

1 O
, O
two O
main O
parts O
of O
our O
translation-based O
fusion O
model O
are O
: O
( O
1 O
) O
sequence O
predictor O
and O
( O
2 O
) O
attention O
network O
. O

The O
input-output O
setting O
of O
the O
model O
is O
as O
follows O
. O

Input O
is O
an O
unordered O
set O
of O
structural O
component O
loadings O
of O
a O
subject O
, O
x O
= O
{ O
x1 O
, O
… O
, O
xj O
, O
… O
xJ O
} O
, O
and O

is O
a O
temporally O
ordered O
dFNC O
state O
sequence O
, O
y O
= O
{ O
y1 O
, O
… O
, O
yi O
, O
…yT O
} O
, O
of O
the O
same O
subject O
estimated O
from O
the O

step O
described O
in O
Section O
2.3 O
. O

The O
central O
theme O
of O

model O
is O
that O
information O
for O

a O
sequence O
y O
from O

spread O
through O
out O

, O

. O

This O

from O

. O

Further O

Sequence O
predictor O
The O
sequence O
predictor O
is O
a O
probabilistic O
model O
that O
predicts O
one O
dFNC O
state O
of O
a O
sequence O
at O
each O
time O
step O
, O
where O
we O
define O
each O
conditional O
probability O
as O
where O
si O
is O
the O
current O
hidden O
state O
of O
a O
unidirectional O
recurrent O
layer O
and O
ci O
( O
more O
details O
will O
be O
provided O
shortly O
) O
is O
the O
current O
selective O
focus O
over O
structural O
components O
, O
referred O
to O
as O
context O
hereafter O
. O

A O
few O
points O
about O
the O
probability O
model O
of O
Eq O
. O

( O
1 O
) O
are O
noteworthy O
. O

First O
, O
it O
embodies O
a O
fusion O
implicitly O
as O

is O
conditioned O
on O
previous O
output O
history O
( O
from O
one O
modality O
) O
and O
the O
input O
( O
from O
the O
other O

) O
. O

Second O
, O
the O

index O
i O
indicates O
dynamic O
property O
of O
one O
of O
data O
modalities O
. O

Finally O
, O
right O
hand O
side O
of O
Eq O
. O

( O
1 O
) O
captures O
the O
aspect O
of O
deep O
learning O
, O
i.e. O
, O

works O
with O

of O

, O

from O

. O

We O
realize O
Eq O
. O

( O
1 O
) O
by O
a O
feedforward O

network O
( O
NN O
) O
[ O
a O

with O

output O
] O
stacking O
it O
on O

layer O
. O

At O
each O

point O
, O
the O
recurrent O
layer O
computes O
the O
current O
hidden O
state O
si O
which O
is O
a O
function O
of O
past O
state O
, O
previous O
output O
from O
the O
feedforward O
NN O
, O
and O
the O
current O
context O
, O
i.e. O
, O
The O
recurrent O
layer O
helps O
finding O
a O
learnable O
smooth O
trajectory O
in O
a O
latent O
representational O
space O
. O

We O
use O
gated O
recurrent O
units O
( O
GRUs O
) O
in O
the O
recurrent O
layer O
as O
they O
work O
well O
for O
sequence O

. O

Each O
output O

state O
yi O
indicates O

of O

of O

( O

Since O

47 O
× O
47 O

, O
we O
reduce O
the O

into O
4 O
, O
i.e. O
, O
yi O
∈ O
R4 O
, O
using O
principal O

analysis O
( O

) O
. O

The O
remaining O
term O
, O
current O
context O
ci O
, O
is O

. O

Attention O
network O
For O
our O
study O
, O

network O
is O
the O

part O
as O
it O
enables O
learning O
association O
( O
s O
) O
between O
functional O
dynamics O
and O
structural O
features O
. O

Just O
before O
the O
sequence O
predictor O
predicts O
i-th O
dFNC O
state O
, O
the O
attention O
network O
first O
computes O

( O
indicating O
strength O
of O

) O
as O
to O
how O
well O
the O
structural O
component O
xj O
matches O
with O
dFNC O
state O
yi O
. O

This O
score O
is O
based O
on O
recurrent O
state O
si–1 O
and O
evaluated O
for O
all O
structural O
components O
, O
i.e. O
, O
for O
j O
= O
1 O
, O
2 O
, O
… O
, O
J O
, O
in O
each O
time O
step O
i O
. O

We O
use O
a O
feedforward O
neural O
network O
( O
NN O
) O
with O
a O
single O
hidden O
layer O
for O
the O

as O

. O

Here O
V O
, O

and O

are O

of O

NN O
, O
and O

is O

of O

. O

Then O

are O

according O
to O
Eq O
. O

( O
3 O
) O
to O

. O

The O

network O
modulates O
the O
structural O
components O
with O
its O

and O
computes O
a O
context O
vector O
ci O
at O
i-th O

as O
where O
● O
indicates O
element O

. O

In O

, O

context O
vector O
serves O
as O
the O
currently O
focused O
structural O
components O
with O
their O
soft O

. O

In O
effect O
, O
each O
alignment O
αij O
reflects O
the O
importance O
of O
structural O
component O
xj O
with O
respect O
to O
previous O
hidden O
state O
si–1 O
in O
deciding O
next O
state O
si O
and O
generating O
dFNC O
state O
yi O
by O

. O

Our O
interest O
with O
the O
translation-based O
fusion O
model O
described O
above O
is O
to O
examine O
brain O
structure-function O
relationship O
in O
terms O
of O
the O
alignments O
, O
αij O
, O
for O
i-th O
dFNC O
state O
and O
j-th O
structural O
components O
. O

Note O
that O

are O
learned O
from O
the O
data O
, O
thus O
taking O
representational O
advantage O
of O
deep O

. O

Since O
similar O
models O
have O
been O
proved O
to O
be O
able O
to O
find O

in O
machine O

( O

, O

between O

of O

and O

( O
e.g. O
, O

between O

in O

and O

in O

) O
, O
we O
rely O
on O
our O
method O
for O
finding O
associations O
between O

and O
sMRI O
features O
faithfully O
. O

Both O
the O
sequence O
predictor O
and O
attention O
network O
are O
trained O
jointly O
using O
a O
gradient O
based O
optimization O
algorithm O
called O
rmsprop O
with O
respect O
to O
a O
negative O
log-likelihood O
based O
cost O
function O
, O
In O
order O
to O
avoid O
the O
overfitting O
problem O
, O
we O
use O
L2 O
regularization O
on O
alignments O
and O
a O
50 O
% O
dropout O
in O
the O

layers O
of O
feedforward O
NNs O
( O
see O
Fig O
. O

1 O
) O
. O

No O
dropout O
was O
adopted O
in O
the O
recurrent O
layer O
and O
inputs O
. O

There O
are O
some O
architectural O
choices O
and O
hyper O
parameters O
for O
our O
model O
shown O
in O
Fig O
. O

1 O
. O

Based O
on O
the O
lowest O
negative O
log-likelihood O
on O
a O
hold O
out O
subset O
of O
data O
over O
several O
configurations O
, O
we O
selected O
number O
of O

hidden O
neurons O
in O
both O

NNs O
as O
50 O
, O
the O
number O
of O
recurrent O
units O
in O
the O

layer O
as O
50 O
; O
and O
set O
the O
learning O
rate O
and O
the O
coefficient O
of O

norm O
as O
0.01 O
and O
0.5 O
, O
respectively O
. O

The O
model O
with O
this O
configuration O
was O
trained O
using O
a O
gradient O
descent O
algorithm O
over O
entire O
data O
, O
and O
then O
the O
alignments O
were O
extracted O
from O
the O
model O
. O

We O
took O
100 O
runs O
with O
different O
random O
neural-network O
weight O
initializations O
of O
the O
model O
, O
and O
the O
alignments O
were O
averaged O
over O
100 O
runs O
for O
subsequent O
analysis O
. O

Decreased O
brain O
connectivity O
in O
smoking O
contrasts O
with O
increased O
connectivity O
in O
drinking O
In O
a O
group O
of O
831 O
participants O
from O
the O
general O
population O
in O
the O
Human O
Connectome O
Project O
, O
smokers O
exhibited O
low O
overall O
functional O
connectivity O
, O
and O
more O
specifically O
of O
the O
lateral O
orbitofrontal O
cortex O
which O
is O
associated O
with O
non-reward O
mechanisms O
, O
the O
adjacent O
inferior O
frontal O
gyrus O
, O
and O
the O
precuneus O
. O

Participants O
who O
drank O
a O
high O
amount O
had O
overall O
increases O
in O
resting O
state O
functional O
connectivity O
, O
and O
specific O
increases O
in O
reward-related O
systems O
including O
the O
medial O
orbitofrontal O
cortex O
and O
the O
cingulate O
cortex O
. O

Increased O
impulsivity O
was O
found O
in O
smokers O
, O
associated O
with O
decreased O
functional O
connectivity O
of O
the O
non-reward-related O
lateral O
orbitofrontal O
cortex O
; O
and O
increased O
impulsivity O
was O
found O
in O
high O
amount O
drinkers O
, O
associated O
with O
increased O
functional O
connectivity O
of O
the O
reward-related O
medial O
orbitofrontal O
cortex O
. O

The O
main O
findings O
were O
cross-validated O
in O
an O
independent O
longitudinal O
dataset O
with O
1176 O
participants O
, O
IMAGEN O
. O

Further O
, O
the O
functional O
connectivities O
in O
14-year-old O
non-smokers O
( O
and O
also O
in O
female O
low-drinkers O
) O
were O
related O
to O
who O
would O
smoke O
or O
drink O
at O
age O
19 O
. O

An O
implication O
is O
that O
these O
differences O
in O
brain O
functional O
connectivities O
play O
a O
role O
in O
smoking O
and O
drinking O
, O
together O
with O
other O
factors O
. O

eLife O
digest O
To O
understand O
why O
people O
become O
addicted O
to O
alcohol O
or O
smoking O
, O
it O
is O
important O
to O
look O
at O
how O
the O
brains O
of O
people O
who O
use O
these O
substances O
may O
be O
different O
than O
those O
who O
abstain O
. O

Many O
studies O
show O
that O
substance O
use O
activates O
the O
reward O
systems O
in O
the O
brain O
via O
a O
chemical O
called O
dopamine O
. O

Changes O
or O
differences O
in O
parts O
of O
the O
brain O
that O
control O
decision-making O
and O
restraint O
also O
have O
been O
implicated O
in O
substance O
use O
. O

Functional O
magnetic O
resonance O
imaging O
( O
fMRI O
) O
is O
one O
tool O
scientists O
can O
use O
to O
explore O
such O
differences O
. O

It O
can O
measure O
how O
well O
different O
parts O
of O
the O
brain O
are O
communicating O
with O
each O
other O
by O
measuring O
their O
activity O
when O
a O
person O
is O
at O
rest O
. O

The O
patterns O
of O
activity O
reveal O
which O
parts O
of O
the O
brain O
are O
working O
closely O
together O
or O
have O
high O
functional O
connectivity O
and O
which O
parts O
are O
less O
well O
connected O
, O
or O
have O
low O
functional O
connectivity O
. O

Cheng O
, O
Rolls O
et O
al O
. O

measured O
the O
functional O
connectivity O
between O
different O
parts O
of O
the O
brain O
in O
people O
who O
smoke O
and O
people O
who O
drink O
alcohol O
. O

Smokers O
had O
a O
low O
overall O
functional O
connectivity O
between O
brain O
regions O
. O

Specifically O
, O
they O
had O
weaker O
connections O
involving O
two O
brain O
regions O
that O
help O
people O
change O
or O
stop O
a O
behavior O
, O
the O
lateral O
orbitofrontal O
cortex O
and O
inferior O
frontal O
gyrus O
. O

These O
differences O
may O
make O
people O
more O
impulsive O
and O
less O
able O
to O
resist O
smoking O
. O

The O
stimulating O
effects O
of O
nicotine O
may O
enhance O
communication O
between O
different O
parts O
of O
the O
brain O
, O
so O
people O
also O
may O
use O
it O
to O
overcome O
some O
underlying O
communication O
deficits O
. O

Those O
who O
drink O
alcohol O
had O
high O
overall O
functional O
connectivity O
. O

Reward-related O
systems O
, O
including O
the O
medial O
orbitofrontal O
cortex O
and O
the O
cingulate O
cortex O
, O
were O
especially O
strongly O
connected O
. O

This O
may O
make O
them O
more O
sensitive O
to O
the O
rewarding O
aspects O
of O
drinking O
, O
or O
more O
impulsive O
. O

To O
confirm O
their O
results O
, O
Cheng O
, O
Rolls O
et O
al O
. O

analyzed O
fMRI O
data O
from O
another O
study O
. O

These O
showed O
that O
the O
characteristic O
differences O
in O
brain O
connectivity O
were O
already O
present O
in O
14-year O
olds O
who O
would O
go O
on O
to O
drink O
or O
smoke O
at O
age O
19 O
. O

This O
suggests O
that O
these O
functional O
connectivity O
differences O
in O
the O
brain O
make O
people O
more O
likely O
to O
smoke O
or O
drink O
. O

Materials O
and O
methods O
Participants O
and O
data O
preprocessing O
The O
dataset O
used O
for O
this O
investigation O
was O
selected O
from O
the O
November O
2015 O
public O
data O
release O
from O
the O
Human O
Connectome O
Project O
( O
HCP O
, O
N O
= O
900 O
) O
, O
WU-Minn O
Consortium O
. O

Our O
sample O
includes O
831 O
subjects O
( O
ages O
22–35 O
years O
, O
463 O
females O
) O
scanned O
on O
a O
3 O
T O
Siemens O
connectome-Skyra O
scanner O
. O

The O
HCP O
consortium O
is O
a O
public O
shared O
large-scale O
neuroimaging O
dataset O
which O
aims O
to O
map O
macroscopic O
human O
brain O
circuits O
and O
their O
relationship O
to O
behavior O
in O
a O
large O
population O
of O
healthy O
adults O
and O
which O
has O
been O
widely O
used O
in O
neuroimaging O
studies O
. O

The O
sibships O
with O
individual O
having O
severe O
neurodevelopmental O
disorders O
, O
neuropsychiatric O
disorders O
or O
neurologic O
disorders O
were O
excluded O
, O
but O
individuals O
who O
are O
smokers O
, O
are O
overweight O
, O
or O
have O
a O
history O
of O
heavy O
drinking O
or O
recreational O
drug O
use O
without O
having O
experienced O
severe O
symptoms O
were O
included O
in O
HCP O
consortium O
. O

The O
details O
on O
the O
inclusion O
and O
exclusion O
criteria O
of O
HCP O
consortium O
were O
provided O
in O
the O
previous O
studies O
and O
the O
HCP O
website O
( O
https O
: O
//www.humanconnectome.org/ O
) O
. O

It O
should O
be O
noted O
that O
the O
HCP O
dataset O
was O
not O
specifically O
designed O
for O
the O
study O
of O
substance O
use O
, O
but O
it O
is O
useful O
for O
investigating O
the O
impact O
of O
alcohol O
and O
cigarette O
use O
in O
a O
community O
sample O
. O

Two O
resting O
state O
fMRI O
acquisitions O
on O
different O
days O
were O
used O
. O

The O
four O
resting-state O
runs O
of O
approximately O
15 O
min O
each O
were O
acquired O
in O
separate O
sessions O
on O
two O
different O
days O
, O
with O
eyes O
open O
with O
relaxed O
fixation O
on O
a O
projected O
bright O
cross-hair O
on O
a O
dark O
background O
. O

The O
WU-Minn O
HCP O
Consortium O
obtained O
full O
informed O
consent O
from O
all O
participants O
, O
and O
research O
procedures O
and O
ethical O
guidelines O
were O
followed O
in O
accordance O
with O
the O
Washington O
University O
Institutional O
Review O
Boards O
( O
IRB O
# O
201204036 O
; O
Title O
: O
‘ O
Mapping O
the O
Human O
Connectome O
: O
Structure O
, O
Function O
, O
and O
Heritability O
’ O
) O
. O

The O
demographic O
characteristics O
of O
participants O
are O
summarized O
in O
Table O
2 O
. O

More O
details O
of O
subjects O
are O
provided O
in O
the O
Supplementary O
Material O
and O
the O
collection O
and O
preprocessing O
of O
the O
data O
are O
provided O
at O
the O
HCP O
website O
( O
http O
: O
//www.humanconnectome.org/ O
) O
. O

We O
obtained O
minimally O
preprocessed O
R-fMRI O
data O
conducted O
using O
the O
HCP O
Functional O
Pipeline O
v2.0 O
involving O
gradient O
distortion O
correction O
, O
head O
motion O
correction O
, O
image O
distortion O
correction O
and O
spatial O
transformation O
to O
the O
Montreal O
Neurological O
Institute O
( O
MNI O
) O
space O
using O
one O
step O
spline O
resampling O
from O
the O
original O
functional O
images O
followed O
by O
then O
intensity O
normalization O
. O

In O
this O
study O
, O
these O
minimally O
preprocessed O
images O
were O
further O
analyzed O
using O
FSL O
and O
AFNI O
. O

Briefly O
, O
first O
the O
constant O
, O
linear O
and O
quadratic O
trend O
were O
removed O
from O
these O
functional O
images O
. O

Next O
, O
several O
nuisance O
signals O
were O
regressed O
from O
the O
time O
course O
of O
each O
voxel O
using O
multiple O
linear O
regression O
, O
including O
cerebrospinal O
fluid O
signal O
, O
white O
matter O
signal O
, O
and O
Friston O
’ O
s O
24 O
head O
motion O
parameters O
. O

Then O
, O
temporal O
band-pass O
filtering O
( O
0.01-0.1 O
Hz O
) O
was O
performed O
to O
reduce O
the O
influence O
of O
low-frequency O
drift O
and O
the O
high-frequency O
physiological O
noise O
. O

Finally O
, O
3D O
spatial O
smoothing O
is O
applied O
to O
each O
volume O
of O
the O
fMRI O
data O
using O
a O
Gaussian O
kernel O
with O
Full-width O
at O
Half O
Maximum O
( O
FWHM O
) O
equaling O
to O
4 O
mm O
. O

The O
first O
50 O
volumes O
were O
discarded O
to O
suppress O
equilibration O
effects O
and O
participants O
without O
the O
full O
1200 O
time O
points O
in O
four O
resting-state O
runs O
were O
also O
removed O
from O
the O
following O
analysis O
. O

Any O
data O
affected O
by O
head O
motion O
( O
mean O
framewise O
displacement O
larger O
than O
0.3 O
mm O
) O
were O
excluded O
using O
the O
protocol O
of O
. O

The O
resulting O
time O
courses O
were O
used O
for O
the O
construction O
and O
analysis O
of O
the O
brain O
network O
. O

We O
also O
compared O
the O
findings O
based O
on O
the O
pipeline O
described O
above O
and O
elsewhere O
with O
alternative O
pipelines O
for O
data O
preprocessing O
including O
the O
HCP O
minimal O
preprocessing O
pipeline O
, O
and O
our O
pipeline O
but O
with O
global O
signal O
removal O
. O

More O
details O
on O
the O
effect O
of O
the O
preprocessing O
pipelines O
are O
shown O
in O
the O
Supplementary O
Material O
( O
Figure O
1—figure O
supplements O
1 O
) O
. O

Construction O
of O
the O
whole-brain O
functional O
network O
After O
preprocessing O
, O
the O
whole O
brain O
( O
gray O
matter O
) O
was O
parcellated O
into O
94 O
regions O
of O
interest O
( O
ROI O
) O
according O
to O
the O
automated O
anatomical O
labeling O
( O
AAL2 O
) O
atlas O
( O
47 O
regions O
in O
each O
hemisphere O
) O
, O
and O
the O
time O
series O
were O
extracted O
in O
each O
ROI O
by O
averaging O
the O
signals O
of O
all O
voxels O
within O
that O
region O
. O

The O
names O
of O
the O
ROIs O
and O
their O
corresponding O
abbreviations O
are O
listed O
in O
Supplementary O
file O
1 O
. O

( O
This O
is O
a O
standard O
parcellation O
scheme O
, O
which O
provides O
a O
usable O
number O
of O
different O
divisions O
for O
statistical O
purposes O
when O
differences O
between O
regions O
are O
being O
investigated O
, O
and O
includes O
a O
useful O
parcellation O
of O
the O
orbitofrontal O
cortex O
. O
) O
. O

For O
comparison O
, O
we O
also O
provide O
the O
results O
( O
Figure O
1—figure O
supplement O
2 O
) O
based O
on O
another O
atlas O
which O
has O
also O
been O
validated O
in O
resting O
state O
fMRI O
studies O
, O
although O
its O
parcellation O
of O
the O
orbitofrontal O
cortex O
is O
less O
good O
than O
the O
AAL2 O
atlas O
. O

The O
Pearson O
cross-correlations O
between O
all O
pairs O
of O
regional O
BOLD O
signals O
were O
calculated O
for O
each O
subject O
followed O
by O
z-transformation O
to O
improve O
normality O
, O
and O
the O
whole-brain O
functional O
connectivity O
network O
( O
94 O
× O
94 O
region-based O
network O
with O
4371 O
links O
) O
was O
constructed O
. O

Finally O
, O
the O
mean O
functional O
connectivity O
across O
two O
scans O
( O
each O
scan O
containing O
left O
to O
right O
and O
right O
to O
left O
phase O
encoding O
directions O
) O
was O
used O
for O
the O
following O
analysis O
to O
provide O
a O
more O
reliable O
estimation O
of O
functional O
connectivity O
. O

The O
correlation O
of O
the O
functional O
connectivities O
was O
high O
between O
the O
two O
different O
scans O
as O
shown O
in O
the O
Supplementary O
Material O
( O
Figure O
1—figure O
supplement O
3 O
) O
. O

Categorization O
of O
participants O
into O
groups O
The O
following O
factors O
were O
considered O
in O
choosing O
the O
measures O
to O
define O
the O
groups O
. O

The O
main O
purpose O
of O
the O
current O
study O
was O
to O
investigate O
whether O
there O
were O
differences O
in O
functional O
connectivity O
that O
were O
related O
to O
smoking O
or O
drinking O
. O

Accordingly O
, O
in O
the O
initial O
analysis O
, O
we O
categorized O
the O
participants O
for O
the O
smoking O
analysis O
into O
two O
groups O
, O
one O
which O
used O
significant O
amounts O
of O
cigarettes O
, O
and O
the O
other O
using O
no O
or O
low O
amounts O
of O
cigarettes O
. O

The O
same O
was O
performed O
for O
the O
division O
into O
two O
groups O
with O
respect O
to O
the O
amount O
of O
alcohol O
drunk O
. O

In O
making O
the O
cutoff O
, O
we O
ensured O
that O
there O
were O
reasonable O
numbers O
of O
participants O
in O
the O
high O
and O
the O
low O
amount O
groups O
. O

After O
the O
initial O
analysis O
, O
we O
wished O
to O
investigate O
the O
effect O
of O
the O
different O
amounts O
of O
use O
of O
cigarettes O
or O
alcohol O
, O
and O
therefore O
used O
measures O
of O
the O
different O
amounts O
of O
drinking O
of O
each O
participant O
, O
and O
the O
number O
of O
times O
each O
participant O
had O
smoked O
, O
as O
described O
in O
the O
results O
section O
( O
Figures O
5 O
and O
6 O
) O
. O

Accordingly O
, O
to O
investigate O
smoking-associated O
functional O
connectivity O
, O
we O
divided O
all O
participants O
into O
three O
groups O
according O
to O
their O
smoking O
history O
( O
SSAGA_TB_Smoking_History O
) O
, O
that O
is O
non-smokers O
( O
417 O
participants O
) O
, O
occasional O
smokers O
( O
161 O
participants O
) O
and O
regular O
smokers O
( O
203 O
participants O
) O
. O

The O
non-smoker O
group O
contained O
participants O
who O
had O
never O
smoked O
during O
their O
lifetime O
. O

The O
occasional O
smoker O
group O
contained O
participants O
who O
experimented O
with O
cigarettes O
at O
least O
once O
in O
their O
lifetime O
but O
never O
became O
a O
regular O
smoker O
. O

The O
regular O
smoker O
group O
included O
those O
who O
smoked O
at O
least O
100 O
cigarettes O
in O
his O
or O
her O
lifetime O
and O
smoked O
at O
least O
one O
day O
per O
week O
when O
they O
were O
smoking O
regularly O
. O

( O
A O
score O
of O
3 O
indicates O
a O
regular O
smoker O
; O
of O
1 O
and O
2 O
indicates O
an O
occasional O
smoker O
, O
and O
0 O
a O
non-smoker O
. O
) O

In O
the O
main O
analyses O
described O
in O
this O
paper O
to O
investigate O
whether O
there O
was O
an O
effect O
of O
smoking O
, O
two O
of O
these O
groups O
were O
used O
, O
the O
non-smoker O
and O
regular O
smoker O
groups O
. O

The O
third O
group O
was O
helpful O
in O
further O
analyses O
to O
investigate O
effects O
of O
the O
amount O
of O
smoking O
( O
Figure O
5 O
) O
. O

To O
investigate O
drinking-associated O
functional O
connectivities O
, O
we O
divided O
all O
participants O
into O
two O
groups O
. O

A O
Low O
Amount O
( O
LA O
) O
group O
with O
311 O
participants O
drank O
one O
or O
fewer O
drinks O
per O
drinking O
day O
in O
the O
past O
12 O
months O
. O

A O
High O
Amount O
( O
HA O
) O
group O
with O
470 O
participants O
drank O
two O
or O
more O
drinks O
per O
drinking O
day O
in O
the O
past O
12 O
months O
. O

( O
The O
descriptor O
was O
SSAGA_Alc_12_Drinks_Per_Day O
, O
and O
this O
division O
into O
two O
groups O
was O
made O
to O
help O
comparison O
with O
the O
initial O
analysis O
for O
smokers O
, O
which O
also O
used O
two O
groups O
. O
) O

It O
should O
be O
noted O
that O
the O
‘ O
amount O
’ O
of O
drinking O
in O
the O
current O
study O
refers O
to O
the O
amount O
of O
drinks O
per O
drinking O
day O
( O
and O
not O
for O
example O
to O
the O
total O
number O
of O
drinks O
in O
the O
past O
12 O
months O
) O
. O

The O
rationale O
for O
the O
use O
of O
this O
measure O
is O
provided O
in O
the O
Discussion O
section O
, O
and O
a O
complementary O
analysis O
showed O
that O
there O
was O
a O
good O
correlation O
between O
the O
association O
pattern O
of O
the O
functional O
connectivities O
when O
the O
measures O
were O
the O
'total O
drinks O
' O
and O
the O
'drinks O
per O
drinking O
day O
' O
( O
r O
= O
0.72 O
, O
p O
< O
1 O
× O
10−10 O
) O
. O

In O
order O
to O
compare O
the O
results O
for O
smoking O
and O
drinking O
, O
only O
participants O
with O
information O
about O
both O
drinking O
and O
smoking O
behavior O
were O
included O
. O

The O
demographic O
characteristics O
of O
the O
participants O
in O
each O
group O
are O
summarized O
in O
Table O
2 O
. O

Statistical O
analysis O
In O
order O
to O
investigate O
the O
relationship O
between O
functional O
connectivity O
( O
FC O
) O
and O
smoking O
, O
two O
sample O
two-tailed O
t O
tests O
were O
used O
to O
test O
whether O
smoking O
was O
associated O
with O
functional O
connectivity O
after O
removing O
the O
confounding O
effects O
of O
age O
, O
gender O
, O
years O
of O
education O
, O
race O
, O
handedness O
, O
head O
motion O
( O
mean O
framewise O
displacement O
, O
FD O
) O
, O
BMI O
, O
blood O
pressure O
( O
diastolic O
and O
systolic O
) O
, O
total O
gray O
matter O
volume O
, O
total O
white O
matter O
volume O
, O
drinking O
, O
and O
marijuana O
use O
. O

Considering O
the O
purpose O
of O
this O
study O
described O
above O
and O
the O
sample O
size O
in O
each O
sub-group O
, O
we O
used O
a O
two O
sample O
t-test O
rather O
than O
a O
2 O
× O
2 O
ANOVA O
. O

Then O
a O
Storey O
's O
FDR O
procedure O
was O
used O
to O
correct O
for O
multiple O
comparisons O
. O

Storey O
’ O
s O
FDR O
is O
a O
modification O
of O
FDR O
, O
also O
called O
positive O
False O
Discovery O
Rate O
( O
pFDR O
) O
by O
conditioning O
on O
one O
false O
positive O
finding O
having O
occurred O
. O

The O
Storey O
's O
FDR O
method O
was O
implemented O
by O
the O
Matlab O
function O
mafdr.m O
with O
default O
parameters O
. O

In O
the O
present O
study O
FDR O
correction O
for O
the O
functional O
connectivity O
between O
any O
pair O
of O
AAL2 O
regions O
was O
used O
, O
and O
the O
results O
for O
smoking O
are O
presented O
based O
on O
this O
statistical O
test O
with O
FDR O
p O
< O
0.005 O
. O

We O
then O
performed O
the O
same O
statistical O
analysis O
on O
the O
high O
drinking O
and O
low O
drinking O
groups O
with O
the O
FDR O
correction O
at O
p O
< O
0.05 O
. O

The O
effects O
of O
any O
use O
of O
the O
other O
substance O
was O
always O
removed O
by O
regression O
when O
we O
performed O
the O
analysis O
on O
the O
use O
of O
one O
of O
the O
substances O
. O

For O
the O
effect O
of O
the O
most O
recent O
drink/cigarette O
use O
, O
a O
correlation O
analysis O
confirmed O
that O
the O
association O
pattern O
was O
highly O
consistent O
in O
the O
cases O
with O
and O
without O
the O
covariates O
of O
the O
total O
drinks O
and O
total O
times O
smoked O
in O
the O
past O
7 O
days O
( O
r O
= O
0.957 O
for O
smoking O
and O
r O
= O
0.927 O
for O
drinking O
) O
. O

This O
provides O
evidence O
that O
it O
is O
whether O
one O
is O
a O
smoker O
or O
drinker O
that O
is O
relevant O
to O
the O
results O
described O
in O
this O
paper O
, O
and O
not O
just O
the O
most O
recent O
drug O
use O
. O

Correlation O
of O
functional O
connectivity O
differences O
for O
substances O
with O
extent O
of O
use O
and O
a O
measure O
of O
impulsivity O

explored O
the O
relationship O
between O
the O

connectivity O
links O
identified O
above O
as O
different O
in O
substance O
use O
groups O
with O

measures O
( O
i.e O
. O

drinks O
per O
drinking O
day O
in O
the O
past O
12 O
months O
and O
the O
amount O
of O
smoking O
) O
. O

Specifically O
, O
a O
partial O
correlation O
analysis O
was O
used O
to O
measure O
the O
correlation O
between O
the O

functional O
connectivity O
and O
these O

with O

of O

of O

, O

of O

, O

, O

, O

( O

) O
, O

, O

gray O

, O

matter O
volume O

of O

. O

We O
also O
investigated O
the O
relationship O
between O
the O
functional O
connectivity O
links O
identified O
above O
as O
different O
in O
substance O
use O
groups O
and O

related O
to O
self-regulation O
and O

. O

We O
performed O
a O
partial O
correlation O
of O

delay O
discounting O
score O
with O
the O
amount O
of O
drinking O
per O
drinking O
day O
and O
the O
amount O
of O

respectively O
. O

The O
score O
of O
self-regulation O
and O
impulsivity O
was O
based O
on O
the O
delay O
discounting O
task O
which O
measures O
the O
undervaluing O
of O
rewards O
delayed O
in O
time O
. O

We O
used O
an O
area-under-the-curve O
discounting O
measure O
( O
AUC O
) O
that O
provides O
a O
valid O
and O
reliable O
index O
of O
how O
steeply O
an O
individual O
discounts O
delayed O
rewards O
. O

Specifically O
, O
we O
calculated O
the O
canonical O
correlation O
between O
the O
area O
under O
the O
curve O
for O
discounting O
of O
$ O
200 O
and O
$ O
40,000 O
( O

and O
DDisc_AUC_40K O
) O
with O
the O
strength O
of O
associated O
functional O
connectivities O
for O
drinking O
and O
smoking O
respectively O
, O
after O
removing O
the O
effects O
of O
age O
, O
gender O
, O
years O
of O
education O
, O
race O
, O
handedness O
, O
head O
motion O
( O
mean O
FD O
) O
, O
BMI O
, O
blood O
pressure O
( O
diastolic O
and O
systolic O
) O

gray O
matter O
volume O
, O
total O

matter O

and O

of O
the O
other O
two O

. O

Cross-validation O
with O
the O
IMAGEN O
dataset O
We O
used O
another O
separate O
large O
longitudinal O

dataset O
( O

dataset O
) O
which O
included O
1176 O
participants O
to O
test O
whether O

based O
on O

dataset O
could O
be O

with O
an O
independent O
dataset O
, O
which O
would O
considerably O
strengthen O
the O
findings O
. O

This O
dataset O
also O
enabled O
examination O
of O
whether O
functional O
connectivity O
at O
age O
14 O
when O
participants O
neither O
smoke O
nor O
drank O
was O
associated O
with O
who O
would O
become O
drinkers O
or O

at O
age O
19 O
. O

This O
potentially O
thus O
provides O

to O
investigate O
whether O
differences O
between O
individuals O
that O
were O
not O

by O

and O

( O

there O
was O
little O

and O

when O
the O

were O

) O
might O
lead O
to O
smoking O
or O
drinking O
by O
the O
time O
that O
the O
participants O
were O
19 O
. O

The O
IMAGEN O
dataset O
also O
enabled O

of O
gender O
differences O
in O
the O
behaviors O
that O
may O
be O
predictable O
from O
brain O
functional O

in O
this O
important O
period O
of O
development O
. O

IMAGEN O
14 O
: O

group O
( O

However O
, O

between O

. O

, O
for O

( O

. O

It O

that O

. O

Then O

( O

of O

, O

( O

We O
also O

The O

measure O
is O
based O
on O
the O
Substance O
Use O
Risk O
Profile O
Scale O
by O
using O
the O
sum O
of O
the O
following O
question O
scores O
: O
I O
often O
do O
n't O
think O
things O
through O
before O
I O
speak O
. O

I O
often O
involve O
myself O
in O
situations O
that O
I O
later O
regret O
being O
involved O
in O
. O

I O
usually O
act O
without O
stopping O
to O
think O
. O

Generally O
, O
I O
am O
an O
impulsive O
person O
. O

I O
feel O
I O
have O
to O
be O
manipulative O
to O
get O
what O
I O
want O
. O

Drinking O
and O
smoking O
behavior O
We O
used O
the O
European O
School O
Survey O
Project O
on O
Alcohol O
and O
Other O
Drugs O
( O
ESPAD O
) O
at O
ages O
14 O
and O
19 O
years O
to O
assess O
life O
time O
drinking O
and O
smoking O
. O

The O
primary O
question O
of O
interest O
was O
regarding O
lifetime O
alcohol O
and O
cigarette O
use O
and O
the O
questionnaire O
were O
as O
follows O
: O
1 O
. O

On O
how O
many O
occasions O
during O
your O
lifetime O
have O
you O
smoked O
cigarettes O
? O

0 O
: O
0 O
1 O
: O
1–2 O
2 O
: O
3–5 O
3 O
: O
6–9 O
4 O
: O
10–19 O
5 O
: O
20–39 O
6 O
: O
40 O
or O
mor O
2 O
. O

How O
frequently O
have O
you O
smoked O
cigarettes O
during O
the O
last O
30 O
days O
? O

6 O
: O
more O
than O
20 O
cigarettes O
per O
day O
999 O
: O
non O
smoker O
0 O
: O
not O
at O
all O
1 O
: O
less O
than O
one O
cigarette O
per O
week O
2 O
: O
less O
than O
one O
cigarette O
per O
day O
3 O
: O
1–5 O
cigarettes O
per O
day O
4 O
: O
6–10 O
cigarettes O
per O
day O
5 O
: O
11–20 O
cigarettes O
per O
day O
3 O
. O

How O
many O
drinks O
containing O

do O
you O
have O
on O
a O

when O

are O

1 O
: O
