Imaging O
data O
preprocessing O
for O
the O
IMAGEN O
dataset O
Data O
preprocessing O
was O
performed O
using O
DPARSF O
( O
http O
: O
// O
restfmri.net O
) O
which O
is O
a O
toolbox O
based O
on O
the O
SPM8 O
software O
package O
. O

The O
first O
10 O
EPI O
scans O
were O
discarded O
to O
suppress O
equilibration O
effects O
. O

The O
remaining O
scans O
of O
each O
subject O
underwent O
slice O
timing O
correction O
by O
sinc O
interpolating O
volume O
slices O
, O
motion O
correction O
for O
volume O
to O
volume O
displacement O
, O
spatial O
normalization O
to O
standard O
Montreal O
Neurological O
Institute O
( O
MNI O
) O
space O
using O
affine O
transformation O
and O
nonlinear O
deformation O
with O
a O
voxel O
size O
of O
, O
followed O
by O
spatial O
smoothing O
( O
6 O
mm O
Full O
Width O
Half O
Maximum O
FWHM O
) O
. O

To O
remove O
the O
sources O
of O
spurious O
correlations O
present O
in O
resting-state O
BOLD O
data O
, O
all O
fMRI O
time-series O
underwent O
band-pass O
temporal O
filtering O
( O
0.01-0.1 O
Hz O
) O
, O
nuisance O
signal O
removal O
from O
the O
ventricles O
, O
and O
deep O
white O
matter O
, O
and O
regressing O
out O
any O
effects O
of O
head O
motion O
using O
Friston O
’ O
s O
24 O
head O
motion O
parameters O
procedure O
. O

Finally O
, O
subjects O
with O
the O
mean O
framewise O
displacement O
( O
FD O
) O
of O
head O
motion O
large O
than O
0.3 O
were O
completely O
excluded O
from O
the O
analysis O
as O
it O
is O
likely O
that O
such O
high-level O
of O
movement O
would O
have O
had O
an O
influence O
on O
several O
volumes O
. O

Methodological O
notes O
Effect O
of O
the O
pipeline O
of O
data O
preprocessing O
A O
comparison O
between O
different O
pipelines O
of O
data O
preprocessing O
was O
performed O
, O
as O
follows O
. O

1 O
) O
The O
complete O
HCP O
pipeline O
. O

Data O
pre-processing O
was O
carried O
out O
using O
FSL O
( O
FMRIB O
Software O
Library O
) O
, O
FreeSurfer O
, O
and O
the O
Connectome O
Workbench O
software O
. O

All O
the O
data O
preprocessing O
procedures O
were O
performed O
by O
the O
human O
connectome O
project O
( O
HCP O
) O
as O
described O
in O
. O

Briefly O
, O
the O
data O
preprocessing O
included O
correction O
for O
spatial O
and O
gradient O
distortions O
and O
head O
motion O
, O
intensity O
normalization O
and O
bias O
field O
removal O
, O
registration O
to O
the O
T1 O
weighted O
structural O
image O
, O
transformation O
to O
2 O
mm O
Montreal O
Neurological O
Institute O
( O
MNI O
) O
space O
, O
and O
the O
FIX O
artefact O
removal O
procedure O
. O

2 O
) O
The O
HCP O
minimal O
preprocessing O
pipeline O
+ O
other O
standard O
preprocessing O
procedures O
but O
without O
global O
signal O
removal O
. O

The O
HCP O
minimal O
preprocessing O
pipeline O
was O
used O
for O
the O
HCP O
data O
set O
. O

This O
pipeline O
includes O
artifact O
removal O
, O
motion O
correction O
and O
registration O
to O
standard O
space O
. O

Then O
standard O
preprocessing O
procedures O
were O
applied O
to O
the O
fMRI O
data O
: O
first O
the O
linear O
trend O
and O
quadratic O
term O
were O
removed O
from O
these O
functional O
images O
; O
several O
nuisance O
signals O
were O
regressed O
from O
the O
time O
course O
of O
each O
voxel O
using O
multiple O
linear O
regression O
, O
including O
cerebrospinal O
fluid O
, O
white O
matter O
and O
head O
motion O
parameters O
; O
finally O
, O
temporal O
band-pass O
filtering O
( O
0.09–0.1 O
Hz O
) O
was O
performed O
to O
reduce O
the O
influence O
of O
low-frequency O
drift O
and O
the O
high-frequency O
physiological O
noise O
. O

This O
pipeline O
has O
been O
widely O
used O
in O
previous O
studies O
based O
on O
the O
HCP O
dataset O
and O
our O
paper O
also O
focuses O
on O
the O
results O
based O
on O
this O
pipeline O
. O

3 O
) O
The O
HCP O
minimal O
preprocessing O
pipeline O
+ O
other O
standard O
preprocessing O
procedures O
and O
with O
global O
signal O
removal O
. O

Same O
as O
pipeline O
two O
but O
with O
the O
global O
signal O
removal O
. O

Targeting O
Reduced O
Neural O
Oscillations O
in O
Patients O
with O
Schizophrenia O
by O
Transcranial O
Alternating O
Current O
Stimulation O
Transcranial O
alternating O
current O
stimulation O
( O
tACS O
) O
modulates O
endogenous O
neural O
oscillations O
in O
healthy O
human O
participants O
by O
the O
application O
of O
a O
low-amplitude O
electrical O
current O
with O
a O
periodic O
stimulation O
waveform O
. O

Yet O
, O
it O
is O
unclear O
if O
tACS O
can O
modulate O
and O
restore O
neural O
oscillations O
that O
are O
reduced O
in O
patients O
with O
psychiatric O
illnesses O
such O
as O
schizophrenia O
. O

Here O
, O
we O
asked O
if O
tACS O
modulates O
network O
oscillations O
in O
schizophrenia O
. O

We O
performed O
a O
randomized O
, O
double-blind O
, O
sham-controlled O
clinical O
trial O
to O
contrast O
tACS O
with O
transcranial O
direct O
current O
stimulation O
( O
tDCS O
) O
and O
sham O
stimulation O
in O
22 O
schizophrenia O
patients O
with O
auditory O
hallucinations O
. O

We O
used O
high-density O
electroencephalography O
to O
investigate O
if O
a O
five-day O
, O
twice-daily O
10HztACS O
protocol O
enhances O
alpha O
oscillations O
and O
modulates O
network O
dynamics O
that O
are O
reduced O
in O
schizophrenia O
. O

We O
found O
that O
10Hz-tACS O
enhanced O
alpha O
oscillations O
and O
modulated O
functional O
connectivity O
in O
the O
alpha O
frequency O
band O
. O

In O
addition O
, O
10Hz-tACS O
enhanced O
the O
40Hz O
auditory O
steady-state O
response O
( O
ASSR O
) O
, O
which O
is O
reduced O
in O
patients O
with O
schizophrenia O
. O

Importantly O
, O
clinical O
improvement O
of O
auditory O
hallucinations O
correlated O
with O
enhancement O
of O
alpha O
oscillations O
and O
the O
40Hz-ASSR O
. O

Together O
, O
our O
findings O
suggest O
that O
tACS O
has O
potential O
as O
a O
network-level O
approach O
to O
modulate O
reduced O
neural O
oscillations O
related O
to O
clinical O
symptoms O
in O
patients O
with O
schizophrenia O
. O

Methods O
Participants O
This O
study O
was O
performed O
at O
the O
University O
of O
North O
Carolina O
at O
Chapel O
Hill O
( O
UNC-CH O
) O
( O
ClinicalTrials.gov O
, O
NCT02360228 O
) O
and O
was O
approved O
by O
the O
Biomedical O
Institutional O
Review O
Board O
of O
UNC-CH O
. O

Participants O
were O
recruited O
from O
local O
clinics O
and O
academic O
medical O
centers O
. O

All O
participants O
met O
DSM-IV O
criteria O
for O
schizophrenia O
or O
schizoaffective O
disorder O
. O

Participants O
with O
at O
least O
three O
auditory O
hallucinations O
per O
week O
and O
clinically O
stability O
as O
demonstrated O
by O
no O
hospitalizations O
for O
the O
past O
3 O
months O
. O

Antipsychotic O
medications O
were O
documented O
at O
the O
initial O
and O
final O
sessions O
to O
ensure O
stable O
medication O
during O
participation O
( O
Table O
S1 O
) O
. O

Brief O
demographics O
and O
clinical O
assessments O
are O
tabulated O
( O
Table O
S2 O
) O
. O

Detailed O
information O
including O
inclusion/exclusion O
criteria O
and O
clinical O
analyses O
are O
described O
in O
a O
separate O
paper O
. O

Data O
from O
22 O
participants O
were O
analyzed O
. O

Study O
design O
This O
study O
was O
a O
randomized O
, O
double-blind O
, O
and O
sham-controlled O
clinical O
trial O
, O
with O
three O
stimulation O
conditions O
( O
10Hz-tACS O
, O
tDCS O
, O
and O
sham O
) O
. O

Each O
participant O
was O
randomly O
assigned O
with O
equal O
probability O
to O
one O
of O
the O
three O
conditions O
. O

To O
achieve O
integrity O
of O
the O
double-blind O
, O
a O
researcher O
not O
involved O
in O
the O
study O
developed O
5-digit O
random O
numbers O
and O
assigned O
the O
numbers O
to O
the O
participants O
. O

Each O
participant O
was O
randomized O
to O
one O
of O
the O
three O
stimulation O
conditions O
( O
e.g O
. O

1 O
: O
sham O
, O
2 O
: O
tACS O
, O
3 O
: O
tDCS O
) O
with O
the O
5-digit O
numbers O
. O

One O
of O
the O
co-authors O
in O
the O
study O
wrote O
MATLAB O
scripts O
to O
deliver O
and O
control O
stimulation O
waveforms O
with O
the O
three O
stimulation O
conditions O
. O

This O
author O
was O
blinded O
to O
the O
5-digit O
numbers O
and O
excluded O
from O
all O
stimulation O
sessions O
. O

The O
other O
two O
co-authors O
( O
study O
coordinators O
) O
performed O
all O
stimulation O
sessions O
with O
the O
5-digit O
numbers O
for O
each O
participant O
. O

Further O
, O
the O
display O
on O
the O
stimulators O
was O
covered O
during O
stimulation O
to O
conceal O
information O
about O
the O
stimulation O
provided O
by O
the O
stimulators O
. O

All O
researchers O
were O
unaware O
of O
the O
condition O
assignments O
until O
all O
participants O
had O
completed O
the O
study O
. O

The O
auditory O
hallucination O
severity O
was O
measured O
by O
the O
auditory O
hallucination O
rating O
scale O
( O
AHRS O
) O
. O

The O
AHRS O
was O
administered O
before O
the O
1st O
stimulation O
on O
day O
1 O
( O
baseline O
) O
, O
after O
the O
10th O
stimulation O
on O
day O
5 O
, O
and O
at O
the O
1-week O
and O
1-month O
follow-up O
study O
visits O
. O

A O
detailed O
description O
of O
the O
clinical O
data O
and O
analyses O
is O
provided O
in O
a O
separate O
paper O
. O

EEG O
data O
were O
collected O
at O
the O
same O
time O
points O
with O
the O
exception O
of O
the O
recording O
on O
day O
5 O
, O
which O
was O
performed O
before O
stimulation O
to O
avoid O
contamination O
by O
potential O
instantaneous O
effects O
of O
stimulation O
on O
brain O
network O
dynamics O
. O

On O
day O
5 O
, O
EEG O
and O
the O
AHRS O
were O
not O
administered O
simultaneously O
but O
were O
spaced O
by O
the O
last O
stimulation O
session O
. O

We O
do O
not O
expect O
any O
large O
changes O
of O
the O
AHRS O
scores O
within O
less O
than O
an O
hour O
since O
the O
AHRS O
queries O
symptoms O
for O
a O
time O
window O
of O
several O
days O
. O

The O
sample O
size O
was O
determined O
by O
the O
amount O
of O
funding O
available O
for O
the O
grant O
that O
supported O
this O
work O
. O

The O
study O
was O
performed O
between O
June O
2015 O
and O
February O
2017 O
. O

Brain O
stimulation O
We O
developed O
a O
custom-built O
interface O
in O
MATLAB O
and O
controlled O
two O
Neuroconn O
DC O
Plus O
stimulators O
( O
Neuroconn O
Ltd. O
, O
Ilmenau O
, O
Germany O
) O
using O
“ O
remote-mode O
” O
to O
ensure O
double-blind O
administration O
of O
stimulation O
. O

Our O
setup O
saved O
the O
applied O
stimulation O
waveform O
, O
which O
was O
validated O
offline O
by O
a O
lab O
member O
not O
otherwise O
involved O
in O
this O
study O
. O

The O
electrode O
montage O
was O
identical O
for O
all O
three O
stimulation O
conditions O
to O
ensure O
blinding O
of O
the O
research O
personnel O
to O
each O
stimulation O
condition O
. O

We O
used O
two O
stimulators O
since O
the O
maximum O
current O
from O
one O
stimulator O
is O
1.5mA O
zero-to-peak O
amplitude O
for O
the O
safety O
guidelines O
. O

We O
applied O
three O
rubber O
electrodes O
to O
the O
scalp O
with O
Ten20 O
conductive O
paste O
( O
Bio-Medical O
Instruments O
, O
Clinton O
Township O
, O
MI O
) O
. O

Each O
stimulator O
has O
two O
output O
connectors O
for O
electrode O
cables O
. O

One O
of O
the O
two O
outputs O
of O
each O
stimulator O
was O
connected O
together O
to O
form O
a O
common O
return O
path O
for O
the O
stimulation O
current O
through O
a O
5×7cm O
electrode O
placed O
on O
Cz O
( O
center O
of O
the O
scalp O
) O
. O

The O
other O
output O
of O
each O
stimulator O
was O
connected O
to O
a O
5×5cm O
electrode O
placed O
between O
F3 O
and O
Fp1 O
( O
DLPFC O
) O
and O
between O
T3 O
and O
P3 O
( O
TPJ O
) O
, O
respectively O
. O

For O
10Hz-tACS O
, O
each O
5×5cm O
electrode O
delivered O
an O
in-phase O
sinusoidal O
waveform O
with1mA O
amplitude O
. O

Both O
amplitude O
and O
phase O
of O
the O
stimulation O
waveforms O
were O
verified O
with O
an O
oscilloscope O
. O

For O
tDCS O
, O
the O
electrode O
between O
F3 O
and O
Fp1 O
delivered O
+2m O
A O
amplitude O
current O
and O
the O
other O
electrode O
between O
T3 O
and O
P3 O
delivered O
−2mA O
amplitude O
current O
. O

Stimulation O
montage O
and O
modeling O
of O
electric O
field O
distribution O
were O
calculated O
by O
NEUROPHET O
tCS O
Lab O
( O
Neurophet O
Inc. O
, O
Seoul O
, O
South O
Korea O
) O
as O
depicted O
in O
Figure O
1 O
. O

We O
used O
these O
simulations O
of O
the O
electric O
field O
to O
determine O
the O
“ O
stimulated O
” O
scalp O
locations O
for O
subsequent O
analysis O
of O
the O
EEG O
signal O
. O

Sham O
stimulation O
delivered O
10 O
seconds O
of O
ramp-up O
, O
followed O
by O
20 O
seconds O
of O
10Hz-tACS O
, O
followed O
by O
10 O
seconds O
of O
ramp-down O
for O
a O
total O
of O
40 O
seconds O
. O

All O
participants O
completed O
twice-daily O
stimulation O
sessions O
for O
five O
consecutive O
days O
. O

Each O
stimulation O
session O
was O
20 O
minutes O
long O
with O
a O
three-hour O
break O
between O
the O
two O
stimulation O
sessions O
. O

This O
structuring O
into O
two O
sessions O
per O
day O
was O
adopted O
to O
from O
earlier O
work O
on O
tDCS O
for O
the O
treatment O
of O
auditory O
hallucinations O
. O

During O
stimulation O
, O
all O
participants O
were O
seated O
comfortably O
and O
watched O
a O
video O
of O
tropical O
fish O
( O
Undersea O
Productions O
, O
Queensland O
, O
Australia O
) O
to O
minimize O
the O
perception O
of O
phosphenes O
induced O
by O
stimulation O
. O

Participants O
were O
asked O
to O
watch O
the O
video O
and O
keep O
their O
eyes O
open O
. O

EEG O
tasks O
EEG O
data O
were O
recorded O
using O
a O
128-channel O
Geodesic O
EEG O
system O
( O
EGI O
Inc. O
, O
Eugene O
, O
OR O
) O
at O
a O
sampling O
rate O
of O
1kHz O
. O

Channel O
Cz O
and O
one O
channel O
between O
Cz O
and O
Pz O
were O
used O
as O
the O
reference O
and O
as O
the O
ground O
, O
respectively O
. O

All O
instructions O
and O
experimental O
tasks O
were O
implemented O
in O
Presentation O
( O
Neurobehavioral O
Systems O
, O
Inc. O
, O
Berkeley O
, O
CA O
) O
. O

Two O
experimental O
tasks O
were O
used O
. O

First O
, O
resting-state O
EEG O
data O
with O
eyes-open O
and O
eyes-closed O
were O
recorded O
for O
eight O
minutes O
. O

Participants O
were O
instructed O
by O
a O
computer O
voice O
to O
fixate O
on O
a O
crosshair O
and O
open O
or O
close O
their O
eyes O
while O
staying O
relaxed O
. O

Eyes-closed O
and O
eyes-open O
conditions O
were O
alternated O
every O
two O
minutes O
and O
starting O
condition O
was O
randomized O
across O
the O
participants O
. O

We O
only O
present O
eyes-open O
data O
here O
since O
stimulation O
was O
applied O
in O
that O
state O
and O
we O
wanted O
to O
avoid O
confounds O
caused O
by O
the O
change O
in O
alpha O
oscillation O
strength O
due O
to O
eye O
closing O
. O

Second O
, O
the O
response O
to O
auditory O
click-trains O
was O
recorded O
. O

The O
auditory O
stimuli O
were O
delivered O
binaurally O
through O
air-conducting O
earphone O
tubes O
ER-3C O
( O
Etymotic O
Research O
Inc. O
, O
Elk O
Grove O
Village O
, O
IL O
) O
at O
sound O
pressure O
level O
( O
SPL O
) O
of O
90 O
dB O
. O

Participants O
fixated O
on O
a O
crosshair O
on O
a O
computer O
monitor O
while O
listening O
to O
500ms O
long O
click-trains O
at O
rates O
of O
10Hz O
, O
20Hz O
, O
30Hz O
, O
40Hz O
and O
80Hz O
. O

This O
task O
was O
15 O
minutes O
in O
length O
, O
separated O
into O
five O
3-minute O
blocks O
. O

Subsequent O
click-trains O
were O
separated O
by O
a O
jittered O
interval O
between O
450ms O
and O
550ms O
of O
silence O
. O

The O
order O
of O
the O
click-train O
frequencies O
was O
pseudo-random O
and O
balanced O
within O
each O
3-minute O
block O
, O
for O
a O
total O
of O
200 O
click-trains O
per O
block O
and O
a O
grand O
total O
of O
1000 O
click-trains O
. O

Synchronization O
between O
the O
auditory O
stimulus O
presentation O
and O
EEG O
acquisition O
was O
achieved O
by O
splitting O
the O
stereo O
output O
of O
the O
sound O
card O
into O
two O
separate O
mono O
outputs O
. O

One O
channel O
was O
used O
for O
the O
actual O
auditory O
stimuli O
while O
the O
other O
channel O
was O
recorded O
together O
with O
data O
. O

EEG O
analysis O
and O
statistical O
testing O
Offline O
processing O
was O
performed O
by O
EEGLAB O
, O
FieldTrip O
, O
and O
custom-built O
scripts O
in O
MATLAB O
. O

First O
, O
all O
data O
were O
downsampled O
to O
250Hz O
with O
anti-aliasing O
filtering O
( O
0.9π O
rad/sample O
cutoff O
and O
0.2π O
rad/sample O
transition O
bandwidth O
) O
and O
band-pass O
filtered O
from O
1 O
to O
50Hz O
for O
the O
resting-state O
data O
, O
from O
1 O
to O
100Hz O
with O
60Hz O
notch O
filter O
for O
the O
click-trains O
data O
. O

Second O
, O
the O
data O
were O
preprocessed O
by O
an O
artifact O
subspace O
reconstruction O
algorithm O
to O
identify O
high-variance O
data O
epochs O
and O
reconstruct O
missing O
data O
. O

Briefly O
, O
the O
algorithm O
first O
finds O
a O
minute O
of O
data O
that O
represents O
clean O
EEG O
signals O
that O
serve O
as O
a O
baseline O
. O

Then O
, O
principle O
component O
analysis O
is O
applied O
to O
the O
whole O
data O
set O
with O
a O
sliding O
window O
to O
find O
the O
subspaces O
in O
which O
there O
is O
activity O
that O
is O
more O
than O
five O
standard O
deviations O
away O
from O
the O
baseline O
EEG O
. O

Once O
the O
function O
has O
identified O
the O
outlier O
subspaces O
, O
it O
treats O
them O
as O
missing O
data O
and O
reconstructs O
their O
content O
using O
a O
mixing O
matrix O
that O
is O
calculated O
on O
the O
clean O
data O
. O

Third O
, O
bad O
channels O
that O
were O
found O
in O
the O
previous O
step O
were O
interpolated O
and O
common O
average O
referencing O
was O
performed O
. O

After O
then O
, O
infomax O
independent O
component O
analysis O
( O
ICA O
) O
was O
performed O
to O
remove O
eye O
blinking O
, O
eye O
movement O
, O
muscle O
activity O
, O
and O
heartbeat O
artefact O
. O

All O
ICA O
components O
were O
visually O
inspected O
and O
noise O
components O
were O
manually O
selected O
for O
rejection O
. O

These O
initial O
pre-processing O
steps O
were O
carried O
out O
on O
the O
full O
EEG O
dataset O
before O
unblinding O
the O
study O
. O

For O
the O
resting-state O
EEG O
, O
data O
were O
epoched O
into O
2-second O
windows O
. O

Each O
epoch O
was O
visually O
inspected O
in O
the O
temporal O
domain O
and O
bad O
epochs O
that O
contained O
abnormal O
signal O
spikes O
or O
very O
pronounced O
fluctuations O
( O
larger O
than O
100uV O
) O
due O
to O
head O
movement O
( O
2.61 O
±1.1 O
of O
120 O
trials O
) O
for O
all O
three O
conditions O
were O
removed O
. O

We O
found O
no O
significant O
difference O
of O
the O
rejected O
epochs O
between O
the O
three O
conditions O
( O
one-way O
ANOVA O
, O
F2,19=0.65 O
, O
p=0.53 O
) O
. O

Power O
spectral O
density O
( O
PSD O
) O
was O
computed O
by O
Welch O
’ O
s O
method O
with O
a O
2-sec O
window O
and O
a O
12.5 O
% O
overlap O
resulting O
in O
a O
PSD O
with O
0.5Hz O
frequency O
bins O
. O

Individual O
alpha O
frequency O
( O
IAF O
) O
, O
which O
we O
defined O
as O
the O
frequency O
of O
the O
peak O
power O
in O
the O
occipital O
alpha O
band O
( O
8–12Hz O
) O
in O
the O
eye-closed O
condition O
, O
was O
selected O
for O
each O
participant O
. O

The O
power O
of O
alpha O
oscillations O
was O
determined O
by O
averaging O
of O
the O
PSD O
around O
the O
IAF O
( O
IAF O
- O
1Hz O
≤ O
IAF O
≤ O
IAF O
+ O
1Hz O
) O
and O
the O
alpha O
oscillations O
were O
spatially O
normalized O
by O
the O
average O
of O
all O
channels O
to O
remove O
the O
inter-subject O
variability O
of O
alpha O
oscillations O
. O

Thirty-eight O
channels O
outside O
of O
the O
scalp O
were O
excluded O
and O
the O
remaining O
90 O
channels O
corresponding O
to O
scalp O
locations O
were O
used O
for O
topographical O
representation O
. O

For O
statistical O
analysis O
, O
custom-built O
scripts O
in O
R O
( O
R O
Foundation O
for O
Statistical O
Computing O
, O
Vienna O
, O
Austria O
) O
were O
used O
. O

We O
adopted O
a O
linear O
mixed O
model O
analysis O
with O
fixed O
factors O
of O
“ O
session O
” O
( O
baseline O
, O
day O
5 O
, O
1-week O
, O
and O
1-month O
) O
and O
“ O
condition O
” O
( O
10Hz-tACS O
, O
tDCS O
, O
and O
sham O
) O
, O
with O
random O
factor O
“ O
participant O
” O
to O
account O
for O
repeat O
measures O
within O
participants O
. O

We O
used O
the O
power O
of O
the O
alpha O
oscillations O
averaged O
across O
channels O
( O
41 O
channels O
, O
Fig O
. O

S3 O
) O
in O
the O
stimulated O
regions O
( O
left O
hemisphere O
) O
as O
a O
dependent O
variable O
since O
we O
hypothesized O
that O
the O
left O
hemisphere O
was O
modulated O
by O
tACS O
or O
tDCS O
based O
on O
the O
electric O
field O
modeling O
( O
Fig O
. O

1 O
) O
. O

Kenward-Roger O
approximations O
were O
used O
to O
obtain O
p-values O
and O
perform O
F-tests O
for O
each O
factor O
and O
their O
interaction O
. O

Post-hoc O
statistical O
tests O
were O
performed O
using O
student O
’ O
s O
t-test O
across O
participants O
at O
each O
channel O
and O
it O
was O
corrected O
by O
false O
discovery O
rate O
( O
FDR O
) O
from O
the O
entire O
scalp O
channels O
. O

Changes O
of O
alpha O
oscillations O
over O
sessions O
were O
quantified O
with O
a O
modulation O
index O
, O
( O
Alphapost O
− O
Alphabase O
) O
/ O
( O
Alphapost O
+ O
Alphabase O
) O
where O
Alphapost O
and O
Alphabase O
are O
alpha O
oscillations O
post-stimulation O
( O
day O
5 O
, O
1-week O
, O
and O
1-month O
) O
and O
at O
baseline O
( O
day O
1 O
of O
stimulation O
) O
, O
respectively O
. O

To O
compute O
functional O
connectivity O
in O
terms O
of O
phase O
synchronization O
in O
the O
resting-state O
EEG O
data O
, O
we O
adopted O
a O
debiased O
weighted O
phase O
lag O
index O
( O
WPLI O
) O
to O
minimize O
the O
effects O
of O
volume O
conduction O
and O
noise O
originating O
from O
other O
scalp O
locations O
. O

This O
method O
is O
also O
debiased O
in O
terms O
of O
sample O
size O
. O

We O
computed O
WPLI O
as O
Here O
denotes O
the O
imaginary O
component O
of O
the O
cross-spectrum O
. O

E O
{ O
· O
} O
is O
the O
expected O
value O
operator O
and O
sgn O
indicates O
the O
sign O
of O
. O

is O
the O
magnitude O
. O

Phase O
synchronization O
was O
computed O
with O
0.5Hz O
frequency O
resolution O
for O
frequencies O
from O
1 O
to O
50Hz O
for O
all O
channel O
pairs O
on O
the O
scalp O
. O

For O
statistical O
testing O
in O
functional O
connectivity O
, O
we O
used O
the O
circular O
block O
bootstrapping O
to O
preserve O
temporal O
dependencies O
in O
the O
time O
series O
. O

Block-length O
for O
each O
calculation O
was O
determined O
by O
a O
block-length O
algorithm O
. O

Each O
trial O
was O
resampled O
using O
the O
circular O
block O
bootstrapping O
with O
defined O
block-length O
. O

After O
constructing O
this O
surrogate O
data O
in O
this O
way O
up O
to O
1000 O
times O
, O
only O
statistically O
significant O
WPLI O
values O
were O
extracted O
( O
p O
< O
0.05 O
) O
. O

Global O
functional O
connectivity O
was O
obtained O
by O
averaging O
of O
all O
WPLI O
values O
for O
all O
scalp O
channels O
at O
each O
frequency O
( O
0.5Hz O
bin O
) O
. O

The O
peak O
frequency O
was O
obtained O
by O
selecting O
a O
dominant O
peak O
in O
the O
frequency O
domain O
. O

In O
the O
auditory O
task O
, O
EEG O
data O
were O
epoched O
from O
−0.1 O
to O
0.5 O
seconds O
, O
resulting O
in O
200 O
trials O
of O
click-trains O
for O
each O
frequency O
( O
10 O
, O
20 O
, O
30 O
, O
40 O
and O
80Hz O
) O
. O

Each O
epoch O
was O
visually O
inspected O
in O
time-domain O
and O
noisy O
epochs O
( O
8.8±1.7 O
of O
200 O
trials O
) O
for O
all O
three O
conditions O
were O
removed O
. O

We O
found O
no O
significant O
difference O
of O
the O
rejected O
epochs O
between O
the O
three O
conditions O
( O
one-way O
ANOVA O
, O
F2,19=1.15 O
, O
p=0.33 O
) O
. O

Time-frequency O
analysis O
was O
performed O
using O
Morlet O
wavelet O
transform O
( O
7 O
cycles O
) O
. O

Amplitudes O
and O
phase O
information O
were O
obtained O
and O
inter-trial O
phase O
coherence O
( O
ITPC O
) O
of O
auditory O
steady-state O
response O
( O
ASSR O
) O
was O
computed O
using O
the O
phase O
information O
across O
trials O
as O
where O
Xe O
( O
c O
, O
f O
, O
t O
) O
is O
the O
spectral O
estimate O
of O
epoch O
e O
at O
channel O
c O
, O
frequency O
f O
, O
and O
time O
t O
( O
n O
=total O
number O
of O
epochs O
) O
. O

We O
followed O
the O
same O
statistical O
approach O
with O
the O
resting-state O
EEG O
data O
and O
set O
averaged O
ITPC O
over O
significant O
activation O
regions O
by O
the O
auditory O
click-trains O
as O
a O
dependent O
variable O
. O

The O
topographical O
distribution O
of O
ITPC O
was O
computed O
by O
averaging O
from O
0 O
to O
0.5 O
seconds O
( O
stimulus O
duration O
) O
at O
each O
click-trains O
frequency O
. O

Post-hoc O
tests O
were O
performed O
using O
student O
’ O
s O
t-test O
across O
participant O
at O
each O
EEG O
channel O
. O

Brain O
connectivity O
alterations O
in O
early O
psychosis O
: O
from O
clinical O
to O
neuroimaging O
staging O
Early O
in O
the O
course O
of O
psychosis O
, O
alterations O
in O
brain O
connectivity O
accompany O
the O
emergence O
of O
psychiatric O
symptoms O
and O
cognitive O
impairments O
, O
including O
processing O
speed O
. O

The O
clinical-staging O
model O
is O
a O
refined O
form O
of O
diagnosis O
that O
places O
the O
patient O
along O
a O
continuum O
of O
illness O
conditions O
, O
which O
allows O
stage-specific O
interventions O
with O
the O
potential O
of O
improving O
patient O
care O
and O
outcome O
. O

This O
cross-sectional O
study O
investigates O
brain O
connectivity O
features O
that O
characterize O
the O
clinical O
stages O
following O
a O
first O
psychotic O
episode O
. O

Structural O
brain O
networks O
were O
derived O
from O
diffusion-weighted O
MRI O
for O
71 O
early-psychosis O
patients O
and O
76 O
healthy O
controls O
. O

Patients O
were O
classified O
into O
stage O
II O
( O
first-episode O
) O
, O
IIIa O
( O
incomplete O
remission O
) O
, O
IIIb O
( O
one O
relapse O
) O
, O
and O
IIIc O
( O
two O
or O
more O
relapses O
) O
, O
according O
to O
the O
course O
of O
the O
illness O
until O
the O
time O
of O
scanning O
. O

Brain O
connectivity O
measures O
and O
diffusion O
parameters O
( O
fractional O
anisotropy O
, O
apparent O
diffusion O
coefficient O
) O
were O
investigated O
using O
general O
linear O
models O
and O
sparse O
linear O
discriminant O
analysis O
( O
sLDA O
) O
, O
studying O
distinct O
subgroups O
of O
patients O
who O
were O
at O
specific O
stages O
of O
early O
psychosis O
. O

We O
found O
that O
brain O
connectivity O
impairments O
were O
more O
severe O
in O
clinical O
stages O
following O
the O
first-psychosis O
episode O
( O
stages O
IIIa O
, O
IIIb O
, O
IIIc O
) O
than O
in O
first-episode O
psychosis O
( O
stage O
II O
) O
patients O
. O

These O
alterations O
were O
spatially O
diffuse O
but O
converged O
on O
a O
set O
of O
vulnerable O
regions O
, O
whose O
inter-connectivity O
selectively O
correlated O
with O
processing O
speed O
in O
patients O
and O
controls O
. O

The O
sLDA O
suggested O
that O
relapsing-remitting O
( O
stages O
IIIb O
, O
IIIc O
) O
and O
non-remitting O
( O
stage O
IIIa O
) O
patients O
are O
characterized O
by O
distinct O
dysconnectivity O
profiles O
. O

Our O
results O
indicate O
that O
neuroimaging O
markers O
of O
brain O
dysconnectivity O
in O
early O
psychosis O
may O
reflect O
the O
heterogeneity O
of O
the O
illness O
and O
provide O
a O
connectomics O
signature O
of O
the O
clinical-staging O
model O
. O

Materials O
and O
methods O
Subjects O
A O
total O
of O
147 O
subjects O
( O
71 O
early-psychosis O
patients O
( O
EPPs O
) O
and O
76 O
healthy O
controls O
( O
HCs O
) O
) O
were O
included O
in O
this O
cross-sectional O
study O
( O
Table O
1 O
) O
. O

The O
71 O
EPPs O
( O
49 O
males O
, O
26.0 O
± O
6.2yo O
) O
were O
recruited O
from O
an O
early O
intervention O
program O
( O
Treatment O
and O
Early O
Intervention O
in O
Psychosis O
Program O
( O
TIPP O
) O
) O
of O
the O
Lausanne O
University O
Hospital O
, O
Switzerland O
. O

The O
entry O
criteria O
into O
the O
TIPP O
were O
the O
following O
: O
between O
18 O
and O
35 O
years O
of O
age O
; O
residence O
in O
the O
catchment O
area O
; O
and O
meeting O
the O
threshold O
criteria O
for O
psychosis O
according O
to O
CAARMS O
psychosis-threshold O
subscale O
. O

A O
total O
of O
76 O
age O
, O
gender O
and O
handedness-matched O
HCs O
( O
48 O
males O
, O
26.7 O
± O
6.1yo O
) O
were O
recruited O
from O
the O
same O
catchment O
area O
; O
they O
were O
not O
affected O
by O
any O
mood O
, O
psychotic O
or O
substance-use O
disorder O
and O
had O
no O
first-degree O
relative O
with O
a O
psychotic O
disorder O
. O

A O
history O
of O
neurological O
disorder O
, O
severe O
head O
trauma O
or O
mental O
retardation O
( O
IQ O
< O
70 O
) O
were O
exclusion O
criteria O
for O
all O
subjects O
. O

All O
of O
the O
participants O
provided O
informed O
written O
consent O
for O
this O
study O
, O
and O
the O
procedure O
was O
approved O
by O
the O
Ethics O
Committee O
of O
Clinical O
Research O
of O
the O
Faculty O
of O
Biology O
and O
Medicine O
, O
University O
of O
Lausanne O
, O
Switzerland O
. O

Clinical O
staging O
The O
clinical O
stage O
was O
rated O
as O
the O
highest O
stage O
achieved O
at O
the O
time O
of O
imaging O
. O

The O
patients O
were O
stratified O
into O
four O
distinct O
groups O
( O
stages O
II O
and O
IIIa-c O
( O
Fig O
. O

1 O
) O
) O
based O
on O
a O
consensus O
assessment O
by O
two O
experienced O
psychiatrists O
, O
according O
to O
the O
clinical-staging O
model O
proposed O
by O
McGorry O
and O
colleagues O
. O

Any O
unclear O
issue O
was O
discussed O
with O
the O
case-managers O
. O

The O
subjects O
in O
stage O
II O
were O
first-episode O
psychosis O
patients O
, O
with O
one O
psychotic O
episode O
according O
to O
the O
CAARMS O
psychosis-threshold O
subscale O
and O
no O
past O
episodes O
at O
the O
time O
of O
the O
study O
( O
i.e. O
, O
discrete O
disorder O
) O
. O

Patients O
in O
stage O
III O
were O
defined O
as O
follows O
: O
IIIa O
: O
incomplete O
remission O
from O
stage O
II O
at O
12 O
months O
after O
entry O
to O
care O
and O
following O
a O
reasonable O
course O
of O
treatment O
( O
> O
3 O
months O
) O
, O
with O
duration O
of O
illness O
no O
longer O
than O
5 O
years O
; O
IIIb O
: O
recurrence O
or O
relapse O
of O
a O
psychotic O
episode O
( O
i.e. O
, O
discrete O
disorder O
has O
fully O
recovered O
but O
then O
relapsed O
to O
the O
full O
extent O
described O
in O
stage O
II O
) O
; O
IIIc O
: O
two O
or O
more O
relapses O
after O
stage O
II O
with O
remission O
between O
episodes O
. O

Further O
details O
on O
the O
patients O
’ O
assessment O
can O
be O
found O
in O
SI.1 O
. O

Other O
clinical O
and O
cognitive O
assessments O
In O
patients O
, O
the O
symptoms O
severity O
was O
assessed O
with O
the O
Positive O
and O
Negative O
Syndrome O
Scale O
( O
PANSS O
) O
, O
and O
the O
functioning O
level O
was O
assessed O
with O
the O
Global O
Assessment O
of O
Functioning O
( O
GAF O
) O
scale O
. O

For O
each O
patient O
, O
a O
consensus O
diagnosis O
was O
realized O
by O
a O
senior O
psychiatrist O
and O
a O
senior O
psychologist O
in O
charge O
of O
scale-based O
assessment O
over O
the O
treatment O
period O
, O
based O
on O
DSM-IV O
criteria O
. O

The O
levels O
of O
cannabis O
and O
alcohol O
use O
were O
assessed O
with O
the O
Case O
Manager O
Rating O
Scale O
( O
CMRS O
) O
and O
ranked O
as O
none O
, O
mild O
, O
moderate O
, O
severe O
or O
extremely O
severe O
. O

None O
of O
the O
patients O
had O
extremely O
sever O
level O
of O
cannabis O
or O
alcohol O
use O
. O

Antipsychotic O
doses O
were O
converted O
to O
chlorpromazine O
equivalents O
. O

All O
of O
the O
subjects O
were O
assessed O
with O
the O
MATRICS O
Consensus O
Cognitive O
Battery O
. O

MRI O
measurements O
and O
connectome O
reconstruction O
Each O
subject O
underwent O
an O
MR-imaging O
session O
on O
a O
3-Tesla O
Siemens O
scanner O
, O
including O
magnetization-prepared O
rapid O
acquisition O
gradient O
echo O
( O
MPRAGE O
) O
sequence O
( O
1-mm O
in-plane O
resolution O
, O
1.2-mm O
slice O
thickness O
) O
and O
diffusion O
spectrum O
imaging O
( O
DSI O
) O
sequences O
( O
257 O
diffusion-weighted O
volumes O
and O
1 O
b0 O
volume O
, O
maximum O
b-value O
8000 O
s/mm2 O
, O
2.2 O
× O
2.2 O
× O
3 O
mm3 O
resolution O
) O
. O

During O
the O
study O
, O
there O
was O
a O
routine O
MRI-system O
upgrade O
from O
the O
MAGNETOM-Trio O
to O
the O
MAGNETOM-Prisma O
Siemens O
system O
. O

Imaging O
parameters O
were O
precisely O
matched O
before O
and O
after O
the O
upgrade O
, O
and O
the O
same O
32-channel O
head O
coil O
was O
used O
. O

Individual O
connectomes O
were O
estimated O
by O
combining O
MPRAGE O
and O
DSI O
data O
. O

Briefly O
, O
MPRAGE O
volumes O
were O
segmented O
into O
WM O
, O
GM O
and O
cerebrospinal O
fluid O
compartments O
. O

The O
GM O
was O
parcellated O
into O
82 O
( O
68 O
cortical O
and O
14 O
subcortical O
) O
regions O
based O
on O
the O
Desikan-Killiany O
atlas O
. O

Reconstructed O
DSI-data O
were O
used O
to O
compute O
generalized O
fractional O
anisotropy O
( O
gFA O
) O
and O
apparent O
diffusion O
coefficient O
( O
ADC O
) O
scalar O
maps O
, O
and O
for O
deterministic O
streamline O
tractography O
. O

The O
structural O
connectivity O
between O
each O
pair O
of O
cortical O
and O
subcortical O
regions O
was O
quantified O
as O
the O
number O
of O
streamlines O
connecting O
the O
two O
regions O
, O
which O
resulted O
in O
82-nodes O
, O
weighted O
undirected O
brain-networks O
. O

For O
consistency O
reasons O
and O
to O
limit O
possible O
biases O
in O
the O
network O
analyses O
, O
connections O
that O
were O
present O
in O
less O
than O
50 O
% O
of O
the O
subjects O
were O
discarded O
. O

Further O
details O
regarding O
MRI O
acquisitions O
’ O
parameters O
, O
data O
processing O
and O
connectome O
reconstruction O
can O
be O
found O
in O
the O
SI.2 O
, O
SI.3 O
. O

Brain O
connectivity O
measures O
Global O
and O
nodal O
( O
i.e. O
, O
specific O
to O
single O
brain O
regions O
) O
connectivity O
measures O
were O
considered O
. O

The O
overall O
brain O
network O
strength O
was O
quantified O
as O
the O
total O
streamline O
count O
in O
the O
network O
. O

The O
centrality O
of O
each O
brain O
region O
in O
the O
network O
was O
quantified O
with O
the O
nodal O
strength O
, O
which O
was O
defined O
as O
the O
weighted O
sum O
of O
the O
node O
’ O
s O
connections O
. O

Tract-average O
gFA O
and O
ADC O
values O
were O
computed O
for O
each O
connection O
of O
individual O
brain O
networks O
. O

gFA O
and O
ADC O
values O
relate O
to O
organizational O
and O
microstructural O
properties O
of O
the O
WM O
, O
including O
myelination O
levels O
, O
axonal O
packing O
and O
fibre O
coherence O
. O

The O
network O
efficiency O
and O
clustering O
coefficient O
were O
investigated O
in O
supplementary O
analyses O
( O
SI.8 O
, O
Figure O
S4−S5 O
) O
. O

Statistical O
methods O
Statistical O
differences O
between O
the O
subjects O
’ O
groups O
were O
assessed O
with O
multi-factor O
ANCOVA O
within O
a O
general O
linear O
model O
( O
GLM O
) O
framework O
. O

Age O
, O
gender O
, O
handedness O
and O
a O
‘ O
scanner-upgrade O
’ O
variable O
were O
added O
as O
co-variates O
in O
all O
of O
the O
analyses O
. O

Global O
network O
analyses O
were O
repeated O
on O
data O
acquired O
on O
the O
MAGNETOM-Trio O
or O
on O
the O
MAGNETOM-Prisma O
system O
only O
to O
further O
exclude O
major O
effects O
of O
the O
scanner O
upgrade O
on O
the O
results O
. O

The O
effect O
size O
was O
quantified O
with O
the O
Cohen O
’ O
s O
d O
coefficient O
between O
GLM O
residual O
distributions O
, O
after O
correcting O
for O
covariates O
. O

Continuous O
variables O
’ O
cross-group O
progression O
was O
tested O
with O
the O
Jonckheere-Terpstra O
( O
JT O
) O
test O
for O
ordered O
alternative O
hypotheses O
. O

The O
false O
discovery O
rate O
correction O
for O
multiple O
comparisons O
was O
applied O
when O
indicated O
. O

Logistic O
regression O
was O
used O
to O
assess O
the O
cognitive O
impairments O
( O
MATRICS O
scores O
) O
of O
patients O
with O
respect O
to O
healthy O
controls O
( O
see O
SI.4 O
) O
. O

Relationships O
between O
neuroimaging O
and O
clinical/cognitive O
variables O
were O
assessed O
with O
Pearson O
’ O
s O
correlation O
coefficient O
( O
r O
) O
. O

A O
sparse O
linear O
discriminant O
analysis O
( O
sLDA O
) O
on O
nodal O
strength O
values O
was O
performed O
on O
patients O
only O
to O
investigate O
whether O
distinct O
brain O
connectivity O
features O
can O
be O
associated O
with O
distinct O
clinical O
stages O
. O

Leave-one-out O
cross O
validation O
( O
LOOCV O
) O
error O
and O
inter-class O
distances O
in O
the O
sLDA O
feature O
space O
were O
used O
as O
indicators O
of O
classes O
’ O
separability O
. O

In O
these O
analyses O
, O
sLDA O
was O
meant O
to O
explore O
the O
neuroimaging O
patterns O
characterizing O
the O
different O
early-psychosis O
stages O
, O
and O
not O
to O
generalize O
to O
a O
prediction O
setting O
. O

For O
further O
details O
see O
SI.5 O
, O
Figure O
S1 O
. O

Functional O
Connectivity O
in O
Distinct O
Cognitive O
Subtypes O
in O
Psychosis O
Background O
: O
Cognitive O
dysfunction O
is O
common O
in O
psychotic O
disorders O
, O
and O
may O
reflect O
underlying O
pathophysiology O
. O

However O
, O
substantial O
cognitive O
heterogeneity O
exists O
both O
within O
and O
between O
diagnostic O
categories O
, O
creating O
challenges O
for O
studying O
the O
neurobiology O
of O
cognitive O
dysfunction O
in O
patients O
. O

The O
aim O
of O
this O
study O
was O
to O
identify O
patients O
with O
psychosis O
with O
intact O
versus O
impaired O
cognitive O
profiles O
, O
and O
to O
examine O
resting O
state O
functional O
connectivity O
between O
patient O
groups O
and O
compared O
to O
healthy O
controls O
to O
determine O
the O
extent O
to O
which O
patterns O
of O
connectivity O
are O
overlapping O
or O
distinct O
. O

Methods O
: O
Participants O
with O
affective O
or O
non-affective O
psychosis O
( O
n=120 O
) O
and O
healthy O
controls O
( O
n=31 O
) O
were O
administered O
the O
MATRICS O
Consensus O
Cognitive O
Battery O
, O
clinical O
and O
community O
functioning O
assessments O
, O
and O
an O
fMRI O
scan O
to O
measure O
resting O
state O
functional O
connectivity O
( O
RSFC O
) O
. O

Cognitive O
composite O
scores O
were O
used O
to O
identify O
groups O
of O
patients O
with O
and O
without O
cognitive O
dysfunction O
. O

RSFC O
was O
compared O
between O
groups O
of O
patients O
and O
healthy O
controls O
, O
controlling O
for O
demographic O
and O
clinical O
variables O
. O

Results O
: O
Both O
cognitively O
intact O
and O
cognitively O
impaired O
patients O
showed O
decreased O
intrinsic O
connectivity O
compared O
to O
controls O
in O
frontoparietal O
control O
( O
FPN O
) O
and O
motor O
networks O
. O

Patients O
with O
cognitive O
impairment O
showed O
additional O
reductions O
in O
FPN O
connectivity O
compared O
to O
patients O
with O
intact O
cognition O
, O
particularly O
in O
subnetwork O
A O
. O

Conclusions O
: O
We O
leveraged O
the O
heterogeneity O
in O
cognitive O
ability O
among O
patients O
with O
psychosis O
to O
disentangle O
the O
relative O
contributions O
of O
cognitive O
dysfunction O
and O
presence O
of O
an O
underlying O
psychotic O
illness O
using O
resting O
state O
functional O
connectivity O
. O

These O
findings O
suggest O
at O
least O
partially O
separable O
effects O
of O
presence O
of O
a O
psychotic O
disorder O
and O
neurocognitive O
impairment O
contributing O
to O
network O
dysconnectivity O
in O
psychosis O
. O

Materials O
and O
Materials O
Participants O
Participants O
with O
diagnoses O
of O
affective O
or O
non-affective O
psychosis O
( O
n=120 O
) O
and O
healthy O
controls O
( O
n=31 O
) O
were O
recruited O
through O
the O
Schizophrenia O
and O
Bipolar O
Disorder O
Program O
( O
SBDP O
) O
and O
via O
fliers O
posted O
at O
McLean O
Hospital O
. O

Participants O
were O
recruited O
in O
the O
context O
of O
several O
separate O
but O
related O
studies O
: O
1 O
) O
cognitive O
remediation O
in O
SZ O
or O
Bipolar O
Disorder O
( O
BD O
) O
( O
n= O
42 O
) O
, O
2 O
) O
neuroimaging O
( O
n=33 O
) O
, O
or O
3 O
) O
clinical O
characterization O
of O
psychosis O
( O
n=76 O
) O
. O

For O
subjects O
who O
participated O
in O
one O
of O
the O
cognitive O
remediation O
intervention O
studies O
, O
baseline O
cognitive O
and O
imaging O
data O
were O
used O
. O

Inclusion O
criteria O
included O
a O
DSM-IV O
diagnosis O
of O
SZ O
, O
Schizoaffective O
Disorder O
( O
SZA O
) O
, O
Schizophreniform O
Disorder O
, O
Psychosis O
NOS O
, O
BD O
I O
with O
psychosis O
, O
or O
MDD O
with O
psychosis O
, O
ages O
18 O
to O
65 O
. O

Exclusion O
criteria O
for O
all O
participants O
included O
history O
of O
head O
trauma O
with O
loss O
of O
consciousness O
, O
history O
of O
seizure O
, O
and O
current O
substance O
abuse O
or O
dependence O
. O

Healthy O
controls O
had O
no O
personal O
or O
first-degree O
family O
history O
of O
a O
psychiatric O
diagnosis O
, O
and O
no O
history O
of O
substance O
abuse O
or O
dependence O
. O

All O
procedures O
were O
approved O
by O
the O
McLean O
Hospital O
IRB O
. O

Materials O
Diagnosis O
was O
determined O
using O
the O
Structured O
Clinical O
Interview O
for O
DSM-IV O
( O
SCID-IV-TR O
) O
through O
patient O
interview O
, O
medical O
record O
review O
, O
and O
consultation O
with O
the O
participants O
’ O
treatment O
providers O
. O

Clinical O
assessment O
included O
the O
Young O
Mania O
Rating O
Scale O
( O
YMRS O
) O
, O
the O
Montgomery-Asberg O
Depression O
Rating O
Scale O
( O
MADRS O
) O
, O
and O
the O
Positive O
and O
Negative O
Syndrome O
Scale O
( O
PANSS O
) O
. O

Community O
functioning O
was O
measured O
using O
an O
abbreviated O
version O
of O
the O
Multnomah O
Community O
Ability O
Scale O
( O
MCAS O
) O
, O
as O
described O
by O
Lewandowski O
et O
al O
.. O
Premorbid O
IQ O
was O
measured O
with O
the O
North O
American O
Adult O
Reading O
Test O
( O
NAART O
) O
. O

Cognition O
was O
measured O
using O
the O
MATRICS O
Consensus O
Cognitive O
Battery O
( O
MCCB O
) O
. O

The O
MCCB O
is O
comprised O
of O
ten O
subtests O
that O
make O
up O
seven O
domain O
scores O
and O
a O
composite O
. O

Domains O
include O
: O
Speed O
of O
Processing O
( O
Trail O
Making O
Test O
A O
; O
Brief O
Assessment O
of O
Cognition O
in O
Schizophrenia O
: O
Symbol O
Coding O
; O
Category O
Fluency O
) O
; O
Attention/Vigilance O
( O
Continuous O
Performance O
Test O
: O
Identical O
Pairs O
) O
; O
Working O
Memory O
( O
Wechsler O
Memory O
Scale O
Spatial O
Span O
; O
Letter O
Number O
Span O
) O
; O
Visual O
Learning O
( O
Brief O
Visuospatial O
Memory O
Test O
) O
; O
Verbal O
Learning O
( O
Hopkins O
Verbal O
Learning O
Test O
) O
; O
Reasoning/Problem O
Solving O
( O
Neuropsychological O
Assessment O
Battery O
: O
Mazes O
) O
; O
and O
Social O
Cognition O
( O
Mayer-Salovey-Caruso O
Emotional O
Intelligence O
Test O
: O
Managing O
Emotions O
) O
. O

Subtest O
, O
domain O
, O
and O
composite O
scores O
are O
converted O
to O
T-scores O
based O
on O
MCCB O
age O
and O
gender O
adjusted O
norms O
. O

The O
MCCB O
takes O
approximately O
60-90 O
minutes O
to O
complete O
. O

Image O
Acquisition O
Details O
of O
image O
acquisition O
for O
the O
majority O
of O
participants O
have O
been O
described O
previously O
. O

Briefly O
, O
data O
were O
acquired O
using O
a O
Siemens O
3T O
Tim O
Trio O
scanner O
with O
a O
12-channel O
phased-array O
head O
coil O
. O

High-resolution O
, O
T1-weighted O
, O
multiecho O
, O
magnetization-prepared O
, O
gradient-echo O
structural O
images O
were O
collected O
. O

Functional O
data O
were O
collected O
with O
a O
gradient-echo O
echo O
planar O
imaging O
sequence O
to O
detect O
blood O
oxygenation O
level-dependent O
( O
BOLD O
) O
contrast O
. O

BOLD O
acquisition O
parameters O
for O
the O
three O
protocols O
combined O
in O
this O
analysis O
were O
as O
follows O
: O
( O
1 O
) O
TR O
= O
3000ms O
, O
TE O
= O
30ms O
, O
flip O
angle O
= O
85° O
, O
3×3×3mm O
voxels O
, O
72×72 O
matrix O
, O
FOV O
= O
216mm O
, O
47 O
interleaved O
axial O
slices O
with O
no O
gap O
, O
and O
duration O
= O
6.2 O
minutes O
( O
124 O
time O
points O
) O
; O
( O
2 O
) O
TR O
= O
2500ms O
, O
TE O
= O
24ms O
; O
flip O
angle O
= O
82° O
, O
3.5×3.5×3.5mm O
voxels O
, O
64×64 O
matrix O
, O
FOV O
= O
224mm O
, O
42 O
axial O
slices O
, O
and O
duration O
= O
10 O
minutes O
( O
240 O
time O
points O
) O
; O
and O
( O
3 O
) O
TR O
= O
2500ms O
, O
TE O
= O
30ms O
; O
flip O
angle O
= O
82° O
, O
3.5×3.5×3.5mm O
voxels O
, O
64×64 O
matrix O
, O
FOV O
= O
224mm O
, O
41 O
axial O
slices O
, O
and O
duration O
= O
6.67 O
minutes O
( O
160 O
time O
points O
) O
. O

An O
automated O
alignment O
procedure O
aligning O
whole O
brain O
coverage O
to O
the O
anterior O
commissure-posterior O
commissure O
was O
used O
for O
consistency O
across O
participants O
. O

One O
to O
two O
functional O
scans O
were O
acquired O
per O
participant O
, O
and O
we O
assessed O
mean O
estimates O
across O
scans O
in O
the O
case O
of O
two O
acquisitions O
. O

Procedure O
Neuropsychological O
, O
neuroimaging O
, O
and O
diagnostic O
data O
were O
collected O
in O
2–3 O
sessions O
. O

Patient-reported O
information O
regarding O
medication O
and O
dose O
was O
collected O
, O
and O
chlorpromazine O
equivalents O
( O
CPZ O
) O
were O
calculated O
using O
guidelines O
described O
by O
Baldessarini O
. O

During O
resting-state O
functional O
scans O
, O
participants O
were O
told O
to O
stay O
awake O
, O
remain O
still O
, O
keep O
their O
eyes O
open O
, O
and O
think O
of O
nothing O
in O
particular O
; O
no O
fixation O
marker O
was O
used O
. O

Participants O
were O
monitored O
with O
eye O
tracking O
to O
ensure O
that O
eyes O
remained O
open O
during O
the O
functional O
scan O
. O

Statistical O
Approach O
Cognitive O
groupings O
were O
determined O
using O
MCCB O
Composite O
scores O
, O
using O
a O
cutoff O
of O
MCCB O
Composite O
< O
−1.0SD O
to O
define O
a O
group O
characterized O
by O
impaired O
neuropsychological O
functioning O
( O
Impaired O
) O
, O
and O
MCCB O
Composite O
scores O
of O
> O
/=−.5SD O
to O
define O
a O
group O
characterized O
by O
intact O
neuropsychological O
functioning O
( O
Intact O
) O
. O

Similar O
strategies O
have O
been O
used O
in O
previous O
reports O
to O
identify O
more O
homogeneous O
groups O
of O
patients O
based O
on O
cognition O
. O

This O
approach O
was O
selected O
a O
) O
to O
create O
groups O
that O
were O
distinct O
from O
each O
other O
, O
and O
b O
) O
because O
cognitive O
scores O
within O
.5SD O
of O
the O
mean O
are O
generally O
considered O
to O
be O
within O
the O
normal O
range O
whereas O
scores O
< O
1.0SD O
below O
the O
mean O
are O
generally O
considered O
impaired O
, O
thereby O
creating O
conceptually O
meaningful O
groupings O
. O

Groups O
were O
compared O
on O
all O
MCCB O
domains O
scores O
using O
ANOVA O
; O
T-scores O
were O
reported O
for O
all O
MCCB O
variables O
. O

Groups O
were O
also O
compared O
on O
demographic O
and O
clinical O
variables O
using O
ANOVA O
or O
Chi2 O
as O
appropriate O
. O

Post-hoc O
paired O
t-tests O
were O
conducted O
for O
all O
significant O
ANOVA O
effects O
. O

All O
group O
comparisons O
of O
behavioral O
data O
were O
conducted O
using O
Bonferroni O
correction O
for O
multiple O
comparisons O
. O

The O
neuroimaging O
analytic O
approach O
has O
been O
described O
previously O
. O

Briefly O
, O
resting O
state O
fMRI O
data O
were O
preprocessed O
for O
fcMRI O
analysis O
and O
temporally O
filtered O
to O
retain O
frequencies O
below O
0.08 O
Hz O
. O

We O
regressed O
1 O
) O
six O
parameters O
obtained O
by O
correction O
for O
rigid O
body O
head O
motion O
, O
2 O
) O
the O
signal O
averaged O
over O
the O
whole O
brain O
, O
3 O
) O
the O
signal O
averaged O
over O
the O
ventricles O
, O
and O
4 O
) O
the O
signal O
averaged O
over O
the O
deep O
cerebral O
white O
matter O
. O

BOLD O
data O
were O
projected O
to O
the O
FreeSurfer O
( O
4.5.0 O
) O
cortical O
ribbon O
of O
each O
participant O
, O
and O
then O
assessed O
for O
correlation O
structure O
between O
122 O
surface-based O
regions O
of O
interest O
( O
sROIs O
, O
61 O
per O
hemisphere O
) O
derived O
from O
the O
Yeo O
et O
al O
. O

17-network O
parcellation O
, O
which O
is O
publicly O
available O
for O
download O
( O
https O
: O
//surfer.nmr.mgh.harvard.edu/fswiki/CorticalParcellation_Yeo2011 O
) O
. O

Specifically O
, O
we O
computed O
Pearson O
correlation O
coefficients O
between O
each O
regional O
fMRI O
time O
course O
, O
averaged O
across O
all O
vertices O
within O
the O
region O
, O
and O
the O
mean O
fMRI O
time O
course O
for O
every O
other O
region O
. O

The O
regional O
correlation O
values O
were O
z-transformed O
to O
approximate O
normality O
and O
then O
compared O
across O
the O
groups O
using O
ANOVA O
after O
linear O
regression O
of O
age O
, O
sex O
, O
and O
race O
. O

All O
tests O
were O
corrected O
for O
multiple O
comparisons O
using O
a O
false O
discovery O
rate O
( O
FDR O
) O
of O
q O
< O
0.05 O
, O
corresponding O
in O
this O
data O
set O
to O
− O
log O
P O
=1.411 O
FDR O
corrected O
. O

Association O
between O
Thalamocortical O
Functional O
Connectivity O
Abnormalities O
and O
Cognitive O
Deficits O
in O
Schizophrenia O
Cognitive O
deficits O
are O
considered O
a O
core O
component O
of O
schizophrenia O
and O
may O
predict O
functional O
outcome O
. O

However O
, O
the O
neural O
underpinnings O
of O
neuropsychological O
impairment O
remain O
to O
be O
fully O
elucidated O
. O

Data O
of O
59 O
schizophrenia O
patients O
and O
72 O
healthy O
controls O
from O
a O
public O
resting-state O
fMRI O
database O
was O
employed O
in O
our O
study O
. O

Measurement O
and O
Treatment O
Research O
to O
Improve O
Cognition O
in O
Schizophrenia O
( O
MATRICS O
) O
Battery O
was O
used O
to O
measure O
deficits O
of O
cognitive O
abilities O
in O
schizophrenia O
. O

Neural O
correlates O
of O
cognitive O
deficits O
in O
schizophrenia O
were O
examined O
by O
linear O
regression O
analysis O
of O
the O
thalamocortical O
network O
activity O
with O
scores O
of O
seven O
cognitive O
domains O
. O

We O
confirmed O
the O
combination O
of O
reduced O
prefrontal-thalamic O
connectivity O
and O
increased O
sensorimotor-thalamic O
connectivity O
in O
patients O
with O
schizophrenia O
. O

Correlation O
analysis O
with O
cognition O
revealed O
that O
in O
schizophrenia O
( O
1 O
) O
the O
thalamic O
functional O
connectivity O
in O
the O
bilateral O
pre- O
and O
postcentral O
gyri O
was O
negatively O
correlated O
with O
attention/vigilance O
and O
speed O
of O
processing O
( O
Pearson O
’ O
s O
r O
≤ O
−0.443 O
, O
p O
≤ O
0.042 O
, O
FWE O
corrected O
) O
, O
and O
positively O
correlated O
with O
patients O
’ O
negative O
symptoms O
( O
Pearson O
’ O
s O
r O
≥ O
0.375 O
, O
p O
≤ O
0.003 O
, O
FWE O
corrected O
) O
; O
( O
2 O
) O
the O
thalamic O
functional O
connectivity O
in O
the O
right O
cerebellum O
was O
positively O
correlated O
with O
speed O
of O
processing O
( O
Pearson O
’ O
s O
r O
= O
0.388 O
, O
p O
= O
0.01 O
, O
FWE O
corrected O
) O
. O

Our O
study O
demonstrates O
that O
thalamic O
hyperconnectivity O
with O
sensorimotor O
areas O
is O
related O
to O
the O
severity O
of O
cognitive O
deficits O
and O
clinical O
symptoms O
, O
and O
extends O
our O
understanding O
of O
the O
neural O
underpinnings O
of O
“ O
cognitive O
dysmetria O
” O
in O
schizophrenia O
. O

Methods O
Participants O
An O
open O
access O
resting-state O
fMRI O
dataset O
of O
schizophrenia O
patients O
and O
healthy O
subjects O
, O
formerly O
studied O
by O
different O
authors O
, O
was O
employed O
in O
our O
study O
. O

This O
publicly O
available O
dataset O
is O
maintained O
by O
the O
Center O
for O
Biomedical O
Research O
Excellence O
( O
COBRE O
, O
http O
: O
//fcon_1000.projects.nitrc.org/indi/retro/cobre.html O
) O
. O

Patients O
were O
recruited O
from O
the O
outpatient O
clinic O
at O
the O
University O
of O
New O
Mexico O
Health O
Sciences O
Center O
. O

A O
psychiatrist O
made O
judgments O
about O
whether O
patients O
were O
clinically O
stable O
and O
appropriate O
for O
the O
study O
. O

Participants O
were O
administered O
the O
Structured O
Clinical O
Interview O
for O
the O
Diagnostic O
and O
Statistical O
Manual O
of O
Mental O
Disorders O
, O
4th O
edition O
( O
DSM-IV O
SCID–Clinician O
Version O
) O
by O
a O
trained O
research O
assistant O
, O
and O
the O
interview O
process O
was O
supervised O
by O
either O
F. O
M. O
Hanlon O
or O
J. O
R. O
Bustillo O
. O

The O
patients O
’ O
exclusion O
criteria O
were O
as O
follows O
: O
history O
of O
neurological O
disorder O
, O
mental O
retardation O
, O
severe O
head O
trauma O
with O
more O
than O
5-minute O
loss O
of O
consciousness O
, O
and O
substance O
abuse O
or O
dependence O
within O
the O
last O
12 O
months O
. O

The O
controls O
’ O
exclusion O
criterion O
was O
having O
any O
psychiatric O
dysfunction O
. O

Informed O
consent O
was O
obtained O
from O
all O
subjects O
, O
according O
to O
institutional O
guidelines O
required O
by O
the O
Institutional O
Review O
Board O
at O
the O
University O
of O
New O
Mexico O
. O

All O
experiments O
were O
performed O
in O
accordance O
with O
relevant O
guidelines O
and O
regulations O
. O

Neuropsychological O
Measures O
Premorbid O
intelligence O
was O
assessed O
by O
the O
Wechsler O
Test O
of O
Adult O
Reading O
( O
WTAR O
) O
and O
intellectual O
functioning O
was O
assessed O
by O
the O
Wechsler O
Abbreviated O
Scale O
of O
Intelligence O
( O
WASI O
) O
, O
a O
short O
and O
reliable O
measure O
of O
intelligence O
. O

Of O
the O
WASI O
subtests O
, O
the O
Vocabulary O
and O
Similarities O
tests O
were O
used O
to O
estimate O
verbal O
IQ O
( O
VIQ O
) O
, O
Block O
Design O
and O
Matrix O
Reasoning O
were O
used O
to O
estimate O
performance O
IQ O
( O
PIQ O
) O
, O
and O
full-scale O
IQ O
( O
FSIQ O
) O
was O
computed O
by O
averaging O
the O
PIQ O
and O
VIQ O
scores O
. O

The O
MATRICS O
consensus O
cognitive O
battery O
consists O
of O
seven O
separable O
factors O
, O
including O
attention/vigilance O
, O
problem O
solving O
, O
speed O
of O
processing O
, O
social O
cognition O
, O
verbal O
learning O
, O
visual O
learning O
, O
and O
working O
memory O
. O

Here O
, O
t-scores O
were O
used O
for O
MATRICS O
, O
and O
lower O
scores O
indicated O
greater O
impairments O
in O
cognitive O
functions O
. O

Additionally O
, O
patients O
were O
also O
assessed O
with O
the O
Positive O
and O
Negative O
Syndrome O
Scale O
( O
PANSS O
) O
to O
quantify O
the O
severity O
of O
psychosis O
symptoms O
. O

fMRI O
Data O
Acquisition O
and O
Preprocessing O
The O
subjects O
underwent O
resting-state O
scans O
in O
a O
3-T O
SIEMENS O
MRI O
scanner O
with O
the O
following O
parameters O
: O
33 O
axial O
slices O
, O
repetition O
time O
= O
2000 O
ms O
, O
echo O
time O
= O
29 O
ms O
, O
flip O
angle O
= O
75° O
, O
slice O
thickness O
= O
3.5 O
mm O
, O
slice O
gap O
= O
1.05 O
mm O
, O
acquisition O
matrix O
= O
64 O
× O
64 O
, O
field O
of O
view O
= O
240 O
mm O
. O

The O
total O
scan O
lasted O
5 O
min O
, O
and O
150 O
volumes O
of O
functional O
images O
were O
obtained O
. O

More O
information O
about O
the O
data O
acquisition O
can O
be O
found O
at O
http O
: O
//coins.mrn.org/dx O
. O

Data O
preprocessing O
was O
performed O
using O
SPM8 O
software O
( O
Wellcome O
Department O
of O
Imaging O
Neuroscience O
, O
University O
College O
London O
, O
UK O
; O
http O
: O
//www.fil.ion.ucl.ac.uk/spm O
) O
. O

Prior O
to O
preprocessing O
, O
the O
first O
5 O
volumes O
of O
each O
scan O
were O
discarded O
due O
to O
magnetic O
saturation O
. O

Images O
were O
normalized O
to O
the O
standard O
EPI O
template O
in O
the O
MNI O
space O
and O
were O
resliced O
to O
3 O
× O
3 O
× O
3 O
mm3 O
. O

The O
resulting O
images O
were O
spatially O
smoothed O
with O
a O
Gaussian O
filter O
of O
6 O
mm O
full-width O
half-maximum O
kernel O
. O

For O
functional O
connectivity O
analyses O
, O
several O
additional O
de-noising O
steps O
were O
conducted O
to O
reduce O
spurious O
variance O
that O
was O
unlikely O
to O
reflect O
neuronal O
activity O
. O

These O
steps O
included O
: O
( O
1 O
) O
removal O
of O
nuisance O
signals O
from O
the O
data O
via O
multiple O
regression O
, O
including O
signals O
averaged O
from O
white O
matter O
, O
cerebrospinal O
fluid O
, O
and O
the O
whole O
brain O
, O
and O
the O
six O
parameters O
obtained O
by O
head O
motion O
correction O
, O
( O
2 O
) O
temporal O
filtering O
with O
a O
band-pass O
filter O
( O
0.01–0.1 O
Hz O
) O
, O
and O
( O
3 O
) O
linear O
detrending O
to O
remove O
any O
residual O
drift O
. O

Head O
motion O
has O
been O
increasingly O
found O
to O
be O
a O
serious O
factor O
that O
confounds O
estimation O
of O
functional O
connectivity O
. O

Here O
, O
we O
used O
the O
artifact O
detection O
tool O
( O
ART O
; O
http O
: O
//www.nitrc.org/projects/artifact_detect O
) O
to O
identify O
motion O
outliers O
. O

An O
image O
was O
defined O
as O
an O
outlier O
if O
the O
absolute O
head O
motion O
was O
> O
1 O
mm O
from O
previous O
scan O
, O
or O
if O
the O
scan-to-scan O
global O
signal O
change O
was O
> O
3 O
standard O
deviations O
of O
the O
global O
brain O
signal O
for O
the O
entire O
resting O
scan O
. O

Subjects O
with O
serious O
head O
motion O
( O
> O
20 O
% O
outlier O
volumes O
) O
were O
excluded O
from O
this O
study O
, O
leaving O
a O
final O
sample O
of O
72 O
healthy O
subjects O
and O
59 O
schizophrenia O
patients O
. O

Outliers O
in O
the O
global O
mean O
signal O
intensity O
and O
motion O
were O
scrubbed O
by O
including O
them O
as O
nuisance O
regressors O
( O
i.e O
. O

one O
regressor O
per O
outlier O
) O
during O
the O
de-noising O
procedure O
. O

After O
scrubbing O
, O
residual O
head O
motion O
was O
still O
significantly O
different O
between O
groups O
( O
control O
: O
0.25 O
± O
0.11 O
mm O
; O
patient O
: O
0.30 O
± O
0.13 O
mm O
; O
two-sample O
t-test O
, O
p O
= O
0.024 O
) O
. O

To O
minimize O
potential O
bias O
caused O
by O
subtle O
motion O
, O
residual O
head O
motion O
was O
included O
as O
a O
nuisance O
covariate O
in O
the O
statistical O
comparisons O
. O

Functional O
connectivity O
analysis O
First O
, O
we O
compared O
functional O
connectivity O
between O
anatomically O
defined O
cortical O
ROIs O
and O
functionally O
defined O
thalamic O
ROIs O
across O
groups O
. O

As O
described O
previously O
, O
the O
cortex O
was O
divided O
into O
six O
non-overlapping O
ROIs O
corresponding O
to O
the O
main O
targets O
of O
specific O
thalamic O
nuclei O
( O
the O
PFC O
, O
motor O
cortex O
, O
somatosensory O
cortex O
, O
posterior O
parietal O
cortex O
, O
temporal O
lobe O
and O
occipital O
lobe O
) O
. O

The O
cortical O
ROI O
and O
thalamus O
masks O
were O
separately O
defined O
in O
standard O
MNI O
space O
by O
using O
the O
Harvard-Oxford O
cortical O
and O
subcortical O
probabilistic O
atlases O
in O
FSL O
( O
http O
: O
//fsl.fmrib.ox.ac.uk/fsl/fslwiki/Atlases O
) O
. O

A O
25 O
% O
threshold O
was O
applied O
to O
these O
atlases O
to O
avoid O
partial O
inclusion O
of O
neighboring O
ventricles O
. O

Figure O
2A O
shows O
the O
six O
cortical O
ROI O
masks O
, O
which O
are O
equivalent O
to O
those O
used O
in O
Woodward O
et O
al O
.. O

The O
Pearson O
’ O
s O
correlation O
coefficient O
was O
then O
computed O
between O
the O
average O
BOLD O
signals O
from O
each O
of O
the O
cortical O
ROIs O
and O
BOLD O
signals O
from O
every O
voxel O
in O
the O
thalamus O
. O

Fisher O
’ O
s O
z-transformation O
was O
applied O
to O
the O
correlation O
values O
to O
ensure O
normality O
. O

Based O
on O
the O
entire O
dataset O
of O
131 O
subjects O
, O
functional O
thalamic O
subdivision O
was O
created O
using O
the O
winner-takes-all O
strategy O
, O
in O
which O
each O
thalamic O
voxel O
was O
labeled O
according O
to O
the O
cortical O
ROI O
with O
the O
highest O
connectivity O
strength O
. O

For O
each O
participant O
, O
six O
thalamocortical O
network O
values O
were O
calculated O
by O
averaging O
connectivity O
strength O
of O
the O
voxels O
within O
each O
thalamic O
functional O
ROI O
with O
its O
respective O
cortical O
ROI O
, O
which O
served O
as O
the O
dependent O
variable O
in O
the O
cortical O
ROI-to-thalamic O
ROI O
analysis O
. O

Second O
, O
seed-based O
analyses O
examining O
connectivity O
of O
functionally O
defined O
thalamic O
subregions O
with O
the O
rest O
of O
the O
brain O
were O
performed O
to O
better O
localize O
thalamocortical O
network O
abnormalities O
in O
patients O
with O
schizophrenia O
. O

Briefly O
, O
for O
each O
subject O
and O
for O
each O
thalamic O
ROI O
, O
the O
correlation O
map O
was O
created O
by O
calculating O
the O
Pearson O
’ O
s O
correlation O
coefficients O
between O
the O
average O
BOLD O
signal O
of O
the O
thalamus O
ROI O
and O
BOLD O
signals O
of O
all O
voxels O
in O
the O
brain O
. O

These O
correlation O
maps O
were O
then O
converted O
to O
Z-value O
maps O
using O
Fisher O
’ O
s O
r-to-z O
transformation O
. O

Statistical O
analysis O
Behavioral O
data O
and O
cortical O
ROI-to-thalamic O
ROI O
functional O
connectivity O
data O
were O
compared O
between O
the O
control O
and O
schizophrenia O
groups O
using O
SPSS O
( O
version O
20 O
, O
IBM O
Inc O
, O
USA O
) O
. O

To O
reduce O
the O
number O
of O
false O
positive O
or O
Type O
I O
error O
, O
the O
results O
were O
considered O
significant O
at O
p O
< O
0.05 O
, O
Bonferroni O
corrected O
for O
multiple O
comparisons O
replaced O
the O
nominal O
significance O
level O
α O
with O
the O
level O
α/k O
for O
each O
test O
( O
k O
is O
the O
number O
of O
tests O
being O
performed O
) O
. O

Voxel-wise O
statistical O
analyses O
were O
carried O
out O
using O
the O
general O
linear O
model O
in O
SPM8 O
. O

First O
, O
correlation O
maps O
of O
control O
and O
schizophrenia O
subjects O
separately O
underwent O
a O
two-tailed O
, O
one-sample O
t-test O
, O
to O
determine O
brain O
regions O
with O
significant O
positive O
or O
negative O
correlations O
with O
each O
thalamic O
ROI O
. O

Then O
, O
a O
two-tailed O
, O
two-sample O
t-test O
was O
conducted O
to O
identify O
significant O
functional O
connectivity O
differences O
in O
the O
correlation O
maps O
of O
each O
thalamic O
ROI O
between O
the O
schizophrenia O
and O
control O
groups O
. O

The O
correlation O
analysis O
with O
the O
MATRICS O
domain O
scores O
across O
schizophrenia O
subjects O
was O
restricted O
to O
voxels O
within O
the O
masks O
, O
which O
were O
identified O
in O
the O
analysis O
between O
groups O
, O
to O
determine O
the O
association O
between O
thalamocortical O
functional O
connectivity O
abnormalities O
and O
cognitive O
deficits O
in O
schizophrenia O
. O

We O
also O
examined O
the O
correlations O
between O
thalamocortical O
functional O
connectivity O
and O
patients O
’ O
symptoms O
, O
including O
PANSS O
positive O
, O
negative O
and O
general O
. O

Each O
analysis O
was O
adjusted O
using O
nuisance O
covariates O
for O
age O
, O
sex O
and O
residual O
head O
motion O
. O

Duration O
of O
illness O
and O
CPZ O
equivalents O
were O
also O
used O
as O
nuisance O
covariates O
for O
the O
correlation O
analysis O
with O
cognition O
. O

The O
significance O
level O
was O
set O
at O
a O
cluster-level O
of O
p O
< O
0.05 O
, O
and O
data O
were O
corrected O
for O
multiple O
comparisons O
with O
the O
family O
wise O
error O
( O
FWE O
) O
and O
a O
voxel-level O
threshold O
of O
p O
< O
0.005 O
. O

Structural O
and O
Functional O
Neuroimaging O
of O
Polygenic O
Risk O
for O
Schizophrenia O
: O
A O
Recall-by-Genotype–Based O
Approach O
Abstract O
Risk O
profile O
scores O
( O
RPS O
) O
derived O
from O
genome-wide O
association O
studies O
( O
GWAS O
) O
explain O
a O
considerable O
amount O
of O
susceptibility O
for O
schizophrenia O
( O
SCZ O
) O
. O

However O
, O
little O
is O
known O
about O
how O
common O
genetic O
risk O
factors O
for O
SCZ O
influence O
the O
structure O
and O
function O
of O
the O
human O
brain O
, O
largely O
due O
to O
the O
constraints O
of O
imaging O
sample O
sizes O
. O

In O
the O
current O
study O
, O
we O
use O
a O
novel O
recall-by-genotype O
( O
RbG O
) O
methodological O
approach O
, O
where O
we O
sample O
young O
adults O
from O
a O
population O
cohort O
( O
Avon O
Longitudinal O
Study O
of O
Parents O
and O
Children O
: O
N O
genotyped O
= O
8365 O
) O
based O
on O
their O
SCZ-RPS O
. O

We O
compared O
197 O
healthy O
individuals O
at O
extremes O
of O
low O
( O
N O
= O
99 O
) O
or O
high O
( O
N O
= O
98 O
) O
SCZ-RPS O
with O
behavioral O
tests O
, O
and O
structural O
and O
functional O
magnetic O
resonance O
imaging O
( O
fMRI O
) O
. O

We O
first O
provide O
methodological O
details O
that O
will O
inform O
the O
design O
of O
future O
RbG O
studies O
for O
common O
SCZ O
genetic O
risk O
. O

We O
further O
provide O
an O
between O
group O
analysis O
of O
the O
RbG O
individuals O
( O
low O
vs O
high O
SCZ-RPS O
) O
who O
underwent O
structural O
neuroimaging O
data O
( O
T1—weighted O
scans O
) O
and O
fMRI O
data O
during O
a O
reversal O
learning O
task O
. O

While O
we O
found O
little O
evidence O
for O
morphometric O
differences O
between O
the O
low O
and O
high O
SCZ-RPS O
groups O
, O
we O
observed O
an O
impact O
of O
SCZ-RPS O
on O
blood O
oxygen O
level-dependent O
( O
BOLD O
) O
signal O
during O
reward O
processing O
in O
the O
ventral O
striatum O
( O
PFWE-VS-CORRECTED O
= O
.037 O
) O
, O
a O
previously O
investigated O
broader O
reward-related O
network O
( O
PFWE-ROIS-CORRECTED O
= O
.008 O
) O
, O
and O
across O
the O
whole O
brain O
( O
PFWE-WHOLE-BRAIN-CORRECTED O
= O
.013 O
) O
. O

We O
also O
describe O
the O
study O
strategy O
and O
discuss O
specific O
challenges O
of O
RbG O
for O
SCZ O
risk O
( O
such O
as O
SCZ-RPS O
related O
homoscedasticity O
) O
. O

This O
study O
will O
help O
to O
elucidate O
the O
behavioral O
and O
imaging O
phenotypes O
that O
are O
associated O
with O
SCZ O
genetic O
risk O
. O

Materials O
and O
Methods O
ALSPAC O
Participants O
The O
broader O
cohort O
sample O
from O
which O
we O
selected O
individuals O
consisted O
of O
young O
individuals O
recruited O
via O
the O
ALSPAC O
cohort O
. O

This O
broader O
cohort O
consisted O
of O
14062 O
children O
born O
to O
women O
residing O
in O
the O
former O
Avon O
Health O
Authority O
area O
with O
an O
expected O
delivery O
date O
from O
April O
1 O
, O
1991 O
to O
December O
31 O
, O
1992 O
( O
http O
: O
//www.bristol.ac.uk/alspac/ O
; O
available O
at O
http O
: O
//www.bristol.ac.uk/alspac/researchers/access/ O
) O
. O

Data O
were O
collected O
periodically O
from O
September O
6 O
, O
1990 O
, O
and O
collection O
is O
ongoing O
. O

Ethical O
approval O
for O

study O
was O
obtained O
from O
the O

and O

Committee O
and O
the O
local O

committees O
( O
listed O
at O

: O

) O
. O

ALSPAC O
Participant O
Genotyping O
All O
individuals O
recruited O
via O
the O
ALSPAC O
sample O
were O
genotyped O
using O
the O
Illumina O
HumanHap550 O
quad O
chip O
genotyping O
platforms O
by O
23andme O
subcontracting O
the O
Wellcome O
Trust O
Sanger O
Institute O
, O
Cambridge O
, O
UK O
and O
the O
Laboratory O
Corporation O
of O
America O
, O
Burlington O
, O
NC O
. O

The O
raw O
genome-wide O
data O
were O
subjected O
to O
standard O
quality O
control O
methods O
. O

Briefly O
, O
individuals O
were O
excluded O
on O
the O
basis O
of O
gender O
mismatches O
; O
minimal O
or O
excessive O
heterozygosity O
; O
disproportionate O
levels O
of O
individual O
missingness O
( O
> O
3 O
% O
) O
and O
insufficient O
sample O
replication O
( O
IBD O
< O
0.8 O
) O
. O

Population O
stratification O
was O
assessed O
by O
multidimensional O
scaling O
analysis O
and O
compared O
with O
Hapmap O
II O
( O
release O
22 O
) O
European O
descent O
( O
CEU O
) O
, O
Han O
Chinese O
, O
Japanese O
, O
and O
Yoruba O
reference O
populations O
; O
all O
individuals O
with O
non-European O
ancestry O
were O
removed O
. O

SNPs O
with O
a O
minor O
allele O
frequency O
of O
< O
1 O
% O
, O
a O
call O
rate O
of O
< O
95 O
% O
or O
evidence O
for O
violations O
of O
Hardy-Weinberg O
equilibrium O
( O
P O
< O
5E-7 O
) O
were O
removed O
. O

Cryptic O
relatedness O
was O
measured/excluded O
as O
proportion O
of O
identity O
by O
descent O
( O
IBD O
> O
0.1 O
) O
. O

Related O
subjects O
that O
passed O
all O
other O
quality O
control O
thresholds O
were O
retained O
during O
subsequent O
phasing O
and O
imputation O
. O

Nine O
thousand O
one O
hundred O
fifteen O
subjects O
and O
500527 O
SNPs O
passed O
these O
quality O
control O
filters O
. O

We O
combined O
477482 O
SNP O
genotypes O
in O
common O
between O
the O
sample O
of O
mothers O
and O
sample O
of O
children O
. O

We O
removed O
SNPs O
with O
genotype O
missingness O
above O
1 O
% O
due O
to O
poor O
quality O
( O
11396 O
SNPs O
removed O
) O
and O
removed O
a O
further O
321 O
subjects O
due O
to O
potential O
ID O
mismatches O
, O
resulting O
in O
a O
data O
set O
containing O
465740 O
SNPs O
. O

We O
estimated O
haplotypes O
using O
ShapeIT O
( O
v2.r644 O
) O
which O
utilizes O
relatedness O
during O
phasing O
. O

We O
obtained O
a O
phased O
version O
of O
the O
1000 O
genomes O
reference O
panel O
( O
phase O
1 O
, O
version O
3 O
) O
from O
the O
Impute2 O
reference O
data O
repository O
( O
phased O
using O
ShapeIt O
v2.r644 O
, O
haplotype O
release O
date O
Dec O
2013 O
) O
. O

Imputation O
of O
the O
target O
data O
was O
performed O
using O
Impute O
V2.2.2 O
against O
the O
reference O
panel O
( O
all O
polymorphic O
SNPs O
excluding O
singletons O
) O
, O
using O
all O
2186 O
reference O
haplotypes O
( O
including O
non-Europeans O
) O
. O

After O
quality O
control O
, O
a O
total O
of O
8365 O
individuals O
were O
genotyped O
and O
underwent O
SCZ-RPS O
calculations O
. O

ALSPAC O
Participant O
SCZ-RPS O
Creation O
Construction O
of O
the O
SCZ-RPS O
follows O
the O
methods O
described O
by O
the O
International O
Schizophrenia O
Consortium O
, O
using O
results O
from O
the O
Psychiatric O
Genomics O
Consortium O
( O
PGC O
) O
SCZ O
genome-wide O
association O
studies O
( O
GWAS O
) O
. O

Polygenic O
scores O
were O
calculated O
for O
each O
ALSPAC O
individual O
using O
the O
“ O
score O
” O
command O
in O
PLINK O
( O
version O
1.07 O
) O
. O

Individual O
SCZ-RPS O
were O
created O
by O
summing O
the O
number O
of O
risk O
alleles O
present O
for O
each O
SNP O
( O
0 O
, O
1 O
, O
or O
2 O
) O
weighted O
by O
the O
logarithm O
of O
each O
SNP O
’ O
s O
OR O
for O
SCZ O
from O
the O
PGC O
summary O
statistics O
for O
each O
individual O
. O

Our O
SCZ-RPS–based O
RbG O
was O
solely O
based O
upon O
a O
RPS O
generated O
from O
SNPs O
with O
a O
GWAS O
training-set O
P O
≤ O
. O

05 O
threshold O
, O
approximately O
5 O
% O
of O
all O
imputed O
SNPs O
. O

This O
threshold O
was O
specifically O
chosen O
as O
it O
captures O
the O
most O
SCZ O
liability O
( O
most O
variance O
explained O
) O
in O
the O
primary O
RPS O
analysis O
using O
training O
data/summary O
statistics O
derived O
from O
the O
largest O
SCZ O
GWAS O
of O
34241 O
SCZ O
cases O
and O
45604 O
controls O
. O

SCZ-RPS O
Stratification O
and O
Cardiff O
Subsample O
From O
the O
8365 O
individuals O
who O
were O
considered O
for O
SCZ-RPS O
calculation O
, O
a O
total O
of O
197 O
individuals O
( O
99 O
with O
low O
SCZ-RPS O
, O
98 O
with O
high O
SCZ-RPS O
) O
participated O
in O
a O
battery O
of O
psychometric/neuroimaging O
paradigms O
, O
previously O
linked O
to O
the O
etiology O
of O
SCZ O
. O

A O
further O
104 O
individuals O
declined O
our O
invitation O
( O
by O
written O
reply O
) O
to O
participate O
in O
the O
study O
( O
low O
SCZ-RPS O
[ O
n O
= O
40 O
] O
; O
high O
SCZ-RPS O
[ O
n O
= O
64 O
] O
) O
, O
conforming O
to O
prior O
observations O
that O
SCZ-RPS O
is O
related O
to O
nonparticipation O
. O

Researchers O
were O
blind O
to O
which O
tail O
of O
the O
SCZ-RPS O
distribution O
each O
individual O
was O
selected O
from O
during O
the O
data O
collection O
and O
processing O
. O

All O
participants O
provided O
written O
informed O
consent O
. O

The O
SCZ-RPS O
groups O
were O
matched O
for O
gender O
( O
low O
SCZ-RPS O
: O
52 O
female O
, O
47 O
male O
; O
high O
SCZ-RPS O
: O
52 O
female O
, O
46 O
male O
) O
. O

A O
Priori O
Power O
Analysis O
Using O
the O
RbG O
approach O
, O
we O
estimated O
we O
had O
> O
80 O
% O
power O
to O
detect O
an O
relatively O
small O
effect O
( O
R2 O
> O
.03 O
) O
, O
at O
a O
conservative O
alpha O
level O
( O
alpha O
> O
0.001 O
) O
; O
see O
supplementary O
methods O
S1 O
and O
supplementary O
figure O
S1 O
for O
further O
details O
. O

Psychotic O
Experiences O
and O
Cognition O
The O
semi-structured O
Psychosis-Like O
Symptom O
Interview O
was O
used O
to O
assess O
psychotic O
experiences O
( O
hallucinations O
, O
delusions O
, O
or O
experiences O
of O
thought O
interference O
) O
at O
18 O
years O
of O
age O
. O

Individuals O
were O
deemed O
to O
have O
a O
psychotic O
experience O
if O
rated O
as O
having O
1 O
or O
more O
suspected O
and/or O
definite O
psychotic O
experiences O
at O
18 O
years O
of O
age O
( O
pliks18 O
) O
. O

Individuals O
were O
administered O
the O
short O
form O
Wechsler O
Intelligence O
Scale O
for O
Children O
( O
WISC-III O
) O
at O
8 O
years O
of O
age O
. O

Scores O
for O
verbal O
, O
performance O
, O
and O
total O
IQ O
were O
taken O
forward O
for O
SCZ-RPS O
regression O
analysis O
. O

Statistical O
Analysis O
Associations O
between O
SCZ-RPS O
groups O
and O
psychotic O
experiences O
were O
explored O
using O
Firth O
’ O
s O
Bias-Reduced O
Logistic O
Regression O
via O
the O
logistf O
package O
in O
R. O
This O
approach O
computes O
confidence O
intervals O
computed O
by O
penalized O
profile O
likelihood O
to O
control O
for O
rare O
events O
. O

For O
WISC-III O
, O
Verbal O
, O
Performance O
, O
and O
Total O
IQ O
from O
the O
WISC O
were O
regressed O
against O
SCZ-RPS O
in O
a O
series O
of O
linear O
models O
. O

Gender O
was O
added O
into O
each O
model O
as O
a O
regressor O
in O
all O
cases O
. O

Structural O
Imaging O
Preprocessing O
and O
Analysis O
Structural O
brain O
scans O
were O
acquired O
for O
each O
individual O
using O
a O
3T O
GT O
HDx O
system O
at O
Cardiff O
University O
Brain O
Research O
Imaging O
Centre O
( O
CUBRIC O
) O
, O
School O
of O
Psychology O
, O
Cardiff O
University O
. O

High-resolution O
3-dimensional O
T1-weighted O
images O
were O
acquired O
using O
a O
3-dimensional O
fast O
spoiled O
gradient O
echo O
sequence O
( O
FSPGR O
) O
with O
contiguous O
sagittal O
slices O
of O
1 O
mm O
thickness O
( O
TR O
7.9 O
s O
, O
TE O
3.0 O
ms O
, O
TI O
450 O
ms O
, O
flip O
angle O
20° O
, O
FOV O
256 O
mm O
× O
256 O
mm O
× O
176 O
mm O
to O
yield O
1 O
mm O
isotropic O
voxel O
resolution O
images O
. O

Cortical O
and O
subcortical O
segmentations O
for O
each O
subject O
were O
estimated O
with O
well-validated O
segmentation O
software O
FreeSurfer O
version O
6.0 O
. O

In O
alignment O
with O
ENIGMA O
analysis O
strategies O
in O
SCZ O
and O
genomics O
, O
we O
explored O
( O
1 O
) O
subcortical O
volume O
( O
mm3 O
) O
( O
2 O
) O
cortical O
( O
a O
) O
thickness O
( O
mm O
) O
and O
( O
b O
) O
surface O
area O
( O
mm2 O
) O
. O

Segmentations O
of O
68 O
( O
34 O
left/right O
) O
cortical O
gray O
matter O
regions O
were O
created O
based O
on O
the O
Desikan–Killiany O
atlas O
and O
7 O
subcortical O
regions O
( O
as O
well O
as O
the O
hemispheric O
total O
intracranial O
volume O
, O
average O
cortical O
thickness O
, O
and O
surface O
area O
) O
. O

Segmented O
subcortical O
and O
cortical O
regions O
were O
visually O
inspected O
and O
statistically O
evaluated O
for O
outliers O
following O
standardized O
ENIGMA O
protocols O
( O
http O
: O
//enigma.ini.usc.edu/protocols/imaging-protocols O
) O
. O

For O
the O
statistical O
analysis O
, O
we O
averaged O
each O
segmentation/parcellation O
across O
hemispheres O
. O

Each O
ROI O
was O
regressed O
against O
SCZ-RPS O
group O
( O
low/high O
) O
with O
gender O
& O
ICV O
added O
as O
covariates O
. O

Age O
was O
not O
included O
as O
a O
covariate O
as O
all O
participants O
were O
born O
in O
the O
same O
year O
. O

Functional O
Imaging O
Acquisition O
and O
Preprocessing O
Gradient O
echoplanar O
imaging O
data O
were O
acquired O
for O
each O
subject O
on O
the O
same O
3T O
GT O
HDx O
system O
with O
an O
8-channel O
receiver O
at O
CUBRIC O
( O
Cardiff O
University O
Brain O
Research O
Imaging O
Centre O
) O
, O
School O
of O
Psychology O
, O
Cardiff O
University O
( O
parameters O
: O
35 O
slices O
, O
slice O
thickness O
; O
3 O
mm/1 O
mm O
gap O
, O
acquisition O
matrix O
; O
64 O
× O
64 O
; O
FOV O
; O
220 O
mm O
, O
TR O
2000 O
ms O
, O
TE O
35 O
ms O
, O
flip O
angle O
90° O
, O
acceleration O
[ O
ASSET O
] O
factor O
; O
2 O
) O
. O

All O
functional O
images O
were O
first O
motion O
scrubbed O
, O
where O
TRs O
with O
a O
frame O
wise O
displacement O
> O
0.9 O
were O
removed O
, O
as O
previously O
recommended O
. O

Image O
processing O
and O
statistical O
analyses O
were O
conducted O
using O
statistical O
parametric O
mapping O
methods O
as O
implemented O
in O
FMRI O
Expert O
Analysis O
Tool O
( O
FEAT O
, O
Version O
5.98 O
, O
part O
of O
FMRIB O
’ O
s O
Software O
Library O
, O
www.fmrib.ox.ac.uk/fsl O
) O
. O

The O
following O
prestatistics O
processing O
was O
applied O
; O
motion O
correction O
using O
MCFLIRT O
; O
slice-timing O
correction O
using O
Fourier-space O
time-series O
phase-shifting O
; O
nonbrain O
removal O
using O
BET O
( O
Brain O
Extraction O
Tool O
) O
spatial O
smoothing O
using O
a O
Gaussian O
kernel O
of O
FWHM O
5 O
mm O
; O
grand-mean O
intensity O
normalization O
of O
the O
entire O
4D O
data O
set O
by O
a O
single O
multiplicative O
factor O
; O
high-pass O
temporal O
filtering O
( O
Gaussian-weighted O
least-squares O
straight O
line O
fitting O
, O
with O
sigma O
= O
50.0 O
s O
) O
. O

Registration O
to O
high O
resolution O
structural O
( O
single O
subject O
general O
linear O
model O
[ O
GLM O
] O
) O
and O
standard O
space O
( O
group-level O
GLM O
) O
images O
was O
carried O
out O
using O
FLIRT O
. O

Time-series O
analysis O
was O
carried O
out O
using O
FMRIB O
’ O
s O
Improved O
Linear O
Model O
( O
FILM O
) O
with O
local O
autocorrelation O
correction O
. O

To O
further O
correct O
for O
any O
potential O
movement O
confounds O
, O
motion O
regressors O
were O
estimated O
via O
MCFLIRT O
and O
scrubbed O
TRs O
were O
added O
as O
covariates O
of O
no O
interest O
to O
each O
individual O
design O
matrix O
. O

After O
quality O
