functional O
connectivity O
is O
proposed O
to O
play O
a O
critical O
role O
in O
the O
development O
of O
psychotic O
symptoms O
. O

Previous O
resting-state O
functional O
magnetic O
resonance O
imaging O
( O
rs-fMRI O
) O
studies O
typically O
reported O
disrupted O
striatal O
connectivity O
in O
patients O
with O
psychosis O
and O
in O
individuals O
at O
clinical O
and O
genetic O
high O
risk O
of O
the O
disorder O
relative O
to O
healthy O
controls O
. O

This O
has O
not O
been O
widely O
studied O
in O
healthy O
individuals O
with O
subclinical O
psychotic-like O
experiences O
( O
schizotypy O
) O
. O

Here O
we O
applied O
the O
emerging O
technology O
of O
multi-echo O
rs-fMRI O
to O
examine O
corticostriatal O
connectivity O
in O
this O
group O
, O
which O
is O
thought O
to O
drastically O
maximize O
physiological O
noise O
removal O
and O
increase O
BOLD O
contrast-to-noise O
ratio O
. O

Multi-echo O
rs-fMRI O
data O
( O
echo O
times O
, O
12 O
, O
28 O
, O
44 O
, O
60 O
ms O
) O
were O
acquired O
from O
healthy O
individuals O
with O
low O
( O
LS O
, O
n O
= O
20 O
) O
and O
high O
( O
HS O
, O
n O
= O
19 O
) O
positive O
schizotypy O
as O
determined O
with O
the O
Oxford-Liverpool O
Inventory O
of O
Feelings O
and O
Experiences O
( O
O-LIFE O
) O
. O

After O
preprocessing O
to O
ensure O
optimal O
contrast O
and O
removal O
of O
non-BOLD O
signal O
components O
, O
whole-brain O
functional O
connectivity O
from O
six O
striatal O
seeds O
was O
compared O
between O
the O
HS O
and O
LS O
groups O
. O

Effects O
were O
considered O
significant O
at O
cluster-level O
p O
< O
.05 O
family-wise O
error O
correction O
. O

Compared O
to O
LS O
, O
HS O
subjects O
showed O
lower O
rs-fMRI O
connectivity O
between O
ventromedial O
prefrontal O
regions O
and O
ventral O
striatal O
regions O
. O

Lower O
connectivity O
was O
also O
observed O
between O
the O
dorsal O
putamen O
and O
the O
hippocampus O
, O
occipital O
regions O
, O
as O
well O
as O
the O
cerebellum O
. O

These O
results O
demonstrate O
that O
subclinical O
positive O
psychotic-like O
experiences O
in O
healthy O
individuals O
are O
associated O
with O
striatal O
hypoconnectivity O
as O
detected O
using O
multi-echo O
rs-fMRI O
. O

Further O
application O
of O
this O
approach O
may O
aid O
in O
characterizing O
functional O
connectivity O
abnormalities O
across O
the O
extended O
psychosis O
phenotype O
. O

Highlights O
Multi-echo O
fMRI O
was O
used O
to O
investigate O
resting-state O
connectivity O
in O
subjects O
with O
low O
and O
high O
psychometric O
schizotypy O
( O
HS O
) O
. O

High O
schizotypy O
subjects O
showed O
hypoconnectivity O
between O
ventral O
striatum O
and O
ventromedial O
prefrontal O
cortex O
. O

These O
subjects O
also O
showed O
hypoconnectivity O
between O
dorsal O
striatum O
and O
temporooccipital O
regions O
. O

Methods O
and O
materials O
Participants O
Two O
hundred O
and O
fifty O
potential O
participants O
who O
had O
responded O
to O
online O
advertising O
via O
the O
Research O
Volunteer O
Recruitment O
Webpage O
of O
King O
's O
College O
London O
were O
pre-screened O
using O
the O
short O
version O
of O
the O
Oxford-Liverpool O
Inventory O
of O
Feelings O
and O
Experiences O
( O
O-LIFE O
) O
. O

Subjects O
were O
invited O
to O
participate O
in O
the O
study O
if O
they O
scored O
< O
2 O
( O
low O
positive O
schizotypy O
, O
LS O
) O
or O
> O
7 O
( O
high O
positive O
schizotypy O
, O
HS O
) O
on O
the O
Unusual O
Experiences O
subscale O
of O
the O
O-LIFE O
, O
as O
in O
a O
previous O
imaging O
study O
in O
our O
center O
. O

The O
UE O
subscale O
of O
the O
O-LIFE O
questionnaire O
reflects O
positive O
schizotypy O
and O
is O
associated O
with O
positive O
symptoms O
in O
schizophrenia O
patients O
. O

Participants O
were O
excluded O
if O
they O
had O
a O
history O
of O
neurologic/psychiatric O
disorders O
as O
assessed O
using O
the O
Mini O
International O
Neuropsychiatric O
Inventory O
and O
the O
Psychosis O
Screening O
Questionnaire O
( O
administered O
by O
a O
trained O
interviewer O
and O
reviewed O
by O
an O
experienced O
neuropsychologist O
, O
GM O
) O
. O

Other O
exclusion O
criteria O
included O
contraindications O
to O
MRI O
scanning O
, O
having O
a O
first-degree O
relative O
with O
present/past O
history O
of O
psychotic O
disorder O
, O
present/past O
history O
of O
use O
of O
psychotropic O
medications O
, O
and O
use O
of O
recreational O
drugs O
in O
the O
two O
weeks O
prior O
to O
scanning O
or O
meeting O
criteria O
for O
substance O
abuse/dependence O
by O
self-report O
. O

The O
final O
sample O
included O
20 O
participants O
in O
both O
the O
HS O
( O
10 O
males O
; O
age O
range O
18–39 O
years O
, O
M O
= O
26.35 O
, O
SD O
= O
5.47 O
) O
and O
LS O
groups O
( O
11 O
males O
; O
age O
range O
18–44 O
years O
, O
M O
= O
26.70 O
, O
SD O
= O
7.06 O
) O
. O

Three O
studies O
have O
reported O
previous O
findings O
from O
overlapping O
sub-samples O
of O
this O
cohort O
with O
other O
imaging O
modalities O
. O

Ethical O
approval O
for O
the O
study O
was O
obtained O
from O
the O
KCL O
College O
Research O
Ethics O
Committee O
( O
CREC O
) O
and O
all O
participants O
provided O
written O
informed O
consent O
before O
initiating O
any O
study O
procedures O
. O

Behavioral O
assessments O
On O
the O
day O
of O
scanning O
, O
before O
scanning O
commenced O
, O
participants O
completed O
a O
semi-structured O
interview O
adapted O
from O
the O
Early O
Psychosis O
Prevention O
and O
Intervention O
Centre O
( O
EPPIC O
) O
Drug O
and O
Alcohol O
Assessment O
Schedule O
( O
http O
: O
//www.eppic.org.au O
) O
to O
assess O
current/past O
medication O
use O
and O
current/past O
use O
of O
alcohol O
, O
tobacco O
and O
cannabis O
; O
the O
Social O
Function O
Questionnaire O
( O
SFQ O
) O
to O
measure O
social O
functioning O
; O
and O
a O
validated O
short O
version O
of O
the O
Wechsler O
Adult O
Intelligence O
Scale-III O
( O
WAIS- O
III O
) O
to O
measure O
intellectual O
ability O
. O

Analysis O
of O
demographic O
and O
questionnaire O
data O
was O
performed O
in O
SPSS O
24 O
( O
https O
: O
//www.ibm.com/analytics/us/en/technology/spss/ O
) O
, O
with O
the O
effect O
of O
group O
being O
tested O
using O
independent O
sample O
t-tests O
for O
parametric O
data O
and O
χ2-tests O
for O
non-parametric O
data O
( O
significance O
threshold O
p O
< O
.05 O
) O
. O

Imaging O
acquisition O
Scanning O
was O
performed O
on O
a O
General O
Electric O
Discovery O
MR750 O
3 O
T O
system O
( O
Milwaukee O
, O
WI O
, O
USA O
) O
at O
the O
Institute O
of O
Psychiatry O
, O
Psychology O
& O
Neuroscience O
, O
King O
's O
College O
London O
. O

For O
the O
rs-fMRI O
, O
participants O
were O
asked O
to O
lie O
still O
with O
their O
eyes O
open O
, O
and O
to O
think O
of O
nothing O
in O
particular O
while O
a O
fixation O
cross O
was O
displayed O
in O
the O
center O
of O
a O
screen O
which O
they O
viewed O
through O
a O
mirror O
system O
. O

Scanning O
time O
for O
the O
rs-fMRI O
was O
12 O
min O
. O

During O
this O
time O
, O
ME-EPI O
images O
sensitive O
to O
BOLD O
contrast O
were O
acquired O
to O
measure O
hemodynamic O
responses O
( O
repetition O
time O
: O
2500 O
ms O
; O
echo O
times O
, O
12 O
, O
28 O
, O
44 O
, O
60 O
ms O
; O
flip O
angle O
, O
80° O
; O
4.0 O
× O
4.0 O
× O
3.0-mm O
voxels O
; O
field O
of O
view O
, O
240 O
; O
32 O
axial O
sections O
collected O
with O
sequential O
( O
top O
down O
) O
acquisition O
and O
1-mm O
interslice O
gap O
) O
. O

A O
structural O
scan O
was O
acquired O
for O
co-registration O
of O
the O
ME-EPI O
data O
by O
means O
of O
a O
three-dimensional O
T1-weighted O
inversion O
recovery-prepared O
gradient O
echo O
sequence O
( O
voxel O
size O
: O
1.05 O
× O
1.05 O
× O
1.2 O
mm O
, O
field O
of O
view O
: O
270 O
mm O
, O
196 O
slices O
, O
repetition O
time O
: O
7.3 O
ms O
, O
echo O
time O
: O
3.0 O
ms O
, O
inversion O
time O
: O
400 O
ms O
) O
. O

Imaging O
preprocessing O
After O
resetting O
of O
the O
origins O
for O
both O
T1-weighted O
and O
ME-EP O
images O
, O
a O
study O
specific O
template O
was O
created O
using O
Advanced O
Normalization O
Tools O
( O
ANTs O
; O
http O
: O
//stnava.github.io/ANTs/ O
) O
for O
later O
normalization O
, O
in O
order O
to O
reduce O
localization O
error O
and O
improve O
sensitivity O
. O

One O
subject O
from O
the O
HS O
group O
had O
to O
be O
excluded O
because O
of O
atypical O
anatomy O
which O
undermined O
the O
template O
quality O
, O
resulting O
in O
a O
final O
sample O
of O
20 O
LS O
and O
19 O
HS O
subjects O
. O

The O
ME-EPI O
echoes O
were O
separated O
into O
four O
distinct O
time O
series O
( O
corresponding O
to O
the O
four O
individual O
echoes O
) O
, O
which O
were O
then O
de-spiked O
using O
3dDespike O
in O
the O
Analysis O
of O
Functional O
NeuroImages O
( O
AFNI O
) O
framework O
( O
https O
: O
//afni.nimh.nih.gov O
) O
, O
and O
slice O
time O
corrected O
using O
SPM12 O
( O
http O
: O
//www.fil.ion.ucl.ac.uk/spm/software/spm12/ O
) O
. O

Parameters O
for O
motion O
correction O
were O
estimated O
from O
the O
first O
echo O
, O
and O
applied O
to O
all O
four O
echoes O
using O
FSL O
's O
mcFLIRT O
. O

Subjects O
' O
ME-EP O
images O
were O
then O
co-registered O
to O
the O
T1 O
scan O
using O
boundary-based O
registration O
as O
implemented O
in O
FLIRT O
. O

Again O
, O
parameters O
were O
estimated O
for O
the O
first O
echo O
, O
and O
subsequently O
applied O
to O
all O
four O
echoes O
. O

All O
echoes O
were O
spatially O
normalized O
to O
the O
study-specific O
template O
, O
and O
from O
there O
to O
Montreal O
Neurological O
Institute O
( O
MNI O
) O
space O
. O

Finally O
, O
the O
images O
from O
all O
echoes O
were O
z-concatenated O
for O
further O
processing O
, O
i.e O
. O

the O
space-by-time O
matrices O
from O
each O
echo O
were O
appended O
to O
one O
another O
in O
the O
z-direction O
to O
form O
a O
single O
matrix O
using O
the O
3dZcat O
function O
in O
AFNI O
. O

TEDANA O
, O
a O
python O
script O
that O
forms O
part O
of O
the O
Multi O
Echo O
Independent O
Component O
Analysis O
( O
MEICA O
) O
package O
( O
https O
: O
//afni.nimh.nih.gov/pub/dist/src/pkundu/meica.py O
) O
was O
called O
to O
perform O
TE O
dependent O
ICA-based O
denoising O
and O
T2 O
* O
weighted O
averaging O
( O
optimal O
combination O
) O
of O
echoes O
as O
described O
above O
. O

The O
denoised O
, O
optimally O
combined O
images O
were O
subsequently O
taken O
forward O
for O
motion O
correction O
, O
removal O
of O
white O
matter O
( O
WM O
) O
and O
cerebrospinal O
fluid O
( O
CSF O
) O
signal O
via O
regression O
, O
and O
band-pass-filtering O
( O
frequency O
range O
0.08–0.01 O
Hz O
) O
. O

A O
comparison O
of O
the O
mean O
framewise O
displacement O
( O
FD O
) O
between O
HS O
and O
LS O
subjects O
revealed O
no O
significant O
difference O
in O
head O
motion O
between O
groups O
( O
t O
= O
0.358 O
, O
p O
= O
.72 O
) O
. O

No O
individual O
subject O
showed O
mean O
FD O
in O
excess O
of O
0.12 O
mm O
. O

Imaging O
analysis O
We O
defined O
six O
bilateral O
striatal O
seeds O
based O
on O
previous O
validated O
work O
on O
striatal O
connectivity O
: O
ventral O
striatum O
inferior/nucleus O
accumbens O
( O
VSi O
; O
±9 O
, O
9 O
, O
−8 O
) O
; O
ventral O
striatum O
superior O
( O
VSs O
; O
±10 O
, O
15 O
, O
0 O
) O
; O
dorsal O
caudate O
( O
DC O
; O
±13 O
, O
15 O
, O
9 O
) O
; O
dorsal O
caudal O
putamen O
( O
DCP O
; O
±28 O
, O
1 O
, O
3 O
) O
; O
dorsal O
rostral O
putamen O
( O
DRP O
; O
±25 O
, O
8 O
, O
6 O
) O
; O
and O
ventral O
rostral O
putamen O
( O
VRP O
; O
±20 O
, O
12 O
, O
–3 O
) O
( O
Fig O
. O

2A O
) O
, O
with O
the O
radius O
set O
at O
3.5 O
mm O
. O

The O
mean O
signal O
was O
extracted O
from O
the O
seed O
regions O
( O
voxel-wise O
) O
using O
the O
REST O
toolbox O
to O
perform O
Pearson O
's O
correlation O
coefficients O
between O
these O
regressors O
and O
the O
rest O
of O
the O
brain O
( O
voxel-wise O
) O
, O
which O
were O
subsequently O
Fisher O
's O
Z O
transformed O
. O

The O
resulting O
Z-maps O
were O
then O
taken O
to O
group-level O
whole-brain O
analysis O
using O
the O
General O
Linear O
Model O
as O
implemented O
in O
SPM12 O
. O

Connectivity O
differences O
between O
groups O
were O
examined O
using O
t-contrasts O
. O

We O
used O
a O
cluster O
forming O
threshold O
of O
p O
< O
.001 O
uncorrected O
, O
to O
then O
enforce O
cluster-wise O
correction O
for O
multiple O
testing O
at O
p O
< O
.05 O
family-wise O
error O
( O
FWE O
) O
rate O
, O
based O
on O
previous O
studies O
. O

Potential O
effects O
of O
age O
or O
substance O
use O
( O
alcohol O
, O
cigarettes O
and O
cannabis O
) O
on O
areas O
showing O
significant O
group O
differences O
in O
connectivity O
were O
examined O
with O
an O
additional O
ANCOVA O
in O
SPM O
. O

Finally O
, O
associations O
between O
symptom O
scores O
( O
O-LIFE O
UE O
) O
in O
HS O
subjects O
and O
Z-scores O
averaged O
across O
clusters O
showing O
group O
differences O
were O
analyzed O
using O
linear O
regression O
in O
SPSS O
. O

Linking O
Genes O
, O
Circuits O
, O
and O
Behavior O
: O
Network O
Connectivity O
as O
a O
Novel O
Endophenotype O
of O
Externalizing O
Background O
: O
Externalizing O
disorders O
are O
known O
to O
be O
partly O
heritable O
, O
but O
the O
biological O
pathways O
linking O
genetic O
risk O
to O
the O
manifestation O
of O
these O
costly O
behaviors O
remain O
under O
investigation O
. O

This O
study O
sought O
to O
identify O
neural O
phenotypes O
associated O
with O
genomic O
vulnerability O
for O
externalizing O
disorders O
. O

Methods O
: O
155 O
White O
, O
non-Hispanic O
veterans O
were O
genotyped O
using O
a O
genome-wide O
array O
and O
underwent O
resting-state O
functional O
magnetic O
resonance O
imaging O
. O

Genetic O
susceptibility O
was O
assessed O
using O
an O
independently-developed O
polygenic O
score O
for O
externalizing O
, O
and O
functional O
neural O
networks O
were O
identified O
using O
graph O
theory-based O
network O
analysis O
. O

Tasks O
of O
inhibitory O
control O
and O
psychiatric O
diagnosis O
( O
alcohol/substance O
use O
disorders O
) O
were O
used O
to O
measure O
externalizing O
phenotypes O
. O

Results O
: O
A O
polygenic O
externalizing O
disorder O
score O
( O
PS O
) O
predicted O
connectivity O
in O
a O
brain O
circuit O
( O
10 O
nodes O
, O
9 O
links O
) O
centered O
on O
left O
amygdala O
that O
included O
several O
cortical O
( O
bilateral O
IFG O
pars O
triangularis O
, O
left O
rostral O
anterior O
cingulate O
cortex O
) O
and O
subcortical O
( O
bilateral O
amygdala O
, O
hippocampus O
, O
and O
striatum O
) O
regions O
. O

Directional O
analyses O
revealed O
that O
bilateral O
amygdala O
influenced O
left O
prefrontal O
cortex O
( O
IFG O
) O
in O
participants O
scoring O
higher O
on O
the O
externalizing O
PS O
, O
whereas O
the O
opposite O
direction O
of O
influence O
was O
observed O
for O
those O
scoring O
lower O
on O
the O
PS O
. O

Polygenic O
variation O
was O
also O
associated O
with O
higher O
Participation O
Coefficient O
for O
bilateral O
amygdala O
and O
left O
rACC O
, O
suggesting O
that O
genes O
related O
to O
externalizing O
modulated O
the O
extent O
to O
which O
these O
nodes O
functioned O
as O
communication O
hubs O
. O

Conclusions O
: O
Findings O
suggest O
that O
externalizing O
polygenic O
risk O
is O
associated O
with O
disrupted O
connectivity O
in O
a O
neural O
network O
implicated O
in O
emotion O
regulation O
, O
impulse O
control O
, O
and O
reinforcement O
learning O
. O

Results O
provide O
evidence O
that O
this O
network O
represents O
a O
genetically-associated O
neurobiological O
vulnerability O
for O
externalizing O
disorders O
. O

Methods O
and O
Materials O
Participants O
Participants O
were O
military O
veterans O
of O
Operations O
Enduring O
Freedom O
and O
Iraqi O
Freedom O
. O

Exclusion O
criteria O
were O
a O
history O
of O
seizures O
, O
serious O
medical O
illness O
( O
including O
prior O
cerebrovascular O
accident O
or O
myocardial O
infarction O
) O
, O
acute O
suicide O
risk O
, O
current O
psychotic O
disorder O
, O
bipolar O
disorder O
, O
or O
cognitive O
disorder O
due O
to O
general O
medical O
condition O
, O
pregnancy O
, O
metal O
implant O
, O
shrapnel O
, O
aneurysm O
clip O
, O
or O
pacemaker O
, O
and O
moderate O
or O
severe O
TBI O
. O

To O
avoid O
potential O
genetic O
confounds O
related O
to O
ancestry O
, O
the O
sample O
was O
limited O
to O
genetically-confirmed O
White O
non-Hispanic O
individuals O
. O

We O
did O
not O
have O
adequate O
statistical O
power O
in O
our O
sample O
to O
conduct O
analyses O
with O
other O
ethnically-homogenous O
groups O
. O

Only O
participants O
with O
viable O
functional O
neuroimaging O
data O
were O
analyzed O
. O

Study O
approval O
was O
obtained O
from O
all O
relevant O
Institutional O
Review O
Boards O
and O
regulatory O
committees O
. O

Participants O
provided O
written O
informed O
consent O
and O
were O
compensated O
financially O
. O

The O
final O
sample O
consisted O
of O
155 O
male O
and O
female O
military O
veterans O
ages O
19–57 O
. O

Demographic O
information O
and O
clinical O
characteristics O
are O
presented O
in O
Table O
1 O
. O

The O
predominately O
male O
composition O
of O
this O
sample O
( O
~92 O
% O
) O
is O
representative O
of O
other O
military O
veteran O
samples O
, O
but O
likely O
limits O
the O
generalizability O
of O
the O
findings O
to O
men O
. O

Measures O
Genotyping O
. O

DNA O
was O
extracted O
from O
peripheral O
blood O
samples O
and O
genotyping O
details O
are O
provided O
in O
Supplemental O
Methods O
. O

Polygenic O
Scores O
. O

To O
calculate O
the O
externalizing O
polygenic O
score O
, O
we O
obtained O
a O
list O
of O
reference O
alleles O
and O
effect O
sizes O
for O
587,378 O
SNPs O
from O
the O
investigators O
of O
the O
discovery O
externalizing O
disorders O
GWAS O
that O
reflect O
polygenic O
associations O
with O
externalizing O
disorders O
( O
e.g. O
, O
alcohol O
use O
disorder O
, O
substance O
use O
disorder O
, O
antisocial O
personality O
disorder O
) O
. O

We O
confirmed O
this O
list O
had O
been O
pruned O
of O
SNPs O
with O
ambiguous O
coding O
( O
i.e O
. O

A/T O
and O
G/C O
SNPs O
) O
in O
our O
data O
. O

Of O
the O
SNPS O
, O
480,856 O
were O
genotyped O
on O
the O
Illumina O
OMNI O
2.5–8 O
array O
in O
our O
sample O
and O
available O
for O
externalizing O
risk-score O
calculations O
( O
after O
removal O
of O
SNPs O
with O
missing O
rates O
> O
0.01 O
and O
Hardy–Weinberg O
equilibrium O
p-values O
< O
0.000001 O
) O
. O

Polygenic O
scores O
were O
calculated O
by O
PLINK1 O
using O
the O
-- O
score O
option O
, O
which O
computes O
a O
linear O
function O
of O
the O
additively O
coded O
number O
of O
reference O
alleles O
weighted O
by O
the O
betas O
from O
the O
discovery O
externalizing O
GWAS O
sample O
. O

Externalizing O
Phenotypes O
. O

Participants O
completed O
the O
color-word O
interference O
test O
( O
i.e. O
, O
Stroop O
) O
from O
the O
Delis-Kaplan O
Executive O
Function O
System O
to O
measure O
inhibitory O
control O
. O

The O
inhibition O
subtest O
measures O
inhibition O
of O
an O
automatic O
response O
( O
word O
reading O
) O
to O
generate O
a O
less O
salient O
incongruent O
response O
( O
color O
naming O
) O
, O
and O
the O
inhibition/switching O
subtest O
measures O
flexibly O
switching O
between O
these O
response O
sets O
. O

We O
used O
the O
scaled O
scores O
from O
these O
subtests O
adjusted O
for O
performance O
on O
the O
color-naming O
and O
word-reading O
component O
tests O
[ O
e.g. O
, O
inhibition O
- O
( O
color O
naming O
+ O
word O
reading O
) O
/2 O
] O
. O

( O
See O
for O
details O
) O
. O

Lifetime O
alcohol O
and O
substance O
use O
disorders O
was O
assessed O
via O
the O
Structured O
Clinical O
Interview O
for O
DSM-IV O
based O
on O
the O
alcohol O
, O
cannabis O
, O
cocaine O
, O
opioids O
, O
amphetamines O
, O
polysubstance O
, O
and O
the O
other O
substances O
modules O
. O

We O
did O
not O
model O
the O
latent O
externalizing O
dimension O
, O
because O
we O
did O
not O
have O
a O
measure O
of O
antisocial O
behavior O
or O
trait O
constraint O
. O

MRI O
Acquisition O
and O
Preprocessing O
. O

Participants O
were O
instructed O
to O
remain O
still O
with O
eyes O
open O
while O
2 O
EPI O
runs O
( O
voxel O
size O
= O
3×3×3mm O
, O
TR O
= O
3000ms O
, O
TE O
= O
30ms O
, O
scan O
time O
per O
run O
= O
360s O
) O
were O
acquired O
on O
a O
Siemens O
3T O
TIM O
Trio O
. O

Two O
MPRAGEs O
( O
voxel O
size O
= O
1×1×1mm O
, O
T1 O
= O
1000ms O
, O
TR O
= O
2530s O
, O
TE O
= O
3.32ms O
) O
were O
acquired O
and O
averaged O
to O
create O
a O
single O
high O
contrast-to-noise O
image O
. O

Individualized O
cortical O
parcellations O
and O
subcortical O
segmentations O
were O
created O
via O
FreeSurfer O
. O

Cortical O
surface O
models O
were O
manually O
checked O
slice-by-slice O
and O
edited O
for O
accuracy O
. O

The O
Desikan/Killiany O
parcellation O
was O
used O
( O
34 O
regions O
per O
hemisphere O
) O
, O
along O
with O
subcortical O
segmentation O
( O
7 O
regions O
per O
hemisphere O
) O
. O

Frontal O
and O
temporal O
poles O
were O
excluded O
due O
to O
frequent O
susceptibility O
artifact O
, O
and O
5 O
visual O
regions O
( O
the O
regions O
of O
least O
interest O
) O
were O
excluded O
to O
reduce O
the O
number O
of O
multiple O
comparisons O
. O

The O
number O
of O
brain O
region O
connections O
that O
were O
examined O
, O
and O
corrected O
for O
, O
in O
the O
network O
analysis O
was O
2,278 O
. O

To O
ensure O
that O
our O
choice O
of O
particular O
preprocessing O
stream O
did O
not O
drive O
the O
findings O
, O
preprocessing O
was O
repeated O
with O
other O
options O
: O
( O
i O
) O
slice-timing O
correction O
, O
( O
ii O
) O
partialing O
of O
the O
square O
, O
autocorrelation O
, O
and O
1st O
derivative O
of O
motion O
parameters O
, O
( O
iii O
) O
partialing O
the O
1st O
derivative O
of O
global O
, O
ventricular O
, O
and O
white O
matter O
signals O
, O
( O
iv O
) O
determination O
on O
a O
participant-specific O
basis O
whether O
partialling O
of O
global O
signal O
was O
necessary O
( O
via O
the O
Global O
Negative O
Index O
) O
, O
( O
v O
) O
motion O
scrubbing O
. O

Connectivity O
matrices O
remained O
extremely O
similar O
( O
correlations O
> O
.97 O
) O
, O
indicating O
that O
findings O
were O
not O
specific O
to O
our O
preprocessing O
stream O
. O

Pairwise O
LiNGAM O
Analyses O
. O

Given O
that O
the O
Pairwise O
LiNGAM O
method O
requires O
non-Gaussian O
information O
to O
be O
retained O
in O
the O
timeseries O
, O
preprocessing O
was O
repeated O
substituting O
in O
FSL O
’ O
s O
non-linear O
high-pass O
filter O
. O

Only O
high-pass O
filtering O
was O
performed O
given O
evidence O
that O
low-pass O
filtering O
removes O
important O
non-Gaussian O
information O
. O

For O
each O
connection O
, O
a O
pairwise O
LiNGAM O
coefficient O
was O
first O
estimated O
for O
each O
participant O
. O

Significance O
of O
analyses O
was O
determined O
via O
permutation O
( O
5000 O
permutations O
) O
. O

In O
order O
to O
ensure O
that O
outliers O
did O
not O
drive O
findings O
, O
analyses O
were O
repeated O
after O
winsorization O
of O
LiNGAM O
coefficients O
to O
2.5SD O
, O
after O
which O
all O
findings O
remained O
significant O
. O

Graph O
Property O
Computation O
. O

Resting O
data O
were O
preprocessed O
using O
the O
Graph O
Theory O
GLM O
( O
GTG O
) O
toolbox O
version O
0.44 O
( O
www.nitrc.org/projects/metalab_gtg O
; O
RRID O
: O
SCR_014075 O
) O
. O

Data O
were O
motion O
corrected O
, O
detrended O
( O
linear O
and O
quadratic O
) O
, O
bandpass O
filtered O
( O
retaining O
0.01–0.10Hz O
) O
, O
and O
the O
mean O
global O
, O
ventricular O
, O
and O
white O
matter O
signals O
were O
partialled O
out O
, O
along O
with O
estimated O
motion O
parameters O
. O

Timeseries O
for O
FreeSurfer O
nodes O
were O
extracted O
by O
calculating O
mean O
signal O
across O
the O
node O
for O
each O
time O
point O
, O
for O
each O
EPI O
run O
. O

Timeseries O
for O
the O
EPI O
runs O
were O
concatenated O
after O
mean-centering O
each O
timeseries O
within O
run O
, O
and O
a O
68×68 O
Pearson O
correlation O
matrix O
was O
created O
for O
each O
participant O
. O

Before O
graph O
properties O
were O
computed O
, O
each O
participant O
’ O
s O
connectivity O
matrix O
was O
thresholded O
to O
include O
only O
positive O
weights O
and O
normalized O
via O
division O
by O
the O
median O
positive O
weight O
for O
each O
matrix O
( O
excluding O
zeros O
) O
. O

Normalization O
was O
performed O
to O
remove O
bias O
due O
to O
individual O
differences O
in O
overall O
network O
weight O
. O

Graph O
theory O
networks O
, O
including O
modules O
, O
were O
derived O
from O
a O
data-driven O
approach O
based O
on O
the O
current O
sample O
. O

Details O
about O
module O
membership O
are O
provided O
in O
Supplemental O
Methods O
. O

Statistical O
Analyses O
An O
externalizing O
PS O
computed O
with O
a O
p-value O
threshold O
cutoff O
of O
< O
.50 O
was O
the O
primary O
variable O
used O
in O
all O
analyses O
, O
selected O
based O
on O
prior O
work O
. O

We O
also O
report O
associations O
between O
the O
neural O
network O
connectivity O
measures O
and O
externalizing O
PSs O
calculated O
with O
other O
p-value O
thresholds O
for O
reference O
. O

To O
identify O
network O
connections O
that O
varied O
with O
polygenic O
variation O
, O
connectivity O
matrices O
were O
entered O
as O
dependent O
variables O
into O
the O
Network O
Based O
Statistic O
( O
NBS O
) O
toolbox O
, O
with O
the O
PS O
as O
the O
independent O
variable O
of O
interest O
. O

An O
individual O
connection O
level O
threshold O
of O
t O
= O
2.9 O
was O
used O
with O
intensity-based O
correction O
for O
multiple O
comparisons O
( O
5000 O
permutations O
) O
and O
an O
overall O
corrected O
α O
< O
.05 O
. O

Pairwise O
LiNGAM O
31 O
) O
was O
used O
to O
gain O
initial O
insight O
into O
the O
overall O
direction O
of O
influence O
of O
those O
connections O
observed O
in O
NBS O
analyses O
between O
cortical O
and O
subcortical O
structures O
. O

First O
, O
we O
tested O
the O
significance O
of O
the O
mean O
direction O
( O
across O
participants O
) O
for O
each O
connection O
via O
a O
one-sample O
t-test O
. O

Next O
, O
we O
tested O
whether O
the O
PS O
moderated O
the O
direction O
of O
influence O
for O
each O
connection O
via O
a O
regression O
with O
the O
same O
covariates O
used O
in O
the O
NBS O
analyses O
. O

False O
discovery O
rate O
was O
used O
to O
correct O
( O
across O
connections O
) O
for O
multiple O
comparisons O
. O

We O
then O
identified O
graph O
theory O
properties O
that O
varied O
with O
polygenic O
variation O
. O

First O
, O
resting-state O
connectivity O
matrices O
were O
entered O
into O
the O
GTG O
toolbox O
, O
which O
computes O
properties O
for O
each O
participant O
using O
the O
Brain O
Connectivity O
Toolbox O
. O

Two O
graph O
properties O
were O
examined O
: O
Participation O
Coefficient O
or O
the O
extent O
to O
which O
a O
node O
is O
connected O
to O
nodes O
in O
different O
modules O
, O
and O
Within-Module O
Degree O
Z-Score O
or O
the O
extent O
to O
which O
a O
node O
is O
connected O
to O
other O
nodes O
within O
its O
own O
module O
. O

Graph O
properties O
were O
examined O
only O
for O
nodes O
that O
emerged O
in O
the O
NBS O
analysis O
. O

Properties O
were O
entered O
as O
dependent O
variables O
in O
robust O
regressions O
in O
the O
GTG O
toolbox O
. O

Predictor O
models O
were O
the O
same O
as O
NBS O
analyses O
. O

Significance O
was O
determined O
via O
permutation O
tests O
( O
5000 O
repetitions O
) O
. O

False O
discovery O
rate O
was O
used O
to O
correct O
( O
across O
nodes O
) O
for O
multiple O
comparisons O
, O
and O
adjusted O
p-values O
are O
in O
brackets O
. O

We O
included O
covariates O
in O
our O
analyses O
to O
conduct O
a O
rigorous O
test O
of O
our O
hypotheses O
and O
reduce O
the O
likelihood O
that O
these O
variables O
could O
account O
for O
findings O
. O

All O
analyses O
were O
adjusted O
for O
age O
, O
sex O
, O
the O
first O
two O
ancestry O
principal O
components O
, O
deployment-related O
blast O
exposure O
, O
handedness O
, O
current O
employment O
, O
and O
total O
cholesterol O
. O

Covariates O
were O
selected O
based O
on O
demonstrated O
associations O
with O
neural O
connectivity/integrity O
, O
genetic O
effects O
, O
and/or O
externalizing O
phenotypes O
in O
previous O
research O
. O

Given O
high O
rates O
of O
trauma O
exposure O
, O
PTSD O
, O
and O
mild O
TBI O
in O
this O
sample O
, O
we O
also O
examined O
whether O
these O
variables O
and O
other O
comorbidities O
altered O
study O
findings O
and O
found O
that O
they O
did O
not O
( O
see O
Supplemental O
Results O
for O
details O
) O
. O

Correlations O
between O
the O
covariates O
and O
study O
variables O
are O
reported O
in O
the O
supplemental O
materials O
( O
Supplemental O
Table O
1 O
) O
. O

Capturing O
spontaneous O
activity O
in O
the O
medial O
prefrontal O
cortex O
using O
near-infrared O
spectroscopy O
and O
its O
application O
to O
schizophrenia O
Near-infrared O
spectroscopy O
( O
NIRS O
) O
is O
an O
optimal O
imaging O
modality O
used O
to O
examine O
spontaneous O
brain O
activity O
because O
it O
can O
quietly O
measure O
blood O
flow O
changes O
with O
less O
physical O
restriction O
during O
the O
resting O
state O
. O

Here O
, O
NIRS O
was O
used O
at O
rest O
to O
measure O
spontaneous O
activity O
in O
the O
medial O
prefrontal O
cortex O
( O
mPFC O
) O
, O
a O
main O
locus O
of O
default O
mode O
network O
. O

Consistent O
with O
previous O
fMRI O
studies O
, O
magnitude O
of O
the O
spontaneous O
activity O
in O
this O
region O
declined O
with O
increasing O
age O
in O
healthy O
subjects O
. O

The O
magnitude O
reduced O
in O
the O
mPFC O
of O
patients O
with O
schizophrenia O
. O

Additionally O
, O
in O
the O
mPFC O
of O
patients O
with O
schizophrenia O
, O
the O
spontaneous O
activity O
did O
not O
show O
any O
age-related O
decline O
; O
the O
activity O
was O
already O
low O
in O
younger O
patients O
. O

Further O
analysis O
using O
fractional O
amplitude O
of O
low-frequency O
fluctuations O
confirmed O
the O
reduction O
of O
spontaneous O
activity O
in O
the O
mPFC O
of O
patients O
with O
schizophrenia O
, O
consistent O
with O
the O
findings O
of O
fMRI O
studies O
. O

Our O
findings O
demonstrate O
the O
ability O
of O
NIRS O
to O
evaluate O
the O
spontaneous O
activity O
in O
the O
mPFC O
of O
patients O
with O
schizophrenia O
, O
particularly O
younger O
patients O
. O

Considering O
the O
safety O
and O
ease O
of O
the O
NIRS O
measurements O
, O
the O
current O
NIRS O
study O
of O
the O
resting-state O
activity O
indicates O
its O
utility O
for O
clinical O
applications O
to O
schizophrenia O
, O
which O
may O
facilitate O
chronological O
assessment O
of O
larger O
cohorts O
of O
patients O
with O
schizophrenia O
in O
further O
studies O
. O

Methods O
Subjects O
Fifty-three O
healthy O
, O
right-handed O
males O
aged O
between O
23 O
and O
66 O
years O
( O
mean O
± O
s.e.m O
. O

= O
41.1 O
± O
1.5 O
) O
with O
no O
history O
of O
neurological O
or O
psychiatric O
disorders O
participated O
in O
this O
study O
. O

Twenty O
right-handed O
male O
patients O
( O
25–68 O
years O
, O
50.6 O
± O
3.0 O
) O
hospitalised O
with O
schizophrenia O
and O
having O
apparent O
deficits O
in O
social O
functioning O
based O
on O
a O
GAF O
score O
of O
≤35 O
were O
also O
included O
. O

Two O
or O
more O
psychiatrists O
diagnosed O
each O
patient O
on O
the O
basis O
of O
the O
DSM-5 O
criteria O
for O
schizophrenia O
. O

The O
diagnosis O
was O
verified O
based O
on O
detailed O
clinical O
observations O
during O
hospitalisation O
. O

All O
patients O
were O
administered O
antipsychotics O
, O
and O
none O
had O
a O
history O
of O
substance/alcohol O
abuse O
. O

Clinical O
variables O
of O
the O
patients O
were O
as O
follows O
: O
GAF O
score O
, O
24.2 O
± O
1.4 O
; O
illness O
duration O
, O
27.9 O
± O
3.5 O
years O
; O
onset O
age O
, O
23.9 O
± O
1.6 O
years O
; O
and O
chlorpromazine-equivalent O
antipsychotic O
dose O
, O
804.5 O
± O
143.7 O
mg/day O
. O

The O
symptoms O
of O
the O
patients O
with O
schizophrenia O
were O
assessed O
based O
on O
Clinician-Rated O
Dimensions O
of O
Psychosis O
Symptom O
Severity O
( O
CRDPSS O
) O
by O
two O
research O
psychiatrists O
who O
were O
blinded O
to O
the O
NIRS O
data O
, O
along O
with O
the O
information O
obtained O
from O
the O
clinical O
psychiatrist O
in O
charge O
and O
ward O
nurses O
. O

The O
CRDPSS O
scores O
were O
as O
follows O
; O
Hallucinations O
( O
mean O
± O
s.e.m O
. O

= O
2.5 O
± O
0.3 O
, O
Delusions O
( O
2.6 O
± O
0.2 O
) O
, O
Disorganized O
speech O
( O
3.0 O
± O
0.2 O
) O
, O
Abnormal O
psychomotor O
behaviour O
( O
2.5 O
± O
0.2 O
) O
, O
Negative O
symptoms O
( O
3.3 O
± O
0.2 O
) O
, O
Impaired O
cognition O
( O
3.2 O
± O
0.2 O
) O
, O
Depression O
( O
0.9 O
± O
0.1 O
) O
and O
Mania O
( O
0.3 O
± O
0.2 O
) O
. O

A O
complete O
description O
of O
the O
study O
was O
provided O
, O
and O
written O
informed O
consent O
was O
obtained O
from O
all O
subjects O
. O

The O
study O
was O
approved O
by O
the O
Ethics O
Committee O
of O
the O
Kindai O
University O
Faculty O
of O
Medicine O
and O
was O
conducted O
in O
accordance O
with O
the O
relevant O
guidelines O
and O
regulations O
. O

Near-infrared O
spectroscopy O
NIRS O
measurements O
were O
conducted O
using O
a O
10-channel O
NIRS O
device O
( O
WOT-100 O
system O
; O
Hitachi O
High-Technologies O
Corporation O
, O
Tokyo O
, O
Japan O
) O
, O
as O
previously O
described O
. O

Briefly O
, O
the O
device O
measured O
relative O
changes O
in O
oxygenated- O
( O
oxy- O
) O
and O
deoxygenated- O
( O
deoxy- O
) O
haemoglobin O
( O
Hb O
) O
concentrations O
using O
two O
wavelengths O
( O
705 O
and O
830 O
nm O
) O
with O
a O
sampling O
rate O
of O
200 O
ms. O
Optical O
data O
were O
analysed O
using O
the O
modified O
Beer–Lambert O
law O
to O
calculate O
the O
signals O
reflecting O
changes O
in O
Hb O
levels O
expressed O
as O
arbitrary O
units O
( O
mM–mm O
) O
because O
the O
differential O
path O
lengths O
of O
the O
wavelengths O
are O
indefinite O
in O
this O
system O
. O

The O
NIRS O
probe O
unit O
has O
a O
2 O
× O
4 O
alternating O
arrangement O
of O
irradiation O
and O
detection O
positions O
. O

The O
lowest O
probes O
were O
positioned O
along O
the O
Fp1-Fp2 O
line O
, O
according O
to O
the O
International O
10–20 O
system O
. O

The O
distance O
between O
pairs O
of O
emission O
and O
detector O
probes O
was O
set O
at O
30 O
mm O
, O
and O
the O
measurement O
area O
between O
the O
probes O
was O
defined O
as O
a O
channel O
. O

The O
arrangement O
of O
channels O
covered O
the O
entire O
forehead O
to O
monitor O
activation O
in O
prefrontal O
regions O
. O

This O
experimental O
setup O
was O
corroborated O
by O
that O
of O
a O
multi-individual O
study O
of O
anatomical O
craniocerebral O
correction O
using O
the O
International O
10–20 O
system O
. O

Three-dimensional O
coordinates O
of O
the O
channels O
were O
obtained O
from O
six O
healthy O
subjects O
using O
a O
three-dimensional O
digitiser O
( O
Patriot O
, O
POLHEMUS O
, O
Inc. O
, O
Colchester O
, O
Vermont O
, O
USA O
) O
, O
and O
the O
mean O
estimate O
for O
the O
spatial O
registration O
of O
the O
channels O
using O
the O
probabilistic-determination O
method O
was O
mapped O
onto O
the O
Montreal O
Neurological O
Institute O
space O
based O
on O
NIRS-SPM O
( O
http O
: O
//bispl.weebly.com/nirs-spm.html O
# O
/ O
) O
, O
as O
shown O
in O
Fig O
. O

3a O
and O
Supplementary O
Table O
S1 O
. O

Resting-state O
paradigm O
For O
the O
resting-state O
acquisition O
, O
the O
subjects O
were O
seated O
in O
a O
comfortable O
chair O
in O
a O
silent O
room O
. O

They O
were O
instructed O
to O
keep O
their O
eyes O
open O
and O
remain O
still O
while O
focusing O
on O
the O
central O
fixation O
point O
( O
cross O
hair O
) O
displayed O
on O
a O
monitor O
. O

The O
NIRS O
measurement O
commenced O
when O
the O
cross O
hair O
appeared O
on O
the O
monitor O
and O
continued O
for O
three O
minutes O
at O
rest O
. O

Data O
analysis O
Magnitude O
of O
low-frequency O
fluctuations O
( O
Δoxy-Hbpeak O
) O
Relative O
changes O
in O
oxy-Hb O
signals O
were O
analysed O
according O
to O
a O
previous O
report O
that O
demonstrated O
a O
strong O
correlation O
between O
oxy-Hb O
NIRS O
measurements O
and O
blood O
oxygenation O
level-dependent O
signals O
measured O
using O
fMRI O
. O

Further O
, O
relative O
changes O
in O
deoxy-Hb O
signals O
were O
analysed O
supplementarily O
. O

The O
time O
courses O
of O
oxy- O
and O
deoxy-Hb O
signals O
were O
diagrammed O
using O
the O
BRainSuite_Analyzer O
( O
BRSystems O
. O

Inc. O
, O
Kanagawa O
, O
Japan O
) O
with O
low O
pass O
filter O
( O
< O
0.1 O
Hz O
) O
to O
eliminate O
physiological O
noises O
, O
such O
as O
those O
of O
heart O
beat O
, O
respiration O
and O
quick O
body O
movements O
. O

Figure O
3b O
presents O
the O
representative O
time O
course O
of O
oxy- O
and O
deoxy-Hb O
signals O
during O
the O
resting O
state O
. O

To O
represent O
the O
magnitude O
of O
low-frequency O
fluctuations O
during O
the O
resting O
state O
, O
Δoxy-Hbpeak O
was O
indexed O
as O
the O
peak O
value O
minus O
the O
lowest O
value O
for O
oxy-Hb O
signals O
during O
the O
resting O
state O
( O
Fig O
. O

3b O
) O
. O

The O
Δoxy-Hbpeak O
was O
calculated O
for O
the O
10 O
individual O
channels O
of O
NIRS O
, O
and O
selectively O
, O
the O
following O
region O
of O
interest O
( O
ROI O
) O
was O
chosen O
to O
examine O
the O
spontaneous O
activity O
. O

The O
ROI O
was O
set O
as O
channels O
5 O
and O
6 O
located O
on O
the O
superficial O
part O
of O
the O
mPFC O
, O
and O
then O
, O
the O
Δoxy-Hbpeak O
of O
channels O
5 O
and O
6 O
were O
averaged O
for O
the O
ROI O
signal O
. O

Fractional O
Amplitude O
of O
the O
low O
frequency O
fluctuations O
( O
fALFF O
) O
fALFF O
was O
calculated O
using O
the O
ALFF/fALFF O
software O
( O
BRSystems O
Inc. O
; O
Brainsuit O
ALFF O
; O
Kanagawa O
, O
Japan O
) O
according O
to O
previous O
reports O
. O

In O
this O
software O
, O
first O
, O
the O
time O
series O
for O
each O
channel O
was O
transformed O
to O
a O
frequency O
domain O
using O
the O
fast O
Fourier O
transform O
, O
and O
the O
power O
spectrum O
was O
obtained O
. O

Then O
, O
the O
square O
root O
was O
calculated O
at O
each O
frequency O
of O
the O
power O
spectrum O
. O

The O
sum O
of O
the O
square O
root O
across O
the O
low-frequency O
range O
( O
0.01–0.08 O
Hz O
) O
was O
divided O
by O
that O
across O
the O
entire O
frequency O
range O
( O
0–0.25 O
Hz O
) O
to O
calculate O
fALFF O
. O

The O
fALFF O
was O
analysed O
for O
ROI O
as O
selected O
in O
the O
previous O
section O
. O

Statistical O
analysis O
Between-group O
difference O
of O
the O
NIIRS O
data O
between O
the O
patients O
with O
schizophrenia O
and O
healthy O
subjects O
was O
examined O
using O
a O
general O
linear O
model O
with O
the O
Δoxy−/deoxy-Hbpeak O
or O
fALFF O
as O
dependent O
variables O
, O
group O
( O
patients O
with O
schizophrenia/healthy O
subjects O
) O
as O
a O
between-subject O
factor O
and O
age O
as O
a O
covariate O
. O

To O
examine O
the O
relationships O
between O
the O
Δoxy−/deoxy-Hbpeak O
or O
fALFF O
and O
clinical O
variables O
in O
patients O
with O
schizophrenia O
, O
Spearman O
’ O
s O
correlation O
coefficient O
( O
rs O
) O
was O
initially O
analysed O
. O

If O
any O
significance O
was O
found O
, O
multiple O
regression O
analysis O
was O
conducted O
with O
the O
NIRS O
measurements O
as O
dependent O
variables O
, O
thereby O
controlling O
for O
other O
potential O
confounding O
variables O
( O
age O
and O
antipsychotic O
dose O
) O
, O
and O
added O
factors O
such O
as O
GAF O
and O
CRDPSS O
scores O
. O

The O
threshold O
for O
the O
significance O
of O
p-values O
was O
set O
at O
0.05 O
. O

All O
statistical O
tests O
were O
two-tailed O
and O
were O
performed O
using O
GraphPad O
Prism O
6.0 O
for O
Windows O
version O
6.07 O
( O
GraphPad O
Software O
, O
Inc. O
, O
La O
Jolla O
, O
CA O
, O
USA O
) O
or O
SPSS O
version O
25.0 O
( O
IBM O
Inc. O
, O
New O
York O
, O
USA O
) O
. O

Exclusion O
of O
probe O
error O
channels O
Within O
the O
10 O
channels O
measured O
using O
NIRS O
, O
those O
judged O
to O
be O
probe O
errors O
for O
each O
subject O
by O
the O
WOT-100 O
software O
were O
excluded O
from O
the O
analysis O
. O

According O
to O
this O
criterion O
, O
ch O
. O

1 O
and O
ch O
. O

9 O
were O
excluded O
for O
one O
healthy O
subject O
and O
ch O
. O

10 O
was O
excluded O
for O
two O
. O

In O
schizophrenia O
, O
ch O
. O

2 O
and O
ch O
. O

3 O
were O
excluded O
for O
two O
patients O
, O
ch O
. O

7 O
and O
ch O
. O

9 O
were O
excluded O
for O
one O
, O
ch O
. O

8 O
was O
excluded O
for O
three O
, O
and O
ch O
. O

10 O
was O
excluded O
for O
seven O
. O

Notably O
, O
ch O
. O

4 O
, O
ch O
. O

5 O
and O
ch O
. O

6 O
were O
intact O
for O
all O
healthy O
subjects O
and O
patients O
with O
schizophrenia O
. O

Resting O
state O
connectivity O
best O
predicts O
alcohol O
use O
severity O
in O
moderate O
to O
heavy O
alcohol O
users O
Background O
In O
the O
United O
States O
, O
13 O
% O
of O
adults O
are O
estimated O
to O
have O
alcohol O
use O
disorder O
( O
AUD O
) O
. O

Most O
studies O
examining O
the O
neurobiology O
of O
AUD O
treat O
individuals O
with O
this O
disorder O
as O
a O
homogeneous O
group O
; O
however O
, O
the O
theories O
of O
the O
neurocircuitry O
of O
AUD O
call O
for O
a O
quantitative O
and O
dimensional O
approach O
. O

Previous O
imaging O
studies O
find O
differences O
in O
brain O
structure O
, O
function O
, O
and O
resting-state O
connectivity O
in O
AUD O
, O
but O
few O
use O
a O
multimodal O
approach O
to O
understand O
the O
association O
between O
severity O
of O
alcohol O
use O
and O
the O
brain O
differences O
. O

Methods O
Adults O
( O
ages O
22–60 O
) O
with O
problem O
drinking O
patterns O
( O
n O
= O
59 O
) O
completed O
a O
behavioral O
and O
neuroimaging O
protocol O
at O
the O
National O
Institutes O
of O
Health O
. O

Alcohol O
severity O
was O
quantified O
with O
the O
Alcohol O
Use O
Disorders O
Identification O
Test O
( O
AUDIT O
) O
. O

In O
a O
3 O
T O
MRI O
scanner O
, O
participants O
underwent O
a O
structural O
MRI O
as O
well O
as O
resting-state O
, O
monetary O
incentive O
delay O
, O
and O
face O
matching O
fMRI O
scans O
. O

Machine O
learning O
was O
applied O
and O
trained O
using O
the O
neural O
data O
from O
MRI O
scanning O
. O

The O
model O
was O
tested O
for O
generalizability O
in O
a O
validation O
sample O
( O
n O
= O
24 O
) O
. O

Results O
The O
resting O
state-connectivity O
features O
model O
best O
predicted O
AUD O
severity O
in O
the O
naïve O
sample O
, O
compared O
to O
task O
fMRI O
, O
structural O
MRI O
, O
combined O
MRI O
features O
, O
or O
demographic O
features O
. O

Network O
connectivity O
features O
between O
salience O
network O
, O
default O
mode O
network O
, O
executive O
control O
network O
, O
and O
sensory O
networks O
explained O
33 O
% O
of O
the O
variance O
associated O
with O
AUDIT O
in O
this O
model O
. O

Conclusions O
These O
findings O
indicate O
that O
the O
neural O
effects O
of O
AUD O
vary O
according O
to O
severity O
. O

Our O
results O
emphasize O
the O
utility O
of O
resting O
state O
fMRI O
as O
a O
neuroimaging O
biomarker O
for O
quantitative O
clinical O
evaluation O
of O
AUD O
. O

Highlights O
Brain O
features O
predict O
alcohol O
use O
disorder O
severity O
. O

Resting O
state O
brain O
connectivity O
is O
the O
most O
stable O
predictive O
feature O
set O
. O

Salience O
, O
default O
mode O
, O
and O
executive O
control O
networks O
predict O
alcohol O
use O
severity O
. O

Differing O
imaging O
modalities O
detect O
shared O
and O
distinct O
alcohol O
related O
features O
. O

Methods O
and O
materials O
Participants O
Primary O
sample O
Adult O
men O
and O
women O
with O
moderate O
to O
heavy O
alcohol O
