= O
59 O
) O
completed O
a O
neuroimaging O
protocol O
at O
the O
National O
Institutes O
of O
Alcohol O
Abuse O
and O
Alcoholism O
( O
NIAAA O
) O
. O

Participants O
were O
recruited O
from O
NIAAA O
inpatient O
treatment O
and O
from O
the O
community O
( O
See O
Supplemental O
Table O
3 O
for O
the O
demographic O
features O
of O
inpatient O
and O
outpatient O
samples O
) O
. O

This O
study O
was O
carried O
out O
in O
accordance O
with O
and O
as O
approved O
by O
the O
National O
Institutes O
of O
Health O
Addictions O
Institutional O
Review O
Board O
. O

All O
participants O
gave O
written O
, O
informed O
consent O
in O
accordance O
with O
the O
Declaration O
of O
Helsinki O
. O

See O
Table O
1 O
( O
A O
& O
C O
) O
for O
a O
description O
of O
the O
sample O
demographics O
. O

Exclusion O
criteria O
were O
as O
follows O
: O
currently O
experiencing O
withdrawal O
from O
alcohol O
, O
left O
handedness O
, O
currently O
testing O
positive O
for O
drugs O
( O
THC O
, O
cocaine O
, O
methamphetamine O
, O
opiates O
, O
or O
benzodiazepine O
) O
, O
or O
MRI O
contraindicated O
. O

Additionally O
, O
participants O
with O
IQ O
< O
70 O
or O
age O
> O
60 O
were O
excluded O
from O
analysis O
. O

The O
final O
sample O
included O
four O
subjects O
with O
one O
comorbid O
substance O
use O
disorder O
( O
cannabis O
abuse O
, O
mild O
cannabis O
use O
disorder O
, O
cocaine O
abuse O
, O
and O
anxiolytic O
dependence O
) O
. O

This O
sub-group O
( O
75 O
% O
male O
, O
50 O
% O
inpatient O
) O
did O
not O
differ O
significantly O
from O
the O
overall O
sample O
on O
age O
, O
IQ O
, O
years O
of O
education O
, O
AUDIT O
, O
average O
drinks O
per O
day O
, O
or O
Fagerstrom O
Test O
of O
Nicotine O
Dependence O
smoking O
score O
. O

Validation O
sample O
Participants O
( O
n O
= O
24 O
) O
were O
recruited O
and O
included O
based O
on O
the O
procedures O
described O
above O
. O

See O
Table O
1 O
( O
B O
& O
D O
) O
for O
a O
description O
of O
sample O
demographics O
. O

Behavioral O
data O
collection O
Participants O
completed O
a O
standardized O
screening O
procedure O
, O
including O
demographic O
, O
health O
, O
and O
alcohol O
use O
information O
. O

We O
collected O
the O
AUDIT O
to O
measure O
problem O
alcohol O
use O
severity O
; O
when O
we O
refer O
to O
alcohol O
use O
severity O
, O
we O
are O
referring O
to O
score O
on O
the O
AUDIT O
, O
rather O
than O
DSM-5 O
diagnosed O
disorder O
severity O
. O

The O
AUDIT O
is O
a O
10-item O
self-report O
measure O
covering O
alcohol O
consumption O
, O
drinking O
behavior O
, O
and O
alcohol-related O
problems O
. O

Each O
item O
is O
scored O
between O
0 O
( O
least O
severe O
) O
and O
4 O
( O
most O
severe O
) O
. O

When O
the O
AUDIT O
is O
used O
for O
diagnosis O
, O
a O
score O
of O
8 O
or O
above O
is O
suggested O
to O
indicate O
AUD O
. O

Average O
number O
of O
consumed O
alcoholic O
drinks O
per O
day O
was O
collected O
using O
the O
Alcohol O
Timeline O
Follow O
Back O
, O
which O
assesses O
drinking O
over O
the O
last O
90 O
days O
. O

We O
also O
collected O
the O
Wechsler O
Abbreviated O
Scale O
of O
Intelligence O
II O
( O
WASI O
) O
to O
assess O
IQ O
. O

The O
WASI O
is O
a O
short O
form O
measurement O
to O
estimate O
intelligence O
based O
on O
two-subtests O
: O
vocabulary O
and O
matrix O
reasoning O
. O

The O
Fagerstrom O
Test O
for O
Nicotine O
Dependence O
was O
collected O
to O
quantify O
levels O
of O
smoking O
. O

Participants O
were O
breathalyzed O
at O
the O
beginning O
of O
each O
study O
visit O
, O
and O
were O
not O
run O
with O
a O
blood O
alcohol O
level O
> O
0.00 O
g/dl O
. O

fMRI O
tasks O
Monetary O
Incentive O
Delay O
( O
MID O
) O
Task O
Anticipation O
of O
monetary O
reward O
and O
loss O
was O
measured O
following O
a O
modified O
version O
of O
the O
procedures O
described O
in O
. O

During O
this O
task O
, O
participants O
saw O
cue O
symbols O
to O
indicate O
one O
of O
five O
conditions O
: O
1 O
) O
low O
reward O
( O
win O
$ O
0.20 O
) O
, O
2 O
) O
high O
reward O
( O
win O
$ O
1.00 O
) O
, O
3 O
) O
low O
loss O
( O
lose O
$ O
0.20 O
) O
, O
4 O
) O
high O
loss O
( O
lose O
$ O
1.00 O
) O
, O
and O
5 O
) O
neutral O
( O
no O
loss O
or O
reward O
) O
. O

Following O
this O
cue O
at O
a O
variable O
interval O
( O
2000–2500 O
msec O
) O
, O
the O
participant O
responded O
to O
a O
target O
stimulus O
with O
a O
button O
press O
. O

For O
reward O
conditions O
, O
successfully O
pressing O
during O
the O
target O
period O
resulted O
in O
receipt O
of O
monetary O
reward O
. O

For O
loss O
conditions O
, O
failing O
to O
press O
during O
the O
target O
period O
resulted O
in O
loss O
of O
monetary O
reward O
. O

Failure O
to O
hit O
a O
reward O
target O
, O
successfully O
hitting O
a O
loss O
target O
, O
and O
all O
responses O
to O
neutral O
targets O
did O
not O
result O
in O
any O
monetary O
outcome O
. O

Participants O
were O
given O
feedback O
after O
another O
jittered O
delay O
of O
1500–5000 O
msec O
following O
their O
button O
press O
. O

There O
were O
17 O
trials O
per O
cue O
type O
. O

Face O
matching O
task O
Processing O
of O
emotional O
faces O
was O
measured O
following O
a O
modified O
version O
of O
the O
procedures O
described O
in O
. O

During O
this O
task O
, O
participants O
viewed O
a O
target O
picture O
and O
two O
additional O
pictures O
; O
participants O
were O
instructed O
to O
select O
the O
picture O
that O
matched O
the O
target O
by O
pressing O
the O
corresponding O
button O
. O

Six O
types O
of O
pictures O
were O
shown O
: O
1 O
) O
angry O
faces O
, O
2 O
) O
sad O
faces O
, O
3 O
) O
fearful O
faces O
, O
4 O
) O
happy O
faces O
, O
5 O
) O
neutral O
faces O
, O
and O
6 O
) O
shapes O
. O

There O
were O
two O
interleaved O
blocks O
of O
each O
picture O
type O
. O

Prior O
to O
each O
block O
, O
instructions O
were O
presented O
for O
two O
seconds O
for O
subjects O
to O
“ O
match O
shapes O
” O
or O
“ O
match O
faces O
” O
. O

Each O
block O
contained O
6 O
images O
of O
the O
same O
type O
, O
displayed O
for O
5 O
s O
with O
no O
inter-stimulus O
interval O
, O
for O
a O
total O
of O
30 O
s O
per O
block O
. O

Male O
and O
female O
faces O
were O
equally O
represented O
. O

For O
the O
purpose O
of O
this O
study O
, O
we O
focused O
on O
negative O
emotional O
faces O
because O
the O
previous O
literature O
has O
consistently O
found O
alcohol-related O
effects O
in O
this O
domain O
and O
in O
fact O
have O
used O
happy O
faces O
as O
a O
control O
condition O
in O
some O
cases O
. O

This O
task O
is O
an O
implicit O
processing O
task O
; O
behavioral O
responses O
were O
not O
of O
interest O
and O
thus O
not O
included O
in O
the O
model O
. O

Imaging O
data O
acquisition O
Participants O
were O
scanned O
on O
a O
Siemens O
3T O
Skyra O
Magnetic O
Resonance O
Imaging O
( O
MRI O
) O
machine O
at O
the O
NIH O
Clinical O
Center O
. O

While O
in O
the O
scanner O
, O
they O
completed O
a O
sMRI O
scan O
, O
a O
rs-fMRI O
scan O
, O
and O
then O
two O
task- O
fMRI O
scans O
, O
described O
above O
. O

For O
the O
rs-fMRI O
, O
participants O
lay O
in O
the O
dark O
for O
ten O
minutes O
with O
eyes O
open O
and O
no O
additional O
stimuli O
. O

All O
three O
functional O
scans O
were O
acquired O
using O
an O
echoplanar-imaging O
pulse O
sequence O
( O
TR O
: O
2000 O
msec O
, O
TE O
: O
30 O
msec O
, O
flip O
angle O
: O
90° O
, O
FOV O
: O
24 O
× O
24 O
cm O
, O
38 O
mm O
slice O
thickness O
, O
36 O
slices O
, O
multi-slice O
mode O
: O
interleaved O
) O
. O

Tasks O
were O
presented O
during O
fMRI O
using O
Presentation® O
software O
( O
Version O
18.0 O
, O
, O
Berkeley O
, O
CA O
, O
www.neurojobs.com O
) O
in O
a O
counterbalanced O
order O
. O

The O
sMRI O
scan O
was O
acquired O
using O
a O
T1-MPRAGE O
sequence O
( O
TR O
: O
1900 O
msec O
, O
TE O
: O
3.09 O
msec O
, O
flip O
angle O
: O
10° O
, O
FOV O
: O
24 O
× O
24 O
cm O
, O
1 O
mm O
slice O
thickness O
, O
144 O
slices O
, O
muli-slice O
mode O
: O
single O
shot O
) O
. O

Image O
processing O
and O
data O
analysis O
See O
Fig O
. O

1 O
for O
a O
flowchart O
of O
analysis O
procedures O
. O

The O
fMRI O
data O
from O
each O
subject O
were O
processed O
using O
AFNI O
( O
v16.2.16 O
: O
afni.nimh.nih.gov O
) O
. O

Preprocessing O
was O
done O
on O
a O
single-subject O
basis O
. O

The O
first O
three O
TRs O
were O
removed O
from O
each O
time O
course O
. O

Then O
, O
3dDespike O
was O
applied O
to O
smooth O
spikes O
in O
signal O
over O
the O
time O
course O
. O

Next O
, O
time O
courses O
were O
shifted O
for O
each O
voxel O
to O
be O
aligned O
to O
the O
same O
temporal O
origin O
by O
detrending O
then O
interpolating O
the O
time O
series O
. O

Volumes O
across O
the O
time O
series O
were O
then O
aligned O
to O
the O
base O
volume O
and O
to O
the O
skull-stripped O
anatomy O
of O
the O
subject O
, O
then O
warped O
to O
standard O
Talairach O
space O
using O
the O
non-linear O
warping O
procedure O
3dNwarpApply O
. O

Finally O
, O
each O
volume O
was O
blurred O
with O
a O
4-mm O
full-width O
at O
half-maximum O
Gaussian O
smoothing O
kernel O
. O

For O
the O
task-fMRI O
data O
, O
TRs O
where O
the O
motion O
derivative O
value O
was O
0.3 O
mm/TR O
or O
higher O
were O
censored O
from O
future O
analysis O
and O
stimuli O
onset O
times O
were O
regressed O
to O
identify O
signal O
associated O
with O
each O
condition O
, O
with O
demeaned O
motion O
parameters O
and O
their O
derivatives O
regressed O
to O
remove O
variance O
associated O
with O
movement O
. O

In O
rest O
data O
, O
individual O
data O
with O
an O
average O
motion O
derivative O
value O
of O
0.3 O
mm/TR O
or O
higher O
( O
n O
= O
5 O
) O
, O
with O
> O
3 O
% O
of O
TRs O
being O
identified O
as O
above O
that O
cut O
off O
( O
n O
= O
2 O
) O
, O
or O
with O
> O
50 O
TRs O
having O
motion O
were O
removed O
prior O
to O
group O
level O
analysis O
. O

Additional O
control O
for O
nuisance O
variables O
occurred O
as O
part O
of O
the O
independent O
components O
analysis O
( O
ICA O
) O
procedure O
, O
described O
below O
, O
which O
identified O
and O
extracted O
signal O
due O
to O
sources O
such O
as O
motion O
or O
physiologic O
noise O
. O

Individual O
masks O
and O
registrations O
across O
modality O
were O
visually O
inspected O
to O
ensure O
quality O
and O
several O
additional O
subjects O
were O
removed O
from O
the O
analysis O
( O
MID O
: O
n O
= O
2 O
, O
Face O
: O
n O
= O
3 O
; O
final O
subjects O
: O
rs-fMRI O
, O
n O
= O
52 O
, O
sMRI O
, O
n O
= O
59 O
, O
MID O
n O
= O
57 O
, O
Face O
Matching O
n O
= O
56 O
) O
. O

The O
rs-fMRI O
data O
were O
analyzed O
using O
ICA O
in O
the O
GIFT O
( O
v3.0b O
) O
toolbox O
in O
SPM O
12 O
after O
the O
preprocessing O
described O
above O
( O
: O
mialab.mrn.org/software/gift/ O
) O
. O

ICA O
is O
a O
data-driven O
technique O
that O
extracts O
maximally O
different O
independent O
sources O
from O
signal O
data O
. O

It O
concatenates O
data O
across O
the O
time O
series O
, O
extracting O
networks O
of O
related O
fluctuating O
activity O
. O

In O
the O
primary O
sample O
, O
group O
ICA O
was O
used O
to O
extract O
75 O
component O
time O
series O
using O
a O
PCA O
based O
separation O
algorithm O
at O
a O
single-subject O
level O
. O

Then O
a O
group O
PCA O
step O
was O
run O
to O
reduce O
the O
data O
to O
a O
single O
set O
of O
components O
for O
the O
group O
. O

Single-subject O
time O
courses O
for O
each O
group O
IC O
were O
back-reconstructed O
using O
the O
GICA3 O
algorithm O
. O

ICs O
were O
reviewed O
manually O
, O
and O
31 O
components O
were O
identified O
as O
noise O
related O
and O
removed O
. O

Resulting O
independent O
components O
( O
ICs O
) O
were O
labeled O
using O
the O
Component O
Labeling O
toolbox O
within O
GIFT O
, O
where O
the O
label O
was O
generated O
based O
on O
correlation O
with O
Resting O
State O
Network O
mask O
. O

Based O
on O
our O
a O
priori O
hypotheses O
, O
ICs O
labeled O
anterior O
salience O
network O
( O
ASN O
) O
, O
posterior O
salience O
network O
( O
PSN O
) O
, O
dorsal O
Default O
Mode O
Network O
( O
dDMN O
) O
, O
ventral O
Default O
Mode O
Network O
( O
vDMN O
) O
, O
left O
or O
right O
Executive O
Control O
Network O
( O
ECN O
) O
, O
or O
basal O
ganglia O
( O
BG O
) O
were O
identified O
. O

Following O
all O
data O
selection O
procedures O
, O
rs-fMRI O
data O
from O
the O
validation O
sample O
was O
processed O
by O
back-reconstructing O
subject O
data O
into O
the O
already O
defined O
component O
space O
using O
the O
GIG-ICA O
algorithm O
. O

Between O
component O
functional O
network O
connectivity O
( O
FNC O
) O
was O
also O
examined O
. O

This O
procedure O
correlated O
the O
time O
courses O
of O
each O
IC O
with O
each O
other O
, O
creating O
a O
matrix O
of O
component O
connectivity O
. O

This O
matrix O
was O
calculated O
individually O
for O
each O
subject O
, O
based O
on O
back-reconstructed O
component O
data O
. O

See O
Supplemental O
Material O
1 O
for O
unimodal O
analysis O
methods O
and O
results O
. O

sMRI O
data O
were O
analyzed O
using O
Freesurfer O
( O
version O
5.3.0 O
: O
surfer.nmr.mgh.harvard.edu O
) O
. O

We O
used O
an O
auto-segmentation O
procedure O
on O
individual O
subjects O
based O
on O
the O
standard O
Freesurfer O
and O
Destrieux O
atlases O
to O
measure O
gray O
matter O
volume O
of O
structures O
. O

The O
T1-MPRAGE O
sMRI O
scan O
was O
first O
conformed O
to O
1 O
mm O
voxel O
size O
, O
resliced O
using O
trilinear O
interpolation O
, O
transformed O
to O
Talairach O
space O
, O
corrected O
for O
intensity O
non-uniformity O
using O
NU O
intensity O
correction O
, O
and O
skull O
stripped O
using O
a O
watershed O
algorithm O
and O
surface O
deformation O
process O
. O

Then O
auto-segmentation O
proceeded O
with O
labels O
assigned O
based O
on O
probabilistic O
location O
of O
structures O
. O

10 O
% O
of O
auto-segmented O
volumes O
were O
manually O
checked O
with O
recon_checker O
from O
FreeSurfer O
's O
QATools O
. O

This O
included O
checking O
for O
outliers O
, O
calculating O
signal-to-noise O
ratio O
, O
and O
visually O
examining O
generated O
snapshots O
of O
brain O
volume O
segmentation O
. O

From O
the O
auto-segmented O
regions O
, O
GMV O
from O
regions O
of O
interest O
( O
ROIs O
) O
were O
selected O
for O
inclusion O
in O
the O
analysis O
based O
on O
previous O
associations O
with O
AUD O
within O
selected O
networks O
of O
interest O
( O
ECN O
, O
SN O
, O
DMN O
, O
basal O
ganglia O
) O
: O
the O
amygdala O
, O
hippocampus O
, O
ACC O
, O
PCC O
, O
NAcc O
, O
GP O
, O
caudate O
, O
putamen O
, O
thalamus O
, O
cerebellum O
, O
OFC O
, O
SFG O
, O
MFG O
, O
TPJ O
, O
temporal O
poles O
, O
anterior O
insula O
, O
and O
posterior O
insula O
. O

Right O
and O
left O
regions O
were O
extracted O
separately O
, O
as O
applicable O
. O

See O
Supplemental O
Material O
2 O
for O
unimodal O
analysis O
methods O
and O
results O
. O

Task-fMRI O
data O
was O
analyzed O
for O
the O
primary O
data O
set O
only O
using O
multivariate O
modeling O
( O
3dMVM O
) O
in O
AFNI O
. O

First O
, O
masks O
were O
created O
from O
the O
rest O
ICs O
described O
above O
( O
see O
Fig O
. O

2A O
for O
a O
depiction O
of O
these O
masks O
) O
. O

Each O
was O
used O
as O
a O
mask O
in O
6 O
separate O
runs O
of O
3dMVM O
. O

For O
each O
mask O
, O
the O
full O
MVM O
( O
[ O
AUDIT+age O
+ O
IQ O
+ O
education O
+ O
gender O
] O
* O
condition O
) O
was O
run O
for O
overall O
significance O
for O
all O
main O
effects O
and O
interactions O
. O

Then O
, O
conditions O
of O
interest O
were O
modeled O
using O
general O
linear O
tests O
and O
related O
to O
AUDIT O
score O
. O

For O
the O
MID O
task-fMRI O
, O
our O
conditions O
of O
interest O
were O
Reward O
Anticipation O
( O
High O
Reward O
– O
Neutral O
) O
and O
Loss O
Anticipation O
( O
High O
Loss O
– O
Neutral O
) O
. O

Percentage O
of O
hits O
for O
reward O
and O
loss O
cued O
targets O
was O
examined O
behaviorally O
. O

In O
the O
Face O
Matching O
task-fMRI O
, O
our O
condition O
of O
interest O
was O
Negative O
Emotional O
Face O
Processing O
( O
[ O
Angry O
Faces O
+ O
Sad O
Faces O
+ O
Fearful O
Faces O
] O
/3 O
– O
Neutral O
Faces O
) O
. O

See O
Supplemental O
Material O
3 O
for O
results O
from O
these O
unimodal O
analyses O
. O

We O
then O
used O
a O
machine O
learning O
procedure O
trained O
in O
a O
subsample O
of O
our O
subjects O
to O
predict O
AUDIT O
score O
based O
on O
neural O
features O
. O

The O
inputs O
to O
these O
learning O
models O
were O
neural O
features O
extracted O
from O
the O
rs-fMRI O
, O
task-fMRI O
, O
and O
sMRI O
analyses O
. O

For O
rs-fMRI O
, O
beta O
coefficients O
within O
5 O
mm O
radius O
spheres O
of O
locations O
in O
ICs O
related O
to O
AUDIT O
( O
based O
on O
the O
primary O
sample O
only O
) O
were O
extracted O
and O
included O
as O
within-network O
connectivity O
features O
. O

FNC O
connectivity O
matrices O
for O
each O
subject O
were O
also O
included O
as O
between-network O
connectivity O
features O
. O

For O
task-fMRI O
data O
, O
peak O
beta O
coefficients O
within O
5 O
mm O
radius O
spheres O
of O
locations O
of O
AUDIT O
* O
condition O
effects O
( O
defined O
based O
on O
primary O
sample O
only O
) O
at O
a O
per-voxel O
p-value O
threshold O
of O
p O
= O
.05 O
were O
extracted O
and O
included O
as O
task-fMRI O
features O
. O

The O
beta-coefficients O
were O
also O
extracted O
at O
these O
locations O
in O
the O
validation O
sample O
. O

This O
uncorrected O
p-value O
was O
used O
for O
feature O
selection O
only O
, O
not O
for O
evaluation O
of O
statistical O
significance O
. O

Behavioral O
data O
was O
not O
included O
because O
there O
was O
not O
a O
significant O
correlation O
between O
AUDIT O
and O
hit O
percentages O
for O
reward O
or O
loss O
cued O
targets O
in O
the O
primary O
sample O
. O

For O
sMRI O
data O
, O
volumes O
of O
ROIs O
, O
described O
in O
the O
preceding O
paragraph O
, O
were O
included O
as O
features O
. O

The O
overlap O
between O
these O
features O
was O
evaluated O
qualitatively O
. O

Within O
the O
initial O
sample O
that O
had O
data O
for O
all O
fMRI O
and O
sMRI O
scans O
( O
n O
= O
44 O
) O
, O
we O
used O
10 O
repeats O
of O
a O
10-fold O
cross O
validation O
procedure O
to O
train O
a O
fast O
implementation O
random O
forest O
regression O
tree O
model O
through O
the O
‘ O
ranger O
’ O
method O
using O
the O
caret O
package O
in O
R. O
This O
model O
generated O
500 O
trees O
and O
was O
tuned O
( O
tunelength O
= O
10 O
) O
in O
each O
iteration O
across O
number O
of O
randomly O
selected O
predictors O
, O
tree O
split O
rule O
( O
variance O
or O
extra O
trees O
) O
, O
and O
minimum O
node O
size O
; O
by O
default O
, O
maximum O
tree O
depth O
was O
set O
to O
unlimited O
while O
other O
options O
( O
probability O
, O
replace O
, O
scale.permutation.importance O
, O
keep.inbag O
, O
houldout O
, O
quantreg O
, O
save.memory O
) O
are O
set O
to O
FALSE O
. O

Feature O
importance O
was O
evaluated O
using O
an O
impurity O
measure O
based O
on O
standardized O
response O
variance O
in O
prediction O
of O
AUDIT O
across O
trees O
. O

This O
feature O
importance O
was O
then O
normalized O
such O
that O
the O
feature O
with O
the O
maximum O
importance O
is O
scaled O
to O
100 O
. O

The O
optimum O
model O
was O
selected O
based O
on O
minimizing O
Root-Mean-Square O
Error O
( O
RMSE O
) O
. O

We O
also O
report O
R2 O
as O
a O
goodness O
of O
fit O
measure O
( O
calculated O
as O
the O
squared O
correlation O
between O
the O
predicted O
and O
observed O
AUDIT O
scores O
) O
. O

The O
significance O
of O
the O
R2 O
values O
was O
evaluated O
using O
a O
permutation O
testing O
procedure O
in O
which O
we O
compare O
the O
observed O
R2 O
with O
a O
distribution O
of O
R2 O
values O
generated O
based O
on O
2000 O
random O
permutations O
of O
the O
sample O
data O
. O

The O
number O
of O
simulated O
R2 O
values O
that O
were O
as O
or O
more O
extreme O
than O
the O
observed O
R2 O
was O
divided O
by O
the O
number O
of O
simulations O
to O
produce O
a O
p-value O
for O
determining O
significance O
. O

Then O
, O
the O
capacity O
of O
that O
model O
to O
generalize O
was O
tested O
using O
the O
validation O
data O
set O
( O
n O
= O
24 O
) O
, O
which O
was O
not O
used O
in O
any O
way O
to O
determine O
which O
features O
were O
included O
in O
the O
models O
, O
providing O
us O
an O
estimate O
of O
the O
true O
error O
and O
performance O
of O
the O
model O
. O

This O
procedures O
follows O
recommendations O
by O
. O

Demographic O
features O
included O
were O
age O
, O
IQ O
, O
years O
of O
education O
, O
and O
gender O
; O
we O
selected O
these O
features O
to O
serve O
as O
a O
baseline O
comparison O
model O
to O
aid O
in O
understanding O
the O
utility O
of O
the O
neuroimaging O
feature O
sets O
above O
features O
that O
could O
be O
more O
easily O
and O
affordably O
collected O
in O
primary O
care O
or O
hospital O
settings O
. O

In O
order O
to O
evaluate O
the O
relative O
performance O
of O
rs-fMRI O
, O
task-fMRI O
, O
sMRI O
, O
and O
demographic O
features O
, O
five O
versions O
of O
these O
models O
were O
trained O
, O
tested O
, O
and O
then O
compared O
: O
all O
neural O
features O
in O
combination O
( O
# O
features O
= O
5653 O
) O
, O
just O
rs-fMRI O
features O
( O
# O
features O
= O
922 O
) O
, O
just O
task-fMRI O
features O
( O
# O
features O
= O
4699 O
) O
, O
just O
sMRI O
features O
( O
# O
features O
= O
32 O
) O
, O
and O
just O
demographic O
features O
( O
# O
features O
= O
4 O
) O
. O

Bayesian O
computational O
markers O
of O
relapse O
in O
methamphetamine O
dependence O
Methamphetamine O
use O
disorder O
is O
associated O
with O
a O
high O
likelihood O
of O
relapse O
. O

Identifying O
robust O
predictors O
of O
relapse O
that O
have O
explanatory O
power O
is O
critical O
to O
develop O
secondary O
prevention O
based O
on O
a O
mechanistic O
understanding O
of O
relapse O
. O

Computational O
approaches O
have O
the O
potential O
to O
identify O
such O
predictive O
markers O
of O
psychiatric O
illness O
, O
with O
the O
advantage O
of O
providing O
a O
finer O
mechanistic O
explanation O
of O
the O
cognitive O
processes O
underlying O
psychiatric O
vulnerability O
. O

In O
this O
study O
, O
sixty-two O
recently O
sober O
methamphetamine-dependent O
individuals O
were O
recruited O
from O
a O
28-day O
inpatient O
treatment O
program O
, O
and O
completed O
a O
Stop O
Signal O
Task O
( O
SST O
) O
while O
undergoing O
functional O
magnetic O
resonance O
imaging O
( O
fMRI O
) O
. O

These O
individuals O
were O
prospectively O
followed O
for O
1 O
year O
and O
assessed O
for O
relapse O
to O
methamphetamine O
use O
. O

Thirty-three O
percent O
of O
followed O
participants O
reported O
relapse O
. O

We O
found O
that O
neural O
activity O
associated O
with O
two O
types O
of O
Bayesian O
prediction O
error O
, O
i.e O
. O

the O
difference O
between O
actual O
and O
expected O
need O
to O
stop O
on O
a O
given O
trial O
, O
significantly O
differentiated O
those O
individuals O
who O
remained O
abstinent O
and O
those O
who O
relapsed O
. O

Specifically O
, O
relapsed O
individuals O
exhibited O
smaller O
neural O
activations O
to O
such O
Bayesian O
prediction O
errors O
relative O
to O
those O
individuals O
who O
remained O
abstinent O
in O
the O
left O
temporoparietal O
junction O
( O
Cohen O
's O
d O
= O
0.91 O
) O
, O
the O
left O
inferior O
frontal O
gyrus O
( O
Cohen O
's O
d O
= O
0.57 O
) O
, O
and O
left O
anterior O
insula O
( O
Cohen O
's O
d O
= O
0.63 O
) O
. O

In O
contrast O
, O
abstinent O
and O
relapsed O
participants O
did O
not O
differ O
in O
neural O
activation O
to O
non-model O
based O
task O
contrasts O
or O
on O
various O
self-report O
clinical O
measures O
. O

In O
conclusion O
, O
Bayesian O
cognitive O
models O
may O
help O
identify O
predictive O
biomarkers O
of O
relapse O
, O
while O
providing O
a O
computational O
explanation O
of O
belief O
processing O
and O
updating O
deficits O
in O
individuals O
with O
methamphetamine O
use O
disorder O
. O

Highlights O
Methamphetamine-dependent O
individuals O
( O
MDI O
) O
face O
a O
high O
rate O
of O
relapse O
after O
treatment O
. O

Can O
a O
Bayesian O
learning O
modeling O
and O
fMRI O
be O
used O
to O
identify O
markers O
of O
relapse O
? O

MDI O
who O
relapsed O
within O
1 O
year O
have O
smaller O
activation O
to O
Bayesian O
model-based O
prediction O
errors O
. O

Such O
neural O
pattern O
was O
observed O
in O
left O
temporo-parietal O
junction O
, O
IFG O
, O
and O
anterior O
insula O
. O

MDI O
more O
likely O
to O
relapse O
show O
weaker O
tracking O
of O
uncertainty O
and O
updating O
of O
their O
belief O
model O
. O

Methods O
Participants O
The O
study O
protocol O
was O
approved O
by O
the O
UCSD O
Human O
Research O
Protections O
Program O
and O
all O
subjects O
gave O
written O
informed O
consent O
. O

Sixty-two O
( O
21 O
% O
female O
) O
recently O
sober O
methamphetamine-dependent O
individuals O
were O
recruited O
from O
a O
28-day O
inpatient O
Alcohol O
and O
Drug O
Treatment O
Program O
at O
the O
Veterans O
Affairs O
San O
Diego O
Healthcare O
System O
and O
Scripps O
Green O
Hospital O
( O
La O
Jolla O
, O
CA O
; O
cross-sectional O
analysis O
of O
these O
data O
published O
elsewhere O
) O
. O

All O
study O
procedures O
, O
including O
the O
neuroimaging O
session O
examining O
brain O
and O
behavior O
responses O
during O
the O
SST O
, O
occurred O
during O
the O
third O
or O
fourth O
week O
of O
treatment O
for O
all O
participants O
( O
i.e. O
, O
all O
had O
been O
abstinent O
from O
methamphetamine O
or O
any O
other O
drugs O
, O
including O
alcohol O
, O
for O
3–4 O
weeks O
) O
. O

To O
maintain O
sobriety O
during O
the O
program O
, O
participants O
were O
screened O
for O
the O
presence O
of O
drugs O
via O
random O
urine O
toxicology O
or O
whenever O
they O
left O
the O
facility O
, O
and O
were O
terminated O
from O
the O
program O
if O
tested O
positive O
. O

Participants O
also O
performed O
the O
North O
American O
Adult O
Reading O
Test O
as O
a O
measure O
of O
verbal O
intelligence O
, O
and O
completed O
self-report O
measures O
of O
personality O
and O
affective O
measures O
previously O
associated O
with O
stimulant O
addiction O
vulnerability O
, O
including O
the O
Barratt O
Impulsiveness O
Scale O
( O
BIS-11 O
) O
, O
the O
Sensation O
Seeking O
Scale O
( O
SSS-V O
) O
, O
and O
the O
Beck O
Depression O
Inventory O
( O
BDI O
) O
. O

Lifetime O
DSM-IV O
Axis O
I O
and O
II O
diagnoses O
at O
baseline O
were O
assessed O
with O
the O
Semi O
Structured O
Assessment O
for O
the O
Genetics O
of O
Alcoholism O
and O
based O
on O
consensus O
meetings O
with O
the O
supervising O
clinician O
and O
trained O
study O
personnel O
, O
including O
a O
Masters-level O
research O
assistant O
and O
postdoctoral-level O
psychologist O
( O
see O
Supplementary O
Text O
1 O
for O
exclusion O
criteria O
) O
. O

Methamphetamine O
dependence O
, O
and O
not O
DSM-5 O
diagnosis O
of O
methamphetamine O
use O
disorder O
, O
was O
assessed O
because O
DSM-IV O
was O
in O
effect O
at O
the O
start O
of O
the O
study O
. O

Participants O
were O
contacted O
one O
year O
later O
for O
a O
brief O
structured O
phone O
interview O
to O
assess O
for O
any O
use O
of O
methamphetamine O
, O
level O
of O
use O
, O
and O
time O
of O
relapse O
. O

At O
baseline O
, O
we O
also O
assessed O
for O
use O
and O
abuse/dependence O
criteria O
for O
other O
drugs O
( O
i.e. O
, O
sedatives O
, O
hallucinogens O
, O
marijuana O
, O
cocaine O
or O
opiates O
) O
in O
the O
past O
year O
, O
as O
part O
of O
a O
larger O
longitudinal O
study O
, O
which O
also O
followed O
individuals O
with O
other O
primary O
drugs O
of O
abuse O
. O

For O
all O
participants O
in O
this O
study O
, O
methamphetamine O
was O
confirmed O
as O
participants O
' O
drug O
of O
choice O
. O

Relapse O
was O
defined O
as O
use O
of O
methamphetamine O
at O
any O
point O
during O
the O
follow-up O
period O
, O
while O
some O
participants O
may O
have O
additionally O
relapsed O
to O
any O
of O
these O
other O
substances O
( O
not O
assessed O
at O
follow-up O
) O
. O

Based O
on O
interview O
responses O
, O
thirty-nine O
methamphetamine-dependent O
individuals O
remained O
abstinent O
from O
methamphetamine O
from O
the O
time O
of O
treatment O
to O
one-year O
follow-up O
. O

Nineteen O
individuals O
reported O
that O
they O
relapsed O
. O

Four O
participants O
could O
not O
be O
tracked O
. O

Stop O
signal O
task O
Participants O
completed O
a O
stop-signal O
task O
( O
6 O
blocks O
of O
48 O
trials O
) O
while O
undergoing O
fMRI O
. O

On O
216 O
go O
trials O
( O
75 O
% O
of O
all O
trials O
) O
, O
they O
had O
to O
press O
as O
fast O
as O
possible O
the O
left O
button O
when O
an O
‘ O
X O
' O
appeared O
or O
the O
right O
button O
when O
an O
‘ O
O O
' O
appeared O
. O

On O
72 O
stop O
trials O
( O
25 O
% O
of O
all O
trials O
) O
, O
they O
heard O
a O
tone O
shortly O
after O
onset O
of O
the O
go O
stimulus O
, O
which O
instructed O
them O
not O
to O
press O
either O
button O
. O

Each O
trial O
lasted O
around O
1300 O
ms O
, O
and O
trials O
were O
separated O
by O
a O
200-ms O
inter-stimulus O
intervals O
( O
blank O
screen O
) O
. O

Individuals O
' O
reaction O
time O
( O
time O
from O
stimulus O
onset O
to O
button O
press O
) O
provided O
a O
natural O
jitter O
. O

The O
sequence O
of O
trial O
types O
presented O
was O
pseudo-randomized O
. O

Finally O
, O
prior O
to O
scanning O
, O
participants O
completed O
the O
SST O
outside O
the O
scanner O
to O
determine O
their O
mean O
‘ O
Go O
’ O
reaction O
time O
( O
MRT O
) O
. O

This O
measure O
was O
then O
used O
to O
determine O
the O
stop O
signal O
delay O
( O
SSD O
) O
for O
six O
different O
types O
stop O
trial O
of O
increasing O
difficulty O
, O
providing O
a O
subject-dependent O
jittered O
reference O
function O
. O

Specifically O
, O
stop O
signals O
were O
delivered O
in O
equal O
amounts O
at O
MRT-0 O
ms O
, O
MRT-100 O
ms O
, O
MRT-200 O
ms O
, O
MRT-300 O
ms O
, O
MRT-400 O
ms O
, O
and O
MRT-500 O
ms O
providing O
an O
individually O
customized O
range O
of O
difficulty O
; O
see O
Supplementary O
Text O
2 O
for O
task O
instructions O
) O
. O

Bayesian O
model O
of O
the O
inhibitory O
response O
expectation O
To O
model O
behavior O
, O
we O
used O
a O
Bayes-optimal O
Dynamic O
Belief O
Model O
, O
which O
has O
been O
robustly O
established O
to O
capture O
behavioral O
adjustments O
in O
the O
SST O
in O
both O
healthy O
individuals O
and O
substance O
users O
. O

The O
model O
assumes O
that O
one O
1 O
) O
updates O
the O
prior O
probability O
of O
encountering O
stop O
trials O
, O
P O
( O
stop O
) O
, O
on O
a O
trial-by-trial O
basis O
based O
on O
trial O
history O
, O
and O
2 O
) O
adjusts O
behavior O
as O
a O
function O
of O
P O
( O
stop O
) O
with O
higher O
predicted O
P O
( O
stop O
) O
prompting O
slower O
Go O
RT O
and O
higher O
likelihood O
of O
correctly O
stopping O
on O
a O
stop O
trial O
. O

Mathematically O
, O
on O
each O
trial O
k O
, O
Pk O
( O
stop O
) O
is O
the O
mean O
of O
the O
predictive O
distribution O
p O
( O
rk|sk-1 O
) O
, O
which O
is O
a O
mixture O
of O
the O
previous O
posterior O
distribution O
and O
a O
fixed O
prior O
distribution O
, O
with O
α O
and O
1 O
− O
α O
acting O
as O
the O
mixing O
coefficients O
, O
respectively O
, O
and O
where O
Sk O
= O
( O
s1 O
, O
… O
, O
sk O
) O
is O
1 O
on O
stop O
trials O
and O
0 O
on O
go O
trials O
: O
with O
the O
posterior O
distribution O
being O
updated O
according O
to O
Bayes O
' O
Rule O
: O
In O
this O
study O
, O
model O
parameters O
for O
the O
beta O
distribution O
p0 O
( O
r O
) O
and O
α O
were O
kept O
constant O
across O
all O
participants O
, O
based O
on O
prior O
simulations O
that O
sought O
to O
optimize O
behavioral O
fit O
at O
the O
group O
level O
, O
i.e. O
, O
maximizing O
the O
goodness-of-fit O
of O
the O
linear O
regression O
of O
P O
( O
Stop O
) O
on O
RT O
across O
all O
participants O
( O
see O
Supplementary O
Text O
3 O
) O
. O

A O
fixed O
setting O
of O
p0 O
= O
Beta O
( O
a O
= O
2.5 O
, O
b O
= O
7.5 O
; O
s O
= O
a O
+ O
b O
= O
10 O
; O
mean O
= O
0.25 O
) O
was O
used O
, O
and O
alpha O
was O
fit O
to O
participants O
' O
data O
( O
range O
tested O
: O
0.25–1.0 O
; O
α O
= O
0.5 O
maximized O
overall O
fit O
across O
all O
participants O
; O
see O
Fig O
. O

1A O
for O
P O
( O
stop O
) O
sequence O
) O
. O

Image O
acquisition O
and O
preprocessing O
Using O
a O
fast O
event-related O
fMRI O
design O
, O
six O
T2 O
* O
-weighted O
EPI O
functional O
runs O
were O
collected O
for O
each O
participant O
, O
along O
with O
one O
T1-weighted O
anatomical O
image O
. O

Each O
scanning O
session O
was O
conducted O
on O
a O
3 O
T O
General O
Electric O
scanner O
with O
the O
following O
parameters O
: O
T2 O
* O
-weighted O
EPI O
, O
repetition O
time O
= O
2000 O
ms O
, O
echo O
time O
= O
40 O
ms O
, O
64 O
× O
64 O
matrix O
, O
30 O
4-mm O
axial O
slices O
, O
FOV O
= O
220 O
× O
220 O
mm O
, O
in-plane O
voxel O
size O
= O
3.437 O
, O
and O
flip O
angle O
= O
90o O
. O

Each O
run O
included O
256 O
repetitions O
for O
a O
length O
of O
8 O
min O
and O
32 O
s. O
Functional O
volume O
acquisitions O
were O
time-locked O
to O
task O
onset O
. O

During O
the O
same O
experimental O
session O
, O
we O
collected O
a O
T1-weighted O
image O
( O
MPRAGE O
, O
TR O
= O
11.4 O
ms O
, O
TE O
= O
4.4 O
ms O
, O
flip O
angle O
= O
10 O
degree O
, O
FOV O
= O
256 O
× O
256 O
, O
1 O
mm3 O
voxels O
) O
to O
be O
used O
for O
anatomical O
reference O
. O

All O
structural O
and O
functional O
image O
processing O
and O
analysis O
was O
performed O
with O
the O
Analysis O
of O
Functional O
Neuroimages O
( O
AFNI O
) O
software O
package O
, O
and O
MRI O
x-y O
slices O
were O
reconstructed O
into O
AFNI O
BRIK O
format O
. O

Echoplanar O
images O
underwent O
automatic O
coregistration O
to O
the O
anatomical O
image O
and O
each O
participant O
dataset O
was O
visually O
inspected O
to O
confirm O
successful O
alignment O
. O

Outlier O
voxels O
were O
identified O
in O
the O
aligned O
images O
based O
on O
whether O
a O
given O
time O
point O
greatly O
exceeded O
the O
mean O
number O
of O
voxel O
outliers O
for O
the O
time-series O
. O

Time O
points O
with O
high O
numbers O
of O
outlier O
voxels O
were O
excluded O
from O
subsequent O
analyses O
. O

First-level O
fMRI O
analyses O
In O
a O
first O
general O
linear O
model O
( O
GLM O
) O
, O
Go O
, O
Stop O
Success/SS O
, O
and O
Stop O
Error/SE O
trials O
were O
distinguished O
and O
convolved O
with O
a O
canonical O
hemodynamic O
response O
function O
( O
Go O
Error O
trials O
were O
scarce O
and O
not O
included O
in O
these O
analyses O
) O
. O

Each O
was O
entered O
as O
both O
categorical O
and O
P O
( O
stop O
) O
-modulated O
regressor O
( O
i.e. O
, O
Go O
, O
SS O
, O
SE O
, O
GoxPk O
( O
stop O
) O
, O
SSxPk O
( O
stop O
) O
, O
and O
SExPk O
( O
stop O
) O
) O
. O

To O
more O
specifically O
isolate O
neural O
activity O
related O
to O
belief O
updating O
processes O
vs O
uncertainty O
tracking O
, O
a O
second O
GLM O
was O
created O
with O
two O
types O
of O
trial-wise O
Bayesian O
prediction O
errors O
as O
parametric O
regressors O
, O
representing O
the O
discrepancy O
between O
expected O
likelihood O
of O
having O
to O
stop O
on O
the O
upcoming O
trial O
( O
i.e. O
, O
P O
( O
stop O
) O
) O
and O
actual O
trial O
type O
observed O
( O
i.e. O
, O
Go O
= O
0 O
, O
Stop O
= O
1 O
) O
. O

These O
regressors O
included O
in O
this O
order O
the O
signed O
prediction O
error O
( O
SPE O
= O
outcome-P O
( O
stop O
) O
= O
sk-Pk O
( O
stop O
) O
) O
and O
the O
unsigned O
prediction O
error O
( O
UPE O
= O
|outcome-Pk O
( O
stop O
) O
| O
= O
|sk-Pk O
( O
stop O
) O
| O
; O
see O
Fig O
. O

1A O
, O
bottom O
) O
, O
as O
well O
as O
trial O
error O
( O
0 O
= O
correct O
or O
1 O
= O
error O
) O
to O
control O
for O
performance O
error O
related O
activity O
. O

Each O
of O
these O
regressors O
were O
orthogonalized O
with O
respect O
to O
the O
preceding O
one O
given O
the O
non-trivial O
collinearity O
between O
them O
. O

Both O
GLMs O
included O
the O
following O
regressors O
of O
no-interest O
: O
a O
baseline O
regressor O
( O
inter-trial O
intervals O
) O
, O
three O
linear O
drift O
regressors O
( O
x O
, O
y O
, O
z O
) O
, O
and O
three O
motion O
regressors O
( O
pitch O
, O
yaw O
, O
roll O
) O
, O
and O
Go O
RTs O
( O
residualized O
with O
respect O
to O
P O
( O
stop O
) O
) O
to O
control O
for O
motor O
response O
confounds O
. O

Images O
were O
spatially O
filtered O
( O
Gaussian O
full O
width O
half O
maximum O
4 O
mm O
) O
to O
account O
for O
individual O
anatomical O
differences O
. O

Automated O
Talairach O
transformations O
were O
applied O
to O
anatomical O
images O
and O
functional O
images O
were O
subsequently O
transformed O
into O
Talairach O
space O
. O

Percent O
signal O
change O
( O
% O
SC O
) O
was O
determined O
by O
dividing O
the O
signal O
for O
each O
regressor O
of O
interest O
by O
the O
baseline O
regressor O
. O

Second-level O
analyses O
At O
the O
between-subject O
level O
, O
two O
types O
of O
voxelwise O
mixed-effects O
linear O
models O
( O
LME O
) O
were O
fit O
to O
the O
coefficients O
of O
our O
first-level O
GLM O
. O

In O
the O
first O
LME O
, O
we O
first O
tested O
for O
the O
interaction O
of O
clinical O
status O
( O
abstinent O
vs O
relapsed O
) O
and O
modulation O
of O
P O
( O
Stop O
) O
under O
each O
Go O
vs O
Stop O
trials O
( O
i.e O
, O
GoxP O
( O
stop O
) O
vs O
StopxPk O
( O
stop O
) O
, O
SS O
and O
SE O
were O
averaged O
) O
, O
with O
subject O
treated O
as O
random O
intercept O
effect O
. O

Whole O
brain O
statistical O
maps O
were O
obtained O
for O
the O
group O
main O
effect O
( O
reflecting O
areas O
tracking O
a O
clinical O
status O
group O
difference O
in O
prior O
P O
( O
stop O
) O
value O
irrespective O
of O
trial O
type O
) O
and O
the O
clinical O
status O
X O
P O
( O
stop O
) O
modulated O
trial O
type O
interaction O
. O

In O
order O
to O
assess O
for O
potential O
group O
difference O
in O
the O
modulation O
of O
trial O
accuracy O
( O
i.e. O
, O
successful O
vs O
failed O
inhibition O
) O
by O
P O
( O
stop O
) O
, O
a O
similar O
LME O
approach O
was O
used O
. O

Specifically O
, O
we O
obtained O
statistical O
maps O
for O
the O
main O
effect O
of O
clinical O
status O
( O
reflecting O
potential O
group O
difference O
in O
P O
( O
stop O
) O
activation O
on O
Stop O
trials O
irrespective O
of O
accuracy O
) O
and O
for O
the O
clinical O
status O
X O
P O
( O
stop O
) O
modulated O
trial O
type O
( O
SE O
vs O
SS O
) O
interaction O
. O

To O
correct O
for O
multiple O
comparisons O
, O
we O
used O
a O
cluster O
threshold O
adjustment O
based O
on O
Monte O
Carlo O
simulations O
( O
generated O
with O
AFNI O
's O
3dClustSim O
program O
) O
. O

We O
first O
calculated O
spatial O
autocorrelation O
function O
( O
acf O
) O
parameters O
from O
the O
1st O
glm O
model O
residuals O
, O
using O
the O
3dFHWMx O
function O
( O
which O
does O
not O
assume O
a O
purely O
Gaussian O
acf O
function O
, O
but O
rather O
a O
mixture O
of O
Gaussian O
and O
mono-exponential O
) O
. O

The O
obtained O
parameters O
, O
averaged O
across O
participants O
, O
were O
fed O
to O
the O
3dClustSim O
function O
to O
determine O
FWER O
corrected O
cluster O
size O
. O

Based O
on O
the O
simulations O
, O
a O
minimum O
cluster O
volume O
of O
896 O
μL O
was O
found O
to O
be O
sufficient O
to O
correct O
for O
multiple O
comparisons O
at O
FWER O
= O
p O
< O
.05 O
with O
a O
minimum O
voxelwise O
significant O
threshold O
of O
p O
< O
.005 O
. O

While O
less O
conservative O
than O
using O
a O
p O
< O
.001 O
or O
p O
< O
.002 O
voxelwise O
threshold O
, O
this O
setting O
provides O
a O
balance O
of O
adequate O
correction O
for O
multiple O
comparisons O
while O
ensuring O
a O
substantial O
minimum O
cluster O
size O
. O

We O
also O
note O
that O
this O
threshold O
is O
still O
relatively O
conservative O
in O
light O
of O
previous O
work O
having O
applied O
this O
Bayesian O
computational O
model O
in O
similar O
populations O
and O
experimental O
settings O
, O
which O
would O
provide O
grounds O
for O
a O
more O
focused O
search O
within O
the O
brain O
based O
on O
regions O
of O
interest O
. O

Finally O
, O
within O
the O
regions O
identified O
with O
those O
LMEs O
, O
we O
identified O
those O
that O
were O
consistent O
with O
a O
potential O
group O
difference O
in O
either O
type O
of O
Bayesian O
prediction O
errors O
( O
UPE O
or O
SPE O
) O
, O
using O
our O
second O
GLM O
for O
regions O
of O
interest O
( O
ROI O
) O
analyses O
. O

Moreover O
, O
for O
regions O
consistent O
with O
a O
group O
main O
effect O
or O
group O
X O
trial O
type O
interaction O
, O
we O
specifically O
checked O
for O
convergence O
between O
results O
from O
the O
second O
GLM O
and O
the O
pattern O
of O
activation O
to O
P O
( O
Stop O
) O
as O
function O
of O
trial O
type O
( O
first O
GLM O
) O
. O

Specifically O
, O
regions O
with O
non-zero O
P O
( O
stop O
) O
activations O
of O
opposite O
signs O
or O
with O
the O
same O
signs O
across O
Go O
and O
Stop O
trials O
, O
should O
be O
consistent O
with O
a O
significant O
group O
difference O
in O
UPE O
and O
SPE O
activations O
, O
respectively O
. O

This O
is O
because O
an O
SPE O
is O
equal O
to O
0 O
- O
P O
( O
stop O
) O
= O
− O
P O
( O
stop O
) O
on O
Go O
trials O
, O
and O
SPE O
= O
1 O
– O
P O
( O
stop O
) O
on O
Stop O
trials O
, O
and O
thus O
negatively O
correlated O
with O
P O
( O
stop O
) O
on O
both O
type O
of O
trials O
. O

In O
contrast O
, O
UPE O
is O
equal O
to O
|0 O
- O
P O
( O
stop O
) O
| O
= O
P O
( O
stop O
) O
on O
Go O
trials O
and O
to O
|1 O
- O
P O
( O
stop O
) O
| O
= O
1 O
– O
P O
( O
stop O
) O
on O
Stop O
trials O
, O
and O
thus O
should O
be O
positively O
correlated O
on O
Go O
trials O
but O
negatively O
correlated O
with O
P O
( O
stop O
) O
on O
Stop O
trials O
( O
see O
. O

Default O
mode O
network O
connectivity O
is O
associated O
with O
long-term O
clinical O
outcome O
in O
patients O
with O
schizophrenia O
This O
study O
investigated O
whether O
resting-state O
functional O
connectivity O
is O
associated O
with O
long-term O
clinical O
outcomes O
of O
patients O
with O
schizophrenia O
. O

Resting-state O
brain O
images O
were O
obtained O
from O
79 O
outpatients O
with O
schizophrenia O
and O
30 O
healthy O
controls O
( O
HC O
) O
, O
using O
a O
3 O
T-MRI O
scanner O
. O

All O
patients O
were O
20–50 O
years O
old O
with O
> O
3 O
years O
' O
duration O
of O
illness O
and O
appeared O
clinically O
stable O
. O

We O
assessed O
their O
psychopathology O
using O
the O
18-item O
Brief O
Psychiatric O
Rating O
Scale O
( O
BPRS-18 O
) O
and O
divided O
them O
into O
“ O
good O
, O
” O
“ O
moderate O
, O
” O
and O
“ O
poor O
” O
outcome O
( O
SZ-GO O
, O
SZ-MO O
, O
and O
SZ-PO O
) O
groups O
depending O
on O
BPRS-18 O
total O
score O
. O

We O
obtained O
individual O
functional O
connectivity O
maps O
between O
a O
seed O
region O
of O
the O
bilateral O
posterior O
cingulate O
cortex O
( O
PCC O
) O
and O
all O
other O
brain O
regions O
and O
compared O
the O
functional O
connectivity O
of O
the O
default O
mode O
network O
( O
DMN O
) O
among O
the O
HC O
and O
3 O
schizophrenia O
outcome O
groups O
, O
with O
a O
voxel-wise O
threshold O
of O
P O
< O
.001 O
within O
a O
cluster-extent O
threshold O
of O
114 O
voxels O
. O

Additionally O
, O
we O
assessed O
correlations O
between O
functional O
connectivity O
and O
BPRS-18 O
scores O
. O

The O
SZ-MO O
and O
SZ-PO O
groups O
showed O
decreased O
functional O
connectivity O
between O
PCC O
and O
right O
ventromedial O
prefrontal O
cortex O
( O
vmPFC O
) O
, O
left O
middle O
cingulate O
cortex O
, O
and O
left O
frontopolar O
cortex O
( O
FPC O
) O
compared O
to O
the O
SZ-GO O
and O
HC O
groups O
. O

DMN O
connectivity O
in O
the O
right O
vmPFC O
and O
left O
FPC O
negatively O
correlated O
with O
subscale O
scores O
of O
the O
BPRS-18 O
, O
except O
the O
negative O
symptoms O
subscale O
. O

In O
this O
study O
, O
poorer O
clinical O
outcomes O
in O
patients O
with O
schizophrenia O
were O
associated O
with O
decreased O
DMN O
connectivity O
. O

In O
particular O
, O
the O
decreased O
functional O
connectivity O
might O
be O
related O
to O
the O
severity O
of O
positive O
and O
mood O
symptoms O
rather O
than O
negative O
symptoms O
. O

Highlights O
Long-term O
outcome O
of O
schizophrenia O
is O
related O
to O
default O
mode O
network O
connectivity O
. O

Decreased O
functional O
connectivity O
is O
associated O
with O
poorer O
clinical O
outcome O
. O

Functional O
connectivity O
negatively O
correlates O
with O
positive O
and O
mood O
symptoms O
. O

Materials O
and O
methods O
Subjects O
All O
subjects O
were O
interviewed O
by O
a O
psychologist O
( O
K.P O
. O

) O
, O
who O
used O
the O
Mini-International O
Neuropsychiatric O
Interview O
( O
MINI O
) O
to O
make O
diagnoses O
of O
psychiatric O
disorders O
according O
to O
the O
Diagnostic O
and O
Statistical O
Manual O
of O
Mental O
Disorders O
, O
Fourth O
Edition O
( O
DSM-IV O
) O
. O

Patients O
who O
met O
the O
DSM-IV O
criteria O
for O
schizophrenia O
were O
recruited O
from O
outpatient O
clinics O
of O
the O
National O
Center O
for O
Mental O
Health O
, O
Seoul O
, O
Republic O
of O
Korea O
. O

Inclusion O
criteria O
were O
as O
follows O
: O
( O
1 O
) O
aged O
20–50 O
years O
; O
( O
2 O
) O
duration O
of O
illness O
> O
3 O
years O
; O
( O
3 O
) O
appeared O
clinically O
stable O
, O
as O
defined O
by O
no O
exacerbation O
of O
psychotic O
symptoms O
and O
no O
change O
in O
general O
clinical O
state O
and O
medication O
for O
at O
least O
3 O
months O
prior O
to O
the O
time O
of O
assessment O
. O

We O
excluded O
patients O
with O
a O
concurrent O
axis O
I O
diagnosis O
according O
to O
the O
DSM-IV O
, O
current O
or O
past O
neurological O
disease O
, O
any O
contraindication O
to O
MRI O
scan O
, O
or O
a O
physical O
condition O
that O
would O
render O
an O
MRI O
scan O
difficult O
to O
administer O
or O
interpret O
, O
e.g. O
, O
severe O
extrapyramidal O
symptoms O
. O

The O
HCs O
consisted O
of O
volunteers O
from O
the O
local O
community O
who O
were O
free O
of O
any O
history O
of O
psychiatric O
disorders O
. O

The O
same O
exclusion O
criteria O
that O
were O
applied O
to O
the O
patients O
also O
applied O
to O
the O
HC O
group O
with O
regard O
to O
medical O
, O
neurological O
, O
and O
physical O
conditions O
. O

Data O
from O
79 O
patients O
and O
30 O
HCs O
were O
included O
in O
the O
final O
analysis O
. O

This O
study O
was O
initiated O
after O
approval O
of O
the O
Institutional O
Review O
Board O
of O
the O
National O
Center O
for O
Mental O
Health O
( O
IRB O
approval O
number O
: O
116271–2017-26 O
) O
, O
and O
written O
informed O
consent O
was O
obtained O
from O
all O
subjects O
. O

Clinical O
assessments O
and O
group O
assignment O
We O
defined O
long-term O
outcome O
of O
schizophrenia O
as O
overall O
severity O
of O
residual O
psychopathology O
in O
clinically O
stable O
patients O
with O
chronic O
schizophrenia O
whose O
clinical O
progression O
was O
considered O
to O
have O
reached O
a O
plateau O
after O
3 O
years O
of O
onset O
. O

The O
overall O
level O
of O
the O
patient O
's O
psychopathology O
was O
evaluated O
by O
a O
psychiatrist O
( O
S.R O
. O

) O
, O
who O
used O
the O
18-item O
Brief O
Psychiatric O
Rating O
Scale O
( O
BPRS-18 O
) O
. O

proposed O
that O
“ O
mildly O
ill O
” O
according O
to O
the O
Clinical O
Global O
Impression O
( O
CGI O
) O
scale O
corresponds O
to O
BPRS-18 O
total O
scores O
of O
18–31 O
and O
“ O
moderately O
ill O
” O
corresponds O
to O
BPRS-18 O
total O
scores O
of O
32–41 O
. O

Based O
on O
these O
criteria O
, O
we O
classified O
the O
patients O
into O
3 O
groups O
: O
SZ-GO O
( O
BPRS-18 O
total O
scores O
of O
18–31 O
, O
N O
= O
25 O
) O
, O
SZ-MO O
( O
BPRS-18 O
total O
scores O
of O
32–41 O
, O
N O
= O
31 O
) O
, O
and O
SZ-PO O
( O
BPRS-18 O
total O
scores O
of O
≥42 O
, O
N O
= O
23 O
) O
. O

In O
addition O
, O
according O
to O
the O
factor O
structure O
proposed O
by O
, O
the O
“ O
affect O
, O
” O
“ O
positive O
symptoms O
, O
” O
“ O
negative O
symptoms O
, O
” O
“ O
resistance O
, O
” O
and O
“ O
activation O
” O
subscales O
of O
the O
BPRS-18 O
were O
analyzed O
as O
continuous O
variables O
. O

We O
also O
assessed O
the O
overall O
level O
of O
the O
patient O
's O
functioning O
using O
the O
WHO O
Disability O
Assessment O
Schedule O
2.0 O
( O
WHODAS O
2.0 O
) O
. O

Considering O
that O
functional O
outcomes O
of O
patients O
with O
schizophrenia O
correlate O
with O
their O
clinical O
outcomes O
, O
we O
compared O
the O
WHODAS O
2.0 O
total O
score O
among O
SZ-GO O
, O
SZ-MO O
, O
and O
SZ-PO O
groups O
to O
confirm O
whether O
the O
grouping O
was O
appropriate O
. O

MRI O
acquisition O
The O
MRI O
data O
were O
acquired O
using O
a O
3-T O
MR O
scanner O
( O
Ingenia O
CX O
; O
Philips O
, O
Erlangen O
) O
equipped O
with O
a O
32-channel O
head O
coil O
. O

Blood O
oxygen-level O
dependent O
( O
BOLD O
) O
signals O
were O
obtained O
using O
a O
T2 O
* O
-weighted O
gradient O
echo O
planar O
imaging O
( O
EPI O
) O
sequence O
( O
TR O
= O
2000 O
ms O
, O
TE O
= O
30 O
ms O
, O
matrix O
size O
: O
64 O
× O
64 O
, O
45 O
interleaved O
slices O
, O
field O
of O
view O
= O
220 O
mm O
, O
slice O
thickness O
= O
3.5 O
mm O
, O
flip O
angle O
= O
90° O
) O
parallel O
to O
the O
anterior O
commissure-posterior O
commissure O
line O
. O

All O
subjects O
received O
a O
5-min O
scan O
( O
150 O
volumes O
) O
during O
functional O
imaging O
plus O
two O
initial O
dummy O
volumes O
, O
which O
were O
acquired O
to O
ensure O
magnetization O
stabilization O
. O

During O
the O
functional O
scans O
, O
the O
participants O
were O
explicitly O
instructed O
to O
open O
their O
eyes O
and O
fixate O
on O
a O
white O
cross O
presented O
in O
the O
center O
of O
visual O
field O
. O

A O
high-resolution O
anatomical O
T1 O
weighted O
image O
was O
also O
acquired O
using O
a O
turbo O
field O
echo O
sequence O
( O
spin-echo O
TR O
= O
9.8 O
ms O
, O
TE O
= O
4.6 O
ms O
, O
matrix O
size O
: O
240 O
× O
240 O
, O
170 O
sagittal O
slices O
, O
FOV O
= O
240 O
mm O
, O
slice O
thickness O
= O
1 O
mm O
, O
flip O
angle O
= O
8° O
) O
. O

Resting-state O
fMRI O
analysis O
The O
fMRI O
data O
analysis O
was O
performed O
using O
the O
Analysis O
of O
Functional O
NeuroImages O
( O
AFNI O
) O
software O
( O
version O
18.2.04 O
) O
. O

The O
first O
three O
volumes O
were O
discarded O
from O
the O
functional O
dataset O
to O
allow O
for O
signal O
stabilization O
. O

Despiking O
was O
performed O
for O
each O
voxel O
time-series O
to O
suppress O
local O
spikes O
in O
the O
EPI O
signals O
. O

Head O
motion O
correction O
was O
conducted O
by O
rigid O
body O
registration O
of O
EPI O
volumes O
to O
a O
base O
EPI O
volume O
. O

Physiological O
respiratory O
and O
cardiac O
artifacts O
were O
estimated O
and O
corrected O
using O
Physiologic O
EStimation O
by O
Temporal O
ICA O
( O
PESTICA O
) O
. O

Slice-timing O
correction O
was O
carried O
out O
for O
all O
slices O
within O
a O
volume O
. O

After O
co-registration O
to O
high-resolution O
anatomical O
T1 O
images O
, O
spatial O
normalization O
was O
performed O
by O
affine O
transform O
, O
using O
the O
parameters O
obtained O
from O
spatial O
normalization O
of O
the O
T1 O
images O
into O
Montreal O
Neurological O
Institute O
( O
MNI O
) O
stereotactic O
space O
with O
the O
MNI O
avg152T1 O
template O
. O

All O
voxels O
were O
resampled O
to O
2 O
× O
2 O
× O
2 O
mm O
by O
nearest O
neighbor O
interpolation O
. O

A O
temporal O
band-pass O
filter O
was O
applied O
at O
0.009 O
Hz O
< O
f O
< O
0.08 O
Hz O
. O

The O
nuisance O
signals O
, O
which O
consisted O
of O
six O
parameters O
obtained O
by O
correction O
of O
head O
motion O
and O
non-neural O
sources O
of O
variance O
from O
the O
eroded O
white O
matter O
and O
the O
eroded O
large O
ventricle O
mask O
, O
were O
regressed O
out O
. O

Additionally O
, O
outlier O
volumes O
were O
censored O
from O
the O
time-series O
based O
on O
a O
threshold O
of O
framewise O
displacement O
, O
which O
was O
taken O
as O
the O
sum O
of O
the O
absolute O
value O
of O
temporal O
differences O
across O
the O
six O
motion O
parameters O
. O

The O
time-points O
with O
a O
framewise O
displacement O
that O
exceeded O
0.5 O
mm O
, O
also O
including O
the O
one O
preceding O
and O
following O
time-points O
, O
were O
excluded O
. O

Spatial O
smoothing O
was O
conducted O
with O
an O
isotropic O
Gaussian O
kernel O
of O
7 O
mm O
full O
width O
at O
half-maximum O
. O

In O
order O
to O
identify O
the O
default O
mode O
network O
, O
we O
performed O
seed-based O
functional O
connectivity O
analysis O
using O
the O
bilateral O
PCC O
( O
MNI O
coordinate O
x O
= O
±6 O
, O
y O
= O
54 O
, O
z O
= O
26 O
, O
radius O
= O
6 O
mm O
) O
. O

Individual O
functional O
connectivity O
maps O
were O
produced O
by O
correlation O
analysis O
between O
the O
average O
time O
course O
in O
the O
seed O
region O
and O
the O
time O
courses O
from O
the O
whole O
brain O
. O

The O
correlation O
coefficients O
were O
converted O
into O
z-values O
as O
functional O
connectivity O
strengths O
, O
using O
Fisher O
's O
r-to-z O
transformation O
. O

Statistical O
analyses O
To O
identify O
within-group O
functional O
connectivity O
patterns O
, O
a O
one-sample O
t-test O
was O
performed O
. O

Then O
, O
we O
explored O
brain O
regions O
showing O
differences O
in O
DMN O
connectivity O
among O
the O
HC O
and O
3 O
schizophrenia O
outcome O
groups O
using O
analysis O
of O
covariance O
( O
ANCOVA O
) O
, O
adjusting O
for O
sex O
, O
age O
, O
and O
education O
in O
the O
AFNI O
software O
. O

Significance O
thresholding O
for O
group O
analysis O
was O
determined O
using O
3dClustSim O
, O
as O
available O
in O
the O
AFNI O
software O
suite O
. O

We O
adopted O
a O
voxel-wise O
threshold O
of O
P O
< O
.001 O
within O
a O
cluster O
extent O
threshold O
of O
114 O
voxels O
, O
which O
corresponded O
to O
a O
family-wise O
error O
corrected O
P O
< O
.01 O
. O

In O
the O
regions O
showing O
significant O
differences O
among O
the O
4 O
groups O
, O
we O
extracted O
mean O
values O
of O
functional O
connectivity O
strength O
. O

Then O
, O
we O
examined O
differences O
in O
DMN O
connectivity O
between O
pairs O
of O
groups O
using O
Bonferroni O
post-hoc O
test O
after O
ANCOVA O
adjusting O
for O
sex O
, O
age O
, O
and O
education O
, O
using O
the O
Statistical O
Package O
for O
the O
Social O
Science O
( O
SPSS O
) O
version O
21.0 O
( O
IBM O
Corp. O
, O
Armonk O
, O
NY O
, O
USA O
) O
. O

In O
addition O
, O
we O
performed O
partial O
correlation O
analyses O
between O
mean O
values O
of O
DMN O
connectivity O
and O
BPRS-18 O
subscale O
scores O
, O
adjusting O
for O
sex O
, O
age O
, O
education O
, O
and O
chlorpromazine O
equivalent O
dose O
of O
antipsychotic O
drug O
( O
only O
in O
patients O
with O
schizophrenia O
) O
. O

The O
partial O
correlation O
analyses O
were O
also O
performed O
using O
SPSS O
. O

For O
the O
post-hoc O
tests O
and O
partial O
correlation O
analyses O
, O
P O
< O
.05 O
was O
considered O
statistically O
significant O
. O

Adolescent O
binge O
drinking O
disrupts O
normal O
trajectories O
of O
brain O
functional O
organization O
and O
personality O
maturation O
Adolescent O
binge O
drinking O
has O
been O
associated O
with O
higher O
risks O
for O
the O
development O
of O
many O
health O
problems O
throughout O
the O
lifespan O
. O

Adolescents O
undergo O
multiple O
changes O
that O
involve O
the O
co-development O
processes O
of O
brain O
, O
personality O
and O
behavior O
; O
therefore O
, O
certain O
behavior O
, O
such O
as O
alcohol O
consumption O
, O
can O
have O
disruptive O
effects O
on O
both O
brain O
development O
and O
personality O
maturation O
. O

However O
, O
these O
effects O
remain O
unclear O
due O
to O
the O
scarcity O
of O
longitudinal O
studies O
. O

In O
the O
current O
study O
, O
we O
used O
multivariate O
approaches O
to O
explore O
discriminative O
features O
in O
brain O
functional O
architecture O
, O
personality O
traits O
, O
and O
genetic O
variants O
in O
19-year-old O
individuals O
( O
n O
= O
212 O
) O
. O

Taking O
advantage O
of O
a O
longitudinal O
design O
, O
we O
selected O
features O
that O
were O
more O
drastically O
altered O
in O
drinkers O
with O
an O
earlier O
onset O
of O
binge O
drinking O
. O

With O
the O
selected O
features O
, O
we O
trained O
a O
hierarchical O
model O
of O
support O
vector O
machines O
using O
a O
training O
sample O
( O
n O
= O
139 O
) O
. O

Using O
an O
independent O
sample O
( O
n O
= O
73 O
) O
, O
we O
tested O
the O
model O
and O
achieved O
a O
classification O
accuracy O
of O
71.2 O
% O
. O

We O
demonstrated O
longitudinally O
that O
after O
the O
onset O
of O
binge O
drinking O
the O
developmental O
trajectory O
of O
improvement O
in O
impulsivity O
slowed O
down O
. O

This O
study O
identified O
the O
disrupting O
effects O
of O
adolescent O
binge O
drinking O
on O
the O
developmental O
trajectories O
of O
both O
brain O
and O
personality O
. O

Highlights O
History O
of O
binge O
drinking O
could O
be O
identified O
by O
multivariate O
features O
at O
age O
19 O
. O

Adolescent O
binge O
drinking O
disrupted O
frontal O
connectivity O
maturation O
in O
the O
brain O
. O

Impulsivity O
improvement O
slowed O
down O
after O
the O
onset O
of O
adolescent O
binge O
drinking O
. O

Materials O
and O
methods O
Participants O
The O
IMAGEN O
study O
recruited O
a O
cohort O
of O
healthy O
adolescents O
at O
the O
age O
of O
14 O
. O

Informed O
consent O
was O
obtained O
from O
all O
subjects O
and O
their O
parents/guardians O
. O

The O
genetic O
data O
were O
collected O
at O
baseline O
, O
the O
neuroimaging O
data O
were O
collected O
at O
ages O
14 O
and O
19 O
, O
and O
environmental O
and O
behavioral O
data O
were O
collected O
at O
ages O
14 O
, O
16 O
and O
19 O
. O

The O
details O
of O
the O
study O
design O
and O
data O
quality O
are O
described O
in O
a O
previous O
report O
( O
G O
) O
. O

In O
total O
, O
212 O
participants O
were O
included O
in O
the O
current O
study O
; O
a O
flowchart O
of O
the O
inclusion O
criterion O
is O
presented O
in O
eFig O
. O

1 O
. O

Measurements O
Resting-state O
functional O
imaging O
data O
A O
proportion O
of O
the O
participants O
in O
the O
IMAGEN O
study O
underwent O
resting-state O
fMRI O
( O
rsfMRI O
) O
. O

In O
the O
IMAGEN O
study O
, O
much O
less O
rsfMRI O
data O
( O
n O
= O
389 O
) O
were O
collected O
at O
the O
base O
line O
( O
i.e O
. O

age O
14 O
) O
. O

As O
rsfMRI O
got O
more O
and O
more O
attention O
, O
more O
data O
( O
n O
= O
1069 O
) O
were O
collected O
at O
the O
follow-up O
stage O
( O
i.e O
. O

age O
19 O
) O
. O

All O
fMRI O
data O
were O
preprocessed O
by O
the O
Data O
Processing O
Assistant O
for O
Resting O
State O
fMRI O
( O
rfmri.org/DPARSF O
) O
. O

For O
each O
individual O
, O
we O
calculated O
the O
resting-state O
functional O
connectivity O
( O
rsFC O
) O
between O
each O
pair O
of O
brain O
regions O
[ O
19,900 O
links O
for O
200 O
atlas-defined O
brain O
regions O
, O
Craddock O
2011 O
Atlas O
eTable O
3 O
] O
. O

Genome-wide O
genotype O
data O
Details O
of O
genetic O
data O
have O
been O
reported O
previously O
; O
we O
have O
included O
detailed O
descriptions O
in O
the O
eMethods O
. O

Briefly O
, O
we O
converted O
all O
single O
nucleotide O
polymorphisms O
( O
SNP O
) O
into O
binary O
variables O
; O
no O
mutations O
were O
assigned O
the O
number O
“ O
zero O
” O
and O
mutations O
were O
assigned O
the O
number O
“ O
one O
” O
. O

Substance O
use O
We O
used O
the O
European O
School O
Survey O
Project O
on O
Alcohol O
and O
Drugs O
[ O
ESPAD O
( O
G. O
) O
] O
for O
ages O
14 O
, O
16 O
, O
and O
19 O
years O
to O
assess O
the O
alcohol O
consumption O
, O
smoking O
, O
and O
cannabis O
use O
. O

The O
ESPAD O
category O
scores O
are O
as O
follows O
: O
0 O
( O
0 O
) O
, O
1 O
( O
1–2 O
) O
, O
2 O
( O
3–5 O
) O
, O
3 O
( O
6–9 O
) O
, O
4 O
( O
10–19 O
) O
, O
5 O
( O
20–39 O
) O
, O
6 O
( O
≥40 O
) O
. O

The O
primary O
questions O
of O
interest O
concerned O
lifetime O
alcohol O
use O
[ O
for O
example O
, O
On O
how O
many O
occasions O
( O
if O
any O
) O
in O
your O
lifetime O
have O
you O
had O
any O
alcoholic O
beverage O
? O

] O
; O
lifetime O
drunken O
episodes O
[ O
for O
example O
, O
On O
how O
many O
occasions O
( O
if O
any O
) O
in O
your O
lifetime O
have O
you O
been O
drunk O
from O
drinking O
alcoholic O
beverages O
? O

] O
; O
lifetime O
smoking O
( O
for O
example O
, O
On O
how O
many O
occasions O
during O
your O
lifetime O
have O
you O
smoked O
cigarettes O
? O

) O
; O
and O
lifetime O
cannabis O
use O
( O
for O
example O
, O
On O
how O
many O
occasions O
in O
your O
whole O
lifetime O
have O
you O
used O
marijuana O
or O
hashish O
? O
) O
. O

Variables O
associated O
with O
the O
occasions O
of O
alcohol O
use O
and O
the O
episodes O
of O
binge O
drinking O
were O
measured O
at O
three O
time O
points O
( O
ages O
14 O
, O
16 O
, O
and O
19 O
) O
, O
and O
the O
data O
were O
organized O
according O
to O
the O
duration O
and O
amount O
of O
binge O
drinking O
during O
adolescence O
( O
Fig O
. O

1 O
, O
eFig O
. O

1 O
) O
. O

More O
details O
are O
provided O
in O
the O
eMethods O
. O

Cognition O
and O
personality O
We O
used O
the O
Cambridge O
Neuropsychological O
Test O
Automated O
Battery O
[ O
Cantab O
] O
, O
Monetary-Choice O
Questionnaire O
( O
KIRBY O
rate O
) O
, O
personality O
characteristics O
tests O
, O
including O
the O
Revised O
NEO O
Personality O
Inventory O
[ O
NEO-PI-R O
] O
, O
and O
the O
Substance O
Use O
Risk O
Profile O
Scale O
[ O
SURPS O
] O
to O
assess O
cognition O
and O
personality O
factors O
. O

Further O
details O
are O
provided O
in O
the O
eMethods O
. O

Statistical O
analyses O
Univariate O
approach O
We O
used O
two-sample O
Student O
's O
t-tests O
, O
controlling O
for O
covariates O
( O
sex O
and O
site O
) O
for O
univariate O
analyses O
, O
and O
employed O
a O
false O
discovery O
rate O
( O
FDR O
) O
correction O
for O
multiple O
comparisons O
. O

Multivariate O
approach O
with O
hypothesis-guided O
feature O
selection O
To O
identify O
discriminative O
features O
in O
high O
dimensional O
space O
and O
control O
for O
the O
over-fitting O
problem O
, O
we O
combined O
several O
dimension O
reduction O
approaches O
with O
the O
multivariate O
pattern O
analysis O
approach O
[ O
Support-Vector O
Machine O
( O
SVM O
) O
, O
] O
. O

The O
main O
steps O
are O
described O
below O
and O
additional O
details O
are O
provided O
in O
the O
eMethods O
. O

Candidate O
feature O
selection O
and O
dimension O
reduction O
To O
reduce O
dimensionality O
, O
we O
first O
used O
the O
lasso-regularized O
logistic O
regression O
to O
select O
the O
most O
discriminative O
rsFCs O
between O
the O
binge O
drinkers O
and O
non-drinking O
controls O
. O

Chi-squared O
tests O
were O
used O
to O
select O
the O
SNPs O
with O
significantly O
different O
frequencies O
in O
subjects O
with O
a O
history O
of O
binge O
drinking O
compared O
to O
those O
without O
a O
binge O
drinking O
history O
. O

Next O
, O
instead O
of O
using O
these O
features O
as O
inputs O
to O
the O
SVM O
, O
we O
further O
reduced O
the O
dimensionality O
by O
calculating O
four O
summary O
scores O
, O
including O
increased/decreased O
rsFC O
( O
iFC/dFC O
) O
or O
risk/protective O
SNP O
( O
rSNP/pSNP O
) O
scores O
( O
Fig O
. O

2A O
) O
. O

To O
prevent O
model O
over-fitting O
in O
the O
training O
sample O
, O
we O
applied O
the O
leave-one-out O
( O
LOO O
) O
cross-validation O
procedure O
to O
the O
SVM O
, O
which O
was O
built O
by O
the O
two O
steps O
described O
above O
. O

Only O
those O
features O
( O
rsFC O
and O
SNP O
) O
that O
were O
repeatedly O
selected O
in O
> O
90 O
% O
of O
iterations O
during O
the O
LOO O
were O
considered O
robustly O
discriminating O
features O
( O
namely O
, O
the O
candidate O
features O
) O
between O
the O
binge O
drinkers O
and O
the O
control O
subjects O
. O

We O
trained O
one O
SVM O
for O
the O
long-term O
drinkers O
( O
SVM-long O
classifier O
) O
and O
the O
other O
SVM O
for O
the O
short-term O
drinkers O
( O
SVM-short O
classifier O
) O
. O

To O
assess O
the O
contribution O
of O
each O
domain O
( O
SNP O
, O
rsFC O
, O
and O
covariates O
) O
in O
classification O
, O
we O
compared O
the O
model O
performance O
before O
and O
after O
the O
removal O
of O
each O
domain O
from O
the O
model O
inputs O
. O

The O
candidate O
features O
in O
the O
domains O
significantly O
contributed O
to O
SVM-long O
and O
SVM-short O
were O
summarized O
into O
four O
new O
scores O
( O
iFC O
, O
dFC O
, O
rSNP O
, O
and O
pSNP O
) O
for O
next O
stage O
. O

Hypothesis-guided O
feature O
selection O
According O
to O
our O
hypothesis O
of O
trend O
for O
the O
consequences O
of O
adolescent O
binge O
drinking O
, O
we O
focused O
on O
the O
personality O
scores O
and O
the O
four O
new O
scores O
established O
by O
candidate O
features O
. O

We O
employed O
the O
Jonckheere-Terpstra O
trend O
test O
to O
identify O
the O
features O
that O
were O
consistent O
with O
the O
hypothesis O
of O
trend O
( O
i.e O
. O

the O
discriminative O
features O
having O
the O
largest O
, O
intermediate O
and O
smallest O
deviations O
from O
the O
control O
group O
in O
the O
binge O
drinkers O
with O
the O
longest O
, O
medium O
, O
and O
shortest O
history O
of O
binge O
drinking O
, O
respectively O
; O
Fig O
. O

3A O
, O
B O
, O
and O
C O
) O
. O

Hierarchical O
classifier O
Finally O
, O
we O
built O
a O
hierarchical O
classifier O
, O
which O
consisted O
of O
two O
layers O
: O
the O
in-layer O
and O
the O
out-layer O
( O
Fig O
. O

3D O
) O
. O

To O
further O
reduce O
dimensionality O
, O
we O
constructed O
the O
in-layer O
with O
three O
SVMs O
taking O
the O
inputs O
from O
covariates O
( O
SVM1 O
) O
, O
rsFC O
and O
SNP O
( O
SVM2 O
) O
, O
and O
personality O
( O
SVM3 O
) O
. O

Each O
of O
these O
SVMs O
was O
trained O
using O
the O
LOO O
procedure O
on O
the O
training O
data O
, O
including O
the O
Control O
I O
group O
, O
the O
long-term O
binge O
drinking O
group O
, O
and O
the O
short-term O
binge O
drinking O
group O
. O

In O
the O
out-layer O
, O
one O
SVM O
( O
SVM4 O
) O
received O
only O
3 O
input O
values O
from O
the O
output O
values O
of O
SVM1–3 O
( O
a O
greater O
output O
value O
means O
more O
likely O
to O
be O
a O
binge O
drinker O
) O
. O

With O
this O
hierarchical O
classifier O
, O
we O
significantly O
reduced O
the O
model O
complexity O
by O
taking O
the O
inputs O
from O
three O
kinds O
of O
features O
, O
so O
as O
to O
achieve O
a O
better O
generalizability O
. O

The O
model O
was O
then O
tested O
using O
an O
independent O
test O
sample O
( O
i.e O
. O

the O
medium-term O
drinkers O
and O
the O
Control O
II O
group O
) O
. O

Longitudinal O
analysis O
We O
could O
not O
conduct O
a O
longitudinal O
analysis O
on O
the O
rsfMRI O
data O
because O
we O
only O
had O
32 O
subjects O
( O
18 O
binge O
drinkers O
and O
14 O
controls O
) O
with O
rsfMRI O
data O
available O
at O
the O
age O
of O
14 O
after O
participant O
selection O
( O
eFig O
. O

1 O
) O
. O

However O
, O
personalities O
were O
assessed O
at O
three O
time O
points O
( O
ages O
14 O
, O
16 O
, O
and O
19 O
) O
; O
therefore O
, O
we O
estimated O
changes O
in O
personality O
between O
14 O
and O
16 O
years O
( O
difference16–14 O
) O
and O
between O
16 O
and O
19 O
years O
( O
difference19–16 O
) O
. O

To O
compare O
the O
developmental O
trajectory O
of O
personality O
between O
the O
two O
different O
time O
periods O
( O
i.e O
. O

from O
14 O
to O
16 O
and O
from O
16 O
to O
19 O
) O
, O
difference16–14 O
and O
difference19–16 O
in O
binge O
drinkers O
must O
be O
established O
before O
and O
after O
binge O
drinking O
onset O
, O
respectively O
, O
thus O
only O
the O
short-term O
drinkers O
satisfied O
this O
condition O
. O

These O
differences O
were O
compared O
before O
and O
after O
the O
onset O
of O
binge O
drinking O
( O
significance O
was O
given O
by O
1000 O
permutations O
of O
the O
paired O
median O
test O
) O
. O

By O
conducting O
an O
Analysis O
of O
Variance O
( O
ANOVA O
) O
with O
repeated O
measures O
using O
SPSS O
( O
Released O
2011 O
. O

IBM O
SPSS O
Statistics O
for O
Windows O
, O
Version O
20.0 O
. O

Armonk O
, O
NY O
: O
IBM O
Corp O
) O
, O
we O
were O
able O
to O
compare O
the O
longitudinal O
evolutions O
of O
both O
the O
impulsivity O
and O
the O
sensation-seeking O
scores O
between O
the O
short-term O
drinkers O
and O
the O
control O
subjects O
. O

The O
same O
approach O
was O
also O
applied O
to O
difference16–14 O
and O
difference19–16 O
. O

The O
covariates O
( O
sex O
and O
data O
collection O
sites O
) O
were O
regressing O
out O
from O
the O
measurements O
before O
the O
group O
comparisons O
. O

Multimodal O
neuroimaging O
evidence O
for O
looser O
lexico-semantic O
networks O
in O
schizophrenia O
: O
Evidence O
from O
masked O
indirect O
semantic O
priming O
It O
has O
been O
hypothesized O
that O
schizophrenia O
is O
characterized O
by O
overly O
broad O
automatic O
activity O
within O
lexico-semantic O
networks O
. O

We O
used O
two O
complementary O
neuroimaging O
techniques O
, O
Magnetoencephalography O
( O
MEG O
) O
and O
functional O
Magnetic O
Resonance O
Imaging O
( O
fMRI O
) O
, O
in O
combination O
with O
a O
highly O
automatic O
indirect O
semantic O
priming O
paradigm O
, O
to O
spatiotemporally O
localize O
this O
abnormality O
in O
the O
brain O
. O

Eighteen O
people O
with O
schizophrenia O
and O
20 O
demographically-matched O
control O
participants O
viewed O
target O
words O
( O
“ O
bell O
” O
) O
preceded O
by O
directly O
related O
( O
“ O
church O
” O
) O
, O
indirectly O
related O
( O
“ O
priest O
” O
) O
, O
or O
unrelated O
( O
“ O
hammer O
” O
) O
prime O
words O
in O
MEG O
and O
fMRI O
sessions O
. O

To O
minimize O
top-down O
processing O
, O
the O
prime O
was O
masked O
, O
the O
target O
appeared O
only O
140 O
ms O
after O
prime O
onset O
, O
and O
participants O
simply O
monitored O
for O
words O
within O
a O
particular O
semantic O
category O
that O
appeared O
in O
filler O
trials O
. O

Both O
techniques O
revealed O
a O
significantly O
larger O
automatic O
indirect O
priming O
effect O
in O
people O
with O
schizophrenia O
than O
in O
control O
participants O
. O

MEG O
temporally O
localized O
this O
enhanced O
effect O
to O
the O
N400 O
time O
window O
( O
300–500 O
ms O
) O
— O
the O
critical O
stage O
of O
accessing O
meaning O
from O
words O
. O

fMRI O
spatially O
localized O
the O
effect O
to O
the O
left O
temporal O
fusiform O
cortex O
, O
which O
plays O
a O
role O
in O
mapping O
of O
orthographic O
word-form O
on O
to O
meaning O
. O

There O
was O
no O
evidence O
of O
an O
enhanced O
automatic O
direct O
semantic O
priming O
effect O
in O
the O
schizophrenia O
group O
. O

These O
findings O
provide O
converging O
neural O
evidence O
for O
abnormally O
broad O
highly O
automatic O
lexico-semantic O
activity O
in O
schizophrenia O
. O

We O
argue O
that O
, O
rather O
than O
arising O
from O
an O
unconstrained O
spread O
of O
automatic O
activation O
across O
semantic O
memory O
, O
this O
broader O
automatic O
lexico-semantic O
activity O
stems O
from O
looser O
mappings O
between O
the O
form O
and O
meaning O
of O
words O
. O

Methods O
Materials O
The O
stimulus O
materials O
have O
previously O
been O
described O
in O
detail O
. O

They O
constituted O
192 O
unique O
targets O
( O
e.g O
. O

“ O
bell O
” O
) O
paired O
with O
primes O
that O
were O
either O
directly O
related O
( O
e.g O
. O

“ O
church O
” O
) O
, O
indirectly O
related O
( O
e.g O
. O

“ O
priest O
” O
) O
, O
or O
unrelated O
( O
e.g O
. O

“ O
hammer O
” O
) O
. O

As O
previously O
described O
, O
the O
primes O
of O
the O
indirectly O
related O
pairs O
did O
not O
share O
obvious O
categorical O
relationships O
or O
direct O
associations O
with O
their O
targets O
. O

However O
, O
they O
did O
share O
more O
global O
similarities O
with O
their O
targets O
than O
the O
unrelated O
word-pairs O
, O
as O
indexed O
by O
Latent O
Semantic O
Analysis O
( O
; O
see O
also O
) O
, O
as O
well O
as O
by O
a O
norming O
study O
in O
which O
participants O
were O
explicitly O
asked O
to O
identify O
the O
unstated O
mediator O
word O
( O
described O
by O
, O
pages O
553 O
and O
556–557 O
) O
. O

The O
same O
targets O
were O
counterbalanced O
across O
three O
lists O
. O

Each O
list O
contained O
64 O
directly O
related O
pairs O
, O
64 O
indirectly O
related O
pairs O
, O
and O
64 O
unrelated O
pairs O
, O
in O
randomized O
order O
. O

No O
prime O
or O
target O
word O
appeared O
twice O
in O
the O
same O
list O
, O
but O
across O
all O
participants O
, O
the O
same O
targets O
could O
appear O
in O
all O
three O
conditions O
. O

Thus O
, O
differences O
between O
conditions O
could O
not O
be O
attributed O
to O
differences O
to O
the O
lexical O
properties O
of O
the O
targets O
or O
the O
primes O
. O

Each O
list O
also O
contained O
40 O
filler O
unrelated O
word-pairs O
in O
which O
either O
the O
prime O
( O
50 O
% O
) O
or O
the O
target O
( O
50 O
% O
) O
was O
the O
name O
of O
an O
insect O
. O

These O
were O
included O
for O
the O
purpose O
of O
the O
semantic O
monitoring O
task O
( O
described O
below O
) O
. O

Participants O
People O
with O
a O
DSM-IV O
diagnosis O
of O
schizophrenia O
or O
schizoaffective O
disorder O
( O
confirmed O
with O
a O
Structured O
Clinical O
Interview O
, O
see O
) O
were O
recruited O
from O
the O
Lindemann O
Mental O
Health O
Center O
, O
Boston O
. O

Demographically O
matched O
volunteers O
without O
histories O
of O
psychiatric O
disorders O
were O
recruited O
by O
advertisement O
. O

All O
participants O
were O
right-handed O
, O
as O
assessed O
using O
the O
Edinburgh O
handedness O
questionnaire O
, O
and O
were O
native O
, O
primarily O
monolingual O
American O
English O
speakers O
. O

Participants O
were O
excluded O
if O
they O
had O
a O
history O
of O
neurological O
injury O
, O
medical O
disorders O
impairing O
neurocognitive O
function O
, O
or O
if O
they O
met O
DSM-IV O
criteria O
for O
substance O
abuse O
( O
within O
three O
months O
) O
or O
substance O
dependence O
. O

Written O
consent O
was O
obtained O
following O
the O
guidelines O
of O
the O
Massachusetts O
General O
Hospital O
Human O
Subjects O
Research O
Committee O
. O

Most O
patients O
’ O
symptoms O
were O
assessed O
on O
the O
day O
of O
either O
the O
fMRI O
or O
the O
MEG O
session O
using O
the O
Scale O
for O
the O
Assessment O
of O
Positive O
Symptoms O
( O
SAPS O
: O
) O
, O
and O
the O
Scale O
for O
the O
Assessment O
of O
Negative O
Symptoms O
( O
SANS O
: O
) O
. O

Our O
control O
dataset O
was O
n O
= O
20 O
for O
fMRI O
and O
n O
= O
18 O
for O
MEG O
. O

Twenty-one O
control O
participants O
were O
originally O
recruited O
. O

One O
was O
subsequently O
excluded O
because O
of O
a O
structural O
MRI O
abnormality O
, O
and O
two O
failed O
to O
return O
for O
the O
MEG O
session O
. O

Our O
schizophrenia O
dataset O
was O
n O
= O
16 O
for O
fMRI O
and O
n O
= O
18 O
for O
MEG O
. O

Twenty-two O
schizophrenia O
participants O
were O
originally O
recruited O
, O
but O
two O
were O
excluded O
from O
both O

and O
MEG O
analysis O
( O
technical O
problems O
and O
a O
failure O
to O
complete O
the O
fMRI O
study O
) O
. O

Four O
additional O
patients O
were O
excluded O
from O
the O
fMRI O
analysis O
: O
two O
because O
more O
than O
20 O
% O
of O
volumes O
yielded O
evidence O
of O
artifact O
as O
detected O
using O
the O
ArtRepair O
toolbox O
( O
; O
for O
further O
details O
, O
see O
fMRI O
analysis O
below O
) O
, O
one O
because O
of O
a O
susceptibility O
artifact O
on O
the O
functional O
scans O
( O
of O
unknown O
origin O
) O
, O
and O
one O
because O
of O
poor O
behavioral O
performance O
. O

In O
addition O
, O
two O
patients O
failed O
to O
return O
for O
the O
MEG O
session O
. O

In O
our O
analyses O
of O
the O
MEG O
and O
fMRI O
data O
, O
we O
included O
all O
participants O
who O
completed O
that O

. O

Of O
these O
participants O
, O
14 O
control O
participants O
and O
18 O
people O
with O

participated O
in O
both O

and O

sessions O
. O

We O
show O
the O
demographic O
and O
clinical O
data O
of O
this O
subset O
of O
participants O
in O
Table O
1 O
. O

The O
two O
groups O
were O
matched O
closely O
on O
gender O
, O
race O
, O
and O
ethnicity O
, O
all O
ps O
> O
0.1 O
, O
and O
on O
age O
, O
years O
of O
education O
, O
and O

status O
, O
all O
ps O
> O
0.3 O
. O

Premorbid O

, O
assessed O
with O

Test O
, O
was O

in O

patient O
than O

group O
( O
t O
( O
30 O
) O
= O
2.103 O
, O
p O
= O

) O
. O

Overall O
procedure O
For O
the O
subset O
of O
participants O
who O
completed O
both O
MEG O
and O
MRI O
sessions O
, O
these O
sessions O
were O
carried O
out O
on O
different O
days O
, O
with O
a O
minimum O
of O
two O
days O
in O
between O
sessions O
. O

The O
order O
of O
these O
sessions O
was O
counterbalanced O
across O
participants O
. O

In O
addition O
, O
participants O
were O
assigned O
different O
lists O
in O
each O
session O
so O
that O
no O
participant O
saw O
the O
same O
list O
( O
or O
target O
word O
) O
twice O
. O

Stimuli O
presentation O
and O
task O
The O
structure O
of O
trials O
is O
shown O
in O
Fig O
. O

2 O
. O

For O
fMRI O
, O
additional O
fixations O
( O
2–8 O
s O
) O
were O
added O
after O
25 O
% O
of O
trials O
to O
optimize O
the O
de­convolution O
of O
the O
event-related O
hemodynamic O
response O
function O
( O
; O
see O
https O
: O
//surfer.nmr.mgh.harvard.edu/optseq O
) O
. O

For O
MEG O
, O
at O
least O
700 O
ms O
was O
inserted O
between O
trials O
, O
allowing O
participants O
time O
to O
blink O
. O

In O
both O
sessions O
, O
participants O
carried O
out O
a O
semantic O
monitoring O
task O
: O
to O
press O
a O
response O
button O
as O
quickly O
as O
possible O
whenever O
they O
saw O
an O
insect O
word O
, O
regardless O
of O
whether O
it O
appeared O
in O
the O
prime O
or O
target O
position O
. O

Responses O
were O
considered O
accurate O
if O
they O
were O
registered O
within O
5 O
s O
of O
prime O
onset O
. O

Trials O
were O
presented O
in O
two O
runs O
, O
separated O
by O
a O
short O
break O
. O

A O
brief O
practice O
session O
preceded O
both O
the O
MEG O
and O
fMRI O
sessions O
. O

MEG O
acquisition O
MEG O
data O
was O
acquired O
inside O
a O
magnetically O
shielded O
room O
( O
IMEDCO O
AG O
, O
Switzerland O
) O
using O
a O
Neuromag O
VectorView O
system O
( O
Elekta-Neuromag O
Oy O
, O
Finland O
; O
102 O
sets O
of O
triplet O
sensors O
— O
two O
orthogonal O
planar O
gradiometers O
and O
one O
magnetometer O
) O
, O
with O
an O
online O
bandpass O
filter O
of O
0.03–200 O
Hz O
and O
continuously O
sampled O
at O
600 O
Hz O
. O

We O
also O
