and O
global O
bizarre O
behavior O
.. O
Pearson O
’ O
s O
r O
was O
calculated O
to O
test O
for O
an O
association O
between O
disorganization O
and O
FC O
. O

Functional O
connectomics O
of O
affective O
and O
psychotic O
pathology O
Significance O
Historically O
, O
most O
research O
on O
the O
biological O
origins O
of O
psychiatric O
illness O
has O
focused O
on O
individual O
diagnostic O
categories O
, O
studied O
in O
isolation O
. O

Mounting O
evidence O
indicates O
that O
nominally O
distinct O
psychiatric O
diagnoses O
are O
not O
separated O
by O
clear O
neurobiological O
boundaries O
. O

Here O
, O
we O
derive O
functional O
connectomic O
signatures O
in O
over O
1,000 O
individuals O
, O
including O
patients O
presenting O
with O
different O
categories O
of O
impairment O
( O
psychosis O
) O
, O
clinical O
diagnoses O
, O
and O
severity O
of O
illness O
as O
reflected O
in O
treatment O
seeking O
. O

Our O
analyses O
reveal O
features O
of O
connectome O
functioning O
that O
are O
commonly O
disrupted O
across O
distinct O
forms O
of O
pathology O
, O
scaling O
with O
clinical O
severity O
. O

Conversely O
, O
other O
aspects O
of O
network O
connectivity O
were O
preferentially O
disrupted O
in O
patients O
with O
psychotic O
illness O
. O

These O
data O
have O
important O
implications O
for O
the O
establishment O
of O
functional O
connectome O
fingerprints O
of O
severe O
mental O
disease O
. O

Converging O
evidence O
indicates O
that O
groups O
of O
patients O
with O
nominally O
distinct O
psychiatric O
diagnoses O
are O
not O
separated O
by O
sharp O
or O
discontinuous O
neurobiological O
boundaries O
. O

In O
healthy O
populations O
, O
individual O
differences O
in O
behavior O
are O
reflected O
in O
variability O
across O
the O
collective O
set O
of O
functional O
brain O
connections O
( O
functional O
connectome O
) O
. O

These O
data O
suggest O
that O
the O
spectra O
of O
transdiagnostic O
symptom O
profiles O
observed O
in O
psychiatric O
patients O
may O
map O
onto O
detectable O
patterns O
of O
network O
function O
. O

To O
examine O
the O
manner O
through O
which O
neurobiological O
variation O
might O
underlie O
clinical O
presentation O
, O
we O
obtained O
fMRI O
data O
from O
over O
1,000 O
individuals O
, O
including O
210 O
diagnosed O
with O
a O
primary O
psychotic O
disorder O
or O
affective O
psychosis O
( O
bipolar O
disorder O
with O
psychosis O
and O
schizophrenia O
or O
schizoaffective O
disorder O
) O
, O
192 O
presenting O
with O
a O
primary O
affective O
disorder O
without O
psychosis O
( O
unipolar O
depression O
, O
bipolar O
disorder O
without O
psychosis O
) O
, O
and O
608 O
demographically O
matched O
healthy O
comparison O
participants O
recruited O
through O
a O
large-scale O
study O
of O
brain O
imaging O
and O
genetics O
. O

Here O
, O
we O
examine O
variation O
in O
functional O
connectomes O
across O
psychiatric O
diagnoses O
, O
finding O
striking O
evidence O
for O
disease O
connectomic O
“ O
fingerprints O
” O
that O
are O
commonly O
disrupted O
across O
distinct O
forms O
of O
pathology O
and O
appear O
to O
scale O
as O
a O
function O
of O
illness O
severity O
. O

The O
presence O
of O
affective O
and O
psychotic O
illnesses O
was O
associated O
with O
graded O
disruptions O
in O
frontoparietal O
network O
connectivity O
( O
encompassing O
aspects O
of O
dorsolateral O
prefrontal O
, O
dorsomedial O
prefrontal O
, O
lateral O
parietal O
, O
and O
posterior O
temporal O
cortices O
) O
. O

Conversely O
, O
other O
properties O
of O
network O
connectivity O
, O
including O
default O
network O
integrity O
, O
were O
preferentially O
disrupted O
in O
patients O
with O
psychotic O
illness O
, O
but O
not O
patients O
without O
psychotic O
symptoms O
. O

This O
work O
allows O
us O
to O
establish O
key O
biological O
and O
clinical O
features O
of O
the O
functional O
connectomes O
of O
severe O
mental O
disease O
. O

Methods O
Between O
November O
2008 O
and O
June O
2017 O
, O
fMRI O
data O
were O
collected O
from O
a O
total O
of O
1,010 O
individuals O
, O
including O
210 O
diagnosed O
with O
a O
primary O
psychotic O
disorder O
( O
137 O
meeting O
criteria O
for O
schizophrenia O
or O
schizoaffective O
disorder O
, O
73 O
with O
bipolar O
disorder O
with O
psychosis O
) O
, O
192 O
presenting O
with O
a O
primary O
affective O
disorder O
without O
psychosis O
( O
26 O
with O
bipolar O
disorder O
without O
psychosis O
, O
57 O
treatment-seeking O
individuals O
with O
unipolar O
depression O
, O
109 O
nontreatment-seeking O
individuals O
with O
unipolar O
depression O
) O
, O
and O
608 O
demographically O
matched O
healthy O
comparison O
participants O
recruited O
through O
an O
ongoing O
, O
large-scale O
study O
of O
brain O
imaging O
and O
genetics O
. O

Diagnosis O
was O
determined O
using O
the O
Structured O
Clinical O
Interview O
for O
the O
DSM-IV O
. O

Details O
regarding O
participant O
recruitment O
and O
characterization O
, O
as O
well O
as O
the O
demographic O
and O
clinical O
characteristics O
of O
the O
patient O
and O
matched O
healthy O
comparison O
samples O
, O
are O
available O
in O
SI O
Appendix O
, O
Table O
S1 O
. O

In O
brief O
, O
patients O
were O
recruited O
from O
clinical O
services O
at O
MGH O
or O
McLean O
Hospital O
through O
the O
procedures O
detailed O
in O
Baker O
et O
al O
.. O
Nontreatment-seeking O
individuals O
who O
met O
diagnostic O
criteria O
for O
unipolar O
depression O
were O
recruited O
from O
the O
surrounding O
Boston O
area O
using O
the O
procedures O
detailed O
in O
Dillon O
et O
al O
.. O

Healthy O
comparison O
participants O
were O
selected O
from O
an O
existing O
database O
of O
adults O
( O
aged O
18–83 O
y O
) O
, O
scanned O
previously O
using O
identical O
pulse O
sequences O
on O
identical O
scanners O
, O
and O
selected O
to O
match O
patients O
on O
the O
basis O
of O
age O
, O
gender O
, O
race O
, O
handedness O
, O
as O
well O
as O
a O
mean O
slice-based O
signal-to-noise O
ratio O
( O
SNR O
) O
derived O
from O
the O
participant O
’ O
s O
blood O
oxygenation O
level–dependent O
( O
BOLD O
) O
T2 O
* O
image O
series O
. O

In O
this O
context O
, O
SNR O
is O
calculated O
as O
the O
mean/SD O
of O
the O
mean O
slice O
intensity O
time O
series O
. O

Using O
this O
strategy O
, O
we O
were O
able O
to O
ensure O
statistically O
matched O
distributions O
for O
both O
demographic O
variables O
and O
comparable O
data O
quality O
( O
as O
well O
as O
head O
movement O
metrics O
) O
. O

The O
reported O
experiments O
were O
approved O
by O
the O
Partners O
HealthCare O
Institutional O
Review O
Board O
and O
the O
Harvard O
University O
Committee O
on O
the O
Use O
of O
Human O
Subjects O
in O
Research O
McLean O
Hospital O
Institutional O
Review O
Board O
, O
and O
all O
participants O
gave O
written O
informed O
consent O
before O
participating O
in O
the O
study O
. O

MRI O
Data O
Acquisition O
. O

Imaging O
data O
were O
collected O
on O
3T O
Tim O
Trio O
scanners O
( O
Siemens O
) O
using O
either O
12- O
or O
32-channel O
phased-array O
head O
coils O
at O
Harvard O
University O
, O
MGH O
, O
or O
McLean O
Hospital O
as O
detailed O
in O
Holmes O
et O
al O
.. O

Briefly O
, O
structural O
data O
included O
a O
high-resolution O
, O
multiecho O
T1-weighted O
magnetization-prepared O
gradient-echo O
image O
[ O
144 O
slices O
, O
repetition O
time O
( O
TR O
) O
= O
2,200 O
ms O
, O
inversion O
time O
( O
TI O
) O
= O
1,100 O
ms O
, O
echo O
time O
( O
TE O
) O
= O
1.54 O
ms O
for O
image O
1 O
to O
7.01 O
ms O
for O
image O
4 O
, O
flip O
angle O
= O
7° O
, O
voxels O
= O
1.2 O
mm3 O
, O
field-of-view O
( O
FOV O
) O
= O
230 O
] O
. O

Functional O
data O
were O
acquired O
using O
a O
gradient-echo O
echoplanar O
imaging O
sequence O
( O
47 O
axial O
slices O
, O
interleaved O
with O
no O
gap O
) O
, O
124 O
time O
points O
( O
TR O
= O
3000 O
ms O
, O
TE O
= O
30 O
ms O
, O
flip O
angle O
= O
85° O
, O
voxels O
= O
3 O
mm3 O
, O
FOV O
= O
216 O
) O
. O

Participants O
were O
instructed O
to O
remain O
still O
and O
keep O
their O
eyes O
open O
, O
while O
blinking O
normally O
. O

Although O
no O
fixation O
image O
was O
used O
, O
participants O
with O
psychotic O
illness O
were O
monitored O
via O
eye-tracking O
video O
to O
ensure O
compliance O
during O
functional O
scans O
. O

Software O
upgrades O
( O
VB13 O
, O
VB15 O
, O
VB17 O
) O
occurred O
during O
data O
collection O
. O

All O
results O
are O
reported O
after O
partialing O
out O
variance O
associated O
with O
coil O
, O
scanner O
( O
Harvard O
Bay O
1 O
, O
McLean O
Bay O
1 O
, O
MGH O
Bay O
4 O
, O
MGH O
Bay O
8 O
, O
and O
so O
forth O
) O
, O
and O
software O
upgrade O
, O
as O
well O
as O
age O
, O
sex O
, O
handedness O
, O
race O
, O
and O
ethnicity O
. O

All O
treatment-seeking O
patient O
samples O
were O
collected O
on O
a O
12-channel O
coil O
. O

In O
the O
healthy O
comparison O
, O
participants O
and O
nontreatment-seeking O
individuals O
with O
unipolar O
depression O
78.5 O
and O
36.7 O
% O
of O
the O
data O
were O
collected O
on O
a O
12-channel O
coil O
, O
respectively O
. O

All O
reported O
analyses O
are O
consistent O
when O
separately O
considering O
only O
12-channel O
and O
32-channel O
coil O
data O
. O

The O
patient O
and O
healthy O
comparison O
samples O
did O
not O
differ O
in O
mean O
slice-based O
signal-to-noise O
[ O
all O
patients O
: O
172.4 O
± O
66.8 O
; O
healthy O
comparison O
: O
175.3 O
± O
51.2 O
; O
F O
( O
1 O
, O
1,008 O
) O
= O
0.61 O
, O
P O
= O
0.43 O
] O
. O

Patients O
displayed O
a O
significantly O
greater O
number O
of O
micromovements O
( O
translations O
> O
0.1 O
mm O
) O
during O
data O
collection O
[ O
all O
patients O
: O
25.5 O
± O
27.2 O
; O
healthy O
comparison O
: O
20.3 O
± O
24.7 O
; O
F O
( O
1 O
, O
1,008 O
) O
= O
9.89 O
, O
P O
≤ O
0.005 O
] O
. O

The O
reported O
group-level O
effects O
are O
consistent O
when O
incorporating O
mean O
slice-based O
SNR O
and O
micromovement O
counts O
as O
model O
covariates O
. O

Preprocessing O
. O

Data O
were O
analyzed O
with O
a O
series O
of O
steps O
common O
to O
intrinsic O
connectivity O
analyses O
and O
further O
elaborated O
in O
Holmes O
et O
al O
. O

and O
Yeo O
et O
al O
.. O
Preprocessing O
included O
discarding O
the O
first O
four O
volumes O
of O
each O
run O
to O
allow O
for O
T1-equilibration O
effects O
, O
compensating O
for O
slice O
acquisition-dependent O
time O
shifts O
per O
volume O
, O
and O
correcting O
for O
head O
motion O
using O
rigid O
body O
translation O
and O
rotation O
. O

Additional O
steps O
involved O
the O
removal O
of O
constant O
offset O
and O
linear O
trends O
over O
each O
run O
and O
the O
use O
of O
a O
temporal O
filter O
to O
retain O
frequencies O
below O
0.08 O
Hz O
. O

Sources O
of O
spurious O
variance O
, O
along O
with O
their O
temporal O
derivatives O
, O
were O
removed O
through O
linear O
regression O
. O

These O
included O
six O
parameters O
obtained O
by O
correction O
for O
rigid-body O
head O
motion O
, O
the O
signal O
averaged O
over O
the O
whole O
brain O
, O
the O
signal O
averaged O
over O
the O
ventricles O
, O
and O
the O
signal O
averaged O
over O
the O
deep O
cerebral O
white O
matter O
. O

Functional O
data O
were O
first O
aligned O
to O
the O
structural O
image O
using O
the O
FreeSurfer O
software O
package O
, O
smoothed O
using O
a O
6-mm O
kernel O
applied O
in O
surface O
space O
, O
and O
down-sampled O
to O
a O
4-mm O
mesh O
Yeo O
et O
al O
.. O
Functional O
Parcellation O
. O

Cortical O
functional O
coupling O
matrices O
were O
computed O
for O
each O
participant O
, O
across O
all O
available O
regions O
within O
the O
17 O
network O
functional O
parcellation O
of O
Yeo O
et O
al O
. O

( O
Fig O
. O

1A O
) O
. O

This O
parcellation O
consisted O
of O
122 O
cortical O
regions O
composed O
of O
61 O
roughly O
symmetric O
territories O
in O
the O
left O
and O
right O
hemispheres O
. O

Correlation O
matrices O
were O
constructed O
to O
include O
all O
regional O
pairs O
arranged O
by O
network O
membership O
. O

Pearson O
correlation O
coefficients O
were O
computed O
between O
each O
regional O
fMRI O
time O
course O
, O
averaged O
across O
all O
vertices O
within O
the O
region O
, O
and O
the O
mean O
fMRI O
time O
course O
for O
every O
other O
region O
( O
Fig O
. O

1 O
B–D O
) O
. O

Correlation O
values O
were O
z-transformed O
to O
increase O
normality O
of O
the O
correlation O
distribution O
and O
compared O
across O
groups O
using O
an O
ANOVA O
after O
linear O
regression O
of O
nuisance O
variables O
. O

Reported O
tests O
survived O
correction O
for O
multiple O
comparisons O
using O
a O
family-wise O
error O
rate O
( O
Bonferroni O
procedure O
) O
of O
P O
≤ O
0.05 O
or O
FDR O
of O
q O
≤ O
0.05 O
. O

Readers O
should O
note O
that O
caution O
is O
warranted O
when O
interpreting O
group O
differences O
in O
within-network O
connectivity O
for O
subnetworks O
with O
limited O
numbers O
of O
parcels O
( O
e.g. O
, O
frontoparietal O
control O
C O
and O
default O
D O
) O
. O

A O
method O
for O
building O
a O
genome-connectome O
bipartite O
graph O
model O
It O
has O
been O
widely O
shown O
that O
genomic O
factors O
influence O
both O
risk O
for O
schizophrenia O
and O
variation O
in O
functional O
brain O
connectivity O
. O

Moreover O
, O
schizophrenia O
is O
characterized O
by O
disrupted O
brain O
connectivity O
. O

In O
this O
work O
, O
we O
proposed O
a O
genome-connectome O
bipartite O
graph O
model O
to O
perform O
imaging O
genomic O
analysis O
. O

Functional O
network O
connectivity O
( O
FNC O
) O
was O
estimated O
after O
decomposing O
resting O
state O
functional O
magnetic O
resonance O
imaging O
data O
from O
both O
healthy O
controls O
( O
HC O
) O
and O
patients O
with O
schizophrenia O
( O
SZ O
) O
into O
spatial O
brain O
components O
using O
group O
independent O
component O
analysis O
( O
G-ICA O
) O
. O

Then O
83 O
FNC O
connections O
showing O
a O
group O
difference O
( O
HC O
vs O
SZ O
) O
were O
selected O
as O
fMRI O
nodes O
, O
and O
eighty-one O
schizophrenia-related O
single O
nucleotide O
polymorphisms O
( O
SNPs O
) O
were O
selected O
as O
genetic O
nodes O
respectively O
in O
the O
bipartite O
graph O
. O

Edges O
connecting O
pairs O
of O
genetic O
and O
fMRI O
nodes O
were O
defined O
based O
on O
the O
SNP-FNC O
associations O
across O
subjects O
evaluated O
by O
a O
general O
linear O
model O
. O

Results O
show O
that O
some O
SNP O
nodes O
in O
the O
bipartite O
graph O
have O
a O
high O
degree O
implying O
they O
are O
influential O
in O
modulating O
brain O
connectivity O
and O
may O
be O
more O
strongly O
associated O
with O
the O
risk O
of O
schizophrenia O
than O
other O
SNPs O
. O

A O
bi-clustering O
analysis O
detected O
a O
cluster O
with O
15 O
SNPs O
interacting O
with O
38 O
FNC O
connections O
, O
most O
of O
which O
were O
within O
or O
between O
somato-motor O
and O
visual O
brain O
areas O
. O

This O
suggests O
that O
the O
activity O
of O
these O
brain O
regions O
may O
be O
related O
to O
common O
SNPs O
and O
provides O
insights O
into O
the O
pathology O
of O
schizophrenia O
. O

The O
findings O
suggest O
that O
the O
SNP-FNC O
bipartite O
graph O
approach O
is O
a O
novel O
model O
to O
investigate O
genetic O
influences O
on O
functional O
brain O
connectivity O
in O
mental O
illness O
. O

Materials O
and O
Methods O
: O
Participants O
A O
total O
of O
97 O
HCs O
( O
30 O
female O
; O
5 O
left O
handed O
; O
age O
: O
range O
19 O
– O
60 O
; O
mean O
± O
SD O
37 O
± O
11 O
) O
and O
70 O
SZs O
( O
11 O
female O
; O
1 O
left O
handed O
; O
age O
: O
range O
18 O
– O
60 O
; O
mean O
± O
SD O
38 O
± O
11 O
) O
from O
7 O
research O
sites O
participated O
in O
this O
study O
. O

All O
participants O
provided O
written O
, O
informed O
consent O
in O
accordance O
with O
internal O
review O
boards O
of O
their O
corresponding O
institutions O
. O

fMRI O
data O
acquisition O
Brain O
imaging O
data O
were O
collected O
from O
3T O
Siemens O
Tim O
Trio O
MRI O
Systems O
( O
6 O
of O
the O
7 O
sites O
) O
and O
a O
3T O
General O
Electric O
Discovery O
MR750 O
scanner O
( O
the O
other O
site O
) O
. O

Resting O
state O
fMRI O
scans O
were O
acquired O
using O
a O
standard O
gradient-echo O
planar O
imaging O
paradigm O
: O
FOV O
of O
220 O
× O
220 O
mm O
( O
64 O
× O
64 O
matrix O
) O
, O
TR O
= O
2 O
s O
, O
TE O
= O
30 O
ms O
, O
flip O
angle O
= O
70° O
, O
32 O
sequential O
ascending O
axial O
slices O
of O
4 O
mm O
thickness O
and O
1 O
mm O
skip O
. O

A O
total O
of O
162 O
brain O
volumes O
were O
acquired O
for O
each O
subject O
with O
eyes O
closed O
over O
5 O
minutes O
and O
24 O
seconds O
. O

fMRI O
data O
preprocessing O
FMRI O
data O
preprocessing O
was O
performed O
using O
a O
combination O
of O
toolboxes O
( O
AFNI O
: O
https O
: O
//afni.nimh.nih.gov/ O
; O
SPM O
: O
http O
: O
//www.fil.ion.ucl.ac.uk/spm/ O
; O
GIFT O
: O
http O
: O
//mialab.mrn.org/software/gift O
) O
and O
custom O
Matlab O
code O
( O
https O
: O
//www.mathworks.com/products/matlab.html O
) O
. O

We O
performed O
rigid O
body O
motion O
correction O
using O
the O
INRIAlign O
toolbox O
in O
SPM O
to O
correct O
for O
subject O
head O
motion O
followed O
by O
slice-timing O
correction O
to O
account O
for O
timing O
differences O
in O
slice O
acquisition O
. O

Then O
the O
fMRI O
data O
were O
de-spiked O
using O
AFNI O
’ O
s O
3dDespike O
algorithm O
to O
mitigate O
the O
impact O
of O
outliers O
. O

The O
fMRI O
data O
were O
subsequently O
warped O
to O
a O
Montreal O
Neurological O
Institute O
( O
MNI O
) O
template O
and O
resampled O
to O
3 O
× O
3 O
× O
3 O
mm O
isotropic O
voxels O
. O

Instead O
of O
Gaussian O
smoothing O
, O
we O
smoothed O
the O
data O
to O
6 O
mm O
full O
width O
at O
half O
maximum O
( O
FWHM O
) O
using O
AFNI O
’ O
s O
BlurToFWHM O
algorithm O
which O
performs O
smoothing O
by O
a O
conservative O
finite O
difference O
approximation O
to O
the O
diffusion O
equation O
. O

This O
approach O
had O
been O
shown O
to O
reduce O
scanner O
specific O
variability O
in O
smoothness O
providing O
“ O
smoothness O
equivalence O
” O
to O
data O
across O
sites O
. O

Each O
voxel O
time O
course O
was O
variance O
normalized O
prior O
to O
performing O
group O
ICA O
as O
this O
has O
shown O
to O
better O
decompose O
subcortical O
sources O
in O
addition O
to O
cortical O
networks O
. O

Group O
ICA O
of O
fMRI O
After O
preprocessing O
, O
fMRI O
of O
both O
controls O
and O
patients O
were O
analyzed O
using O
a O
spatial O
group O
ICA O
as O
implemented O
in O
GIFT O
software O
. O

Spatial O
ICA O
decomposes O
the O
subject O
data O
into O
linear O
mixtures O
of O
spatially O
independent O
components O
( O
ICs O
) O
that O
exhibit O
unique O
time O
course O
profiles O
. O

A O
subject-specific O
data O
reduction O
step O
was O
first O
used O
to O
reduce O
162-time-point O
data O
into O
100 O
directions O
of O
maximal O
variability O
using O
principal O
component O
analysis O
( O
PCA O
) O
. O

Then O
subject-reduced O
data O
were O
concatenated O
along O
the O
time O
dimension O
and O
a O
second O
PCA O
step O
reduced O
this O
grouped O
data O
matrix O
further O
into O
100 O
components O
along O
directions O
of O
maximal O
group O
variability O
. O

One O
hundred O
ICs O
were O
obtained O
from O
the O
group O
PCA O
reduced O
matrix O
using O
the O
Infomax O
algorithm O
. O

To O
ensure O
stability O
of O
estimation O
, O
we O
repeated O
the O
ICA O
algorithm O
20 O
times O
in O
ICASSO O
( O
http O
: O
//research.ics.aalto.fi/ica/icasso/ O
) O
, O
and O
the O
most O
central O
run O
was O
selected O
and O
further O
analyzed O
. O

Subject O
specific O
spatial O
maps O
( O
SMs O
) O
and O
time O
courses O
( O
TCs O
) O
were O
obtained O
using O
the O
spatiotemporal O
regression O
back O
reconstruction O
approach O
implemented O
in O
GIFT O
. O

Post-ICA O
processing O
Subject-specific O
SMs O
and O
TCs O
underwent O
post-processing O
as O
described O
in O
our O
earlier O
work O
. O

Briefly O
, O
we O
obtained O
one O
sample O
t-test O
maps O
for O
each O
SM O
across O
all O
subjects O
and O
thresholded O
these O
maps O
to O
obtain O
regions O
of O
peak O
activation O
clusters O
for O
that O
component O
. O

We O
also O
computed O
mean O
power O
spectra O
of O
the O
corresponding O
TCs O
. O

We O
identified O
a O
set O
of O
components O
as O
intrinsic O
connectivity O
networks O
( O
ICNs O
) O
if O
their O
peak O
activation O
clusters O
fell O
on O
gray O
matter O
and O
showed O
less O
overlap O
with O
known O
vascular O
, O
susceptibility O
, O
ventricular O
, O
and O
edge O
regions O
corresponding O
to O
head O
motion O
. O

We O
also O
ensured O
that O
the O
mean O
power O
spectra O
of O
the O
selected O
ICN O
time O
courses O
showed O
higher O
low O
frequency O
spectral O
power O
. O

This O
selection O
procedure O
resulted O
in O
50 O
ICNs O
out O
of O
the O
100 O
ICs O
obtained O
. O

The O
subject O
specific O
TCs O
corresponding O
to O
the O
50 O
ICNs O
selected O
were O
detrended O
, O
despiked O
, O
and O
then O
band O
pass O
filtered O
( O
0.01 O
− O
0.10 O
Hz O
) O
before O
the O
subsequent O
FNC O
analysis O
. O

FNC O
analysis O
and O
the O
definition O
of O
connectome O
nodes O
We O
constructed O
the O
FNC O
which O
is O
defined O
as O
pairwise O
correlations O
between O
ICN O
time O
courses O
, O
as O
a O
measure O
of O
connectivity O
among O
different O
ICNs O
during O
the O
scan O
duration O
for O
each O
individual O
. O

In O
this O
work O
, O
the O
FNC O
computed O
using O
the O
whole O
ICN O
time O
courses O
is O
referred O
to O
as O
stationary O
or O
static O
FNC O
( O
sFNC O
) O
. O

The O
mean O
sFNC O
matrix O
across O
subjects O
was O
also O
computed O
in O
each O
group O
. O

FMRI O
nodes O
in O
the O
gene-fMRI O
bipartite O
graph O
represent O
FNC O
connections O
in O
the O
sFNC O
matrix O
. O

Eighty-three O
fMRI O
nodes O
were O
selected O
by O
below O
criteria O
: O
1 O
. O

Correlation O
value O
of O
the O
group O
mean O
FNC O
connection O
of O
HCs O
is O
higher O
than O
0.3268 O
( O
r O
> O
0.3268 O
) O
. O

This O
criterion O
was O
determined O
based O
on O
the O
significant O
correlation O
between O
ICNs O
( O
q O
< O
0.05 O
, O
Bonferroni O
correction O
) O
. O

2 O
. O

Group O
difference O
( O
HCs O
vs O
SZs O
) O
on O
the O
correlation O
value O
is O
significant O
( O
q O
< O
0.05 O
, O
false O
discovery O
rate O
[ O
FDR O
] O
correction O
) O
. O

SNP O
data O
acquisition O
and O
processing O
DNA O
of O
each O
subject O
was O
extracted O
from O
blood O
or O
saliva O
samples O
. O

Illumina O
Human O
Omni1-Quad O
, O
Illumina O
Human O
Omni5 O
, O
and O
Illumina O
Infinium O
MEGA O
+ O
Psych O
were O
used O
for O
genotyping O
. O

No O
significant O
difference O
was O
noted O
in O
genotyping O
call O
rates O
between O
blood O
and O
saliva O
samples O
. O

The O
data O
then O
went O
through O
quality O
control O
( O
QC O
) O
, O
imputation O
and O
post-imputation O
QC O
as O
described O
in O
. O

In O
brief O
, O
a O
standard O
QC O
was O
firstly O
performed O
using O
PLINK O
. O

Then O
imputation O
was O
conducted O
with O
SHAPEIT O
used O
for O
pre-phasing O
, O
IMPUTE2 O
for O
imputation O
, O
and O
the O
1000 O
Genomes O
data O
as O
the O
reference O
panel O
. O

Only O
markers O
with O
high O
imputation O
qualities O
( O
INFO O
score O
> O
0.95 O
) O
were O
retained O
. O

The O
imputed O
data O
were O
then O
aggregated O
and O
went O
through O
the O
post-imputation O
QC O
. O

Finally O
, O
linkage O
disequilibrium O
( O
LD O
) O
pruning O
( O
r2 O
> O
0.9 O
) O
was O
applied O
to O
yield O
977,242 O
SNPs O
for O
which O
population O
structure O
was O
corrected O
using O
PCA O
. O

Definition O
of O
genome O
nodes O
In O
this O
study O
, O
we O
used O
schizophrenia-related O
SNPs O
as O
genetic O
nodes O
. O

Firstly O
, O
the O
SNP O
with O
the O
lowest O
p O
value O
in O
each O
of O
the O
108 O
schizophrenia-associated O
genetic O
loci O
reported O
by O
the O
largest O
psychiatric O
genomic O
consortium O
( O
PGC O
) O
study O
( O
Schizophrenia O
Working O
Group O
of O
the O
Psychiatric O
Genomics O
, O
2014 O
) O
was O
identified O
. O

SNPs O
with O
0 O
risk O
alleles O
occurring O
in O
less O
than O
17 O
subjects O
were O
excluded O
. O

This O
resulted O
in O
a O
set O
of O
81 O
SNPs O
selected O
as O
gene O
nodes O
in O
the O
genome-connectome O
bipartite O
graph O
. O

Building O
the O
genome-connectome O
bipartite O
graph O
To O
build O
edges O
in O
the O
bipartite O
graph O
, O
we O
used O
a O
general O
linear O
model O
( O
a O
MANCOVA O
framework O
: O
http O
: O
//mialab.mrn.org/software/mancovan O
) O
to O
evaluate O
the O
association O
between O
each O
pair O
of O
genome-connectome O
nodes O
. O

In O
this O
model O
, O
for O
each O
pair O
of O
SNP-FNC O
, O
correlation O
values O
of O
all O
subjects O
for O
the O
FNC O
connection O
were O
input O
as O
the O
dependent O
variable O
, O
and O
the O
SNP O
data O
coded O
based O
on O
number O
of O
risk O
allele O
( O
0 O
, O
1 O
, O
or O
2 O
) O
of O
all O
subjects O
were O
input O
as O
the O
independent O
variable O
. O

To O
control O
sites O
, O
groups O
, O
and O
ethnicity O
effects O
, O
they O
were O
input O
as O
covariates O
. O

A O
significant O
( O
p O
< O
0.05 O
, O
uncorrected O
) O
association O
was O
used O
to O
determine O
whether O
there O
is O
an O
edge O
between O
those O
two O
nodes O
. O

Finally O
the O
degree O
of O
each O
SNP O
node O
in O
the O
bipartite O
graph O
was O
computed O
. O

Biclustering O
analysis O
Biclustering O
is O
a O
data O
mining O
technique O
which O
allows O
simultaneous O
clustering O
of O
the O
rows O
and O
columns O
of O
a O
matrix O
. O

As O
a O
result O
, O
submatrices O
exhibiting O
unique O
patterns O
can O
be O
revealed O
helping O
us O
to O
better O
understand O
the O
relationship O
between O
row O
and O
column O
variables O
. O

To O
investigate O
if O
any O
subset O
of O
SNPs O
are O
densely O
associated O
with O
any O
subset O
of O
FNC O
connections O
, O
we O
performed O
a O
biclustering O
analysis O
on O
the O
SNP-FNC O
bipartite O
graph O
using O
MTBA O
( O
a O
Matlab O
toolbox O
for O
biclustering O
analysis O
) O
. O

Deficient O
Functioning O
of O
Fronto-Striatal O
Circuits O
During O
the O
Resolution O
of O
Cognitive O
Conflict O
in O
Cannabis-Using O
Youth O
Objective O
: O
Disturbances O
in O
self-regulatory O
control O
are O
involved O
in O
the O
initiation O
and O
maintenance O
of O
addiction O
, O
including O
cannabis O
use O
disorder O
( O
CUD O
) O
. O

In O
adults O
, O
chronic O
cannabis O
use O
is O
associated O
with O
disturbances O
in O
fronto-striatal O
circuits O
during O
tasks O
that O
require O
the O
engagement O
of O
self-regulatory O
control O
, O
including O
the O
resolution O
of O
cognitive O
conflict O
. O

Understudied O
are O
the O
behavioral O
and O
neural O
correlates O
of O
these O
processes O
earlier O
in O
the O
course O
of O
cannabis O
use O
, O
disentangled O
from O
effects O
of O
long-term O
use O
. O

The O
present O
study O
investigates O
the O
functioning O
of O
fronto-striatal O
circuits O
during O
the O
resolution O
of O
cognitive O
conflict O
in O
cannabis-using O
youth O
. O

Method O
: O
Functional O
magnetic O
resonance O
imaging O
data O
was O
acquired O
from O
28 O
cannabis-using O
( O
CU O
) O
youth O
and O
32 O
age-matched O
healthy O
participants O
( O
HC O
) O
during O
the O
performance O
of O
a O
Simon O
task O
. O

General O
linear O
modeling O
was O
used O
to O
compare O
patterns O
of O
brain O
activation O
during O
correct O
responses O
to O
conflict O
stimuli O
across O
groups O
. O

Psychophysiological O
interaction O
analyses O
were O
used O
to O
examine O
conflict-related O
fronto-striatal O
connectivity O
across O
groups O
. O

Associations O
of O
fronto-striatal O
activation O
and O
connectivity O
with O
cannabis O
use O
measures O
were O
explored O
. O

Results O
: O
Reduced O
conflict-related O
activity O
was O
detected O
in O
CU O
relative O
to O
HC O
youth O
in O
fronto-striatal O
regions O
, O
including O
ventromedial O
prefrontal O
cortex O
( O
vmPFC O
) O
, O
striatum O
, O
pallidum O
and O
thalamus O
. O

Fronto-striatal O
connectivity O
did O
not O
differ O
across O
groups O
, O
but O
negative O
connectivity O
between O
vmPFC O
and O
striatum O
was O
detected O
in O
both O
groups O
. O

Conclusion O
: O
These O
findings O
are O
consistent O
with O
previous O
reports O
of O
cannabis-associated O
disturbances O
in O
fronto-striatal O
circuits O
in O
adults O
and O
point O
to O
the O
specific O
influence O
of O
cannabis O
on O
neurodevelopmental O
changes O
in O
youth O
. O

Future O
studies O
should O
examine O
whether O
fronto-striatal O
functioning O
is O
a O
reliable O
marker O
of O
CUD O
severity O
and O
potential O
target O
for O
circuit-based O
interventions O
. O

METHOD O
Participants O
Participants O
were O
28 O
adolescents O
and O
emerging O
adults O
with O
significant O
cannabis O
use O
( O
CU O
) O
and O
32 O
healthy O
controls O
( O
HC O
) O
, O
aged O
14–23 O
years O
, O
group O
matched O
on O
age O
, O
gender O
, O
socioeconomic O
status O
( O
SES O
) O
, O
race O
and O
ethnicity O
. O

Demographics O
for O
all O
participants O
and O
clinical O
ratings O
for O
the O
CU O
group O
are O
shown O
in O
Table O
1 O
. O

Participants O
were O
recruited O
through O
flyers O
, O
Internet O
advertisements O
, O
word-of-mouth O
, O
and O
local O
mental O
health O
clinics O
and O
schools O
. O

This O
study O
aimed O
to O
assess O
the O
functioning O
of O
fronto-striatal O
circuits O
early O
in O
the O
course O
of O
a O
problematic O
cannabis O
use O
trajectory O
. O

DSM O
diagnostic O
criteria O
poorly O
capture O
the O
patterns O
, O
consequences O
, O
and O
severity O
of O
cannabis O
use O
in O
youth O
and O
teens O
often O
experience O
impairment O
without O
meeting O
criteria O
for O
DSM-IV O
substance O
abuse/dependence O
or O
a O
DSM-5 O
SUD O
. O

Thus O
, O
inclusion O
in O
the O
CU O
group O
required O
meeting O
at O
least O
one O
DSM-IV O
diagnostic O
criterion O
. O

Because O
it O
is O
possible O
that O
infrequent O
cannabis O
use O
may O
not O
be O
associated O
with O
neural O
changes O
, O
inclusion O
in O
the O
CU O
group O
required O
“ O
moderate O
” O
use O
defined O
as O
at O
least O
twice O
weekly O
. O

CU O
participants O
were O
excluded O
if O
they O
had O
a O
lifetime O
diagnosis O
of O
SUD O
( O
dependence O
or O
abuse O
) O
other O
than O
cannabis O
or O
if O
any O
substance O
other O
than O
cannabis O
( O
THC O
) O
was O
detected O
by O
a O
urine O
drug O
test O
( O
Construction O
12-Drug O
Screen O
Test O
, O
Innovacon O
, O
Inc. O
, O
San O
Diego O
, O
CA O
) O
administered O
on O
the O
day O
of O
the O
scan O
. O

In O
addition O
, O
CU O
participants O
were O
asked O
to O
abstain O
at O
least O
12 O
hours O
prior O
to O
assessment/scanning O
. O

It O
should O
be O
noted O
, O
however O
, O
that O
urine O
drug O
testing O
was O
not O
used O
to O
determine O
cannabis O
use O
abstinence O
prior O
to O
scanning O
because O
THC O
can O
be O
detected O
in O
urine O
beyond O
12 O
hours O
after O
use O
. O

HC O
participants O
did O
not O
meet O
DSM-IV O
criteria O
for O
any O
SUD O
and O
had O
no O
history O
of O
cannabis O
use O
. O

Cannabis O
use O
and O
DSM O
criteria O
for O
cannabis-related O
disorders O
were O
assessed O
with O
the O
Comprehensive O
Adolescent O
Severity O
Inventory O
( O
CASI-A O
) O
, O
the O
Timeline O
Follow-Back O
( O
TLFB O
) O
, O
the O
Structured O
Clinical O
Interview O
for O
DSM-IV O
Axis-I O
Disorders O
( O
SCID-I O
) O
for O
participants O
18 O
years O
and O
older O
, O
and O
the O
Kiddie-Schedule O
for O
Affective O
Disorders O
and O
Schizophrenia-Present O
and O
Lifetime O
Version O
( O
K-SADS-PL O
) O
for O
those O
under O
18 O
years O
. O

Participants O
with O
a O
history O
of O
neurological O
illness O
, O
past O
seizures O
, O
head O
trauma O
with O
loss O
of O
consciousness O
, O
mental O
retardation O
, O
developmental O
disorder O
, O
or O
Axis O
I O
psychiatric O
disorders O
were O
excluded O
. O

Depressive O
, O
anxiety O
and O
attention O
deficit O
hyperactivity O
( O
ADHD O
) O
disorders O
were O
permitted O
in O
the O
CU O
group O
, O
given O
their O
high O
co-morbidity O
with O
moderate O
to O
heavy O
cannabis O
use O
in O
youth O
. O

The O
presence O
of O
these O
and O
other O
Axis O
1 O
disorders O
was O
determined O
based O
on O
the O
SCID-I O
or O
K-SADS-PL O
. O

The O
DuPaul-Barkley O
Attention-Deficit O
Hyperactivity O
Disorder O
Rating O
Scale O
quantified O
symptoms O
of O
inattention O
and O
hyperactivity O
. O

Full-scale O
IQs O
were O
estimated O
using O
the O
Wechsler O
Abbreviated O
Scale O
of O
Intelligence O
( O
WASI O
) O
, O
and O
SES O
was O
calculated O
based O
on O
parental O
academic O
and O
occupational O
achievement O
using O
the O
Modified O
Hollingshead O
4-Factor O
Index O
. O

All O
clinical O
data O
were O
reviewed O
and O
confirmed O
by O
a O
psychiatrist O
who O
also O
conducted O
clinical O
interviews O
for O
all O
participants O
. O

Adult O
participants O
provided O
informed O
consent O
. O

Minor O
participants O
provided O
assent O
, O
and O
their O
caregivers O
provided O
consent O
. O

The O
research O
protocol O
was O
approved O
by O
the O
Institutional O
Review O
Board O
of O
the O
New O
York O
State O
Psychiatric O
Institute O
. O

FMRI O
Paradigm O
Participants O
completed O
the O
Simon O
task O
( O
previously O
described O
) O
. O

Briefly O
, O
participants O
were O
presented O
with O
a O
leftward O
or O
rightward O
pointing O
arrow O
on O
each O
trial O
that O
was O
either O
congruent O
or O
incongruent O
with O
its O
position O
( O
left O
or O
right O
) O
on O
the O
screen O
. O

They O
were O
instructed O
to O
respond O
as O
quickly O
and O
accurately O
as O
possible O
to O
the O
direction O
of O
the O
arrow O
by O
pressing O
a O
button O
on O
a O
response O
box O
using O
the O
index O
finger O
for O
left O
and O
the O
middle O
finger O
for O
right O
. O

Stimulus O
duration O
was O
1300 O
ms O
, O
with O
jittered O
intervals O
ranging O
from O
4160 O
to O
6960 O
ms O
( O
M=5350 O
, O
SD=1159.98 O
) O
between O
each O
trial O
. O

Each O
of O
3 O
runs O
consisted O
of O
55 O
trials O
, O
with O
11 O
blank O
, O
22 O
congruent O
, O
and O
22 O
incongruent O
stimuli O
. O

E-prime O
software O
( O
Psychology O
Software O
Tools O
, O
Inc. O
, O
Sharpsburg O
, O
Pa. O
) O
was O
used O
to O
program O
and O
run O
the O
experiment O
and O
to O
record O
participants O
’ O
responses O
and O
reaction O
times O
( O
RTs O
) O
. O

Behavioral O
Analyses O
RTs O
on O
correct O
trials O
were O
entered O
as O
dependent O
variables O
in O
a O
repeated O
measures O
, O
mixed-model O
ANOVA O
in O
IBM O
SPSS O
Statistics O
22.0 O
( O
Armonk O
, O
NY O
: O
IBM O
Corp. O
) O
with O
Stimulus O
( O
post-congruent O
Incongruent O
vs. O
post-congruent O
Congruent O
) O
as O
the O
within-subject O
variable O
and O
group O
( O
CU O
vs. O
HC O
) O
as O
the O
between-subject O
variable O
. O

Image O
Acquisition O
and O
Processing O
Images O
were O
collected O
using O
a O
GE O
Signa O
3 O
Tesla O
LC O
scanner O
( O
Milwaukee O
, O
WI O
) O
. O

Functional O
images O
were O
acquired O
using O
a O
T2 O
* O
sensitive O
, O
gradient-recalled O
, O
single O
shot O
, O
echo-planar O
pulse O
sequence O
( O
repetition O
time O
= O
2200 O
ms O
, O
echo O
time O
= O
30 O
ms O
, O
90 O
degree O
flip O
angle O
, O
single O
excitation O
per O
image O
, O
24 O
* O
24 O
cm O
field O
of O
view O
, O
64 O
* O
64 O
matrix O
, O
34 O
slices O
3.5mm O
thick O
, O
no O
gap O
, O
covering O
the O
entire O
brain O
) O
. O

We O
collected O
140 O
echo-planar O
imaging O
( O
EPI O
) O
volumes O
for O
each O
run O
. O

Image O
preprocessing O
and O
first-level O
analyses O
were O
carried O
out O
using O
SPM12 O
( O
http O
: O
//www.fil.ion.ucl.ac.uk/spm/ O
) O
and O
MATLAB O
9.0 O
( O
Mathworks O
, O
Natick O
, O
MA O
) O
. O

Functional O
images O
were O
corrected O
for O
differences O
in O
slice O
timing O
using O
sinc-interpolation O
, O
and O
head O
movement O
was O
corrected O
using O
a O
least-squares O
approach O
and O
a O
6-parameter O
rigid O
body O
spatial O
transformation O
. O

Structural O
data O
were O
coregistered O
to O
the O
functional O
data O
and O
segmented O
into O
tissue O
probability O
maps O
, O
bias O
corrected O
and O
spatially O
normalized O
to O
the O
Montreal O
Neurological O
Institute O
( O
MNI O
) O
space O
of O
1 O
× O
1 O
× O
1 O
mm3 O
voxels O
. O

Using O
the O
deformation O
fields O
of O
these O
segmented O
images O
, O
the O
functional O
images O
were O
subsequently O
spatially O
normalized O
to O
MNI O
space O
of O
and O
3 O
× O
3 O
× O
3 O
mm3 O
voxels O
. O

An O
8-mm O
full-width/half-maximum O
isotropic O
Gaussian O
smoothing O
kernel O
was O
applied O
to O
all O
normalized O
functional O
images O
. O

All O
analyses O
included O
a O
temporal O
high-pass O
filter O
( O
128 O
s O
) O
and O
correction O
for O
temporal O
autocorrelation O
using O
an O
autoregressive O
AR O
( O
1 O
) O
model O
. O

Each O
image O
was O
scaled O
to O
have O
a O
global O
mean O
intensity O
of O
100 O
. O

For O
each O
participant O
, O
preprocessed O
time O
series O
data O
from O
all O
three O
Simon O
task O
runs O
( O
420 O
volumes O
) O
were O
modeled O
using O
a O
General O
Linear O
Model O
( O
GLM O
) O
with O
six O
conditions O
: O
1 O
) O
Incongruent O
correct O
trials O
preceded O
by O
congruent O
trials O
( O
cI O
) O
, O
2 O
) O
Congruent O
correct O
trials O
preceded O
by O
incongruent O
trials O
( O
iC O
) O
, O
3 O
) O
Incongruent O
correct O
trials O
preceded O
by O
incongruent O
trials O
( O
iI O
) O
, O
4 O
) O
Congruent O
correct O
trials O
preceded O
by O
congruent O
trials O
( O
cC O
) O
, O
5 O
) O
fixation O
trials O
, O
and O
6 O
) O
incorrect O
trials O
( O
incongruent O
or O
congruent O
) O
, O
including O
those O
trials O
with O
RTs O
below O
the O
minimum O
RT O
of O
200 O
ms O
required O
for O
stimulus O
detection O
and O
processing O
. O

Because O
of O
the O
limited O
number O
of O
incorrect O
trials O
, O
contrasts O
involving O
these O
trials O
were O
not O
assessed O
. O

All O
of O
the O
task O
regressors O
were O
convolved O
with O
the O
canonical O
HRF O
, O
and O
least-squares O
regression O
was O
used O
to O
estimate O
parameters O
for O
each O
independent O
variable O
for O
each O
participant O
. O

To O
ensure O
that O
the O
non-significant O
motion O
differences O
could O
not O
account O
for O
our O
results O
, O
we O
included O
24 O
nuisance O
motion O
regressors O
as O
covariates O
of O
non-interest O
to O
capture O
linear O
, O
quadratic O
, O
differential O
, O
and O
quadratic O
differential O
motion O
. O

Runs O
in O
which O
a O
participant O
had O
more O
than O
30 O
% O
error O
rate O
( O
ER O
) O
on O
the O
task O
or O
more O
than O
3mm O
of O
total O
displacement O
in O
any O
of O
the O
6 O
standard O
motion O
parameters O
, O
following O
conversion O
of O
rotational O
parameters O
to O
distances O
by O
computing O
the O
arc O
length O
displacement O
on O
the O
surface O
of O
a O
sphere O
with O
radius O
50 O
mm O
, O
were O
considered O
poor O
quality O
data O
and O
excluded O
from O
our O
analyses O
. O

Conflict-related O
Activation O
Parameter O
estimates O
averaged O
across O
the O
3 O
runs O
were O
used O
to O
produce O
an O
incongruent O
( O
cI O
and O
cC O
) O
versus O
congruent O
( O
cC O
and O
iC O
) O
contrast O
( O
I-C O
) O
for O
each O
participant O
to O
isolate O
brain O
activation O
associated O
with O
the O
engagement O
of O
self-regulatory O
control O
and O
resolution O
of O
cognitive O
conflict O
( O
i.e. O
, O
interference O
effect O
) O
. O

The O
I-C O
parameter O
estimates O
maps O
were O
compared O
across O
groups O
in O
a O
second-level O
GLM O
adjusting O
for O
age O
and O
gender O
, O
using O
the O
two-sample O
t-test O
function O
with O
covariates O
implemented O
in O
SPM12 O
. O

A O
voxel-wise O
cluster-defining O
threshold O
( O
CDT O
) O
of O
p O
< O
.001 O
was O
applied O
whole-brain O
, O
and O
minimum O
cluster O
extent O
for O
significance O
at O
a O
Family O
Wise O
Error O
( O
FWE O
) O
rate O
of O
p O
< O
.05 O
was O
determined O
by O
the O
FWEc O
cluster-level O
correction O
for O
multiple O
comparison O
function O
implemented O
in O
SPM12 O
. O

Conflict-related O
Functional O
Connectivity O
To O
further O
assess O
the O
functioning O
of O
fronto-striatal O
circuits O
involved O
in O
the O
resolution O
of O
cognitive O
conflict O
in O
CU O
relative O
to O
HC O
, O
we O
investigated O
group O
differences O
in O
conflict-related O
functional O
connectivity O
. O

To O
do O
so O
, O
we O
computed O
a O
psychophysiological O
interaction O
( O
PPI O
) O
of O
the O
trial-by-trial O
psychometric O
estimate O
of O
conflict O
( O
I-C O
) O
by O
the O
physiological O
activation O
during O
I-C O
trials O
in O
a O
functionally O
defined O
frontal O
seed O
. O

The O
seed O
was O
defined O
as O
a O
6-mm-radius O
sphere O
centered O
on O
the O
coordinates O
where O
maximal O
group O
differences O
in O
I-C O
activation O
were O
found O
within O
the O
vmPFC O
. O

We O
then O
regressed O
this O
PPI O
term O
against O
whole-brain O
activation O
maps O
to O
identify O
regions O
in O
which O
coupling O
with O
the O
vmPFC O
varied O
as O
a O
function O
of O
conflict O
( O
I-C O
) O
. O

Positive O
and O
negative O
connectivity O
are O
respectively O
defined O
as O
significant O
positive O
and O
negative O
correlations O
between O
regions O
’ O
timeseries O
. O

Regions O
in O
which O
timeseries O
are O
uncorrelated O
are O
considered O
unconnected O
. O

A O
second-level O
analysis O
was O
conducted O
to O
test O
group O
differences O
in O
conflict-related O
functional O
connectivity O
, O
adjusting O
for O
age O
and O
gender O
. O

Because O
of O
our O
a O
priori O
hypotheses O
of O
fronto-striatal O
disturbances O
, O
these O
group-level O
analyses O
of O
connectivity O
with O
vmPFC O
were O
restricted O
to O
the O
striatal O
voxels O
within O
the O
caudate O
and O
putamen O
as O
defined O
by O
the O
AAL O
atlas O
. O

A O
voxel-wise O
CDT O
of O
p O
< O
.001 O
was O
applied O
to O
the O
second-level O
t-maps O
, O
and O
minimum O
cluster O
extent O
for O
significance O
at O
a O
FWE O
rate O
of O
p O
< O
.05 O
was O
determined O
by O
the O
FWEc O
cluster-level O
correction O
for O
multiple O
comparison O
function O
implemented O
in O
SPM12 O
. O

Findings O
that O
did O
not O
survive O
FWEc O
correction O
are O
reported O
as O
uncorrected O
. O

Clinical O
Correlates O
In O
the O
CU O
group O
, O
correlation O
analyses O
were O
conducted O
to O
examine O
the O
relationships O
of O
conflict-related O
activation O
and O
connectivity O
with O
cannabis O
use O
. O

Each O
participant O
’ O
s O
average O
activation O
and O
connectivity O
estimates O
were O
extracted O
from O
each O
cluster O
that O
was O
determined O
to O
be O
significant O
in O
our O
second-level O
group O
analyses O
. O

Pearson O
’ O
s O
coefficients O
were O
then O
computed O
between O
these O
estimates O
and O
the O
1 O
) O
age O
of O
first O
regular O
cannabis O
use O
, O
2 O
) O
duration O
of O
use O
( O
in O
years O
) O
,3 O
) O
days O
of O
use O
in O
the O
past O
30 O
days O
, O
and O
4 O
) O
days O
of O

prior O
to O
scanning O
. O

Potential O
Confounding O
Effects O
To O
assess O
potential O
confounding O
effects O
of O
comorbidity O
in O
the O
CU O
group O
, O
I-C O
activation O
maps O
were O
compared O
across O
groups O
in O
additional O
second-level O
two-sample O
t-tests O
( O
FWEc O
) O
after O
excluding O
CU O
participants O
with O
comorbid O
1 O
) O
attention-deficit/hyperactivity O
disorder O
( O
ADHD O
) O
, O
2 O
) O
major O
depressive O
disorder O
( O
MDD O
) O
, O
3 O
) O
anxiety O
disorders O
, O
and O
4 O
) O
significant O
alcohol O
use O
. O

We O
additionally O
explored O
and O
controlled O
for O
the O
effects O
of O
IQ O
and O
SES O
on O
our O
group O
differences O
in O
conflict-related O
activation O
and O
connectivity O
by O
conducting O
ROI-based O
analyses O
using O
the O
extracted O
parameter O
estimates O
from O
each O
significant O
cluster O
detected O
in O
our O
main O
analyses O
. O

Simultaneous O
fMRI-EEG-DTI O
recording O
of O
MMN O
in O
patients O
with O
schizophrenia O
Functional O
magnetic O
resonance O
imaging O
( O
fMRI O
) O
, O
electroencephalogram O
( O
EEG O
) O
, O
and O
diffusion O
tensor O
imaging O
( O
DTI O
) O
recording O
have O
complementary O
spatiotemporal O
resolution O
limitations O
but O
can O
be O
powerful O
methods O
when O
used O
together O
to O
enable O
both O
functional O
and O
anatomical O
modeling O
, O
with O
each O
neuroimaging O
procedure O
used O
to O
maximum O
advantage O
. O

We O
recorded O
EEGs O
during O
event-related O
fMRI O
followed O
by O
DTI O
in O
15 O
healthy O
volunteers O
and O
12 O
patients O
with O
schizophrenia O
using O
an O
omission O
mismatch O
negativity O
( O
MMN O
) O
paradigm O
. O

Blood O
oxygenation O
level-dependent O
( O
BOLD O
) O
signal O
changes O
were O
calculated O
in O
a O
region O
of O
interest O
( O
ROI O
) O
analysis O
, O
and O
fractional O
anisotropy O
( O
FA O
) O
in O
the O
white O
matter O
fibers O
related O
to O
each O
area O
was O
compared O
between O
groups O
using O
tract-specific O
analysis O
. O

Patients O
with O
schizophrenia O
had O
reduced O
BOLD O
activity O
in O
the O
left O
middle O
temporal O
gyrus O
, O
and O
BOLD O
activity O
in O
the O
right O
insula O
and O
right O
parahippocampal O
gyrus O
significantly O
correlated O
with O
positive O
symptoms O
on O
the O
Positive O
and O
Negative O
Syndrome O
Scale O
( O
PANSS O
) O
and O
hostility O
subscores O
. O

BOLD O
activation O
of O
Heschl O
’ O
s O
gyri O
also O
correlated O
with O
the O
limbic O
system O
, O
including O
the O
insula O
. O

FA O
values O
in O
the O
left O
anterior O
cingulate O
cortex O
( O
ACC O
) O
significantly O
correlated O
with O
changes O
in O
the O
BOLD O
signal O
in O
the O
right O
superior O
temporal O
gyrus O
( O
STG O
) O
, O
and O
FA O
values O
in O
the O
right O
ACC O
significantly O
correlated O
with O
PANSS O
scores O
. O

This O
is O
the O
first O
study O
to O
examine O
MMN O
using O
simultaneous O
fMRI O
, O
EEG O
, O
and O
DTI O
recording O
in O
patients O
with O
schizophrenia O
to O
investigate O
the O
potential O
implications O
of O
abnormalities O
in O
the O
ACC O
and O
limbic O
system O
, O
including O
the O
insula O
and O
parahippocampal O
gyrus O
, O
as O
well O
as O
the O
STG O
. O

Structural O
changes O
in O
the O
ACC O
during O
schizophrenia O
may O
represent O
part O
of O
the O
neural O
basis O
for O
the O
observed O
MMN O
deficits O
. O

The O
deficits O
seen O
in O
the O
feedback/feedforward O
connections O
between O
the O
prefrontal O
cortex O
and O
STG O
modulated O
by O
the O
ACC O
and O
insula O
may O
specifically O
contribute O
to O
impaired O
MMN O
generation O
and O
clinical O
manifestations O
. O

Methods O
Ethical O
statement O
This O
study O
was O
approved O
by O
the O
Juntendo O
University O
Koshigaya O
Hospital O
Ethics O
Committee O
and O
Juntendo O
University O
Shizuoka O
Hospital O
Ethics O
Committee O
. O

Subjects O
Twelve O
patients O
with O
schizophrenia O
( O
10 O
men O
and O
2 O
women O
, O
mean O
age O
36.8 O
± O
6.0 O
years O
, O
all O
right-handed O
except O
for O
one O
left-handed O
patient O
) O
and O
15 O
healthy O
controls O
( O
13 O
men O
and O
2 O
women O
, O
mean O
age O
28.4 O
± O
9.6 O
years O
, O
all O
right-handed O
except O
for O
one O
left-handed O
subject O
) O
were O
included O
in O
the O
study O
. O

The O
groups O
were O
not O
age-matched O
( O
F O
[ O
1,25 O
] O
= O
5.3 O
, O
p O
= O
0.11 O
) O
. O

Attempts O
were O
made O
to O
match O
the O
groups O
for O
years O
of O
education O
, O
but O
this O
proved O
to O
be O
difficult O
because O
patients O
with O
schizophrenia O
are O
more O
likely O
to O
require O
hospitalization O
and O
the O
early O
age O
of O
onset O
, O
which O
can O
interfere O
with O
schooling O
. O

Therefore O
, O
controls O
had O
significantly O
more O
( O
F O
[ O
1,25 O
] O
= O
0.130 O
, O
p O
< O
0.001 O
) O
years O
of O
education O
( O
17.3 O
± O
1.9 O
) O
than O
patients O
( O
13.3 O
± O
2.0 O
) O
. O

The O
statistical O
procedures O
were O
adjusted O
for O
age O
and O
education O
. O

Patients O
were O
recruited O
from O
among O
the O
outpatients O
at O
Juntendo O
University O
Koshigaya O
Hospital O
in O
Saitama O
and O
Juntendo O
University O
Shizuoka O
Hospital O
in O
Shizuoka O
, O
Japan O
, O
and O
healthy O
controls O
were O
recruited O
from O
the O
staff O
of O
the O
same O
hospitals O
. O

All O
controls O
were O
healthy O
and O
native O
to O
Japan O
. O

The O
mean O
disease O
duration O
in O
the O
patient O
group O
was O
14.3 O
± O
5.7 O
years O
, O
and O
the O
mean O
drug O
dose O
used O
for O
treatment O
( O
risperidone O
equivalent O
) O
was O
10.5 O
± O
6.2 O
mg O
( O
Table O
1 O
) O
. O

All O
patients O
were O
determined O
to O
be O
in O
good O
physical O
health O
based O
on O
medical O
history O
, O
physical O
examination O
, O
and O
laboratory O
measures O
. O

None O
of O
the O
subjects O
had O
a O
history O
of O
electroconvulsive O
shock O
treatment O
, O
alcohol O
or O
other O
drug O
abuse O
( O
DSM-5 O
criteria O
) O
, O
addiction O
, O
or O
a O
neurological O
illness O
affecting O
the O
central O
nervous O
system O
, O
and O
all O
subjects O
reported O
having O
normal O
visual O
acuity O
. O

The O
DSM-5 O
diagnosis O
and O
Positive O
and O
Negative O
Syndrome O
Scale O
( O
PANSS O
) O
score O
were O
determined O
for O
each O
patient O
using O
a O
structured O
psychiatric O
interview O
and O
by O
reviewing O
the O
patients O
’ O
medical O
charts O
. O

The O
PANSS O
is O
a O
semi-structured O
interview O
with O
a O
7-point O
scale O
to O
rate O
30 O
symptoms O
common O
in O
schizophrenia O
and O
other O
mental O
disorders O
. O

The O
mean O
PANSS O
scores O
were O
15.4±6.9 O
( O
positive O
scales O
) O
, O
22.8±9.2 O
( O
negative O
scales O
) O
, O
36.8±10.3 O
( O
general O
psychopathology O
scales O
) O
, O
and O
74.9±22.9 O
( O
total O
score O
) O
. O

All O
participants O
were O
informed O
of O
the O
objectives O
and O
methods O
of O
the O
study O
and O
given O
written O
informed O
consent O
before O
the O
study O
began O
. O

The O
treating O
psychiatrists O
evaluated O
the O
capability O
of O
the O
patients O
to O
give O
informed O
consent O
and O
confirmed O
that O
they O
understood O
the O
voluntariness O
of O
their O
participation O
. O

Any O
participants O
who O
lacked O
adequate O
understanding O
of O
the O
study O
were O
excluded O
. O

Five-component O
model O
of O
the O
PANSS O
As O
described O
previously O
, O
clinical O
manifestations O
were O
evaluated O
by O
the O
PANSS O
, O
which O
is O
classified O
into O
five O
components O
according O
to O
the O
five-component O
model O
: O
negative O
( O
passive O
withdrawal O
, O
emotional O
withdrawal O
, O
blunted O
affects O
, O
lack O
of O
spontaneity O
, O
poor O
rapport O
, O
disturbance O
of O
volition O
, O
preoccupation O
, O
motor O
retardation O
) O
, O
positive O
( O
delusions O
, O
unusual O
thoughts O
, O
somatic O
concern O
, O
grandiosity O
, O
suspiciousness O
, O
hallucinations O
) O
, O
cognitive O
( O
difficulty O
in O
abstract O
thinking O
, O
stereotyped O
thinking O
, O
cognitive O
disorganization O
, O
lack O
of O
judgment O
and O
insight O
, O
poor O
attention O
, O
tension O
, O
mannerisms O
and O
posturing O
) O
, O
emotional O
discomfort O
( O
depression O
, O
anxiety O
, O
guilt O
, O
active O
social O
avoidance O
) O
, O
and O
hostility O
( O
excitement O
, O
hostility O
, O
impulse O
control O
, O
uncooperativeness O
) O
. O

Auditory O
stimuli O
: O
Passive O
oddball-omission O
paradigm O
ERPs O
and O
fMRI O
were O
recorded O
during O
a O
sound O
omission O
MMN O
paradigm O
in O
which O
repetitive O
sequences O
of O
a O
frequent O
auditory O
stimulus O
were O
omitted O
occasionally O
. O

A O
computer O
with O
custom-designed O
software O
generated O
the O
acoustic O
stimuli O
and O
controlled O
stimulus O
timing O
and O
presentation O
. O

Tones O
were O
presented O
binaurally O
at O
a O
constant O
listening O
level O
( O
92–95 O
dB O
sound O
pressure O
level O
) O
through O
tube-connected O
headphones O
held O
in O
place O
by O
a O
headset O
. O

The O
acoustic O
stimuli O
consisted O
of O
sine O
wave O
tones O
with O
a O
duration O
of O
35 O
ms O
, O
including O
0 O
ms O
rise O
and O
5 O
ms O
fall O
times O
. O

The O
tone O
frequency O
was O
3000 O
Hz O
, O
and O
the O
onset-to-onset O
interval O
was O
136 O
ms O
. O

The O
experimental O
task O
consisted O
of O
a O
single O
block O
including O
6547 O
tones O
and O
53 O
omission O
events O
. O

The O
probability O
of O
omission O
was O
0.00803 O
( O
53/6600 O
) O
, O
and O
omission O
occurred O
in O
the O
19th O
location O
in O
the O
sound O
trains O
during O
the O
“ O
event O
” O
scans O
. O

ERPs O
were O
recorded O
in O
a O
‘ O
passive O
’ O
condition O
in O
which O
the O
subjects O
were O
asked O
to O
ignore O
the O
stimuli O
and O
watch O
a O
silent O
movie O
projected O
on O
a O
video O
monitor O
. O

All O
subjects O
were O
told O
that O
they O
would O
have O
to O
give O
specific O
feedback O
about O
the O
movie O
at O
the O
end O
of O
the O
ERP O
session O
to O
standardize O
their O
level O
of O
attention O
. O

Subjects O
were O
also O
instructed O
to O
avoid O
unnecessary O
eye O
movement O
and O
blinking O
during O
the O
session O
. O

The O
136-ms O
stimulus O
onset O
asynchrony O
( O
SOA O
) O
of O
the O
acoustic O
stimuli O
used O
in O
the O
present O
study O
was O
selected O
to O
be O
within O
the O
temporal O
window O
of O
integration O
( O
TWI O
) O
proposed O
by O
Yabe O
et O
al O
.. O
Acoustic O
signals O
presented O
within O
an O
approximate O
200 O
ms O
temporal O
window O
are O
integrated O
into O
a O
single O
perceptual O
unit O
. O

In O
addition O
, O
Yabe O
et O
al O
. O

showed O
that O
acoustic O
information O
is O
integrated O
into O
a O
single O
unit O
within O
160–170 O
ms O
to O
form O
a O
sound O
trace O
in O
sensory O
memory O
via O
a O
stimulus-omission O
MMN O
paradigm O
. O

TWI O
is O
an O
aspect O
of O
temporal O
integration O
that O
determines O
the O
initial O
sound O
energy O
unit O
in O
the O
early O
, O
pre-attentive O
stages O
of O
auditory O
information O
processing O
. O

fMRI O
design O
and O
synchronization O
between O
scan O
noise O
and O
auditory O
stimuli O
We O
used O
an O
event-related O
design O
for O
the O
fMRI O
. O

Scans O
of O
22 O
slices O
generated O
equal O
numbers O
of O
scan O
noises O
during O
a O
single O
repetition O
time O
( O
TR O
) O
of O
2992 O
ms O
, O
and O
the O
same O
number O
of O
tones O
with O
an O
SOA O
of O
136 O
ms O
( O
TR/slice O
number O
= O
2992/22 O
) O
were O
presented O
. O

The O
presentation O
of O
tones O
was O
completely O
synchronized O
to O
scans O
by O
triggers O
generated O
by O
the O
MRI O
system O
in O
order O
to O
minimize O
the O
effect O
of O
scan O
noise O
on O
fMRI O
and O
EEG O
raw O
data O
, O
which O
were O
also O
used O
to O
segregate O
and O
average O
EEG O
epochs O
in O
the O
ERP O
analysis O
. O

We O
averaged O
EEG O
epochs O
and O
subtracted O
the O
waveforms O
of O
the O
baseline O
tones O
from O
the O
omission O
events O
during O
ERP O
processing O
to O
eliminate O
fluctuations O
in O
the O
EEG O
signals O
due O
to O
scan O
noise O
. O

A O
similar O
concept O
was O
applied O
for O
blood O
oxygen O
level-dependent O
( O
BOLD O
) O
signal O
processing O
using O
an O
event-related O
fMRI O
design O
. O

The O
SOA O
for O
event O
scans O
including O
the O
omission O
events O
and O
tones O
in O
the O
regular O
positions O
represent O
7 O
or O
8 O
scans O
( O
20,944 O
or O
23,936 O
ms O
) O
. O

Fifty-three O
event O
scans O
were O
assorted O
at O
random O
among O
the O
247 O
baseline O
scans O
including O
baseline O
tones O
only O
, O
with O
no O
omission O
( O
Fig O
1 O
) O
. O

BOLD O
hemodynamic O
responses O
for O
event O
scans O
were O
then O
compared O
to O
those O
for O
baseline O
scans O
. O

Image O
acquisition O
for O
fMRI O
BOLD O
fMRI O
data O
acquisition O
was O
performed O
at O
Juntendo O
University O
Hospital O
using O
a O
Philips O
Achieva O
3.0 O
Tesla O
MRI O
scanner O
with O
a O
T2 O
* O
-weighted O
gradient-echo O
echo-planar O
imaging O
( O
EPI O
) O
sequence O
and O
8-channel O
array O
receiving O
head O
coil O
for O
sensitivity-encoding O
parallel O
imaging O
. O

The O
parameters O
were O
as O
follows O
: O
echo O
time O
( O
TE O
) O
= O
35 O
ms O
, O
TR O
= O
2992 O
ms O
, O
field O
of O
view O
( O
FOV O
) O
= O
240 O
× O
240 O
mm O
, O
matrix O
= O
96 O
× O
96 O
, O
flip O
angle O
= O
90° O
, O
number O
of O
axial O
slices O
= O
22 O
, O
and O
voxel O
size O
= O
2.5 O
× O
2.5 O
× O
6.0 O
mm O
. O

Three O
hundred O
scans O
were O
collected O
in O
each O
session O
( O
total O
time O
= O
2992 O
ms O
× O
300 O
= O
897,600 O
ms O
) O
. O

Image O
processing O
As O
described O
in O
detail O
previously O
, O
imaging O
data O
were O
preprocessed O
and O
voxel-based O
statistical O
analysis O
performed O
using O
SPM8 O
software O
( O
Wellcome O
Department O
of O
Imaging O
Neuroscience O
) O
running O
on O
MATLAB O
( O
version O
8.3.0 O
, O
Math O
Works O
Inc. O
, O
2014 O
) O
. O

The O
first O
four O
volumes O
were O
discarded O
, O
and O
the O
remaining O
296 O
volumes O
were O
preprocessed O
. O

Preprocessing O
steps O
prior O
to O
statistical O
analysis O
included O
slice O
time O
correction O
, O
motion O
correction O
, O
and O
spatial O
normalization O
to O
a O
standard O
template O
in O
Montreal O
Neurological O
Institute O
( O
MNI O
) O
space O
. O

The O
slice O
timing O
was O
corrected O
according O
to O
the O
slice O
order O
and O
the O
fMRI O
data O
realigned O
and O
subsequently O
normalized O
to O
the O
standard O
MNI O
template O
using O
the O
T1 O
SPM O
template O
, O
resulting O
in O
voxels O
of O
2 O
× O
2 O
× O
2 O
mm O
. O

All O
functional O
images O
were O
spatially O
smoothed O
using O
a O
Gaussian O
filter O
kernel O
( O
full O
width O
at O
half O
maximum O
[ O
FWHM O
] O
8 O
mm O
) O
and O
the O
data O
bandpass O
filtered O
( O
0.008–0.09 O
Hz O
) O
. O

Image O
artifacts O
originating O
from O
head O
movement O
were O
handled O
using O
the O
ART O
scrubbing O
procedure O
( O
www.nitrc.org/projects/artifact_detect/ O
) O
, O
and O
signal O
contributions O
from O
white O
brain O
matter O
, O
cerebrospinal O
fluid O
, O
and O
micro O
head-movement O
( O
six O
parameters O
) O
were O
discerned O
from O
the O
data O
. O

The O
six O
realignment O
parameters O
were O
included O
in O
the O
design O
matrix O
to O
correct O
for O
signal O
changes O
caused O
by O
head O
movement O
. O

Event O
conditions O
( O
omission O
vs. O
baseline O
) O
were O
modeled O
using O
the O
standard O
hemodynamic O
response O
function O
. O

First O
level O
analysis O
of O
individual O
participant O
images O
was O
performed O
to O
produce O
estimates O
for O
the O
contrast O
of O
interest O
( O
omission O
vs. O
tones O
) O
according O
to O
the O
general O
linear O
model O
( O
GLM O
) O
, O
and O
significant O
signal O
changes O
in O
the O
contrast O
were O
assessed O
using O
F-statistics O
on O
a O
voxel-by-voxel O
basis O
. O

The O
resulting O
set O
of O
voxel O
values O
for O
the O
contrast O
constituted O
statistical O
parametric O
mapping O
( O
SPM O
) O
of O
the O
F-statistic O
. O

Second O
level O
analysis O
was O
performed O
on O
contrast O
images O
in O
a O
group O
random-effects O
analysis O
using O
a O
one-sample O
t-test O
. O

Two-sample O
t-tests O
between O
groups O
were O
performed O
with O
age O
and O
education O
as O
covariates O
( O
significance O
threshold O
p O
< O
0.05 O
, O
family-wise O
error O
[ O
FWE O
] O
corrected O
) O
. O

Correlation O
analysis O
was O
also O
performed O
between O
BOLD O
activities O
and O
other O
factors O
, O
including O
the O
PANSS O
, O
ERP O
, O
and O
DTI O
data O
. O

The O
activated O
images O
were O
superimposed O
on O
the O
standardized O
T1-weighted O
images O
, O
and O
the O
MNI O
coordinates O
of O
the O
maximum O
response O
in O
the O
activated O
regions O
presented O
in O
SPM8 O
were O
converted O
to O
Talairach O
coordinates O
using O
the O
algorithm O
reported O
by O
Lacadie O
et O
al O
.. O
Talairach O
labels O
of O
activated O
regions O
were O
detected O
using O
the O
Talairach O
client O
version O
2.4.2 O
( O
http O
: O
//www.talairach.org/client.html O
) O
. O

ROI O
analysis O
Quantitative O
analysis O
of O
the O
event-related O
fMRI O
data O
was O
performed O
using O
the O
region O
of O
interest O
( O
ROI O
) O
method O
centered O
on O
our O
areas O
of O
interest O
in O
the O
cingulate O
cortex O
and O
temporal O
lobe O
. O

Estimates O
of O
BOLD O
signal O
( O
% O
) O
and O
t-value O
changes O
at O
sound O
omission O
were O
also O
extracted O
from O
select O
ROIs O
, O
including O
the O
anterior O
( O
S1A O
Fig O
) O
and O
middle O
cingulate O
cortex O
( O
S1B O
Fig O
) O
, O
superior O
and O
middle O
temporal O
gyrus O
( O
S1C O
Fig O
) O
, O
and O
Heschl O
’ O
s O
gyrus O
( O
HSC O
; O
S1D O
Fig O
) O
, O
for O
each O
participant O
using O
the O
MarsBar O
SPM O
toolbox O
( O
MRC O
Cognition O
and O
Brain O
Sciences O
Unit O
, O
Cambridge O
, O
UK O
; O
http O
: O
//marsbar.sourceforge.net O
) O
. O

Registration O
and O
analysis O
of O
EEG O
data O
We O
used O
a O
Brain O
Amp O
MR-compatible O
amplifier O
( O
Brain O
Products O
, O
Gilching O
, O
Germany O
) O
to O
simultaneously O
record O
the O
EEG O
and O
fMRI O
according O
to O
previously O
reported O
procedures O
. O

We O
used O
a O
32-channel O
EEG O
cap O
( O
Easycap O
BrainCap-MR O
3–0 O
32Ch O
) O
with O
30 O
sintered O
Ag/Ag O
Cl O
ring O
electrodes O
placed O
in O
accordance O
with O
the O
international O
10–10 O
system O
. O

The O
FCz O
site O
( O
between O
Fz O
and O
Cz O
) O
served O
as O
the O
online O
reference O
, O
maintaining O
a O
small O
distance O
between O
the O
recording O
reference O
and O
the O
“ O
active O
” O
electrodes O
to O
minimize O
the O
risk O
of O
amplifier O
saturation O
. O

We O
placed O
an O
electrode O
on O
the O
subject O
’ O
s O
back O
to O
record O
the O
electrocardiogram O
and O
another O
under O
their O
left O
eye O
to O
record O
the O
electrooculogram O
. O

We O
used O
custom O
head O
coils O
covered O
with O
inner O
foam O
padding O
compatible O
with O
the O
electrodes O
and O
cables O
to O
decrease O
head O
movements O
by O
reducing O
any O
discomfort O
or O
pressure O
from O
the O
electrode O
cap O
. O

We O
maintained O
an O
impedance O
of O
< O
5 O
kΩ O
between O
the O
electrode O
and O
scalp O
during O
EEG O
recording O
. O

Data O
were O
acquired O
at O
a O
5000 O
Hz O
sampling O
rate O
( O
16 O
bit O
, O
0.5 O
mV O
resolution O
, O
16.38 O
mV O
dynamic O
range O
) O
with O
an O
online O
bandpass O
filter O
of O
0.016–250 O
Hz O
. O

EEG O
artifact O
correction O
and O
validation O
We O
subtracted O
averaged O
artifacts O
using O
Brain O
Vision O
Analyzer O
software O
algorithms O
( O
BrainProducts O
, O
Gilching O
, O
Germany O
) O
to O
correct O
the O
EEG O
data O
for O
MR O
gradient O
and O
ballistocardiac O
artifacts O
as O
described O
previously O
. O

The O
EEG O
data O
were O
processed O
using O
a O
bandpass O
filter O
of O
0.53–70 O
Hz O
, O
down-sampled O
to O
250 O
Hz O
, O
and O
re-referenced O
to O
a O
common O
average O
. O

We O
applied O
additional O
artifact O
correction O
based O
on O
independent O
component O
analysis O
( O
ICA O
) O
to O
exclude O
repetitive O
uniform O
artifacts O
, O
such O
as O
line O
noise O
and O
eye O
blinks O
. O

All O
independent O
components O
that O
appeared O
to O
correspond O
to O
horizontal O
eye O
movements O
, O
blinks O
, O
or O
components O
potentially O
assignable O
to O
ballistocardiac O
and O
residual O
gradient O
artifacts O
were O
visually O
inspected O
and O
excluded O
. O

We O
then O
performed O
back-projection O
of O
the O
remaining O
independent O
components O
to O
restore O
the O
EEG O
data O
to O
the O
original O
voltage O
and O
time O
scales O
. O

Finally O
, O
we O
rejected O
any O
intervals O
that O
included O
amplitudes O
> O
70 O
mV O
. O

ERP O
analysis O
EEG O
epochs O
( O
100 O
ms O
pre-stimulus O
, O
412 O
ms O
post-stimulus O
) O
associated O
with O
each O
stimulus O
type O
were O
excised O
from O
the O
continuous O
record O
at O
the O
conclusion O
of O
the O
experiment O
. O

All O
single-trial O
epochs O
were O
pre-stimulus O
baseline-corrected O
, O
and O
artifact-free O
epochs O
were O
segregated O
by O
stimulus O
codes O
( O
omission O
or O
baseline O
tone O
) O
and O
averaged O
for O
each O
subject O
. O

No O
significant O
difference O
was O
found O
in O
the O
number O
of O
accepted O
epochs O
between O
the O
conditions O
, O
and O
a O
group O
average O
was O
calculated O
across O
all O
subjects O
of O
each O
group O
. O

Difference O
waveforms O
were O
constructed O
by O
subtracting O
the O
tone-associated O
waveforms O
from O
the O
omission-associated O
waveforms O
. O

Topographic O
distributions O
were O
inspected O
to O
verify O
that O
the O
maximum O
MMN O
was O
observed O
at O
the O
Fz O
or O
Cz O
electrodes O
, O
where O
the O
MMN O
is O
typically O
greatest O
. O

Peak O
MMN O
amplitudes O
were O
detected O
within O
latency O
ranges O
of O
120–185 O
ms O
. O

Analyses O
were O
restricted O
to O
MMN O
amplitudes O
and O
latencies O
at O
Fz O
and O
Cz O
for O
the O
purposes O
of O
this O
study O
, O
and O
the O
MMN O
amplitudes O
were O
measured O
relative O
to O
the O
pre-stimulus O
baseline O
. O

Image O
acquisition O
for O
DTI O
All O
MRI O
scans O
for O
DTI O
were O
obtained O
following O
image O
acquisition O
for O
fMRI O
as O
described O
previously O
. O

Regular O
structural O
images O
, O
such O
as O
T1-weighted O
spin-echo O
images O
, O
T2-weighted O
turbo O
spin-echo O
images O
, O
and O
fluid-attenuated O
inversion O
recovery O
images O
, O
were O
obtained O
before O
the O
acquisition O
of O
diffusion O
tensor O
images O
. O

DTI O
was O
performed O
utilizing O
the O
spin-echo O
echo-planar O
technique O
with O
the O
following O
parameters O
: O
echo O
time O
= O
70 O
ms O
, O
repetition O
time O
= O
5452 O
ms O
, O
voxel O
size O
= O
1.75 O
× O
1.75 O
× O
3 O
mm O
, O
number O
of O
averages O
= O
2 O
, O
and O
contiguous O
axial O
slices O
= O
50 O
. O

Images O
were O
obtained O
with O
32-direction O
diffusion O
encoding O
( O
b O
= O
1000 O
s/mm2 O
for O
each O
direction O
) O
and O
no O
diffusion O
encoding O
( O
b O
= O
0 O
s/mm2 O
) O
. O

The O
scan O
time O
was O
7 O
min O
17 O
s. O
DTI O
analysis O
Tract-based O
spatial O
statistics O
As O
described O
in O
detail O
previously O
, O
we O
first O
carried O
out O
voxel-wise O
statistical O
analysis O
as O
an O
exploratory O
analysis O
using O
tract-based O
spatial O
statistics O
( O
TBSS O
) O
( O
S2 O
Fig O
) O
, O
which O
is O
available O
as O
part O
of O
the O
FMRIB O
software O
library O
( O
FSL O
) O
. O

Diffusion O
tensor O
images O
were O
preprocessed O
by O
FSL O
version O
4.2.1 O
, O
including O
skull O
stripping O
and O
eddy O
current O
correction O
. O

All O
subjects O
’ O
fractional O
anisotropy O
( O
FA O
) O
data O
were O
aligned O
into O
a O
common O
space O
by O
applying O
the O
non-linear O
registration O
tool O
FNIRT O
, O
which O
uses O
a O
b-spline O
representation O
of O
the O
registration O
warp O
field O
. O

A O
mean O
FA O
image O
was O
provided O
and O
thinned O
to O
create O
a O
mean O
FA O
skeleton O
representing O
the O
centers O
of O
all O
tracts O
common O
to O
the O
group O
. O

Group O
comparisons O
were O
performed O
with O
Randomise O
version O
2.1 O
from O
FSL O
, O
and O
both O
control O
vs. O
patient O
and O
patient O
vs. O
control O
contrasts O
were O
tested O
with O
5000 O
permutations O
. O

We O
used O
threshold-free O
cluster O
enhancement O
as O
implemented O
within O
Randomise O
, O
which O
provides O
the O
ability O
to O
perform O
cluster-based O
inferences O
without O
setting O
an O
arbitrary O
cluster-forming O
threshold O
. O

Voxel-wise O
statistical O
inferences O
were O
made O
on O
the O
resulting O
statistic O
image O
, O
and O
the O
significance O
was O
set O
to O
p O
< O
0.05 O
with O
correction O
for O
FWE O
. O

Tract-specific O
analysis O
As O
our O
specific O
interest O
was O
the O
ACC O
, O
we O
performed O
tract-specific O
analysis O
of O
the O
3D O
diffusion O
tensor O
tractograph O
using O
dTV O
II O
and O
VOLUME-ONE O
software O
( O
free O
software O
from O
Masutani O
, O
http O
: O
//www.medimg.info.hiroshima-cu.ac.jp/dTV.IISR/dTV.htm O
) O
on O
a O
Windows O
PC O
workstation O
as O
described O
previously O
. O

Two O
ROIs O
were O
used O
to O
extract O
the O
cingulum O
bundle O
in O
accordance O
with O
the O
two-ROI O
method O
. O

The O
first O
ROI O
( O
‘ O
seed O
’ O
) O
was O
chosen O
on O
the O
coronal O
plane O
anterior O
to O
the O
pons O
( O
S3A O
Fig O
) O
. O

The O
second O
ROI O
( O
‘ O
target O
’ O
) O
was O
placed O
on O
a O
coronal O
slice O
posterior O
to O
the O
genu O
of O
the O
corpus O
callosum O
( O
S3B O
Fig O
) O
. O

The O
average O
FA O
values O
and O
mean O
diffusivity O
of O
the O
AC O
included O
in O
the O
seed O
and O
target O
( O
S3D O
Fig O
) O
were O
calculated O
separately O
for O
each O
hemisphere O
after O
extracting O
the O
cingulum O
bundle O
( O
S3C O
Fig O
) O
. O

Statistical O
analysis O
The O
MMN O
, O
ROI O
, O
and O
DTI O
data O
were O
analyzed O
by O
analysis O
of O
covariance O
( O
ANCOVA O
) O
with O
repeated O
measures O
using O
age O
and O
education O
as O
covariates O
. O

Two O
factors O
were O
included O
for O
MMN O
amplitudes O
and O
latencies O
at O
Fz O
and O
Cz O
: O
group O
( O
patient O
or O
control O
) O
as O
a O
between-subject O
factor O
, O
and O
electrode O
( O
Fz O
or O
Cz O
) O
as O
a O
within-subject O
factor O
. O

Three O
factors O
were O
included O
for O
changes O
in O
t-values O
in O
the O
ROI O
analysis O
of O
the O
cingulate O
and O
temporal O
cortex O
: O
group O
as O
a O
between-subject O
factor O
, O
and O
laterality O
( O
right O
or O
left O
) O
and O
location O
( O
anterior O
or O
middle O
cingulate O
; O
STG O
, O
MTG O
, O
or O
HSC O
) O
as O
within-subject O
factors O
. O

Two O
factors O
were O
included O
for O
DTI O
FA O
values O
: O
group O
as O
a O
between-subject O
factor O
, O
and O
laterality O
( O
right O
or O
left O
) O
as O
a O
within-subject O
factor O
. O

Reduced O
degrees O
of O
freedom O
( O
Greenhouse-Geisser O
) O
were O
used O
when O
appropriate O
to O
counter O
violations O
of O
the O
sphericity O
assumption O
underlying O
ANCOVA O
with O
repeated O
measures O
( O
epsilon O
values O
were O
provided O
) O
. O

Changes O
in O
the O
BOLD O
signal O
analyzed O
in O
ROI O
analysis O
using O
MarsBar O
were O
correlated O
with O
other O
fMRI O
and O
MMN O
measures O
by O
Pearson O
’ O
s O
correlation O
, O
and O
alpha O
values O
of O
0.05 O
were O
considered O
significant O
. O

PASW O
Statistics O
software O
for O
Windows O
version O
18.0.0 O
( O
SPSS O
Inc. O
, O
Chicago O
, O
IL O
, O
USA O
) O
was O
used O
for O
all O
analyses O
. O

Classification O
of O
cocaine-dependent O
participants O
with O
dynamic O
functional O
connectivity O
from O
functional O
magnetic O
resonance O
imaging O
data O
Static O
functional O
connectivity O
( O
FC O
) O
analyses O
based O
on O
functional O
magnetic O
resonance O
imaging O
( O
fMRI O
) O
data O
have O
been O
extensively O
explored O
for O
studying O
various O
psychiatric O
conditions O
in O
the O
brain O
, O
including O
cocaine O
addiction O
. O

A O
recently O
emerging O
, O
more O
powerful O
technique O
, O
dynamic O
functional O
connectivity O
( O
DFC O
) O
, O
studies O
how O
the O
FC O
dynamics O
change O
during O
the O
course O
of O
the O
fMRI O
experiments O
. O

The O
aim O
in O
this O
paper O
was O
to O
develop O
a O
computational O
approach O
, O
using O
a O
machine O
learning O
framework O
, O
to O
determine O
if O
DFC O
features O
were O
more O
successful O
than O
FC O
features O
in O
the O
classification O
of O
cocaine-dependent O
patients O
and O
healthy O
controls O
. O

fMRI O
data O
were O
obtained O
from O
of O
25 O
healthy O
and O
58 O
cocaine-dependent O
participants O
while O
performing O
a O
motor O
response O
inhibition O
task O
, O
stop O
signal O
task O
. O

Group O
independent O
component O
analysis O
was O
carried O
out O
on O
all O
participant O
data O
to O
compute O
spatially O
independent O
components O
( O
ICs O
) O
. O

Eight O
ICs O
were O
selected O
manually O
as O
relevant O
brain O
networks O
, O
which O
were O
used O
to O
classify O
healthy O
versus O
cocaine-dependent O
participants O
. O

FC O
and O
DFC O
measures O
of O
the O
chosen O
IC O
pairs O
were O
used O
as O
features O
for O
the O
classification O
algorithm O
. O

Support O
Vector O
Machines O
were O
used O
for O
both O
feature O
selection/reduction O
and O
participant O
classification O
. O

Based O
on O
DFC O
with O
only O
seven O
IC O
pairs O
, O
participants O
were O
successfully O
classified O
with O
95 O
% O
accuracy O
( O
and O
with O
90 O
% O
accuracy O
with O
three O
IC O
pairs O
) O
, O
whereas O
static O
FC O
yielded O
only O
81 O
% O
accuracy O
. O

Visual O
, O
sensorimotor O
, O
default O
mode O
, O
and O
executive O
control O
networks O
, O
amygdala O
, O
and O
insula O
played O
the O
most O
significant O
role O
in O
the O
DFC-based O
classification O
. O

These O
findings O
support O
the O
use O
of O
DFC-based O
classification O
of O
fMRI O
data O
as O
a O
potential O
biomarker O
for O
the O
identification O
of O
cocaine O
dependence O
. O

METHODS O
AND O
MATERIALS O
Participants O
Research O
participants O
were O
58 O
cocaine-dependent O
individuals O
and O
25 O
age-matched O
healthy O
controls O
. O

Cocaine-dependent O
participants O
were O
recruited O
from O
three O
residential O
treatment O
programs O
in O
Dallas O
, O
Texas O
: O
the O
VA O
North O
Texas O
Health O
Care O
System O
, O
Homeward O
Bound O
, O
Inc. O
, O
and O
Nexus O
Recovery O
Center O
, O
Inc O
. O

Participants O
were O
financially O
compensated O
for O
their O
participation O
. O

The O
criteria O
for O
cocaine O
dependence O
was O
the O
Structured O
Clinical O
Interview O
for O
DSM-IV-TR O
Axis O
I O
Disorders O
; O
all O
cocaine-dependent O
participants O
endorsed O
cocaine O
as O
their O
primary O
drug O
of O
choice O
. O

Cocaine-dependent O
participants O
were O
administered O
a O
comprehensive O
medical O
history O
and O
physical O
examination O
, O
a O
general O
laboratory O
panel O
, O
urine O
drug O
screen O
, O
and O
a O
guided O
interview O
of O
lifetime O
substance O
use O
history O
during O
the O
first O
and O
second O
week O
of O
inpatient O
treatment O
. O

Participants O
were O
excluded O
if O
they O
had O
any O
history O
of O
major O
illness O
, O
had O
an O
estimated O
IQ O
below O
70 O
( O
per O
the O
Wechsler O
Test O
of O
Adult O
Reading O
) O
, O
met O
criteria O
for O
any O
neurological O
or O
active O
Axis O
I O
disorder O
( O
other O
than O
substance O
use O
disorders O
) O
, O
or O
were O
on O
any O
central O
nervous O
system O
active O
medications O
( O
including O
all O
psychotropics O
) O
. O

Other O
drug O
use O
among O
cocaine-dependent O
individuals O
was O
not O
a O
criterion O
for O
exclusion O
, O
as O
long O
as O
cocaine O
dependence O
was O
the O
primary O
diagnosis O
. O

15 O
of O
the O
CD O
participants O
also O
had O
history O
of O
alcohol O
, O
whereas O
none O
of O
the O
CD O
participants O
had O
alcohol O
abuse O
history O
. O

Cocaine-dependent O
participants O
were O
recruited O
following O
admission O
to O
one O
of O
three O
residential O
cocaine O
dependence O
treatment O
programs O
in O
Dallas O
, O
Texas O
, O
and O
were O
admitted O
as O
soon O
as O
possible O
after O
their O
last O
reported O
use O
of O
cocaine O
. O

All O
three O
programs O
utilized O
the O
Minnesota O
Model O
psychosocial O
treatment O
approach O
. O

Urine O
drug O
screens O
were O
conducted O
throughout O
residential O
treatment O
to O
verify O
abstinence O
. O

The O
time O
in O
treatment O
varied O
between O
2 O
and O
4 O
weeks O
. O

This O
time O
frame O
allowed O
the O
resolution O
of O
cocaine O
intoxication O
, O
cocaine O
withdrawal O
symptoms O
, O
and O
reasonable O
stability O
of O
other O
mood O
symptoms O
while O
remaining O
in O
a O
monitored O
residential O
setting O
. O

It O
was O
anticipated O
that O
variability O
with O
this O
small O
window O
of O
abstinence O
in O
a O
substance-free O
, O
residential O
treatment O
program O
would O
be O
minimal O
. O

All O
participants O
admitted O
into O
the O
three O
treatment O
programs O
over O
a O
4-year O
period O
were O
screened O
. O

Informed O
consent O
was O
obtained O
on O
180 O
participants O
( O
46 O
female O
, O
134 O
male O
) O
. O

Ninety O
seven O
were O
excluded O
from O
the O
analyses O
of O
this O
paper O
due O
to O
not O
meeting O
inclusion O
criteria O
, O
early O
discharge O
from O
program O
, O
or O
withdrawal O
of O
consent O
or O
technical O
problems O
with O
fMRI O
data O
. O

Healthy O
control O
participants O
had O
no O
lifetime O
history O
of O
substance O
use O
disorder O
. O

Other O
psychiatric O
, O
medical O
, O
and O
cognitive O
exclusion O
criteria O
were O
similar O
to O
that O
of O
the O
cocaine-dependent O
participants O
. O

All O
aspects O
of O
the O
research O
protocol O
were O
reviewed O
and O
approved O
by O
the O
Institutional O
Review O
Boards O
of O
the O
University O
of O
Texas O
Southwestern O
Medical O
Center O
at O
Dallas O
and O
the O
Veterans O
Administration O
North O
Texas O
Health O
Care O
System O
. O

Participants O
signed O
an O
informed O
consent O
before O
study O
participation O
and O
were O
compensated O
for O
their O
participation O
. O

Relevant O
demographic O
and O
clinical O
characteristics O
of O
the O
participants O
are O
provided O
in O
Table O
1 O
. O

MRI O
data O
acquisition O
Cocaine-dependent O
individuals O
completed O
scans O
during O
their O
final O
week O
of O
a O
2- O
to O
4-week O
residential O
treatment O
program O
. O

Participants O
completed O
fMRI O
scans O
during O
which O
they O
were O
instructed O
to O
lie O
as O
still O
as O
possible O
with O
their O
eyes O
open O
. O

Two O
control O
participants O
were O
excluded O
from O
all O
imaging O
analysis O
due O
to O
a O
technical O
error O
during O
acquisition O
of O
the O
resting O
data O
. O

Functional O
MRI O
acquisition O
was O
performed O
on O
a O
Philips O
3T O
magnetic O
resonance O
scanner O
( O
Philips O
Medical O
Systems O
, O
Best O
, O
The O
Netherlands O
) O
. O

BOLD O
fMRI O
data O
during O
the O
SST O
experiment O
were O
acquired O
using O
a O
single-shot O
echo-planar O
imaging O
sequence O
with O
3.25 O
χ O
3.25 O
mm2 O
in-plane O
resolution O
, O
36 O
slices O
( O
thickness/gap O
= O
3/0 O
mm O
) O
, O
field-of-view O
( O
FOV O
) O
208 O
× O
208 O
× O
108 O
mm O
, O
matrix O
size O
64 O
× O
64 O
× O
36 O
, O
repetition O
time/echo O
time O
= O
1,700/25 O
milliseconds O
, O
gradient-echo O
echo-planar O
imaging O
( O
EPI O
) O
with O
flip O
angle O
70° O
, O
and O
384 O
volumes O
over O
the O
duration O
of O
about O
653 O
s. O
For O
spatial O
normalization O
purposes O
, O
high-resolution O
T1-weighted O
images O
were O
acquired O
with O
a O
spatial O
resolution O
of O
1 O
× O
1 O
× O
1 O
mm3 O
. O

Stop O
signal O
task O
The O
task O
