has O
previously O
been O
proposed O
and O
described O
by O
and O
been O
used O
to O
classify O
ADHD O
from O
healthy O
controls O
with O
almost O
80 O
% O
classification O
accuracy O
. O

Goggles O
were O
used O
for O
stimulus O
presentation O
. O

A O
rapid O
mixed-trial O
event-related O
fMRI O
design O
was O
used O
. O

Horizontal O
white O
arrows O
( O
“ O
Go O
” O
stimulus O
) O
on O
a O
black O
background O
pointing O
either O
left O
or O
right O
appeared O
for O
500 O
ms O
with O
a O
mean O
inter-stimulus O
interval O
( O
ISI O
) O
of O
1.8 O
s O
( O
1.6 O
, O
1.8 O
, O
2.0 O
s O
) O
. O

The O
three O
ISIs O
were O
randomly O
presented O
to O
optimize O
statistical O
efficiency O
. O

Participants O
were O
instructed O
to O
make O
a O
button O
response O
to O
Go O
signals O
with O
their O
left O
or O
right O
thumb O
corresponding O
to O
the O
arrow O
direction O
as O
soon O
as O
possible O
. O

In O
the O
unpredictable O
, O
infrequent O
Stop O
trials O
( O
74 O
Stop O
trials O
, O
approximately O
20 O
% O
of O
the O
trials O
) O
, O
horizontal O
arrows O
were O
followed O
( O
after O
a O
variable O
250–900 O
ms O
delay O
) O
, O
by O
vertical O
arrows O
pointing O
upward O
( O
“ O
Stop O
” O
stimulus O
) O
. O

Participants O
were O
instructed O
to O
inhibit O
their O
response O
to O
the O
preceding O
Go O
stimulus O
when O
a O
Stop O
arrow O
was O
presented O
after O
the O
Go O
stimulus O
. O

The O
delay O
between O
Go O
and O
Stop O
stimuli O
was O
titrated O
, O
according O
to O
each O
participant O
’ O
s O
performance O
. O

The O
tracking O
algorithm O
was O
designed O
to O
assure O
the O
task O
was O
equally O
challenging O
for O
each O
individual O
, O
providing O
50 O
% O
successful O
( O
StopSuccess O
) O
and O
50 O
% O
unsuccessful O
( O
StopFail O
) O
inhibition O
trials O
. O

Seventy-four O
Stop O
trials O
( O
evenly O
distributed O
between O
right O
and O
left O
Go O
arrows O
) O
were O
pseudo-randomly O
interspersed O
with O
288 O
Go O
trials O
. O

Successive O
Stop O
trials O
were O
separated O
by O
at O
least O
three O
Go O
trials O
to O
allow O
better O
separation O
of O
the O
hemodynamic O
response O
. O

Stop O
and O
Go O
trials O
were O
equally O
distributed O
between O
right O
and O
left O
arrows O
. O

The O
number O
of O
Stop O
and O
Go O
trials O
, O
74 O
and O
288 O
, O
respectively O
, O
were O
the O
same O
for O
each O
participant O
. O

Performance O
on O
the O
SST O
was O
calculated O
for O
each O
participant O
. O

The O
Stop O
Signal O
Response O
Time O
( O
SSRT O
) O
is O
the O
time O
required O
for O
a O
participant O
to O
cancel O
their O
movement O
after O
seeing O
the O
stop O
signal O
, O
where O
longer O
SSRTs O
indicate O
poorer O
response O
inhibition O
. O

SSRT O
was O
calculated O
by O
subtracting O
the O
average O
stop O
signal O
delay O
at O
which O
participants O
achieve O
50 O
% O
of O
inhibition O
from O
the O
average O
reaction O
time O
to O
go O
signals O
. O

The O
mean O
and O
standard O
deviation O
of O
the O
SSRT O
for O
each O
of O
the O
two O
groups O
, O
as O
well O
as O
other O
task O
performance O
measures O
such O
as O
mean O
response O
time O
to O
Go O
trials O
( O
MRT O
) O
, O
stop O
signal O
delay O
( O
SSD O
) O
, O
omission O
percentage O
to O
Go O
trials O
, O
and O
inhibition O
percentage O
, O
are O
presented O
in O
Table O
1 O
. O

Data O
processing O
and O
analysis O
The O
fMRI O
time O
series O
data O
were O
realigned O
( O
motion-corrected O
) O
using O
MCFLIRT O
, O
slice O
time O
corrected O
, O
resampled O
, O
and O
normalized O
into O
standard O
2 O
mm O
× O
2 O
mm O
× O
2 O
mm O
MNI O
space O
( O
91 O
× O
109 O
× O
91 O
matrix O
) O
for O
all O
of O
the O
volumes O
, O
using O
FSL O
( O
http O
: O
//fsl.fmrib.ox.ac.uk O
) O
. O

Spatial O
smoothing O
with O
a O
Gaussian O
kernel O
of O
5-mm O
full-width O
at O
half-maximum O
( O
FWHM O
) O
was O
also O
performed O
. O

A O
2 O
mm O
MNI O
T1 O
brain O
mask O
was O
applied O
for O
the O
brain O
extraction O
. O

Spatial O
group O
ICA O
was O
done O
on O
normalized O
data O
using O
the O
Group O
ICA O
of O
fMRI O
( O
GIFT O
) O
Toolbox O
( O
http O
: O
//mialab.mrn.org/ O
software/gift O
) O
. O

The O
number O
of O
independent O
components O
was O
set O
to O
20 O
to O
keep O
the O
number O
or O
ICs O
manageable O
. O

Static O
FC O
and O
DFC O
analyses O
were O
done O
using O
a O
MATLAB-based O
graphical O
user O
interface O
software O
which O
was O
developed O
in-house O
and O
was O
based O
on O
an O
earlier O
work O
by O
. O

Procedurally O
the O
Group O
ICA O
begins O
by O
reducing O
the O
ICs O
to O
be O
evaluated O
by O
ICA O
by O
first O
using O
principal O
component O
analysis O
( O
PCA O
) O
in O
two O
stages O
. O

Each O
participant O
file O
contains O
384 O
fMRI O
time O
points O
. O

The O
first O
stage O
reduced O
each O
of O
the O
83 O
participants O
with O
384 O
BOLD O
fMRI O
time O
points O
to O
83 O
participants O
, O
each O
with O
20 O
ICs O
. O

The O
second O
stage O
of O
PCA O
reduced O
this O
group O
to O
a O
single O
group O
of O
20 O
ICs O
for O
the O
participants O
grouped O
together O
. O

This O
final O
group O
is O
evaluated O
with O
InfoMax O
ICA O
. O

InfoMax O
ICA O
was O
setup O
with O
bias O
and O
sphering O
on O
. O

Block O
size O
, O
stop O
, O
Irate O
, O
max O
step O
, O
anneal O
, O
and O
anneal O
angle O
were O
set O
to O
default O
values O
of O
275 O
, O
1 O
× O
106 O
, O
0.0050071 O
, O
512 O
, O
0.9 O
, O
and O
60 O
degrees O
, O
respectively O
. O

The O
results O
are O
then O
back O
reconstructed O
for O
each O
of O
the O
83 O
participants O
, O
each O
with O
20 O
ICs O
and O
an O
accompanying O
time O
course O
for O
each O
IC O
. O

After O
detailed O
visual O
inspection O
, O
12 O
of O
the O
20 O
ICs O
were O
found O
to O
be O
artifactual O
or O
nonrelevant O
components O
; O
therefore O
, O
the O
number O
of O
relevant O
ICs O
were O
reduced O
to O
8 O
, O
which O
constitute O
the O
relevant O
brain O
networks O
for O
our O
analysis O
. O

Static O
FC O
between O
any O
two O
ICs O
was O
measured O
by O
calculating O
the O
2D O
correlation O
between O
the O
time O
courses O
of O
the O
two O
ICs O
. O

The O
result O
is O
a O
single O
cross-correlation O
coefficient O
( O
cc O
) O
, O
which O
reveals O
how O
strong O
the O
connection O
is O
between O
the O
two O
ICs O
. O

A O
matrix O
of O
cc O
values O
is O
generated O
by O
calculating O
the O
2D O
correlation O
for O
all O
IC O
and O
participant O
combinations O
. O

Therefore O
, O
with O
83 O
participants O
, O
8 O
ICs O
and O
28 O
IC-pair O
combinations O
, O
a O
matrix O
with O
83 O
rows O
and O
28 O
columns O
is O
generated O
. O

Column O
labels O
were O
added O
to O
the O
data O
to O
identify O
the O
IC O
combinations O
the O
data O
belonged O
to O
. O

Row O
labels O
were O
added O
to O
identify O
which O
group O
( O
control O
or O
CD O
) O
each O
participant O
belonged O
to O
. O

This O
static O
FC O
matrix O
is O
then O
used O
for O
classification O
between O
control O
and O
CD O
. O

The O
method O
used O
to O
calculate O
DFC O
was O
by O
sweeping O
a O
time O
window O
across O
a O
time O
course O
( O
Figure O
2 O
) O
. O

All O
points O
from O
each O
time O
course O
that O
are O
inside O
the O
sliding O
window O
rectangle O
are O
used O
in O
the O
2D O
correlation O
to O
produce O
a O
single O
cross-correlation O
coefficient O
( O
cc O
) O
. O

For O
each O
participant O
, O
pair-wise O
regions O
are O
determined O
and O
their O
fMRI O
time O
courses O
are O
recorded O
in O
two O
single-dimensional O
arrays O
. O

Two O
parameters O
were O
required O
: O
window O
size O
and O
window O
step O
size O
. O

Correlation O
coefficients O
of O
the O
resulting O
DFC O
, O
which O
is O
also O
a O
dynamic O
time O
series O
data O
, O
are O
calculated O
for O
each O
of O
the O
windowed O
time O
courses O
of O
each O
IC O
pair O
, O
at O
every O
window O
step O
. O

Each O
IC O
for O
each O
of O
the O
participants O
has O
a O
corresponding O
time O
course O
, O
and O
thereby O
the O
time O
coursers O
were O
extracted O
from O
the O
ICA O
’ O
s O
computations O
, O
for O
the O
IC O
’ O
s O
of O
interest O
( O
the O
ones O
that O
are O
deemed O
to O
represent O
meaningful O
brain O
networks O
, O
not O
artifacts O
) O
. O

Throughout O
this O
paper O
, O
the O
calculation O
of O
DFC O
correlation O
coefficients O
from O
two O
time O
courses O
is O
considered O
the O
smallest O
calculation O
unit O
of O
the O
DFC O
analyses O
. O

In O
general O
, O
once O
the O
time O
courses O
are O
extracted O
( O
via O
ICA O
or O
otherwise O
, O
such O
as O
ROI-based O
average O
time O
course O
extraction O
) O
, O
DFC O
analyses O
investigate O
interactions O
among O
brain O
networks O
or O
regions O
using O
sliding O
window O
correlation O
. O

The O
outcome O
of O
DFC O
analysis O
between O
two O
networks O
or O
brain O
regions O
is O
also O
another O
time O
course O
that O
summarizes O
dynamics O
between O
the O
regions O
of O
interest O
. O

At O
the O
end O
, O
this O
method O
identified O
pairs O
of O
brain O
areas O
that O
are O
interacting O
together O
and O
the O
dynamics O
of O
the O
interaction O
. O

The O
DFC O
between O
two O
brain O
networks O
or O
regions O
is O
summarized O
in O
Figure O
2 O
. O

In O
our O
case O
, O
we O
determined O
the O
brain O
networks O
via O
ICA O
. O

More O
details O
on O
the O
methodology O
of O
the O
DFC O
can O
be O
found O
in O
. O

In O
our O
study O
, O
the O
size O
of O
the O
sliding O
window O
is O
32 O
time O
points O
. O

With O
a O
TR O
= O
1.7 O
s O
, O
the O
time O
window O
is O
54.4 O
s O
wide O
. O

Each O
time O
the O
window O
steps O
across O
the O
TCs O
, O
8 O
time O
points O
are O
jumped O
over O
( O
window O
step O
size O
of O
8 O
) O
, O
which O
corresponds O
to O
a O
13.6 O
s. O
We O
chose O
the O
size O
of O
32 O
for O
the O
sliding O
window O
since O
one O
needs O
n O
> O
30 O
data O
points O
in O
order O
to O
obtain O
a O
reliable O
correlation O
coefficient O
statistically O
( O
for O
n O
> O
30 O
samples O
, O
the O
t-distribution O
and O
the O
Normal O
distribution O
are O
very O
similar O
) O
. O

Choice O
of O
8 O
for O
the O
window O
step O
size O
was O
somewhat O
arbitrary O
; O
we O
wanted O
to O
keep O
a O
balance O
between O
having O
too O
short O
of O
a O
step O
size O
( O
which O
would O
probably O
not O
capture O
any O
real O
DFC O
changes O
but O
probably O
mostly O
noise O
) O
and O
too O
long O
( O
which O
could O
miss O
any O
real O
DFC O
changes O
) O
. O

We O
discuss O
the O
effects O
of O
our O
window O
size O
and O
the O
window O
step O
size O
more O
in O
the O
Discussion O
section O
. O

In O
our O
case O
, O
since O
there O
are O
384 O
total O
time O
points O
, O
as O
a O
result O
, O
the O
DFC O
analysis O
results O
in O
45 O
cc O
values O
. O

There O
are O
28 O
pairing O
combinations O
between O
8 O
ICs O
. O

Therefore O
, O
with O
83 O
participants O
, O
8 O
ICs O
, O
28 O
IC O
pairs O
, O
and O
45 O
cc O
values O
per O
IC O
combination O
, O
a O
matrix O
with O
83 O
rows O
and O
1,260 O
columns O
was O
generated O
. O

Column O
labels O
were O
added O
to O
the O
data O
to O
identify O
the O
IC O
combination O
that O
the O
data O
belonged O
to O
as O
well O
as O
the O
order O
number O
of O
the O
cc O
. O

Row O
labels O
were O
added O
to O
identify O
which O
group O
( O
controls O
or O
CD O
) O
each O
participant O
belonged O
to O
. O

This O
DFC O
cc O
matrix O
was O
then O
used O
for O
classification O
between O
controls O
and O
CD O
. O

Anatomical O
identification O
of O
the O
independent O
components O
Anatomical O
identification O
of O
the O
ICs O
was O
performed O
using O
the O
Harvard-Oxford O
brain O
atlas O
in O
order O
to O
determine O
which O
anatomical O
brain O
regions O
that O
had O
the O
most O
coverage O
by O
each O
IC O
. O

The O
procedure O
which O
is O
used O
to O
score O
the O
coverage O
of O
each O
atlas O
region O
by O
an O
IC O
network O
is O
described O
in O
the O
pseudocode O
shown O
in O
Table O
2 O
. O

In O
this O
process O
, O
we O
calculate O
regionCoverage O
, O
which O
is O
the O
percent O
coverage O
of O
the O
region O
by O
the O
IC O
. O

Only O
ICA O
voxels O
for O
which O
the O
absolute O
value O
Z-score O
is O
greater O
than O
1.7 O
qualify O
as O
region O
covering O
voxels O
. O

The O
value O
of O
1.7 O
indicates O
that O
the O
voxel O
is O
beyond O
99 O
% O
of O
the O
Z-score O
distribution O
. O

For O
the O
Harvard-Oxford O
atlas O
, O
the O
values O
outside O
the O
region O
have O
a O
value O
zero O
, O
but O
the O
values O
inside O
the O
region O
are O
between O
the O
values O
0 O
and O
1 O
. O

The O
Harvard-Oxford O
atlas O
is O
a O
probability O
map O
so O
the O
voxel O
values O
inside O
a O
region O
increase O
as O
the O
likelihood O
of O
being O
in O
the O
region O
increases O
. O

Therefore O
, O
the O
regionCoverage O
for O
the O
Harvard-Oxford O
atlas O
is O
percent O
likelihood O
of O
being O
a O
specific O
region O
as O
opposed O
to O
being O
a O
flat O
coverage O
or O
overlap O
of O
the O
region O
. O

Feature O
selection O
and O
classification O
Classification O
was O
performed O
using O
Weka O
, O
a O
widely O
used O
data O
mining O
and O
classification O
software O
written O
with O
a O
Java O
platform O
. O

The O
FC O
and O
DFC O
matrices O
were O
converted O
from O
MATLAB O
into O
Weka O
’ O
s.arff O
data O
format O
to O
be O
compatible O
with O
the O
Weka O
software O
. O

All O
features O
, O
which O
are O
cross-correlation O
coefficients O
, O
are O
normalized O
between O
[ O
−1 O
, O
1 O
] O
; O
however O
, O
no O
standardization O
( O
zero-mean O
, O
unit-standard O
deviation O
) O
was O
applied O
to O
the O
dataset O
. O

Each O
column O
( O
28 O
columns O
in O
FC O
, O
1,232 O
columns O
in O
DFC O
) O
in O
the O
two O
matrices O
was O
initially O
considered O
a O
feature O
to O
be O
used O
in O
the O
classification O
. O

The O
SVM O
classification O
algorithm O
from O
LIBSVM O
, O
a O
popular O
open O
source O
machine O
learning O
library O
, O
was O
used O
. O

During O
classification O
, O
the O
least O
significant O
IC O
pairs O
were O
iteratively O
reduced O
one O
at O
a O
time O
, O
in O
order O
to O
determine O
how O
the O
classification O
accuracy O
changed O
after O
removal O
of O
the O
pair O
. O

Having O
a O
high O
number O
of O
features O
does O
not O
simply O
yield O
the O
highest O
classification O
accuracy O
for O
nonlinear O
classification O
algorithms O
such O
as O
SVM O
, O
and O
in O
general O
when O
the O
number O
of O
samples O
are O
not O
high O
( O
curse O
of O
dimensionality O
) O
. O

Therefore O
, O
the O
number O
of O
features O
were O
reduced O
. O

This O
process O
constitutes O
the O
first O
step O
in O
feature O
reduction O
in O
which O
the O
minimal O
set O
of O
ICs O
yielding O
the O
best O
classification O
accuracy O
was O
found O
. O

The O
process O
of O
iterative O
removal O
of O
IC O
pairs O
started O
with O
the O
set O
of O
all O
28 O
pairs O
, O
including O
all O
initial O
feature O
sets O
used O
in O
SVM O
classification O
. O

In O
the O
case O
of O
DFC-based O
classification O
, O
the O
features O
associated O
with O
an O
IC O
pair O
were O
removed O
all O
together O
as O
a O
group O
, O
i.e. O
, O
removal O
of O
an O
IC O
pair O
required O
removal O
of O
all O
45 O
DFC O
measures O
computed O
for O
the O
IC O
pair O
. O

This O
group O
removal O
process O
was O
only O
specific O
to O
DFC O
since O
each O
pair O
in O
FC O
involves O
only O
one O
FC O
measure O
, O
not O
a O
group O
of O
45 O
features O
as O
in O
DFC O
. O

In O
the O
beginning O
of O
DFC O
experiments O
, O
the O
number O
of O
features O
was O
28 O
× O
45 O
, O
whereas O
FC O
experiments O
started O
with O
only O
28 O
features O
( O
one O
for O
each O
IC O
pair O
) O
. O

In O
both O
experiments O
( O
DFC O
, O
FC O
) O
, O
the O
pair O
to O
be O
removed O
in O
each O
iteration O
were O
selected O
utilizing O
a O
weight O
vector O
( O
where O
n O
= O
28 O
for O
FC O
and O
n O
= O
28 O
× O
45 O
for O
DFC O
) O
in O
SVM O
. O

Since O
each O
entry O
of O
w O
corresponds O
to O
a O
feature O
in O
the O
classification O
problem O
, O
showed O
that O
the O
larger O
∣wj∣ O
, O
j O
≤ O
n O
, O
the O
more O
the O
contribution O
to O
the O
classification O
decision O
. O

In O
this O
notation O
, O
n O
is O
the O
number O
of O
features O
in O
the O
classification O
problem O
, O
and O
n-element O
w O
vector O
is O
the O
weight O
vector O
, O
which O
, O
after O
iterations O
of O
the O
classification O
algorithm O
, O
becomes O
the O
solution O
of O
the O
classification O
problem O
. O

Wj O
is O
the O
jth O
element O
of O
w. O
Following O
, O
linear O
SVM O
classifiers O
were O
run O
iteratively O
, O
removing O
the O
least O
significant O
pair O
from O
the O
current O
set O
at O
every O
iteration O
. O

The O
stopping O
condition O
was O
satisfied O
once O
all O
but O
one O
pair O
was O
removed O
. O

In O
each O
iteration O
, O
participants O
were O
classified O
using O
the O
leave-one-out O
( O
LOO O
) O
model O
validation O
method O
. O

The O
LOO O
scheme O
is O
the O
exhaustive O
version O
of O
k-fold O
cross-validation O
with O
k O
= O
N O
= O
83 O
and O
avoids O
the O
combination-driven O
calculation O
problem O
of O
k-fold O
cross-validation O
. O

In O
an O
LOO O
scheme O
, O
one O
test O
participant O
, O
S O
, O
is O
excluded O
from O
the O
overall O
group O
of O
N O
= O
83 O
, O
and O
it O
is O
classified O
to O
be O
control O
or O
CD O
using O
the O
model O
built O
based O
on O
the O
remaining O
N O
– O
S O
= O
82 O
participants O
, O
which O
is O
the O
training O
group O
. O

S O
is O
also O
called O
the O
validation O
participant O
. O

This O
classification O
process O
is O
repeated O
N O
= O
83 O
times O
, O
once O
for O
each O
of O
the O
participants O
. O

The O
accuracy O
of O
model O
is O
reported O
in O
each O
case O
. O

Note O
that O
SVM O
classification O
models O
obtained O
for O
each O
training O
dataset O
result O
in O
different O
but O
similar O
classification O
models O
( O
a O
hyperline O
in O
multidimensional O
space O
) O
even O
if O
the O
SVM O
is O
trained O
with O
exactly O
the O
same O
parameters O
and O
constraints O
. O

In O
general O
, O
a O
dataset O
with O
significant O
informative O
features O
would O
be O
more O
robust O
to O
removal O
of O
a O
particular O
S O
, O
assuming O
that O
the O
other O
participants O
who O
are O
of O
the O
same O
class O
as O
S O
will O
cover O
the O
missing O
information O
excluded O
by O
the O
removal O
of O
S. O
Because O
of O
the O
nature O
of O
SVM O
’ O
s O
heavy O
dependence O
to O
parameter O
selection O
, O
in O
each O
iteration O
, O
training O
and O
classification O
were O
done O
using O
various O
parameters O
and O
kernels O
. O

The O
list O
of O
parameters O
and O
kernels O
is O
provided O
in O
Table O
3 O
. O

The O
parameters O
used O
for O
DFC-based O
results O
, O
which O
provide O
the O
best O
classification O
with O
7 O
IC O
pairs O
, O
are O
provided O
in O
bold O
font O
. O

Reward O
activation O
in O
childhood O
predicts O
adolescent O
substance O
use O
initiation O
in O
a O
high-risk O
sample O
* O
Background O
Substance O
use O
at O
an O
early O
age O
conveys O
substantial O
risk O
for O
later O
substance-related O
problems O
. O

A O
better O
understanding O
of O
early O
risk O
factors O
could O
result O
in O
more O
timely O
and O
effective O
intervention O
. O

This O
study O
investigated O
the O
predictive O
utility O
of O
the O
brain O
’ O
s O
response O
to O
reward O
anticipation O
as O
a O
risk O
factor O
for O
early O
substance O
use O
initiation O
. O

Methods O
Participants O
were O
34 O
children O
( O
25 O
male O
) O
at O
high O
risk O
for O
alcohol O
and O
other O
substance O
use O
disorders O
from O
a O
longitudinal O
functional O
magnetic O
resonance O
imaging O
study O
, O
scanned O
at O
a O
mean O
age O
of O
10.5 O
years O
( O
SD O
= O
1.2 O
) O
when O
participants O
were O
substance-naïve O
. O

We O
used O
a O
monetary O
incentive O
delay O
task O
to O
examine O
the O
hemodynamic O
response O
of O
the O
nucleus O
accumbens O
to O
gain O
and O
loss O
anticipation O
. O

Logistic O
regression O
was O
used O
to O
test O
the O
hypothesis O
that O
these O
brain O
response O
patterns O
would O
have O
predictive O
utility O
over O
and O
above O
early O
externalizing O
behaviors O
and O
family O
history O
of O
substance O
use O
disorder O
, O
two O
key O
risk O
factors O
for O
substance O
use O
problems O
, O
in O
differentiating O
those O
who O
initiated O
substance O
use O
before O
age O
16 O
( O
n O
= O
18 O
) O
and O
those O
who O
did O
not O
( O
n O
= O
16 O
) O
. O

Results O
Greater O
nucleus O
accumbens O
activation O
during O
monetary O
gain O
anticipation O
in O
childhood O
increased O
the O
likelihood O
of O
initiating O
substance O
use O
during O
early O
adolescence O
( O
p O
= O
.023 O
) O
. O

The O
model O
that O
comprised O
neural O
data O
in O
addition O
to O
early O
externalizing O
behaviors O
and O
family O
history O
showed O
significantly O
better O
fit O
than O
the O
model O
without O
neural O
data O
( O
χ22 O
= O
7.38 O
, O
p O
= O
.025 O
) O
. O

Conclusions O
Heightened O
gain O
anticipation O
activation O
in O
the O
nucleus O
accumbens O
may O
predispose O
individuals O
to O
early O
substance O
use O
, O
beyond O
the O
risk O
conveyed O
by O
other O
known O
factors O
. O

Material O
and O
Methods O
Participants O
Participants O
were O
34 O
youth O
( O
25 O
male O
) O
from O
the O
MLS O
, O
aged O
8.2–12.9 O
at O
the O
time O
of O
the O
fMRI O
scan O
( O
M O
= O
10.5 O
, O
SD O
= O
1.2 O
) O
. O

The O
MLS O
is O
a O
multi-wave O
, O
community-recruited O
study O
of O
families O
with O
and O
without O
parental O
alcohol O
use O
disorder O
( O
AUD O
) O
. O

As O
part O
of O
the O
MLS O
, O
assessments O
were O
conducted O
every O
three O
years O
starting O
when O
the O
children O
were O
aged O
3–5 O
; O
adolescents O
and O
young O
adults O
were O
also O
assessed O
every O
year O
from O
age O
11–26 O
. O

Families O
were O
excluded O
if O
the O
target O
child O
displayed O
evidence O
of O
fetal O
alcohol O
effects O
or O
the O
mother O
reported O
drinking O
during O
pregnancy O
. O

The O
majority O
of O
participants O
in O
the O
present O
analyses O
( O
82.4 O
% O
) O
were O
FH+ O
for O
SUD O
, O
making O
this O
a O
high-risk O
sample O
. O

( O
Although O
the O
original O
recruitment O
strategy O
of O
the O
MLS O
involved O
accessing O
a O
community-based O
sample O
of O
parents O
with O
AUD O
, O
their O
high O
other O
drug O
comorbidity O
meant O
that O
their O
offspring O
would O
be O
at O
elevated O
risk O
for O
both O
alcohol O
and O
other O
drug O
use O
. O

The O
MLS O
has O
historically O
focused O
on O
understanding O
these O
other O
risk O
patterns O
as O
well O
) O
Full O
details O
on O
MLS O
assessment O
and O
data O
collection O
can O
be O
found O
elsewhere O
. O

For O
the O
present O
imaging O
study O
, O
participants O
were O
excluded O
if O
they O
had O
any O
neurological O
, O
acute O
, O
uncorrected O
, O
or O
chronic O
medical O
illness O
; O
current O
or O
recent O
( O
within O
6 O
months O
) O
treatment O
with O
centrally O
active O
medications O
; O
MRI O
contraindications O
such O
as O
metal O
implants O
or O
claustrophobia O
; O
IQ O
< O
70 O
; O
history O
of O
psychosis O
in O
self O
or O
first-degree O
relatives O
; O
or O
current O
, O
active O
Axis O
I O
disorder O
according O
to O
the O
Diagnostic O
and O
Statistical O
Manual O
of O
Mental O
Disorders O
( O
DSM-IV O
) O
criteria O
. O

However O
, O
disorders O
that O
are O
often O
comorbid O
with O
substance O
use O
were O
not O
part O
of O
the O
exclusion O
criteria O
( O
so O
as O
not O
to O
bias O
the O
sample O
against O
our O
construct O
of O
interest O
) O
: O
current O
or O
past O
anxiety O
, O
conduct O
or O
attention O
deficit O
hyperactivity O
( O
ADHD O
) O
disorder O
, O
or O
past O
mood O
disorder O
. O

Participants O
who O
were O
taking O
medication O
for O
ADHD O
were O
asked O
to O
abstain O
at O
least O
48 O
hours O
before O
the O
MRI O
scan O
. O

Parents/guardians O
of O
participants O
provided O
written O
informed O
consent O
and O
participants O
provided O
written O
informed O
assent O
. O

Study O
materials O
and O
procedures O
were O
approved O
by O
the O
University O
of O
Michigan O
Medical O
School O
Institutional O
Review O
Board O
. O

Measures O
Substance O
use O
Drinking O
and O
drug O
use O
histories O
were O
obtained O
from O
each O
participant O
by O
trained O
research O
staff O
as O
part O
of O
the O
regular O
MLS O
assessment O
schedule O
. O

Beginning O
at O
age O
6 O
and O
occurring O
at O
three-year O
intervals O
thereafter O
, O
a O
health O
and O
daily O
living O
questionnaire O
was O
used O
to O
assess O
the O
use O
of O
alcohol O
( O
more O
than O
a O
sip O
) O
, O
cigarettes O
, O
marijuana O
, O
and O
other O
drugs O
. O

If O
applicable O
, O
the O
age O
at O
which O
use O
occurred O
and O
the O
quantity/frequency O
of O
use O
was O
also O
recorded O
. O

At O
annual O
assessments O
beginning O
at O
age O
11 O
, O
the O
Drinking O
and O
Drug O
History O
Form O
for O
Children O
was O
used O
to O
assess O
the O
quantity O
and O
frequency O
of O
alcohol O
, O
nicotine O
, O
and O
illicit O
drug O
( O
i.e. O
, O
marijuana O
and O
17 O
other O
drugs O
, O
including O
inhalants O
and O
prescription O
drugs O
used O
non-medically O
) O
use O
. O

Problems O
associated O
with O
alcohol O
and O
drug O
use O
, O
respectively O
( O
e.g. O
, O
missed O
school O
because O
of O
drinking O
, O
had O
trouble O
getting O
along O
with O
friends O
because O
of O
drug O
use O
) O
, O
were O
also O
assessed O
. O

Previous O
research O
has O
shown O
that O
substance O
use O
initiation O
before O
the O
age O
of O
16 O
confers O
a O
higher O
risk O
for O
later O
problems O
than O
does O
initiation O
in O
young O
adulthood O
. O

Therefore O
, O
we O
used O
age O
16 O
as O
the O
threshold O
for O
increased O
risk O
and O
selected O
participants O
from O
the O
ongoing O
longitudinal O
study O
for O
whom O
we O
had O
follow-up O
substance O
use O
data O
at O
age O
16 O
or O
older O
( O
ensuring O
that O
all O
comparison O
participants O
were O
beyond O
the O
highest-risk O
window O
) O
. O

Participants O
also O
had O
to O
have O
a O
fMRI O
scan O
prior O
to O
any O
substance O
use O
in O
order O
to O
be O
included O
in O
the O
present O
analyses O
. O

Of O
the O
34 O
participants O
who O
met O
these O
criteria O
, O
18 O
eventually O
initiated O
substance O
use O
( O
11 O
male O
; O
initiation O
group O
) O
, O
whereas O
16 O
did O
not O
( O
14 O
male O
; O
comparison O
group O
) O
. O

On O
average O
, O
those O
in O
the O
comparison O
group O
were O
17.9 O
years O
old O
( O
SD O
1.5 O
) O
at O
the O
most O
recent O
substance O
use O
assessment O
, O
whereas O
those O
in O
the O
initiation O
group O
were O
13.4 O
years O
old O
( O
SD O
1.5 O
) O
at O
substance O
use O
initiation O
. O

Other O
measures O
The O
Wechsler O
Intelligence O
Scale O
for O
Children O
( O
WISC-III O
) O
was O
used O
to O
assess O
full-scale O
IQ O
. O

Early O
externalizing O
behaviors O
( O
M O
= O
7.4 O
years O
old O
, O
SD O
= O
1.0 O
) O
were O
assessed O
via O
parent-report O
with O
T-scores O
from O
the O
Child O
Behavior O
Checklist O
( O
CBCL O
) O
. O

For O
ADHD O
, O
conduct O
disorder O
, O
depression O
, O
and O
anxiety O
diagnoses O
( O
i.e. O
, O
disorders O
that O
were O
not O
exclusionary O
during O
screening O
) O
, O
the O
computerized O
Diagnostic O
Interview O
Schedule O
for O
Children O
( O
C-DISC O
) O
was O
given O
, O
and O
diagnoses O
were O
tallied O
based O
on O
DSM-IV O
criteria O
. O

Finally O
, O
FH O
was O
defined O
as O
the O
number O
of O
parents O
( O
0 O
, O
1 O
, O
or O
2 O
) O
with O
a O
lifetime O
diagnosis O
of O
drug O
or O
alcohol O
abuse O
or O
dependence O
, O
according O
to O
DSM-IV O
criteria O
. O

Stimuli O
and O
Task O
A O
modified O
MID O
task O
was O
used O
to O
probe O
the O
brain O
’ O
s O
response O
to O
the O
anticipation O
of O
monetary O
incentive O
( O
i.e. O
, O
gain O
and O
loss O
) O
. O

Each O
trial O
was O
6-s O
long O
and O
consisted O
of O
4 O
stimuli O
, O
presented O
consecutively O
: O
1 O
) O
2000-ms O
incentive O
cue O
( O
“ O
Win O
$ O
5.00 O
, O
” O
“ O
Win O
$ O
0.20 O
, O
” O
“ O
Don O
’ O
t O
Lose O
$ O
5.00 O
, O
” O
“ O
Don O
’ O
t O
Lose O
$ O
0.20 O
, O
” O
or O
“ O
No O
Money O
at O
Stake O
” O
) O
, O
2 O
) O
2000-ms O
anticipation O
fixation O
cross O
, O
3 O
) O
variable-duration O
response O
target O
( O
i.e. O
, O
a O
solid O
black O
shape O
cuing O
a O
button O
press O
) O
, O
and O
4 O
) O
variable-duration O
feedback O
( O
e.g. O
, O
“ O
Correct O
Response O
. O

You O
earn O
$ O
5.00 O
! O
” O
) O
. O

There O
was O
no O
inter-trial O
interval O
. O

Participants O
were O
instructed O
to O
press O
the O
button O
to O
the O
target O
; O
responding O
while O
the O
target O
was O
on O
the O
screen O
signified O
a O
successful O
trial O
( O
i.e. O
, O
hit O
) O
. O

Response O
target O
duration O
was O
calculated O
based O
on O
each O
participant O
’ O
s O
reaction O
time O
during O
a O
practice O
session O
prior O
to O
scanning O
and O
recalibrated O
after O
the O
first O
run O
for O
an O
overall O
success O
rate O
of O
approximately O
60 O
% O
. O

Participants O
were O
also O
instructed O
to O
respond O
to O
neutral O
targets O
( O
i.e. O
, O
“ O
No O
Money O
at O
Stake O
” O
) O
despite O
no O
incentive O
value O
. O

Trials O
were O
presented O
in O
pseudorandom O
order O
in O
two O
5-minute O
runs O
of O
20 O
gain O
trials O
, O
20 O
loss O
trials O
, O
and O
10-neutral O
trials O
per O
run O
. O

Participants O
were O
paid O
money O
won O
during O
the O
task O
. O

fMRI O
Data O
Acquisition O
Whole-brain O
BOLD O
, O
functional O
images O
were O
acquired O
on O
a O
3.0T O
GE O
MR750 O
scanner O
( O
Milwaukee O
, O
WI O
) O
using O
T2 O
* O
-weighted O
single-shot O
combined O
spiral O
in/out O
sequences O
( O
TR O
2000 O
ms O
, O
TE O
30 O
ms O
, O
flip O
angle O
90 O
degrees O
, O
field-of-view O
200 O
mm O
, O
matrix O
size O
64 O
× O
64 O
, O
slice O
thickness O
4 O
mm O
, O
in-plane O
resolution O
3.12 O
× O
3.12 O
mm O
, O
29 O
slices O
) O
. O

High-resolution O
anatomical O
T1 O
scans O
were O
also O
obtained O
for O
spatial O
normalization O
( O
TR O
12.2 O
ms O
, O
TE O
5.2 O
ms O
, O
flip O
angle O
15 O
degrees O
, O
field-of-view O
26 O
mm O
, O
matrix O
size O
256 O
× O
192 O
, O
slice O
thickness O
1.2 O
mm O
, O
in-plane O
resolution O
1.02 O
× O
1.08 O
mm O
, O
124 O
slices O
) O
. O

Motion O
was O
minimized O
with O
foam O
padding O
around O
the O
head O
and O
instructing O
participants O
on O
the O
importance O
of O
keeping O
still O
. O

Data O
processing O
and O
analytic O
strategy O
Preprocessing O
Functional O
images O
were O
reconstructed O
using O
an O
iterative O
algorithm O
and O
motion O
corrected O
using O
FSL O
v5.0.2.2 O
( O
FMRIB O
, O
Oxford O
, O
UK O
) O
. O

Runs O
exceeding O
3 O
mm O
translation O
or O
3° O
rotation O
were O
excluded O
. O

The O
difference O
between O
initiation O
and O
comparison O
groups O
on O
the O
number O
of O
runs O
excluded O
was O
not O
significant O
: O
initiation O
= O
16.7 O
% O
, O
comparison O
= O
15.6 O
% O
, O
t O
( O
32 O
) O
= O
0.13 O
, O
p O
= O
.901 O
. O

Image O
preprocessing O
was O
completed O
using O
Statistical O
Parametric O
Mapping O
( O
SPM8 O
; O
Wellcome O
Institute O
of O
Cognitive O
Neurology O
, O
Oxford O
, O
UK O
) O
. O

Functional O
images O
were O
slice-time O
corrected O
, O
spatially O
normalized O
to O
the O
Montreal O
Neurological O
Institute O
( O
MNI O
) O
template O
using O
SPM8 O
defaults O
, O
and O
smoothed O
with O
a O
6-mm O
full-width O
at O
half-maximum O
( O
FWHM O
) O
smoothing O
kernel O
. O

Low-frequency O
noise O
was O
removed O
with O
a O
high-pass O
filter O
( O
128 O
sec O
) O
. O

Individual-level O
analyses O
Image O
processing O
was O
done O
in O
SPM8 O
, O
and O
individual-level O
analyses O
were O
carried O
out O
using O
the O
general O
linear O
model O
. O

Two O
general O
events O
were O
modeled O
: O
1 O
) O
incentive O
cue O
+ O
anticipation O
fixation O
, O
and O
2 O
) O
response O
target O
+ O
feedback O
. O

The O
incentive O
cue O
+ O
anticipation O
fixation O
event O
was O
modeled O
separately O
for O
each O
cue O
type O
: O
large O
gain O
, O
small O
gain O
, O
large O
loss O
, O
small O
loss O
, O
and O
neutral O
. O

The O
response O
+ O
feedback O
event O
was O
modeled O
separately O
for O
each O
cue O
( O
except O
neutral O
) O
and O
feedback O
type O
: O
positive O
( O
i.e. O
, O
hit O
) O
and O
negative O
( O
i.e. O
, O
miss O
) O
for O
each O
of O
large O
gain O
, O
small O
gain O
, O
large O
loss O
, O
and O
small O
loss O
. O

These O
were O
convolved O
with O
the O
standard O
hemodynamic O
response O
function O
, O
along O
with O
six O
realignment O
parameters O
and O
white O
matter O
signal O
intensity O
as O
nuisance O
variables O
. O

Owing O
to O
our O
focus O
in O
this O
study O
on O
NAcc O
activation O
during O
the O
anticipation O
of O
gaining O
and O
losing O
money O
, O
NAcc O
spherical O
anatomical O
masks O
of O
5 O
mm O
in O
diameter O
and O
centered O
on O
the O
Montreal O
Neurological O
Institute O
coordinates O
of O
[ O
x O
= O
−10 O
, O
y O
= O
13 O
, O
z O
= O
−8 O
] O
and O
[ O
x O
= O
10 O
, O
y O
= O
13 O
, O
z O
= O
−8 O
] O
were O
used O
to O
extract O
mean O
parameter O
estimates O
with O
MarsBaR O
for O
two O
contrasts O
of O
interest O
: O
large O
gain O
anticipation O
vs. O
neutral O
anticipation O
( O
i.e. O
, O
Win O
$ O
5.00 O
vs. O
No O
Money O
at O
Stake O
) O
and O
large O
loss O
anticipation O
vs. O
neutral O
anticipation O
( O
i.e. O
, O
Don O
’ O
t O
Lose O
$ O
5.00 O
vs. O
No O
Money O
at O
Stake O
) O
. O

This O
task O
was O
originally O
developed O
with O
different O
incentive O
values O
so O
that O
the O
parametric O
effect O
of O
different O
monetary O
amounts O
could O
be O
investigated O
. O

Our O
interest O
here O
was O
in O
the O
function O
of O
reward O
processing O
overall O
rather O
than O
the O
difference O
between O
large O
and O
small O
incentives O
, O
and O
previous O
work O
has O
found O
that O
large O
incentives O
elicit O
a O
more O
robust O
signal O
than O
do O
small O
incentives O
. O

Thus O
, O
we O
focused O
on O
large O
gain O
and O
loss O
for O
the O
present O
analyses O
. O

After O
extraction O
, O
comparisons O
of O
the O
left O
and O
right O
NAcc O
using O
paired O
samples O
t-tests O
( O
large O
gain O
: O
t O
( O
33 O
) O
=0.94 O
, O
p=.353 O
; O
large O
loss O
: O
t O
( O
33 O
) O
=0.09 O
, O
p=.928 O
) O
and O
correlational O
analyses O
( O
large O
gain O
: O
r=.84 O
, O
p O
< O
.001 O
; O
large O
loss O
: O
r=.73 O
, O
p O
< O
.001 O
) O
indicated O
that O
a O
single O
averaged O
left/right O
NAcc O
variable O
for O
each O
of O
the O
two O
contrasts O
of O
interest O
could O
be O
used O
. O

Prediction O
of O
substance O
use O
initiation O
using O
logistic O
regression O
Hierarchical O
logistic O
regression O
was O
used O
to O
test O
the O
predictive O
utility O
of O
substance O
use O
risk O
factors O
on O
the O
initiation O
of O
substance O
use O
by O
age O
16 O
. O

Group O
membership O
( O
initiation O
or O
comparison O
) O
was O
the O
dependent O
variable O
. O

Phenotypic O
variables O
( O
externalizing O
behaviors O
[ O
continuous O
variable O
] O
and O
FH O
[ O
i.e. O
, O
0 O
, O
1 O
, O
or O
2 O
parents O
] O
) O
were O
entered O
as O
predictors O
in O
the O
first O
block O
( O
restricted O
model O
) O
. O

NAcc O
variables O
( O
large O
gain O
anticipation O
and O
large O
loss O
anticipation O
[ O
continuous O
variables O
] O
) O
were O
added O
in O
the O
second O
block O
( O
full O
model O
) O
. O

No O
other O
covariates O
were O
included O
in O
either O
block O
. O

Model O
comparison O
was O
performed O
using O
a O
likelihood O
ratio O
test O
to O
determine O
whether O
the O
full O
model O
( O
i.e. O
, O
phenotypic O
and O
NAcc O
variables O
) O
showed O
a O
significantly O
better O
fit O
than O
the O
restricted O
model O
( O
i.e. O
, O
phenotypic O
variables O
alone O
) O
. O

In O
addition O
, O
beta O
coefficients O
were O
individually O
tested O
for O
significance O
. O

Alpha O
was O
set O
at O
.05 O
for O
both O
of O
these O
analyses O
. O

Demographic O
, O
Psychometric O
, O
and O
Task O
Performance O
Measures O
Independent O
samples O
t-tests O
or O
Fisher O
’ O
s O
exact O
tests O
were O
used O
to O
evaluate O
differences O
between O
initiation O
and O
comparison O
groups O
on O
demographic O
, O
psychometric O
, O
and O
task O
performance O
measures O
. O

The O
spatial O
chronnectome O
reveals O
a O
dynamic O
interplay O
between O
functional O
segregation O
and O
integration O
The O
brain O
is O
highly O
dynamic O
, O
reorganizing O
its O
activity O
at O
different O
interacting O
spatial O
and O
temporal O
scales O
, O
including O
variation O
within O
and O
between O
brain O
networks O
. O

The O
chronnectome O
is O
a O
model O
of O
the O
brain O
in O
which O
nodal O
activity O
and O
connectivity O
patterns O
change O
in O
fundamental O
and O
recurring O
ways O
over O
time O
. O

Most O
literature O
assume O
fixed O
spatial O
nodes/networks O
, O
ignoring O
the O
possibility O
that O
spatial O
nodes/networks O
may O
vary O
in O
time O
. O

Here O
, O
we O
introduce O
an O
approach O
to O
calculate O
a O
spatially O
fluid O
chronnectome O
( O
called O
the O
spatial O
chronnectome O
for O
clarity O
) O
, O
which O
focuses O
on O
the O
variations O
of O
networks O
coupling O
at O
the O
voxel O
level O
, O
and O
identify O
a O
novel O
set O
of O
spatially O
dynamic O
features O
. O

Results O
reveal O
transient O
spatially O
fluid O
interactions O
between O
intra-and O
inter-network O
relationships O
in O
which O
brain O
networks O
transiently O
merge O
and O
separate O
, O
emphasizing O
dynamic O
segregation O
and O
integration O
. O

Brain O
networks O
also O
exhibit O
distinct O
spatial O
patterns O
with O
unique O
temporal O
characteristics O
, O
potentially O
explaining O
a O
broad O
spectrum O
of O
inconsistencies O
in O
previous O
studies O
that O
assumed O
static O
networks O
. O

Moreover O
, O
we O
show O
anticorrelative O
connections O
to O
brain O
networks O
are O
transient O
as O
opposed O
to O
constant O
across O
the O
entire O
scan O
. O

Preliminary O
assessments O
using O
a O
multi-site O
dataset O
reveal O
the O
ability O
of O
the O
approach O
to O
obtain O
new O
information O
and O
nuanced O
alterations O
that O
remain O
undetected O
during O
static O
analysis O
. O

Patients O
with O
schizophrenia O
( O
SZ O
) O
display O
transient O
decreases O
in O
voxel-wise O
network O
coupling O
within O
visual O
and O
auditory O
networks O
, O
and O
higher O
intra-domain O
coupling O
variability O
. O

In O
summary O
, O
the O
spatial O
chronnectome O
represents O
a O
new O
direction O
of O
research O
enabling O
the O
study O
of O
functional O
networks O
which O
are O
transient O
at O
the O
voxel O
level O
, O
and O
the O
identification O
of O
mechanisms O
for O
within-and O
between-subject O
spatial O
variability O
. O

Method O
Outline O
of O
our O
approach O
Our O
approach O
assessing O
spatiotemporal O
variations O
of O
individual O
brain O
networks O
includes O
the O
following O
steps O
( O
Figure O
1 O
( O
A O
) O
) O
: O
Spatial O
independent O
component O
analysis O
( O
sICA O
) O
is O
applied O
to O
obtain O
large-scale O
brain O
networks O
and O
their O
associated O
time O
courses O
( O
Figure O
1 O
( O
A O
) O
Step O
1 O
) O
. O

The O
time O
course O
of O
each O
brain O
network O
obtained O
from O
sICA O
represents O
the O
temporal O
activity O
of O
that O
large-scale O
brain O
network O
. O

Details O
can O
be O
found O
in O
Section O
2.4 O
. O

Identifying O
large-scale O
brain O
networks O
: O
Spatial O
ICA O
. O

Temporal O
coupling O
and O
sliding-window O
approaches O
were O
employed O
to O
capture O
spatiotemporal O
variations O
of O
the O
large-scale O
brain O
networks O
. O

For O
each O
brain O
network O
and O
time O
window O
, O
we O
calculated O
the O
correlation O
between O
the O
time O
course O
of O
the O
brain O
network O
and O
the O
time O
courses O
of O
every O
voxel O
of O
the O
brain O
. O

The O
resulting O
correlation O
values O
represent O
the O
association O
( O
involvement O
) O
of O
all O
voxels O
across O
the O
brain O
to O
the O
given O
network O
at O
each O
time O
window O
( O
Figure O
1 O
( O
A O
) O
Step O
2 O
) O
. O

This O
results O
in O
one O
dynamic O
coupling O
map O
( O
dCM O
) O
per O
window O
for O
each O
brain O
network O
. O

This O
approach O
, O
unlike O
its O
predecessors O
, O
such O
as O
whole O
brain O
dynamic O
functional O
network O
connectivity O
( O
dFNC O
) O
and O
co-activation O
patterns O
( O
CAP O
) O
, O
provides O
nuanced O
information O
regarding O
temporal O
variations O
of O
spatial O
patterns O
of O
multiple O
brain O
networks O
simultaneously O
at O
the O
level O
of O
the O
voxel O
. O

Details O
can O
be O
found O
in O
Section O
2.5 O
. O

Calculating O
dynamic O
coupling O
maps O
( O
dCMs O
) O
for O
each O
brain O
network O
using O
a O
sliding-window O
approach O
. O

Time-varying O
properties O
were O
evaluated O
for O
each O
brain O
network O
( O
Figure O
1 O
( O
A O
) O
Step O
3 O
) O
. O

First O
, O
the O
dCMs O
of O
each O
individual O
network O
were O
clustered O
into O
a O
set O
of O
distinct O
spatial O
patterns O
called O
spatial O
states O
on O
which O
multiple O
dynamic O
metrics O
were O
calculated O
and O
investigated O
( O
see O
Section O
2.6 O
. O

Calculating O
the O
spatial O
states O
of O
each O
brain O
network O
and O
their O
dynamic O
patterns O
) O
. O

Next O
, O
the O
spatially-continuous O
variations O
of O
each O
brain O
network O
over O
time O
were O
evaluated O
by O
calculating O
voxel-wise O
changes O
in O
their O
dCMs O
( O
See O
Section O
2.7 O
. O

Evaluating O
the O
spatial O
variations O
of O
each O
brain O
network O
over O
time O
) O
. O

Data O
collection O
Data O
collection O
was O
performed O
at O
7 O
imaging O
sites O
across O
the O
United O
States O
, O
and O
all O
analyzed O
data O
passed O
data O
quality O
control O
. O

All O
participants O
are O
at O
least O
18 O
years O
old O
and O
gave O
written O
informed O
consent O
prior O
to O
enrollment O
. O

Data O
were O
collected O
from O
160 O
healthy O
participants O
, O
including O
46 O
females O
and O
114 O
males O
( O
average O
age O
: O
36.71 O
± O
10.92 O
; O
range O
: O
19–60 O
years O
) O
, O
and O
149 O
age-and O
gender-matched O
patients O
with O
SZ O
, O
including O
36 O
females O
and O
113 O
males O
( O
average O
age O
: O
37.95 O
± O
11.47 O
; O
range O
: O
18–60 O
years O
) O
. O

The O
imaging O
data O
were O
collected O
on O
a O
3-Tesla O
Siemens O
Tim O
Trio O
scanner O
for O
six O
of O
the O
seven O
sites O
and O
on O
a O
3-Tesla O
General O
Electric O
Discovery O
MR750 O
scanner O
at O
one O
site O
. O

Resting O
state O
fMRI O
( O
rsfMRI O
) O
data O
was O
acquired O
using O
a O
standard O
gradient O
echo-planar O
imaging O
( O
EPI O
) O
sequence O
with O
following O
imaging O
parameters O
: O
repetition O
time O
( O
TR O
) O
= O
2000 O
ms O
, O
echo O
time O
( O
TE O
) O
= O
30 O
ms O
, O
flip O
angle O
( O
FA O
) O
= O
77° O
, O
field O
of O
view O
( O
FOV O
) O
= O
220 O
× O
220 O
mm O
, O
matrix O
size O
= O
64 O
× O
64 O
, O
mm O
, O
pixel O
spacing O
size O
= O
3.4375 O
× O
3.4375 O
mm O
, O
slice O
thickness O
= O
4 O
mm O
, O
slice O
gap O
= O
1 O
mm O
, O
number O
of O
excitations O
( O
NEX O
) O
= O
1 O
, O
and O
a O
total O
of O
162 O
volumes O
. O

During O
rsfMRI O
scans O
, O
participants O
were O
instructed O
to O
keep O
their O
eyes O
closed O
and O
rest O
quietly O
without O
falling O
asleep O
. O

Further O
details O
on O
this O
dataset O
can O
be O
found O
in O
our O
earlier O
work O
. O

Preprocessing O
The O
preprocessing O
was O
performed O
primarily O
using O
SPM O
( O
http O
: O
//www.fil.ion.ucl.ac.uk/spm/ O
) O
and O
AFNI O
( O
https O
: O
//afni.nimh.nih.gov O
) O
software O
packages O
. O

The O
pipeline O
includes O
brain O
extraction O
, O
motion O
correction O
using O
the O
INRIAlign O
, O
slice-timing O
correction O
using O
the O
middle O
slice O
as O
the O
reference O
time O
frame O
, O
and O
despiking O
using O
AFNI O
’ O
s O
3dDespike O
. O

The O
data O
of O
each O
subject O
was O
subsequently O
warped O
to O
the O
Montreal O
Neurological O
Institute O
( O
MNI O
) O
template O
using O
non-linear O
registration O
, O
resampled O
to O
3 O
mm3 O
isotropic O
voxels O
, O
and O
spatially O
smoothed O
using O
a O
Gaussian O
kernel O
with O
a O
6 O
mm O
full O
width O
at O
half O
maximum O
( O
FWHM O
= O
6 O
mm O
) O
. O

Finally O
, O
voxel O
time O
courses O
were O
z-scored O
( O
variance O
normalized O
) O
as O
it O
has O
been O
shown O
in O
our O
analysis O
to O
better O
estimate O
brain O
networks O
relative O
to O
other O
scaling O
methods O
for O
independent O
component O
analysis O
. O

Identifying O
large-scale O
brain O
networks O
: O
Spatial O
ICA O
Spatial O
ICA O
( O
sICA O
) O
was O
applied O
to O
the O
fMRI O
data O
to O
obtain O
brain O
networks O
. O

ICA O
was O
performed O
using O
the O
GIFT O
software O
package O
( O
http O
: O
//mialab.mrn.org/software/gift/ O
) O
in O
the O
following O
steps O
similar O
to O
our O
previous O
work O
: O
1 O
) O
Subject-level O
principal O
component O
analysis O
( O
PCA O
) O
was O
applied O
and O
the O
30 O
principal O
components O
accounting O
for O
the O
maximum O
variance O
in O
each O
individual O
dataset O
were O
retained O
. O

2 O
) O
All O
subject-level O
principal O
components O
were O
concatenated O
together O
across O
the O
time O
dimension O
, O
and O
group-level O
spatial O
PCA O
was O
applied O
on O
9270 O
( O
30 O
× O
Subject O
) O
concatenated O
components O
. O

3 O
) O
The O
first O
20 O
group-level O
principal O
components O
with O
the O
highest O
variance O
were O
selected O
as O
input O
for O
the O
infomax O
algorithm O
to O
estimate O
the O
20 O
group O
independent O
components O
. O

Infomax O
ICA O
algorithm O
was O
repeated O
100 O
times O
on O
the O
20 O
group-level O
principal O
components O
using O
ICASSO O
framework O
in O
order O
to O
obtain O
a O
stable O
and O
reliable O
estimation O
of O
independent O
components O
, O
and O
the O
most O
representative O
run O
was O
selected O
for O
further O
analysis O
. O

4 O
) O
The O
subject-specific O
independent O
components O
and O
component O
time O
courses O
were O
calculated O
using O
group O
information O
guided O
ICA O
( O
GIG-ICA O
) O
. O

5 O
) O
The O
twelve O
independent O
components O
were O
identified O
as O
brain O
networks O
based O
on O
the O
spatial O
and O
temporal O
properties O
and O
prior O
knowledge O
from O
previous O
studies O
. O

Calculating O
dynamic O
coupling O
maps O
( O
dCMs O
) O
for O
each O
brain O
network O
using O
a O
sliding-window O
approach O
The O
spatiotemporal O
variations O
of O
each O
brain O
network O
can O
be O
captured O
by O
evaluating O
its O
dynamic O
coupling O
at O
a O
voxel-wise O
level O
. O

For O
this O
purpose O
, O
we O
calculated O
the O
temporal O
coupling O
between O
the O
brain O
network O
and O
every O
voxel O
of O
the O
brain O
using O
the O
sliding-window O
correlation O
approach O
. O

Temporal O
correlations O
have O
been O
used O
as O
the O
primary O
metric O
to O
measure O
functional O
connectivity O
, O
fully O
capturing O
the O
relationship O
between O
a O
given O
voxel O
and O
the O
brain O
network O
without O
regard O
to O
its O
contributions O
of O
other O
networks O
. O

For O
instance O
, O
if O
a O
given O
voxel O
is O
highly O
correlated O
with O
two O
networks O
, O
using O
correlation O
allows O
detecting O
both O
of O
these O
associations O
. O

As O
a O
result O
, O
we O
compute O
dCMs O
for O
a O
given O
network O
, O
which O
encapsulates O
the O
spatiotemporal O
variations O
of O
that O
brain O
network O
at O
a O
voxel-wise O
level O
. O

The O
same O
cleaning O
procedure O
that O
has O
previously O
demonstrated O
its O
effectiveness O
in O
improving O
the O
detection O
of O
dynamic O
patterns O
was O
first O
performed O
on O
the O
time O
courses O
of O
brain O
networks O
and O
every O
voxel O
of O
the O
brain O
to O
reduce O
noise O
. O

The O
cleaning O
procedure O
includes O
orthogonalizing O
with O
respect O
to O
estimated O
subject O
motion O
parameters O
, O
linear O
detrending O
, O
despiking O
, O
and O
band-pass O
filtering O
using O
a O
fifth-order O
Butterworth O
filter O
( O
0.01–0.15 O
Hz O
) O
. O

It O
is O
worth O
mentioning O
that O
to O
evaluate O
the O
noise O
effect O
, O
we O
performed O
various O
cleaning O
procedures O
including O
various O
bandpass O
filtering O
methods O
with O
different O
frequency O
bands O
, O
and O
these O
approaches O
resulted O
in O
almost O
identical O
spatial O
states O
. O

Further O
details O
of O
different O
cleaning O
procedures O
can O
be O
found O
in O
our O
recent O
work O
. O

We O
used O
the O
tapered O
window O
obtained O
by O
convolving O
a O
rectangle O
( O
width O
= O
30 O
TRs O
; O
see O
the O
discussion O
for O
our O
reasoning O
for O
the O
specific O
window O
length O
chosen O
) O
with O
a O
Gaussian O
( O
σ O
= O
3 O
TRs O
) O
and O
the O
sliding O
step O
size O
of O
one O
TR O
resulting O
in O
131 O
windows O
per O
subject.The O
spatial O
evolution O
( O
i.e O
. O

continuous O
spatial O
variations O
) O
of O
brain O
networks O
were O
evaluated O
using O
different O
metrics O
including O
spatial O
states O
and O
spatiotemporal O
variation O
analyses O
. O

Calculating O
the O
spatial O
states O
of O
each O
brain O
network O
and O
their O
dynamic O
patterns O
First O
, O
we O
modeled O
the O
spatiotemporal O
fluctuations O
of O
each O
brain O
network O
as O
temporal O
variations O
in O
a O
set O
of O
distinct O
spatial O
patterns O
called O
spatial O
states O
. O

Clustering O
approaches O
can O
be O
used O
to O
summarize O
the O
dCMs O
of O
each O
brain O
network O
into O
a O
set O
of O
spatial O
states O
which O
allows O
us O
to O
investigate O
the O
spatiotemporal O
variations O
of O
the O
brain O
network O
via O
temporal O
variations O
of O
these O
distinct O
spatial O
states O
. O

Here O
, O
k-means O
clustering O
was O
employed O
to O
detect O
the O
spatial O
states O
of O
each O
brain O
network O
. O

For O
each O
brain O
network O
, O
k-means O
clustering O
was O
applied O
on O
the O
40479 O
( O
309 O
subjects O
× O
131 O
windows O
) O
dCMs O
of O
the O
brain O
network O
. O

K-means O
clustering O
was O
repeated O
100 O
times O
with O
different O
initializations O
using O
the O
k-means++ O
technique O
to O
increase O
chances O
of O
escaping O
local O
minima O
. O

The O
correlation O
distance O
metric O
was O
used O
to O
measure O
the O
similarity O
between O
data O
points O
( O
i.e. O
, O
the O
dCMs O
) O
, O
as O
it O
is O
more O
effective O
in O
the O
detection O
of O
spatial O
patterns O
irrespective O
of O
voxel O
intensities O
. O

However O
, O
an O
exploratory O
analysis O
using O
Euclidean O
distance O
demonstrated O
almost O
identical O
results O
. O

K-means O
clustering O
was O
performed O
for O
3 O
to O
10 O
clusters O
, O
and O
the O
spatial O
maps O
of O
the O
cluster O
centroids O
were O
compared O
( O
Supporting O
Information O
File O
S1 O
) O
. O

For O
each O
brain O
network O
, O
the O
maximum O
number O
of O
clusters O
that O
provides O
distinct O
spatial O
maps O
for O
centroids O
were O
selected O
by O
visual O
inspection O
for O
further O
analysis O
. O

Thus O
, O
each O
network O
includes O
multiple O
spatial O
states O
as O
defined O
by O
the O
cluster O
centroids O
, O
and O
the O
number O
of O
spatial O
states O
( O
centroids O
) O
can O
vary O
between O
networks O
. O

We O
also O
compared O
our O
numbers O
of O
clusters O
with O
the O
estimated O
number O
of O
clusters O
using O
the O
elbow O
criterion O
. O

With O
the O
exception O
of O
the O
left O
frontoparietal O
and O
subcortical O
domains O
, O
in O
which O
the O
elbow O
criterion O
estimates O
a O
higher O
number O
of O
clusters O
than O
those O
chosen O
by O
visual O
inspection O
, O
the O
estimated O
cluster O
numbers O
using O
elbow O
criterion O
were O
the O
same O
as O
the O
expert O
selections O
. O

Using O
temporal O
profiles O
of O
the O
spatial O
states O
, O
various O
state O
level O
and O
meta-state O
level O
dynamic O
indices O
can O
be O
calculated O
for O
each O
brain O
network O
. O

For O
example O
, O
the O
mean O
dwell O
time O
( O
the O
average O
of O
