the O
LOC O
and O
EVC O
, O
controls O
showed O
the O
expected O
reduced O
fMRI O
responses O
to O
repeated O
presentation O
of O
the O
same O
objects O
compared O
to O
different O
objects O
( O
i.e. O
, O
fMRI O
adaptation O
for O
objects O
, O
p O
< O
.001 O
) O
. O

SZ O
patients O
showed O
an O
adaptation O
effect O
that O
was O
significantly O
smaller O
compared O
to O
controls O
. O

BD O
patients O
showed O
a O
lack O
of O
fMRI O
adaptation O
. O

The O
whole O
brain O
analyses O
showed O
enhanced O
fMRI O
responses O
to O
repeated O
presentation O
of O
the O
same O
objects O
only O
in O
BD O
patients O
in O
several O
brain O
regions O
including O
anterior O
cingulate O
cortex O
. O

This O
study O
was O
the O
first O
to O
employ O
fMRI O
adaptation O
for O
objects O
in O
SZ O
and O
BD O
. O

The O
current O
findings O
provide O
empirical O
evidence O
of O
aberrant O
fMRI O
adaptation O
in O
the O
visual O
cortex O
in O
SZ O
and O
BD O
, O
but O
in O
distinctly O
different O
ways O
. O

METHOD O
Participants O
Fifty-three O
SZ O
outpatients O
, O
55 O
BD O
outpatients O
and O
53 O
community O
controls O
enrolled O
in O
the O
study O
. O

Patients O
were O
recruited O
from O
local O
board O
and O
care O
facilities O
in O
Los O
Angeles O
, O
outpatient O
clinics O
at O
University O
of O
California O
Los O
Angeles O
( O
UCLA O
) O
and O
the O
Veterans O
Affairs O
Greater O
Los O
Angeles O
Healthcare O
System O
( O
VAGLAHS O
) O
. O

Controls O
were O
recruited O
through O
website O
postings O
. O

All O
participants O
were O
evaluated O
for O
the O
capacity O
to O
give O
informed O
consent O
and O
provided O
written O
informed O
consents O
after O
procedures O
were O
fully O
explained O
, O
as O
approved O
by O
the O
Institutional O
Review O
Boards O
at O
UCLA O
and O
VAGLAHS O
. O

Diagnostic O
eligibility O
for O
all O
participants O
was O
determined O
with O
the O
Structured O
Clinical O
Interview O
for O
DSM-IV O
Axis O
I O
Disorders O
( O
SCID-I O
) O
for O
all O
participants O
and O
the O
Structured O
Clinical O
Interview O
for O
DSM-IV O
Axis O
II O
Disorders O
( O
SCID-II O
) O
for O
controls O
. O

Inclusion O
criteria O
for O
patients O
were O
: O
1 O
) O
a O
diagnosis O
of O
SZ O
or O
BD O
based O
on O
SCID-I O
; O
and O
2 O
) O
clinical O
stability O
( O
i.e. O
, O
no O
inpatient O
hospitalization O
for O
three O
months O
prior O
to O
enrollment O
, O
no O
change O
in O
psychoactive O
medication O
in O
the O
4 O
weeks O
prior O
to O
enrollment O
) O
. O

Inclusion O
criteria O
for O
controls O
were O
: O
1 O
) O
no O
history O
of O
psychotic O
disorder O
, O
bipolar O
spectrum O
disorder O
or O
other O
major O
mood O
disorder O
based O
on O
SCID-I O
; O
2 O
) O
no O
diagnosis O
of O
avoidant O
, O
paranoid O
, O
schizotypal O
, O
schizoid O
, O
or O
borderline O
personality O
disorders O
based O
on O
SCID-II O
; O
and O
3 O
) O
no O
first-degree O
relative O
with O
a O
psychotic O
disorder O
or O
BD O
based O
on O
self-report O
. O

We O
did O
not O
exclude O
controls O
for O
other O
Axis-I O
disorders O
, O
including O
obsessive-compulsive O
disorder O
or O
post-traumatic O
stress O
disorder O
. O

Additional O
inclusion O
criteria O
for O
all O
participants O
were O
: O
1 O
) O
age O
18–65 O
years O
; O
2 O
) O
sufficient O
fluency O
in O
English O
to O
understand O
study O
procedures O
; O
3 O
) O
no O
evidence O
of O
IQ O
< O
70 O
or O
development O
disability O
based O
on O
medical O
record O
and/or O
the O
Wide O
Range O
Achievement O
Test O
, O
Reading-Recognition O
subtest O
; O
4 O
) O
no O
substance O
or O
alcohol O
dependence O
in O
the O
past O
three O
months O
and O
no O
evidence O
of O
substance O
or O
alcohol O
abuse O
in O
the O
past O
month O
; O
5 O
) O
no O
clinically O
significant O
neurological O
disorder O
that O
could O
affect O
cognitive O
function O
( O
e.g. O
, O
epilepsy O
) O
; O
6 O
) O
no O
loss O
of O
consciousness O
greater O
than O
one O
hour O
, O
neuropsychological O
sequelae O
or O
cognitive O
rehabilitation O
post O
head O
injury O
; O
7 O
) O
normal O
or O
corrected O
to O
normal O
vision O
; O
8 O
) O
no O
history O
of O
mood O
episode O
in O
the O
past O
two O
months O
; O
9 O
) O
no O
known O
contraindications O
for O
MRI O
scanning O
; O
and O
10 O
) O
no O
sedatives O
or O
benzodiazepines O
within O
12 O
hours O
of O
testing O
and O
no O
positive O
urine O
toxicology O
screening O
on O
the O
day O
of O
assessment O
. O

Clinical O
characteristics O
for O
patients O
were O
assessed O
with O
the O
Expanded O
24-item O
version O
of O
the O
Brief O
Psychiatric O
Rating O
Scale O
( O
BPRS O
) O
, O
the O
Clinical O
Assessment O
Interview O
for O
Negative O
Symptoms O
, O
Young O
Mania O
Rating O
Scale O
( O
YMRS O
) O
, O
and O
Hamilton O
Depression O
Rating O
Scale O
( O
HAMD O
) O
. O

Cognitive O
function O
was O
assessed O
using O
MATRICS O
Consensus O
Cognitive O
Battery O
. O

All O
interviewers O
were O
trained O
through O
the O
Treatment O
Unit O
of O
the O
Department O
of O
VA O
VISN O
22 O
Mental O
Illness O
Research O
, O
Education O
, O
and O
Clinical O
Center O
. O

SCID O
interviewers O
were O
trained O
to O
a O
minimum O
kappa O
of O
0.75 O
for O
key O
psychotic O
and O
mood O
items O
, O
and O
symptom O
raters O
were O
trained O
to O
a O
minimum O
intraclass O
correlation O
of O
0.80 O
. O

Procedures O
All O
participants O
completed O
the O
object O
discrimination O
task O
, O
along O
with O
two O
localizer O
tasks O
( O
EVC O
and O
LOC O
) O
, O
in O
the O
MRI O
scanner O
. O

The O
object O
discrimination O
task O
consisted O
of O
three O
conditions O
, O
each O
trial O
of O
which O
presented O
a O
pair O
of O
objects O
in O
sequence O
: O
1 O
) O
two O
of O
the O
same O
object O
( O
SS O
) O
, O
2 O
) O
different O
exemplars O
from O
the O
same O
category O
( O
SD O
) O
; O
and O
3 O
) O
different O
exemplars O
from O
different O
categories O
( O
DD O
) O
. O

Stimuli O
subtended O
approximately O
6 O
degrees O
of O
visual O
angle O
and O
comprised O
two O
exemplars O
from O
five O
categories O
of O
common O
household O
objects O
( O
i.e. O
, O
chair O
, O
couch O
, O
desk O
, O
glass O
, O
table O
) O
. O

In O
a O
rapid O
event-related O
design O
, O
each O
trial O
started O
with O
two O
100 O
ms O
flashes O
of O
a O
fixation O
cross O
. O

Then O
, O
a O
pair O
of O
objects O
was O
shown O
for O
400 O
ms O
each O
, O
separated O
by O
a O
200-ms O
interstimulus O
interval O
( O
Figure O
1 O
) O
. O

The O
two O
objects O
were O
presented O
in O
slightly O
different O
locations O
( O
jittered O
by O
approximately O
1 O
degree O
of O
visual O
angle O
) O
. O

Participants O
were O
asked O
to O
decide O
whether O
the O
second O
object O
was O
the O
same O
as O
the O
first O
. O

They O
had O
2100 O
ms O
to O
make O
a O
response O
, O
and O
a O
complete O
trial O
lasted O
3.5 O
seconds O
. O

The O
task O
had O
3 O
runs O
, O
each O
with O
24 O
trials O
per O
condition O
and O
24 O
null O
trials O
that O
included O
fixation O
but O
no O
stimuli O
. O

Within O
each O
run O
, O
the O
order O
of O
trials O
was O
randomized O
using O
maximum-length O
shift O
register O
sequences O
or O
m-sequence O
. O

Full O
descriptions O
of O
the O
two O
localizer O
tasks O
are O
provided O
elsewhere O
. O

For O
the O
EVC O
, O
participants O
viewed O
slowly O
rotating O
wedges O
of O
a O
contrast-reversing O
checkerboard O
. O

For O
the O
LOC O
localizer O
, O
participants O
viewed O
alternating O
blocked O
presentations O
of O
pictures O
of O
abstract O
sculptures O
and O
scrambled O
sculptures O
. O

fMRI O
data O
acquisition O
All O
MR O
data O
were O
collected O
at O
the O
UCLA O
Staglin O
Center O
for O
Cognitive O
Neuroscience O
on O
a O
3T O
Siemens O
Tim O
Trio O
scanner O
with O
a O
12-channel O
head O
coil O
( O
Siemens O
Medical O
Solutions O
, O
Erlangen O
, O
Germany O
) O
using O
MR-compatible O
LCD O
goggles O
( O
Resonance O
Technology O
, O
Northridge O
, O
CA O
) O
( O
see O
Supplement O
for O
details O
) O
. O

All O
tasks O
were O
presented O
using O
E-prime O
software O
and O
behavioral O
performance O
was O
recorded O
using O
an O
MR-compatible O
4-button O
response O
box O
( O
Resonance O
Technology O
, O
Northridge O
, O
CA O
) O
. O

fMRI O
data O
analysis O
fMRI O
data O
were O
analyzed O
using O
the O
FMRIB O
Software O
Library O
( O
FSL O
version O
5.0.9 O
, O
) O
. O

To O
examine O
neural O
adaptation O
for O
object O
, O
we O
conducted O
fMRI O
analyses O
in O
two O
complementary O
ways O
: O
an O
ROI-based O
analysis O
and O
an O
exploratory O
whole O
brain O
analysis O
. O

Additional O
details O
are O
provided O
in O
the O
Supplement O
. O

In O
the O
ROI O
analysis O
, O
we O
first O
identified O
EVC O
and O
LOC O
in O
each O
participant O
using O
the O
functional O
localizer O
tasks O
. O

The O
EVC O
was O
defined O
as O
a O
set O
of O
contiguously O
activated O
voxels O
p O
< O
0.001 O
, O
uncorrected O
; O
≥ O
10 O
voxels O
) O
on O
the O
medial O
surface O
of O
the O
occipital O
lobe O
that O
was O
temporally O
correlated O
with O
a O
sinusoid O
at O
the O
stimulus O
frequency O
. O

The O
EVC O
primarily O
includes O
, O
but O
is O
not O
limited O
to O
, O
V1 O
. O

LOC O
was O
identified O
as O
a O
cluster O
of O
contiguously O
activated O
voxels O
( O
object O
> O
scrambled O
) O
within O
the O
lateral O
occipital O
cortex O
bilaterally O
( O
p O
< O
0.001 O
, O
uncorrected O
; O
≥ O
10 O
voxels O
) O
. O

Three O
groups O
did O
not O
differ O
in O
terms O
of O
the O
size O
of O
LOC O
( O
voxels O
, O
SZ=500 O
± O
764 O
, O
BD=442±568 O
, O
CO=560±664 O
; O
F2,156=.42 O
, O
NS O
) O
or O
EVC O
( O
voxels O
, O
SZ=3223±1691 O
, O
BD=3790±1608 O
, O
CO=3554±1432 O
; O
F2,156=1.79 O
, O
NS O
) O
. O

See O
the O
Supplement O
for O
representative O
images O
of O
LOC O
and O
EVC O
. O

After O
identifying O
each O
ROI O
for O
each O
participant O
, O
we O
extracted O
response-amplitudes O
for O
each O
ROI O
during O
the O
object O
discrimination O
task O
. O

Specifically O
, O
we O
modeled O
hemodynamic O
response O
functions O
( O
HRFs O
) O
for O
each O
condition O
using O
7 O
finite O
impulse O
responses O
( O
FIR O
) O
, O
one O
for O
each O
peristimulus O
time-point O
( O
total O
window O
= O
17.5 O
s O
) O
. O

The O
FIR O
model O
is O
well O
suited O
to O
average O
each O
trial O
type O
in O
this O
study O
because O
it O
provides O
unbiased O
and O
statistically O
efficient O
estimates O
of O
hemodynamic O
responses O
associated O
with O
task O
conditions O
in O
a O
rapid O
event-related O
design O
with O
few O
assumptions O
about O
the O
exact O
shape O
of O
the O
HRF O
. O

Next O
, O
response O
amplitudes O
were O
calculated O
by O
averaging O
event-related O
responses O
across O
trials O
, O
separately O
for O
each O
condition O
, O
within O
each O
ROI O
. O

To O
identify O
the O
peak O
activation O
, O
mean O
amplitudes O
of O
three O
peristimulus O
time-points O
( O
2.5 O
, O
5 O
, O
and O
7.5 O
s O
post-stimulus O
) O
were O
averaged O
for O
each O
condition O
in O
each O
ROI O
and O
utilized O
for O
further O
analyses O
. O

Machine O
learning O
identifies O
unaffected O
first-degree O
relatives O
with O
functional O
network O
patterns O
and O
cognitive O
impairment O
similar O
to O
those O
of O
schizophrenia O
patients O
Schizophrenia O
( O
SCZ O
) O
patients O
and O
their O
unaffected O
first-degree O
relatives O
( O
FDRs O
) O
share O
similar O
functional O
neuroanatomy O
. O

However O
, O
it O
remains O
largely O
unknown O
to O
what O
extent O
unaffected O
FDRs O
with O
functional O
neuroanatomy O
patterns O
similar O
to O
patients O
can O
be O
identified O
at O
an O
individual O
level O
. O

In O
this O
study O
, O
we O
used O
a O
multivariate O
pattern O
classification O
method O
to O
learn O
informative O
large-scale O
functional O
networks O
( O
FNs O
) O
and O
build O
classifiers O
to O
distinguish O
32 O
patients O
from O
30 O
healthy O
controls O
and O
to O
classify O
34 O
FDRs O
as O
with O
or O
without O
FNs O
similar O
to O
patients O
. O

Four O
informative O
FNs O
were O
identified O
based O
on O
a O
training O
cohort O
– O
the O
cerebellum O
, O
default O
mode O
network O
( O
DMN O
) O
, O
ventral O
fronto-temporal O
network O
, O
and O
posterior O
DMN O
with O
parahippocampal O
gyrus O
– O
and O
pattern O
classifiers O
built O
upon O
these O
FNs O
achieved O
a O
correct O
classification O
rate O
of O
83.9 O
% O
( O
sensitivity O
87.5 O
% O
, O
specificity O
80.0 O
% O
, O
and O
area O
under O
the O
ROC O
[ O
AUC O
] O
0.914 O
) O
estimated O
based O
on O
leave-one-out O
cross-validation O
for O
the O
training O
cohort O
and O
a O
correct O
classification O
rate O
of O
77.5 O
% O
( O
sensitivity O
72.5 O
% O
, O
specificity O
82.5 O
% O
, O
and O
AUC O
0.811 O
) O
for O
an O
independent O
validation O
cohort O
. O

The O
classification O
scores O
of O
the O
FDRs O
and O
patients O
were O
negatively O
correlated O
with O
their O
measures O
of O
cognitive O
function O
. O

FDRs O
identified O
by O
the O
classifiers O
as O
having O
SCZ O
patterns O
were O
similar O
to O
the O
patients O
, O
but O
significantly O
different O
from O
the O
controls O
and O
FDRs O
with O
normal O
patterns O
in O
terms O
of O
their O
cognitive O
measures O
. O

These O
results O
demonstrate O
that O
the O
pattern O
classifiers O
built O
upon O
the O
informative O
FNs O
can O
serve O
as O
biomarkers O
for O
quantifying O
brain O
alterations O
in O
schizophrenia O
and O
help O
to O
identify O
FDRs O
with O
FN O
patterns O
and O
cognitive O
impairment O
similar O
to O
those O
of O
SCZ O
patients O
. O

Methods O
and O
Materials O
Participants O
The O
study O
included O
60 O
SCZ O
patients O
, O
43 O
unaffected O
FDRs O
of O
patients O
( O
18 O
siblings O
, O
15 O
sons/daughters O
, O
and O
10 O
parents O
) O
, O
and O
50 O
healthy O
controls O
. O

Of O
the O
43 O
unaffected O
FDRs O
, O
10 O
were O
relatives O
of O
the O
patients O
recruited O
in O
this O
study O
. O

An O
independent O
dataset O
of O
40 O
patients O
and O
40 O
controls O
was O
used O
as O
a O
validation O
cohort O
to O
evaluate O
the O
performance O
of O
classifiers O
developed O
in O
our O
study O
( O
see O
Supplementary O
material O
for O
details O
) O
. O

All O
participants O
provided O
written O
informed O
consent O
and O
the O
protocol O
was O
approved O
by O
the O
Ethics O
Committee O
of O
Beijing O
Hui-Long-Guan O
Hospital O
, O
Beijing O
, O
China O
. O

Participants O
were O
interviewed O
with O
the O
Structured O
Clinical O
Interview O
of O
the O
Diagnostic O
and O
Statistical O
Manual O
of O
Mental O
Disorders O
, O
4th O
edition O
, O
text O
revision O
( O
DSM-IV-TR O
) O
axis O
I O
disorders O
( O
SCID-I O
, O
Chinese O
version O
) O
. O

Based O
on O
interviews O
and O
reviews O
of O
clinical O
history O
, O
patients O
who O
met O
the O
DSM-IV-TR O
criteria O
for O
SCZ O
were O
included O
. O

FDRs O
were O
excluded O
for O
Axis O
I O
psychopathology O
and O
all O
FDRs O
included O
in O
this O
study O
did O
not O
have O
personal O
history O
of O
Axis O
I O
disorders O
according O
to O
SCID-I O
. O

The O
controls O
did O
not O
have O
family O
history O
of O
SCZ O
, O
personal O
psychiatric O
, O
or O
neurological O
disorder O
. O

The O
following O
exclusion O
criteria O
were O
applied O
to O
all O
groups O
: O
( O
a O
) O
< O
18 O
or O
> O
45 O
years O
of O
age O
; O
( O
b O
) O
left-handedness O
; O
( O
c O
) O
history O
of O
brain O
trauma O
with O
loss O
of O
consciousness O
, O
neurological O
diseases O
, O
or O
serious O
physical O
diseases O
( O
such O
as O
respiratory O
disorders O
and O
cardiovascular O
disease O
) O
; O
( O
d O
) O
diagnosis O
of O
alcohol/substance O
abuse O
within O
12 O
months O
before O
participation O
; O
and O
( O
e O
) O
contraindications O
for O
MRI O
scan O
. O

SCZ O
patients O
were O
also O
evaluated O
with O
the O
Positive O
and O
Negative O
Syndrome O
Scale O
for O
symptom O
severity O
. O

In O
addition O
, O
cognitive O
function O
was O
assessed O
using O
the O
digit-span O
and O
digit-symbol O
coding O
tests O
of O
the O
Wechsler O
Adult O
Intelligence O
Scale O
in O
all O
participants O
. O

More O
information O
on O
the O
medication O
histories O
of O
the O
patients O
can O
be O
found O
in O
the O
supplemental O
material O
. O

Data O
acquisition O
and O
preprocessing O
MR O
images O
were O
collected O
using O
a O
Siemens O
Magnetom O
Trio O
3.0 O
Tesla O
imaging O
system O
with O
a O
standard O
head O
coil O
at O
Peking O
University O
Third O
Hospital O
. O

For O
image O
registration O
, O
high-resolution O
structural O
T1 O
MRI O
data O
were O
acquired O
( O
256×256×192 O
matrix O
; O
slice O
thickness O
1 O
mm O
; O
voxel O
resolution O
1×1×1 O
mm3 O
; O
flip O
angle O
7° O
; O
repetition O
time O
[ O
TR O
] O
2530 O
ms O
; O
echo O
time O
[ O
TE O
] O
3.44 O
ms O
; O
inversion O
time O
1100 O
ms O
) O
. O

RsfMRI O
scans O
were O
obtained O
using O
a O
gradient-recalled O
echo-planar O
imaging O
sequence O
( O
field O
of O
view O
220 O
mm O
, O
64×64×64 O
matrix O
; O
TR O
2000 O
ms O
; O
TE O
30 O
ms O
; O
flip O
angle O
90° O
; O
slice O
thickness O
4 O
mm O
; O
voxel O
resolution O
3.4×3.4×4.0 O
mm³ O
) O
. O

Each O
rsfMRI O
scan O
had O
240 O
volumes O
of O
33 O
axial O
slices O
. O

During O
acquisition O
, O
participants O
were O
instructed O
to O
close O
their O
eyes O
, O
relax O
, O
and O
remain O
awake O
. O

All O
images O
were O
visually O
checked O
for O
artefacts O
, O
structural O
abnormalities O
, O
and O
pathologies O
by O
neuroradiologists O
. O

Frame-wise O
displacement O
( O
FD O
) O
was O
calculated O
to O
measure O
volume-to-volume O
changes O
in O
head O
position O
. O

Thirty-seven O
participants O
were O
excluded O
because O
of O
large O
head-movements O
( O
mean O
FD O
> O
0.5 O
mm O
) O
. O

The O
final O
sample O
comprised O
40 O
controls O
, O
34 O
FDRs O
, O
and O
42 O
SCZ O
patients O
. O

The O
preprocessing O
steps O
are O
outlined O
in O
the O
supplemental O
material O
. O

Identification O
of O
informative O
functional O
networks O
in O
schizophrenia O
Independent O
component O
analysis O
guided O
by O
group O
information O
( O
GIG-ICA O
) O
was O
adopted O
to O
extract O
subject-specific O
FNs O
from O
the O
rsfMRI O
data O
of O
patients O
, O
unaffected O
FDRs O
, O
and O
controls O
. O

The O
number O
of O
independent O
components O
( O
ICs O
) O
was O
estimated O
automatically O
to O
be O
15 O
, O
based O
on O
10 O
randomly O
selected O
controls O
and O
10 O
randomly O
selected O
SCZ O
patients O
for O
computing O
group-level O
ICs O
using O
FSL O
Melodic O
with O
its O
default O
setting O
of O
Laplace O
approximation O
to O
the O
evidence O
of O
the O
model O
order O
. O

The O
resulting O
group-level O
ICs O
were O
then O
used O
as O
guidance O
information O
to O
compute O
the O
ICs O
of O
the O
remaining O
participants O
using O
GIG-ICA O
, O
finally O
each O
subject O
was O
characterized O
with O
15 O
FNs O
( O
supplemental O
Figure O
S1 O
) O
. O

Particularly O
, O
we O
used O
a O
gray O
matter O
mask O
in O
ICA O
in O
order O
to O
minimize O
the O
partial O
volume O
effects O
of O
cerebrospinal O
fluid O
and O
spurious O
effects O
on O
connectivity O
measures O
, O
as O
well O
as O
to O
increase O
the O
sensitivity O
to O
BOLD O
signal O
changes O
. O

A O
pattern O
classification O
method O
was O
used O
to O
identify O
informative O
FNs O
and O
build O
SVM O
classifiers O
to O
distinguish O
32 O
patients O
from O
30 O
controls O
who O
were O
not O
included O
in O
the O
computation O
of O
group-level O
ICs O
. O

Particularly O
, O
we O
built O
classifiers O
on O
a O
subset O
of O
FNs O
that O
were O
selected O
to O
optimize O
the O
classification O
performance O
for O
distinguishing O
SCZs O
from O
HCs O
using O
an O
SVM O
classification O
algorithm O
. O

The O
SVM O
classification O
was O
based O
on O
similarity O
measures O
between O
subjects O
computed O
based O
on O
their O
FNs O
. O

A O
forward O
component O
selection O
technique O
was O
adopted O
to O
identify O
the O
most O
discriminative O
set O
of O
FNs O
using O
following O
procedure O
. O

Classifiers O
were O
first O
built O
on O
individual O
FNs O
, O
one O
for O
each O
FN O
, O
then O
the O
classifiers O
were O
evaluated O
with O
a O
leave-one-out O
( O
LOO O
) O
cross-validation O
, O
and O
finally O
the O
FN O
with O
the O
best O
classification O
performance O
was O
selected O
to O
be O
included O
in O
the O
classification O
. O

By O
combining O
the O
first O
selected O
FN O
and O
one O
of O
the O
other O
FNs O
, O
a O
classifier O
could O
be O
built O
upon O
two O
FNs O
. O

All O
classifiers O
built O
on O
two O
FNs O
were O
then O
evaluated O
using O
the O
same O
LOO O
cross‐validation O
, O
and O
the O
FNs O
with O
the O
best O
classification O
performance O
were O
selected O
to O
be O
included O
in O
the O
classification O
. O

This O
procedure O
was O
repeated O
to O
include O
more O
FNs O
in O
the O
classification O
one O
by O
one O
until O
one O
single O
classifier O
was O
built O
upon O
all O
available O
FNs O
. O

Finally O
, O
the O
combination O
of O
FNs O
with O
the O
overall O
best O
classification O
performance O
was O
identified O
to O
be O
included O
in O
the O
final O
classification O
. O

The O
FN O
selection O
and O
the O
classifier O
construction O
were O
carried O
out O
based O
on O
the O
training O
data O
. O

In O
the O
LOO O
cross-validation O
setting O
, O
each O
participant O
was O
analyzed O
as O
testing O
data O
once O
to O
evaluate O
a O
sigmoid O
kernel O
SVM O
classifier O
that O
was O
built O
upon O
the O
data O
of O
all O
other O
subjects O
. O

To O
avoid O
bias O
of O
the O
classification O
, O
we O
applied O
a O
nested O
LOO O
procedure O
to O
optimize O
the O
parameters O
of O
the O
SVM O
classifier O
by O
tuning O
them O
and O
choosing O
an O
optimal O
combination O
of O
FNs O
with O
a O
forward O
component O
selection O
algorithm O
( O
details O
in O
supplemental O
material O
) O
. O

FNs O
with O
high O
frequency O
( O
frequency O
> O
0.8 O
) O
were O
defined O
as O
informative O
FNs O
. O

Based O
on O
the O
informative O
FNs O
of O
62 O
subjects O
, O
the O
LOO O
cross-validation O
model O
yielded O
62 O
SVM O
classifiers O
. O

Each O
of O
the O
SVM O
classifiers O
generated O
a O
classification O
score O
which O
was O
a O
median O
value O
of O
classification O
scores O
of O
its O
nested O
LOO O
classifiers O
, O
with O
a O
positive O
value O
to O
indicate O
SCZ O
or O
a O
negative O
value O
to O
indicate O
normal O
. O

In O
addition O
to O
classification O
accuracy O
, O
sensitivity O
, O
and O
specificity O
, O
the O
receiver O
operating O
characteristic O
curve O
( O
ROC O
) O
and O
the O
area O
under O
the O
ROC O
( O
AUC O
) O
were O
also O
calculated O
to O
evaluate O
the O
classification O
performance O
. O

Nonparametric O
permutation O
tests O
were O
used O
to O
estimate O
the O
statistical O
significance O
of O
the O
classification O
performance O
. O

The O
null O
distribution O
of O
the O
classification O
rate O
was O
estimated O
for O
all O
subject-specific O
SVM O
models O
using O
10-fold O
cross-validation O
by O
performing O
10000 O
random O
permutation O
tests O
with O
subject O
class O
labels O
randomly O
permuted O
. O

Finally O
, O
the O
null O
distribution O
of O
the O
classification O
error O
was O
visualized O
as O
a O
histogram O
of O
classification O
rates O
. O

The O
informative O
FNs O
were O
further O
validated O
in O
terms O
of O
their O
classification O
performance O
using O
an O
independent O
dataset O
( O
see O
supplemental O
material O
for O
details O
) O
. O

The O
LOO O
cross-validation O
classifiers O
were O
applied O
to O
the O
FNs O
of O
FDRs O
, O
so O
each O
FDR O
was O
given O
62 O
individual O
classification O
scores O
. O

The O
median O
of O
the O
individual O
classification O
scores O
was O
finally O
used O
as O
a O
robust O
measure O
to O
characterize O
the O
affinity O
of O
each O
FDR O
to O
SCZ O
( O
a O
positive O
score O
indicates O
a O
SCZ O
pattern O
) O
. O

A O
flowchart O
of O
the O
pattern O
classification O
algorithm O
is O
shown O
in O
supplemental O
Figure O
S3 O
. O

Based O
on O
the O
classification O
scores O
, O
the O
FDRs O
were O
classified O
as O
SCZ-specific O
( O
S-FDRs O
) O
or O
HC-specific O
( O
H-FDRs O
) O
. O

We O
also O
adopted O
a O
certainty O
measure O
to O
evaluate O
the O
classification O
reliability O
for O
each O
individual O
subject O
based O
on O
the O
LOO O
cross-validation O
classifiers O
. O

Particularly O
, O
the O
classification O
certainty O
was O
measured O
by O
, O
where O
np O
is O
the O
number O
of O
positive O
classification O
scores O
and O
n O
is O
the O
total O
number O
of O
LOO O
classifiers O
. O

A O
higher O
value O
indicated O
a O
higher O
classification O
reliability O
, O
and O
vice O
versa O
. O

We O
excluded O
subjects O
with O
lower O
classification O
certainty O
( O
< O
0.9 O
) O
in O
post-hoc O
analyses O
. O

Finally O
, O
the O
sample O
comprised O
27 O
controls O
, O
33 O
FDRs O
, O
and O
28 O
SCZs O
in O
the O
post-hoc O
analysis O
. O

Voxelwise O
functional O
connectivity O
( O
FC O
) O
measures O
of O
each O
informative O
FN O
were O
computed O
as O
Pearson O
correlation O
coefficients O
between O
time O
courses O
of O
the O
whole-brain O
voxels O
and O
the O
FN O
, O
and O
transferred O
to O
z-scores O
for O
every O
participant O
. O

Then O
, O
the O
voxelwise O
FC O
measures O
were O
compared O
between O
any O
two O
groups O
using O
statistical O
nonparametric O
mapping O
software O
( O
SnPM13 O
, O
http O
: O
//warwick.ac.uk/snpm O
; O
p O
= O
0.05 O
, O
permutation O
tests O
n O
= O
10000 O
, O
age O
, O
sex O
, O
years O
of O
education O
, O
and O
FD O
as O
covariates O
) O
. O

The O
comparisons O
were O
restricted O
to O
brain O
regions O
with O
significant O
FC O
within O
the O
FN O
( O
one O
sample O
t-test O
, O
p O
= O
0.05 O
, O
family-wise O
error O
correction O
, O
and O
cluster O
size O
> O
100 O
) O
. O

Similarity O
measures O
of O
informative O
FNs O
between O
individuals O
were O
computed O
based O
on O
principal O
angles O
for O
visualizing O
the O
similarity O
among O
FDRs O
, O
SCZs O
, O
and O
HCs O
. O

Statistical O
comparisons O
of O
clinical O
characteristics O
between O
groups O
To O
identify O
functional O
patterns O
for O
clinical O
characteristics O
analysis O
, O
FDRs O
were O
divided O
into O
two O
subgroups O
: O
those O
with O
SCZ-specific O
classification O
scores O
> O
0 O
, O
and O
those O
with O
HC-specific O
classification O
scores O
≤0 O
( O
positive O
scores O
reflect O
the O
presence O
of O
an O
SZC-specific O
functional O
pattern O
, O
and O
negative O
scores O
indicate O
a O
control-specific O
pattern O
) O
. O

The O
pseudo O
two-sample O
t-test O
at O
5 O
% O
significance O
level O
( O
permutation O
tests O
, O
n O
= O
10000 O
) O
was O
used O
to O
quantify O
the O
statistical O
significance O
of O
group O
differences O
. O

Correlation O
analysis O
between O
cognitive O
function O
and O
classification O
scores O
A O
general O
linear O
model O
with O
outliers O
removed O
at O
95 O
% O
confidence O
intervals O
was O
used O
to O
investigate O
correlations O
between O
the O
classification O
scores O
and O
measures O
of O
cognitive O
function O
in O
groups O
, O
with O
age O
, O
sex O
, O
years O
of O
education O
, O
and O
FD O
as O
covariates O
. O

Increased O
thalamocortical O
connectivity O
in O
schizophrenia O
correlates O
with O
sleep O
spindle O
deficits O
: O
evidence O
for O
a O
common O
pathophysiology O
Background O
: O
Converging O
evidence O
implicates O
abnormal O
thalamocortical O
interactions O
in O
the O
pathophysiology O
of O
schizophrenia O
. O

This O
evidence O
includes O
consistent O
findings O
of O
increased O
resting-state O
functional O
connectivity O
MRI O
of O
the O
thalamus O
with O
somatosensory O
and O
motor O
cortex O
during O
wake O
and O
reduced O
spindle O
activity O
during O
sleep O
. O

We O
hypothesized O
that O
these O
abnormalities O
would O
be O
correlated O
, O
reflecting O
a O
common O
mechanism O
: O
reduced O
inhibition O
of O
thalamocortical O
neurons O
by O
the O
thalamic O
reticular O
nucleus O
( O
TRN O
) O
, O
which O
is O
the O
major O
inhibitory O
nucleus O
of O
the O
thalamus O
and O
is O
abnormal O
in O
schizophrenia O
. O

Reduced O
TRN O
inhibition O
would O
be O
expected O
to O
lead O
to O
increased O
and O
less O
filtered O
thalamic O
relay O
of O
sensory O
and O
motor O
information O
to O
the O
cortex O
during O
wake O
and O
reduced O
burst O
firing O
necessary O
for O
spindle O
initiation O
during O
sleep O
. O

Methods O
: O
Twenty-six O
schizophrenia O
outpatients O
and O
30 O
demographically O
matched O
healthy O
individuals O
had O
overnight O
polysomnography O
and O
resting-state O
functional O
connectivity O
MRI O
scans O
. O

We O
examined O
the O
relations O
of O
sleep O
spindle O
density O
during O
stage O
2 O
non-rapid O
eye O
movement O
sleep O
with O
connectivity O
of O
the O
thalamus O
with O
the O
cortex O
during O
wakeful O
rest O
. O

Results O
: O
As O
in O
prior O
studies O
, O
schizophrenia O
patients O
exhibited O
increased O
functional O
connectivity O
of O
the O
thalamus O
with O
bilateral O
somatosensory O
and O
motor O
cortex O
, O
and O
reduced O
sleep O
spindle O
density O
. O

Spindle O
density O
inversely O
correlated O
with O
thalamocortical O
connectivity O
, O
including O
in O
somotosensory O
and O
motor O
cortex O
, O
regardless O
of O
diagnosis O
. O

Conclusions O
: O
These O
findings O
link O
two O
biomarkers O
of O
schizophrenia O
– O
the O
sleep O
spindle O
density O
deficit O
and O
abnormally O
increased O
thalamocortical O
functional O
connectivity O
– O
and O
point O
to O
deficient O
TRN O
inhibition O
as O
a O
plausible O
mechanism O
. O

If O
TRN-mediated O
thalamocortical O
dysfunction O
increases O
risk O
for O
schizophrenia O
and O
contributes O
to O
its O
manifestations O
, O
understanding O
its O
mechanism O
could O
guide O
the O
development O
of O
targeted O
interventions O
. O

Methods O
Participants O
Twenty-six O
schizophrenia O
outpatients O
, O
recruited O
from O
an O
urban O
mental O
health O
center O
, O
and O
30 O
healthy O
individuals O
, O
recruited O
from O
the O
community O
through O
poster O
and O
website O
advertisements O
, O
participated O
. O

After O
exclusion O
for O
excessive O
motion O
during O
scanning O
( O
see O
description O
below O
) O
, O
22 O
patients O
and O
29 O
controls O
were O
retained O
for O
group O
comparisons O
of O
functional O
connectivity O
. O

Group O
comparison O
of O
sleep O
spindle O
density O
was O
based O
on O
26 O
patients O
and O
29 O
controls O
after O
one O
control O
was O
excluded O
due O
to O
technical O
problems O
with O
the O
sleep O
recording O
. O

Correlations O
of O
connectivity O
and O
spindle O
density O
included O
22 O
patients O
and O
28 O
controls O
. O

Patient O
and O
control O
groups O
did O
not O
differ O
in O
age O
, O
sex O
, O
handedness O
, O
mean O
parental O
education O
or O
estimated O
premorbid O
verbal O
IQ O
( O
Table O
1 O
) O
. O

Two O
patients O
were O
unmedicated O
and O
the O
rest O
had O
been O
maintained O
on O
stable O
doses O
of O
antipsychotic O
and O
adjunctive O
medications O
for O
at O
least O
six O
weeks O
prior O
to O
enrollment O
( O
Supplemental O
Table O
1 O
) O
. O

Diagnoses O
were O
confirmed O
with O
Structured O
Clinical O
Interviews O
for O
DSM-IV O
and O
symptoms O
were O
rated O
with O
the O
Positive O
and O
Negative O
Syndrome O
Scale O
( O
PANSS O
, O
) O
. O

Healthy O
participants O
were O
screened O
to O
exclude O
individuals O
with O
a O
personal O
history O
of O
mental O
illness O
( O
SCID-Non-patient O
edition O
, O
) O
or O
a O
family O
history O
of O
either O
schizophrenia O
spectrum O
disorder O
or O
psychosis O
. O

All O
participants O
were O
screened O
to O
exclude O
those O
with O
a O
diagnosed O
sleep O
disorder O
, O
treatment O
with O
sleep O
medications O
, O
a O
history O
of O
significant O
head O
injury O
or O
neurological O
disorder O
, O
a O
history O
of O
substance O
abuse O
or O
dependence O
within O
the O
past O
six O
months O
( O
based O
on O
interview O
, O
chart O
review O
, O
clinician O
report O
and O
urine O
toxicological O
screening O
) O
and O
contraindications O
for O
MRI O
( O
e.g. O
, O
metal O
in O
the O
body O
, O
pregnancy O
) O
. O

All O
participants O
gave O
written O
informed O
consent O
. O

The O
study O
was O
approved O
by O
the O
Partners O
Human O
Research O
Committee O
. O

Procedures O
Overview O
: O
Participants O
had O
four O
nights O
of O
polysomnography O
( O
PSG O
) O
in O
the O
Massachusetts O
General O
Hospital O
Clinical O
Research O
Center O
as O
part O
of O
a O
double-blind O
, O
randomized O
, O
placebo O
controlled O
clinical O
trial O
that O
involved O
adding O
3 O
mg O
of O
eszopiclone O
to O
ongoing O
medications O
for O
the O
two O
treatment O
nights O
. O

Placebo O
and O
treatment O
visits O
were O
separated O
by O
one O
week O
and O
took O
place O
on O
two O
consecutive O
weeknights O
, O
with O
the O
first O
night O
of O
each O
visit O
serving O
as O
the O
baseline O
night O
and O
the O
second O
the O
learning O
night O
. O

For O
the O
present O
study O
, O
we O
measured O
spindle O
activity O
during O
N2 O
on O
the O
baseline O
night O
of O
the O
placebo O
visit O
. O

MRI O
scans O
were O
acquired O
approximately O
one O
week O
after O
completion O
of O
the O
sleep O
visits O
. O

Spindle O
measurement O
and O
analysis O
: O
PSG O
was O
acquired O
at O
400Hz O
using O
an O
Aura O
LTM64 O
acquisition O
system O
( O
Grass O
Technologies O
, O
Astro-Med O
Inc. O
, O
RI O
) O
and O
Easycap O
EEG O
( O
electroencephalography O
) O
caps O
( O
Easycap O
GmbH O
, O
Herrsching O
, O
Germany O
) O
with O
58 O
EEG O
, O
two O
submental O
EMG O
( O
electromyography O
) O
, O
and O
two O
EOG O
( O
electrooculography O
) O
channels O
. O

Each O
30s O
epoch O
of O
PSG O
was O
visually O
classified O
into O
stages O
( O
Wake O
, O
N1 O
, O
N2 O
, O
N3 O
, O
REM O
) O
according O
to O
standard O
criteria O
by O
raters O
blind O
to O
visit O
, O
group O
and O
night O
. O

N2 O
EEG O
data O
were O
preprocessed O
and O
analyzed O
using O
BrainVision O
Analyzer O
2.0 O
( O
BrainProducts O
, O
Germany O
) O
and O
MATLAB O
R2014a O
( O
MathWorks O
, O
MA O
) O
, O
filtered O
at O
0.3-35Hz O
and O
notch O
filtered O
at O
60Hz O
. O

Channels O
displaying O
significant O
artifacts O
for O
more O
than O
30 O
minutes O
of O
the O
recording O
were O
interpolated O
with O
spherical O
splines O
. O

After O
referencing O
to O
the O
average O
of O
all O
EEG O
channels O
, O
data O
were O
visually O
inspected O
and O
30s O
epochs O
with O
artifacts O
were O
removed O
. O

Sleep O
spindles O
were O
automatically O
detected O
at O
each O
channel O
using O
a O
wavelet-based O
algorithm O
that O
was O
previously O
validated O
against O
hand-counted O
spindles O
in O
both O
patients O
with O
schizophrenia O
and O
healthy O
individuals O
. O

The O
threshold O
for O
spindle O
detection O
, O
9 O
times O
the O
median O
signal O
amplitude O
of O
artifact-free O
epochs O
, O
was O
chosen O
to O
maximize O
between-class O
( O
‘ O
spindle O
’ O
vs O
‘ O
non-spindle O
’ O
) O
variance O
in O
the O
wavelet O
coefficient O
in O
samples O
of O
schizophrenia O
patients O
and O
controls O
from O
a O
previous O
study O
. O

The O
outcome O
measure O
was O
spindle O
density O
( O
spindles O
per O
minute O
) O
during O
N2 O
sleep O
. O

Group O
comparisons O
of O
sleep O
spindle O
density O
were O
based O
on O
t-tests O
at O
each O
electrode O
. O

A O
nonparametric O
clustering O
method O
optimized O
for O
EEG O
and O
implemented O
in O
R O
( O
http O
: O
//www.R-project.org/ O
) O
was O
used O
to O
correct O
for O
multiple O
comparisons O
. O

Adjacent O
electrodes O
that O
met O
an O
uncorrected O
threshold O
of O
p≤.05 O
were O
clustered O
and O
within O
each O
cluster O
the O
t-values O
were O
summed O
across O
electrodes O
. O

Cluster-level O
corrected O
p-values O
were O
determined O
by O
estimating O
the O
likelihood O
that O
a O
cluster O
of O
that O
summed O
t-value O
would O
be O
found O
by O
chance O
under O
the O
null O
distribution O
derived O
from O
10,000 O
permutations O
with O
random O
group O
assignment O
. O

MRI O
Acquisition O
: O
Scans O
were O
acquired O
with O
a O
3T O
Siemens O
( O
Erlangen O
, O
Germany O
) O
Trio O
TIM O
whole O
body O
high O
speed O
imaging O
device O
equipped O
for O
echo O
planar O
imaging O
( O
EPI O
) O
and O
a O
32-channel O
head O
coil O
. O

Head O
stabilization O
was O
achieved O
with O
cushioning O
and O
participants O
wore O
earplugs O
to O
attenuate O
noise O
. O

Autoalign O
was O
used O
for O
automatic O
slice O
positioning O
. O

Anatomical O
images O
were O
acquired O
with O
a O
3D O
multiecho O
magnetization-prepared O
rf-spoiled O
rapid O
gradient-echo O
MEMPRAGE O
sequence O
( O
T1-weighted O
) O
with O
EPI O
based O
volumetric O
navigators O
for O
real O
time O
motion O
correction O
( O
TR=2530ms O
, O
Flip O
Angle=7° O
, O
TEs=1.7ms/3.6ms/5.5ms/7.3ms O
, O
iPAT=2 O
; O
FOV=256mm O
; O
176 O
in-plane O
sagittal O
slices O
; O
voxel O
size=1mm3 O
isotropic O
, O
scan O
duration O
6m O
12s O
) O
. O

Two O
rs-fcMRI O
scans O
were O
collected O
with O
a O
gradient O
echo O
T2 O
* O
-weighted O
sequence O
for O
Blood O
Oxygen O
Level O
Dependent O
( O
BOLD O
) O
contrast O
( O
TR=3000 O
ms O
, O
Flip O
Angle=85° O
TE=30 O
ms O
, O
FOV=216mm O
, O
47 O
contiguous O
horizontal O
slices O
parallel O
to O
the O
intercommissural O
plane O
, O
voxel O
size O
= O
3mm3 O
, O
interleaved O
, O
scan O
duration O
6m O
12s O
) O
. O

Rs-fcMRI O
sequences O
included O
prospective O
acquisition O
correction O
( O
PACE O
) O
for O
head O
motion O
to O
adjust O
slice O
position O
and O
orientation O
during O
data O
acquisition O
. O

Participants O
were O
instructed O
to O
keep O
their O
eyes O
open O
for O
the O
duration O
of O
the O
resting O
state O
scans O
. O

MRI O
Preprocessing O
: O
Rs-fcMRI O
data O
were O
preprocessed O
and O
analyzed O
using O
Statistical O
Parametric O
Mapping O
( O
SPM8 O
, O
Wellcome O
Department O
of O
Cognitive O
Neurology O
, O
London O
, O
UK O
) O
implemented O
in O
MATLAB O
. O

Anatomical O
images O
were O
segmented O
into O
white O
matter O
, O
gray O
matter O
and O
cerebrospinal O
fluid O
masks O
. O

Images O
were O
corrected O
for O
the O
time O
of O
slice O
acquisition O
, O
spatially O
realigned O
with O
respect O
to O
the O
reference O
image O
, O
resliced O
, O
and O
coregistered O
with O
the O
anatomical O
images O
. O

The O
volumes O
were O
normalized O
to O
the O
Montreal O
Neurological O
Institute O
( O
MNI O
) O
template O
and O
spatially O
smoothed O
using O
a O
Gaussian O
kernel O
with O
a O
full O
width O
at O
half O
maximum O
of O
6 O
mm O
. O

MRI O
Data O
Quality O
: O
To O
minimize O
spurious O
correlations O
in O
rs-fcMRI O
data O
and O
to O
avoid O
artifactual O
group O
differences O
due O
to O
head O
motion O
, O
we O
excluded O
data O
from O
four O
patients O
and O
one O
control O
based O
on O
high O
levels O
of O
residual O
motion O
— O
greater O
than O
two O
standard O
deviations O
above O
the O
sample O
mean O
( O
root O
mean O
square O
of O
translation O
in O
x O
, O
y O
and O
z O
directions O
averaged O
across O
the O
two O
runs O
) O
. O

In O
the O
remaining O
participants O
, O
we O
identified O
and O
removed O
artifactual O
volumes O
using O
Artifact O
Detection O
Tools O
( O
ART O
; O
http O
: O
//www.nitrc.org/projects/artifact_detect/ O
) O
based O
on O
either O
head O
displacement O
in O
the O
x O
, O
y O
or O
z O
direction O
that O
was O
more O
than O
1mm O
from O
the O
previous O
frame O
or O
if O
the O
global O
mean O
intensity O
of O
the O
volume O
was O
more O
than O
three O
standard O
deviations O
above O
that O
of O
the O
entire O
functional O
scan O
. O

There O
were O
no O
group O
differences O
in O
residual O
motion O
( O
t O
( O
49 O
) O
=.39 O
, O
p=.70 O
) O
or O
the O
number O
of O
artifactual O
volumes O
( O
t O
( O
49 O
) O
=1.49 O
, O
p=.14 O
) O
in O
the O
final O
sample O
. O

Functional O
connectivity O
analyses O
: O
Analyses O
were O
implemented O
in O
CONN O
version O
17 O
using O
a O
component O
base O
noise O
reduction O
method O
, O
Anatomical O
CompCor O
rather O
than O
global O
signal O
regression O
, O
to O
remove O
physiological O
and O
other O
noise O
. O

Preprocessing O
involved O
applying O
a O
temporal O
band-pass O
filter O
of O
.008-.09 O
Hz O
to O
the O
time O
series O
. O

Residual O
head O
motion O
parameters O
( O
rotation O
and O
translations O
in O
x O
, O
y O
and O
z O
directions O
and O
their O
first-order O
temporal O
derivatives O
) O
and O
artifactual O
volumes O
( O
flagged O
by O
ART O
) O
were O
regressed O
out O
in O
the O
model O
. O

Functional O
connectivity O
maps O
were O
generated O
for O
each O
participant O
by O
extracting O
the O
average O
time O
course O
of O
the O
BOLD O
signal O
from O
the O
bilateral O
whole O
thalamus O
seed O
, O
which O
was O
defined O
using O
the O
probabilistic O
FSL O
Oxford O
thalamic O
connectivity O
atlas O
with O
a O
threshold O
of O
25 O
( O
: O
Fig O
. O

S1 O
) O
, O
and O
correlating O
it O
with O
every O
other O
gray O
matter O
voxel O
. O

The O
resulting O
Pearson O
coefficients O
were O
transformed O
into O
Fisher O
’ O
s O
z-values O
. O

This O
yielded O
a O
map O
for O
each O
resting-state O
run O
where O
the O
value O
at O
voxel O
indexed O
connectivity O
with O
the O
thalamus O
. O

The O
two O
runs O
for O
each O
subject O
were O
averaged O
. O

We O
examined O
group O
differences O
in O
thalamocortical O
functional O
connectivity O
with O
t-tests O
at O
every O
voxel O
. O

We O
examined O
the O
relations O
of O
sleep O
spindle O
density O
( O
averaged O
across O
electrodes O
) O
with O
thalamocortical O
connectivity O
using O
regression O
with O
Group O
, O
Spindle O
Density O
and O
Group O
by O
Spindle O
Density O
as O
predictors O
. O

Whole O
brain O
correction O
for O
multiple O
comparisons O
was O
based O
on O
a O
voxel O
level O
uncorrected O
threshold O
of O
p≤.001 O
and O
a O
false O
discovery O
rate O
( O
FDR O
) O
-corrected O
cluster O
threshold O
of O
p≤.05 O
. O

Aberrant O
activity O
in O
conceptual O
networks O
underlies O
N400 O
deficits O
and O
unusual O
thoughts O
in O
schizophrenia O
Background O
The O
N400 O
event-related O
potential O
( O
ERP O
) O
is O
triggered O
by O
meaningful O
stimuli O
that O
are O
incongruous O
, O
or O
unmatched O
, O
with O
their O
semantic O
context O
. O

Functional O
magnetic O
resonance O
imaging O
( O
fMRI O
) O
studies O
have O
identified O
brain O
regions O
activated O
by O
semantic O
incongruity O
, O
but O
their O
precise O
links O
to O
the O
N400 O
ERP O
are O
unclear O
. O

In O
schizophrenia O
( O
SZ O
) O
, O
N400 O
amplitude O
reduction O
is O
thought O
to O
reflect O
overly O
broad O
associations O
in O
semantic O
networks O
, O
but O
the O
abnormalities O
in O
brain O
networks O
underlying O
deficient O
N400 O
remain O
unknown O
. O

We O
utilized O
joint O
independent O
component O
analysis O
( O
JICA O
) O
to O
link O
temporal O
patterns O
in O
ERPs O
to O
neuroanatomical O
patterns O
from O
fMRI O
and O
investigate O
relationships O
between O
N400 O
amplitude O
and O
neuroanatomical O
activation O
in O
SZ O
patients O
and O
healthy O
controls O
( O
HC O
) O
. O

Methods O
SZ O
patients O
( O
n O
= O
24 O
) O
and O
HC O
participants O
( O
n O
= O
25 O
) O
performed O
a O
picture-word O
matching O
task O
, O
in O
which O
words O
were O
either O
matched O
( O
APPLE→apple O
) O
by O
preceding O
pictures O
, O
or O
were O
unmatched O
by O
semantically O
related O
( O
in-category O
; O
IC O
, O
APPLE→lemon O
) O
or O
unrelated O
( O
out O
of O
category O
; O
OC O
, O
APPLE→cow O
) O
pictures O
, O
in O
separate O
ERP O
and O
fMRI O
sessions O
. O

A O
JICA O
“ O
data O
fusion O
” O
analysis O
was O
conducted O
to O
identify O
the O
fMRI O
brain O
regions O
specifically O
associated O
with O
the O
ERP O
N400 O
component O
. O

SZ O
and O
HC O
loading O
weights O
were O
compared O
and O
correlations O
with O
clinical O
symptoms O
were O
assessed O
. O

Results O
JICA O
identified O
an O
ERP-fMRI O
“ O
fused O
” O
component O
that O
captured O
the O
N400 O
, O
with O
loading O
weights O
that O
were O
reduced O
in O
SZ O
. O

The O
JICA O
map O
for O
the O
IC O
condition O
showed O
peaks O
of O
activation O
in O
the O
cingulate O
, O
precuneus O
, O
bilateral O
temporal O
poles O
and O
cerebellum O
, O
whereas O
the O
JICA O
map O
from O
the O
OC O
condition O
was O
linked O
primarily O
to O
visual O
cortical O
activation O
and O
the O
left O
temporal O
pole O
. O

Among O
SZ O
patients O
, O
fMRI O
activity O
from O
the O
IC O
condition O
was O
inversely O
correlated O
with O
unusual O
thought O
content O
. O

Conclusions O
The O
neural O
networks O
associated O
with O
the O
N400 O
ERP O
response O
to O
semantic O
violations O
depends O
on O
conceptual O
relatedness O
. O

These O
findings O
are O
consistent O
with O
a O
distributed O
network O
underlying O
neural O
responses O
to O
semantic O
incongruity O
including O
unimodal O
visual O
areas O
as O
well O
as O
integrative O
, O
transmodal O
areas O
. O

Unusual O
thoughts O
in O
SZ O
may O
reflect O
impaired O
processing O
in O
transmodal O
hub O
regions O
such O
as O
the O
precuneus O
, O
leading O
to O
overly O
broad O
semantic O
associations O
. O

Highlights O
Hemodynamic O
activity O
linked O
to O
N400 O
responses O
is O
distributed O
across O
the O
brain O
. O

N400 O
linked O
networks O
depend O
on O
conceptual O
relatedness O
. O

Magnitude O
of O
the O
N400 O
ERP-fMRI O
fused O
component O
is O
reduced O
in O
schizophrenia O
. O

N400 O
linked O
network O
activity O
inversely O
correlates O
with O
unusual O
thought O
content O
. O

Materials O
and O
methods O
Participants O
Patients O
with O
schizophrenia O
( O
n O
= O
26 O
) O
and O
age-matched O
healthy O
controls O
( O
n O
= O
27 O
) O
participated O
in O
both O
EEG O
and O
fMRI O
recording O
sessions O
( O
five O
participants O
were O
excluded O
for O
motion O
artifact O
, O
3 O
HCs O
and O
2 O
SZs O
, O
see O
below O
) O
. O

ERP O
and O
fMRI O
recording O
session O
order O
was O
counterbalanced O
across O
groups O
and O
performed O
on O
average O
16.1 O
days O
apart O
( O
range O
: O
same O
day-93 O
days O
, O
see O
Supplementary O
Table O
1 O
) O
. O

Demographic O
data O
( O
including O
age O
, O
sex O
, O
parental O
SES O
, O
handedness O
, O
years O
of O
education O
and O
PANSS O
symptom O
ratings O
are O
included O
in O
Supplementary O
Table O
1 O
. O
) O

Experimental O
procedures O
were O
fully O
described O
to O
all O
participants O
after O
which O
they O
provided O
written O
informed O
consent O
. O

This O
study O
was O
approved O
by O
the O
Human O
Subjects O
Committees O
at O
the O
Connecticut O
VA O
Healthcare O
System O
and O
Yale O
University O
. O

Patients O
were O
recruited O
from O
community O
mental O
health O
centers O
, O
outpatient O
services O
of O
the O
Veterans O
Affairs O
Connecticut O
Healthcare O
System O
in O
West O
Haven O
, O
and O
outpatient O
services O
of O
the O
Connecticut O
Mental O
Health O
Center O
in O
New O
Haven O
. O

All O
patients O
were O
interviewed O
by O
a O
clinical O
psychologist O
or O
a O
clinically O
trained O
research O
assistant O
using O
the O
Structured O
Clinical O
Interview O
for O
DSM-IV O
( O
SCID O
. O

Patients O
who O
met O
DSM-IV O
criteria O
for O
schizophrenia O
were O
included O
in O
this O
analysis O
. O

Patients O
were O
excluded O
if O
they O
met O
DSM-IV O
criteria O
for O
alcohol O
or O
drug O
abuse O
within O
30 O
days O
prior O
to O
the O
study O
. O

Patients O
and O
control O
participants O
were O
excluded O
for O
significant O
head O
injury O
, O
neurological O
disorders O
, O
or O
other O
medical O
illnesses O
compromising O
the O
central O
nervous O
system O
. O

Symptoms O
were O
rated O
using O
the O
positive O
and O
negative O
symptom O
scale O
( O
PANSS O
. O

Control O
participants O
were O
recruited O
by O
newspaper O
advertisements O
and O
word-of-mouth O
, O
screened O
by O
telephone O
using O
questions O
from O
the O
SCID O
non-patient O
screening O
module O
, O
and O
excluded O
for O
any O
history O
of O
Axis O
I O
psychiatric O
illness O
. O

Task O
and O
behavior O
We O
used O
the O
same O
picture–word O
verification O
task O
utilized O
in O
the O
prior O
publication O
of O
ERP O
data O
pertaining O
to O
this O
dataset O
for O
both O
ERP O
and O
fMRI O
recording O
sessions O
( O
Fig O
. O

1A O
) O
. O

In O
this O
task O
, O
a O
simple O
line O
drawing O
of O
an O
object O
is O
presented O
( O
250 O
ms O
) O
, O
and O
following O
a O
short O
delay O
( O
75 O
ms O
) O
, O
a O
word O
appears O
. O

Subjects O
are O
instructed O
to O
respond O
by O
indicating O
whether O
the O
word O
was O
a O
semantic O
match O
( O
50 O
% O
of O
trials O
) O
or O
non-match O
( O
unmatched O
, O
50 O
% O
of O
trials O
) O
to O
the O
preceding O
picture O
. O

Pictures O
consisted O
of O
102 O
line O
drawings O
selected O
from O
and O
classified O
into O
10 O
natural O
categories O
( O
clothing O
, O
animal O
, O
bird O
, O
appliance O
, O
tool O
, O
vehicle O
, O
vegetable O
, O
fruit O
, O
toy O
, O
and O
musical O
instrument O
) O
. O

The O
full O
set O
of O
pictures O
comprised O
a O
block O
of O
102 O
trials O
which O
was O
repeated O
across O
a O
total O
of O
four O
blocks O
, O
with O
the O
order O
of O
pictures O
varying O
across O
blocks O
. O

Half O
of O
the O
unmatched O
trials O
comprised O
picture-word O
pairs O
from O
a O
related O
semantic O
category O
( O
related O
co-hyponym O
, O
e.g. O
, O
APPLE O
→lemon O
) O
and O
the O
other O
half O
comprised O
picture-word O
pairs O
from O
unrelated O
semantic O
categories O
( O
unrelated O
, O
e.g. O
, O
APPLE O
→cow O
) O
. O

Subjects O
were O
not O
asked O
to O
distinguish O
between O
related O
and O
unrelated O
unmatched O
target O
words O
. O

Occasional O
null O
events O
were O
inserted O
between O
trials O
, O
resulting O
in O
trial-to-trial O
intervals O
that O
ranged O
from O
3 O
to O
11 O
s. O
Participants O
responded O
by O
button O
press O
with O
right O
or O
left O
index O
fingers O
to O
indicate O
if O
the O
word O
matched O
or O
did O
not O
match O
the O
picture O
. O

Left O
/ O
right O
button O
presses O
were O
counterbalanced O
across O
participants O
. O

All O
participants O
performed O
several O
practice O
trials O
prior O
to O
ERP O
or O
fMRI O
recordings O
. O

No O
feedback O
was O
given O
to O
signal O
performance O
accuracy O
and O
participants O
were O
told O
to O
respond O
as O
quickly O
as O
possible O
without O
sacrificing O
accuracy O
. O

All O
subjects O
performed O
the O
task O
at O
> O
90 O
% O
accuracy O
( O
See O
Supplementary O
Table O
1 O
. O

HC O
= O
95.0 O
% O
and O
SZ O
= O
91.8 O
% O
, O
F O
( O
1,45 O
) O
= O
5.7295 O
, O
p O
= O
0.02 O
) O
. O

We O
found O
no O
effect O
of O
practice O
across O
the O
two O
sessions O
, O
performance O
accuracy O
was O
similar O
for O
the O
first O
and O
second O
session O
across O
groups O
( O
paired O
t-test O
, O
t-stat O
= O
−0.70 O
, O
p O
= O
0.49 O
) O
and O
remained O
insignificant O
after O
controlling O
for O
the O
time O
difference O
between O
sessions O
( O
p O
= O
0.49 O
) O
. O

Moreover O
, O
there O
was O
no O
effect O
of O
session O
order O
or O
time O
between O
sessions O
on O
the O
loading O
weight O
of O
the O
joint O
component O
reported O
below O
( O
ANCOVA O
model O
with O
covariates O
of O
group O
, O
session O
order O
and O
times O
between O
sessions O
) O
. O

Reaction O
latency O
data O
were O
collected O
, O
and O
the O
median O
reaction O
times O
per O
subject O
, O
per O
condition O
( O
matched O
, O
unmatched O
) O
was O
determined O
( O
see O
Supplementary O
Methods O
and O
Results O
) O
. O

All O
participants O
showed O
slower O
reaction O
times O
during O
the O
fMRI O
session O
than O
EEG O
session O
( O
see O
Supplementary O
Fig O
. O

1 O
) O
without O
higher O
level O
interaction O
effects O
between O
Group O
( O
HC O
or O
SZ O
) O
or O
Session O
( O
EEG O
or O
fMRI O
) O
. O

EEG O
acquisition O
Data O
acquisition O
is O
as O
described O
in O
, O
to O
summarize O
briefly O
: O
EEG O
data O
were O
digitized O
using O
a O
1000 O
Hz O
sampling O
rate O
, O
low O
pass O
filtered O
at O
100 O
Hz O
, O
and O
high O
pass O
filtered O
at O
0.05 O
Hz O
. O

Data O
were O
acquired O
from O
F7 O
, O
F3 O
, O
Fz O
, O
F4 O
, O
F8 O
, O
T3 O
, O
C3 O
, O
Cz O
, O
C4 O
, O
T4 O
, O
T5 O
, O
P3 O
, O
Pz O
, O
P4 O
, O
T6 O
, O
O1 O
, O
Oz O
, O
and O
O2 O
. O

Data O
were O
referenced O
to O
linked O
ears O
. O

Additional O
electrodes O
were O
place O
on O
the O
outer O
canthi O
of O
both O
eyes O
and O
above O
and O
below O
the O
left O
eye O
to O
record O
eye O
movements O
and O
blinks O
( O
vertical O
and O
horizontal O
electro-oculogram O
( O
EOG O
) O
; O
VEOG O
, O
HEOG O
) O
. O

All O
impedances O
were O
maintained O
at O
or O
below O
10 O
kΩ O
throughout O
the O
recording O
session O
with O
most O
EEG O
sites O
around O
5 O
kΩ O
. O

EEG O
processing O
Continuous O
EEG O
Data O
were O
bandpass O
filtered O
between O
1 O
and O
30 O
Hz O
, O
epoched O
and O
stimulus-locked O
to O
picture O
onset O
. O

Individual O
trials O
were O
baseline O
corrected O
using O
the O
100 O
ms O
period O
preceding O
picture O
onset O
after O
correcting O
for O
eye O
movements O
and O
blinks O
using O
EOG O
data O
. O

Trials O
containing O
artifacts O
( O
voltages O
exceeding O
±100 O
μV O
) O
were O
rejected O
. O

Only O
data O
from O
correct O
trials O
were O
included O
in O
the O
analyses O
. O

N400 O
difference O
waveforms O
were O
derived O
on O
a O
subject-by-subject O
basis O
by O
subtracting O
matched O
trial O
averages O
from O
the O
two O
unmatched O
conditions O
( O
related O
and O
unrelated O
) O
. O

The O
resulting O
difference O
waveforms O
from O
electrode O
Cz O
( O
electrode O
with O
maximal O
N400 O
magnitude O
) O
were O
used O
for O
Joint O
Independent O
Component O
Analysis O
( O
see O
details O
below O
) O
. O

MRI O
data O
acquisition O
, O
preprocessing O
and O
analysis O
Structural O
and O
functional O
MRI O
data O
were O
collected O
using O
a O
3T O
Siemens O
Trio O
scanner O
. O

The O
structural O
imaging O
protocol O
was O
a O
magnetization-prepared O
rapid O
gradient-echo O
( O
MPRAGE O
) O
T1-weighted O
high-resolution O
image O
( O
2530 O
ms O
TR O
, O
3.66 O
ms O
TE O
, O
1 O
mm O
slice O
thickness O
, O
256 O
mm O
field O
of O
view O
, O
1.0 O
× O
1.0 O
× O
1.0 O
voxel O
size O
, O
flip O
angle O
7° O
, O
sagittal O
orientation O
, O
8:07 O
min O
) O
. O

The O
fMRI O
protocol O
was O
an O
AC-PC O
aligned O
echo O
planar O
imaging O
( O
EPI O
) O
sequence O
( O
2000 O
ms O
TR O
, O
28 O
ms O
TE O
, O
flip O
angle O
60° O
, O
33 O
slices O
collected O
sequentially O
in O
ascending O
order O
with O
a O
12 O
% O
( O
0.5 O
mm O
) O
gap O
, O
4.0 O
× O
4.0 O
× O
4.0 O
mm O
voxel O
size O
, O
257 O
frames O
, O
8:34 O
min O
per O
run O
) O
. O

Preprocessing O
of O
fMRI O
images O
was O
done O
using O
Statistical O
Parametric O
Mapping O
8 O
( O
SPM8 O
; O
http O
: O
//www.fil.ion.ucl.ac.uk/spm/software/spm8/ O
) O
. O

Motion O
correction O
was O
performed O
via O
affine O
registration O
, O
where O
the O
first O
image O
of O
each O
run O
was O
realigned O
to O
the O
first O
image O
of O
the O
first O
run O
, O
followed O
by O
re-alignment O
within O
each O
run O
. O

Next O
, O
Images O
were O
slice-time O
corrected O
with O
respect O
to O
the O
middle O
slice O
. O

We O
implemented O
aCompCor O
( O
anatomic O
component-based O
noise O
correction O
, O
) O
, O
a O
principal O
components-based O
approach O
for O
noise O
reduction O
of O
fMRI O
time-series O
data O
. O

Given O
that O
aCompCor O
uses O
white O
matter O
and O
CSF O
regions O
identified O
from O
FreeSurfer O
anatomical O
segmentation O
of O
T1 O
images O
to O
identify O
noise O
components O
, O
five O
participants O
were O
excluded O
( O
3 O
HCs O
and O
2 O
SZs O
) O
due O
to O
excessive O
head O
motion O
or O
scanning O
artifacts O
as O
determined O
by O
manual O
examination O
of O
FreeSurfer O
reconstructions O
. O

First-level O
modeling O
of O
the O
fMRI O
data O
was O
performed O
using O
an O
event-related O
analysis O
aligned O
to O
the O
onset O
of O
the O
picture O
. O

SPM O
's O
canonical O
hemodynamic O
response O
function O
( O
a O
double O
gamma O
function O
) O
was O
convolved O
with O
task O
event O
vectors O
to O
create O
a O
first-level O
task O
regressor O
representing O
the O
predicted O
response O
of O
a O
voxel O
activated O
by O
visual O
onset O
of O
the O
picture O
. O

A O
high O
pass O
temporal O
filter O
( O
128 O
s O
cut-off O
) O
was O
applied O
to O
remove O
low-frequency O
noise O
and O
a O
general O
linear O
model O
was O
implemented O
voxel-wise O
, O
regressing O
each O
voxel O
's O
time O
series O
on O
the O
task O
regressor O
, O
as O
well O
as O
on O
nuisance O
regressors O
consisting O
of O
the O
aCompCor O
noise O
components O
. O

The O
time O
of O
correct O
or O
incorrect O
button O
presses O
were O
modeled O
and O
included O
as O
nuisance O
regressors O
during O
the O
denoising O
step O
. O

Beta O
coefficients O
representing O
the O
fit O
of O
the O
task O
regressor O
to O
a O
voxel O
's O
time O
series O
were O
estimated O
, O
to O
generate O
beta O
images O
for O
the O
3 O
conditions O
of O
interest O
( O
matched O
, O
OC O
unmatched O
and O
IC O
unmatched O
) O
versus O
implicit O
baseline O
( O
null O
time O
) O
. O

Mean O
beta O
images O
across O
runs O
were O
normalized O
by O
applying O
the O
spatial O
transformation O
matrix O
derived O
from O
normalization O
of O
the O
mean O
functional O
image O
( O
generated O
during O
motion O
correction O
) O
to O
the O
Montreal O
Neurological O
Institute O
's O
EPI O
template O
( O
http O
: O
//www.bic.mni.mcgill.ca O
) O
. O

Normalized O
beta O
images O
were O
resliced O
to O
3 O
mm3 O
isotropic O
voxel O
dimensions O
using O
a O
fourth O
degree O
B-spline O
and O
were O
then O
spatially O
smoothed O
with O
an O
8 O
mm O
full-width-half-maximum O
Gaussian O
kernel O
. O

Subsequently O
, O
each O
subject O
's O
first-level O
analysis O
brain O
mask O
image O
was O
normalized O
and O
applied O
to O
the O
smoothed O
beta O
image O
to O
mask O
out O
regions O
with O
insufficient O
signal O
intensity O
, O
as O
determined O
by O
SPM O
during O
first O
level O
modeling O
. O

The O
resulting O
first-level O
model O
contrast O
images O
were O
utilized O
in O
the O
JICA O
, O
see O
below O
. O

We O
report O
the O
results O
of O
a O
second-level O
general O
linear O
model O
( O
GLM O
) O
in O
the O
supplementary O
material O
. O

Joint O
independent O
component O
analysis O
of O
EEG O
and O
fMRI O
data O
To O
identify O
anatomical O
regions O
linked O
to O
the O
N400 O
component O
, O
we O
conducted O
a O
joint O
independent O
component O
analysis O
( O
JICA O
) O
using O
the O
Matlab-based O
Fusion O
ICA O
Toolbox O
or O
“ O
FIT O
” O
( O
Rachakonda O
, O
Liu O
, O
and O
Calhoun O
2008 O
; O
http O
: O
//mialab.mrn.org/software/fit O
) O
. O

We O
entered O
each O
subject O
's O
N400 O
difference O
waves O
and O
first-level O
model O
contrast O
images O
for O
the O
two O
conditions O
of O
interest O
: O
IC O
versus O
matched O
and O
OC O
versus O
matched O
. O

These O
two O
conditions O
formed O
two O
“ O
features O
” O
within O
the O
JICA O
analysis O
, O
so O
were O
concatenated O
side-by-side O
for O
a O
total O
of O
four O
“ O
features O
: O
” O
( O
1 O
) O
OC O
versus O
matched O
ERPs O
, O
( O
2 O
) O
OC O
versus O
matched O
fMRI O
, O
( O
3 O
) O
IC O
versus O
matched O
ERPs O
, O
( O
4 O
) O
OC O
versus O
matched O
fMRI O
. O

The O
ERP O
waveforms O
are O
upsampled O
by O
a O
factor O
of O
121 O
so O
that O
the O
number O
of O
samples O
in O
time O
match O
the O
number O
of O
fMRI O
samples O
in O
space O
. O

The O
use O
of O
difference O
waves O
, O
instead O
of O
condition O
grand O
averages O
as O
reported O
previously O
resulted O
in O
similar O
statistical O
effects O
: O
N400 O
difference O
waves O
which O
are O
larger O
for O
OC O
and O
reduced O
in O
SZ O
( O
Supplementary O
Fig O
. O

2 O
; O
main O
effect O
of O
group O
, O
F O
( O
1,47 O
) O
= O
15.36 O
, O
p O
= O
0.0003 O
; O
main O
effect O
of O
condition O
, O
F O
( O
1,47 O
) O
= O
217.22 O
, O
p O
< O
0.00001 O
; O
group O
x O
condition O
, O
F O
( O
1,47 O
) O
= O
14.22 O
, O
p O
= O
0.0004 O
) O
. O

Briefly O
, O
the O
JICA O
algorithm O
utilizes O
temporal O
information O
in O
the O
ERPs O
and O
spatial O
information O
in O
the O
fMRI O
to O
look O
for O
inter-subject O
covariation O
and O
identify O
“ O
fused O
” O
ERP-fMRI O
components O
which O
maximize O
the O
joint O
likelihood O
function O
. O

This O
approach O
identifies O
“ O
features O
” O
which O
covary O
the O
same O
way O
across O
participants O
. O

The O
algorithm O
outputs O
loading O
weights O
for O
each O
subject O
, O
which O
reflect O
the O
magnitude O
of O
the O
joint O
component O
for O
that O
particular O
subject O
( O
the O
coefficients O
of O
the O
unmixing O
matrix O
) O
. O

Loading O
scores O
were O
compared O
between O
groups O
using O
independent O
samples O
t-tests O
. O

Loading O
weights O
can O
be O
used O
to O
“ O
back-project O
” O
temporal O
and O
spatial O
maps O
for O
each O
feature O
: O
in O
our O
case O
, O
one O
spatial O
map O
and O
time O
course O
for O
the O
IC O
vs. O
match O
condition O
and O
one O
spatial O
map O
and O
time O
courses O
for O
the O
OC O
vs. O
match O
condition O
. O

A O
priori O
, O
we O
planned O
to O
investigate O
components O
with O
time O
courses O
that O
correlated O
with O
the O
N400 O
and O
regressed O
those O
time O
courses O
onto O
the O
N400 O
grand O
average O
ERP O
to O
assist O
with O
component O
selection O
. O

We O
estimated O
the O
number O
of O
components O
to O
calculate O
based O
on O
minimum O
descriptive O
length O
criteria O
for O
fMRI O
and O
a O
parallel O
test O
for O
ERP O
for O
each O
feature O
. O

Given O
the O
primacy O
of O
our O
interest O
in O
identifying O
a O
joint O
component O
that O
clearly O
captured O
the O
N400 O
difference O
wave O
in O
the O
ERP O
waveforms O
, O
we O
considered O
ICA O
solutions O
involving O
extractions O
of O
between O
2 O
and O
7 O
components O
. O

After O
reviewing O
the O
components O
resulting O
from O
these O
solutions O
, O
it O
was O
clear O
that O
the O
2-component O
solution O
yielded O
a O
joint O
component O
that O
clearly O
captured O
the O
N400 O
difference O
waveform O
for O
both O
IC O
and O
OC O
conditions O
( O
IC O
condition O
: O
R2 O
= O
0.924 O
, O
p O
< O
0.0001 O
, O
OC O
condition O
: O
R2 O
= O
0.944 O
, O
p O
< O
0.0001 O
) O
. O

Accordingly O
, O
this O
joint O
component O
was O
extracted O
and O
used O
in O
our O
subsequent O
analyses O
. O

Given O
our O
interest O
in O
identifying O
regions O
correlated O
with O
the O
N400 O
, O
we O
focused O
our O
follow-up O
analyses O
on O
voxels O
with O
a O
positive O
correlation O
with O
the O
N400 O
. O

Spatial O
maps O
were O
subject O
to O
thresholding O
at O
Z O
> O
4.42 O
( O
p O
< O
0.000005 O
) O
and O
convolved O
with O
the O
FSL-Harvard O
Standard O
Atlas O
. O

All O
voxels O
in O
the O
brain O
contribute O
to O
the O
loading O
weight O
; O
empirical O
thresholding O
identifies O
regions O
that O
are O
most O
strongly O
linked O
to O
the O
N400 O
magnitude O
. O

In O
our O
analyses O
, O
the O
maps O
revealed O
a O
max O
z-score O
of O
~8 O
for O
the O
OC O
map O
and O
max O
z-score O
of O
~10 O
for O
the O
IC O
map O
, O
so O
we O
selected O
a O
z-score O
cutoff O
that O
approximated O
half O
of O
the O
height O
of O
the O
average O
maximum O
for O
the O
two O
maps O
( O
Z O
> O
4.42 O
) O
. O

Threshold O
free O
maps O
are O
also O
available O
on O
neurovault O
( O
https O
: O
//neurovault.org/ O
) O
. O

All O
clusters O
larger O
than O
18 O
voxels O
( O
the O
minimum O
ROI O
size O
in O
the O
FSL-Harvard O
Standard O
Atlas O
) O
were O
included O
and O
labeled O
according O
to O
the O
regional O
area O
that O
composed O
the O
majority O
of O
the O
voxels O
for O
that O
cluster O
. O

Clinical O
correlations O
We O
conducted O
correlations O
between O
activity O
( O
contrast O
estimates O
) O
extracted O
from O
z-thresholded O
IC O
and O
OC O
JICA O
spatial O
maps O
with O
clinical O
measures O
. O

We O
predicted O
that O
clinical O
deficits O
in O
language O
function O
( O
as O
reflected O
in O
scores O
on O
thought O
process O
and O
content O
) O
in O
SZ O
patients O
would O
be O
related O
to O
reductions O
of O
activity O
in O
conceptual O
networks O
( O
inverse O
correlation O
between O
activity O
and O
impairment O
) O
. O

We O
extracted O
conceptual O
disorganization O
( O
P2 O
) O
and O
unusual O
thought O
content O
( O
G9 O
) O
from O
the O
PANSS O
ratings O
. O

Given O
the O
correlation O
between O
disorganization O
and O
content O
( O
r O
= O
0.69 O
, O
p O
= O
0.0002 O
) O
we O
conducted O
multivariate O
regression O
analysis O
to O
look O
for O
independent O
effects O
of O
process O
and O
content O
. O

To O
examine O
the O
distribution O
of O
symptom O
correlations O
within O
the O
thresholded O
JICA O
maps O
, O
conceptual O
disorganization O
and O
unusual O
thought O
content O
PANSS O
ratings O
were O
entered O
as O
predictors O
in O
a O
GLM O
analysis O
in O
SPM O
separately O
for O
the O
IC O
minus O
matched O
and O
OC O
minus O
matched O
contrasts O
of O
interest O
. O

We O
used O
inclusive O
masks O
from O
the O
corresponding O
JICA O
z-thresholded O
spatial O
maps O
( O
one O
for O
each O
condition O
) O
to O
restrict O
whole O
brain O
T-maps O
for O
visualizing O
the O
distributions O
of O
relationships O
between O
contrast O
images O
and O
PANSS O
ratings O
. O

Dynamic O
functional O
connectivity O
in O
schizophrenia O
and O
autism O
spectrum O
disorder O
: O
Convergence O
, O
divergence O
and O
classification O
Background O
Over O
the O
recent O
years O
there O
has O
been O
a O
growing O
debate O
regarding O
the O
extent O
and O
nature O
of O
the O
overlap O
in O
neuropathology O
between O
schizophrenia O
( O
SZ O
) O
and O
autism O
spectrum O
disorder O
( O
ASD O
) O
. O

Dynamic O
functional O
network O
connectivity O
( O
dFNC O
) O
is O
a O
recent O
analysis O
method O
that O
explores O
temporal O
patterns O
of O
functional O
connectivity O
( O
FC O
) O
. O

We O
compared O
resting-state O
dFNC O
in O
SZ O
, O
ASD O
and O
healthy O
controls O
( O
HC O
) O
, O
characterized O
the O
associations O
between O
temporal O
patterns O
and O
symptoms O
, O
and O
performed O
a O
three-way O
classification O
analysis O
based O
on O
dFNC O
indices O
. O

Methods O
Resting-state O
fMRI O
was O
collected O
from O
100 O
young O
adults O
: O
33 O
SZ O
, O
33 O
ASD O
, O
34 O
HC O
. O

Independent O
component O
analysis O
( O
ICA O
) O
was O
performed O
, O
followed O
by O
dFNC O
analysis O
( O
window O
= O
33 O
s O
, O
step O
= O
1TR O
, O
k-means O
clustering O
) O
. O

Temporal O
patterns O
were O
compared O
between O
groups O
, O
correlated O
with O
symptoms O
, O
and O
classified O
via O
cross-validated O
three-way O
discriminant O
analysis O
. O

Results O
Both O
clinical O
groups O
displayed O
an O
increased O
fraction O
of O
time O
( O
FT O
) O
spent O
in O
a O
state O
of O
weak O
, O
intra-network O
connectivity O
[ O
p O
< O
.001 O
] O
and O
decreased O
FT O
in O
a O
highly-connected O
state O
[ O
p O
< O
.001 O
] O
. O

SZ O
further O
showed O
decreased O
number O
of O
transitions O
between O
states O
[ O
p O
< O
.001 O
] O
, O
decreased O
FT O
in O
a O
widely-connected O
state O
[ O
p O
< O
.001 O
] O
, O
increased O
dwell O
time O
( O
DT O
) O
in O
the O
weakly-connected O
state O
[ O
p O
< O
.001 O
] O
, O
and O
decreased O
DT O
in O
the O
highly-connected O
state O
[ O
p O
= O
.001 O
] O
. O

Social O
behavior O
scores O
correlated O
with O
DT O
in O
the O
widely-connected O
state O
in O
SZ O
[ O
r O
= O
0.416 O
, O
p O
= O
.043 O
] O
, O
but O
not O
ASD O
. O

Classification O
correctly O
identified O
SZ O
at O
high O
rates O
( O
81.8 O
% O
) O
, O
while O
ASD O
and O
HC O
at O
lower O
rates O
. O

Conclusions O
Results O
indicate O
a O
severe O
and O
pervasive O
pattern O
of O
temporal O
aberrations O
in O
SZ O
( O
specifically O
, O
being O
“ O
stuck O
” O
in O
a O
state O
of O
weak O
connectivity O
) O
, O
that O
distinguishes O
SZ O
participants O
from O
both O
ASD O
and O
HC O
, O
and O
is O
associated O
with O
clinical O
symptoms O
. O

Highlights O
Temporal O
patterns O
of O
fMRI O
functional O
connectivity O
were O
assessed O
in O
schizophrenia O
, O
autism O
spectrum O
disorder O
( O
ASD O
) O
, O
and O
healthy O
controls O
( O
HC O
) O
. O

Both O
the O
schizophrenia O
and O
ASD O
groups O
displayed O
restricted O
temporal O
patterns O
, O
however O
the O
schizophrenia O
group O
displayed O
a O
more O
pervasive O
abnormality O
. O

Schizophrenia O
participants O
remain O
in O
a O
state O
of O
weak O
connectivity O
between O
brain O
regions O
, O
at O
the O
expense O
of O
more O
highly O
connected O
states O
. O

Temporal O
patterns O
were O
associated O
with O
clinical O
symptoms O
in O
the O
schizophrenia O
group O
. O

Temporal O
patterns O
distinguish O
schizophrenia O
participants O
from O
both O
ASD O
and O
healthy O
individuals O
. O

Methods O
and O
materials O
Participants O
One-hundred O
young O
adults O
( O
age O
18–35 O
) O
, O
without O
intellectual O
disability O
( O
IQ O
> O
80 O
) O
were O
included O
in O
the O
analyses O
: O
34 O
HC O
, O
33 O
ASD O
, O
and O
33 O
SZ O
( O
including O
six O
diagnosed O
with O
schizoaffective O
disorder O
) O
. O

Participants O
were O
recruited O
via O
Olin O
Neuropsychiatry O
Research O
Center O
( O
ONRC O
) O
and O
Yale O
University O
School O
of O
Medicine O
. O

Data O
were O
selected O
from O
a O
larger O
collected O
sample O
so O
that O
groups O
matched O
on O
age O
and O
sex O
. O

Inclusion/exclusion O
criteria O
are O
provided O
in O
Appendix O
1 O
. O

Clinical O
assessment O
Severity O
of O
positive O
and O
negative O
symptoms O
and O
general O
psychopathology O
were O
assessed O
using O
the O
Positive O
and O
Negative O
Syndrome O
Scale O
( O
PANSS O
) O
in O
patients O
. O

To O
assess O
sub-clinical O
symptoms O
in O
HC O
, O
the O
self-report O
Schizotypal O
Personality O
Questionnaire O
( O
SPQ O
, O
) O
was O
used O
. O

Social O
behavior O
was O
assessed O
using O
the O
Autism O
Diagnostic O
Observation O
Schedule O
module O
4 O
total O
score O
( O
ADOS-T O
) O
. O

IQ O
was O
estimated O
using O
the O
Wechsler O
Adult O
Intelligence O
Scale O
( O
WAIS-III O
) O
- O
vocabulary O
and O
block O
design O
subscales O
. O

Imaging O
data O
acquisition O
All O
fMRI O
scans O
were O
performed O
on O
a O
Siemens O
Skyra O
3 O
T O
scanner O
at O
ONRC O
. O

Participants O
lay O
with O
eyes O
open O
, O
fixating O
on O
a O
centrally O
presented O
cross O
for O
7.5 O
min O
. O

Blood O
oxygenation O
level O
dependent O
( O
BOLD O
) O
signal O
was O
obtained O
with O
T2 O
* O
-weighted O
echo O
planar O
imaging O
( O
EPI O
) O
sequence O
: O
TR/TE O
= O
475/30 O
msec O
, O
flip-angle O
= O
600 O
, O
48 O
slices O
, O
multiband O
( O
8 O
) O
, O
interleaved O
slice O
order O
, O
3 O
mm3 O
voxels O
. O

Datasets O
portraying O
head O
motion O
> O
10 O
mm O
were O
discarded O
. O

Preprocessing O
fMRI O
data O
were O
preprocessed O
using O
SPM8 O
( O
www.fil.ion.ucl.ac.uk/spm/software/spm8/ O
) O
. O

Each O
individual O
's O
dataset O
was O
realigned O
to O
the O
first O
T2 O
* O
image O
using O
the O
INRIAlign O
toolbox O
( O
https O
: O
//www-sop.inria.fr/epidaure/Collaborations/IRMf/INRIAlign.html O
) O
, O
coregistered O
to O
their O
high O
signal-to-noise O
single-band O
reference O
image O
( O
sbREF O
) O
, O
spatially O
normalized O
to O
the O
Montreal O
Neurological O
Institute O
( O
MNI O
) O
standard O
template O
, O
and O
spatially O
smoothed O
( O
9 O
mm3 O
) O
. O

Group O
ICA O
and O
post-processing O
Imaging O
data O
were O
decomposed O
into O
independent O
components O
( O
ICs O
) O
in O
a O
data-driven O
manner O
, O
using O
group-level O
spatial O
ICA O
, O
via O
the O
GIFT O
toolbox O
( O
; O
http O
: O
//mialab.mrn.org/software/gift O
) O
. O

High-order O
model O
( O
100 O
components O
) O
was O
used O
, O
and O
subject-specific O
data-reduction O
principle O
component O
analysis O
( O
PCA O
) O
was O
set O
to O
150 O
, O
in O
accordance O
with O
Erhardt O
et O
al O
.. O

The O
Infomax O
group O
ICA O
algorithm O
was O
iterated O
using O
ICASSO O
and O
the O
most O
central O
run O
was O
selected O
for O
further O
analysis O
. O

Subject-specific O
spatial O
maps O
( O
SMs O
) O
and O
time-courses O
were O
estimated O
using O
the O
GICA3 O
back-reconstruction O
method O
. O

Out O
of O
the O
100 O
components O
obtained O
, O
we O
identified O
56 O
components O
as O
physiologically O
relevant O
ICNs O
( O
rather O
than O
noise O
) O
, O
based O
on O
the O
following O
: O
peak O
cluster O
locations O
in O
gray O
matter O
with O
minimal O
overlap O
with O
either O
white O
matter O
, O
ventricles O
or O
edges O
of O
the O
brain O
, O
and O
a O
high O
ratio O
of O
low-frequency/high-frequency O
activity O
. O

Components O
were O
then O
labeled O
using O
the O
Desikan-Killiany-Tourville O
( O
DKT O
) O
atlas O
, O
the O
Allen O
Brain O
Atlas O
and O
the O
Automated O
Anatomical O
Labeling O
( O
AAL O
) O
atlas O
as O
implemented O
in O
xjview O
( O
http O
: O
//www.alivelearn.net/xjview8 O
) O
, O
in O
addition O
to O
MRICron O
( O
http O
: O
//www.mccauslandcenter.sc.edu/mricro/mricron O
) O
for O
visualization O
of O
results O
. O

ICs O
were O
organized O
into O
functional O
networks O
, O
in O
a O
data-driven O
manner O
: O
pairwise O
correlations O
were O
computed O
between O
ICs O
' O
time-courses O
in O
GIFT O
, O
reflecting O
static O
functional O
network O
connectivity O
( O
sFNC O
) O
. O

The O
sFNC O
matrix O
was O
then O
partitioned O
using O
the O
community O
Louvain O
algorithm O
from O
the O
brain O
connectivity O
toolbox O
( O
https O
: O
//sites.google.com/site/bctnet/ O
) O
, O
which O
maximizes O
within-group O
edges O
, O
and O
minimizes O
between-group O
edges O
. O

Motion O
correction O
Following O
the O
exclusion O
of O
high-motion O
participants O
from O
the O
analysis O
, O
the O
following O
steps O
were O
taken O
: O
ICA O
artifact O
rejection O
served O
as O
the O
first O
denoising O
step O
. O

ICA O
has O
been O
shown O
to O
successfully O
remove O
motion-related O
noise O
from O
fMRI O
data O
( O
e.g O
. O
) O

and O
has O
the O
added O
benefit O
of O
leaving O
the O
integrity O
of O
the O
fMRI O
time-series O
intact O
. O

Subsequently O
, O
IC O
time-courses O
were O
detrended O
and O
despiked O
using O
3D-despike O
via O
AFNI O
( O
https O
: O
//afni.nimh.nih.gov/ O
) O
, O
and O
low-pass O
filtered O
with O
0.15 O
Hz O
cutoff O
. O

Despiking O
replaced O
data O
points O
larger O
than O
the O
absolute O
median O
deviation O
with O
a O
third O
order O
spline O
fit O
to O
the O
clean O
portions O
of O
the O
data O
. O

This O
is O
similar O
to O
the O
“ O
scrubbing O
” O
method O
, O
with O
the O
advantage O
that O
it O
does O
not O
eliminate O
volumes O
that O
would O
disrupt O
temporal O
continuity O
which O
is O
crucial O
for O
a O
dFNC O
analysis O
. O

Previous O
research O
has O
shown O
that O
despiking O
decreases O
outlier O
impact O
on O
FC O
analyses O
. O

Motion O
was O
then O
regressed O
out O
of O
the O
data O
during O
dFNC O
processing O
using O
six O
realignment O
parameters O
. O

The O
combination O
of O
these O
strategies O
provides O
an O
effective O
combination O
of O
linear O
and O
non-linear O
motion O
reduction O
. O

To O
rule O
out O
an O
association O
between O
extent O
of O
motion O
to O
our O
parameters O
of O
interest O
at O
the O
individual O
level O
, O
we O
conducted O
spearman O
's O
correlations O
between O
dFNC O
indices O
and O
participants O
' O
mean O
framewise-displacement O
( O
root O
mean O
square O
; O
appendix O
3 O
) O
. O

Finally O
, O
we O
repeated O
our O
main O
analyses O
controlling O
for O
framewise-displacement O
, O
to O
ensure O
that O
results O
were O
not O
driven O
by O
group O
differences O
in O
motion O
. O

Dynamic O
functional O
network O
connectivity O
( O
dFNC O
) O
dFNC O
was O
computed O
using O
a O
sliding O
window O
approach O
, O
instantiated O
in O
the O
dFNC O
toolbox O
in O
GIFT O
( O
as O
illustrated O
in O
Fig O
. O

1 O
) O
. O

Window O
size O
was O
set O
to O
70 O
TRs O
( O
33.25 O
s O
) O
, O
with O
a O
step-size O
of O
1 O
TR O
. O

Covariance O
was O
then O
calculated O
per O
window O
, O
between O
all O
pairwise O
ICs O
for O
each O
participant O
. O

The O
optimal O
number O
of O
distinct O
connectivity O
states O
was O
estimated O
, O
by O
conducting O
k-means O
analyses O
with O
a O
range O
k O
= O
2–10 O
and O
comparing O
the O
cluster O
validity O
index O
( O
Appendix O
4 O
) O
. O

The O
identified O
optimal O
number O
of O
clusters O
was O
four O
. O

Subsequently O
, O
k-means O
clustering O
( O
k O
= O
4 O
) O
was O
applied O
to O
the O
individual O
arrays O
of O
FNC O
covariance O
matrices O
( O
using O
the O
City O
method O
and O
L1 O
norm O
) O
. O

Fraction O
time O
( O
FT O
) O
- O
percentage O
of O
overall O
time O
spent O
in O
each O
state O
; O
Dwell O
time O
( O
DT O
) O
- O
average O
duration O
of O
time O
spent O
in O
each O
state O
before O
transitioning O
to O
the O
next O
state O
; O
Number O
of O
transitions O
( O
NT O
) O
- O
number O
of O
times O
a O
participant O
switched O
between O
states O
; O
Number O
of O
states O
( O
NS O
) O
- O
number O
of O
different O
states O
entered O
; O
State O
engagement O
( O
SE O
) O
- O
whether O
each O
particular O
state O
was O
entered O
. O

For O
each O
participant O
several O
dFNC O
indices O
were O
computed O
: O
Group O
differences O
Statistical O
analyses O
were O
conducted O
in O
IBM O
SPSS O
v.21 O
. O

Data O
of O
one O
ASD O
participant O
was O
excluded O
due O
to O
diagnostic O
ambiguity O
, O
thus O
statistical O
analyses O
included O
n O
= O
99 O
. O

Univariate O
ANOVAs O
were O
conducted O
to O
compare O
age O
, O
ADOS O
, O
PANSS O
and O
WAIS O
between O
the O
groups O
, O
and O
followed O
by O
post-hoc O
tests O
when O
found O
significant O
. O

For O
sex O
, O
chi-square O
test O
was O
used O
. O

To O
assess O
group O
differences O
in O
dFNC O
ordinal O
indices O
, O
Welch O
's O
ANOVAs O
were O
used O
. O

Welch O
's O
is O
a O
more O
stringent O
variation O
of O
ANOVA O
, O
suitable O
in O
cases O
of O
unequal O
group O
sizes O
, O
and/or O
unequal O
homogeneity O
of O
variance O
. O

When O
found O
significant O
, O
concurrent O
Games-Howell O
post-hoc O
tests O
were O
conducted O
. O

ANOVAs O
were O
chosen O
over O
a O
MANOVA O
given O
the O
different O
N O
sizes O
within O
the O
states O
( O
and O
choice O
of O
Welch O
's O
test O
) O
. O

For O
SE O
( O
nominal O
) O
, O
chi-square O
( O
Fischer O
's O
exact O
test O
) O
was O
conducted O
. O

To O
test O
for O
possible O
associations O
between O
dFNC O
results O
and O
medication O
intake O
as O
well O
as O
IQ O
score O
, O
sensitivity O
analyses O
were O
performed O
( O
Appendix O
5 O
) O
. O

Correlation O
with O
symptoms O
Spearman O
's O
correlations O
were O
calculated O
between O
ordinal O
dFNC O
indices O
( O
DT2 O
, O
DT3 O
, O
