FT1 O
, O
FT2 O
, O
FT3 O
, O
NT O
) O
and O
ADOS-T O
and O
PANSS O
( O
subscales O
and O
total O
) O
scores O
, O
in O
the O
combined O
clinical O
sample O
. O

Significant O
results O
were O
followed O
by O
correlation O
analyses O
within O
each O
group O
. O

DT1 O
was O
not O
included O
the O
correlation O
analysis O
as O
it O
had O
a O
small O
sample O
( O
N O
= O
12 O
) O
. O

NS O
was O
also O
not O
included O
since O
it O
had O
a O
binary O
result O
( O
3/4 O
) O
in O
most O
participants O
. O

Classification O
analysis O
Classification O
was O
conducted O
using O
three-way O
linear O
discriminant O
analysis O
( O
DA O
) O
, O
with O
diagnostic O
group O
as O
the O
grouping O
variable O
, O
and O
all O
dFNC O
indices O
as O
independent O
variables O
except O
for O
DT O
( O
DT O
could O
not O
be O
included O
, O
since O
participants O
that O
did O
not O
enter O
a O
specific O
state O
have O
no O
dwell O
time O
value O
for O
that O
state O
. O

DA O
analyses O
mandate O
entries O
for O
all O
data O
points O
) O
. O

Leave-one-out O
cross-validation O
was O
performed O
. O

Additionally O
, O
DA O
was O
repeated O
using O
NT O
as O
the O
only O
independent O
variable O
, O
to O
provide O
a O
simple O
generalizable O
version O
that O
does O
n't O
depend O
on O
the O
specifics O
of O
the O
states O
. O

NT O
was O
chosen O
for O
this O
single-parameter O
classification O
since O
it O
is O
the O
most O
generalizable O
of O
all O
parameters- O
not O
depending O
on O
the O
specifics O
of O
the O
states O
or O
the O
number O
of O
different O
states O
. O

Distance O
from O
cluster O
centroid O
( O
i.e. O
, O
the O
distance O
of O
each O
participant O
's O
discriminant O
scores O
from O
the O
centroid O
of O
the O
diagnostic O
group O
to O
which O
they O
belong O
) O
was O
calculated O
, O
and O
compared O
between O
groups O
using O
a O
univariate O
ANOVA O
. O

This O
value O
represents O
disparity O
, O
thus O
reflecting O
homogeneity O
of O
scores O
within O
the O
groups O
. O

Finally O
, O
to O
assess O
symptom O
severity O
differences O
between O
the O
emerging O
clusters O
, O
univariate O
ANOVAs O
were O
performed O
with O
ADOS-T O
and O
PANSS O
( O
total O
score O
and O
subscales O
) O
as O
dependent O
variables O
. O

When O
significant O
, O
ANOVA O
was O
followed O
by O
simple-effects O
analysis O
to O
asses O
within O
each O
diagnostic O
group O
, O
whether O
correct- O
vs. O
miss-classified O
individuals O
differed O
in O
symptoms O
( O
data O
of O
the O
one O
SZ O
participant O
that O
was O
misclassified O
as O
HC O
was O
excluded O
from O
this O
analysis O
, O
to O
refrain O
from O
biasing O
results O
by O
a O
single-case O
cell O
) O
. O

To O
compare O
HCs O
that O
were O
correctly O
classified O
vs. O
misclassified O
, O
a O
t-test O
was O
conducted O
comparing O
SPQ O
total O
score O
. O

Evidence O
for O
cerebello-thalamo-cortical O
hyperconnectivity O
as O
a O
heritable O
trait O
for O
schizophrenia O
Our O
recent O
study O
has O
demonstrated O
that O
increased O
connectivity O
in O
the O
cerebello-thalamo-cortical O
( O
CTC O
) O
circuitry O
is O
a O
state-independent O
neural O
trait O
that O
can O
potentially O
predict O
the O
onset O
of O
psychosis O
. O

One O
possible O
cause O
of O
such O
“ O
trait O
” O
abnormality O
would O
be O
genetic O
predisposition O
. O

Here O
, O
we O
tested O
this O
hypothesis O
using O
multi-paradigm O
functional O
magnetic O
resonance O
imaging O
( O
fMRI O
) O
data O
from O
two O
independent O
twin O
cohorts O
. O

In O
a O
sample O
of O
85 O
monozygotic O
( O
MZ O
) O
and O
52 O
dizygotic O
( O
DZ O
) O
healthy O
twin O
pairs O
acquired O
from O
the O
Human O
Connectome O
Project O
, O
we O
showed O
that O
the O
connectivity O
pattern O
of O
the O
identified O
CTC O
circuitry O
was O
more O
similar O
in O
the O
MZ O
twins O
( O
r O
= O
0.54 O
) O
compared O
with O
that O
in O
the O
DZ O
twins O
( O
r O
= O
0.22 O
) O
. O

The O
structural O
equation O
modeling O
analysis O
revealed O
a O
heritability O
estimate O
of O
0.52 O
for O
the O
CTC O
connectivity O
, O
suggesting O
a O
moderately O
strong O
genetic O
effect O
. O

Moreover O
, O
using O
an O
independent O
schizophrenia O
cotwin O
sample O
( O
10 O
discordant O
MZ O
cotwins O
, O
30 O
discordant O
DZ O
cotwins O
, O
and O
32 O
control O
cotwins O
) O
, O
we O
observed O
a O
significant O
linear O
relationship O
between O
genetic O
distance O
to O
schizophrenia O
and O
the O
connectivity O
strength O
in O
the O
CTC O
circuitry O
( O
i.e. O
, O
schizophrenia O
MZ O
cotwins O
> O
schizophrenia O
DZ O
cotwins O
> O
control O
twins O
, O
P O
= O
0.045 O
) O
. O

The O
present O
data O
provide O
converging O
evidence O
that O
increased O
connectivity O
in O
the O
CTC O
circuitry O
is O
likely O
to O
be O
a O
heritable O
trait O
that O
is O
associated O
with O
the O
genetic O
risk O
of O
schizophrenia O
. O

Methods O
Subjects O
Two O
independent O
twin O
data O
sets O
were O
used O
in O
this O
study O
: O
the O
HCP O
twin O
sample O
and O
the O
STAR O
sample O
. O

The O
HCP O
data O
included O
a O
total O
of O
137 O
healthy O
twin O
pairs O
that O
have O
completed O
all O
eight O
fMRI O
paradigms O
used O
in O
the O
project O
( O
resting O
state O
, O
gambling O
, O
emotional O
processing O
, O
motor O
, O
working O
memory O
, O
relational O
processing O
, O
language O
processing O
, O
and O
social O
cognition O
) O
and O
have O
genotyping O
data O
available O
. O

Among O
these O
twin O
pairs O
, O
85 O
were O
MZ O
( O
age O
29.32 O
± O
3.39 O
years O
, O
70 O
males O
) O
and O
52 O
were O
DZ O
( O
age O
28.50 O
± O
3.50 O
years O
, O
52 O
males O
) O
. O

The O
STAR O
sample O
comprised O
of O
40 O
schizophrenia O
discordant O
cotwins O
( O
10 O
MZ O
, O
age O
43.79 O
± O
11.94 O
years O
, O
7 O
males O
; O
30 O
DZ O
, O
age O
51.11 O
± O
10.07 O
years O
, O
16 O
males O
) O
and O
32 O
healthy O
control O
twins O
( O
46.37 O
± O
6.92 O
years O
, O
14 O
males O
) O
, O
each O
assessed O
with O
a O
battery O
of O
two O
fMRI O
paradigms O
( O
working O
memory O
, O
emotional O
processing O
) O
. O

The O
zygosity O
in O
both O
data O
sets O
was O
determined O
by O
genotyping O
data O
from O
subjects O
’ O
blood O
samples O
. O

The O
STAR O
participants O
were O
recruited O
through O
the O
Swedish O
Twin O
Registry O
and O
were O
evaluated O
by O
psychiatrists O
using O
the O
Structured O
Clinical O
Interview O
for O
DSM-IV O
. O

The O
exclusion O
criteria O
for O
control O
twins O
included O
prior O
history O
of O
neurological O
or O
psychiatric O
disorders O
, O
head O
injury O
, O
substance O
dependence O
in O
the O
last O
6 O
months O
, O
mental O
retardation O
, O
and O
inability O
to O
read O
or O
comprehend O
Swedish O
. O

All O
schizophrenia O
discordant O
cotwins O
were O
free O
of O
any O
psychotic O
disorders O
according O
to O
the O
DSM-IV O
criteria O
. O

The O
participants O
provided O
written O
informed O
consents O
and O
the O
research O
protocol O
was O
approved O
by O
the O
Regional O
Ethical O
Review O
Board O
in O
Stockholm O
. O

For O
sample O
details O
, O
see O
Tables O
1 O
and O
2 O
. O

Imaging O
paradigms O
A O
total O
of O
eight O
fMRI O
paradigms O
were O
employed O
in O
the O
HCP O
project O
. O

For O
details O
on O
these O
paradigms O
see O
previously O
published O
work O
. O

Notably O
, O
the O
resting-state O
paradigm O
was O
scanned O
with O
four O
sessions O
spanned O
across O
two O
consecutive O
days O
, O
and O
the O
other O
paradigms O
were O
scanned O
with O
two O
sessions O
on O
a O
single O
day O
. O

To O
balance O
the O
amount O
of O
data O
across O
paradigms O
and O
to O
avoid O
overrepresentation O
of O
resting O
state O
in O
the O
following O
cross-paradigm O
computations O
, O
we O
only O
used O
the O
resting-state O
data O
from O
the O
two O
sessions O
acquired O
on O
the O
first O
day O
. O

The O
STAR O
data O
set O
used O
two O
fMRI O
paradigms O
that O
have O
been O
described O
previously O
. O

In O
brief O
, O
the O
spatial O
working O
memory O
task O
used O
an O
event-related O
design O
where O
subjects O
were O
asked O
to O
encode O
the O
location O
of O
three O
target O
circles O
and O
to O
indicate O
whether O
the O
ensuing O
probe O
circle O
appeared O
at O
the O
same O
location O
as O
one O
of O
the O
target O
circles O
. O

During O
the O
block-designed O
emotional O
face O
processing O
task O
, O
subjects O
were O
shown O
a O
series O
of O
emotional O
faces O
and O
geometric O
shapes O
and O
were O
instructed O
to O
match O
either O
the O
target O
faces O
or O
the O
target O
shapes O
. O

Data O
acquisition O
The O
HCP O
data O
were O
collected O
from O
a O
customized O
3T O
Siemens O
Connectome O
scanner O
equipped O
with O
a O
32-channel O
head O
coil O
. O

BOLD O
images O
were O
acquired O
using O
a O
multiband O
GRE-EPI O
sequence O
with O
the O
following O
parameters O
: O
TR O
= O
720 O
ms O
, O
TE O
= O
33.1 O
ms O
, O
FA O
= O
52° O
, O
FOV O
= O
208 O
× O
180 O
mm2 O
, O
2 O
mm O
slice O
thickness O
, O
72 O
slices O
, O
multiband O
factor O
= O
8 O
. O

Of O
note O
, O
unlike O
the O
commonly O
applied O
phase-encoding O
directions O
along O
the O
“ O
anterior-posterior O
” O
axis O
, O
the O
HCP O
fMRI O
data O
were O
acquired O
using O
left-right O
and O
right-left O
phase-encoding O
directions O
to O
accelerate O
scan O
time O
and O
to O
minimize O
image O
distortion O
. O

Each O
paradigm O
was O
scanned O
with O
two O
sessions O
, O
with O
each O
direction O
per O
session O
. O

In O
addition O
, O
T1-weighted O
and O
T2-weighted O
images O
were O
acquired O
using O
3D-MPRAGE O
and O
3D-T2-SPACE O
sequences O
with O
0.7 O
mm O
voxel O
size O
and O
224 O
× O
224 O
mm2 O
FOV O
. O

The O
T1 O
images O
used O
a O
TR O
of O
2400 O
ms O
and O
TE O
of O
2.14 O
ms O
, O
and O
the O
T2 O
images O
used O
a O
TR O
of O
3200 O
ms O
and O
TE O
of O
565 O
ms O
. O

The O
STAR O
data O
were O
acquired O
from O
a O
1.5 O
T O
GE O
scanner O
equipped O
with O
a O
standard O
8-channel O
head O
coil O
. O

GRE-EPI O
sequence O
was O
used O
for O
functional O
imaging O
: O
TR O
= O
2500 O
ms O
, O
TE O
= O
40 O
ms O
, O
FA O
= O
90° O
, O
3.5 O
mm O
slice O
thickness O
, O
voxel O
size O
3.44 O
× O
3.44 O
× O
4.5 O
mm3 O
. O

T2-weighted O
images O
were O
scanned O
using O
a O
spin-echo O
sequence O
with O
4000 O
ms O
TR O
, O
82 O
ms O
TE O
, O
and O
4 O
mm O
slice O
thickness O
. O

Data O
preprocessing O
The O
HCP O
data O
were O
downloaded O
after O
the O
completion O
of O
imaging O
preprocessing O
( O
https O
: O
//db.humanconnectome.org O
) O
. O

The O
preprocessing O
procedure O
followed O
the O
standard O
HCP O
preprocessing O
pipeline O
including O
five O
major O
steps O
: O
PreFreeSurfer O
, O
FreeSurfer O
, O
PostFreeSurfer O
, O
fMRIVolume O
, O
and O
fMRISurface O
. O

In O
brief O
, O
images O
were O
corrected O
for O
gradient O
nonlinearity O
induced O
distortion O
, O
head O
motion O
, O
and O
phase-encoding O
related O
distortion O
, O
registered O
to O
individuals O
’ O
T1-weighted O
images O
, O
and O
normalized O
to O
the O
MNI O
space O
. O

The O
STAR O
data O
were O
preprocessed O
using O
the O
standard O
pipeline O
implemented O
in O
the O
Statistical O
Parametric O
Mapping O
software O
( O
SPM12 O
, O
https O
: O
//www.fil.ion.ucl.ac.uk/spm/software/spm12/ O
) O
, O
including O
slice O
timing O
, O
head O
motion O
realignment O
, O
functional-structural O
image O
coregistration O
, O
MNI O
space O
normalization O
, O
and O
spatial O
smoothing O
. O

All O
preprocessed O
images O
were O
further O
scrutinized O
for O
head O
motion O
using O
the O
measure O
of O
frame-wise O
displacement O
( O
FD O
) O
to O
ensure O
data O
quality O
. O

All O
subjects O
in O
both O
data O
sets O
had O
a O
mean O
FD O
< O
0.5 O
mm O
. O

Cross-paradigm O
connectivity O
and O
extraction O
of O
CTC O
network O
The O
overall O
processing O
pipeline O
of O
this O
study O
is O
presented O
in O
Fig O
. O

1 O
. O

The O
cross-paradigm O
connectivity O
( O
CPC O
) O
computation O
and O
extraction O
of O
CTC O
network O
followed O
our O
prior O
work O
. O

Specifically O
, O
the O
mean O
time O
series O
for O
each O
of O
the O
270 O
nodes O
in O
the O
expanded O
Power O
brain O
atlas O
were O
extracted O
from O
the O
preprocessed O
images O
. O

The O
extracted O
time O
series O
were O
further O
corrected O
for O
task-related O
coactivations O
( O
for O
task O
data O
) O
, O
white O
matter O
and O
cerebrospinal O
fluid O
signals O
, O
the O
24 O
head O
motion O
parameters O
( O
i.e. O
, O
the O
six O
rigid-body O
parameters O
generated O
from O
the O
realignment O
step O
, O
their O
first O
derivatives O
, O
and O
the O
squares O
of O
these O
12 O
parameters O
) O
, O
and O
the O
FD O
. O

The O
corrected O
time O
series O
were O
then O
temporally O
filtered O
( O
task O
data O
: O
0.008 O
Hz O
high O
pass O
, O
rest O
data O
: O
0.008–0.1 O
Hz O
band O
pass O
) O
to O
account O
for O
scanner O
and O
physiological O
noise O
. O

Subsequently O
, O
a O
270 O
× O
270 O
pairwise O
connectivity O
matrix O
was O
generated O
using O
Pearson O
correlation O
for O
each O
subject O
during O
each O
paradigm O
and O
scan O
session O
. O

Following O
prior O
suggestions O
, O
we O
averaged O
the O
derived O
connectivity O
matrices O
across O
the O
two O
sessions O
for O
each O
paradigm O
to O
boost O
signals O
, O
generating O
eight O
paradigm-specific O
connectivity O
matrices O
for O
each O
subject O
in O
the O
HCP O
data O
and O
two O
paradigm-specific O
connectivity O
matrices O
for O
each O
subject O
in O
the O
STAR O
data O
. O

The O
matrices O
for O
each O
subject O
were O
vectorized O
, O
concatenated O
across O
paradigms O
, O
and O
then O
decomposed O
into O
a O
set O
of O
principal O
components O
( O
PCs O
) O
using O
singular O
value O
decomposition O
( O
SVD O
) O
. O

The O
first O
PCs O
generated O
from O
the O
analysis O
represented O
the O
shared O
CPC O
and O
were O
thus O
extracted O
. O

From O
these O
CPC O
matrices O
we O
further O
extracted O
the O
identified O
CTC O
network O
based O
on O
our O
prior O
work O
. O

Heritability O
estimation O
of O
CTC O
connectivity O
The O
HCP O
data O
were O
employed O
to O
quantify O
heritability O
of O
the O
CTC O
connectivity O
. O

We O
first O
calculated O
the O
similarities O
of O
the O
MZ O
and O
DZ O
twin O
pairs O
using O
intra-class O
correlations O
. O

A O
larger O
correlation O
coefficient O
between O
MZ O
pairs O
compared O
with O
that O
between O
DZ O
pairs O
indicates O
a O
potential O
genetic O
effect O
. O

Since O
the O
MZ O
correlation O
was O
larger O
than O
twice O
of O
the O
DZ O
correlation O
in O
our O
sample O
( O
see O
Results O
section O
) O
, O
we O
estimated O
an O
ADE O
model O
using O
structural O
equation O
modeling O
( O
SEM O
) O
. O

This O
is O
due O
to O
the O
fact O
that O
dominant O
genetic O
effects O
( O
D O
) O
would O
decrease O
the O
DZ O
correlation O
relative O
to O
the O
MZ O
correlation O
. O

Specifically O
, O
using O
the O
SEM O
toolbox O
OpenMx O
implemented O
in O
R O
( O
https O
: O
//openmx.ssri.psu.edu/ O
) O
, O
we O
decomposed O
the O
total O
variance O
of O
phenotype O
into O
additive O
genetic O
effects O
( O
A O
) O
, O
dominant O
genetic O
effects O
( O
D O
) O
, O
and O
unique O
environmental O
effects O
( O
E O
) O
. O

In O
general O
, O
the O
MZ O
twins O
share O
100 O
% O
of O
additive O
and O
dominant O
genetic O
effects O
, O
while O
the O
DZ O
twins O
share O
50 O
% O
and O
25 O
% O
of O
additive O
and O
dominant O
genetic O
effects O
, O
respectively O
. O

Based O
on O
this O
information O
, O
we O
estimated O
the O
squares O
of O
each O
path O
coefficients O
( O
a2 O
, O
d2 O
, O
e2 O
) O
that O
reflect O
the O
proportion O
of O
phenotypic O
variation O
attributable O
to O
the O
A O
, O
D O
, O
E O
effects O
, O
respectively O
. O

This O
was O
done O
by O
iteratively O
maximizing O
the O
log-likelihood O
between O
observed O
and O
predicted O
covariance O
matrices O
. O

The O
goodness-of-fit O
of O
the O
estimated O
model O
was O
quantified O
by O
−2 O
times O
the O
log-likelihood O
( O
−2LL O
, O
ref O
. O
) O

as O
well O
as O
the O
Akaike O
Information O
Criterion O
( O
AIC O
, O
ref O
. O

) O
, O
and O
was O
compared O
to O
the O
saturated O
model O
in O
which O
all O
covariances O
were O
treated O
as O
free O
parameters O
using O
Chi-squared O
test O
. O

A O
non-significant O
P O
value O
( O
> O
0.05 O
) O
indicates O
a O
good O
model O
fit O
. O

Moreover O
, O
the O
full O
ADE O
model O
was O
further O
compared O
with O
nested O
AE O
, O
DE O
, O
and O
E O
models O
, O
and O
the O
most O
parsimonious O
model O
was O
determined O
by O
the O
one O
with O
the O
smallest O
−2LL O
and O
AIC O
values O
. O

Heritability O
( O
h2 O
) O
was O
subsequently O
quantified O
as O
the O
proportion O
of O
phenotypic O
variance O
attributable O
to O
genetic O
effects O
in O
the O
most O
parsimonious O
model O
. O

Association O
of O
CTC O
connectivity O
with O
schizophrenia O
genetic O
risk O
We O
examined O
the O
association O
between O
CTC O
connectivity O
and O
genetic O
risk O
of O
schizophrenia O
in O
the O
STAR O
data O
. O

Specifically O
, O
a O
linear O
regression O
model O
was O
employed O
where O
CTC O
connectivity O
was O
included O
as O
dependent O
variable O
and O
genetic O
proximity O
to O
schizophrenia O
( O
i.e. O
, O
schizophrenia O
MZ O
cotwins O
> O
schizophrenia O
DZ O
cotwins O
> O
control O
twins O
) O
, O
age O
, O
sex O
, O
and O
FD O
were O
included O
as O
regressors O
. O

A O
significant O
regression O
coefficient O
for O
genetic O
proximity O
indicates O
that O
CTC O
connectivity O
is O
associated O
with O
schizophrenia O
genetic O
risk O
. O

Since O
the O
size O
of O
STAR O
sample O
was O
relatively O
small O
, O
we O
further O
included O
all O
twins O
in O
the O
HCP O
sample O
as O
controls O
in O
the O
regression O
model O
. O

To O
control O
for O
discrepancy O
between O
the O
two O
data O
sets O
, O
cohort O
was O
included O
as O
an O
additional O
regressor O
in O
the O
model O
for O
the O
combined O
sample O
. O

Convergence O
of O
three O
parcellation O
approaches O
demonstrating O
cerebellar O
lobule O
volume O
deficits O
in O
Alcohol O
Use O
Disorder O
Recent O
advances O
in O
robust O
and O
reliable O
methods O
of O
MRI-derived O
cerebellar O
lobule O
parcellation O
volumetry O
present O
the O
opportunity O
to O
assess O
effects O
of O
Alcohol O
Use O
Disorder O
( O
AUD O
) O
on O
selective O
cerebellar O
lobules O
and O
relations O
with O
indices O
of O
nutrition O
and O
motor O
functions O
. O

In O
pursuit O
of O
this O
opportunity O
, O
we O
analyzed O
high-resolution O
MRI O
data O
acquired O
in O
24 O
individuals O
with O
AUD O
and O
20 O
age- O
and O
sex-matched O
controls O
with O
a O
32-channel O
head O
coil O
using O
three O
different O
atlases O
: O
the O
online O
automated O
analysis O
pipeline O
volBrain O
Ceres O
, O
SUIT O
, O
and O
the O
Johns O
Hopkins O
atlas O
. O

Participants O
had O
also O
completed O
gait O
and O
balance O
examination O
and O
hematological O
analysis O
of O
nutritional O
and O
liver O
status O
, O
enabling O
testing O
of O
functional O
meaningfulness O
of O
each O
cerebellar O
parcellation O
scheme O
. O

Compared O
with O
controls O
, O
each O
quantification O
approach O
yielded O
similar O
patterns O
of O
group O
differences O
in O
regional O
volumes O
: O
All O
three O
approaches O
identified O
AUD-related O
deficits O
in O
total O
tissue O
and O
total O
gray O
matter O
, O
but O
only O
Ceres O
identified O
a O
total O
white O
matter O
volume O
deficit O
. O

Convergent O
volume O
differences O
occurred O
in O
lobules O
I-V O
, O
Crus O
I O
, O
VIIIB O
, O
and O
IX O
. O

Coefficients O
of O
variation O
( O
CVs O
) O
were O
< O
20 O
% O
for O
46 O
of O
56 O
regions O
measured O
and O
in O
general O
were O
graded O
: O
Ceres O
< O
SUIT O
< O
Hopkins O
. O

The O
most O
robust O
correlations O
were O
identified O
between O
poorer O
stability O
in O
balancing O
on O
one O
leg O
and O
smaller O
lobule O
VI O
and O
Crus O
I O
volumes O
from O
the O
Ceres O
atlas O
. O

Lower O
values O
of O
two O
essential O
vitamins—thiamine O
( O
vitamin O
B1 O
) O
and O
serum O
folate O
( O
vitamin O
B9 O
) O
—along O
with O
lower O
red O
blood O
cell O
count O
, O
which O
are O
dependent O
on O
adequate O
levels O
of O
B O
vitamins O
, O
correlated O
with O
smaller O
gray O
matter O
volumes O
of O
lobule O
VI O
and O
Crus O
I O
. O

Higher O
γ-glutamyl O
transferase O
( O
GGT O
) O
levels O
, O
possibly O
reflecting O
compromised O
liver O
function O
, O
correlated O
with O
smaller O
volumes O
of O
lobules O
VI O
and O
X O
. O

These O
initial O
results O
based O
on O
high O
resolution O
data O
produced O
with O
clinically O
practical O
imaging O
procedures O
hold O
promise O
for O
expanding O
our O
knowledge O
about O
the O
relevance O
of O
focal O
cerebellar O
morphology O
in O
AUD O
and O
other O
neuropsychiatric O
conditions O
. O

Highlights O
Ceres O
, O
SUIT O
, O
and O
Johns O
Hopkins O
atlases O
quantified O
cerebellar O
lobules O
. O

Coefficients O
of O
variation O
( O
CVs O
) O
were O
< O
20 O
% O
for O
46 O
of O
56 O
regions O
measured O
. O

CVs O
were O
graded O
: O
Ceres O
< O
SUIT O
< O
Hopkins O
. O

Convergent O
volume O
deficits O
in O
alcoholics O
occurred O
in O
lobules O
I-V O
, O
Crus O
I O
, O
VIIIB O
, O
IX O
. O

Greater O
instability O
correlated O
with O
smaller O
lobule O
VI O
volumes O
across O
methods O
. O

Material O
and O
methods O
Participants O
MRI O
data O
were O
available O
for O
24 O
alcoholics O
( O
17 O
men O
, O
7 O
women O
) O
and O
20 O
controls O
( O
13 O
men O
, O
7 O
women O
) O
, O
age O
39 O
to O
74 O
years O
. O

As O
stated O
previously O
and O
summarized O
next O
, O
all O
participants O
provided O
written O
informed O
consent O
to O
partake O
in O
this O
study O
, O
which O
was O
conducted O
with O
the O
approval O
of O
the O
Institutional O
Review O
Boards O
of O
Stanford O
University O
and O
SRI O
International O
. O

Participants O
received O
a O
stipend O
of O
$ O
200 O
for O
completing O
the O
study O
. O

All O
but O
2 O
control O
participants O
underwent O
interviews O
with O
the O
Structured O
Clinical O
Interview O
for O
DSM-IV O
revised O
by O
research O
clinicians O
in O
our O
laboratory O
to O
determine O
eligibility O
for O
the O
study O
and O
for O
MRI O
scanning O
. O

Interviews O
also O
included O
structured O
health O
questionnaires O
, O
a O
semi-structured O
timeline O
follow-back O
interview O
to O
quantify O
lifetime O
alcohol O
consumption O
( O
Skinner O
, O
1982 O
; O
Skinner O
and O
Sheu O
, O
1982 O
) O
, O
and O
the O
Clinical O
Institute O
Withdrawal O
Assessment O
for O
Alcohol O
( O
CIWA O
) O
. O

Subjects O
were O
excluded O
for O
significant O
history O
of O
medical O
( O
e.g. O
, O
epilepsy O
, O
stroke O
, O
multiple O
sclerosis O
, O
uncontrolled O
diabetes O
, O
or O
loss O
of O
consciousness O
> O
30 O
min O
) O
, O
psychiatric O
( O
i.e. O
, O
schizophrenia O
or O
bipolar O
I O
disorder O
) O
, O
or O
neurological O
disorders O
( O
e.g. O
, O
neurodegenerative O
disease O
) O
. O

Each O
participant O
also O
underwent O
a O
blood O
draw O
and O
a O
neuropsychological O
test O
battery O
. O

Blood O
samples O
( O
~40 O
cc O
) O
were O
collected O
and O
analyzed O
by O
Quest O
Diagnostics O
for O
complete O
blood O
count O
with O
differential O
, O
comprehensive O
metabolic O
panel O
, O
and O
human O
immunodeficiency O
virus O
( O
HIV O
) O
and O
hepatitis O
C O
( O
HCV O
) O
screening O
, O
which O
identified O
2 O
controls O
and O
4 O
AUD O
subjects O
to O
be O
seropositive O
for O
hepatitis O
C O
virus O
( O
HCV O
) O
infection O
. O

The O
total O
lifetime O
alcohol O
consumption O
of O
the O
AUD O
group O
was O
> O
30 O
times O
that O
of O
the O
controls O
. O

Further O
, O
the O
AUD O
group O
had O
fewer O
years O
of O
education O
, O
had O
lower O
socioeconomic O
status O
, O
and O
endorsed O
more O
depressive O
symptoms O
than O
the O
controls O
. O

Compared O
with O
controls O
, O
more O
AUD O
participants O
were O
African O
American O
and O
were O
cigarette O
smokers O
. O

Group O
demographic O
and O
hematological O
descriptive O
statistics O
appear O
in O
Table O
1 O
. O

Of O
the O
24 O
alcoholics O
, O
9 O
( O
37.5 O
% O
) O
had O
a O
lifetime O
history O
of O
Major O
Depressive O
Disorder O
; O
however O
, O
all O
nine O
were O
in O
remission O
at O
the O
time O
of O
assessment O
, O
and O
none O
had O
current O
depression O
. O

In O
addition O
, O
12 O
alcoholics O
( O
50.0 O
% O
) O
had O
a O
lifetime O
history O
of O
an O
anxiety O
disorder O
; O
10 O
or O
the O
12 O
had O
a O
current O
anxiety O
disorder O
. O

Further O
, O
18 O
alcoholics O
had O
a O
lifetime O
history O
of O
DSM-IV O
substance O
abuse/dependence O
, O
but O
all O
18 O
were O
in O
remission O
( O
remission O
range O
= O
9 O
to O
2099 O
weeks O
, O
mean O
± O
SD O
= O
515.7 O
± O
728.8 O
weeks O
; O
median O
= O
70 O
weeks O
. O

The O
most O
common O
substance O
of O
abuse O
was O
cocaine O
, O
occurring O
in O
12 O
of O
the O
18 O
with O
substance O
abuse/dependence O
. O

MRI O
acquisition O
parameters O
MRI O
structural O
data O
were O
acquired O
in O
the O
sagittal O
plane O
on O
a O
3 O
T O
General O
Electric O
( O
GE O
) O
Discovery O
MR750 O
( O
GE O
Healthcare O
Systems O
, O
Waukesha O
, O
MI O
) O
with O
an O
Array O
Spatial O
Sensitivity O
Encoding O
Technique O
( O
ASSET O
) O
for O
parallel O
and O
accelerated O
imaging O
with O
a O
32-channel O
head O
coil O
( O
Nova O
Medical O
, O
Wilmington O
, O
MA O
) O
. O

T1-weighted O
scans O
were O
cerebral O
spinal O
fluid O
( O
CSF O
) O
-nulled O
Magnetization O
Prepared O
Rapid O
Gradient O
echo O
( O
MPRAGE O
) O
acquired O
with O
the O
following O
parameters O
: O
TR O
= O
8 O
ms O
, O
TE O
= O
3.5 O
ms O
, O
TI O
= O
1100 O
ms O
, O
TS O
( O
i.e. O
, O
time O
between O
two O
successive O
inversion O
pulses O
) O
= O
3.0 O
s O
, O
Flip O
Angle O
= O
9 O
, O
FOV O
= O
18 O
cm O
, O
matrix O
= O
200 O
× O
200 O
, O
thick O
= O
1 O
mm O
, O
slices O
= O
210 O
slices O
, O
resolution O
= O
0.9 O
× O
0.9 O
× O
1.0 O
. O

T2-weighted O
scans O
were O
3D O
fast O
spin-echo O
with O
variable O
refocusing O
flip O
angle O
( O
T2 O
Cube O
) O
and O
acquired O
with O
the O
following O
parameters O
: O
Fat O
Sat O
= O
ON O
, O
TR O
= O
3500 O
ms O
, O
Effective O
TE O
= O
62 O
ms O
, O
Echo O
Train O
Length O
( O
ETL O
) O
= O
84 O
, O
FOV O
= O
18 O
cm O
, O
matrix O
= O
224 O
× O
224 O
, O
thick O
= O
1 O
mm O
, O
slices O
= O
210 O
, O
resolution O
= O
0.8×.08 O
× O
1.0 O
. O

Acquisition O
extended O
from O
ear O
to O
ear O
and O
from O
the O
top O
of O
scalp O
to O
the O
base O
of O
cerebellum O
. O

The O
T1-weighted O
scans O
yielded O
excellent O
gray/white O
tissue O
conspicuity O
, O
and O
the O
T2 O
scans O
provided O
full O
information O
about O
brain O
volume O
, O
especially O
when O
cortical O
and O
cerebellar O
tissue O
shrinkage O
is O
replaced O
by O
CSF O
, O
as O
occurs O
in O
disorders O
such O
as O
AUD O
. O

MRI O
analysis O
The O
T1-weighted O
( O
T1w O
) O
and O
T2-weighted O
( O
T2w O
) O
MRIs O
of O
each O
participant O
were O
first O
processed O
via O
our O
laboratory O
pipeline O
using O
FreeSurfer O
6.0 O
. O

Preprocessing O
of O
the O
T1w O
and O
T2w O
MRI O
data O
involved O
noise O
removal O
, O
correcting O
field O
inhomogeneity O
using O
N4ITK O
, O
aligning O
T2w O
to O
T1w O
MRIs O
using O
CMTK O
, O
repeating O
image O
inhomogeneity O
correction O
of O
both O
modalities O
confined O
to O
the O
brain O
mask O
defined O
by O
aligning O
SRI24 O
atlas O
to O
T1w O
MRI O
using O
the O
symmetric O
, O
diffeomorphic O
non-rigid O
registration O
called O
ANTS O
. O

The O
brain O
mask O
was O
refined O
with O
FSL O
BET O
applied O
to O
bias O
corrected O
T2w O
images O
. O

Using O
the O
refined O
masked O
, O
we O
repeated O
the O
image O
inhomogeneity O
correction O
. O

Whole O
brain O
imaging O
enabled O
quantification O
of O
the O
total O
intracranial O
volume O
( O
ICV O
) O
to O
serve O
as O
control O
for O
normal O
variation O
in O
headsize O
. O

Cerebellar O
parcellation O
of O
lobular O
gray O
matter O
volumes O
Ceres O
Cerebellar O
segmentation O
was O
accomplished O
with O
Ceres O
. O

T1 O
data O
were O
uploaded O
and O
retrieved O
from O
[ O
http O
: O
//volbrain.upv.es O
] O
. O

Data O
comprised O
left O
and O
right O
measures O
of O
the O
whole O
cerebellum O
volume O
and O
gray O
matter O
, O
and O
12 O
lobules O
( O
I O
+ O
II O
, O
III O
, O
IV O
, O
V O
, O
VI O
, O
Crus O
I O
, O
Crus O
II O
, O
VIIB O
, O
VIIIA O
, O
VIIIB O
, O
IX O
, O
X O
) O
. O

For O
comparison O
with O
SUIT O
output O
, O
we O
summed O
the O
volumes O
of O
I O
to O
IV O
; O
for O
comparison O
with O
Hopkins O
output O
, O
we O
summed O
the O
volumes O
of O
lobules O
I O
to O
V. O
Cerebellar O
volume O
of O
the O
total O
white O
matter O
was O
determined O
from O
the O
difference O
between O
whole O
volume O
and O
whole O
gray O
matter O
volume O
. O

In-house O
software O
extracted O
volumetric O
data O
from O
the O
downloaded O
Ceres O
result O
tables O
; O
pdf O
rendering O
of O
Ceres O
fits O
were O
inspected O
for O
quality O
, O
and O
all O
images O
were O
acceptable O
. O

Included O
in O
the O
Ceres O
downloads O
were O
estimates O
of O
SNR O
and O
ICV O
. O

Only O
data O
with O
SNR O
> O
20 O
were O
considered O
usable O
. O

Our O
32-channel O
MRI O
data O
surpassed O
the O
recommendation O
with O
SNR O
ranging O
from O
22.7 O
to O
89.8 O
across O
the O
two O
groups O
( O
AUD O
mean O
= O
48.7 O
; O
control O
mean O
= O
56.2 O
) O
. O

The O
ICV O
from O
T2-weighted O
masking O
was O
used O
because O
CSF-nulled O
T1 O
scan O
produced O
too O
vigorous O
skull O
stripping O
via O
Ceres O
. O

Fig O
. O

1 O
displays O
an O
example O
segmentation O
and O
parcellation O
of O
regions O
from O
a O
single O
case O
. O

Fig O
. O

2 O
displays O
plots O
of O
total O
cerebellar O
tissue O
, O
gray O
matter O
, O
and O
white O
matter O
for O
each O
analysis O
approach O
. O

SUIT O
This O
atlas O
enabled O
identification O
and O
volumetry O
of O
total O
cerebellar O
tissue O
, O
gray O
matter O
, O
and O
white O
matter O
. O

Regional O
parcellation O
yielded O
volumes O
of O
10 O
lobules O
: O
I-IV O
, O
V O
, O
VI O
, O
Crus O
I O
, O

, O

, O
VIIIA O
, O
VIIIB O
, O
IX O
, O
and O
X O
( O
Fig O
. O

1B O
) O
. O

The O
software O
is O
an O
open-source O
SPM O
toolbox O
[ O
http O
: O
//www.diedrichsenlab.org/imaging/propatlas.htm O
] O
and O
was O
applied O
to O
the O
skull-stripped O
and O
inhomogeneity-corrected O
T1 O
data O
. O

Johns O
Hopkins O
atlas O
Implementation O
of O
this O
atlas O
required O
the O
cerebellum O
to O
be O
preprocessed O
with O
FreeSurfer O
( O
V5.3 O
) O
and O
then O
parcellelated O
by O
the O
Hopkins O
software O
tool O
, O
which O
combines O
multi-atlas O
segmentation O
with O
the O
graph-cut O
algorithm O
and O
random O
forest O
. O

The O
software O
tool O
uses O
an O
atlas O
consisting O
of O
15 O
manually O
generated O
segmentations O
, O
each O
identifying O
25 O
cerebellar O
regions O
, O
including O
unilateral O
hemisphere O
measures O
( O
Fig O
. O

1B O
) O
. O

For O
comparison O
across O
the O
three O
analysis O
approaches O
herein O
, O
we O
used O
bilateral O
volumes O
of O
three O
global O
measures O
( O
total O
tissue O
, O
gray O
matter O
, O
and O
white O
matter O
) O
and O
8 O
bilateral O
hemisphere O
measures O
( O
I-V O
, O
VII O
, O
Crus O
I O
, O
Crus O
II O
, O
VIIB O
, O
VIII O
, O
IX O
, O
and O
X O
) O
. O

Cognitive O
and O
postural O
stability O
testing O
Participants O
completed O
a O
neuropsychological O
battery O
to O
assess O
current O
levels O
of O
general O
cognitive O
and O
performance O
abilities O
. O

The O
Wechsler O
Test O
of O
Adult O
Reading O
( O
WTAR O
) O
estimated O
a O
premorbid O
intelligence O
quotient O
( O
IQ O
) O
. O

The O
Montreal O
Cognitive O
Assessment O
( O
MoCA O
) O
battery O
provided O
a O
measure O
of O
current O
general O
cognitive O
capacity O
. O

Ataxia O
testing O
was O
conducted O
under O
the O
following O
conditions O
, O
first O
with O
eyes O
open O
and O
then O
for O
another O
set O
of O
trials O
with O
eyes O
closed O
: O
stand O
heel-to-toe O
( O
60 O
s/trial O
) O
, O
stand O
on O
one O
foot O
( O
30 O
s/trial O
for O
each O
foot O
) O
; O
and O
walk O
a O
line O
for O
a O
maximum O
of O
10 O
steps O
. O

Each O
condition O
was O
conducted O
twice O
unless O
a O
maximum O
score O
was O
achieved O
on O
the O
first O
trial O
; O
then O
by O
default O
the O
score O
would O
be O
the O
maximum O
for O
two O
trials O
( O
e.g. O
, O
60 O
s O
for O
trial O
1 O
of O
standing O
heel-to-toe O
would O
result O
in O
the O
maximum O
( O
best O
) O
score O
of O
120 O
s O
) O
. O

Scores O
from O
each O
of O
the O
8 O
conditions O
were O
expressed O
as O
Z-scores O
standardized O
for O
age O
based O
on O
the O
controls O
. O

Statistical O
analysis O
The O
mainstay O
of O
statistical O
analysis O
was O
performed O
using O
R O
3.5.1 O
( O
R O
Core O
Team O
, O
2019 O
) O
on O
bilateral O
volumes O
, O
which O
were O
the O
sums O
of O
left O
and O
right O
regional O
volumes O
. O

The O
R O
code O
is O
provided O
in O
Supplemental O
Material O
. O

Separate O
linear O
models O
( O
lm O
) O
were O
constructed O
predicting O
the O
volume O
of O
described O
each O
lobule O
from O
sex O
, O
ICV O
, O
and O
age O
, O
for O
the O
diagnostic O
and O
control O
groups O
separately O
. O

This O
process O
was O
applied O
for O
volumes O
obtained O
using O
Ceres O
, O
Hopkins O
, O
and O
SUIT O
, O
and O
each O
regional O
volume O
was O
analyzed O
separately O
. O

For O
more O
intuitive O
graphical O
presentation O
, O
group O
means O
were O
added O
to O
the O
residuals O
. O

Group O
differences O
were O
determined O
by O
t-tests O
, O
which O
were O
considered O
significant O
at O
p O
= O
.05 O
( O
2-tailed O
) O
. O

In O
addition O
, O
we O
tested O
for O
diagnosis-by-age O
and O
diagnosis-by-sex O
interactions O
. O

Coefficients O
of O
variation O
( O
CVs O
) O
were O
calculated O
( O
SD/mean O
) O
for O
each O
regional O
volume O
for O
each O
measurement O
approach O
and O
for O
each O
subject O
group O
to O
index O
, O
without O
the O
need O
for O
scalar O
equivalence O
, O
variation O
in O
the O
distributions O
of O
regional O
volumes O
for O
a O
volume O
's O
mean O
. O

Smaller O
CVs O
indicate O
less O
variation O
in O
volumes O
and O
have O
been O
considered O
a O
measure O
of O
precision O
or O
repeatability O
. O

Pearson O
correlations O
tested O
relations O
between O
cerebellar O
lobular O
volumes O
and O
ataxia O
scores O
, O
alcohol O
history O
measures O
, O
and O
hematological O
values O
. O

All O
correlations O
with O
p O
≤ O
.05 O
are O
reported O
and O
those O
meeting O
family-wise O
Bonferroni O
correction O
( O
1-tailed O
) O
and O
False O
Discovery O
Rate O
( O
FDR O
) O
correction O
. O

Cocaine O
and O
HIV O
are O
independently O
associated O
with O
neural O
activation O
in O
response O
to O
gain O
and O
loss O
valuation O
during O
economic O
risky O
choice O
Stimulant O
abuse O
is O
disproportionately O
common O
in O
HIV-positive O
persons O
. O

Both O
HIV O
and O
stimulants O
are O
independently O
associated O
with O
deficits O
in O
reward-based O
decision O
making O
, O
but O
their O
interactive O
and/or O
additive O
effects O
are O
poorly O
understood O
despite O
their O
prevalent O
comorbidity O
. O

Here O
, O
we O
examined O
the O
effects O
of O
cocaine O
dependence O
and O
HIV O
infection O
in O
69 O
adults O
who O
underwent O
functional O
magnetic O
resonance O
imaging O
( O
fMRI O
) O
while O
completing O
an O
economic O
loss O
aversion O
task O
. O

We O
identified O
two O
neural O
networks O
that O
correlated O
with O
the O
evaluation O
of O
the O
favorable O
characteristics O
of O
the O
gamble O
( O
i.e. O
, O
higher O
gains/lower O
losses O
; O
ventromedial O
prefrontal O
cortex O
, O
anterior O
cingulate O
, O
anterior O
and O
posterior O
precuneus O
, O
and O
visual O
cortex O
) O
versus O
unfavorable O
characteristics O
of O
the O
gamble O
( O
i.e. O
, O
lower O
gains/higher O
losses O
; O
dorsal O
prefrontal O
, O
lateral O
orbitofrontal O
, O
and O
posterior O
parietal O
cortex O
, O
anterior O
insula O
, O
and O
dorsal O
caudate O
) O
. O

Behaviorally O
, O
cocaine O
and O
HIV O
had O
additive O
effects O
on O
loss O
aversion O
scores O
, O
with O
HIV-positive O
cocaine O
users O
being O
the O
least O
loss O
averse O
. O

Cocaine O
users O
had O
greater O
activation O
in O
brain O
regions O
that O
tracked O
the O
favorability O
of O
gamble O
characteristics O
( O
i.e. O
, O
increased O
activation O
to O
gains O
, O
but O
decreased O
activation O
to O
losses O
) O
. O

In O
contrast O
, O
HIV O
infection O
was O
independently O
associated O
with O
lesser O
activation O
in O
regions O
that O
tracked O
the O
unfavorability O
of O
gamble O
characteristics O
. O

These O
results O
suggest O
that O
cocaine O
is O
associated O
with O
an O
overactive O
reward-seeking O
system O
, O
while O
HIV O
is O
associated O
with O
an O
underactive O
cognitive O
control O
system O
. O

Together O
, O
these O
alterations O
may O
leave O
HIV-positive O
cocaine O
users O
particularly O
vulnerable O
to O
making O
unfavorable O
decisions O
when O
outcomes O
are O
uncertain O
. O

Material O
and O
Methods O
Participants O
The O
sample O
included O
adults O
aged O
18–55 O
years O
who O
differed O
on O
cocaine O
and O
HIV O
status O
. O

Exclusion O
criteria O
were O
: O
< O
8th O
grade O
education O
; O
severe O
learning O
disability O
; O
illiteracy O
; O
non-fluency O
in O
English O
; O
serious O
neurological O
disorders O
; O
acute O
opportunistic O
brain O
infections O
or O
a O
history O
of O
such O
infections O
without O
return O
to O
normal O
cognition O
; O
severe O
head O
trauma O
with O
loss O
of O
consciousness O
> O
30 O
minutes O
and O
persistent O
functional O
decline O
; O
severe O
mental O
illness O
; O
MRI O
contraindications O
; O
and O
impaired O
mental O
status O
. O

Cocaine O
( O
COC O
) O
status O
. O

COC+ O
was O
defined O
as O
: O
≥3 O
days O
of O
cocaine O
use O
in O
the O
past O
month O
or O
a O
positive O
urine O
drug O
screen O
for O
cocaine O
; O
≥1 O
year O
of O
regular O
cocaine O
use O
; O
and O
lifetime O
cocaine O
dependence O
. O

For O
COC+ O
, O
current O
alcohol O
or O
marijuana O
dependence O
were O
permitted O
if O
cocaine O
dependence O
was O
the O
principal O
diagnosis O
. O

Exclusions O
for O
COC+ O
were O
: O
any O
other O
drug O
use O
disorder O
within O
the O
past O
20 O
years O
; O
regular O
use O
of O
other O
drugs O
in O
the O
past O
year O
; O
any O
other O
drug O
use O
in O
the O
past O
30 O
days O
( O
other O
than O
alcohol O
and O
marijuana O
) O
; O
and O
positive O
urine O
screen O
for O
non-prescribed O
opioids O
or O
amphetamines O
. O

COC-was O
defined O
as O
: O
no O
lifetime O
cocaine O
use O
disorder O
; O
no O
history O
of O
regular O
cocaine O
use O
; O
no O
cocaine O
use O
in O
the O
past O
year O
; O
and O
a O
cocaine O
negative O
drug O
screen O
. O

Exclusions O
for O
COC-were O
: O
current O
alcohol O
or O
marijuana O
dependence O
; O
lifetime O
abuse O
or O
dependence O
on O
any O
other O
drug O
; O
history O
of O
regular O
drug O
use O
; O
any O
drug O
use O
in O
the O
past O
30 O
days O
( O
other O
than O
alcohol O
and O
marijuana O
) O
; O
and O
positive O
urine O
screen O
for O
any O
other O
drug O
. O

HIV O
status O
. O

For O
individuals O
with O
diagnosed O
HIV O
infection O
, O
HIV+ O
status O
was O
verified O
by O
medical O
record O
review O
. O

For O
others O
, O
an O
OraQuick© O
rapid O
test O
was O
conducted O
to O
verify O
HIV-status O
. O

Procedures O
Participants O
were O
recruited O
via O
advertisements O
in O
local O
newspapers O
, O
websites O
, O
community-based O
organizations O
, O
and O
infectious O
diseases O
clinics O
. O

After O
completing O
a O
telephone O
pre-screen O
, O
potential O
participants O
completed O
an O
in-person O
screening O
. O

Eligible O
participants O
returned O
on O
another O
day O
for O
an O
MRI O
scan O
. O

Participants O
gave O
informed O
consent O
, O
and O
all O
procedures O
were O
approved O
by O
the O
Institutional O
Review O
Board O
at O
Duke O
University O
Health O
System O
. O

Screening O
measures O
Participants O
completed O
demographics O
and O
smoking O
history O
surveys O
and O
provided O
a O
urine O
sample O
for O
drug O
and O
pregnancy O
testing O
. O

The O
screening O
measures O
included O
: O
Wechsler O
Test O
of O
Adult O
Reading O
for O
premorbid O
verbal O
IQ O
; O
Structured O
Clinical O
Interview O
for O
DSM-IV-TR O
for O
substance O
use O
disorders O
; O
Addiction O
Severity O
Index-Lite O
for O
substance O
use O
; O
and O
timeline O
follow-back O
for O
frequency O
of O
substance O
use O
in O
the O
past O
90 O
days O
. O

Participants O
provided O
a O
release O
for O
their O
medical O
records O
, O
which O
were O
used O
to O
obtain O
HIV O
disease O
indicators O
( O
e.g. O
, O
CD4 O
cell O
counts O
) O
. O

HIV+ O
participants O
estimated O
adherence O
to O
their O
antiretroviral O
medications O
using O
a O
visual O
analogue O
scale O
. O

fMRI O
task O
The O
loss O
aversion O
task O
presents O
participants O
with O
gambles O
that O
have O
an O
equal O
probability O
of O
gaining O
or O
losing O
a O
variable O
amount O
of O
money O
Gambles O
were O
sampled O
from O
a O
matrix O
that O
ranged O
from O
$ O
0 O
to O
$ O
40 O
in O
$ O
4 O
increments O
for O
gains O
and O
$ O
0 O
to O
- O
$ O
20 O
in O
- O
$ O
2 O
increments O
for O
losses O
( O
Figure O
1 O
) O
. O

Participants O
were O
extensively O
trained O
on O
the O
task O
prior O
to O
scanning O
. O

All O
120 O
combinations O
of O
gambles O
( O
excluding O
$ O
0/ O
$ O
0 O
) O
were O
randomized O
once O
and O
divided O
across O
three O
functional O
runs O
( O
each O
6 O
min O
) O
. O

The O
order O
of O
the O
runs O
was O
randomized O
across O
participants O
. O

Participants O
chose O
whether O
to O
accept O
or O
reject O
each O
gamble O
. O

They O
were O
instructed O
to O
consider O
each O
gamble O
independently O
, O
like O
a O
coin O
flip O
, O
and O
the O
gambles O
were O
not O
played O
out O
during O
the O
scan O
. O

Each O
trial O
was O
presented O
for O
5.75s O
, O
during O
which O
participants O
made O
their O
choice O
, O
followed O
by O
a O
variable O
inter-stimulus O
interval O
of O
2–8s O
( O
M= O
3.2s O
) O
. O

This O
task O
was O
programed O
in O
MATLAB O
R2012a O
( O
Mathworks O
, O
Natick O
, O
MA O
) O
using O
the O
Psychtoolbox O
extension O
( O
www.psychtoolbox.org O
) O
. O

Visual O
stimuli O
were O
displayed O
via O
projector O
onto O
a O
screen O
within O
the O
scanner O
bore O
, O
and O
responses O
were O
recorded O
using O
an O
MR-compatible O
response O
box O
held O
in O
the O
right O
hand O
. O

Participants O
were O
told O
that O
, O
after O
the O
scan O
, O
one O
trial O
would O
be O
randomly O
selected O
. O

If O
they O
had O
rejected O
that O
gamble O
, O
the O
gamble O
was O
not O
played O
. O

If O
they O
had O
accepted O
that O
gamble O
, O
the O
outcome O
was O
determined O
with O
a O
coin O
flip O
. O

Rewards O
were O
scaled O
: O
$ O
0 O
for O
losses O
of O
$ O
11–20 O
, O
$ O
1 O
for O
losses O
of O
$ O
0–10 O
, O
$ O
2 O
for O
gain O
of O
$ O
1–10 O
, O
$ O
3 O
for O
gains O
of O
$ O
11–13 O
, O
$ O
4 O
for O
gains O
of O
$ O
21–30 O
, O
and O
$ O
5 O
for O
gains O
of O
$ O
31–40 O
. O

To O
estimate O
behavioral O
loss O
aversion O
( O
lambda O
) O
, O
a O
logistic O
regression O
predicting O
participants O
’ O
choice O
to O
accept O
each O
gamble O
was O
used O
to O
generate O
unstandardized O
regression O
coefficients O
( O
β O
values O
) O
for O
gains O
and O
losses O
. O

Trials O
with O
a O
$ O
0 O
gain O
or O
$ O
0 O
loss O
option O
were O
excluded O
from O
this O
analysis O
. O

As O
in O
prior O
studies O
, O
lambda O
was O
computed O
as O
-βloss/ O
βgain O
; O
higher O
scores O
indicate O
greater O
loss O
aversion O
. O

MRI O
data O
acquisition O
Imaging O
was O
performed O
on O
a O
3T O
General O
Electric O
Signa O
EXCITE O
HD O
scanner O
( O
Milwaukee O
, O
WI O
) O
equipped O
with O
40 O
mT/m O
gradients O
and O
an O
8-channel O
head O
coil O
. O

Whole-brain O
BOLD O
images O
were O
collected O
using O
high-throughput O
T2 O
* O
-weighted O
echo-planar O
imaging O
with O
the O
following O
parameters O
: O
TR= O
2000ms O
; O
TE= O
25ms O
; O
FOV= O
24.0cm O
; O
flip O
angle= O
90° O
; O
in-plane O
matrix O
size= O
64 O
× O
64 O
; O
and O
slice O
thickness= O
3.8mm O
, O
resulting O
in O
functional O
data O
from O
35 O
axial O
slices O
with O
voxels O
of O
3.75×3.75×3.8mm O
. O

High-resolution O
T1-weighted O
structural O
images O
were O
acquired O
with O
the O
following O
parameters O
: O
TR= O
8.156ms O
; O
TE= O
3.18ms O
; O
FOV= O
25.6cm O
; O
flip O
angle= O
12° O
; O
in-plane O
matrix O
size= O
256 O
× O
256 O
; O
slice O
thickness= O
1mm O
; O
and O
number O
of O
slices= O
166 O
. O

These O
images O
were O
collected O
as O
part O
of O
a O
90-minute O
scanning O
session O
. O

Quality O
control O
Of O
the O
81 O
participants O
who O
completed O
the O
experiment O
, O
one O
was O
excluded O
because O
of O
a O
procedural O
error O
during O
the O
scan O
. O

Ten O
participants O
were O
excluded O
because O
their O
behavioral O
performance O
on O
the O
loss O
aversion O
task O
indicated O
inattention O
or O
poor O
comprehension O
. O

Specifically O
, O
they O
were O
excluded O
for O
: O
a O
negative O
βgain O
value O
( O
i.e. O
, O
they O
were O
less O
likely O
to O
accept O
gambles O
as O
potential O
gains O
increased O
) O
; O
a O
positive O
βloss O
value O
( O
i.e. O
, O
they O
were O
more O
likely O
to O
accept O
gambles O
as O
potential O
loss O
increased O
) O
; O
and/or O
very O
small O
regression O
coefficients O
that O
indicated O
random O
or O
heuristic O
responding O
( O
βgain O
< O
.03 O
and O
βloss O
values O
> O
−.015 O
) O
. O

Visual O
inspection O
of O
heatmaps O
converged O
with O
the O
initial O
quality O
control O
check O
( O
see O
Supplementary O
Figure O
S1 O
for O
examples O
) O
. O

One O
additional O
participant O
was O
excluded O
for O
skipping O
> O
30 O
% O
of O
trials O
. O

Among O
the O
69 O
participants O
in O
the O
final O
analysis O
, O
63 O
( O
91 O
% O
) O
missed O
≤10 O
% O
of O
trials O
( O
M= O
2.58 O
, O
SD= O
4.69 O
) O
. O

The O
heatmaps O
of O
the O
6 O
participants O
who O
missed O
> O
10 O
% O
showed O
clear O
response O
patterns O
consistent O
with O
their O
loss O
aversion O
scores O
. O

FSL O
’ O
s O
Motion O
Outliers O
tool O
was O
used O
to O
calculate O
motion O
metrics O
during O
scanning O
. O

Framewise O
displacement O
( O
FD O
) O
ranged O
from O
0.06 O
to O
1.30 O
( O
M= O
0.15 O
, O
SD= O
0.15 O
) O
. O

An O
analysis O
of O
variance O
( O
ANOVA O
) O
revealed O
a O
main O
effect O
of O
cocaine O
on O
FD O
[ O
F O
( O
1,65 O
) O
= O
4.62 O
, O
p= O
.035 O
] O
, O
such O
that O
COC+ O
had O
higher O
values O
than O
COC- O
. O

There O
was O
no O
significant O
effect O
of O
HIV O
( O
both O
p O
> O
.20 O
) O
. O

No O
participants O
were O
excluded O
for O
motion O
. O

To O
control O
for O
the O
effects O
of O
motion O
, O
six O
motion O
parameters O
calculated O
with O
MCFLIRT O
were O
included O
as O
regressors O
in O
the O
first O
level O
analyses O
. O

We O
also O
added O
mean O
FD O
as O
a O
covariate O
in O
the O
group O
comparison O
model O
. O

Data O
analysis O
Behavioral O
data O
. O

Participants O
were O
characterized O
in O
terms O
of O
demographics O
, O
substance O
use O
, O
and O
HIV O
infection O
using O
descriptive O
statistics O
. O

Group O
differences O
were O
identified O
using O
chi-square O
, O
ANOVA O
, O
and O
Mann-Whitney O
tests O
. O

Loss O
aversion O
scores O
were O
examined O
using O
a O
2 O
( O
COC+/COC- O
) O
x O
2 O
( O
HIV+/HIV- O
) O
between-subjects O
ANOVA O
. O

All O
behavioral O
analyses O
were O
conducted O
in O
SPSS O
22.0. O
fMRI O
data O
. O

Functional O
images O
were O
processed O
using O
FMRIB O
Software O
Library O
FSL O
v5.0 O
. O

The O
first O
5 O
volumes O
of O
each O
run O
were O
deleted O
to O
allow O
for O
magnetic O
resonance O
equilibrium O
. O

Functional O
images O
were O
temporally O
realigned O
to O
correct O
for O
interleaved O
slice O
acquisition O
, O
motion O
corrected O
using O
the O
MCFLIRT O
linear O
realignment O
tool O
, O
and O
high-pass O
temporal O
filtered O
( O
cutoff= O
100s O
) O
. O

Nonbrain O
voxels O
were O
removed O
from O
the O
anatomical O
images O
using O
the O
brain O
extraction O
tool O
( O
BET O
) O
. O

Functional O
images O
were O
co-registered O
to O
participants O
’ O
anatomical O
image O
with O
a O
12-degrees O
of O
freedom O
( O
DOF O
) O
linear O
transformation O
, O
and O
then O
normalized O
to O
the O
Montreal O
Neurological O
Institute O
152 O
template O
( O
2×2×2mm O
) O
using O
FNIRT O
. O

Functional O
images O
were O
spatially O
smoothed O
using O
a O
5mm O
full-width O
half-maximum O
( O
FWHM O
) O
Gaussian O
kernel O
. O

Data O
from O
individual O
runs O
for O
each O
participant O
were O
subjected O
to O
a O
general O
linear O
model O
using O
FILM O
prewhitening O
, O
a O
temporal O
derivative O
, O
and O
temporal O
filtering O
. O

Explanatory O
variables O
were O
modeled O
by O
convolving O
a O
delta O
function O
representing O
trial O
onset O
times O
with O
a O
canonical O
( O
double-gamma O
) O
hemodynamic O
response O
function O
. O

All O
trials O
were O
modeled O
using O
a O
single O
condition O
representing O
overall O
task-related O
activation O
, O
and O
two O
additional O
orthogonal O
regressors O
were O
included O
representing O
the O
magnitude O
of O
the O
potential O
gains O
( O
gain-related O
BOLD O
) O
and O
the O
magnitude O
of O
the O
potential O
losses O
( O
loss-related O
BOLD O
) O
. O

Contrasts O
were O
defined O
for O
each O
of O
these O
three O
explanatory O
variables O
, O
and O
then O
were O
averaged O
across O
the O
three O
functional O
runs O
for O
each O
participant O
using O
a O
fixed-effects O
model O
. O

In O
all O
analyses O
, O
gain O
and O
loss O
were O
analyzed O
separately O
. O

First O
, O
the O
overall O
pattern O
of O
gain-and O
loss-related O
activations O
in O
the O
sample O
was O
examined O
using O
one-sample O
t-tests O
. O

These O
whole-brain O
images O
were O
thresholded O
at O
z O
> O
3.1 O
. O

Cluster O
correction O
was O
determined O
using O
3DClustSim O
using O
FWHM O
and O
running O
10,000 O
Monte O
Carlo O
simulations O
on O
a O
whole-brain O
mask O
composed O
of O
258,298 O
voxels O
( O
https O
: O
//afni.nimh.nih.gov/ O
) O
. O

This O
produced O
an O
individual O
voxel O
threshold O
of O
p O
< O
0.001 O
and O
an O
extent O
threshold O
of O
≥30 O
contiguous O
voxels O
for O
an O
overall O
corrected O
false O
positive O
rate O
of O
p O
< O
0.05 O
. O

To O
ensure O
subsequent O
analyses O
were O
related O
to O
the O
main O
effects O
of O
the O
gain-and O
loss-related O
activations O
, O
a O
mask O
was O
created O
by O
adding O
both O
gain-and O
loss-related O
main O
effects O
using O
a O
more O
liberal O
threshold O
of O
p O
< O
0.01 O
, O
extent O
threshold O
≥80 O
voxels O
. O

Second O
, O
gain-and O
loss-related O
activations O
were O
correlated O
with O
behavioral O
loss O
aversion O
scores O
, O
which O
were O
natural O
log O
transformed O
and O
mean-centered O
. O

The O
results O
of O
the O
correlations O
were O
masked O
with O
the O
main O
effects O
and O
thresholded O
at O
p O
< O
0.001 O
, O
extent O
threshold O
≥20 O
voxels O
for O
an O
overall O
corrected O
false O
positive O
detection O
rate O
of O
p O
< O
0.05 O
. O

Third O
, O
group O
differences O
in O
gain-and O
loss-related O
activations O
were O
examined O
using O
mixed-effects O
2 O
( O
COC+/COC- O
) O
by O
2 O
( O
HIV+/HIV- O
) O
ANOVAs O
controlling O
for O
motion O
. O

ANOVA O
results O
were O
masked O
with O
the O
main O
effects O
and O
thresholded O
at O
p O
< O
0.001 O
, O
extent O
threshold O
≥20 O
voxels O
for O
an O
overall O
corrected O
false O
positive O
detection O
rate O
of O
p O
< O
0.05 O
. O

To O
reduce O
the O
likelihood O
of O
Type O
II O
errors O
, O
clusters O
that O
survived O
p O
< O
0.005 O
, O
extent O
threshold O
≥40 O
voxels O
are O
also O
reported O
. O

The O
Harvard-Oxford O
cortical O
and O
subcortical O
structural O
atlases O
were O
used O
to O
identify O
neuroanatomical O
locations O
of O
activation O
peaks O
. O

Figures O
were O
made O
using O
MRIcron O
( O
www.mccauslandcenter.sc.edu/mricro/ O
) O
. O

Synergistic O
effects O
of O
marijuana O
abuse O
and O
HIV O
infection O
on O
neural O
activation O
during O
a O
cognitive O
interference O
task O
Marijuana O
use O
, O
which O
is O
disproportionately O
prevalent O
among O
HIV-infected O
persons O
, O
can O
alter O
activity O
in O
fronto-parietal O
regions O
during O
cognitively O
demanding O
tasks O
. O

While O
HIV O
is O
also O
associated O
with O
altered O
neural O
activation O
, O
it O
is O
not O
known O
how O
marijuana O
may O
further O
affect O
brain O
function O
in O
this O
population O
. O

Our O
study O
examined O
the O
independent O
and O
additive O
effects O
of O
HIV O
infection O
and O
regular O
marijuana O
use O
on O
neural O
activation O
during O
a O
cognitive O
interference O
task O
. O

The O
sample O
included O
93 O
adults O
who O
differed O
on O
marijuana O
and O
HIV O
statuses O
( O
20 O
MJ+/HIV+ O
, O
19 O
MJ+/HIV− O
, O
29 O
MJ−/HIV+ O
, O
25 O
MJ−/HIV− O
) O
. O

Participants O
completed O
a O
counting O
Stroop O
task O
during O
a O
functional O
magnetic O
resonance O
imaging O
scan O
. O

Main O
and O
interactive O
effects O
on O
neural O
activation O
during O
interference O
versus O
neutral O
blocks O
were O
examined O
using O
a O
mixed-effects O
analysis O
. O

The O
sample O
showed O
the O
expected O
Stroop O
effect O
for O
both O
speed O
and O
accuracy O
. O

There O
were O
main O
effects O
of O
MJ O
in O
the O
right O
and O
left O
inferior O
parietal O
lobules O
, O
with O
the O
left O
cluster O
extending O
into O
the O
posterior O
middle O
temporal O
gyrus O
, O
and O
a O
main O
effect O
of O
HIV O
in O
the O
dorsal O
anterior O
cingulate O
cortex O
. O

There O
was O
an O
interaction O
in O
the O
left O
fronto-insular O
cortex O
, O
such O
that O
the O
MJ+/HIV+ O
group O
had O
the O
largest O
increase O
in O
activation O
compared O
to O
other O
groups O
. O

Among O
MJ+ O
, O
signal O
change O
in O
this O
cluster O
correlated O
positively O
with O
cumulative O
years O
of O
regular O
marijuana O
use O
. O

These O
results O
suggest O
that O
comorbid O
HIV O
and O
marijuana O
use O
is O
associated O
with O
complex O
neural O
alterations O
in O
multiple O
brain O
regions O
during O
cognitive O
interference O
. O

Follow-up O
research O
is O
needed O
to O
determine O
how O
marijuana-related O
characteristics O
may O
moderate O
HIV O
neurologic O
disease O
and O
impact O
real-world O
functioning O
. O

Materials O
and O
Methods O
Participants O
The O
sample O
included O
93 O
adults O
aged O
18–55 O
years O
who O
were O
active O
marijuana O
users O
with O
HIV O
( O
MJ+/HIV+ O
, O
n= O
20 O
) O
and O
without O
HIV O
( O
MJ+/HIV− O
, O
n= O
19 O
) O
or O
non-marijuana O
users O
with O
HIV O
( O
MJ−/HIV+ O
, O
n= O
29 O
) O
and O
without O
HIV O
( O
MJ−/HIV− O
, O
n= O
25 O
) O
. O

The O
MJ+ O
groups O
met O
the O
following O
criteria O
: O
≥4 O
days O
of O
marijuana O
use O
in O
the O
past O
month O
and O
≥1 O
year O
of O
regular O
marijuana O
use O
[ O
i.e. O
, O
consistent O
use O
at O
a O
frequency O
of O
≥3 O
or O
more O
days O
per O
week O
] O
. O

The O
MJ− O
groups O
met O
the O
following O
criteria O
: O
no O
lifetime O
cannabis O
use O
disorder O
, O
no O
history O
of O
regular O
marijuana O
use O
, O
0 O
days O
of O
marijuana O
use O
in O
the O
past O
90 O
days O
, O
and O
a O
THC-negative O
drug O
screen O
. O

Alcohol O
and O
nicotine O
use O
were O
permitted O
in O
all O
groups O
, O
but O
participants O
could O
not O
have O
current O
alcohol O
dependence O
. O

Participants O
also O
could O
have O
no O
history O
of O
abusing O
other O
drugs O
, O
including O
cocaine O
, O
amphetamine O
, O
benzodiazepines O
, O
and O
opioids O
, O
as O
defined O
by O
any O
of O
the O
following O
: O
history O
of O
regular O
use O
, O
lifetime O
dependence O
, O
use O
in O
the O
past O
30 O
days O
, O
or O
positive O
drug O
screen O
. O

HIV-negative O
status O
was O
verified O
by O
an O
OraQuick© O
rapid O
test O
, O
and O
self-reported O
HIV-positive O
status O
was O
verified O
by O
medical O
record O
review O
. O

Additional O
exclusion O
criteria O
were O
: O
English O
non-fluency O
or O
illiteracy O
; O
< O
8th O
grade O
education O
; O
severe O
learning O
disability O
; O
serious O
neurological O
disorders O
not O
due O
to O
HIV O
; O
acute O
opportunistic O
brain O
infections O
or O
history O
of O
such O
infections O
without O
return O
to O
normal O
cognition O
; O
severe O
head O
trauma O
with O
loss O
of O
consciousness O
> O
30 O
minutes O
and O
persistent O
functional O
decline O
; O
severe O
mental O
illness O
; O
current O
use O
of O
antipsychotic O
or O
mood O
stabilizing O
medications O
; O
MRI O
contraindications O
; O
and O
impaired O
mental O
status O
. O

Procedures O
Data O
were O
collected O
as O
part O
of O
two O
concurrent O
neuroimaging O
studies O
on O
drug O
abuse O
and O
HIV O
that O
had O
shared O
sampling O
and O
assessment O
procedures O
. O

Participants O
were O
recruited O
via O
advertisements O
in O
local O
newspapers O
, O
websites O
, O
community-based O
organizations O
, O
and O
infectious O
diseases O
clinics O
. O

After O
passing O
a O
brief O
pre-screener O
, O
individuals O
completed O
an O
in-person O
screening O
. O

Eligible O
participants O
returned O
for O
the O
MRI O
scan O
and O
additional O
assessments O
. O

Participants O
were O
asked O
to O
abstain O
from O
marijuana O
use O
for O
> O
4 O
hours O
prior O
to O
the O
scan O
; O
the O
mean O
number O
of O
hours O
since O
last O
use O
was O
23.36 O
( O
SD= O
13.44 O
) O
. O

All O
study O
groups O
were O
represented O
in O
each O
protocol O
. O

Although O
not O
statistically O
significant O
( O
X O
( O
3 O
) O
2= O
7.27 O
, O
p= O
.06 O
) O
, O
MJ+/HIV− O
was O
underrepresented O
( O
8 O
% O
vs. O
25 O
% O
) O
and O
MJ−/HIV+ O
was O
overrepresented O
( O
50 O
% O
vs. O
25 O
% O
) O
in O
the O
first O
protocol O
. O

Therefore O
, O
protocol O
was O
controlled O
for O
in O
analyses O
. O

Procedures O
were O
approved O
by O
the O
institutional O
review O
boards O
at O
Duke O
University O
and O
University O
of O
North O
Carolina O
at O
Chapel O
Hill O
. O

Measures O
Participants O
completed O
clinical O
interviews O
, O
questionnaires O
, O
urine O
drug O
screening O
, O
and O
pregnancy O
tests O
. O

Module O
E O
of O
the O
Structured O
Clinical O
Interview O
for O
DSM-IV-TR O
identified O
current O
and O
past O
substance O
use O
disorders O
, O
and O
the O
Addiction O
Severity O
Index-Lite O
assessed O
history O
of O
substance O
use O
and O
associated O
impairments O
. O

Timeline O
follow-back O
methodology O
was O
used O
to O
assess O
substance O
use O
in O
the O
past O
90 O
days O
at O
both O
the O
screening O
and O
MRI O
visits O
. O

The O
Wechsler O
Test O
of O
Adult O
Reading O
estimated O
premorbid O
verbal O
IQ O
. O

The O
Stroop O
Color O
and O
Word O
Test O
was O
used O
to O
assess O
executive O
functioning O
, O
and O
published O
norms O
were O
used O
to O
convert O
raw O
interference O
scores O
to O
demographically O
corrected O
T-score O
. O

An O
audio O
computer-assisted O
self-interview O
assessed O
demographics O
, O
smoking O
behavior O
, O
and O
medical O
history O
. O

Healthcare O
records O
were O
reviewed O
to O
confirm O
no O
exclusionary O
neurologic O
, O
psychiatric O
, O
or O
medical O
conditions O
. O

For O
HIV+ O
participants O
, O
we O
abstracted O
HIV O
disease O
indicators O
, O
including O
date O
of O
diagnosis O
and O
CD4 O
cell O
counts O
. O

fMRI O
counting O
Stroop O
Task O
The O
counting O
Stroop O
is O
a O
cognitive O
interference O
task O
that O
was O
designed O
for O
administration O
during O
MRI O
. O

Participants O
were O
presented O
alternating O
blocks O
of O
neutral O
and O
interference O
trials O
. O

During O
each O
trial O
, O
the O
same O
word O
was O
listed O
vertically O
1–4 O
times O
, O
and O
participants O
were O
instructed O
to O
indicate O
as O
quickly O
as O
possible O
the O
number O
of O
words O
using O
a O
response O
pad O
. O

Interference O
trials O
consisted O
of O
number O
words O
( O
one O
, O
two O
, O
three O
, O
or O
four O
) O
, O
while O
neutral O
trials O
consisted O
of O
animal O
words O
( O
dog O
, O
cat O
, O
mouse O
, O
and O
bird O
) O
; O
the O
conditions O
were O
balanced O
for O
word O
length O
. O

Each O
block O
contained O
six O
randomly O
selected O
trials O
that O
were O
presented O
for O
1.5s O
, O
and O
there O
was O
a O
0.75s O
fixed O
interval O
between O
trials O
during O
which O
a O
crosshair O
was O
displayed O
. O

The O
single O
4-minute O
run O
consisted O
of O
16 O
alternating O
interference O
and O
neutral O
blocks O
, O
with O
the O
initial O
block O
type O
randomized O
across O
participants O
. O

Prior O
to O
the O
fMRI O
session O
, O
participants O
were O
trained O
on O
the O
task O
to O
ensure O
comprehension O
. O

MRI O
data O
acquisition O
MRI O
data O
were O
acquired O
using O
a O
3.0T O
GE O
MR750 O
scanner O
with O
an O
8-channel O
head O
coil O
. O

High-resolution O
T O
1-weighted O
structural O
images O
were O
acquired O
with O
the O
following O
parameters O
: O
TR= O
8.1ms O
; O
TE= O
3.18ms O
; O
FOV= O
25.6cm O
; O
matrix= O
256 O
* O
256 O
; O
slice O
thickness= O
1mm O
; O
voxel O
size= O
1mm3 O
; O
and O
number O
of O
slices= O
172 O
. O

Whole-brain O
blood-oxygen-level-dependent O
( O
BOLD O
) O
images O
were O
collected O
using O
high-throughput O
T2 O
* O
-weighted O
echo-planar O
imaging O
in O
the O
axial O
plane O
. O

Parameters O
for O
the O
two O
protocols O
were O
the O
same O
( O
TR= O
2000ms O
; O
FOV= O
240 O
; O
matrix= O
64 O
* O
64 O
; O
slice O
thickness= O
3.8mm O
; O
voxel O
resolution= O
3.75mm O
× O
3.75mm O
× O
3.79mm O
) O
, O
except O
there O
were O
slight O
differences O
for O
TE O
( O
27ms O
vs. O
25ms O
) O
and O
number O
of O
slices O
( O
35 O
and O
39 O
) O
. O

Interleaved O
images O
covered O
the O
entire O
brain O
. O

There O
was O
no O
difference O
in O
signal-to-fluctuation O
noise O
ratio O
( O
SFNR O
) O
between O
protocols O
[ O
141.33 O
± O
33.13 O
vs. O
142.57 O
± O
22.48 O
; O
t O
( O
91 O
) O
= O
0.21 O
, O
p= O
.84 O
] O
. O

This O
measure O
of O
temporal O
intensity O
stability O
reflects O
factors O
like O
scanner O
and O
electronics O
noise O
, O
head O
motion O
, O
and O
physiological O
changes O
. O

Quality O
control O
From O
99 O
study O
completers O
, O
3 O
were O
excluded O
for O
poor O
task O
performance O
indicative O
of O
inattention O
across O
multiple O
blocks O
( O
defined O
as O
mean O
accuracy O
of O
< O
67 O
% O
on O
neutral O
blocks O
) O
. O

Three O
additional O
participants O
were O
excluded O
for O
SFNR O
< O
75 O
. O

In O
the O
final O
sample O
( O
N=93 O
) O
, O
all O
participants O
had O
a O
relative O
mean O
displacement O
of O
< O
0.20mm O
( O
M= O
0.053mm O
, O
SD= O
0.035 O
) O
. O

DVARS O
, O
an O
index O
of O
the O
rate O
of O
change O
of O
BOLD O
signal O
across O
the O
brain O
at O
each O
frame O
of O
data O
, O
was O
also O
calculated O
using O
the O
motion O
outliers O
tool O
in O
FMRIB O
’ O
s O
Software O
Library O
( O
FSL O
) O
v6.00 O
. O

A O
2×2 O
between-subjects O
ANOVA O
revealed O
no O
main O
effects O
of O
HIV O
[ O
F O
( O
1,89 O
) O
= O
0.04 O
, O
p= O
.84 O
) O
or O
MJ O
[ O
F O
( O
1,89 O
) O
= O
0.18 O
, O
p= O
.68 O
) O
and O
no O
interaction O
effect O
[ O
F O
( O
1,89 O
) O
= O
0.04 O
, O
p= O
.84 O
] O
for O
DVARS O
. O

Six O
motion O
parameters O
calculated O
using O
FSL O
’ O
s O
MCFLIRT O
were O
included O
as O
regressors O
of O
no O
interest O
in O
first O
level O
analyses O
to O
control O
for O
linear O
movement O
across O
the O
run O
, O
and O
DVARS O
was O
included O
in O
third O
level O
analyses O
to O
control O
for O
individual O
differences O
in O
motion O
. O

fMRI O
Data O
Analysis O
The O
functional O
and O
anatomical O
data O
were O
pre-processed O
and O
analyzed O
using O
FSL O
’ O
s O
FEAT O
. O

Preprocessing O
steps O
included O
: O
motion O
correction O
with O
MCFLIRT O
; O
slice-timing O
correction O
using O
Fourier-space O
time-series O
phase-shifting O
; O
spatial O
smoothing O
with O
a O
Gaussian O
kernel O
of O
5mm O
full-width O
at O
half-maximum O
; O
high-pass O
temporal O
filtering O
( O
Gaussian-weighted O
least O
squares O
straight O
line O
fitting O
with O
σ= O
50s O
) O
; O
grand-mean O
intensity O
normalization O
of O
the O
entire O
4D O
dataset O
by O
a O
single O
multiplicative O
factor O
; O
and O
skull O
stripping O
of O
structural O
images O
with O
BET O
. O

Registration O
of O
functional O
data O
to O
the O
T1-weighted O
anatomical O
slices O
and O
registration O
of O
structural O
images O
to O
the O
2mm O
Montreal O
Neurological O
Institute O
( O
MNI O
) O
standard-space O
template O
were O
done O
with O
FLIRT O
using O
a O
12-parameter O
affine O
transformation O
. O

Individual O
time-series O
statistical O
analysis O
was O
carried O
out O
using O
FILM O
with O
local O
autocorrelation O
correction O
. O

The O
interference O
blocks O
, O
serving O
as O
the O
regressor O
, O
were O
convolved O
with O
a O
double-gamma O
hemodynamic O
response O
function O
. O

Statistical O
contrasts O
of O
the O
interference O
condition O
compared O
to O
the O
implicitly O
modeled O
neutral O
condition O
were O
conducted O
using O
a O
fixed- O
effects O
analysis O
. O

For O
visualization O
, O
task O
activation O
maps O
for O
all O
participants O
combined O
were O
generated O
using O
FSL O
’ O
s O
Local O
Analysis O
of O
Mixed O
Effects O
( O
FLAME O
1+2 O
) O
with O
a O
stringent O
cluster O
threshold O
of O
Z O
> O
3.5 O
and O
p O
< O
.05 O
, O
corrected O
over O
the O
entire O
brain O
using O
Gaussian O
random O
field O
theory O
. O

A O
2-factor O
between-subjects O
general O
linear O
model O
( O
GLM O
) O
, O
implemented O
using O
FLAME O
1+2 O
, O
was O
used O
to O
identify O
main O
and O
interaction O
effects O
of O
marijuana O
and O
HIV O
. O

Age O
, O
education O
, O
DVAR O
, O
and O
protocol O
were O
entered O
as O
covariates O
. O

In O
FSL O
, O
the O
interaction O
is O
modeled O
as O
a O
2-group O
comparison O
; O
in O
this O
case O
, O
the O
combined O
effects O
of O
MJ+/HIV+ O
and O
MJ−/HIV− O
were O
compared O
to O
the O
combined O
effects O
of O
MJ+/HIV− O
and O
MJ−/HIV+ O
. O

This O
model O
was O
cluster O
thresholded O
at O
Z O
> O
2.3 O
and O
a O
corrected O
cluster O
significance O
level O
of O
p O
< O
.05 O
. O

For O
all O
analyses O
, O
the O
Harvard-Oxford O
cortical O
and O
subcortical O
structural O
atlases O
were O
used O
to O
identify O
regions O
within O
significant O
clusters O
. O

For O
each O
significant O
cluster O
identified O
in O
the O
ANOVA O
, O
percent O
signal O
change O
was O
extracted O
using O
Featquery O
. O

Further O
analyses O
were O
conducted O
in O
SPSS O
24.0 O
. O

Group O
averages O
were O
examined O
to O
determine O
the O
direction O
of O
effects O
. O

Pearson O
partial O
correlation O
tests O
were O
run O
to O
examine O
the O
relation O
of O
signal O
change O
to O
clinical O
variables O
( O
cumulative O
years O
of O
marijuana O
use O
among O
MJ+ O
participants O
and O
nadir O
CD4 O
count O
among O
HIV+ O
participants O
) O
. O

These O
correlations O
controlled O
for O
age O
, O
education O
, O
DVAR O
, O
and O
protocol O
. O

Associations O
between O
drinking O
and O
cortical O
thickness O
in O
younger O
adult O
drinkers O
: O
Findings O
from O
the O
Human O
Connectome O
Project O
Background O
. O

Previous O
neuroimaging O
studies O
examining O
relations O
between O
alcohol O
misuse O
and O
cortical O
thickness O
have O
revealed O
that O
increased O
drinking O
quantity O
and O
alcohol-related O
problems O
are O
associated O
with O
thinner O
cortex O
. O

Although O
conflicting O
regional O
effects O
are O
often O
observed O
, O
associations O
are O
generally O
localized O
to O
frontal O
regions O
( O
e.g. O
, O
dorsolateral O
prefrontal O
cortex O
( O
DLPFC O
) O
, O
inferior O
frontal O
gyrus O
( O
IFG O
) O
, O
and O
anterior O
cingulate O
cortex O
) O
. O

Inconsistent O
findings O
may O
be O
attributed O
to O
methodological O
differences O
, O
modest O
sample O
sizes O
, O
and O
limited O
consideration O
of O
sex O
differences O
. O

Method O
. O

This O
study O
examined O
neuroanatomical O
correlates O
of O
drinking O
quantity O
and O
heavy O
episodic O
drinking O
in O
a O
large O
sample O
of O
younger O
adults O
( O
N=706 O
; O
M O
age O
= O
28.8 O
; O
51 O
% O
female O
) O
using O
magnetic O
resonance O
imaging O
data O
from O
the O
Human O
Connectome O
Project O
. O

Exploratory O
analyses O
examined O
neuroanatomical O
correlates O
of O
executive O
function O
( O
flanker O
task O
) O
and O
working O
memory O
( O
list O
sorting O
) O
. O

Results O
. O

Hierarchical O
linear O
regression O
models O
( O
controlling O
for O
age O
, O
sex O
, O
education O
, O
income O
, O
smoking O
, O
drug O
use O
, O
twin O
status O
, O
and O
intracranial O
volume O
) O
revealed O
significant O
inverse O
associations O
between O
drinks O
in O
past O
week O
and O
frequency O
of O
heavy O
drinking O
and O
cortical O
thickness O
in O
a O
majority O
of O
regions O
examined O
. O

The O
largest O
effect O
sizes O
were O
found O
for O
frontal O
regions O
( O
DLPFC O
, O
IFG O
, O
and O
the O
precentral O
gyrus O
) O
. O

Follow-up O
regression O
models O
revealed O
that O
the O
left O
DLPFC O
was O
uniquely O
associated O
with O
both O
drinking O
variables O
. O

Sex O
differences O
were O
also O
observed O
, O
with O
significant O
effects O
largely O
specific O
to O
men O
. O

Conclusions O
. O

This O
study O
adds O
to O
the O
understanding O
of O
brain O
correlates O
of O
alcohol O
use O
in O
a O
large O
, O
gender-balanced O
sample O
of O
younger O
adults O
. O

Although O
the O
cross-sectional O
methodology O
precludes O
causal O
inferences O
, O
these O
findings O
provide O
a O
foundation O
for O
rigorous O
hypothesis O
testing O
in O
future O
longitudinal O
investigations O
. O

Materials O
and O
Methods O
Participants O
Structural O
MRI O
brain O
scans O
were O
drawn O
from O
the O
1200 O
Subjects O
HCP O
dataset O
( O
released O
March O
1 O
, O
2017 O
; O
available O
at O
http O
: O
//www.humanconnectome.org/ O
) O
. O

The O
primary O
HCP O
participant O
pool O
consisted O
of O
community O
adults O
between O
the O
ages O
of O
22–37 O
. O

Participants O
were O
excluded O
from O
the O
HCP O
study O
if O
they O
had O
a O
history O
of O
neurodevelopmental O
, O
neuropsychiatric O
, O
or O
neurological O
disorders O
, O
as O
well O
as O
significant O
medical O
conditions O
such O
as O
diabetes O
or O
high O
blood O
pressure O
. O

The O
use O
of O
drugs O
or O
tobacco O
were O
not O
exclusionary O
and O
these O
variables O
were O
included O
as O
covariates O
in O
all O
analyses O
( O
see O
below O
) O
. O

The O
current O
study O
sample O
consisted O
of O
HCP O
participants O
who O
reported O
consuming O
at O
least O
one O
alcoholic O
drink O
in O
the O
past-week O
retrospective O
alcohol O
assessment O
( O
details O
below O
) O
, O
resulting O
in O
a O
sample O
of O
711 O
participants O
. O

An O
additional O
5 O
participants O
were O
excluded O
due O
to O
incomplete O
data O
( O
3 O
did O
not O
complete O
the O
drinking O
assessments O
, O
and O
2 O
did O
not O
provide O
full O
demographic O
information O
) O
. O

The O
final O
sample O
consisted O
of O
706 O
participants O
. O

Assessments O
Access O
to O
restricted O
participant O
demographic O
and O
clinical O
data O
was O
granted O
via O
written O
authorization O
from O
the O
HCP O
Connectome O
Coordination O
Facility O
. O

Participants O
completed O
the O
Semi-Structured O
Assessment O
for O
the O
Genetics O
of O
Alcoholism O
( O
SSAGA O
, O
) O
. O

The O
SSAGA O
assesses O
physical O
, O
psychological O
, O
and O
social O
symptoms O
of O
alcohol O
abuse O
and O
dependence O
as O
well O
as O
other O
psychiatric O
disorders O
using O
DSM-III-R O
and O
DSM-IV O
criteria O
. O

The O
SSAGA O
also O
covers O
general O
demographic O
information O
, O
medical O
history O
, O
information O
about O
tobacco O
and O
drug O
use O
, O
and O
other O
mental O
health O
variables O
. O

Participants O
also O
completed O
a O
seven-day O
retrospective O
report O
of O
alcohol O
and O
tobacco O
use O
. O

Participants O
provided O
a O
commercially O
available O
urine O
drug O
screen O
for O
biochemical O
testing O
of O
recent O
drug O
use O
. O

Two O
neurocognitive O
measures O
from O
the O
HCP O
behavioral O
assessment O
battery O
were O
assessed O
here O
. O

These O
measures O
were O
drawn O
from O
the O
NIH O
Toolbox O
( O
http O
: O
//www.healthmeasures.net/exploremeasurement-systems/nih-toolbox O
) O
, O
including O
a O
measure O
of O
executive O
function/inhibition O
( O
flanker O
task O
) O
and O
a O
measure O
of O
working O
memory O
( O
list O
sorting O
) O
. O

Full O
details O
of O
the O
HCP O
behavioral O
measures O
are O
provided O
elsewhere O
. O

Alcohol O
Variables O
Two O
alcohol O
variables O
from O
the O
HCP O
dataset O
were O
examined O
in O
the O
current O
study O
. O

The O
first O
, O
“ O
Total O
drinks O
in O
past O
7 O
days O
” O
, O
was O
taken O
from O
the O
retrospective O
alcohol O
use O
assessment O
. O

The O
second O
, O
“ O
Frequency O
of O
drinking O
5+ O
drinks O
in O
past O
12 O
months O
” O
, O
was O
taken O
from O
the O
SSAGA O
assessment O
. O

This O
variable O
was O
coded O
categorically O
in O
the O
HCP O
dataset O
, O
but O
the O
coding O
for O
the O
highest O
frequency O
differed O
for O
males O
and O
females O
( O
i.e. O
, O
the O
maximum O
response O
of O
3+ O
days/week O
was O
coded O
as O
1 O
for O
males O
, O
but O
2 O
for O
females O
) O
. O

The O
next O
lowest O
value O
( O
1–2 O
days/week O
) O
was O
coded O
as O
2 O
for O
both O
males O
and O
females O
. O

Therefore O
, O
no O
distinction O
could O
be O
made O
between O
1–2 O
vs. O
3+ O
days/week O
for O
females O
. O

To O
standardize O
the O
maximum O
response O
, O
the O
data O
were O
recoded O
as O
follows O
( O
and O
reverse-scored O
such O
that O
higher O
values O
reflect O
greater O
frequency O
) O
: O
1 O
= O
never O
; O
1–11 O
days/year O
= O
2 O
; O
13 O
days/month O
= O
3 O
; O
weekly O
or O
greater O
= O
4 O
. O

Selection O
of O
these O
two O
alcohol O
variables O
was O
based O
on O
previous O
research O
examining O
continuous O
associations O
between O
recent O
drinking O
quantity O
and O
cortical O
thickness O
( O
e.g. O
, O
) O
and O
prior O
research O
that O
focused O
specifically O
on O
structural O
brain O
correlates O
of O
binge O
drinking O
as O
a O
unique O
predictor O
of O
cortical O
thickness O
differences O
( O
e.g. O
, O
) O
. O

MRI O
Data O
Acquisition O
and O
Data O
Quality O
Control O
High-resolution O
T1-weighted O
structural O
images O
were O
collected O
on O
a O
3T O
Siemens O
Skyra O
scanner O
( O
Siemens O
AG O
, O
Erlanger O
, O
Germany O
) O
with O
a O
32-channel O
head O
coil O
( O
for O
full O
acquisition O
protocol O
, O
see O
) O
. O

Briefly O
, O
images O
were O
acquired O
with O
a O
0.7 O
mm3 O
isotropic O
resolution O
( O
FOV O
= O
224 O
× O
240 O
, O
matrix O
= O
320 O
× O
320 O
, O
256 O
sagittal O
slices O
; O
TR O
= O
2400 O
ms O
and O
TE O
= O
2.14 O
ms O
) O
. O

Following O
MRI O
, O
each O
structural O
scan O
was O
examined O
by O
a O
trained O
rater O
to O
assess O
the O
overall O
quality O
of O
the O
scan O
’ O
s O
contrast O
, O
blurring O
, O
ringing O
, O
and O
other O
possible O
artifacts O
. O

Only O
the O
scans O
rated O
as O
excellent O
were O
released O
as O
part O
of O
the O
HCP O
dataset O
. O

For O
full O
explanation O
of O
HCP O
quality O
control O
procedures O
, O
see O
. O

FreeSurfer O
Processing O
Pipelines O
Cortical O
thickness O
data O
were O
generated O
using O
the O
HCP O
minimal O
preprocessing O
pipeline O
described O
in O
. O

In O
the O
first O
part O
of O
the O
pipeline O
, O
PreFreeSurfer O
is O
used O
to O
produce O
a O
clear O
structural O
volume O
space O
for O
each O
subject O
, O
align O
the O
images O
, O
perform O
a O
B1 O
correction O
, O
and O
register O
the O
subject O
’ O
s O
structural O
volume O
space O
to O
the O
MNI O
space O
. O

The O
second O
part O
of O
the O
pipeline O
is O
based O
on O
FreeSurfer O
version O
5.2 O
( O
http O
: O
//surfer.nmr.mgh.harvard.edu O
) O
. O

This O
pipeline O
ensures O
that O
the O
volume O
is O
segmented O
into O
predefined O
structures O
, O
that O
the O
white O
and O
pial O
surfaces O
are O
reconstructed O
, O
and O
that O
FreeSurfer O
’ O
s O
folding O
based O
surface O
registration O
( O
to O
the O
surface O
atlas O
fsaverage O
) O
is O
performed O
. O

Structural O
data O
analyzed O
for O
the O
current O
study O
came O
from O
this O
second O
step O
. O

This O
pipeline O
generates O
34 O
anatomical O
regions O
of O
interest O
( O
ROIs O
) O
per O
cortical O
hemisphere O
. O

The O
mean O
cortical O
thickness O
in O
each O
of O
the O
68 O
ROIs O
was O
provided O
per O
person O
in O
the O
HCP O
public O
dataset O
. O

Selection O
of O
Regions O
of O
Interest O
We O
examined O
cortical O
thickness O
in O
a O
series O
of O
a O
priori O
regions O
that O
were O
chosen O
based O
on O
previous O
studies O
on O
cortical O
thickness O
in O
alcohol O
use O
samples O
. O

Specifically O
, O
we O
identified O
18 O
bilateral O
ROIs O
that O
have O
shown O
significant O
differences O
in O
at O
least O
one O
of O
these O
prior O
studies O
. O

Following O
conventions O
used O
in O
prior O
studies O
( O
e.g. O
, O
) O
, O
a O
subset O
of O
these O
regions O
were O
combined O
into O
composite O
regions O
corresponding O
to O
the O
ACC O
, O
OFC O
, O
IFG O
, O
and O
DLPFC O
, O
reducing O
the O
number O
of O
regions O
from O
18 O
to O
12 O
. O

The O
ACC O
composite O
region O
was O
created O
by O
combining O
the O
caudal O
and O
rostral O
ACC O
segments O
. O

The O
DLPFC O
composite O
was O
created O
by O
combining O
the O
caudal O
MFG O
, O
rostral O
MFG O
, O
and O
the O
SFG O
segments O
. O

Lastly O
, O
the O
OFC O
composite O
was O
created O
by O
combining O
the O
lateral O
and O
medial O
OFC O
segments O
. O

The O
only O
previous O
study O
to O
observe O
significant O
results O
for O
the O
IFG O
did O
not O
indicate O
a O
specific O
sub-component O
of O
the O
IFG O
( O
pars O
opercularis O
, O
pars O
orbitalis O
, O
pars O
triangularis O
) O
, O
so O
these O
three O
regions O
were O
combined O
into O
a O
single O
IFG O
composite O
region O
. O

The O
final O
list O
of O
12 O
a O
priori O
ROIs O
and O
the O
studies O
reporting O
differences O
in O
these O
areas O
is O
provided O
in O
Table O
1 O
. O

The O
anatomical O
locations O
of O
individual O
ROIs O
and O
composite O
regions O
are O
depicted O
in O
Figure O
1 O
. O

These O
ROIs O
were O
examined O
separately O
for O
the O
left O
and O
right O
hemispheres O
using O
the O
average O
cortical O
thickness O
values O
for O
each O
region O
provided O
in O
the O
HCP O
dataset O
. O

Data O
Analytic O
Plan O
Selection O
of O
the O
covariates O
was O
