Table O
1 O
. O

Cognitive O
Testing O
Participant O
emotional O
intelligence O
was O
assessed O
using O
the O
MATRICS O
Consensus O
Cognitive O
Battery O
( O
MCCB O
) O
. O

This O
testing O
battery O
includes O
7 O
composite O
scores O
of O
processing O
speed O
, O
attention O
, O
working O
memory O
, O
verbal O
learning O
, O
visual O
learning O
, O
problem O
solving O
, O
and O
social O
cognition O
. O

The O
social O
cognition O
score O
is O
calculated O
from O
the O
Mayer-Salovey-Caruso O
Emotional O
Intelligence O
Test O
( O
MSCEIT O
) O
“ O
managing O
emotions O
” O
subscale O
. O

The O
MSCEIT O
includes O
a O
series O
of O
vignettes O
. O

Participants O
are O
presented O
with O
a O
series O
of O
possible O
actions O
related O
to O
each O
vignette O
and O
asked O
to O
assess O
the O
effects O
of O
each O
action O
on O
the O
actor O
’ O
s O
or O
other O
characters O
’ O
mood O
states O
or O
behaviors O
. O

Responses O
are O
based O
on O
a O
Likert-type O
scale O
. O

We O
used O
age O
and O
sex O
normed O
T O
scores O
, O
which O
were O
calculated O
using O
the O
MCCB O
scoring O
package O
. O

MRI O
data O
acquisition O
Boston O
& O
Belmont O
sites O
Data O
were O
acquired O
on O
3T O
Siemens O
Trio O
( O
TIM O
upgrade O
) O
scanners O
using O
a O
standard O
head O
coil O
. O

The O
echoplanar O
imaging O
parameters O
were O
as O
follows O
: O
repetition O
time O
, O
3000 O
milliseconds O
; O
echo O
time O
, O
30 O
milliseconds O
; O
flip O
angle O
, O
85° O
; O
3 O
× O
3 O
× O
3-mm O
voxels O
; O
and O
47 O
axial O
sections O
collected O
with O
interleaved O
acquisition O
and O
no O
gap O
. O

Structural O
data O
included O
a O
high-resolution O
T1 O
image O
. O

In O
addition O
, O
all O
participants O
underwent O
a O
resting O
fMRI O
run O
with O
the O
instructions O
‘ O
remain O
still O
, O
stay O
awake O
, O
and O
keep O
your O
eyes O
open O
’ O
. O

Each O
functional O
run O
lasted O
6.2 O
minutes O
( O
124 O
time O
points O
) O
. O

Pittsburgh O
site O
Data O
were O
acquired O
on O
a O
3T O
Siemens O
Verio O
scanner O
using O
a O
standard O
head O
coil O
. O

The O
echoplanar O
imaging O
parameters O
were O
as O
follows O
: O
repetition O
time O
, O
3000 O
milliseconds O
; O
echo O
time O
, O
30 O
milliseconds O
; O
flip O
angle O
, O
85° O
; O
3 O
× O
3 O
× O
3-mm O
voxels O
; O
and O
45 O
axial O
sections O
collected O
with O
interleaved O
acquisition O
and O
no O
gap O
. O

Structural O
data O
included O
a O
high-resolution O
T1 O
image O
. O

In O
addition O
, O
all O
participants O
underwent O
a O
resting O
fMRI O
run O
that O
lasted O
6.2 O
minutes O
( O
124 O
time O
points O
) O
. O

MRI O
data O
processing O
The O
imaging O
data O
was O
preprocessed O
using O
DPABI O
image O
processing O
software O
. O

To O
minimize O
effects O
of O
scanner O
signal O
stabilization O
, O
the O
first O
four O
images O
were O
omitted O
from O
all O
analysis O
. O

Scans O
with O
head O
motion O
exceeding O
3 O
mm O
or O
3° O
of O
maximum O
rotation O
through O
the O
resting-state O
run O
were O
discarded O
( O
n O
= O
28 O
) O
. O

Functional O
and O
structural O
images O
were O
co-registered O
. O

Structural O
images O
were O
then O
normalized O
and O
segmented O
into O
gray O
, O
white O
and O
CSF O
partitions O
using O
the O
DARTEL O
technique O
. O

A O
Friston O
24-parameter O
model O
was O
used O
to O
regress O
out O
head O
motion O
effects O
from O
the O
realigned O
data O
. O

CSF O
and O
white O
matter O
signals O
, O
global O
signal O
as O
well O
as O
the O
linear O
trend O
were O
also O
regressed O
out O
. O

The O
decision O
to O
regress O
the O
global O
signal O
was O
based O
on O
prior O
demonstration O
that O
the O
combination O
of O
this O
step O
plus O
volume-wise O
‘ O
scrubbing O
’ O
for O
head O
‘ O
micromovements O
’ O
is O
an O
effective O
strategy O
for O
removal O
of O
motion O
artifacts O
. O

After O
realigning O
, O
slice O
timing O
correction O
, O
and O
co-registration O
, O
framewise O
displacement O
( O
FD O
) O
was O
calculated O
for O
all O
resting O
state O
volumes O
. O

All O
volumes O
within O
a O
scan O
with O
a O
FD O
greater O
than O
0.2-mm O
were O
censored O
. O

Any O
scan O
with O
at O
least O
50 O
% O
of O
volumes O
requiring O
censoring O
was O
discarded O
( O
n O
= O
18 O
) O
. O

After O
nuisance O
covariate O
regression O
, O
the O
resultant O
data O
were O
band-pass O
filtered O
to O
select O
low O
frequency O
( O
0.01 O
– O
0.08Hz O
) O
signals O
. O

Filtered O
data O
were O
normalized O
by O
DARTEL O
into O
MNI O
space O
and O
then O
smoothed O
by O
a O
Gaussian O
kernel O
of O
8mm3 O
full-width O
at O
half O
maximum O
( O
FWHM O
) O
. O

Voxels O
within O
a O
group O
derived O
gray O
matter O
mask O
were O
used O
for O
further O
analyses O
. O

After O
preprocessing O
, O
a O
total O
of O
60 O
participants O
with O
schizophrenia O
or O
schizoaffective O
disorder O
, O
and O
45 O
HC O
participants O
across O
all O
sites O
remained O
in O
the O
study O
( O
Supplemental O
Table O
1 O
) O
. O

Functional O
Connectivity O
Analysis O
Multivariate O
Distance O
Matrix O
Regression O
We O
performed O
a O
connectome-wide O
association O
study O
using O
multivariate O
distance O
matrix O
regression O
( O
MDMR O
) O
as O
originally O
described O
in O
. O

Briefly O
, O
MDMR O
tests O
every O
voxel O
to O
determine O
if O
whole-brain O
connectivity O
to O
that O
voxel O
is O
more O
similar O
in O
individuals O
with O
similar O
MSCEIT O
score O
than O
in O
individuals O
with O
dissimilar O
MSCEIT O
score O
. O

As O
previously O
described O
, O
this O
analysis O
occurs O
in O
several O
stages O
: O
First O
, O
a O
seed-to-voxel O
connectivity O
map O
is O
generated O
by O
using O
an O
individual O
voxel O
’ O
s O
BOLD O
signal O
time-course O
to O
calculate O
the O
temporal O
Pearson O
’ O
s O
correlation O
coefficients O
between O
that O
voxel O
and O
all O
other O
gray O
matter O
voxels O
( O
Figure O
1B O
) O
. O

These O
maps O
are O
generated O
for O
every O
participant O
. O

In O
the O
second O
stage O
, O
the O
temporal O
correlation O
coefficients O
for O
each O
voxel O
in O
the O
connectivity O
map O
is O
correlated O
with O
the O
values O
of O
corresponding O
voxels O
in O
maps O
generated O
from O
every O
other O
participant O
. O

This O
Pearson O
’ O
s O
correlation O
coefficient O
, O
r O
is O
a O
measure O
of O
the O
similarity O
of O
whole-brain O
connectivity O
to O
that O
voxel O
between O
patients O
. O

This O
value O
is O
used O
to O
calculate O
between-subject O
distance O
( O
or O
dissimilarity O
) O
using O
the O
metric O
where O
i O
and O
j O
are O
two O
subjects O
and O
r O
is O
the O
correlation O
coefficient O
above O
. O

( O
Figure O
1C O
) O
. O

The O
next O
stage O
tests O
the O
relationship O
between O
a O
given O
variable O
( O
here O
MSCEIT O
score O
) O
and O
the O
inter-subject O
distances O
in O
connectivity O
generated O
in O
the O
previous O
stage O
. O

Broadly O
speaking O
, O
this O
process O
consists O
of O
ANOVA-like O
hypothesis O
testing O
where O
the O
tested O
relationship O
is O
between O
a O
variable O
of O
interest O
and O
a O
matrix O
of O
distances O
. O

This O
process O
was O
originally O
termed O
multivariate O
distance O
matrix O
regression O
by O
Zapala O
and O
Schork O
and O
used O
to O
test O
associations O
between O
gene O
expression O
and O
related O
variables O
. O

Shezhad O
et O
al O
. O

then O
used O
their O
framework O
for O
testing O
the O
relationship O
between O
variables O
of O
interest O
and O
a O
matrix O
of O
distances O
where O
the O
matrix O
is O
between-subject O
similarity O
in O
whole-brain O
functional O
connectivity O
. O

This O
test O
consists O
of O
first O
forming O
a O
distance O
matrix O
among O
n O
participants O
where O
d O
= O
the O
between O
subject O
distance O
metric O
calculated O
above O
. O

Next O
, O
this O
matrix O
is O
used O
to O
create O
a O
Gower O
’ O
s O
centered O
matrix O
, O
in O
which O
n O
is O
the O
number O
of O
participants O
, O
I O
is O
the O
n O
× O
n O
identity O
matrix O
, O
and O
1 O
is O
a O
vector O
of O
n O
1s O
. O

The O
F O
statistic O
for O
assessing O
the O
relationship O
between O
a O
predictor O
variable O
( O
e.g O
. O

MSCEIT O
score O
) O
and O
dissimilarities O
in O
connectivity O
is O
calculated O
as O
follows O
: O
For O
m O
predictor O
variables O
, O
let O
X O
be O
a O
n× O
m O
design O
matrix O
of O
predictor O
values O
, O
and O
let O
H O
= O
X O
( O
XT O
X O
) O
−1 O
XT O
be O
the O
associated O
n O
× O
m O
“ O
hat O
” O
matrix O
. O

( O
Figure O
1D O
) O
. O

This O
process O
is O
repeated O
for O
every O
voxel O
. O

The O
result O
is O
a O
whole O
brain O
map O
of O
how O
significantly O
MSCEIT O
scores O
are O
related O
to O
functional O
connectivity O
at O
every O
voxel O
( O
Figure O
1E O
) O
. O

From O
that O
map O
, O
ROIs O
for O
follow-up O
analysis O
are O
defined O
based O
on O
clusters O
of O
significant O
voxelwise O
F-statistics O
. O

To O
correct O
for O
multiple O
comparisons O
, O
a O
nonparametric O
permutation O
was O
calculated O
for O
voxels O
that O
exceeded O
the O
significance O
threshold O
of O
p O
< O
0.001 O
and O
clusters O
of O
such O
with O
an O
extent O
threshold O
of O
p O
< O
0.05 O
, O
with O
a O
null O
distribution O
calculated O
from O
5000 O
such O
permutations O
( O
Figure O
1F O
) O
. O

Scanner O
site O
was O
included O
as O
a O
covariate O
in O
this O
analysis O
. O

The O
voxelwise O
threshold O
was O
selected O
to O
maximize O
the O
likelihood O
of O
replicability O
. O

This O
analysis O
identifies O
anatomical O
regions O
where O
MSCEIT O
score O
is O
significantly O
related O
to O
functional O
connectivity O
. O

Recall O
that O
at O
each O
brain O
voxel O
MDMR O
calculates O
a O
distance O
metric O
r O
between O
subjects O
by O
first O
calculating O
the O
temporal O
correlation O
in O
BOLD O
signal O
between O
that O
voxel O
and O
every O
other O
brain O
voxel O
. O

The O
generated O
set O
of O
temporal O
correlations O
is O
then O
correlated O
with O
the O
analogous O
set O
of O
temporal O
correlations O
from O
a O
different O
subject O
. O

The O
resulting O
between-subject O
correlation O
determines O
a O
distance O
metric O
that O
is O
a O
measure O
of O
between-subject O
similarity O
( O
or O
dissimilarity O
) O
in O
terms O
of O
functional O
connectivity O
at O
that O
voxel O
. O

Notably O
, O
this O
process O
disregards O
spatial O
information O
about O
the O
voxels O
that O
gave O
rise O
to O
between-individual O
distances O
e.g O
. O

Two O
individuals O
may O
be O
very O
distant O
( O
dissimilar O
) O
in O
the O
functional O
connectivity O
of O
a O
voxel O
in O
the O
precuneus O
, O
but O
is O
their O
dissimilarity O
driven O
by O
differences O
in O
precuneus O
connectivity O
to O
the O
mPFC O
or O
temporal O
lobe O
or O
parietal O
lobe O
or O
all O
of O
the O
above O
? O

MDMR O
as O
implemented O
by O
Shehzad O
et O
al O
. O

does O
not O
display O
this O
information O
. O

To O
visualize O
this O
spatial O
information O
requires O
follow-on O
seed-based O
connectivity O
analysis O
. O

Shehzad O
et O
al O
. O

and O
others O
have O
termed O
this O
follow-on O
analysis O
‘ O
post-hoc O
’ O
testing O
to O
make O
clear O
that O
this O
should O
not O
be O
considered O
independent O
hypothesis O
testing O
nor O
should O
it O
be O
considered O
independent O
validation O
of O
the O
original O
MDMR O
finding O
. O

As O
in O
these O
prior O
manuscripts O
, O
we O
conducted O
the O
MDMR O
analysis O
to O
find O
anatomical O
regions O
where O
connectivity O
significantly O
varied O
with O
MSCEIT O
score O
and O
then O
conducted O
follow-on O
seed-based O
connectivity O
analysis O
to O
examine O
the O
spatial O
distribution O
of O
these O
connectivity O
differences O
. O

Seed O
based O
connectivity O
analyses O
For O
seed O
based O
connectivity O
analyses O
we O
used O
DPABI O
to O
extract O
the O
time O
course O
of O
the O
BOLD O
signal O
in O
a O
given O
ROI O
. O

We O
then O
generated O
whole O
brain O
maps O
of O
z-transformed O
Pearson O
’ O
s O
correlation O
coefficients O
. O

These O
maps O
were O
entered O
into O
SPM12 O
( O
Statistical O
and O
Parametric O
Mapping O
, O
http O
: O
//www.fil.ion.ucl.ac.uk/spm O
) O
. O

For O
ROIs O
generated O
from O
MDMR O
above O
, O
we O
regressed O
the O
maps O
against O
MSCEIT O
score O
to O
generate O
spatial O
maps O
of O
how O
whole O
brain O
functional O
connectivity O
to O
the O
ROIs O
varies O
with O
MSCEIT O
score O
. O

To O
control O
for O
participant O
variables O
of O
non-interest O
, O
we O
performed O
these O
analyses O
with O
age O
, O
race O
, O
diagnosis O
( O
Schizophrenia O
or O
Healthy O
Comparison O
) O
, O
scanner O
site O
, O
and O
sex O
as O
additional O
covariates O
. O

To O
control O
for O
movement O
effects O
we O
also O
included O
individual O
mean O
FD O
( O
framewise O
displacement O
) O
as O
a O
covariate O
as O
a O
subject-level O
correction O
for O
motion O
effects O
in O
all O
subjects O
. O

In O
addition O
to O
including O
mean O
FD O
as O
a O
covariate O
in O
the O
seed-based O
connectivity O
analysis O
, O
we O
did O
not O
observe O
a O
significant O
correlation O
between O
MSCEIT O
score O
and O
either O
mean O
within-scanner O
movement O
as O
measured O
by O
average O
framewise O
displacement O
( O
r=−.109 O
, O
p=.268 O
) O
, O
nor O
did O
we O
observe O
a O
significant O
correlation O
between O
MSCEIT O
score O
and O
the O
number O
of O
volumes O
remaining O
after O
preprocessing O
for O
movement O
( O
r=0.14 O
and O
p=0.15 O
) O
. O

To O
control O
for O
the O
effects O
of O
medication O
regimen O
, O
the O
analyses O
were O
re-performed O
with O
prescribed O
anti-psychotic O
dosage O
( O
in O
chlorpromazine O
equivalents O
, O
CPZE O
) O
as O
a O
covariate O
within O
the O
schizophrenia/schizoaffective O
group O
. O

For O
other O
, O
subsequent O
ROI O
based O
connectivity O
analyses O
described O
below O
, O
we O
used O
DPABI O
to O
calculate O
the O
time O
course O
of O
the O
average O
BOLD O
signal O
in O
a O
sphere O
, O
and O
then O
generated O
whole O
brain O
maps O
of O
z-transformed O
Pearson O
’ O
s O
correlation O
coefficients O
. O

We O
then O
used O
SPM12 O
to O
generate O
single-sample O
t-tests O
of O
these O
connectivity O
maps O
. O

Correlations O
between O
ROI O
to O
ROI O
connectivity O
and O
emotional O
intelligence O
Partial O
correlation O
coefficients O
and O
statistic O
values O
were O
calculated O
in O
R O
using O
the O
ppcor O
package O
. O

Nth-order O
partial O
correlation O
coefficients O
are O
Pearson O
’ O
s O
correlations O
between O
two O
variables O
of O
interest O
while O
controlling O
for O
n O
covariates O
. O

Categorical O
covariates O
were O
binarized O
. O

Structural O
MRI O
Analysis O
Structural O
MPRAGE O
images O
were O
checked O
for O
artifacts O
and O
were O
processed O
using O
Freesurfer O
6 O
( O
http O
: O
//surfer.nmr.mgh.harvard.edu/ O
) O
. O

The O
images O
went O
through O
first-level O
auto-reconstruction O
to O
register O
the O
scans O
in O
standard O
space O
and O
skull O
strip O
the O
brains O
. O

One O
rater O
( O
OL O
) O
edited O
the O
images O
to O
remove O
dura O
, O
sinuses O
and O
vessels O
that O
could O
interfere O
with O
segmentation O
. O

After O
visual O
inspection O
, O
98 O
images O
were O
retained O
for O
analysis O
. O

The O
images O
then O
went O
through O
second O
and O
third O
level O
auto-reconstruction O
to O
register O
the O
brains O
to O
the O
Desikan-Killiany O
atlas O
and O
extract O
sulcal O
depth O
measurements O
. O

Sulcal O
depth O
in O
Freesurfer O
is O
the O
integrated O
dot O
product O
of O
the O
movement O
vector O
and O
the O
surface O
normal O
during O
inflation O
. O

Deep O
regions O
therefore O
are O
expressed O
as O
positive O
values O
as O
they O
move O
outwards O
while O
more O
superficial O
regions O
move O
inwards O
. O

Units O
are O
the O
standard O
deviation O
from O
the O
median O
value O
. O

Table O
and O
figure O
generation O
Graphs O
of O
relationships O
between O
emotional O
intelligence O
and O
structural/functional O
measures O
were O
generated O
using O
R. O
Projections O
of O
ROIs O
and O
T O
contrast O
maps O
onto O
cortical O
surfaces O
was O
accomplished O
using O
FSL O
, O
Caret O
and O
Surf O
Ice O
( O
www.nitrc.org/projects/surfice/ O
) O
. O

Functional O
Connectome O
Organization O
Predicts O
Conversion O
to O
Psychosis O
in O
Clinical O
High-Risk O
Youth O
from O
the O
SHARP O
Program O
The O
emergence O
of O
prodromal O
symptoms O
of O
schizophrenia O
and O
their O
evolution O
into O
overt O
psychosis O
may O
stem O
from O
an O
aberrant O
functional O
reorganization O
of O
the O
brain O
during O
adolescence O
. O

To O
examine O
whether O
abnormalities O
in O
connectome O
organization O
precede O
psychosis O
onset O
, O
we O
performed O
a O
functional O
connectome O
analysis O
in O
a O
large O
cohort O
of O
medication-naïve O
youth O
at O
risk O
for O
psychosis O
from O
the O
Shanghai O
At O
Risk O
for O
Psychosis O
( O
SHARP O
) O
study O
. O

The O
SHARP O
program O
is O
a O
longitudinal O
study O
of O
adolescents O
and O
young O
adults O
at O
Clinical O
High O
Risk O
( O
CHR O
) O
for O
psychosis O
, O
conducted O
at O
the O
Shanghai O
Mental O
Health O
Center O
in O
collaboration O
with O
neuroimaging O
laboratories O
at O
Harvard O
and O
MIT O
. O

Our O
study O
involved O
a O
total O
of O
251 O
subjects O
, O
including O
158 O
CHRs O
and O
93 O
age- O
, O
sex- O
, O
and O
education-matched O
healthy O
controls O
. O

During O
one-year O
follow-up O
, O
23 O
CHRs O
developed O
psychosis O
. O

CHRs O
who O
would O
go O
on O
to O
develop O
psychosis O
were O
found O
to O
show O
abnormal O
modular O
connectome O
organization O
at O
baseline O
, O
while O
CHR O
non-converters O
did O
not O
. O

In O
all O
CHRs O
, O
abnormal O
modular O
connectome O
organization O
at O
baseline O
was O
associated O
with O
a O
three-fold O
conversion O
rate O
. O

A O
region-specific O
analysis O
showed O
that O
brain O
regions O
implicated O
in O
early-course O
schizophrenia O
, O
including O
superior O
temporal O
gyrus O
and O
anterior O
cingulate O
cortex O
, O
were O
most O
abnormal O
in O
terms O
of O
modular O
assignment O
. O

Our O
results O
show O
that O
functional O
changes O
in O
brain O
network O
organization O
precede O
the O
onset O
of O
psychosis O
and O
may O
drive O
psychosis O
development O
in O
at-risk O
youth O
. O

Materials O
and O
methods O
Participants O
This O
study O
involved O
a O
total O
of O
251 O
participants O
, O
including O
158 O
Clinical O
High O
Risk O
( O
CHR O
) O
subjects O
and O
93 O
Healthy O
Controls O
( O
HC O
) O
matched O
to O
CHRs O
based O
on O
age O
, O
sex O
, O
and O
education O
in O
years O
. O

The O
large O
majority O
of O
CHRs O
was O
naïve O
to O
psychotropic O
medication O
at O
baseline O
clinical O
assessment O
( O
> O
95 O
% O
) O
and O
neuroimaging O
( O
> O
80 O
% O
) O
. O

Participants O
were O
recruited O
at O
the O
Shanghai O
Mental O
Health O
Center O
( O
SMHC O
) O
, O
as O
part O
of O
the O
Shanghai O
At O
Risk O
for O
Psychosis O
( O
SHARP O
) O
program O
. O

This O
NIMH-funded O
study O
is O
a O
collaboration O
between O
SMHC O
, O
Harvard O
Medical O
School O
at O
Beth O
Israel O
Deaconess O
Medical O
Center O
( O
BIDMC O
) O
and O
Brigham O
and O
Women O
’ O
s O
Hospital O
, O
and O
Massachusetts O
Institute O
of O
Technology O
( O
study O
details O
including O
power O
analysis O
and O
in/exclusion O
criteria O
in O
Supplementary O
Information O
1.1 O
) O
. O

The O
study O
was O
approved O
by O
Institutional O
Review O
Boards O
of O
BIDMC O
and O
SMHC O
. O

All O
subjects O
or O
their O
legal O
guardians O
gave O
written O
informed O
consent O
. O

Table O
1 O
provides O
demographic O
and O
clinical O
characteristics O
of O
all O
participants O
. O

Clinical O
and O
cognitive O
assessment O
Prodromal O
symptoms O
were O
assessed O
using O
a O
validated O
Chinese O
version O
of O
the O
Structured O
Interview O
for O
Prodromal O
Symptoms O
( O
SIPS O
) O
. O

Total O
IQ O
was O
estimated O
using O
the O
Wechsler O
Abbreviated O
Scale O
of O
Intelligence O
( O
WASI O
) O
. O

Conversion O
criteria O
During O
a O
mean O
( O
sd O
) O
follow-up O
of O
392 O
( O
77 O
) O
days O
, O
23 O
CHRs O
developed O
psychosis O
( O
CHR+ O
) O
, O
while O
135 O
did O
not O
( O
CHR- O
) O
. O

Conversion O
to O
psychosis O
was O
determined O
using O
the O
SIPS O
operational O
definition O
of O
psychosis O
onset O
, O
with O
at O
least O
one O
psychotic O
level O
symptom O
( O
rated O
“ O
6 O
” O
on O
the O
SIPS O
positive O
scale O
) O
with O
either O
sufficient O
frequency O
or O
duration O
. O

For O
CHR+ O
, O
the O
date O
of O
conversion O
was O
recorded O
and O
time O
to O
psychosis O
computed O
as O
the O
number O
of O
days O
between O
study O
inclusion O
and O
psychosis O
onset O
. O

Image O
acquisition O
Magnetic O
Resonance O
Imaging O
( O
MRI O
) O
scans O
were O
acquired O
on O
a O
3T O
Siemens O
MR O
B17 O
( O
Verio O
) O
system O
, O
32-channel O
head O
coil O
at O
the O
SMHC O
and O
included O
an O
anatomical O
T1-weighted O
MRI O
scan O
( O
MP-RAGE O
; O
TR=2300 O
ms O
, O
TE=2.96 O
ms O
, O
FA=9 O
degree O
, O
FOV=256mm O
, O
voxel O
size O
: O
1×1×1mm O
, O
192 O
contiguous O
sagittal O
slices O
, O
duration O
9 O
’ O
14 O
’ O
’ O
) O
and O
resting-state O
fMRI O
( O
rs-fMRI O
) O
scan O
( O
149 O
functional O
volumes O
; O
TR=2500 O
ms O
, O
TE=30 O
ms O
, O
FA=90 O
degree O
, O
FOV=224mm O
, O
voxel O
size O
: O
3.5×3.5×3.5mm O
, O
37 O
contiguous O
axial O
slices O
, O
duration O
6 O
’ O
19 O
’ O
’ O
) O
. O

Image O
preprocessing O
Figure O
1 O
provides O
an O
overview O
of O
all O
analysis O
steps O
. O

As O
connectivity O
and O
connectome O
metrics O
are O
sensitive O
to O
methodological O
factors O
including O
image O
preprocessing O
and O
node O
selection O
, O
two O
processing O
streams O
were O
used O
to O
process O
our O
data O
to O
ensure O
that O
results O
were O
not O
specific O
to O
any O
one O
methodology O
( O
Figure O
1A O
) O
: O
a O
surface-based O
method O
, O
the O
results O
of O
which O
are O
presented O
as O
primary O
findings O
, O
and O
an O
MNI-based O
method O
used O
to O
verify O
primary O
findings O
. O

Image O
processing O
is O
described O
in O
detail O
in O
Supplementary O
Information O
1.2 O
. O

Briefly O
, O
FreeSurfer O
( O
v6.0 O
) O
and O
CONN O
( O
v17d O
) O
software O
were O
used O
to O
preprocess O
T1 O
and O
rs-fMRI O
data O
. O

For O
surface-based O
processing O
, O
a O
total O
of O
162 O
subject-specific O
ROIs O
derived O
from O
FreeSurfer O
were O
used O
as O
nodes O
, O
including O
148 O
regions O
comprising O
the O
Destrieux O
Atlas O
and O
14 O
subcortical O
structures O
( O
bilateral O
thalamus O
, O
hippocampus O
, O
amygdala O
, O
nucleus O
accumbens O
, O
caudate O
nucleus O
, O
putamen O
and O
global O
pallidus O
) O
. O

For O
MNI-based O
processing O
, O
T1 O
and O
rs-fMRI O
scans O
were O
normalized O
to O
MNI O
space O
and O
the O
Harvard-Oxford O
Atlas O
was O
used O
to O
divide O
the O
cerebrum O
into O
a O
total O
of O
105 O
brain O
regions O
, O
including O
91 O
cortical O
brain O
regions O
and O
the O
same O
14 O
subcortical O
structures O
. O

Rigorous O
motion O
correction O
and O
artifact O
removal O
were O
performed O
to O
deal O
with O
spurious O
correlations O
. O

There O
were O
no O
significant O
group-differences O
in O
motion O
parameters O
or O
the O
number O
of O
rejected O
fMRI O
volumes O
( O
Supplementary O
Information O
1.2 O
) O
. O

Functional O
connectome O
reconstruction O
A O
functional O
connectome O
was O
constructed O
for O
each O
participant O
, O
consisting O
of O
162 O
subject-specific O
( O
or O
105 O
atlas-based O
) O
nodes O
representing O
the O
aforementioned O
brain O
regions O
. O

The O
level O
of O
functional O
connectivity O
between O
each O
node O
pair O
was O
computed O
as O
the O
normalized O
z-score O
of O
the O
Pearson O
’ O
s O
correlation O
between O
the O
noise-corrected O
timeseries O
of O
each O
pair O
of O
brain O
regions O
and O
stored O
in O
a O
functional O
connectivity O
matrix O
( O
Figure O
1B O
) O
. O

Modular O
organization O
of O
the O
functional O
connectome O
Various O
methods O
exist O
to O
examine O
the O
modular O
organization O
of O
complex O
networks O
. O

Here O
, O
we O
use O
the O
Louvain O
community O
detection O
method O
( O
https O
: O
//sites.google.com/site/bctnet/ O
) O
, O
which O
partitions O
a O
network O
so O
as O
to O
maximize O
metric O
Q O
, O
representing O
the O
strength O
of O
edges O
inside O
communities O
relative O
to O
edges O
between O
communities O
. O

The O
method O
is O
suitable O
for O
functional O
connectome O
analysis O
as O
it O
can O
take O
both O
positive O
and O
negative O
edge O
weights O
( O
i.e. O
, O
connectivity O
estimates O
) O
into O
account O
without O
requiring O
an O
arbitrary O
connectivity O
threshold O
. O

Group-networks O
. O

As O
a O
first O
step O
to O
assess O
the O
modular O
organization O
of O
the O
functional O
connectome O
, O
one O
group-averaged O
functional O
network O
was O
constructed O
for O
HC O
, O
CHR- O
, O
and O
CHR+ O
groups O
. O

Each O
group-network O
’ O
s O
modular O
organization O
was O
assessed O
using O
the O
Louvain O
method O
. O

As O
the O
algorithm O
searches O
for O
high O
modularity O
partitions O
in O
a O
heuristic O
fashion O
, O
resulting O
partitions O
differ O
slightly O
from O
run O
to O
run O
. O

Therefore O
, O
the O
algorithm O
was O
run O
10,000 O
times O
for O
each O
group-network O
and O
the O
partition O
associated O
with O
the O
highest O
level O
of O
Q O
selected O
( O
Figure O
1C O
) O
. O

A O
consensus O
similarity O
method O
was O
used O
as O
an O
alternative O
method O
to O
select O
modular O
partitions O
for O
both O
group O
and O
individual O
networks O
( O
Supplementary O
Information O
1.3 O
) O
. O

Individual O
subjects O
. O

Second O
, O
the O
Louvain O
algorithm O
was O
applied O
to O
individual O
connectome O
reconstructions O
. O

To O
assess O
how O
similar O
the O
modular O
organization O
of O
each O
individual O
network O
was O
to O
an O
average O
healthy O
network O
, O
network O
partitions O
of O
individual O
subjects O
were O
compared O
to O
the O
group-averaged O
HC O
network O
using O
the O
Rand O
similarity O
coefficient O
( O
SR O
) O
, O
providing O
an O
intuitive O
measure O
( O
between O
0 O
and O
1 O
) O
of O
the O
similarity O
between O
two O
partitions O
( O
details O
in O
Supplementary O
Information O
1.3 O
) O
. O

Network O
resolution O
parameter O
γ O
was O
set O
to O
1.5 O
, O
in O
order O
to O
identify O
more O
fine-grained O
modules O
while O
not O
overinflating O
the O
total O
number O
of O
modules O
, O
as O
this O
would O
hamper O
comparisons O
of O
network O
partitions O
. O

In O
addition O
, O
modular O
organization O
was O
examined O
across O
a O
range O
of O
γ O
( O
Supplementary O
Information O
1.3 O
) O
. O

Region-specific O
alterations O
in O
modular O
connectome O
organization O
As O
an O
exploratory O
analysis O
to O
assess O
which O
brain O
regions O
are O
most O
abnormal O
in O
terms O
of O
module O
assignment O
in O
CHR+ O
versus O
CHR- O
, O
individual O
networks O
were O
again O
compared O
to O
the O
HC O
network O
, O
now O
determining O
for O
each O
node O
i O
in O
the O
network O
the O
fraction O
of O
neighboring O
nodes O
with O
equal O
module O
assignment O
( O
details O
in O
Supplementary O
Information O
1.3 O
) O
. O

Code O
availability O
All O
image O
processing O
and O
graph O
analyses O
were O
performed O
using O
freely O
available O
software O
. O

Version O
and O
access O
details O
are O
provided O
in O
Supplementary O
Information O
1.2 O
and O
1.3 O
. O

Statistical O
analysis O
Group O
analysis O
. O

Analysis O
of O
Covariance O
( O
ANCOVA O
) O
was O
used O
to O
compare O
SR O
among O
subject O
groups O
. O

Assumptions O
of O
normality O
and O
homogeneity O
of O
variance O
were O
met O
( O
Supplementary O
Information O
1.4 O
) O
. O

Age O
, O
sex O
, O
and O
the O
number O
of O
rejected O
fMRI O
volumes O
were O
included O
in O
the O
model O
as O
covariates O
, O
and O
group-covariate O
interactions O
were O
assessed O
. O

Medication O
status O
was O
included O
as O
a O
covariate O
of O
non-interest O
as O
a O
minority O
of O
CHRs O
( O
< O
20 O
% O
) O
were O
on O
psychotropic O
medication O
by O
the O
time O
of O
scanning O
. O

Region-specific O
metrics O
were O
analyzed O
using O
the O
same O
ANCOVA O
model O
, O
applying O
FDR-correction O
( O
q O
= O
.05 O
) O
to O
account O
for O
multiple O
comparisons O
. O

Psychosis-free O
survival O
analysis O
. O

To O
determine O
whether O
abnormal O
modular O
connectome O
organization O
at O
baseline O
predicted O
conversion O
to O
psychosis O
, O
CHRs O
were O
divided O
by O
median O
split O
into O
two O
groups O
with O
above O
and O
below-average O
SR O
, O
reflecting O
normal O
and O
abnormal O
modular O
organization O
respectively O
. O

Kaplan O
Meier O
analysis O
was O
used O
to O
assess O
psychosis-free O
survival O
for O
each O
group O
. O

Survival O
functions O
were O
compared O
using O
log-rank O
tests O
. O

Cox O
regression O
analysis O
was O
used O
to O
assess O
how O
baseline O
modular O
organization O
and O
clinical O
characteristics O
( O
i.e. O
, O
age O
, O
sex O
, O
IQ O
, O
SIPS O
symptoms O
, O
and O
GAF O
functioning O
) O
predicted O
time O
to O
conversion O
. O

Functional O
connectivity O
of O
the O
striatum O
in O
schizophrenia O
and O
psychotic O
bipolar O
disorder O
Background O
: O
The O
striatum O
is O
abnormal O
in O
schizophrenia O
, O
and O
possibly O
represents O
a O
common O
neurobiological O
mechanism O
underlying O
psychotic O
disorders O
. O

Resting-state O
fMRI O
( O
RS-fMRI O
) O
studies O
have O
not O
reached O
a O
consensus O
regarding O
striatal O
dysconnectivity O
in O
schizophrenia O
, O
although O
these O
studies O
generally O
find O
impaired O
fronto-parietal O
and O
salience O
network O
connectivity O
. O

The O
goal O
of O
the O
current O
study O
was O
to O
clarify O
the O
pattern O
of O
cortico-striatal O
connectivity O
, O
including O
whether O
cortico-striatal O
dysconnectivity O
is O
transdiagnostic O
and O
extends O
into O
psychotic O
bipolar O
disorder O
. O

Methods O
: O
We O
examined O
cortico-striatal O
functional O
connectivity O
in O
60 O
healthy O
subjects O
and O
117 O
individuals O
with O
psychosis O
, O
including O
77 O
with O
a O
schizophrenia O
spectrum O
illness O
and O
40 O
with O
psychotic O
bipolar O
disorder O
. O

We O
conducted O
both O
a O
cortical O
seed-based O
region-of-interest O
( O
ROI O
) O
analysis O
with O
follow-up O
voxel-wise O
analysis O
for O
any O
significant O
results O
. O

Further O
, O
a O
striatum O
seed-based O
analysis O
was O
conducted O
to O
examine O
group O
differences O
in O
connectivity O
between O
the O
striatum O
and O
the O
whole O
cortex O
. O

Results O
: O
Cortical O
ROI O
analysis O
indicated O
that O
overall O
connectivity O
of O
the O
salience O
network O
with O
the O
striatum O
was O
reduced O
in O
psychotic O
disorders O
, O
which O
follow-up O
voxel-wise O
analysis O
localized O
to O
the O
left O
putamen O
. O

Striatum O
seed-based O
analyses O
showed O
reduced O
ventral O
rostral O
putamen O
connectivity O
with O
the O
salience O
network O
portion O
of O
the O
medial O
PFC O
in O
both O
schizophrenia O
and O
psychotic O
bipolar O
disorders O
. O

Conclusions O
: O
The O
current O
study O
found O
evidence O
of O
transdiagnostic O
cortico-striatal O
dysconnectivity O
in O
both O
schizophrenia O
and O
psychotic O
bipolar O
disorder O
, O
including O
reduced O
salience O
network O
connectivity O
, O
as O
well O
as O
reduced O
connectivity O
between O
the O
putamen O
and O
the O
medial O
PFC O
. O

Overall O
, O
the O
current O
study O
points O
to O
the O
relative O
importance O
of O
salience O
network O
hypo-connectivity O
in O
psychotic O
disorders O
. O

METHODS O
Study O
Participants O
193 O
individuals O
( O
61 O
healthy O
subjects O
, O
132 O
individuals O
with O
a O
psychotic O
disorder O
) O
that O
participated O
in O
an O
on-going O
NIMH-funded O
study O
on O
brain O
connectivity O
in O
psychotic O
disorders O
were O
initially O
screened O
for O
inclusion O
in O
this O
investigation O
. O

16 O
participants O
did O
not O
meet O
our O
neuroimaging O
quality O
assurance O
( O
QA O
) O
procedures O
described O
below O
. O

Thus O
, O
the O
final O
cohort O
consisted O
of O
177 O
study O
participants O
: O
60 O
healthy O
individuals O
, O
77 O
individuals O
with O
a O
schizophrenia O
spectrum O
illness O
( O
i.e O
. O

schizophrenia O
, O
schizoaffective O
, O
and O
schizophreniform O
disorder O
) O
, O
and O
40 O
individuals O
with O
bipolar O
disorder O
with O
psychotic O
features O
( O
i.e O
. O

psychotic O
bipolar O
disorder O
) O
. O

Demographic O
data O
are O
presented O
in O
Table O
1 O
. O

Patients O
were O
recruited O
through O
the O
Psychotic O
Disorders O
Program O
within O
the O
Department O
of O
Psychiatry O
and O
Behavioral O
Sciences O
at O
Vanderbilt O
University O
Medical O
Center O
( O
VUMC O
) O
. O

Healthy O
individuals O
were O
recruited O
from O
Nashville O
and O
surrounding O
area O
via O
advertisement O
and O
word-of-mouth O
. O

This O
study O
was O
approved O
by O
the O
Vanderbilt O
University O
Institutional O
Review O
Board O
. O

All O
study O
participants O
provided O
written O
informed O
consent O
prior O
to O
participating O
. O

Psychiatric O
diagnoses O
were O
confirmed O
in O
patients O
and O
ruled O
out O
in O
healthy O
subjects O
using O
the O
Structured O
Clinical O
Interview O
for O
Diagnosing O
DSM-IV O
Disorders O
( O
SCID O
) O
. O

Patients O
were O
further O
assessed O
with O
the O
Positive O
and O
Negative O
Syndrome O
Scale O
( O
PANSS O
) O
, O
Young O
Mania O
Rating O
Scale O
( O
YMRS O
) O
, O
and O
Hamilton O
Depression O
Scale O
( O
HAM-D O
) O
to O
quantify O
severity O
of O
psychotic O
, O
mania O
, O
and O
depression O
symptoms O
, O
respectively O
. O

The O
Wechsler O
Test O
of O
Adult O
Reading O
( O
WTAR O
) O
was O
administered O
to O
all O
subjects O
to O
provide O
an O
estimate O
of O
pre-morbid O
intellect O
. O

Study O
participants O
also O
completed O
the O
Screen O
for O
Cognitive O
Impairment O
in O
Psychiatry O
( O
SCIP O
) O
, O
a O
brief O
neuropsychological O
battery O
that O
includes O
a O
word O
list O
learning O
test O
of O
verbal O
memory O
, O
a O
version O
of O
the O
Auditory O
Consonant O
Trigrams O
test O
of O
working O
memory O
, O
phonemic O
verbal O
fluency O
, O
and O
a O
coding O
test O
of O
processing O
speed O
. O

SCIP O
sub-test O
raw O
scores O
were O
converted O
to O
z-scores O
using O
previously O
published O
normative O
data O
and O
averaged O
to O
create O
a O
“ O
composite O
” O
z-score O
of O
overall O
cognitive O
functioning O
. O

Exclusion O
criteria O
included O
age O
less O
than O
16 O
or O
greater O
than O
55 O
; O
estimated O
pre-morbid O
IQ O
less O
than O
70 O
; O
presence O
of O
a O
medical O
illness O
or O
central O
nervous O
system O
disorder O
( O
e.g O
. O

multiple O
sclerosis O
, O
epilepsy O
) O
that O
would O
affect O
study O
results O
; O
reported O
pregnancy O
or O
lactation O
; O
history O
of O
significant O
head O
trauma O
; O
psychotropic O
drug O
use O
( O
healthy O
subjects O
only O
) O
; O
substance O
abuse O
within O
last O
three O
months O
( O
patients O
) O
or O
lifetime O
history O
of O
substance O
abuse/dependence O
( O
healthy O
subjects O
) O
; O
and O
MRI O
contra-indicators O
( O
e.g O
. O

metal O
implants O
, O
claustrophobia O
) O
. O

Neuroimaging O
Data O
Acquisition O
, O
Preprocessing O
, O
and O
Quality O
Assurance O
A O
10-minute O
resting-state O
( O
eyes O
open O
, O
fixation O
) O
echo O
planar O
imaging O
functional O
scan O
and O
T1-weigthed O
anatomical O
scan O
were O
collected O
on O
each O
subject O
during O
a O
single O
scanning O
session O
on O
a O
3T O
Philips O
Intera O
Achieva O
MRI O
scanner O
located O
at O
Vanderbilt O
University O
Institute O
of O
Imaging O
Sciences O
( O
VUIIS O
) O
. O

The O
resting-state O
fMRI O
scan O
had O
the O
following O
parameters O
: O
38 O
axial O
slices O
( O
slice O
thickness=3.0 O
mm O
; O
gap=0.3 O
mm O
) O
, O
field O
of O
view O
( O
FOV O
) O
=80×80 O
matrix O
( O
3.0 O
mm×3.0 O
mm O
in-plane O
resolution O
) O
, O
90-degree O
flip O
angle O
, O
300 O
volumes O
, O
TR/TE=2000/25 O
ms. O
A O
high O
resolution O
T1-weighted O
turbo O
field O
echo O
( O
TFE O
) O
structural O
scan O
( O
170 O
sagital O
slices O
, O
FOV=256×256 O
matrix O
, O
1.0 O
mm O
isovoxel O
resolution O
, O
TR/TE=8.9/4.6 O
ms O
) O
was O
also O
acquired O
. O

T1-weighted O
anatomical O
images O
were O
segmented O
into O
grey O
matter O
, O
white O
matter O
, O
and O
CSF O
using O
the O
Voxel-based O
Morphometry O
, O
version O
8 O
toolbox O
( O
VBM8 O
; O
http O
: O
//dbm.neuro.uni-jena.de/vbm/ O
) O
for O
Statistical O
Parametric O
Mapping O
version O
12 O
( O
SPM12 O
: O
https O
: O
//www.fil.ion.ucl.ac.uk/spm/ O
) O
. O

Following O
segmentation O
, O
each O
tissue O
class O
was O
spatially O
warped O
to O
an O
MNI-space O
template O
image O
comprised O
of O
550 O
subjects O
included O
with O
the O
VBM8 O
toolbox O
( O
http O
: O
//dbm.neuro.uni-jena.de.libproxy.wustl.edu/vbm/ O
) O
using O
the O
high O
dimensional O
DARTEL O
normalization O
method O
. O

Functional O
resting-state O
scans O
were O
slice-time O
corrected O
, O
motion O
corrected O
, O
co-registered O
to O
native O
space O
structural O
data O
, O
and O
normalized O
to O
MNI O
space O
using O
DARTEL O
deformation O
fields O
obtained O
from O
spatially O
normalizing O
the O
T1-weighted O
anatomical O
images O
. O

All O
resting O
state O
data O
underwent O
quality O
assurance O
( O
QA O
) O
using O
an O
automated O
QA O
pipeline O
that O
calculated O
median O
voxel O
displacement O
, O
median O
temporal O
signal-to-noise O
ratio O
( O
SNR O
) O
, O
and O
95th O
percentile O
signal O
change O
. O

Scans O
with O
log O
SNR O
and O
log O
median O
voxel O
displacement O
above O
the O
95th O
percentile O
of O
the O
distribution O
of O
the O
entire O
dataset O
were O
excluded O
from O
the O
analysis O
, O
leaving O
( O
as O
previously O
mentioned O
) O
n=177 O
subjects O
passing O
these O
criteria O
. O

Diagnostic O
groups O
did O
not O
differ O
on O
median O
signal-to-noise O
ratio O
( O
F O
( O
2,174 O
) O
=0.51 O
, O
p=.60 O
) O
, O
median O
voxel O
displacement O
( O
F O
( O
2,174 O
) O
=0.33 O
, O
p=.72 O
) O
, O
and O
95th O
percentile O
signal O
change O
( O
F O
( O
2,174 O
) O
=1.24 O
, O
p=.29 O
) O
. O

Functional O
Connectivity O
Analysis O
Prior O
striatal O
functional O
connectivity O
studies O
in O
psychosis O
used O
either O
cortical O
seeds O
to O
examine O
connectivity O
of O
cortical O
areas O
with O
the O
striatum O
( O
i.e O
. O

cortex O
seed-based O
analysis O
) O
, O
or O
striatal O
seeds O
to O
examine O
connectivity O
of O
striatal O
sub-regions O
with O
the O
rest O
of O
the O
brain O
( O
i.e O
. O

striatum O
seed-based O
analysis O
) O
. O

We O
used O
both O
approaches O
to O
comprehensively O
map O
functional O
connectivity O
of O
the O
striatum O
and O
facilitate O
comparison O
of O
our O
results O
to O
prior O
studies O
. O

Each O
approach O
is O
described O
in O
detail O
below O
. O

Functional O
connectivity O
maps O
of O
cortex O
and O
striatum O
seeds O
were O
generated O
using O
the O
CONN-fMRI O
toolbox O
v.17.f O
( O
http O
: O
//www.nitrc.org/projects/conn O
) O
. O

The O
mean O
BOLD O
time O
series O
was O
extracted O
from O
seeds O
and O
entered O
as O
a O
predictor O
in O
a O
multiple O
regression O
general O
linear O
model O
( O
GLM O
) O
. O

Regressors O
corresponding O
to O
the O
6 O
motion O
correction O
parameters O
and O
their O
first O
temporal O
derivatives O
, O
along O
with O
grey O
matter O
, O
white O
matter O
, O
and O
CSF O
were O
included O
to O
remove O
variance O
related O
to O
head O
motion O
, O
the O
global O
grey O
matter O
signal O
, O
white O
matter O
, O
and O
CSF O
, O
respectively O
. O

In O
addition O
to O
12 O
nuisance O
regressors O
related O
to O
motion O
( O
6 O
translations/rotations O
and O
their O
temporal O
first O
derivatives O
) O
, O
the O
first O
6 O
principal O
components O
were O
extracted O
from O
each O
subject O
’ O
s O
white O
matter O
and O
CSF O
segmentations O
( O
i.e O
. O

anatomical O
CompCor O
) O
. O

Anatomical O
CompCor O
has O
been O
shown O
to O
be O
at O
least O
as O
effective O
as O
another O
commonly O
used O
approach O
, O
the O
“ O
scrubbing O
” O
procedure O
described O
by O
Power O
et O
al. O
, O
at O
mitigating O
the O
residual O
effects O
of O
head O
motion O
on O
functional O
connectivity O
. O

Motion O
correction O
parameters O
were O
regressed O
out O
prior O
to O
temporal O
band-pass O
filtering O
. O

Performing O
these O
steps O
in O
reverse O
order O
( O
i.e O
. O

band-pass O
filtering O
before O
nuisance O
regression O
) O
re-introduces O
nuisance O
related O
variation O
thereby O
overestimating O
connectivity O
estimates O
and O
exacerbating O
the O
effects O
of O
head O
motion O
. O

In O
addition O
, O
a O
mask O
was O
created O
for O
each O
subject O
’ O
s O
mean O
fMRI O
image O
to O
identify O
in-brain O
voxels O
( O
i.e. O
, O
an O
in-brain O
mask O
) O
and O
exclude O
voxels O
with O
low O
SNR O
. O

Briefly O
, O
after O
rescaling O
and O
standardizing O
each O
subject O
’ O
s O
voxel O
intensity O
, O
the O
mean O
voxel O
intensity O
for O
all O
177 O
subjects O
was O
calculated O
, O
and O
a O
threshold O
was O
identified O
using O
the O
SPM12 O
’ O
s O
antimode O
function O
to O
estimate O
a O
brain-nonbrain O
threshold O
. O

Any O
voxels O
that O
did O
not O
meet O
this O
in-brain O
threshold O
were O
removed O
, O
after O
applying O
the O
mask O
to O
MNI O
space O
. O

This O
mask O
was O
used O
in O
all O
cortical O
analyses O
in O
to O
remove O
non-brain O
and O
low O
SNR O
voxels O
from O
the O
analyses O
. O

Cortex O
Seed-based O
Analysis O
The O
7-network O
cortical O
parcellation O
identified O
by O
Yeo O
et O
al O
. O

was O
used O
to O
define O
seeds O
for O
the O
cortical O
seed-based O
analysis O
( O
see O
Figure O
1a O
) O
. O

Briefly O
, O
the O
Yeo O
7-network O
cortical O
parcellation O
is O
comprised O
of O
the O
default O
mode O
( O
DMN O
) O
, O
fronto-parietal O
( O
FPN O
) O
, O
salience O
( O
SAL O
) O
, O
limbic O
( O
LN O
) O
, O
sensorimotor O
( O
SMN O
) O
, O
dorsal O
attention O
( O
DAN O
) O
, O
and O
visual O
( O
VN O
) O
networks O
. O

Functional O
connectivity O
maps O
were O
generated O
for O
each O
of O
the O
Yeo O
networks O
, O
except O
the O
DAN O
and O
VN O
which O
have O
minimal O
functional O
connectivity O
with O
the O
striatum O
. O

The O
functional O
connectivity O
maps O
were O
masked O
to O
only O
include O
voxels O
in O
the O
striatum O
. O

To O
maximize O
statistical O
power O
, O
we O
first O
performed O
a O
region-of-interest O
( O
ROI O
) O
analysis O
that O
generated O
a O
single O
value O
approximating O
overall O
functional O
connectivity O
of O
each O
cortical O
seed O
with O
the O
striatum O
. O

Specifically O
, O
the O
unsmoothed O
cortical O
seed-based O
connectivity O
maps O
were O
entered O
into O
separate O
one-sample O
voxel-wise O
t-tests O
to O
identify O
voxels O
in O
the O
striatum O
exhibiting O
positive O
functional O
connectivity O
with O
each O
cortical O
seed O
. O

This O
analysis O
included O
the O
entire O
cohort O
of O
study O
participants O
, O
including O
healthy O
subjects O
and O
individuals O
with O
a O
psychotic O
disorder O
. O

The O
resultant O
statistical O
parametric O
maps O
( O
SPM O
) O
were O
thresholded O
at O
voxel-wise O
family-wise O
error O
( O
FWE O
) O
corrected O
p=.05 O
, O
minimum O
cluster O
size=10 O
voxels O
, O
and O
the O
‘ O
eigenvariate O
’ O
function O
in O
SPM12 O
was O
used O
to O
extract O
the O
first O
principal O
component O
from O
the O
voxels O
that O
survived O
thresholding O
. O

This O
yielded O
a O
single O
measure O
of O
functional O
connectivity O
with O
the O
striatum O
for O
each O
cortical O
seed O
for O
each O
subject O
. O

These O
measures O
served O
as O
dependent O
variables O
in O
a O
repeated O
measures O
ANCOVA O
with O
network O
entered O
as O
a O
repeating O
variable O
and O
diagnostic O
group O
( O
healthy O
controls O
, O
schizophrenia O
, O
psychotic O
bipolar O
disorder O
) O
entered O
as O
a O
between-subjects O
factor O
along O
with O
age O
and O
sex O
as O
covariates O
. O

Significant O
main O
effects O
and O
interactions O
were O
followed-up O
with O
post-hoc O
t-tests O
. O

The O
well-powered O
ROI O
approach O
described O
above O
was O
followed-up O
with O
voxel-wise O
analyses O
comparing O
functional O
connectivity O
of O
each O
cortical O
seed O
within O
the O
striatum O
between O
groups O
, O
in O
order O
to O
examine O
the O
specific O
locations O
of O
connectivity O
differences O
between O
the O
groups O
. O

Briefly O
, O
the O
unsmoothed O
cortical O
seed-based O
connectivity O
maps O
were O
analyzed O
separately O
using O
one-way O
ANOVAs O
with O
group O
( O
healthy O
controls O
, O
schizophrenia O
, O
psychotic O
bipolar O
disorder O
) O
entered O
as O
a O
between-subjects O
variable O
along O
with O
age O
and O
sex O
as O
covariates O
. O

Voxel-wise O
ANOVAs O
were O
masked O
with O
the O
one-sample O
t-test O
results O
described O
above O
such O
that O
only O
voxels O
that O
demonstrated O
positive O
functional O
connectivity O
with O
the O
cortex-based O
seeds O
were O
included O
in O
the O
analysis O
. O

Results O
were O
thresholded O
at O
cluster-level O
pFWE=.05 O
for O
voxel-wise O
p=.001 O
. O

Striatum O
Seed-based O
Analysis O
We O
used O
the O
striatum O
seeds O
from O
previous O
striatal O
seed-based O
connectivity O
research O
. O

These O
striatum O
seeds O
are O
comprised O
of O
six O
3.5-mm-radius O
spherical O
ROIs O
, O
totaling O
three O
bilateral O
caudate O
and O
three O
bilateral O
putamen O
regions O
corresponding O
to O
: O
dorsal O
caudate O
( O
DC O
; O
x=±13 O
, O
y=15 O
, O
z=9 O
) O
, O
superior O
ventral O
caudate O
( O
sVC O
; O
x=±10 O
, O
y=15 O
, O
z=0 O
) O
, O
inferior O
ventral O
caudate O
( O
iVC O
; O
x=±9 O
, O
y=9 O
, O
z=−8 O
) O
, O
dorsocaudal O
putamen O
( O
dcPT O
; O
x=±28 O
, O
y=1 O
, O
z=3 O
) O
, O
dorsorostral O
putamen O
( O
drPT O
; O
x=±25 O
, O
y=8 O
, O
z=6 O
) O
, O
and O
the O
ventrorostral O
putamen O
( O
vrPT O
; O
x=±20 O
, O
y=12 O
, O
z=−3 O
) O
. O

Functional O
connectivity O
maps O
were O
generated O
for O
each O
of O
these O
striatum O
seeds O
. O

Functional O
connectivity O
maps O
were O
masked O
to O
only O
include O
voxels O
in O
the O
cortex O
( O
using O
the O
in-brain O
mask O
detailed O
in O
the O
Supplement O
) O
and O
smoothed O
( O
6 O
mm O
) O
. O

A O
one-sample O
voxel-wise O
t-test O
was O
performed O
for O
each O
striatum O
seed O
to O
identify O
voxels O
in O
the O
cortex O
exhibiting O
positive O
functional O
connectivity O
with O
each O
striatum O
seed O
. O

The O
resultant O
statistical O
parametric O
maps O
( O
SPM O
) O
were O
thresholded O
at O
voxel-wise O
p=.001 O
. O

Group O
differences O
in O
functional O
connectivity O
of O
each O
striatum O
seed O
were O
then O
analyzed O
using O
a O
one-way O
ANOVA O
with O
group O
( O
healthy O
controls O
, O
schizophrenia O
, O
psychotic O
bipolar O
disorder O
) O
entered O
as O
a O
between-subjects O
variable O
along O
with O
age O
and O
sex O
as O
covariates O
. O

These O
analyses O
were O
masked O
with O
the O
one-sample O
t-test O
results O
described O
above O
such O
that O
only O
voxels O
that O
demonstrated O
positive O
functional O
connectivity O
with O
striatum-based O
seeds O
were O
included O
in O
the O
analysis O
. O

Results O
were O
thresholded O
at O
cluster-level O
pFWE=.05 O
for O
voxel-wise O
p=.001 O
. O

Testing O
Associations O
Between O
Striatal O
Connectivity O
and O
Clinical O
Variables O
Next O
, O
we O
examined O
whether O
there O
were O
associations O
between O
connectivity O
impairments O
and O
both O
cognitive O
impairment O
and O
symptoms O
( O
and O
specifically O
positive O
psychotic O
symptoms O
) O
, O
as O
has O
been O
found O
in O
previous O
research O
. O

To O
test O
these O
hypotheses O
, O
we O
examined O
whether O
there O
were O
significant O
associations O
between O
each O
significant O
cortico-striatal O
connectivity O
finding O
and O
both O
cognitive O
impairment O
on O
the O
SCIP O
and O
PANSS O
symptoms O
. O

These O
regressions O
included O
the O
following O
predictors O
: O
sex O
, O
age O
, O
diagnostic O
group O
( O
i.e. O
, O
healthy O
subjects O
, O
schizophrenia O
, O
psychotic O
bipolar O
disorder O
) O
, O
the O
variable O
of O
interest O
( O
e.g. O
, O
SCIP O
“ O
composite O
” O
z-score O
) O
, O
and O
an O
interaction O
between O
diagnostic O
group O
and O
the O
variable O
of O
interest O
. O

For O
the O
cortex O
seed-based O
ROI O
analysis O
described O
above O
, O
overall O
connectivity O
between O
each O
cortical O
network O
and O
the O
striatum O
served O
as O
the O
dependent O
variable O
in O
regression O
analyses O
. O

For O
the O
voxel-wise O
analyses O
, O
mean O
functional O
connectivity O
was O
extracted O
from O
the O
clusters O
that O
survived O
thresholding O
using O
the O
eigenvariate O
function O
in O
SPM12 O
and O
this O
served O
as O
the O
dependent O
variable O
in O
regression O
analyses O
. O

Regression O
analyses O
were O
corrected O
for O
multiple O
comparisons O
( O
using O
False O
Discovery O
Rate O
( O
FDR O
) O
correction O
) O
based O
on O
the O
number O
of O
associations O
examined O
( O
i.e. O
, O
FDR-corrected O
for O
every O
cognitive O
impairment O
and O
symptom O
variable O
of O
interest O
for O
a O
total O
of O
four O
FDR-corrected O
comparisons O
) O
for O
each O
significant O
cortico-striatal O
connectivity O
finding O
. O

Common O
increased O
hippocampal O
volume O
but O
specific O
changes O
in O
functional O
connectivity O
in O
schizophrenia O
patients O
in O
remission O
and O
non-remission O
following O
electroconvulsive O
therapy O
: O
A O
preliminary O
study O
Highlights O
Electroconvulsive O
therapy O
( O
ECT O
) O
induced O
enlargement O
in O
hippocampus O
volume O
contrast O
to O
pharmaceutical O
therapy O
in O
schizophrenia O
. O

Both O
ECT O
responders O
and O
non-responders O
show O
hippocampal O
volume O
expansion O
. O

Increased O
FC O
between O
hippocampus O
and O
brain O
cognitive O
networks O
only O
in O
ECT O
responders O
. O

Electroconvulsive O
therapy O
( O
ECT O
) O
is O
considered O
a O
treatment O
option O
in O
patients O
with O
drug-resistant O
schizophrenia O
( O
SZ O
) O
. O

However O
, O
approximately O
one-third O
of O
patients O
do O
not O
benefit O
from O
ECT O
in O
the O
clinic O
. O

Thus O
, O
it O
is O
critical O
to O
investigate O
differences O
between O
ECT O
responders O
and O
non-responders O
. O

Accumulated O
evidence O
has O
indicated O
that O
one O
region O
of O
ECT O
action O
is O
the O
hippocampus O
, O
which O
also O
plays O
an O
important O
role O
in O
SZ O
pathophysiology O
. O

To O
date O
, O
no O
studies O
have O
investigated O
differences O
in O
ECT O
effects O
in O
the O
hippocampus O
between O
treatment O
responders O
and O
non-responders O
. O

This O
study O
recruited O
twenty-one O
SZ O
patients O
treated O
for O
four O
weeks O
with O
ECT O
( O
MSZ O
, O
n O
= O
21 O
) O
and O
twenty-one O
SZ O
patients O
who O
received O
pharmaceutical O
therapy O
( O
DSZ O
, O
n O
= O
21 O
) O
. O

The O
MSZ O
group O
was O
further O
categorized O
into O
responders O
( O
MSR O
, O
n O
= O
10 O
) O
or O
non-responders O
( O
MNR O
, O
n O
= O
11 O
) O
based O
on O
treatment O
outcomes O
by O
the O
criterion O
of O
a O
50 O
% O
reduction O
in O
the O
Positive O
and O
Negative O
Syndrome O
Scale O
total O
scores O
. O

Using O
structural O
and O
resting-state O
functional O
MRI O
, O
we O
measured O
the O
hippocampal O
volume O
and O
functional O
connectivity O
( O
FC O
) O
in O
all O
SZ O
patients O
( O
before O
and O
after O
treatment O
) O
and O
23 O
healthy O
controls O
. O

In O
contrast O
to O
pharmaceutical O
therapy O
, O
ECT O
induced O
bilateral O
hippocampal O
volume O
increases O
in O
the O
MSZ O
. O

Both O
the O
MSR O
and O
MNR O
exhibited O
hippocampal O
expansion O
after O
ECT O
, O
whereas O
a O
lower O
baseline O
volume O
in O
one O
of O
hippocampal O
subfield O
( O
hippocampus-amygdala O
transition O
area O
) O
was O
found O
in O
the O
MNR O
. O

After O
ECT O
, O
increased O
FC O
between O
the O
hippocampus O
and O
brain O
networks O
associated O
with O
cognitive O
function O
was O
only O
observed O
in O
the O
MSR O
. O

The O
mechanism O
of O
action O
of O
ECT O
in O
schizophrenia O
is O
complex O
. O

A O
combination O
of O
baseline O
impairment O
level O
, O
ECT-introduced O
morphological O
changes O
and O
post-ECT O
FC O
increases O
in O
the O
hippocampus O
may O
jointly O
contribute O
to O
the O
post-ECT O
symptom O
improvements O
in O
patients O
with O
SZ O
. O

Materials O
and O
methods O
Participants O
In O
the O
present O
study O
, O
forty-two O
patients O
with O
acute O
SZ O
were O
divided O
into O
two O
groups O
according O
to O
treatment O
strategy O
. O

One O
group O
received O
a O
four-week O
ECT O
series O
in O
addition O
to O
antipsychotic O
drugs O
( O
MSZ O
group O
, O
n O
= O
21 O
) O
; O
the O
other O
group O
received O
only O
antipsychotic O
drugs O
( O
DSZ O
group O
, O
n O
= O
21 O
) O
. O

All O
inpatients O
were O
recruited O
from O
the O
Shanghai O
Mental O
Health O
Centre O
( O
SMHC O
) O
from O
October O
2013 O
to O
January O
2015 O
. O

The O
patients O
were O
diagnosed O
with O
SZ O
by O
trained O
clinical O
psychiatrists O
using O
the O
SCID-I/P O
( O
Structural O
Clinical O
Interview O
for O
DSM-IV-TR O
, O
Patient O
edition O
) O
and O
met O
the O
indications O
for O
ECT O
. O

In O
addition O
, O
the O
patients O
had O
no O
history O
of O
ECT O
within O
the O
previous O
six O
months O
. O

Psychiatric O
symptom O
severity O
was O
assessed O
by O
the O
Positive O
and O
Negative O
Syndrome O
Scale O
( O
PANSS O
) O
, O
and O
the O
total O
PANSS O
scores O
of O
all O
patients O
were O
greater O
than O
60 O
. O

All O
patients O
received O
antipsychotic O
medications O
, O
and O
the O
daily O
antipsychotic O
medication O
dosage O
was O
converted O
to O
chlorpromazine O
equivalents O
( O
mg/d O
) O
. O

Additional O
details O
regarding O
the O
antipsychotic O
medication O
for O
each O
patient O
are O
provided O
in O
Supplementary O
Information O
1 O
. O

A O
sample O
of O
healthy O
controls O
( O
HC O
, O
n O
= O
23 O
) O
, O
which O
was O
matched O
to O
the O
patient O
groups O
by O
age O
, O
sex O
and O
education O
level O
( O
Table O
1 O
) O
, O
was O
also O
recruited O
from O
the O
faculty O
in O
SMHC O
. O

All O
healthy O
controls O
did O
not O
have O
a O
lifetime O
psychiatric O
disorder O
or O
family O
history O
of O
psychosis O
in O
their O
first-degree O
relatives O
. O

Potential O
participants O
were O
excluded O
if O
they O
had O
brain O
injuries O
, O
organic O
mental O
disorders O
, O
neurological O
abnormalities O
, O
other O
serious O
physical O
illnesses O
, O
dementia O
, O
substance O
abuse O
or O
dependence O
, O
or O
contraindications O
to O
MRI O
. O

The O
Ethics O
Committee O
of O
SMHC O
approved O
the O
study O
protocol O
. O

Written O
informed O
consent O
was O
obtained O
from O
all O
subjects O
prior O
to O
study O
participation O
. O

Electroconvulsive O
therapy O
Using O
a O
therapeutic O
apparatus O
Thymatron O
System O
IV O
( O
Somatics O
, O
Lake O
Bluff O
, O
IL O
, O
USA O
) O
, O
ECT O
was O
administered O
3 O
times O
weekly O
for O
4 O
weeks O
and O
12 O
sessions O
. O

Before O
ECT O
, O
succinylcholine O
chloride O
( O
1.0 O
mg/kg O
) O
was O
used O
to O
relax O
muscles O
, O
atropine O
( O
0.5 O
mg O
) O
was O
applied O
to O
reduce O
airway O
secretion O
, O
etomidate O
( O
0.21–0.3 O
mg/kg O
) O
and O
propofol O
( O
1.82–2.44 O
mg/kg O
) O
were O
conducted O
to O
keep O
anaesthesia O
. O

Two O
electrodes O
were O
placed O
at O
bilateral O
temporal O
scalps O
. O

The O
main O
parameters O
of O
ECT O
were O
similar O
for O
all O
patients O
( O
frequency O
, O
10–70 O
Hz O
; O
maximum O
charge O
delivered O
, O
504 O
mC O
; O
output O
current O
, O
0.9 O
A O
; O
pulse O
width O
, O
1.0 O
ms O
; O
maximum O
stimulus O
duration O
, O
8 O
s O
) O
. O

During O
ECT O
, O
we O
monitored O
motor O
convulsions O
and O
induced O
tachycardia O
, O
and O
also O
recorded O
electroencephalogram O
and O
electromyogram O
( O
when O
necessary O
) O
. O

The O
antipsychotic O
therapy O
remained O
stable O
during O
ECT O
period O
except O
for O
the O
discontinuation O
of O
pharmacotherapy O
in O
the O
morning O
before O
ECT O
. O

Symptom O
assessments O
At O
pre- O
and O
post-treatment O
, O
we O
measured O
the O
positive O
( O
PANSS-P O
) O
, O
negative O
( O
PANSS-N O
) O
, O
general O
psychopathology O
( O
PANSS-G O
) O
subscales O
and O
total O
scores O
( O
PANSS-T O
) O
. O

The O
PANSS O
reductive O
ratio O
was O
defined O
as O
percentage O
PANSS O
changes O
as O
: O
△PANSS-T O
% O
= O
( O
PANSS-Tt1−PANSS-Tt2 O
) O
× O
100 O
/ O
( O
PANSS-Tt1−30 O
) O
. O

PANSS-Tt1−30 O
was O
used O
as O
baseline O
value O
instead O
of O
PANSS-Tt1 O
as O
30 O
was O
the O
lowest O
possible O
value O
for O
PANSS O
total O
score O
. O

Similarly O
, O
△PANSS-P O
% O
, O
△PANSS-N O
% O
, O
△PANSS-G O
% O
were O
also O
calculated O
. O

After O
ECT O
, O
the O
MSZ O
group O
was O
further O
classified O
as O
the O
ECT O
responder O
( O
MSR O
group O
, O
n O
= O
10 O
) O
and O
non-responder O
( O
MNR O
group O
, O
n O
= O
11 O
) O
groups O
, O
with O
the O
criterion O
of O
less O
than O
50 O
% O
individual O
symptom O
relief O
for O
non-response O
according O
to O
the O
PANSS O
total O
reductive O
ratio O
. O

Similarly O
, O
the O
DSZ O
group O
was O
also O
grouped O
to O
the O
drug O
responder O
( O
DR O
, O
n O
= O
12 O
) O
and O
non-responder O
groups O
( O
DNR O
, O
n O
= O
9 O
) O
. O

The O
responders O
and O
non-responders O
did O
not O
differ O
in O
terms O
of O
gender O
, O
age O
, O
education O
, O
illness O
duration O
and O
baseline O
PANSS O
scores O
( O
Table O
1 O
) O
. O

Data O
acquisition O
Whole-brain O
imaging O
data O
were O
acquired O
using O
a O
3-T O
Siemens O
Magnetom O
veriosyngo O
MR O
B17 O
scanner O
. O

Functional O
MRI O
data O
were O
obtained O
by O
a O
gradient O
echo O
planar O
imaging O
( O
EPI O
) O
sequence O
( O
TR O
2000 O
ms O
; O
TE O
, O
30 O
ms O
; O
flip O
angle O
, O
90° O
; O
FOV O
, O
220 O
mm O
× O
220 O
mm O
; O
matrix O
, O
64 O
× O
64 O
; O
slice O
thickness O
, O
4 O
mm O
; O
30 O
slices O
; O
voxel O
size O
, O
3.4 O
× O
3.4 O
× O
3.4 O
mm O
; O
180 O
vol O
) O
. O

In O
addition O
, O
high-resolution O
T1-weighted O
structural O
images O
were O
collected O
using O
a O
magnetization-prepared O
rapid O
acquisition O
gradient O
echo O
( O
MPRAGE O
) O
sequence O
( O
TR O
, O
2530 O
ms O
, O
TE O
, O
2.56 O
ms O
, O
flip O
angle O
, O
7° O
, O
inversion O
time O
, O
1100 O
ms O
, O
FOV O
, O
256 O
mm O
× O
256 O
mm O
, O
matrix O
, O
256 O
× O
256 O
, O
224 O
slices O
, O
slice O
thickness O
, O
1 O
mm O
; O
voxel O
size O
, O
1.0 O
× O
1.0 O
× O
1.0 O
mm O
) O
. O

The O
patients O
were O
scanned O
twice O
before O
( O
baseline O
) O
and O
after O
4-week O
therapy O
. O

The O
HC O
underwent O
scanning O
only O
at O
baseline O
. O

The O
first O
MRI O
scan O
of O
patients O
was O
obtained O
within O
24 O
h O
before O
the O
first O
ECT O
, O
and O
the O
final O
MRI O
scan O
was O
collected O
24–48 O
h O
after O
the O
last O
session O
of O
ECT O
. O

Participants O
were O
instructed O
to O
keep O
their O
eyes O
closed O
, O
relax O
, O
but O
not O
to O
fall O
sleep O
. O

Data O
processing O
2.5.1 O
. O

Hippocampal O
structural O
analysis O
A O
longitudinal O
segmentation O
of O
hippocampal O
substructures O
was O
performed O
using O
FreeSurfer O
( O
version O
6.0 O
, O
http O
: O
//surfer.nmr.mgh.harvard.edu/ O
) O
. O

Specifically O
, O
a O
longitudinal O
processing O
stream O
including O
skull O
stripping O
, O
tissue O
segmentation O
, O
surface O
reconstruction O
, O
registration O
and O
parcellation O
, O
was O
applied O
to O
all O
subjects O
' O
T1 O
images O
in O
Freesurfer O
. O

This O
stream O
created O
an O
unbiased O
within-subject O
template O
space O
by O
using O
robust O
, O
inverse O
consistent O
registration O
across O
scanning O
images O
. O

A O
longitudinal O
segmentation O
of O
hippocampal O
subfields O
tool O
in O
Freesurfer O
was O
also O
applied O
to O
segmented O
hippocampal O
regions O
to O
obtain O
twelve O
hippocampal O
subfields O
for O
each O
hemisphere O
. O

The O
longitudinal O
algorithm O
uses O
a O
subject-specific O
atlas O
and O
treats O
all O
scanning O
time O
points O
the O
same O
way O
to O
avoid O
processing O
bias O
, O
and O
thus O
increases O
the O
robustness O
of O
segmentation O
. O

Whole O
hippocampal O
volume O
and O
twelve O
subfields O
volumes O
were O
measured O
for O
each O
hemisphere O
, O
including O
the O
hippocampal O
tail O
, O
subiculum O
, O
presubiculum O
, O
parasubiculum O
, O
cornu O
ammonis O
area O
1 O
( O
CA1 O
) O
, O
CA3 O
, O
CA4 O
, O
hippocampal O
fissure O
, O
granular O
cells O
layer O
of O
the O
dentate O
gyrus O
( O
GC-ML-DG O
) O
, O
molecular O
layer O
, O
hippocampus-amygdala O
transition O
area O
( O
HATA O
) O
and O
fimbria O
. O

Illustrations O
of O
hippocampal O
subfield O
segmentation O
for O
each O
subject O
are O
provided O
in O
Supplementary O
Information O
2 O
. O

2.5.2 O
. O

Hippocampal O
resting-state O
functional O
connectivity O
analysis O
Resting-state O
fMRI O
processing O
was O
performed O
in O
SPM12 O
( O
http O
: O
//www.fil.ion.ucl.ac.uk/spm O
) O
and O
DPABI O
( O
http O
: O
//rfmri.org/dpabi O
) O
software O
. O

The O
fMRI O
data O
preprocessing O
pipeline O
was O
similar O
with O
previous O
study O
and O
was O
only O
briefly O
described O
here O
. O

Firstly O
, O
the O
first O
10 O
time O
points O
were O
removed O
for O
signal O
equilibrium O
and O
to O
allow O
the O
subjects O
’ O
adaptation O
to O
the O
scanning O
noise O
; O
secondly O
, O
we O
did O
the O
slice-timing O
correction O
, O
realignment O
correction O
, O
normalization O
and O
resampling O
to O
3 O
× O
3 O
× O
3 O
mm3 O
; O
thirdly O
, O
the O
nuisance O
covariates O
including O
24 O
motion O
parameters O
, O
white O
matter O
and O
cerebrospinal O
fluid O
signals O
and O
linear O
trending O
were O
regressed O
out O
; O
then O
, O
we O
performed O
temporally O
scrubbing O
and O
temporal O
filtering O
( O
0.01–0.1 O
Hz O
) O
; O
finally O
, O
the O
data O
was O
smoothed O
( O
FWHM= O
6 O
mm O
) O
. O

Following O
the O
preprocessing O
, O
seed-based O
FC O
analysis O
was O
used O
to O
evaluate O
the O
hippocampal O
FC O
. O

Four O
regions O
of O
bilateral O
rostral O
hippocampus O
( O
RosHIP O
) O
and O
caudal O
hippocampus O
( O
CauHIP O
) O
were O
defined O
as O
the O
seed O
ROIs O
according O
to O
the O
Human O
Brainnetome O
Atlas O
. O

Pearson O
's O
correlation O
coefficients O
between O
the O
time O
series O
of O
each O
seed O
and O
that O
of O
the O
other O
voxels O
in O
the O
whole O
brain O
were O
calculated O
and O
then O
Fisher O
's O
z-transformed O
to O
z-scores O
. O

For O
each O
subject O
and O
each O
seed O
, O
a O
FC O
z-score O
map O
was O
obtained O
and O
used O
for O
following O
statistical O
analysis O
. O

2.6 O
. O

Statistical O
analysis O
2.6.1 O
. O

Hippocampal O
volume O
comparisons O
To O
determine O
whether O
the O
hippocampal O
volume O
changes O
were O
a O
specific O
effect O
induced O
by O
ECT O
rather O
than O
drug O
, O
repeated O
measured O
two-way O
ANOVA O
was O
performed O
on O
the O
volumes O
of O
the O
whole O
hippocampus O
and O
each O
subfield O
with O
the O
between-subject O
factor O
( O
treatment O
strategy O
: O
MSZ O
vs. O
DSZ O
) O
and O
the O
within-subject O
factor O
( O
time O
: O
t1 O
vs. O
t2 O
) O
. O

Post-hoc O
paired O
t-tests O
were O
performed O
in O
the O
MSZ O
and O
DSZ O
groups O
to O
indentify O
longitudinal O
changes O
after O
controlling O
for O
the O
overall O
intracranial O
volume O
. O

To O
further O
examine O
whether O
hippocampal O
volume O
changes O
were O
different O
between O
the O
ECT O
responders O
and O
non-responders O
, O
repeated O
measured O
two-way O
ANOVA O
was O
conducted O
with O
the O
between-subject O
factor O
( O
MSR O
vs. O
MNR O
) O
and O
the O
within-subject O
factor O
( O
time O
: O
t1 O
vs. O
t2 O
) O
. O

Two O
post-hoc O
paired O
t-tests O
were O
separately O
performed O
in O
the O
MSR O
and O
MNR O
groups O
to O
characterize O
the O
longitudinal O
changes O
in O
hippocampal O
volume O
after O
the O
ECT O
when O
controlling O
the O
effect O
of O
the O
overall O
intracranial O
volume O
. O

Additionally O
, O
ANOVA O
and O
post-hoc O
tests O
were O
used O
to O
compare O
the O
baseline O
differences O
among O
the O
MSR O
, O
MNR O
and O
HC O
groups O
. O

2.6.2 O
. O

Hippocampal O
FC O
comparisons O
To O
verify O
the O
hypothesis O
that O
ECT O
induced O
specific O
changes O
in O
hippocampal O
FC O
in O
the O
ECT O
responders O
, O
repeated O
measured O
two-way O
ANOVA O
was O
conducted O
with O
the O
between-subject O
factor O
( O
outcome O
: O
MSR O
vs. O
MNR O
) O
and O
the O
within-subject O
factor O
( O
time O
: O
t1 O
vs. O
t2 O
) O
; O
the O
interaction O
effect O
of O
outcome O
and O
time O
was O
used O
to O
investigate O
the O
specific O
changes O
observed O
in O
the O
ECT O
responders O
. O

Two O
post-hoc O
paired O
t-tests O
were O
separately O
performed O
in O
the O
MSR O
and O
MNR O
groups O
to O
detect O
the O
longitudinal O
changes O
in O
hippocampal O
FC O
after O
the O
ECT O
. O

In O
addition O
, O
ANOVA O
and O
post-hoc O
tests O
were O
applied O
to O
the O
comparisons O
amongststststst O
the O
MSR O
, O
MNR O
and O
HC O
groups O
at O
the O
baseline O
. O

For O
these O
analyses O
on O
the O
voxel-wise O
FC O
z-score O
maps O
, O
a O
multiple O
comparison O
correction O
was O
performed O
using O
a O
height O
threshold O
( O
z O
> O
2.7 O
) O
for O
individual O
voxels O
and O
a O
cluster O
size O
based O
on O
the O
Gaussian O
random O
field O
theory O
, O
which O
corresponds O
to O
p O
< O
0.05 O
after O
correction O
. O
. O

Relationship O
between O
hippocampal O
changes O
and O
symptom O
improvements O
The O
hippocampal O
volume O
and O
FC O
values O
that O
exhibited O
significant O
longitudinal O
changes O
were O
extracted O
. O

The O
hippocampal O
volume O
change O
was O
defined O
as O
the O
difference O
in O
volume O
( O
Volumet2 O
- O
Volumet1 O
) O
. O

Similarly O
, O
the O
FC O
changes O
were O
computed O
as O
difference O
values O
( O
FCt2 O
- O
FCt1 O
) O
. O

As O
these O
values O
did O
not O
conform O
to O
a O
normal O
distribution O
according O
to O
the O
Kolmogorov-Smirnov O
tests O
, O
Spearman O
rank O
correlations O
were O
used O
to O
assess O
the O
relationships O
between O
the O
hippocampal O
volume O
or O
FC O
changes O
and O
the O
reductive O
ratios O
of O
the O
symptoms O
( O
△PANSS-P O
% O
, O
△PANSS-N O
% O
, O
△PANSS-G O
% O
, O
and O
△PANSS-T O
% O
) O
in O
the O
MSR O
group O
. O

Power O
analysis O
on O
the O
longitudinal O
changes O
in O
hippocampal O
volume O
and O
FC O
Finally O
, O
to O
estimate O
the O
statistical O
power O
for O
these O
longitudinal O
changes O
in O
hippocampal O
volume O
and O
functional O
connectivity O
in O
the O
MSR O
and O
MNR O
groups O
, O
power O
analyses O
were O
conducted O
using O
the O
G O
* O
Power O
3.1.9.2 O
( O
http O
: O
//www.gpower.hhu.de/ O
) O
. O

Additional O
analysis O
Baseline O
comparisons O
between O
MSZ O
and O
DSZ O
To O
investigate O
the O
differences O
in O
hippocampal O
volume O
and O
FC O
between O
the O
MSZ O
and O
DSZ O
groups O
at O
baseline O
, O
we O
performed O
two-sample O
t-tests O
to O
compare O
the O
differences O
between O
the O
MSZ O
and O
DSZ O
in O
the O
volume O
of O
each O
hippocampal O
subfield O
and O
FC O
. O

Comparisons O
between O
responders O
and O
non-responders O
In O
addition O
, O
we O
divided O
all O
the O
SZ O
patients O
into O
responders O
( O
SZR O
group O
: O
N O
= O
22 O
; O
14 O
female O
; O
30.72±7.38 O
years O
of O
age O
) O
and O
non-responders O
( O
SZNR O
group O
: O
N O
= O
20 O
; O
9 O
female O
; O
29.05±7.24 O
years O
of O
age O
) O
to O
further O
compare O
the O
baseline O
volume O
and O
FC O
across O
groups O
and O
the O
group-by-time O
interactions O
using O
repeated O
measured O
ANOVA O
. O

FC O
changes O
in O
the O
DR O
and O
DNR O
groups O
To O
further O
investigate O
the O
FC O
changes O
due O
to O
pharmacological O
treatment O
, O
paired O
t-tests O
were O
used O
to O
separately O
compare O
the O
differences O
between O
t1 O
and O
t2 O
in O
the O
DR O
and O
DNR O
groups O
. O

Understanding O
marijuana O
’ O
s O
effects O
on O
functional O
connectivity O
of O
the O
default O
mode O
network O
in O
patients O
with O
schizophrenia O
and O
co-occurring O
cannabis O
use O
disorder O
: O
A O
Pilot O
Investigation O
Nearly O
half O
of O
patients O
with O
schizophrenia O
( O
SCZ O
) O
have O
co-occurring O
cannabis O
use O
disorder O
( O
CUD O
) O
, O
which O
has O
been O
associated O
with O
decreased O
treatment O
efficacy O
, O
increased O
risk O
of O
psychotic O
relapse O
, O
and O
poor O
global O
functioning O
. O

While O
reports O
on O
the O
effects O
of O
cannabis O
on O
cognitive O
performance O
in O
patients O
with O
SCZ O
have O
been O
mixed O
, O
study O
of O
brain O
networks O
related O
to O
executive O
function O
may O
clarify O
the O
relationship O
between O
cannabis O
use O
and O
cognition O
in O
these O
dual-diagnosis O
patients O
. O

In O
the O
present O
pilot O
study O
, O
patients O
with O
SCZ O
and O
CUD O
( O
n=12 O
) O
and O
healthy O
controls O
( O
n=12 O
) O
completed O
two O
functional O
magnetic O
resonance O
imaging O
( O
fMRI O
) O
resting O
scans O
. O

Prior O
to O
the O
second O
scan O
, O
patients O
smoked O
a O
3.6 O
% O
tetrahydrocannabinol O
( O
THC O
) O
cannabis O
cigarette O
or O
ingested O
a O
15mg O
delta-9-tetrahydrocannabinol O
( O
THC O
) O
pill O
. O

We O
used O
resting-state O
functional O
connectivity O
to O
examine O
the O
default O
mode O
network O
( O
DMN O
) O
during O
both O
scans O
, O
as O
connectivity/activity O
within O
this O
network O
is O
negatively O
correlated O
with O
connectivity O
of O
the O
network O
involved O
in O
executive O
control O
and O
shows O
reduced O
activity O
during O
task O
performance O
in O
normal O
individuals O
. O

At O
baseline O
, O
relative O
to O
controls O
, O
patients O
exhibited O
DMN O
hyperconnectivity O
that O
correlated O
with O
positive O
symptom O
severity O
, O
and O
reduced O
anticorrelation O
between O
the O
DMN O
and O
the O
executive O
control O
network O
( O
ECN O
) O
. O

Cannabinoid O
administration O
reduced O
DMN O
hyperconnectivity O
and O
increased O
DMN-ECN O
anticorrelation O
. O

Moreover O
, O
the O
magnitude O
of O
anticorrelation O
in O
the O
controls O
, O
and O
in O
the O
patients O
after O
cannabinoid O
administration O
, O
positively O
correlated O
with O
WM O
performance O
. O

The O
finding O
that O
DMN O
brain O
connectivity O
is O
plastic O
may O
have O
implications O
for O
future O
pharmacotherapeutic O
development O
, O
as O
treatment O
efficacy O
could O
be O
assessed O
through O
the O
ability O
of O
therapies O
to O
normalize O
underlying O
circuit-level O
dysfunction O
. O

Experimental O
Materials O
and O
Methods O
Subjects O
Twelve O
patients O
with O
SCZ O
and O
CUD O
and O
twelve O
healthy O
control O
subjects O
participated O
in O
this O
study O
. O

As O
previously O
described O
in O
all O
patients O
were O
recruited O
from O
community O
mental O
health O
centers O
and O
met O
criteria O
for O
SCZ O
and O
CUD O
, O
defined O
as O
either O
current O
cannabis O
abuse O
or O
dependence O
with O
use O
within O
the O
past O
month O
prior O
to O
study O
enrollment O
, O
as O
determined O
by O
the O
Structured O
Clinical O
Interview O
for O
DSM-IV-TR O
( O
SCID O
) O
. O

While O
a O
history O
of O
alcohol O
or O
substance O
use O
( O
other O
than O
cannabis O
) O
was O
permitted O
in O
the O
patient O
group O
, O
they O
were O
required O
to O
be O
alcohol O
and O
substance O
free O
for O
a O
minimum O
of O
seven O
days O
prior O
to O
testing O
and O
scanning O
. O

Tobacco O
users O
were O
included O
in O
the O
study O
, O
since O
up O
to O
90 O
% O
of O
patients O
with O
SCZ O
smoke O
cigarettes O
. O

All O
patients O
were O
on O
a O
stable O
dose O
of O
antipsychotic O
medication O
for O
a O
minimum O
of O
one O
month O
prior O
to O
study O
participation O
. O

Patients O
taking O
clozapine O
were O
excluded O
given O
its O
proposed O
ability O
to O
decrease O
alcohol O
and O
cannabis O
use O
in O
patients O
with O
SCZ O
. O

Pharmacotherapies O
for O
addiction O
, O
mental O
retardation O
, O
a O
history O
of O
head O
injury O
, O
or O
factors O
that O
contraindicate O
the O
use O
of O
fMRI O
served O
as O
exclusion O
criteria O
. O

The O
healthy O
control O
group O
was O
matched O
to O
the O
patient O
sample O
on O
age O
, O
gender O
and O
handedness O
. O

In O
addition O
to O
the O
exclusion O
criteria O
noted O
above O
, O
controls O
were O
excluded O
if O
they O
had O
any O
current O
or O
history O
of O
Axis O
I O
or O
II O
disorders O
, O
including O
any O
substance O
use O
disorder O
. O

A O
signed O
informed O
consent O
was O
obtained O
from O
participants O
prior O
to O
initiation O
of O
the O
study O
. O

The O
protocol O
was O
approved O
by O
the O
Committee O
for O
the O
Protection O
of O
Human O
Subjects O
( O
IRB O
) O
at O
Dartmouth O
College O
. O

Further O
details O
of O
the O
study O
design O
were O
reviewed O
in O
. O

Study O
Design O
and O
Procedure O
Participants O
refrained O
from O
substance O
use O
( O
except O
for O
tobacco O
or O
caffeine O
) O
for O
the O
duration O
of O
the O
study O
. O

Subjects O
completed O
a O
‘ O
baseline O
’ O
session O
( O
T1 O
) O
, O
and O
then O
returned O
one O
week O
later O
for O
a O
second O
scan O
session O
( O
T2 O
) O
during O
which O
patients O
were O
randomized O
to O
one O
of O
two O
double-blinded O
cannabinoid O
intervention O
groups O
: O
an O
oral O
THC O
group O
( O
N=6 O
) O
or O
an O
active O
cannabis O
cigarette O
( O
3.6 O
% O
THC O
) O
group O
( O
N=6 O
) O
. O

Those O
in O
the O
THC O
group O
were O
given O
a O
15mg O
THC O
pill O
( O
three O
hours O
prior O
to O
scanning O
) O
and O
then O
smoked O
a O
placebo O
cannabis O
cigarette O
immediately O
prior O
to O
scanning O
. O

Those O
in O
the O
cannabis O
group O
were O
given O
a O
placebo O
pill O
( O
3 O
hours O
prior O
to O
scanning O
) O
and O
then O
smoked O
an O
active O
3.6 O
% O
THC O
cannabis O
cigarette O
immediately O
before O
scanning O
. O

Smoking O
took O
place O
in O
a O
smoking O
chamber O
within O
the O
scanner O
bay O
, O
immediately O
prior O
to O
scanning O
( O
Figure O
1a O
) O
. O

Patients O
who O
were O
tobacco O
smokers O
were O
asked O
to O
smoke O
a O
cigarette O
90 O
minutes O
prior O
to O
scanning O
, O
based O
upon O
pharmacokinetics O
of O
smoked O
tobacco O
. O

Further O
details O
can O
be O
found O
in O
. O

Healthy O
control O
participants O
followed O
the O
same O
study O
protocol O
, O
but O
did O
not O
receive O
any O
pharmacologic O
intervention O
during O
T2 O
. O

In O
order O
to O
assist O
patients O
in O
remaining O
abstinent O
from O
substance O
use O
for O
the O
duration O
of O
the O
study O
, O
they O
were O
assessed O
three O
times O
in O
the O
week O
prior O
to O
each O
scan O
session O
. O

Each O
time O
, O
they O
were O
screened O
for O
substance O
use O
with O
an O
alcohol O
breathalyzer O
, O
a O
Timeline O
Follow-Back O
interview O
, O
and O
a O
urine O
toxicology O
screen O
( O
ToxCup O
Drug O
Screen O
cup O
; O
CLIAwaived O
, O
Sand O
Diego O
, O
CA O
) O
. O

Patients O
were O
discontinued O
from O
the O
study O
if O
screening O
suggested O
substance O
use O
during O
study O
participation O
. O

THC O
and O
symptom O
measures O
Venous O
blood O
samples O
were O
collected O
from O
patients O
at O
T1 O
, O
in O
the O
morning O
of O
the O
T2 O
session O
, O
immediately O
prior O
to O
fMRI O
scanning O
, O
and O
before O
cognitive O
testing O
( O
Figure O
1b O
) O
. O

The O
Marijuana O
Craving O
Questionnaire O
( O
MCQ O
) O
, O
Cannabis O
Withdrawal O
Scale O
( O
CWS O
) O
, O
and O
Positive O
and O
Negative O
Syndrome O
Scale O
( O
PANSS O
) O
were O
administered O
to O
assess O
for O
change O
in O
marijuana O
craving O
, O
withdrawal O
, O
and O
positive O
and O
negative O
symptoms O
. O

Change O
in O
these O
measures O
was O
analyzed O
using O
repeated O
measures O
analysis O
of O
variance O
( O
ANOVA O
) O
with O
group O
as O
the O
between O
group O
factor O
and O
time O
as O
the O
within-subjects O
factor O
, O
followed O
by O
post-hoc O
analysis O
using O
Tukey O
’ O
s O
LSD O
test O
for O
pairwise O
comparisons O
. O

Working O
memory O
performance O
To O
assess O
for O
change O
in O
working O
memory O
performance O
induced O
by O
cannabis O
and O
THC O
, O
the O
Wechsler O
Adult O
Intelligence O
Scale O
( O
WAIS O
) O
III O
Letter O
Number O
Sequencing O
Test O
was O
administered O
approximately O
30 O
minutes O
after O
the O
end O
of O
the O
scanning O
sessions O
at O
T1 O
and O
T2 O
. O

This O
test O
was O
selected O
because O
of O
availability O
of O
alternate O
forms O
and O
thus O
its O
applicability O
to O
the O
repeated-measures O
study O
design O
. O

The O
change O
in O
WM O
performance O
in O
patients O
was O
evaluated O
with O
a O
repeated-measures O
ANOVA O
. O

A O
correlation O
analysis O
between O
WM O
performance O
and O
the O
magnitude O
of O
DMN-ECN O
anticorrelation O
was O
performed O
between O
the O
MPFC O
component O
of O
the O
DMN O
and O
the O
DLPFC O
component O
of O
the O
ECN O
. O

fMRI O
data O
acquisition O
fMRI O
data O
were O
obtained O
using O
a O
3T O
Phillips O
Achieva O
fMRI O
scanner O
with O
an O
8 O
channel O
head O
coil O
. O

Each O
subject O
underwent O
two O
8-minute O
resting O
scans O
during O
the O
study O
with O
eyes O
open O
, O
one O
at O
baseline O
( O
T1 O
) O
, O
and O
the O
second O
during O
the O
‘ O
intervention O
’ O
session O
( O
T2 O
) O
. O

Further O
details O
can O
be O
found O
in O
. O

The O
resting O
state O
data O
were O
acquired O
transverse O
to O
the O
AC-PC O
plane O
, O
with O
a O
T2 O
* O
-weighted O
single O
shot O
echo O
planar O
imaging O
( O
EPI O
) O
pulse O
sequence O
designed O
to O
measure O
whole O
brain O
BOLD O
contrast O
with O
optimal O
temporal O
and O
spatial O
resolution O
[ O
repetition O
time O
( O
TR O
) O
=2000ms O
; O
echo O
time O
( O
TE O
) O
=30ms O
; O
Flip O
angle O
( O
FA O
) O
=90 O
degrees O
; O
field O
of O
view O
( O
FOV O
) O
=240 O
mm O
; O
Slice O

mm O
; O
Slice O
skip O
0.5 O
; O
Slice O
location=Pat O
. O

; O

; O
Reps=240 O
; O
NEX=1 O
; O
