36 O
contiguous O
transverse O
functional O
images O
in O
an O
80×80 O
matrix O
with O
an O
isotropic O
resolution O
of O
3.0 O
mm3 O
] O
. O

T1-weighted O
anatomic O
reference O
images O
were O
acquired O
in O
the O
same O
planes O
and O
thickness O
immediately O
following O
the O
resting O
scans O
. O

fMRI O
data O
analysis O
Resting O
state O
data O
were O
analyzed O
using O
a O
seed O
driven O
approach O
( O
http O
: O
//www.nitrc.org/projects/conn O
) O
. O

We O
used O
methods O
that O
minimize O
the O
influence O
of O
motion O
and O
artifact O
and O
that O
allow O
for O
valid O
identification O
of O
correlated O
and O
anticorrelated O
networks O
. O

Data O
were O
slice O
time O
corrected O
, O
realigned O
, O
coregistered O
, O
normalized O
, O
and O
spatially O
smoothed O
with O
a O
6-mm O
kernel O
. O

To O
address O
the O
spurious O
correlations O
in O
resting-state O
networks O
caused O
by O
head O
motion O
we O
used O
quality O
assurance O
software O
Artifact O
Detection O
Tools O
( O
http O
: O
//www.nitrc.org/projects/artifact_detect O
; O
http O
: O
//www.nitrc.org/projects/conn O
) O
to O
identify O
problematic O
time O
points O
during O
the O
scan O
. O

Specifically O
, O
an O
image O
was O
defined O
as O
an O
outlier O
if O
the O
head O
displacement O
in O
x O
, O
y O
, O
or O
z O
direction O
was O
greater O
than O
.5mm O
from O
the O
previous O
frame O
, O
or O
if O
the O
global O
mean O
intensity O
in O
the O
image O
was O
greater O
than O
3 O
standard O
deviations O
from O
the O
mean O
image O
intensity O
for O
the O
entire O
resting O
scan O
. O

A O
single O
regressor O
for O
each O
outlier O
image O
was O
included O
in O
the O
first O
level O
general O
linear O
model O
along O
with O
motion O
parameters O
and O
first O
order O
derivatives O
. O

Physiological O
and O
other O
spurious O
sources O
of O
noise O
were O
estimated O
and O
regressed O
using O
the O
anatomical O
CompCor O
method O
( O
aCompCor O
) O
as O
opposed O
to O
global O
signal O
regression O
, O
a O
widely O
used O
preprocessing O
method O
known O
to O
artificially O
introduce O
negative O
correlations O
. O

The O
anatomical O
image O
for O
each O
participant O
was O
segmented O
into O
white O
matter O
, O
grey O
matter O
, O
and O
cerebrospinal O
fluid O
( O
CSF O
) O
masks O
using O
SPM8 O
. O

To O
minimize O
partial O
voluming O
with O
grey O
matter O
, O
the O
white O
matter O
and O
CSF O
masks O
were O
eroded O
by O
one O
voxel O
, O
which O
resulted O
in O
substantially O
smaller O
masks O
than O
the O
original O
segmentations O
. O

The O
eroded O
white O
matter O
and O
CSF O
masks O
were O
then O
used O
as O
noise O
regions O
of O
interest O
( O
ROI O
) O
. O

Signals O
from O
the O
white O
matter O
and O
CSF O
noise O
ROIs O
were O
extracted O
from O
the O
unsmoothed O
functional O
volumes O
to O
avoid O
additional O
risk O
of O
contaminating O
white O
matter O
and O
CSF O
signals O
with O
grey O
matter O
signals O
. O

Previous O
results O
showed O
that O
aCompCor O
signals O
were O
considerably O
different O
from O
the O
global O
signal O
, O
as O
regressing O
higher O
order O
principal O
components O
of O
the O
global O
signal O
diminished O
both O
positive O
and O
negative O
correlations O
whereas O
regressing O
aCompCor O
signals O
resulted O
in O
stronger O
anticorrelations O
and O
eliminated O
spurious O
correlations O
. O

Based O
on O
previous O
results O
, O
five O
principal O
components O
of O
the O
signals O
from O
white O
matter O
and O
CSF O
noise O
ROIs O
were O
removed O
with O
regression O
. O

A O
temporal O
band-pass O
filter O
of O
0.009 O
Hz O
to O
0.08 O
Hz O
was O
applied O
to O
the O
time O
series O
. O

The O
residual O
BOLD O
time-series O
was O
band-pass O
filtered O
over O
a O
low-frequency O
window O
of O
interest O
( O
0.009Hz O
< O
f O
< O
0.08Hz O
) O
. O

Correlation O
maps O
were O
produced O
by O
extracting O
the O
residual O
BOLD O
time O
course O
from O
seed O
regions O
based O
on O
the O
literature O
. O

The O
DMN O
seed O
was O
defined O
using O
a O
10 O
mm O
sphere O
around O
peak O
MPFC O
coordinates O
, O
as O
specified O
in O
. O

Pearson O
’ O
s O
correlation O
coefficients O
were O
then O
calculated O
between O
the O
DMN O
time O
course O
and O
the O
time O
course O
of O
all O
other O
voxels O
in O
the O
brain O
. O

Correlation O
coefficients O
were O
converted O
to O
normally O
distributed O
scores O
using O
Fisher O
’ O
s O
transformation O
to O
allow O
for O
second-level O
General O
Linear O
Model O
analyses O
. O

Second-level O
within-group O
( O
one O
sample O
t-tests O
) O
and O
between O
group O
( O
ANOVA O
) O
analyses O
were O
performed O
on O
the O
Z-maps O
from O
the O
MPFC O
. O

Correction O
for O
multiple O
comparisons O
on O
analyses O
were O
implemented O
with O
an O
FDR O
correction O
of O
p O
< O
0.001 O
. O

Machine O
learning O
: O
assessing O
neurovascular O
signals O
in O
the O
prefrontal O
cortex O
with O
non-invasive O
bimodal O
electro-optical O
neuroimaging O
in O
opiate O
addiction O
Chronic O
and O
recurrent O
opiate O
use O
injuries O
brain O
tissue O
and O
cause O
serious O
pathophysiological O
changes O
in O
hemodynamic O
and O
subsequent O
inflammatory O
responses O
. O

Prefrontal O
cortex O
( O
PFC O
) O
has O
been O
implicated O
in O
drug O
addiction O
. O

However O
, O
the O
mechanism O
underlying O
systems-level O
neuroadaptations O
in O
PFC O
during O
abstinence O
has O
not O
been O
fully O
characterized O
. O

The O
objective O
of O
our O
study O
was O
to O
determine O
what O
neural O
oscillatory O
activity O
contributes O
to O
the O
chronic O
effect O
of O
opiate O
exposure O
and O
whether O
the O
activity O
could O
be O
coupled O
to O
neurovascular O
information O
in O
the O
PFC O
. O

We O
employed O
resting-state O
functional O
connectivity O
to O
explore O
alterations O
in O
8 O
patients O
with O
heroin O
dependency O
who O
stayed O
abstinent O
( O
> O
3 O
months O
; O
HD O
) O
compared O
with O
11 O
control O
subjects O
. O

A O
non-invasive O
neuroimaging O
strategy O
was O
applied O
to O
combine O
electrophysiological O
signals O
through O
electroencephalography O
( O
EEG O
) O
with O
hemodynamic O
signals O
through O
functional O
near-infrared O
spectroscopy O
( O
fNIRS O
) O
. O

The O
electrophysiological O
signals O
indicate O
neural O
synchrony O
and O
the O
oscillatory O
activity O
, O
and O
the O
hemodynamic O
signals O
indicate O
blood O
oxygenation O
in O
small O
vessels O
in O
the O
PFC O
. O

A O
supervised O
machine O
learning O
method O
was O
used O
to O
obtain O
associations O
between O
EEG O
and O
fNIRS O
modalities O
to O
improve O
precision O
and O
localization O
. O

HD O
patients O
demonstrated O
desynchronized O
lower O
alpha O
rhythms O
and O
decreased O
connectivity O
in O
PFC O
networks O
. O

Asymmetric O
excitability O
and O
cerebrovascular O
injury O
were O
also O
observed O
. O

This O
pilot O
study O
suggests O
that O
cerebrovascular O
injury O
in O
PFC O
may O
result O
from O
chronic O
opiate O
intake O
. O

Materials O
and O
Methods O
Study O
design O
This O
study O
focuses O
on O
heroin-dependent O
patients O
( O
HD O
) O
who O
had O
exposed O
to O
heroin O
for O
over O
20 O
years O
and O
who O
managed O
to O
stay O
abstinent O
for O
at O
least O
three O
months O
. O

They O
were O
compared O
with O
the O
healthy O
subjects O
in O
control O
group O
( O
CG O
) O
enrolled O
with O
demography O
matching O
the O
recruited O
HD O
patients O
with O
age O
, O
education O
level O
, O
and O
IQ O
( O
Fig O
. O

1A O
) O
. O

This O
is O
an O
exploratory O
study O
to O
assess O
the O
resting-state O
neural O
synchrony O
, O
electrical O
oscillations O
, O
the O
cerebrovascular O
effect O
, O
and O
the O
functional O
connectivity O
of O
HD O
patients O
after O
protracted O
abstinence O
. O

This O
study O
is O
based O
on O
the O
assumption O
that O
neuronal O
activity O
is O
generated O
by O
electrical O
field O
and O
greatly O
relies O
on O
the O
neurovascular O
coupling O
mechanism O
. O

Hence O
, O
through O
modern O
machine O
learning O
method O
, O
the O
study O
is O
to O
design O
to O
examine O
neurophysiological O
information O
in O
the O
PFC O
in O
opiate O
addiction O
during O
abstinence O
through O
electrophysiological O
and O
neurovascular O
neuroimaging O
techniques O
. O

The O
work O
flows O
of O
EEG O
and O
fNIRS O
data O
processing O
analyses O
are O
showed O
in O
Fig O
. O

1B O
. O

Study O
subjects O
HD O
patients O
were O
eligible O
if O
they O
were O
diagnosed O
of O
OUD O
by O
a O
physician O
, O
had O
a O
history O
of O
at-least-20-years O
of O
recurrent O
heroin O
use O
, O
stayed O
abstinent O
for O
at O
least O
3 O
months O
by O
the O
time O
of O
the O
study O
and O
were O
righted-handed O
between O
39 O
and O
57 O
years O
old O
. O

Control O
subjects O
were O
enrolled O
with O
demographic O
factors O
( O
i.e. O
, O
age O
, O
education O
level O
, O
and O
IQ O
) O
matching O
the O
recruited O
HD O
patients O
( O
Fig O
. O

1A O
) O
. O

Prior O
to O
inclusion O
in O
the O
study O
, O
all O
enrolled O
subjects O
were O
required O
to O
complete O
a O
preclinical O
interview O
and O
collect O
a O
urine O
sample O
for O
urinalysis O
. O

The O
Structured O
Clinical O
Interview O
for O
DSM-IV O
( O
SCID O
) O
was O
administrated O
in O
the O
interview O
to O
verify O
opioid O
dependence O
and O
mental-state O
suitability O
for O
the O
study O
. O

Subjects O
with O
history O
of O
any O
neurological O
illness O
, O
head O
trauma O
, O
brain O
injury O
, O
or O
psychiatric O
disorders O
other O
than O
OUDs O
and O
Tabaco O
use O
disorder O
, O
and O
72-hour O
of O
psychoactive O
substance O
use O
before O
any O
experimental O
measurements O
were O
excluded O
. O

The O
protocol O
was O
approved O
by O
the O
Medical O
Ethics O
Committee O
of O
the O
University O
of O
Macau O
. O

The O
experiments O
were O
performed O
in O
accordance O
with O
the O
relevant O
guidelines O
and O
regulations O
in O
the O
latest O
version O
of O
the O
Declaration O
of O
Helsinki O
. O

Written O
informed O
consents O
were O
provide O
to O
all O
subjects O
. O

Subjects O
were O
introduced O
and O
instructed O
to O
sit O
comfortably O
on O
a O
chair O
in O
a O
quiet O
and O
dim O
room O
located O
at O
the O
Bioimaging O
Core O
of O
the O
Faculty O
of O
Health O
Sciences O
where O
the O
study O
was O
conducted O
. O

EEG O
and O
fNIRS O
signals O
in O
the O
eye-closed O
resting O
state O
were O
simultaneously O
and O
continuously O
recorded O
for O
11 O
minutes O
. O

The O
first O
2-minute O
measurements O
were O
eliminated O
to O
generate O
relatively O
steady O
signals O
and O
rule O
out O
potential O
effects O
of O
instability O
for O
analysis O
. O

In O
part O
of O
Fig O
. O

1B O
shows O
the O
configuration O
of O
the O
EEG O
electrodes O
and O
fNIRS O
channels O
. O

A O
three-dimensional O
( O
3-D O
) O
digitizer O
( O
Polhemus O
Inc. O
, O
Vermont O
) O
was O
used O
to O
complete O
the O
spatial O
registration O
of O
the O
electrode O
and O
channel O
locations O
, O
and O
thus O
, O
the O
MNI O
coordinates O
were O
obtained O
( O
see O
Supplementary O
Table O
S1 O
) O
. O

Electrophysiological O
measurements O
The O
electrical O
activity O
of O
manifold O
neurons O
up O
to O
large O
neuronal O
assemblies O
can O
be O
directly O
measured O
non-invasively O
with O
extracellular O
electrophysiological O
recordings O
, O
such O
as O
MEG O
or O
EEG O
, O
which O
are O
primarily O
generated O
by O
post-synaptic O
potentials O
and O
thus O
often O
susceptible O
to O
changes O
in O
neurotransmission O
secondary O
to O
neural O
dysfunction O
or O
neuropharmacological O
manipulations O
. O

The O
EEG O
recordings O
were O
conducted O
on O
the O
Biosemi O
ActiveTwo O
system O
( O
Biosemi O
, O
Amsterdam O
, O
The O
Netherlands O
; O
sampling O
rate O
: O
2048 O
Hz O
) O
from O
64 O
electrodes O
on O
the O
International O
10–20 O
system O
with O
a O
nose O
reference O
based O
. O

The O
horizontal O
and O
vertical O
electrooculogram O
( O
EOGs O
) O
were O
additionally O
acquired O
to O
oversee O
eye O
movements O
. O

Electrode O
impedance O
was O
less O
than O
10 O
kΩ O
. O

EEG O
data O
were O
preprocessed O
using O
EEGLAB O
( O
https O
: O
//sccn.ucsd.edu/eeglab O
) O
. O

Ocular O
artifacts O
acquired O
by O
EOGs O
channels O
were O
corrected O
in O
the O
recorded O
EEG O
data O
. O

The O
EEG O
data O
were O
segmented O
into O
2-second O
epochs O
, O
of O
which O
with O
voltage O
exceeded O
± O
150 O
µV O
were O
excluded O
. O

Frequency O
bands O
of O
interest O
were O
filtered O
and O
classified O
by O
delta O
( O
1.5–4 O
Hz O
) O
, O
theta O
( O
4–8 O
Hz O
) O
, O
lower O
alpha O
( O
8–10 O
Hz O
) O
, O
upper O
alpha O
( O
10–13 O
Hz O
) O
, O
beta O
( O
14–30 O
Hz O
) O
, O
and O
gamma O
( O
30–50 O
Hz O
) O
. O

Classification O
of O
alpha O
oscillations O
in O
lower O
and O
upper O
alpha O
frequency O
bands O
offers O
a O
narrowed O
range O
of O
interest O
. O

EEG O
data O
were O
then O
down-sampled O
from O
2048 O
to O
256 O
Hz O
. O

For O
each O
subject O
, O
the O
first O
10 O
artifact-free O
baseline-corrected O
epochs O
( O
5120 O
samples O
; O
20 O
seconds O
) O
were O
selected O
for O
further O
processing O
and O
analysis O
. O

The O
detailed O
preprocessing O
method O
is O
documented O
in O
Kim O
et O
al O
.. O
Because O
neuronal O
oscillations O
have O
been O
associated O
practically O
with O
many O
aspects O
of O
cognitive O
function O
, O
two O
important O
and O
distinct O
temporal O
variables O
from O
the O
EEG O
: O
neural O
synchrony O
and O
oscillations O
were O
the O
subjects O
of O
investigation O
in O
the O
study O
. O

Hemodynamic O
measurements O
Neurovascular O
activity O
, O
often O
known O
as O
hemodynamic O
activity O
, O
can O
be O
indirectly O
measured O
without O
exogenous O
contrast O
agents O
non-invasively O
by O
functional O
MRI O
or O
functional O
intrinsic O
optional O
imaging O
, O
such O
as O
fNIRS O
. O

The O
fNIRS O
recordings O
were O
conducted O
on O
the O
NIRS O
Continuous O
Wave O
( O
CW O
) O
system O
( O
CW6 O
fNIRS O
system O
; O
TechEn O
Inc O
, O
Milford O
, O
MA O
; O
sampling O
rate O
: O
50 O
Hz O
; O
bandpass O
range O
: O
0.1–200 O
Hz O
) O
, O
with O
four O
sources O
and O
eight O
detectors O
to O
generate O
fourteen O
channels O
on O
the O
scalp O
, O
covering O
the O
PFC O
. O

Each O
set O
of O
a O
source O
and O
detectors O
covered O
one O
particular O
PFC O
subregions O
, O
resulting O
in O
four O
ROIs O
: O
the O
right O
dlPFC O
, O
the O
left O
FP O
, O
the O
right O
FP O
, O
and O
the O
left O
dlPFC O
( O
see O
Supplementary O
Table O
S1 O
for O
details O
) O
. O

The O
source-detector O
distance O
was O
3 O
cm O
, O
measuring O
the O
neural O
activity O
of O
the O
cortex O
with O
an O
estimated O
2.5 O
cm O
penetration O
depth O
. O

The O
fNIRS O
monitors O
hemodynamic O
responses O
evoked O
by O
brain O
activity O
by O
using O
two O
CW O
lights O
at O
wavelengths O
of O
690 O
nm O
and O
830 O
nm O
- O
the O
characteristic O
absorption O
patterns O
in O
the O
near-infrared O
light O
, O
to O
obtain O
quantitative O
data O
of O
HbO O
and O
Hb O
. O

fNIRS O
data O
were O
preprocessed O
using O
Homer2 O
( O
www.homer-fnirs.org/documentation O
) O
. O

The O
preprocessed O
procedures O
were O
as O
follow O
: O
( O
1 O
) O
Conversion O
from O
optical O
density O
to O
the O
changes O
in O
HbO O
or O
Hb O
concentration O
at O
different O
time O
points O
based O
on O
the O
modified O
Beer-Lambert O
Law O
; O
( O
2 O
) O
Bandpass O
filtering O
( O
0.01 O
< O
fr O
< O
0.1 O
Hz O
) O
; O
( O
3 O
) O
Detrending O
; O
and O
( O
4 O
) O
Motion O
correction O
using O
the O
spline O
interpolation O
method O
. O

There O
are O
two O
main O
types O
of O
noise O
due O
to O
poor O
contact O
between O
the O
optodes O
and O
scalp O
: O
motion O
artifacts O
and O
a O
low O
signal-to-noise O
ratio O
( O
SNR O
) O
. O

And O
thus O
, O
quality O
control O
is O
necessary O
before O
functional O
connectivity O
analysis O
. O

To O
reduce O
the O
motion-induced O
artifacts O
, O
the O
spline O
interpolation O
method O
detected O
the O
artifacts O
by O
calculating O
the O
moving O
standard O
deviation O
within O
sliding O
time O
windows O
in O
a O
2-seoncd O
window O
length O
. O

Any O
data O
with O
average O
signal O
intensity O
over O
five O
standard O
deviations O
of O
the O
HbO O
and O
Hb O
concentrations O
over O
time O
are O
considered O
low O
SNRs O
and O
thus O
should O
be O
excluded O
. O

The O
detailed O
preprocessing O
method O
is O
documented O
in O
Niu O
et O
al O
.. O
No O
channel O
was O
excluded O
due O
to O
poor O
contact O
. O

Changes O
in O
HbO O
and O
Hb O
concentrations O
were O
extracted O
from O
each O
channel O
across O
all O
subjects O
to O
visually O
verify O
if O
there O
were O
changes O
of O
these O
molecules O
to O
reflect O
brain O
functional O
activity O
( O
i.e. O
, O
an O
increase O
in O
[ O
HbO O
] O
and O
a O
decrease O
in O
[ O
Hb O
] O
indicate O
typical O
CBO O
, O
and O
thus O
brain O
activation O
) O
. O

Functional O
connectivity O
analyses O
Functional O
connectivity O
is O
a O
statistical O
dependence O
between O
the O
time O
series O
of O
measured O
neurophysiological O
signals O
. O

Two O
points O
in O
a O
brain O
are O
considered O
functionally O
connected O
if O
they O
have O
synchronized O
or O
coherent O
dynamics O
. O

The O
translation O
of O
different O
measures O
in O
the O
neurophysiological O
signals O
depends O
on O
the O
modality O
of O
recordings O
being O
used O
. O

In O
this O
study O
, O
we O
used O
the O
measure O
of O
SL O
in O
electrophysiological O
signal O
on O
the O
EEG O
recording O
and O
the O
measures O
of O
change O
in O
both O
HbO O
and O
Hb O
concentrations O
in O
neurovascular O
signal O
on O
the O
fNIRS O
recording O
. O

To O
analyze O
the O
rsFC O
electrophysiological O
signal O
, O
the O
temporal O
information O
from O
the O
EEG O
, O
such O
as O
synchrony O
, O
was O
measured O
by O
SL O
. O

It O
is O
a O
generalized O
synchronization O
approach O
that O
can O
detect O
linear O
and O
nonlinear O
interdependences O
between O
two O
signals O
in O
a O
given O
number O
of O
electrodes O
, O
especially O
sensitive O
to O
the O
long-distanced O
synchronization O
of O
structured O
oscillatory O
activities O
of O
across O
whole-brain O
areas O
. O

SL O
in O
each O
frequency O
band O
as O
a O
measure O
of O
rsFC O
across O
time O
and O
electrode O
and O
then O
the O
functional O
connectivity O
were O
computed O
using O
the O
HERMES O
toolbox O
( O
http O
: O
//hermes.ctb.upm.es/ O
) O
. O

SL O
values O
of O
each O
subject O
were O
then O
averaged O
across O
each O
pair O
nodes O
. O

Permutation O
test O
was O
performed O
to O
determine O
the O
between-group O
difference O
at O
rest O
. O

Mean O
SL O
was O
analyzed O
to O
determine O
which O
frequency O
band O
was O
significant O
between O
groups O
, O
and O
its O
band O
power O
would O
be O
selected O
for O
further O
machine O
learning O
method O
. O

Connection-wise O
SL O
was O
analyzed O
by O
performing O
CBPT O
for O
multiple O
comparisons O
not O
only O
to O
identify O
the O
between-group O
significance O
where O
the O
SL O
value O
in O
HD O
group O
was O
significant O
compared O
to O
the O
controls O
, O
but O
also O
to O
offer O
a O
powerful O
and O
intuitive O
nonparametric O
framework O
for O
statistical O
analysis O
of O
power O
spectra O
in O
what O
brain O
region O
. O

Methodological O
details O
can O
be O
found O
in O
Nico O
et O
al O
.. O

The O
electrodes O
corresponding O
to O
the O
significant O
brain O
region O
( O
i.e. O
, O
source O
) O
calculated O
by O
CBPT O
would O
be O
selected O
for O
machine O
learning O
method O
. O

To O
analyze O
the O
rsFC O
neurovascular O
effect O
, O
the O
information O
regarding O
to O
the O
changes O
in O
HbO O
and O
Hb O
concentrations O
from O
the O
fNIRS O
were O
evaluated O
. O

Whole-brain O
correlation O
analysis O
was O
performed O
because O
it O
allowed O
us O
to O
easily O
observe O
the O
change O
of O
the O
two O
chromophores O
in O
a O
matrix O
and O
, O
more O
importantly O
, O
to O
compute O
a O
functional O
connectivity O
map O
between O
any O
two O
channel O
pairs O
in O
the O
PFC O
system O
, O
where O
the O
channels O
represented O
nodes O
, O
and O
where O
the O
functional O
connections O
with O
correlation O
coefficient O
, O
r O
, O
greater O
than O
a O
predefined O
threshold O
were O
considered O
edges O
. O

The O
result O
of O
computing O
r O
for O
each O
channel O
of O
a O
chromophore O
was O
a O
14 O
× O
14 O
matrix O
. O

All O
correlation O
values O
were O
converted O
to O
z-scores O
using O
the O
Fisher O
z-transformation O
prior O
to O
any O
statistical O
analysis O
. O

For O
simplicity O
, O
the O
concentration O
change O
in O
HbO O
was O
primarily O
analyzed O
and O
selected O
for O
further O
processing O
in O
the O
subsequent O
quantitative O
nodal O
network O
analysis O
as O
a O
feature O
for O
machine O
learning O
method O
because O
it O
is O
thought O
to O
be O
the O
most O
responsive O
indicator O
of O
differences O
in O
CBF O
and O
the O
most O
sensitive O
parameter O
of O
change O
in O
rCBO O
. O

Consisting O
with O
our O
previous O
work O
, O
the O
threshold O
value O
was O
determined O
by O
the O
foremost O
5 O
% O
of O
the O
connections O
before O
generating O
a O
network O
topological O
map O
. O

For O
visualization O
, O
BrainNet O
Viewer O
toolbox O
( O
https O
: O
//www.nitrc.org/projects/bnv O
) O
was O
applied O
. O

For O
nodal O
network O
analysis O
, O
the O
degree O
strength O
of O
each O
channel O
was O
quantified O
by O
averaging O
connectivity O
of O
a O
channel O
in O
the O
PFC O
system O
. O

Methodological O
details O
can O
be O
found O
in O
our O
previous O
work O
. O

Machine O
learning O
: O
multi-modal O
data O
analysis O
for O
PFC O
imaging O
One O
of O
the O
most O
modern O
multimodal O
neuroimaging O
setups O
is O
to O
combine O
the O
measurement O
of O
electrophysiology O
with O
the O
measurement O
of O
hemodynamics O
. O

Machine O
learning O
method O
is O
used O
to O
obtain O
correlations O
between O
EEG O
and O
fNIRS O
modalities O
by O
extracting O
physiologically O
plausible O
components O
. O

It O
is O
believed O
that O
the O
data O
obtained O
through O
this O
multimodality O
which O
otherwise O
offers O
exceptional O
spatial O
and O
temporal O
imaging O
resolution O
allows O
for O
combination O
of O
complementary O
information O
, O
thereby O
a O
desirable O
diagnosis O
, O
and O
a O
deeper O
understanding O
of O
how O
electrophysiological O
and O
neurovascular O
aspects O
of O
brain O
activity O
are O
related O
. O

To O
increase O
precision O
and O
detect O
minuscule O
signals O
from O
both O
of O
the O
electrophysiological O
and O
hemodynamic O
measurements O
, O
the O
mSPoC O
analysis O
was O
performed O
. O

The O
amplitude O
( O
i.e. O
, O
band O
power O
) O
and O
the O
frequency O
of O
the O
temporal O
oscillation O
selected O
from O
the O
EEG-based O
connectivity O
analysis O
, O
were O
extracted O
as O
an O
EEG O
feature O
. O

In O
order O
to O
perform O
the O
bi-modal O
EEG-fNIRS O
fusion O
, O
the O
number O
of O
samples O
from O
fNIRS O
data O
must O
equal O
to O
the O
number O
of O
epoch O
from O
EEG O
data O
because O
the O
modulations O
of O
a O
source O
extracted O
from O
fNIRS O
is O
related O
to O
the O
modulations O
of O
the O
power O
of O
a O
source O
from O
EEG O
. O

The O
preprocessed O
fNIRS O
data O
were O
then O
down-sampled O
from O
50 O
to O
5 O
Hz O
. O

For O
each O
subject O
, O
the O
first O
10 O
HbO-based O
samples O
( O
i.e. O
, O
[ O
HbOf O
] O
) O
were O
extracted O
as O
a O
fNIRS O
feature O
( O
in O
part O
, O
Fig O
. O

1B O
) O
. O

Both O
datasets O
were O
preprocessed O
to O
extract O
features O
using O
a O
sliding O
window O
of O
2 O
seconds O
. O

The O
mSPoC O
method O
was O
proposed O
to O
examine O
the O
comodulation O
between O
resting-state-induced O
power O
dynamics O
of O
the O
selected O
oscillatory O
rhythm O
and O
changes O
in O
HbO O
concentration O
. O

Through O
this O
supervised O
machine O
learning O
strategy O
, O
it O
finds O
the O
direction O
( O
i.e. O
, O
spatial O
filters O
) O
of O
the O
two O
class O
( O
i.e. O
, O
EEG O
and O
fNIRS O
) O
in O
a O
high-dimensional O
space O
such O
that O
the O
spectral O
power O
dynamics O
of O
the O
projected O
electrophysiological O
signal O
( O
i.e. O
, O
EEG-source O
) O
maximizing O
covaried O
with O
the O
time-course O
of O
the O
project O
hemodynamic O
signal O
( O
i.e. O
, O
a O
corresponding O
fNIRS-source O
) O
. O

The O
time-invariant O
coupling O
coefficients O
of O
each O
source O
with O
the O
different O
sensors O
( O
i.e. O
, O
the O
common O
spatial O
patterns O
) O
of O
EEG O
and O
fNIRS O
data O
were O
then O
calculated O
. O

The O
detailed O
fusion O
method O
is O
documented O
in O
Dähne O
et O
al O
.. O

The O
brain O
area O
generating O
the O
EEG O
mSPoC O
component O
was O
localized O
in O
the O
PFC O
subregions O
and O
across O
PFC O
region O
as O
a O
whole O
. O

The O
EEG O
mSPoC O
component O
which O
has O
the O
greatest O
coupling O
coefficient O
value O
was O
then O
selected O
to O
fuse O
with O
the O
corresponding O
fNIRS O
component O
. O

In O
addition O
to O
mSPoC O
analysis O
, O
sensor-space O
cortical O
source O
estimation O
was O
separately O
performed O
for O
both O
EEG O
and O
fNIRS O
datasets O
by O
using O
the O
eConnectome O
toolbox O
( O
http O
: O
//econnectome.umn.edu/ O
) O
and O
the O
NIRS-SPM O
toolbox O
( O
http O
: O
//bispl.weebly.com/nirs-spm.html O
# O
/ O
) O
, O
respectively O
, O
to O
visually O
scan O
through O
activation O
locations O
. O

The O
activation O
pattern O
of O
the O
fused O
EEG O
and O
fNIRS O
component O
estimated O
by O
mSPoC O
method O
was O
then O
visualized O
by O
using O
BrainNet O
Viewer O
( O
https O
: O
//www.nitrc.org/projects/bnv O
) O
. O

Statistical O
analysis O
Statistical O
analyses O
were O
performed O
using O
SPSS O
( O
IBM O
SPSS O
Statistics O
, O
version O
22 O
, O
Armonk O
, O
NY O
) O
. O

Group O
differences O
in O
demographic O
and O
ROI O
data O
were O
investigated O
using O
two-sample O
t O
test O
and O
Bonferroni O
correction O
. O

Statistical O
permutation O
test O
was O
performed O
throughout O
the O
study O
for O
connectivity O
analysis O
and O
machine O
learning O
method O
to O
determine O
group O
difference O
between O
two O
means O
in O
which O
the O
null O
distribution O
of O
test O
statistic O
was O
obtained O
by O
a O
number O
of O
random O
rearrangements O
for O
each O
study O
group O
( O
i.e. O
, O
permutations O
) O
. O

It O
worked O
as O
follows O
. O

First O
, O
a O
t-test O
was O
performed O
at O
p O
< O
0.05 O
significance O
level O
( O
uncorrected O
for O
multiplicity O
) O
to O
give O
an O
initial O
approximation O
to O
the O
study O
of O
statistical O
differences O
between O
the O
HD O
and O
control O
groups O
. O

Second O
, O
each O
subject O
was O
randomly O
reassigned O
to O
either O
a O
patient O
or O
a O
control O
group O
, O
thereby O
forming O
a O
division O
that O
was O
no O
longer O
faithful O
to O
the O
original O
real O
partition O
of O
the O
data O
sets O
. O

The O
procedure O
was O
repeated O
1,000 O
times O
. O

The O
t-values O
were O
recalculated O
, O
and O
the O
null O
distribution O
of O
test O
statistics O
for O
the O
group O
difference O
was O
obtained O
. O

Finally O
, O
the O
proportion O
of O
sampled O
permutations O
where O
the O
t-values O
were O
larger O
than O
the O
observed O
test O
statistics O
was O
computed O
as O
the O
p-value O
of O
the O
observed O
group O
difference O
. O

Similarly O
in O
mSPoC O
analysis O
, O
permutation O
was O
performed O
to O
randomize O
the O
initial O
set O
of O
EEG-signal O
spatial O
filters O
until O
a O
suitable O
convergence O
criterion O
was O
met O
in O
order O
to O
optimize O
the O
fusion O
objective O
. O

A O
level O
of O
significance O
was O
set O
p O
< O
0.05 O
( O
uncorrected O
) O
, O
and O
subject O
’ O
s O
age O
, O
gender O
, O
IQ O
were O
defined O
as O
covariates O
to O
minimize O
potential O
biases O
to O
the O
results O
. O

Due O
to O
the O
small O
sample O
size O
of O
the O
study O
, O
we O
used O
the O
current O
alternative O
strategy O
for O
convention O
, O
in O
which O
the O
matched O
sample O
size O
was O
appropriately O
adapted O
to O
the O
cost O
concerns O
of O
the O
study O
. O

All O
p O
values O
were O
two-tailed O
( O
α O
= O
0.05 O
) O
. O

MATLAB O
( O
MathWorks O
, O
Inc. O
, O
Natick O
, O
MA O
, O
USA O
) O
was O
used O
for O
all O
computations O
. O

Integrative O
Transcriptomics O
Reveals O
Sexually O
Dimorphic O
Control O
of O
the O
Cholinergic/Neurokine O
Interface O
in O
Schizophrenia O
and O
Bipolar O
Disorder O
Summary O
RNA O
sequencing O
analyses O
are O
often O
limited O
to O
identifying O
lowest O
p O
value O
transcripts O
, O
which O
does O
not O
address O
polygenic O
phenomena O
. O

To O
overcome O
this O
limitation O
, O
we O
developed O
an O
integrative O
approach O
that O
combines O
large-scale O
transcriptomic O
meta-analysis O
of O
patient O
brain O
tissues O
with O
single-cell O
sequencing O
data O
of O
CNS O
neurons O
, O
short O
RNA O
sequencing O
of O
human O
male- O
and O
female-originating O
cell O
lines O
, O
and O
connectomics O
of O
transcription O
factor O
and O
microRNA O
interactions O
with O
perturbed O
transcripts O
. O

We O
used O
this O
pipeline O
to O
analyze O
cortical O
transcripts O
of O
schizophrenia O
and O
bipolar O
disorder O
patients O
. O

Although O
these O
pathologies O
show O
massive O
transcriptional O
parallels O
, O
their O
clinically O
well-known O
sexual O
dimorphisms O
remain O
unexplained O
. O

Our O
method O
reveals O
the O
differences O
between O
afflicted O
men O
and O
women O
and O
identifies O
disease-affected O
pathways O
of O
cholinergic O
transmission O
and O
gp130-family O
neurokine O
controllers O
of O
immune O
function O
interlinked O
by O
microRNAs O
. O

This O
approach O
may O
open O
additional O
perspectives O
for O
seeking O
biomarkers O
and O
therapeutic O
targets O
in O
other O
transmitter O
systems O
and O
diseases O
. O

Graphical O
Abstract O
Highlights O
Single-cell O
transcriptomes O
reveal O
a O
unique O
profile O
of O
cortical O
cholinergic O
neurons O
Female- O
and O
male-derived O
cells O
show O
distinct O
neurokine-induced O
miRNA O
responses O
Differentially O
enriched O
microRNA O
families O
constitute O
a O
self-organizing O
network O
Integrative O
analysis O
identifies O
mir-10/mir-199 O
regulators O
of O
cholinergic O
function O
Lobentanzer O
et O
al O
. O

show O
how O
bioinformatically O
supported O
high-throughput O
techniques O
such O
as O
short O
RNA O
sequencing O
can O
bridge O
the O
gap O
between O
traditional O
molecular O
interaction O
studies O
and O
purely O
bioinformatic O
prediction O
paradigms O
in O
an O
example O
focused O
on O
disentangling O
the O
sexual O
dimorphism O
in O
microRNA O
regulation O
of O
the O
cholinergic/neurokine O
interface O
in O
mental O
disorders O
. O

and O

for O

and O

should O
be O
directed O
to O
and O
will O
be O
fulfilled O
by O
the O
Lead O

, O
Hermona O
Soreq O
( O

) O
. O

This O
study O
did O
not O
generate O
new O
unique O
reagents O
. O

Experimental O
Model O
and O
Subject O
Details O
Cell O
Lines O
We O
employed O
LA-N-2 O
( O
female O
) O
( O
DSMZ O
Cat O
# O
ACC-671 O
, O
RRID O
: O
CVCL_1829 O
) O
and O
LA-N-5 O
( O
male O
) O
( O
DSMZ O
Cat O
# O
ACC-673 O
, O
RRID O
: O
CVCL_0389 O
) O
cells O
as O
our O
main O
experimental O
model O
system O
. O

The O
cells O
were O
purchased O
at O
DSMZ O
( O
Braunschweig O
, O
Germany O
) O
. O

These O
cells O
respond O
to O
differentiation O
by O
several O
neurokines O
( O
CNTF O
, O
LIF O
, O
IL-6 O
) O
by O
cholinergic O
differentiation O
corresponding O
with O
elevation O
of O
choline O
acetyltransferase O
( O
ChAT O
) O
, O
the O
central O
cholinergic O
marker O
( O
mRNA O
, O
protein O
, O
and O
activity O
) O
as O
well O
as O
its O
intronic O
vesicular O
ACh-transporter O
gene O
, O
vAChT O
( O
aka O
SLC18A3 O
) O
. O

Cells O
were O
maintained O
at O
37°C O
in O
8 O
% O
CO2 O
atmosphere O
in O
medium O
consisting O
of O
1:1 O
DMEM O
and O
RPMI O
1640 O
, O
with O
20 O
% O
FCS O
, O
with O
weekly O
splits O
. O

Experiments O
were O
performed O
between O
splits O
2-6 O
after O
thawing O
. O

HEK293T O
and O
U937 O
cells O
were O
purchased O
at O
ATCC O
and O
maintained O
according O
to O
ATCC O
guidelines O
. O

Experiments O
were O
performed O
between O
splits O
2-10 O
. O

Patient O
Data O

used O
previously O
published O
datasets O
for O
several O
analyses O
. O

These O
comprise O
several O
cortical O
datasets O
in O
raw O
format O
( O
Affymetrix O
) O
from O
NCBI O
GEO O
: O
GSE35978 O
( O
SCZ O
& O
BD O
) O
, O
GSE53987 O
( O
SCZ O
& O

) O
, O

( O
SCZ O
& O

, O

, O

of O

patients O
and O

from O
the O
Common O
Mind O
Consortium O
( O

: O
//www.synapse.org/CMC O
) O
. O

Method O
Details O
Methodological O
Outline O
Focusing O
on O
a O
well-defined O
set O
of O
genes O
aims O
to O
avoid O
some O
of O
the O
data O
loss O
that O
occurs O
when O
patient O
tissues O
comprising O
multiple O
cell O
types O
are O
homogenized O
for O
analysis O
. O

This O
is O
particularly O
relevant O
for O
cortical O
cholinergic O
interneurons O
, O
where O
the O
cell O
type O
of O
interest O
is O
numerically O
inferior O
, O
and O
transcriptomic O
data O
can O
be O
“ O
diluted O
” O
by O
the O
other O
, O
more O
prominent O
cell O
types O
, O
such O
as O
glia O
or O
astrocytes O
. O

The O
consequent O
increase O
in O
detection O
threshold O
can O
be O
re-lowered O
by O
reducing O
the O
number O
of O
genes O
tested O
. O

Analysis O
of O
single O
cell O
datasets O
can O
ascertain O
that O
the O
genes O
analyzed O
are O
representative O
and O
fairly O
unique O
to O
the O
cell O
type O
in O
question O
, O
as O
was O
the O
case O
for O
cholinergic O
markers O
in O
our O
study O
, O
and O
utmost O
care O
should O
be O
taken O
for O
any O
gene O
set O
of O
interest O
and O
any O
kind O
of O
tissue O
subjected O
to O
this O
kind O
of O
analysis O
. O

Our O
approach O
is O
based O
on O
the O
availability O
of O
suitable O
amounts O
of O
patient O
data O
in O
web-available O
form O
, O
combined O
with O
a O
standardized O
pipeline O
of O
statistical O
pre-processing O
to O
equilibrate O
individual O
statistical O
influences O
. O

Regardless O
of O
how O
patient O
data O
and O
the O
subset O
of O
genes O
of O
interest O
are O
selected O
, O
the O
reduction O
in O
number O
of O
analyzed O
genes O
has O
to O
be O
performed O
after O
application O
of O
the O
linear O
model O
to O
the O
batch- O
and O
covariate-corrected O
data O
to O
avoid O
interference O
with O
correct O
linear O
regression O
. O

Once O
the O
expression O
data O
( O
be O
it O
array- O
or O
sequencing-derived O
) O
has O
been O
corrected O
for O
batch O
effects O
and O
covariates O
, O
and O
outliers O
have O
been O
removed O
, O
it O
can O
be O
analyzed O
with O
a O
suitable O
differential O
gene O
expression O
algorithm O
. O

The O
resulting O
, O
individual O
datasets O
should O
ideally O
converge O
on O
similar O
logFC O
values O
, O
but O
may O
also O
show O
controversy O
between O
individual O
experiments O
, O
which O
can O
result O
from O
a O
multitude O
of O
factors O
from O
biological O
variety O
to O
sampling O
procedures O
or O
exact O
tissue O
composition O
, O
all O
of O
which O
have O
to O
be O
interpreted O
at O
the O
discretion O
of O
the O
scientist O
. O

Neuronal O
Differentiation/Short O
RNA O
Sequencing O
Model O
LA-N-2 O
and O
LA-N-5 O
cells O
respond O
to O
ciliary O
neurotrophic O
factor O
( O
CNTF O
) O
by O
cholinergic O
differentiation O
corresponding O
with O
elevation O
of O
choline O
acetyltransferase O
( O
ChAT O
) O
, O
the O
central O
cholinergic O
marker O
( O
mRNA O
, O
protein O
, O
and O
activity O
) O
as O
well O
as O
its O
intronic O
vesicular O
ACh-transporter O
gene O
, O
vAChT O
( O
aka O
SLC18A3 O
) O
. O

We O
measured O
the O
changes O
in O
short O
RNA O
levels O
following O
this O
intervention O
at O
several O
time O
points O
. O

Differentiation O
To O
determine O
effective O
concentrations O
of O
the O
differentiation O
agent O
, O
we O
performed O
a O
dose-response O
experiment O
with O
both O
cell O
lines O
. O

Cells O
were O
seeded O
at O
approximately O
200 O
000 O
cells O
per O
well O
in O
12-well O
plates O
, O
and O
after O
24h O
incubated O
with O
1 O
, O
10 O
, O
or O
100 O
ng/ml O
CNTF O
( O
Sigma-Aldrich O
) O
. O

Dose-response O
was O
measured O
by O
qPCR O
of O
CHAT O
mRNA O
, O
at O
time O
points O
30 O
minutes O
, O
60 O
minutes O
, O
2 O
days O
, O
and O
4 O
days O
. O

For O
each O
sample O
, O
a O
corresponding O
control O
culture O
was O
generated O
. O

RNA O
Extraction O
for O
qPCR O
and O
Sequencing O
RNA O
was O
extracted O
in O
biological O
quadruplicates O
using O
TRIzol O
according O
to O
the O
manufacturer′s O
instructions O
, O
as O
described O
in O
. O

RNA O
was O
precipitated O
using O
ethanol O
, O
washed O
, O
and O
air-dried O
before O
resuspension O
in O
RNase-free O
water O
. O

Concentration O
was O
measured O
by O
Nanodrop O
2000 O
( O
ThermoFisher O
Scientific O
) O
, O
RNA O
quality O
was O
measured O
via O
Bioanalyzer O
2100 O
( O
Agilent O
) O
. O

RNA O
quality O
for O
all O
samples O
was O
near O
optimal O
( O
RIN O
> O
9 O
) O
. O

Quantitative O
Real-time O
PCR O
RNA O
was O
analyzed O
on O
a O
BioRad O
CFX96 O
real-time O
PCR O
cycler O
using O
PowerUp O
SYBR O
Green O
Master O
Mix O
( O
Applied O
Biosystems O
) O
in O
technical O
duplicates O
. O

Primers O
were O
designed O
using O
primer3 O
and O
are O
as O
follows O
( O
5′ O
to O
3′ O
) O
: O
ChAT O
[ O
FW O
: O
CAC O
TTG O
GTG O
TCT O
GAG O
CA O
, O
RV O
: O
AGT O
TTC O
TGC O
TGC O
AGG O
GTC O
TC O
] O
, O
ACTB O
( O
housekeeping O
) O
[ O
FW O
: O
GCT O
GTA O
TTC O
CCC O
TCC O
ATC O
GT O
, O
RV O
: O
CTT O
CTC O
CAT O
GTC O
GTC O
CCA O
GT O
] O
; O
additional O
primers O
were O
ordered O
from O
BioRad O
, O
Germany O
: O
vAChT O
[ O
PrimePCR O
“ O
qHsaCED0047922 O
” O
] O
, O
RPLP0 O
( O
housekeeping O
) O
[ O
PrimePCR O
“ O
qHsaCED0038653 O
” O
] O
. O

Data O
were O
analyzed O
with O
BioRad O
CFX O
manager O
and O
expression O
values O
( O
normalized O
to O
housekeeping O
genes O
) O
exported O
for O
statistical O
testing O
in O
R. O
Short O
RNA O
Sequencing O
Short O
RNA O
sequencing O
was O
performed O
using O
Illumina O
NextSeq O
550 O
according O
to O
the O
manufacturer O
’ O
s O
instructions O
, O
after O
cDNA O
library O
preparation O
using O
the O
NEBNext O
Multiplex O
Small O
RNA O
Library O
Prep O
Set O
for O
Illumina O
( O
New O
England O
BioLabs O
) O
as O
described O
. O

Sequenced O
reads O
were O
aligned O
to O
miRBase O
v21 O
sequences O
via O
miRExpress O
( O
version O
2.1.4 O
) O
. O

Differential O
expression O
was O
determined O
via O
R/DESeq2 O
. O

The O
Count-Change O
Metric O
We O
calculated O
the O
count-change O
for O
individual O
miRs O
by O
combining O
base O
mean O
expression O
with O
the O
de-logarithmized O
fold-change O
( O
from O
DESeq2 O
output O
) O
.CC O
: O
countChange O
, O
BM O
: O
baseMean O
, O
LFC O
: O
log2-fold O
change O
It O
is O
important O
to O
note O
that O
the O
count-change O
metric O
, O
by O
deriving O
from O
the O
base O
mean O
expression O
across O
samples O
, O
is O
dependent O
on O
sequencing O
depth O
, O
and O
thus O
is O
not O
instantly O
generalizable O
, O
for O
instance O
when O
comparing O
different O
experiments O
. O

However O
, O
it O
could O
be O
normalized O
to O
a O
degree O
by O
considering O
the O
total O
amount O
of O
raw O
reads O
generated O
from O
each O
sample O
. O

Whole-Transcriptome O
Meta-analysis O
Data O
Preparation O
We O
processed O
web-available O
patient O
transcriptome O
datasets O
by O
state-of-the-art O
procedures O
, O
analogous O
to O
, O
to O
generate O
transcriptional O
disease O
profiles O
. O

The O
following O
R O
packages O
( O
Bioconductor O
) O
were O
used O
according O
to O
the O
developer O
’ O
s O
instructions O
: O
Raw O
data O
read O
, O
RMA O
normalization O
, O
RNA O
degradation O
: O
affy O
. O

Batch O
correction O
( O
as O
per O
chip O
scan O
date O
) O
involved O
: O
sva O
( O
Combat O
) O
. O

Outliers O
were O
removed O
as O
described O
in O
. O

The O
array O
probes O
were O
annotated O
via O
ENSEMBL O
gene O
ID O
, O
database O
version O
v75 O
, O
to O
ensure O
congruency O
with O
prior O
analyses O
, O
using O
biomaRt O
, O
and O
were O
collapsed O
via O
the O
collapseRows O
function O
of O
WGCNA O
. O

Prior O
to O
application O
of O
the O
generalized O
linear O
mixed O
model O
( O
nlme O
) O
, O
datasets O
were O
rebalanced O
and O
regressed O
to O
correct O
for O
technical O
and O
biological O
covariate O
influences O
. O

Regression O
Analysis O
Meta-analysis O
on O
all O
genes O
present O
in O
all O
datasets O
( O
12,391 O
genes O
in O
total O
) O
employed O
a O
generalized O
linear O
mixed O
model O
to O
account O
for O
variation O
per O
dataset O
and O
individual O
, O
yielding O
log2-fold O
change O
( O
logFC O
) O
values O
for O
each O
gene O
between O
control O
and O
disease O
, O
which O
were O
correlated O
between O
SCZ O
and O
BD O
using O
Spearman O
’ O
s O
method O
. O

To O
determine O
significance O
, O
the O
meta-analysis O
process O
was O
repeated O
10,000 O
times O
with O
randomized O
case/control O
status O
, O
forming O
a O
permutation O
null O
distribution O
of O
the O
individual O
correlation O
coefficients O
( O
Figure O
S3 O
) O
. O

Of O
note O
, O
several O
cholinergic O
and O
neurokine O
genes O
were O
missing O
from O
the O
whole-genome O
meta-analysis O
because O
of O
annotation O
deficits O
( O
CHRNA7 O
, O
CHRM1 O
, O
LHX8 O
, O
CHKB O
, O
PRIMA1 O
, O
CNTF O
) O
, O
and O
, O
at O
this O
stage O
, O
could O
not O
be O
easily O
re-introduced O
. O

Gene O
Ontology O
( O
GO O
) O
Enrichment O
Analyses O
To O
focus O
on O
the O
differences O
, O
as O
opposed O
to O
the O
similarities O
, O
between O
BD O
and O
SCZ O
patient O
brain O
transcriptomes O
, O
we O
performed O
GO O
enrichment O
analysis O
on O
the O
genes O
showing O
the O
highest O
rank O
differences O
between O
datasets O
( O
Figure O
S4 O
) O
, O
using O
the O
R O
package O
topGO O
. O

Briefly O
, O
we O
evaluated O
( O
smaller O
) O
groups O
of O
genes O
for O
enrichment O
against O
a O
( O
bigger O
) O
background O
of O
genes O
for O
presence O
in O
individual O
GO O
terms O
exceeding O
statistical O
estimates O
. O

The O
background O
comprised O
of O
the O
first O
2000 O
genes O
according O
to O
the O
applied O
rank O
system O
, O
computed O
as O
a O
function O
of O
Spearman O
’ O
s O
rank O
differences O
of O
regression O
beta O
values O
( O
logFC O
) O
between O
the O
two O
compared O
groups O
, O
either O
as O
absolute O
values O
or O
“ O
as O
is O
” O
( O
elevation O
in O
one O
group O
as O
opposed O
to O
the O
other O
) O
. O

The O
target O
genes O
of O
the O
analysis O
were O
defined O
as O
the O
100 O
top O
ranked O
genes O
( O
top O
5 O
% O
of O
background O
) O
, O
unless O
otherwise O
stated O
. O

Statistically O
significant O
GO O
results O
were O
compiled O
and O
curated O
for O
CNS-relevant O
terms O
. O

Sex O
Influence O
on O
Transcriptomic O
Differences O
Studying O
web-available O
datasets O
of O
non-degenerative O
mental O
disease O
patients O
revealed O
that O
SCZ O
and O
BD O
datasets O
possessed O
sufficient O
numbers O
to O
allow O
sex-discriminative O
meta-analysis O
of O
statistical O
significance O
. O

Hence O
, O
we O
repeated O
the O
above O
steps O
for O
the O
individual O
subsets O
of O
male O
and O
female O
patients O
, O
with O
the O
sole O
change O
of O
eliminating O
the O
covariate O
regression O
for O
sex O
, O
as O
this O
would O
preclude O
further O
analysis O
of O
this O
variable O
, O
in O
4 O
distinct O
GO O
enrichment O
group O
comparisons O
between O
SCZ-biased O
, O
BD-biased O
, O
male-biased O
, O
and O
female-biased O
genes O
. O

miR-gene-TF-targeting O
: O
miRNet O
To O
address O
miR-mRNA O
targeting O
relations O
, O
we O
developed O
an O
integrated O
miR-targeting O
graph O
database O
( O
‘ O
miRNet O
’ O
) O
out O
of O
publicly O
available O
validated O
and O
predicted O
data O
, O
implementing O
a O
scoring O
system O
derived O
from O
10 O
leading O
prediction O
algorithms O
based O
on O
their O
statistical O
performance O
at O
the O
whole-genome O
level O
. O

To O
facilitate O
the O
selection O
process O
, O
targeting O
data O
were O
cumulated O
by O
summing O
the O
amount O
of O
positive O
“ O
hits O
” O
of O
prediction O
algorithms O
( O
1 O
point O
) O
and O
positive O
experimental O
validations O
( O
only O
“ O
strong O
” O
evidence O
, O
miRTarBase O
, O
10,5 O
points O
) O
of O
the O
targeting O
relationship O
, O
yielding O
a O
targeting O
score O
between O
0 O
and O
20,5 O
. O

We O
found O
a O
minimal O
score O
of O
6 O
to O
suffice O
for O
a O
good O
balance O
between O
type O
I O
and O
II O
errors O
. O

In O
case O
of O
whole-genome O
interactions O
, O
this O
threshold O
was O
raised O
to O
7 O
to O
enable O
computational O
accessibility O
in O
all O
steps O
( O
in O
this O
case O
, O
graphical O
analysis O
was O
the O
bottleneck O
) O
. O

The O
database O
was O
supplemented O
by O
comprehensive O
transcription O
factor O
targeting O
data O
via O
bioinformatically O
processed O
“ O
cap O
analysis O
of O
gene O
expression O
” O
( O
CAGE O
) O
, O
focusing O
on O
brain O
tissues O
, O
including O
the O
tissue-specific O
transcriptional O
activities O
( O
Figure O
S5 O
) O
. O

The O
code O
used O
to O
create O
and O
test O
this O
database O
is O
available O
in O
the O
accompanying O
repository O
. O

A O
public O
release O
is O
planned O
, O
but O
not O
completed O
at O
the O
moment O
; O
requests O
can O
be O
directed O
at O
the O
corresponding O
author O
. O

Analyses O
performed O
using O
this O
database O
were O
implemented O
in O
R O
using O
the O
‘ O
RNeo4j O
’ O
package O
. O

Limitations O
Through O
recent O
methodical O
and O
bioinformatical O
advances O
, O
targeting O
data O
of O
transcription O
factors O
and O
miRs O
has O
become O
comprehensive O
. O

However O
, O
these O
“ O
complete O
” O
datasets O
are O
subject O
to O
limitations O
derived O
from O
the O
methods O
used O
to O
accumulate O
raw O
data O
. O

For O
TF-targeting O
, O
CAGE O
5′ O
peaks O
were O
analyzed O
toward O
their O
correlation O
with O
gene O
expression O
in O
all O
available O
tissues O
. O

A O
cholinergic O
example O
of O
limitations O
derived O
from O
this O
data O
involves O
the O
CHAT O
gene O
, O
which O
does O
not O
provide O
a O
measurable O
CAGE O
peak O
, O
leading O
to O
non-representation O
in O
the O
targeting O
dataset O
. O

In O
those O
cases O
, O
targeting O
data O
acquired O
through O
conventional O
methods O
have O
to O
be O
substituted O
, O
but O
this O
can O
not O
be O
easily O
done O
for O
all O
affected O
genes O
, O
and O
is O
also O
not O
comprehensive O
. O

In O
the O
case O
of O
miR-targeting O
, O
validated O
interactions O
are O
based O
on O
experimental O
work O
mainly O
performed O
on O
rodents O
, O
leading O
to O
a O
research O
bias O
toward O
evolutionarily O
conserved O
miRs O
. O

Primate-specific O
miRs O
therefore O
are O
under-represented O
, O
at O
least O
in O
validated O
data O
. O

Permutation O
Targeting O
Analyses O
In O
the O
current O
state O
of O
comprehensive O
data O
on O
miR-gene O
( O
and O
TF-gene O
) O
targeting O
, O
no O
statements O
can O
be O
made O
with O
absolute O
certainty O
. O

Thus O
, O
an O
approach O
which O
considers O
relative O
measures O
is O
preferable O
. O

For O
this O
reason O
, O
whenever O
whole-genome/whole-miRnome O
targeting O
was O
concerned O
, O
we O
employed O
random O
permutation O
of O
the O
prediction O
dataset O
or O
each O
single O
predicted O
miR O
against O
a O
randomized O
background O
of O
the O
same O
size O
as O
the O
original O
set O
( O
also O
considering O
family- O
and O
precursor-relationships O
) O
. O

The O
resulting O
null O
distribution O
yields O
a O
basis O
for O
determination O
of O
a O
false O
discovery O
rate O
. O

Neurokine-Induced O
miRs O
and O
the O
Cholinergic/Neurokine O
Pathway O
Gene O
targets O
of O
the O
490 O
differentially O
regulated O
miRs O
following O
CNTF O
exposure O
were O
determined O
by O
miRNet O
query O
( O
targeting O
score O
minimum O
of O
6 O
) O
. O

The O
full O
network O
, O
originally O
comprising O
∼160,000 O
unique O
relationships O
, O
was O
re-filtered O
by O
raising O
the O
threshold O
to O
score O
minimum O
of O
7 O
to O
be O
computationally O
accessible O
. O

The O
resulting O
network O
and O
individual O
miR-family-subnetworks O
were O
plotted O
using O
a O
force-directed O
layout O
( O
Force O
Atlas O
2 O
) O
in O
gephi O
. O

Single-Cell O
Sequencing O
Dataset O
Analysis O
and O
Permutation O
We O
analyzed O
4 O
web-available O
datasets O
of O
brain O
single O
cell O
gene O
expression O
for O
neurokine O
signaling O
transcripts O
in O
cholinergic O
neurons O
, O
identified O
by O
their O
expression O
of O
the O
ACh-synthesizing O
enzyme O
choline O
acetyltransferase O
( O
ChAT O
) O
, O
and O
its O
embedded O
gene O
encoding O
the O
vesicular O
acetylcholine O
transporter O
SLC18A3 O
, O
also O
known O
as O
vAChT O
. O

Raw O
gene O
expression O
data O
were O
normalized O
and O
then O
clustered O
and O
plotted O
via O
R/pheatmap O
. O

The O
genes O
expressed O
in O
more O
than O
one O
sample O
per O
dataset O
were O
enriched O
for O
targeting O
of O
TFs O
and O
miRs O
by O
random O
permutation O
analysis O
( O
via O
miRNet O
) O
, O
with O
10 O
000 O
permutations O
for O
conserved O
and O
primate O
miR-target O
relationships O
, O
and O
human O
CNS O
TF O
interactions O
. O

Subset O
Analyses O
Cholinergic O
Genes O
, O
Transcription O
Factor O
, O
and O
Neurokine O
Analyses O
To O
follow O
our O
cholinergic O
interest O
, O
we O
used O
a O
recent O
review O
to O
define O
a O
core O
set O
of O
genes O
, O
adding O
to O
it O
the O
neurokine O
and O
circadian O
pathway O
genes O
indicated O
in O
the O
previous O
analyses O
( O
to O
a O
total O
of O
76 O
genes O
) O
. O

Via O
miRNet O
permutation O
( O
Data O
S2 O
) O
, O
we O
identified O
18 O
brain-expressed O
“ O
cholinergic O
” O
TFs O
( O
p O
< O
0.05 O
) O
and O
their O
CNS O
transcriptional O
activity O
toward O
each O
targeted O
cholinergic O
gene O
. O

These O
94 O
genes O
( O
Data O
S7 O
) O
were O
then O
subjected O
to O
differential O
expression O
analysis O
in O
the O
deposited O
patient O
datasets O
. O

Execution O
of O
Subset O
Analyses O
To O
separately O
analyze O
male O
and O
female O
data O
in O
the O
original O
datasets O
, O
we O
repeated O
the O
sex-independent O
analyses O
of O
the O
identified O
94 O
cholinergic O
genes O
and O
TFs O
using O
the O
limma O
pipeline O
. O

Pre-processing O
was O
identical O
to O
the O
whole-transcriptome O
approach O
, O
and O
dataset O
reduction O
involved O
restricting O
the O
output O
table O
( O
topTable O
( O
) O
function O
) O
to O
the O
studied O
genes O
. O

This O
further O
allowed O
controlling O
of O
missing O
genes O
of O
interest O
by O
manually O
solving O
problems O
of O
annotation O
, O
which O
in O
a O
whole-genome O
analysis O
would O
have O
led O
to O
loss O
of O
information O
on O
, O
e.g. O
, O
the O
nicotinic O
α7 O
and O
stress-responding O
M1 O
cholinergic O
receptors O
. O

miR-125b-5p O
Validation O
To O
test O
binding O
of O
hsa-miR-125b-5p O
to O
the O
acetylcholinesterase O
( O
AChE O
) O
3′-UTR O
, O
we O
performed O
vector-based O
assays O
via O
suppression O
of O
a O
cytotoxic O
sensor O
as O
well O
as O
of O
Renilla O
luciferase O
, O
both O
fused O
to O
the O
AChE-3′-UTR O
. O

Briefly O
, O
the O
3′ O
untranslated O
region O
( O
3′-UTR O
) O
of O
human O
AChE O
mRNA O
was O
cloned O
into O
the O
microRNA O
Target O
Selection O
System O
plasmid O
( O
System O
Biosciences O
, O
CA O
, O
USA O
) O
multiple O
cloning O
site O
, O
using O
EcoRI O
and O
NotI O
restriction O
enzymes O
( O
New O
England O
Biolabs O
) O
. O

All O
plasmids O
were O
verified O
by O
DNA O
sequencing O
. O

For O
luciferase O
assays O
, O
HEK293T O
cells O
were O
transfected O
with O
miRNA O
Target O
Selection-AChE-3′UTR O
, O
and O
selected O
in O
the O
presence O
of O
Puromycin O
for O
3 O
weeks O
. O

Stably O
transfected O
HEK293T O
( O
293T-AChE O
3′UTR O
) O
cells O
were O
grown O
on O
12-well O
plates O
and O
infected O
with O
lentiviruses O
expressing O
miR-125b-5p O
, O
miR-132-3p O
or O
a O
negative O
control O
sequence O
. O

After O
48 O
hours O
incubation O
, O
cells O
were O
analyzed O
using O
the O
Dual O
Luciferase O
Assay O
kit O
( O
Promega O
, O
WI O
USA O
) O
and O
Luciferase O
activity O
was O
measured O
using O
an O
Envision O
luminescent O
plate O
reader O
( O
Perkin-Elmer O
, O
Waltham O
, O
MA O
) O
, O
essentially O
as O
previously O
described O
. O

For O
each O
reporter O
construct O
, O
renilla O
luciferase O
activity O
was O
normalized O
according O
to O
that O
of O
the O
firefly O
. O

Normalized O
activity O
after O
infection O
of O
miR-132-3p O
or O
miR-125b-5p O
was O
expressed O
as O
relative O
to O
that O
obtained O
after O
infection O
with O
the O
same O
plasmid O
with O
miR O
negative O
control O
. O

For O
life/death O
assay O
, O
a O
similar O
protocol O
was O
used O
. O

Stably O
transfected O
HEK293T O
( O
293T-AChE O
3′UTR O
) O
cells O
were O
infected O
with O
lentiviruses O
expressing O
miR-125b-5p O
, O
miR-132-3p O
or O
a O
negative O
control O
sequence O
. O

72 O
hours O
post-infection O
a O
cytotoxic O
reporter O
fused O
to O
AChE O
3′-UTR O
was O
added O
to O
the O
media O
and O
cells O
were O
kept O
for O
an O
additional O
5 O
days O
to O
assess O
their O
viability O
. O

Statistical O
significance O
was O
determined O
using O
ANOVA O
with O
correction O
for O
multiple O
testing O
. O

To O
show O
effects O
of O
changes O
in O
this O
miR O
’ O
s O
levels O
on O
real-life O
protein O
activities O
, O
we O
performed O
an O
AChE O
hydrolytic O
activity O
assay O
following O
infection O
of O
human O
monocyte-like O
U937 O
cells O
with O
hsa-miR-125b-5p O
, O
miR-132-3p O
or O
a O
negative O
control O
lentiviral O
vector O
. O

AChE O
hydrolytic O
activity O
levels O
were O
assessed O
by O
kinetic O
measurements O
of O
the O
hydrolysis O
rates O
of O
1 O
mM O
acetylthiocholine O
( O
ATCh O
, O
Sigma O
) O
at O
room O
temperature O
, O
following O
20 O
min O
incubation O
with O
and O
without O
5x10−5 O
M O
tetraisopropyl O
pyrophosphoramide O
( O
iso-OMPA O
, O
Sigma O
) O
, O
a O
specific O
inhibitor O
of O
butyrylcholinesterase O
, O
to O
selectively O
assay O
for O
AChE-specific O
or O
total O
cholinesterase O
activity O
. O

Each O
sample O
was O
assayed O
in O
at O
least O
3 O
biological O
replicates O
. O

In O
all O
cases O
, O
hsa-miR-132-3p O
served O
as O
a O
positive O
control O
. O

Quantification O
and O
Statistical O
Analysis O
Statistical O
analyses O
were O
performed O
in O
R. O
Small O
sets O
of O
continuous O
variables O
, O
such O
as O
qPCR O
and O
miR-125b-5p O
validation O
experiments O
, O
were O
tested O
using O
Welch O
’ O
s O
Two O
Sample O
t O
test O
( O
because O
in O
most O
cases O
, O
equal O
variance O
could O
not O
be O
assumed O
; O
R/t.test O
) O
and O
ANOVA O
; O
statistical O
significance O
was O
assumed O
at O
p O
< O
0.05 O
. O

For O
sequencing O
count O
data O
, O
the O
negative O
binomial O
generalized O
linear O
model O
was O
tested O
using O
the O
R/DESeq2 O
package O
( O
“ O
Wald O
” O
test O
including O
log-fold O
change O
shrinkage O
) O
to O
detect O
differentially O
expressed O
miRs O
, O
using O
the O
supplied O
independent O
filtering O
and O
correction O
for O
multiple O
testing O
at O
an O
alpha O
level O
of O
0.1 O
. O

In O
cases O
where O
additional O
power O
was O
desirable O
or O
p O
values O
could O
not O
be O
obtained O
by O
other O
means O
( O
transcriptome O
meta-analysis O
, O
whole O
genome O
miR-targeting O
) O
, O
permutation O
analysis O
was O
performed O
. O

This O
comprised O
random O
assignment O
of O
test O
variables O
in O
the O
same O
size O
as O
the O
original O
test O
set O
and O
repeating O
the O
analysis O
for O
a O
large O
number O
of O
times O
, O
such O
that O
a O
null O
distribution O
of O
values O
could O
be O
generated O
, O
which O
can O
be O
used O
to O
determine O
a O
false O
discovery O
ratio O
for O
the O
original O
result O
. O

Statistical O
significance O
was O
assumed O
at O
p O
< O
0.05. O
qPCR O
of O
ChAT/vAChT O
mRNA O
against O
housekeeping O
in O
LA-N-2 O
, O
p O
values O
are O
found O
in O
Results O
( O
Welch O
two-sample O
t O
test O
) O
: O

. O

) O
. O

. O

Data O
and O
Code O
Availability O
The O
code O
and O
additional O
supplementary O
materials O
generated O
during O
this O
study O
are O
available O
at O
https O
: O
//github.com/slobentanzer/integrative-transcriptomics O
. O

The O
sequencing O
datasets O
generated O
during O
this O
study O
are O
available O
at O
NCBI O
GEO O
: O
GSE120520 O
and O
GSE132951 O
. O

Accompanying O
website O
: O
https O
: O
//slobentanzer.github.io/cholinergic-neurokine O

Hypothalamic O
Responses O
to O
Cocaine O
and O
Food O
Cues O
in O
Individuals O
with O
Cocaine O
Dependence O
Abstract O
Background O
Individuals O
with O
cocaine O
addiction O
are O
characterized O
by O
under-responsiveness O
to O
natural O
reinforcers O
. O

As O
part O
of O
the O
dopaminergic O
pathways O
, O
the O
hypothalamus O
supports O
motivated O
behaviors O
. O

Rodent O
studies O
suggested O
inter-related O
roles O
of O
the O
hypothalamus O
in O
regulating O
drug O
and O
food O
intake O
. O

However O
, O
few O
studies O
have O
investigated O
hypothalamic O
responses O
to O
drugs O
and O
food O
or O
related O
cues O
in O
humans O
. O

Methods O
We O
examined O
regional O
responses O
in O
20 O
cocaine-dependent O
and O
24 O
healthy O
control O
participants O
exposed O
to O
cocaine/food O
( O
cocaine O
dependent O
) O
and O
food O
( O
healthy O
control O
) O
vs O
neutral O
cues O
during O
functional O
magnetic O
resonance O
imaging O
. O

We O
examined O
the O
relationship O
between O
imaging O
findings O
and O
clinical O
variables O
and O
performed O
mediation O
analyses O
to O
examine O
the O
inter-relationships O
between O
cue-related O
activations O
, O
tonic O
cocaine O
craving O
, O
and O
recent O
cocaine O
use O
. O

Results O
At O
a O
corrected O
threshold O
, O
cocaine-dependent O
participants O
demonstrated O
higher O
activation O
to O
cocaine O
than O
to O
food O
cues O
in O
the O
hypothalamus O
, O
inferior O
parietal O
cortex O
, O
and O
visual O
cortex O
. O

Cocaine-dependent O
participants O
as O
compared O
with O
healthy O
control O
participants O
also O
demonstrated O
higher O
hypothalamic O
activation O
to O
food O
cues O
. O

Further O
, O
the O
extent O
of O
these O
cue-induced O
hypothalamic O
activations O
was O
correlated O
with O
tonic O
craving O
, O
as O
assessed O
by O
the O
Cocaine O
Craving O
Questionnaire O
, O
and O
days O
of O
cocaine O
use O
in O
the O
prior O
month O
. O

In O
mediation O
analyses O
, O
hypothalamic O
activation O
to O
cocaine O
and O
food O
cues O
both O
completely O
mediated O
the O
relationship O
between O
the O
Cocaine O
Craving O
Questionnaire O
score O
and O
days O
of O
cocaine O
use O
in O
the O
past O
month O
. O

Conclusions O
The O
results O
were O
consistent O
with O
the O
proposition O
that O
the O
mechanisms O
of O
feeding O
and O
drug O
addiction O
are O
inter-linked O
in O
the O
hypothalamus O
and O
altered O
in O
cocaine O
addiction O
. O

The O
findings O
provide O
new O
evidence O
in O
support O
of O
hypothalamic O
dysfunction O
in O
cocaine O
addiction O
. O

Materials O
and O
Methods O
Participants O
, O
Informed O
Consent O
, O
and O
Assessment O
Twenty O
recently O
abstinent O
participants O
with O
cocaine O
dependence O
( O
CD O
, O
17 O
men O
) O
and O
24 O
age- O
, O
gender- O
, O
and O
BMI-matched O
healthy O
controls O
( O
HC O
, O
19 O
men O
) O
participated O
in O
the O
study O
( O
Table O
1 O
) O
. O

CD O
met O
criteria O
for O
current O
cocaine O
dependence O
as O
diagnosed O
by O
the O
Structured O
Clinical O
Interview O
for O
DSM-IV O
. O

Recent O
cocaine O
use O
was O
confirmed O
by O
urine O
toxicology O
screens O
. O

They O
were O
drug-free O
for O
about O
7 O
to O
10 O
days O
while O
staying O
in O
the O
Clinical O
Neuroscience O
Research O
Unit O
of O
the O
Connecticut O
Mental O
Health O
Center O
, O
a O
locked O
treatment O
facility O
, O
prior O
to O
the O
current O
fMRI O
study O
. O

All O
participants O
were O
physically O
healthy O
with O
no O
major O
medical O
illnesses O
or O
current O
use O
of O
prescription O
medications O
. O

None O
reported O
having O
a O
history O
of O
head O
injury O
or O
neurological O
illness O
. O

Other O
exclusion O
criteria O
included O
dependence O
on O
another O
psychoactive O
substance O
( O
except O
nicotine O
) O
and O
current O
or O
past O
history O
of O
Axis O
I O
disorders O
. O

The O
Human O
Investigation O
Committee O
at O
Yale O
University O
School O
of O
Medicine O
approved O
the O
study O
procedures O
, O
and O
all O
participants O
signed O
an O
informed O
consent O
prior O
to O
the O
study O
. O

CD O
participants O
were O
interviewed O
with O
the O
18-item O
CSSA O
to O
evaluate O
cocaine O
withdrawal O
signs O
and O
symptoms O
. O

CSSA O
scores O
were O
highly O
correlated O
with O
recent O
cocaine O
use O
and O
with O
severity O
measures O
of O
the O
Addiction O
Severity O
Index O
, O
including O
the O
interviewer O
severity O
rating O
and O
composite O
score O
in O
the O
drug O
section O
. O

For O
cocaine-dependent O
individuals O
, O
initial O
CSSA O
scores O
were O
higher O
for O
those O
who O
failed O
to O
achieve O
abstinence O
or O
who O
subsequently O
dropped O
out O
of O
treatment O
. O

Cocaine O
craving O
was O
assessed O
with O
the O
Cocaine O
Craving O
Questionnaire-Brief O
version O
for O
all O
CDs O
every O
2 O
to O
3 O
days O
. O

The O
CCQ-Brief O
version O
is O
a O
10-item O
questionnaire O
abbreviated O
from O
the O
CCQ-Now O
and O
highly O
congruent O
with O
the O
CCQ-Now O
and O
other O
cocaine O
craving O
measures O
. O

Each O
item O
was O
rated O
on O
a O
scale O
from O
1 O
to O
7 O
, O
with O
a O
higher O
total O
score O
( O
ranging O
from O
10 O
to O
70 O
) O
indicating O
greater O
craving O
. O

CCQ O
score O
was O
averaged O
across O
all O
assessments O
during O
the O
2- O
to O
3-week O
inpatient O
stay O
to O
index O
a O
tonic O
level O
of O
craving O
. O

Behavioral O
Tasks O
We O
employed O
a O
cue-induced O
cocaine O
craving O
task O
( O
CCT O
) O
for O
CD O
only O
and O
a O
cue-induced O
food O
craving O
task O
( O
FCT O
) O
for O
both O
CD O
and O
HC O
( O
Figure O
1 O
) O
. O

The O
order O
of O
CCT O
and O
FCT O
was O
counter-balanced O
across O
subjects O
for O
CD O
. O

Details O
can O
be O
found O
in O
the O
Supplement O
. O

Imaging O
Protocol O
and O
Data O
Preprocessing O
The O
imaging O
protocol O
is O
described O
in O
detail O
in O
the O
Supplement O
. O

Data O
were O
analyzed O
with O
SPM O
( O
Statistical O
Parametric O
Mapping O
) O
software O
following O
established O
routines O
, O
as O
in O
the O
Supplement O
. O

Imaging O
Data O
Modeling O
Data O
blocks O
were O
first O
distinguished O
by O
“ O
cocaine/food O
picture O
” O
and O
“ O
neutral O
picture O
” O
for O
CCT/FCT O
. O

A O
statistical O
analytical O
block O
design O
was O
constructed O
for O
each O
participant O
using O
a O
general O
linear O
model O
. O

Because O
each O
block O
was O
associated O
with O
a O
craving O
rating O
, O
we O
included O
a O
column O
of O
block O
onset O
parametrically O
modulated O
by O
its O
corresponding O
craving O
score O
as O
a O
regressor O
in O
the O
model O
. O

Realignment O
parameters O
in O
all O
6 O
dimensions O
were O
also O
entered O
in O
the O
model O
. O

Serial O
autocorrelation O
caused O
by O
aliased O
cardiovascular O
and O
respiratory O
effects O
was O
corrected O
by O
a O
first-degree O
autoregressive O
or O
AR O
( O
1 O
) O
model O
. O

The O
general O
linear O
model O
estimated O
the O
component O
of O
variance O
that O
could O
be O
explained O
by O
each O
of O
the O
regressors O
. O

In O
the O
first-level O
analysis O
, O
we O
constructed O
for O
each O
participant O
statistical O
contrasts O
of O
“ O
cocaine O
picture O
” O
vs O
“ O
neutral O
picture O
” O
for O
CCT O
and O
“ O
food O
picture O
” O
vs O
“ O
neutral O
picture O
” O
for O
FCT O
. O

These O
contrasts O
allowed O
us O
to O
evaluate O
brain O
regions O
that O
responded O
differently O
to O
viewing O
of O
cocaine O
and O
food O
pictures O
, O
compared O
with O
viewing O
of O
neutral O
pictures O
, O
in O
CCT O
and O
FCT O
, O
respectively O
. O

The O
contrast O
images O
of O
the O
first-level O
analysis O
were O
then O
used O
for O
the O
second-level O
group O
statistics O
. O

We O
conducted O
paired O
t O
test O
to O
examine O
differences O
between O
“ O
cocaine O
picture O
” O
vs O
“ O
neutral O
picture O
” O
and O
“ O
food O
picture O
” O
vs O
“ O
neutral O
picture O
” O
in O
CD O
and O
2-sample O
t O
test O
to O
examine O
differences O
between O
CD O
and O
HC O
for O
contrast O
of O
“ O
food O
picture O
” O
vs O
“ O
neutral O
picture. O
” O
In O
addition O
to O
whole-brain O
analyses O
, O
we O
examined O
cue-related O
responses O
of O
the O
hypothalamus O
with O
a O
mask O
as O
in O
earlier O
studies O
. O

Following O
current O
reporting O
standards O
, O
all O
imaging O
results O
were O
evaluated O
with O
voxel O
P O
< O
.001 O
, O
uncorrected O
, O
in O
combination O
with O
cluster O
P O
< O
.05 O
, O
FWE O
or O
family-wise O
error O
corrected O
for O
the O
whole O
brain O
or O
small O
volume O
correction O
for O
a O
hypothalamus O
mask O
obtained O
from O
the O
WFU O
Pick O
Atlas O
( O
http O
: O
//fmri.wfubmc.edu/software/pickatlas O
) O
, O
on O
the O
basis O
of O
Gaussian O
random O
field O
theory O
as O
implemented O
in O
SPM O
. O

With O
small O
volume O
correction O
, O
one O
applied O
standard O
voxel O
level O
statistics O
( O
e.g. O
, O
FWE O
) O
to O
voxels O
within O
the O
small O
region O
instead O
of O
within O
the O
whole O
brain O
. O

On O
the O
basis O
of O
our O
previous O
study O
, O
we O
had O
a O
very O
strong O
hypothesis O
that O
the O
hypothalamus O
would O
show O
differences O
in O
cue-related O
activities O
in O
the O
study O
. O

Thus O
, O
we O
tested O
the O
hypothesis O
using O
small O
volume O
correction O
. O

In O
region O
of O
interest O
( O
ROI O
) O
analysis O
, O
we O
used O
MarsBaR O
( O
http O
: O
//marsbar.sourceforge.net/ O
) O
to O
derive O
for O
each O
participant O
the O
activity O
difference O
( O
β O
contrast O
) O
for O
the O
ROIs O
. O

Functional O
ROIs O
were O
defined O
based O
on O
clusters O
obtained O
from O
whole O
brain O
analysis O
. O

All O
voxel O
activations O
were O
presented O
in O
Montreal O
Neurological O
Institute O
coordinates O
. O

Mediation O
Analysis O
Owing O
to O
space O
limitations O
, O
mediation O
analyses O
are O
presented O
in O
the O
Supplement O
. O

Fronto-striatal O
effective O
connectivity O
of O
working O
memory O
in O
adults O
with O
cannabis O
use O
disorder O
Previous O
working O
memory O
( O
WM O
) O
studies O
found O
that O
relative O
to O
controls O
, O
subjects O
with O
cannabis O
use O
disorder O
( O
CUD O
) O
showed O
greater O
brain O
activation O
in O
some O
regions O
( O
e.g. O
, O
left O
[ O
L O
] O
and O
right O
[ O
R O
] O
ventrolateral O
prefrontal O
cortex O
[ O
VLPFC O
] O
, O
and O
L O
dorsolateral O
prefrontal O
cortex O
[ O
L-DLPFC O
] O
) O
, O
and O
lower O
activation O
in O
other O
regions O
( O
e.g. O
, O
R-DLPFC O
) O
. O

In O
this O
study O
, O
effective O
connectivity O
( O
EC O
) O
analysis O
was O
applied O
to O
functional O
magnetic O
resonance O
imaging O
data O
acquired O
from O
23 O
CUD O
subjects O
and O
23 O
controls O
( O
two O
groups O
matched O
for O
sociodemographic O
factors O
and O
substance O
use O
history O
) O
while O
performing O
an O
n-back O
WM O
task O
with O
interleaved O
2-back O
and O
0-back O
periods O
. O

A O
2-back O
minus O
0-back O
modulator O
was O
defined O
to O
measure O
the O
modulatory O
changes O
of O
EC O
corresponding O
to O
the O
2-back O
relative O
to O
0-back O
conditions O
. O

Compared O
to O
the O
controls O
, O
the O
CUD O
group O
showed O
smaller O
modulatory O
change O
in O
the O
R-DLPFC O
to O
L-caudate O
pathway O
, O
and O
greater O
modulatory O
changes O
in O
L-DLPFC O
to O
L-caudate O
, O
R-DLPFC O
to O
R- O
caudate O
, O
and O
R-VLPFC O
to O
L-caudate O
pathways O
. O

Based O
on O
previous O
fMRI O
studies O
consistently O
suggesting O
that O
greater O
brain O
activations O
are O
related O
to O
a O
compensatory O
mechanism O
for O
cannabis O
neural O
effects O
( O
less O
regional O
brain O
activations O
) O
, O
the O
smaller O
modulatory O
change O
in O
the O
R-DLPFC O
to O
L-caudate O
EC O
may O
be O
compensated O
by O
the O
larger O
modulatory O
changes O
in O
the O
other O
prefrontal-striatal O
ECs O
in O
the O
CUD O
individuals O
. O

Methods O
and O
materials O
Participants O
Data O
were O
obtained O
from O
the O
Human O
Connectome O
Project O
( O
HCP O
) O
. O

The O
experiments O
were O
performed O
in O
accordance O
with O
relevant O
guidelines O
and O
regulations O
and O
all O
experimental O
protocol O
was O
approved O
by O
the O
Institutional O
Review O
Board O
( O
IRB O
) O
( O
IRB O
# O
201204036 O
; O
Title O
: O
‘ O
Mapping O
the O
Human O
Connectome O
: O
Structure O
, O
Function O
, O
and O
Heritability O
’ O
) O
. O

Written O
informed O
consent O
was O
obtained O
from O
all O
participants O
. O

Our O
data O
analysis O
was O
performed O
in O
accordance O
with O
ethical O
guidelines O
of O
the O
Virginia O
Commonwealth O
University O
. O

The O
subject O
inclusion O
criteria O
were O
: O
( O
I O
) O
right-handed O
; O
( O
II O
) O
lifetime O
cannabis O
dependence O
( O
for O
CUD O
subjects O
) O
as O
defined O
by O
the O
Self-Reported O
Substance O
Use O
and O
Abuse O
measures O
from O
Semi-Structured O
Assessment O
for O
the O
Genetics O
of O
Alcoholism O
; O
and O
( O
III O
) O
positive O
urine O
test O
for O
delta-9-tetrahydrocannabinol O
( O
THC O
) O
( O
for O
CUD O
subjects O
) O
. O

The O
positive O
THC O
result O
and O
other O
drug O
use O
measures O
are O
based O
on O
the O
data O
and O
HCP O
Data O
Dictionary O
released O
by O
HCP O
( O
https O
: O
//db.humanconnectome.org/data/projects/HCP_1200 O
. O

Information O
regarding O
the O
device O
and O
THC O
threshold O
used O
for O
the O
urine O
test O
is O
not O
directly O
available O
to O
the O
authors O
of O
this O
manuscript O
. O

The O
exclusion O
criteria O
were O
: O
( O
I O
) O
higher O
than O
moderate O
level O
of O
nicotine O
dependence O
as O
determined O
by O
the O
scoring O
on O
the O
Fagerstrom O
Test O
for O
Nicotine O
Dependence O
; O
( O
II O
) O
breath O
alcohol O
concentration O
greater O
than O
0.05 O
g/210 O
L O
; O
( O
III O
) O
positive O
urine O
test O
for O
cocaine O
, O
opiates O
, O
and O
drugs O
other O
than O
cannabis O
; O
and O
( O
IV O
) O
meeting O
DSM-IV O
criteria O
of O
alcohol O
dependence O
. O

Based O
on O
the O
inclusion/exclusion O
criteria O
, O
23 O
CUD O
subjects O
and O
676 O
potential O
non-drug-using O
subjects O
were O
identified O
from O
900 O
participants O
. O

Twenty-three O
non-drug-using O
controls O
were O
then O
selected O
from O
676 O
non-drug-using O
subjects O
in O
order O
to O
match O
the O
23 O
CUD O
subjects O
, O
in O
sex O
, O
age O
, O
education O
, O
alcohol O
use O
, O
tobacco O
use O
, O
and O
self-reported O
lifetime O
use O
of O
other O
non-cannabis O
drugs O
. O

Specifically O
, O
one O
control O
subject O
was O
selected O
to O
match O
one O
CUD O
subject O
, O
with O
sex O
as O
the O
first O
priority O
, O
age O
, O
and O
education O
as O
the O
second O
priority O
, O
and O
alcohol O
use O
, O
tobacco O
use O
, O
and O
self-reported O
lifetime O
use O
of O
other O
non-cannabis O
drugs O
as O
the O
third O
priority O
in O
matching O
. O

See O
Table O
1 O
for O
the O
demographic O
information O
of O
both O
groups O
. O

The O
two O
groups O
were O
not O
significantly O
different O
in O
age O
( O
t=0.4708 O
, O
degrees O
of O
freedom O
[ O
df O
] O
=44 O
, O
p O
= O
0.6401 O
) O
, O
sex O
( O
Fisher O
’ O
s O
exact O
test O
p O
= O
1 O
, O
two-tail O
) O
, O
education O
( O
t O
= O
0 O
, O
df O
= O
44 O
, O
p O
= O
1 O
) O
, O
alcohol O
use O
( O
t O
= O
0.2497 O
, O
df O
= O
44 O
, O
p=0.8040 O
) O
, O
tobacco O
use O
( O
t O
= O
0.5144 O
, O
df O
= O
44 O
, O
p O
= O
0.6096 O
) O
, O
and O
self-reported O
lifetime O
use O
on O
more O
than O
10 O
occasions O
of O
any O
non-cannabis O
drug O
( O
Fisher O
’ O
s O
exact O
test O
p O
> O
0.1868 O
, O
two-tail O
) O
. O

The O
age O
of O
17 O
years O
was O
used O
as O
the O
threshold O
of O
early-onset O
. O

Based O
on O
this O
threshold O
, O
16 O
CUD O
individuals O
belonged O
to O
the O
early-onset O
CUD O
subgroup O
( O
11 O
males O
, O
6 O
females O
, O
28.4 O
± O
3.4 O
years O
old O
, O
15.0 O
± O
1.7 O
years O
of O
education O
) O
and O
the O
7 O
remaining O
CUD O
individuals O
belonged O
to O
the O

CUD O
subgroup O
( O
6 O
males O
, O
1 O
female O
, O
27.6 O
± O
4.0 O
years O
old O
, O
13.6 O
± O
1.7 O
years O
of O
education O
) O
. O

The O
two O
CUD O
subgroups O
showed O
a O
trend O
significant O
difference O
in O

( O

= O
1.8389 O
, O
df O
= O
21 O
, O

) O
, O

( O

, O

, O

0.8887 O
) O
, O

difference O

use O
( O

= O
0.5923 O
, O
df O
= O

, O

) O
. O

In-scanner O
working O
memory O
task O
The O
HCP O
n-back O
working O
memory O
task O
used O
pictures O
of O
faces O
, O
places O
, O
tools O
and O
body O
parts O
as O
the O
stimuli O
to O
assess O
WM O
. O

Two O
n-back O
fMRI O
runs O
were O
conducted O
. O

Each O
run O
consists O
of O
four O
“ O
2-back O
” O
task O
blocks O
( O
10 O
trials O
of O
2.5 O
s O
each O
per O
block O
, O
block O
duration O
= O
25 O
s O
) O
, O
four O
“ O
0-back O
” O
task O
blocks O
( O
10 O
trials O
of O
2.5 O
s O
each O
per O
block O
, O
block O
duration O
= O
25 O
s O
) O
and O
four O
fixation O
blocks O
( O
block O
duration O
= O
15 O
s O
) O
. O

All O
the O
stimulus O
types O
were O
used O
in O
each O
task O
type O
, O
but O
the O
order O
of O
stimulus O
types O
was O
random O
. O

A O
2.5 O
s O
cue O
indicated O
the O
task O
type O
( O
and O
target O
for O
0-back O
) O
at O
the O
start O
of O
the O
block O
. O

On O
each O
trial O
, O
the O
stimulus O
was O
presented O
for O
2 O
s O
, O
followed O
by O
a O
500 O
ms O
inter-trial-interval O
. O

Two O
or O
three O
trials O
in O
each O
task O
block O
presented O
non-target O
lures O
. O

Out-scanner O
tasks O
testing O
executive O
function/working O
memory O
Dimensional O
change O
card O
sort O
HCP O
used O
dimensional O
change O
card O
task O
( O
about O
4 O
min O
) O
to O
measure O
executive O
function/cognitive O
flexibility O
. O

Two O
target O
pictures O
were O
presented O
that O
vary O
along O
two O
dimensions O
( O
e.g. O
, O
shape O
and O
color O
) O
. O

Participants O
were O
asked O
to O
match O
a O
series O
of O
bivalent O
test O
pictures O
( O
e.g. O
, O
yellow O
balls O
and O
blue O
trucks O
) O
to O
the O
target O
pictures O
, O
first O
according O
to O
one O
dimension O
( O
e.g. O
, O
color O
) O
and O
then O
, O
after O
a O
number O
of O
trials O
, O
according O
to O
the O
other O
dimension O
( O
e.g. O
, O
shape O
) O
. O

Some O
“ O
Switch O
” O
trials O
, O
in O
which O
the O
participant O
must O
change O
the O
dimension O
being O
matched O
, O
were O
used O
in O
order O
to O
test O
cognitive O
flexibility O
. O

Scoring O
was O
based O
on O
a O
combination O
of O
accuracy O
and O
reaction O
time O
. O

Flanker O
task O
HCP O
used O
the O
Flanker O
task O
( O
about O
3 O
min O
) O
to O
jointly O
measure O
attention O
and O
inhibitory O
control O
. O

During O
the O
test O
, O
the O
participant O
was O
requested O
to O
focus O
on O
a O
given O
stimulus O
while O
inhibiting O
attention O
to O
stimuli O
( O
arrows O
) O
flanking O
it O
. O

Sometimes O
the O
middle O
stimulus O
is O
pointing O
in O
the O
same O
direction O
as O
the O
“ O
flankers O
” O
( O
congruent O
) O
and O
sometimes O
in O
the O
opposite O
direction O
( O
incongruent O
) O
. O

Scoring O
was O
based O
on O
a O
combination O
of O
accuracy O
and O
reaction O
time O
. O

List O
sorting O
HCP O
used O
the O
list O
sorting O
task O
to O
assess O
working O
memory O
. O

With O
two O
different O
conditions O
( O
1-List O
and O
2-List O
) O
, O
this O
task O
requires O
the O
participant O
to O
sequence O
different O
visually- O
and O
orally-presented O
stimuli O
. O

Pictures O
of O
different O
foods O
and O
animals O
were O
displayed O
with O
both O
a O
sound O
clip O
and O
written O
text O
that O
name O
the O
item O
. O

In O
the O
1-List O
condition O
, O
participants O
were O
required O
to O
order O
a O
series O
of O
objects O
( O
either O
food O
or O
animals O
) O
in O
size O
order O
from O
smallest O
to O
largest O
. O

In O
the O
2-List O
condition O
, O
participants O
were O
presented O
both O
food O
and O
animals O
and O
are O
asked O
to O
report O
the O
food O
in O
size O
order O
, O
followed O
by O
the O
animals O
in O
size O
order O
. O

fMRI O
data O
acquisition O
As O
described O
in O
, O
whole-brain O
echo-planar O
imaging O
acquisitions O
were O
acquired O
with O
a O
32-channel O
head O
coil O
on O
a O
modified O
3 O
T O
Siemens O
Skyra O
scanner O
( O
Erlangen O
, O
Germany O
) O
, O
with O
repetition O
time O
= O
720 O
ms O
, O
echo O
time O
= O
33.1 O
ms O
, O
flip O
angle O
= O
52° O
, O
band- O
width O
= O
2290 O
Hz/pixel O
, O
in-plane O
field-of-view O
= O
208 O
mm O
× O
180 O
mm O
, O
72 O
slices O
, O
2.0 O
mm O
isotropic O
voxels O
, O
multi-band O
acceleration O
factor O
of O
8 O
. O

Two O
fMRI O
runs O
, O
with O
left-to-right O
and O
right-to-left O
phase O
encodings O
, O
respectively O
, O
were O
acquired O
, O
preprocessed O
and O
concatenated O
for O
DCM O
analysis O
. O

fMRI O
preprocessing O
Per O
, O
fMRI O
data O
were O
“ O
minimally O
” O
preprocessed O
to O
implement O
gradient O
unwarping O
, O
motion O
correction O
, O
fieldmap-based O
EPI O
distortion O
correction O
, O
brain-boundary-based O
registration O
of O
EPI O
to O
structural O
T1-weighted O
scan O
, O
non-linear O
registration O
into O
standard O
MNI152 O
space O
, O
and O
grand-mean O
intensity O
normalization O
( O
Functional O
Pipelines O
v3.4.0 O
; O
v3.12.0 O
; O
v3.13.2 O
) O
. O

The O
voxel O
size O
of O
the O
minimally- O
processed O
data O
is O
[ O
2 O
× O
2 O
× O
2 O
] O
mm O
. O

Twelve O
head O
motion O
correction O
parameters O
were O
released O
by O
HCP O
. O

See O
Table O
2 O
for O
the O
detailed O
information O
of O
these O
parameters O
for O
both O
groups O
. O

For O
each O
fMRI O
run O
, O
we O
quantified O
these O
head O
motion O
parameters O
using O
cumulative O
value O
and O
maximal O
value O
. O

For O
each O
motion O
parameter O
, O
the O
corresponding O
cumulative O
value O
and O
maximal O
value O
were O
computed O
as O
the O
summation O
and O
the O
maximum O
respectively O
, O
of O
the O
absolute O
values O
of O
this O
motion O
parameter O
across O
the O
entire O
run O
. O

For O
each O
subject O
, O
the O
cumulative O
value O
and O
maximal O
value O
were O
computed O
as O
the O
mean O
and O
the O
maximum O
respectively O
, O
across O
the O
left-to-right O
phase-encoding O
