fMRI O
run O
and O
right- O
to-left O
phase O
encoding O
fMRI O
run O
. O

As O
shown O
in O
Table O
2 O
, O
none O
of O
the O
differences O
between O
groups O
for O
the O
cumulative O
head O
motion O
value O
was O
statistically O
significant O
after O
Bonferroni O
correction O
( O
corrected O
p O
> O
0.95 O
) O
. O

In O
addition O
, O
none O
of O
the O
differences O
between O
groups O
for O
the O
maximal O
head O
motion O
value O
was O
statistically O
significant O
after O
Bonferroni O
correction O
( O
corrected O
p O
> O
0.35 O
) O
. O

Following O
, O
an O
additional O
step O
of O
pre- O
processing O
was O
performed O
on O
the O
minimally-processed O
fMRI O
data O
: O
spatial O
smoothing O
with O
a O
4-mm O
Gaussian O
kernel O
, O
using O
Statistical O
Para- O
metric O
Mapping O
12 O
( O
SPM12 O
) O
software O
( O
http O
: O
//www.fil.ion.ucl.ac.uk/spm/ O
) O
. O

SPM O
univariate O
analysis O
of O
contrast O
activation O
The O
nodes O
of O
DCM O
were O
selected O
based O
on O
brain O
activation O
elicited O
by O
the O
working O
memory O
task O
, O
as O
revealed O
by O
SPM O
univariate O
analysis O
of O
contrast O
activation O
. O

In O
the O
first-level O
univariate O
statistical O
analysis O
, O
the O
two O
preprocessed O
fMRI O
runs O
were O
included O
in O
the O
model O
as O
two O
sessions O
. O

The O
2-back O
and O
0-back O
blocks O
were O
modeled O
by O
boxcar O
functions O
convolved O
with O
the O
SPM12 O
canonical O
hemodynamic O
response O
function O
. O

The O
parameters O
for O
each O
task O
condition O
were O
estimated O
using O
the O
General O
Linear O
Model O
without O
global O
normalization O
. O

Following O
, O
the O
fMRI O
data O
was O
high-pass O
filtered O
with O
a O
cut-off O
period O
of O
200 O
s. O
Activation O
was O
defined O
as O
the O
contrast O
of O
2-back O
– O
( O
minus O
) O
0-back O
parameter O
estimate O
. O

In O
order O
to O
determine O
between-group O
differences O
in O
regional O
activation O
, O
an O
SPM12 O
second-level O
two-sample O
t-test O
was O
conducted O
voxel- O
wise O
for O
the O
2-back–0-back O
contrast O
image O
. O

Statistical O
significance O
was O
defined O
as O
family-wise O
error O
corrected O
cluster O
probability O
( O
p O
) O
< O
( O
less O
than O
) O
0.05 O
( O
two-tail O
) O
. O

An O
SPM12 O
second-level O
one-sample O
t-test O
was O
conducted O
to O
determine O
the O
DCM O
nodes O
, O
which O
were O
selected O
based O
on O
the O
regions O
that O
activated O
across O
both O
groups O
combined O
. O

Uncorrected O
cluster O
p O
< O
0.05 O
( O
two-tail O
) O
, O
which O
is O
commonly O
accepted O
for O
DCM O
node O
selection O
, O
was O
used O
as O
the O
activation O
threshold O
to O
define O
nodes O
for O
DCM O
analysis O
. O

For O
all O
second-level O
analyses O
, O
the O
cluster-defining O
threshold O
was O
t O
= O
2.4 O
. O

Anatomical O
labels O
for O
regions O
of O
activation O
were O
determined O
using O
the O
Anatomical O
Automatic O
Labeling2 O
( O
AAL2 O
) O
toolbox O
. O

Dynamic O
causal O
modeling O
FMRI-based O
DCM O
is O
a O
biophysical O
model O
of O
how O
the O
underlying O
neuronal O
connectivity O
generates O
the O
observed O
fMRI O
signal O
. O

DCM O
has O
been O
described O
elsewhere O
. O

In O
brief O
, O
DCM O
is O
a O
system O
of O
bilinear O
differential O
state O
equations O
with O
coefficients O
( O
in O
units O
of O
Hz O
) O
. O

A O
node O
in O
the O
model O
that O
receives O
driving O
inputs O
is O
the O
brain O
region O
which O
first O
experiences O
a O
change O
in O
neuronal O
activity O
. O

This O
node O
then O
influences O
other O
nodes O
. O

The O
endogenous O
connectivity O
measures O
the O
EC O
strengths O
between O
nodes O
, O
regardless O
of O
the O
moment-to-moment O
switching O
on O
and O
off O
of O
inputs O
. O

In O
other O
words O
, O
endogenous O
connectivity O
is O
the O
overall O
default O
directionality O
and O
strength O
of O
connectivity O
irrespective O
of O
momentary O
task O
condition O
. O

Experimental O
conditions O
can O
modulate O
the O
endogenous O
connectivities O
. O

Their O
modulation O
effects O
quantify O
increased O
or O
decreased O
connectivity O
strength O
compared O
to O
the O
endogenous O
connectivity O
. O

Following O
, O
two O
new O
experimental O
conditions O
called O
“ O
All-back O
” O
and O
“ O
2-back O
– O
( O
minus O
) O
0-back O
” O
were O
created O
using O
appropriate O
parametric O
regressors O
as O
described O
in O
. O

The O
“ O
All-back O
” O
condition O
, O
which O
reflects O
the O
combined O
effect O
of O
the O
2-back O
and O
0-back O
stimuli O
, O
was O
used O
as O
a O
single O
input O
to O
the O
DCM O
. O

The O
2-back–0-back O
condition O
, O
which O
reflects O
the O
special O
effect O
of O
2-back O
over O
0-back O
( O
i.e. O
, O
increased O
WM O
demand O
) O
, O
was O
used O
as O
a O
putative O
modulator O
of O
EC O
. O

In O
this O
study O
, O
the O
change O
in O
EC O
corresponding O
to O
the O
2-back O
– O
0-back O
modulator O
is O
termed O
as O
modulatory O
change O
. O

DCM O
nodes O
Following O
the O
procedures O
by O
) O
, O
the O
DCM O
nodes O
( O
regions O
) O
were O
chosen O
based O
on O
simultaneously O
meeting O
all O
of O
the O
following O
criteria O
: O
( O
I O
) O
show O
activation O
( O
p O
< O
0.05 O
two-tail O
at O
uncorrected O
cluster O
level O
) O
in O
the O
SPM O
second-level O
analysis O
of O
the O
combined O
groups O
; O
( O
II O
) O
activate O
consistently O
during O
WM O
tasks O
in O
previous O
studies O
; O
( O
III O
) O
belong O
to O
visual O
and O
spatial O
cortico-striatal O
circuits O
; O
and O
( O
IV O
) O
belong O
to O
aberrant O
neurocircuits O
thought O
to O
underlie O
substance O
use O
disorders O
. O

Based O
on O
these O
criteria O
, O
the O
following O
six O
nodes O
were O
selected O
as O
DCM O
nodes O
: O
( O
1 O
) O
L O
DLPFC O
; O
( O
2 O
) O
R O
DLPFC O
; O
( O
3 O
) O
L O
VLPFC O
( O
including O
inferior O
frontal O
gyrus O
pars O
opercularis O
, O
pars O
triangularis O
, O
and O
pars O
orbitalis O
) O
; O
( O
4 O
) O
R O
VLPFC O
; O
( O
5 O
) O
L O
caudate O
; O
and O
( O
6 O
) O
R O
caudate O
. O

The O
posterior O
parietal O
cortex O
was O
not O
included O
as O
a O
DCM O
node O
because O
this O
study O
chose O
to O
focus O
on O
fronto-striatal O
connectivity O
( O
see O
the O
Discussion O
section O
for O
expanded O
discussions O
) O
. O

The O
regional O
activation O
corresponding O
to O
each O
node O
was O
obtained O
based O
on O
the O
set-theoretic O
intersection O
of O
the O
corresponding O
atlas-based O
binary O
mask O
and O
the O
activation O
clusters O
that O
were O
determined O
by O
the O
SPM O
second-level O
one-sample O
t-test O
. O

The O
atlas-derived O
binary O
masks O
for O
all O
brain O
regions O
were O
obtained O
from O
the O
AAL2 O
atlas O
. O

The O
binary O
mask O
for O
DLPFC O
was O
based O
on O
the O
binary O
mask O
of O
middle O
frontal O
gyrus O
( O
MFG O
) O
, O
which O
was O
further O
constrained O
by O
the O
conservative O
bounding O
box O
( O
Brodmann O
Areas O
46 O
and O
9 O
) O
defined O
in O
. O

The O
regional O
fMRI O
activations O
were O
constrained O
by O
these O
binary O
masks O
, O
and O
the O
local O
maximum O
within O
each O
activation O
cluster O
was O
obtained O
. O

The O
nodes O
of O
DCM O
were O
defined O
as O
spheres O
( O
see O
Fig O
. O

1 O
for O
the O
location O
) O
centered O
at O
the O
local O
maximum O
within O
each O
regional O
activation O
. O

The O
radius O
for O
prefrontal O
nodes O
was O
5 O
mm O
, O
and O
the O
radius O
for O
the O
caudate O
nodes O
was O
3 O
mm O
. O

Smaller O
spheres O
were O
used O
as O
the O
caudate O
nodes O
because O
the O
regional O
activations O
in O
these O
regions O
were O
relatively O
smaller O
. O

The O
same O
nodes O
were O
used O
for O
each O
subject O
. O

The O
fMRI O
time O
series O
of O
each O
node O
, O
i.e. O
, O
the O
blood-oxygen-level O
de- O
pendent O
( O
BOLD O
) O
signal O
over O
time O
in O
that O
node O
, O
was O
extracted O
by O
using O
the O
principal-eigenvariate O
of O
that O
node O
. O

Each O
time O
series O
was O
also O
adjusted O
by O
the O
F-contrast O
of O
the O
effects-of-interest O
. O

DCM O
parametric O
empirical O
Bayes O
( O
PEB O
) O
analysis O
The O
PEB O
approach O
, O
as O
implemented O
in O
SPM12 O
( O
Revision O
6906 O
) O
, O
was O
used O
to O
evaluate O
group O
differences O
in O
the O
DCM O
parameters O
. O

PEB O
allows O
to O
empirically O
update O
priors O
for O
each O
subject O
during O
the O
DCM O
analysis O
. O

The O
method O
of O
conducting O
PEB O
analysis O
can O
be O
found O
online O
( O
https O
: O
//en.wikibooks.org/wiki/User O
: O
Peterz/sandbox O
) O
. O

In O
brief O
, O
the O
analysis O
started O
from O
specifying O
an O
initial O
putative O
“ O
full O
” O
model O
, O
which O
was O
related O
to O
the O
driving O
input O
( O
All-back O
stimuli O
) O
and O
the O
2-back–0-back O
modulator O
defined O
above O
. O

The O
term O
“ O
full O
” O
is O
used O
here O
in O
the O
sense O
that O
( O
1 O
) O
the O
putative O
driving O
input O
entered O
all O
of O
the O
six O
nodes O
; O
( O
2 O
) O
each O
node O
was O
putatively O
interconnected O
to O
all O
other O
nodes O
, O
and O
( O
3 O
) O
the O
2-back O
– O
0-back O
modulator O
putatively O
modulated O
all O
of O
the O
30 O
interconnectivities O
between O
nodes O
. O

Then O
, O
all O
full O
models O
( O
one O
per O
subject O
) O
were O
assembled O
into O
a O
cell O
array O
with O
one O
subject O
per O
row O
and O
one O
DCM O
per O
column O
. O

These O
models O
, O
as O
organized O
by O
the O
cell O
array O
, O
were O
estimated O
using O
the O
SPM12 O
code O
( O
spm_dcm_peb_fit.m O
) O
, O
which O
facilitates O
drawing O
subjects O
out O
of O
local O
optima O
towards O
the O
group O
mean O
( O
https O
: O
//en.wikibooks.org/wiki/User O
: O
Peterz/sandbox O
) O
. O

Next O
, O
a O
second O
level O
( O
group O
) O
GLM O
and O
a O
design O
matrix O
( O
ones O
“ O
1 O
” O
for O
CUD O
subjects O
and O
negative O
ones O
“ O
−1 O
” O
for O
controls O
) O
were O
specified O
, O
with O
alcohol O
and O
tobacco O
use O
as O
the O
covariates O
( O
Table O
1 O
) O
. O

Based O
on O
the O
GLM O
, O
design O
matrix O
, O
and O
the O
estimated O
full O
models O
, O
the O
second O
level O
( O
group O
) O
PEB O
model O
was O
estimated O
using O
the O
SPM12 O
code O
( O
spm_dcm_peb.m O
) O
. O

The O
estimated O
PEB O
model O
contains O
all O
parameters O
representing O
group O
effects O
on O
each O
DCM O
parameter O
. O

After O
that O
, O
between-group O
effects O
were O
identified O
using O
the O
SPM12 O
code O
( O
spm_dcm_peb_bmc.m O
) O
, O
which O
prunes O
away O
any O
para- O
meters O
from O
the O
PEB O
model O
that O
do O
not O
contribute O
to O
the O
model O
evidence O
. O

Statistical O
analysis O
Student O
’ O
s O
t-test O
was O
used O
to O
evaluate O
group O
differences O
on O
continuous O
variables O
( O
e.g. O
, O
age O
) O
. O

Fisher O
’ O
s O
exact O
test O
was O
used O
to O
evaluate O
group O
differences O
on O
categorical O
variables O
( O
e.g. O
, O
sex O
) O
. O

An O
analysis O
of O
variance O
( O
ANOVA O
) O
was O
used O
to O
analyze O
behavioral O
performance O
, O
with O
group O
( O
CUD O
and O
Control O
) O
as O
the O
between-subjects O
factor O
, O
and O
working O
memory O
level O
( O
2-back O
and O
0-back O
) O
as O
the O
within-subjects O
factor O
. O

Spearman O
partial O
correlation O
( O
with O
alcohol O
use O
and O
tobacco O
use O
as O
covariates O
) O
was O
used O
for O
the O
correlation O
analysis O
. O

Craving O
and O
Cue-Reactivity O
in O
Nicotine-Dependent O
Tobacco O
Smokers O
is O
associated O
with O
different O
insula O
networks O
. O

Background O
: O
The O
insula O
has O
a O
well-established O
role O
in O
nicotine O
dependence O
and O
is O
a O
node O
of O
the O
salience O
network O
( O
SN O
) O
, O
which O
integrates O
internal O
and O
external O
information O
to O
guide O
behavior O
. O

Recent O
findings O
reveal O
that O
internal O
and O
external O
processing O
occurs O
in O
the O
ventral O
and O
dorsal O
anterior O
insula O
( O
vAI/dAI O
) O
, O
respectively O
. O

Whether O
vAI/dAI O
network O
connectivity O
differentially O
reflects O
internally-generated O
craving O
and O
externally-triggered O
smoking O
cue O
reactivity O
was O
tested O
. O

Methods O
: O
Thirty-six O
male O
and O
female O
nicotine-dependent O
individuals O
smoked O
1 O
hour O
before O
functional O
magnetic O
resonance O
imaging O
. O

Baseline O
craving O
was O
measured O
, O
followed O
by O
resting-state O
and O
smoking O
cue-reactivity O
scans O
, O
and O
another O
assessment O
of O
craving O
. O

Craving O
and O
cue-reactivity O
interactions O
were O
measured O
by O
focusing O
on O
specific O
nodes O
of O
the O
SN O
: O
the O
vAI/dAI O
and O
anterior O
cingulate O
cortex O
( O
ACC O
) O
. O

Results O
: O
Resting-state O
vAI/dAI O
networks O
overlapped O
with O
the O
prototypical O
SN O
, O
yet O
they O
possess O
distinct O
patterns O
, O
linking O
the O
vAI O
with O
nodes O
of O
the O
internally-focused O
default O
mode O
network O
( O
DMN O
) O
and O
the O
dAI O
with O
nodes O
of O
the O
external/goal-related O
frontoparietal O
network O
( O
FPN O
) O
. O

Internally O
generated O
baseline O
craving O
was O
associated O
with O
enhanced O
vAI O
connectivity O
while O
rostral O
ACC O
( O
rACC O
) O
reactivity O
to O
external O
smoking O
cues O
was O
associated O
with O
greater O
dAI O
connectivity O
. O

We O
also O
found O
that O
cue O
reactivity O
in O
the O
rACC O
was O
associated O
with O
a O
rise O
in O
subjective O
cue-induced O
craving O
, O
while O
baseline O
subjective O
craving O
did O
not O
influence O
brain O
cue-reactivity O
. O

Conclusions O
: O
These O
data O
show O
that O
brain O
reactivity O
to O
smoking O
cues O
is O
associated O
with O
a O
subsequent O
increase O
in O
craving O
. O

Additionally O
, O
separate O
insula O
networks O
play O
a O
role O
in O
an O
individual O
’ O
s O
vulnerability O
to O
internally-related O
craving O
and O
externally-triggered O
cue-reactivity O
, O
which O
may O
guide O
the O
development O
of O
new O
neurobiologically-targeted O
therapies O
. O

Methods O
Participants O
Participants O
included O
36 O
nicotine-dependent O
individuals O
( O
13 O
women O
) O
who O
reported O
an O
interest O
in O
quitting O
smoking O
( O
Table O
1 O
) O
. O

A O
Fagerström O
Test O
for O
Nicotine O
Dependence O
( O
FTND O
) O
score O
≥ O
4 O
and O
an O
expired O
carbon O
monoxide O
concentration O
of O
≥ O
5 O
ppm O
at O
the O
time O
of O
screening O
were O
required O
. O

Serious O
medical O
illness O
, O
pregnancy O
( O
confirmed O
by O
urinalysis O
) O
drug O
or O
alcohol O
( O
except O
nicotine O
) O
dependence O
, O
major O
depressive O
disorder O
within O
the O
past O
6 O
months O
, O
and O
current O
or O
lifetime O
history O
of O
schizophrenia O
, O
schizoaffective O
disorder O
, O
bipolar O
disorder O
, O
or O
psychotic O
disorders O
not O
otherwise O
specified O
( O
confirmed O
via O
Structured O
Clinical O
Interview O
for O
DSM O
( O
SCID O
) O
IV O
) O
were O
exclusionary O
criteria O
. O

Abstinence O
from O
drug/alcohol O
use O
was O
confirmed O
by O
urine/breath O
samples O
respectively O
( O
QuickTox11 O
Panel O
Drug O
Test O
Card O
, O
Branan O
Medical O
Corporation O
, O
Irvine O
California O
; O
Alco-Sensor O
IV O
, O
Intoximeters O
Inc. O
, O
St. O
Louis O
, O
MO O
) O
. O

All O
procedures O
were O
completed O
at O
McLean O
Hospital O
and O
were O
approved O
by O
the O
Partners O
Human O
Research O
Committee O
. O

Participants O
provided O
written O
and O
verbal O
informed O
consent O
after O
receiving O
a O
complete O
study O
description O
. O

Procedures O
As O
in O
our O
prior O
research O
with O
an O
independent O
sample O
, O
participants O
were O
asked O
to O
smoke O
as O
usual O
prior O
to O
the O
study O
visit O
. O

To O
standardize O
all O
procedures O
relative O
to O
the O
last O
cigarette O
smoked O
, O
participants O
smoked O
one O
of O
their O
own O
cigarettes O
in O
the O
lab O
~1 O
hour O
prior O
to O
scanning O
. O

To O
evaluate O
pre-cue O
exposure O
craving O
state O
, O
fifteen O
minutes O
prior O
to O
scanning O
, O
participants O
completed O
the O
Questionnaire O
of O
Smoking O
Urges O
( O
; O
QSU O
) O
. O

In O
the O
scanner O
, O
participants O
completed O
a O
6-minute O
resting O
state O
scan O
where O
they O
were O
told O
to O
keep O
their O
eyes O
open O
and O
think O
of O
nothing O
in O
particular O
. O

Next O
, O
participants O
performed O
the O
smoking O
cue-reactivity O
task O
, O
which O
has O
been O
described O
elsewhere O
. O

Briefly O
, O
participants O
viewed O
smoking O
and O
neutral O
images O
matched O
for O
general O
content O
( O
e.g. O
, O
hands O
holding O
a O
cigarette O
or O
a O
neutral O
object O
, O
faces O
in O
a O
neutral O
or O
smoking O
related O
context O
) O
, O
and O
pressed O
a O
button O
when O
the O
target O
image O
of O
an O
animal O
was O
shown O
. O

Button O
presses O
confirmed O
participants O
were O
awake O
and O
attending O
to O
the O
task O
but O
were O
not O
included O
in O
subsequent O
analyses O
. O

After O
exiting O
the O
scanner O
, O
craving O
was O
measured O
again O
with O
the O
QSU O
and O
the O
change O
in O
craving O
was O
calculated O
( O
QSU O
post O
– O
QSU O
pre O
) O
. O

Functional O
neuroimaging O
Scanning O
was O
performed O
on O
a O
Siemens O
Prisma O
3T O
scanner O
( O
Erlagen O
, O
Germany O
) O
with O
a O
64-channel O
head O
coil O
. O

Functional O
scans O
( O
resting O
and O
cue O
reactivity O
) O
were O
acquired O
with O
TR O
= O
720 O
ms O
, O
TE O
= O
30 O
ms O
, O
slices O
= O
66 O
, O
phase O
encode O
direction O
posterior O
to O
anterior O
, O
Flip O
angle O
= O
66o O
voxel O
size O
= O
2.5 O
× O
2.5 O
× O
2×5 O
mm O
, O
GRAPPA O
factor O
of O
2 O
, O
and O
a O
multi-band O
acceleration O
factor O
= O
6 O
. O

After O
all O
functional O
scans O
, O
multiecho O
multi-planar O
rapidly O
acquired O
gradient O
echo-structural O
images O
were O
acquired O
with O
the O
following O
: O
TR O
= O
2530 O
ms O
, O
TE1= O
3.3 O
ms O
, O
TE2 O
= O
6.98 O
ms O
, O
TE3 O
= O
8.79 O
ms O
, O
TE4 O
= O
10.65 O
ms O
, O
flip O
angle O
7o O
, O
resolution O
= O
1.33 O
× O
1 O
× O
1 O
mm O
. O

fMRI O
Pre-processing O
Data O
were O
analyzed O
using O
tools O
from O
the O
Functional O
Magnetic O
Resonance O
Imaging O
of O
the O
Brain O
( O
FMRIB O
) O
Software O
Library O
( O
FSL O
: O
www.fmrib.ox.ac.uk/fsl O
) O
. O

Standard O
pre-processing O
was O
conducted O
on O
both O
the O
resting O
and O
task-based O
data O
including O
: O
motion O
correction O
with O
MCFLIRT O
, O
brain O
extraction O
using O
BET O
, O
slice O
time O
correction O
, O
spatial O
smoothing O
with O
a O
Gaussian O
kernel O
of O
full-width O
half-max O
of O
6mm O
, O
and O
high O
pass O
filtering O
at O
0.01 O
Hz O
. O

The O
only O
non-FSL O
tool O
used O
was O
spikefix O
( O
https O
: O
//github.com/bbfrederick/spikefix O
) O
, O
which O
evaluates O
fMRI O
data O
for O
motion/intensity O
spikes O
. O

For O
task-based O
data O
, O
these O
spikes O
are O
removed O
and O
single O
point O
confound O
regressors O
representing O
noise-related O
timepoints O
were O
generated O
. O

Resting-state O
data O
was O
denoised O
via O
independent O
component O
analysis O
using O
the O
FSL O
tool O
for O
multivariate O
exploratory O
linear O
decomposition O
into O
independent O
components O
( O
MELODIC O
) O
. O

As O
in O
our O
prior O
studies O
, O
MELODIC O
was O
run O
for O
each O
subject O
and O
spatial/temporal O
information O
for O
each O
independent O
component O
was O
visually O
inspected O
to O
identify O
noise-related O
components O
, O
which O
were O
then O
regressed O
out O
of O
the O
resting-state O
fMRI O
data O
to O
generate O
a O
denoised O
fMRI O
timeseries O
. O

Regions O
of O
Interest O
All O
regions O
of O
interest O
( O
ROIs O
) O
were O
defined O
a O
priori O
. O

Four O
anatomically O
defined O
anterior O
insula O
( O
AI O
) O
sub-regions O
, O
divided O
into O
the O
right O
and O
left O
hemispheres O
and O
the O
dorsal O
and O
ventral O
components O
, O
were O
used O
as O
ROIs O
in O
both O
the O
resting O
state O
and O
task-based O
analyses O
. O

The O
ACC O
was O
only O
assessed O
during O
cue-reactivity O
and O
was O
divided O
into O
two O
ROIs O
based O
on O
our O
prior O
work O
- O
the O
dorsal O
ACC O
and O
rostral O
ACC O
. O

All O
ROIs O
are O
shown O
in O
Supplemental O
Figure O
1 O
. O

Cue O
Reactivity O
Cue O
reactivity O
methods O
largely O
replicate O
our O
prior O
work O
. O

During O
each O
of O
the O
5 O
cue-reactivity O
runs O
, O
10 O
smoking O
, O
10 O
neutral O
, O
and O
2 O
target O
images O
were O
shown O
for O
4 O
seconds O
each O
. O

Images O
were O
separated O
by O
a O
jittered O
inter-trial-interval O
averaging O
10 O
seconds O
and O
ranging O
from O
6 O
-14 O
seconds O
in O
steps O
of O
2 O
seconds O
. O

Subject-level O
general O
linear O
models O
( O
GLMs O
) O
were O
implemented O
with O
task O
regressors O
representing O
the O
presentation O
of O
smoking O
, O
neutral O
, O
and O
target O
images O
convolved O
with O
the O
standard O
gamma O
heymodynamic O
response O
function O
. O

Confound O
regressors O
included O
motion O
time O
courses O
( O
x O
, O
y O
, O
z O
translation O
and O
rotation O
) O
and O
the O
motion/intensity O
artifacts O
defined O
by O
the O
spikefix O
tool O
described O
above O
. O

Given O
that O
participants O
completed O
5 O
cue-reactivity O
runs O
, O
a O
second-level O
fixed O
effects O
GLM O
was O
implemented O
to O
combine O
the O
runs O
for O
each O
subject O
and O
then O
beta O
weights O
for O
the O
smoking O
vs. O
neutral O
contrast O
were O
extracted O
for O
each O
subject O
, O
e.g. O
, O
the O
average O
value O
computed O
for O
each O
of O
the O
6 O
ROIs O
, O
from O
the O
second-level O
regression O
maps O
. O

Resting O
State O
Connectivity O
: O
AI O
Networks O
A O
dual O
regression O
approach O
was O
used O
to O
calculate O
subject O
specific O
time O
courses O
and O
spatial O
maps O
reflecting O
the O
functional O
connectivity O
for O
each O
of O
the O
four O
insula O
sub-regions O
. O

In O
the O
first O
step O
of O
dual O
regression O
, O
a O
whole O
brain O
multivariate O
spatial O
regression O
was O
conducted O
using O
spatial O
maps O
of O
all O
insula O
ROIs O
. O

These O
resulting O
time O
courses O
were O
then O
each O
normalized O
to O
unit O
variance O
and O
used O
as O
regressors O
in O
a O
second O
multivariate O
regression O
against O
each O
subject O
’ O
s O
dataset O
to O
identify O
participant-specific O
spatial O
maps O
reflecting O
the O
functional O
connectivity O
for O
each O
insula O
sub-region O
in O
that O
participant O
. O

This O
approach O
allows O
the O
functional O
connectivity O
maps O
for O
each O
ROI O
to O
be O
disentangled O
into O
the O
set O
of O
networks O
for O
which O
each O
ROI O
is O
connected O
, O
while O
screening O
out O
any O
overlapping O
network O
connectivity O
with O
the O
other O
ROIs O
. O

These O
v/dAI O
connectivity O
maps O
were O
used O
for O
further O
statistical O
analyses O
to O
assess O
relationships O
with O
baseline O
craving O
and O
brain O
cue-reactivity O
. O

Statistical O
Analyses O
SPSS O
version O
24 O
was O
used O
to O
conduct O
two O
regression O
analyses O
to O
confirm O
that O
pre-existing O
baseline O
craving O
does O
not O
influence O
subsequent O
cue-induced O
reactivity O
, O
while O
brain O
reactivity O
to O
smoking O
cues O
predicts O
the O
resulting O
change O
in O
craving O
. O

First O
, O
a O
multivariate O
regression O
was O
fit O
with O
baseline O
craving O
as O
the O
predictor O
and O
beta O
weights O
from O
the O
6 O
ROIs O
for O
the O
smoking O
vs. O
neutral O
contrast O
as O
dependent O
variables O
. O

A O
second O
multiple O
linear O
regression O
was O
run O
with O
the O
6 O
ROI O
beta O
weights O
for O
the O
smoking O
vs. O
neutral O
contrast O
as O
predictors O
and O
the O
change O
in O
QSU O
score O
as O
the O
dependent O
variable O
. O

Baseline O
craving O
was O
included O
in O
the O
model O
to O
control O
for O
this O
factor O
. O

For O
resting O
state O
functional O
connectivity O
analyses O
, O
group-level O
analyses O
implemented O
GLMs O
with O
non-parametric O
permutation O
testing O
via O
FSL O
Randomise O
with O
cluster-based O
thresholding O
( O
Z O
= O
3.1 O
, O
number O
of O
permutations O
= O
5000 O
) O
. O

This O
was O
done O
to O
determine O
relationships O
between O
1 O
) O
vAI O
network O
connectivity O
and O
baseline O
craving O
, O
and O
2 O
) O
dAI O
network O
connectivity O
and O
smoking O
cue-reactivity O
, O
with O
control O
of O
family-wise O
error O
at O
p O
< O
0.05 O
. O

Predictors O
included O
baseline O
craving O
, O
and O
brain O
reactivity O
to O
smoking O
vs. O
neutral O
cues O
in O
the O
6 O
ROIs O
noted O
above O
. O

The O
contrasts O
of O
interest O
were O
specific O
to O
the O
AI O
subregion O
and O
aimed O
to O
confirm O
that O
baseline O
craving O
corresponds O
with O
vAI O
connectivity O
while O
brain O
reactivity O
to O
smoking O
cues O
is O
related O
to O
dAI O
connectivity O
. O

Prediction O
Analysis O
While O
baseline O
craving O
was O
not O
associated O
with O
brain O
activation O
to O
smoking O
cues O
, O
brain O
reactivity O
to O
smoking O
cues O
was O
associated O
with O
the O
change O
in O
subjective O
craving O
following O
cue O
presentation O
. O

The O
model O
showing O
brain O
reactivity O
to O
smoking O
cues O
predicts O
the O
rise O
in O
cue-induced O
craving O
was O
significant O
( O
F O
( O
7 O
, O
28 O
) O
= O
2.82 O
, O
p O
= O
0.024 O
, O
R O
=0.64 O
, O
adjusted O
R2 O
= O
0.27 O
) O
. O

Figure O
2 O
shows O
the O
results O
of O
the O
predictors O
associated O
with O
cue-induced O
craving O
including O
a O
positive O
relationship O
with O
smoking-cue O
reactivity O
in O
the O
rACC O
( O
unstandardized O
β O
= O
0.13 O
, O
standardized O
β O
= O
0.44 O
, O
t O
= O
2.59 O
, O
p O
= O
0.015 O
) O
and O
a O
negative O
relationship O
with O
cue-reactivity O
in O
the O
right O
vAI O
( O
unstandardized O
β O
= O
− O
0.21 O
, O
standardized O
β O
= O
− O
0.54 O
, O
t O
= O
−2.15 O
, O
p O
= O
0.040 O
) O
. O

There O
was O
a O
trend O
positive O
association O
between O
cue-induced O
subjective O
craving O
and O
left O
vAI O
reactivity O
to O
smoking O
cues O
( O
unstandardized O
β O
= O
0.17 O
, O
standardized O
β O
= O
0.48 O
, O
t O
= O
1.92 O
, O
p O
= O
0.066 O
) O
. O

No O
other O
individual O
predictors O
were O
significant O
. O

Resting O
state O
fMRI O
based O
multilayer O
network O
configuration O
in O
patients O
with O
schizophrenia O
Highlights O
Higher O
flexibility O
in O
schizophrenia O
at O
the O
resting O
state O
network O
and O
node O
level O
. O

Higher O
flexibility O
in O
the O
thalamus O
due O
to O
default-mode O
sensory/motor O
transitions O
. O

Altered O
between O
sub-network O
dynamic O
modular O
configuration O
in O
schizophrenia O
. O

Flexibility O
scores O
affected O
by O
methodological O
choices O
such O
as O
window O
size O
. O

Novel O
methods O
for O
measuring O
large-scale O
dynamic O
brain O
organisation O
are O
needed O
to O
provide O
new O
biomarkers O
of O
schizophrenia O
. O

Using O
a O
method O
for O
modelling O
dynamic O
modular O
organisation O
( O
Mucha O
et O
al. O
, O
2010 O
) O
, O
evidence O
suggests O
higher O
‘ O
flexibility O
’ O
( O
switching O
between O
multilayer O
network O
communities O
) O
to O
be O
a O
feature O
of O
schizophrenia O
( O
Braun O
et O
al. O
, O
2016 O
) O
. O

The O
current O
study O
compared O
flexibility O
between O
55 O
patients O
with O
schizophrenia O
and O
72 O
controls O
( O
the O
COBRE O
Dataset O
) O
. O

In O
addition O
, O
novel O
methods O
of O
‘ O
between O
resting O
state O
network O
synchronisation O
’ O
( O
BRSNS O
) O
and O
the O
probability O
of O
transition O
from O
one O
community O
to O
another O
were O
used O
to O
further O
describe O
group O
differences O
in O
dynamic O
community O
structure O
. O

There O
was O
significantly O
higher O
schizophrenia O
group O
flexibility O
scores O
in O
cerebellar O
( O
F O
( O
1124 O
) O
= O
9.33 O
, O
p O
( O
FDR O
) O
= O
0.017 O
) O
, O
subcortical O
( O
F O
( O
1124 O
) O
= O
13.14 O
, O
p O
( O
FDR O
) O
= O
0.005 O
) O
, O
and O
fronto-parietal O
task O
control O
( O
F O
( O
1124 O
) O
= O
7.19 O
, O
p O
( O
FDR O
) O
= O
0.033 O
) O
resting O
state O
networks O
( O
RSNs O
) O
, O
as O
well O
as O
in O
the O
left O
thalamus O
( O
MNI O
XYZ O
: O
-2 O
, O
-13 O
, O
12 O
; O
F O
( O
1 O
, O
124 O
) O
= O
17.1 O
, O
p O
( O
FDR O
) O
< O
0.001 O
) O
and O
the O
right O
crus O
I O
( O
MNI O
XYZ O
: O
35 O
, O
-67 O
, O
-34 O
; O
F O
( O
1 O
, O
124 O
) O
= O
19.65 O
, O
p O
( O
FDR O
) O
< O
0.001 O
) O
. O

Flexibility O
in O
the O
left O
thalamus O
reflected O
transitions O
between O
communities O
covering O
default O
mode O
and O
sensory-somatomotor O
RSNs O
. O

BRSNS O
scores O
suggested O
altered O
dynamic O
inter-RSN O
modular O
configuration O
in O
schizophrenia O
. O

This O
study O
suggests O
less O
stable O
community O
structure O
in O
a O
schizophrenia O
group O
at O
an O
RSN O
and O
node O
level O
and O
provides O
novel O
methods O
of O
exploring O
dynamic O
community O
structure O
. O

Mediation O
of O
group O
differences O
by O
mean O
time O
window O
correlation O
did O
however O
suggest O
flexibility O
to O
be O
no O
better O
as O
a O
schizophrenia O
biomarker O
than O
simpler O
measures O
and O
a O
range O
of O
methodological O
choices O
affected O
results O
. O

Methods O
Participants O
The O
COBRE O
dataset O
has O
72 O
patients O
with O
schizophrenia O
and O
75 O
healthy O
controls O
. O

Participants O
underwent O
a O
5 O
minute O
resting O
state O
scan O
( O
TR O
= O
2s O
, O
TE O
= O
29 O
ms O
, O
150 O
volumes O
, O
matrix O
size O
= O
64 O
× O
64 O
, O
32 O
slices O
, O
voxel O
size O
= O
3 O
× O
3 O
× O
4 O
mm3 O
) O
. O

Two O
controls O
and O
19 O
patients O
were O
removed O
during O
preprocessing O
( O
see O
below O
) O
, O
and O
two O
participants O
withdrew O
their O
data O
, O
leaving O
data O
from O
72 O
controls O
and O
55 O
patients O
for O
analysis O
. O

Group O
characteristics O
are O
described O
in O
Table O
1 O
. O

Preprocessing O
Preprocessing O
followed O
the O
same O
steps O
as O
in O
) O
using O
AFNI O
version O
17.2.17 O
and O
FSL O
version O
5.0.11 O
. O

Briefly O
this O
involved O
slice O
timing O
correction O
, O
rigid-body O
head O
movement O
realignment O
to O
the O
first O
volume O
, O
co-registration O
to O
structural O
image O
using O
a O
gray O
matter O
mask O
, O
transformation O
to O
MNI O
space O
, O
spatial O
smoothing O
with O
a O
6 O
mm O
FWHM O
, O
wavelet O
despiking O
using O
the O
BrainWavelet O
Toolbox O
with O
default O
settings O
( O
www.brainwavelet.org O
) O
, O
regression O
of O
6 O
movement O
parameters O
( O
x O
, O
y O
, O
z O
, O
pitch O
, O
roll O
, O
and O
yaw O
) O
and O
CSF O
based O
confounding O
signal O
. O

A O
band-pass O
filter O
of O
0.08 O
< O
f O
< O
0.15 O
Hz O
was O
applied O
, O
which O
is O
the O
same O
frequency O
band O
studied O
in O
a O
previous O
investigation O
of O
flexibility O
in O
schizophrenia O
. O

Although O
the O
Wavelet O
Despiking O
algorithm O
is O
a O
robust O
movement O
correction O
procedure O
there O
was O
a O
significant O
difference O
in O
median O
mean O
spike O
percentage O
( O
a O
measure O
of O
movement O
related O
noise O
) O
between O
the O
two O
groups O
( O
U O
= O
1598 O
, O
p O
< O
0.001 O
) O
. O

Participants O
with O
a O
mean O
spike O
percentage O
> O
7.5 O
% O
were O
excluded O
from O
the O
analysis O
, O
however O
there O
was O
still O
a O
higher O
median O
mean O
spike O
percentage O
in O
the O
patient O
group O
( O
U O
= O
1477 O
, O
p O
= O
0.014 O
) O
. O

As O
a O
result O
, O
mean O
spike O
percentage O
was O
included O
as O
a O
covariate O
in O
the O
group O
comparisons O
. O

Resting O
state O
scans O
were O
parcellated O
using O
the O
atlas O
( O
5mm O
spheres O
around O
suggested O
coordinates O
) O
. O

This O
atlas O
was O
chosen O
as O
it O
has O
pre-defined O
allocations O
of O
nodes O
into O
RSNs O
. O

The O
atlas O
has O
12 O
RSNs O
: O
default O
mode O
, O
cerebellar O
, O
cingulo-opercular O
task O
control O
, O
sensory-somatomotor O
hand O
/ O
mouth O
, O
subcortical O
, O
fronto-parietal O
task O
control O
, O
visual O
, O
memory O
retrieval O
, O
salience O
, O
dorsal O
attention O
, O
ventral O
attention O
, O
and O
auditory O
. O

In O
the O
current O
study O
the O
two O
sensory-somatomotor O
networks O
were O
combined O
. O

To O
confirm O
results O
main O
group O
comparisons O
of O
flexibility O
were O
repeated O
using O
the O
atlas O
, O
which O
contains O
a O
similar O
set O
of O
11 O
RSNs O
, O
with O
the O
omission O
of O
the O
cerebellar O
, O
subcortical O
, O
and O
memory O
retrieval O
networks O
, O
and O
the O
addition O
of O
the O
retrosplenial-temporal O
and O
cingulo-parietal O
RSNs O
. O

These O
two O
atlases O
were O
chosen O
as O
they O
have O
pre-defined O
allocations O
of O
nodes O
into O
RSNs O
. O

Areas O
of O
signal O
drop O
out O
were O
defined O
as O
those O
with O
a O
mean O
time-series O
signal O
intensity O
z O
score O
( O
across O
nodes O
) O
less O
than O
or O
equal O
to O
1.64 O
in O
any O
subject O
, O
corresponding O
to O
outliers O
> O
95th O
percentile O
or O
< O
5th O
percentile O
. O

These O
nodes O
were O
removed O
from O
the O
analysis O
, O
leaving O
207 O
regions O
in O
the O
) O
parcellation O
and O
268 O
in O
the O
parcellation O
. O

Areas O
of O
signal O
loss O
were O
mostly O
in O
ventral O
prefrontal O
and O
temporal O
areas O
, O
which O
is O
a O
common O
issue O
in O
MRI O
imaging O
. O

Sliding O
time O
windows O
Time-series O
data O
were O
split O
into O
a O
consecutive O
series O
of O
non-overlapping O
windows O
. O

Similar O
to O
scans O
were O
cut O
into O
30 O
s O
/ O
15 O
TR O
segments O
. O

Additionally O
, O
flexibility O
results O
were O
repeated O
with O
25 O
TRs O
( O
50 O
s O
) O
and O
30 O
TRs O
( O
60 O
s O
) O
window O
sizes O
, O
in O
order O
to O
report O
whether O
window O
size O
affected O
results O
. O

These O
window O
sizes O
were O
chosen O
so O
that O
the O
total O
number O
of O
volumes O
( O
150 O
) O
was O
divisible O
by O
each O
window O
length O
and O
because O
it O
has O
been O
suggested O
that O
30–60 O
s O
time O
windows O
are O
reasonable O
in O
studying O
fMRI O
based O
dynamic O
functional O
connectivity O
and O
such O
window O
sizes O
have O
typically O
been O
used O
in O
dynamic O
functional O
connectivity O
studies O
. O

It O
has O
been O
suggested O
also O
that O
the O
minimum O
window O
size O
that O
can O
be O
used O
in O
a O
dynamic O
functional O
connectivity O
study O
is O
1/fmin O
, O
where O
fmin O
is O
the O
minimum O
frequency O
included O
. O

In O
the O
present O
study O
this O
would O
allow O
for O
a O
window O
size O
of O
12.5 O
s O
( O
1/0.08 O
= O
12.5 O
) O
. O

However O
, O
window O
sizes O
below O
30 O
s O
appeared O
to O
have O
low O
variance O
of O
flexibility O
across O
participants O
and O
across O
nodes O
( O
supplementary O
materials O
Section O
1 O
) O
. O

Windowed O
correlation O
matrices O
were O
proportionally O
thresholded O
at O
10 O
% O
to O
give O
a O
series O
of O
weighted O
adjacency O
matrices O
. O

Adjacency O
matrices O
in O
sequence O
were O
used O
as O
ordered O
layers O
in O
the O
multilayer O
network O
. O

Additionally O
, O
the O
analysis O
was O
repeated O
at O
5 O
and O
15 O
% O
thresholds O
, O
as O
well O
as O
over O
a O
range O
of O
parameters O
specific O
to O
the O
multilayer O
community O
detection O
algorithm O
: O
γ O
( O
0.9 O
, O
1 O
, O
1.1 O
) O
and O
ω O
( O
0.5 O
, O
0.75 O
, O
1 O
) O
. O

The O
parameter O
γ O
controls O
the O
size O
and O
therefore O
number O
of O
communities O
within O
layers O
of O
the O
network O
( O
larger O
γ O
= O
more O
communities O
) O
. O

The O
parameter O
ω O
in O
the O
current O
study O
controls O
the O
number O
of O
communities O
found O
across O
layers O
( O
larger O
ω O
= O
less O
communities O
) O
. O

An O
exploration O
of O
how O
these O
parameters O
affected O
flexibility O
and O
group O
differences O
is O
shown O
in O
the O
supplementary O
materials O
Section O
1 O
. O

Multilayer O
community O
detection O
Communities O
describe O
groups O
of O
nodes O
more O
strongly O
connected O
to O
each O
other O
than O
to O
nodes O
outside O
of O
their O
community O
, O
as O
compared O
to O
a O
null O
model O
representing O
what O
would O
be O
expected O
in O
a O
network O
of O
similar O
size O
and O
density O
with O
randomly O
distributed O
connections O
. O

Modularity O
describes O
a O
formal O
measurement O
of O
this O
, O
which O
can O
be O
used O
in O
iterative O
processes O
of O
finding O
a O
partition O
of O
a O
network O
with O
an O
optimal O
set O
of O
community O
assignments O
. O

In O
the O
current O
study O
the O
GenLouvain O
community O
detection O
algorithm O
was O
used O
, O
which O
involves O
the O
following O
modularity O
measurement O
that O
is O
formulated O
to O
work O
on O
multilayer O
networks O
: O
Here O
μ O
is O
the O
total O
edge O
weight O
of O
the O
network O
, O
Aijl O
is O
the O
adjacency O
matrix O
between O
nodes O
i O
and O
j O
at O
layer O
l. O
Pijl O
describes O
the O
matrix O
of O
expected O
weights O
under O
the O
null O
model O
. O

The O
structural O
resolution O
parameter O
γl O
sets O
the O
weight O
of O
intralayer O
edges O
, O
and O
the O
temporal O
ωjlr O
resolution O
parameter O
sets O
the O
weight O
of O
inter O
layer O
edges O
( O
here O
γl O
= O
ωjlr O
= O
1 O
) O
. O

g O
refers O
to O
community O
assignments O
: O
gil O
and O
gjr O
are O
the O
community O
assignments O
of O
node O
i O
in O
layer O
l O
, O
and O
node O
j O
in O
layer O
r O
( O
respectively O
) O
. O

δ O
describes O
the O
Kronecker O
delta O
, O
which O
for O
δ O
( O
gil O
, O
gjr O
) O
is O
1 O
if O
il O
= O
jr O
, O
and O
0 O
if O
il O
≠ O
jr O
In O
the O
current O
study O
the O
GenLouvain O
community O
detection O
algorithm O
was O
used O
on O
each O
participant O
's O
sequence O
of O
weighted O
adjacency O
matrices O
( O
node O
x O
node O
x O
layer O
) O
. O

Here O
, O
the O
network O
was O
treated O
as O
ordinal O
, O
with O
interlayer O
links O
between O
sequential O
layers O
for O
nodes O
at O
the O
same O
position O
. O

This O
was O
a O
similar O
implementation O
used O
in O
previous O
studies O
( O
Fig O
. O

1 O
) O
. O

Module O
allegiance O
and O
between O
/ O
out O
of O
RSN O
synchronisation O
In O
order O
to O
measure O
the O
dynamic O
reorganisation O
of O
communities O
between O
RSNs O
the O
concept O
of O
a O
“ O
module O
allegiance O
matrix O
” O
was O
used O
. O

This O
concept O
has O
also O
been O
termed O
the O
“ O
temporal O
co-occurrence O
matrix O
” O
in O
a O
previous O
study O
. O

The O
benefit O
of O
the O
module O
allegiance O
matrix O
is O
that O
it O
allows O
for O
the O
level O
of O
synchronisation O
between O
specific O
nodes O
or O
RSNs O
to O
be O
measured O
. O

To O
create O
each O
participant O
's O
module O
allegiance O
matrix O
a O
node O
x O
node O
matrix O
was O
formed O
with O
each O
element O
giving O
the O
proportion O
of O
times O
a O
node O
shared O
a O
community O
with O
another O
node O
over O
the O
course O
of O
the O
scan O
. O

Mean O
module O
allegiance O
between O
RSNs O
was O
found O
in O
order O
to O
give O
a O
measure O
of O
synchronisation O
between O
pairs O
of O
RSNs O
. O

We O
refer O
to O
this O
measure O
as O
‘ O
between O
RSN O
synchronisation O
’ O
( O
BRSNS O
) O
. O

To O
provide O
a O
summary O
measure O
of O
how O
often O
RSNs O
coupled O
with O
nodes O
outside O
of O
their O
network O
, O
the O
mean O
of O
all O
out O
of O
RSN O
module O
allegiance O
values O
for O
each O
RSN O
was O
taken O
. O

For O
simplicity O
we O
refer O
to O
this O
measure O
as O
‘ O
out O
of O
RSN O
synchronisation O
’ O
( O
ORSNS O
) O
. O

This O
is O
a O
similar O
concept O
to O
“ O
temporal O
flexibility O
” O
proposed O
by O
. O

ORSNS O
was O
measured O
in O
controls O
in O
order O
to O
validate O
the O
module O
allegiance O
procedure O
, O
by O
comparing O
relative O
levels O
with O
suggested O
‘ O
processing O
/ O
control O
’ O
profiles O
of O
RSNs O
, O
which O
are O
described O
based O
on O
profiles O
of O
inter O
and O
intra O
RSN O
connectivity O
. O

Transition O
matrices O
A O
transition O
matrix O
containing O
the O
probability O
of O
transition O
from O
one O
community O
to O
another O
was O
formed O
for O
each O
participant O
. O

Group O
differences O
were O
then O
tested O
using O
permutation O
tests O
( O
two O
tailed O
; O
5000 O
permutations O
of O
group O
assignments O
) O
. O

Transition O
matrices O
were O
treated O
as O
undirected O
by O
averaging O
inward O
and O
outward O
transition O
probabilities O
. O

K O
means O
clustering O
was O
used O
( O
Scikit-Learn O
: O
) O
in O
order O
to O
label O
the O
communities O
found O
in O
each O
participant O
into O
a O
set O
of O
standard O
communities O
shared O
across O
subjects O
. O

This O
approach O
is O
commonly O
used O
with O
dynamic O
functional O
connectivity O
as O
it O
provides O
a O
way O
to O
standardise O
participant O
's O
sliding O
time O
windows O
into O
a O
set O
of O
group O
meta-states O
. O

Every O
community O
from O
every O
participant O
was O
entered O
into O
the O
k O
means O
algorithm O
, O
the O
feature O
space O
being O
a O
vector O
of O
probability O
of O
node O
assignment O
for O
all O
nodes O
( O
207 O
features O
) O
. O

A O
full O
description O
of O
the O
k O
means O
procedure O
is O
given O
in O
the O
supplementary O
materials O
Section O
2 O
. O

Each O
cluster O
was O
equally O
represented O
in O
patient O
and O
controls O
groups O
( O
supplementary O
materials O
Table O
2.1 O
) O
. O

Confounding O
factors O
Group O
characteristics O
suggested O
a O
significant O
difference O
in O
the O
proportions O
of O
left O
and O
right O
handed O
participants O
( O
Fischer O
's O
Exact O
Test O
, O
p O
= O
0.012 O
) O
. O

As O
some O
cell O
counts O
would O
be O
too O
small O
to O
enter O
as O
a O
covariate O
in O
a O
logistic O
regression O
the O
results O
were O
instead O
repeated O
including O
only O
right O
handed O
participants O
. O

In O
addition O
, O
the O
analysis O
was O
repeated O
using O
overlapping O
windows O
( O
in O
steps O
of O
1 O
TR O
) O
, O
as O
previous O
studies O
have O
used O
both O
overlapping O
/ O
non O
overlapping O
windows O
. O

It O
is O
also O
the O
case O
that O
complex O
measures O
such O
as O
flexibility O
may O
be O
explained O
by O
simpler O
network O
characteristics O
. O

The O
current O
study O
tested O
whether O
the O
mean O
number O
of O
communities O
in O
time O
windows O
and O
the O
mean O
of O
time O
windowed O
correlation O
matrices O
were O
mediators O
in O
the O
relationship O
between O
group O
assignment O
and O
flexibility O
. O

Ethics O
statement O
The O
COBRE O
( O
The O
Centre O
for O
Biomedical O
Research O
Excellence O
) O
dataset O
was O
obtained O
through O
the O
International O
Neuroimaging O
Data-sharing O
Initiative O
( O
http O
: O
//fcon_1000.projects.nitrc.org/indi/retro/cobre.html O
) O
. O

This O
was O
originally O
released O
under O
Creative O
Commons O
– O
Attribution O
Non-Commercial O
. O

Written O
informed O
consent O
was O
obtained O
for O
all O
participants O
. O

Code O
availability O
In O
order O
to O
aid O
reproducibility O
and O
transparency O
, O
tailor O
made O
scripts O
used O
in O
this O
study O
have O
been O
made O
available O
( O
https O
: O
//github.com/george-gifford/COBRE_multilayer_community O
) O
. O

Statistical O
analysis O
was O
performed O
using O
R O
version O
3.5.1 O
. O

The O
current O
study O
used O
a O
Matlab O
version O
9.2.0. O
when O
implementing O
the O
GenLouvain O
multilayer O
community O
detection O
algorithm O
, O
which O
is O
currently O
available O
from O
( O
netwiki.amath.unc.edu/GenLouvain/GenLouvain O
) O
. O

Reduced O
Resting-State O
Connectivity O
in O
the O
Precuneus O
is O
correlated O
with O
Apathy O
in O
Patients O
with O
Schizophrenia O
A O
diagnosis O
of O
schizophrenia O
is O
associated O
with O
a O
heterogeneous O
psychopathology O
including O
positive O
and O
negative O
symptoms O
. O

The O
disconnection O
hypothesis O
, O
an O
early O
pathophysiological O
framework O
conceptualizes O
the O
diversity O
of O
symptoms O
as O
a O
result O
of O
disconnections O
in O
neural O
networks O
. O

In O
line O
with O
this O
hypothesis O
, O
previous O
neuroimaging O
studies O
of O
patients O
with O
schizophrenia O
reported O
alterations O
within O
the O
default O
mode O
network O
( O
DMN O
) O
, O
the O
most O
prominent O
network O
at O
rest O
. O

The O
aim O
of O
the O
present O
study O
was O
to O
investigate O
the O
functional O
connectivity O
during O
rest O
in O
patients O
with O
schizophrenia O
and O
with O
healthy O
individuals O
and O
explore O
whether O
observed O
functional O
alterations O
are O
related O
to O
the O
psychopathology O
of O
patients O
. O

Therefore O
, O
functional O
magnetic O
resonance O
images O
at O
rest O
were O
recorded O
of O
35 O
patients O
with O
schizophrenia O
and O
41 O
healthy O
individuals O
. O

Independent O
component O
analysis O
( O
ICA O
) O
was O
used O
to O
extract O
resting O
state O
networks O
. O

Comparing O
ICA O
results O
between O
groups O
indicated O
alterations O
only O
within O
the O
network O
of O
the O
DMN O
. O

More O
explicitly O
, O
reduced O
connectivity O
in O
the O
precuneus O
was O
observed O
in O
patients O
with O
schizophrenia O
compared O
to O
healthy O
controls O
. O

Connectivity O
in O
this O
area O
was O
negatively O
correlated O
with O
the O
severity O
of O
negative O
symptoms O
, O
more O
specifically O
with O
the O
domain O
of O
apathy O
. O

Taken O
together O
, O
the O
current O
results O
provide O
further O
evidence O
for O
a O
role O
DMN O
alterations O
might O
play O
in O
schizophrenia O
and O
especially O
in O
negative O
symptoms O
such O
as O
apathy O
. O

Methods O
Participants O
In O
total O
, O
76 O
participants O
were O
included O
in O
the O
reported O
analysis O
, O
of O
which O
41 O
were O
healthy O
individuals O
and O
of O
which O
35 O
individuals O
met O
the O
criteria O
for O
a O
diagnosis O
of O
schizophrenia O
following O
the O
International O
Classification O
for O
Diseases O
and O
Related O
Health O
Problems O
( O
ICD-10 O
) O
. O

Patients O
diagnosed O
with O
schizophrenia O
were O
recruited O
at O
St. O
Hedwig O
Hospital O
, O
Department O
for O
Psychiatry O
and O
Psychotherapy O
of O
the O
Charité-Universitätsmedizin O
Berlin O
( O
Germany O
) O
. O

Healthy O
individuals O
were O
recruited O
using O
online O
advertisements O
and O
flyers O
and O
did O
not O
meet O
the O
criteria O
for O
any O
psychiatric O
disorder O
based O
on O
information O
acquired O
with O
the O
Mini O
International O
Neuropsychiatric O
Interview O
( O
MINI O
) O
and O
were O
not O
in O
current O
or O
past O
psychotherapy O
of O
an O
ongoing O
mental O
health-related O
problem O
. O

MRI O
exclusion O
criteria O
such O
as O
claustrophobia O
, O
neurological O
disorders O
and O
metallic O
implants O
applied O
to O
all O
participants O
. O

Healthy O
individuals O
matched O
the O
group O
of O
patients O
in O
terms O
of O
age O
, O
sex O
, O
handedness O
and O
level O
of O
education O
( O
Table O
1 O
) O
. O

Handedness O
was O
acquired O
with O
Edinburgh O
Handedness O
Inventory O
( O
n O
= O
75 O
) O
, O
cognitive O
functioning O
was O
tested O
using O
the O
Brief O
Assessment O
of O
Cognition O
in O
Schizophrenia O
( O
n O
= O
65 O
) O
and O
verbal O
intelligence O
with O
a O
German O
Vocabulary O
Test O
( O
n O
= O
72 O
) O
. O

Supplemental O
information O
provides O
details O
regarding O
the O
medication O
of O
patients O
. O

All O
procedures O
of O
the O
study O
were O
approved O
by O
the O
ethics O
committee O
of O
the O
Charité-Universitätsmedizin O
Berlin O
. O

All O
subjects O
gave O
written O
informed O
consent O
in O
accordance O
with O
the O
Declaration O
of O
Helsinki O
. O

Assessment O
of O
psychopathology O
Trained O
clinicians O
rated O
the O
severity O
of O
symptoms O
with O
the O
Scale O
for O
Assessment O
of O
Negative O
Symptoms O
( O
SANS O
) O
and O
the O
Scale O
for O
Assessment O
of O
Positive O
Symptoms O
( O
SAPS O
) O
. O

Table O
1 O
includes O
details O
of O
patients O
’ O
psychopathology O
. O

The O
SANS O
assesses O
negative O
symptoms O
within O
the O
domains O
of O
affective O
blunting O
, O
alogia O
, O
avolition-apathy O
, O
anhedonia-asociality O
, O
attentional O
impairment O
and O
the O
SAPS O
assesses O
positive O
symptoms O
in O
the O
domains O
of O
hallucinations O
, O
delusions O
, O
bizarre O
behavior O
, O
and O
positive O
formal O
thought O
disorder O
. O

Both O
scales O
rate O
severity O
of O
symptoms O
on O
a O
scale O
from O
0 O
( O
absent O
) O
to O
5 O
( O
severe O
) O
. O

For O
both O
scales O
a O
composite O
score O
of O
all O
items O
was O
computed O
. O

Additionally O
, O
both O
scales O
contain O
a O
global O
assessment O
item O
of O
each O
subdomain O
. O

MRI O
data O
acquisition O
Images O
were O
collected O
on O
a O
Siemens O
Tim O
Trio O
3 O
T O
scanner O
( O
Erlangen O
, O
Germany O
) O
using O
a O
12-channel O
head O
coil O
. O

Structural O
images O
were O
obtained O
using O
a O
T1-weighted O
magnetization O
prepared O
gradient-echo O
sequence O
( O
MPRAGE O
) O
based O
on O
the O
ADNI O
protocol O
( O
TR O
= O
2500 O
ms O
; O
TE O
= O
4.77 O
ms O
; O
TI O
= O
1100 O
ms O
, O
acquisition O
matrix O
= O
256 O
× O
256 O
× O
176 O
; O
flip O
angle O
= O
7° O
; O
1 O
× O
1 O
× O
1 O
mm3 O
voxel O
size O
) O
. O

Whole O
brain O
functional O
resting O
state O
images O
during O
5 O
minutes O
were O
collected O
using O
a O
T2 O
* O
-weighted O
EPI O
sequence O
sensitive O
to O
BOLD O
contrast O
( O
TR O
= O
2000 O
ms O
, O
TE O
= O
30 O
ms O
, O
image O
matrix O
= O
64 O
× O
64 O
, O
FOV O
= O
216 O
mm O
, O
flip O
angle O
= O
80° O
, O
slice O
thickness O
= O
3.0 O
mm O
, O
distance O
factor O
= O
20 O
% O
, O
voxel O
size O
3 O
× O
3 O
× O
3 O
mm3 O
, O
36 O
axial O
slices O
) O
. O

Before O
resting O
state O
data O
acquisition O
was O
started O
, O
participants O
were O
in O
the O
scanner O
for O
about O
10 O
minutes O
, O
during O
which O
a O
localizer O
and O
anatomical O
images O
were O
acquired O
so O
that O
subjects O
could O
get O
used O
to O
the O
scanner O
noise O
. O

During O
resting O
state O
data O
acquisition O
, O
participants O
were O
asked O
to O
close O
their O
eyes O
and O
relax O
. O

Preprocessing O
of O
resting O
state O
data O
To O
ensure O
for O
steady-state O
longitudinal O
magnetization O
, O
the O
first O
5 O
images O
were O
discarded O
. O

The O
acquired O
data O
was O
corrected O
for O
slice O
timing O
and O
realigned O
. O

Structural O
individual O
T1 O
images O
were O
coregistered O
to O
functional O
images O
and O
segmented O
into O
gray O
matter O
, O
white O
matter O
, O
and O
cerebrospinal O
fluid O
. O

Data O
was O
then O
spatially O
normalized O
to O
the O
MNI O
template O
and O
spatially O
smoothed O
with O
a O
6-mm O
FWHM O
to O
improve O
signal-to-noise O
ratio O
. O

All O
steps O
of O
data O
preprocessing O
were O
performed O
using O
SPM12 O
. O

In O
addition O
, O
to O
control O
for O
motion O
, O
we O
used O
the O
voxel-specific O
mean O
frame-wise O
displacement O
( O
FD O
) O
. O

FD O
values O
were O
below O
the O
default O
threshold O
of O
0.5 O
for O
control O
and O
patient O
group O
( O
0.15 O
± O
0.02 O
and O
0.17 O
± O
0.02 O
, O
t-test O
p O
= O
0.42 O
) O
. O

Independent O
component O
analysis O
( O
ICA O
) O
ICA O
is O
a O
data-driven O
analysis O
tool O
in O
which O
source O
signals O
are O
blindly O
recovered O
from O
mixtures O
of O
sources O
. O

ICA O
was O
calculated O
using O
GIFT O
software O
( O
http O
: O
//icatb.sourceforge.net/ O
) O
in O
Matlab O
2012b O
using O
Infomax O
algorithm O
to O
estimate O
independent O
sources O
. O

ICA O
was O
run O
20 O
times O
and O
the O
results O
were O
clustered O
by O
GIFT O
toolbox O
ICASSO O
min O
cluster O
size O
of O
16 O
and O
max O
of O
20 O
( O
number O
of O
runs O
) O
and O
RandInit O
and O
Bootstrap O
were O
selected O
. O

Preprocessed O
data O
from O
all O
subjects O
in O
both O
groups O
were O
used O
. O

The O
optimal O
number O
of O
spatially O
independent O
resting-state O
networks O
( O
N O
) O
to O
be O
extracted O
was O
estimated O
by O
the O
software O
( O
N O
= O
21 O
; O
see O
Supplemental O
Material O
Fig O
. O

S1 O
) O
. O

Only O
components O
with O
ICASO O
stability O
index O
Iq O
of O
> O
0.9 O
were O
considered O
and O
the O
related O
spatial O
maps O
. O

The O
networks O
were O
identified O
using O
predefined O
templates O
in O
GIFT O
and O
a-posteriori O
by O
experts O
C.G.F O
and O
S.K O
. O

Among O
the O
ICA O
components O
, O
the O
default O
mode O
network O
was O
identified O
and O
taken O
to O
the O
second O
level O
analysis O
in O
SPM12 O
using O
a O
mask O
for O
individual O
networks O
provided O
by O
http O
: O
//findlab.stanford.edu/functional_ROIs.html O
. O

To O
make O
use O
of O
the O
full O
potentiality O
of O
the O
method O
, O
we O
conducted O
an O
exploratory O
analysis O
selecting O
the O
following O
networks O
that O
were O
concomitantly O
extracted O
by O
ICA O
( O
Fig O
. O

S1 O
in O
Supplemental O
Material O
) O
: O
basal O
ganglia O
, O
visual O
, O
salience O
, O
auditory O
, O
executive O
control O
, O
and O
visuospatial O
. O

Differences O
between O
groups O
were O
calculated O
using O
a O
two-sample O
t-test O
( O
p O
= O
0.001 O
uncorrected O
) O
, O
significant O
threshold O
was O
set O
to O
p O
< O
0.05 O
corrected O
for O
multiple O
comparison O
using O
family O
wise O
error O
( O
FWE O
) O
at O
cluster-level O
. O

Mean O
FD O
, O
gender O
and O
age O
were O
used O
as O
covariates O
. O

In O
those O
clusters O
where O
we O
found O
significant O
group O
differences O
, O
we O
extracted O
the O
mean O
absolute O
ICA O
values O
( O
spatial O
maps O
) O
for O
each O
subject O
for O
a O
posteriori O
correlation O
analysis O
of O
functional O
connectivity O
with O
psychopathology O
. O

Correlation O
with O
psychopathology O
To O
investigate O
whether O
these O
differences O
in O
resting O
state O
networks O
between O
healthy O
individuals O
and O
patients O
with O
schizophrenia O
were O
related O
to O
the O
psychopathology O
of O
patients O
, O
Spearman O
’ O
s O
correlation O
coefficients O
between O
resting O
state O
network O
connectivity O
and O
severity O
of O
symptoms O
were O
calculated O
. O

The O
resting O
state O
functional O
connectivity O
was O
extracted O
from O
the O
cluster O
in O
the O
DMN O
in O
which O
we O
found O
group O
differences O
: O
for O
each O
subject O
we O
extracted O
the O
mean O
absolute O
ICA O
value O
( O
spatial O
maps O
) O
. O

In O
a O
first O
step O
, O
we O
correlated O
the O
functional O
connectivity O
in O
the O
DMN O
cluster O
with O
the O
composite O
scores O
of O
the O
SANS O
and O
SAPS O
. O

In O
case O
of O
a O
significant O
correlation O
, O
we O
conducted O
further O
exploratory O
correlations O
with O
the O
global O
ratings O
of O
the O
associated O
symptom O
domains O
. O

Statistical O
analysis O
was O
performed O
using O
SPSS O
22 O
. O

For O
the O
correlation O
with O
the O
SAPS O
and O
SANS O
composite O
scores O
, O
a O
Bonferroni O
adjusted O
significance O
level O
of O
0.025 O
( O
0.05/2 O
) O
was O
applied O
. O

For O
the O
correlations O
with O
subdomains O
we O
used O
a O
Bonferroni O
corrected O
alpha O
value O
of O
0.0125 O
( O
0.05/4 O
) O
for O
the O
SAPS O
and O
of O
0.01 O
( O
0.05/5 O
) O
for O
the O
SANS O
. O

Reduced O
Parietal O
Alpha O
Power O
and O
Psychotic O
Symptoms O
: O
Test-Retest O
Reliability O
of O
Resting-State O
Magnetoencephalography O
in O
Schizophrenia O
and O
Healthy O
Controls O
Background O
: O
Despite O
increased O
reporting O
of O
resting-state O
magnetoencephalography O
( O
MEG O
) O
, O
reliability O
of O
those O
measures O
remains O
scarce O
and O
predominately O
reported O
in O
healthy O
controls O
( O
HC O
) O
. O

As O
such O
, O
there O
is O
limited O
knowledge O
on O
MEG O
resting-state O
reliability O
in O
schizophrenia O
( O
SZ O
) O
. O

Methods O
: O
To O
address O
test-retest O
reliability O
in O
psychosis O
, O
a O
reproducibility O
study O
of O
26 O
participants O
( O
13-SZ O
, O
13-HC O
) O
was O
performed O
. O

We O
collected O
eyes O
open O
and O
eyes O
closed O
resting-state O
data O
during O
4 O
separate O
instances O
( O
2 O
Visits O
, O
2 O
runs O
per O
visit O
) O
to O
estimate O
spectral O
power O
reliability O
( O
power O
, O
normalized O
power O
, O
alpha O
reactivity O
) O
across O
one O
hour O
and O
one O
week O
. O

Intraclass O
correlation O
coefficients O
( O
ICCs O
) O
were O
calculated O
. O

For O
source O
modeling O
, O
we O
applied O
an O
anatomically O
constrained O
linear O
estimation O
inverse O
model O
known O
as O
dynamic O
statistical O
parametric O
mapping O
( O
MNE O
dSPM O
) O
and O
source-based O
connectivity O
using O
the O
weighted O
phase O
lag O
index O
. O

Results O
: O
Across O
one O
week O
there O
was O
excellent O
test-retest O
reliability O
in O
global O
spectral O
measures O
in O
theta-gamma O
bands O
( O
HC O
ICCAvg=0.87 O
, O
SZ O
ICCAvg=0.87 O
) O
, O
regional O
spectral O
measures O
in O
all O
bands O
( O
HC O
ICCAvg=0.86 O
, O
SZ O
ICCAvg=0.80 O
) O
, O
and O
parietal O
alpha O
measures O
( O
HC O
ICCAvg=0.90 O
, O
SZ O
ICCAvg=0.84 O
) O
. O

Conversely O
, O
functional O
connectivity O
had O
poor O
reliability O
, O
as O
did O
source O
spectral O
power O
across O
one O
hour O
for O
SZ O
. O

Relative O
to O
HC O
, O
SZ O
also O
had O
reduced O
parietal O
alpha O
normalized O
power O
during O
eyes O
closed O
only O
, O
reduced O
alpha O
reactivity O
, O
and O
an O
association O
between O
higher O
PANSS O
positive O
scores O
and O
lower O
parietal O
alpha O
power O
. O

Conclusions O
: O
There O
was O
excellent O
to O
good O
test-retest O
reliability O
in O
most O
MEG O
spectral O
measures O
with O
a O
few O
exceptions O
in O
the O
schizophrenia O
patient O
group O
. O

Overall O
, O
these O
findings O
encourage O
the O
use O
of O
resting-state O
MEG O
while O
emphasizing O
the O
importance O
of O
determining O
reliability O
in O
clinical O
populations O
. O

Materials O
and O
Methods O
Participants O
The O
current O
study O
included O
13 O
individuals O
diagnosed O
with O
schizophrenia O
( O
SZ O
) O
and O
13 O
healthy O
controls O
( O
HC O
) O
, O
age O
and O
gender O
matched O
, O
Table O
1 O
. O

Informed O
consent O
was O
obtained O
from O
all O
participants O
according O
to O
institutional O
guidelines O
. O

The O
study O
was O
approved O
by O
the O
University O
of O
New O
Mexico O
Health O
Sciences O
Center O
Human O
Research O
Review O
Committee O
. O

All O
participants O
were O
within O
21–49 O
years O
of O
age O
with O
no O
history O
of O
neurological O
disorder O
( O
e.g O
. O

epilepsy O
) O
, O
no O
history O
of O
major O
head O
trauma O
( O
loss O
of O
consciousness O
> O
5 O
min O
) O
, O
no O
current O
substance O
abuse O
diagnosis O
( O
excluding O
nicotine O
) O
, O
no O
current O
dependence/abuse O
of O
PCP/amphetamine/cocaine O
within O
the O
past O
12 O
months O
, O
and O
were O
not O
currently O
on O
mood O
stabilizers O
such O
as O
lithium O
or O
valproic O
acid O
. O

HC O
had O
IQ O
scores O
within O
the O
normal O
range O
and O
no O
history O
of O
developmental O
delays O
or O
neurological O
or O
psychiatric O
disorders O
based O
on O
the O
Structured O
Clinical O
Interview O
for O
DSM-IV-Non-patient O
( O
SCIDNP O
) O
. O

HCs O
also O
did O
not O
have O
a O
family O
history O
of O
a O
psychotic O
disorder O
in O
first-degree O
relatives O
or O
a O
history O
of O
more O
than O
1 O
lifetime O
depressive O
episode O
. O

Participants O
with O
schizophrenia O
were O
confirmed O
to O
have O
a O
DSM-IV-TR O
diagnosis O
of O
schizophrenia O
with O
the O
Structured O
Clinical O
Interview O
for O
DSM-IV-Patient O
( O
SCID-IP O
) O
and O
retrospective O
clinical O
stability O
. O

Participants O
were O
not O
excluded O
for O
nicotine O
use O
, O
however O
, O
they O
were O
not O
allowed O
to O
smoke O
within O
1 O
hour O
of O
the O
MEG O
session O
or O
be O
more O
than O
5 O
hours O
from O
their O
previous O
cigarette O
to O
avoid O
confounds O
of O
acute O
nicotine O
exposure O
or O
withdrawal O
. O

The O
following O
assessments O
were O
collected O
in O
SZ O
participants O
and O
reported O
in O
Table O
1 O
: O
Wechsler O
Test O
of O
Adult O
Reading O
( O
WTAR O
) O
, O
Standard O
and O
Predicted O
( O
premorbid O
) O
IQ O
, O
Positive O
and O
Negative O
Syndrome O
Scale O
( O
PANSS O
) O
, O
antipsychotic O
medication O
dose O
information O
, O
and O
duration O
of O
illness O
. O

PANSS O
scores O
were O
determined O
for O
each O
visit O
. O

Antipsychotic O
medication O
was O
converted O
to O
olanzapine O
equivalents O
for O
comparison O
between O
medication O
. O

Duration O
of O
illness O
was O
calculated O
by O
subtracting O
age O
at O
onset O
of O
psychotic O
symptoms O
from O
current O
age O
. O

MEG O
Behavioral O
Tasks O
All O
participants O
had O
two O
visits O
across O
7 O
days O
[ O
HC=7.54 O
days O
±60 O
minutes O
, O
SZ=7.84 O
days O
±51 O
minutes O
] O
. O

Time O
of O
day O
between O
visits O
was O
matched O
to O
take O
into O
account O
circadian O
rhythm O
. O

Each O
visit O
began O
with O
a O
10-minute O
rest O
task O
( O
referred O
to O
as O
Rest10 O
) O
and O
ended O
with O
a O
4-minute O
rest O
task O
( O
referred O
to O
as O
Rest4 O
) O
, O
see O
Figure O
1 O
. O

No O
responses O
were O
required O
from O
the O
participant O
; O
however O
, O
participants O
were O
instructed O
to O
attend O
the O
instructions O
for O
prompts O
to O
close O
their O
eyes O
or O
fixate O
on O
a O
white O
cross O
. O

Each O
task O
alternated O
between O
EC O
and O
EO O
. O

In O
total O
, O
resting-state O
activity O
was O
recorded O
4 O
separate O
times O
with O
14 O
minutes O
of O
EO O
and O
14 O
minutes O
of O
EC O
. O

MEG O
Data O
Acquisition O
MEG O
data O
were O
collected O
in O
a O
magnetically O
shielded O
room O
( O
Vacuumschmelze O
– O
Ak3B O
) O
at O
the O
Mind O
Research O
Network O
in O
Albuquerque O
, O
New O
Mexico O
using O
a O
306-channel O
whole-head O
MEG O
system O
( O
Elekta O
Neuromag O
) O
with O
a O
sampling O
rate O
of O
1000 O
Hz O
and O
an O
antialiasing O
filter O
with O
a O
passband O
of O
0.1–330 O
Hz O
. O

Prior O
to O
data O
acquisition O
, O
four O
electromagnetic O
coils O
were O
placed O
on O
the O
participant O
’ O
s O
mastoid O
bone O
and O
upper O
forehead O
, O
along O
with O
electro-oculogram O
and O
electrocardiogram O
channels O
. O

The O
location O
of O
the O
coils O
were O
registered O
to O
the O
nasion O
and O
preauricular O
points O
using O
three-dimensional O
digitization O
equipment O
( O
Polhemus O
FastTrack O
) O
. O

Participants O
sat O
upright O
in O
the O
MEG O
during O
the O
task O
. O

Continuous O
Head O
Position O
Indicator O
( O
cHPI O
) O
monitoring O
allowed O
for O
motion O
correction O
. O

Head O
position O
was O
checked O
between O
visits O
. O

For O
the O
Rest10 O
task O
, O
average O
Euclidean O
distance O
between O
visits O
was O
4.62 O
mm O
for O
HC O
and O
6.06 O
mm O
for O
SZ O
. O

For O
the O
Rest4 O
task O
, O
the O
distance O
was O
4.90 O
mm O
for O
HC O
and O
6.12 O
mm O
for O
SZ O
. O

Head O
position O
consistency O
was O
similar O
between O
HC O
and O
SZ O
( O
all O
p O
’ O
s O
> O
0.31 O
) O
. O

Structural O
MRI O
Data O
Acquisition O
Structural O
MRIs O
were O
obtained O
for O
mapping O
source O
locations O
. O

Sagittal O
T1-weighted O
anatomical O
MR O
images O
were O
obtained O
using O
a O
Siemens O
TIM O
Trio O
3 O
Tesla O
MRI O
system O
with O
a O
32-channel O
head O
coil O
. O

Parameters O
of O
the O
multiecho O
3D O
MPRAGE O
sequence O
were O
: O
TR/TE/TI O
= O
2530/1.64 O
, O
3.5 O
, O
5.36 O
, O
7.22 O
, O
9.08/1200 O
ms O
, O
flip O
angle O
= O
7° O
, O
field O
of O
view O
( O
FOV O
) O
= O
256 O
mm O
x O
256 O
mm O
, O
matrix O
= O
256 O
× O
256 O
, O
1 O
mm O
thick O
slice O
, O
192 O
slices O
, O
GRAPPA O
acceleration O
= O
2 O
. O

MEG O
Data O
Preprocessing O
Raw O
MEG O
data O
were O
filtered O
for O
noise O
and O
corrected O
for O
head O
motion O
with O
the O
Neuromag O
Max-Filter O
2.2 O
software O
using O
the O
temporal O
extension O
of O
signal O
space O
separation O
( O
t-SSS O
) O
method O
with O
movement O
compensation O
. O

MEG O
data O
from O
each O
subject O
’ O
s O
Visit O
2 O
was O
transformed O
to O
Visit O
1 O
head O
position O
using O
Maxfilter O
2.2 O
MaxMove O
option O
to O
ensure O
equivalent O
sensor O
locations O
between O
visits O
. O

No O
downsampling O
of O
the O
data O
was O
implemented O
at O
the O
preprocessing O
stage O
. O

Heartbeat O
and O
eye-blink O
artifacts O
were O
automatically O
detected O
and O
removed O
using O
signal O
space O
projection O
( O
SSP O
) O
in O
MNE O
software O
. O

The O
continuous O
data O
were O
segmented O
into O
artifact-free O
2 O
second O
epochs O
. O

Epochs O
in O
which O
the O
magnetic O
field O
exceeded O
5 O
pT O
were O
rejected O
. O

HC O
had O
2.4 O
% O
and O
SZ O
had O
4.6 O
% O
of O
all O
epochs O
rejected O
. O

The O
total O
number O
of O
epochs O
used O
for O
further O
analysis O
included O
401 O
EC O
, O
402 O
EO O
epochs O
in O
HC O
, O
and O
393 O
EC O
, O
403 O
EO O
epochs O
in O
SZ O
. O

The O
number O
of O
closed/open O
epochs O
did O
not O
differ O
between O
groups O
( O
all O
p O
’ O
s O
> O
0.25 O
) O
. O

MEG O
Spectral O
Analyses O
For O
sensor O
analysis O
, O
we O
applied O
the O
summary O
spectral O
measures O
described O
in O
to O
simplify O
multi-channel O
MEG O
spectral O
data O
. O

Using O
only O
planar O
gradiometers O
, O
the O
sensor O
array O
was O
divided O
into O
left O
and O
right O
equivalent O
regions O
, O
see O
Figure O
2 O
. O

Spectral O
power O
was O
estimated O
using O
Matlab O
’ O
s O
FFT O
function O
with O
a O
window O
size O
of O
2048 O
for O
the O
following O
frequency O
bands O
: O
Delta O
( O
1–4 O
Hz O
) O
, O
Theta O
( O
5–8 O
Hz O
) O
, O
Alpha O
( O
9–13 O
Hz O
) O
, O
Beta O
( O
14–29 O
Hz O
) O
, O
and O
Gamma O
( O
31–58 O
Hz O
) O
. O

Spectral O
measures O
included O
: O
power O
, O
normalized O
power O
, O
half-power O
, O
Shannon O
Spectral O
Entropy O
( O
SSE O
) O
, O
and O
alpha O
reactivity O
. O

Normalized O
power O
was O
obtained O
by O
dividing O
the O
power O
within O
the O
frequency O
band O
by O
total O
1–50 O
Hz O
power O
. O

Half O
power O
was O
defined O
as O
the O
midpoint O
frequency O
where O
half O
of O
the O
power O
is O
below/above O
for O
the O
1–50 O
Hz O
range O
and O
indicates O
overall O
spectral O
power O
shifts O
from O
low O
to O
high O
frequencies O
. O

Alpha O
reactivity O
was O
calculated O
using O
normalized O
spectral O
power O
values O
with O
the O
following O
: O
( O
EC-EO O
) O
/EO O
. O

Global O
measures O
were O
the O
average O
of O
all O
regions O
and O
gradiometers O
. O

For O
source O
analysis O
, O
the O
cortical O
surface O
of O
each O
participant O
was O
reconstructed O
from O
T1-weighted O
MRI O
files O
using O
FreeSurfer O
with O
a O
repeatedly O
subdivided O
octahedron O
as O
the O
spatial O
subsampling O
method O
, O
creating O
4,098 O
locations O
per O
hemisphere O
with O
a O
source O
space O
of O
4.9 O
mm O
. O

Source O
analysis O
was O
performed O
with O
MNE O
software O
using O
an O
anatomically O
constrained O
linear O
estimation O
inverse O
model O
known O
as O
dynamic O
statistical O
parametric O
mapping O
( O
dSPM O
) O
. O

The O
regularization O
parameter O
corresponded O
with O
a O
signal-to-noise O
ratio O
of O
3 O
. O

Source O
orientation O
had O
a O
loose O
constraint O
of O
0.2 O
. O

The O
forward O
solution O
was O
calculated O
with O
a O
single O
layer O
( O
inner O
skull O
) O
boundary O
element O
method O
. O

The O
dSPM O
inverse O
model O
identified O
where O
the O
estimated O
current O
at O
each O
cortical O
surface O
vertex O
differed O
significantly O
from O
baseline O
noise O
( O
empty O
room O
data O
) O
. O

Power O
spectral O
density O
( O
PSD O
) O
measures O
were O
computed O
from O
epochs O
using O
a O
multi-taper O
method O
with O
Discrete O
Prolate O
Spheroidal O
Sequence O
( O
DPSS O
) O
windows O
for O
each O
frequency O
band O
and O
region O
, O
using O
7 O
tapers O
at O
4 O
Hz O
and O
regions O
of O
interest O
based O
on O
the O
FreeSurfer O
DKT O
atlas O
. O

PSD O
represents O
the O
average O
spectral O
power O
derived O
from O
each O
voxel O
time O
series O
for O
each O
regional O
label O
. O

Global O
measures O
were O
data O
from O
all O
regional O
labels O
averaged O
. O

Normalized O
power O
was O
obtained O
by O
dividing O
the O
power O
within O
frequency O
band O
by O
the O
total O
1–58 O
Hz O
power O
. O

Functional O
network O
connectivity O
was O
estimated O
using O
a O
debiased O
estimator O
of O
the O
squared O
weighted O
phase O
lag O
index O
( O
wPLI-debiased O
) O
. O

The O
FNC O
measure O
, O
wPLI-debiased O
, O
detects O
true O
changes O
in O
phase-synchronization O
, O
while O
reducing O
the O
influence O
of O
common O
noise O
sources O
, O
changes O
in O
phase O
of O
coherency O
, O
and O
avoids O
spuriously O
increases O
by O
volume-conduction O
. O

It O
estimates O
the O
extent O
of O
observed O
phase O
leads O
and O
lags O
by O
the O
magnitude O
of O
the O
imaginary O
component O
of O
the O
cross-spectrum O
. O

All O
data O
were O
exported O
to O
MATLAB O
( O
2018a O
, O
MathWorks O
) O
and O
run O
through O
custom O
scripts O
. O

Intraclass O
Correlation O
( O
ICC O
) O
ICC O
estimates O
and O
their O
95 O
% O
confidence O
intervals O
were O
calculated O
in O
SPSS O
to O
assess O
the O
between O
and O
within-subject O
variability O
using O
a O
two-way O
mixed O
effects O
model O
with O
absolute O
agreement O
, O
single O
measurement O
criteria O
, O
also O
known O
as O
ICC O
( O
3,1 O
) O
model O
. O

ICCs O
were O
calculated O
for O
multiple O
rest O
iterations O
: O
for O
each O
visit O
( O
across O
one O
hour O
) O
, O
for O
each O
task O
( O
across O
one O
week O
) O
and O
for O
all O
runs O
. O

ICCs O
ranged O
from O
0 O
to O
1 O
( O
negative O
values O
scored O
as O
zero O
) O
with O
higher O
values O
indicating O
better O
reliability O
. O

Following O
the O
guidelines O
of O
we O
defined O
ICCs O
as O
: O
excellent O
reliability O
> O
0.75 O
, O
good O
reliability O
0.75–0.60 O
, O
fair O
reliability O
0.59–0.40 O
, O
and O
poor O
reliability O
< O
0.40 O
. O

Statistical O
Analysis O
All O
statistics O
were O
performed O
using O
SPSS O
( O
version O
25 O
for O
Macintosh O
) O
. O

Mixed O
Effect O
Repeated O
Measures-Analysis O
of O
Variance O
( O
RM-ANOVAs O
) O
had O
statistical O
thresholds O
set O
at O
p O
< O
0.05 O
. O

Greenhouse-Geisser O
corrections O
were O
made O
for O
sphericity O
violations O
. O

The O
between-subject O
factor O
was O
Group O
( O
HC O
, O
SZ O
) O
, O
within-subject O
factors O
included O
Hemisphere O
( O
Left O
, O
Right O
) O
, O
Resting-State O
( O
EO O
, O
EC O
) O
, O
and/or O
Region O
[ O
Superior O
Parietal O
( O
SupPar O
) O
, O
Inferior O
Parietal O
( O
InfPar O
) O
, O
Precuneus O
] O
depending O
on O
measure O
explored O
. O

Significant O
interactions O
were O
followed-up O
with O
separate O
one-way O
ANOVAs O
, O
or O
t-tests O
on O
the O
factors O
of O
interest O
with O
familywise O
multiple O
comparisons O
correction O
using O
false O
discovery O
rate O
( O
FDR O
) O
correction O
with O
q=0.05 O
. O

Brain O
morphological O
and O
functional O
features O
in O
cognitive O
subgroups O
of O
schizophrenia O
Aim O
Previous O
studies O
have O
reported O
different O
brain O
morphologies O
in O
different O
cognitive O
subgroups O
of O
patients O
with O
schizophrenia O
. O

We O
aimed O
to O
examine O
the O
brain O
structures O
and O
functional O
connectivity O
in O
these O
cognitive O
subgroups O
of O
schizophrenia O
. O

Methods O
We O
compared O
brain O
structures O
among O
healthy O
controls O
and O
cognitively O
deteriorated O
and O
preserved O
subgroups O
of O
patients O
with O
schizophrenia O
according O
to O
the O
decline O
in O
IQ O
. O

Connectivity O
analyses O
between O
subcortical O
regions O
and O
other O
brain O
areas O
were O
performed O
using O
resting‐state O
functional O
magnetic O
resonance O
imaging O
among O
the O
groups O
. O

Results O
Whole O
brain O
and O
total O
cortical O
gray O
matter O
, O
right O
fusiform O
gyrus O
, O
left O
pars O
orbitalis O
gyrus O
, O
right O
pars O
triangularis O
, O
left O
superior O
temporal O
gyrus O
and O
left O
insula O
volumes O
, O
and O
bilateral O
cortical O
thickness O
were O
decreased O
in O
the O
deteriorated O
group O
compared O
to O
the O
control O
and O
preserved O
groups O
. O

Both O
schizophrenia O
subgroups O
had O
increased O
left O
lateral O
ventricle O
, O
right O
putamen O
and O
left O
pallidum O
, O
and O
decreased O
bilateral O
hippocampus O
, O
left O
precentral O
gyrus O
, O
right O
rostral O
middle O
frontal O
gyrus O
, O
and O
bilateral O
superior O
frontal O
gyrus O
volumes O
compared O
with O
controls O
. O

Hyperconnectivity O
between O
the O
thalamus O
and O
a O
broad O
range O
of O
brain O
regions O
was O
observed O
in O
the O
deteriorated O
group O
compared O
to O
connectivity O
in O
the O
control O
group O
, O
and O
this O
hyperconnectivity O
was O
less O
evident O
in O
the O
preserved O
group O
. O

We O
also O
found O
hyperconnectivity O
between O
the O
accumbens O
and O
the O
superior O
and O
middle O
frontal O
gyri O
in O
the O
preserved O
group O
compared O
with O
connectivity O
in O
the O
deteriorated O
group O
. O

Conclusion O
These O
findings O
provide O
evidence O
of O
prominent O
structural O
and O
functional O
brain O
abnormalities O
in O
deteriorated O
patients O
with O
schizophrenia O
, O
suggesting O
that O
cognitive O
subgroups O
in O
schizophrenia O
might O
be O
useful O
biotypes O
to O
elucidate O
brain O
pathophysiology O
for O
new O
diagnostic O
and O
treatment O
strategies O
. O

Methods O
Participants O
The O
subjects O
consisted O
of O
171 O
patients O
with O
schizophrenia O
( O
60 O
for O
brain O
connectivity O
analysis O
) O
and O
633 O
HC O
( O
234 O
for O
brain O
connectivity O
analysis O
) O
. O

Diagnostic O
and O
exclusion O
criteria O
have O
been O
described O
previously.19 O
, O
25 O
Written O
informed O
consent O
was O
obtained O
from O
all O
subjects O
after O
the O
procedures O
had O
been O
fully O
explained O
. O

The O
study O
was O
performed O
in O
accordance O
with O
the O
World O
Medical O
Association O
's O
Declaration O
of O
Helsinki O
and O
was O
approved O
by O
the O
Research O
Ethical O
Committee O
of O
Osaka O
University O
. O

All O
participants O
provided O
written O
consent O
to O
the O
study O
after O
full O
explanation O
of O
the O
study O
procedures O
. O

Anonymity O
was O
preserved O
for O
all O
participants O
. O

Cognitive O
measures O
and O
other O
measures O
All O
participants O
were O
administered O
the O
full‐scale O
Wechsler O
Adult O
Intelligence O
Scale O
–III O
( O
WAIS‐III O
) O
26 O
to O
obtain O
their O
current O
IQ O
and O
the O
Japanese O
version O
of O
the O
National O
Adult O
Reading O
Test O
50 O
( O
JART O
) O
27 O
to O
obtain O
an O
estimated O
premorbid O
IQ O
score O
. O

The O
Wechsler O
Memory O
Scale O
– O
Revised28 O
was O
administered O
to O
assess O
the O
memory O
functioning O
of O
the O
participants O
. O

Current O
symptoms O
of O
schizophrenia O
were O
evaluated O
using O
the O
Positive O
and O
Negative O
Syndrome O
Scale O
( O
PANSS O
) O
.29 O
Daily O
doses O
of O
antipsychotics O
, O
expressed O
as O
the O
chlorpromazine O
equivalent O
( O
CPZeq O
) O
, O
in O
patients O
were O
calculated O
according O
to O
previous O
literature.30 O
Classification O
of O
IQ O
decline O
subgroups O
Based O
on O
previous O
findings,22 O
we O
classified O
patients O
with O
schizophrenia O
into O
three O
groups O
: O
( O
i O
) O
deteriorated O
, O
those O
displaying O
a O
meaningful O
decline O
in O
IQ O
( O
≥10 O
points O
) O
as O
evidenced O
by O
the O
difference O
between O
current O
IQ O
( O
based O
on O
the O
full‐scale O
IQ O
score O
of O
the O
WAIS‐III O
) O
and O
estimated O
premorbid O
IQ O
score O
( O
based O
on O
the O
JART O
score O
) O
; O
( O
ii O
) O
preserved O
, O
those O
having O
an O
estimated O
premorbid O
IQ O
score O
above O
90 O
and O
less O
than O
a O
10‐point O
difference O
between O
their O
estimated O
premorbid O
IQ O
and O
their O
current O
IQ O
; O
and O
( O
iii O
) O
compromised O
, O
those O
displaying O
an O
estimated O
premorbid O
IQ O
score O
below O
90 O
and O
less O
than O
a O
10‐point O
difference O
between O
their O
estimated O
premorbid O
IQ O
and O
their O
current O
IQ O
. O

The O
existence O
of O
a O
10‐point O
IQ O
decline O
took O
precedence O
over O
either O
of O
the O
cut‐off O
strategies O
described O
. O

The O
numbers O
in O
each O
group O
were O
as O
follows O
: O
deteriorated O
, O
n O
= O
111 O
( O
65 O
% O
) O
; O
preserved O
, O
n O
= O
54 O
( O
32 O
% O
) O
; O
and O
compromised O
, O
n O
= O
6 O
( O
4 O
% O
) O
( O
Fig O
. O

S1 O
) O
. O

As O
the O
compromised O
group O
was O
too O
small O
( O
n O
= O
6 O
) O
, O
we O
excluded O
this O
group O
from O
the O
analysis O
. O

Statistical O
analysis O
for O
demographics O
and O
clinical O
characteristics O
Statistical O
analyses O
were O
performed O
using O

for O

Version O
24 O
( O
SPSS O
Japan O
Inc. O
, O
Tokyo O
, O
Japan O
) O
. O

Group O
comparisons O
of O
sex O
were O
performed O
using O
the O
χ2‐test O
. O

We O
performed O
t‐tests O
to O
compare O
clinical O
characteristics O
between O
preserved O
and O
deteriorated O
groups O
, O
and O

of O
variance O
( O
anova O
) O
was O
employed O
for O
comparisons O
of O
continuous O
variables O
, O
as O
appropriate O
. O

For O

statistical O
significance O
, O
we O
set O
the O
type O
I O
error O
rate O
( O
P‐value O
) O
at O
0.05 O
. O

Cohen O
's O
d O
effect O
sizes O
were O
calculated O
from O
the O
overall O
group O
contrast O
. O

Structural O
and O
functional O
imaging O
and O

and O

processing O

performed O

( O

with O

: O

. O

We O
scanned O
109 O

( O

; O

patients O
( O

; O

The O

for O

was O
a O

T O
, O
Signa O
EXCITE O
. O

images O
, O

: O

( O

, O

× O

of O

( O

= O

, O

. O

, O
Signa O
HDxt O
. O

T1‐weighted O
images O
, O

= O

ms O
, O

= O

, O

= O

degrees O
, O

= O
256 O
× O
256 O
× O

, O

= O
240 O
× O

× O
172 O
mm O
, O
voxel O
size O
= O
0.9375 O
× O
0.9375 O
× O
1 O
mm O
, O
slice O
thickness O
= O
1 O
mm O
, O
and O
number O
of O
slices O
= O

. O

The O
slice O
orientation O
was O
in O

plane O
. O

We O
performed O
structural O
image O
processing O
in O
the O
same O
way O
as O
that O
performed O
in O

previous O

18 O
, O
19 O
We O
checked O

T1‐weighted O
images O
through O
visual O
inspection O
for O
quality O
control O
. O

We O
excluded O
images O
with O
a O
low O
signal‐to‐noise O
ratio O
or O
any O
artifacts O
, O
those O
with O
partial O
deficits O
, O
and O
those O
with O
any O
abnormal O
organic O
findings O
. O

Next O
, O
we O
processed O
T1‐weighted O
imaging O
data O
that O
had O
passed O
the O
first O
quality‐control O
step O
with O
FreeSurfer O
software O
version O
5.3 O
( O
http O
: O
//surfer.nmr.mgh.harvard.edu O
) O
.30 O
Through O
this O
procedure O
, O
we O
obtained O
images O
showing O
the O
subcortical O
segmentation O
and O
regional O
volumes O
( O
for O
the O

, O
amygdala O
, O

, O

accumbens O
, O

, O

, O

in O
both O
hemispheres O
, O
and O
the O
