volume O
[ O

] O
) O
. O

After O

, O
two O
independent O
researchers O
visually O
inspected O
each O
segmentation O
image O
to O
exclude O
images O
with O
poor O
segmentation O
. O

No O
subject O
was O
excluded O
due O
to O
the O
failure O
of O
FreeSurfer O
processing O
. O

After O
these O
two O
quality‐control O
steps O
, O
we O
obtained O
the O
raw O
subcortical O
volume O
data O
. O

The O
analytical O
methods O
used O
in O
the O
study O
by O
van O
Erp O
et O
al.16 O
from O
ENIGMA‐SZ O
were O
followed O
in O
this O
analysis O
. O

We O
employed O
the O
normalized O
regional O
volume O
to O
remove O
the O
effects O
of O
the O
confounding O
factors O
considering O
linear O
and O
nonlinear O

effects O
on O
subcortical O
regional O

as O
described O
previously.17 O
, O
18 O
, O
19 O
We O
also O
extracted O

thickness O
measures O
from O
both O
scanners O
using O
Freesurfer O
5.3 O
( O
http O
: O
//surfer.nmr.mgh.harvard.edu O
) O
. O

Cortical O
parcellations O
were O
created O
based O
on O
the O
Desikan–Killiany O
atlas O
, O
with O
a O
total O
of O
68 O
( O

34 O

) O
cortical O
gray O
matter O
regions O
. O

Hemispheric O
average O
cortical O
thicknesses O
were O
also O
calculated O
. O

Based O
on O
the O
standardized O
ENIGMA O
protocols O
( O
http O
: O
//enigma.ini.usc.edu/protocols/imaging-protocols O
) O
, O

were O

by O
three O
independent O
researchers O
and O
statistically O
evaluated O
for O
outliers O
. O

MRI O
scanning O
for O
resting‐state O
fMRI O
( O
rs‐fMRI O
) O
was O
performed O
on O
Osaka O
B O
, O
a O
GE O
3.0T O
Signa O
HDxt O
using O
an O
8HRBRAIN O
head O
coil O
. O

RsfMRI O
was O
acquired O
using O
a O
T2 O
* O
echo‐planar O
imaging O
( O
EPI O
) O
sequence O
with O
the O
following O
parameters O
: O
TR/TE O
, O
2000 O
ms/30 O
ms O
; O
flip O
angle O
, O
90° O
; O
acquisition O
matrix O
, O
64 O
× O
64 O
; O
FOV O
, O
220 O
mm O
× O
220 O
mm O
; O
voxel O
size O
, O
3.44 O
mm O
× O
3.44 O
mm O
× O
3.50 O
mm O
; O
slice O
thickness O
, O
3.50 O
mm O
; O
and O
slice O
gap O
, O
none O
. O

Each O
brain O
volume O
consisted O
of O
40 O
axial O
slices O
, O
and O
each O
functional O
run O
contained O
150 O
image O
volumes O
preceded O
by O
four O
dummy O
volumes O
. O

Participants O
were O
asked O
to O
stay O
awake O
, O
not O
to O
focus O
their O
thoughts O
on O
anything O
in O
particular O
, O
and O
to O
keep O
their O

closed O
during O
rsfMRI O
scanning O
. O

RsfMRI O
data O
preprocessing O
was O
performed O
with O
Data O
Processing O
Assistant O
for O
Resting‐State O
fMRI O
Advanced O
Edition O
( O
DPARSF‐A O
) O
version O
2.1 O
software,31 O
, O
32 O
which O
is O
a O
matlab O
( O
MathWorks O
, O
Natick O
, O
MA O
, O
USA O
) O
toolbox O
. O

Imaging O
data O
were O
adjusted O
for O
a O
temporal O
shift O
in O
acquisition O
, O
spatially O
realigned O
to O
the O
middle O
slice O
, O
nonlinearly O
normalized O
to O
the O
EPI O
MNI O
template O
( O
resulting O
in O
an O
isotropic O
voxel O
size O
of O
3 O
× O
3 O
× O
3 O
mm O
) O
, O
smoothed O
using O
a O
full‐width O
at O
half‐maximum O
kernel O
of O
4 O
mm O
, O
and O
bandpass O
filtered O
( O
0.01–0.1 O
Hz O
) O
. O

Nuisance O
signals O
from O
the O
head‐motion O
time O
series O
estimated O
by O
the O
Friston O
24‐parameter O
model,33 O
as O
well O
as O
signals O
from O
white O
matter O
and O
cerebrospinal O
fluid O
signals O
, O
were O
regressed O
out O
of O
each O
voxel O
's O
time O
course O
. O

Moreover O
, O
the O
head O
motion O
scrubbing O
regression O
was O
modeled O
using O
the O
following O
parameters O
: O
framewise O
displacement O
threshold O
for O
‘ O
bad O
’ O
time‐points O
, O
0.5 O
; O
scrubbing O
time‐points O
before O
‘ O
bad O
’ O
time‐points O
, O
1 O
; O
and O
scrubbing O
time‐points O
after O
‘ O
bad O
’ O
time‐points O
, O
2.34 O
Finally O
, O
the O
time O
course O
data O
were O
processed O
for O
each O
voxel O
, O
as O
well O
as O
for O
each O
of O
the O
brain O
regions O
defined O
by O
the O
Harvard–Oxford O
atlas O
distributed O
with O
FSL O
( O
http O
: O
//www.fmrib.ox.ac.uk/fsl/ O
) O
, O
by O
averaging O
over O
voxels O
within O
each O
region O
. O

Intraregional O
correlation O
coefficients O
indicating O
the O
extent O
of O
synchronicity O
were O
calculated O
between O
every O
pair O
of O
a O
subcortical O
region O
and O
a O
voxel O
, O
and O
connectivity O
maps O
were O
created O
. O

Correlation O
coefficients O
representing O
functional O
connectivity O
( O
FC O
) O
were O
converted O
to O
z‐scores O
using O
Fisher O
's O
transformation O
. O

Statistical O
analysis O
for O
imaging O
data O
Statistical O
analyses O
were O
performed O
using O
spss O
for O
Windows O
Version O
24 O
( O
SPSS O
Japan O
Inc. O
, O
Tokyo O
, O
Japan O
) O
. O

For O
each O
segmented O
structure O
, O
except O
for O
the O
ICV O
, O
a O
total O
of O
798 O
subjects O

and O
54 O
patients O
with O
preserved O
IQ O
) O
were O
compared O
using O
analysis O
of O
covariance O
( O
ancova O
) O
, O
including O
age O
, O
sex O
, O
type O
of O
MRI O
scanner O
, O
and O
ICV O
as O
covariates O
. O

The O
ICV O
was O
analyzed O
using O
ancova O
, O
including O
age O
, O
sex O
, O
and O
type O
of O
MRI O
scanner O
as O
covariates O
. O

Because O
there O
were O
94 O
brain O
regions O
, O
statistical O
significance O
was O
defined O
at O
P O
< O
5.3 O
× O
10−4 O
. O

All O
reported O
P‐values O
are O
based O
on O
two‐tailed O
tests O
. O

Post‐hoc O
comparisons O
were O
performed O
after O
ancova O
using O
the O
Bonferroni O
correction O
when O
there O
was O
a O
significant O
difference O
among O
the O
groups O
. O

Statistical O
significance O
was O
defined O
for O
post‐hoc O
comparisons O
at O
P O
< O
0.05 O
. O

Cohen O
's O
d O
effect O
sizes O
were O
calculated O
between O
the O
groups O
. O

A O
total O
of O
294 O
subjects O
( O
234 O
controls O
, O
40 O
patients O
with O
deteriorated O
IQ O
, O
and O
20 O
patients O
with O
preserved O
IQ O
) O
were O
analyzed O
for O
brain O
connectivity O
. O

The O
second‐level O
analyses O
of O
seed‐based O
FC O
maps O
were O
performed O
in O
spm12 O
( O
Wellcome O
Department O
of O
Cognitive O
Neurology O
, O
London O
, O
UK O
) O
running O
on O
MATLAB O
R2014b O
. O

We O
compared O
functional O
connectivity O
maps O
seeded O
in O
the O
bilateral O
thalamus O
, O
accumbens O
, O
amygdala O
, O
caudate O
nucleus O
, O
hippocampus O
, O
pallidum O
, O
and O
putamen O
between O
the O
deteriorated O
group O
and O
control O
group O
, O
the O
preserved O
group O
and O
control O
group O
, O
and O
the O
deteriorated O
group O
and O
preserved O
group O
controlling O
for O
age O
and O
sex O
. O

For O
the O
analysis O
of O
FC O
maps O
, O
the O
statistical O
threshold O
was O
set O
at O
an O
uncorrected O
P O
< O
0.001 O
at O
the O
voxel O
level O
and O
a O
family‐wise‐error‐corrected O
P O
< O
0.05 O
at O
the O
cluster O
level O
. O

Accelerated O
alcohol O
use O
across O
adolescence O
predicts O
early O
adult O
symptoms O
of O
alcohol O
use O
disorder O
via O
reward-related O
neural O
function O
Background O
Alcohol O
use O
is O
commonly O
initiated O
during O
adolescence O
, O
with O
earlier O
onset O
known O
to O
increase O
risk O
for O
alcohol O
use O
disorder O
( O
AUD O
) O
. O

Altered O
function O
in O
neural O
reward O
circuitry O
is O
thought O
to O
increase O
risk O
for O
AUD O
. O

To O
test O
the O
hypothesis O
that O
adolescent O
alcohol O
misuse O
primes O
the O
brain O
for O
alcohol-related O
psychopathology O
in O
early O
adulthood O
, O
we O
examined O
whether O
adolescent O
alcohol O
consumption O
rates O
predicted O
reward O
responsivity O
in O
the O
ventral O
striatum O
( O
VS O
) O
, O
and O
in O
turn O
, O
AUD O
symptoms O
in O
adulthood O
. O

Methods O
139 O
low O
income O
, O
racially O
diverse O
urban O
males O
reported O
on O
their O
alcohol O
use O
at O
ages O
11 O
, O
12 O
, O
15 O
, O
and O
17 O
; O
completed O
self-reports O
of O
personality O
, O
psychiatric O
interviews O
, O
and O
an O
fMRI O
scan O
at O
age O
20 O
; O
and O
completed O
a O
psychiatric O
interview O
at O
age O
22 O
. O

We O
measured O
adolescent O
alcohol O
use O
trajectories O
using O
latent O
growth O
curve O
modeling O
and O
measured O
neural O
responses O
to O
monetary O
reward O
using O
a O
VS O
region O
of O
interest O
. O

We O
tested O
indirect O
effects O
of O
adolescent O
alcohol O
use O
on O
AUD O
symptoms O
at O
age O
22 O
via O
VS O
reward-related O
reactivity O
at O
age O
20 O
. O

Results O
Greater O
acceleration O
in O
adolescent O
alcohol O
use O
predicted O
increased O
VS O
response O
during O
reward O
anticipation O
at O
age O
20 O
. O

VS O
reactivity O
to O
reward O
anticipation O
at O
age O
20 O
predicted O
AUD O
symptoms O
at O
age O
22 O
, O
over O
and O
above O
concurrent O
symptoms O
. O

Accelerated O
adolescent O
alcohol O
use O
predicted O
AUD O
symptoms O
in O
early O
adulthood O
via O
greater O
VS O
reactivity O
to O
reward O
anticipation O
. O

Conclusions O
Prospective O
findings O
support O
a O
pathway O
through O
which O
adolescent O
alcohol O
use O
increases O
risk O
for O
AUD O
in O
early O
adulthood O
by O
impacting O
reward-related O
neural O
functioning O
. O

These O
results O
highlight O
increased O
VS O
reward-related O
reactivity O
as O
a O
biomarker O
for O
AUD O
vulnerability O
. O

Methods O
and O
Materials O
Participants O
139 O
participants O
were O
drawn O
from O
the O
Pitt O
Mother O
& O
Child O
Project O
, O
a O
longitudinal O
study O
of O
310 O
racially O
diverse O
and O
low-income O
boys O
and O
their O
families O
. O

The O
sample O
is O
at O
risk O
for O
externalizing O
outcomes O
based O
on O
being O
male O
, O
urban O
, O
and O
from O
low-income O
families O
. O

Boys O
and O
their O
mothers O
were O
seen O
in O
person O
almost O
yearly O
from O
ages O
1.5–22 O
in O
their O
home O
and/or O
the O
lab O
( O
assessments O
at O
1 O
1/2 O
, O
2 O
, O
3 O
1/2 O
, O
5 O
, O
6 O
, O
7 O
, O
8 O
, O
9 O
, O
10 O
, O
11 O
, O
12 O
, O
15 O
, O
17 O
, O
20 O
, O
and O
22 O
years O
old O
) O
. O

In O
the O
current O
study O
, O
we O
focused O
on O
the O
latter O
six O
assessment O
points O
that O
covered O
adolescence O
and O
early O
adulthood O
: O
11 O
, O
12 O
, O
15 O
, O
17 O
, O
20 O
and O
22 O
years O
old O
. O

Assessments O
included O
questionnaires O
and O
a O
psychiatric O
interview O
. O

At O
age O
20 O
, O
the O
assessment O
also O
included O
an O
fMRI O
scan O
at O
age O
20 O
. O

Participants O
were O
reimbursed O
after O
assessments O
and O
procedures O
were O
approved O
by O
the O
University O
of O
Pittsburgh O
IRB O
. O

Attrition O
to O
the O
age O
20 O
and O
22 O
visits O
was O
low O
for O
such O
a O
long-term O
study O
( O
252 O
and O
256 O
men O
participated O
at O
ages O
20 O
and O
22 O
, O
respectively O
81 O
% O
and O
83 O
% O
retention O
across O
more O
than O
20 O
years O
) O
. O

Of O
the O
256 O
at O
age O
20 O
, O
144 O
men O
had O
usable O
fMRI O
reward O
data O
and O
139 O
had O
both O
fMRI O
and O
adolescent O
alcohol O
use O
data O
( O
Supplemental O
Table O
1 O
summarizes O
details O
on O
attrition O
) O
. O

The O
139 O
males O
with O
fMRI O
data O
at O
age O
20 O
did O
not O
differ O
significantly O
from O
the O
full O
sample O
retained O
at O
age O
20 O
based O
on O
self-reported O
alcohol O
( O
p O
> O
.39 O
) O
or O
marijuana O
( O
p O
> O
.76 O
) O
consumption O
via O
the O
Alcohol O
and O
Drug O
Consumption O
Questionnaire O
or O
self-reported O
antisocial O
behavior O
( O
p O
> O
.37 O
) O
via O
the O
Self-Report O
of O
Delinquency O
Questionnaire O
. O

Measures O
Adolescent O
Alcohol O
Use O
( O
ages O
11 O
, O
12 O
, O
15 O
, O
and O
17 O
) O
We O
assessed O
adolescent O
alcohol O
use O
using O
items O
from O
the O
Self-Report O
Delinquency O
Questionnaire O
, O
which O
assesses O
engagement O
in O
antisocial O
activities O
in O
the O
past O
year O
via O
a O
three-point O
scale O
( O
0=never O
, O
1=once/twice O
, O
2=more O
often O
; O
α=.90 O
) O
. O

Three O
separate O
items O
assessing O
consumption O
of O
beer O
, O
liquor O
, O
or O
wine O
were O
summed O
to O
create O
alcohol O
frequency O
scores O
at O
each O
age O
, O
which O
were O
subjected O
to O
latent O
growth O
curve O
modeling O
to O
derive O
alcohol O
trajectories O
( O
see O
Supplemental O
Table O
2 O
) O
. O

Rates O
were O
similar O
to O
those O
reported O
via O
surveys O
of O
adolescents O
within O
community O
samples O
. O

Symptoms O
of O
Alcohol O
Use O
Disorder O
( O
ages O
20 O
and O
22 O
) O
To O
assess O
alcohol O
use O
disorder O
( O
AUD O
) O
at O
ages O
20 O
and O
22 O
, O
we O
used O
interviewer O
assessments O
from O
the O
Structured O
Clinical O
Interview O
for O
DSM-IV O
Axis O
I O
( O
SCID-I O
) O
( O
American O
Psychiatric O
) O
( O
Supplemental O
Methods O
outline O
the O
training O
and O
reliability O
procedures O
) O
. O

Results O
are O
presented O
using O
an O
AUD O
symptom O
count O
combining O
total O
number O
of O
alcohol O
use O
and O
dependence O
symptoms O
. O

To O
confirm O
these O
results O
within O
a O
DSM-5 O
framework O
, O
which O
removed O
the O
abuse-dependence O
distinction O
, O
we O
compared O
findings O
for O
a O
symptom O
count O
excluding O
“ O
recurrent O
substance-related O
legal O
problems O
” O
that O
does O
not O
appear O
in O
DSM-5 O
( O
American O
Psychiatric O
) O
. O

We O
also O
found O
similar O
results O
using O
separate O
alcohol O
abuse O
versus O
dependence O
symptom O
counts O
. O

At O
age O
22 O
, O
approximately O
21 O
% O
of O
our O
sample O
met O
lifetime O
criteria O
for O
Alcohol O
Abuse O
or O
Dependence O
diagnoses O
. O

These O
estimates O
are O
consistent O
with O
epidemiological O
surveys O
of O
community O
samples O
. O

Personality O
Confounds O
( O
age O
20 O
) O
To O
ensure O
that O
effects O
were O
not O
accounted O
for O
by O
stable O
personality O
traits O
linked O
to O
hypersensitivity O
to O
reward O
or O
alcohol O
misuse O
, O
we O
controlled O
for O
impulsivity O
, O
which O
has O
been O
linked O
to O
VS O
reward-related O
reactivity O
and O
alcohol O
use O
, O
and O
extraversion O
, O
which O
predicts O
brain O
reward-related O
functioning O
and O
alcohol O
use O
. O

Impulsivity O
was O
assessed O
at O
age O
20 O
via O
self-report O
using O
the O
Barratt O
Impulsiveness O
Scale-Version O
II O
, O
a O
30 O
item O
measure O
tapping O
several O
aspects O
of O
impulsivity O
, O
including O
deficits O
in O
behavioral O
control O
( O
α=.79 O
) O
Extraversion O
was O
assessed O
age O
20 O
via O
self-report O
on O
the O
12-item O
extraversion O
subscale O
of O
the O
NEO O
Personality O
Inventory-Revised O
( O
NEO O
PI-R O
Short O
Form O
) O
( O
α=.64 O
) O
. O

Adolescent O
comorbid O
psychiatric O
disorders O
To O
confirm O
that O
relationships O
between O
adolescent O
alcohol O
use O
and O
brain O
reward-related O
functioning O
were O
not O
due O
to O
earlier O
ADHD O
or O
Conduct O
Disorder O
( O
CD O
) O
, O
both O
well-established O
risk O
factors O
for O
AUD O
, O
we O
included O
ADHD O
and O
CD O
diagnoses O
from O
the O
Schedule O
for O
Affective O
Disorders O
and O
Schizophrenia O
for O
School O
Age O
Children O
, O
a O
semi-structured O
psychiatric O
interview O
using O
DSM-IV O
criteria O
. O

At O
ages O
11 O
, O
15 O
, O
and O
17 O
years O
old O
, O
examiners O
administered O
interviews O
to O
boys O
and O
their O
mothers O
and O
diagnoses O
were O
made O
through O
clinician O
consensus O
. O

Training O
and O
reliability O
procedures O
are O
described O
in O
Supplemental O
Methods O
. O

Earlier O
ADHD O
or O
CD O
were O
included O
as O
a O
present/absent O
dichotomous O
variable O
( O
i.e. O
, O
present=diagnosis O
at O
any O
prior O
assessment O
) O
. O

Other O
comorbid O
psychiatric O
disorders O
Finally O
, O
to O
ensure O
that O
effects O
were O
not O
accounted O
for O
by O
psychiatric O
comorbidities O
related O
to O
hypersensitivity O
to O
reward O
or O
engagement O
in O
alcohol O
misuse O
, O
we O
controlled O
symptoms O
of O
the O
following O
DSM-IV O
disorders O
at O
age O
20 O
as O
covariates O
based O
on O
SCID-I O
and O
SCID-II O
interviews O
: O
antisocial O
personality O
disorder O
( O
APD O
) O
, O
major O
depressive O
disorder O
( O
MDD O
) O
, O
generalized O
anxiety O
disorder O
( O
GAD O
) O
, O
post-traumatic O
stress O
disorder O
, O
and O
social O
phobia O
( O
SP O
) O
. O

Although O
we O
included O
symptom O
counts O
as O
covariates O
in O
models O
, O
the O
findings O
were O
similar O
if O
we O
included O
diagnoses O
. O

Finally O
, O
in O
addition O
to O
including O
comorbid O
psychiatric O
disorders O
as O
covariates O
at O
age O
20 O
, O
we O
explored O
the O
specificity O
of O
pathways O
to O
AUD O
, O
by O
including O
Substance O
Use O
Disorder O
( O
SUD O
) O
and O
APD O
symptoms O
as O
dependent O
variables O
at O
age O
22 O
. O

Other O
Covariates O
. O

To O
ensure O
that O
results O
relating O
to O
differences O
in O
reward O
functioning O
were O
not O
due O
to O
race O
or O
socioeconomic O
status O
, O
we O
accounted O
for O
the O
effects O
of O
race O
and O
income O
. O

As O
alcohol O
use O
tends O
to O
co-occur O
with O
marijuana O
and O
tobacco O
use O
, O
we O
also O
accounted O
for O
rates O
of O
comorbid O
adolescent O
marijuana O
and O
tobacco O
use O
assessed O
via O
the O
same O
method O
as O
alcohol O
use O
( O
i.e. O
, O
trajectories O
across O
adolescence O
; O
Supplemental O
Table O
2 O
) O
. O

Finally O
, O
all O
models O
included O
the O
age O
at O
which O
participants O
first O
reporting O
drinking O
as O
a O
covariate O
. O

Descriptive O
statistics O
for O
all O
study O
variables O
are O
presented O
in O
Table O
1 O
and O
bivariate O
correlations O
between O
study O
variables O
in O
Supplemental O
Table O
3 O
. O

Neuroimaging O
Procedures O
After O
participants O
completed O
questionnaires O
and O
clinical O
interviews O
, O
they O
underwent O
an O
fMRI O
scan O
. O

The O
fMRI O
reward O
paradigm O
was O
a O
slow O
event-related O
card-guessing O
game O
that O
evaluates O
neural O
response O
to O
the O
anticipation O
and O
receipt O
of O
monetary O
reward O
. O

During O
trials O
, O
participants O
guessed O
via O
button O
press O
whether O
the O
values O
of O
visually O
presented O
cards O
, O
with O
possible O
values O
of O
1–9 O
, O
were O
higher O
or O
lower O
than O
5 O
( O
4s O
) O
, O
learned O
the O
trial O
type O
( O
possible-win O
) O
to O
anticipate O
feedback O
( O
6s O
) O
, O
and O
receive O
feedback O
( O
e.g. O
, O
win O
money/no O
change O
; O
1s O
plus O
9s O
inter-trial O
interval O
) O
. O

Participants O
were O
told O
that O
their O
performance O
would O
determine O
a O
monetary O
reward O
after O
the O
scan O
( O
$ O
1 O
per O
win O
) O
. O

Trials O
were O
presented O
in O
pseudorandom O
order O
with O
predetermined O
outcomes O
in O
a O
single O
, O
8-minute O
run O
, O
with O
24 O
trials O
and O
a O
balanced O
number O
of O
trial O
types O
. O

This O
task O
has O
previously O
been O
shown O
to O
differentiate O
anticipation O
versus O
receipt O
phases O
of O
reward O
processing O
with O
large O
task-based O
effect O
sizes O
in O
the O
VS O
( O
; O
see O
Supplemental O
Figure O
1 O
for O
a O
fuller O
task O
description O
) O
. O

Bold O
fMRI O
acquisition O
parameters O
As O
described O
previously O
, O
participants O
were O
scanned O
with O
a O
research-dedicated O
Siemens O
3-T O
Trio O
scanner O
with O
an O
12-channel O
head O
coil O
at O
the O
University O
of O
Pittsburgh O
. O

Blood O
oxygenation O
level–dependent O
( O
BOLD O
) O
functional O
images O
were O
acquired O
with O
a O
gradient-echo O
echoplanar O
imaging O
sequence O
repetition O
time O
( O
TR O
) O
/echo O
time O
( O
TE O
) O
/flip O
angle=2000/29 O
milliseconds/90° O
, O
field O
of O
view=200×200mm O
, O
matrix=64×64 O
) O
, O
that O
covered O
34 O
interleaved O
axial O
slices O
( O
3mm O
slice O
thickness O
) O
aligned O
with O
the O
AC-PC O
plane O
and O
encompassing O
the O
entire O
cerebrum O
and O
most O
of O
the O
cerebellum O
to O
maximize O
coverage O
of O
limbic O
structures O
. O

MRI O
data O
analysis O
Image O
processing O
and O
analysis O
. O

Analyses O
were O
completed O
using O
the O
general O
linear O
model O
of O
SPM8 O
( O
http O
: O
//www.fil.ion.ucl.ac.uk/spm/ O
) O
. O

Images O
for O
each O
participant O
were O
segmented O
, O
realigned O
to O
the O
first O
volume O
in O
the O
time O
series O
, O
unwarped O
to O
correct O
for O
head O
motion O
, O
co-registered O
to O
high-resolution O
structural O
scans O
, O
spatially O
normalized O
into O
Montreal O
Neurological O
Institute O
space O
using O
a O
12-parameter O
affine O
model O
, O
and O
smoothed O
to O
minimize O
noise O
and O
residual O
difference O
in O
gyral O
anatomy O
with O
a O
6mm O
FWHM O
Gaussian O
filter O
. O

Voxelwise O
signal O
intensities O
were O
ratio-normalized O
to O
the O
whole-brain O
global O
mean O
. O

After O
preprocessing O
, O
Artifact O
detection O
Tools O
software O
( O
http O
: O
//www.nitrc.org/projects/artifact_detect/ O
) O
was O
used O
by O
detecting O
global O
mean O
intensity O
and O
translation O
or O
rotational O
motion O
outliers O
( O
> O
4.5 O
SD O
from O
the O
mean O
global O
brain O
activation O
, O
> O
2mm O
movement O
, O
or O
2× O
translation O
in O
any O
direction O
) O
by O
creating O
a O
regressor O
within O
each O
participant O
’ O
s O
first-level O
analysis O
to O
account O
for O
confounding O
effects O
of O
volumes O
with O
large O
motion O
deflections O
or O
intensity O
spikes O
. O

Single-subject O
BOLD O
fMRI O
data O
were O
only O
included O
in O
analyses O
if O
there O
was O
a O
minimum O
of O
85 O
% O
VS O
coverage O
using O
a O
bilateral O
, O
anatomically-based O
VS O
ROI O
. O

Participants O
with O
less O
than O
80 O
% O
task O
responding O
were O
excluded O
from O
analysis O
. O

BOLD O
fMRI O
data O
analysis O
. O

Linear O
contrasts O
employing O
canonical O
hemodynamic O
response O
functions O
were O
used O
to O
estimate O
condition-specific O
BOLD O
activation O
for O
each O
individual O
. O

Individual O
contrast O
images O
were O
used O
in O
second-level O
random O
effects O
models O
to O
determine O
mean O
reward-related O
reactivity O
using O
one-sample O
t-tests O
for O
: O
reward O
anticipation O
> O
baseline O
and O
reward O
outcome O
> O
baseline O
. O

Baseline O
was O
defined O
as O
the O
last O
3 O
seconds O
of O
the O
9-second O
inter-trial O
interval O
as O
previously O
described O
. O

As O
the O
VS O
is O
central O
to O
reward O
processing O
, O
we O
examined O
results O
within O
the O
VS O
ROI O
masking O
for O
main O
effects O
of O
the O
task O
using O
a O
Family-Wise O
Error O
( O
FWE O
) O
correction O
. O

A O
bilateral O
VS O
ROI O
was O
constructed O
in O
the O
WFU O
PickAtlas O
Tool O
v2.4 O
using O
two O
spheres O
of O
10mm O
radius O
around O
MNI O
coordinates O
x=+/−12 O
, O
y=12 O
, O
z=−10 O
. O

Analytic O
strategy O
Deriving O
Trajectories O
of O
Alcohol O
Use O
across O
Adolescence O
. O

To O
measure O
trajectories O
of O
alcohol O
use O
across O
adolescence O
, O
we O
used O
latent O
growth O
curve O
modeling O
( O
LGCM O
) O
in O
Mplus O
version O
7.2 O
using O
alcohol O
frequency O
scores O
at O
ages O
11 O
, O
12 O
, O
15 O
, O
and O
17 O
( O
Supplemental O
Table O
2 O
) O
. O

We O
estimated O
latent O
factors O
for O
the O
intercept O
, O
slope O
, O
and O
quadratic O
slope O
. O

Comparative O
Fit O
Index O
( O
CFI O
: O
cut-off O
value O
.95 O
) O
, O
and O
Root O
Mean O
Square O
Error O
of O
Approximation O
( O
RMSEA O
: O
cut-off O
value O
.06 O
) O
were O
used O
to O
assess O
model O
fit O
. O

We O
compared O
a O
no-change O
( O
intercept-only O
) O
model O
, O
linear O
model O
, O
and O
quadratic O
model O
, O
judging O
the O
best-fitting O
model O
based O
on O
CFI O
and O
RMSEA O
values O
and O
whichever O
had O
the O
lowest O
Bayesian O
Information O
Criterion O
. O

Adolescent O
Alcohol O
Use O
, O
Brain O
Reward-Related O
Functioning O
, O
and O
AUD O
in O
adulthood O
. O

First O
, O
regression O
analysis O
was O
performed O
in O
SPM8 O
to O
determine O
whether O
adolescent O
alcohol O
use O
was O
associated O
with O
neural O
response O
during O
reward O
anticipation O
or O
outcome O
. O

We O
first O
ran O
a O
model O
where O
we O
included O
only O
starting O
levels O
of O
alcohol O
, O
race O
, O
and O
income O
( O
i.e. O
, O
“ O
no O
covariates O
models O
” O
) O
. O

Second O
, O
we O
ran O
a O
model O
including O
the O
following O
covariates O
: O
race O
, O
income O
, O
alcohol O
starting O
levels O
, O
impulsivity O
, O
extraversion O
, O
psychiatric O
diagnoses O
, O
and O
adolescent O
marijuana O
and O
nicotine O
use O
( O
Table O
1 O
presents O
descriptive O
data O
) O
. O

To O
link O
differences O
in O
neural O
response O
to O
reward O
to O
later O
alcohol O
use O
, O
we O
used O
two O
approaches O
. O

First O
, O
we O
employed O
conjunction O
analysis O
in O
SPM8 O
to O
determine O
whether O
AUD O
symptoms O
at O
age O
22 O
were O
related O
to O
reward O
responsivity O
in O
overlapping O
regions O
associated O
with O
adolescent O
alcohol O
use O
. O

Second O
, O
as O
conjunction O
analyses O
can O
not O
test O
indirect O
effects O
, O
we O
tested O
a O
path O
model O
in O
Mplus O
to O
examine O
whether O
adolescent O
alcohol O
use O
was O
related O
to O
AUD O
symptoms O
at O
age O
22 O
via O
brain O
reward-related O
functioning O
at O
age O
20 O
. O

To O
avoid O
double O
correlation O
issues O
inherent O
in O
extracting O
data O
from O
SPM8 O
based O
on O
our O
variables O
of O
interest O
( O
i.e. O
, O
alcohol O
use O
) O
, O
we O
extracted O
left O
and O
right O
VS O
peaks O
within O
an O
anatomical O
VS O
mask O
from O
the O
main O
effects O
of O
the O
reward O
task O
using O
the O
VOI O
tool O
( O
Supplemental O
Figure O
2 O
) O
( O
for O
examples O
of O
this O
approach O
, O
see O
) O
. O

The O
indirect O
pathway O
from O
adolescent O
alcohol O
use O
to O
AUD O
symptoms O
at O
age O
22 O
via O
VS O
reactivity O
at O
age O
20 O
was O
estimated O
as O
the O
product O
of O
the O
coefficients O
( O
AB O
) O
( O
“ O
Sobel O
test O
” O
) O
. O

To O
test O
the O
specificity O
of O
effects O
to O
AUD O
, O
we O
included O
direct O
and O
indirect O
pathways O
from O
to O
SUD O
and O
APD O
symptoms O
at O
age O
22 O
. O

Alcohol O
effects O
on O
globus O
pallidus O
connectivity O
: O
Role O
of O
impulsivity O
and O
binge O
drinking O
Despite O
the O
harm O
caused O
by O
binge O
drinking O
, O
the O
neural O
mechanisms O
leading O
to O
risky O
and O
disinhibited O
intoxication-related O
behaviors O
are O
not O
well O
understood O
. O

Evidence O
suggests O
that O
the O
globus O
pallidus O
externus O
( O
GPe O
) O
, O
a O
substructure O
within O
the O
basal O
ganglia O
, O
participates O
in O
inhibitory O
control O
processes O
, O
as O
examined O
in O
stop-signaling O
tasks O
. O

In O
fact O
, O
studies O
in O
rodents O
have O
revealed O
that O
alcohol O
can O
change O
GPe O
activity O
by O
decreasing O
neuronal O
firing O
rates O
, O
suggesting O
that O
the O
GPe O
may O
have O
a O
central O
role O
in O
explaining O
impulsive O
behaviors O
and O
failures O
of O
inhibition O
that O
occur O
during O
binge O
drinking O
. O

In O
this O
study O
, O
twenty-five O
healthy O
volunteers O
underwent O
intravenous O
alcohol O
infusion O
to O
achieve O
a O
blood O
alcohol O
level O
of O
0.08 O
g/dl O
, O
which O
is O
equivalent O
to O
a O
binge O
drinking O
episode O
. O

A O
resting O
state O
functional O
magnetic O
resonance O
imaging O
scan O
was O
collected O
prior O
to O
the O
infusion O
and O
at O
binge-level O
exposure O
. O

Functional O
connectivity O
analysis O
was O
used O
to O
investigate O
the O
association O
between O
alcohol-induced O
changes O
in O
GPe O
connectivity O
, O
drinking O
behaviors O
, O
and O
impulsivity O
traits O
. O

We O
found O
that O
individuals O
with O
greater O
number O
of O
drinks O
or O
heavy O
drinking O
days O
in O
the O
recent O
past O
had O
greater O
alcohol-induced O
deficits O
in O
GPe O
connectivity O
, O
particularly O
to O
the O
striatum O
. O

Our O
data O
also O
indicated O
an O
association O
between O
impulsivity O
and O
alcohol-induced O
deficits O
in O
GPe—frontal/precentral O
connectivity O
. O

Moreover O
, O
alcohol O
induced O
changes O
in O
GPe-amygdala O
circuitry O
suggested O
greater O
vulnerabilities O
to O
stress-related O
drinking O
in O
some O
individuals O
. O

Taken O
together O
, O
these O
findings O
suggest O
that O
alcohol O
may O
interact O
with O
impulsive O
personality O
traits O
and O
drinking O
patterns O
to O
drive O
alterations O
in O
GPe O
circuitry O
associated O
with O
behavioral O
inhibition O
, O
possibly O
indicating O
a O
neural O
mechanism O
by O
which O
binge O
drinking O
could O
lead O
to O
impulsive O
behaviors O
. O

Methods O
This O
study O
was O
approved O
by O
the O
NIH O
Addictions O
Institutional O
Review O
Board O
under O
12-AA-0032 O
. O

All O
subjects O
provided O
written O
informed O
consent O
prior O
to O
their O
participation O
in O
the O
study O
. O

Participants O
Twenty-five O
healthy O
( O
13 O
males O
, O
12 O
females O
; O
mean O
age O
: O
28.85 O
years O
) O
, O
light O
social O
drinkers O
were O
recruited O
by O
local O
advertisement O
, O
according O
to O
approved O
National O
Institutes O
of O
Health O
Institutional O
Review O
Board O
procedures O
. O

The O
demographic O
data O
of O
participants O
is O
summarized O
in O
Table O
1 O
. O

After O
obtaining O
written O
informed O
consent O
, O
all O
participants O
underwent O
a O
comprehensive O
medical O
screen O
, O
including O
blood O
work O
, O
urinalysis O
, O
medical O
history O
, O
physical O
exam O
, O
and O
a O
Structured O
Clinical O
Interview O
for O
the O
DSM O
Axis-I O
Disorders O
( O
SCID-IV O
) O
. O

Criteria O
for O
inclusion O
in O
this O
study O
were O
: O
healthy O
, O
21–45 O
years O
old O
, O
consumption O
of O
1 O
to O
10 O
drinks O
per O
week O
for O
females O
and O
1 O
to O
14 O
drinks O
per O
week O
for O
males O
. O

Subjects O
also O
had O
to O
have O
consumed O
at O
least O
two O
standard O
drinks O
of O
alcohol O
within O
one O
hour O
on O
at O
least O
one O
occasion O
in O
their O
lifetime O
. O

Criteria O
for O
exclusion O
included O
: O
abnormal O
blood O
or O
urine O
lab O
test O
values O
or O
findings O
from O
the O
medical O
screen O
, O
DSM-IV O
criteria O
for O
alcohol O
or O
other O
substance O
dependence O
( O
excluding O
nicotine O
) O
at O
any O
time O
; O
current O
or O
past O
major O
psychiatric O
disorder O
( O
DSM-IV O
Axis O
I O
) O
, O
head O
injury O
requiring O
hospitalization O
, O
Body O
Mass O
Index O
( O
BMI O
) O
value O
over O
30 O
, O
inability O
to O
stop O
taking O
any O
medication O
or O
drugs O
3 O
days O
prior O
to O
study O
days O
, O
and O
MRI O
contraindications O
. O

Also O
, O
non-drinkers O
were O
excluded O
from O
the O
study O
due O
to O
ethical O
concerns O
related O
to O
alcohol O
administration O
. O

Measures O
Alcohol O
drinking O
measures O
The O
amount O
of O
daily O
alcohol O
consumption O
over O
the O
last O
90 O
days O
was O
measured O
using O
the O
Alcohol O
Timeline-Followback O
( O
TLFB O
) O
calendar—a O
drinking O
assessment O
method O
with O
good O
psychometric O
characteristics O
for O
estimating O
retrospective O
daily O
drinking O
patterns O
. O

The O
number O
of O
heavy O
drinking O
days O
in O
the O
last O
90 O
days O
was O
calculated O
from O
the O
TLFB O
; O
a O
heavy O
drinking O
day O
is O
defined O
as O
4 O
or O
more O
drinks O
per O
day O
for O
women O
and O
5 O
or O
more O
drinks O
per O
day O
for O
men O
. O

We O
used O
this O
as O
a O
measure O
for O
binge O
drinking O
. O

Total O
drinks O
in O
the O
past O
30 O
days O
was O
also O
calculated O
from O
the O
TLFB O
. O

Past O
30-day O
drinking O
was O
used O
rather O
than O
90-day O
drinking O
given O
that O
we O
were O
interested O
in O
recent O
drinking O
, O
and O
that O
recent O
reports O
of O
drinking O
may O
be O
more O
reliable O
. O

Impulsivity O
measures O
Impulsive O
behavioral O
traits O
were O
measured O
using O
the O
Barratt O
Impulsiveness O
Scale O
( O
BIS-11 O
) O
and O
the O
UPPS-P O
Impulsive O
Behavior O
Scale O
, O
two O
of O
the O
most O
widely-used O
self-report O
tools O
in O
the O
evaluation O
of O
trait O
impulsivity O
. O

The O
BIS-11 O
scale O
evaluates O
impulsive O
behavior O
in O
general O
, O
and O
the O
motor O
, O
attentional O
and O
non-planning O
sub-scales O
evaluate O
acting O
without O
thinking O
, O
inability O
to O
focus O
attention O
and O
lack O
of O
forethought O
, O
respectively O
. O

The O
UPPS-P O
measures O
personality O
traits O
conducive O
to O
impulsive O
behavior O
including O
Urgency O
( O
negative O
) O
—tendency O
to O
impulsively O
act O
under O
strong O
negative O
emotions O
, O
Premeditation O
( O
lack O
of O
) O
—tendency O
to O
act O
without O
thinking O
, O
Perseverance O
( O
lack O
of O
) O
to O
remain O
focused O
on O
a O
task O
, O
Sensation-seeking—tendency O
to O
seek O
out O
novel/thrilling O
experiences O
, O
and O
Positive-urgency—tendency O
to O
impulsively O
act O
under O
strong O
positive O
emotions O
. O

We O
also O
evaluated O
choice O
impulsivity O
with O
the O
Delay O
Discounting O
Task O
( O
DDT O
) O
. O

The O
DDT O
measures O
impulsivity O
by O
presenting O
the O
subject O
with O
a O
series O
of O
hypothetical O
choices O
between O
receiving O
a O
smaller O
immediate O
monetary O
reward O
or O
a O
larger O
delayed O
reward O
. O

Subjects O
were O
presented O
as O
their O
immediate O
reward O
values O
between O
$ O
100 O
and O
$ O
0 O
dollars O
in O
increments O
of O
$ O
10 O
, O
while O
the O
delayed O
reward O
was O
$ O
100 O
. O

Delays O
were O
0 O
, O
7 O
, O
14 O
, O
20 O
, O
25 O
, O
or O
30 O
days O
. O

Subjects O
completed O
trials O
with O
all O
iterations O
of O
these O
parameters O
. O

The O
rate O
of O
discounting O
of O
the O
delayed O
outcome O
( O
k O
) O
was O
calculated O
and O
then O
a O
natural O
log-transformation O
was O
applied O
to O
correct O
for O
the O
non-normal O
distribution O
of O
k O
values O
. O

The O
resulting O
ln O
( O
k O
) O
is O
used O
to O
represent O
delay O
discounting O
, O
where O
higher O
ln O
( O
k O
) O
values O
mean O
greater O
preference O
for O
immediate O
rewards O
( O
see O
Table O
1 O
for O
descriptive O
statistics O
of O
drinking O
and O
impulsivity O
scores O
for O
the O
sample O
) O
. O

Experimental O
design O
and O
statistical O
analysis O
Overall O
timeline O
In O
this O
two-session O
study O
, O
healthy O
light O
drinkers O
received O
an O
IV O
alcohol O
infusion O
on O
two O
separate O
days O
. O

The O
first O
session O
was O
conducted O
outside O
the O
scanner O
to O
establish O
the O
alcohol O
infusion O
rate O
profile O
to O
achieve O
and O
maintain O
the O
target O
BrAC O
exposure O
, O
and O
to O
ensure O
tolerability O
. O

The O
alcohol O
infusion O
for O
the O
second O
session O
was O
conducted O
inside O
the O
scanner O
at O
least O
three O
days O
after O
the O
first O
session O
( O
Fig O
1 O
) O
. O

Participants O
were O
asked O
to O
fast O
the O
night O
before O
each O
session O
. O

At O
the O
start O
of O
each O
visit O
, O
breath O
alcohol O
levels O
, O
urine O
pregnancy O
tests O
( O
if O
applicable O
) O
and O
urine O
drug O
screens O
were O
collected O
. O

In O
addition O
, O
we O
conducted O
a O
brief O
history O
interview O
about O
recent O
alcohol O
, O
medication O
, O
and O
nicotine O
use O
, O
changes O
in O
physical O
health O
, O
and O
menstruation O
( O
if O
applicable O
) O
. O

Alcohol O
infusion O
to O
binge O
level O
exposure O
We O
performed O
the O
alcohol O
infusion O
procedure O
following O
previously O
published O
methods O
( O
fMRI O
and O
PET O
) O
. O

In O
both O
sessions O
, O
participants O
received O
an O
intravenous O
( O
IV O
) O
infusion O
of O
6 O
% O
v/v O
ethanol O
solution O
in O
saline O
to O
achieve O
a O
target O
breath O
alcohol O
concentration O
( O
BrAC O
) O
of O
0.08 O
± O
0.005 O
g/dl O
at O
15 O
min O
after O
the O
start O
of O
the O
infusion O
, O
and O
to O
maintain O
( O
or O
clamp O
) O
the O
target O
BrAC O
level O
for O
30 O
min O
( O
Fig O
1 O
) O
. O

The O
infusion-rate O
profile O
was O
computed O
for O
each O
subject O
using O
a O
physiologically-based O
pharmacokinetic O
( O
PBPK O
) O
model-based O
algorithm O
, O
with O
individualized O
estimates O
of O
the O
model O
parameters O
estimated O
from O
the O
subject O
’ O
s O
height O
, O
weight O
, O
age O
and O
sex O
. O

During O
the O
first O
session O
conducted O
outside O
the O
scanner O
, O
serial O
BrACs O
were O
measured O
at O
frequent O
intervals O
( O
5–15 O
minutes O
) O
using O
the O
Alcotest O
7410+ O
handheld O
breathalyzer O
( O
Drager O
Safety O
Inc. O
, O
CO O
) O
, O
to O
ensure O
that O
each O
BrAC O
was O
within O
0.005 O
g/dl O
of O
the O
target O
, O
and O
to O
enable O
minor O
adjustments O
to O
the O
infusion O
rates O
to O
overcome O
errors O
in O
parameter O
estimation O
and O
experimental O
variability O
. O

The O
adjusted O
infusion O
rate O
profile O
from O
the O
first O
session O
was O
used O
in O
the O
imaging O
session O
to O
replicate O
the O
target O
BrAC O
profile O
for O
each O
subject O
. O

This O
approach O
has O
been O
used O
to O
successfully O
achieve O
and O
maintain O
target O
BrACs O
, O
as O
verified O
by O
blood O
alcohol O
concentrations O
measured O
in O
samples O
drawn O
during O
the O
scan O
in O
other O
neuroimaging O
studies O
. O

After O
the O
end O
of O
the O
infusion O
, O
subjects O
were O
provided O
a O
meal O
, O
and O
BrAC O
was O
tracked O
until O
it O
dropped O
to O
0.02 O
g/dL O
or O
below O
, O
at O
which O
time O
subjects O
were O
taken O
home O
by O
a O
designated O
driver O
or O
taxi O
. O

Neuroimaging O
acquisition O
and O
preprocessing O
During O
session O
2 O
, O
after O
the O
IV O
catheters O
were O
placed O
for O
alcohol O
infusion O
, O
participants O
were O
placed O
in O
a O
3T O
SIEMENS O
Skyra O
MR O
scanner O
at O
the O
NMR O
Research O
Center O
at O
the O
NIH O
. O

Before O
starting O
the O
IV O
infusion O
of O
alcohol O
, O
a O
5-min O
closed O
eyes O
resting-state O
fMRI O
scan O
was O
acquired O
with O
an O
echo-planar O
imaging O
sequence O
( O
36 O
axial O
slices O
, O
3.8 O
mm O
thickness O
, O
64 O
× O
64 O
matrix O
and O
repetition O
time O
of O
2000 O
ms O
, O
echo O
time O
30 O
, O
flip O
angle O
90 O
) O
. O

After O
collecting O
this O
baseline O
resting-state O
fMRI O
scan O
, O
the O
alcohol O
infusion O
started O
and O
once O
the O
target O
BAC O
was O
achieved O
, O
a O
10-minute O
waiting O
period O
was O
allowed O
to O
ensure O
the O
BAC O
was O
stable O
at O
the O
0.08 O
g/dl O
level O
. O

During O
the O
waiting O
period O
, O
whole-brain O
structural O
and O
diffusion-weighted O
images O
of O
the O
brain O
were O
collected O
. O

Then O
, O
a O
second O
eyes-closed O
resting-state O
fMRI O
scan O
was O
collected O
while O
the O
target O
BAC O
( O
0.08 O
g/dl O
) O
was O
maintained O
. O

Following O
the O
MRI O
session O
, O
the O
Drug O
Effects O
Questionnaire O
was O
used O
to O
evaluate O
and O
quantify O
subjective O
effects O
of O
alcohol O
( O
DEQ O
) O
. O

CONN O
ver.17f O
( O
http O
: O
//www.conn-toolbox.org O
) O
, O
a O
MATLAB/SPM-based O
( O
www.fil.ion.ucl.ac.uk/spm/ O
) O
software O
, O
was O
used O
to O
conduct O
spatial/temporal O
preprocessing O
and O
analyses O
. O

Spatial O
preprocessing O
included O
slice-timing O
correction O
, O
realignment O
, O
co-registration O
, O
normalization O
, O
and O
spatial O
smoothing O
( O
8 O
mm O
) O
. O

Using O
the O
default O
settings O
in O
CONN O
, O
images O
were O
resliced O
into O
isotropic O
2mm O
voxels O
. O

Anatomical O
volumes O
were O
segmented O
into O
grey O
matter O
, O
white O
matter O
, O
and O
cerebrospinal O
fluid O
( O
CSF O
) O
areas O
and O
the O
resulting O
masks O
were O
eroded O
to O
minimize O
partial O
volume O
effects O
. O

At O
the O
individual O
level O
, O
the O
temporal O
timeseries O
of O
the O
participant-specific O
six O
rotation-translation O
motion O
parameters O
and O
the O
timeseries O
from O
within O
the O
white O
matter/CSF O
masks O
were O
used O
as O
temporal O
covariates O
, O
and O
removed O
from O
the O
blood O
oxygen O
level-dependent O
( O
BOLD O
) O
functional O
data O
using O
linear O
regression O
. O

The O
resulting O
residual O
BOLD O
timeseries O
were O
band-pass O
filtered O
( O
0.008Hz O
< O
f O
< O
0.15Hz O
) O
. O

Neuroimaging O
analysis O
To O
our O
knowledge O
there O
is O
no O
reported O
sub-division O
of O
human O
GPe O
with O
concrete O
landmark O
definition O
and/or O
Talairach O
coordinate O
demarcation O
. O

Therefore O
, O
for O
these O
analyses O
, O
we O
used O
right O
and O
left O
GPe O
masks O
obtained O
from O
the O
Lead-DBS O
toolbox O
( O
http O
: O
//www.lead-dbs.org/ O
) O
. O

These O
anatomical O
masks O
were O
generated O
using O
manual O
tracing O
of O
several O
structural O
MRIs O
and O
subsequent O
co-registration O
with O
histological O
studies O
, O
and O
have O
a O
combined O
volume O
of O
approximately O
929 O
mm3 O
. O

Seed-based O
correlations O
were O
calculated O
as O
Fisher-transformed O
bivariate O
correlation O
coefficients O
between O
the O
BOLD O
activity O
timeseries O
in O
the O
seed O
ROI O
and O
each O
other O
individual O
voxel O
BOLD O
. O

CSF O
, O
grey O
matter O
, O
white O
matter O
signals O
and O
motion O
were O
included O
as O
covariates O
for O
this O
model O
at O
the O
single O
subject O
level O
. O

These O
correlations O
were O
calculated O
separately O
for O
the O
pre-infusion O
and O
post-infusion O
scans O
and O
for O
right O
and O
left O
GPe O
seeds O
. O

For O
each O
of O
the O
pre- O
and O
post-infusion O
analyses O
, O
150 O
time O
points O
( O
across O
300 O
seconds O
) O
were O
used O
. O

To O
examine O
group O
level O
effects O
, O
the O
resulting O
single-subject O
connectivity O
maps O
were O
used O
as O
input O
for O
second O
level O
analyses O
in O
a O
general O
linear O
model O
. O

We O
modeled O
the O
within-subject O
effect O
of O
timepoint O
( O
i.e. O
, O
post- O
versus O
pre-alcohol O
infusion O
; O
see O
S1 O
File O
, O
S1 O
Fig O
and O
S1 O
Table O
for O
report O
of O
the O
main O
effects O
of O
alcohol O
administration O
) O
and O
between-subject O
effects O
of O
impulsivity O
( O
BIS-11 O
, O
UPPS-P O
, O
and O
DDT O
) O
and O
recent O
drinking O
behaviors O
( O
number O
of O
drinks O
in O
the O
last O
30 O
days O
, O
number O
of O
heavy O
drinking O
days O
) O
. O

S1 O
Table O
indicates O
clusters O
identified O
as O
showing O
significant O
changes O
from O
pre O
to O
post O
alcohol O
infusion O
, O
as O
well O
as O
associated O
statistics O
. O

For O
the O
seed-to-voxel O
analysis O
, O
reported O
clusters O
survived O
a O
height O
threshold O
of O
uncorrected O
p O
< O
0.001 O
with O
a O
cluster O
level O
extent O
threshold O
of O
FDR-corrected O
p O
< O
0.05 O
. O

In O
Figs O
3–5 O
, O
these O
clusters O
are O
shown O
overlaid O
on O
structural O
brain O
cutaways O
. O

Corresponding O
line O
plots O
are O
only O
for O
visual O
interpretation O
of O
these O
effects O
. O

We O
also O
examined O
sex O
effects O
on O
alcohol-related O
changes O
in O
GPe O
connectivity O
at O
the O
whole O
brain O
level O
; O
there O
were O
no O
significant O
differences O
between O
males O
and O
females O
. O

In O
order O
to O
test O
our O
hypothesis O
that O
the O
interaction O
between O
recent O
drinking O
behaviors O
and O
impulsivity O
would O
contribute O
to O
alcohol-induced O
changes O
in O
GPe O
functional O
connectivity O
, O
we O
extracted O
ROI-to-voxel O
correlation O
values O
between O
the O
seeds O
and O
significant O
clusters O
and O
used O
those O
values O
to O
conduct O
multiple O
regression O
analysis O
in O
R/RStudio O
( O
version O
3.4.2/1.1.383 O
) O
. O

We O
modeled O
drinking O
history O
, O
impulsivity O
, O
and O
the O
interaction O
between O
the O
two O
as O
independent O
variables O
on O
the O
dependent O
variable O
of O
change O
in O
GPe O
connectivity O
. O

We O
conducted O
these O
analyses O
only O
for O
significant O
clusters O
identified O
in O
the O
seed-to-voxel O
analysis O
, O
and O
only O
for O
the O
significant O
drinking O
and O
impulsivity O
measures O
. O

For O
the O
drinking O
measures O
identified O
in O
that O
seed-to-voxel O
analysis O
, O
models O
( O
for O
the O
specific O
significant O
cluster O
only O
) O
included O
the O
significant O
drinking O
variable O
as O
well O
as O
one O
of O
the O
two O
significant O
impulsivity O
variables O
; O
thus O
, O
2 O
regressions O
per O
cluster O
were O
run O
. O

Similarly O
, O
for O
significant O
impulsivity O
measures O
, O
2 O
regressions O
per O
cluster O
were O
run O
( O
as O
there O
are O
two O
drinking O
variables O
) O
. O

This O
resulted O
in O
a O
total O
of O
20 O
tests O
. O

We O
then O
adjusted O
the O
omnibus O
test O
statistics O
to O
correct O
for O
multiple O
comparisons O
using O
FDR O
of O
< O
0.05 O
. O

Of O
those O
regressions O
, O
only O
those O
with O
significant O
interaction O
effects O
are O
reported O
. O

Impaired O
interactions O
among O
white‐matter O
functional O
networks O
in O
antipsychotic‐naive O
first‐episode O
schizophrenia O
Abstract O
Schizophrenia O
has O
been O
conceptualized O
as O
a O
disorder O
arising O
from O
structurally O
pathological O
alterations O
to O
white‐matter O
fibers O
in O
the O
brain O
. O

However O
, O
few O
studies O
have O
focused O
on O
white‐matter O
functional O
changes O
in O
schizophrenia O
. O

Considering O
that O
converging O
evidence O
suggests O
that O
white‐matter O
resting O
state O
functional O
MRI O
( O
rsfMRI O
) O
signals O
can O
effectively O
depict O
neuronal O
activity O
and O
psychopathological O
status O
, O
this O
study O
examined O
white‐matter O
network‐level O
interactions O
in O
antipsychotic‐naive O
first‐episode O
schizophrenia O
( O
FES O
) O
to O
facilitate O
the O
interpretation O
of O
the O
psychiatric O
pathological O
mechanisms O
in O
schizophrenia O
. O

We O
recruited O
42 O
FES O
patients O
( O
FESs O
) O
and O
38 O
healthy O
controls O
( O
HCs O
) O
, O
all O
of O
whom O
underwent O
rsfMRI O
. O

We O
identified O
11 O
white‐matter O
functional O
networks O
, O
which O
could O
be O
further O
classified O
into O
deep O
, O
middle O
, O
and O
superficial O
layers O
of O
networks O
. O

We O
then O
examined O
network‐level O
interactions O
among O
these O
11 O
white‐matter O
functional O
networks O
using O
coefficient O
Granger O
causality O
analysis O
. O

We O
employed O
group O
comparisons O
on O
the O
influences O
among O
11 O
networks O
using O
network‐based O
statistic O
. O

Excitatory O
influences O
from O
the O
middle O
superior O
corona O
radiate O
network O
to O
the O
superficial O
orbitofrontal O
and O
deep O
networks O
were O
disrupted O
in O
FESs O
compared O
with O
HCs O
. O

Additionally O
, O
an O
extra O
failure O
of O
suppression O
within O
superficial O
networks O
( O
including O
the O
frontoparietal O
network O
, O
temporofrontal O
network O
, O
and O
the O
orbitofrontal O
network O
) O
was O
observed O
in O
FESs O
. O

We O
additionally O
recruited O
an O
independent O
cohort O
( O
13 O
FESs O
and O
13 O
HCs O
) O
from O
another O
center O
to O
examine O
the O
replicability O
of O
our O
findings O
across O
centers O
. O

Similar O
replication O
results O
further O
verified O
the O
white‐matter O
functional O
network O
interaction O
model O
of O
schizophrenia O
. O

The O
novel O
findings O
of O
impaired O
interactions O
among O
white‐matter O
functional O
networks O
in O
schizophrenia O
indicate O
that O
the O
pathophysiology O
of O
schizophrenia O
may O
also O
lie O
in O
white‐matter O
functional O
abnormalities O
. O

METHODS O
Participants O
Primary O
cohort O
A O
total O
of O
80 O
right‐handed O
participants O
were O
recruited O
, O
including O
42 O
FESs O
, O
and O
38 O
sex‐ O
, O
age‐ O
, O
and O
education O
level‐matched O
HCs O
with O
informed O
consent O
( O
see O
Table O
1 O
for O
detailed O
demographic O
and O
clinical O
information O
) O
. O

All O
examinations O
were O
carried O
out O
under O
the O
guidance O
of O
the O
Declaration O
of O
Helsinki O
. O

This O
study O
was O
approved O
by O
the O
Ethics O
Committee O
of O
the O
Second O
Affiliated O
Hospital O
of O
Xinxiang O
Medical O
University O
, O
China O
. O

Patients O
were O
recruited O
from O
outpatient O
treatment O
settings O
at O
the O
Second O
Affiliated O
Hospital O
of O
Xinxiang O
Medical O
University O
, O
a O
psychiatric O
hospital O
with O
1,500 O
beds O
. O

Controls O
were O
recruited O
through O
media O
advertisements O
. O

All O
the O
subjects O
were O
Chinese O
Han O
people O
living O
in O
towns O
around O
the O
hospital O
, O
with O
household O
earnings O
around O
the O
national O
average O
. O

The O
diagnosis O
of O
schizophrenia O
was O
in O
accordance O
with O
the O
Structured O
Clinical O
Interview O
for O
DSM‐IV‐TR O
, O
patient O
version O
( O
SCID‐I/P O
) O
, O
and O
was O
confirmed O
by O
two O
trained O
psychiatrists O
. O

All O
the O
patients O
were O
experiencing O
first‐episode O
psychosis O
with O
less O
than O
1‐year O
disease O
duration O
. O

Psychiatric O
symptomatology O
of O
the O
FESs O
was O
evaluated O
using O
the O
Positive O
and O
Negative O
Syndrome O
Scale O
( O
PANSS O
) O
. O

Both O
HCs O
and O
their O
first‐degree O
relatives O
were O
screened O
using O
the O
nonpatient O
version O
of O
the O
SCID O
to O
rule O
out O
individuals O
who O
presented O
with O
any O
history O
of O
neurological O
disorders O
or O
psychiatric O
illnesses O
. O

Participants O
were O
excluded O
if O
they O
( O
a O
) O
were O
< O
18 O
years O
old O
; O
( O
b O
) O
had O
current O
comorbid O
substance‐use O
disorder O
( O
daily O
consumption O
of O
substances O
for O
at O
least O
1 O
year O
) O
; O
( O
c O
) O
had O
a O
history O
of O
neurological O
disorders O
or O
family O
history O
of O
hereditary O
neurological O
disorders O
; O
( O
d O
) O
had O
gross O
morphological O
anomalies O
as O
evidenced O
by O
brain O
MRI O
scans O
; O
and O
( O
d O
) O
had O
any O
electronic O
or O
metal O
implants O
. O

Replication O
cohort O
Considering O
the O
methodological O
novelty O
of O
this O
study O
and O
increasing O
concern O
about O
reproducibility O
of O
neuroscientific O
findings O
( O
Button O
et O
al. O
, O
2013 O
) O
, O
an O
independent O
replication O
cohort O
was O
necessary O
to O
determine O
the O
replicability O
of O
current O
findings O
. O

A O
total O
of O
26 O
right‐handed O
participants O
were O
recruited O
( O
see O
Table O
S3 O
in O
Supplementary O
5 O
for O
detailed O
demographic O
information O
) O
, O
including O
13 O
FESs O
, O
and O
13 O
sex‐ O
, O
age‐ O
, O
and O
education O
level‐matched O
HCs O
after O
providing O
informed O
consent O
according O
to O
the O
guidelines O
of O
the O
First O
Affiliated O
Hospital O
of O
Chongqing O
Medical O
University O
. O

Patients O
were O
recruited O
from O
outpatient O
treatment O
settings O
at O
the O
First O
Affiliated O
Hospital O
of O
Chongqing O
Medical O
University O
, O
which O
is O
a O
general O
hospital O
with O
3,200 O
beds O
. O

All O
the O
patients O
were O
experiencing O
first‐episode O
psychosis O
with O
less O
than O
1‐year O
disease O
duration O
. O

Controls O
were O
recruited O
through O
media O
advertisements O
. O

All O
the O
participants O
were O
Chinese O
Han O
people O
living O
in O
towns O
around O
the O
hospital O
, O
with O
household O
earnings O
around O
the O
national O
average O
. O

The O
exclusion O
criteria O
were O
the O
same O
for O
both O
the O
primary O
cohort O
and O
the O
replication O
cohort O
. O

See O
Supplementary O
5 O
for O
data O
acquisition O
. O

One O
FES O
patient O
and O
one O
HC O
were O
excluded O
for O
their O
excessive O
head O
motion O
( O
see O
following O
data O
preprocessing O
) O
. O

Ultimately O
, O
24 O
subjects O
took O
part O
in O
further O
analyses O
, O
which O
were O
identical O
with O
data O
analyses O
of O
the O
primary O
cohort O
described O
below O
. O

Data O
acquisition O
Imaging O
data O
of O
the O
primary O
cohort O
were O
collected O
using O
a O
3.0 O
Tesla O
MRI O
scanner O
( O
Siemens O
Medical O
Systems O
, O
Erlangen O
, O
Germany O
) O
at O
the O
Second O
Affiliated O
Hospital O
of O
Xinxiang O
Medical O
University O
. O

Participants O
were O
instructed O
to O
stay O
awake O
with O
their O
eyes O
closed O
and O
not O
to O
think O
of O
anything O
in O
particular O
. O

T1‐weighted O
anatomical O
images O
were O
acquired O
by O
a O
three‐dimensional O
fast O
spoiled O
gradient‐echo O
sequence O
with O
the O
following O
parameters O
: O
TR O
= O
1,900 O
ms O
; O
TE O
= O
2.52 O
ms O
; O
flip O
angle O
= O
90° O
; O
field O
of O
view O
= O
250 O
× O
250 O
mm2 O
; O
matrix O
= O
256 O
× O
256 O
, O
176 O
axial O
slices O
; O
slice O
thickness O
= O
1 O
mm O
, O
no O
gap O
. O

Resting‐state O
functional O
images O
were O
acquired O
using O
an O
echo‐planar O
imaging O
( O
EPI O
) O
sequence O
with O
the O
following O
parameters O
: O
TR O
= O
2,000 O
ms O
; O
TE O
= O
30 O
ms O
; O
flip O
angle O
= O
90° O
; O
field O
of O
view O
= O
220 O
× O
220 O
mm2 O
; O
matrix O
= O
64 O
× O
64 O
, O
33 O
axial O
slices O
; O
slice O
thickness O
= O
3 O
mm O
, O
0.6 O
mm O
gap O
; O
240 O
volumes O
. O

Data O
Preprocessing O
fMRI O
data O
of O
both O
the O
primary O
cohort O
and O
the O
replication O
cohort O
were O
preprocessed O
using O
the O
Data O
Processing O
Assistant O
for O
resting‐state O
fMRI O
software O
( O
DPARSF O
, O
Advanced O
Edition O
, O
V4.3 O
; O
http O
: O
//www.restfmri.net O
) O
and O
Statistical O
Parametric O
Mapping O
toolkits O
( O
SPM8 O
; O
http O
: O
//www.fil.ion.ucl.ac.uk/spm O
) O
. O

T1‐weighted O
anatomical O
images O
were O
segmented O
into O
white‐matter O
, O
gray‐matter O
, O
and O
cerebrospinal O
fluid O
( O
CSF O
) O
using O
SPM8 O
's O
New O
Segment O
algorithm O
and O
then O
normalized O
to O
the O
Montreal O
Neurological O
Institute O
template O
. O

The O
first O
10 O
volumes O
were O
discarded O
. O

The O
remaining O
volumes O
were O
then O
slice‐time O
corrected O
and O
motion O
corrected O
( O
cutoff O
< O
3 O
mm O
or O
3° O
) O
to O
the O
mean O
functional O
image O
, O
and O
coregistered O
with O
an O
anatomical O
image O
. O

One O
FES O
patient O
and O
one O
HC O
in O
the O
replication O
cohort O
were O
excluded O
for O
excessive O
head O
movement O
, O
and O
no O
participant O
was O
excluded O
in O
the O
primary O
cohort O
. O

The O
framewise O
displacement O
( O
FD O
) O
was O
calculated O
and O
used O
to O
determine O
motion O
“ O
spikes O
” O
( O
FD O
> O
1 O
mm O
) O
to O
further O
minimize O
motion O
effects O
( O
J. O
Guo O
et O
al. O
, O
2019 O
; O
X. O
Guo O
et O
al. O
, O
2019 O
; O
Power O
, O
Barnes O
, O
Snyder O
, O
Schlaggar O
, O
& O
Petersen O
, O
2012 O
) O
. O

The O
functional O
images O
were O
then O
detrended O
to O
remove O
linear O
drifts O
. O

Next O
, O
nuisance O
covariates O
, O
including O
24 O
head O
motion O
parameters O
( O
Friston O
, O
Williams O
, O
Howard O
, O
Frackowiak O
, O
& O
Turner O
, O
1996 O
) O
and O
the O
mean O
CSF O
signals O
were O
regressed O
out O
, O
while O
the O
white‐matter O
and O
global O
brain O
signals O
( O
Han O
et O
al. O
, O
2019 O
) O
were O
not O
regressed O
out O
to O
avoid O
eliminating O
signals O
of O
interest O
. O

Additionally O
, O
motion O
“ O
spikes O
” O
were O
also O
included O
as O
separate O
regressors O
to O
effectively O
censored O
the O
data O
at O
the O
spike O
without O
further O
changes O
to O
correlation O
values O
( O
Jiang O
et O
al. O
, O
2018 O
; O
R. O
Li O
et O
al. O
, O
2018 O
) O
. O

A O
0.01–0.15 O
Hz O
temporal O
band‐pass O
filter O
was O
applied O
to O
reduce O
nonneuronal O
contributions O
to O
BOLD O
fluctuations O
. O

Next O
, O
white‐matter O
functional O
images O
were O
spatially O
smoothed O
. O

Specifically O
, O
the O
T1 O
segmentation O
image O
for O
each O
participant O
was O
coregistered O
to O
the O
functional O
space O
for O
identifying O
the O
white‐matter O
mask O
( O
using O
a O
threshold O
of O
0.5 O
as O
a O
previous O
study O
suggested O
) O
( O
Peer O
et O
al. O
, O
2017 O
) O
. O

The O
functional O
images O
were O
then O
smoothed O
( O
4 O
mm O
full‐width O
half‐maximum O
) O
on O
the O
mask O
. O

The O
smoothed O
white‐matter O
functional O
images O
were O
used O
for O
further O
analyses O
. O

Finally O
, O
the O
images O
were O
normalized O
to O
the O
standard O
EPI O
template O
and O
resampling O
to O
3 O
mm3 O
cubic O
voxels O
. O

White‐matter O
functional O
networks O
clustering O
The O
analysis O
codes O
were O
adapted O
from O
the O
online O
codes O
published O
by O
Peer O
and O
colleagues O
( O
Peer O
et O
al. O
, O
2017 O
) O
, O
and O
the O
analysis O
steps O
are O
briefly O
described O
here O
. O

First O
, O
the O
unified O
group‐level O
white‐matter O
masks O
were O
obtained O
using O
the O
T1‐weighted O
anatomical O
image O
segmentation O
results O
. O

Voxels O
with O
a O
percentage O
of O
participants O
> O
60 O
% O
were O
identified O
as O
the O
group‐level O
white‐matter O
mask O
( O
Peer O
et O
al. O
, O
2017 O
) O
. O

The O
subcortical O
areas O
( O
based O
on O
the O
Harvard‐Oxford O
Atlas O
) O
were O
removed O
from O
the O
white‐matter O
mask O
. O

Next O
, O
the O
white‐matter O
functional O
networks O
were O
identified O
by O
a O
clustering O
approach O
based O
on O
the O
Pearson O
's O
correlation O
matrices O
between O
white‐matter O
voxels O
that O
group O
masks O
restricted O
. O

K‐means O
clustering O
( O
distance O
metric‐correlation O
, O
10 O
replicates O
) O
was O
employed O
on O
the O
averaged O
correlation O
matrices O
across O
groups O
. O

The O
numbers O
of O
clusters O
ranged O
from O
2 O
to O
22 O
. O

Finally O
, O
by O
assessing O
the O
stability O
of O
the O
number O
of O
clusters O
using O
an O
averaged O
Dice O
's O
coefficient O
( O
the O
threshold O
was O
set O
at O
0.85 O
) O
, O
the O
most O
stable O
and O
detailed O
white‐matter O
functional O
network O
masks O
were O
obtained O
. O

( O
See O
Supplementary O
1 O
for O
further O
details O
concerning O
the O
steps O
taken O
in O
white‐matter O
functional O
networks O
clustering O
. O
) O

In O
the O
primary O
cohort O
, O
according O
to O
the O
Dice O
's O
coefficient O
of O
each O
number O
of O
clusters O
, O
the O
most O
stable O
and O
detailed O
white‐matter O
functional O
network O
number O
was O
11 O
( O
see O
Figure O
S1 O
in O
Supplementary O
1 O
) O
. O

Similar O
to O
the O
previous O
study O
( O
Peer O
et O
al. O
, O
2017 O
) O
, O
each O
white‐matter O
functional O
network O
was O
compared O
with O
20 O
major O
white‐matter O
fiber O
tracts O
based O
on O
the O
JHU O
white‐matter O
tractography O
atlas O
( O
Hua O
et O
al. O
, O
2008 O
) O
to O
measure O
the O
network‐tract O
correspondence O
. O

Moreover O
, O
as O
suggested O
by O
Peer O
et O
al. O
, O
these O
networks O
were O
further O
compared O
with O
48 O
white‐matter O
tracts O
defined O
by O
the O
ICBM O
DTI O
workgroup O
to O
estimate O
more O
accurate O
correspondence O
. O

The O
symmetrical O
, O
interlaced O
pattern O
of O
white‐matter O
functional O
networks O
could O
be O
divided O
into O
three O
layers O
( O
superficial O
, O
middle O
, O
and O
deep O
) O
. O

( O
Detailed O
network O
information O
is O
shown O
in O
Table O
2 O
. O
) O

In O
the O
replication O
cohort O
, O
the O
most O
stable O
and O
detailed O
white‐matter O
functional O
network O
number O
was O
11 O
according O
to O
the O
Dice O
's O
coefficient O
of O
each O
number O
of O
clusters O
( O
see O
Figure O
S4 O
in O
Supplementary O
5 O
) O
, O
which O
were O
also O
classified O
into O
deep O
, O
middle O
, O
and O
superficial O
layers O
of O
networks O
. O

Coefficient O
GCA O
Out‐strength O
: O
Sum O
of O
absolute O
regression O
coefficients O
of O
certain O
network O
where O
the O
network O
is O
the O
source O
variable O
to O
significantly O
predict O
other O
networks O
. O

It O
denotes O
Granger O
causal O
afferent O
connections O
of O
each O
network O
. O

In‐strength O
: O
Sum O
of O
absolute O
regression O
coefficients O
of O
certain O
network O
where O
the O
network O
is O
the O
target O
variable O
significantly O
predicted O
by O
other O
networks O
. O

It O
denotes O
Granger O
causal O
efferent O
connections O
of O
each O
network O
. O

The O
signed O
and O
directional O
influences O
among O
11 O
white‐matter O
functional O
networks O
were O
measured O
using O
cGCA O
. O

For O
each O
network O
, O
the O
individual O
preprocessed O
resting‐state O
fMRI O
time O
series O
was O
extracted O
by O
averaging O
the O
time O
series O
of O
all O
voxels O
within O
it O
. O

The O
influence O
strengths O
among O
functional O
networks O
were O
evaluated O
by O
regression O
coefficients O
of O
the O
multivariate O
autoregression O
model O
in O
REST O
software O
( O
V1.8 O
, O
http O
: O
//www.restfmri.net O
) O
( O
see O
Supplementary O
2 O
for O
details O
) O
. O

Each O
regression O
coefficient O
characterizes O
the O
signed O
strength O
and O
direction O
of O
the O
relationship O
between O
two O
networks O
, O
in O
line O
with O
our O
previous O
works O
( O
Liao O
et O
al. O
, O
2018 O
) O
. O

Positive O
coefficients O
denote O
excitant O
paths O
( O
source O
activity O
predicts O
subsequent O
increases O
in O
target O
activity O
) O
, O
while O
negative O
coefficients O
denote O
inhibited O
paths O
( O
source O
predicts O
subsequent O
decreases O
in O
target O
) O
. O

Finally O
, O
a O
directed O
asymmetric O
matrix O
( O
11 O
× O
11 O
regression O
coefficient O
matrix O
) O
was O
obtained O
for O
each O
participant O
. O

The O
definition O
of O
the O
following O
cGCA O
graph‐theoretic O
metric O
( O
Liao O
et O
al. O
, O
2011 O
) O
is O
listed O
to O
describe O
the O
outflow/inflow O
influence O
strengths O
of O
each O
network O
: O
Disturbance O
of O
correlation O
analyses O
Considering O
the O
relatively O
low O
frequency O
scale O
of O
our O
study O
, O
the O
spread O
of O
hemodynamic O
effects O
across O
time O
may O
potentially O
disturb O
direct O
correlation O
at O
the O
same O
time O
point O
. O

Therefore O
, O
the O
seemingly O
across‐time O
causality O
we O
observed O
can O
be O
simply O
due O
to O
disturbance O
of O
correlation O
. O

For O
diluting O
the O
effect O
of O
direct O
correlation O
, O
the O
Pearson O
's O
correlations O
among O
white‐matter O
functional O
networks O
were O
calculated O
and O
added O
as O
covariates O
in O
group O
comparison O
of O
cGCA O
in O
the O
primary O
cohort O
( O
see O
Supplementary O
2 O
for O
further O
details O
) O
. O

Statistical O
analyses O
In O
the O
primary O
cohort O
, O
the O
within‐group O
11 O
networks O
influence O
patterns O
were O
examined O
using O
one‐sample O
t O
tests O
on O
the O
influence O
coefficient O
matrices O
across O
all O
participants O
including O
FESs O
and O
HCs O
. O

The O
out/in O
strengths O
of O
each O
network O
were O
calculated O
within O
the O
significant O
group O
mask O
across O
all O
subjects O
. O

The O
11 O
networks O
influence O
differences O
between O
FESs O
and O
HCs O
were O
measured O
using O
permutation O
tests O
( O
5,000 O
times O
permutations O
) O
( O
Zhang O
et O
al. O
, O
2011 O
) O
, O
controlling O
for O
sex O
, O
age O
, O
and O
education O
level O
as O
confounding O
variables O
. O

Specifically O
, O
a O
permutation O
distribution O
of O
differences O
was O
generated O
by O
randomly O
assigning O
each O
subject O
to O
one O
of O
the O
two O
groups O
with O
the O
same O
size O
as O
the O
original O
FES O
and O
HC O
groups O
and O
computing O
their O
between‐group O
differences O
using O
two‐sample O
t O
tests O
with O
sex O
, O
age O
, O
and O
education O
level O
as O
confounding O
variables O
. O

This O
procedure O
was O
repeated O
for O
5,000 O
permutations O
. O

The O
p O
value O
was O
estimated O
by O
calculating O
the O
percentage O
of O
permutations O
higher O
than O
the O
actual O
group O
difference O
measured O
by O
two‐sample O
t O
test O
with O
the O
same O
covariates O
. O

The O
statistical O
significance O
level O
was O
set O
at O
p O
< O
.05 O
and O
network‐based O
statistic O
( O
NBS O
) O
adjusted O
for O
multiple O
testing O
. O

By O
using O
this O
statistical O
method O
, O
connected O
subnetworks O
of O
edges O
showing O
a O
particular O
effect O
of O
a O
size O
larger O
than O
which O
would O
be O
expected O
by O
chance O
can O
be O
identified O
( O
Zalesky O
, O
Fornito O
, O
& O
Bullmore O
, O
2010 O
) O
. O

As O
the O
11 O
white‐matter O
networks O
can O
be O
further O
classified O
into O
deep O
, O
middle O
, O
and O
superficial O
layers O
of O
networks O
, O
for O
each O
subject O
, O
the O
out/in O
strengths O
of O
each O
layer O
were O
calculated O
by O
summing O
the O
absolute O
out/in O
strengths O
of O
all O
belonging O
networks O
. O

The O
out/in O
strengths O
of O
tri‐layer O
networks O
were O
compared O
between O
FESs O
and O
HCs O
using O
two‐sample O
t O
tests O
( O
p O
< O
.05 O
) O
, O
false O
discovery O
rate O
( O
FDR O
) O
corrected O
. O

The O
relationships O
between O
altered O
11 O
networks O
influence O
values O
and O
symptom O
severity O
( O
PANSS‐N O
or O
PANSS‐P O
scores O
) O
were O
investigated O
using O
Pearson O
's O
correlation O
analyses O
in O
FESs O
. O

In O
the O
replication O
cohort O
, O
the O
within‐group O
networks O
influence O
patterns O
were O
also O
examined O
using O
one‐sample O
t O
tests O
across O
all O
participants O
including O
FESs O
and O
HCs O
. O

Group O
differences O
on O
the O
11 O
networks O
influence O
between O
FESs O
and O
HCs O
were O
measured O
using O
two‐sample O
t O
tests O
( O
p O
< O
.05 O
, O
FDR O
corrected O
) O
, O
controlling O
for O
sex O
, O
age O
, O
and O
education O
level O
as O
confounding O
variables O
. O

The O
out O
strengths O
of O
tri‐layer O
networks O
were O
compared O
between O
FESs O
and O
HCs O
using O
two‐sample O
t O
tests O
( O
p O
< O
.05 O
, O
FDR O
corrected O
) O
. O

Validation O
analyses O
Considering O
that O
potential O
leakage O
of O
the O
gray‐matter O
fMRI O
signal O
may O
affect O
the O
clustering O
pattern O
of O
the O
white‐matter O
fMRI O
signal O
, O
two O
relative O
stricter O
group‐level O
masks O
( O
percentages O
> O
70 O
and O
80 O
% O
) O
were O
applied O
to O
identify O
white‐matter O
voxels O
to O
validate O
the O
consistency O
of O
the O
main O
results O
of O
the O
primary O
cohort O
( O
see O
Supplementary O
3 O
for O
further O
details O
) O
. O

Disturbances O
across O
whole O
brain O
networks O
during O
reward O
anticipation O
in O
an O
abstinent O
addiction O
population O
Graphical O
abstract O
Network O
based O
statistics O
( O
NBS O
) O
analyses O
detected O
a O
graph O
sub-network O
comprising O
153 O
edges O
between O
59 O
nodes O
of O
the O
connectome O
where O
the O
ADD O
group O
demonstrated O
significantly O
less O
connectivity O
compared O
with O
the O
CON O
group O
. O

These O
differences O
in O
connectivity O
were O
mostly O
intra-hemispheric O
( O
55 O
% O
) O
, O
the O
majority O
( O
38 O
% O
) O
being O
in O
the O
right O
hemisphere O
. O

The O
anatomical O
distribution O
of O
these O
connectivity O
differences O
between O
the O
two O
groups O
involved O
frontal O
( O
insula O
, O
inferior O
frontal O
gyrus O
, O
orbitofrontal O
cortex O
) O
, O
limbic-associated O
( O
anterior O
cingulate O
gyrus O
, O
thalamus O
) O
, O
and O
striatal O
( O
accumbens O
, O
caudate O
, O
pallidum O
) O
regions O
. O

The O
connectivity O
differences O
reported O
in O
this O
ADD O
sample O
indicate O
alterations O
between O
cognitive O
, O
striatal O
and O
limbic-associated O
regions O
during O
reward O
anticipation O
that O
persist O
into O
extended O
abstinence O
. O

Highlights O
Analytical O
methods O
can O
capture O
key O
features O
of O
whole O
brain O
networks O
in O
addiction O
. O

We O
compared O
reward O
network O
connectivity O
in O
addiction O
( O
ADD O
) O
and O
control O
( O
CON O
) O
groups O
. O

The O
ADD O
group O
showed O
disruptions O
in O
global O
network O
connectivity O
. O

Global O
network O
measures O
may O
be O
more O
sensitive O
than O
traditional O
voxel-wise O
analyses O
. O

The O
prevalent O
spatial O
distribution O
of O
abnormalities O
reported O
in O
cognitive O
fMRI O
studies O
in O
addiction O
suggests O
there O
are O
extensive O
disruptions O
across O
whole O
brain O
networks O
. O

Studies O
using O
resting O
state O
have O
reported O
disruptions O
in O
network O
connectivity O
in O
addiction O
, O
but O
these O
studies O
have O
not O
revealed O
characteristics O
of O
network O
functioning O
during O
critical O
psychological O
processes O
that O
are O
disrupted O
in O
addiction O
populations O
. O

Analytic O
methods O
that O
can O
capture O
key O
features O
of O
whole O
brain O
networks O
during O
psychological O
processes O
may O
be O
more O
sensitive O
in O
revealing O
additional O
and O
widespread O
neural O
disturbances O
in O
addiction O
, O
that O
are O
the O
provisions O
for O
relapse O
risk O
, O
and O
targets O
for O
medication O
development O
. O

The O
current O
study O
compared O
a O
substance O
addiction O
( O
ADD O
; O
n O
= O
83 O
) O
group O
in O
extended O
abstinence O
with O
a O
control O
( O
CON O
; O
n O
= O
68 O
) O
group O
on O
functional O
MRI O
( O
voxel-wise O
activation O
) O
and O
global O
network O
( O
connectivity O
) O
measures O
related O
to O
reward O
anticipation O
on O
a O
monetary O
incentive O
delay O
task O
. O

In O
the O
absence O
of O
group O
differences O
on O
MID O
performance O
, O
the O
ADD O
group O
showed O
reduced O
activation O
predominantly O
across O
temporal O
and O
visual O
regions O
, O
but O
not O
across O
the O
striatum O
. O

The O
ADD O
group O
also O
showed O
disruptions O
in O
global O
network O
connectivity O
( O
lower O
clustering O
coefficient O
and O
higher O
characteristic O
path O
length O
) O
, O
and O
significantly O
less O
connectivity O
across O
a O
sub-network O
comprising O
frontal O
, O
temporal O
, O
limbic O
and O
striatal O
nodes O
. O

These O
results O
show O
that O
an O
addiction O
group O
in O
extended O
abstinence O
exhibit O
localised O
disruptions O
in O
brain O
activation O
, O
but O
more O
extensive O
disturbances O
in O
functional O
connectivity O
across O
whole O
brain O
networks O
. O

We O
propose O
that O
measures O
of O
global O
network O
functioning O
may O
be O
more O
sensitive O
in O
highlighting O
latent O
and O
more O
widespread O
neural O
disruptions O
during O
critical O
psychological O
processes O
in O
addiction O
and O
other O
psychiatric O
disorders O
. O

Material O
and O
methods O
Participants O
Sixty-eight O
control O
( O
CON O
: O
mean O
age O
39.79 O
± O
1.22 O
; O
18 O
females O
, O
50 O
males O
) O
and O
83 O
addiction O
( O
ADD O
: O
mean O
age O
40.05 O
± O
0.92 O
; O
16 O
females O
, O
67 O
males O
) O
participants O
completed O
the O
current O
study O
. O

The O
current O
dataset O
was O
collected O
as O
part O
of O
a O
multi-centre O
study O
involving O
three O
study O
sites O
in O
the O
United O
Kingdom O
( O
Imperial O
College O
London O
, O
University O
of O
Cambridge O
and O
University O
of O
Manchester O
– O
ICCAM O
) O
. O

For O
a O
more O
detailed O
description O
of O
the O
ICCAM O
Platform O
, O
see O
) O
and O
. O

Inclusion O
criteria O
were O
individuals O
who O
met O
DSM-IV O
measures O
for O
current O
or O
prior O
substance O
dependence O
( O
e.g. O
, O
alcohol O
, O
cocaine O
, O
opiates O
) O
. O

The O
ADD O
group O
consisted O
of O
29 O
( O
35 O
% O
) O
pure O
alcohol-dependent O
, O
42 O
( O
50 O
% O
) O
poly O
substance-dependent O
( O
e.g. O
, O
alcohol O
and O
cocaine O
, O
cocaine O
and O
opiate O
) O
and O
12 O
( O
15 O
% O
) O
mono O
substance-dependent O
( O
e.g. O
, O
cocaine O
, O
opiates O
) O
volunteers O
. O

While O
addiction O
studies O
typically O
recruit O
volunteers O
in O
early O
abstinence O
, O
there O
was O
no O
upper O
limit O
in O
the O
current O
study O
. O

The O
mean O
abstinence O
length O
from O
alcohol O
in O
the O
current O
sample O
was O
15.00 O
± O
3.50 O
months O
, O
while O
for O
cocaine O
and O
opiates O
it O
was O
27.99 O
± O
3.72 O
and O
39.04 O
± O
7.75 O
months O
, O
respectively O
. O

Therefore O
, O
the O
current O
ADD O
group O
was O
made O
of O
a O
heterogenous O
sample O
with O
former O
substance-dependencies O
, O
and O
with O
variable O
levels O
of O
substance O
abstinence O
at O
the O
time O
of O
testing O
. O

This O
meant O
that O
there O
was O
no O
substance O
dependence O
measure O
that O
was O
shared O
by O
all O
members O
of O
the O
ADD O
group O
. O

The O
CON O
group O
had O
no O
previous O
history O
of O
substance O
abuse O
, O
as O
assessed O
using O
the O
Alcohol O
, O
Smoking O
and O
Substance O
Involvement O
Screening O
Test O
( O
ASSIST O
) O
and O
timeline O
follow-back O
. O

All O
participants O
were O
required O
to O
provide O
a O
negative O
breath O
alcohol O
test O
and O
a O
negative O
urine O
sample O
for O
various O
drugs O
of O
abuse O
on O
the O
day O
of O
testing O
( O
screening O
for O
the O
presence O
of O
amphetamines O
, O
benzodiazepines O
, O
cannabinoids O
, O
cocaine O
and O
opiates O
) O
. O

The O
Mini-International O
Neuropsychiatric O
Interview O
( O
MINI O
) O
was O
administered O
to O
all O
participants O
by O
a O
trained O
psychiatrist O
to O
screen O
for O
the O
presence O
of O
Axis O
I O
psychiatric O
disorders O
that O
were O
part O
of O
the O
study O
exclusion O
criteria O
. O

Exclusion O
criteria O
included O
1 O
) O
current O
use O
of O
regular O
prescription O
or O
non-prescription O
medication O
that O
could O
not O
be O
stopped O
; O
2 O
) O
current O
primary O
axis O
I O
diagnosis O
, O
past O
history O
of O
psychosis O
( O
unless O
drug-induced O
) O
; O
3 O
) O
current O
or O
past O
history O
of O
enduring O
severe O
mental O
illness O
( O
e.g. O
, O
schizophrenia O
, O
bipolar O
affective O
disorder O
) O
; O
4 O
) O
other O
current O
or O
past O
psychiatric O
history O
that O
, O
in O
the O
opinion O
of O
a O
psychiatrist O
, O
contraindicated O
participation O
; O
5 O
) O
history O
or O
presence O
of O
a O
significant O
neurological O
diagnosis O
that O
may O
have O
influenced O
the O
outcome O
or O
analysis O
of O
the O
results O
; O
6 O
) O
claustrophobia O
or O
unable O
to O
lie O
still O
in O
the O
MRI O
scanner O
for O
up O
to O
90 O
min O
and O
7 O
) O
presence O
of O
a O
cardiac O
pacemaker O
, O
other O
electronic O
device O
or O
other O
MRI O
contraindication O
, O
including O
pregnancy O
, O
as O
assessed O
by O
a O
standard O
pre-MRI O
questionnaire O
. O

Secondary O
or O
lifetime O
history O
of O
depression O
or O
anxiety O
was O
permitted O
in O
both O
the O
ADD O
and O
CON O
groups O
since O
these O
are O
very O
common O
psychiatric O
disorders O
. O

All O
participants O
provided O
written O
informed O
consent O
. O

The O
study O
was O
conducted O
in O
accordance O
with O
the O
Declaration O
of O
Helsinki O
. O

Ethical O
approval O
was O
obtained O
from O
West O
London O
and O
Gene O
Therapy O
Advisory O
Committee O
National O
Research O
Ethics O
Service O
Committee O
( O
11/H0707/9 O
) O
and O
relevant O
research O
governance O
and O
Participant O
Identification O
Centre O
( O
PIC O
) O
approvals O
obtained O
. O

Monetary O
incentive O
delay O
task O
( O
MID O
) O
We O
used O
a O
“ O
monetary O
incentive O
delay O
task O
” O
( O
MID O
) O
, O
which O
was O
based O
on O
that O
originally O
employed O
by O
Knutson O
, O
and O
which O
we O
have O
used O
to O
already O
publish O
data O
from O
the O
ICCAM O
platform O
. O

At O
the O
beginning O
of O
each O
trial O
, O
participants O
viewed O
one O
of O
three O
symbols O
( O
a O
cue O
) O
that O
indicated O
the O
potential O
to O
gain O
fifty O
pence O
( O
square O
containing O
an O
ascending O
arrow O
) O
, O
lose O
fifty O
pence O
( O
square O
containing O
a O
descending O
arrow O
) O
or O
experience O
no O
financial O
outcome O
( O
square O
containing O
a O
horizontal O
line O
- O
here O
referred O
to O
as O
a O
neutral O
trial O
) O
. O

Each O
cue O
was O
presented O
for O
one O
second O
, O
with O
a O
variable O
duration O
( O
2–4 O
s O
) O
for O
the O
subsequent O
anticipation O
period O
. O

Following O
the O
anticipation O
period O
, O
participants O
made O
a O
button O
press O
response O
upon O
the O
presentation O
of O
a O
visual O
target O
( O
star O
located O
within O
a O
circle O
) O
. O

Following O
their O
response O
to O
the O
visual O
target O
, O
participants O
received O
feedback O
( O
1.5 O
s O
) O
as O
to O
whether O
they O
were O
successful O
( O
“ O
Hit O
” O
) O
or O
unsuccessful O
( O
“ O
Miss O
” O
) O
on O
that O
trial O
and O
saw O
a O
running O
total O
of O
their O
winnings O
up O
to O
that O
point O
in O
the O
task O
. O

Following O
feedback O
, O
there O
was O
an O
end O
fixation O
period O
( O
3–5 O
s O
) O
before O
the O
commencement O
of O
the O
next O
trial O
. O

Because O
the O
primary O
objective O
of O
ICCAM O
was O
to O
examine O
the O
neural O
correlates O
of O
reward O
anticipation O
, O
we O
chose O
to O
use O
a O
smaller O
number O
of O
loss O
trials O
in O
order O
to O
amplify O
the O
incentive O
salience O
of O
the O
gain O
trials O
during O
the O
task O
. O

Consequently O
, O
there O
was O
a O
total O
of O
18 O
gain O
, O
6 O
lose O
and O
18 O
neutral O
trials O
on O
each O
run O
of O
the O
task O
. O

The O
MID O
task O
was O
tailored O
to O
adapt O
to O
the O
visual O
target O
reaction O
time O
of O
each O
participant O
by O
using O
a O
staircase O
algorithm O
, O
such O
that O
the O
presentation O
of O
the O
visual O
target O
became O
shorter O
as O
performance O
improved O
during O
the O
experiment O
. O

This O
enabled O
us O
to O
set O
a O
limit O
on O
the O
success O
rate O
of O
each O
participant O
( O
∼66 O
% O
) O
, O
which O
additionally O
served O
to O
incentivize O
participants O
to O
engage O
in O
the O
task O
. O

Participants O
were O
instructed O
to O
maximize O
their O
winnings O
and O
were O
told O
they O
would O
receive O
them O
at O
the O
end O
of O
the O
study O
. O

Dependent O
measures O
were O
accuracy O
( O
percentage O
) O
and O
mean O
reaction O
time O
( O
milliseconds O
) O
to O
the O
visual O
target O
on O
each O
of O
the O
gain O
, O
lose O
and O
neutral O
trials O
, O
and O
the O
amount O
won O
( O
£ O
) O
on O
the O
task O
. O

Participants O
completed O
two O
runs O
of O
the O
task O
( O
432 O
s O
each O
) O
during O
scanning O
. O

The O
task O
was O
programmed O
using O
E-Prime O
version O
2.0 O
( O
Psychology O
Software O
Tools O
, O
Pittsburgh O
, O
USA O
) O
. O

Statistics O
Group O
demographics O
were O
compared O
using O
simple O
independent O
samples O
t-test O
analyses O
. O

For O
analyses O
conducted O
on O
MID O
performance O
, O
two O
( O
Group O
: O
CON O
vs. O
ADD O
) O
by O
two O
( O
Condition O
: O
Gain O
vs O
. O

Neutral O
) O
analyses O
of O
variance O
were O
conducted O
. O

The O
CON O
and O
ADD O
groups O
were O
also O
compared O
on O
the O
lose O
accuracy O
and O
lose O
reaction O
time O
performance O
measures O
, O
as O
well O
as O
the O
amount O
of O
money O
won O
( O
£ O
) O
, O
using O
analyses O
of O
variance O
. O

These O
analyses O
were O
conducted O
controlling O
for O
study O
site O
. O

For O
the O
graph O
measures O
( O
see O
below O
) O
we O
conducted O
two O
( O
Group O
: O
CON O
vs. O
ADD O
) O
by O
five O
( O
1 O
⩽ O
K O
⩽ O
5 O
) O
analyses O
of O
variance O
, O
while O
also O
controlling O
for O
study O
site O
. O

All O
these O
analyses O
were O
conducted O
using O
