permutation O
testing O
( O
5000 O
iterations O
) O
in O
the O
R O
statistical O
software O
package O
( O
www.R-project.org O
) O
. O

Functional O
MRI O
( O
fMRI O
) O
Data O
acquisition O
The O
ICCAM O
platform O
was O
designed O
to O
allow O
the O
rapid O
testing O
across O
sites O
of O
multiple O
compounds O
relevant O
to O
addiction O
treatment O
. O

Imaging O
at O
multiple O
sites O
in O
parallel O
on O
the O
ICCAM O
platform O
accelerated O
study O
completion O
, O
through O
the O
sharing O
of O
expertise O
, O
infrastructure O
and O
capacity O
. O

For O
a O
more O
comprehensive O
description O
of O
data O
acquisition O
across O
the O
three O
sites O
on O
ICCAM O
, O
please O
see O
McGonigle O
et O
al O
. O

Briefly O
, O
all O
centres O
operated O
MRI O
machines O
with O
a O
main O
magnetic O
field O
of O
3 O
T O
( O
T O
) O
. O

Centres O
in O
London O
and O
Cambridge O
operated O
nominally O
identical O
3 O
T O
Siemens O
Tim O
Trio O
systems O
running O
the O
syngo O
MR O
B17 O
software O
with O
a O
Siemens O
32 O
channel O
receive-only O
phased-array O
head O
coil O
. O

The O
Manchester O
centre O
operated O
a O
3 O
T O
Philips O
Achieva O
running O
version O
2.6.3.5 O
software O
and O
an O
8 O
element O
SENSE O
head O
coil O
. O

For O
anatomical O
images O
, O
160 O
high-resolution O
T1-weighted O
anatomic O
MPRAGE O
axial O
images O
( O
FOV O
256 O
mm O
, O
thickness O
1.0 O
mm O
, O
voxel O
size O
1.0 O
× O
1.0 O
× O
1.0 O
) O
were O
acquired O
( O
total O
duration O
303 O
s O
) O
. O

Functional O
data O
were O
acquired O
using O
a O
T2 O
* O
weighted O
echo-planar O
imaging O
sequence O
collecting O
36 O
non-contiguous O
( O
0 O
% O
gap O
) O
3.0 O
mm O
axial O
slices O
covering O
the O
entire O
brain O
( O
TE O
= O
31 O
ms O
, O
TR O
= O
2000 O
ms O
, O
FOV O
225 O
mm O
, O
64 O
× O
64 O
mm O
matrix O
size O
in O
Fourier O
space O
) O
. O

Each O
run O
of O
the O
MID O
task O
produced O
a O
total O
of O
216 O
volumes O
of O
functional O
MRI O
data O
. O

fMRI O
Data O
analyses O
Data O
pre-processing O
and O
statistical O
analysis O
were O
conducted O
using O
FEAT O
( O
fMRI O
Expert O
Analysis O
Tool O
) O
from O
the O
FMRIB O
Software O
Library O
( O
www.fmrib.ox.ac.uk/fsl O
) O
. O

Pre-statistical O
processing O
was O
as O
follows O
: O
motion O
correction O
utilizing O
FMRIB O
’ O
s O
Linear O
Image O
Registration O
Tool O
( O
MCFLIRT O
; O
non-brain O
matter O
removal O
using O
Brain O
Extraction O
Tool O
( O
BET O
) O
; O
spatial O
smoothing O
with O
a O
5-mm O
full-width O
half O
maximum O
Gaussian O
kernel O
; O
mean-based O
intensity O
normalization O
; O
nonlinear O
high-pass O
temporal O
filtering O
( O
Gaussian-weighted O
least O
squares O
straight O
line O
fit O
, O
with O
sigma O
= O
25.0 O
s O
) O
. O

The O
six O
rigid O
body O
movement O
parameters O
were O
also O
included O
as O
regressors O
in O
the O
model O
in O
FSL O
FEAT O
. O

For O
each O
participant O
, O
first O
level O
whole-brain O
mixed-effects O
analyses O
were O
performed O
by O
modelling O
the O
MID O
anticipation O
periods O
( O
i.e O
. O

gain O
, O
neutral O
) O
as O
explanatory O
variables O
within O
the O
context O
of O
the O
general O
linear O
model O
on O
a O
voxel-by-voxel O
basis O
( O
variable O
boxcar O
functions O
for O
the O
cue O
+ O
variable O
anticipation O
period O
regressors O
were O
convolved O
with O
the O
haemodynamic O
response O
function O
) O
. O

The O
gain O
and O
neutral O
outcome O
periods O
( O
“ O
Hit O
” O
and O
“ O
Miss O
” O
) O
were O
regressed O
out O
of O
the O
functional O
time O
series O
as O
conditions O
of O
no O
interest O
for O
the O
analyses O
reported O
here O
. O

During O
these O
first O
level O
analyses O
, O
the O
gain O
anticipation O
> O
neutral O
anticipation O
contrast O
was O
formulated O
. O

Owing O
to O
the O
small O
number O
of O
loss O
trials O
in O
the O
current O
task O
, O
the O
lose O
cue O
+ O
anticipation O
and O
outcome O
periods O
( O
“ O
Hit O
” O
and O
“ O
Miss O
” O
) O
were O
additionally O
regressed O
out O
of O
the O
functional O
time O
series O
as O
conditions O
of O
no O
interest O
. O

Therefore O
, O
the O
fewer O
number O
of O
lose O
trials O
on O
the O
MID O
task O
meant O
we O
were O
unable O
to O
examine O
voxel-wise O
group O
differences O
in O
loss O
anticipation O
. O

The O
end O
fixation O
period O
of O
the O
task O
served O
as O
the O
implicit O
baseline O
. O

Registration O
was O
conducted O
through O
a O
two-step O
procedure O
, O
whereby O
EPI O
images O
were O
first O
registered O
to O
the O
high-resolution O
T1 O
structural O
image O
, O
then O
into O
standard O
( O
Montreal O
Neurological O
Institute O
, O
MNI O
avg152 O
template O
) O
space O
, O
with O
12-parameter O
affine O
transformations O
. O

Higher-level O
( O
within O
group O
one-sample O
t-tests O
and O
between-group O
independent O
samples O
t-tests O
) O
were O
conducted O
on O
the O
gain O
anticipation O
> O
neutral O
anticipation O
contrast O
using O
the O
randomise O
programme O
in O
FSL O
. O

Randomise O
employs O
a O
permutation O
approach O
through O
resampling O
. O

Significance O
( O
PFWE O
< O
0.05 O
) O
for O
the O
gain O
anticipation O
> O
neutral O
anticipation O
contrast O
on O
both O
the O
one-sample O
and O
independent O
samples O
t-tests O
was O
conducted O
taking O
a O
threshold-free O
cluster O
enhancement O
( O
TFCE O
) O
approach O
and O
using O
5000 O
permutations O
. O

TFCE O
aims O
to O
maintain O
the O
sensitivity O
of O
cluster-based O
thresholding O
, O
while O
avoiding O
the O
arbitrary O
nature O
of O
threshold O
choice O
. O

Given O
the O
differences O
in O
scanners O
across O
the O
three O
sites O
, O
these O
analyses O
were O
conducted O
while O
also O
controlling O
for O
study O
site O
. O

Trial-Wise O
beta O
value O
image O
analyses O
Data O
pre-processing O
was O
also O
initially O
conducted O
using O
FEAT O
( O
fMRI O
Expert O
Analysis O
Tool O
) O
from O
the O
FMRIB O
Software O
Library O
( O
www.fmrib.ox.ac.uk/fsl O
) O
as O
described O
above O
. O

For O
each O
participant O
, O
each O
individual O
gain O
and O
neutral O
anticipation O
epoch O
( O
cue O
+ O
variable O
anticipation O
period O
) O
was O
separately O
modelled O
within O
the O
context O
of O
the O
general O
linear O
model O
. O

This O
approach O
yielded O
a O
total O
of O
18 O
unique O
beta O
value O
images O
for O
each O
of O
the O
gain O
and O
neutral O
anticipation O
conditions O
on O
each O
run O
of O
the O
MID O
task O
. O

This O
meant O
that O
each O
voxel-wise O
beta O
value O
image O
reflected O
the O
magnitude O
of O
the O
hemodynamic O
response O
evoked O
by O
each O
of O
the O
gain O
and O
neutral O
anticipation O
epochs O
. O

Each O
beta O
value O
image O
for O
each O
MID O
run O
was O
then O
subsequently O
registered O
into O
standard O
( O
MNI O
avg152 O
template O
) O
space O
before O
being O
concatenated O
to O
generate O
a O
beta O
value O
“ O
trial-wise O
” O
( O
e.g. O
, O
gain O
anticipation O
) O
time O
series O
. O

Each O
beta O
value O
trial-wise O
time O
series O
for O
each O
MID O
run O
was O
further O
concatenated O
across O
runs O
to O
generate O
a O
single O
beta O
value O
trial-wise O
time O
series O
for O
the O
gain O
and O
neutral O
MID O
anticipation O
conditions O
. O

This O
procedure O
yielded O
a O
thirty-six O
beta O
value O
trial-wise O
time O
series O
image O
for O
each O
participant O
for O
the O
gain O
and O
neutral O
anticipation O
conditions O
. O

The O
neutral O
trial-wise O
time O
series O
was O
then O
simply O
subtracted O
from O
the O
gain O
trial-wise O
time O
series O
to O
yield O
a O
gain O
anticipation O
> O
neutral O
anticipation O
contrast O
time O
series O
( O
see O
Supplementary O
Fig O
. O

1 O
) O
. O

This O
beta O
value O
trial-wise O
time O
series O
method O
has O
been O
previously O
used O
to O
examine O
connectivity O
during O
cognitive O
tasks O
, O
including O
the O
MID O
task O
. O

The O
small O
, O
variable O
( O
performance-dependent O
) O
number O
of O
events O
for O
the O
outcome O
periods O
( O
“ O
hits O
” O
and O
“ O
misses O
” O
) O
, O
and O
the O
small O
number O
of O
loss O
trials O
in O
the O
task O
, O
meant O
that O
we O
could O
not O
generate O
trial-wise O
beta O
value O
images O
for O
these O
events O
. O

Therefore O
, O
gain O
and O
neutral O
outcome O
( O
well O
as O
lose O
anticipation O
and O
outcome O
) O
events O
were O
regressed O
out O
of O
the O
functional O
time O
series O
as O
conditions O
of O
no O
interest O
during O
the O
first O
level O
analyses O
. O

This O
meant O
that O
the O
same O
end O
fixation O
period O
of O
the O
task O
also O
served O
as O
the O
implicit O
baseline O
for O
these O
analyses O
. O

Time O
series O
Extraction O
and O
correlation O
matrices O
Using O
the O
Harvard-Oxford O
atlas O
( O
96 O
cortical O
and O
14 O
subcortical O
nodes/regions O
) O
as O
our O
connectome O
of O
interest O
, O
we O
used O
the O
fslmeants O
programme O
to O
extract O
the O
mean O
beta O
value O
time O
series O
from O
each O
of O
110 O
anatomical O
regions O
of O
interest O
( O
ROI O
) O
for O
the O
gain O
anticipation O
> O
neutral O
contrast O
beta O
image O
for O
each O
participant O
. O

Using O
these O
mean O
ROI O
time O
series O
outputs O
, O
we O
then O
conducted O
Pearson O
correlation O
coefficient O
analyses O
to O
construct O
whole O
brain O
ROI‐to‐ROI O
pairwise O
matrices O
( O
see O
Supplementary O
Fig O
. O

1 O
) O
. O

Each O
matrix O
was O
made O
up O
of O
5995 O
( O
=N O
* O
( O
N O
− O
1 O
) O
/2 O
, O
with O
N O
= O
110 O
nodes O
) O
pairwise O
connections O
( O
edges O
) O
. O

These O
matrices O
were O
generated O
in O
MATLAB O
( O
The O
MathWorks O
, O
Inc. O
, O
Natick O
, O
Massachusetts O
, O
United O
States O
) O
and O
used O
to O
compare O
network O
connectivity O
between O
the O
CON O
and O
ADD O
groups O
( O
see O
below O
) O
. O

Graph O
measures O
Global O
( O
characteristic O
path O
length O
and O
clustering O
coefficient O
) O
graph O
measures O
were O
estimated O
from O
each O
correlation O
matrix O
using O
the O
GraphVar O
( O
www.rfmri.org/GraphVar O
) O
toolbox O
for O
functional O
brain O
connectivity O
in O
MATLAB O
( O
The O
MathWorks O
, O
Inc. O
, O
Natick O
, O
Massachusetts O
, O
United O
States O
) O
. O

More O
detailed O
descriptions O
of O
brain O
network O
graph O
measures O
can O
be O
found O
elsewhere O
, O
but O
we O
will O
briefly O
describe O
these O
metrics O
here O
. O

Characteristic O
path O
length O
is O
the O
minimum O
number O
of O
edges O
that O
must O
be O
traversed O
to O
go O
from O
one O
node O
( O
brain O
region O
) O
to O
another O
in O
a O
network O
. O

For O
a O
pair O
of O
nodes O
that O
are O
nearest O
neighbours O
, O
the O
path O
length O
is O
1 O
. O

The O
clustering O
coefficient O
, O
by O
contrast O
, O
quantifies O
the O
density O
of O
connections O
between O
the O
nearest O
neighbour O
of O
a O
node O
, O
and O
describes O
how O
segregated O
the O
network O
is O
. O

The O
path O
and O
clustering O
measures O
are O
first O
estimated O
at O
each O
node O
of O
the O
connectome O
before O
an O
average O
( O
global O
value O
) O
is O
computed O
for O
the O
entire O
connectome O
for O
each O
participant O
’ O
s O
correlation O
matrix O
. O

Graph O
measures O
for O
each O
participant O
were O
then O
estimated O
by O
thresholding O
each O
matrix O
at O
a O
selection O
of O
proportional O
cost O
( O
K O
) O
thresholds O
– O
i.e O
. O

thresholds O
that O
retain O
only O
a O
percentage O
of O
the O
strongest O
connections O
( O
edges O
) O
in O
the O
network O
. O

Biological O
networks O
are O
represented O
by O
sparse O
connections O
, O
however O
, O
and O
thresholding O
is O
a O
necessary O
step O
to O
extract O
the O
appropriate O
topological O
properties O
of O
networks O
. O

Because O
graph O
measures O
can O
also O
be O
sensitive O
to O
threshold O
value O
, O
we O
have O
reported O
our O
measures O
across O
a O
range O
of O
K O
thresholds O
( O
1 O
⩽ O
K O
⩽ O
5 O
, O
increments O
of O
1 O
) O
. O

Here O
K O
represents O
the O
percentage O
( O
e.g. O
, O
1 O
= O
10 O
% O
) O
number O
of O
edges O
in O
each O
matrix O
that O
are O
maintained O
following O
thresholding O
. O

We O
employed O
a O
range O
of O
thresholds O
to O
represent O
the O
lower O
and O
upper O
bound O
of O
a O
small-world O
system O
, O
and O
that O
preserve O
only O
the O
strongest O
functional O
connections O
for O
efficient O
parallel O
information O
processing O
at O
a O
relatively O
low O
wiring O
cost O
. O

All O
graph O
measures O
were O
computed O
from O
matrices O
in O
their O
weighted O
form O
following O
this O
thresholding O
procedure O
. O

Functional O
connectivity O
Group O
comparisons O
in O
ROI‐to‐ROI O
connectivity O
across O
matrices O
were O
assessed O
using O
the O
Networks O
Based O
Statistics O
( O
NBS O
) O
Toolbox O
for O
MATLAB O
( O
The O
MathWorks O
, O
Inc. O
, O
Natick O
, O
Massachusetts O
, O
United O
States O
) O
. O

Comparisons O
between O
the O
CON O
and O
ADD O
groups O
were O
conducted O
to O
identify O
those O
nodes O
across O
the O
connectome O
that O
showed O
differences O
in O
connectivity O
. O

Independent O
groups O
t-tests O
were O
first O
performed O
to O
test O
for O
a O
between-group O
difference O
in O
the O
correlation O
coefficients O
at O
each O
of O
the O
110 O
× O
( O
110–1 O
) O
/2 O
= O
5995 O
regional O
pairings O
. O

Graph O
sub-components O
were O
identified O
among O
the O
connections O
using O
a O
t-statistic O
threshold O
t O
> O
3.1 O
. O

From O
here O
, O
a O
family-wise O
error O
( O
FWE O
) O
corrected O
p-value O
( O
p O
< O
0.05 O
) O
was O
calculated O
for O
the O
size O
of O
each O
resulting O
component O
using O
permutation O
testing O
( O
5000 O
permutations O
) O
. O

Two O
( O
CON O
> O
ADD O
and O
ADD O
> O
CON O
) O
analyses O
were O
conducted O
independently O
on O
the O
gain O
anticipation O
> O
neutral O
anticipation O
contrast O
matrices O
. O

Given O
the O
differences O
in O
scanners O
across O
the O
three O
sites O
, O
these O
NBS O
analyses O
were O
conducted O
while O
controlling O
for O
study O
site O
. O

NBS O
has O
previously O
been O
used O
to O
identify O
specific O
networks O
of O
nodes O
across O
a O
connectome O
that O
differ O
between O
clinical O
populations O
during O
different O
psychological O
processes O
. O

Network O
visualisation O
Networks O
that O
emerged O
from O
group O
comparisons O
in O
NBS O
were O
visualised O
and O
presented O
using O
brain O
connectivity O
maps O
and O
circular O
connectograms O
using O
the O
NeuroMArVL O
software O
( O
www.immersive.erc.monash.edu.au/neuromarvl O
) O
. O

A O
decrease O
in O
spontaneous O
activity O
in O
medial O
prefrontal O
cortex O
is O
associated O
with O
sustained O
hallucinations O
in O
chronic O
schizophrenia O
: O
An O
NIRS O
study O
In O
functional O
imaging O
, O
accumulating O
evidence O
suggests O
that O
spontaneous O
activity O
decreases O
during O
the O
resting O
state O
in O
the O
core O
brain O
regions O
of O
the O
default-mode O
network O
[ O
e.g O
. O

medial O
prefrontal O
cortex O
( O
mPFC O
) O
] O
in O
schizophrenia O
. O

However O
, O
the O
significance O
of O
this O
decreased O
activity O
has O
not O
been O
clarified O
in O
relation O
to O
its O
clinical O
symptoms O
. O

In O
this O
study O
, O
near-infrared O
spectroscopy O
( O
NIRS O
) O
, O
which O
is O
a O
simple O
imaging O
modality O
suitable O
for O
resting O
state O
paradigm O
, O
was O
used O
to O
evaluate O
the O
intensity O
of O
the O
spontaneous O
activity O
during O
the O
resting O
state O
in O
chronic O
schizophrenia O
. O

Consistent O
with O
previous O
findings O
of O
fMRI O
studies O
, O
spontaneous O
activity O
decreased O
in O
the O
mPFC O
of O
patients O
with O
schizophrenia O
. O

In O
addition O
, O
the O
decreased O
spontaneous O
activity O
was O
associated O
with O
severe O
hallucinations O
in O
this O
region O
where O
reality O
monitoring O
is O
fundamentally O
engaged O
. O

These O
results O
may O
encourage O
additional O
application O
of O
NIRS O
with O
the O
resting O
state O
paradigm O
into O
daily O
clinical O
settings O
for O
addressing O
the O
broad O
phenotypes O
and O
unstable O
course O
of O
schizophrenia O
. O

Methods O
Subjects O
Twenty O
hospitalised O
male O
patients O
( O
25–68 O
years O
, O
mean O
± O
SEM O
= O
50.6 O
± O
3.0 O
) O
with O
chronic O
schizophrenia O
and O
their O
case-matched O
healthy O
controls O
( O
26–66 O
years O
, O
50.1 O
± O
2.5 O
) O
participated O
in O
this O
study O
. O

All O
of O
them O
were O
right-handed O
. O

Each O
patient O
was O
diagnosed O
by O
two O
or O
more O
psychiatrists O
on O
the O
basis O
of O
the O
DSM-5 O
criteria O
for O
schizophrenia O
, O
and O
the O
diagnosis O
was O
verified O
based O
on O
detailed O
clinical O
observations O
during O
hospitalisation O
. O

All O
the O
patients O
were O
medicated O
with O
antipsychotics O
at O
doses O
that O
had O
been O
largely O
unchanged O
for O
> O
3 O
months O
because O
of O
the O
persistent O
symptoms O
accompanying O
their O
chronic O
disease O
. O

Three O
patients O
were O
medicated O
using O
the O
first O
generation O
antipsychotics O
, O
seven O
using O
the O
second O
generation O
, O
and O
10 O
using O
both O
. O

None O
had O
a O
history O
of O
substance/alcohol O
abuse O
. O

The O
patients O
were O
having O
apparent O
deficits O
in O
social O
functioning O
based O
on O
the O
Global O
Assessment O
of O
Functioning O
( O
GAF O
) O
score O
of O
≤35 O
. O

The O
clinical O
variables O
of O
the O
patients O
were O
as O
follows O
: O
GAF O
score O
, O
24.2 O
± O
1.4 O
; O
illness O
duration O
, O
27.9 O
± O
3.5 O
years O
; O
onset O
age O
, O
23.9 O
± O
1.6 O
years O
; O
and O
chlorpromazine-equivalent O
antipsychotic O
dose O
, O
804.5 O
± O
143.7 O
mg/day O
. O

The O
patients O
’ O
symptoms O
were O
assessed O
based O
on O
the O
Clinician-Rated O
Dimensions O
of O
Psychosis O
Symptom O
Severity O
( O
CRDPSS O
) O
, O
which O
is O
an O
eight-item O
scale O
for O
dimensional O
assessment O
proposed O
in O
the O
DSM-5 O
to O
objectively O
rate O
the O
severity O
of O
the O
primary O
symptoms O
of O
psychosis O
, O
by O
two O
research O
psychiatrists O
who O
were O
blinded O
to O
the O
NIRS O
data O
, O
along O
with O
the O
information O
obtained O
from O
the O
clinical O
psychiatrist O
in O
charge O
and O
the O
ward O
nurses O
. O

The O
mean O
scores O
of O
the O
CRDPSS O
among O
the O
patients O
were O
as O
follows O
: O
hallucinations O
( O
2.5 O
± O
0.3 O
) O
, O
delusions O
( O
2.6 O
± O
0.2 O
) O
, O
disorganized O
speech O
( O
3.0 O
± O
0.2 O
) O
, O
abnormal O
psychomotor O
behaviour O
( O
2.5 O
± O
0.2 O
) O
, O
negative O
symptoms O
( O
3.3 O
± O
0.2 O
) O
, O
impaired O
cognition O
( O
3.2 O
± O
0.2 O
) O
, O
depression O
( O
0.9 O
± O
0.1 O
) O
, O
and O
mania O
( O
0.3 O
± O
0.2 O
) O
. O

The O
controls O
had O
no O
history O
of O
neurological O
or O
psychiatric O
disorders O
. O

A O
complete O
description O
of O
the O
study O
was O
provided O
, O
and O
written O
informed O
consent O
was O
obtained O
from O
all O
the O
subjects O
. O

The O
study O
was O
approved O
by O
the O
Ethics O
Committee O
of O
the O
Kindai O
University O
Faculty O
of O
Medicine O
, O
and O
carried O
out O
in O
accordance O
with O
the O
ethical O
principles O
of O
the O
Declaration O
of O
Helsinki O
and O
its O
later O
amendments O
. O

Near-infrared O
spectroscopy O
NIRS O
measurements O
were O
performed O
using O
a O
10-channel O
wearable O
NIRS O
device O
( O
WOT-100 O
system O
; O
Hitachi O
High-Technologies O
Corporation O
, O
Tokyo O
, O
Japan O
) O
, O
as O
previously O
described O
. O

Briefly O
, O
the O
device O
measured O
relative O
changes O
in O
oxygenated- O
( O
oxy- O
) O
and O
deoxygenated- O
( O
deoxy- O
) O
hemoglobin O
( O
Hb O
) O
concentrations O
using O
two O
wavelengths O
( O
705 O
and O
830 O
nm O
) O
with O
a O
sampling O
rate O
of O
200 O
ms. O
Optical O
data O
were O
analysed O
using O
the O
modified O
Beer–Lambert O
law O
to O
calculate O
the O
signals O
reflecting O
changes O
in O
Hb O
levels O
expressed O
as O
arbitrary O
units O
( O
mM–mm O
) O
. O

The O
NIRS O
probe O
unit O
has O
a O
2 O
× O
4 O
alternating O
arrangement O
of O
irradiation O
and O
detection O
positions O
. O

The O
distance O
between O
the O
pairs O
of O
emission O
and O
detector O
probes O
was O
set O
at O
30 O
mm O
, O
and O
the O
measurement O
area O
between O
the O
probes O
was O
defined O
as O
a O
channel O
. O

The O
lowest O
probes O
were O
positioned O
along O
the O
Fp1–Fp2 O
line O
, O
according O
to O
the O
International O
10–20 O
system O
. O

The O
arrangement O
of O
channels O
covered O
the O
entire O
forehead O
to O
monitor O
the O
activation O
in O
the O
prefrontal O
regions O
. O

Three-dimensional O
coordinates O
of O
the O
channels O
were O
obtained O
using O
a O
three-dimensional O
digitizer O
( O
Patriot O
, O
POLHEMUS O
, O
Inc. O
, O
Colchester O
, O
Vermont O
, O
USA O
) O
, O
as O
previously O
described O
. O

The O
estimate O
for O
the O
spatial O
registration O
of O
the O
channels O
using O
the O
probabilistic-determination O
method O
was O
mapped O
onto O
the O
Montreal O
Neurological O
Institute O
space O
based O
on O
NIRS-SPM O
( O
http O
: O
//bispl.weebly.com/nirs-spm.html O
# O
/ O
) O
( O
Fig O
. O

3a O
) O
. O

A O
previous O
NIRS O
study O
of O
the O
resting-state O
paradigm O
was O
referenced O
to O
designate O
the O
mPFC O
region O
for O
the O
mapped O
channels O
. O

Resting-state O
paradigm O
The O
NIRS O
signals O
were O
acquired O
during O
the O
resting O
state O
as O
previously O
described O
. O

The O
subjects O
were O
seated O
in O
a O
comfortable O
chair O
in O
a O
silent O
room O
to O
achieve O
a O
resting-state O
condition O
. O

They O
were O
instructed O
to O
focus O
on O
the O
central O
fixation O
point O
displayed O
on O
a O
monitor O
during O
the O
NIRS O
measurement O
while O
keeping O
their O
eyes O
open O
and O
remaining O
still O
. O

The O
NIRS O
measurement O
commenced O
when O
the O
subject O
continually O
focused O
on O
the O
fixation O
point O
on O
the O
monitor O
for O
3 O
min O
while O
at O
rest O
. O

The O
resting O
paradigm O
was O
of O
relatively O
short O
duration O
, O
thus O
enabling O
patients O
to O
continue O
following O
the O
instructions O
without O
falling O
asleep O
. O

Data O
analysis O
The O
time O
courses O
of O
oxy- O
and O
deoxy-Hb O
signals O
were O
plotted O
using O
the O
BRainSuite_Analyzer O
( O
BRSystems O
. O

Inc. O
, O
Kanagawa O
, O
Japan O
) O
with O
low O
pass O
filter O
( O
< O
0.1 O
Hz O
) O
to O
eliminate O
physiological O
noises O
, O
such O
as O
those O
of O
the O
heartbeat O
, O
respiration O
, O
and O
quick O
body O
movements O
. O

Relative O
changes O
in O
oxy-Hb O
signals O
were O
analysed O
according O
to O
a O
previous O
report O
that O
demonstrated O
a O
strong O
correlation O
between O
oxy-Hb O
NIRS O
measurements O
and O
blood O
oxygenation O
level-dependent O
signals O
measured O
using O
fMRI O
. O

The O
ALFF O
and O
fALFF O
were O
analysed O
using O
the O
ALFF/fALFF O
software O
( O
BRSystems O
Inc. O
; O
Brainsuit O
ALFF O
; O
Kanagawa O
, O
Japan O
) O
according O
to O
previous O
reports O
. O

This O
software O
first O
transformed O
the O
time O
series O
of O
the O
NIRS O
data O
to O
a O
frequency O
domain O
using O
the O
fast O
Fourier O
transform O
, O
and O
the O
power O
spectrum O
was O
obtained O
for O
each O
channel O
. O

Then O
, O
the O
square O
root O
was O
calculated O
at O
each O
frequency O
of O
the O
power O
spectrum O
. O

The O
ALFF O
was O
calculated O
as O
the O
sum O
of O
the O
square O
root O
across O
the O
low-frequency O
range O
( O
0.01–0.08 O
Hz O
) O
, O
and O
the O
value O
of O
the O
ALFF O
was O
divided O
by O
the O
square O
root O
across O
the O
total O
frequency O
range O
between O
0 O
and O
0.25 O
Hz O
to O
calculate O
the O
fALFF O
. O

Statistics O
The O
ALFF O
and O
fALFF O
were O
compared O
between O
schizophrenia O
and O
control O
groups O
using O
the O
Student O
’ O
s O
t-test O
on O
the O
10 O
individual O
channels O
of O
NIRS O
. O

For O
the O
channels O
where O
significant O
changes O
of O
the O
ALFF/fALFF O
were O
observed O
in O
the O
schizophrenia O
group O
, O
stepwise O
multiple O
regression O
analysis O
was O
conducted O
to O
investigate O
the O
association O
between O
the O
ALFF/fALFF O
and O
clinical O
variables O
, O
including O
the O
CRDPSS O
scores O
. O

The O
ALFF O
or O
fALFF O
was O
analysed O
as O
the O
dependent O
variable O
, O
and O
the O
independent O
variables O
were O
set O
with O
clinical O
variables O
, O
such O
as O
CRDPSS O
scores O
, O
GAF O
score O
, O
current O
age O
, O
onset O
age O
, O
illness O
duration O
, O
and O
the O
chlorpromazine-equivalent O
antipsychotic O
dose O
. O

The O
threshold O
for O
the O
significance O
of O
p-values O
was O
set O
at O
0.005 O
( O
0.05/10 O
) O
by O
the O
Bonferroni O
correction O
because O
10 O
channel O
regions O
were O
measured O
in O
this O
study O
. O

All O
statistical O
tests O
were O
two-tailed O
and O
were O
conducted O
using O
GraphPad O
Prism O
6.0 O
for O
Windows O
version O
6.07 O
( O
GraphPad O
Software O
, O
Inc. O
, O
La O
Jolla O
, O
CA O
, O
USA O
) O
or O
SPSS O
version O
25.0 O
( O
IBM O
Inc. O
, O
New O
York O
, O
USA O
) O
. O

Exclusion O
of O
probe O
error O
channels O
Within O
the O
10 O
channels O
measured O
using O
NIRS O
, O
those O
judged O
to O
be O
probe O
errors O
by O
the O
WOT-100 O
software O
were O
excluded O
from O
the O
analysis O
for O
each O
subject O
. O

According O
to O
this O
criterion O
, O
ch2 O
was O
excluded O
for O
two O
patients O
; O
ch3 O
, O
ch7 O
, O
and O
ch9 O
were O
excluded O
for O
one O
patient O
; O
ch8 O
was O
excluded O
for O
three O
patients O
; O
and O
ch10 O
was O
excluded O
for O
seven O
patients O
with O
schizophrenia O
. O

There O
were O
no O
probe O
errors O
in O
the O
control O
subjects O
. O

Because O
the O
number O
of O
the O
probe O
errors O
on O
ch10 O
was O
significantly O
different O
between O
the O
schizophrenia O
and O
control O
groups O
( O
Fischer O
’ O
s O
exact O
test O
; O
p O
= O
0.008 O
) O
, O
we O
eliminated O
the O
whole O
dataset O
of O
ch10 O
from O
the O
analysis O
. O

Notably O
, O
ch4 O
, O
ch5 O
, O
and O
ch6 O
were O
intact O
for O
all O
patients O
with O
schizophrenia O
and O
the O
control O
subjects O
. O

Publisher O
’ O
s O
note O
Springer O
Nature O
remains O
neutral O
with O
regard O
to O
jurisdictional O
claims O
in O
published O
maps O
and O
institutional O
affiliations O
. O

Identifying O
commonality O
and O
specificity O
across O
psychosis O
sub-groups O
via O
classification O
based O
on O
features O
from O
dynamic O
connectivity O
analysis O
Highlights O
Identified O
the O
common O
and O
specific O
connectivity O
changes O
across O
psychosis O
sub-groups O
. O

Proposed O
a O
classification O
framework O
using O
dynamic O
connectivity O
measures O
. O

Yielded O
high O
classification O
accuracy O
for O
both O
the O
four- O
and O
pair-group O
classifications O
. O

Revealed O
the O
disorder-common O
impairments O
in O
the O
thalamocortical O
connectivity O
. O

It O
is O
difficult O
to O
distinguish O
schizophrenia O
( O
SZ O
) O
, O
schizoaffective O
disorder O
( O
SAD O
) O
, O
and O
bipolar O
disorder O
with O
psychosis O
( O
BPP O
) O
as O
their O
clinical O
diagnoses O
rely O
on O
symptoms O
that O
overlap O
. O

In O
this O
paper O
, O
we O
investigate O
if O
there O
is O
biological O
evidence O
to O
support O
the O
symptom-based O
clinical O
categories O
by O
looking O
across O
the O
three O
disorders O
using O
dynamic O
connectivity O
measures O
, O
and O
provide O
meaningful O
characteristics O
on O
which O
brain O
functional O
connectivity O
measures O
are O
commonly O
or O
uniquely O
impaired O
. O

Large-sample O
functional O
magnetic O
resonance O
image O
( O
fMRI O
) O
datasets O
from O
623 O
subjects O
including O
238 O
healthy O
controls O
( O
HCs O
) O
, O
113 O
SZ O
patients O
, O
132 O
SAD O
patients O
, O
and O
140 O
BPP O
patients O
were O
analyzed O
. O

First O
, O
we O
computed O
whole-brain O
dynamic O
functional O
connectivity O
( O
DFC O
) O
using O
a O
sliding-window O
technique O
, O
and O
then O
extracted O
the O
individual O
connectivity O
states O
by O
applying O
our O
previously O
proposed O
decomposition-based O
DFC O
analysis O
method O
. O

Next O
, O
with O
the O
features O
from O
the O
dominant O
connectivity O
state O
, O
we O
assessed O
the O
clinical O
categories O
by O
performing O
both O
four-group O
( O
SZ O
, O
SAD O
, O
BPP O
and O
healthy O
control O
groups O
) O
and O
pair-wise O
classification O
using O
a O
support O
vector O
machine O
within O
cross-validation O
. O

Furthermore O
, O
we O
comprehensively O
summarized O
the O
shared O
and O
unique O
connectivity O
alterations O
among O
the O
disorders O
. O

In O
terms O
of O
the O
classification O
performance O
, O
our O
method O
achieved O
69 O
% O
in O
the O
four-group O
classification O
and O
> O
80 O
% O
in O
the O
between-group O
classifications O
for O
the O
mean O
overall O
accuracy O
; O
and O
yielded O
66 O
% O
in O
the O
four-group O
classification O
and O
> O
80 O
% O
in O
the O
between-group O
classifications O
for O
the O
mean O
balanced O
accuracy O
. O

Through O
summarizing O
the O
features O
that O
were O
automatically O
selected O
in O
the O
classifications O
, O
we O
found O
that O
among O
the O
three O
symptom-related O
disorders O
, O
their O
disorder-common O
impairments O
primarily O
included O
the O
decreased O
connectivity O
strength O
between O
thalamus O
and O
cerebellum O
and O
the O
increased O
strength O
between O
postcentral O
gyrus O
and O
thalamus O
. O

The O
disorder-unique O
changes O
included O
more O
various O
brain O
regions O
, O
mainly O
in O
the O
temporal O
and O
frontal O
gyrus O
. O

Our O
work O
demonstrates O
that O
dynamic O
functional O
connectivity O
provides O
biological O
evidence O
that O
both O
common O
and O
unique O
impairments O
exist O
in O
psychosis O
sub-groups O
. O

Materials O
and O
methods O
Materials O
In O
this O
study O
, O
we O
analyzed O
resting-state O
fMRI O
data O
of O
623 O
subjects O
including O
238 O
HCs O
, O
113 O
SZ O
patients O
, O
132 O
SAD O
patients O
and O
140 O
BPP O
patients O
from O
the O
multi-site O
Bipolar O
and O
Schizophrenia O
Network O
on O
Intermediate O
Phenotypes O
( O
BSNIP-1 O
) O
study O
. O

Age O
and O
sex O
were O
matched O
among O
different O
groups O
( O
p O
= O
0.19 O
for O
age O
examined O
by O
analysis O
of O
variance O
; O
p O
= O
0.31 O
for O
sex O
examined O
by O
Chi O
Square O
test O
) O
. O

The O
scanning O
period O
was O
about O
five O
minutes O
for O
all O
subjects O
. O

The O
detailed O
scanning O
information O
of O
each O
site O
is O
shown O
in O
the O
supplementary O
Table O
S1 O
. O

All O
subjects O
provided O
informed O
consent O
, O
and O
were O
in O
a O
stable O
mental O
state O
and O
took O
stable O
medications O
at O
the O
time O
of O
the O
study O
. O

During O
the O
scanning O
, O
all O
participants O
were O
asked O
to O
rest O
with O
their O
eyes O
closed O
and O
stay O
awake O
. O

Patients O
were O
classified O
diagnostically O
using O
DSM-IV-TR O
criteria O
ascertained O
using O
the O
SCID O
. O

Medication O
use O
primarily O
included O
antipsychotic O
drugs O
( O
BPP O
72.14 O
% O
, O
SAD O
87.12 O
% O
, O
SZ O
88.50 O
% O
) O
, O
antidepressant O
drugs O
( O
BPP O
41.43 O
% O
, O
SAD O
56.82 O
% O
, O
SZ O
38.94 O
% O
) O
, O
and O
mood O
stabilizers O
( O
BPP O
69.29 O
% O
, O
SAD O
56.06 O
% O
, O
SZ O
23.01 O
% O
) O
. O

More O
detailed O
information O
about O
the O
used O
data O
can O
be O
found O
in O
our O
previous O
study O
. O

Methods O
Data O
preprocessing O
As O
described O
in O
the O
previous O
work O
, O
we O
preprocessed O
the O
fMRI O
data O
with O
the O
Data O
Processing O
Assistant O
for O
Resting-State O
fMRI O
( O
DPARSF O
) O
toolbox O
based O
on O
statistical O
parametric O
mapping O
software O
( O
SPM O
) O
. O

The O
first O
six O
volumes O
were O
discarded O
, O
and O
then O
the O
remaining O
images O
were O
slice-time O
corrected O
and O
realigned O
to O
the O
first O
volume O
for O
head-motion O
correction O
. O

For O
each O
subject O
that O
we O
included O
, O
the O
translations O
of O
head O
motion O
were O
less O
than O
3 O
mm O
, O
and O
the O
rotation O
of O
head O
motion O
did O
not O
exceed O
in O
all O
axis O
through O
the O
whole O
scanning O
process O
. O

As O
summarized O
in O
Table O
S2 O
, O
there O
are O
no O
significant O
group O
differences O
in O
the O
head O
motion O
( O
p O
= O
0.17 O
for O
the O
translation O
and O
p O
= O
0.23 O
for O
the O
rotation O
, O
tested O
by O
analysis O
of O
variance O
) O
. O

Subsequently O
, O
we O
spatially O
normalized O
the O
images O
to O
the O
Montreal O
Neurological O
Institute O
( O
MNI O
) O
EPI O
template O
, O
resliced O
to O
3 O
mm O
× O
3 O
mm O
× O
3 O
mm O
voxels O
, O
and O
smoothed O
them O
with O
a O
Gaussian O
kernel O
with O
a O
full-width O
at O
half-maximum O
( O
FWHM O
) O
of O
8 O
mm O
. O

Detrending O
and O
filtering O
( O
0.01 O
Hz~0.08 O
Hz O
) O
were O
performed O
afterwards O
. O

Finally O
, O
nuisance O
covariates O
including O
six O
head O
motion O
parameters O
, O
white O
matter O
signal O
, O
cerebrospinal O
fluid O
signal O
and O
global O
mean O
signal O
were O
regressed O
out O
. O

Estimation O
of O
dynamic O
functional O
connectivity O
For O
each O
individual O
, O
whole-brain O
dynamic O
functional O
connectivity O
was O
constructed O
using O
a O
sliding O
time-window O
method O
based O
on O
116 O
regions O
of O
interest O
( O
ROIs O
) O
from O
the O
automated O
anatomical O
labeling O
( O
AAL O
) O
template O
, O
as O
shown O
in O
the O
top O
of O
Fig O
. O

1 O
( O
i.e. O
, O
the O
step O
1 O
) O
. O

First O
, O
a O
representative O
time O
series O
was O
computed O
by O
averaging O
all O
time O
series O
within O
voxels O
for O
each O
ROI O
. O

Then O
, O
a O
tapered O
window O
, O
created O
by O

a O
rectangle O
( O

= O
20 O

) O

( O

= O

TRs O
) O
, O
was O
moved O
in O
step O
of O
1 O

to O

. O

Next O
, O

a O

( O

116 O
× O

) O

, O

. O

Thus O
, O

along O

were O

. O

To O

( O

) O
. O

of O

It O

for O

. O

. O

Using O

Here O
, O
and O

, O

. O

is O

This O

. O

. O

is O

. O

In O

, O

Classification O
across O

, O

with O

, O

. O

An O
unbiased O
10-fold O
cross-validation O
procedure O
with O
100 O

was O
used O
to O
evaluate O
the O
classification O
performance O
, O
as O
shown O
in O

. O

2 O
. O

In O

, O

( O
623 O

) O
were O
divided O
into O
ten O

equally O
, O
each O

of O
which O
was O
used O
as O
the O
testing O
data O
and O
the O
remaining O
nine O
folds O
were O
used O
as O
the O
training O
data O
. O

Since O
there O
were O
more O
available O
features O
than O
samples O
, O
we O
used O
a O
support O
vector O
machine O
with O
recursive O
feature O
elimination O
( O

) O
technique O
combined O
with O
an O
inner O

to O
perform O

automatic O
feature O
selection O
within O
the O
training O
data O
of O
each O
run O
. O

In O
each O
run O
, O
the O
optimal O
features O
were O
determined O
only O
based O
on O
the O
training O
data O
so O
that O

data O
were O

from O

selection O
and O
model O

. O

The O
following O
describes O

details O
of O
feature O
selection O
. O

The O
training O
data O
were O
divided O
into O
ten O
folds O
, O
nine O
of O
which O
were O
taken O
as O
the O
inner O
training O
data O
to O
perform O
SVM-RFE O
while O
the O
remaining O
one O
was O
used O
to O
test O
the O
trained O
model O
. O

Each O
iteration O
process O
removed O
the O
least O
significant O
10 O
% O
features O
according O
to O
the O
sorting O
sequence O
, O
and O
the O
maximum O
number O
of O
iterations O
was O
set O
to O
35 O
. O

After O
each O
iteration O
time O
, O
an O
SVM O
model O
was O
trained O
using O
the O
updated O
features O
on O
the O

, O
and O
then O
tested O
on O
the O
remaining O
fold O
. O

The O
above O
feature O
sorting O
and O

process O
was O

10 O
times O
, O
resulting O
in O
a O
classification O
accuracy O
matrix O
( O
size O
: O
10 O
× O
35 O
) O
within O
the O
inner O
10-fold O
cross-validation O
process O
. O

Subsequently O
, O
we O
chose O
the O
optimal O
feature O

corresponding O
to O
the O
maximum O

classification O

( O

10 O

) O
. O

By O

, O

. O

In O
each O
run O
, O
we O
trained O
a O
SVM O
classifier O
based O
on O
the O
selected O
features O
using O
the O
outer O
training O
data O
. O

SVM O
has O
been O
successful O
in O
distinguishing O
various O
brain O
disorders O
. O

For O
the O
multi-class O
classification O
problem O
, O
the O
one-against-all O
strategy O
that O
is O
often O
better O
than O
one-against-one O
was O
used O
since O
the O
SVM O
was O
originally O
designed O
for O
two-class O
problem O
. O

A O
linear O
kernel O
was O
utilized O
in O
SVM O
, O
with O
the O
regularization O
parameter O
C O
determining O
the O
tradeoff O
between O
the O
empirical O
error O
and O
the O
complexity O
term O
as O
2 O
. O

In O
theory O
, O
non-linear O
kernels O
may O
work O
better O
than O
linear O
kernels O
in O
solving O
complex O
classification O
task O
, O
but O
in O
practice O
many O
researchers O
in O
the O
neuroimaging O
field O
prefer O
linear O
kernels O
due O
to O
that O
feature O
number O
is O
often O
more O
than O
sample O
size O
. O

Based O
on O
the O
well-trained O
SVM O
, O
we O
examined O
its O
classification O
ability O
on O
the O
held-out O
testing O
data O
. O

Finally O
, O

from O

. O

The O

, O

, O

. O

The O

of O

of O

to O

The O

of O

of O

the O

number O
of O
subjects O

as O

class O
. O

The O

of O
correctly O

subjects O
of O
all O

of O

. O

. O

These O
features O
can O
be O
indicators O
about O
which O
connectivity O
values O
are O
common O
to O
the O
illness O
groups O
and O
which O
connectivity O
values O
may O
differentiate O
the O
illness O
groups O
, O
benefiting O
our O
understanding O
of O
these O
disorders O
’ O
brain O
functional O
mechanisms O
. O

DRD2 O
methylation O
is O
associated O
with O
executive O
control O
network O
connectivity O
and O
severity O
of O
alcohol O
problems O
among O
a O
sample O
of O
polysubstance O
users O
Chronic O
exposure O
to O
alcohol O
and O
other O
drugs O
of O
abuse O
has O
been O
associated O
with O
deleterious O
consequences O
, O
including O
functional O
connectivity O
deficits O
within O
neural O
networks O
associated O
with O
executive O
control O
. O

Altered O
functional O
connectivity O
within O
the O
executive O
control O
network O
( O
ECN O
) O
might O
underlie O
the O
progressive O
inability O
to O
control O
consumption O
of O
alcohol O
and O
other O
drugs O
as O
substance O
use O
disorders O
progress O
. O

Genetic O
and O
epigenetic O
factors O
have O
been O
associated O
with O
substance O
use O
disorders O
( O
SUDs O
) O
. O

For O
example O
, O
dopamine O
receptor O
2 O
( O
DRD2 O
) O
functioning O
has O
been O
associated O
with O
alcohol O
use O
disorder O
( O
AUD O
) O
and O
related O
phenotypes O
, O
including O
correlates O
of O
executive O
functioning O
. O

The O
present O
study O
aims O
to O
explore O
the O
relationship O
between O
a O
continuous O
measure O
of O
alcohol-related O
problems O
, O
epigenetic O
markers O
( O
methylation O
) O
within O
the O
DRD2 O
gene O
, O
and O
functional O
connectivity O
within O
the O
ECN O
among O
a O
sample O
of O
polysubstance O
users O
. O

A O
community O
sample O
of O
658 O
subjects O
, O
whose O
consumption O
of O
alcohol O
, O
nicotine O
, O
and O
cannabis O
span O
across O
a O
spectrum O
of O
quantity O
and O
frequency O
of O
use O
, O
were O
obtained O
across O
previous O
studies O
in O
polysubstance O
using O
populations O
. O

Resting O
state O
functional O
magnetic O
resonance O
imaging O
was O
analyzed O
to O
identify O
intrinsic O
connectivity O
networks O
using O
a O
priori O
regions O
of O
interest O
. O

Methylation O
measurement O
of O
functionally O
relevant O
sites O
within O
the O
DRD2 O
gene O
was O
achieved O
via O
pyrosequencing O
. O

Regression-based O
models O
, O
including O
mediation O
and O
moderation O
models O
, O
tested O
the O
association O
between O
DRD2 O
methylation O
, O
functional O
connectivity O
within O
intrinsic O
neural O
networks O
( O
including O
the O
ECN O
) O
, O
and O
severity O
of O
alcohol O
problems O
. O

Results O
suggest O
that O
average O
DRD2 O
methylation O
was O
negatively O
associated O
with O
right O
ECN O
( O
RECN O
) O
and O
left O
ECN O
( O
LECN O
) O
connectivity O
, O
but O
not O
associated O
with O
other O
networks O
tested O
, O
and O
DRD2 O
methylation O
was O
significantly O
associated O
with O
alcohol O
problems O
severity O
. O

Mediation O
models O
were O
not O
supported O
, O
although O
moderation O
models O
suggested O
that O
connectivity O
between O
edges O
within O
the O
RECN O
moderated O
the O
relationship O
between O
DRD2 O
methylation O
and O
AUD O
severity O
. O

Results O
support O
a O
theoretical O
model O
in O
which O
epigenetic O
factors O
are O
associated O
with O
neurobiological O
correlates O
of O
alcohol O
consumption O
among O
a O
sample O
of O
polysubstance O
users O
. O

MATERIALS O
AND O
METHODS O
Study O
samples O
Resting O
state O
connectivity O
and O
epigenomic O
data O
were O
obtained O
across O
previous O
studies O
in O
polysubstance O
using O
populations O
. O

The O
current O
analyses O
included O
data O
from O
three O
studies O
. O

The O
main O
differences O
across O
the O
three O
studies O
include O
the O
following O
: O
One O
study O
enrolled O
regular O
binge O
drinkers O
, O
another O
study O
enrolled O
treatment O
seekers O
who O
met O
criteria O
for O
AUD O
, O
and O
the O
third O
study O
enrolled O
treatment O
seeking O
cigarette O
smokers O
. O

See O
Table O
1 O
for O
descriptive O
statistics O
on O
substance O
use O
by O
source O
study O
. O

Two O
of O
the O
three O
studies O
were O
clinical O
trials O
involving O
pharmacotherapies O
( O
olanzapine O
and O
varenicline O
) O
; O
however O
, O
the O
imaging O
data O
included O
in O
the O
present O
set O
of O
analyses O
were O
collected O
during O
baseline O
magnetic O
resonance O
imaging O
( O
MRI O
) O
scans O
. O

Therefore O
, O
the O
imaging O
data O
were O
collected O
prior O
to O
the O
initiation O
of O
the O
medication O
regimens O
. O

Briefly O
, O
participants O
were O
recruited O
from O
the O
Albuquerque O
or O
the O
Boulder/Denver O
metropolitan O
regions O
through O
advertisements O
in O
local O
print O
, O
online O
media O
, O
and O
radio O
advertisements O
. O

Exclusionary O
criteria O
across O
studies O
included O
previous O
brain O
injury O
or O
loss O
of O
consciousness O
for O
more O
than O
5 O
minutes O
, O
history O
of O
bipolar O
disorder O
or O
a O
psychotic O
disorder O
, O
or O
a O
positive O
pregnancy O
test O
. O

Additionally O
, O
across O
the O
three O
studies O
, O
subjects O
were O
excluded O
if O
they O
tested O
positive O
for O
illicit O
drugs O
of O
abuse O
( O
other O
than O
marijuana O
) O
. O

Subjects O
abstained O
from O
smoking O
for O
2 O
hours O
before O
scanning O
, O
from O
alcohol O
consumption O
for O
24 O
hours O
( O
per O
patient O
report O
) O
, O
and O
were O
required O
to O
pass O
a O
breathalyzer O
test O
immediately O
prior O
to O
participation O
. O

The O
resting O
state O
neuroimaging O
and O
methylation O
analysis O
procedures O
were O
identical O
across O
all O
studies O
that O
were O
included O
in O
these O
analyses O
. O

Written O
informed O
consent O
, O
approved O
by O
the O
University O
of O
New O
Mexico O
Human O
Research O
Committee O
, O
was O
obtained O
from O
all O
participants O
. O

Data O
collection O
for O
all O
studies O
included O
in O
this O
manuscript O
has O
concluded O
. O

While O
data O
from O
these O
studies O
have O
been O
previously O
published O
( O
eg O
, O
Bidwell O
et O
al O
and O
Claus O
et O
al O
) O
, O
the O
aims O
of O
the O
current O
investigation O
are O
distinct O
from O
aims O
of O
any O
of O
the O
original O
studies O
and O
resulting O
manuscripts O
. O

A O
total O
of O
658 O
participants O
were O
included O
on O
the O
basis O
of O
having O
complete O
epigenetic O
, O
and O
behavioral O
data O
and O
a O
subsample O
of O
621 O
subjects O
were O
included O
in O
all O
neuroimaging O
analyses O
on O
the O
basis O
of O
having O
complete O
neuroimaging O
, O
epigenetic O
, O
and O
behavioral O
data O
after O
excluding O
subjects O
with O
excessive O
motion O
during O
the O
MRI O
scan O
( O
see O
below O
) O
. O

The O
average O
age O
of O
the O
sample O
was O
31.4 O
( O
SD O
= O
9.51 O
) O
, O
and O
the O
gender O
breakdown O
was O
as O
follows O
: O
242 O
females O
and O
416 O
males O
. O

On O
average O
, O
study O
samples O
had O
an O
AUDIT O
score O
of O
12.11 O
( O
SD O
= O
8.12 O
) O
at O
the O
time O
of O
the O
study O
appointment O
. O

On O
average O
, O
subjects O
within O
the O
sample O
reported O
1.57 O
drinks O
per O
drinking O
day O
( O
SD O
= O
6.09 O
) O
, O
10.46 O
cigarettes O
per O
smoking O
day O
( O
SD O
= O
8.39 O
) O
. O

According O
to O
the O
30-day O
Timeline O
Follow O
Back O
, O
subjects O
used O
alcohol O
12.131 O
days/month O
on O
average O
( O
SD O
= O
8.947 O
) O
, O
used O
cannabis O
4.562 O
days/month O
on O
average O
( O
SD O
= O
8.872 O
) O
, O
and O
smoked O
nicotine O
cigarettes O
17.79 O
days/month O
on O
average O
( O
SD O
= O
14.21 O
) O
. O

We O
conducted O
a O
power O
analysis O
for O
the O
primary O
models O
( O
ie O
, O
DRD2 O
methylation O
predicting O
RECN/LECN O
connectivity O
) O
. O

The O
power O
analysis O
was O
specified O
with O
the O
following O
parameters O
: O
testing O
a O
single O
regression O
coefficient O
in O
linear O
multiple O
regression O
, O
based O
on O
a O
sample O
size O
of O
621 O
subjects O
with O
three O
predictors O
( O
DRD2 O
methylation O
, O
age O
, O
and O
sex O
) O
, O
with O
a O
two-tailed O
alpha O
significance O
threshold O
of O
0.05 O
and O
80 O
% O
power O
. O

With O
this O
sample O
size O
, O
the O
primary O
analyses O
were O
fully O
powered O
to O
detect O
small O
effect O
size O
f O
2 O
= O
0.01 O
( O
G O
* O
Power O
3.1 O
; O
Faul O
et O
al O
, O
2009 O
) O
. O

Measures O
In O
addition O
to O
providing O
basic O
demographic O
information O
, O
participants O
responded O
to O
a O
battery O
of O
mood O
and O
substance O
use O
questionnaires O
. O

Relevant O
to O
the O
current O
study O
, O
participants O
completed O
the O
Alcohol O
Use O
Disorders O
Identification O
Test O
, O
which O
assesses O
symptoms O
of O
alcohol O
abuse O
and O
dependence O
over O
the O
past O
6 O
months O
. O

Given O
that O
the O
sample O
included O
aggregated O
data O
from O
three O
different O
subsamples O
, O
we O
felt O
it O
important O
to O
examine O
the O
distribution O
of O
the O
AUDIT O
measure O
, O
both O
within O
the O
full O
sample O
and O
within O
each O
of O
the O
subsamples O
. O

Within O
the O
full O
sample O
, O
the O
skewness O
of O
the O
AUDIT O
measure O
is.658 O
, O
and O
the O
kurtosis O
of O
the O
AUDIT O
measure O
within O
the O
first O
sample O
is O
2.908 O
. O

See O
Table O
1 O
for O
skewness O
and O
kurtosis O
of O
the O
AUDIT O
measure O
across O
each O
of O
the O
samples O
that O
comprise O
the O
full O
aggregate O
sample O
( O
ie O
, O
Littlewood O
et O
al O
; O
Littlewood O
et O
al O
; O
Claus O
et O
al O
) O
. O

Skewness O
< O
2 O
and O
kurtosis O
< O
7 O
are O
commonly O
used O
cutoffs O
on O
these O
parameters O
. O

Thus O
, O
this O
suggests O
that O
the O
distribution O
of O
the O
AUDIT O
measure O
for O
the O
full O
sample O
and O
for O
each O
of O
the O
subsamples O
that O
comprise O
the O
full O
sample O
is O
considered O
normal O
, O
which O
lends O
justification O
for O
combining O
the O
subsamples O
with O
regard O
to O
the O
AUDIT O
measure O
. O

Image O
acquisition O
and O
preprocessing O
Whole O
brain O
resting O
state O
functional O
magnetic O
resonance O
imaging O
( O
fMRI O
) O
was O
performed O
on O
a O
3-T O
Siemens O
Trio O
scanner O
with O
a O
12-channel O
radio O
frequency O
coil O
. O

In O
the O
scanner O
, O
tape O
was O
placed O
across O
the O
participants O
’ O
forehead O
to O
serve O
as O
feedback O
for O
movement O
reduction O
. O

T2 O
* O
-weighted O
functional O
images O
were O
acquired O
using O
a O
gradient-echo O
echo-planer O
imaging O
( O
EPI O
) O
sequence O
: O
TE O
= O
29 O
milliseconds O
, O
TR O
= O
2 O
seconds O
, O
flip O
angle O
= O
75° O
, O
slice O
thickness O
= O
3.5 O
mm O
, O
slice O
gap O
= O
1.05 O
mm O
, O
field O
of O
view O
= O
240 O
mm O
, O
64× O
64matrix O
, O
voxel O
size O
= O
3.75 O
mm O
× O
3.75 O
mm O
× O
3.5 O
mm O
. O

Resting-state O
scans O
were O
5 O
minutes O
in O
duration O
. O

Subjects O
were O
instructed O
to O
keep O
their O
eyes O
open O
and O
fixate O
on O
a O
cross O
. O

High-resolution O
T1-weighted O
structural O
image O
were O
acquired O
with O
a O
5-echo O
MPRAGE O
sequence O
with O
the O
following O
parameters O
: O
TE O
= O
1.64 O
, O
3.5 O
, O
5.36 O
, O
7.22 O
, O
and O
9.08 O
milliseconds O
, O
TR O
= O
2.53 O
seconds O
, O
TI O
= O
1.2 O
seconds O
, O
flip O
angle O
= O
7° O
, O
excitations O
= O
1 O
, O
slice O
thickness O
= O
1 O
mm O
, O
field O
of O
view O
= O
256 O
mm O
, O
resolution O
= O
256 O
× O
256 O
× O
176 O
, O
voxel O
size O
= O
1 O
× O
1 O
× O
1 O
mm O
, O
pixel O
bandwidth O
= O
650 O
Hz O
. O

Images O
were O
preprocessed O
with O
Statistical O
Parametric O
Mapping O
Version O
5 O
( O
SPM5 O
) O
software O
( O
WellcomeTrust O
Centre O
for O
Neuroimaging O
, O
London O
, O
UK O
) O
for O
slice-time O
and O
motion O
correction O
, O
and O
then O
normalization O
to O
Montreal O
Neurological O
Institute O
( O
MNI O
) O
space O
. O

Additionally O
, O
participants O
with O
excessive O
head O
motion O
( O
> O
2 O
mm O
translational O
or O
0.035 O
radians O
rotational O
movement O
) O
were O
excluded O
from O
all O
analyses O
for O
additional O
quality O
control O
, O
consistent O
with O
the O
motion O
exclusion O
criterion O
used O
in O
other O
published O
studies O
from O
our O
group O
. O

A O
total O
of O
65 O
subjects O
were O
excluded O
for O
excessive O
motion O
based O
on O
these O
parameters O
. O

The O
decision O
to O
exclude O
a O
given O
participant O
on O
the O
basis O
of O
excessive O
motion O
absolutely O
( O
rather O
than O
frame O
to O
frame O
) O
was O
based O
on O
findings O
suggesting O
that O
functional O
connectivity O
analyses O
are O
particularly O
vulnerable O
to O
excessive O
motion O
, O
and O
head O
motion O
is O
a O
relatively O
stable O
trait O
within O
individuals O
. O

Network O
functional O
connectivity O
analysis O
In O
order O
to O
investigate O
connectivity O
, O
we O
used O
methods O
consistent O
with O
previous O
studies O
conducted O
within O
our O
group O
. O

Briefly O
, O
we O
used O
the O
functionally O
defined O
intrinsic O
connectivity O
networks O
( O
ICNs O
) O
, O
which O
have O
been O
defined O
previously O
. O

These O
networks O
are O
derived O
from O
90 O
distinct O
network O
nodes O
that O
represent O
regions O
of O
interest O
( O
ROIs O
) O
that O
span O
across O
the O
majority O
of O
cortical O
and O
subcortical O
gray O
matter O
. O

Using O
in O
house O
scripts O
, O
functional O
connections O
between O
nodes O
( O
ie O
, O
edges O
) O
were O
calculated O
by O
creating O
a O
correlation O
matrix O
between O
the O
time O
series O
of O
all O
nodes O
within O
each O
network O
for O
each O
subject O
. O

A O
Fisher O
r- O
to-z O
transformation O
was O
applied O
, O
yielding O
z-scores O
for O
use O
in O
subsequent O
analyses O
. O

As O
noted O
in O
Lynall O
et O
al O
, O
connectivity O
strength O
is O
a O
global O
measure O
of O
connectivity O
calculated O
as O
the O
mean O
of O
all O
pairwise O
correlations O
between O
nodes O
within O
each O
network O
. O

Given O
past O
findings O
that O
implicate O
RECN O
and O
LECN O
connectivity O
in O
AUD O
, O
and O
previous O
literature O
suggesting O
an O
association O
between O
D2 O
functioning O
and O
measures O
of O
executive O
functioning O
, O
we O
were O
particularly O
interested O
in O
the O
association O
between O
DRD2 O
methylation O
and O
connectivity O
within O
the O
LECN O
and O
RECN O
. O

In O
order O
to O
assess O
whether O
the O
association O
between O
DRD2 O
methylation O
and O
connectivity O
is O
unique O
to O
the O
ECN O
, O
we O
a O
priori O
selected O
a O
subset O
of O
additional O
networks O
for O
follow O
up O
analyses O
, O
including O
the O
default O
mode O
network O
( O
DMN O
) O
, O
anterior O
salience O
( O
AS O
) O
network O
, O
posterior O
salience O
( O
PS O
) O
network O
, O
and O
the O
ventral O
default O
mode O
network O
( O
VDMN O
) O
. O

DNA O
preparation O
and O
methylation O
assay O
Genomic O
DNA O
was O
isolated O
from O
saliva O
samples O
using O
Qiagen O
’ O
s O
Puregene O
DNA O
prep O
kit O
( O
Qiagen O
, O
Venlo O
, O
Limburg O
) O
. O

CpG O
sites O
within O
the O
DRD2 O
gene O
were O
selected O
a O
priori O
based O
on O
prior O
research O
in O
the O
lab O
. O

To O
determine O
the O
methylation O
status O
of O
CpG O
sites O
near O
of O
the O
DRD2 O
gene O
, O
pyrosequencing O
was O
performed O
at O
EpigenDX O
( O
Worcester O
, O
MA O
) O
. O

Pyrosequencing O
quantitatively O
monitors O
the O
real-time O
incorporation O
of O
nucleotides O
through O
the O
enzymatic O
conversion O
of O
released O
pyrophosphate O
into O
a O
proportional O
light O
signal O
. O

The O
DRD2 O
methylation O
assay O
covered O
six O
CG O
dinucleotides O
across O
the O
DRD2 O
gene O
. O

Methylation O
assays O
were O
designed O
by O
EpigenDx O
. O

Site O
analysis O
was O
based O
on O
the O
ability O
to O
generate O
primers O
located O
around O
CpG O
islands O
and O
that O
meet O
the O
requirements O
for O
pyrosequencing O
of O
each O
site O
accurately O
. O

All O
primer O
sequences O
are O
owned O
by O
EpigenDx O
. O

Because O
methylation O
values O
across O
the O
six O
sites O
of O
interest O
were O
highly O
correlated O
, O
we O
created O
an O
average O
methylation O
variable O
( O
eg O
, O
average O
methylation O
across O
the O
six O
CpG O
sites O
assayed O
) O
, O
which O
was O
used O
in O
all O
analyses O
outlined O
below O
. O

Data O
analysis O
R O
version O
3.2.1 O
( O
2015-06-18 O
) O
was O
used O
to O
perform O
all O
general O
linear O
models O
( O
GLMs O
) O
, O
where O
we O
tested O
the O
association O
between O
DRD2 O
methylation O
and O
network O
connectivity O
, O
controlling O
for O
age O
and O
sex O
covariates O
. O

We O
planned O
to O
include O
age O
and O
sex O
as O
covariates O
in O
all O
analyses O
given O
that O
the O
literature O
suggests O
an O
association O
between O
age O
and O
methylation O
( O
see O
Jung O
and O
Pfeifer O
for O
review O
) O
, O
between O
age O
and O
functional O
connectivity O
, O
and O
between O
sex O
and O
functional O
connectivity O
. O

Based O
on O
findings O
from O
prior O
studies O
implicating O
the O
ECN O
connectivity O
with O
problem O
drinking O
as O
well O
as O
D2 O
function O
with O
substance O
abuse O
, O
we O
were O
particularly O
interested O
in O
testing O
the O
association O
between O
DRD2 O
methylation O
and O
the O
ECN O
. O

To O
start O
, O
we O
tested O
the O
relationship O
between O
DRD2 O
methylation O
and O
both O
the O
average O
connectivity O
within O
the O
RECN O
and O
LECN O
. O

We O
then O
chose O
four O
additional O
networks O
to O
test O
individually O
in O
GLMs O
, O
where O
we O
tested O
the O
association O
between O
DRD2 O
methylation O
and O
network O
connectivity O
for O
each O
of O
the O
four O
networks O
, O
controlling O
for O
age O
and O
sex O
covariates O
. O

The O
additional O
networks O
tested O
included O
DMN O
, O
AS O
, O
PS O
, O
and O
VDMN O
. O

These O
four O
additional O
networks O
served O
as O
comparison O
networks O
, O
which O
we O
used O
to O
determine O
whether O
the O
association O
between O
DRD2 O
methylation O
and O
connectivity O
was O
unique O
to O
the O
ECN O
in O
this O
sample O
of O
substance O
users O
. O

As O
the O
ECN O
was O
the O
primary O
focus O
of O
our O
analyses O
, O
we O
tested O
the O
association O
between O
DRD2 O
methylation O
and O
“ O
edges O
” O
( O
ie O
, O
connectivity O
between O
individual O
nodes O
within O
the O
LECN O
and O
RECN O
) O
. O

Using O
a O
series O
of O
GLMs O
, O
we O
tested O
the O
relationship O
between O
DRD2 O
methylation O
and O
edge O
connectivity O
for O
each O
of O
the O
15 O
edges O
within O
the O
RECN O
and O
LECN O
. O

We O
conducted O
these O
post O
hoc O
GLMs O
for O
the O
purpose O
of O
determining O
which O
edges O
within O
the O
networks O
were O
driving O
the O
association O
between O
RECN O
and O
LECN O
connectivity O
and O
DRD2 O
methylation O
. O

Based O
on O
these O

, O
edges O
were O
selected O
based O
on O
a O
test O
statistic O
threshold O
of O
P O
< O
0.05 O
for O
the O
correlation O
between O
edge O
connectivity O
and O
DRD2 O

. O

Subsequently O
, O
the O
edges O
that O
demonstrated O
a O
significant O
association O
between O
methylation O
and O
edge O
connectivity O
were O
used O
in O
mediation O
and O
moderation O
models O
. O

Based O
on O
these O
criteria O
, O
the O
top O
4 O
edges O
within O
the O
RECN O
( O
ie O
, O
the O
top O
4 O
edges O
that O
showed O
the O
most O

association O
) O
and O
the O
3 O
and O
only O

edges O
within O
the O
LECN O
were O
included O
in O
follow-up O
models O
, O
where O
connectivity O
of O
these O
edges O
were O
tested O
as O
mediators O
and O
moderators O
between O
DRD2 O
methylation O
and O
AUDIT O
scores O
( O
see O
below O
for O
details O
) O
. O

Per O
our O
theoretical O
model O
, O
mediation O
analyses O
were O
executed O
using O
SPSS O
19.0 O
( O
IBM O
Corp O
, O
2010 O
) O
via O
the O
products O
of O
the O
coefficients O
method O
, O
which O
estimates O
the O
following O
: O
a O
( O
independent O
variable O
[ O
IV O
] O
-mediator O
[ O
M O
] O
) O
, O
b O
( O
M-independent O
variable O
[ O
DV O
] O
) O
, O
c O
( O
total O
effect O
of O
IV O
on O
DV O
) O
, O
and O
ab O
( O
indirect O
effect O
of O
IV O
on O
DV O
via O
M O
) O
paths O
for O
each O
mediation O
model O
. O

Because O
normality O
of O
the O
sampling O
distribution O
of O
total O
indirect O
effects O
can O
not O
be O
assumed O
, O
bias-corrected O
95 O
% O
confidence O
intervals O
of O
the O
indirect O
effect O
were O
estimated O
by O
using O
bootstrapping O
methods O
. O

We O
tested O
the O
edges O
that O
were O
significantly O
associated O
with O
DRD2 O
methylation O
within O
the O
RECN O
and O
LECN O
as O
mediators O
of O
the O
association O
between O
DRD2 O
methylation O
and O
our O
clinical O
variable O
of O
interest O
, O
AUDIT O
. O

This O
was O
tested O
using O
a O
multiple O
mediation O
model O
, O
where O
the O
significant O
edges O
were O
used O
as O
the O
mediators O
( O

) O
, O
AUDIT O
score O
was O
used O
as O
the O
DV O
, O
and O
DRD2 O
methylation O
was O
used O
as O
the O
IV O
. O

In O
the O
event O
that O
the O
mediation O
model O
was O
not O
supported O
, O
we O
planned O
to O
follow O
up O
the O
