analyses O
by O
testing O
a O
series O
of O
exploratory O
interaction O
models O
. O

These O
models O
tested O
whether O
edge O
connectivity O
moderated O
the O
relationship O
between O
DRD2 O
methylation O
and O
AUDIT O
, O
again O
using O
R O
version O
3.2.1 O
( O
2015-06-18 O
) O
for O
the O
interaction O
model O
GLMs O
. O

For O
these O
models O
, O
we O
planned O
to O
test O
the O
interaction O
between O
each O
of O
the O
edges O
within O
the O
RECN O
and O
LECN O
that O
demonstrated O
a O
significant O
relationship O
between O
DRD2 O
methylation O
edge O
connectivity O
and O
DRD2 O
methylation O
on O
AUDIT O
( O
for O
each O
edge O
within O
the O
RECN O
and O
LECN O
, O
AUDIT O
score O
was O
regressed O
on O
edge O
connectivity O
, O
DRD2 O
methylation O
, O
and O
the O
edge O
connectivity O
* O
DRD2 O
methylation O
interaction O
) O
, O
using O
separate O
models O
for O
each O
edge O
within O
the O
RECN O
and O
LECN O
) O
. O

Given O
that O
the O
study O
tests O
multiple O
models O
, O
we O
conceptualize O
the O
issue O
of O
multiple O
comparisons O
as O
follows O
. O

We O
consider O
the O
two O
models O
in O
which O
we O
test O
the O
relationship O
between O
DRD2 O
methylation O
and O
average O
RECN/LECN O
to O
be O
the O
primary O
models O
. O

Given O
that O
we O
used O
the O
other O
networks O
( O
ie O
, O
DMN O
, O
PS O
, O
and O
AS O
) O
as O
control O
networks O
, O
we O
used O
an O
uncorrected O
P O
< O
0.05 O
significance O
threshold O
for O
the O
primary O
models O
. O

Next O
, O
we O
consider O
the O
follow O
up O
analysis O
of O
individual O
edges O
within O
both O
the O
RECN O
and O
LECN O
as O
a O
way O
of O
determining O
which O
edges O
within O
the O
overall O
networks O
are O
driving O
the O
association O
between O
LECN/RECN O
connectivity O
and O
DRD2 O
methylation O
. O

Given O
that O
the O
purpose O
of O
these O
follow O
up O
tests O
is O
to O
determine O
what O
is O
driving O
the O
overall O
effect O
, O
these O
tests O
are O
considered O
significant O
at O
the O
P O
< O
0.05 O
threshold O
. O

This O
logic O
is O
akin O
to O
the O
argument O
made O
by O
Stevens O
regarding O
multivariate O
analyses O
of O
variance O
( O
MANOVAs O
) O
and O
follow O
up O
univariate O
tests O
. O

Briefly O
, O
Stevens O
argues O
that O
if O
the O
overall O
MANOVA O
is O
significant O
, O
then O
the O
individual O
univariate O
tests O
are O
protected O
from O
multiple O
comparisons O
. O

In O
order O
to O
use O
this O
logic O
, O
we O
also O
tested O
the O
relationship O
between O
RECN O
edge O
connectivity O
and O
DRD2 O
methylation O
using O
15 O
degree O
of O
freedom O
MANOVAs O
, O
which O
included O
all O
15 O
RECN O
edges O
and O
all O
15 O
LECN O
edges O
in O
two O
separate O
MANOVA O
models O
. O

Finally O
, O
the O
moderation O
and O
mediation O
analyses O
are O
considered O
exploratory O
post O
hoc O
analyses O
and O
are O
therefore O
presented O
as O
uncorrected O
P O
values O
. O

The O
Effects O
of O
Music O
Intervention O
on O
Pallidum-DMN O
Circuit O
of O
Schizophrenia O
Music O
intervention O
has O
been O
applied O
to O
improve O
symptoms O
of O
schizophrenic O
subjects O
as O
a O
complementary O
treatment O
in O
medicine O
. O

Although O
the O
psychiatric O
symptoms O
, O
especially O
for O
motivation O
and O
emotion O
, O
could O
be O
increased O
in O
schizophrenia O
, O
the O
underlying O
neural O
mechanisms O
remain O
poorly O
understood O
. O

We O
employed O
a O
longitudinal O
study O
to O
measure O
the O
alteration O
of O
striatum O
functional O
networks O
in O
schizophrenic O
subjects O
undergoing O
Mozart O
music O
listening O
using O
resting-state O
functional O
magnetic O
resonance O
imaging O
( O
fMRI O
) O
. O

Forty-five O
schizophrenic O
inpatients O
were O
recruited O
and O
randomly O
assigned O
to O
two O
groups O
. O

Under O
the O
standard O
care O
with O
antipsychotic O
medication O
, O
one O
group O
received O
music O
intervention O
for O
1 O
month O
and O
the O
other O
group O
is O
set O
as O
control O
. O

Both O
schizophrenic O
groups O
were O
compared O
to O
healthy O
subjects O
. O

Resting-state O
fMRI O
was O
acquired O
from O
schizophrenic O
subjects O
at O
baseline O
and O
after O
one-month O
music O
intervention O
and O
from O
healthy O
subjects O
at O
baseline O
. O

Striatum O
network O
was O
assessed O
through O
seed-based O
static O
and O
dynamic O
functional O
connectivity O
( O
FC O
) O
analyses O
. O

After O
music O
intervention O
, O
increased O
static O
FC O
was O
observed O
between O
pallidum O
and O
ventral O
hippocampus O
in O
schizophrenic O
subjects O
. O

Increased O
dynamic O
FCs O
were O
also O
found O
between O
pallidus O
and O
subregions O
of O
default O
mode O
network O
( O
DMN O
) O
, O
including O
cerebellum O
crus O
and O
posterior O
cingulate O
cortex O
. O

Moreover O
, O
static O
pallidus-hippocampus O
FC O
increment O
was O
positively O
correlated O
with O
the O
improvement O
of O
negative O
symptoms O
in O
schizophrenic O
subjects O
. O

Together O
, O
these O
findings O
provided O
evidence O
that O
music O
intervention O
might O
have O
an O
effect O
on O
the O
FC O
of O
the O
striatum-DMN O
circuit O
and O
might O
be O
related O
to O
the O
remission O
of O
symptoms O
of O
schizophrenia O
. O

2 O
. O

Materials O
and O
Methods O
2.1 O
. O

Demographic O
Characteristics O
Forty-five O
schizophrenic O
subjects O
were O
recruited O
in O
this O
study O
from O
the O
clinical O
hospital O
of O
Chengdu O
Brain O
Science O
Institute O
( O
CBSI O
) O
. O

The O
inclusion O
criterion O
for O
the O
inpatients O
was O
a O
diagnosis O
of O
schizophrenia O
based O
on O
the O
Structured O
Clinical O
Interview O
for O
the O
DSM-IV O
Axis O
I O
disorders—clinical O
version O
( O
SCID-I-CV O
) O
. O

The O
exclusion O
criteria O
were O
acute O
psychotic O
symptoms O
, O
a O
secondary O
diagnosis O
of O
organic O
psychosis O
or O
dementia O
, O
and O
unstable O
drug O
treatment O
. O

The O
psychiatric O
symptoms O
of O
the O
patients O
were O
measured O
using O
Positive O
and O
Negative O
Symptom O
Scale O
( O
PANSS O
) O
. O

A O
set O
of O
matched O
MRI O
data O
of O
healthy O
controls O
( O
HC O
, O
n O
= O
19 O
) O
were O
obtained O
from O
CBSI O
research O
databases O
, O
which O
were O
screened O
for O
a O
history O
of O
medical O
or O
neuropsychiatric O
illness O
, O
as O
well O
as O
for O
major O
neurological O
or O
psychiatric O
illness O
in O
their O
first-degree O
relatives O
. O

The O
study O
was O
approved O
by O
the O
Ethics O
Committee O
of O
the O
clinical O
hospital O
of O
CBSI O
in O
accordance O
with O
the O
Helsinki O
Declaration O
. O

These O
data O
have O
been O
used O
to O
measure O
the O
music O
intervention O
on O
static O
global O
FC O
and O
insular O
networks O
, O
respectively O
, O
in O
schizophrenic O
subjects O
. O

In O
this O
study O
, O
we O
focused O
on O
music O
effects O
on O
static O
and O
dynamic O
FC O
of O
striatum O
in O
schizophrenia O
. O

2.2 O
. O

Design O
and O
Content O
of O
Music O
Intervention O
A O
quasirandomized O
controlled O
trial O
was O
performed O
in O
this O
study O
. O

The O
experimental O
schizophrenic O
patients O
and O
controlled O
patients O
were O
compared O
using O
the O
reference O
of O
the O
HCs O
. O

Then O
, O
the O
patients O
were O
randomly O
divided O
into O
two O
groups O
by O
psychiatrists O
. O

Twenty-two O
schizophrenic O
subjects O
were O
selected O
as O
the O
music O
intervention O
group O
( O
MTSZ O
) O
. O

Twenty-three O
inpatients O
were O
chosen O
as O
controls O
( O
UMTSZ O
) O
. O

One O
professional O
music O
therapist O
participated O
in O
this O
study O
. O

Two O
groups O
of O
schizophrenia O
are O
chronic O
schizophrenic O
subjects O
with O
a O
stable O
drug O
treatment O
strategy O
( O
changeless O
antipsychotic O
drugs O
and O
their O
doses O
) O
in O
CBSI O
. O

Additionally O
, O
MTSZ O
inpatients O
listened O
Mozart O
's O
sonata O
K. O
448 O
( O
half O
an O
hour O
per O
day O
, O
30 O
days O
) O
, O
which O
has O
been O
widely O
used O
in O
scientific O
studies O
to O
assess O
the O
effects O
of O
music O
. O

During O
each O
session O
, O
the O
inpatients O
were O
peaceful O
listening O
to O
the O
music O
of O
Mozart O
's O
sonata O
K. O
448 O
from O
a O
stereo O
system O
in O
a O
quiet O
room O
. O

2.3 O
. O

Data O
Acquisition O
and O
Image O
Preprocessing O
Imaging O
was O
conducted O
on O
a O
3 O
T O
MRI O
scanner O
( O
GE O
DISCOVERY O
MR750 O
) O
. O

During O
scanning O
, O
we O
used O
foam O
padding O
and O
earplugs O
to O
reduce O
head O
motion O
and O
scanner O
noise O
, O
respectively O
. O

High-resolution O
T1-weighted O
images O
were O
acquired O
using O
a O
3-dimensional O
fast O
spoiled O
gradient-echo O
sequence O
( O
repetition O
time O
( O
TR O
) O
= O
6.008 O
ms O
, O
flip O
angle O
( O
FA O
) O
= O
9° O
, O
matrix O
= O
256 O
× O
256 O
, O
field O
of O
view O
( O
FOV O
) O
= O
256 O
× O
256 O
mm2 O
, O
slice O
thickness O
= O
1 O
mm O
, O
no O
gap O
, O
and O
152 O
slices O
) O
. O

Subsequently O
, O
resting-state O
functional O
MRI O
data O
were O
acquired O
using O
gradient-echo O
echo-planar O
imaging O
sequences O
( O
TR O
= O
2000 O
ms O
, O
echo O
time O
( O
TE O
) O
= O
30 O
ms O
, O
FA O
= O
90° O
, O
matrix O
= O
64 O
× O
64 O
, O
FOV O
= O
240 O
× O
240 O
mm2 O
, O
slice O
thickness/gap O
= O
4 O
mm/0.4 O
mm O
, O
and O
number O
of O
slices O
= O
35 O
) O
, O
with O
an O
eight-channel O
phased-array O
head O
coil O
. O

All O
subjects O
underwent O
a O
510-second O
resting-state O
scan O
to O
yield O
255 O
volumes O
. O

During O
resting-state O
fMRI O
, O
all O
subjects O
were O
instructed O
to O
have O
their O
eyes O
closed O
and O
to O
move O
as O
little O
as O
possible O
without O
falling O
asleep O
. O

Functional O
image O
preprocessing O
was O
performed O
using O
NIT O
( O
Neuroscience O
Information O
Toolbox O
) O
according O
to O
a O
standard O
pipeline O
and O
briefly O
described O
here O
. O

Slice O
time O
and O
head O
motion O
correction O
and O
normalization O
( O
3 O
mm O
∗ O
3 O
mm O
∗ O
3 O
mm O
) O
into O
EPI O
template O
were O
performed O
. O

Further O
, O
the O
images O
were O
spatial O
smoothed O
( O
FWHM O
6 O
mm O
) O
. O

Detrending O
analysis O
was O
performed O
. O

Temporal O
filtering O
was O
performed O
at O
bandpass O
0.01–0.08 O
Hz O
. O

Then O
, O
the O
sources O
of O
nuisance O
signals O
were O
removed O
from O
these O
images O
, O
including O
six O
motion O
parameters O
and O
their O
first O
temporal O
derivative O
, O
white O
matter O
signal O
, O
and O
cerebrospinal O
fluid O
signal O
. O

The O
global O
signal O
was O
not O
regressed O
out O
. O

Power O
reported O
that O
head O
motion O
has O
a O
substantial O
impact O
on O
the O
functional O
map O
. O

Thus O
, O
in O
this O
study O
, O
subjects O
who O
had O
a O
maximum O
translation O
in O
any O
of O
orthogonal O
direction O
larger O
than O
3 O
mm O
or O
rotation O
larger O
than O
3 O
degrees O
were O
excluded O
. O

Moreover O
, O
framewise O
displacement O
( O
FD O
) O
was O
evaluated O
for O
all O
subjects O
as O
suggested O
by O
Power O
et O
al O
. O

Structural O
images O
were O
processed O
using O
SPM8 O
toolbox O
. O

The O
structural O
image O
was O
spatially O
normalized O
to O
MNI O
space O
using O
a O
diffeomorphic O
anatomical O
registration O
through O
exponentiated O
lie O
algebra O
( O
DARTEL O
) O
and O
segmented O
into O
gray O
matter O
( O
GM O
) O
, O
white O
matter O
, O
and O
cerebrospinal O
fluid O
. O

Then O
the O
segmented O
GM O
was O
modulated O
using O
nonlinear O
deformation O
. O

The O
normalized O
GM O
score O
was O
calculated O
as O
follows O
: O
GM O
score O
divided O
by O
the O
total O
intracranial O
volume O
. O

The O
normalized O
GM O
score O
of O
subjects O
was O
as O
a O
variable O
in O
the O
statistical O
analysis O
to O
correct O
for O
the O
global O
GM O
volume O
of O
different O
subjects O
. O

2.4 O
. O

Static O
and O
Sliding O
Window-Based O
Dynamic O
Functional O
Connectivity O
Analyses O
First O
, O
we O
calculated O
static O
functional O
networks O
of O
the O
striatum O
system O
. O

Six O
subregions O
within O
striatum O
systems O
were O
defined O
based O
on O
the O
automated O
anatomical O
labeling O
( O
AAL O
) O
template O
, O
including O
left O
and O
right O
caudate O
, O
left O
and O
right O
putamen O
, O
and O
left O
and O
right O
pallidum O
. O

The O
mean O
BOLD O
time O
courses O
of O
these O
regions O
were O
extracted O
. O

Subsequently O
, O
the O
Pearson O
correlation O
coefficients O
were O
calculated O
between O
these O
regions O
and O
all O
voxels O
in O
the O
brain O
. O

This O
correlation O
coefficient O
was O
considered O
as O
static O
FC O
based O
on O
the O
whole O
time O
course O
. O

The O
resulting O
values O
were O
transformed O
through O
Fisher O
's O
r-to-z O
transformation O
. O

We O
calculated O
the O
sliding O
window-based O
dynamic O
functional O
map O
for O
each O
subregion O
of O
the O
striatum O
system O
as O
follows O
: O
first O
, O
the O
time O
course O
was O
segmented O
into O
shorter O
windows O
. O

In O
the O
sliding O
window-based O
dynamic O
functional O
connectivity O
analysis O
, O
the O
optimal O
window O
length O
is O
an O
open O
area O
of O
research O
. O

Recent O
study O
has O
indicated O
that O
the O
minimum O
window O
length O
should O
be O
no O
less O
than O
1/fmin O
. O

Thus O
, O
the O
time O
courses O
were O
segmented O
into O
100 O
s O
( O
50TR O
) O
windows O
( O
fmin O
= O
0.01 O
Hz O
) O
, O
sliding O
the O
onset O
by O
2 O
s O
( O
1TR O
) O
. O

Second O
, O
within O
each O
window O
, O
the O
Pearson O
correlation O
analysis O
was O
performed O
between O
the O
subregions O
of O
striatum O
and O
all O
voxels O
, O
respectively O
. O

Finally O
, O
the O
dynamic O
FC O
was O
estimated O
by O
calculating O
the O
standard O
deviation O
( O
SD O
) O
in O
correlation O
coefficients O
at O
each O
voxel O
. O

2.5 O
. O

Statistical O
Analysis O
First O
, O
to O
measure O
the O
effects O
of O
music O
intervention O
on O
static O
and O
dynamic O
functional O
networks O
, O
the O
statistical O
analysis O
was O
performed O
on O
the O
longitudinal O
date O
of O
MTSZ O
and O
UMTSZ O
groups O
through O
repeated-measure O
ANOVA O
. O

The O
repeated-measure O
ANOVA O
was O
performed O
with O
age O
, O
gender O
, O
education O
years O
, O
GM O
, O
and O
medication O
dosage O
as O
covariates O
. O

Multiple O
comparisons O
correction O
was O
performed O
using O
a O
high O
threshold O
( O
p=0.001 O
) O
and O
an O
extent O
threshold O
based O
on O
Gaussian O
random O
field O
theory O
( O
pcorrected=0.05 O
) O
. O

For O
the O
altered O
regions O
, O
we O
extracted O
the O
FC O
value O
in O
MTSZ O
and O
UMTSZ O
groups O
for O
post O
hoc O
analysis O
. O

Second O
, O
for O
the O
altered O
FC O
from O
repeated-measure O
ANOVA O
, O
we O
established O
the O
baseline O
abnormalities O
between O
HC O
and O
MTSZ O
, O
and O
UMTSZ O
, O
respectively O
. O

Two-sample O
t-test O
was O
calculated O
between O
HC O
and O
schizophrenic O
subjects O
( O
MTSZ O
and O
UMTSZ O
of O
baseline O
) O
. O

Using O
the O
different O
FC O
between O
HC O
and O
patients O
as O
a O
reference O
, O
the O
inverse O
FC O
( O
1 O
month O
minus O
baseline O
) O
might O
be O
defined O
as O
normalized O
FC O
through O
music O
intervention O
in O
MTSZ O
. O

2.6 O
. O

Correlations O
with O
Pathological O
Factors O
The O
partial O
correlation O
analysis O
was O
performed O
between O
the O
mean O
changed O
static/dynamic O
FC O
( O
1 O
month O
later O
minus O
baseline O
) O
with O
altered O
symptom O
scores O
( O
1 O
month O
later O
minus O
baseline O
) O
of O
schizophrenic O
subjects O
with O
age O
, O
gender O
, O
illness O
duration O
, O
education O
years O
, O
GM O
, O
and O
medication O
dosage O
as O
covariates O
in O
this O
study O
. O

Altered O
amygdala-based O
functional O
connectivity O
in O
individuals O
with O
attenuated O
psychosis O
syndrome O
and O
first-episode O
schizophrenia O
Altered O
resting-state O
functional O
connectivity O
( O
FC O
) O
of O
the O
amygdala O
( O
AMY O
) O
has O
been O
demonstrated O
to O
be O
implicated O
in O
schizophrenia O
( O
SZ O
) O
and O
attenuated O
psychosis O
syndrome O
( O
APS O
) O
. O

Specifically O
, O
no O
prior O
work O
has O
investigated O
FC O
in O
individuals O
with O
APS O
using O
subregions O
of O
the O
AMY O
as O
seed O
regions O
of O
interest O
. O

The O
present O
study O
examined O
AMY O
subregion-based O
FC O
in O
individuals O
with O
APS O
and O
first-episode O
schizophrenia O
( O
FES O
) O
and O
healthy O
controls O
( O
HCs O
) O
. O

The O
resting O
state O
FC O
maps O
of O
the O
three O
AMY O
subregions O
were O
computed O
and O
compared O
across O
the O
three O
groups O
. O

Correlation O
analysis O
was O
also O
performed O
to O
examine O
the O
relationship O
between O
the O
Z-values O
of O
regions O
showing O
significant O
group O
differences O
and O
symptom O
rating O
scores O
. O

Individuals O
with O
APS O
showed O
hyperconnectivity O
between O
the O
right O
centromedial O
AMY O
( O
CMA O
) O
and O
left O
frontal O
pole O
cortex O
( O
FPC O
) O
and O
between O
the O
laterobasal O
AMY O
and O
brain O
stem O
and O
right O
inferior O
lateral O
occipital O
cortex O
compared O
to O
HCs O
. O

Patients O
with O
FES O
showed O
hyperconnectivity O
between O
the O
right O
superficial O
AMY O
and O
left O
occipital O
pole O
cortex O
and O
between O
the O
left O
CMA O
and O
left O
thalamus O
compared O
to O
the O
APS O
and O
HCs O
respectively O
. O

A O
negative O
relationship O
was O
observed O
between O
the O
connectivity O
strength O
of O
the O
CMA O
with O
the O
FPC O
and O
negative-others O
score O
of O
the O
Brief O
Core O
Schema O
Scales O
in O
the O
APS O
group O
. O

We O
observed O
different O
altered O
FC O
with O
subregions O
of O
the O
AMY O
in O
individuals O
with O
APS O
and O
FES O
compared O
to O
HCs O
. O

These O
results O
shed O
light O
on O
the O
pathogenetic O
mechanisms O
underpinning O
the O
development O
of O
APS O
and O
SZ O
. O

Methods O
Participants O
Participants O
were O
help-seeking O
individuals O
with O
APS O
, O
patients O
with O
FES O
, O
and O
HCs O
. O

Diagnostic O
evaluation O
was O
performed O
by O
trained O
psychiatrists O
according O
to O
the O
Structured O
Clinical O
Interview O
for O
DSM-IV O
( O
SCID O
) O
. O

For O
diagnosis O
and O
subtype O
classification O
of O
CHR O
states O
for O
psychosis O
, O
criteria O
of O
the O
DSM-5 O
and O
Comprehensive O
Assessment O
of O
At-Risk O
Mental O
States O
( O
CAARMS O
) O
were O
employed O
. O

We O
recruited O
only O
the O
subjects O
with O
APS O
because O
it O
was O
most O
extensively O
studied O
syndrome O
within O
the O
psychosis O
continuum O
. O

The O
duration O
of O
illness O
( O
DI O
) O
for O
APS O
was O
calculated O
since O
the O
first O
significant O
attenuated O
psychotic O
symptoms O
appeared O
. O

First O
episode O
was O
defined O
as O
having O
experienced O
only O
a O
single O
episode O
of O
psychosis O
after O
the O
onset O
( O
individuals O
relapsing O
with O
another O
psychotic O
episode O
were O
excluded O
) O
and O
a O
DI O
of O
< O
2 O
years O
. O

Patients O
or O
individuals O
with O
alcohol O
or O
drug O
use O
disorders O
within O
the O
past O
6 O
months O
, O
intellectual O
disability O
( O
IQ O
≤ O
70 O
) O
, O
current O
or O
historical O
neurological O
disorders O
, O
a O
serious O
medical O
illness O
, O
pregnancy O
, O
and O
claustrophobia O
were O
excluded O
from O
the O
study O
. O

HCs O
were O
recruited O
via O
advertisements O
. O

The O
participants O
were O
interviewed O
using O
the O
screening O
module O
of O
the O
SCID-IV O
non-patient O
edition O
and O
were O
required O
to O
have O
no O
previous O
or O
current O
psychiatric O
disorders O
, O
neurological O
disorders O
, O
or O
significant O
medical O
conditions O
. O

Controls O
having O
a O
first-degree O
relative O
with O
a O
psychiatric O
disorder O
were O
also O
excluded O
. O

All O
participants O
were O
between O
19 O
and O
60 O
years O
of O
age O
and O
were O
assessed O
as O
right-handed O
using O
the O
Edinburgh O
Handedness O
Inventory O
. O

They O
joined O
the O
study O
voluntarily O
and O
provided O
written O
informed O
consent O
. O

The O
study O
was O
approved O
by O
the O
Ethics O
Committee O
of O
Jeonbuk O
National O
University O
Hospital O
( O
approval O
number O
: O
CUH O
2012-08-001 O
) O
. O

A O
statement O
confirming O
that O
all O
experiments O
were O
performed O
in O
accordance O
with O
relevant O
guidelines O
and O
regulations O
. O

Clinical O
assessment O
The O
severity O
of O
symptoms O
was O
evaluated O
within O
a O
week O
of O
fMRI O
scanning O
using O
the O
Scale O
of O
Prodromal O
Symptoms O
( O
SOPS O
) O
or O
PANSS O
. O

These O
scales O
were O
administered O
by O
trained O
psychiatrists O
. O

In O
addition O
, O
the O
BCSS O
, O
a O
self-rating O
scale O
, O
was O
administered O
. O

The O
BCSS O
yields O
four O
subscale O
scores O
on O
negative-self O
, O
positive-self O
, O
negative-others O
, O
and O
positive-others O
schemas O
. O

A O
higher O
score O
indicates O
a O
greater O
endorsement O
of O
a O
schema O
. O

This O
scale O
was O
chosen O
on O
the O
basis O
of O
the O
close O
association O
between O
negative O
schemas O
and O
positive O
symptoms O
. O

Image O
acquisition O
and O
preprocessing O
Resting-state O
functional O
and O
structural O
MRI O
data O
were O
obtained O
at O
the O
Jeonbuk O
National O
University O
Hospital O
on O
a O
3 O
T O
Verio O
scanner O
( O
Siemens O
Magnetom O
Verio O
, O
Erlangen O
, O
Germany O
) O
using O
a O
12-channel O
standard O
quadrature O
head O
coil O
. O

The O
three-dimensional O
T1-weighted O
image O
was O
acquired O
using O
magnetization-prepared O
rapid O
gradient O
echo O
( O
repetition O
time O
[ O
TR O
] O
: O
1900 O
ms O
, O
echo O
time O
[ O
TE O
] O
: O
2.5 O
ms O
; O
flip O
angle O
: O
9° O
; O
field O
of O
view O
[ O
FOV O
] O
: O
250 O
mm O
; O
image O
matrix O
: O
256 O
× O
246 O
mm O
; O
voxel O
size O
= O
1.0 O
× O
1.0 O
× O
1.0 O
mm3 O
; O
176 O
slices O
) O
. O

For O
each O
participant O
, O
we O
collected O
a O
5-min O
resting-state O
scan O
consisting O
of O
150 O
contiguous O
echo-planar O
imaging O
functional O
images O
( O
TR O
: O
2000 O
ms O
; O
TE O
: O
30 O
ms O
; O
flip O
angle O
: O
90° O
; O
FOV O
: O
220 O
mm O
; O
image O
matrix O
: O
64 O
× O
64 O
mm O
; O
voxel O
size O
= O
1.0 O
× O
1.0 O
× O
1.0 O
mm3 O
; O
26 O
slices O
) O
. O

During O
resting-state O
image O
acquisition O
, O
the O
participants O
were O
asked O
to O
relax O
with O
their O
eyes O
closed O
and O
not O
to O
sleep O
. O

MRI O
data O
processing O
was O
conducted O
using O
Statistical O
Parametric O
Mapping O
software O
package O
, O
version O
12 O
( O
SPM12 O
; O
www.fil.ion.ucl.ac.uk/spm O
; O
Wellcome O
Department O
of O
Cognitive O
Neurology O
, O
London O
, O
UK O
) O
implemented O
in O
MATLAB O
. O

The O
first O
three O
volumes O
were O
discarded O
to O
adjust O
for O
magnetization O
equilibrium O
effects O
. O

Functional O
images O
were O
slice-time O
corrected O
, O
realigned O
to O
correct O
for O
head O
motion O
artifacts O
, O
and O
co-registered O
with O
each O
participant O
’ O
s O
structural O
image O
. O

Then O
, O
the O
co-registered O
functional O
data O
were O
transformed O
into O
a O
standard O
anatomical O
space O
based O
on O
the O
parameters O
obtained O
by O
spatially O
normalizing O
each O
T1 O
image O
to O
the O
Montreal O
Neurological O
Institute O
( O
MNI O
) O
template O
. O

Normalized O
images O
were O
smoothed O
with O
an O
8-mm O
full-width O
at O
half-maximum O
isotropic O
Gaussian O
kernel O
. O

The O
criteria O
for O
excessive O
head O
motion O
were O
translation O
> O
2 O
mm O
or O
rotation O
> O
2° O
in O
any O
direction O
and O
frame O
displacement O
( O
FD O
) O
values O
> O
0.5 O
mm O
. O

Participants O
for O
whom O
more O
than O
10 O
% O
of O
volumes O
showed O
excessive O
head O
motion O
were O
excluded O
from O
the O
analysis O
. O

FD O
values O
were O
computed O
using O
the O
FSL O
toolbox O
( O
https O
: O
//www.fmrib.ox.ac.uk/fsl/index.html O
) O
. O

Head O
motion O
was O
measured O
in O
six O
dimensions O
and O
the O
component O
correction O
( O
CompCor O
) O
noise O
components O
were O
used O
as O
nuisance O
variables O
. O

The O
CompCor O
built O
into O
the O
CONN O
toolbox O
( O
V O
14f. O
, O
https O
: O
//www.nitrc.org/projects/conn O
) O
was O
used O
to O
increase O
the O
accuracy O
of O
grey O
matter O
( O
GM O
) O
signals O
by O
removing O
physiological O
noises O
such O
as O
heart O
rate O
and O
breathing O
signals O
, O
followed O
by O
the O
removal O
of O
the O
main O
components O
from O
the O
white O
matter O
( O
WM O
) O
and O
cerebrospinal O
fluid O
( O
CSF O
) O
signals O
. O

Afterward O
, O
the O
linear O
trend O
was O
removed O
through O
the O
time O
course O
, O
and O
the O
band-pass O
filter O
( O
0.008 O
< O
f O
< O
0.09 O
Hz O
) O
was O
applied O
. O

Functional O
connectivity O
analysis O
The O
SPM O
Anatomy O
toolbox O
( O
V O
2.2c O
) O
was O
used O
to O
parcellate O
the O
AMY O
into O
three O
ROIs O
, O
i.e. O
, O
CMA O
, O
LBA O
, O
and O
SA O
. O

After O
applying O
predefined O
ROIs O
to O
the O
image O
data O
of O
each O
subject O
, O
we O
used O
MANGO O
( O
https O
: O
//ric.uthscsa.edu/mango/mango.html O
) O
to O
check O
whether O
they O
matched O
well O
. O

For O
each O
ROI O
, O
the O
BOLD O
time O
series O
of O
the O
voxels O
within O
the O
ROI O
were O
averaged O
to O
generate O
the O
reference O
time O
series O
for O
the O
ROI O
. O

FC O
analysis O
was O
performed O
using O
correlation O
analysis O
between O
the O
seed O
amygdala O
ROI O
and O
other O
voxels O
of O
the O
entire O
brain O
in O
a O
voxel-wise O
manner O
using O
the O
CONN O
toolbox O
. O

Group O
comparison O
was O
performed O
using O
a O
one-way O
analysis O
of O
variance O
( O
ANOVA O
) O
with O
sex O
and O
education O
as O
covariates O
. O

Direct O
group O
comparisons O
were O
further O
evaluated O
using O
post-hoc O
t-tests O
. O

In O
both O
analyses O
, O
we O
applied O
the O
voxel-level O
height O
threshold O
of O
uncorrected O
p O
< O
0.001 O
and O
the O
cluster-level O
extent O
threshold O
of O
p O
< O
0.05 O
, O
which O
was O
corrected O
for O
multiple O
comparisons O
using O
the O
false O
discovery O
rate O
( O
FDR O
) O
. O

To O
control O
the O
probability O
of O
a O
type O
I O
error O
, O
we O
further O
performed O
10,000 O
permutation O
tests O
implemented O
in O
the O
CONN O
toolbox O
. O

Statistical O
analysis O
Demographic O
and O
clinical O
data O
were O
compared O
among O
the O
three O
groups O
using O
ANOVA O
, O
t-test O
, O
or O
Chi-square O
test O
depending O
on O
the O
variables O
. O

For O
the O
correlation O
analyses O
, O
the O
Region O
of O
Interest O
Extraction O
Tool O
( O
https O
: O
//software.incf.org/software/rex O
) O
in O
the O
CONN O
toolbox O
was O
used O
to O
extract O
Fisher O
's O
Z O
transformed O
signal O
intensity O
values O
for O
brain O
regions O
with O
significant O
group O
differences O
. O

Relationships O
between O
the O
PANSS O
, O
BCSS O
, O
or O
SOPS O
score O
and O
z-scores O
were O
explored O
using O
sex O
and O
education O
as O
covariates O
with O
SPSS O
20.0 O
. O

Multiple O
comparison O
corrections O
were O
performed O
using O
the O
Bonferroni O
correction O
. O

Publisher O
's O
note O
Springer O
Nature O
remains O
neutral O
with O
regard O
to O
jurisdictional O
claims O
in O
published O
maps O
and O
institutional O
affiliations O
. O

Intrinsic O
connectivity O
patterns O
of O
task-defined O
brain O
networks O
allow O
individual O
prediction O
of O
cognitive O
symptom O
dimension O
of O
schizophrenia O
and O
are O
linked O
to O
molecular O
architecture O
Background O
: O
Despite O
the O
marked O
inter-individual O
variability O
in O
the O
clinical O
presentation O
of O
schizophrenia O
, O
it O
remains O
unclear O
the O
extent O
to O
which O
individual O
dimensions O
of O
psychopathology O
relate O
to O
the O
functional O
variability O
in O
brain O
networks O
among O
patients O
. O

Here O
, O
we O
address O
this O
question O
using O
network-based O
predictive O
modeling O
of O
individual O
psychopathology O
along O
four O
data-driven O
symptom O
dimensions O
. O

Follow-up O
analyses O
assess O
the O
molecular O
underpinnings O
of O
predictive O
networks O
by O
relating O
them O
to O
neurotransmitter-receptor O
distribution O
patterns O
. O

Methods O
: O
We O
investigated O
resting-state O
fMRI O
data O
from O
147 O
schizophrenia O
patients O
recruited O
at O
seven O
sites O
. O

Individual O
expression O
along O
negative O
, O
positive O
, O
affective O
, O
and O
cognitive O
symptom O
dimensions O
was O
predicted O
using O
relevance O
vector O
machine O
based O
on O
functional O
connectivity O
within O
17 O
meta-analytic O
task-networks O
following O
a O
repeated O
10-fold O
cross-validation O
and O
leave-one-site-out O
analyses O
. O

Results O
were O
validated O
in O
an O
independent O
sample O
. O

Networks O
robustly O
predicting O
individual O
symptom O
dimensions O
were O
spatially O
correlated O
with O
density O
maps O
of O
nine O
receptors/transporters O
from O
prior O
molecular O
imaging O
in O
healthy O
populations O
. O

Results O
: O
Ten-fold O
and O
leave-one-site-out O
analyses O
revealed O
five O
predictive O
network-symptom O
associations O
. O

Connectivity O
within O
theory-of-mind O
, O
cognitive O
reappraisal O
, O
and O
mirror O
neuron O
networks O
predicted O
negative O
, O
positive O
, O
and O
affective O
symptom O
dimensions O
, O
respectively O
. O

Cognitive O
dimension O
was O
predicted O
by O
theory-of-mind O
and O
socio-affective-default O
networks O
. O

Importantly O
, O
these O
predictions O
generalized O
to O
the O
independent O
sample O
. O

Intriguingly O
, O
these O
two O
networks O
were O
positively O
associated O
with O
D1 O
dopamine O
receptor O
and O
serotonin O
reuptake O
transporter O
densities O
as O
well O
as O
dopamine-synthesis-capacity O
. O

Conclusions O
: O
We O
revealed O
a O
robust O
association O
between O
intrinsic O
functional O
connectivity O
within O
networks O
for O
socio-affective O
processes O
and O
the O
cognitive O
dimension O
of O
psychopathology O
. O

By O
investigating O
the O
molecular O
architecture O
, O
this O
work O
links O
dopaminergic O
and O
serotonergic O
systems O
with O
the O
functional O
topography O
of O
brain O
networks O
underlying O
cognitive O
symptoms O
in O
schizophrenia O
. O

Materials O
and O
Methods O
Sample O
A O
total O
of O
147 O
schizophrenia O
patients O
from O
seven O
centers O
located O
in O
Europe O
and O
the O
USA O
represented O
the O
main O
sample O
( O
Table O
S1 O
; O
Supplement O
) O
. O

These O
sites O
differed O
significantly O
in O
illness O
duration O
( O
p O
< O
0.001 O
) O
( O
Table O
S1 O
) O
. O

An O
independent O
sample O
with O
117 O
schizophrenia O
patients O
( O
Table O
S2 O
; O
Supplement O
) O
retrieved O
from O
the O
Bipolar-Schizophrenia O
Network O
on O
Intermediate O
Phenotypes O
( O
B-SNIP O
) O
database O
was O
used O
for O
independent O
model O
validation O
. O

For O
both O
samples O
, O
diagnosis O
of O
schizophrenia O
was O
established O
based O
on O
the O
DSM-IV O
, O
the O
DSM-IV-TR O
, O
or O
the O
ICD-10 O
criteria O
( O
see O
Supplement O
and O
[ O
6 O
] O
) O
. O

These O
international O
datasets O
cover O
a O
broad O
range O
of O
clinical O
states O
, O
settings O
, O
and O
medical O
systems O
, O
facilitating O
identification O
of O
robust O
network-symptom O
associations O
. O

Current O
drug O
dosages O
of O
antipsychotic O
medication O
were O
olanzapine-equivalent O
transformed O
. O

For O
each O
site O
, O
subjects O
gave O
written O
informed O
consent O
and O
study O
approval O
was O
given O
by O
the O
respective O
ethics O
committees/institutional O
review O
boards O
. O

Approval O
for O
pooled O
re-analysis O
was O
provided O
by O
the O
ethics O
committee O
of O
the O
University O
of O
Düsseldorf O
, O
Germany O
. O

Calculation O
of O
dimensional O
symptom O
scores O
Severity O
of O
psychopathology O
was O
assessed O
using O
the O
PANSS O
. O

The O
30 O
PANSS O
items O
were O
compressed O
into O
four O
( O
negative O
, O
positive O
, O
affective O
, O
and O
cognitive O
) O
symptom O
dimensions O
( O
Figure O
S1A O
) O
identified O
in O
our O
prior O
factorization O
analysis O
on O
two O
large O
, O
multi-site O
schizophrenia O
samples O
as O
stable O
and O
well-generalizable O
across O
populations O
, O
settings O
, O
and O
medical O
systems O
. O

Each O
dimensional O
score O
for O
an O
individual O
was O
calculated O
as O
the O
dot O
product O
between O
the O
coefficients O
loaded O
on O
the O
particular O
dimension O
within O
the O
dimensional-structure O
( O
Figure O
S1 O
) O
and O
the O
30 O
PANSS O
item O
scores O
of O
that O
individual O
( O
as O
implemented O
in O
DCTS O
: O
http O
: O
//webtools.inm7.de/sczDCTS/ O
) O
. O

Higher O
scores O
on O
a O
dimension O
indicate O
more-severe O
symptoms O
( O
Figure O
S1B O
) O
. O

Definition O
of O
functional O
brain O
networks O
Seventeen O
functional O
networks O
, O
which O
cover O
a O
broad O
range O
of O
domains O
reflecting O
cognitive O
, O
socio-affective O
, O
and O
sensory-motor O
functions O
that O
have O
been O
implicated O
in O
schizophrenia O
, O
were O
employed O
( O
Table O
S3 O
) O
. O

These O
networks O
were O
based O
on O
coordinate-based O
meta-analyses O
and O
represent O
regions O
demonstrating O
convergent O
activations O
associated O
with O
specific O
functional O
domains O
across O
many O
prior O
task-fMRI O
studies O
. O

They O
hence O
provide O
the O
best O
“ O
a O
priori O
” O
estimate O
of O
the O
location O
of O
specific O
functional O
networks O
and O
hence O
here O
assessed O
by O
resting-state O
fMRI O
in O
new O
subjects O
. O

For O
convenience O
, O
we O
grouped O
these O
17 O
networks O
into O
six O
broad O
functional O
domains O
( O
Figure O
1 O
& O
Table O
S3 O
) O
, O
though O
it O
must O
be O
stressed O
that O
each O
network O
was O
analyzed O
separately O
. O

FMRI O
data O
processing O
All O
resting-state O
fMRI O
scans O
( O
Tables O
S4 O
& O
S5 O
) O
were O
preprocessed O
using O
SPM12 O
( O
http O
: O
//www.fil.ion.ucl.ac.uk/spm O
) O
( O
see O
[ O
6 O
] O
and O
Supplement O
) O
. O

After O
excluding O
subjects O
with O
excessive O
head-motion O
or O
poor O
image O
quality O
( O
cf O
. O

Supplement O
) O
, O
126 O
and O
100 O
schizophrenia O
patients O
were O
retained O
in O
the O
main O
and O
the O
B-SNIP O
validation O
sample O
, O
respectively O
( O
Table O
1 O
) O
. O

Head O
motion O
differed O
significantly O
between O
the O
sites O
but O
did O
not O
correlate O
with O
the O
residuals O
of O
any O
symptom O
dimensions O
after O
adjusting O
for O
age/gender/site O
. O

Still O
, O
we O
adjusted O
head-motion O
effects O
in O
predictive O
modeling O
as O
a O
conservative O
approach O
to O
rule O
out O
( O
any O
) O
possible O
predictability O
based O
on O
movement O
. O

White O
matter O
and O
CSF O
signals O
as O
well O
as O
24 O
head-motion O
parameters O
were O
regressed O
out O
from O
the O
overall O
fMRI O
time-series O
but O
the O
global O
mean O
signals O
were O
not O
removed O
given O
ongoing O
controversies O
. O

Voxels O
within O
a O
6 O
mm O
sphere O
around O
each O
of O
the O
meta-analytically O
derived O
peak-activation O
coordinate O
formed O
a O
node O
. O

The O
first O
eigenvariate O
of O
the O
time-series O
from O
all O
the O
voxels O
within O
each O
node O
was O
calculated O
as O
the O
regional O
characteristic O
time-series O
containing O
better O
signal-to-noise O
ratio O
than O
the O
peak O
voxel O
alone O
. O

For O
each O
network O
, O
Pearson O
’ O
s O
correlation O
was O
calculated O
between O
the O
characteristic O
time-series O
for O
each O
pair O
of O
the O
nodes O
resulting O
in O
an O
N O
x O
N O
matrix O
of O
resting-state O
functional O
connectivity O
( O
rs-FC O
) O
. O

The O
upper O
triangle O
of O
the O
resulting O
connectivity O
matrix O
was O
extracted O
, O
linearized O
and O
Fisher O
’ O
s O
Z-transformed O
to O
provide O
the O
features O
for O
our O
predictive O
modeling O
. O

Prediction O
of O
symptom O
dimensions O
using O
network O
rs-FC O
Multivariable O
regression O
via O
a O
relevance O
vector O
machine O
( O
RVM O
) O
was O
implemented O
and O
evaluated O
using O
500x O
repeated10-fold O
cross-validation O
, O
individually O
for O
each O
combination O
of O
functional O
network O
and O
symptom O
dimension O
in O
the O
main O
sample O
. O

Using O
each O
network O
individually O
in O
the O
model O
was O
intended O
to O
ensure O
the O
functional O
specificity O
of O
our O
results O
. O

Importantly O
, O
RVM O
is O
a O
sparse O
learning O
method O
, O
i.e. O
, O
only O
a O
few O
of O
the O
learned O
feature O
weights O
are O
non-zero O
, O
lending O
interpretability O
as O
to O
which O
features O
( O
connections O
) O
are O
predictive O
. O

As O
recommended O
, O
the O
symptom O
dimensional-scores O
and O
rs-FC O
features O
were O
adjusted O
for O
confounding O
effects O
of O
age O
, O
gender O
, O
site O
, O
and O
head-motion O
( O
DVARS O
) O
. O

To O
avoid O
data-leakage O
within O
cross-validation O
, O
confound O
regression O
models O
were O
learned O
only O
on O
the O
training-set O
and O
then O
applied O
on O
both O
training O
and O
test O
data O
. O

The O
RVM O
model O
trained O
on O
the O
( O
confound-adjusted O
) O
training O
data O
and O
was O
then O
applied O
to O
the O
( O
confound-adjusted O
) O
held-out O
data O
. O

Folds O
were O
stratified O
to O
accommodate O
different O
sample O
sizes O
across O
sites O
. O

Prediction O
performance O
was O
evaluated O
using O
Pearson O
’ O
s O
correlation O
between O
the O
( O
adjusted O
) O
scores O
and O
their O
predictions O
. O

Significant O
predictions O
were O
further O
validated O
for O
their O
generalizability O
across O
sites O
using O
leave-one-site-out O
cross-validation O
following O
the O
same O
schematic O
but O
training O
on O
all O
sites O
but O
one O
and O
testing O
on O
the O
left-out O
site O
( O
Supplement O
) O
. O

Statistical O
significance O
of O
the O
cross-validation-based O
correlations O
was O
determined O
through O
1000 O
permutations O
by O
shuffling O
the O
symptom O
dimensional-scores O
( O
lowest O
p=0.001 O
, O
right-tailed O
; O
Supplement O
) O
. O

Critically O
, O
we O
validated O
predictive O
associations O
confirmed O
by O
leave-one-site-out O
cross-validation O
in O
the O
independent O
B-SNIP O
sample O
. O

For O
this O
, O
we O
trained O
RVM O
models O
on O
the O
significantly O
predictive O
networks O
in O
the O
entire O
main O
sample O
and O
then O
, O
without O
further O
fitting O
or O
modification O
, O
applied O
them O
to O
held-out O
B-SNIP O
data O
. O

Robust O
associations O
passing O
this O
strict O
three-step O
validation O
procedure O
were O
then O
further O
assessed O
as O
described O
below O
. O

In O
addition O
, O
connections O
within O
the O
networks O
identified O
with O
robust O
associations O
with O
symptoms O
were O
combined O
to O
test O
the O
possible O
improvement O
in O
prediction O
performance O
. O

Control O
analyses O
were O
performed O
by O
repeating O
all O
validation O
procedures O
by O
including O
illness O
duration O
or O
olanzapine-equivalent O
dosage O
as O
confounds O
. O

For O
comparison O
, O
i O
) O
we O
predicted O
the O
three O
PANSS O
subscales O
( O
positive O
, O
negative O
, O
and O
general O
psychopathology O
) O
using O
the O
same O
three-step O
validation O
procedure O
and O
each O
network O
individually O
as O
in O
our O
main O
analyses O
, O
and O
ii O
) O
we O
predicted O
the O
four O
symptom O
dimensions O
using O
whole-connectome O
( O
39060 O
connections O
) O
which O
comprised O
pairwise O
connectivity O
between O
all O
the O
nodes O
pooled O
from O
the O
17 O
meta-analytic O
networks O
. O

Identification O
of O
reliably O
predictive O
connections O
and O
subnetworks O
The O
intrinsic O
feature O
selection O
in O
RVM O
through O
its O
sparse O
modeling O
was O
leveraged O
to O
identify O
reliably O
predictive O
connections O
and O
the O
potential O
subnetworks O
formed O
by O
them O
. O

A O
connection O
was O
identified O
as O
reliably O
predictive O
when O
it O
had O
non-zero O
weights O
in O
: O
i O
) O
at O
least O
80 O
% O
of O
the O
10-fold O
cross-validation O
repetitions O
, O
ii O
) O
at O
least O
six O
out O
of O
the O
seven O
( O
i.e. O
, O
> O
80 O
% O
) O
leave-one-site-out O
analyses O
, O
and O
iii O
) O
the O
models O
trained O
on O
the O
entire O
main O
sample O
for O
validation O
in O
B-SNIP O
. O

The O
cutoff O
of O
80 O
% O
is O
suggested O
as O
a O
conservative O
threshold O
in O
both O
real O
and O
simulated O
data O
. O

To O
assess O
the O
predictive O
capacity O
of O
the O
subnetworks O
, O
RVM O
models O
were O
trained O
using O
the O
rs-FC O
of O
the O
subnetworks O
on O
the O
main O
sample O
and O
tested O
in O
B-SNIP O
. O

Spatial O
correlation O
with O
receptor/transporter O
densities O
Finally O
, O
we O
evaluated O
the O
topographical O
relationship O
between O
network-node O
location O
and O
the O
distribution O
of O
several O
receptor/transporter O
systems O
, O
assessing O
for O
highly-expressed O
receptors/transporters O
in O
the O
identified O
networks O
relative O
to O
the O
entire O
brain O
. O

This O
was O
tested O
by O
comparing O
the O
average O
receptor/transporter O
density O
across O
all O
nodes O
within O
a O
given O
network O
against O
a O
null-distribution O
based O
on O
1000 O
random O
network O
configurations O
generated O
by O
re-distributing O
the O
nodes O
throughout O
the O
grey O
matter O
while O
preserving O
the O
between-node O
distances O
( O
±6mm O
tolerance O
) O
. O

Seven O
dopamine O
and O
serotonin O
receptors O
( O
dopaminergic O
: O
D1 O
and O
D2/3 O
; O
serotonergic O
: O
5-HT1a O
, O
5-HT1b O
, O
and O
5-HT2a O
) O
and O
transporters O
( O
dopamine O
transporter O
and O
5-HTT O
serotonin O
reuptake O
transporter O
) O
, O
together O
with O
F-DOPA O
( O
a O
reflection O
of O
presynaptic O
dopamine-synthesis-capacity O
) O
and O
the O
GABAergic O
receptor O
GABAa O
were O
investigated O
. O

While O
all O
systems O
are O
linked O
to O
schizophrenia O
, O
we O
here O
tested O
specific O
receptors/transporters O
. O

Density O
estimates O
were O
derived O
from O
average O
group O
maps O
of O
healthy O
volunteers O
( O
D1 O
: O
N=13 O
; O
D2/3 O
: O
N=7 O
; O
5-HT1a O
: O
N=35 O
; O
5-HT1b O
: O
N=23 O
; O
5-HT2a O
: O
N=19 O
; O
5-HTT O
: O
N=18 O
; O
dopamine O
transporter O
: O
N=147 O
; O
F-DOPA O
: O
N=12 O
; O
GABAa O
: O
N=6 O
) O
scanned O
in O
prior O
multi-tracer O
molecular O
imaging O
studies O
( O
Supplement O
) O
. O

For O
comparability O
, O
these O
maps O
, O
in O
MNI152 O
space O
, O
were O
all O
resampled O
to O
an O
isotropic O
2mm O
spatial O
resolution O
as O
in O
our O
fMRI O
data O
and O
linearly O
rescaled O
to O
0-100 O
. O

Furthermore O
, O
the O
significantly O
higher O
expressed O
receptors/transporters O
were O
entered O
into O
a O
spatial O
correlation O
analysis O
calculated O
as O
rank O
correlation O
between O
the O
node O
importance O
scores O
and O
receptor/transporter O
densities O
calculated O
for O
these O
nodes O
( O
Figure O
4B O
) O
. O

The O
node O
importance O
score O
was O
calculated O
by O
summing O
the O
selection O
frequency O
of O
the O
connections O
of O
each O
node O
derived O
from O
the O
repeated O
10-fold O
cross-validation O
. O

Bootstrap O
analysis O
was O
conducted O
to O
ensure O
robustness O
. O

To O
establish O
the O
statistical O
significance O
of O
a O
spatial O
correlation O
against O
chance O
, O
spatial O
permutation O
test O
was O
employed O
where O
the O
null O
distribution O
was O
estimated O
based O
on O
the O
correlations O
between O
the O
node O
importance O
scores O
for O
a O
given O
network O
and O
the O
nodal O
receptor/transporter O
densities O
extracted O
from1000 O
simulated O
( O
random O
) O
networks O
( O
Supplement O
) O
. O

Cognitive O
control O
network O
dysconnectivity O
and O
response O
to O
antipsychotic O
treatment O
in O
schizophrenia O
To O
better O
understand O
cognitive O
control O
impairment O
in O
schizophrenia O
, O
it O
is O
vital O
to O
determine O
the O
extent O
of O
dysfunctional O
connectivity O
in O
the O
associated O
fronto-striatal O
brain O
network O
, O
with O
a O
focus O
on O
the O
connections O
with O
the O
anterior O
cingulate O
cortex O
( O
ACC O
) O
, O
prior O
to O
the O
potential O
confounding O
effect O
of O
medication O
. O

It O
is O
also O
essential O
to O
determine O
the O
effects O
following O
antipsychotic O
medication O
and O
the O
relationship O
of O
those O
effects O
on O
psychosis O
improvement O
. O

Twenty-two O
patients O
with O
schizophrenia O
, O
initially O
unmedicated O
and O
after O
a O
6-week O
course O
of O
risperidone O
, O
and O
20 O
matched O
healthy O
controls O
( O
HC O
) O
performed O
a O
fMRI O
task O
twice O
, O
six O
weeks O
apart O
. O

We O
investigated O
group O
and O
longitudinal O
differences O
in O
ACC-related O
functional O
connectivity O
during O
performance O
of O
a O
Stroop O
color O
task O
as O
well O
as O
connectivity O
patterns O
associated O
with O
improvement O
in O
psychosis O
symptoms O
. O

Unmedicated O
patients O
with O
schizophrenia O
showed O
greater O
functional O
connectivity O
between O
ACC O
and O
bilateral O
caudate O
and O
midbrain O
and O
lower O
connectivity O
with O
left O
putamen O
compared O
to O
healthy O
controls O
. O

At O
baseline O
, O
greater O
functional O
connectivity O
between O
ACC O
and O
bilateral O
putamen O
predicted O
subsequent O
better O
treatment O
response O
. O

Change O
in O
functional O
connectivity O
between O
ACC O
and O
left O
putamen O
positively O
correlated O
with O
better O
treatment O
response O
. O

These O
results O
suggest O
that O
patterns O
of O
functional O
connectivity O
in O
fronto-striatal O
networks O
can O
be O
utilized O
to O
predict O
potential O
response O
to O
antipsychotic O
medication O
. O

Prior O
to O
treatment O
, O
brain O
function O
may O
be O
structured O
with O
a O
predisposition O
that O
favors O
or O
not O
treatment O
response O
. O

Methods O
Twenty-eight O
subjects O
with O
schizophrenia O
or O
schizoaffective O
disorder O
( O
SZ O
) O
were O
recruited O
for O
this O
study O
from O
the O
psychiatry O
clinics O
and O
emergency O
room O
at O
the O
University O
of O
Alabama O
at O
Birmingham O
( O
UAB O
) O
based O
on O
being O
off O
antipsychotic O
medication O
for O
at O
least O
10 O
days O
. O

Twenty-five O
healthy O
controls O
( O
HC O
) O
, O
matched O
on O
age O
, O
sex O
, O
smoking O
, O
and O
parental O
occupation O
, O
without O
personal O
or O
family O
history O
in O
a O
first-degree O
relative O
of O
psychiatric O
disorders O
were O
recruited O
using O
advertisements O
. O

Exclusion O
criteria O
were O
major O
medical O
or O
neurological O
conditions O
, O
substance O
use O
disorders O
( O
except O
for O
nicotine O
) O
within O
six O
months O
of O
imaging O
( O
drug O
screen O
was O
done O
prior O
to O
scanning O
) O
, O
head O
injury O
with O
loss O
of O
consciousness O
> O
2 O
minutes O
, O
and O
pregnancy O
. O

Subjects O
gave O
written O
informed O
consent O
prior O
to O
participating O
in O
this O
UAB O
Institutional O
Review O
Board O
approved O
study O
. O

Diagnoses O
were O
established O
using O
subjects O
’ O
medical O
records O
and O
the O
Diagnostic O
Interview O
for O
Genetic O
Studies O
( O
DIGS O
) O
. O

The O
Repeatable O
Battery O
for O
the O
Assessment O
of O
Neuropsychological O
Status O
( O
RBANS O
) O
characterized O
general O
cognitive O
function O
. O

SZ O
were O
scanned O
while O
unmedicated O
and O
after O
a O
six-week O
trial O
with O
risperidone O
. O

Medication O
was O
managed O
by O
two O
psychiatrists O
( O
ACL O
and O
NVK O
) O
, O
and O
dose O
determinations O
were O
based O
on O
therapeutic O
and O
side O
effects O
. O

Starting O
doses O
were O
1–3mg O
; O
titration O
was O
done O
in O
1–2mg O
increments O
. O

Use O
of O
concomitant O
medications O
was O
permitted O
as O
clinically O
indicated O
. O

Symptom O
severity O
was O
assessed O
weekly O
using O
the O
Brief O
Psychiatric O
Rating O
Scale O
( O
BPRS O
) O
. O

Medication O
compliance O
was O
monitored O
by O
weekly O
pill O
count O
. O

HC O
were O
scanned O
twice O
six O
weeks O
apart O
. O

Subjects O
were O
excluded O
due O
to O
excess O
movement O
( O
> O
2mm O
translation O
; O
2° O
rotation O
within O
a O
run O
; O
4 O
SZ O
, O
2 O
HC O
) O
or O
lack O
of O
complete O
task O
performance O
, O
defined O
as O
no O
responses O
to O
more O
than O
¼ O
of O
the O
total O
number O
of O
trials O
, O
( O
2 O
SZ O
baseline O
, O
2 O
SZ O
week O
six O
, O
3 O
HC O
) O
, O
leaving O
22 O
SZ O
and O
20 O
HC O
at O
baseline O
and O
20 O
SZ O
and O
20 O
HC O
at O
week O
six O
. O

Task O
Subjects O
performed O
a O
computerized O
version O
of O
the O
Stroop O
color-naming O
task O
. O

Stimuli O
consisted O
of O
three O
words O
: O
“ O
RED O
” O
, O
“ O
GREEN O
” O
, O
or O
“ O
BLUE O
, O
” O
displayed O
in O
one O
of O
the O
corresponding O
colors O
. O

Trials O
were O
either O
“ O
congruent O
” O
or O
“ O
incongruent O
, O
” O
where O
the O
word O
and O
the O
color O
of O
the O
word O
differed O
in O
incongruent O
trials O
. O

Subjects O
were O
instructed O
to O
indicate O
the O
color O
but O
ignore O
the O
word O
and O
to O
respond O
as O
quickly O
and O
as O
accurately O
as O
possible O
. O

Responses O
were O
recorded O
by O
button O
press O
using O
an O
IFIS-SA O
system O
( O
In O
Vivo O
, O
Orlando O
, O
Florida O
) O
running O
E-Prime O
( O
version O
1.2 O
; O
Psychology O
Software O
Tools O
, O
Pittsburgh O
, O
Pennsylvania O
) O
. O

The O
event-related O
design O
consisted O
of O
three O
runs O
of O
88 O
trials O
per O
run O
( O
~30 O
% O
incongruent O
, O
70 O
% O
congruent O
) O
. O

The O
3 O
seconds O
trials O
were O
comprised O
of O
a O
word O
stimulus O
for O
1.5 O
seconds O
and O
a O
fixation O
cross O
for O
1.5 O
seconds O
. O

Subjects O
completed O
a O
practice O
run O
before O
each O
scanning O
session O
. O

Image O
Acquisition O
Imaging O
was O
performed O
on O
a O
3T O
head-only O
MRI O
scanner O
( O
Magnetom O
Allegra O
, O
Siemens O
Medical O
Solutions O
, O
Erlangen O
, O
Germany O
) O
, O
with O
a O
circularly O
polarized O
transmit/receive O
head O
coil O
. O

fMRI O
data O
were O
acquired O
using O
the O
gradient O
recalled O
echo-planar O
imaging O
sequence O
( O
repetition O
time/echo O
time O
[ O
TR/TE O
] O
= O
2100/30 O
milliseconds O
, O
flip O
angle= O
70° O
, O
field O
of O
view= O
24× O
24cm2 O
, O
64 O
× O
64 O
matrix O
, O
4mm O
slice O
thickness O
, O
1mm O
gap O
, O
26 O
axial O
slices O
) O
. O

A O
high-resolution O
structural O
scan O
was O
acquired O
for O
anatomical O
reference O
( O
MPRAGE O
; O
TR/TE/inversion O
time O
[ O
TI O
] O
= O
2300/3.93/1100 O
milliseconds O
, O
flip O
angle= O
12° O
, O
256 O
× O
256 O
matrix O
, O
1mm3 O
voxel O
size O
) O
. O

Analyses O
between O
groups O
and O
across O
time O
found O
no O
significant O
differences O
in O
mean O
scan-to-scan O
head O
movement O
for O
the O
six O
movement O
parameters O
. O

Statistical O
Analysis O
Analyses O
were O
conducted O
in O
SPSS O
20 O
( O
IBM O
SPSS O
Inc. O
, O
Chicago O
, O
IL O
) O
. O

Group O
comparisons O
were O
performed O
using O
chi-square O
or O
analysis O
of O
variance O
, O
as O
appropriate O
. O

Analyzes O
of O
reaction O
time O
( O
RT O
) O
for O
correct O
trials O
[ O
congruent O
, O
incongruent O
, O
and O
Stroop O
( O
incongruent O
- O
congruent O
) O
] O
and O
errors O
( O
congruent O
, O
incongruent O
) O
were O
analyzed O
using O
linear O
mixed O
models O
comparing O
fixed O
effects O
of O
group O
( O
HC O
vs O
SZ O
) O
, O
time O
( O
unmedicated O
vs O
week O
six O
) O
, O
condition O
( O
congruent O
vs O
incongruent O
) O
, O
and O
interactions O
. O

Post O
hoc O
analyses O
were O
performed O
where O
appropriate O
with O
Bonferroni O
corrections O
. O

Image O
analyses O
Data O
analyses O
were O
implemented O
in O
SPM8 O
( O
Wellcome O
Trust O
Centre O
for O
Neuroimaging O
) O
. O

Preprocessing O
included O
slice-timing O
correction O
, O
realignment O
, O
reslicing O
at O
1.5mm O
isotropic O
voxels O
, O
motion/artifact O
correction O
using O
ArtRepair O
, O
DARTEL O
normalization O
, O
and O
smoothing O
( O
4mm O
full O
width O
at O
half O
maximum O
Gaussian O
kernel O
) O
. O

Analysis O
for O
the O
Stroop O
task O
consisted O
of O
a O
single-subject O
voxel-by-voxel O
general O
linear O
model O
. O

Five O
conditions O
were O
included O
: O
incongruent O
, O
congruent O
, O
stimulus O
repetitions O
( O
exact O
repetition O
of O
a O
previous O
trial O
) O
, O
error O
, O
and O
no O
response O
trials O
. O

The O
conditions O
were O
convolved O
with O
the O
canonical O
hemodynamic O
response O
function O
with O
temporal O
derivatives O
. O

The O
contrast O
of O
interest O
was O
correct O
incongruent O
trials O
minus O
correct O
congruent O
trials O
, O
subsequently O
referred O
to O
as O
the O
Stroop O
effect O
. O

A O
contrast O
z-map O
of O
the O
BOLD O
signal O
during O
the O
Stroop O
effect O
was O
generated O
for O
each O
subject O
at O
each O
time O
point O
. O

Generalized O
psycho-physiological O
interaction O
( O
gPPI O
) O
is O
an O
analysis O
method O
that O
investigates O
functional O
connectivity O
between O
a O
selected O
brain O
region O
and O
the O
rest O
of O
the O
brain O
during O
the O
presence O
of O
task O
conditions O
. O

gPPI O
analysis O
is O
an O
interaction O
analysis O
that O
allows O
one O
to O
analyze O
changes O
in O
connectivity O
across O
conditions O
, O
in O
this O
case O
between O
the O
incongruent O
and O
congruent O
conditions O
, O
and O
allows O
more O

in O
analyses O
compared O
to O
standard O
PPI O
. O

Stroop O
effect-dependent O
connectivity O
with O
the O
ACC O
( O
defined O
using O
the O
IBASPM O
116 O
WFU O
pickatlas O
with O
subsequent O

of O
being O
one O

forward O
from O
the O

of O

of O
the O
anterior O

from O
both O
hemispheres O
and O
the O
posterior O
end O
as O
the O
first O
vertical O
slice O
posterior O
to O
the O

) O
was O
assessed O
using O
the O
gPPI O
toolbox O
. O

On O
first-level O
, O
the O
gPPI O
analysis O
included O
the O
following O
regressors O
: O
the O
psychological O
component O
of O
the O
task O
condition O
( O

, O

) O
, O

( O
time O

of O
activation O
in O
the O

region O
) O
and O
the O

interaction O
of O
these O
two O
components O
throughout O
the O
whole O
brain O
. O

The O
Stroop O
effect O
contrast O
condition O
was O
created O
by O
subtracting O
the O
gPPI O
interaction O
regressor O
of O

from O
the O

of O

condition O
. O

A O
contrast O
map O
of O
the O
interaction O
of O
interest O
, O
Stroop O
effect O
× O
ACC O
activation O
interaction O
, O
was O
generated O
for O
each O
subject O
at O
each O
time O
point O
. O

On O
second-level O
, O
between- O
group O
differences O
for O
baseline O
ACC-Stroop O
effect O
functional O
connectivity O
were O
characterized O
via O
a O

within O
SPM O
. O

Exploratory O
analyses O
: O
in O
regions O
where O
baseline O
functional O
connectivity O
was O
significantly O
different O
between O
groups O
, O
the O

of O

was O

for O

via O
REX O
( O
CIBSR O
Stanford O
University O
, O
CA O
) O
using O
a O
6mm O
sphere O
centered O
on O
the O
maximum O
intensity O
projections O
; O
these O
values O
were O
plotted O
against O
average O
errors O
and O
Stroop O
RT O
and O
R2 O
values O
( O
converted O
to O
z O
) O
compared O
between O
groups O
. O

Outlier O
values O
beyond O
two O
standard O
deviations O
were O
removed O
from O
the O
descriptive O
plots O
and O
correlation O
analysis O
between O
connectivity O
values O
and O
Stroop O
performance O
( O
RT O
and O
errors O
) O
values O
. O

To O
examine O
APD O
effects O
on O
functional O
connectivity O
, O
we O
employed O
a O
full O

analysis O
. O

Independent O
variables O
were O

for O
group O
( O
HC O
vs O

) O
, O
time O
( O
unmedicated/baseline O
vs O
week O
six O
) O
and O
the O

of O
group O
and O
time O
( O
group O
× O
time O
) O
. O

Contrast O
images O
were O
generated O
for O
the O
group O
× O
time O
interaction O
. O

To O
correctly O
partition O
the O
variance O
for O
valid O

of O

effects O
of O
group O
and O
time O
independent O

and O

were O
run O
. O

In O

of O
a O
significant O
group O
× O

, O

values O
were O

. O

For O

, O
we O
correlated O
the O
change O
in O
functional O

between O
regions O
identified O
in O

group O
× O

interaction O
and O

between O
groups O
. O

Linear O
regression O
was O
used O
to O

whether O

connectivity O
at O
baseline O
in O

to O

to O

of O
6 O

were O

to O

. O

For O

( O

. O

To O

of O

, O
we O
extracted O
the O
first O
eigenvariate O
of O
the O
effect O
of O
interest O
in O
regions O
where O

response O
was O

with O

and O

( O

) O

. O

Treatment O

was O

as O
the O
percent O
change O
on O
the O
BPRS O

subscale O
from O
baseline O
( O
A O
) O
to O

of O

( O
B O
) O
: O
Analyses O
were O
corrected O
for O
multiple O
comparisons O
using O

( O

) O
in O
accordance O
with O
Gaussian O
random O
field O
theory O
( O
p O
< O
0.05 O
) O
. O

In O
order O
to O

functional O
connectivity O
in O
the O
network O
of O
interest O
, O

were O

. O

and O

from O

116 O
and O

from O

lobes O

. O
